column2: It is very greatly to be hoped that the intimation given to a New-Haven paper, the News, that Mr. HARRISON intends to give an unpartisan character to the new Court of Appeals is true. It is an occasion on which the President may give a new proof of his respect for the Federal judiciary.

ALBANY, May 7. -- There are a great many Democrats who are interested in the subject of the Gubernatorial nomination. Some of them have adopted the plan of sounding the Governor on it. They drop into the Executive Chamber and bring the question to the front as diplomatically as they can. David listens and then replies that the fruit prospects this Spring are not flattering, especially in the Hudson Valley.

The parishioners of the Rev. Dr. Cornelius Roosevelt Duffie, who for over thirty years has been rector of the Church of St. John the Baptist, will be surprised to learn to-day that their venerable and popular rector has married the leading soprano singer of his choir, Miss Lillian A. Pelton. The ceremony took place Tuesday afternoon at 3 o'clock in the church of which Dr. Duffie is rector, and Bishop Potter performed the ceremony.

" Of course if the law of June 7, 1890, is not repealed, the gas companies of Brooklyn will be compelled to reduce their prices on May 1 to $1.25." Those are the words of the President of the Nassau Gas Company of Brooklyn. Well, the law of June 7 was not repealed, May 1 has come and gone, and now the Brooklyn gas companies are of another mind.

LONDON, May 7. -- Col. North, the "Nitrate King," to-day, in speaking of reports that drafts given by the Itata in payment for supplies were drawn on the Bank of London (Limited) and the Bank of Tarapaca, both of which he is supposed to control, declared that he was neutral in the fight, and said:
ST. LOUIS, May 7. -- C.S. Hall, President of the Farmers' Alliance of Missouri, was asked if the Missouri Alliance would be represented at the Cincinnati Convention, and replied:

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 7. -- The capitalists interested in the extensive and growing trade in live cattle now being carried on between Canada and Great Britain are alarmed at the prospect of any unrestricted reciprocity agreement with the United States that would place animals shipped via the St. Lawrence on a par with those exported from the United States.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New-York held its one hundred and twenty-third annual meeting yesterday. The occasion brought together a larger attendance of members than was ever known at any similar occasion. Many members were present who had not attended in many years, and renewed acquaintanceships with others whom they had not met since their last appearance in the rooms of the Chamber.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 7. -- Dispite the unlooked-for crevasse at Ferriday the engineers feel that the danger season is practically at an end. State Engineer Thomson, in charge of the Fifth Levee District, extending from the Arkansas line to the Red River, with a front of 245 miles, reports that within a week the river will be within its banks between those points.

Winno. Minn., was visited by a disatrous fire Wednesday night, were the entire plant of the Schroth Ahreus Mill Company went up in Names. The mill Warehouse, and three blocks of lumber were borned. The fire started in the wheelpit of the planning mill and spread rapidly, being stopped only at the bounderies of the lumner yards. The lose will approximately $ 100,000; insurance, between $40,000; decrease $59,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7. -- A brief exposition of the Harvard position will be interesting to the public. Well-informed Harvard men say that Yale's grievances may be summarized under two heads: First, the alleged breaking of the Princeton agreement by Harvard, and, second, the breaking of certain portions of the Yale agreement by Harvard.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 7. -- The stockholders of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company met at Tracy City to-day. Neither President Platt nor John H. Inman attended. It was the largest meeting, so far as stock represented was concerned, that was ever held by the company, over $9,000,000 being represented.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., May 7. -- About 5:30 o'clock last evening the Chilean steamer Itata lifted her anchors and quietly steamed down the bay and out into the ocean, carrying with her Deputy United States Marshal Spencer. The departure of the Itata was not unexpected, though it was not supposed she would leave as soon as she did.

PARIS, April 13. -- Harmony of color was supposed to be a genuine Parisian virtue, but either the superabundance of flower trimming or fin de siecle triviality has destroyed artistic equilibrium, for never was the mixture more extraordinary and effects more glaring. I have actually seen black tulle capotes with moss velvet bows, pink roses, mimosa sprays, and helio trope string! In spite of signature, I am not prepared to like the result.

There is a reaction from the movement in favor of Major MCKINLEY as a candidate for Governor of Ohio, which only a few weeks ago seemed irresistible, and, curiously enough, it has come about from the series of "triumphs" enjoyed so greatly by the Major in his recent tour through the East.

The third of the opening concerts at the new Music Hall was given yesterday afternoon and was enjoyed by a very large and enthusiastic audience. The programme was as follows: Overture and second act finale from Mozart's "Figaro," suite No. 3, Tschaikowsky; aria from "Esclarmonde," Massenet; aria, "Ich liebe Dich," from Marschner's "Hans Heiling," and the concert arrangement of the vorspiel and liebestod from "Tristan und Isolde."

VALPARAISO, May 7. -- Much excitement was caused here to-day by an attempt to assassinate the leading members of the Cabinet. The persons engaged in the plot sought to take the lives o the Ministers by means of a bomb, which was thrown at the intended victims in the street.

There seems to be no doubt that our Government was acting in the line of its duty toward a friendly power in causing the seizure of the Itata in the port of San Diego. We have not recognized the so-called Congressional party in Chile as a belligerent, but we may do so in the very act of dealing with this case.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Secretary Blaine lets the public have a part of the correspondence in the Bering Sea controversy, but it is so old and lacking in pertinency to the situation, as it has bean discussed for a month, that it has the suggestion of sawdust stuffing. The old question of jurisdiction beyond the three-mile limit is gone over with what Mr. Blaine evidently regards as an instance in illustration.

At yesterday's meeting of the Chamber of Commerce a resolution was adopted by which the Committee on Foreign Commerce and Revenue Laws was requested to inquire and report whether the employment of Special Agents of the Treasury Department in connection with the collection of the customs revenue at this port is conducive to the remedy of abuses and to the better conduct of the customs service.

Secretary BLAINE'S last official "note" to Sir JULIAN PAUNCEFOTE in continuation of the Bering Sea controversy, dated April 14, is just now made public. It is made up largely of a repetition of certain points previously insisted upon, which the Marquis of SALISBURY is assumed to have ignored or misconstrued, but its chief interest lies in the six questions proposed for arbitration.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 7. -- An exceedingly well-informed New-Orleans newspaper man who has just returned from a trip to Costa Rica makes the following statement regarding the revolt just announced in that country:

Representatives of nearly all of the eighty-eight insurance companies holding membership were present at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, held at the rooms of the New-York Board, 32 Nassau Street, yesterday. Much business of a routine character was disposed of, including reports from the standing committees.

LONDON, May 7. -- Replying to a question in the House of Commons to-day in regard to the reported Boer "trek" being prepared for the invasion of Mashonaland, Manicaland, and other South African territory, for the purpose of establishing the so-called "Republic of the North," the Hon. Edward Stanhope, Secretary of State for War, intimated that troops were being sent to British Bechuanaland in order to oppose the proposed Boer "trek."

In their full uniforms the officers of the Spanish schoolship Nautilus visited the City Hall yesterday, escorted by the Reception Committee of the Board of Aldermen. The visitors were introduced to Mayor Grant by Signor S. Guanes, the Spanish Consul General. Capt. Palos made a brief address to the Mayor, thanking him for the courtesies extended.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Attorney General Miller this afternoon made public the substance of the correspondence that has passed between the officials here and the authorities at Wilmington and at San Diego, Cal., relating to the Chilean insurgent vessel Itata and the schooner Robert and Minnie. He refused to give out for publication the full text of the correspondence.

LANSING, Mich., May 7. -- The protracted deadlock in the Michigan Senate over partisan bills has been broken at last, and the final adjournment of the anomalous Legislature of 1891 will occur within a month.

Mayor GRANT has at last made a formal reply to the report of the Advisory Committee on Street Cleaning. He explains the delay on the ground that he was waiting for action by the Legislature which should make it possible to adopt those recommendations of the committee which would require an increase of the appropriations for the Department of Street Cleaning.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 7. -- The political horizon in North Carolina is clouded. Although for fifteen years the Democrats have been in power and the election returns of last Fall showed the most disastrous defeat the Republicans have ever met, yet the former are not oversanguine or the latter hopeless.

Ascension Day services were held in Trinity Church, yesterday both morning and afternoon. The crush at the high celebration at 11 o'clock was the greatest ever known in the history of the church, and while many hundreds of people were unable to gain admission, the admirable arrangements of Sexton Thomas P. Browns precluded all confusion or friction in the handling of the crowd.

The decision of Judge LACOMBE, in the Circuit Court last Wednesday, concerning the duty on knit goods, gives force to a job of considerable magnitude that was skillfully inserted in the wool schedule of the McKinley tariff by the agents of the Philadelphia Manufacturers' Club and their allies, the three political shepherds of Ohio.

After a long delay Mayor Grant yesterday acknowledged the receipt of the report made to him by the special street-cleaning advisory commission appointed by him to make recommendations as to the best way to keep the streets clean. The Mayor agrees with the report in the main. The answer is directed to Messrs. Morris K. Jesup, Thatcher M. Adams, Prof. Charles F. Chandler.

The object of this communication is to enlist your sympathy and co-operation -- always so cheerfully accorded -- in our plan of fresh-air work for the coming season. In this regard no one can form an adequate idea of what the poor really need unless he moves among them and sees for himself their condition and surroundings.

MONTREAL, May 7. -- This morning, at high mass in St. Patrick's Church, Father Dowd said he felt it his duty to again read the Archbishop's letter, in view of some unauthorized documents recently published. He said: "You ought to see the necessity for refraining from taking part in a movement condemned by the Holy See."

A wonderful piece of tapestry has a room to itself at the Sloane stores, Nineteenth Street and Broadway, and proves almost too large for the chamber in which it is shown. It was wrought in the national factory at Paris called the Gobelins, after one of the artists in tapestry earliest to revive that superb branch of decorative art in France, a couple of centuries ago.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Warner Miller, President of the Nicaragua Canal Company, reached Washington this afternoon on his return from Nicaragua, whither he went to inspect the work on the canal.

BOSTON, May 7. -- For the first time this season the New-Yorks won a game from the Bostons to-day. For five times in succession they had to lower their colors, but they finally triumphed after a hard struggle. The leadership alternated on four different occasions, and twice the scores were "tied." After a final spurt in the eighth inning, however, the New-Yorks won by a single run.

The eighteenth auction sale of unclaimed property in the hands of the Property Clerk of the Police Department was held yesterday at Police Headquarters. The catalogue comprised the usual miscellaneous collection of firearms, men's and women's clothing, watches, jewelry, and various other property. The goods brought fair prices, and several hundred dollars will be added to the police pension fund in consequence.

THE DALLES, Oregon, May 7. -- When the train left Portland the skies were clouded, but about 10:30 o'clock they cleared, and the remainder of the trip through the picturesque valley of the Columbia was made in the bright sunlight, which disclosed the mountains and cascades in all their beauty and grandeur. The first stop of any importance was made at the Dalles, where the party received an enthusiastic welcome.

CHESTER, Penn., May 7. -- Edward S. Worrell of Denver, Col., accompanied by his wife, reached this city to-day and went immediately to the Worrell mansion on Edgemont Avenue, where he was seen to-night by a reporter in regard to the story connecting himself and his mother with the poisoning of Mrs. Barnaby.

HARTFORD, May 7. -- The counsel for the Republicans in the quo warranto proceedings -- Henry C. Robinson, Charles J. Cole, and William C. Case -- have agreed on the plan of action which will be pursued at the opening of the court in New-Haven to-morrow. It has been decided to file an answer to the information made by the counsel for Judge Morris, the demurrer process being abandoned without dissent.

After finding the Missouri Pacific Railroad guilty of cutting freight rates on sugar and making Freight Traffic Manager Leeds the scapegoat the Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association, at the Windsor Hotel, yesterday unanimously approved of Jay Gould's joint-agency scheme and ordered the Commissioners to prepare a plan to put the scheme into operation.

ALBANY, May 8. -- Gen. Martin T. McMahon, Chairman of the Democratic committee appointed to investigate Democratic corruption along the line of the canals, came to Albany to-day and had a brief session with the Governor. The General said his visit had no connection with the work of the committee. This may be taken for what it is worth.

PORTLAND, Me., May 8. -- The affairs of the late Rufus Prince of Turner are found to be in a very bad condition. For thirty years he had been one of the most prominent men in the State and had served in many public offices. He had been much sought for as an administrator of the estates of deceased persons and guardian of minor children.

BRIDGEPORT, May 8. -- The authorities here have in their possession two persons, leaders of a gang of burglars who for a long time have been a terror to those living in the outlying districts near this city. They are Henry Luddington and a woman named Conroy, who has lived with him for nearly a dozen years.

BOSTON, May 8. -- In the cleanest possible manner the New-Yorks won from Boston to-day. They did not allow the local players to score a solitary run, and in the field played without an error of any description. The spectators looked on in silence for some time, but finally they were compelled to shower applause on the Giants. The latter's work was up to championship form.

The proposal of Lieut. GRAYDON, formerly of our navy, to fit up all the smooth-bores in the forts as torpedo tubes for projectiles containing heavy charges of dynamite is rather an attractive one, since these cannons are mostly of little use now. Lieut. GRAYDON at one time tried to throw high-explosive shells of his invention from ordinary guns with ordinary powder.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 8. -- A wave of murderous impulses seems to have passed over Rhode Island within the last forty-eight hours.

For the last three years the public-school children of this city have taken great interest in the observance of Arbor Day. For most of the schools there have not been the facilities to admit of planting trees or shrubs, but a pleasant feature of the exercises has been the sowing of seeds or bulbs which would mature in time to be given for the decoration of the graves of the war heroes on Memorial Day.

The will of Mrs. Miriam A. Osborn, the widow of Charles J. Osborn, was filed in the Surrogate's office for probate yesterday. It contains thirty-seven pages of closely-printed typewritten matter, and was executed June 2, 1888. The executors and trustees named are John W. Sterling of the law firm of Shearman Sterling and the Central Trust Company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 8. -- Attorney William C. Case of this city, acting for Gov. Morgan G. Bulkeley and Lieut. Gov. Samuel P. Merwin, filed the answer of those two gentlemen in answer to the quo warranto proceedings brought by Luzon B. Morris and Dr. Alsop in the Superior Court this morning. Like the other occasions, the courtroom was filled, but neither Gov. Bulkeley nor Mr. Merwin was present.

It is not too much to say of Mayor GRANT'S reply to the report of the Advisory Committee on Street Cleaning that it is characterized by true Tammany ignorance and impudence. The people of this city have been complaining for years of the foul condition of the streets. These complaints increased after Commissioner COLEMAN was displaced, because the condition grew distinctly worse.

G.S. Ellis, Secretary of the Bondholders' Committee -- commonly called the Olcott Committee -- which is trying to bring about a settlement of the Virginia debt, is back from his trip to England, and yesterday he met the committee at the office of the Central Trust Company. Mr. Ellis had some hard work to do on the other side of the ocean.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 8. -- At a meeting of the graduate students of Johns Hopkins University to-day an association was formed that promises to exercise an important influence on the future life of the university. The work of the association is to be in three departments, international, national, and local.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- State Department people are quite as unwilling to give out information when Mr. Blaine is away as when he is present, and inquirers are told there is nothing to add to the Blaine note of April 14 in the line of news on the Bering Sea controversy.

A few days ago the New-York Tribune sought to make its readers believe that American tin plate was already driving foreign tin plate out of our markets. We quote from an editorial paragraph, published by the Tribune on April 24, the following curious and amusing remarks:
The result of the Western Association games yesterday were: Sioux City 11, Denver 9; Milwaukee 13, Lincoln 12; Minneapolis 13, Omaha 12.

Mr. Jay Gould seems to have recovered his health. There was a very brisk air about him yesterday. An old-fashioned bear jubilee was in progress all day long. The Gould stocks led, but every other stock on the list was in the downward scramble. The lamented Leeds was being avenged.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- There was selling of Provisions at the opening by Ream and Cudahy. There was considerable selling by Baldwin Farnum, Schwartz Dupee, and Walker Co. Certain of the Wheat traders, Tuttle McHenry among the number, put out good-sized lines, some of this selling. That by the professional room traders was for short account.

We are just now agitated, though in a provisional way, with the problem of consolidating into a metropolis New-York and its suburbs, insomuch that every effort of the same kind elsewhere ought to inspire in us a not unsympathetic interest. A citizen of St. Paul, or Minneapolis, has just issued a pamphlet upon the possible consolidation of those two cities which has an interest of its own, apart from our relation to the problem.

BUFFALO, May 8. -- A great deal of interest is manifested in the proposed visit next week to this city, his old home, of ex-President Cleveland. He has not been here since November, 1885, when, during the first year of his Administration, he came home to vote. He then felt a great deal of interest in the result of the State election, and made a flying trip for the purpose of manifesting it.

An old, old fight in the Custom House has broken out again, and yesterday the friends and oes of the civil service were busy rallying their forces for a contest next Monday night, when the Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District will have a meeting. Two weeks ago, at a meeting of these Republicans, there was introduced a set of resolutions which started the trouble all over again.

POCATELLO, Idaho, May 8. -- The President and his party reached this place to-night. The State was entered by the Presidential train at 2 o'clock this morning and at 7 o'clock Boise City was reached. Gov. Willey, Mayor Pinney, Senator Shoup, and other prominent men met the party at the station and escorted it through the streets, which were gay with flags and bunting.

ROME, May 8. -- The memorial recently presented to the Pope, in the name of all the United States emigration committees, who recently held a congress at Lucerne, begs the protection of the Holy Father for the 400,000 to 500,000 Catholics who annually emigrate. The memorial is also signed by a representative of Canada, and contains statistics of a very pessimistic character. Leo XIII. accepted the memorial and promised to give the matter special attention.

The letter of the Italian Consul at New-Orleans to the foreman of the Grand Jury which reported on the circumstances and consequences of the Hennessy trial puts a pretty severe strain upon the English language, but it makes one or two sharp points against the presentment with reference to the killing "for political purposes, defenseless but fearful adversaries."
Last month we received from Paris a small invoice of marble clock cases, such as we have been importing for years and fitting up with movements of our own make, for sale in this market.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8. -- The Chronicle's San Diego special says: Pilot Hill, who took the steamer Itata out of the harbor Wednesday night has not yet returned, and until he does get book, nothing will probably be known of the direction the vessel took, and whether she has transferred the arms and ammunition from the schooner Robert and Minnie.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The dispatches from Chile this morning throw a peculiar side light on the war, being to the effect that President Balmaceda has directed the suspension of all paper payments to the Government. He proclaims that during the present emergency payments of revenue and other dues to the Government must be made in silver.
A dispatch from London announces the death of Mme. Blavatsky of the Theosophical Society. She died in that city three weeks ago of influenza. The body was cremated.

" ETHELRED the Unready" is not a good model for persons charged with the management of naval operations. It was on Sunday that the Itata appeared in the harbor of San Diego. The Robert and Minnie then lay outside with rifles for the Chilean insurgents. It was known on Monday that the Itata was violating our neutrality laws. On Wednesday she was seized by the United States Marshal.

If Frederick Elson had not been a successful lawyer he might have mistrusted his own judgment of human nature. But he had broken down so many witnesses by the skillful application of his psychological theories that he had come to regard his own idea of any character as something to be received with awe and entertained with reverence.

If all preceptors were like Ernest Legouve, it would be difficult to find commonplace people, disciples for Schopenhauer, readers for Ohnet, and everybody who wished would become Emperor of the Occident, carry on his shoulders the gates of Gaza, have a mind similar to the chariots of fairies that have wheels of flaming carbuncles and are drawn in the dazzling light by a team of wild butterflies.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Rowing at the University of Pennsylvania gained a considerable impetus last Fall at the time of the class races, when a larger number of crews than ever before rowed for the championship. The College Department entered three boats, the Medical and Dental Departments two each, and the Law Department one crew.

BOSTON, May 9. -- The renovation of the old Granary Burying Ground in Tremont Street has brought to light unexpected prizes for the antiquarian. The grasping roots of old trees lava been forced to surrender their spoils, and silent witnesses have been unearthed to the great antiquity of the ground, as well as to the family history of some of Boston's well-named "old families."

PARIS, May 9. -- On Thursday the National Fine Arts Society, the formidable rival of the older Champs Elysees Salon, invites all Paris to to its "Varnishing Day," and Friday the paying public will be admitted. Although there is still much confusion in the galleries, a list can be given of some of the principal canvases and sculptures.

The Kempton Park Great Jubilee Stakes, a handicap at a mile, was run at Kempton Park yesterday and resulted in a victory for Col. North's b.h. Nunthorpe, 5 years, a 14 to 1 chance in the betting, Douglas Baird's b.c. Martagon running second, and Hamar Bangs's Rusticus third. Sixteen others ran. Surefoot, the favorite, was never prominent in the race.

The outdoor season of athletic sports was opened yesterday afternoon. The day was warm and clear and served to bring out athletes of various specialties. At the grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club, Livingston, S.I., were contested two sets of games. At Princeton, N.J., were held the annual Spring games of Princeton College, and the boys who manage the affairs of the Interscholastic Athletic Association gave their annual games at the Berkeley Oval.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 9. -- The men elected by the Sophomore Class as the Epitome editors for next year are as follows: H.R. Blickle, C.H. Durfee, F.P. Fuller, C.W. Gearhart, R.C.H. Heck, S.B. Knox, H.D. McCaskey, C.J. O'Neill, N.M. Osborne, Jr., and C.W. Parkhurst.

George Wilson, fourteen years old, living in Rockport, had a narrow escape from death at an early hour Tuesday morning. The boy lives with his parents on a farm by the side of the river, about 200 feet from the Nickel Plate trestle bridge, the farm having a roadway leading to the bridge. The boy is subject to sleep walking.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 9. -- The season is fairly opening, not the social season with its round of dances, dinners, and Casino concerts, but the season of quiet sojourn of cottagers at their beautiful Summer homes during the delightful days of May and June, before the gay whirl of fashionable life begins, and while the beauties of air, sea, sky, and earth can be fully and really enjoyed.

BOSTON, May 9. -- Lawley's yard shows unusual activity just now. The big fleet of yachts stored in the yard or lying afloat in the basin are being rapidly put into commission. A trip to Lawley's would be a good lesson to the cynic who believes that yachting is dying out, and that it only thrives during the stimulus of an America's Cup contest.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Chief Constructor Wilson has just returned to Washington from Norfolk, and reports that work is advancing rapidly at the navy yard. The Atlanta will be taken out of dock Tuesday, and the Boston will be docked immediately afterward. The Boston and the Chicago were both painted with two kinds of patent protective marine paint about six month ago, and there is some curiosity to learn the result of the test.

It would, perhaps, tend to assuage the apprehension with which some of the Wall Street operators regard the export of gold if they should reflect that one of the causes why we are just now sending gold abroad is that we have locked up the silver that we might have sent and would have sent in its place.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, May 9. -- An adjourned meeting of the Board of Trustees of Rutgers was held yesterday at which the new rules were adopted and the action of President Scott in selecting two new professors was approved. There were a large number of applicants for the Chair of General and Applied Chemistry. Dr. Scott selected Dr. Albert H. Chester of Hamilton College as the best and strongest of them all.

There was another attempt made yesterday morning to fire the Reeve apartment house, 131 East One Hundred and First Street, near Lexington Avenue, the fourth in a month. The house is a five-story structure with accommodations for ten families, but owing to the many mysterious attempts to burn the building there are only five families in the house, and two of them are already preparing to move.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9. -- The Rev. T.M. Hodgden, assistant pastor of the First Congregational Church in Middletown, has accepted the pastorate of the West Hartford Church, succeeding the late Rev. C.W. Mallory.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9. -- The Athletic Association has disposed of the boathouse to the Hartford branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. The house stands on the Connecticut, on the Colt property, and has been unused for years since an accident of drowning disbanded the Trinity Navy. The four-oared scull will also be sold, while the single-oared one will be placed in the trophy room of the gymnasium.

ORANGE, N.J., May 9. -- At Overlook, the residence of Col. Cyrus F. Loutrel, Miss Elizabeth Loutrel gave a dainty tea to a number of her friends on Saturday afternoon. Miss Marion Knight, Miss Agnes Miles, and Miss Sarah Osborne assisted Miss Loutrel in receiving, and Miss Mary Chur and Miss Edith Powles presided at the tea table.

ITHACA, May 9. -- The baseball nine left Thursday night for a short Western trip, playing Oberlin at Oberlin Friday and University of Michigan at Detroit Saturday. More interest is taken in the latter game than in any other this year. The second game with Stevens resulted in a victory for Cornell, 25 to 0, and the game with Union College was won by Cornell, 9 to 3.

The British East Africa Company has found a new source of trouble in Uganda. King MWANGA has come under the influence of the Catholic missionaries and wants no British protection. Yet it is difficult to say how long this mood will last. Before he succeeded to the throne he attended some mission services, but as King he murdered Bishop HANNINGTON and burned at the stake scores of native Christians.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- That Secretary Foster has learned from the Attorney General what that authority thinks of the question of the Secretary's power to suspend the killing of seals for the season by the North American Commercial Company is evident from the fact that the sailing instructions to the revenue cutters Bear and Rush were sent to San Francisco to-day, instructions to Special Agents Brown and Williams having been previously forwarded.
ALBANY, May 9. -- For the first quarter of this year these reports have been made:

The committee of the Chamber of Commerce which will look into the star chamber methods by which investigations of the Appraiser's department have been carried on by special agents is in the way of getting a good deal of information to illustrate the old adage about queer bedfellows in politics. Evidence is at hand to show that Solicitor Hepburn and the Biglin coterie have made the Fifth Avenue Hotel an almost nightly trysting place.

BERLIN, May 9. -- The Reichstag to-day finally passed the Sugar bill by a vote of 159 to 126, and approved the Spirit Taxation Amendment bill. The House then adjourned until Nov. 11, after giving three cheers for the Emperor. The week was full of legislative work. The Trades Regulations bill, which had been before the House for a year, was passed by a large majority. The only opponents of the measure were the Socialists.

Most readers will have been apprised for the first time, by remarking the announcement of a convention of the Catholic Press Association of the United States, that there was such an association in existence. The proceedings of the convention, however, are calculated to interest and entertain the observer who has no special interest in the subject.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 9. -- Orders are expected from the Secretary of the Navy in a few days directing a reduction in the crew complements of all of the new vessels of the navy. The cause of this order is the inability of the Navy Department to man the several war ships about to go into commission.

The residents of the north side of West Fifty- eighth Street, particularly those near Fifth Avenue, are considerably disturbed over a notification that each one has received to change the number of his or her house. It seems that the Plaza Hotel, which occupies the northwest corner lot at Fifth Avenue and Fifth-eighth Street, and the lot adjoining it, have not been numbered.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 9. -- The Dominion Parliament at the present session will be asked to subsidize the Niagara and Queenston Land and Electric Company, which proposes to utilize, on the Canadian side, for manufacturing purposes, the wasted energies of Niagara Falls. It is proposed to bring the power to Queenston, as it will here have a fall of 320 feet, instead of 160, the amount obtainable at the precipice.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- There have been strong attractions at most of the down-town theatres this week, and business has been above the average. Fanny Davenport's production of Sardou's "Cleopatra" has filled the Columbia at every performance, and the receipts for her engagement are greater than for any the house has had this season.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- It was net apparent this morning that the Navy Department was exercising itself greatly to recapture the Chilean steamer Itata. Secretary Tracy left the city early in the morning in company with Commodore Folger to inspect officially the new ordnance proving ground at Indian Head, about forty miles down the Potomac, without leaving any trace of an order relating to the matter.

A newspaper woman told a story the other day illustrating the difficulty of doing other people's work. "I had the grip this Winter along with the rest of the world," she said, "and was obliged to give up work for a few days. Nothing really pressed except a department I do for one of the weeklies, and how to supply this copy I did not see.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Financial circles in this city were rather hysterical to-day. Rumors of all sorts filled the air, and those who were fortunate or unfortunate enough to have a balance at any of the banks were kept busy running about trying to verify reports, or, happily for them, confirming the stability of the institution in which they were interested.

The title page of this "memoir of Jenny Lind" indicates its authenticity. It has been prepared from documents collected by the great singer's husband, who survives her. The material has been "sifted and sanctioned" by him, and "everything possible has been done under this competent and exact scrutiny to secure that the memoir should be trustworthy and authentic."
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The following west crop bulletin was issued from the Signal Office to-day:

Orders have been given to overhaul yachts and get them ready for the coming season. Work has been begun on nearly all which are to be in commission this year. For two weeks scrapers and painters have been at work, the result being that a number of boats are already in commission and more will be ready for sailing this week.

A good deal of surprise was expressed yesterday at the authorities selecting the firm of Woodrow Lewis of 94 Pearl Street for prosecution for violation of a city ordinance when there are so many flagrant mock auctions of furniture in different parts of the city.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 9. -- The weather has been excellent for training in Kentucky during the last week. It was perhaps a trifle cool, but the good track has been made much use of and fast miles will soon be reported. Each weekday morning the track is alive with the trotters.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- The attractions in athletics have been numerous in Princeton today. This morning an open inter-scholastic tennis tournament for doubles was held on the university courts. Eight preparatory schools entered. In the finals Colby and McCormick of Browning's School, New-York City, defeated Randolph and Dodge of Lawrenceville Preparatory School, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 5.

BERLIN, April 27. -- It would scarcely have entered into the dreams of the most devoted Oriental scholar twenty years ago that the oldest Biblical accounts would now be brought into clearest light, not in the way of learned speculation, but by the discovery of great literary productions on the banks of the Tigris, in Mesopotamia.

Mr. Montagu Williams, whose half-legal and half-dramatic reminiscences appeared a year or more ago, takes up the further recital of his experiences at the bar, and in his "Later Leaves" adds to his "Leaves of a Life." We like this book better than the first one, because he dwells more particularly on the state of the London poor.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- Though very little room was given for the display of high dramatic talent in the amateur performance of "The Pirates of Penzance" at the Lyceum Theatre Monday evening, still several of the roles, and especially those impersonated by Miss Nellie Robinson and J. Alexander Godby, were so admirably executed as to call forth much applause.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- The university Trustees have decided to establish a memorial fund in memory of the late Dr. Joseph Leidy. It is hoped that at least $100,000 will be secured for the purpose. The character which the memorial will assume has not yet been definitely settled. It has been suggested that a fine structure shall be erected for the rapidly-growing archaeological collection, and that it shall be named the Leidy Museum.

Ten years ago I was traveling through Illinois in a parlor car when the train was detained for some tame by a hot box. The car was comfortably full of pleasant persons, among whom I had made a number of acquaintances. Since leaving Chicago, I had noticed that the colored porter stared very hard at me whenever he passed.

A striking instance of the difficulties in which the partisan quarrel in Connecticut has plunged that State is the refusal of the Controller to pay the salary of a Judge. This is Judge DEMING of the Court of Common Pleas in New-Haven. His term expired April 1. The Legislature adjourned without appointing his successor.

The reports of the attacks of the Government torpedo cruisers oh the insurgents' ironclad Huascar off the Chilean coast brings to the mind of the naval officers who served on the Pensacola in 1879 and 1880 some interesting details of the famous battle between the Huascar and the Chilean armor-clads Blanco Encalada and Almirante Cochrane, Oct. 8, 1879.

TRENTON, N.J., May 9. -- New-Jersey is laying claim to a superior record for the longevity of her citizens. The list of persons of very old age is certainly remarkable and quite a contest is now raging over the subject. There are a number of claimants for first place, and some ancient twins and antiquated triplets are on the list. Simon Wallen and his sister, living in Salem, are each seventy-eight years old.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9. -- Trinity scored another victory to-day by defeating the team of the Amherst Agricultural College. The features of the game were the battery work of the home team. They pounded out twelve hits with a total of thirteen. The visitors made three with a total of three. Score:

Some curious and impressive warnings have recently been published by CHARLES A.L. TOTTEN, who describes himself as "Professor of Military Science and Tactics in Sheffield School of Yale University." The author of these warnings is a Lieutenant in the Fourth Artillery, United States Army, and he has been detailed from the army to instruct the students in New-Haven.

In the Winter of 1863 I had "veteranized," spent a gay season on recruiting detail, enjoying greater popularity with the girls than I had ever known before, by virtue of certain brass buttons and scarlet facings, and returned, to the army at Culpeper to find my first commission awaiting me, and just in time to join Gen. Grant's columns pouring through the fords of the Rapidan.

Business men in Canal Street between Broadway and South Fifth Avenue or West Broadway have been complaining justly of the atrocious condition which that street has been in since last December, when the authorities first began the work of repaving. This part of Canal Street is one of the very busiest thoroughfares in the city.

NEW-HAVEN, May 9. -- No action has yet been taken in regard to the letter received from the Harvard baseball managers on Thursday. Manager St. John is out of town, and Capt. Calhoun has been in Providence yesterday and to-day, where his nine is playing the Brown College team. Little interest is shown at Yale in the reply from Harvard, which contains nothing new.

The principal point of interest pertaining to the State Camp of Instruction developed the last week is the statement that the Adjutant General is seriously contemplating placing the military post at Peekskill under the command of one of the four Brigadier Generals in charge of the troops of the National Guard the coming encampment season.

The biggest "biscuit" of rubber ever seen in North America is on exhibition in a store in Warren Street. It came from the upper Amazon, weighs a trifle over a thousand pounds, and cost its owners $1,010. Around its largest circumference it measures 10 feet, being composed of successive layers that form a practically solid mass throughout.

An assignment without preferences was made yesterday by Robert P. McBride, David McBride, Leslie McBride, and William A. McBride, doing business as McBride Brothers Co., and the Union Pacific Tea Company, to George H. Macy of the firm of Carter, Macy Co. The firm was one of the largest in the United States.

There is only one topic of interest in the financial world now -- the struggle of the leading European nations to strengthen their gold reserves. Each one has been making efforts to draw gold to itself, and as we are in that position that it could be drawn most easily from this centre, the exports have been very large and the drain is not over yet.

That some irritation should be excited in Italy by the report of the Grand Jury of New-Orleans is natural enough, but the expression this irritation finds is not severely logical. The Popolo Romano goes so far as to say that "it will be impossible hereafter for any civilized country to make a treaty with the United States based upon reciprocal protection of the lives of citizens of either country."

Dainty little dresses for children are of crepon in delicate colors, pale blue, pink, and straw color, with silk embroidery at the top of the hem, and buttonholing on the bretelles. The latter are often of chiffon and make the fairy wearers of the tiny frocks look even more airy and angel-like than usual.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 9. -- On Sunday last the Rev. Julius S. Pattengill of Walton, N.Y., resigned the pastorate of the Presbyterian church of the neighboring village of Cannonsville on account of the increasing infirmities of old age. He is in his eighty-second year, and has served in the Presbyterian ministry for fifty-two years.

One day, a good many years ago, Mr. Barnum and a party of friends went to Bethel, Conn., for an outing. As they passed through the waiting room of the little railroad station they saw, huddled up on one of the benches, an old man, infirm, and poorly clad. He was, in fact, one of the few persons in the town who could fairly be classed as paupers.

LAKEWOOD, May 9. -- Lakewood's newest pastime is cricket. A number of games have been played recently on the Laurel House grounds, Mr. Steckley of the Standard Oil Company, the Rev. A.H. Dashiell, Mr. Morehouse, and Mr. Lynch being among the players.

The second annual Spring driving meet of the New-York Tandem Club yesterday proved to be a brilliant success. The meet was named for 4 o'clock at the Casino, in Central Park, the start to take place thirty minutes later. Everybody was on time, and promptly to the minute President Baudouine led off the procession, to the admiration of several thousand interested spectators, on foot and in carriages, who lined the route of the drive.

LONDON, May 9. -- For Monday next at the Royal Albert Hall, the very last and absolutely final concert of the veteran singer, Sims Reeves, is announced. Mr. Reeves, who is certain of a most enthusiastic "send-off," will be supported by Christine Nilsson, who will come on purpose from Madrid in order to do honor to Mr. Reeves; Mme. Eaton, Miss Alice Gomez, Mme. Antoinette Sterling, Herbert Reeves, Barrington Foote, and Signor Foli.

President DWIGHT of Yale University, in his last annual report on the condition and affairs of the institution, lately distributed to the graduates, makes this suggestive observation: "Yale University, like all our collegiate institutions, must depend very largely for its success and development on the generosity of men who have not themselves participated in its undergraduate life during their early years."

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Particulars were received at the Navy Department to-day giving fuller details of the armor plate tests completed yesterday at the Annapolis proving ground. This trial was of even more importance than the celebrated trials of September last, which so signally demonstrated the superiority of homogeneous armor plates over compound.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- The "congress" held recently in Princeton suggested several important methods of working for the advancement of Princeton's interest through the united effort of the sectional clubs. The union of these clubs was advocated by M. Taylor Pyne and James M. Alexander of New-York City and by Bayard Henry of Philadelphia and President Patton.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 9. -- The recent cool weather has had no depressing effect upon the many persons interested in the business of keeping boarders and entertaining Summer tourists in the Catskills. Abundant applications for rooms is a sure indication that the season of 1891 will be a prosperous and notable one.

Mr. James Payn was a bold man when he wrote down, some years ago, the names of many books that Englishmen and, by inference, Americans praised and never read. He did not include the letters of Mme. de Sevigne in the catalogue; nevertheless, the essentially clever correspondence of Marie de Rabutin-Chantal, who, by marriage, became Marquise de Sevigne, is much lauded and rarely read, save in France.

-- A Practical Guide to Whist, by the latest scientific methods, with the laws of the game. By Fisher Ames. New-York: Charles Scribner's Sons. -- Those were the good old times when whist had for rules those Mother Goose rhymes, one stanza of which ran: "When second hand a doubtful trick you see, Don't trump it if you hold more trumps than three, But having three or less, trump fearlessly."

NEWARK, N.J., May 10. -- The circumstances surrounding the disappearance from her home on Lafayette Street of Mrs. Henry McCann with $3,000 of her husband's money are interesting. McCann is a seafaring man, and some time ago sold an interest he had in a vessel for $4,000. Instead of placing the cash in bank, he gave it to his wife for safekeeping.

According to the dispatches from San Francisco this morning, the United States war steamer Charleston sailed from that port on Saturday morning, provisioned and coaled for a long voyage, "and instead of going outside to try her guns, as was the general supposition, it is stated she has gone in pursuit of the Chilean steamer Itata, with orders to capture her."

The centennial of the Baptist Church of the Epiphany was celebrated yesterday in the church edifice, Madison Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, with all-day services. The pulpit platform and organ loft were banked with palms and blooming hydrangeas, and in front of the choir rail were the two dates 1791 -- 1891 in green leaves against a white background.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10. -- John Penton, the noted Covington County desperado, was shot and killed while resisting arrest near Milton, Fla., last night.

PARIS, May 10. -- Mr. James Gordon Bennett has returned from his Winter's sojourn in Nice, and has arranged a service of road coaches between Paris and St. Germain. The coaches will be under the care of gentlemen drivers, including Mr. Bennett, Messrs. Tiffany and Ridgway, and two French noblemen. The fact that the passengers must pay fare puzzles the French sporting gentlemen, who are unable to understand how business and pleasure can be mingled.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 10. -- Oregon has received much unwelcome notoriety recently through an utterance of her Governor in regard to the reception of President Harrison. But Gov. Pennoyer is not Oregon. His conception of the duty of a State Executive to a visiting President is shared by no one in Oregon. Gov. Pennoyer is an exceptional person.

The angler who whipped the dead waters of the handsome Swamp River between South Dover and Dover Furnace, Dutchess County, N.Y., on Friday, can tell why he and others who visit this stream have poor luck. The stream is netted and the netting on Friday was witnessed by the angler at one point and by the crew of a train of the Harlem Railroad at another.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., May 10. -- The special train bearing the Presidential party arrived here early this morning. A crowd gathered about the cars and eagerly watched the movements of the inmates. They were waited on about 8 o'clock by a committee from Denver, including Gov. Rouett, ex-Senator Hill, Mayor Rogers, and other citizens and officials, by whom they were assured of a cordial welcome at Denver.

The diplomatic history of the century which M. Debidour has written begins with the Congress of Vienna, and it ends with the Congress of Berlin. There are sixty six years of international politics explained. The first half of the period, occupied, incumbered, absorbed by the Holy Alliance, is the continuation, enforced by Europe, of the ancient regime.

News of the change in the law of Michigan relating to the choosing of Presidential Electors has finally reached Columbus, and the Leader (Republican) is in a rare state of mind over it. Its editorial on the subject, which was probably written with a pen wet with aquafortis, is entitled "The Michigan Electoral Steal." It begins its denunciation by saying: "From a political standpoint no meaner piece of partisanship was ever perpetrated.

DETROIT, Mich., May 10. -- The ravages of the forest fires are increasing. Foxville was entirely wiped out last night, eight houses and the railroad building being destroyed. At Lumerton, Charles Fortune's residence caught fire from flying sparks and was consumed. To the west of Boyne Falls a number of houses and barns and a large amount of valuable timber was destroyed last night.

KANSAS CITY, May 10. -- A special from Guthrie, Oklahoma Territory, says: "The skill with which the Wells-Fargo Express car of the Santa Fe train was robbed last night was only exceeded by the skill with which the express messenger guarded the property in his car from the bandits.

The terrible experiences of Prof. Theodore S. Palmer in the scorched sands of Death Valley, California, as told in THE TIMES last Thursday, has aroused much interest in that unsavory country, the great sterility of which so nearly cost the young explorer his life. It is well named Death Valley. It 1850 a party of thirty pioneers left Salt Lake City for the California of their dreams.

Gangs of young men flock into Westchester County every Sunday to play baseball, and in several sections of the county prove a nuisance to residents. At Mount Vernon Stephen B. Odell has a hotel and a park containing three diamonds for the baseball players.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 10. -- For the first time in many years the Sabbath quiet of Newport was disturbed early this morning by the fire-alarm bells striking a general call for the entire police force to report immediately at the police station. It soon became known that Phenix, the cottage burglar and sneak thief, had broken jail in the most skillful manner.

-- Mr. Amos K. Fiske, whose "Midnight Talks at the Club" was one of the successful books of last year, will publish at once through the same house. Fords, Howard Hulbert, a new work entitled "Beyond the Bourn: Reports by a Traveler Returned from the Undiscovered Country."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 10. -- Anna Clara Kenoye is the ten-year-old daughter of a widow. Previous to April, 1890, the widow and little girl lived over a butcher's shop here and were in abject poverty, the mother making a scanty living for them by sewing. Last April the little girl inherited $25,000 in a romantic manner.

The Derringer wife-murder case, which, but for the persistency of the sisters of the dead woman, might never have been brought to light owing to the careless blunder of one of the Coroner's physicians, recalled an almost similar case which occurred in this city over eight years ago. Capt. John Gunner of the Twenty-fifth Precinct, who had charge of the case, related his experience to a TIMES reporter the other day:

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 10. -- The entire population of the capital of Missouri are discussing the outcome of the Noland trial. Edward T. Noland, defaulting ex-Treasurer of the State, was tried for stealing $32,000 of the State's money. The case was very clear; the evidence was very plain. Some of the money he stole by simply raising checks; some of it he took bodily from the safe.

LONDON, May 11. -- Mr. Gladstone writes that he is not prepared to say what steps should be taken in the matter of the American Copyright act, but whether in relation to the interests of labor, the dignity of authorship, or the nations' interests, he regards the act as highly unsatisfactory.

TRENTON, May 10. -- Following with significant closeness on the heels of the dispatch from this point last Monday morning that reviewed the political situation in New-Jersey as related to the Presidential and Senatorial canvasses of next year, an interview holding Senator McPherson up as a possible Presidential candidate was going the rounds of the State papers all of last week.

The report that Attorney General MILLER is to receive a judicial appointment recurs with distressing regularity in Washington. It has always been a mystery to us why Mr. MILLER should be regarded as particularly liable to this honor. He had no great reputation as a lawyer when he was appointed to the Cabinet, and he has not made one since.

The village of Peekskill is at present laboring under the disadvantage of having no public hall in which traveling companies can give entertainments, and this will continue until the new Music Hall, now in course of erection, is completed.

PATERSON, N.J., May 10. -- Altogether the liveliest contest that has ever been waged in Passaic County for Director of the Board of Chosen Freeholders is now on. Director Halstead has held the office for three years, and John C. Roe of Manchester and John H. Morrow of the Sixth Ward of Paterson believe the time has come for a "change" in their favor.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Gov. Hill says there is no truth in the statement that he is scheming to be the candidate of the Democracy to succeed himself. "It's all nonsense," is the way he disposes of the charge, and some people and newspapers take him at his word.

PARIS, May 10. -- The Chilean Congressional leaders here deny that the failure of the peace negotiations was due to the demands of the Congressional party. Their advices state that President Balmaceda, after offering to treat, changed his mind upon hearing of the sinking of the war ship Blanco Encalada, and made the publicity given to the proposals of the Congressional party an excuse for rupturing the negotiations.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 10. -- The Republicans of Wilmington, in their nomination contest for candidates for city offices, yesterday again severely rebuked Senator Higgins for his presumptuous interference in local politics. There were three candidates for the Mayoralty nomination -- Stansbury J. Willey, Samuel H. Baynard, and Dr. E.G. Shortlidge -- and the last was the choice of Senator Higgins.

BOSTON, May 10. -- For some time there have been rumors of a proposed consolidation of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Boston Singers, but it was not until Saturday that Mr. George L. Osgood, the director of the latter society, announced to his singers that Mr. Henry I. Higginson had invited them to unite with the Symphony Orchestra.

Nearly every steamship which arrived yesterday and Saturday had undesirable passengers on board. Twenty-four were excluded and will be returned to the custody of the vessels which brought them. These are the Gellert, Australia, Columbia, Elbe, Etruria, Entella, and Bothnia. The Australia had two convicts among her passengers. The others were debarred because of loathsome diseases and their liability to become public charges.

ANNAPOLIS, May 10. -- The completed programme for graduation week at the Naval Academy has just been announced. It will begin on the arrival of the Board of Visitors, June 1, when salutes will be fired and informal receptions held at the Board House, where the visitors will be quartered. An escort will meet the board and the battalion of cadets will be drawn up as a part of the reception.

MADRID, May 10. -- Gen. John W. Foster, the American reciprocity envoy, having failed in his negotiations for a general treaty between Spain and the United States, suggested a secret treaty, which also failed to meet the approval of the Spanish Ministry. He therefore agreed to conclude a simple convention on the basis O'Donnell proposed for a treaty.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 10. -- The attorneys of the State Temperance Alliance engaged in bringing the action to reincorporate the prohibitory amendment in the State Constitution have filed an amendment to the substituted petition which, they claim, greatly strengthens their case.

PATERSON, N.J., May 10. -- The $200,000 of Passaic County road bonds which were advertised in THE TIMES last week were sold yesterday upon sealed bids. Seven bids were received, ranging from a trifle under 1 per cent. to 1.53 premium, at which latter figure the whole issue was disposed of to Vermilyea Co. of New-York.

There is a current legend of a wedding in South Carolina at which a "difficulty" occurred in the course of which the officiating clergyman, being a man of ready wit, gained "the drop" by shooting through his surplice and killing the bridegroom. The anecdote is commonly regarded as apocryphal, but some plausibility is given to it by the report of an actual occurrence in St. Louis on Friday evening.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Secretary Foster has issued an order restoring Col. J.R. Bennette as Superintendent of Construction of the Lowell (Mass.) Public Building. This ends for the time being a fight which has occupied the attention a fight which has occupied the attention of the Treasury Department for the last three years, and has caused it a great deal of trouble.

TELURIDE, Col., May 10. -- The Belmont Gold Mines have been sold to the China Company, owning the Sheriden and Mendota Mines. The sale was made through J.H. Waters of the Sheriden Company. Judge Costigan is the owner of the property and receives $1,500,000 for it, besides being paid for all the work that has been done on the mine since the agreement to sell was drawn up last Fall.

A most stubborn and destructive fire on the top floor of the nine-story brick building occupied by Francis H. Leggett Co., grocers, at the junction of Franklin Street and West Broadway, gave Chief Bonner and a considerable portion of the Fire Department a difficult task yesterday afternoon. For over three hours the flames burned fiercely in spite of dozens of effective streams which were being poured into the building.

The coming tax levy in Jersey City is going to be so enormous and onerous that the chief of the ring papers has found it necessary to apologize for it in advance. Last year the ring tried to delude the long-suffering taxpayers by reducing the rate two-one-hundredths of 1 per cent., but the valuations were screwed up over 20 per cent.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton at All Souls' Church preached yesterday morning a sermon of more than ordinary interest. His text was:

President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University talked to the members of the Reform Club at the clubhouse. Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, last night about reform in municipal governments. He said that the large cities of this country had brought on themselves evils and deserved disrepute by clinging to worn-out methods of municipal government. Local Solons had failed to keep pace with the progress of events.

WILMINGTON, N.C., May 11. -- The steamer El Monte of the Morgan Line, from New-Orleans to New-York with a cargo of cotton, put into Southport at 9 o'clock this morning with the cotton on fire. The fire was discovered when about 100 miles south of Southport. The burned cotton will be discharged at once and the ship will probably proceed on her voyage to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Those enthusiastic admirers of Mr. Blaine, Democrats and Republicans, who are characterizing the last chapter of the Bering Sea correspondence as particularly appropriate and smart, are evidently unaware that they have been "fooled" "with a back number."

About one hundred members of the Millers' National Association were in the callroom of the Produce Exchange at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon when their annual convention was opened. As many more were in the city preparing for the trip to Europe that they are going to take, and therefore too busy to attend the first session of the convention.

LONDON, May 11. -- Mr. Gladstone is the latest of the prominent men of Great Britain to be announced as on the sick list. He went to church as usual yesterday morning and seemed to be enjoying his usual health. In the afternoon, however, he was seized with a succession of shivering fits. Mrs. Gladstone, alarmed at the symptoms, sent for Sir Andrew Clark, Mr. Gladstone's family physician.

Mr. FOSTER finds himself forced to adopt measures of economy in the Customs Service that will be extremely distasteful to him. The regular permanent appropriation for the collection of customs duties has been for many years only $5,500,000, and, though far more than this has been spent every year, it has had to be provided for by a deficiency bill.
LONDON, May 11. -- In the House of Lords to-day Lord Knutsford's coercive bill relating to Newfoundland passed its third reading.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room Yesterday, Monday, May 11:

The Legislature of this State has shown a curious eagerness for several years to compel this city to pay an alleged debt of gratitude to one CHARLES T. HARVEY, to whom the city owes nothing whatever. What is called the Harvey "claim" is not a claim, but a demand for a considerable fund in the City Treasury as a gratuity to a private citizen.

In spite of the warnings of exposure, which included fair notice that proceedings for conspiracy would be pushed against them in a criminal court, the members of the Carl Sahm Club have persisted in their boycott against Albert Eschert, and have succeeded in depriving him of his engagement as leader of the orchestra at the Felsenkeller, at Fifty-seventh Street and the East River.
The monthly meeting of the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was held yesterday.

There have been various efforts of late to divert attention from the critical point in the Bering Sea negotiations. That was apparently the object of the sudden publication last week of the "note" of April 14, which had nothing to do with the urgent question of suspending the slaughter of seals on sea and land during the present season.

There were lively times at the Coney Island race tracks yesterday, occasioned by the arrival of a couple of hundred racers which Superintendents Brush at Gravesend and Clark at Sheepshead Bay had to find quarters for. The string which excited the most interest was that of J.A. A.H. Morris, twenty-four in number, which came through directly from Washington, and headed by Russell, the Brooklyn Handicap candidate of the stable.

We infer from the reticence of the New-York Tribune that it has been unable to find in the fact that the quantity of tin plate imported in March was 101,174,507 pounds, as against 48,609,428 pounds imported in the corresponding month of last year, any proof of its amusing assertion that "the American market has been so far filled by American tin plate as to compel the Welsh Trust to shut down."

The contemplated production of "King Kaliko" at the Academy of Music on June 1 is off. The backer, who is a Philadelphian, is quite a young man, and his guardian, who did not approve of the affair, has refused to give him the necessary funds. Fred Solomon, the composer, who was to have led the orchestra, left yesterday for Philadelphia to accept a Summer engagement with the Pauline Hall Opera Company.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Business transacted in the United States Supreme Court to-day was as follows:

The trick played by the Republican bosses of Pennsylvania in the matter of the Ballot-Reform bill is confessed by some of their own organs and rather boasted of by others. It is considered good politics in that State to give the people the semblance of the rights they claim and to which they are entitled while withholding the substance.

CAMBRIDGE, May 11. -- The letter which Yale sent to the Harvard management early last week created much excitement at the time, but this was not comparable with that which arose this morning, when it was learned that a second letter had been received refusing the direct challenge made by Harvard. All looked upon the first letter as a huge "bluff," and the second was a genuine surprise.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Many years ago Congress fixed the permanent appropriation for the expenses of the collection of the customs revenues at $5,500,000, and, although the service has grown and more men are employed every year, the appropriation remains the same. Every Congress has to provide for the deficiency of the preceding fiscal year, although successive Secretaries of the Treasury have pointed out that $5,500,000 is not enough.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Civil Service Commission will require, in order to fill vacancies in the Naval Observatory after July 1, a list of eligibles for the following-named places: One electrician at a compensation of $1,500 per annum, one photographer at $1,200 per annum, one assistant librarian at $1,200 per annum, and three computers at $1,200 each per annum.

The contest between Prof. C.A. Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary and those Presbyterian ministers and laymen who allege that certain doctrines he holds and inculcates in the minds of the theological students at the seminary are contrary to the Confession of Faith of the Presbyterian Church opened in earnest yesterday at a meeting of the New-York Presbytery.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- From a letter of inquiry received at the Treasury Department to-day it is inferred that some persons think the copyrighting here of a photographic reproduction of a foreign painting or other work of art bars any later comer from the privilege of photographing the same thing and copyrighting his works.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 11. -- The joint Democratic caucus was called to order at 8:30 tonight, and the sixty-ninth ballot for Senator was taken promptly. It resulted as follows: Call, 51; Mays, 44; Bloxham, 2; Long, 1. Call had gained two votes since the last ballot taken last Friday night. This was due to the action of Messrs. Peacock and Overstreet of the House -- the former from Lafayette, the latter from Osceola County.

CINCINNATI, May 11. -- Two home runs by O'Brien and Foutz and two errors by Cincinnati won the game for Brooklyn to-day. Cincinnati was unfortunate. In every inning but two the home club had men on bases and twice the bases were full, but there were few hits when they were most needed. The weather was chilly. Attendance, 846. Score:

ALBANY, May 11. -- Gov. Hill views with alarm the visit of ex-President Cleveland to Buffalo. To his narrow mind politics alone is at the bottom of Mr. Cleveland's trip to the city where he gained his first honors. In the programme mapped out for the entertainment of the distinguished citizen he sees only an intended blow at himself.

BOSTON, May 11. -- Foreign fraternal beneficiary organizations must leave Massachusetts. That was practically settled by the vote in the House of Representatives this afternoon. It was the last fight over the bill "Relating to Fraternal Beneficiary Organizations," and when it was reached Mr. Knowlton of Hamilton moved an amendment which would stop every company, whether organized in this State or a foreign one, from issuing any more certificates.

The Republican organization of the Twenty-first Assembly District -- the banner Republican district of the city -- was on the point of putting itself in a ridiculous position on the civil service, last night, when a message from Theodore Roosevelt, Civil Service Commissioner, changed the temper of the meeting and prevented the spoilsmen by whom the meeting was packed, from passing an anti-civil service resolution.

In another column we publish the findings of the court-martial in the case of Lieut. Commander BICKNELL, who was tried for stranding the United States ship Galena at Gay Head on the night of March 13. The court finds the officer guilty on two specifications, and the record is now in the hands of Secretary TRACY, awaiting his final action.

BOSTON, May 11. -- If the provisions of Paul Dudley's will are carried out, Harvard College will have to provide for a lecture this year "for the detecting and conviction and exposing the idolatry of the Romish Church, their tyranny, usurpation, damnable heresies, fatal errors, abominable superstitions, and other crying wickedness in their high places," as Justice Dudley expressed it in his last testament.

For purposes of comparison the Census Bureau has obtained statements of the public debt of most of the nations of the world, and is able to show the increase or decrease in the last ten years in the case of the most important countries. In this comparison the United States makes an extremely favorable appearance, even if national, State, and county debts are all lumped together.

It appears that Secretary FOSTER and his associates in the combination of manufacturers of window glass are not satisfied with the advance of about 15 per cent. which was ordered at the recent meeting in Chicago. The Paint, Oil, and Drug Reporter, one of the organs of the trade, said on the 6th inst.:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11. -- This has been a great day with the Germans of Buffalo. The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of their oldest society, the German Young Men's Association, henceforth becomes an "event" which will be constantly referred to in the history of this rapidly-growing town.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 11. -- Francis A. Willard, late Postmaster at Boonville, N.Y., has purchased from John A. Mason his interest in the Newburg Register. Its former owner is at present publishing the Harlem Local Reporter.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day rendered an opinion on a constitutional question of great importance in the case of the Pullman Palace Car Company against the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, brought here on appeal from the highest court of Pennsylvania The court was very much divided on the question at issue, and Justice Bradley delivered a vigorous oral dissent, concurred in by Justices Field and Harlan.

Mr. Sharretts of the United States Board of General Appraisers has one of the most interesting cases before him that has come up under the new Tariff act. He will take the final testimony of domestic manufacturers to-day upon the question of the proper classification of pearl button blanks.

OTTAWA, May 11. -- The much-talked-of charges of misappropriation of public money brought against a Quebec member of parliament were fully ventilated in the House to-day, when Mr. Tarte, member for Montmorency, moved a resolution asking that a committee be appointed to inquire into the conduct of the Hon. Thomas McGreevy, member for Quebec West, concerning certain contracts in Quebec and elsewhere.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 11. -- The fact no longer is concealed, even in official naval circles, that the cruiser Charleston is in hot chase after the Chilean transport Itata. The Chilean cruiser Esmeralda is believed to be lying off Cape San Lucas, which is the southernmost point of land in Lower California, awaiting supplies carried by the Itata.

Chairman Walker, Commissioner Midgely, and President R.R. Cable of the Rock Island Road have reached Chicago from New-York, and all speak hopefully of the future of the Western Traffic Association, and seem to think that the promptness with which Jay Gould acted upon the decision of the Commissioners in the case of Traffic Manager Leeds will have a most salutary effect.

PITTSBURG, May 11. -- The New-Yorkers started their Western trip here to-day and signalized the event by defeating the local team in the easiest manner imaginable. It was a one-sided game, and the Giants won it on their merits, outplaying the Smoky City boys at every point.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Senator Brown's "Oystermen's" bill, which was framed to enable the New-York oystermen to "get even" with Timothy Shea, the lessee of the dock at the foot of West Tenth Street, became a law to-day. Tammany wanted the bill, and its representatives worked hard to get it before the Governor. So did the wicked Gibbs.

NEWBURG, May 12. -- The second of the new-style screw ferryboats was launched at Marvel's ship yard in this city to-day. The hull is of steel and is in every respect similar to the Bergen, which was built in 1888. It is 220 feet over all, 40 feet breadth of beam, 17 feet depth. The boat was named the Bremen by Mary, the little daughter of John Stevens, Vice President of the company.

It is very strange that Mr. CLEVELAND'S visit to his old home at Buffalo should cause Gov. HILL so much distress. He was invited there to attend the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the German Young Men's Association, of which he used to be a member, and the opening of a new house of a Democratic club that bears his name.
ALBANY, May 12. -- With Chapter 361 signed to-day, Senator Jacobs's bill relative to the establishment of Bensonhurst Park, New-Utrecht, Gov. Hill filed the following memorandum:

The election of James A. Blanchard to succeed William Brookfield as executive member of the delegation from the Twenty-first Assembly District to the Republican County Committee is a rather significant move. Mr. Blanchard is a T.C. Plattman. He is also the executive member from New-York State in the Executive Committee of the Republican League of the United States.

CINCINNATI, May 12. -- An evening paper here publishes a story, extravagantly headlined, purporting to be the history of a squeeze in which Jay Gould gained heavily at the expense of Senator Brice, Gen. Thomas, and Gov. Campbell. The name of the author of the alleged history is not given, but he is described as "an ex-Judge, an attorney of prominence, and a Corporation Counsel."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 12. -- Ricardo Trumbull, a member of the Chilean Congress and partisan of the insurgent party, was arrested last night by the United States Marshal for violating the centrality laws in connection with the shipment of arms and munitions on the schooner Robert and Minnie and on the steamer Itata. His bail was fixed at $15,000, and he was released, with John D. and Adolph Spreckels as sureties.

ALBANY, May 12. -- The two weeks' deadlock in the Senate was providential to Gov. Hill in more respects than one. Besides keeping from him 350 bills, including the anti-Pinkerton, the personal liability, the 5 per cent. interest reduction, and the whisky measure, it enabled him to devote the time which otherwise would have been consumed in considering those schemes to numerous Democratic soreheads from all over the country who have come to this city.

Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT'S proposition to the Republicans of the Twenty-first District must have carried disgust to the hearts of many of their number. They had met to pass resolutions "denouncing" a good many things in the administration of the civil service rules, declaring the Washington commission to have but one Republican upon it, charging favoritism in certifications, and not omitting the inevitable accusation that the examinations are not practical.

The address of Mr. CLEVELAND last evening to the Democratic organization that bears his name, and that has been very well satisfied to bear it in the campaigns of the past, was in no sense a partisan harangue. It might easily have been pardoned to the ex-President had he dwelt upon the victories won in his name and sought simply to incite his hearers to renewed zeal.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 12. -- The homely saying of President Lincoln that "there are always some people who are ready to be fooled" seems to have found verification in a new pseudo-religious craze at the little station of Willmore, in the adjoining county of Jessamine.

ST. LOUIS, May 12. -- If Edward T. Noland, the man who as State Treasurer robbed the State of Missouri, is ever brought to trial again, it is altogether probable that the whole truth will come out, and if it does it will in all probability blast David R. Francis's hopes or a seat in the United States Senate.

MONTREAL, May 12. -- The largest cargo of lemons and oranges that has been imported to Canada arrived at this port Saturday morning on the steamship Gerona. The cargo consisted of 52,000 boxes, 17,000 of which were consigned to American firms, while the rest was sold by auction yesterday. The following buyers from the United States were present and secured most of the cargo.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Japanese Legation has received a dispatch in relation to the attempt upon the life of the Czarowitch, which states that the Prince was wounded in the head by a fanatic. The attack was made at Otsu, a place upon Lake Biwa, about twelve miles from Kioto.

TRENTON, May 12. -- Col. George B.M. Harvey, the State Insurance Commissioner, is at last in pursuit of the speculative insurance concerns that overrun the southern section of the State. The plan of operation followed by most of them is so bold a robbery that it is a wonder that any one is deceived into going into them.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 12. -- W.A. Shepard, for the past twelve years special emigration agent in the New-England States, is in the city.
