Speaking of the efforts which are being made by the Dominion Government to induce the thousands of Canadians who have settled in the United States to return to their native land, Mr. Shepard says: "The work of repatriating Canadians from the New-England States is going on well.

The disturbance on the Bourse of Paris yesterday hardly seems to have merited the title of "panic" given to it in the dispatches. The situation in Lisbon is disquieting, and the Paris bankers have for some time been dealing rather more liberally than was prudent in Portuguese securities, which, from the very uncertainty surrounding them, have offered chances for considerable profits.

PITTSBURG, May 12. -- The Rev. B.F. Woodburn of Allegheny, one of the oldest and foremost Baptist clergymen in Western Pennsylvania, was not greatly surprised to hear that the Rev. A.J. Bonsall, the Baptist minister at Rochester, Penn. had taken the same stand as the Rev. Dr. Briggs with relation to the Bible.

PITTSBURG, May 12. -- Poor field work coupled with unfair umpiring lost the game for the New-Yorks to-day. Young Sharrott pitched a good game of ball, but he was supported in wretched style by his colleagues and handicapped to some extent by the partial rulings of Hurst, a young man who gained his knowledge of the national game in the coal-mining regions of this State.

TORONTO, May 12. -- Goldwin Smith read a paper before the Young Men's Liberal Club last evening on "Aristocracy." The nearest approaches to a social aristocracy which this continent had seen, he said, probably were made by the planters of Virginia and the Dutch land owners of New-York. It was good that we should preserve bonds of sentiment.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12. -- The steamship Australia arrived this morning, seven days from Honolulu.
BUFFALO, May 12. -- The festivities arranged for the visit of ex-President Cleveland have come to a close, and to-morrow morning he will return to New-York on the limited express.

The small meeting room of the Cooper Institute was well filled last night at the meeting of the County Committee of the County Democracy. Charles A. Jackson presided, and, in behalf of the committee selected at the last meeting for that purpose, ex-Judge George M. Van Hoesen made a report on the by-laws. This recommended that the organization be conducted this year under the by-laws of last year, with certain amendments.

In the strife for the east-bound lake and rail traffic this Spring the New-York Central people came to the conclusion a short time ago that they were not getting their share of the grain-carrying trade through this State. They looked about them and ascertained, it is asserted, that the east-bound rates were being manipulated the same as were the west-bound rates.

At the meeting of the Union League Club to-morrow night there will be submitted by the Committee on Political Reform a further report upon the evils of undesirable immigration. The report presented at the April meeting, the committee says, was tentative, and for the purpose of calling attention to the evil rather than pointing out a remedy.

Several matters of great interest to the millers were discussed at the session of their National Association in the callroom of the Produce Exchange yesterday. A resolution was adopted favoring an appeal to Congress to take steps to enforce the uniform bill of lading proposed by the National Transportation Association. If the bill is brought into use the millers believe that they will be freed from many vexations attending the present system.

PITTSTON, Penn., May 10. -- Thirty years ago fears were entertained by men engaged in the mining of anthracite coal that the supply would be exhausted in this region before the close of the present century. The northern boundary of the coal field was fixed a short distance above Carbondale, and the so-called experts were confident that coal would not be found in paying quantities outside of this line.

The Tammany Society met last night in the Wigwam to install the following officers: Sachems -- Hugh J. Grant, W. Bourke Cockran, Charles E. Simmons, Charles Welde, Richard Croker, Thomas L. Feitner, John H.V. Arnold, William H. Clark, John J. Gorman, John McQuade, Bernard F. Martin, Henry D. Purroy and Charles M. Clanoy; Secretary -- John B. McGoldrick; Treasurer -- Arthur Leary; Sagamore -- W.H. Dobbs; Wiskinkie -- Daniel M. Donegan.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 12. -- The Grand Jury met to-day and, after finding "not a true bill" against Arthur Dunn, lawyer, for the killing of Frank Waters, newspaper reporter, took up the letter addressed to the foreman by the Italian Consul, Pasgrah Corte. It was decided, on account of its disrespectful tone, not to give it further attention.

As will be seen in the news columns of to-day's TIMES, the Committee on Political Reform of the Union League Club has prepared a report, ostensibly upon undesirable immigration, but really upon promiscuous naturalization. The very presence in the country of undesirable immigrants, the report declares, is a menace and a burden, but it adds that when these immigrants are clothed with citizenship, the burden and the menace are aggravated.

HARTFORD, May 12. -- Henry Woodward of Middletown, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Connecticut Hospital for the Insane, denies the statement that has been published that Gov. Bulkeley has pledged his private fortune to the support of the public institutions of the State, which will be destitute of funds June 30, the Legislature having failed to make appropriations for their maintenance.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were to-day appointed as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Secretary Foster has issued a circular to customs officers in which he says that the quarterly conferences of local Appraisers, provided for by the department's circulars of Feb. 10, 1887, and June 6, 1887, will be continued during the fiscal year 1892, and will be held at New-York the third Tuesday of July, 1891, and the second Tuesdays of October, 1891, and January and April, 1892.

Levy Brothers Co., wholesale clothing manufacturers at 610, 612, and 614 Broadway, were closed up by the Sheriff yesterday who levied under eight writs of attachment aggregating in amount $150,747.24, and Augustus H. Levy, one of the partners in the firm, is pronounced hopelessly insane by physicians who examined him yesterday, his mind having been unbalanced by the catastrophe which has fallen upon his house.
We invite the attention of the three political shepherds in Ohio and of the wool growers who regard these tricksters with veneration to some official reports concerning wool.

LANSING, Mich., May 12. -- James M. Turner, capitalist and defeated Republican candidate for Governor last Fall, is financially embarrassed. He has filed a bill of sale covering all his property of every kind to James F. Joy and Christian H. Buhl of Detroit in trust for themselves and the Lansing banks, the Detroit National Bank and Stephen Baldwin of Detroit, to secure $110,000 worth of indebtedness for drafts, checks, and promissory notes.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 12. -- The Government has decided to build the lock on the Saulte Ste. Maria Canal 100 feet wide instead of 85 feet as originally intended, the increased width being deemed essential owing to the rapid development of traffic between Ontario and Lake Superior ports. The lock will be 600 feet long, having guard gates at both ends, facing in opposite directions, the entrances being 60 feet wide.

The decision was reached in the meeting of the New-York Presbytery held yesterday in the Scotch Presbyterian Church that Dr. Briggs, Professor of Biblical Theology in the Union Theological Seminary, must be brought under judicial investigation on account of the alleged heresy in the address delivered by him last January.

NORWALK, Conn., May 12. -- According to orders issued from the Adjutant General's office at Hartford, received here to-day, the commission of Lieut. Henry Matheis of Company F, Fourth Regiment, C.N.G., of Norwalk, has been revoked and he is dismissed from the service. A further order is also issued, in which the section relating to the awarding of marksmen's badges is annulled, so far as Company F is concerned, in the shoot of last Fall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 12. -- Congressman Bunting of New-York held a long conference with Gov. Campbell to-day, and left feeling quite well satisfied with the political situation from a Democratic standpoint. Mr. Bunting said, among other things, that New-York was closely watching the political current in Ohio, as the result of the election this Fall would largely determine whether Cleveland or Hill would secure the New-York delegation. Said Mr. Bunting:

CHICAGO, May 12. -- John W. Linck, a Special Agent of the Treasury recently stationed in New-Orleans, arrived in Chicago under special orders to investigate a phase of the McKinley tax upon Cuban cigars that the Government had not anticipated and which is seriously impairing the revenue expected from the tobacco trade. Mr. Linck has discovered that the Cubans have got ahead of Uncle Sam without committing any fraud, and nothing can stop them.

Various matters of interest to fishermen came before the Fish Commissioners at their monthly meeting yesterday. The report of J. Warren Pond, Chief Fish and Game Protector, shows that the month of April brought some quaint and instructive experiences to officers in some of the districts. Protector Charles Ripson of the district that includes Buffalo seems to have given a highly successful imitation of the gentleman who, in fishing parlance, is "played for a sucker."

ALBANY, May 12. -- The anguish of Gov. Hill and his satellites over the visit of ex-President Cleveland to Buffalo is something pitiful to see. If any one needed evidence that Hill is secretly scheming for the Presidential nomination next year he utterances of his newspaper organs this week furnish it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 12. -- The American Ticket Brokers' Association meets in its thirteenth annual session here to-morrow. The number of delegates in attendance will be the largest of all their conventions, so great is the interest in the association and so important is the business to be transacted. The members of the association say the war of the railroads upon hem has only cemented their organ ization more closely.

CINCINNATI, May 12. -- Cincinnati received its worst defeat of the season to-day at the hands of Ward's men. Rhines was hit hard throughout the game, and at no time after the second inning did Cincinnati's chances for winning seem good. Cincinnati's errors, too, were very costly, and runs were scored on nearly every one of them. John Reilly roused himself to-day and made three hits, one of them a three-base hit. Score:
Young Mr. HARRISON has discovered an interesting condition of affairs in the tinplate market out in Montana and he describes it as follows in his paper, the Helena Journal, of the 7th inst.:

DETROIT, May 12. -- The hoped-for security from the recent rain did not come for the panic-stricken inhabitants of the burned district in this State. Some idea of the vastness of the fire district can be gained from the fact that almost any two of the dozen counties now filled with fire are as large as the whole State of Rhode Island.

ALBANY, May 12. -- The State campaign this year promises to open early and to be more exciting than any other in recent years. There are lots of offices to fill, and candidates may be expected to blossom long before the time when they usually come to the front. Here is a list of the officers to be chosen next November:
Here is something which one of the most prominent doctors in America recently said about the Grip:

Jay Gould made his long-expected appearance before the Rapid-Transit Commission yesterday and made formal request for the use of eighteen miles more of the streets of New-York City for extensions to his elevated railroad system. The Rapid-Transit Commissioners at their meeting last week declared that the elevated railroad company had made no request for a hearing, nor had it been requested to present any plan for an extension of its system.

LONDON, May 12. -- Edward Pinter, alias "Sheeny Al," said to be known in New-York under the name of Sondheim, the American swindler who has been reaping gold in Europe by pretending to be possessed of the philosopher's stone, was again under examination to-day at the Marlborough Street Police Court, charged with attempting to obtain $40,000 by false pretenses from Edwin Streeter, a Bond Street jeweler. The hearing was again adjourned.

CINCINNATI, May 13. -- By just one run the Brooklyns won a game here to-day. It was a most interesting contest. For seven innings the Cincinnats held the lead. They were playing a steady game of ball, and just when victory seemed to be within their grasp the Brooklyns made one of their characteristic spurts and passed the Porkopolitans. This was in the eighth inning. Foutz made a hit, and he was followed by Burns.

CATLETTSBURG, Ky., May 13. -- For the last year or more a deadly enmity has existed between the families of Robert Hall and Joseph Steele, which culminated in a desperate and fatal fight at Hager, McDowell County, West Va., 150 miles up Tug River, on Saturday. The families are neighbors and live only a few miles from the scene of action.

Signor CORTE, the Italian Consul at New-Orleans, who has been summoned to Rome, says that he is "naturally impulsive" and that "words follow consonantly with the impetuosity" of his thoughts. One would judge so from the extraordinary statements in an interview with him reported elsewhere.
There appeared in the issue of the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette of May 5, in its correspondence from New-York over the signature "M.H.," the following paragraph:

ST. Louis, May 13. -- The second day's meeting of the American Boilermakers' Association convened this morning in the ladies' ordinary of the Lindell House. At 10:15 o'clock President Lappan called the convention to order and the report of the Committee on Materials and Tests was presented. This report was rather a long document of a technical nature.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 13. -- At 12 o'clock to-day the Democratic Convention to nominate State officers for Kentucky met in this city. The Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, Auditor, Treasurer, Superintendent of Public Instruction, and Clerk of the Court of Appeals are the officers to be elected. The convention is the most important and will be, it is believed, the stormiest held in years.

The Land Mortgage and Investment Company (Limited) of London has sold through Jere Johnson, Jr., and Parrish Pendelton of this city the Argyle Hotel property at Babylon, L.I., William Ziegler of Brooklyn being the purchaser. The purchase includes the hotel, fourteen cottages, all furnished, a gasbouse, stables, casino, 250 lots, and a lake.

NEW-HAVEN, May 13. -- The annual Spring regatta of the Yale Boat Club will be held on Lake Whitney to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock. The course will be about seven-eighths of a mile and will be between the first and second bridges. There will be three eight-oared shell races -- one between the Varsity and Freshman crews, one between the Junior and Sophomore crews, and one between the winners of the other two races.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 13. -- The manifest trickery by which the so-called Baker Ballot-Reform bill was amended into a state of idiocy at Harrisburg by the Senate committee has aroused deep indignation through Northeastern Pennsylvania, and curses loud and deep are poured forth on the heads of the subservient legislators who obey the secret orders of the bosses and thwart the will of the people.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- It looks as if several Senators, who have been planning to take a Summer trip to Alaska, at the expense of the Government, are to be disappointed. At the last session the Senate authorized the Committee on Territories to make a special inquiry into the advisability of establishing a Territorial Government for Alaska, and to find out the legislative needs of that region.

BUFFALO, May 13. -- President Harvey Hurd of the Lumber Dealers' Association of Buffalo and Tonawanda called a meeting of the association to-day immediately upon receiving the following telegram from the New-York lumber dealers:
NEW-ORLEANS, May 13. -- In an interview with a reporter to-day, Signor Corte said:

TRENTON, N.J., May 13. -- The State Administration yesterday made another record for itself in its relations to the ring of ballot-box stuffers and hoodlums who run public affairs in Hudson County. The Senate committee which unearthed the great frauds on the ballot in the contest between McDonald and Stuhr for Hudson's seat in the State Senate has not been forgotten.

A practical star was made yesterday before the Park Commissioners in the movement to restore Battery Park to its only legal and proper use as a public pleasure ground. Application was made to the Park Commissioners to request the Corporation Counsel to take into court the injunction which the elevated railroad interposed some years ago when the Park Commissioners ordered the nuisance off the Battery.

We have now passed in review the causes at work to promote the productive power of nations. We have seen in what the people of the United States show their pre-eminence, also in what their deficiency. From what has been said it is easy to understand that our industries, not less than our commerce, depend for their healthful growth upon an exchange of commodities and products with other nations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- It was clear and hot this afternoon at Belmont Park, and the horses reeled off several good miles during the second day's programme of the Circuit meeting. Each heat winner earned a new record, five of them getting below 2:30 for the first time, while Virginia Evans clipped 1 3/4 seconds from her best time last season.

The changes made in the ballot-reform law of Pennsylvania by the Senate were, as we have already noted, practically fatal to the purpose of the law. They were intended to make independent nominations impracticable -- 10,000 signatures were required to such a nomination for State offices, for instance, and they were required long before the State Conventions need be held.

Another incendiary fire was started in the village of Woodside, L.I., at an early hour yesterday morning in the residence of Edward Howell. Awaking soon after midnight, Mr. Howell found his house filled with smoke, A hasty search through the rooms revealed the fact that a basket of clothing had been placed in the parlor and set on fire.

HARTFORD, May 13. -- At the meeting of the Alumni Association of the Hartford Theological Seminary to-day officers were chosen as follows: President -- H.C. Alvord; Vice President -- S.W. Dike; Secretary and Treasurer -- C.H. Barber. In the afternoon the cornerstone of the Case Memorial Library was laid, with addresses by Dr. Webb and Mr. J.M. Allen.

LONDON, May 13. -- What is left of the Parnellite organization in Ireland is to receive a fatal blow within the next few days. I am authoritatively informed that the two Harrington brothers, Timothy and Edward, have decided to give in their adhesion to the Nationalist Party. Timothy, report says, will make the first move.

LONDON, May 13. -- The Princess of Wales, by order of the Queen, held the drawing room at Buckingham Palace to-day all presentations made to the Princess being considered equivalent to being presented to the Queen herself. The attendance at the drawing room was smaller than usual. One of the features of the event was the number of Americans and British colonists present.

KANSAS CITY, May 13. -- Not long ago, as a group of men were sitting around a fire in the waiting room of one of the cable roads, the recent floods in the extreme Southwest were under discussion. One of the party, a slightly-built but very muscular man, with clean-cut features and a fine and somewhat delicate face, was a deeply-interested auditor, as the conversation drifted into the discussion of the destruction of Yuma.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- When the doors of the Navy Department were closed this afternoon Acting Secretary Ramsay was no wiser than he was yesterday respecting the whereabouts of the Charleston and the Itata.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 13. -- The "special" bearing the Presidential party entered the State of Nebraska at an early hour this morning, and the President began the work of the day at 6:30 o'clock, which was the time of his arrival at Hastings. A large crowd, including Grand Army men, civic societies, and school children, were gathered at the station, and the President's appearance on the rear platform provoked enthusiasm.

The Rev. Dr. William W. Newell, whose death on Monday at the home of his son-in-law, E.S. Osgood, at Andover, Mass., was noticed in yesterday's TIMES, was one of the best-known Presbyterian clergymen in the country. He was born in South Natick, Mass., eighty-three years ago, was prepared for college at Phillips Academy, Andover, and was graduated from Yale in 1830.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Congressman James Buchanan of New-Jersey passed through the city to-day journeying to Alaska for a pleasure trip. "Before I left Washington," he said, "a canvass of a majority of the votes showed Mr. Crisp's strength to be much greater than that of the other aspirants for the position of Speaker of the next House.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Dresser Wickham, S.T.D., who died in Manchester, Vt., Tuesday, had been for a number of years the oldest Alumnus of Yale College. He was in the ninety-fifth year of his age. Although born in Thompsonville, Conn., April 4, 1797, he was brought up a New-Yorker, his family removing to this city while he was an infant.

The fifty-seventh anniversary of the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, 32 East Thirtieth Street and 29 East Twenty-ninth Street, occurred yesterday. Meetings were held both morning and afternoon.

PITTSBURG, May 13. -- As a prophet, "Col." James Mutrie, the pilot of the New-York Giants, is a failure. When he arrived here on Sunday last he wanted to bet hats, canes, suits of clothes, baskets of wine, and various other things, that the ex-champions would win three of the four games to be played here. Luckily for James, the Pittsburgers had little faith in their team against the Giants.

BOSTON, May 13. -- Gov. Russell sent to the Legislature to-day a message in which was a recommendation for the passage of a general law for the incorporation of safe deposit, loan, and trust companies, and giving his reason for withholding his signature from the special acts incorporating these companies passed by the present Legislature.

Miss Carrie M. Stivers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G.E.W. Stivers, was married yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, by the Rev. Clement Whipple of Luzerne, N.Y., to Frank Lawrence Jones, formerly connected with THE TIMES. The bride wore a becoming costume, consisting of a white corded silk skirt and a coat of Louis XVL brocade.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 13. -- A collision, which narrowly escaped being a terrible disaster, occurred on the Philadelphia and Reading Railway, two miles beyond Bound Brook, this afternoon, when the fast passenger express, known as the Philadelphia flier No. 522, leaving New-York at 4 o'clock, crashed into a freight train moving in the opposite direction.

That solemn group of citizens known as the Quaint Club dined at the Marlborough Tuesday night. The club is modeled on the Clover Club of Philadelphia, and extremely sensitive persons are warned that a Quaint Club dinner will not agree with them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- One of the most important events in the history of Harvard was the opening of a new Semitic museum here this afternoon. The collection is the generous gift of Mr. Jacob H. Shift of New-York, and differs from others of the kind in that it comprises objects directly or indirectly due to Semitic thought or which cast light on Semitic history.

OMAHA, Neb., May 13. -- Nowhere has the President received a heartier or more enthusiastic welcome than was accorded him by the citizens of Omaha to-day. The people turned out en masse in honor of the occasion, and they cheered the President nearly the entire time of his appearance in the city in public.

A preliminary skirmish in the fight by the alleged heirs of A.T. Stewart to gain some of the millions left by the great merchant resulted yesterday in a decided advantage for the defense; and caused Gen. Butler, who is commanding the attacking party, to ask for delay in order to secure more ammunition. When the case was called before Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, there was a big crowd present.

A "gentleman who bears such a relation to both the President and Secretary BLAINE as to be in a position to speak with some certainty concerning their attitude toward each other" has made a statement to the correspondent of the Post which shows that he has not taken much advantage of his "position," for he speaks with the greatest uncertainty.

Judge WALLACE of the United States Circuit Court has decided that the Adams Express Company is not a corporation, but a partnership. He declined, however, to decide whether the statute of this State taxing the capital of corporations applied to that company, as that is a question for the State courts.

The defection of the brothers HARRINGTON from PARNELL is the most conspicuous notification that has yet been made that the Irish leader now remains without a following in his own country. One of the HARRINGTONS was the only one of the Irish envoys who were in this country when Mr. GLADSTONE declined to co-operate any longer with PARNELL who declined to acquiesce in the decision of the Liberal leader.

ST. LOUIS, May 13. -- Little by little all the inside facts concerning the robbery of the State Treasury by ex-Treasurer Noland are coming out. Developments leave little room to doubt that Gov. Francis, as well as Noland's poker-playing associates, knew that there was a deficit, and that a plan was concocted to cover it up and save the administration of Gov. Francis from the stain of the steal.

The Inman Line steamship City of New-York had no vacant staterooms when she sailed for Liverpool yesterday. Among her passengers were one hundred and fourteen delegates to the Good Templar Convention to be held in Edinburgh. After the convention the party will visit London, Paris, and other European cities. Seventy-five delegates to the Millers' National Convention also took passage on the vessel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 13. -- Ohio has in the Hon. Daniel J. Ryan, Secretary of State, a most efficient officer, and one that keeps fully abreast of the times. In all matters that the people are particularly interested in Mr. Ryan furnishes advance sheets, and in this manner the public is furnished wish official information many months in advance of the publication of the official reports.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the National Academy of Design took place yesterday afternoon in the Academy building at Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, and was followed by a dinner in the evening in the hanging room. All the five gentlemen proposed as academicians were elected. This fills the list of 100, and no new members may enter the honorable ranks until death or a resignation makes a place.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- A heavy shower just before the game commenced made the grounds very wet and muddy, but did not prevent the playing of a very good though net exciting game. Both pitchers were effective, but Getzein had a shade the better of it, besides batting in 2 runs on his double to centre in the fifth inning. Score:

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- The German Correspondent celebrated to-day its fiftieth anniversary, also the seventieth anniversary of the birthday of its founder, editor, and proprietor, Col. Frederick Raine. A special edition of the German Correspondent perpetuates in enduring letter press the glories of the semi-centennial and the septuagismal. It is filled with articles by prominent literary men.

The sixty-sixth annual meeting of the American Tract Society was held yesterday morning in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street. At 10 o'clock the Hon. William Strong, LL.D., of Washington, D.C., opened the meeting with a short address. The Rev. J.R. Kerr led in prayer.

Senator Vance is now at his mountain home in Western North Carolina making preparations for a visit to Europe with his wife. They will sail from New-York on the 27th of May on the steamship Germanic. While in Asheville, in answer to a question as to the length of time they would spend abroad, the Senator laughingly replied: "Not long -- until our money gives out." -- Baltimore Sun.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 13. -- The decision of the United States Supreme Court, holding that Pennsylvania can tax the Pullman Car Company on its mileage in that State, will result, it is said, in the collection of about $25,000 of back taxes by the County Treasurers of Iowa. For four years the Executive Council has been assessing Pullman stock, and each year the company enjoined the County Treasurers from collecting the taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- In view of the possible deficiency in the appropriation for the collection of the customs revenues during the present fiscal year, Secretary Foster has determined, as already stated in THE TIMES, to reduce the force in some of the Custom Houses.

For a long time the State Aid Charities Society, through its Visiting Committee, has been calling the attention of the Board of Commissioners of Charities and Correction to certain improvements which are imperatively demanded in city hospitals and other institutions. The condition of affairs found in these places, at least, is such, the committee said, as to warrant apprehensions of calamities and loss of life.

GIBRALTAR, May 14. -- What might have been a repetition of the fearful Utopia disaster occurred at 11 o'clock last night off Europa Point, very near the spot where, on March 16 last, the Utopia sank, carrying down with her a large number of her passengers and crew. Fortunately last night's accident was accompanied by no loss of life.

Ellen King, who nursed Patrick Trenor, the old Vasey Street cordial maker and miser, for a few weeks before his death, yesterday recovered a verdict for her bill of $380 in a suit tried in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Bookstaver against Trenor's temporary administrator, R.N. Todd. She also recovered about $400 on a claim for some pickles which she said she owned and which Trenor allowed to spoil.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The authorities at the Navy Department ought to feel flattered by the ability which a great many persons seem to attribute to them to keep accurately posted upon the movements of a war vessel which is on the high seas, out of sight of land, and hundreds of miles from any point where its movements can be reported by telegraph or otherwise.

DENVER, CoL, May 14. -- The Trans-Missouri Traffic Association met at the Albany Hotel yesterday with a full representation of all the roads present, and it is very probable that the association will be in session all the week. The question of reducing the tourist rate from the Missouri River to Colorado common points from $29 to $25 was considered yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Stokes Van Dusen, daughter of Mr. Samuel D. Van Dusen, to Mr. John Henry Townsend took place yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock at the home of the bride, 61 West Thirty-sixth Street. The Rev. Dr. William H.P. Faunce, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, officiated. The bride's costume was of white embroidered crepe de chine, with a veil of point lace.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 14. -- The Yale class races over a seven-eighths-of-a-mile course were rowed on Lake Whitney this afternoon and were witnessed by fully 2,000 enthusiastic people. The races were satisfactory to all the classes, for while the Juniors were the winners the Freshmen defeated the 'Varsity crew, made the best time of the day, and were defeated by '92 on account of a disabled member of their eight.

A Jury before Judge O'Brien in the Supreme Court yesterday decided, in mandamus proceedings brought by John W. Goodwin against the Police Commissioners to secure his reinstatement as a policeman, that Goodwin's resignation was not voluntarily made. The questions of law in the case will next go before the Special Term for trial.

PITTSBURG, May 14. -- Capt. Ewing sat on the bench here to-day and watched the Pittsburg batters bat. In the language of the baseball enthusiast, they batted his brother all over the lot. As a pitcher young Ewing is not a success, if his game here to-day is any criterion. The Pittsburgs had little difficulty in ganging his curves, and they sent the ball at will in all directions.

The Forest Commission has a chance to show now whether it is good for anything in an emergency. There is nothing more certain than that the running of railroads through the Adirondack forests means their destruction. Experience shows this. Wherever they go fire and the lumberman's axe follow in their wake, and the forest lands are swept with the besom of destruction.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 14. -- South Carolina has just had a little touch of the inquisition. In the last few days educational and religious circles have been deeply stirred by the announcement of the expulsion of Prof. W.J. Alexander from the Faculty of the State University at Columbia in consequence of his religious views.

ALBANY, May 14. -- The American Casualty Insurance and Security Company of Baltimore, Md., which had been refused permission to do business in this State by ex-Superintendent Maxwell, was notified by Superintendent Pierce that upon complying with the requirements set forth in the following letter it would receive permission to do one kind of business in this State.

PITTSBURG, May 14. -- The labor disturbances in Pittsburg and vicinity during the past few months have caused serious loss to the railroads centering in the city. If kept up a year they would cost $7,000,000 or $8,000,000. It is estimated by the officials of the various lines that their losses will aggregate in excess of $25,000 per day, directly due to troubles in the coke region.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- This morning every union switchman in the employ of the Northwestern Railroad, not only in Chicago but at every other point, was discharged. This was done in carrying out the company's resolve not to allow the switchmen to interfere in the affairs of the road and dictate as to the discharge of yardmasters,

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 14. -- The delegates to the Conference of Charities and Correction this morning listened to the report of the Committee on Reports from States. This was followed by comments by delegates and five-minute reports on incidents and phases of work. This afternoon, from 3 to 6 o'clock, a public reception was given the delegates.

RED BANK, N.J., May 14. -- There is likely to be trouble in Christ Episcopal Church, Middletown, before long. The Rev. J.F. Jowitt is the rector. Mr. Jowitt is also the rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, Red Bank, and has his residence here. Some months ago there was a desire on the part of some of the members of Trinity Church that Mr. Jowitt should resign from the parish.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 14. -- A large delegation of Indiana friends met the Presidential party at Montezuma, and made themselves hoarse cheering Mr. Harrison.

LOUISVILLE, May 14. -- Kentucky's Democratic Convention put in this day talking, principally. There were over 100 contested seats, and the Committee on Credentials struggled for hours trying to get order out of the mass and to-night their report was adopted.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 14, via Galveston. -Information of an authoritative nature is that the Government has decided to pursue a most conservative financial policy with a view of letting the country grow up to its present excellent system of railways before extending aid to new roads, although an exception may be made in favor of one or two railroads of military character, demanded for strategic reasons.

Superintendent PIERCE of the Insurance Department has decided to grant a license to the American Casualty and Security Company of Baltimore to do business in this State, but he is cautious in the matter, and proposes to restrict it to one of the several kinds of insurance business which it is organized to do, permitting it to select the branch for itself.

The wholesale discharge of switchmen on the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad merely because they were union men might appear at first sight to be an unjustifiable proceeding, but the facts of the case seem to show that the fault is with the men themselves. Railroad companies as employers of labor hold a peculiar position.

ROME, May 14. -- The Latin text of the Pope's encyclical on the labor question is about to be published. An analysis of the encyclical shows that his Holiness refutes the Socialist theories tending to abolish private property, and upholds the principles of the Church as the first and main element in the solution of social questions.

The defection of Mr. E. DWYER GRAY from the cause of PARNELL is even more important than that of the brothers HARRINGTON, already noticed, seeing that Mr. GRAY is half owner of the Freeman's Journal, which was a trustworthy Parnellite organ throughout the contest in Kilkenny. Such a defection shows the utter hopelessness of the Parnellite cause.

Solomon Crizar, the Polish Hebrew who was arrested for setting fire to the four-story double frame tenement at 222 Johnson Avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday, was examined before Justice Goetting yesterday. Patrolman Candidus testified that when he arrived at the house two fires were burning, one in Crizar's room and one in the cellar.

ALBANY, May 14. -- Superintendent Pierce of the State Insurance Department to-day received from the Hon. C.H. Smith, Insurance Commissioner of Minnesota, a certificate showing that the St. Paul German Insurance Company had complied with the requirements of the New-York Insurance Department as to the investment of its capital, whereupon Mr. Pierce notified the company that its license to transact business in this State would be renewed immediately.

That was a particularly interesting meeting of the Park Commissioners that was held on Wednesday. A number of intelligent and philanthropic citizens appeared before the board to suggest methods by which the parks of the city in general, and the Central Park in particular, could be made more useful to the class to which they are most needful.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 14. -- The Senate this afternoon ordered an investigation of the State finances, especially in regard to expenditures under the specific appropriation, and the committee in charge of the inquiry will report on June 15. This action was brought about in answer to a communication from Controller Staub, showing that the accounts of the departments should be more accurately adjusted.

Congressman Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts was at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday. Speaking of the probable issues in the next Presidential campaign, he said: "It will be impossible to say what figure the tariff question will cut, until it is known what the Democratic Congress attempts in the way of tariff legislation. I believe silver coinage will be made more prominent than some of the well-informed men profess to believe it will."

LONDON, May 14. -- Advices from Chester say that R.C. Duncan of Washington arrived three weeks ago at the Benar View Hotel, at Bettwsy-coed, accompanied by a young foreign lady, whom he introduced as his wife. Duncan was already known at the Benar View Hotel, where he had staid last Summer with two other Americans.

ROME, May 14. -- The Marquis di Rudini in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, discussing the New-Orleans affair, said that it was simply a legal question. The departure of Baron Fava from Washington, he continued, had been ordered as a protest against the action of the United States in rejecting responsibility for the affair.

ALBANY, May 14. -- The fact that the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company has applied to the Commissioners of the Land Office for a grant of State lands in the Adirondacks on which to build its line from Herkimer to Malone has given rise to the statement that the Forest Commission has no longer power over the construction of railroads in the forest preserve.

BOSTON, May 14. -- The Congressional Redistricting Committee of the Legislature this morning made its report of the new thirteen districts. That the committee went a long distance toward satisfying the Democrats is shown by the fact that both of the two dissenters, Senator Breed and Representative Pratt, are Republicans.

The affairs of Levy Brothers Co. look very blue for the unsecured creditors. Those who have not attached are striving to get hold of their property by replevin, and many more demands and third party claims were filed with the Sheriff yesterday. The goods have been picked out by the creditors and set aside at the store, but no goods have yet been taken away as it is thought that they may be rebonded.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 14. -- Pasqual Corte, the Italian Consul, who has been recalled by his Government, in an interview published this morning is reported to have said that it was true he had been instrumental in saving the life of Mayor Shakespeare and the lives of Wickliffe, Parkinson, and other leaders of the Citizens' Committee.

As early as June 23, 1862, the British Government was informed that the Alabama, then building in the port of Liverpool, was a vessel intended for the Confederate service. The Secretary of the Board of Customs at London was informed by the Solicitor of the United States on July 28 that the Alabama would sail next day.

Alfred C. Chapin was appointed assignee of the firm of John Slade Co. of this city before he became Mayor of Brooklyn. He maintained a hold upon the assigneeship, and, should the report of Referee William L. Findley, appointed to pass on his accounts as assignee, be confirmed, he will shortly come in for about $33,000 as fees.
PANAMA, May 5. -- A correspondent writes to the Lima Diario as follows:

The race track was much more popular than the stock market with Wall Street men yesterday, and the result was a dull and sagging market. The bear contingent alone showed any activity, and, helped by further gold export engagements, they were able to knock quotations down throughout the whole list.

When Medad W. Stone died six weeks ago his record as a business man was believed to be stainless. Within the last few days it has come to light that he issued and placed as collaterals for loans unauthorized warehouse certificates of the company of which he was President, these certificates as a matter of fact representing nothing of value.

A proceeding that is avowedly designed to test the constitutionality and efficacy of the new ballot-reform law was begun in Judge McGrath's District Court in Jersey City yesterday. The defendant in the suit is S.B. Ransom, a well-know lawyer of Jersey City, and a conspicuous leader of the Prohibition Party of the State.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Under the present Administration there appears to be an unconquerable disposition for the families in any way connected with it to use their opportunities with all the enterprise and determination to gain that can be discovered. Pension Commissioner Raum, who has already had about enough on his hands to satisfy the mind of any reasonably busy politician, has encountered another trouble.
WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The President and party arrived in Washington at 5:30 o'clock this evening exactly on schedule time.

PITTSBURG, May 15. -- There was another interesting step in the case of Margaret Lane, the wealthy woman who, several days ago, confessed to having stolen a watch at Cleveland in 1874, for the theft of which John B. Gassaway, an Allegheny druggist, wrongfully served two years in the Ohio penitentiary.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Thomas A. Edison, the electrician, called at the World's Fair headquarters to-day and told the officials that they would make a great mistake if they charged more than 25 cents for tickets. While the subject has not been fully discussed by the Directtory, it has been taken for granted that an admission fee of 50 cents would be charged.

Brighter prospects have gladdened the hearts of anglers during the last few days, and new hopes of future success have been incited. As a blue Monday often gives a bad start to a week, so the bit of cold weather of last week almost disheartened the anglers. This was apparent among not only the fishermen who were having sport with the striped bass in the Hudson, but also among the trout anglers.
TORONTO, May 15. -- An editorial in the Globe to-day on the threatened speedy breaking up of Sir John Macdonald's Government is the subject of discussion in political circles here. It says:

LONDON, May 15. -- Dispatches from Chester state that R.C. Duncan of Washington, D.C., who is charged with attempting to murder his wife at Bettws-y-Coed Tuesday evening by beating her over the head with a stone, has been remanded without bail to await the result of his wife's injuries. The physicians express the opinion that Mrs. Duncan cannot live.

The hearing which was given at the Army Building in this city yesterday by the board of army officers designated to inquire into the question of deepening the channel of the Hudson River from this city to Troy was practically a continuation of the hearing given at Albany in January.

Several of the creditors of Levy Brothers Co. and A. Levy Brother, the insolvent clothing merchants of Broadway and Houston Street, have taken legal proceedings in Philadelphia to get possession of moneys due the firms by various houses in that city. Nine attachments have been issued there against the Messrs. Levy, eight of which are under the Fraudulent Debtors' act.

BOSTON, May 15. -- An association of students of the languages that are written in odd symbols assembled at the hall of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences this morning and transacted the annual routine business. Papers on interesting subjects were read. The organization is called the American Oriental Society.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- The situation of the Chicago and Northwestern Road, as affected by the discharge of all the switchmen and yardmasters, has developed no new features this morning. General Manager Whitman is constantly in receipt of telegrams from all points on the system, and without exception they report an encouraging state of affairs.

The alleged Stewart heirs, who have had visions of millions of dollars dancing before their eyes, are going back to Ireland. To use the expression of lawyers, they have been "knocked out" and need a breathing spell.
ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- A special from the city of Mexico says:

The Evening Post is convinced that when the Geneva tribunal decided that Great Britain did not take proper and effective "measures for the pursuit and arrest" of the Alabama after her escape from Liverpool, it merely meant that she allowed the Confederate cruiser to remain "unmolested" when she "ran into Moelfra Bay" on the evening of her escape.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 15. -- The facts about the establishment of tin-plate works in St. Louis by ex-Congressman F.G. Niedringhaus have caused a great deal of comment. Mr. George Wiegand, Vice President of the Niedringhaus Company, evidently has little faith in the matter as a practical business enterprise, but he declined to discuss the private business affairs of his firm.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 15. -- A personal encounter in the caucus late last night grew out of a criticism of the course of Mann and Kirk of Hernando County made by Representative Saulsbury of Citra County. Mr. Clark of Polk good-naturedly interrupted Kirk, who was replying to Saulsbury. This angered Kirk exceedingly.

The Faculty of the Union Theological Seminary has issued a statement embodying very fully its views on the matter of Prof. Briggs's orthodoxy, and which, coming from theologians of such acknowledged standing, seems likely to have great weight in the present controversy. This statement is here given in full:

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- It was only after a very long delay that the Tribune ventured, a day or two ago, a defense of Blaine and Elkins in the course of those gentlemen on the seal question. According to this defense it was Blaine who proposed, away back last January, that Salisbury consent for a "closed time" this season.

ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- Indications are good for the withdrawal of the boycott against the Anheuser-Busch and Lemps beer that has been so vigorously pushed all over the Union, and for adjustment of the breweries' trouble with the Brewers and Malsters' Union. John Devlin of the General Executive Board, Knights of Labor, has been in the city for several days, and has hold conferences with Adolphus Busch with a view to settling the dispute.

BERLIN, May 15. -- The heavy imports of American gold into Europe in general, in Germany in particular, have drawn the attention of financiers in Germany to the matter. Herr Bleichroder, the well-known banker, who shares with the Rothschilds financial power on the Continent, in an interview to-day said:

The Board of Electrical Control did some important business yesterday. It divided the contract for subway construction between the old Consolidated Subway Company and the new Empire City Subway Company. The Consolidated Company will build high-tension or electric-light subways in the future and control those already built, and the Empire Company will build the low-tension or telegraph and telephone subways and control those of that class now in operation.

Another feast of good things is in store for race-lovers at the Brooklyn track this afternoon. Chief among the attractions is the Carlton Stakes for three-year-olds at a mile, in which Bolero, Strathmeath, Terrifier, Warpath, and other good ones will meet for the first time in their three-year-old form, and that they will make a grand race is a certainty.

A few days ago the American Wool Reporter published a report of some remarks made to its Philadelphia correspondent by Mr. THOMAS DOLAN, President of the high-tariff Manufacturers' Club of that city and a prominent member of the Board of Managers of the Protective Tariff League. Mr. DOLAN appears to have been very angry about the tricks and jobs which the three political shepherds of Ohio put into the McKinley wool schedule.
CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 15. -- Under the caption, "The Real Status of the Strike," the Connellsville Courier, the recognized authority on all matters touching the trade, says in to-day's issue:

ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- Facts that have gradually developed have demonstrated beyond doubt that there was a neat little scheme arranged by which the theft of $32,000 from the State Treasury by Edward Noland was to be concealed, the money paid back by the bondsmen, and the Francis administration saved from disgrace.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- To-day's game was an old-fashioned slugging match, Ryan starting with a home-run hit on the first ball pitched. At the end of the seventh Hutchison was substituted for Gumbert, who was getting hit much harder than Lovett, the latter having settled down to good work. Dahlen, Burns, and Terry did some great stick work. Score:

United States Marshal Daniel Lake of Brooklyn fell or was pushed off the platform of a crowded car on Culver's Railroad while on his way home from the races yesterday afternoon, and fell into the out at Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, receiving injuries of a serious nature. It was said last night that he would probably recover, but that he would be a cripple for life.

The son of Pension Commissioner RAUM seems to have been showing the fruits of the political and official training to which he has been subjected. The scandalous performances which have led to his enforced resignation of the office of assistant chief clerk in the Pension Bureau are merely an imprudent and injudicious application of the principles of spoils politics.

OCEAN GROVE, May 15. -- The programme of the special services to be held at this famous religious resort during the coming season has just been made public by the President of the association, the Rev. Dr. E.H. Stokes. The meetings are varied in their character, and the attractions and the dates on which they occur are as follows:

The description of Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS'S experiments in the manufacture of tin plate, which was published in THE TIMES yesterday, will not help our neighbor, the Tribune, to establish the truth of its assertion that "the American market in six months' time has been so far filled by American tin plate as to compel the Welsh Trust to shut down."

CLEVELAND, May 15. -- For the fourth time in succession the New-Yorks were beaten to-day. It was their first appearance in this city this season, and, as the Philadelphias had just won four successive games from the local club, the Giants naturally looked for a turn of affairs. But they didn't turn worth a cent, and the Giants to-night are in a sorrowful mood.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- There was no trotting at Belmont Park this afternoon, owing to the rain. The two classes will be called to-morrow if the track dries out sufficiently.

LOUISVILLE, May 16. -- A race probably without a parallel in the history of racing was run on the track at Churchill Downs to-day. It was in the second race, a selling affair at a mile, in which thirteen horses started. Ed Leonard, carrying 99 pounds, and with Bunn in the saddle, was the favorite, with Comedy, 106 pounds, Thorpe up, the fourth or fifth choice, at 6 to 1.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- A party of the university's mechanical engineering students has been away this week on a New-England trip under the direction of Prof. H.W. Sprangler, United States Navy, and Instructor C.W. Pike. The tour is decidedly longer than ever before and takes in a dozen of the leading manufacturing towns.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 16. -- The jury in the criminal court to-night returned a verdict of guilty in the case of Philip Baker, charged with the murder of Mrs. Laura Nelson, which sends him to the gallows.

Much as fashionable folk have shown that they enjoy the pony races and steeplechases given by the American Pony Racing Association, they did not dare to brave the inclement weather of yesterday to see the third series of the season run on the Queen and Suffolk County Club course, at Huntington, L.I. The attendance was very small and made up almost wholly of the enthusiasts who own ponies and the attaches of their stables.

The return of Richard Croker has given an impetus to political talk, and from now on Tammany will be active in the arrangements for the Fall campaign. Just what is to be fought for this year is of interest at this time. The list off the State officers that are to be elected is as follows:

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 16. -- Tuesday evening the Senior Class gave a German entertainment consisting of soup and tableaus. "Gretchen," with Schubert's spinning song, "Die Lorelei," and the seven tableaus illustrating the story of "Schneewitzchen," were received with special favor. Miss Glen of the Sophomore Class was Gretchen, Miss Fanning the Lorelei, Miss Freeman the Queen, and Miss Gray of the Junior Class Schneewitzchen.

RIVAS, Nicaragua, April 20. -- Nicaragua Land of beautiful scenery, of sunny skies and mountains blue, and flashing waters; of healthful and delightful climate; of fruitful soil and innumerable fruits; of industrious, simple, polite, and fun-loving people, whose trials of to-day are mitigated by a blissful dream of the possibilities of to-morrow!

NEW-HAVEN, May 16. -- Prof. William R. Harper, President-elect of the new Chicago University, whose labors at Yale are nearly ended, was the recipient of a farewell banquet at Redcliffe's, Thursday evening, given by the Hebrew and Semitic Clubs of this university. The programmes of the banquet were printed in Sanscrit. Dr. F.K. Sanders, the toastmaster, called on Prof. Harper for the first speech, the subject of which was "Semitic Studies at Yale, 1886-91."

If every pretty maiden has not a stock of cotton gowns as pretty as herself this year, it will not be the fault of the manufacturers, but rather of the modistes, who insist that the price of the simple cotton fabrics shall be trebled, and often a good deal more, by that of the silk foundation. This union of silk and cotton is, perhaps, the leading absurdity of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The beneficial effects of legislation recently enacted by Congress, at the instance of the War Department, to cure the evil of desertion are now becoming manifest. April and May usually show the heaviest record of desertions, for the reason that farming operations are resumed, .and the dissatisfied soldiers who are inclined to desert are reasonably sure of finding work and shelter.

I wonder whether Mr. Blaine aver sees those delightful contributions to the humorous literature of our country which appear monthly, issued from the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of State, printed at the Government Prating Office, and entitled "Reports from the Consuls of the United States." Mr. Blaine writes and speaks good English.
CHICAGO, May 16. -- Gen. Green B. Raum, Commissioner of Pensions, was in Chicago yesterday, when the news of his son's resignation was first published.

I thought Hospital Number Ten at Richmond the most wretched and hope-destroying place I had ever been in, and it certainly was up to that time, but it was as a palace to a morgue compared with the poorhouse in Charleston, S.C. The hospital ward must have been the filthiest, most stifling, and malodorous apartment in the building, for it would tax the imagination of Dante himself to conceive of anything worse.

LONDON, May 16. -- The Transatlantic Cattle Trade Committee to-day completed a voluminous report upon the subject which it has been investigating. After an elaborate review of the history and present condition of the trade, the report gives an implied approval of the United States regulations for the inspection and shipment of cattle.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- The programmes for the approaching Commencement Week, from June 6 to June 10, have just been issued. Saturday, June 6, will be one of the most interesting days. The reading of theses by the graduating class of the John C. Green School of Science will take place in Chemical Hall at 10 A.M. The annual Caledonian games will be held on the university athletic grounds at 11:30 A.M.

The car was so densely packed that three rows of men stood in the aisle. The train had just left the Forty-second Street and Sixth Avenue station on its way up town when a woman rose from one of the cross seats in the middle of the car and began to plow her way toward the rear door. She was middle-aged, stout, vigorous, and impetuous. She was also handsomely dressed.

ATHENS. -- It is impossible for any one who visits Athens not to imbibe something of its unique artistic inspiration of the beautiful; it is here alone the most perfect conception of the ideal is to be found, and that architecture and sculpture reveal forms of the beautiful which no convention can alter or amend.

All the calculations yesterday previous to the appearance of the bank statement were that it would show a loss in the surplus reserve of about $3,500,000; and fully impressed with this idea the traders sold stocks with freedom and alacrity from ten o'clock to a quarter to twelve, when the statement did appear. Thereupon ensued a wild scramble to buy back the stocks sold.

Last December, while the "U and I" company were playing in San Francisco, George W. Lederer brought suit against Prof. Herrmann, and succeeded in having the court dissolve the partnership existing between Herrmann and himself. Be brought in a claim of over $3,500 against Prof. Herrmann, stating that the professor had overdrawn to that amount.

It was a Morris day at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's race track yesterday, the representatives of the stable of J.A. A.H. Morris running first and second in both of the stake races, and winning the only two other races in which they started. Four first moneys and two seconds is a good enough record for any one and one that has rarely been equaled in racing annals.

NORWICH, May 16. -- June 15 will be a great day in the annals of the historic Revolutionary town of Lebanon, twelve miles north of this city, for on that day the Connecticut Society of the Sons of the American Revolution and the Connecticut Historical Society of Hartford will unite in celebrating the restoration of the famous "old war office" of Jonathan Trumbull, ("Brother Jonathan,") Connecticut's war Governor in the struggle for independence.

Whitsuntide, the harvest festival of the ancient Hebrews, under the name of Pentecost, and the festival in Christian churches of the commemoration of the miracle of Pentecost related in the second chapter of the Acts of the Apostles, will be celebrated with formal observances in all ritualistic churches to-day, and informally in most orthodox churches that have no set ritual.

LONDON, May 16. -- Henry Irving's revival of "The Corsican Brothers" at the Lyceum Theatre has been made memorable and attractive by the almost unprecedented scenic splendor of the play. This feature and Ellen Terry's debut in the part of Nance Oldfield in Reade's play of that name wore the chief events of the dramatic week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16. -- The first contest for the cup offered by Harvard and Yale graduates to the better college in track athletics was easily won by Harvard on Holmes Field this afternoon. The 4,000 spectators who were crowded on the benches about the field had their pleasure greatly marred by the driving rain which began to pour down upon them shortly after the games began and continued throughout the afternoon.

LONDON, May 16. -- Ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed of the United States House of Representatives, who has been visiting Rome, devoted himself almost entirely to sightseeing there, and, after thoroughly doing Rome, went to Naples, where he visited Vesuvius, Pompeii, Capri, and other attractions in the neighborhood. He is now understood to be in Northern Italy.

Books to popularize the stars are not so infrequent that Miss Clerke's volume will lack rivals. There are the works of the late Richard A. Proctor, especially designed to make easy the study or daily observation of the stars. There are the more formidable works of Prof. Norman Lockyer and the "New Astronomy" of Prof. Charles A. Young, to say nothing of the score of older astronomies meant for students more or less advanced.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Business at the theatres continues to be good, although the end of the regular season is at hand. The presence in the city of first-class attractions at-nearly all the theatres accounts for this. This is the time of year when the New-York stock companies play engagements here, and it is also the time of year when there are many strangers in the city who visit the places of amusement.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 16. -- Newport has had good weather this week, which has brought many cottagers to remain permanently and many more to prospect for Summer homes or to place their own in readiness for early use. On every hand are the signs of the speedy advent of the full tide of Summer life.

BRUNSWICK, May 16. -- The second league game of the season was played on the delta, Wednesday. Bowdoin won easily by a score of 23 to 6, batting both of Colby's pitchers at will. Spring pitched a fine game for Bowdoin, only two hits being made off him up to the ninth inning.

The Furst Bismarck of the Hamburg-American Packet Company steamed triumphantly up the harbor yesterday, having made the fastest maiden trip on record. Her time between Southampton and New-York was 6 days 14 hours and 15 minutes, which lowers all previous maiden records by 7 hours and 15 minutes.

The United States flagship Philadelphia, bearing the blue pennant of Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi, steamed up through the Narrows yesterday afternoon and came to anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I. The colors on the flagstaff at the stern of the cruiser were drooping at half mast when the vessel passed up the river, signifying that death had invaded her crew.

The appropriations for the public expenses of the State of Connecticut expire on the 1st of July, and in consequence of the political dead-lock none have been made for the fiscal year beginning then. The statutes of the State are very strict in forbidding the expenditure of public money without specific appropriation or in excess of appropriations.

New-York City has long been recognized as pro-eminently the club city of America, but possibly that indefinable, intangible personage, "the average clubman," has never realized that it is just as pre-eminently the yacht club city of the Western Continent. There are more yacht clubs with quarters in New-York -- that is to say, in "the greater New-York" -- than in any other American city.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- There is a manifest disposition at the Interior Department to-day to palliate the offenses for which Mr. Green B. Raum, Jr., was required to resign. The story related yesterday about the sale of places and an irregular promotion is glozed over. The alleged misappropriation of conscience funds is "explained," and everything except the enforced "resignation" of Mr. Raum is taken back.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A circular letter of instruction to special agents, relating to timber reservations, was to-day promulgated from the General Land Office. After quoting Section 24 of the General Land act of March 3, 1891, the circular says:

Pelham Bay Park was laid out for the benefit of the poor people of New-York City. So said the commission that laid it out, and added that such a park was needed immediately. It is the grandest of all the new parks. Just now it is as absolutely useless to the poor people of this city as if it had never been laid out.

THE PRETTY FELLOW. -- The dress of a pretty fellow was a matter of constant study and care. Embroidered coats, laced waistcoats -- with gold-worked buttonholes -- and black velvet breeches, were his delight. For the last-mentioned garments, black velvet was for years the extremely fashionable material.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Harrisburg says: "The publication of the small amount paid into the State Treasury by City Treasurer Bardsley for retailers' licenses has led to many inquiries at the financial offices of the State. The report of the Auditor General closes with the 30th of November, which closes the fiscal year, to enable the financial reports to be made up for the Legislature in January.

TRUCKEE, Cal., May 16. -- There is great excitement in Truckee over the discovery of a portion of the treasure buried by the Donner party in 1846-7. In the early days of gold excitement in this State the Donner party attempted to cross the mountains into California by an untried pass. They were snowed up in the mountains, and suffered great hardships, many dying from cold and starvation.

Though Commander Cameron does not specify how he came by the "log" of James Choyce, Master Mariner, it contains sufficient internal evidence of genuineness to warrant one in accepting it as true. The Commander has drawn on the cuts in Juan de Ulloa's travels in South America for illustrations, but these, while curious in themselves, hardly represent the period covered by Choyce's adventures as whaler, prisoner, and pirate off the Chilean and Peruvian coasts.

Gothic art is a term to which we are less accustomed than we are to Gothic architecture, and if the ideas suggested by the latter are somewhat vague, much more so are the ideas suggested by art in general called Gothic. It is well enough known that Gothic is a misnomer, having sprung up as an epithet which was to discredit whatever peoples, fashions, or things to which it was applied.

The discontent that is reported to have steadily grown in the mind of Mr. NOBLE since he assumed charge of the Interior Department can hardly be assuaged by the Raum incident. He says, and we doubt not with entire sincerity, that Commissioner RAUM has acted in the case of his son as an honorable man and a good officer should act.

Here is a story from Western Pennsylvania which matches any told by Miss Wilkins and other delineators of New-England thrift and unconscious humor. A young woman whose maiden home was in one of the small cities of interior New-York followed the fortunes of her husband, a Calvinistic minister, to his first charge, a "Centre" Church near the Ohio line of the Keystone State.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 16. -- The Ulster and Delaware, Stony Clove and Catskill Mountain, and Kaaterskill Railroads are being put in good condition for the coming Summer traffic which there is every reason to expect will be large. Wagner palace and drawing-room coaches will be run through to Stamford from New-York and Philadelphia.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The negotiations for a German-Austrian commercial treaty with Spain have become curiously involved with the reciprocity convention proposed by Gen. John W. Foster, the special representative of the United States.

Major Lewis Balch, the originator of the radical changes proposed to be made by the commission appointed by the Commander in Chief, is not at all disheartened by the failure of his propositions to become law. The scheme to create a Major General who should exercise command of the National Guard force and be intrusted with the functions heretofore reposed in the Commander in Chief has only been delayed for a period.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16. -- The friends and students of Syracuse University were all gratified to learn that the Faculty had reconsidered the question of caps and gowns which were to be worn at the Commencement exercises in June. Neither professors nor students will wear them, at least this year. It was to be truly an innovation, and no good reason was or apparently could be given for the change.

At a sale in London this month some paintings by English artists were sold at very good prices. "Rivaulx Abbey" by Copley Fielding brought $4,575, and "Loch Lomond" $2,500. "St. Agatha's Abbey," water-color by Turner, fetched $3,000, and his "Eridge Castle, Kent," 4,600. Turner's water color "Edinburgh from the Water of Leith," shown in 1802 at the Royal Academy, went for $4,350.

The poolroom keepers are on the run. The arrests of Friday caused them to drop the bold front with which they had so carefully adorned themselves, and when the police, under the spur of THE TIMES'S exposure of their nefarious methods, continued to arrest them yesterday, they gave themselves over to wholesome fear, and next week will see them all in full flight if the police persist in doing their duty.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 16. -- The few who were in the Mayor's parlor to-day shortly before noon were treated to a rare display of "oral pyrotechnics," as his Honor later put it. It happened thus:...

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $141,246,900, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,770,000; 4 12 per cents, $23,173,450; 4 per cents, $110,308,450.

The bank statement yesterday revealed a condition of strength in the money market that the most sanguine observers had not expected. Instead of a falling off in the surplus reserve proportionate to the shipments of gold, and continuing the decrease shown last week, there was a slight advance in the reserve.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 16. -- Prof. Wiggins, the weather prophet, to-day expressed surprise upon reading that Edison had said in Chicago that he hoped to have ready for the World's Fair such a happy combination of photography and electricity that a man can sit in his own parlor and see depicted upon a curtain the forms of the players in opera upon a distant stage, and to hear the voices of the singers.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- At last there is news from Acapulco that is extremely interesting and that may turn out to be vitally important to the cause of the revolutionists in Chile. The United States steamer Charleston and the Esmeralda of the Chilean insurgent navy are both in the Mexican harbor, and the Itata, the object of the Charleston's search, is still to be heard from.

Prof. Freeman here returns to one of his earliest fields of study. He tells us his thoughts were first drawn toward Sicily nearly fifty years ago, and that he had contemplated a history of the island before his intentions in regard to the Norman conquest of England had taken any definite shape.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The Supreme Council of Federated Railway Employes decided against the Chicago and Northwestern switchmen this evening. The council recommended that the switchmen's officers call upon the railway officials with a view to the reinstatement of as many of their old hands as places could be provided for.

Country editors occasionally get, or say they do, apples, or potatoes, or pumpkins in payment of yearly subscriptions; country ministers are sometimes offered queer things as marriage fees; but lawyers, whether of country or city, generally get plain cash in payment of their services. When, therefore, a client sends livestock to a city lawyer the fact becomes worthy of note.

There has been more activity among the boat clubs in the vicinity of New-York this Spring than in any corresponding period in years. The reason for this seemingly new life in boating circles is simple. Never before has there been such a promising season in prospect at this time of the year, and consequently such a great Incentive for amateur oarsmen to train for coming events.

The mammoth new passenger station of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City was illuminated last night, and soon after midnight the first train was sent out over the elevated structure that crosses Jersey City. It was the "owl train" for Philadelphia, and the "owl train" from Philadelphia came into the new station early this morning.

Whenever an act of violence from which a foreigner suffers is committed in Japan, the newspapers of America and Europe are suddenly filled with references to "a long series of outrages and murders," alleged to have been perpetrated by Japanese assassins, in spite of repeated demonstrations that the "outrages and murders" in question are, in the main, purely mythical.

This treatise of Gen. Derrecagaix, who was formerly Vice Commandant of the Superior War School at Paris, and is now Director of the Geographical Service of the French Army, includes the most detailed tactical discussion of the war of 1870, on the French side, that we now recall having seen.

Why are the public schools of the greatest city on the continent among the worst in the world? That is a question that must have occurred to many who have to send their children to the schools and to many who would like to and are put to considerable inconvenience because they cannot do so with a clear conscience.

PATERSON, N.J., May 16. -- Alderman James Miller of the Sixth Ward of this city was tried yesterday before Judge Dixon on an indictment for official extortion. The complainant in the case, and practically the only witness for the State, was Justice of the Peace William P. Hudson. Hudson testified that he induced Alderman Miller to help him get permission from the Board of Aldermen on Feb. 27, 1890, to alter a frame building.

Some of the Episcopal clergymen of this city who united in the remonstrance addressed to the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of the Diocese of New-York, against the uncanonical practices of the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford and the Rev. R. Heber Newton have come to the conclusion that the time has arrived when those ministers should be brought to book and disciplined by ecclesiastical authority.

ALBANY, May 16. -- Gov. Hill's organ, the Albany Times, prints to-night an editorial designed to befuddle the Democrats who are trying to solve the problem connected with the Gubernatorial nomination.

ST. LOUIS, May 16. -- The Rev. Narayan Sheshadri, D.D., and son, of Bombay, India, are now in St. Louis. The doctor is a native of India. In the course of a long interview with THE TIMES'S correspondent he said:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, May 16. -- "What is the Greatest Benefit Contributed to Civilization by the United States During the Past Century?" was the subject given to the ten students who contested for the Bussing prize for extempore speaking at Rutgers this week. Dr. David Murray, Judge Woodbridge Strong, and Prof. W.R. Newton, the judges, awarded the first prize to John H. Raven of Brooklyn, N.Y., and the second to Clifford H. Strang of Montrose-on-Hudson, N.Y.

LONDON, May 16. -- We are are still sitting, as it were, in the dark waiting for the curtain to be lifted upon the strange drama now being arranged behind the scenes, on which the finances of the world and the peace of Europe are made to depend -- upon the treatment meted out by a barbarous peasantry in remote Eastern lands to scarcely more civilized Jewish ghettos.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 16. -- Radbourne did more than any one else to defeat the Boston club to-day, and the hits of the visitors until the last inning, when three were made in succession, were few and far between. Two of Boston's errors let in runs. Attendance 2,400. Score:

LENOX, Mass., May 16. -- The cottagers have been coming to Lenox the last week more rapidly than at any time this season, and by June 1 nearly every house will be occupied. The special reason why so many are coming early is the Turnure-Lanier wedding, which takes place June 11, when George Turnure will wed Miss Lizzie, daughter of Charles Lanier.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 16. -- The Rev. E.C. Hoag of Brooklyn, N.Y., has been assigned to the Methodist church pastorate in Simsbury, succeeding the late Rev. Arza Hill. The Rev. F.M. North of the Methodist church in Middletown has been granted a three months leave of absence by his congregation, and will spend the Summer in Europe.

At last we have from the inner circle of those who are so closely guarding the infant tin-plate industry an admission that will enlighten many worthy persons who have been misled by the McKinley press. It is the Vice President of Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS'S manufacturing company in St. Louis who has consented to make this admission.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17. -- The squabble between the old Government in this city and the new Government, as represented in Boss Smith's new Board of Works, has resulted in the nonpayment of the city laborers. About four hundred of these needy fellows presented their warrants yesterday for the pittances they had earned, but the drafts were not honored.

There are men whose achievements are greater in the truth than in the legend. Carnot occupies the place of honor among the Generals of the first republic of France admirably sketched by Gen. Thoumas; Carnot takes precedence of Jourdan, Hoche, Marceau, Kleber, Desaix, Massens, and Augereau; but not as the creator of fourteen improvised armies.
