WILMINGTON, N.C., May 17. -- Several negroes having been heard making threats to attack the jail last night and release Kit Huggins, the driver of an omnibus which ran over and killed a little white boy named Liston Chadwick, Sheriff Stedman, with twenty well-armed special deputies, took charge of the jail, and the police force of the city received special instructions to be on the alert.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17. -- If any Republican leader supposes the settlement of the strike in the sanitary potteries here within the last week was a victory for protection he is mistaken. If the same leader supposes the workmen who were locked out from December to May will continue to support protection and vote the Republican ticket in the future, as in the past, he is also mistaken.

We have no doubt that the view taken by the more thoughtful financiers in Wall Street as to the probable course of our relations with Europe is reasonable. This view is that the drain of gold now going on cannot be continued very long; that when our crops begin to go forward, or preparations are made for their transfer, the gold now flowing toward Europe will return.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17. -- The sixth annual reunion of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks began here to-day. Delegations are present from Indianapolis, Baltimore, Erie, Penn.; Cleveland, Ohio; Butler, Penn.; Columbus, Ohio; Evansville, Ind.; St. Louis, Chicago, Reading, Penn; Pittsburg, Kalamazoo, Grand Rapids, Detroit, Birmingham, Ala.; Greenville, Miss.; Middlesborough, Ky.; Hartford, Conn.; Washington, New-York, Boston, and San Francisco. The meetings will continue three days.

The Manufacturers' Club of Philadelphia, a well-known high-tariff organization, publishes a fortnightly paper called the Manufacturer, in which the doctrines of McKinleyism are supported. Mr. THOMAS DOLAN is not only the President of this club, but also one of five persons who supervise the publication of the Manufacturer.

Eugene McCaa, in an open letter addressed to Senator Pugh of Alabama, gives that gentleman some excellent advice touching his inclination to sacrifice his convictions in answer to the demands of political quacks. In the course of the letter he says: "The first necessity of Democrats is to win the Presidency and control of Congress: and the coinage questions will be settled in accordance with wise statesmanship and true scientific principles of international finance.

Few who care for Orient antiquities can fail to have consulted the dozen little volumes called "Records of the Past" and regretted that their publication should have ceased for so many years. In 1888 Prof. Sayce determined to renew the publication of these little books, and the first volume belongs to 1889, though it was only last Winter that the first two made their appearance on this side.

It is every day becoming more evident that the plan for embarking the Farmers' Alliance upon a third party movement in the South and West is doomed to failure. A dispatch from Greensborough, N.C., gives some of the reasons why this movement has languished in the South. The main cause was the character of its most active and interested promoter, "Col." POLK, the President of the Alliance.

GREENSBOROUGH, N.C., May 17. -- Any hope that may have been cherished by certain leaders of the Alliance in the South of the consolidation of a third party with this organization as its nucleus and its motive force, and heir of the fortunes of the defunct old parties, and born of the union of the Western and Southern wings of it, seems to have been dispelled by the gradual falling apart of the incoherent mass.

Our readers will find in another column an Albany dispatch giving some interesting notes of the recent visit of Mr. CLEVELAND to Buffalo. It is not the fault of Mr. CLEVELAND or of his friends if notes of this sort relatein part to the comparisons made in many quarters between Mr. CLEVELAND and Gov. HILL.

The railroads are preparing to handle the largest watermelon crop this year they have ever handled. Advices received from growers and agents show that the acreage this year exceeds that of last year by about 3,000 acres, and that the total acreage in the State is between 18,000 and 20,000 acres. The reports also show that the crop is in good condition, and with fair prospects of a large yield.

MALONE, May 17. -- The unanimity and vigor with which all of the great journals of the metropolis have suddenly awakened to the fact that a railroad is to be built through the Adirondacks, is a little amusing here, where the enterprise has been the one absorbing topic of conversation and newspaper comment for more than a month.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- As far as the Navy Department officials know to-night, there has been no change in the situation in the harbor of Acapulco. The Charleston and the Esmeralda are still there, watching each other and waiting for the Itata to arrive.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Two women and a child, members of a pleasure party of eight persons, were drowned before the eyes of hundreds of people, in the Schuylkill River, this afternoon. The party consisted of Mary Carr, single, aged thirty-two; Mrs. Susan Pasco, aged twenty-four, and her four-year-old child, Christopher Pasco; Mrs. Mary Jones, married, and her five-year-old son, Willie Jones; Fred Tiedman, aged forty-one; Robert Chamberlain, aged twenty-nine, and Samuel Peltz, aged twenty-five.

" BOSTON, May 17. -- There is a possibility that the religious foundation of the historical old West Church may be transplanted and given an opportunity to grow up again. When it was announced several months ago that the old church edifice at the West End would have to be sold, the Rev. Brooke Herford suggested a plan for the continuance of the society.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- After an absence of four weeks, Postmaster General Wanamaker was heartily welcomed back to his old place as Superintendent of the Sunday school at Bethany Presbyterian Church this afternoon. When he entered the school room the assembled scholars greeted him with exclamations which expressed no little pleasure at his return.

New materials have accumulated so fast during the last ten years that there is room for a tolerably exhaustive popular textbook which shall cover the entire field of the Mammalia without descending too much to particulars. Practice in popularization was gained by Dr. Flower in the preparation of the articles Mammalia, together with some forty shorter articles to the ninth edition of the Britannica.

LONDON, May 17. -- Discount was a shade easier yesterday, being quoted at 4 3/4 for three months and 4 1/4 for short. High rates are certain to prevail for several weeks. Gold, to the amount of 1,500,000, it is expected, will be drawn by the Russian Government during the present week, partly from here and partly from Paria, with a further drain of 2,500,000 during June.

ST. LOUIS, May 17. -- The Mutual Wheel Company was formed at a meeting of carriagemakers from different parts of the country at the Southern Hotel Saturday. The scheme was brought about by impositions put upon the purchasers of wheels by the Wheel Trust, which has had control of 90 per cent. of the wheel factories of this country for about eighteen months.

Nothing could well be more distressing than the accounts of the persecutions of the Russian Jews, and also nothing could be more puzzling. Why the Czar should have issued the ukases that are inflicting such frightful suffering is a question to which the answer is by no means obvious. Doubtless there is a genuine and extensive religious prejudice against Jews among the members of the orthodox Church.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 17. -- The scheme to give Plainfield rapid transit through the trolley system has been neatly frustrated just when it seemed as though nothing could prevent its consummation. For two years the city has been in a turmoil over the rapid transit question. After months of legislation the Common Council, in spite of stormy meetings held by indignant citizens and much bitter, opposition through the local newspapers, decided to adopt the trolley.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Many people high in official position have been much surprised at the recent revelations concerning the part which S.B. Elkins has taken in the fur-seal scheme which Mr. Blaine tried to carry through secretly and then publicly attempted to place the shame of it on John Bull.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 17. -- The Rev. H.A. Whitman of the Unitarian Church to-day preached a strong sermon regarding the dismissal of Dr. W.J. Alexander from the Faculty of the University of South Carolina for holding Unitarian views. He said:
PARIS, May 17. -- Charles Dudley Warner has returned from his tour of the East and is now in Rome. He has completed a novel depicting American society.

The Casino has begun its Summer season with every promise of success. No prettier spectacle than the production of "Apollo," has graced the stage of this house in some time, and Lillian Russell's success as the priestess of the temple is pronounced. Verses in Italian, French, and German have been added to the duet for Edwin Stevens and Jefferson De Angelis, and the third act has been made the comedy act of the opera.

BOSTON, May 17. -- Under the apportionment of seats for the Fifty-third Congress, based upon the footings of Mr. Porter's decennial census, Massachusetts is entitled to thirteen members in the lower house of Congress, instead of twelve, which constituted her quota by the census of 1880. The duty of redistricting the State for the purpose of securing this increased representation devolved upon the present Legislature.

Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James's Place, Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the memorial services of Charles Pratt. Admission to the church was given by card to a great number of persons, who came to show the respect and regard they felt for the character of the philanthropist.

ROCHESTER, Penn., May 17. -- There was a larger congregation than usual in the Baptist Church this morning. The pastor, the Rev. A.J. Bonsell, last Sunday tendered his resignation on account of the objections of the Rev. Aaron Wilson, a retired Baptist minister and a member of his congregation, to his views on the inspiration of the Bible, the divinity of Christ, and eternal punishment.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 17. -- The 500 members of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne are rejoicing over the completion of their new clubhouse, which will be opened for inspection to-morrow evening. The new clubhouse is situated upon the ten-acre grounds on Avenue A and the Newark Bay shore. It faces the southeast and overlooks the whole field.

ST. LOUIS, May 17. -- The Emma Juch Opera Company closed the season here last night. Yesterday afternoon the audience assembled to hear "Carmen," but it heard the "Bohemian Girl" instead, and during the entire performance two constables sat in the orchestra.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 17. -- Mayor Shakespeare yesterday addressed Gov. Nicholls as follows:

The New York Presbytery assembled yesterday at the Bohemian Church, as Seventy-fourth Street, for the ordination of two young ministers, Frank Pokovny and Vaclav Losa. Before the ordination services, however, Dr. Shearer announced as the committee to formulate the mode of procedure against Prof. Briggs Dr. G.W.F. Birch, Dr. John J. Lampe, Dr. R.F. Sample, Prof. J.J. Stevenson, and John J. McCook.

ST. LOUIS, May 17. -- William Reichert, fresh from Mainz, Germany, called at Police Headquarters to-day and told a queer story, at the same time requesting the police to help him find his wife, who, he had reason to believe, was in St. Louis.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 17. -- Charles A. Binder, the New-York lawyer, who was a fugitive from justice on account of misappropriating $20,000 of the funds of an estate of which he was executor, committed suicide at the Sheridan House, at Broad Street and Rahway Avenue, here, last night.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 17. -- A dispatch from Muskegon to the Democrat says: "The fire which visited this city very early in the afternoon yesterday has never been paralleled in its history. Hundreds of people have been rendered homeless and destitute, with their all swallowed up in the cruel flames. Women and children wander homeless along the streets and are moaning and weeping over their losses.

The magnificent doll sent to this country by Mrs. John Wood for exhibition at the doll show last December, but which arrived too late for that purpose, has been disposed of. It represented Mrs. Wood in her Court costume in "The Cabinet Minister," and was consigned to Charles F. Chatterton, who undertook to sell it by subscription for the benefit of some worthy charity.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17. -- The State Treasurer, E. Stevens Henry of Rockville, is notifying officials throughout the State that the appropriations for departments will be exhausted June 30, preparing them for the announcement, which can no longer be delayed, that a crisis is at hand in the financial administration of the Commonwealth.

The people of New-York will be slow to believe that the Rapid Transit Commission has determined to adopt Mr. JAY GOULD'S plan for the extension of the elevated railway system. We should consider the reports of such an intention on the part of the commission as incredible and preposterous but for certain confirmatory circumstances.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17. -- Gov. Abbett's refusal last week to pay Capt. John Graham of Jersey City for the valuable aid he rendered the Senate investigating committee a year ago in unearthing and exposing the ballot-box frauds in Hudson County rounds up a series of acts that have shown him to be the slave of the rascally ring of hoodlums that perpetrated them.

OMAHA, Neb., May 17. -- For a week the entire male population of Thedford, Thomas County, has been engaged in a search for the two little girls of John Hanamond, who were lost in the sand hills surrounding that town last Sunday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 17. -- The coming week will bring to this city a political gathering of unique form, in whose action there is a wide interest. It is not a convention in the usual sense of that term, for it has no party call as a basis. It is perhaps best described as a national union conference.
I assume that THE TIMES belongs to the class of honorable public journals which concede that persons have a valid claim to respond to their own names, even in the columns of a newspaper.

John Buckley, Jr., twenty-one years old, committed suicide last evening by hanging, in the apartment of his parents at 308 West Twenty-fifth Street. His father is a banjo and guitar teacher, and young Buckley had been sick for several years and despondent in consequence. Yesterday afternoon his mother and sister went to visit friends an Staten Island and his father went out for a walk, leaving the young man alone in the apartment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Senator Quay arrived in the city from Washington shortly before 10 o'clock to-night and went at once to the Continental Hotel Except that he appeared a trifle fatigued after his ride the Senator s looking in excellent health and seemed to be in a very happy frame of mind. He came here to join a fishing 10ary that is going down the coast in a day or two.

Signs of secret cutting of freight rates, both east and west bound, are multiplying. A shipper of largo quantities of merolandise from this city wont into the Broadway olloo of a Western railroad yesterday and gleefully boasted that he had been offered a rate on eastbound freight 3 cents a hundred below the regular t arLq5

CINCINNATI, May 18. -- The three or four hundred delegates and others in attendance upon the National Union Conference, which begins its sessions in this city to-morrow, were reinforced this morning by the arrival of a special train bearing ten carloads of citizens from Kansas and other Western points, and it is estimated that there are now nearly 1,300 people here, representing at least two-thirds of the States of the Union.

Hopes of an early settlement of the rapid-transit question by the Rapid Transit Commission are again indefinitely deferred. Several announcements have recently been made, upon the authority of President William Steinway, that a route -- and presumably a system also -- of rapid transit for the west side had substantially been agreed upon and would soon be reported.

Mr. HARRISON has at last a "straw" showing a favorable direction of the wind of party favor regarding the nomination of 1892. The majority of the State Senators of Kansas have expressed the opinion that he has made a good Administration, that he is entitled to a renomination, and that he will be named again and elected.

ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- Members of the collapsed Emma Juch Opera Company left here for New-York to-day under circumstances that drew a crowd to the Union Station to see them off. A special train had been arranged for over the Big Four Road. This train consisted of two ordinary day coaches, and was variously denominated the "emigrant train" and the "charity train."
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The President disposed of the case of the Navassa rioters to-day. His action is embodied in the fallowing indorsement of the application for executive clemency:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Russian Government Gazette published Saturday an account of the recent attempt upon the life of the Crown Prince in Japan, which is confirmed in all important details by telegrams received by the Japanese Legation in this city.

LONDON, May 18. -- The state of Mr. Blalne's health oontlnue to attract great attention in the newspaper press of Great Brltalm The Dailll Chronicle to-day, in discussing the Presidency, says: "Mr. Harrison as a proteutiouist pure and simple opposes Mr. Blaine's Dolley of reoiprooity, and that while on his tour he endeavored to take credit for the firs fruits of ,his polloy is most significant,"

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- On Saturday, when Mrs. Harrison had her trunks unpacked, all the souvenirs of her journey were brought to light. She has them all arranged on the tables up stairs in the corridor, and they make a glittering array of precious metals. The presents made to the President are also among the display, and between them all the number must certainly reach 400.

BELGRADE, May 18. -- The Prefect of this city, who was charged by the Regents with the duty of expelling ex-Queen Nathalie from Servian territory, went to the latter's residence to-day and, in spite of her earnest protests, compelled her to enter a carriage, which drove toward the quay on the Danube where the royal yacht was moored.

A pretty story goes with the nomination of John Young Brown to be the Democratic candidate for Governor of Kentucky in the coming campaign. The nomination was made last week, and according to a Kentucky man who was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, the beginning of the boom for Mr. Brown was made by his daughter, a pretty girl of eighteen or twenty years.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Leading Western Republicans have finally decided Zhat it would be love's labor lost to support President Harrison for a second nomination. /nd they have determined to stand by Blaine from first to last. This comes from Senator Wolcott of Colorado, who is hero.

The Iron Manufacturers' Association held a meeting last evening at the Chelsea Apartment House, West Twenty-third Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, to discuss the situation caused by the strikes of the house-smiths, architectural ironworkers, and foundrymen. About 100 manufacturers were present. J.M. Cornell presided.

Two hundred books of the library formed by Henry R. Mitchell were sold by Bangs Co. yesterday in two hours for $3,954. If they were of the quality that the Elizabetho maniacs Chew, Bierstadt, and Marshall Lefferts collect, it would not be marvelous, but they were not. They were generally books that collectors discard after they have passed the experiential stage of their collecting.

The unexpected happened last night at the meeting of the Congregational Club at the St. Denis Hotel. The subject under discussion was "Fellowship in Church Work," and several ministers, representing as many denominations, had expressed their views thereon. Then the acting President, the Rev. Dr. S.H. Virgin of Pilgrim Church, Harlem, called upon one of the club's guests, the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water, rector of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

ALBANY, May 18. -- Through his organ in this city, Gov. Hill keeps venting his spleen on Mr. Cleveland in a way that proves most conclusively that he views with alarm the action of the Buffalo Democracy in honoring the ex-President as it did last week. His latest attack is based on the assertion that Mr. Cleveland said nothing on the silver question on "his electioneering trip to Buffalo."

The quality and sumors of the audience shbwed the folly of assure;lag that the New-York theatres have no regular lvarronago after the fashionable season has ielosedHe ,' first night" of the Winter drew t _gether morn well-known persons.

The Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum have now been forced to face and decide the question whether its collections shall be opened to the public on Sundays. We have no doubt whatever that their decision was right, and that it will result in a great gain to the usefulness of the museum and a great boon to the people of New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The depositors of the broken Spring Garden National Bank held an indignation meal;lag to-night in Lincoln Hall, at which, after scoring Bank Examiner Drew and he President and eashier Of the bank, they appointed a eommlttee to investigate with a view to criminally prosecuting the I two latter, after which they adJoulmed unl next Thursday nlgh

John Banvard, the artist, died Saturday last in Watertown, S.D., of heart failure. His career as an artist, a traveler, and an adventurer was unique and interesting, and the story of his life is full of incidents that go beyond the usual.

ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- The delegates to the annual I)lstrict Grand Lodge No. of the Independent Order of B'nai B'rlth met yesterday a Harmonic Hail. They are seventy-five in hum* bet, with headquarters at Cleveland, Ohio.. This is he wealthiest and largest Je-ish soelety in the world, having nine divisions, of which seven are in this country and two in Europe.

SAN JUAN, DEL SUR, Nicaragua, April 27. -From ocean to ocean! We have followed the line of the canal from the Atlantic to the Pacific, seen the work done, explored the route where hitherto only surveying parties had penetrated, and noted the topographical and geological features of the country. The climate being much drier on the Pacific than on the Atlantic slope, the character of the forest and vegetation in general is widely different.

According to the latest number of the London Economist, the holdings by English investors of what are known as "Internationals" have been very much diminished within the past six months, and the marked disturbance in these stocks, it thinks, will affect the London market only indirectly and not seriously.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- There is a strong suspicion in the minds of some of the naval authorities here that the Charleston is about as far from catching the Itata now as when she started out from San Francisco.

BOSTON, May 18. -- The Republican members of the House of Representatives had a menagerie show In the Green Boom of the State House after adjournment to-day. It was a conference called to consider what the policy of the party should be upon the redistricting plan reported to the Logislat.ure. A wrangle first arose over the question or admitting reporters.
LEWISTON, Me., May 18. -- The Directors of the Shoe and Leather National Bank make a report to-day showing the condition of affairs upon the retirement of ex-Cashier Percival. They say:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18. -- A copy of the Chilean Times, which reached here by the steamer San Blas, announces that by special agreement with Germany Great Britain is taking German interests in Chile under her protection until the arrival of three German war ships, which are now en route.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 18. -- George H. Graham, agent here of the American ]Express Company, confessed today to opening a number of valuable letters and abstreting the contents while they were temporarily left here for the r T. Falconer Manufacturing Company. The Falconer Companywlll not prosecute, but Graham will resign his position and leave town after settling the losses.

The delay in beginning the construction of a dock at Pelham Bay Park illustrates the dilly-dallying way in which public business is done. There was a question as to the right to land under water contiguous to the different properties of which the park is made up. All this originally belonged to the State, and in some cases it had been granted to the private owners and in some not.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Signor Corte, the Italian Consul at New-Orleans, arrived here last evening with Gaspari Grimaldo, better known as Asper Marchese, the boy who, it is charged, gave the whistle as a signal that Hennessy was approaching on the night when the Chief was shot in New-Orleans. Consul Corte and the boy are on their way to Rome to give Marquis Rudini a personal account of all that happened in New-Orleans.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Great interest was manifested in to-day's proceedings in the investigation by the Council's sub-committee which is inquiring into the conditions of the city's deposits in the different banks. The answer given by President Lewis of the Third National Bank to questions relative to the choice of that bank as one of the active depositories created a sensation.

The New-York and New-Jersey Bridge scheme, having hibernated for several months, is just now in the enjoyment of a Spring bloom. It got itself into one or more of the Sunday papers as the beneficiary of subscriptions to the amount of $100,000,000, whereas the fact is that it only hopes to get subscriptions for $50,000, 5 per cent. of $1,000,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 18. -- In the debate to-day upon the third reading of the bill to renew the modus vivendi in fishery matters between Canada and the United States. Mr. Mills of Bothwell censured the Government for having interfered with the ratification of the commercial treaty which the Government of Newfoundland had drawn up with the United States.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 18. -- A special to the evening Wisconsin from Racine, Wis., says the entire strawberry crop of the county was blasted by Friday nights fros t Racine County ships more strawberries than all the other counties in the State combined.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Navy Department is much concerned over the small number of cadets who have been nominated to appear at the Naval Academy for examination. The majority of the members of the House of Representatives, who have the privilege of nominating these cadets, have failed to send in the names of their candidates, and only twenty-six boys,have appeared at Annapolis for examination.

ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- Theodore Roosevelt arrived here this morning, and at 1 o'clock visited the Merchants' Exchange at the invitation of President Bernheimer. Upon being called upon for an address, he said:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The following graduates of the United States Naval Academy's six-year course have successfully passed the examination for commissions as Third Lieutenants in the United States Revenue Marine: Francis A. Levis of New-York, Alexander A. Hasson of the District of Columbia, Samuel B. Winram, Jr., of Missouri, Colon S. Craig of Iowa, and Claude S. Cochran of Ohio.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 18. -- For the last few days negotiations have been going on between leading Democratic politicians in the States of Kansas, Nebraska, Illinois, Minnesota, and the Dakotas and the delegates from these States to the Alliance Convention at Cincinnati. This much has become known: The Democracy of the States mentioned is ready to submit a proposition to the Alliance or Industrial Union Party to unite on a fusion Electoral ticket in 1892.

The trial of Eugene Kelly's suit against Jay Gould, George J. Gould, Russell Sage, J. Henry Work, G.M. Dodge, the Mexican Oriental Inter-oceanic and International Railroad Company, the International Railroad Improvement Company, the Southwestern Construction Company, and the Mexican Southern Railway Company was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court before Judge Beach and a jury.

The recent decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission in ordering the New-York and New-England Railroad not to discriminate against the New-York and Northern Railway, but to afford equal facilities to it, and give it the same rates and charges for business as its other connections, is regarded as of much significance by railroad men generally.

The poolroom keepers continued to defy the law yesterday and the police continued to arrest them for doing so. The game is getting interesting. Eight men, acting as cashiers in the poolrooms, have now been arrested three times and each time have been released on $500 bail. That gives District Attorney Nicoll twenty-four cases to try.

We recently expressed the opinion that even if KOCH'S tuberculin should prove to have no value as a remedy for tuberculosis, the discussion excited throughout the civilized world by the result of his experiments would be of very great service in directing attention to the infectious nature of that disease.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Gen. Raum, the Commissioner of Pensions, has returned to Washington from his visit to Chicago. A reporter this evening called his attention to the statements that he contemplated resigning his office. In reply the Commissioner said:

Democratic editors have been talking idiotically about McKinley -- the Cleveland Leader says so, and of course it must be so. These editors have set the Major down as a man of one idea. That's perfectly absurd -- the Leader says so. Why, Major McKinley, as leader of the Republican majority in the last Congress, time and again demonstrated his complete and masterly grasp of the other great questions of government.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- he young swindler whoso operations in this oily under the name of J.B. Graft caused a sensation when exposed about two weeks o, and who was sentenced last week to four year' imprisonment, has been the subject of the most painstaking inquiry by the police of this city and others, and the result of their work has but just been completed.

BOSTON, May 19. -- There was a large attendance of women who had to listen to some pretty pointed speeches at the annual meeting of the New-England Reform Society to-day. Among Others the Rev. Frederick Allen pointed to the great facilities which existed in the community for the dissemination of vice, especially by means of vile publications, pictures, and the like.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 19. -- The political situation in this city is unique. Local politics are in such shape that the help of the courts will be called upon to straighten out matters, and already there are no less than a dozen lawsuits in view.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 19. -- Monday afternoon last a most desperate fight occurred near Stackhouse, in Madison County, N.C., between six young men. The fight came up about a girl, but full particulars are not as yet known. Yesterday afternoon two Stanley brothers and another whose name was not learned met Shelton, a rival of one of the Stanleys, and without any words opened fire on him.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 19. -- The National Union Conference has met and organized, and its committees, appointed after the manner usual to "old-party" conventions, are now struggling with problems of membership, rules of order, and platform. If one were to attempt to predict just what the declaration of principles will be, he would undertake to do more than any person named on the Committee on Resolutions could tell to-day.

DENVER, Col., May 19. -- North, South, and West sank all sectional interests at the first session of the Trans-Mississippi Congress, which opened here to-day. Delegates began to arrive last evening, but the majority came in on the morning trains.

The meetings yesterday at the Liberty Street office of the Trunk Line Association were not productive of great results. The Executive Committee had under discussion the subject of the east-bound freight rate situation. There were certain recommendations made which will come up at a future conference, and it is hoped that these will be effective in preventing a further demoralization.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 19. -- George F. O'Neil, a prominent merchant and Democratic politician, has announced that he is a candidate for State Treasurer. In 1888 and 1889 he was a member of the Democratic State Committee.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 19. -- At a few minutes before 12 o'clock last night fire broke out on the third floor of the Mohawk Block, southwest corner of Bay and Market Streets. The building was occupied on the first floor by the Drew Hardware Company, Church Anderson Co., wholesale produce and fruit; James Douglass, books and stationery; an Italian fruit firm, and the Post Office.

The great aggregation of delegates of the discontented at Cincinnati, somewhat pretentiously called the "National Union Conference," did not get beyond a preliminary organization yesterday. The great question before it is whether a third party movement shall be launched in organized shape now or whether definite action in that respect shall be postponed to a national convention to be held early next year.

The educational committee of the Trustees of the John P. Slater Fund for the education of the colored race in the South met yesterday at 9 University Place and discussed the work of the past year. There were present ex-President Rutherford B. Hayes of Ohio, Dr. J.L.N. Curry of Richmond, Senator A.H. Colquitt of Georgia; William E. Dodge and Morris K. Jesup of New-York, and President Gilman of Johns Hopkins University.

RICHMOND, Va., May 19. -- A conference of the business agents of the Farmers' Alliance of the State was held here to-day. The body is composed of eighty or ninety agents, representing probably nearly all of the counties in the State. It was called by Mr. George Chrisman, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, to consider only matters of interest to the order.

BELGRADE, May 19. -- After a consultation of the Ministers and Regents this morning it was decided to expel Nathalie from Servia, and instructions to that effect were given to the police. Consequently during the morning a strong force of gendarmes made a fresh attack upon the Queen's palace and succeeded in breaking through the cordon of citizens who were guarding Nathalie.

WALLA WALLA, Washington, May 19. -- The court of inquiry ordered by the War Department to investigate the lynching of A.J. Hunt by soldiers of Fort Walla Walla, April 24, convened yesterday. The court is composed of Brig. Gen. A.V. Kautz, Col. Thomas M. Anderson. Fourteenth Infantry; Col. W.P. Carlin, Fourth Infantry, and Capt. Charles McClure, Acting Judge Advocate of the Department of the Columbia.

CINCINNATI, May 19. -- Boston suffered its third defeat and its greatest here to-day. Clarkson was hit hard and his support was not of the best, while Cincinnati's fine fielding kept the visitors' score down. In the fifth inning, after Cincinnati had played its half and two men on the other side were out, the umpire called time on account of rain. The shower soon passed over, however, and play was resumed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- Fifteen heats were trotted and paced at the Philadelphia Driving Park to-day, when the Southeastern Circuit meeting began. C.F. Iseminger, a local horse, won his maiden race in the 2:50 class, where he was a strong favorite. Martin K. had quite a following, but could do nothing with the bay gelding after the first heat, in which he finished ahead, but was set back for running.

The poolroom keepers showed no inclination yesterday to recede from the position they have taken in defiance of law. Nor are they likely to until a wholesome lesson is administered to one of their number by District Attorney Nicoll. The police are doing their duty. Every day since the rooms opened, on Friday of last week, the rooms have been entered by officers and the cashiers arrested and put under bonds.

The twentieth annual meeting of the American Fisheries Society will be held Wednesday and Thursday. May 27 and 28, in the rooms of the National Museum, Washington D.C. The meeting will be of unusaul interest, and it is thought that that there will be a large attendance.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 19. -- Sixteen graves were uncovered yesterday at Fort Ancient, the site of the greatest of the earthworks of that prehistoric people known as the mound builders. The excavation is under the auspices of the World's Fair and the direction of Prof. Putnam of Harvard, the field work being in charge of Warren K. Morehead.

A quantity of dynamite carelessly being transported from Ludlow, near Yonkers, to Holmes's Point, on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, exploded with terrific effect yesterday morning at 11:40 o'clock near Tarrytown, killing thirteen men and badly wounding twenty-two others. Most of the killed were Italians who were riding on the platform car on which the explosive was carried.

The last public meeting of the Harbor Line Board, which was held yesterday morning at the Army Building, was made somewhat more interesting than the preceding sessions by the introduction of a novel project by the Riparian Commissioners of New-Jersey. The subject under discussion was the establishment of pier and bulkhead facilities from Communipaw to Robbin's Reef.

The two Italians who have been detained at the Barge Office on evidence that they were imported under contract by Gelmaro Parento, of 241 Mulberry Street, were yesterday placed on board the steamship Neustria, by which they came, to be returned to Italy. The Neustria sails to-day.

Signor CRISPI'S successor does not repose upon a bed of roses. The Marquis DI RUDINI must have disaffected many sensible Italians by his conduct of the negotiations touching the massacre at New-Orleans, while he has not succeeded in conciliating the Italian Jingo, whose approbation was the object of the performance.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- A letter has been received by Secretary Tracy from Edward Everett Hale, on behalf of the American Antiquarian Society, making the following suggestions in regard to the quadricentennial of the landing of Columbus:

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 19. -- The weddings of a number of Pittsburg couples are delayed by the eight-hour building trades strike, which began May 1. Besides, a dozen or more brides are domiciled with their parents until the homes their husbands are preparing for them can be completed. Other social inconveniences innumerable are resulting, and the strike is coming to possess as great interest to society as to any other class.

year," says the Press, "tin [meaning tin plate] has been imported in large quantities, and during the months of March and April the importations have been greater than ever before." It then makes the following statement concerning the importations at Philadelphia:

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- United States Senator Quay spent to-day in the city, and had a long conference to-night with Col. W.W. Dudley, the Indiana statesman, at the Continental. Col. Dudley left the city soon afterward on the 11 o'clock train for his home.

NEW-HAVEN, May 19. -- A great deal of comment has been caused in local financial circles by the temporary suspension of the banking and brokerage house of Bunnell Scranton since the death of the senior member of the firm, Henry H. Scranton. John W. Alling, one of the leading and most conservative lawyers in New-Haven, is authority for the statement that the firm has failed.

ALBANY, May 19. -- Assemblyman Joseph Blumenthal of New-York came to Albany to-day in behalf of John T. McGrath, a young New-Yorker who was sentenced in 1888 to eight years' imprisonment in Sing Sing on the charge of manslaughter in the second degree. Mr. Blumenthal pleaded for a pardon for the young man and the Governor granted it on condition that McGrath abstain from the use of liquor for five years.
Electrical engineers of prominence from every part of the country gathered at 12 West Thirty-first Street last night to attend the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 19. -- A meeting of the House of Commons adherents to the United Empire Trade League will be held on Saturday to devise a scheme for presentation to the House and the country. Dr. Weldon, the young member from Albert, N.B., is heading the movement and has been distributing the league circulars and forms for membership.

LYNN, Mass., May 19. -- News of the assignment of the Davis Shoe Company and the Hon. Joseph Davis of Lynn reached this city late this afternoon and caused widespread consternation. The assignment was recorded at Salem this afternoon, and includes all the real estate owned by Mr. Davis. The Davis Shoe Company was incorporated with a paid-up capital of $250,000.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 19. -- Considerable interest has been created here by the probability of a contest between the New-York Central and Delaware and Hudson Railroad Companies in the Adirondacks. Col. Le Grand B. Cannon has come to his Summer residence here with his family for the season, and Dr. W. Seward Webb is now on his way by coach from Rutland, selecting a route for the coaching party in June.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- "If I can rise from the coast of France, sail through the air across the Channel, and drop half a ton of nitro-glycerine upon an English city, I can revolutionize the world. I believe I can do it if I live long enough. If I die, some one will come after me who will be successful where I failed."

Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT of the Civil Service Commission has not lost his faculty for outspoken independence and does not hesitate to speak out with reference to powerful politicians of his own party. After his lecture before the Civil Service Reform Club of St. Louis the other evening he took occasion to reply to some of the criticism which Mr. J.S. CLARKSON has been bestowing upon the action of the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- There is a moral for somebody in the story of Mr. Matthew Stanley Quay's latest visit to Washington. Mr. Quay is a United States Senator from the great State of Pennsylvania, the Chairman of the Republican National Committee, and, according to his friends, the man whose masterly conduct of the campaign in 1888 made Benjamin Harrison President of the United States.

BOSTON, May 19. -- The repeal of the anti-public bar law of Massachusetts is now an assured fact. The House to-day took decided action on the matter, ordering the Senate bill to a third reading by a majority of 45.

HANOVER, N.H., May 19. -- The Athletic Association of Dartmouth College held its regular Spring athletic meeting here to-day for the purpose of determining the men to represent the college at the coming intercollegiate meeting at Springfield. The winners were as follows:

The Twenty-fifth Annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of Long Island began its session in the Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City, yesterday. The morning session was opened with prayer and full choral service. There were fully 200 clergy and lay delegates present when the venerable Bishop A. M. Littlejohn delivered his annual address.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 19. -- A spicy correspondence has to-day been made public between Superintendent Griffith of the State Lunatic Asylum and Gov. Tillman, which was concluded by the Governor asking for Dr. Griffith's resignation. For some time rumors have been afloat of mismanagement at the asylum in Columbia, and by the Legislature a commission of inquiry was appointed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 19. -- The Philadelphias hit Staley whenever they pleased and won from Pittsburg easily. Bierbauer's fielding was the only noteworthy feature of the contest. Attendance, 2,000. Score:

A complete rapid-transit railroad route from the Battery to the Harlem River through the west side, designed for a system of solid construction, partly underground and partly viaduct, capable of sustaining the utmost strain of long trains, heavy motors, and the highest attainable speed, is promised by the Rapid-Transit Commission to be reported next Tuesday.

The seventy-third annual meeting of the life members of the New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb was held yesterday at the institution, in Sixty-fifth Street, near Eleventh Avenue. The long-established custom of supplementing these meetings with public exhibitions of the progress of the pupils drew to the beautiful grounds surrounding the institution a large crowd of visitors.

By the McKinley Tariff act the duty on oatmeal was doubled. The old duty was one-half of a cent per pound, or about 20 per cent.; the new one is -1 cent per pound, or about 40 per cent. Why was the duty increased? We do not find in the report of the hearings before the Ways and Means Committee any argument in support of the change that has been made.

The passage by the last Legislature of the act permitting the use of Bronx Park for a botanical garden, under certain conditions, and incorporating an association for its establishment, brought satisfaction to a large number of philanthropic citizens who had long labored to that end. Among those who worked hardest and most successfully for the garden were Mrs. Charles P. Daly, Mrs. Louis Fitzgerald, Mrs. Lena Cowdin Potter, and Mrs. Samuel Sloan.

PITTSBURG, May 19. -- The miners of the region demonstrated their intention to remain out more than one way to-day. Every effort was made by operators to force the men in convention to-day to vote to return to work, but the work of the leaders in an opposite direction was too powerful, and they voted to remain out to a man. After a stormy session a resolution was unanimously adopted to remain out.

About one-third of the 200 Congregational churches in this State were represented in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon when the fifty-eighth annual convention of the General Congregational Association of the State of New-York was opened.

LONDON, May 19. -- The Attorney General, referring to the Copyright bill, writes that the results of intellectual labors, whether of an author or of a mechanic, ought to be protected. The Solicitor General has written a letter giving a strong opinion in favor of a measure for protecting English labor against unfair treatment by the American Copyright law.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 19. -- Commissioners in Lunacy Macdonald and Reeves and Controller Wemple, a majority of the board for the establishment of State hospital districts under the State Care of Insane act, met to-day and considered plans and estimates of the proposed detached buildings to be erected on the grounds of the State hospitals for the accommodation of the country insane.

NEWARK, May 19. -- Two events made the opening day of the seventeenth annual convention of the Episcopal churches in the Newark Diocese at Trinity Church here interesting. The announcement was made by the Standing Committee of the diocese, when it was called upon for a report of its work during the year, that it had unanimously refused to consent to the consecration of the Rev. Dr. Phillips Brooks as Bishop of Massachusetts.

LONDON, May 19. -- Edward Pinder, the American, alias "Sheeny Al," who is charged with attempting to obtain $40,000 from Edwin Streeter, the Bond Street jeweler, by false pretenses in claiming to possess the secret of the "philosopher's stone," was again under examination to-day. Government analysts testified that one of the powders found in Pinder's possession was composed of real gold.

Gov. Hill has deceived and humbugged the people so many years that he now holds deception as a regular stock in trade, which the taxpayer is always willing to take. For instance, he is making much ado about the low tax rate, and impudently claiming all the credit for it. As a matter of fact, the aggregate appropriations of the Legislature this year were only $532,459 less than those of last year, or $12,432,020.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 19. -- In his lecture before the Civil Service Reform Club here last night, Theodore Roosevelt said some things that surprised his hearers, and that will stir up political circles all over the country. He took Mr. Clarkson to task in a manner that will cause that gentleman to squirm and come out with an indignant reply.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 19. -- Ex-Mayor Cregier of Chicago is evidently not enthusiastic over the work done by the World's Fair Directors. Passing through here to-day on a fishing trip he said:

M.H. Tan Kenren, for many years a conductor on the New-York Central and New-York, Ontario and Western Railroads, has been committed to the Homepathic State Hospital for the Insane at Middletown, N.Y. His malady is the result of an injury he received in an accident.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Blair's unfortunate inability to suppress or destroy the Congressional Record containing verbatim reports of the proceedings of the Senate of Sept. 6, 7, and 13, 1888, interferes somewhat with the candor of his present utterances and lays those utterances open to an uncomfortable kind of opinion.

Once more there are hopeful reports from the Rapid-Transit Commission. It is said to have reached an informal conclusion, and to expect to have a formal report ready by next Tuesday in favor of a west-side route from the Battery to Harlem River for a real rapid-transit road. The proposed line will be of solid construction, partly underground and partly viaduct, adapted to heavy trains and motors and a high rate of speed.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Michael Amberg, a Belgian tourist stopping here, has been summoned to Antwerp as a witness in a diamond case. Antwerp and Amsterdam are the cities where most of the valuable diamonds are cut and polished. From what Mr. Amberg says it appears that some of the leaders of Antwerp's Four Hundred are implicated in the diamond case.

BOSTON, May 20. -- An interview was had today with James Houghton of Houghton Godfrey, whose embarrassment is caused by the assignment of the Davis Shoe Company. He said that Mr. Davis's suspension prevented their going on. He was not prepared to give figures as to liabilities, but in a round sum they would aggregate upward of $150,000.

Considering the composition of the "National Union Conference" at Cincinnati, it is not strange that it rushed headlong into the organization of a third party, regardless of the warnings of the few conservatives on the ground. Of the 1,418 delegates present 407 were from Kansas and 317 were from Ohio, these two States furnishing a majority of the whole conference.

ORANGE, N.J., May 20. -- It is rumored here that there is something very wrong with the accounts of Dr. C.E. Prentiss, manager of the New Church Publishing Company, which has an office at 20 Cooper Union, New-York City. The New Church Publishing Company has an office here, its principal publication being The New Jerusalem Messenger.

PITTSBURG, Penn, May 20. -- Representatives of twenty-seven concerns now manufacturing tin plate, or "who contemplate its manufacture," got together here to-day and organized the Tin Plate Manufacturers' Association. The object stated is unity of action of manufacturers of tin plate, so that they may speedily overcome the difficulties as well as utilize the advantages to be had in its manufacture.

Twenty-two immigrants were yesterday debarred admission at the Barge Office. Six of those were excluded on account of their being adjudged as likely to become public charges. One was debarred on account of having consumption. Fifteen Arabs, passengers by the Rotterdam, complete the list. These had no money, and were excluded on general principles as being undesirable citizens. By order of the Superintendent of Immigration they were immediately returned to the vessel that brought them.

NEW-HAVEN, May 20. -- Bunnell Scranton made an assignment in the Probate Court to-day, and similar action was taken individually by Charles W. Scranton, the surviving member of the firm. R.G. Stoddard is named as Trustee. By authority of the firm it is stated that the liabilities are about $250,000, and that the nominal assets are between $100,000 and $125,000.

When the Board of Education adjourned after a long session last evening it was with the conviction strong in many minds that it had transacted more really valuable work and had taken longer strides toward the reform of the entire school system than in any previous session for years.

The citizens who are in the movement to restore Battery Park to its proper uses as a pleasure ground are daily beset with questions by persons who are becoming interested in the movement and want to be stocked with arguments with which they can do missionary work in its behalf. These are some of the reasons why the park should be vacated by the elevated road:

GLASGOW, May 20. -- In an address delivered in this city to-day, Lord Salisbury, referring to the treatment of Hebrews in Russia and other countries of Europe, said: "The terrible persecutions of the Jews show that we must not count too confidently upon the progress of civilization."

Yale's team had an easy victory yesterday at Eastern Park. The Crescents met the New-Haven Collegians and were beaten in one inning. The feature of the game was the batting and general field work of Yale. It is evident that the boys have improved considerably and they are now in fine form to give Princeton a good game.

RICHMOND, Va., May 20. -- raThe Dalrls Shoe Company which failed at Lynn, lIas, yesterday has a branch establishment here which employs 630 convicts in the State prison. Major lobert Stiles, the counsel for the company, went to the house or the clerk of the Chancery Court early this morning and got that officer to go down to h/s oice and nle an assignment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20. -- An attempt is being maple by the Republican organs and some of the anti-Cleveland sheets to create the impression that the late Kentucky State Democratic Convention was an anti-Cleveland body. The failure to adopt the resolution indorsing Mr. Cleveland is cited in substantiation.

DETROIT, Mich., May 20. -- The central figure at the opening of the Presbyterian General Assembly, which meets here to-morrow, by virtue of his official position, will be the retiring Moderator, William Eves Moore, D.D., of Columbus, Ohio, who is also permanent clerk of the assembly, an office he has held since 1884.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 20. -- United States Fish Commissioner Gray, who is recognized as high authority in such matters, declares that the Delaware River, under natural conditions, is the best shad stream in America. The natural conditions referred to are in force this season for the first time since 1828, when the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company built its dam and aqueduct for crossing the river at Lackawaxen, twenty-three miles west of Port Jervis.

The Princeton University nine defeated the Cuban Giants in Princeton yesterday, in a four-inning game. Score, 1 to 0. Princeton played an errorless game. The game was stopped an account of rain. Brokaw did not catch, as he is suffering from a sprained ankle. Capt. Dana had his head out while sliding to second. The whole team, however, will be in good condition for the Yale game on Saturday.

Gambling on the horses at Gravesend track was carried on in open violation of the law at "Shang" Draper's poolroom, 114 West Thirty-third Street, by wholesale yesterday. This place was not visited by the police the day before, and the crowd of gamblers, which has been scared away to some extent at the raided places, walked up to the windows at Draper's and made its bets without the shadow of hesitation.

Mayor GRANT was supposed to be waiting for Boss CROKER'S return before making his appointments to offices in which the incumbents were holding over, but since CROKER got back there seems to have been some kind of a "hitch." It is generally believed that Police Justice SOLON B. SMITH had some kind of a pledge for a reappointment from CROKER which GRANT is averse to fulfilling.

BOSTON, Mass., May 20. -- The announcement that the Diocese of Newark, N.J., at its annual convention yesterday refused to confirm the election of the Rev. Phillips Brooks as Bishop of Massachusetts looked rather foreboding on its face, but the Boston friends of that popular preacher profess not to feel at all alarmed about it. The Rev. Dr. Lindsay of St. Paul's Church says: "

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 20. -- The thirty-first annual convention of the United States Brewers' Association was called to order in Germania Hall this morning, with President T.J. Leffens of Chicago in the chair. There were about two hundred delegates present. E. Mueller, President of the Cleveland Brewers' Association, delivered the address of welcome.

The pottery industry (Schedule B in the McKinley act) has always invited general interest. It is, strictly speaking, an art industry. Besides, in its conduct, the technical branches of industrial life are very important features. Burnt clay, defying the destroying influences of fire, water, air, and time, contains the record of the mental development from prehistoric man to our present time.
ALBANY, May 20. -- After a period of "masterly inactivity" the Forestry Commission now claims to be awake and anxious to prevent further encroachments by railroads on the forest preserve.

The session of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, which opens to-day in Detroit, will have before it two important matters, the revision of the Confession of Faith and the consideration of orthodoxy of Prof. Charles N. Briggs of the chair of Biblical Theology in the Union Theological Seminary. The former of these two questions has already been so long discussed, that a feeling approaching unanimity has been reached throughout the Church.

BOSTON, May 20. -- Chief Inspector Eldridge and Officer G.M. Robinson of the Boston police force will have to pay an award of $125 which G.T. Scott recovered against them in an action for a false arrest, the full bench of the Supreme Court to-day having overruled the department's exception.

It is sometimes easier to elect an American Bishop than it is to secure his confirmation. In order to preserve the episcopal office in its traditional character and to maintain the general identity of an ecclesiastical body, it is necessary that every new Bishop-elect shall run the gantlet of every Bishop and every diocesan Standing Committee within the Church.
At yesterday's meeting of the New-York Board of Underwriters the Board of Inspectors announced the result of the annual election, which was held Monday, as follows:...

When it was made plain that the revision of the Westminster Confession would be made "by its friends," nobody any longer expected that it would be in any sense a radical revision, or that it would meet the wishes of those who had been demanding a revision, and at whose instance the revision had been undertaken.

ORANGE, N.J., May 20. -- A special meeting of the Federation of Women's Clubs was held in Union Hall in this city this morning. Delegates were present from fourteen States and one came from India, representing the Sorosis Club of Bombay.

Miss Lita Constance Pell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walden Pell, was married yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock to Eben Wright of Boston, at the Church of the Transfiguration in West Twenty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton. The church was elaborately decorated with flowers and palms. The bride was dressed in a white satin gown with heavy trimmings of lace.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 20. -- Complete returns from the special election held in this State yesterday show that 17,114 votes were cast "For a Convention" and 115 "Against a Convention." As this affirmative vote was less than "a majority of those who voted for Representatives in the General Assembly" at the general election last November, as required by the Constitution -- about 17,600 -- the cause of convention failed by less than 500 votes.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Unexpectedly the World's Fair Directors refused last night to grant the maximum scale of wages. It had been considered that the question was as good as settled in favor of the workingmen. The workingmen confidently expected it, and most of the Directors as confidently predicted an early and a harmonious settlement of all the issues between organized labor on one side and the local board on the other.

The Chapel of the Good Shepherd, Chelsea Square, was crowded yesterday on the occasion of the Commencement of the General Theological Seminary. The ceremonies were begun by an imposing processional, in which nearly two hundred dignitaries and ecclesiastics of the Episcopal Church, the graduating class, and students of the seminary took part.

Gen. PATRICK R. CLEBURNE, to whose memory a monument has just been unveiled at Helena, Ark., was undoubtedly one of the most gallant of the Confederate soldiers engaged in the Western campaigns. He was a native of Ireland, of good stock, and had begun his education for a profession when he ran away and enlisted in the British Army, where he served three years.

BUDA-PESTH, May 20. -- When the Queen prepared to leave her hotel at Semlin this morning the excitement in the streets increased, and the appearance of the exiled lady was greeted with enthusiastic cheers. The progress of the Queen from her hotel to the quay on the Danube, where she was to embark on a special steamer for Jassy, in Roumania, was a triumphal procession.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Charleston has been three days at sea since leaving Acapulco, and there is still no word of her movements. Secretary Tracy says that he does not expect to hear from her until she reaches Panama, and, according to the calculations of naval officers, this should happen by to-morrow night, unless she has meantime caught the Itata or suffered a mishap.

There have been various attempts made at one time and another to disseminate the notion that ex-President CLEVELAND is not popular among the Democrats of Kentucky, just as efforts were made to create the impression that he was disliked at his old home in Buffalo until his recent visit made it impossible to keep up that delusion.

CINCINNATI, May 20. -- At noon to-day, after a morning session in which there were some curious manifestations of feeling, the National Union Conference revived the name of the "People's Party" for the organization that is to be the third in the great political contest of 1892. While taking the name with which Gen. B.F. Butler made his campaign of 1884, the party began business with a platform of a much more comprehensive description.

IQUIQUE, Chile, May 20, via Galveston. -- On Sunday morning at about 4:30 o'clock the Chilean insurgent torpedo cruiser Almirante Lynch was sighted off Punta de Piedra, in Iquique Bay, by the Chilean war ship Almirante Cochrane, which immediately gave chase to the cruiser, but was soon left far behind by the faster sailing torpedo vessel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- Neither of the two events at the Driving Park to-day were finished, although eleven heats were trotted. The track got a soaking from a thunderstorm after one heat, and the sport was delayed for an hour. The rain held off after that, but the course was unfit to send the horses at top seed, so that the heats were slow.

The fact that Prof. Charles A. Briggs was to speak at yesterday's session of the General Congregational Association of New-York State, now in convention at plymouth Church, Brooklyn, attracted very many people to that familiar old edifice. Every pew was filled.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- O.C. St. Clair, President of the Chicago Watch and Jewelry Company, has failed for $4,000 or $5,000 and his creditors are whistling for their money. While St. Clair figures as the President of the company, it seems he is sole proprietor of the concern. The "company" conducted a business on the plan of a lottery scheme called a watch club.

The committee of citizens who arc enlisted in the crusade against squatter possession of the Battery Park by the elevated railroad company have formulated an address to the residents and property owners of the city, especially appealing to these of the lower part of the city, which they are extensively circulating through the mails.

Insurance men were not much surprised by the announcement of the failure and assignment of the insurance brokerage firm or Satterlee, Bostwick Martin of 58 Cedar Street. The firm's standing had been poor for months. The Lancashire and several other companies are losers by the failure, but to what amount they refuse to say.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Acting under the instructions of Superintendent of Insurance Pierce an examination of the conditions and affairs of the New-York Mutual Live Stock Insurance Company of New-York City was recently made by Deputy Superintendent Shannon and John A. Horan, and they have made their report to the Superintendent.

Mr. CLARKSON, if he drops into any of the numerous reading rooms on the Continent where he can see American papers, will perhaps light on some comments upon his own course that will give him food for reflection. Almost without exception the Republican journals that have noticed it at all have condemned his recent article in the North American Review in unmeasured terms.

It is the habit of the protectionists when the McKinley bill is criticised as smothering export trade to point to the drawback provisions of the bill and to claim that practically they give imported raw material free of duty to the manufacturer who wishes to export goods made from such material.

James Snodgrass, commission dealer in hay and feed at 882 Hudson Street, made an assignment yesterday to Marcus Kendall, giving a preference for $2,000 to Eliza Snodgrass. Mr. Snodgrass has been in business since 1873, was of Gleason Snodgrass, who dissolved in 1878, and has since been alone. He claimed to have an investment of $15,000 in the business.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., May 21. -- The twenty-third anniversary of Hampton Institute has been cloudless as usual and of exceptional interest. Among those present were Trustees the Rev. M.E. Strieby, George F. Peabody, and Charles Mead, New-York: the Rev. Dr. McVicar and Robert C. Ogden, Philadelphia; the Hon. Amzi Dodd, Bloomfield, N.J.; the Rev. Dr. McKenzie, Cambridge, Mass.; Dr. Lewis Steiner, Baltimore, and Col. Tabb, Hampton.

In an editorial article in last Friday's issue, dealing with some of the political and social prospects of the Transvaal, and South Africa in general, you made the erroneous statement that President Paul Kruger of the South African Republic had resigned, but at the solicitation of his friends had reconsidered that determination and had resumed control of the Transvaal Government.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton has sent the following communication to Bishop Henry C. Potter:
The chances of the Rev. Phillips Brooks becoming a Bishop of the Episcopal Church in America were materially increased yesterday by the action of the Standing Committee of the Diocese of New-York.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 21. -- The United States Grand Jury, which has been in session in Des Moines for several days past, to-day returned an indictment against J.C. Newton for conspiring to defraud the Government.

MADISON, N.J., May 21. -- The twenty-fourth annual Commencement of Drew Theological Seminary took place at Christ Church this morning. Several noted divines connected with the Newark Methodist Conference were on the platform with William Hoyt, the President of the Board of Trustees; William White, Chairman of the Executive Committee; the Rev. Drs. Kelly of Brooklyn, and Brown and Griffin of Troy, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- President Harrison today issued the following proclamation opening to public settlement about 1,600,000 acres of the land of the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation in North Dakota:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21. -- Auditor Crites of Allen County appeared in the State Supreme Court to-day in answer to the citation on motion of Tax Inquisitor H.W. Morgenthaler, that he be held in contempt for falling to execute the court's order to place upon the tax duplicate property of Senator C.S. Brice not already listed.

CARLISLE, Penn., May 21. -- The second day's session of the American Methodist Episcopal Conference opened this morning, Bishop J.R. Thompson presiding, assisted by Bishop J.W.W. Hood. The Rev. A.J. Talbott of New-York was admitted to the conference. The Rev. Dr. Walters of the New-York Book Concern was introduced and presented the new hymnal and church discipline now upon the press in New-York.

CONCORD, N.H., May 21. -- Counsel for the Northern Railroad Company has made affidavit that the Directors of the Manchester and North Weare and of the Concord and Montreal Roads have violated the Supreme Court injunction in crossing a highway in Heniker in extending the Manchester and North Weare Road. The court will now be asked to restrain either road from prosecuting work on the extension until this suit is determined.

As one of the clergymen of the Diocese of Newark who regret the action of the Standing Committee in refusing to confirm the election of Dr. Phillips Brooks, and signed a paper expressing their dissent, permit me to say a word of explanation.

ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- The cyclone which wrought such terrible destruction to life and property near Mexico, Mo., is heard from Centralia, Mo., as follows: A funnel-shaped cyclone, one-half mile wide, passed a mile north of this place. By it a number of dwellings were totally destroyed and many persons injured -- some fatally.

Ex-Gov. Gear of Iowa, it may be truthfully said, caught a tartar when he called the Chicago Tribune to account for "aiding to defeat the party last year." The Tribune says in reply: "It looks much as if this individual, whose name was wiped off the Congressional rolls last Fall by an angry constituency, was trying to throw off on other shoulders the responsibility which should rest on his and those of his associates.

PITTSBURG, May 21. -- By a remarkably good streak of batting in the third inning, the Pittsburgs won another game from the Brooklyns to-day. Both teams played a strong game in the field, considering that the ground was in poor condition, and, barring the third inning, Caruthers pitched an excellent game.

UTICA, N.Y., May 21. -- A wet, dismal day dawned in Utica this morning. The festooned streets and bedraped buildings soaked in the prevailing moisture and ran their colors into a blurred mass. The laying of the cornerstone of the Masonic Home was apparently to be celebrated in the weather which Utica has once or twice before furnished for such occasions.

Attorney General MILLER is said to be urging the President to appoint without further delay the nine additional Circuit Court Judges provided for by act of Congress just before the adjournment last March, in order that they may take part in the organization of the new Courts of Appeal, which must take place on the 16th of June.

Charitably inclined members of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this city will be glad to learn that the new House of Mercy at Inwood is to be consecrated next Tuesday morning at 11:30 o'clock by Bishop Potter. A train will leave the Grand Central Station at 10:27 A.M. Cards to the services may be had from the Secretary of the House of Mercy, 52 East Fifty-sixth Street.

PARIS, May 21. -- Pierre Loti, the nautical novelist, whose real name is Viaud, was elected to-day to the fauteuil in the Academy left vacant by the death of Octave Feuillet, M. Loti was elected on the seventh ballot. Emile Zola, on the first ballot, had 8 votes, against 7 for M. Loti, 7 for Ferdinand Fabre, and 5 for Viscount Bernier.

Mr. Erastus Wilman's assertion in the North American Review that "a prolonged dose of McKinleyism will bring Canada into commercial union" with the United States has attracted a good deal of attention in the Dominion and has set thinking men to figuring as to the effect of the recent Tariff act on the industries of this country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, May 21. -- Surprise was created to-night in industrial circles when it became known that strenuous efforts were being made to establish William M. Whitely, the "ex-reaper king," in business here. On May 1 Mr. Whitely, who since his failure in 1886 has labored incessantly toward getting his affairs in shape, issued a circular addressed to creditors and bondholders, the gist of which was as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- It has been generally understood since soon after the adjournment of Congress that President Harrison would not appoint the nine new Circuit Judges who are to help the Supreme Court keep its calendars clear before December. It is now asserted that Attorney General Miller thinks the appointments should be made without waiting for the meeting of Congress, and is urging the President to make no further delay.

Press dispatches have given a brief summary of a lecture by Prof. Goldwin Smith before the Liberal Club of Toronto on the evening of May 11, on "Aristocracy." Prof. Smith has a way of saying what he means and saying it emphatically. In the course of his lecture he said:

The scandal in connection with the building of the new Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn may become public property after all. The old fight between Col. David E. Austen and Architect Rudolph L. Daus, a protege of "Boss" McLaughlin, broke out again yesterday at a meeting of the Armory Commission in Mayor Chapin's office.

Opposition to Senator Van Gorder's renomination has developed in Niagara County. Van Gorder has announced his intention to vote for Frank Hiscock to succeed himself as United States Senator. Hiscock failed to please the people of Niagara, as he has failed to please almost everybody in the State but himself, and Niagara County has no use for him.

So far as form is concerned, Frederick S. Gibbs is no longer in any way connected with the Republican machine in this city. This was decided upon at the meeting of the Republican County Committee in Grand Opera House Hall last night, when this committee's Executive Committee made its report upon the reconstruction which its two special committees have been carrying on in the Fifth and Thirteenth Assembly Districts.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Four of the five events for the third day of the circuit trotting at Point Breeze were disposed of this afternoon, the sport attracting some 3,000 people. The two classes remaining from Wednesday came first. Not till the ninth heat was the 2:32 class over, as Hudson, who had not got to the front yesterday, developed quite a turn of speed on the dry track and captured three heats straight.

PARIS, May 21. -- Mr. Whitelaw Reid, the American Minister, gave a grand dinner at the American Legation this evening. Among the guests were Minister de Freycinet, wife, and daughter; Minister Fallieres and wife, Minister Roche and wife, Minister Guyot, wife, and daughter; Minister Rouvier, M. Floquet and wife, M. Magnin, Governor of the Bank of France, and wife; M. Jules Simon, M. Spuller, and M. Richard Waddington.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 21. -- Commodore Ramsay paid an official visit to-day to the United States training station, inspecting the quarters ashore and the two training snips Richmond and Monongahela, all being found in good condition. On his arrival he was received with the customary honors.

The Hon. Don M. Dickinson of Michigan, ex-Postmaster General, was at the Hoffman House yesterday. He was asked by a TIMES reporter what importance he attached to the recent meeting of third-party people in Cincinnati.

We have already indicated what we believed to be the chief source of apprehension from the third-party movement, which got so far as a platform at Cincinnati. It is in the temptation that the old parties will feel to make concessions toward ideas held by a large but undefined number of voters.

Nicholas Gaulrapp, a German, twenty-seven years old, died early yesterday morning in frightful agony, and Deputy Coroner Jenkins says that his death was caused either by hydrophobia or pseudo-hydrophobia, Gaulrapp lived with his cousin, Mrs. George Johann, at 1,147 Stebbins Avenue, near One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street. He worked at such odd jobs as he could get.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday, and President E.P. Barker of the Tax Department appeared as a member of it for the first time. He was chosen Secretary, President Michael Coleman having held that position. The Controller is now the only man in the board who cannot be classed as an out-and-out Tammany man.

The funeral of ten of the victims of the Tarrytown dynamite explosion took place early yesterday morning. The burial was in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. Many of the relatives and friends of the men were present. The search for bodies continued yesterday, but without much success. Some portions of a human body were found on the Hoe place, which led to the conclusion that one man at least was blown to atoms.

DETROIT, Mich., May 21. -- The one hundred and third annual meeting of the Presbyterian General Assembly convened this morning in the First Presbyterian Church of this City. After invocation by the Rev. Dr. Radcliffe, pastor of the church, and singing by the congregation, the Rev. Dr. F.L. Patton, President of Princeton, read the sixtieth chapter of Isaiah, and prayer was offered by the Rev. James T. Smith of Baltimore.

There may possibly be a dozen miles of the line [the Adirondack and St. Lawrence] between Malone and Herkimer intersecting State lands -- not more; probably less. It all lies in Franklin County, and nearly all of it north of the line proposed by the Forestry Commission as the upper boundary of the projected park, and half of it is denuded and worthless.

BOSTON, May 21. -- Some of the leaders of political affairs in this State were asked to-day their views in regard to the action of the Cincinnati Convention. Collector Beard was not apprehensive that any harm would come to the Republican Party from the formation of a new party. "The platform is pretty near a Democratic platform," he said; "just such a one as they may be expected to adopt at their next Presidential Convention.

The Mercantile Library Association will on Monday throw open to its members its new quarters in the new Clinton Hall Building, in Astor Place. The rooms are all ready for occupancy, with the exception of a few finishing touches. The 235,000 volumes have been arranged on their shelves, and when the doors are opened it will be on one of the most commodious, pleasant, and complete circulating and reference libraries in the world.

Two of the men recently arrested for poolselling in this city have been indicted, and District Attorney NICOLL promises to bring them to trial as soon as possible and to have the cases vigorously prosecuted. He needs to devote the best talent of his office to this task. The poolsellers have been acting under the advice of very shrewd lawyers in their efforts to evade the law instead of directly violating it.
