LONDON, May 21. -- Charles Frohman, the theatrical manager of New-York, reached London last night, having arrived on the steamer City of New-York. To-day he has been in close consultation with Charles Wyndham, and the result of the conference has been that Mr. Frohman has purchased the American rights to "Miss Helyett," the musical comedy by Audran, which has now been running at the Bouffes Parisiennes, in Paris nearly a year.

LISBON, May 21. -- The following Cabinet has been definitively formed: Gem de Sousa, President of the Council and Minister of War; Senhor Vaz, Minister of the Interior; Senhor Marianho Carvalho, Minister of Finance; Senhor Moraes Carvalho, Minister of Justice; Senhor Vilsena, Minister of Marine and of the Colonies; Count Valborn, Minister of Foreign Affairs; Senhor Castello Branco, Minister of Public Works.

Thousands of friends of Packard's Business College filled Music Hall, at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, last evening, on the occasion of the thirty-third anniversary and graduating exercises of the institution. On the platform were many well-known citizens, Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band, and a great heap of handsome bouquets of flowers, which later were presented to the proud and happy graduates.
Nearly a month ago we asked the Cleveland Leader a question about Senator SHERMAN'S so-called Anti-Trust law. The Leader had said:

Baseball is prospering in England, and the American sport is fast supplanting cricket and football among the working classes. Last season a league of four clubs was successfully maintained, and this year the circuit is to be increased to six or eight clubs. The championship season is about opening, and it promises to be more interesting than any of its predecessors.

The fifty-eighth annual convention of the General Congregational Association of the State of New-York came to a close in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The entire morning session was given up to reports from half a dozen ministers in regard to home and foreign missions and to the meeting of the Women's Home Missionary Union.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 21. -- Bribery has won the first blow. The various indictments for attempting to bribe jurors have been virtually quashed. In one case only was formal action taken. The demurrer to the indictment in the case of Charles Granger was fixed for argument to-day, but the demurrer was sustained without argument and Granger's release ordered.

The Forest Commissioners held an all-day meeting yesterday at the office of Commissioner Sherman W. Knevals, in the Mutual Llfe Building, in Nassau Street. The only business transacted was the payment of between $6,000 and $7,000 to the lawyers who appeared for the commission during the investigation conducted by the Committee on Forestry and Public Lands of the last Legislature.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 21. -- In the statement of a rapid increase of Canada's national debt, in comparison with the debt of the United States, and the statement of the proposed expenditure by the Dominion Government for various large schemes, such as a submarine tunnel, a ship canal, a ship railway, , published here yesterday, Canadians have ample cause for alarm.

RED BANK, N.J., May 21. -- Major James S. Yard, one of the leading Democrats in New-Jersey and editor of the Freehold Democrat, is a shrewd political observer and knows perhaps as much about New-Jersey politics as any other man in the State. In to-day's issue of his paper the Major has the following editorial, headed "New-Jersey for Cleveland":

Of seven lawyers who were consulted by the Presidents of the Brooklyn gas companies, five have solemnly decided that the act of the last Legislature by which the price of gas in the city of Brooklyn was reduced from $1.50 per thousand feet to $1.25 is unconstitutional and of no effect, from which, as they declare, it results that the legal rate for gas is still $1.50.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Navy Department does not propose to condemn the pneumatic guns of the Vesuvius without further trials, and a new lot of projectiles will soon be ordered and a new series or trials will be made. The advocates of the pneumatic system claim that the guns of the Vesuvius had not been fired often enough to be properly ranged, and that, with further experience, much better results can be attained.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Secretary Tracy was asked to-day if, in view of the statement that had been published to the effect that Secretary Blaine's condition has been misrepresented, and that really not only is his physical condition precarious, but his mental faculties impaired, he could say anything to throw light on the subject.

ALBANY, May 22. -- A telegram was received this evening at the office of the Forest Commission stating that thus far no evidence of trespass on State lands by the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company had been secured. The dispatch was signed by an employe of the commission who is acting under Warden Garmon.

ST. LOUIS, May 22. -- A great deal of comment is indulged in and not a little severe criticism over the death of Miss Lucy McKeegan, daughter of Judge E. McKeegan, one of the foremost lawyers in this city. She died last Tuesday at the home of her parents, 74 Vandeventer Place, and developments show she was clearly a victim of Christian science.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- One of the methods employed by the last Congress, in reaching the billion-dollar line in its expenditures, was the creation of new places at the public crib, and the increase of salaries of some of those persons already provided for.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- At the recent meeting of the Committee on Safety Appliances appointed at the National Convention of Railroad Commissioners it was decided that information on the following subjects should be obtained: The total number of freight cars owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by each company and how many are equipped with automatic couplers.

Since the Treasury Department yielded to the demands of ex-Controller LAWRENCE and decided that double duties must be paid on all-carpet wools that have been sorted abroad, even for color, the manufacturers have been forced to consider with some anxiety the probable effect of the sorting-clause trick.

The Herald published yesterday some translations from the Italian "Green Book," containing portions of the correspondence between Baron FAVA and the Marquis DI RUDINI after the incident of March 14, in New-Orleans, and some memoranda by Baron FAVA of his conversations with Mr. BLAINE.

" These gates will be closed as exits between 2 and 4:30 P.M.," read signs posted all about the entrance to the Brooklyn Jockey Club track at Gravesend yesterday. Strong-lunged officers informed visitors to the same effect. If these visitors wished to leave the track, there was an open gate over at the Boulevard for their use, and no one was prevented from passing out there.

Recorder Smyth, on taking his seat in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, was confronted with calendar containing twenty-nine cases; two Assistant District Attorneys, Messrs. Stapler and Simms, and ex-Senator Ecclesine, who was appointed a special District Attorney to try bottle cases, or cases in which Junkmen were charged with selling stamped bottles for purposes of refilling.

There will be much disappointment to-day over the fact that Tenny is not named as a starter for the St. James Hotel Stakes. But his shrewd owner has decided not to give him another hard race until the Suburban, and a hard race he would certainly have if he met Kingston. As King Thomas is named as the only starter against Kingston, it looks like a practical walk-over for the latter.

DETROIT, May 22. -- The second day's sessions of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church began promptly at 9 o'clock this morning. As usual, the first half hour was devoted to devotional services, under the leadership of Dr. Samuel C. Logan of Scranton, Penn.

The American Kennel Club held a lively and interesting meeting in the clubrooms at 44 Broadway, Thursday afternoon. The meeting was provoked by the recent trial of Charles J. Peshal, the President of the New-Jersey Kennel Club, on the charge of libel preferred by Secretary Vredenberg of the American Kennel Club, and it resulted in the expulsion of Mr. Peshal, and, through him a its representative, of the New-Jersey Kennel Club, from the American Association.

The Presidents of the railroads in the Trunk Line Association met in the Jersey Central Railroad Building yesterday, and talked nearly all day about the demoralized condition of eastbound rates, incidentally paying some attention to the question of differentials claimed by the West Shore-Canadian Pacific combination.

In making any calculation as to the possible spread of the financial notions of the so-called "People's Party," one fact must be borne in mind, and that is that the farmers of to-day are by no means the same homogeneous class that they were even twenty years ago. Up to the close of the civil war the great body of the farmers were Americans by birth or by descent.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 22. -- A careful analysis of the Supreme Court decision in the Hope case presents it in a far less dangerous light to the finances of the State than was at first apprehended. Attorney General Rogers, who represented the State Board of Liquidation, said that the decision was substantially a victory for the State.

PHILDELPHIA, May 22. -- An important deal was consummated to-day by which the Reading Railroad gained control of the Gettysburg and Harrisburg Road, taking posession at once. The old Board of Directors and President J.C. Fuller resigned, and in their places President McLeod of the Reading and these Directors were elected: J.H. Loomis, J.M. Landis, R. Weston, C.C. Midwood, H.T. Narsby, and R. Tiel.

Things went badly with the city poolrooms yesterday, although about a dozen of the places kept open for business. Uncertainty characterized everything the poolmen did. Arrest, which at first they treated as a joke, had come to look serious in the light of frequent repetition and increased bail. They could not do business without the news from the track, and they did not know how they were going to get that news.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 22. -- The six runaway Aldermen returned to this city this afternoon, and, followed by a large crowd, proceeded at once to the Aldermanic Chamber. There Mayor Marigold and the seven other members of the board were in session, having been in continuous session for two days. They have passed two nights in the Aldermanic Chamber.

ALBANY, May 22. -- There are no more legislative bills to be acted upon by the Governor. He signed ten and vetoed seven to-day, and that cleaned the docket. In all he has signed 389 bills this year, against 569 last year. Of the 102 left in his hands when the Legislature adjourned he has vetoed 15.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The excitement caused by the flight of President Gideon W. Marsh of the Keystone National Bank, the resignation of City Treasurer Bardsley, and his confession that he had collected $930,000 of State taxes, for which he cannot account still runs high.

This is a week remarkable for retirements of high officers in the army and navy. On Monday, Rear Admiral BRAINE, who stood third in his grade, now the highest in the navy, completed his sixty-second year and went upon the shelf after a busy service of close upon forty-five years, including active participation in two wars.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- All of the buildings for the World's Columbian Exposition will be under way within less than six weeks. To-morrow the Grounds and Buildings Committee will let a contract for the Mines and Mining Building if the bids are satisfactory, and from this time forward contracts for the remaining buildings will be given at the rate of one a week.
Four weeks have passed since the New-York Tribune sought to mislead its readers by publishing the following in its editorial columns:

LEBANON, Penn., May 22. -- At this morning's session of the General Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church the service was led by Mr. Robert Weldensall. The Rev. S.E. Greenawalt of Osborne, Ohio, was appointed Assistant Secretary. The following excesses of apportionment were reported: Synod of Maryland, $188.95; Synod of East Pennsylvania, $2,782.92; Synod of Miami, $29.40; Synod of Iowa, $86.09; Synod of Kansas, $138.64; Synod of German Nebraska, $153.05.

CINCINNATI, May 22. -- Welch, the diminutive pitcher of the New-Yorks, faced the Cincinnati Club here to-day. His curves were not of the deceptive order, and the result was that the local players fattened their batting average to some extent at the expense of "Smiling Mickey."

The American Newspaper Publishers' Association adopted, at its last annual meeting in this city, a resolution appointing a committee to arrange for a contest, to be entered by all manufacturers of typesetting machines, in order to determine which is adapted for the production of the best practical results "under ordinary newspaper conditions in well-managed offices."

The slowness with which great bodies move is especially illustrated by the slowness of great theological bodies. It was generally assumed, when the Presbyterian creed, as contained in the Westminster Confession, was put into the hands of its friends to be revised, that the General Assembly to which the report of the revisers was submitted would act upon the report.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 22. -- The Dominion Government has no systematized method of collecting statistics relative to the supply of flour and wheat and crop returns in Canada, and in consequence dealers are generally in the dark as to the stock on hand, and are left to depend largely on the old-fashioned methods of comparing notes.
CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 22. -- The following figures show the exact coke-strike situation to date:

AMHERST, Mass., May 22. -- What with beating Dartmouth in tennis and winning to-day's championship baseball game from Dartmouth by a score of 10 to 1, Amherst is jubilant. Another thing also is a source of much pleasure to the Amherst boys in that the new Pratt field was formally dedicated and given to the college this afternoon.

The popular movement in favor of driving Mr. Gould's trestlework nuisance from the Battery Park gathers head. Petitions are circulating, and if there is an organized effort to procure signatures the Park Commissioners will soon realize that the path of safety does not lie in the direction of protecting the elevated railroad in its trespass on the public pleasure ground.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 22. -- Frank Turk, a German shoemaker, aged forty, who came here three months ago, murdered his wife, Elizabeth, to-night with a thirty-two-calibre revolver and then killed himself in their apartments, in Tenement Row, on Palisade Avenue. Turk's first wife, who came here with him, died last April, leaving a girl three years old.

ST. LOUIS, May 22. -- The United States Circuit Court was engaged this afternoon on the case of Glenn against the National Southern Express Company. This corporation was originally organized in 1860 as the National, but in 1865 it was reorganized as the Southern Express Company, with Gen. Joseph E. Johnston as President.

Why Gov. HILL should have waited nearly a year and a half before filling the vacancy on the Board of Electrical Control caused by the resignation of Mr. GIBBENS in January, 1890, it is difficult to surmise. The board has been embarrassed by his failure to perform this duty and has frequently had to postpone its meetings for lack of a quorum.

WHEELING, West Va., May 22. -- It has been definitely decided to continue the drilling of the Boggs Run experimental well, now 4,500 feet deep, to a depth of at least 5,800 feet, making it the deepest well in the world. Mr. Anton Reymann of this city has guaranteed the money in case the amount is not forthcoming from the funds of the Smithsonian Institution at Washington.

LONDON, May 22. -- The Hamburg-American Line steamer Columbia, Capt. Vogelgesang, which arrived at Hamburg to-day from New-York, reports that on May 17, in latitude 44 north, longitude 48 west, she sighted a steamer belonging to the Netherlands-American Steamship Company, whose machinery was evidently disabled.

NEW BRUNSWICK, May 23. -- Rutgers Seniors have gone home to recruit for the Commencement exercises. The honor men have been announced as follows: Valedictory, Marcus C. Sears, Blooming Grove, N.Y.; salutatory, Eliha C. Bryan, Skekomeko, N.Y.; philosophical oration, George A. Mitchell, Vineland, N.J.; scientific oration, John C. Aydelott, Pekin, Ill.; rhetorical honor, Joseph C. Castner, this city.

LONDON, May 14. -- The financial situation in Europe always depends very greatly upon the political conditions. Just now there is a general wide-spread want of confidence on the part of investors, and consequently all the financial centres of Europe are peculiarly sensitive. The financial collapse of Nov. 15 last, when the great house of the Barings fell, has had more far-reaching effects than is generally known.

Some ten or twelve years ago -- the date is of no importance or the exact place -- an Englishman wandered down to the north of Scotland and invested some of his superfluous capital in a salmon river. Such an adventurer is often but poorly repaid for his enterprise.

The Electrical Engineer of this week will contain an interesting account of the session of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers held at Columbia College last Wednesday evening, at which some really wonderful experiments were shown by Nikola Tesla, the recognized leading expert on alternating currents. For these experiments Mr. Tesla used an alternating machine with 400 poles, which when run at full speed permitted him to obtain 20,000 alternations per second.

Brooklyn held its first coaching carnival yesterday in Prospect Park, and when the long line of vehicles straightened itself out from the Concourse toward Ocean Parkway 30,000 spectators, lining both sides of the road, clapped their hands and waved their handkerchiefs approvingly.

There never was a time in the history of Mayor Grant's administration when his movements were watched so closely as they are watched now. His continued delay in making appointments has created excitement not only among the politicians themselves, but among a large class of people who do not usually disturb themselves about the movements of Mayor Grant or the syndicate which controls the Municipal Government.

The Butte City (Mon.) Inter Mountain, Republican, is for Blaine for President in 1892. "With protection, reciprocity, honest money, clean elections, and equal rights inscribed on the Republican banner, James G. Blaine," it says, "would go forward to victory, without a single repulse, and hundreds of thousands of American Democrats would feel a secret joy in the knowledge that at last justice had been awarded to the greatest living citizen of the Republic."

NEW-ORLEANS, May 23. -- Before the Italian Consul, Pasquale Corte, left here for Europe he prepared a statement of his course in regard to the lynching of his countrymen in the Parish Prison, which he placed in the hands of a friend, for use if necessary. The demand of Mayor Shakespeare that the Consul be not allowed to return to this city is sufficient justification for its use.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 23. -- Long Branch just now is one of the busiest places along the New-Jersey coast. Painters, carpenters, decorators, and gardeners are actively preparing for the exodus that will soon begin in the near-by cities. Houses that have been built this Spring are receiving the finishing touches, and those which have been occupied before are being cleaned, painted, and refurnished for their owners or new tenants.

ALBANY, May 23. -- The resignation Forestry Commissioner Sherman Knevals has been received by Gov. Hill and placed on file. The filing of the resignation in itself creates a vacancy in the office, but the Governor has also officially announced his acceptance of the resignation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 23. -- There is a movement on foot to establish a Federal divorce court in Canada. At present all decrees are granted by the Senate. Recently two, gentlemen whose names were proposed by the leader of the House as members of the Select Committee on Divorce declined to act and a third Senator stated that his name had been omitted at his own request.

Chicago, May 23. -- Chairman Finlay of the Western Passenger Association has no reason to be in doubt as to the Chicago and Alton's position. He devote a portion of his time to-day to a careful perusal of that company's answer to the charge that it had violated its agreement in declining to advance the passenger rates from St. Louis to Chicago and from Kansas City to St. Louis.

BERLIN, May 23. -- The attention of the Foreign Office is absorbed in commercial treaty negotiations, some of the results of which will have a direct bearing on Germany's relations with the United States. The arrangements with Italy, Switzerland, and Roumania are progressing towards an enteric. Belgium is also negotiating with Germany, but that country is less likely than the others to be drawn within the customs bund.

The Abram Bernard Association of the Eleventh Assembly District opened its new clubhouse at 427 Fourth Avenue last night. The club is now described as "a Democratic institution with no factional affiliations." It is named after Abram Bernard, its President, who is the Clerk of Judge Loehmann's District Court. It was formerly regarded as "County Democratic" in its tendencies, but it is made up of all sorts of Democrats.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $141,253,900, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,770,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $23,125,950; 4 per cents, $110,357,950.

HINTS TO ILLUSTRATORS. -- Get in the habit of carrying a small sketch book and of picking up characteristic jottings in the street, on the ferry, in the horse car, or in the audience at the theatre. Notice how men wear their hats, at what angles they are tipped and how much of the head or face is visible below the brim.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- Our fellow-townsman, Mr. John Ewing, is responsible for the defeat administered to the Reds to-day by the Giants. He pitched a remarkably clever game of ball for the New-Yorkers and won in the easiest possible manner. Capt. Ewing was advertised to play, but at the last moment he changed his mind and young Clarke put on the mask.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 23. -- The Rev. W.W. Cole of Pulaski, N.Y., who has just been graduated from Auburn Theological Seminary in the Class of '91, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Presbyterian church at Pompey, N.Y. The Rev. S.L. Emery, of Mexico, N.Y., who was graduated in the same class, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Presbyterian church at West Newark, N.J.

The assurance given by Messrs. BAKER and BUTTERWORTH that the recent rumor of a postponement of the Chicago Fair until 1894 is unfounded will be welcome everywhere. To celebrate in 1893 an event whose commemoration should properly come in 1892 is quite anachronism enough for a community that prides itself on being wide-awake and on time.

MOUNT VERNON BARRACK, Ala., May 23. -- Thirty Indians belonging to the Chiricahua band of Apaches, who were mustered into the United States Army, arrived at this post at noon Thursday and, with fifty-five of the captive Apaches at Mount Vernon, who had also enlisted, were formed into Company L of the Twelfth Infantry. The squad from San Carlos were under command of First Lieut. Dodge of the Twenty-fourth Infantry.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- It will not be the fault of the Civil Service Commissioners if Green B. Raum, Jr., and those who are implicated with him in the alleged violation of the civil service law are not made to feel that the law was not made to be violated.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- This is the sixth day that the Charleston has been at sea since leaving Acapulco, and the Navy Department is still without news from her or the Itata. It is expected that the Charleston will touch at some port on the northern coast of South America within a day or two and report her movements.

After long deliberation and much patient preparation the Encyclical of the Pope on the social questions of the day has made its appearance. It is marked by the characteristics that have made the present Pope heartily respected, even by those who cannot consider well-grounded his claims to supreme authority in matters of belief.

The presence of an unusually large number of our war ships in home waters, with a prospect of their remaining here for several months to come, has brought up the project of having all the available vessels on the Atlantic coast take part in a series of fleet manoeuvres and exercises a little later in the season.

The organizations occupying the State Camp of Instruction the coming season, which begins June 13, will have occasion to thank the Commissary General of Ordnance, Brig. Gen. Joshua M. Varian, for providing for their comfort. Notwithstanding the fact that the present is the last year of the current military administration at Albany, the Commissary General has provided liberally for the welfare of the troops which are to occupy the military post on the Hudson.

THE COST OF FEASTS IN THE PAST. -- I 1638 the opening of Inigo Jones's new theatre was celebrated by an elaborate banquet, attended by the Lords of the Council, and the bill amounted to 84 5s. 4d., exclusive of wine. Glass and plate were hired, and some of the former was broken and had to be paid for.

Third-track construction by the elevated railroad company in Ninth Avenue came to an unceremonious end yesterday morning, when the police stepped in under orders from headquarters. Inspector Byrnes in turn received his orders from the Mayor. There was no dallying over the matter when once the ball started to roll.

Visitors to the Central Park yesterday were surprised, and those with any sense of what is fitting in the Park must have been annoyed, to see at various points on the walks a lot of weighing machines, on which, by the magic "nickel in the slot," the passer by could ascertain with more or less accuracy the number of pounds in his body and its belongings.

The recent visit of ex-Senator Ingalls to this city, while the newspapers are discussing the successorship to Mr. Edmunds in the Senate, has struck some of the politicians who make the Fifth Avenue Hotel their Summer headquarters as in the nature of a striking coincidence. It is not the first time that Ingalls has appeared as a sort of Nemesis to Edmunds.

HANOVER, N.H., May 23. -- The Dartmouth athletic team which will represent the college next week in the intercollegiate meet at Springfield, although not the equal of last year's team, will make a hard fight for the championship and the association cup. It is considerably weakened by the loss of so many of last year's athletes, and very little interest is taken by the college at large as to what men are sent.

The little park at the lower end of Manhattan Island is unique among the breathing places and pleasure grounds of this metropolis. It fronts directly upon our beautiful bay, commanding a view of its whole breadth from the Kills to the Narrows, from the Jersey shore to the heights of Brooklyn, with the picturesque lines of Staten Island in front.

DETROIT, May 23. -- At the close of the usual devotional services this morning, the Committee on Arrangements read its report of appointments for preaching services to-morrow. A rare chance will be presented to the inhabitants of Detroit to hear the most noted men in the Assembly, and some who are not so eminent.

The Cleveland papers say that Sharrott gave a great display of pitching skill in Cleveland. One needed to sit behind the catcher to see now elegantly he would work the corners. Every time that a Cleveland batter "got in the hole" Sharrot would either strike him out or the umpire would call him out. He seems to have better command of the ball than any of the New-York pitchers.

The popular interest that is taken in transatlantic racing nowadays is not in any degree less than it was thirty years ago, when the paddlewheel gave way to the screw, and when several new lines became competitors for ocean laurels. Nearly everybody has forgotten those days, but not so Thomas Schavering, who was an engineer on several of the transatlantic liners before the war, and who recalls the ships of that period with great distinctness.
CLEVELAND, May 23. -- The game today was one-sided. Cleveland's players batted Clarkson at will, and played a remarkably strong game in the field. Score:

ITALIAN FINANCES. -- In the budget of 1881, the last year of political neutrality, the expenditure, ordinary and extraordinary, of the kingdom was 1,229,578,938 lire, (little more than 49,000,000.) In 1889, the eighth year of the policy of alliances, the ordinary and extraordinary expenses were 1,740,578,938 lire, (nearly 70,000,000.)

The recent decision of Judge THAYER of the United States District Court in a case relating to a Trust combination agreement deserves attention mainly for the reason that it was based upon the new Anti-Trust statute of Missouri. Three years ago a combination called the American Preservers' Company was formed by the loading manufacturers of preserves, jellies, and the like, and the Taylor Manufacturing Company of St. Louis became a part of it.

The officers of the Cypress Hills Cemetery have decided on a plan for the improvement of the grounds of this burial place and have begun work which they believe will make the cemetery one of the most attractive in this vicinity.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- The affairs of City Treasurer John Bardsley were brought to a crisis by his arrest a few minutes before 11 o'clock to-night at his home, Penn and Price Streets, Germantown. He is sick in bed, and two detectives are guarding the room in which he lies.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Another instance of Gov. Hill's belief that the average taxpayer possesses a short memory is afforded by his treatment of the bill extending the term of office of Subway Commissioner Hess another year. The measure was introduced in the Assembly by John E. Brodsky of the Eighth New-York District. It came to the Senate during the dead-lock.

The Governors of the Manhattan Athletic Club apparently appreciate the fact that an ounce of gold is twice as alluring as an ounce of silver, for, at the suggestion of Capt. James C. Summers, Commodore of the Cherry Diamond Yacht Club and Director of Yachting in the Manhattan Athletic Club, they have decided to provide the first gold cup ever offered as a prize for a yachting contest in American waters.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 23. -- The Newport season is undoubtedly further advanced than usual at this time. There are hosts of Summer people here, and while they are spending their time quietly and doing absolutely nothing in a social way, yet their presence is perfectly obvious, as the gay equipages are seen daily in large numbers in the streets, while the familiar faces of cottagers are visible on every hand.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- Dean Horace F. Jayne of the college department has returned home from Europe, and on his appearance in the chapel for the first time on Monday he was loudly cheered. He has brought back for the biological department many valuable specimens, purchased principally in Berlin.

In a quarrel which followed, a dispute as to the pay for a room in the lodging house at 154 Thompson Street, near Houston Street, Emil Grob, the night clerk of the house, was dangerously stabbed yesterday morning by Walter Jones, a negro. Jones escaped. He hired a room at the place Friday, and as he slept in it Friday afternoon and again Friday night, Grob demanded double pay.

The enlistment of Indians as soldiers in the regular army, which started off rather slowly, has since shown better results, so that there is little doubt of its ultimate success. It was especially questioned at first whether the red men would consent to serve on foot; but there are already two full Indian companies of infantry, besides a troop of cavalry, and several other troops and companies will soon be completed.

MILWAUKEE, May 23. -- The Rev. Dr. Parkehurst, pastor of the Summerfield Methodist Church, to-day received a note delicately worded canceling his engagement to deliver the Memorial Day sermon at the Soldiers' Home tomorrow. This unprecedented action has aroused angry feelings among both veterans and Methodists.

Poolroom men continued betting in their rooms yesterday as usual in defiance of the law, believing themselves safe under the "commission agent" subterfuge, and with a further belief that the police authorities are in sympathy with them rather than against them in their violation of law, just as the same authorities are with the violators of the excise laws who pay tribute to Tammany Hall, and somebody else, possibly.

Nearly sixty years ago, in the days when gentlewomen in reduced circumstances found the path to remunerative industry strewn with most forbidden obstacles, "The Ladies' Depository" was organized in this city. A few warm-hearted and thoughtful women, who, in the year 1834, were influential in New-York society, informally banded themselves together for the purpose of providing fine sewing for other women whom financial reverses compelled to seek some means of livelihood.

LONDON, May 23. -- An auction at an old country mansion on the Isle of Man this week revealed a collection of valuable paintings which had been formed there by an American resident early in the present century. The collection included a full-length portrait of President Washington by Gilbert Charles Stuart, the celebrated American painter.

Mr. Langton issued privately about eight years ago a small edition of this work, and the interest aroused by it, as well as the accumulation of new material, has led him to publish the present enlarged edition for the general public. Mr. Langton has been a most industrious student of scenes and incidents in Dickens's early life.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 23. -- Norwood Park, Norman L. Munro's cottage colony, never looked lovelier than now, when it is clad in Spring's attire. The twenty-four beautiful cottages and their surroundings represent an expenditure of more than a million dollars, but, if rumor be true, the investment, which was at first regarded simply as a rich man's hobby, is a paying one shrewdly designed by a keen man of affairs.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23. -- The formal opening of the School of Arts took place this week. The new building, which is specially devoted to this department, is now open for public inspection. It contains a large number of rare historical, scientific, and artistic collections and is considered by the professors of the Art School one of the best equipped in the country.

The members of the Citizens' Committee who have had in charge the movement to oust the elevated railroad from Battery Park received encouragement from all sides yesterday. Every mail brought letters to various members of the committee, some of them simply inclosing signed petitions and others containing messages of sympathy and encouragement.

Whole volumes might be filled with a mere noting of gown ideas, any one of which it would be possible to elaborate in many different ways without transgressing the limits of good taste. The canons of fashion admit of such liberal interpretation that there is little danger of incurring the charge of heresy. There are no censors, self-constituted or appointed, and advanced thought is rather at a premium than otherwise.

DUNNING, Neb., May 23. -- Judge C.W. Aikens, Treasurer of Blaine County, and one of the most respected men in Nebraska, while acting as custodian of a stock thief whom he had assisted in capturing, was shot through the body at a late hour last night by citizens who, in the darkness, mistook him for a desperado. He fell from his horse to the ground a corpse.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 23. -- The following awards of prizes to the Seniors have been announced: Underwood Prizes in Chemistry -- First, Thomas E. Hayden, Rudeston; second, George M. Weaver, Utica. Manson Prizes in German -- First, George V. Edwards, Riverhead; second, Aurelian Post, Pulaski.

The declarations of Mr. Cleveland in his Buffalo speech with reference to the dangers of public extravagance are in entire harmony with the warning addressed to Congress in his Presidential messages. For instance, in his annual message of 1886, after speaking of the large excess of Government revenue over expenditures and the approaching extinguishment of the bonds subject to call, he said:

BOSTON, May 23. -- Pneumonia, consumption, and influenza are the principal causes of the rather high death rate this week. There were three deaths caused by influenza and eight others caused partially by the same disease. The number of deaths from pneumonia was 34. This is an unusually large number, as that for the corresponding week last year was but 10.

The Broadway fruit shops are beginning to present a summer appearance. Strawberries, however, are the principal fruit offered for sale. But there may be found cherries that are large, attractive, and luscious, They are from Southern California, and the finest of them sold at wholesale yesterday for upward of 40 cents a pound.

Mr. Mansfield's play of "Don Juan" is now an absorbing theatrical topic, and there have been large audiences at the Garden Theatre since it was produced. A great variety of opinion, founded partly on honest impressions of its first performance and partly on prejudice, has been expressed concerning it. It has excited hot discussion, and book publishers and play producers believe that is a good thing for a book or a play.

The New-York Riding Club could not have chanced upon a better day for its fifteenth annual ride to Jerome Park than yesterday. The air was cool and bracing, and the dust on the roads had been settled by the rain of Friday night. The sky was overcast and a fresh breeze blew from the west, so that no discomfort resulted from the exertion of riding.

LEXINGTON, May 23. -- Kentucky's pioneer trotting horse breeder, Dr. L. Herr, the man who bred the famous Mambrino Patchen, is dead. Heart disease had been troubling him for a long time, and three months ago it was thought his death was rapidly approaching. He seemed to grow better, but it was only a temporary improvement, and on Wednesday he died.

HARRISVILLE, N.Y., May 23. -- If anglers who visit the Adirondacks are not satisfied with the results of the first two weeks of the open season this year, they are exceedingly hard to please. It has been several years since the sport opened so favorably in this region. The month of May has been very dry here and the streams are unusually low for this time of year.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 23. -- The Seniors and Post Seniors in the Department of Mining Engineering, accompanied by Instructor H.H. Staek, went to Drifton, Penn., on Monday and inspected the new iron coal breaker of Messrs. Coxe Brothers Co.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 23, via Galveston. -- There seems no indication of any stop in the rapid extension of this city, which is growing fast in all directions, but mainly toward the west and southwest. Many hundred new houses are building, and plans for a large number more are accepted. Business is excellent, and reports from all parts of the republic show a high degree of prosperity.

MELBOURNE, April 12. -- The week that has just closed will stand as a most eventful one in Australian history, inasmuch as it has seen the labors of the National Federation Convention terminate in the adoption of a Constitution for the proposed "Commonwealth of Australia." An important step toward Australian nationalization has thus been taken -- a step which it now only remains with the various Parliaments of the colonies to confirm.

LONDON, May 23. -- In these prosaic workaday latter times, royalty is for the most part such a humdrum affair, that when we find a real live Queen who has been evicted from her palace by policemen, and who lets down her back hair and, metaphorically at least, screams, and bites, and scratches in resistance, the jaded public imagination feels grateful.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- There was considerable excitement at Ridley Park to-day when it became known that the wife of Gideon W. Marsh, the fugitive President of the defunct Keystone Bank, had returned to her home. Mrs. Marsh got off the 3 o'clock train from this city and hurriedly entered a carriage and was driven to the Marsh residence.

LAKEWOOD, May 23. -- Mr. S.D. Davis, Vice President of the Hocking Valley Railroad, with his daughter, Miss Agnes Davis, and his son, Mr. Archie Davis, will sail for Europe soon after the Laurel House closes, June 1. Mrs. Davis and her daughter, Miss Elsie Davis, will spend a part of the Summer at Jefferson, N.H.

St. John's Guild makes an earnest appeal to the public to provide it with funds so that it can this year do a greatly-increased work among the poor. The Board of Health has asked that six trips of the St. John's Guild's Floating Hospital be made every week, instead of four, as have been made in the Summer months heretofore.

DETROIT, May 24. -- The only action looking toward a consideration of the matter of Dr. Briggs and the Union Seminary which has yet been taken was that mentioned in these dispatches yesterday, providing for the reference of the various overtures of Presbyteries to the Standing Committee on Theological Seminaries. At latest accounts the report of the seminary Board of Directors had not been received.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 24. -- Miss Harriet M. Daniels, daughter of Mr. George H. Daniels, the Passenger Agent of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, is attending Lyndon Hall School, in this city. Yesterday she gave an engine party to a number of schoolmates. Mr. Daniels had charge of the excursion.

Late Saturday night a respectable-looking man applied at the Western Union Hotel, 113 West Street, for a room. He told the clerk that he had but 35 cents, and the cheapest lodging is 50 cents. But the man's appearance aroused the clerk's sympathy and he assigned him a room. The lodger gave his name as Hugh Dougherty of Philadelphia.

CARTHAGE, N.Y., May 24. -- The season for big fish is at hand and anglers in this part of the State are making great records. Jefferson County sportsmen are now busy discussing two remarkable catches that were made last week. One of them was the capture of a salmon weighing eighteen pounds, near Clayton, on the St. Lawrence River.

The use of pigeons as messengers in war is becoming an important factor in military practice in all the countries of Europe. Notably is this true in Italy. It may therefore not be without interest to reproduce a few details on the subject which appear in the yearly supplement to Meyers's Conversations-Lexikon.

The immigration statistics for April lend point to these reflections. During that one month there arrived in the United States from Russia and Poland 7,501 immigrants, an increase over 1890 of 3,291. And the movement is gaining -- not losing -- headway, for in the four months ending with April the arrivals of such refugees numbered only some 9,000 over the previous similar period.

The soldiers and sailors' monument for Portland, Me., designed by Simmons, consists of a pedestal of granite rising fifteen feet above an embankment, bearing on one face a tablet, which reads: "Portland to Her Sons Who Died for the Union," also of two groups in bronze, flanking the pedestal, and of a colossal figure of Victory, fifteen feet in height, which surmounts it.

The Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Dutch Reformed Church, at Sixty-eighth Street and West Boulevard, preached a sermon yesterday, in which he severely rebuked the present tendency of Christian clergymen of all denominations to spend their time in theological squabbling rather than in preaching the religion of Christ.

Owing to a combination agreement, between the two manufacturers of refined sugar on the Pacific coast -- SPRECKELS and representative of the Sugar Trust -- the price of sugar in California suffered only a alight reduction after the removal of the duty on the raw material, but the refiners have recently been compelled by importations to make further concessions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- The announcement of the arrest of City Treasurer Joan Bardsley created a great sensation all over the city this morning and was the inexhaustible topic of conversation everywhere. Owing to the late hour at which the arrest was made on Saturday night but few persons knew of the occurrence until the cries of the newsboys this morning acquainted them with the fact.

Although no stakes are on for decision at the race track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club this afternoon, there is a programme which promises as good sport as any that has been had since the gates of the Gravesend track have been thrown open to the public. It is not a selling platers' day, but one in which high-class handicap and stake horses will meet and try conclusions for purses and sweepstakes.
About 300 naval veterans observed Sailors' Memorial Day yesterday afternoon by decorating 3,000 graves in the United States Naval Cemetery in Brooklyn.
-- Gen. B.F. Butler's "Autobiography and Reminiscences" will be issued in German and French as well as English, and it is announced as somewhere near ready.

NEW-HAVEN, May 24. -- Among the documents recently found under the floor of Gov. Jonathan Trumbull's old war office at Lebanon is a letter written in 1776 by R. Isaacs of New-Haven to Gov. William Franklin of New-Jersey when the latter was a prisoner at Middletown, deprived of freedom on account of his very pronounced Tory sentiment.

The petition that should be signed by all citizens who believe in preserving the public parks is given below. It should be signed at once to help on the good work. Every name will count. A strong fight cow will save the parks from the blight of grabbers.

Twelve candidates were admitted to Deacons orders and six to priests orders yesterday morning in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church. Bishop H.C. Potter officiated, assisted by Dean E.A. Hoffman, the Rev. Prof. Jewett, the Rev. Prof. Oliver, and the Rev. Dr. Tuttle of St. Luke's Church.

Central Park has never been seen to more advantage than Saturday, nor has its usefulness as a people's pleasure ground ever been more signally illustrated. The trees are in full verdure, and all the flowers of latter May in full bloom. The double line of carriages each way on the East Drive above McGown's Pass Tavern is an unfailing indication that the height of the season has been reached, and this was the case Saturday.

" The one and simple argument for a new Post Office building up town, or rather in a central section of the city," said Postmaster Van Cott yesterday, "is that the business to be transacted has outgrown the present building, and new facilities are indispensable to afford quick dispatch and satisfactory delivery of the mail."

The Richmond Dispatch cites the "fiat" cranks -- who were represented at Cincinnati by the voluble speaker, who declared that the people were "going to make their own money and use it too" -- to a bit of history. Says the Dispatch: "The notion is that the Government can issue a thousand millions of so-called dollars and keep the same at par with gold.

WALLA WALLA, Washington, May 24. -- The court of inquiry into the lynching of Hunt by soldiers, so far as taking testimony is concerned, closed yesterday. The court will arrive at its conclusions Monday and forward its report to the War Department.

The Duke of WESTMINSTER, addressing the Guildhall meeting, declared that the Russian laws against Jews were a lasting monument to the infamy of their inventor, and the meeting passed eloquent and most benevolent resolutions beseeching the Czar's pity for his unfortunate subjects. That was scarcely six months ago, and now the telegraph informs us of the organization in London of the Hebrew Lovers of Zion.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 24. -- More than 2,000 people paid admission to the Association baseball grounds to-day. Each one on entering the gate received a ticket containing an order for a refunder of their admission fee in case the game was prevented by police interference, and an hour later each one used his ticket in obtaining the refunder. The Athletics had made the run from Philadelphia in the unparalleled time of eighteen hours.

James B. Werner, one of the two divinity students who ran away from the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this city the night of April 23 last and went to the Paulist College at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, has already tired of his acquaintance with Catholicism and signified his desire to return to the Episcopal fold.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 24. -- Considerable interest is being manifested in this city over the approaching investigation of the International and Great Northern receivership. The recent Legislature of Texas appointed Messrs. Marwood, Brietz, and Gresham to conduct this investigation, and specified that it should be held at Galveston on Monday, June 25.

According to reports that reach this city from San Francisco there will soon take place in a little tailor's shop on Sixth Avenue a reunion between a father and son who have been separated for over sixteen years. Some time ago Paul F. Paulme, a ladies' tailor, eloped from Marseilles to this country with a charming woman, Josephine Fouchard.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 24. -- The New Era Monument Association, organized here about four weeks ago, has got into working order. In 1854 the ship New Era, with 400 German immigrants on board, struck in a storm on Deal Beach, and 200 persons were drowned or perished from exposure. The victims were all buried in West Long Branch cemetery, with no stone to mark their graves.
RONDOUT, N.Y., May 24. -- The Hotel Kaaterskill, in the Catskills, will open for the season on June 27. This year the hotel will be under the management of P. O'Connor of New-York City.

In the volume under notice each State in Europe is taken up separately. Some short historic data are given as to origins, and then a brief sketch presented of their conditions to-day. We have, then, a bird's-eye glance, as it were, of Austria, Hungary, Germany, Russia, Poland, Italy, Spain, Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Iceland, Belgium, Switzerland, the Ottoman Empire, Egypt Servia, and Montenegro.

The recent advance of prices made by the combination of window-glass manufacturers and the reports of the Treasury Department concerning imports, are discussed in an interesting way by some of the trade journals. The imports for March were large. The official statement is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- The decision of the Legislature on Monday night to adjourn finally on the 28th inst. and the votes in the Senate adverse to the Taggart Revenue bill bring the political situation in Pennsylvania to a form in which some judgment may be passed upon it. The work of the Legislature is now practically concluded.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- The fugitive ex-President of the Keystone Bank is still at large, and is not confined in a Virginia jail, as telegrams from Norfolk announced last night.

The facts cited in our Washington dispatches this morning as to the practices in the Pension Office are very disgraceful. If the veterans who are entitled to pensions under the law are to be "steered" by officers of the Pension Bureau to the attorneys who charge money for doing what the bureau should do, it amounts simply to cruel and shameful robbery of the veterans by the officers of the Government.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 24. -- Baron Rudolf Kalnoky de Korospatak, a nephew of Count Kalnoky of Vienna, made his first visit to Chicago about a month ago, registering at the Richelieu merely as "Rudolph Kalnoky" of New-York. He was handsome and distinguished, appeared to be the possessor of unlimited means, and, while evidently suffering from habitual melancholy, soon became a favorite with the few to whom he gave his friendship.

TRENTON, May 24. -- Allan L. McDermott, the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, in an interview published a day or two ago, confirmed the predictions made in these dispatches two weeks ago as to the attitude of Gov. Abbett's political household to the approaching Presidential campaign.

The Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church attacked the narrowness of the Presbyterian Church in general and the persecutors of Prof. Briggs in particular, as they never were attacked before. He likewise paid his compliments to Princeton College. He likened the men who are attacking Prof. Briggs to early-day inquisitors who roasted heretics over slow fires and tickled their flesh with red-hot pincers.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- It is the theory of the pension laws that those who are entitled to receive pensions from the Government shall be able to get them through the Pension Office without being required to pay for the services of an attorney.

LONDON, May 24. -- Discount was easy during the past week at 4 for three months and 3 for short. The influx of gold into the Bank of England during the week amounted to 1,470,000 in value. Another million is coming from Australia and two millions from America. Although the New-York shipments of gold are thought to be nearly ended, the Bank of England yesterday made further purchases of gold eagles at a premium.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Vice President Morton is having hard luck with his Shoreham Hotel, the floors of which were fortunately discovered to be unsafe, by an accident, before a more serious occurrence provoked the indignation of the public. The building was erected by New-York builders at great cost, and with no restrictions, it is understood, to prevent the production of one of the most perfect buildings in this city.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- For some days past a rumor has been current here to the effect that certain employes in the Pension Office occupying responsible positions had bean in the habit of borrowing money from their fellow-clerks and, upon payment being demanded, they not only declined to pay the money but threatened the importunate creditors with dismissal or a reduction in salary.

The long and patiently awaited report of a rapid-transit route by the Rapid-Transit Commission is promised to-day. There will be a meeting of the commission at 2 o'clock at its office in William Street, at which a few unsettled points in the question of a main route will be determined and the line, seventeen miles in length, from the Battery to the northern city limits, will be tentatively adopted.

LONDON, May 25. -- Further details concerning the fight which took place on May 12 near Massa-Kesse between the British and Portuguese have been received here from Lorenzo Marguez. It appears that the Portuguese were marching upon Fort Salisbury, and when they were within twenty yards of that place the British South Africa Company's police fired on them, killing seven and wounding twenty of the Portuguese force.

The crippled Veendam of the Netherlands-American Line steamed slowly up the bay yesterday, and, with the assistance of two of the company's tugboats, made fast to her pier in Hoboken. When the lines were made fast there was probably not one among the vessel's 620 passengers who did not feel grateful that the eventful voyage was ended.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- When the Supreme Court at its last term upheld the constitutionality of the Edmunds law, by which the property of the late corporation of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, otherwise known as the Mormon Church, was escheated to the United States, it found itself in a somewhat embarrassing position.

A genuine old-fashioned game of bunko, something that is getting very rare in these enlightened days, was brought to the attention or the police yesterday. William J. Ramsey was the victim. Mr. Ramsey is a farmer, wealthy and happy in the enjoyment of an innocence that inspires within him a confidence in all mankind.

It is not surprising that the McKinley newspapers as a rule have nothing to say about the tricks and jobs put into the wool schedule by the three political shepherds, and the effect of those tricks and jobs upon manufacturers who use wool of the third class. But if the McKinley press is silent, the manufacturers do not conceal their opinions, as the trade papers show.
The Chilean Minister at Washington received yesterday a copy of President Balmaceda's address to the Chilean Congress which assembled in Santiago April 20, 1891.

PARIS, May 6. -- The first glimpse of the Salon is a pleasant one and a vast improvement upon the old routine. An evident care for decoration has led to a new and more logical hanging of pictures; the lights is softer and more harmonious, and the atmosphere is certainly less oppressive. The first large room, once called the Salon Carre, seems to be particularly bright and pleasant.

BOSTON, May 25. -- Potter, White Bayley, boot and shoe manufacturers, 130 Summer Street, this city, with factories at Cochituate, Mass., and Farmingham, N.H., have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to George S. Bullens of the Revere National Bank, William Henry Allen of Allen, Field Lawrence, and Edward H. Dunn.
PANAMA, May 17. -- The following is a translation of the agreement adopted and signed on New Year's Day by a majority of the members of the two houses of the Chilean Congress:

A runaway accident by which two fashionable turnouts were smashed up, four persons, two of them ladies, badly shaken and seriously frightened, and the most crowded part of Fifth Avenue suddenly made a scene of wild excitement, occurred at about 6 o'clock last evening. The smash-up took place at Thirty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, immediately in front of the New-York Club and in full view of the Manhattan Club.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- Eight hundred and sixty-seven people saw a splendid game at the League Park this afternoon. The fielding on both sides was excellent, and several particularly good plays were made. Both pitchers did well, and nearly every man who went to bat hit the ball. The weather was damp and cloudy. Score:

ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- To-day's meeting of the Evangelical Alliance bordered closely on the sensational owing to a paper read by the Rev. G.H. Grannis on the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby, the noted Presbyterian divine, who for years had charge of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New-York City, into which he worked considerable local matter.

CLEVELAND, May 25. -- John Ward and his men made a very favorable impression here to-day. After losing game after game in Chicago, Cincinnati, and Pittsburg, they made a spurt here and won with hands down. It was a well-played game on the part of both clubs, but the Brooklyns won by their superior batting.

One of the suits by which the aqueduct contractors O'Brien Clark would like to grab about $8,000,000 from the city for alleged extra work done on the new aqueduct was called for trial yesterday before Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court. This particular suit is for work on Section 6, which extends from Gould's Swamp to a point opposite Irvington.

ALBANY, May 25. -- When Gen. McMahon calls the roll of the canal investigating committee on Tuesday, June 2, the gentlemen who respond will discover that their work has been cut out beforehand and with an eye single to the manufacture of political goods for use by the Hill machine in the coming campaign. Ancient history will form one of the chief subjects of study by this amusing combination.

The Baron de Gondoriz of Brazil arrived in New-York last Saturday on the steamer Finance. He is at the Victoria Hotel. He received yesterday a cable dispatch from Para which told him that he had been appointed Financial Commissioner of Brazil to the United States and Europe.

It has been customary on the Cotton Exchange to honor officers of the institution with a re-election, so that each holds an offices for at least two years, but the chances are extremely good this year that in one case there will be no re-election. President Ide will have things all his own way and will be re-elected without any opposition.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 25. -- It is reported here that the Russian Government is preparing for a wholesale series of domiciliary police visits throughout this city and its suburbs, and that all Hebrews discovered will be imprisoned and conveyed later on to the Hebrew pale. It is added that the programme for this movement will be ready in about two weeks' time.

A lady, a communicant of St. John's Church, has recently deeded to the American Security and Trust Company of Washington, D.C., a valuable tract of land in this city in trust, the income from said property to be devoted to the support of a cathedral foundation hereafter to be created by the Episcopal Church in the District of Columbia.

Without any wish to be disrespectful to the Honorable the Secretary of the Treasury, we feel forced to say that his new statement of assets and liabilities suggests the device of a merchant embarrassed by debt but not by scruples. Doubtless Mr. FOSTER, in the course of his business career, has had occasion to study statements made by men in such a situation.

ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- Kirkwood, the aristocratic suburb twelve miles from St. Louis, was invaded by an army of negroes this morning, the occasion being a big picnic on the magnificent grounds of the Cairns Seminary property, which has been purchased by a syndicate of rich negroes, for the ostensible purpose of establishing a manual training school for colored boys.
" I believe that I can take all of the railroads in this country, knock 2 per cent. off the existing rates, as they appear on the surface, and pay 5 per cent. dividends on all the stocks."

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 25. -- The eighty-seventh ballot in the joint Democratic caucus to-night gave Call 52, Mays 42, Bloxham 2. The eighty-eighth ballot was ordered and resulted exactly like the previous one. At this point Senator Yancey of Lake County, one of the leaders of the Call forces, moved to adjourn the joint caucus sine die.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- Counsel for the Star Rubber Company remained up Sunday night until after midnight, and then, by a special arrangement, had the County Clerk's office opened to record mortgages aggregating nearly $500,000 against the property of the concern.

Major John W. Powell, Director of the National Geological Survey, was at the Gilsey House yesterday. He was on his way to Montreal as a delegate from the American Geological Society to the meeting of the Royal Society, which will be held this week. Major Powell said that he regarded the outcome of the fight in the last Congress on the irrigation question with satisfaction.

CORNWALL, N.Y., May 25. -- Yesterday morning Mrs. Divine, a widow, went to church, leaving her two little girls, Nora and Janny, aged, respectively, six and four years, alone in the house. Half an hour later Mrs. Benton, the wife of a neighboring farmer, saw the children sitting on the grass under an apple tree, striking every few moments at something on the ground.

The death is announced in Paris of Theodore Deck, the great ceramist of France. He died at Sevres, in the little pavilion -- with rooms of gold, satin, and velvet, filled with vases painted in manganese violet and eel yellow colors, lacquers, netsukes, and swords of Japan -- so hospitable to American visitors at the Manufacture Nationals de Porcelaine, of which he was for fourteen years the administrator.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- The city is talking of nothing but City Treasurer John Bardsley and his crimes. In the excitement caused by the arrest, and the discovery of his misappropriation of city and State funds, Marsh, the fugitive Keystone National Bank President, who looted the Keystone Bank and is now believed to have had a hand in helping Bardsley to rob the city and State, is almost forgotten.

DETROIT, May 25. -- Devotional exercises were conducted this morning by the Rev. Franklin E. Miller of the Jersey City Presbytery. The first matter to come up was that of the proposed new seal of the General Assembly. The vast majority of the ministers of the Church never saw an impression made by the old seal, but now they are very much interested in the new one.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 25. -- Ira B. Jones, Speaker of the House of Representatives and member of the Board of Trustees of the State University, has issued a statement on behalf of the Trustees in regard to the recent removal of Dr. Alexander from the Faculty. He alleges that Alexander was not removed because he was a Unitarian, but was simply not re-elected to his chair on the reorganization of the university.

Final argument was had yesterday before Judge Wallace in the United States Circuit Court in the equity suit of Art Dealers M. Knoedler Co., against Boussod, Valadon Co. In 1857 Goupil Co. sold out their New-York house to Knoedler Co. More recently they sold their Paris house to Boussod, Valadon Co.

A play called "The Veiled Picture," written by Mr. Albert Roland Haven, was produced by Mr. Robert Mantell at the Lyceum Theatre last night. Its subject is remorse. An American art student in Rome stabs and kills a companion while in the delirium of fever. His friends hush the matter up, and the victim's death is attributed to suicide.

If Tammany does not gobble up the Voorhis Democracy as one result of the Mayor's long-delayed announcement of his appointments, it will be because the plans that Richard Croker has been maturing ever since his return home amount to nothing. Croker and Police Commissioner Voorhis are said by the politicians to understand each other perfectly."

There is something of the spirit of our own Declaration of Independence in the proclamation of the Chilean insurgents signed on New Year's Day and now published. The document has a certain ring of sincerity. Probably the leaders of the Congressional party believe President BALMACEDA to be fully as black as they have painted him, but it is equally probable that their zeal has led them into some exaggerations.

The Park Commissioners will hear citizens interested in the movement to restore Battery Park to its uses as a pleasure ground at 1 o'clock to-morrow, instead of 11 o'clock, the hour originally set. There is some routine matter of which the Commissioners wish to dispose before taking up this special subject. That explains the postponement of the hour.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 25. -- The people of this State were shocked to-day by the announcement of the death of Leonidas Campbell Houk, Representative in Congress of the Second District of Tennessee and one of the most prominent Republican leaders in the South. Mr. Houk's death was very sudden and unexpected. It was due to an accident.

PITTSBURG, May 25. -- When the Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church of North America meets in Pittsburg on Wednesday next a committee of Pittsburg Presbytery will recommend that the first day be devoted entirely to fasting and prayer. This unusual proceeding will be taken in view of the grave crisis which confronts the denomination.

Capt. Converse, the commanding officer of the United States ship Enterprise, just returned from a cruise of seven months in the West Indies, has gone to Washington to make a formal report to the State and Navy Departments on the project of transferring to the World's Columbus Exposition at Chicago a portion of the first permanent European settlement made by Christopher Columbus in 1493 on the Western Hemisphere, at Port Isabella, San Domingo.

ALBANY, May 26. -- The formal announcement that Senator George B. Sloan of Oswego had retired from politics created no comment here, where the Senator's determination has been known for several months.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- Capt. Adrian Constantine Anson is as mad as a March hare to-night. In to-day's game he held the lead over the New-Yorks for seven innings, and just when it seemed positive that victory was going to crown his efforts the Giants made one of their characteristic spurts, and that is the cause of the big Captain's discomfiture. They scored five times, just enough to win.

The long Senatorial contest in the Florida Legislature came to an end yesterday by the re-election of Senator CALL by a vote of 51 to 3, the greater part of the opposition absenting itself from the joint session. The contest has been prolonged for weeks solely by the Democratic caucus practice in Florida of requiring a two-thirds vote to nominate a candidate.

Meetings of importance to the railroads in the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations will be held in this city to-day and to-morrow. From all appearances the freight-traffic managers will be confronted with some knotty problems. There are abundant evidences of rate-cutting from various quarters.

The proceedings in the trial of O'Brien Clark's suit against the city to recover $732,312 for extra work on Section 6 of the new aqueduct, dragged along yesterday before Judge Ingraham and the Jury, half struck and half ordinary, in the Supreme Court, in a way to give promise that the trial will last at least three weeks. The whole day was taken up with the opening of the counsel for the contractors.

ST. LOUIS, May 26. -- A letter has been received here from Cape Town. South Africa, giving an account of the capture and torture by Zulus of Jeff Allen of Decatur, Ill., and W.A. Kennan, whose home is supposed to be either in St. Joseph, Mo., or Silver City, New-Mexico. The letter is dated March 31 and it is signed "Frank Short."

It cannot too often be called to the attention of the American people that every attempt by responsible officials to treat the $100,000,000 gold now held in the Treasury as a reserve for the redemption of the legal-tender notes as if it could be used for any other purpose, is an act of bad faith, full of danger to the most important interests of the country, and calling for instant and severe condemnation.

CLEVELAND, May 26. -- The bases on balls given by Hemming were costly. They were followed by hits on which Cleveland won the game. Young was too much for the Brooklyns when men were on bases. O'Brien's fine batting was the marked feature of the game. Attendance, 1,200. Score:

BOSTON, May 26. -- The Republicans are going in either to gerrymander the State or postpone the redistricting to another year. That is the outcome of the conference to-day of the House Republicans to hear the report of its committee to confer with the Republicans of the Redistricting Committee.

The Tammany forces in the Fourteenth Assembly District have been controlled by the Reilly family for about a quarter of a century. First, there was ex-Sheriff Bernard Reilly, and then came his brother, ex-Register John Reilly, and when the latter, two years ago, grew tired of being leader, he gave the place to the ex-Sheriff's son, Bernard Reilly, Jr.

Several hundred persons, clergy and laity of the Protestant Episcopal Church, journeyed by special train to Inwood-on-Hudson yesterday to take part in the services attending the blessing of the House of Mercy, St. Agnes's House, and St. Saviour's Sanitarium, and the consecration of St. Saviour's Chapel by Bishop Henry C. Potter. Following the ceremonies the visitors inspected the institution, which is one of the most completely appointed of its kind in the country.

PARIS, May 26. -- The strike of stage drivers throughout Paris, which was begun yesterday, continues to-day and is causing great excitement in this city. Crowds of people, the majority of whom are in warm sympathy with the strikers, surround the stations of the omnibus company. During the night and this morning the company's stations and offices were guarded by strong forces of police and detachments of troops.

A Chilean refugee, recently escaped from the scene of civil warfare in the South American republic, called at THE TIMES office yesterday and desired a protest entered against the consideration shown by the Administration at Washington for the Government of Balmaceda. He gave a dramatic and interesting narrative of the condition of affairs in Chile.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 26. -- The last concert this evening was the crowning feature of Berkshire's first annual festival. It brought together the finest musical talent in this country on this occasion. Miss Clementine De Vere sang exquisitely in the first number of the programme, which was Rossini's Stabat Mater, rendered by the festival orchestra, the full choir, and the soloists.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Treasury circular in regard to the 4 1/2 per cent. loan will probably not be issued before next Monday. In it the department will give notice of its readiness to redeem, Sept. 1, the $50,000,000 4 1/2 per cent. bonds outstanding in all cases where the holders are not willing to extend them at an interest rate of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Cabinet meeting was, according to report, given up to-day to consideration of the fur-seal question, but, from all that can be learned, nothing was done to counteract the carefully-matured plans of Elkins, Mills, and Blaine made during the absence of the President in the West.

DETROIT, May 26. -- The evening papers last night and the morning papers from New-York contained abstracts from Sunday's sermon by Dr. Parkhurst in New-York. The impression which the discourse has produced is of the most painful character.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Collector of Customs Erhardt dropped into Washington early this morning, having come over from New-York on the night train. When he sat down to breakfast in the Arlington Hotel he saw, sitting at a near-by table, Senator Frank Hiscock and ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt. The Collector shook hands with the two eminent statesmen after breakfast, and then met Secretary Foster, and went with him over to the Treasury Department.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 26. -- Harvard and Yale will not meet on the diamond this year. That fact was definitely decided at a conference of graduates of the two colleges held at the Massasoit House this afternoon. To Harvard should be given the credit for having attempted to settle the vexed question, for it was at the request of her numerous graduate advisory boards that to-day's meeting was held.
In the Atlantic for June is printed an extended article on Abraham Lincoln by Carl Schurz, from which a few passages printed herewith are taken:

BOSTON, May 26. -- Half a dozen or more actors now playing in "The Wolves of New-York" Company at the Boston Theatre appeared in the Municipal Court this morning. They were charged with assaults upon each other, last Wednesday night, on the stage after the performance.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- The City Commissioners met this morning, and, ignoring the appointment by Gov. Pattison of a successor to City Treasurer Bardsley, proceeded to elect Richard C. Oellers, business manager of the Record, to fill the office. Messrs. Bartley and Stulb, the Republican members of the commission, voted for Mr. Oellers, and Mr. Sensenderfer, the Democratic member, cast his ballot for Mr. Wright, the Governor's appointee.

It was with tender consideration that Dr. W. Seward Webb's project to build a railroad through the Adirondack region was discussed at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Adirondack Park Association in a parlor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

The statement of Senor BATRES, the recently appointed Guatemalan Minister to Washington, that he should endeavor to strengthen the relations between the United States and his own country by the negotiation of a treaty of reciprocity, will probably be hailed as an indication of another triumph for the reciprocity provisions of the McKinley bill.

Owners of trotting horses throughout the country will be interested in learning that Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court yesterday issued an injunction restraining John H. Wallace, individually and as President of the Wallace Trotting Register Company, from transferring the property of that company to the American Trotting Register Company of Illinois.

A suit brought by Harry Allen, a grandson of Commodore Vanderbilt, against Maria Louisa Vand rbilt as executrix and Cornelius Vanderbilt, William K. Vanderbilt, Frederick W. Vanderbilt, and George W. Vanderbilt as executors under the will of William H. Vanderbilt, and other members of the Vanderbilt family, to get possession of about $500,000, was brought to trial yesterday in the Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge Patterson.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 26. -- A notable wedding was celebrated in the First Reformed Church here this evening at 8 o'clock in the presence of a large company. The contracting parties were Miss Alice Tanner, a daughter of Major Alfred Tanner and a niece of Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeals, and Dr. Spencer Lyman Dawes of Saugerties. The marriage ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. J.G. Van Slyke.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Late this afternoon Attorney C.C. Shaw entered the Corporation Clerk's room in the Secretary of State's office with a sort of mysterious air. In one pocket he had a bulky document, with a yellow cover, on which was written, "Amended articles of association of the New-York Cable Railway Company, pursuant to Chapter 563, Laws of 1890."

Do the people of this State appreciate the dangers that threaten the Adirondack forest? Are they aware that Dr. SEWARD WEBB has in some way secured for his proposed Herkimer and St. Lawrence Railroad a political and financial support strong enough to control in its interest the Legislature, the Forestry Commission, the Commissioners of the Land Office, the Governor, the Attorney General, and all the official and organized defenders of the great forest?

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 26. -- The recent fear of the United States revenue cutter Morrill in forcing an inland passage between the North Edisto and Ashley Rivers of South Carolina has caused several Southern steamers now going North to engage in the passenger trade for the Summer to attempt the same passage.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 26. -- A large number of delegates to the Farmers' Union Convention have arrived in the city to take part in the convention to-morrow. Nearly all of the farmers' unions and grange societies in the State will be represented, and the indications now point to a large gathering of delegates from both the open and secret Alliances.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26. -- The two bodies of the Legislature met in separate session to-day for organization. In the Senate the members were duly sworn in by Secretary of State McGuinness, and Eugene F. Warner, Republican, of Coventry, was elected Clerk without opposition. The House was called to order by William P. Clark, First Representative from Newport, and the members were sworn in by Secretary of State McGuinness.

It looks very much as if the result of the delay in bringing the Bering Sea negotiations to a head would be an open season for the slaughter of seals by ELKINS and MILLS'S North American Company on the islands and by the Canadian poachers on the high seas, even though the result in the extermination of the valuable fur-bearing animals.
