The presence of the Spanish schoolship. Nautilus in the North River recalls a curious custom in vogue on war vessels of that nationality. It originated in superstition and has long been the subject of many jeers from English-speaking mariners.

It is not by any means creditable to the Park Board that there ehould be any doubt whatever about the result of the hear'ng to be had to-day upon the occupation of Battery Park by the elevated railroad. The permit nnder which the occupation has been made was granted unlawfully, since the parks rcre excepted from the places that might be taken for the use of the' roads.

The Mills, Robeson Smith failure played a part in a suit which came up in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on a motion to extend the time for the filing of an answer. The plaintiff is Henry H. Isham, as trustee of the estate of the late John G. Trumbull of Elizabeth, N.J., and the defendant is Mary E. Post, widow of the late Augustus T. Post and administratrix of his estate.

Incandescent lamps will occupy the attention of Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, for over a week to come, and the subject of the various patents in regard to these lamps, as well as the known methods of electric lighting, will be exhaustively inquired into. The suit is that of the Edison Electric Light Company against the United States Electric Lighting Company for alleged infringement of patents upon the incandescent electric lamps.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Attorney General Tabor appears to be wobbling a trifle in his opinion of the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad matter. Since the railroad company applied to the Land Board for permission to acquire a strip of land 100 feet wide through a portion of the forest preserve, Mr. Tabor has unnecessarily told the newspaper correspondents that he believed the Commissioners of the Land Office had no jurisdiction in the matter.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 26. -- This morning's session of the Legislature was rather a dull one in the House. Few of the anti-Call men were in the chamber when the session was called to order.

BANGOR, Me., May 26. -- The train over the Maine Central Road, known as the St. John night express, which leaves this city each evening, consists of a sealed car loaded with through baggage for provincial points, this being next the engine, one postal car, baggage car, express car, Pullman sleeper, and three coaches being placed in the train in the order named.

The Cleveland Leader finds time to comment on other matter which it finds in the columns of THE TIMES, but has not yet found time to answer the question we asked more than a month ago about the effect of the Sherman Anti-Trust law upon Trust combinations. The Leader asserted that this law had "struck an effective blow" at certain Trusts which it enumerated.

WASHINGTON, May 26. --The Board of Naval Officers appointed to give effect to Secretary Tracy's recent order respecting the appointment of all foremen and master mechanics in the New-York Navy Yard upon competitive examination has completed its duties and made its report to the Secretary. The applicants for all positions numbered ninety-three, and fifty-nine appeared for examination.

LANSING, Mich., May 26. -- Gov. Winans has had the heaviest possible pressure brought to bear upon him not to veto the bill appropriating $30,000 to lodge the national Grand Army veterans at Detroit next August. The friends of the bill quite believed that he would relent, but, in spite of their hopes, this morning the Governor sent his veto to the House.

It is not unlikely that Paul Cannalle will sincerely regret that his cousin Gennaro Bucarello, a detained Italian immigrant, walked out of Supreme Court, Chambers, where he had been brought on a writ of habeas corpus. Thomas P. Wickes, who was appointed referee to determine who was to blame for Bucarello's flight, has reported that Cannalle was at the bottom of it. Cannalle may be punished for contempt of court.

An auction sale was held on the Real Estate Exchange yesterday, which was remarkable for the size of the attendance, the activity of the bidding, and the high prices realized. For six hours and three-quarters Peter F. Meyer of Adrian H. Muller Son sold lots, and when he had finished close upon $1,500,000 had been secured for the 411 lots offered for sale by the Morgenthau syndicate.
PARIS, May 27. -- Baron Hirsch, in an interview to-day in regard to his plans for the amelioration of the condition of the Hebrews in Russia, said:

NEW-HAVEN, May 27. -- A goodly number of the creditors of the wrecked banking house of Bunnell Scranton appeared personally or were represented by attorneys at the hearing on the appointment of trustees in the Probate Court this morning. E.G. Stoddard, President of the New-Haven County Bank, was appointed trustee of Mr. Scranton's individual estate with a bond of $10,000, and of the firm's estate at a bond of $150,000.

ALBANY, May 27. -- To-morrow, pursuant to law, Secretary of State Rice, Controller Wemple, and Attorney General Tabor will open the proposals for doing the public printing for two years from Oct. 1, 1891. Within the past week there have been received by the Secretary of State a number of copies of a printed form of resolution in these words:

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- The Passaic River Rowing Association regatta Decoration Day promises to be the most extensive affair of the kind that ever came off on the Passaic River. Following are the entries for the regatta:

PONTIAC, Mich., May 27. -- Last June Miss Jennie Webb, a school teacher, whipped Frank Cook, one of her pupils, with a strap. The boy went home, his legs and body marked with great welts caused by the strap. He was shortly after taken with paralysis and died. The doctors said the whipping caused his death. The Coroner's jury found that Miss Webb was to blame, and the police magistrate held her for trial.

The Union Club at its annual meeting last night decided to move further up town, and that by a large majority of votes, representing the biggest meeting in numbers present that the club has ever held. The moving question was settled on quickly, and very little time was spent in discussing it. The matter had been fully canvassed in the last two weeks, and those present had all made up their minds.

OTTAWA, May 27. -- In the Senate to-day the bill extending the modus vivendi for another year to American fishermen was passed, but not without protest from the Opposition. Senator Scott took occasion to rebuke the Canadian Government for its interference between New-foundland and the United States, thus preventing the proposed treaty between the two countries from being ratified by the Imperial Government.

The Adirondack Park Association should at once apply to the courts for permission to change its name. Something like "The Adirondack Railroad Construction and Wood-Pulp Production Concern" would befit its present disposition and designs. "An open foe is better than a false friend," writes Dr. MARTIN BURKE in his letter resigning his membership in the association, which we print in another column.

Col. S.D. Bruce sold at auction in the saddling paddocks at the Gravesend track yesterday fifteen yearlings, the produce of the Ellerslie Stud, and six from the Erdenheim Stock Farm. The latter lot, with one exception, were the first of the get of Dry Monopole, the winner of the first Brooklyn Handicap. "Jack" McDonald secured the prize of the latter lot, getting a half brother to Reclare and Cartoon for $2,000.

The citizens who have been engaged in the movement to restore Battery Park to the people as a pleasure ground were given their first opportunity for an official hearing before the Park Commissioners yesterday. From about 1 o'clock to about 3:30 o'clock arguments for and against the restoration of the Battery were submitted to the Commissioners.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 27. -- One of the most horrible tragedies ever known in Kansas was enacted in this city to-day. Mrs. Luella Updegraff killed her three children -- little girls, aged five, three, and one and a half years -- and herself with fire.

A route for an underground four-truck electric rapid-transit railroad through the west side, running north from the South Ferry, was yesterday adopted by the Board of Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners. It follows the line of Broadway and the Boulevard and Eleventh Avenue to and across Spuyten Duyvil Creek. Thence it will go by a line not yet determined to the city limits.

CINCINNATI, May 27. -- Cincinnati had an easy victory to-day over the Quaker City Club. Two pitchers were stood up before them and knocked out. Gleason did not last even through the first inning. Quite a number of interesting plays were made, and the hitting was hard and general. Score:

The meeting of the State Board of Health at the Everett House yesterday was almost entirely occupied in hearing arguments for and against the proposed sewer system of Far Rockaway, the essential feature of which is the construction of a main discharging into Norton's Creek, which connects the salt-water lagoon in front of Far Rockaway with Jamaica Bay.
There are two kinds -- the NATURAL and the IMITATION.

The Park Commissioners did not finish the hearing yesterday on the Battery Park question, and it will be continued to-morrow. It is a curious state of affairs when the people are obliged to appear before the custodians of the public parks and plead with them to prevent one of the most beautiful parks of the city from being spoiled by a railroad.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- Anson's loud boast that the New-Yorks would be snowed under here were further shattered to-day, when the visitors won again. The "Old Man's" spirits were away down after the game, and he would hardly speak to his acquaintances. To lose two straight to the New-Yorks, when he had given it out with all the positive assertion of which he is capable, is the hardest blow he has had this season.

Postmaster Van Cott has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship City of Peking arrived at that port Tuesday, with mails from China, Japan , of the following dates: Hongkong, April 25; Shanghai, April 27; Yokohama, May 5; Honolulu, May 18--due to arrive in New-York Sunday morning.

George W. Tinsdale, who died Monday at his residence, 45 Carmine Street, was a well-known policeman in the Fifteenth Precinct forty years ago under Capt. George Dilks. Subsequently he was foreman of Hose Company No. 9 of the old Volunteer Fire Department.

The action, of the Executive Committee of the Adirondack Park Association last Tuesday night in practically indorsing Dr. W. Seward Webb's project to build a railroad through the Adirondacks has stirred up a good deal of feeling among the people who are sincere in their desire to preserve that beautiful region.

According to the special correspondent of the Voice of this city, the proceedings of the conference at Cincinnati which started the "People's Party" were not free from the guile that is charged upon the politicians of the old parties. Among the prominent members of the conference there was a difference of opinion as to the launching of a new party.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27. -- A political sensation has been created among the Democrats by the receipt of a confidential circular, signed by the Chairman of the Ross County Democratic Committee, reciting the fact that grave doubts existed in all parts of the State as to the advisability of giving Gov. Campbell a renomination, and further, that to place him again at the head of the State ticket would be political suicide.

Alderman and Mrs. Samuel H. Bailey celebrated their silver wedding last evening at Stuyvesant Hall, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Sixth Street. The hall was elaborately decorated with flowers, among which was piece of roses and carnations representing two hearts, on which the figures 1866-1891 were thrown into bold relief.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 27. -- There was an incident in the life of the Rev. Jacob Mills, (colored,) who was buried Monday afternoon from Centenary Church, which shows the character of the man. At the request of the family it was not related at the church, but it is such a striking example of devotion that it is well worth relating.

CONCORD, N.H., May 27. -- The anniversary exercises at St. Paul's School were begun to-day by the first day's meeting of the Athletic Association. The field officers of the day were: Judges -- The Rev. J.P. Conover, J.M. Lamberton, D.F.C. Elwes, and G.M. Brinley; Referee -- L.C. Dole; Field Marshal -- Alexander Brown; Starter -- W.H. Foster; Timekeepers -- J.H. Coil, Jr., and M.K. Gordon; Measurers -- C. Illingworth and A.P. Meade.

The revenue cutter Rush at San Francisco and the Bear at Seattle have received their orders from the Treasury Department to proceed to Bering Sea on their annual cruise for the protection of the seals. These orders are believed to be substantially the same as those issued last year, and to have in view the usual operations at the seal fisheries.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 27. -- The field day of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association on Hampden Park this afternoon was one of the most successful ever held, both in the matter of record-breaking and attendance. It was Amherst's day from the start, and to-night the championship pennant will return to that college with tremendous rejoicing on the part of nearly 200 Amherst men who came down to cheer on their team to victory.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27. -- The following self-explanatory letter was given out for publication tonight:

It seems that the establishment of weighing machines at the most attractive points in the park was not the act of the Park Board, but the freak of a single Commissioner. The authorization was revoked yesterday, to the great relief of the people who have an intelligent interest in the park and no interest in the profits of the weighing machines.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Boom yesterday. Wednesday May 27:

The unsightly catch-penny weighing machines which President Gallup of the Park Department recently allowed to be placed in Central Park have been ordered out. This action was taken yesterday by the Park Board on Mr. Gallup's own admission that the attitude of the present Park Board did not favor the machines, and hence he had ordered them out. His action was cordially approved by the board.

Mortemer, the imported French-bred stallion, was shot at Mr. Withers's Brookdale farm a few days ago, his ailments, resulting from old age, requiring that he should be put out of the way to save him from suffering. Mortemer was foaled in 1865, and was, therefore, twenty-six years old. He was imported to this country by Pierre Lorillard, who paid $25,000 for him at the time of the Franco-German war.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27. -- The farmers' convention to-day did not assume the large proportions that were anticipated, there being but 200 delegates present. The proceedings, however, were marked with a vim and vigor that could not be misunderstood, and the anticipated call for a State Convention for the nomination of a full State and legislative ticket was decided upon.

ALBANY, May 27. -- A great deal of uncertainty is expressed to-night by the friends of the Adirondacks regarding the outcome of the meeting of the Land Board to-morrow. The Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company will have a strong legal combination at this meeting to argue in behalf of the building of the road across the forest preserve.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 27. -- Walter F. Randall of Oneida, Chief Engineer of the projected new railroad between Syracuse and Oneida Lake, at South Bay, is authority for the statement that the road will be built this season, and in time for shipping next Winter's ice crop from the lake. The new line will be thirteen miles long through a rich farming section, and will be substantially built and equipped.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- James G. Blaine, ex-officio manager of the Columbian Exposition, has another iron in the fire to increase his influence at home and abroad and further his peculiar schemes. A commission of three men is to sail for Europe early in June to work up enthusiasm for the fair among foreign nations.
MONTREAL, May 27. -- A private dispatch, received from authentic sources at Ottawa at 11:15 to-night, says Sir John Macdonald, the Premier, is dying.

Thomas C. Platt got back from Washington yesterday, but brought no news about changes in the Appraiser's Stores with him. At least he brought no information that he would give out. He said that during his visit to Washington the subject of the Appraiser's Stores or the Custom House in this city was not spoken of by him.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Elkins and his sealing company will get the 60,000 sealskins that they want this year, no matter what may be the effect upon the sealing industry by destruction of the rookeries.

According to the manufacturers of Trenton, not only are the piece rates higher by 125 per cent, but the earnings of the workmen and the cost of labor where day wages are paid are higher in like proportions, too. Of course, the same relations must be shown to exist in all of them to make the argument valid -- the protection of labor demanding higher duties.

James W. Morrissey's company, which is presenting "Il Trovatore" at the Grand Opera House this week, is enjoying a delightful season of applause and enthusiasm. The happy residents of the west side are evidently not deeply acquainted with the sufferings of the unhappy troubadour upon whom the Count of Luna wreaked such awful vengeance in the days when people used to sing instead of talk.

There is something almost pathetic in the sound of the voice of ex-Senator INGALLS calling aloud that "the Republicanism of the future must readjust itself to the changed conditions of American life, or it will perish." The Senator, though sometimes careless about his facts, rarely falls into such a rhetorical muddle as this.

DETROIT, May 27. -- In the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day Dr. Patton, the Moderator, made his report on theological seminaries. He explained that the report was made prematurely, because it bore on the case of Dr. Briggs, and it was thought advisable to have it printed and distributed to the assembly before it comes up for action to-morrow.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 27. -- Green Wells, (colored,) who shot and killed John Fly, a farmer residing near Columbia, Saturday last, was lynched by a mob at Columbia this evening. Wells was arrested yesterday, at Iron City, Lawrence County. Judge E.D. Patterson, fearing that a mob would intercept the train and hang the negro, telegraphed to Sheriff Harlon to stop at Lawrenceburg, which the Sheriff did.

OTTAWA, May 28. -- Sir John Macdonald's health is again exciting the liveliest apprehension. In fact, late last night it was stated that he had been stricken with congestion of the lungs, and that his death was hourly expected. Dispatches were received to-day from all parts of the United States and England, all evincing the greatest interest in the matter, and asking for full particulars.

The Park Commissioners will resume their hearing this afternoon on the petition of citizens for the removal of the elevated railway from Battery Park. Everybody understands that this movement is inspired solely from considerations of public spirit. The citizens who are loading it cannot by any possibility secure personal profit or any other benefit except such as may be shared by the community from the success of this movement.

CLEVELAND, May 28. -- Luck was with Cleveland to-day. But two hits were made by the Forest City team, but they sent in 4 runs in the second inning, after Collins's errors. Brooklyn could not bat Young's speed. It drizzled continuously through the game, but the contest was one of brilliancy. Score:

LONDON, May 28. -- In response to a letter from Mr. Montagu, member of Parliament, asking him to join in claiming for Russian Jews the rights accorded to Mohammedan subjects of the Czar, Mr. Gladstone writes:

The protracted fight over one of the wills of the late Mrs. Myra Clarke Gaines, a holographic will, came to an end yesterday, when Surrogate Abbott of Brooklyn handed down a decision pronouncing that will a forgery. This contest has been going on since 1886, and was transferred to Brooklyn because Mrs. Gaines had real estate in that city.

Gov. W.R. Merriam of Minnesota is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, accompanied by Mrs. Merriam. The Governor says that there will probably be good crops in Minnesota this year, and that under the stimulating influence of this prospect business is picking up. This is true, he says, not only in Minnesota, but throughout the Norwest.
DETROIT, May 28. -- The afternoon session of the General Assembly to-day was interrupted and brought to a close by the sudden death of Judge S.M. Breckinridge of St. Louis.

PITTSBURG, May 28. -- The proprietors of twenty-three big iron furnaces in the Shenango and Mahoning Valleys to-day decided to put their stacks in blast on June 1. They were blown out in January and have been idle ever since. The shut-down has been the longest on record. It was brought about by the high prices charged for coke and the heavy rates required by the railroads for bringing in fuel and raw material.

All the farmers do not look to 2 per cent. loans from the "Government" as a remedy for any ills to which they may be exposed. Mr. GEORGE I. POWELL of Columbia County, in this State, is President of the National Farmers' League, a farmer himself by practice, and the descendant of a family of farmers who have not found it necessary to go to Washington to secure the means of making a living.

The attention of Chairman J.F. Goddard of the Trunk Line Association was called yesterday to the alleged fact that the Canadian Pacific Railroad is again offering New-York shippers a cut rate to St. Paul of $1.07 for first-class freight. Mr. Goddard was also informed that the West Shore Road was believed to be interested with the Canadian Pacific in this move.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 28. -- Prof. Henry Daniel Wild of Olivet College, Michigan, has been elected Assistant Professor of Latin at Williams College, to do the teaching done by Prof. Morris. Frederick C. Ferry, valedictorian of the graduating class, is to assist the classical professors next year.

Anastasia Flanagan, twenty-four years old, died yesterday at her home on the Spuyten Duyvil Road from the effects of a dose of chloride of zinc which she had taken two days before with suicidal intent while laboring under religious mania. The girl lived with her father, Thomas Flanagan, who works in Johnson's foundry in Spuyten Duyvil, and her brother, who is a plumber.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Dr. A.M. Soteldo, long the Venezuelan Minister here, informs the Associated Press that dispatches received to-day from most reliable sources in Mexico state that the Mexican Government ordered the insurgent Chilean cruiser Esmeralda to leave the harbor of Acapulco. The commander of the vessel said he was willing to leave, but his ship had no sails and could not depart without steam power.

As usual on Friday, the card for the day's racing at the Brooklyn track is a light one, with the Fort Hamilton Handicap for three-year-olds at a mile and an eighth the feature. The entries and weights are as follows:

A meeting to decide upon the best method of conducting examinations for the Chanler art students' prize was held yesterday afternoon in the studio of President T.W. Wood of the National Academy of Design. Besides President Wood, there were present J. Armstrong Chanler, William M. Chase, President of the Society of American Artists; J.G. Brown, President of the American Water Color Society, and Joe Evans, President of the Art Students' League.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 28. -- The action of the Farmers' Union Convention at Columbus, Ohio, virtually repudiating the work of the Cincinnati convention, is a great surprise to the Alliance people in Kansas. The same branch of the Farmers' Alliance and Industrial Union, which made the third party in the State, has killed it in Ohio.

" The Tools of Modern Warfare" was the subject of a lecture delivered last night before the Electric Club by Hiram Maxim, the inventor of the Maxim gun. Mr. Maxim first briefly described the old brown and black gunpowders, and then followed with a description of the smokeless powders just coming into general use. Samples of each powder were fired.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- There does not appear to be any occasion for Stephen B. Elkins, D.O. Mills, and Mr. Blaine's other friends in the North American Commercial Company to worry very much over the announcement that the British Parliament is to be asked next week to authorize the Government to prohibit the killing of seals by British subjects in Bering Sea for a definite period.

When the counting of ballots for members of the Governing Committee of the Union Club had been finished yesterday morning, it was found that the regular ticket as announced in yesterday's TIMES had been elected with two exceptions. Henry W.T. Mali and Daniel M. Walbridge failed to receive a majority of votes, so that no election resulted in those two cases.

BALTIMORE, May 28. -- President Hood of the Western Maryland Railroad says that the transfer of the control of the Western Maryland Railroad to the West Virginia Central is not at all to the city's interest. The proposition to buy is inspired, it is intimated, by interests which would circumscribe Baltimore and arrest the execution of the Western Maryland's plans for opening new territory to Baltimore trade via the Philadelphia and Reading and other lines.

The application for an injunction made by the high-tension electric lighting companies in their suit against the Consolidated Electrical Telegraph and Subway Company, to prevent the Subway Company from cutting their cables out of the subways and to have the court fix a fair rate of rental to be paid for the use of the subways, was yesterday denied by Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court.

There is something particularly revolting in the indifference shown by the Administration as to the scandals in the Pension Bureau and in the personal career of Mr. RAUM, the Commissioner, and in that of his son. We should suppose that if there were one part of the great work assigned to him as to which Mr. HARRISON would feel an anxious sensitiveness, it would be that of the Pension Bureau.

ALBANY, May 28. -- A smashing blow was administered to the Adirondack vandals to-day by the Commissioners of the Land Office. It was in the form of a decision that the Commissioners have no power of jurisdiction to make the grant of forest lands asked for by the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company. The decision was based on the opinion of Attorney General Tabor.

There is at last a manifestation on the part of steamship people to aid the immigration authorities in the work of excluding undesirable immigrants. The pioneer in this movement is the North German Lloyds. This company has issued an order to its foreign passenger agents, directing that the utmost care be used in the selection of steerage passengers for the United States.

The Harvard nine is in no way discouraged at the prospect of having no games with Yale this season, but is in active training and playing excellent ball. Some good games have been arranged for July, which promise to be of more than usual interest.

The Aldermen recently passed a resolution calling on the Corporation Counsel to ascertain by what right the Metropolitan Cross-town Railroad Company had laid tracks in Greenwich Avenue between Bank and West Eleventh Streets. The company had deliberately taken this block without any right or authority, and upon the advice of the Corporation Counsel Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy sent a gang of men to tear up the tracks yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Though the pneumatic guns of the Vesuvius prove, on further trial, to be incapable of throwing high explosives effectively under the ordinary conditions of sea service, the department will not give up the idea of the use of high explosives. Some officers believe that within the next year or two the problem of firing a high explosive from the powder gun with a high initial velocity will be solved.

TUSKEEGEE, Ala., May 28. -- To-day marks the close of the tenth year of the Tuskeegee Normal and Industrial Institute. Ten years ago its total assets were an act of the Legislature establishing it and making an annual appropriation of $3,000, a rented building, thirty pupils, mostly from Tuskeegee, and one teacher.

The committee of the Twenty-first Assembly District Republicans which is going to examine the workings of the Civil Service Examining Board at the Custom House held another meeting yesterday in the office of Charles A. Hess, at 40 Wall Street. William G. Spencer and William A. Quackenboss, the Appraiser's department clerks, who have grievances against the board, were questioned about the examination held by the board in July, 1890.
The Board of Control have passed favorably upon the following applicants for licenses as trainers and Jockeys and Secretary Vosburgh will issue the necessary documents to them at any time:

Certain manufacturers in New-England who urged Congress a year ago to reduce or remove the duties on some of their raw materials now find that under the McKinley tariff they are much worse off than they were under the law of 1883. A company whose factory is in New-Bedford manufactures a twist drill which it has sold in Europe as well as in this country.

Day after day the report has been given out at Washington that the question of a closed season for sealing in the Bering Sea was still undecided. Efforts have been made to throw the blame for delay upon the British Government, though the proposition originally came from the Marquis of SALISBURY through Sir JULIAN PAUNCEFOTE in ample time for a decision to be made before preparations for the sealing season were begun.

WANATAH, Ind., May 28. -- Mary Ann Grier disappeared from her father's home, two miles south of this place, nearly forty years ago. A few days ago her body was recovered in an abandoned bog iron-ore pit, without one vestige of change from the appearance it had known in life. The last shred of clothing was long ago destroyed, but the same chemicals which removed the garments preserved the flesh.

Two stake races were on the card for decision at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday. The first of these, the May Stakes, for two-year-olds, went to the stable of J.A A.H. Morris, they winning it with the one-eyed Belmont bred colt St. Florian, who thus put the fourth successive race to his credit and added $2,355 to the bank account of the Westchester millionaires.

It is well known that the Civil Service Chronicle of Indianapolis is edited by gentlemen who supported Mr. HARRISON in the campaign of 1888 with great zeal, because they believed that he and his party would be more faithful to the cause of civil service reform than Mr. CLEVELAND and his party.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 28. -- O'Malley himself was before the Criminal Court to-day upon his application for a change of venue. He called a number of the Committee of Safety's leaders to the stand, and they refused to say whether they were at the parish prison on March 14 or as to the verdict as to O'Malley at their secret meetings.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Anson never had a greater scare than he experienced for nearly two hours this afternoon, when it looked as if the New-Yorks would win the third game of the series, thus making it three straight victories from the Chicagos. But in the seventh inning Glasscock and Basset came to Anson's rescue and, by two fumbles, allowed the Chicagos to win the game.

NEW-HAVEN, May 28. -- Depositors in the collapsed bank of Bunnell Scranton have complained to City Attorney Dailey that the bank accepted deposits after the firm knew of its insolvent condition. They ask that Charles W. Scranton be arrested for criminal proceedings. The case is being investigated, but there is hardly any probability that Mr. Scranton will be arrested.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Francis W. Kennedy, President of the suspended Spring Garden National Bank, was arrested this morning on a warrant sworn out by Bank Examiner Drew, charging him with making false entries in the books, false returns to the Controller of the Currency, and the embezzlement of $100,000 and upward of the bank's funds.

ST. LOUIS, May 28. -- Judge Samuel M. Breckinridge, who dropped dead in Detroit to-day, was born in Baltimore, Md., Nov. 3, 1828, and was educated at Princeton College and Center College, Kentucky. He was graduated at the Law School of Transylvania University, at Lexington, Ky., and settled at St. Louis in 1850, where he had since resided.

The scheme for a west side rapid-transit route reported Wednesday by the Rapid-Transit Commission is in so many respects similar to the schemes of private corporations which have talked of building rapid-transit lines that the promoters of several of these corporations were yesterday inclined to claim the credit of having suggested the main features of the route and plan of construction.

The Madison Square Garden Amphitheatre has been transformed into a vista of fairyland for the Summer season of Gilmore promenade concerts, which will begin this evening. The floor of the amphitheatre has been converted into a landscape garden. Avenues of firs and cedars without a straight line and always commanding a view of the band stand extend through the building.
Mayor Grant announced his appointments yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock as follows:

Mrs. Mary Mason Jones, widow of Isaac Jones and eldest daughter of John Mason, died yesterday at her residence, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. Jones, who was in her ninetieth year, was in comparatively good health up to a few weeks ago, and her death was the result of old age more than of any specific disease. She was born Sept. 13, 1801.

At the recent Farmers' Convention in Ohio the wool growers were well represented, and our dispatches of yesterday from Columbus stated that they were "much depressed because of the very low price of wool and the downward tendency of the market." In connection with this report certain statements that are found in this week's trade journals concerning foreign sales of carpet wool should be read. Says the American Wool Reporter:
LEBANON, Penn., May 29. -- At this morning's session of the General Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, Canton, Ohio, was selected as the place of the next meeting.

OTTAWA, May 29. -- Sir John Macdonald is dying. He lies in an unconscious condition and the end is drawing near. The truth can no longer be concealed. Although from the outset efforts have been made to conceal the actual condition of affairs, paralysis has set in. At 9:40 P.M. Dr. Powell issued the following bulletin:

The Brooklyn Jockey Club's Spring meeting will be brought to a close this afternoon, and in order that the holiday crowd that will be at the track may have plenty of sport, the club will have seven races, an extra one having been added to the programme already published. The features will be the Tremont Stakes for two-year-olds at three-quarters of a mile and the Brooklyn Cup at a mile and a half.

ALBANY, May 29. -- Outside of the coterie interested in the construction of the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad and in other enterprises that may be affected, there is general satisfaction expressed over the action of the Land Board in balking, temporarily at least, the scheme of the railroad company to build over State lands. Dr. Webb and his associates must now apply to the Supreme Court for the institution of condemnation proceedings.

Here are some of the propositions which Julien T. Davies, the counsel for the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company, submitted to the Park Commissioners yesterday as reasons why the permit for the elevated structure in Battery Park should not be revoked:

More outdoor sports will take place to-day, weather permitting, than on any day of the year. In amateur athletics, yachting, bicycling, baseball, cricket, lawn tennis, rowing, lacrosse, shooting, and racing there will be an unusually large number of events.

ELIZABETH, May 29. -- "Heavens!" exclaimed the local Superintendent of the New-Jersey Central Road as the Philadelphia and Reading train bound south approached the Union Station in this city at 4:28 this afternoon, "there's going to be a slaughter!" The Union Station is at the junction of the Pennsylvania Railroad and of the Jersey Central, and the tracks of the two roads cross in front of it at right angles.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Navy Department will in a few days readvertise for proposals for the construction of Torpedo Boat No. 2. In order to avoid such a controversy between bidders over the plans as led to the rejection of the first bids, complete plans have been prepared by the department, and it is upon these that bids will be received.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 29. -- A month of legal efforts has passed and the alleged jury bribers in the Hennessy case are as far from the penitentiary as ever. The petit jury in both sections of the Criminal District Court was discharged to-day, and a new jury will be impaneled on Monday. The Hennessy bribery cases will therefore not be tried this month, and the defense fight to prevent such an occurrence has been successful.

The will of Charles Pratt, the Standard Oil magnate, who died suddenly in his office May 4, was filed in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday. It was dated April 16, 1889, and was witnessed by John D. Archbold and John D. Rockefeller. The estate is estimated to be worth about $20,000,000.

DETROIT, May 29. -- The great struggle in the case of Dr. Briggs, Professor of Biblical Theology in Union Theological Seminary, before the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church for disapproval or veto has been decided against him by a vote of 437 to 61.

LONDON, May 29. -- Mr. Bryce asked if the Government, in view of the second reading of the Bering Sea bill being fixed for Monday, would distribute the latest papers with reference to the negotiations with the United States.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 29. -- At an early hour this morning an attempt was made to steal the body of P.T. Barnum from the vault in which it reposes in Mountain Grove Cemetery. Since the funeral two guards have been stationed night and day within a hundred feet of the vault, which is below the surface of the ground.

Mr. JULIEN T. DAVIES, who made the argument before the Park Commissioners yesterday in behalf of the continued or increased occupancy of Battery Park by the elevated roads, does not seem, judging from his argument, to be a very judicious or tactful jurist. That is all the better for the people of the city of New-York and their rights in their own public parks.

The temporary stay in the case of John M.D. Fanshawe, convicted of arson in the Court of General Sessions and sentenced to twelve and one-half years' imprisonment, was vacated yesterday by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court. Judge Lawrence granted the stay last Tuesday, and it was to have been argued Wednesday, but the Assistant District Attorney agreed to a postponement, and Thursday nobody was ready to argue the case.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- John Bardsley, City Treasurer of Philadelphia, was arraigned at noon to-day in the Central Police Court to answer to the triple charges of misappropriating $39,000 of city money, the embezzlement of $400,000 and upward of State funds, and perjury in violating the oath of his office by loaning the city money out at interest.

A bill was introduced in the British House of Commons yesterday to enable the Queen by an order in Council to prohibit the taking of seals in Bering Sea by British vessels during a period to be named in the order. This action is supposed to be based upon some understanding with our Government, but no explanation was made as to the result of negotiations supposed to have been pending.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 29. -- Mayor Noonan has been having something of a hilarious time for nearly a week, and yesterday seemed to be a red letter day in the calendar of his hilarity. He was employed entertaining Mayor Shakespeare of New-Orleans, and late last night added the finishing touch to the day's events by having a row with Chief of Police Lawrence Harrigan in front of the Southern Hotel.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 29. -- The extensive quarries and other real property belonging to John F. Kilgour, the insolvent and fugitive bluestone producer, and lying along the line of the Erie Railroad in Pike County, Penn., were sold at Milford this week by Sheriff Frederick Kessler under legal process in behalf of creditors. The whole was divided into two lots for the purposes of the sale.

The Memorial Day celebration of the Grand Army of the Republic will begin with a parade and review, at the conclusion of which the veterans will repair to the various cemeteries to decorate the graves of the Nation's dead.
LONDON, May 29. -- Richard Somerset Le Poer Trench, fourth Earl of Clancarty, died suddenly to-day.

BERLIN, May 29. -- Miss Ida Green of San Francisco is a claimant to the title and estates of Baroness von Barnekow. Mr. Edwards, the United States Consul General, and a number of lawyers who are interested in the case believe her claim is legal.

At the recent meeting of the National Canned Good Packers' Association Congressman BUNTING of this State, a well-known packer, reminded his associates of the promises and predictions made by the Republican tariff-makers a year ago with respect to tin plate. Mr. BUNTING was a member of the committee which laid before the Ways and Means Committee the association's protest against the proposed increase of the duty.

Gen. Charles H. Freeman, Department Commander Grand Army of the Republic, State of New-York, prints a circular letter as a rejoinder to what he terms "the false and hurtful statements touching the matter of pensions frequently appearing of late in the columns of some leading daily and weekly journals."

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- The Phillies practically won this morning's game from Chicago in the first inning, when they scored 3 runs on Hamilton's base on balls, Anson's fumble of Delehanty's grounder, Thompson's single, Myers's out, and Clements's double. Delahanty made the rankest kind of a muff of Ryan's fly and 2 runs came in. Pfeffer's base on balls and singles by Wilmot and Hutchison gave Chicago its third run in the ninth.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30. -- During the past week the subject of discussion among the students on the campus has been the Yale-Princeton game of last week and the weak points in the Princeton team. Trainer McMaster, the old Brooklyn trainer, asserted last year that his team won the championship by the use of their "bunting" bats, and strongly advocated their Introduction among the collegians.

RICHMOND, Va., May 30. -- The Debt Commission appointed by the Virginia Legislature at its last session will meet here in the Governor's office at noon Monday. Members of the Olcott Committee are expected to reach here from New-York the day following and discuss with the commission their plans for settling a question which has vexed the people of this State for the past twenty years.

Old Polyonomous is taking a hand in the rapid-transit discussion. It is now some moons since as "An Old-Fashioned Democrat," "Jeffersonian Democrat," a "Veteran Observer," he last enlightened the readers of the Sun on the evils of Mugwumpery and the peril of renominating Mr. CLEVELAND.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30. -- The prize debate given by the Cornell Congress took place in Barnes's Hall Monday night. The subject was "Resolved, that it is the sense of this body that the death penalty should be abolished." The speakers were J. Flaherty, A.D. Stillman, and M.V. O'Shea in the affirmative, and O.M. Weeks and E.R. O'Malley in the negative. First prize was awarded to C.M. Weeks and second prize to A.D. Stillman.

Amateur photographers have had a most busy week and have fairly reveled in photographic things. The joint exhibition of the Boston Camera Club and the New-York and Philadelphia Societies of Amateur Photographers in the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-fourth Street, has attracted a large number of photographers, artists, and those who are fond of looking at pictures.

HALIFAX, May 30. -- Joseph Trowsdale of Crapaud, Prince Edward Island, is troubled with a disease which manifests itself in a somewhat peculiar and annoying way. It has the appearance of fever and ague, the fever being the most pronounced. He perspires so freely that he is compolled to change his underclothing ten or twelve times a day.

If there is one most glaring point about the County Court House that shows the entire disregard of the purposes for which the building was to be used which was the leading characteristic of the thieving gang that robbed the city building it, it is the lack of jury accommodations. Courts are supposed to imply juries, and a jury when it retires to decide on its verdict must have some place to retire to.

ALBANY, May 30. -- A genuine sensation has been caused by the announcement that ejectment proceedings may soon be brought by the Forest Commission against the Northern Adirondack and the Chateaugay Railroad Companies, which occupy State lands by reason of illegal grants by the Commissioners of the Land Office.

While we are discussing the evils of the practically unrestricted immigration to our shores of the least desirable elements of foreign populations, and casting about for methods of checking the influx, it is a noticeable fact that the current is increasing. Something seems to be stimulating immigration, especially of the poorer class of European workmen.

ST. LOUIS, May 30. -- Mr. Emerson McMillin has decided to retire from the Presidency of the Laclede Gas Light Company, and with his resignation may come changes in the company, one of which, it is said, has already been determined upon.

Deputy United States Marshals expect that with the organization of the new United States Appellate Court business will increase and they will have more to do. Recently there has been a considerable falling off in the business of the Marshal's office, especially in the matter of serving papers.

If you should ask why the French Academy has preferred Pierre Loti, a man of talent, rather than Emile Zola, a man of genius, it might be answered that Jules Ferry is regaining the political force that he had lost in France.

There may be plenty of hot weather in the coming Summer, however doubtful such a prospect seems now, but it will require an average temperature of considerably over 100 to force the Brooklyn politicians to abandon, even temporarily, their interest in a fight that promises to be one of the most absorbing in the recent history of the city.

It has been the work of several years, with a hard struggle and much vexatious delay, to make a fair start for providing a permanent and adequate system of rapid transit for the city of New-York, and now that a start has been made the only rational course for the people is to push it ahead with all their vigor on the line laid out.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 30. -- Decoration Day in this city was observed in a more fervent spirit than usual, because of the additional celebration of laying the cornerstone of the new State armory. Gov. Hill and staff arrived on a special train from Albany at noon, and were escorted to the Dutchess Club, where the Governor was tendered a reception by the members of the club and 200 prominent citizens of Poughkeepsie.

In your issue of to-day your Washington correspondent writes of some embroidery material taken by American ladies to Europe to be worked on during their sojourn abroad, upon which duty was charged and paid upon return to the United States. This to me seems almost impossible, but as it seems to come very straight and through such a reliable medium as your paper, it is accepted, of course, without question.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Over six thousand persons -- one-third of whom were ladies -- witnessed the Yale University of Pennsylvania game this afternoon. The latter team lost the game because they could not his Bowers. Pennsylvania frequently had men on bases with nobody out, but failed to score. Yale made 4 of her runs in the second inning, when she combined four hits with the only errors that Pennsylvania made.

I notice in your issue of to-day a letter signed by Egbert P. Watson, in which he makes certain observations under the heading of "The Kite Would Not Fly." I think Mr. Watson is quite right in his statements, provided he bases his calculations on the data which he seems to have obtained. However, those do not come from me, and what has lately appeared in the newspapers regarding my experiments is anything but correct.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30. -- Harvard is so eminently the leader in college journalism that a brief consideration of the development of this art with her cannot fail to be of interest to the general reader. Many obstacles obstructed the growth of journalism at the university, and one and another earnest effort to establish magazines and papers failed from lack of support.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 30. -- The Bay State-Bicycle Club held its third annual tournament to-day in Agricultural Hall. The events and their winners are as follows: One-mile novice, Safety; ten starters -- Won by R.A. McDuffee of West Everett. Time -- 3:07. Two-mile. Worcester County championship; four starters -- Won by C.A. Fenner of Worcester. Time -- 7:12 2-5. One-mile tandem, Safety.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- The management of the Pennsylvanian, the university paper, has decided to make it a bi-weekly instead of a weekly, beginning next year.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 30. -- The weather has been quite cool in Kentucky the last week, and as there was no rain the work of training the trotters went on without interruption. Never before in the history of the trotter has there been so many horses in training in Kentucky at one time, and the work many of the youngsters are doing speaks well for the progress trotting-horse breeding is making.
KINGSTON, May 30. -- The Rev. C.L. Barringer will preach his farewell sermon as pastor of the West Camp Lutheran Church to-morrow. Mr. Barringer goes to Valatie, Columbia County.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- Business at the theatres has been uniformly good this week. Manager Davis of the Haymarket reserved his most brilliant attraction for the closing week of his season. The Bostonians opened a week's engagement last Monday evening and played to a succession of the largest audiences the Haymarket has ever known for that length of time.

LONDON, May 21. -- The advance sheets of the first tabulations of the census taken by the Government of British India have just been received here. The results are very surprising. The work of enumerating appears to have been very thoroughly done. On one day, Feb. 26, 1891, 1,000,000 enumerators were engaged in the work of enumerating the inhabitants. In one district (Bengal) the staff exceeded 309,000.

Memorial Day was observed in this city in the customary way, interest centring as usual in the parade, in which veterans, regulars, regiments of the State militia, and detachments from the navy participated. The route of the procession was well lined with spectators throughout its entire length, while about the reviewing stands in Madison and Union Squares were dense crowds.

From time to time in the last three months brief reports have come to this country of the trouble between the Spaniards and the natives on the Caroline Islands, in the Pacific Ocean, in which American missionaries were involved. These islands, among which is Ponape, about fifty miles in circumference, are claimed by the Spaniards, but up to 1887 they were practically independent.

As was predicted in this column last Sunday there was a rush out of town on Saturday week following the coaching parade of the morning and the suburbs last Sunday and throughout the week just closed were filled with members or the gay world of the metropolis, bent on enjoying to their utmost the delights of the country at this season.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 30. -- Richard L. Trumbull, the Chilean Senator who was indicted by the United States Grand Jury for violating the neutrality laws in connection with the schooner Robert and Minnie and the Itata affairs, arrived here from San Francisco yesterday, accompanied by his attorney. He proceeded at once before Judge Ross and pleaded not guilty. The time of the trial will be decided Monday.

LONDON, May 30. -- "Hedda Gabler" goes off the Vaudeville stage to-night. I fear it is doubtful if there has been much money in it, but Americans have a right to be very proud of the reputation Elizabeth Robins has made for herself in the title role. There has been no such unexpected bursting forth of a powerful personality on the London stage since the advent of Mrs. Bernard Beere, ten years and more ago.

FRENCH COFFEE. -- The art of adulteration seems certainly to be carried to a very alarming point when coffee berries are compounded from the flour of some cereal, molded to shape, and then torrefied so as to resemble the true berry, and are, as stated by a French paper, openly sold to grocers and others at a price which yields 60 to 100 per cent. more than the usual profit.

At latest accounts no further progress had been made in the proposed establishment of an independent theatre in Boston beyond the discussion of hastily-formed plans at a meeting of a few enthusiasts. The Boston Post intimates that the names of certain persons well known in literature and art were used to advertise this scheme without authority.
LONDON, May 30. -- The text of the Bering Sea bill, introduced into the House of Commons yesterday by Mr. William Henry Smith, the First Lord of the Treasury, is in substance as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 30. -- The Democratic County Conventions held in the course of the last few days clearly indicate that despite the renewal of the factional warfare upon Gov. Campbell, he is more than holding his own in the reliable counties upon which the Democracy must wholly depend to gain a victory in Ohio this year.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 30. -- The Rev. A.W. Ebersole, late of Syracuse, entered upon his new charge as rector of Grace Episcopal Church at Waverly, N.Y., Sunday last.

The financial statement showing the results of the last season of opera in German at the Metropolitan Opera House has caused considerable chatter and has stirred up some of the dissatisfied stockholders to an open expression of their feelings. There are several millionaires among the stockholders who are always ready to grumble, and this time they have a thoroughly good reason to do so.

BERLIN, May 30 -- Emperor William, before deciding on a reduction or a temporary suspension of the duties on grain, asked Dr. von Boetticher, Secretary of the Imperial Home Office, to submit to him a report upon the crop prospects and upon the general economic position bearing upon the question. The Ministerial Council will meet to-morrow to take definite action touching the matter.

There is a difference of opinion between Prof. WIGGINS of Canada and Prof. CAMILLE FLAMMARION of France that ought to be adjusted for the good of humanity; and as FLAMMARION does not know, perhaps, that the disagreement exists, and that it may to some extent unsettle the minds of many admiring readers of his lovely imaginative works dealing more or less with astronomy, we hasten to set the matter before him.

ST. LOUIS, May 30. -- Centenary Church, the most aristocratic Methodist church in the city of which the Rev. Dr. B. Carradine is pastor, has, during the past two weeks, been the scene of some remarkable demonstrations, culminating last night in an exhibition of religious fervor bordering closely on the sensational.

ALBANY, Texas, May 30. -- The wool sales for the season have begun, and about one-half of the clip has been marketed already. The town is filled with wagons daily, all loaded with wool from the ranches. The Spring clip, though somewhat lighter than last year, will be something over 1,000,000 pounds. Prices range from 21 to 23 cents, and all clips are meeting with ready sales as fast as offered.

A dull market, with small general average of movement; a further export of $4,600,000 of gold; money easy on call, and a bank statement showing an increase of over $2,000,000 in the surplus reserve, part due to decrease of loans and part to receipts of money from the interior -- this about makes up the record of a week shortened one day by a holiday.

No reader of "Midnight Talks at the Club" will fail to be interested in this new volume from the same hand. The year that has passed since the appearance of that volume can scarcely have weakened the impressions made by it on every reverent and thoughtful person, by whom the after-life is accepted as the most weighty of all human concerns.

RUTLAND, Vt., May 30. -- Word is received from Washington that the Treasury Department has decided adversely on the claim of the State of Vermont for its share of the direct tax which Congress voted to refund to the States. The Treasury Department claims that Vermont's share of the direct tax is more than offset by a charge which the Government has against the State for arms furnished during the war.

A holiday crowd that filled the Gravesend track to its utmost capacity was on hand yesterday to enjoy the last day's sport of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Spring meeting. It was a crowd but little smaller than that which packed the grounds on Brooklyn Handicap Day, and it was one which contained an unusual percentage of women, more, possibly, than were ever before at the track.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- To-day is a legal holiday in this State and business in this city was almost entirely suspended. The day was cloudy and threatening, but there was no rainfall, and the many sporting events and decoration ceremonies were all well attended. The principal points of interest, were, of course, those visited by President Harrison and the distinguished members of the party accompanying him from Washington.
Suppose the girl graduate's essay does soar to lofty heights. Why shouldn't it? Isn't she an angel?

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- During the time that Postmaster General Wanamaker was at the President's reception this morning in Independence Hall, he had a few minutes to spare to chat about the Keystone Bank and City Treasury exposures.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 30. -- Tenaciously still does the veteran Premier of Canada hold to life. Last evening it was officially announced that he could not pass the night. This conviction was based on the fact that, in addition to his two distinct strokes of paralysis, which extended over the whole body, hemorrhage had extended to the brain.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 30. -- Under the session laws of 1889, Gov. Bulkeley will be required to appoint the County Commissioners in the State, sixteen vacancies occurring July 1, which must be filled without delay, in order that the regular county business may not be interrupted. These appointments are of decided importance from a political point of view, the County Boards being vested with arbitrary power in the matter of liquor licenses and regulations.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 30. -- The Grand Jury submitted its final report to-day and was discharged. The members regret their inability to fathom the conspiracy by which the firm of O'Malley Adams secure the secrets of the Sheriff's office. They speak well of the institutions visited, and conclude as follows: ...
He touched a man on the shoulder as the ferryboat was leaving its Brooklyn slip and with a drawl asked:

There is likely to be sharp competition in the bidding for the National Democratic Convention next year. Almost every city that is habitable in warm weather between Boston and San Francisco is talked of. Denver would like it very much, and the real estate boomers and silver men of that enterprising city would contribute handsomely for the entertainment of the delegates, expecting of course quid pro quo.

A canoe covered with a white canvas awning, which for several days had been noticed in the lower part of Sheepshead Bay, was visited yesterday afternoon by a man whose curiosity was aroused by the fact that the craft seemed to be deserted. In the bottom of the canoe, lying at full length, was the body of a man who had without doubt been dead for several days.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The month of June promises to be one of many weddings in Washington, as invitations have already been issued for dozen or more of these interesting events.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The news that Wilkinson Call had been elected to represent Florida for another term in the Senate was received here with only a slight degree of interest. It was from the start generally believed that while Mr. Call would have to overcome pretty strong opposition, he would be re-elected, and nobody is much surprised that he has at last succeeded.

The application of electricity to welding, although of the greatest commercial importance and marked by results of surprising benefit to many trades, is a subject on which the public has received little information through the newspapers, the chronicle of its adaptations to modern wants having been confined, for the most part, to a record of progress in are and incaudescent lighting, railway-car propulsion, and telephonic and telegraphic communication.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30. -- During the latter part of last season there was considerable interest taken in catboat racing, especially after the Morgan race, for which Mr. E.D. Morgan gave a number of generous prizes. It was at that time thought that several new boats would be added to the racing class during the Winter by the local builders, but such was not the case.

BOSTON, May 30. -- Staley had the Cincinnatis completely at his mercy this morning, and after Holliday's home-run hit in the first inning they could do nothing with him. The Bostons batted freely and fielded fanitiessly. Slattery roused the crowd by a one-handed catch while running at full speed. Radbuern and Clarkson were pitted against each other in the afternoon game. The former was given quite an ovation.

Every mail has been bringing letters to THE TIMES office, along with signatures to the petitions to restore Battery Park to its proper uses as a pleasure ground for the people. Not only have New-Yorkers at home shown a lively interest in the movement to oust the sqatter, but New-Yorkers in different parts of the country, notably merchants away on business, have sent along their names to be added to the list.

LONDON, May 30. -- The event of the week has been the one hundredth performance of Sullivan and Sturgis's "Ivanhoe" at the Royal English Opera House. This performance took place on Monday last. Sir Arthur Sullivan conducted the music, and the cast was composed of the same actors and actressess who first presented the romantic opera to the public. The house was crowded with notabilities.

The Tammany syndicate that is now running the City Government was given its power through the votes of poor men who were "bunkoed" into voting for Grant and company by the district leaders and heelers who made threats and promises that they never intended to keep. Now that Tammany has been in power so long it is well to inquire what the poor people have got out of the Tammany administration.

Since 1873 the annual regattas of the Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association have been events of more than local interest, but never before has the association given a regatta on such a large scale as the one which took place yesterday at Newark, N.J. The largest number of entries on any former occasion was forty, while yesterday there were sixty-four contestants.
In his "Belles of New-York," published forty-four years ago, N.P. Willis wrote of the late Mrs. Robert L. Cutting, under the name of "Mrs. Vere," the sketch reprinted below:

The nearness of 1892 and the stimulus of the World's Fair have affected the market for portraits of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS in a way that must be deeply gratifying to the few thousands of persons who own them. Mr. WILLIAM E. CURTIS of Pan-American memories has rushed into the fray with all the Christian simplicity of a Western person, and begun to form a collection of portraits of COLUMBUS.

The fruit supply of this city for this week will be liberal, both in quality and variety. There will be cherries, strawberries, blackberries, huckleberries, perhaps a few raspberries, and poaches, all only a few days from the plant which bears them. Besides, there will be a full line of tropical fruits.

LONG BRANCH, May 30. -- The prospects of a good season here were never brighter than now, when the influx of Summer cottagers has already set in. Richard Meares of the Hotel Royal, New-York, is having a substantial bulkhead and jetties built in front of his Scarboro Hotel property, where the waves had gnawed such great crevices into the bluff.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 30. -- The term classes for the Senior Class met Wednesday with the opening of the final examinations, which this year last one week. From the 11th to Commencement the Seniors have vacation. The examinations for advancement take place from the 10th to the 18th.

AMHERST, May 30. -- Since President Gates's advent there has been a marked and continual growth in the college. Changes have been made, plans formed, all tending to build up the institution. The institution has received several large gift, and at the last Trustee meeting it was decided to begin work at once on the new one-hundred-thousand-dollar chemical and physical laboratory.
But, Madame, I do not understand you!"

Edwards H. Goff died Thursday at his residence, 185 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street. During his active business career of about twenty years he figured as the promoter and manager of a great variety of corporate enterprises, some of them visionary in the extreme. Most of these enterprises sooner or later he involved in financial ruin. His death was the signal for the financial collapse of the largest and most daring of them all.

The suggestion that the failure of the re cent negotiations for the purchase of a naval and coaling station for our war vessels at St. Nicholas Mole may be followed by a re-examination of Samana Bay as a site for such a station is rather natural. This latter has a strategic importance quite as well marked at the eastern end of the island as St. Nicholas Mole has at the western.

A religious event of more than usual interest was celebrated by the Jews of the east side yesterday. It was the first lecture of the new Rabbi Rappoport at the First Galician Dueler Mogun Abraham Synagogue at 87 Attorney Street. Rabbi Rappoport arrived only a week ago yesterday from Gallicia, where he had achieved renown as a learned and orthodox teacher.

DETROIT, May 30. -- In the Presbyterian General Assembly this morning, after the reading of the minutes, the Committee on Bills and Overtures reported. Some debate arose as to a proposition to drop from the regular roll and keep a separate list of ministers who do not report annually to their Presbyteries, but it was adopted.

The action of the Presbyterian General Assembly at Detroit in adopting. Friday, the report of the committee, of which Dr. Patton was Chairman, disapproving the appointment of Prof. Charles A. Briggs to the Edward Robinson Chair of Biblical Theology in the Union Theological Seminary, has created a sensation among members of the church in this city unparalleled in many years.

The twenty-five-mile road race over the Irvington-Milburn course in New-Jersey was run yesterday morning. The road was in poor condition owing to the rain. Nearly fifteen hundred wheelmen, however, took the chances of further discomforts and journeyed to the course to witness the event. Several tally-ho coaches and carriages, decorated with club colors and flags, lined the roadside, and, despite the threatening aspect of the weather, it was a gay scene.

The big elephant at Coney Island looked extremely happy yesterday, and in the course of the day swallowed many persons; every one whose business it is to shout at Coney Island was there shouting, and the men who insist that they can take tintypes in five seconds that are far superior to oil paintings, poked night-marish samples of their work in front of he faces of the holiday crowd, with the most provoking persistency.

BRUNSWICK, May 30. -- The Seniors' examination will take place June 1, 2, and 3, after which they will have nothing more until Commencement Week. At the Commencement concert Miss Alice Wentworth, the Boston soprano, will sing, as will Campanini, and the Salem Cadet Band has been engaged for the week.

TROY, N.Y., May 30. -- Michael Fitzgerald, founder of the Garryowen Brewery, in which ex-Mayor Fitzgerald is the sole surviving partner, died several years ago, and his wife soon followed him. They left a very handsome fortune, and their children lived in ease and comfort in the pretty homestead in the stone road.

W.H. Crane, the comedian, gave a dinner at the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, last night, to his company, in commemoration of the close of his second season with "The Senator." All the members of the company were present, including Manager Joseph Brooks, Charles A. Powers, the advance agent; the carpenters, and the property men of the organization.

June, the sixth month in the year, is quite important as far as the sun's motion is concerned, as on the 21st the sun reaches its highest point north and the Summer solstice occurs. The meridian height is the greatest, the sunrise point as well as the sunset point are the furthest north, and the longest day is succeeded by the shortest night.

On a Brooklyn surface road one day recently, among other passengers in the well-filled car, were a gentleman and young lady, strangers to each other, seated side by side. The gentleman was of refined appearance and carefully dressed, and was apparently absorbed in his newspaper. The young lady, it was noticed, became somewhat restless after a time, and once or twice moved somewhat impatiently away from her next neighbor.

Three ladies were making their way through a lot of building materials scattered along the sidewalk in West Fifty-seventh Street one day last week. They came to a big ladder, which enabled the brick and mortar carriers to ascend from the street to the third floor of a half-finished building. One of the ladies passed under the ladder, while the other two went around it by making a detour into the street.

UTICA, N.Y., May 30. -- A remarkable libel suit terminated here this morning. It was brought by Myron W. Van Auken, Republican candidate for District Attorney in 1889, against the Utica Observer, and damages were placed at $42,000.

It is often quite a question with anglers nowadays where to go to secure fair trout fishing. The Adirondack region has been pretty much fished over, and while there are sections of the Great North Woods that contain streams yet well supplied with trout, anglers are in search of new regions where they may be assured of large fish, and an abundance of them.

PARIS, May 4. -- To close up the brilliant season of the Vaudeville Theatre M. Carre has suddenly burst forth in his usual happy, daring style with a new idea and a new star -- none other than Depuis of the Varletes, who happened to be in Paris, midway between a starring tour in the provinces and his annual Summer tour of the watering places.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- If the British Government had become disgusted with the trickery and duplicity which has marked James G. Blaine's conduct of the Bering Sea negotiations, and had determined to force the United States to show its hand and thus disclose where the responsibility for delay belongs, it would have taken just the course it is now pursuing.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 30. -- An organized movement has been instituted to promote the industrial and agricultural development of the Housatonic Valley. Associations are being formed in the various towns along the Housatonic River with a view of infusing activity and prosperity into the region. A meeting of the gentlemen interested in the enterprise was held in Bridgeport this week.

ROME, N.Y., May 30. -- The Rome 'Cyclers held their annual meet in this city this afternoon at Riverside Park. The meet was a success, the attendance being large and the racing excellent. The Murphy brothers of New-York easily won the State championship medals. About twenty bicycle clubs from out of town were present. Following is a summary of the races:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30. -- In the game at Springfield last Wednesday with Trinity, Brown won -- 5 to 4. The nine played the University of Michigan on Lincoln Field on Thursday, winning that game by a score of 5 to 2. The nine is now in quite a crippled condition. Sexton will be unable to pitch any more this year.

LENOX, May 30. -- More than half the cottagers have come on and are occupying their places, and by the end of another week Lenox will be in full Summer dress, with three-fourths, at least, of the cottages occupied. The weather has been delightful this week, though so cool that open fires have been a necessity as well as a luxury.

There are ten or twelve men now employed in the Brooklyn City Works Department who have never passed a civil service examination, and yet they were appointed under a section of the civil service regulations. This seeming anomaly means that the local dispensers of patronage have discovered a way to "beat" the civil service law in a limited manner.

LONDON, May 30. -- Several persons who have recently had occasion to sit up very late report their discovery that it is now broad daylight at 4 in the morning. This is the only indication which has been vouchsafed to Englishmen that their happy sea-girt isle is not still in the midwinter season. Positively no such season has been here before.

We should say that Mr. HARRISON must at times wish that he could ask for the resignation of his son, RUSSELL, and get rid of any further responsibility for that amazing young man. It is not impossible that it was a fellow-feeling for the unfortunate father of young RAUM that induced the President to permit the Commissioner of Pensions to disembarrass himself of his son by that method.

The Scottish-American Athletic Club held its annual games at Caledonian Park, Jersey City Heights, yesterday afternoon. The grounds were well laid out and a large crowd assembled and cheered the competitors. The officials were: Referee -- T.A. Collett; Judges -- J.E. Kelly, J.C. Young, James J. Nagle; Timers -- G.P. Kaiser, W. Launders; Starter -- John Fraser; Clerk of the Course -- John Hart; Assistants -- F. Rush, T. Ambrey; Announcer -- G. Burrell.

This volume records the life, the higher life, of a singularly sincere and devout woman, who, in an earnest way, did all the good she could, and who, seeing her work accomplished, only regretful that her labors on this earth should cease, found her rest with God. Far outside of the creche, or the Grace House-by-the-Sea, had Miss Wiltse's zeal exerted its influence.

Was Count Moltke a General of the first class? He may have been, but as he never had to direct a campaign against any first-class or even second-class General, it cannot be asserted as a fact. The Austrian Generals against whom he was pitted were beneath contempt. Not one of the French Generals that he encountered during the Franco-German war was up to the mark of the worst of the first Napoleon's Marshals.

Small things in the testimony of witnesses frequently are full of meaning and importance. It is the details considered unimportant by the witness himself that are most closely listened to by Judge and lawyers. If the witness is telling a false story, unless he is unusually keen, he has paid his attention to the main points of his story, and has fitted them to the case.

The nomination of John Young Brown by the Democrats of Kentucky to be their candidate for Governor recalls to the mind of the Washington correspondent of the Concord (N.H.) Monitor the fact that at one time Mr. Brown was a much-talked-of man all over the country. It was while he was a member of Congress and the Civil Rights bill was under discussion.

The Commissioners who are to inquire concerning immigration into this country from Europe should take with them, when they cross the ocean not only the published reports of the New-York State Board of Charities but also the proof which that board can supply with respect to the shipment of lunatics, idiots, and paupers from Europe to the United States.

It takes a strong-minded sister to overthrow all manner of things in a few words. In the report given in the Standard of the address of the President of the Northern Women's Missionary Society occurs the following sentence in regard to the women of the last quarter of a century: "They have seen that in subordination to man there is no growth, no freedom, no real help to man."

There is some difficulty between National District Assembly, No. 226, horse car employes, and District Assembly No. 75 of Brooklyn, also horse car men, both Knights of Labor. All the railroad men in both cities formerly belonged to No. 75, but about the time the last great car strikes took place, a national district assembly was organized, and was joined by nearly all the New-York car men. The number 226 was given it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 31. -- United States Senator Quay is nettled at his one-time bosom friend, ex-State Senator James S. Rutan, for saying that Quay would endeavor to turn over the Pennsylvania delegation to Mr. Blaine, giving as a reason for setting aside the President, that he was too cold and did not understand the application of practical politics. Passing through town last night to his Beaver home, Senator Quay said of this story:

LONDON, May 20. -- Baron Bleichroder of Berlin confirms my statements in my previous letters concerning the cause of the heavy importations of gold from the United States and the object of the same, to wit, the replacing of metal which had been withdrawn from England and Germany by Russia The same high authority states that the gold brought from New-York was at a loss.

The indications given in our Washington dispatches yesterday morning are that the President has taken the Bering Sea negotiations completely into his own hands, and is working out as rapidly as possible a practical agreement with Great Britain. If he succeed, Mr. RUSSELL HARRISON may have occasion to revise his opinion that the relations between his father and Mr. BLAINE are of the "pleasantest."

The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Thompson, who has been in attendance at the General Assembly in Detroit, has returned to this city, and last evening addressed his congregation at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, near Fifty-third Street, on the things which have been done at the Assembly. Dr. Thompson did not touch upon the main questions at issue in the way of debate, but simply stated what had been done.

-- Political Americanisms. A Glossary of Terms and Phrases Current at Different Periods in American Politics. By Charles Ledyard Norton.
