New-York: Longmans, Green Co. -- We are, as Americans, ingenious in many ways. As far as our vocabulary goes, we are always adding to it. There is no question as to the duration of the current political argot.

The Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York will convene in annual session to-morrow afternoon in Masonic Hall, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue. This is the one hundred and tenth annual communication since the organization of the Grand Lodge, and Grand Master John W. Vrooman will wield the gavel in the Grand East.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- While the major part of Washington is laughing heartily over the latest interview with the son of the President, here and there is found somebody who takes the talk seriously enough to criticize it. "Should the Republican leaders insist upon it," Russell Harrison is quoted as saying, "then he [the President] will allow his name to go before the convention."

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- Mayor Stuart's retirement from the Presidency of the Young Republicans of this city developed a serious factional disturbance in that organization. The Mayor will in a few months step down from the office of President of the Republican State League of Clubs, and when he does, so a war threatens to invade the ranks of the league which may at least begin the work of disruption.

Such questions as the one that bored and bothered us lately -- "Is marriage a failure?" -- such matters as divorce which perplexes jurists, legislators, and priests, and such troubles as come to municipalities by way of the social evil have relations more or less close with a great many facts presented in this little book.

The churches of this city and vicinity completed last week a census of families, with the view of compiling a reliable and complete record of the religious leanings of every family within the metropolitan district. The canvass has been undertaken by the women of the churches, who have divided the territory into districts, each canvasser agreeing to visit about fifty families.

The unhappiest lot of men who took part in the Decoration Day parade was that composing the second division of the Naval Brigade. They were on hand at the navy yard at the appointed hour in the morning, and the prospect for a pleasant day was good, but the best laid plans of mice and sailors go aft aglee, as did theirs.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 31. -- Although the recent session of the General Assembly of this State was the longest on record, there is already talk of an extra session to correct some of its blunders. The session was interesting, not only on account of the many measures of grave public importance that were considered, but of various attempts to secure legislation by secretly attaching "riders" to bills and by other underhand methods.

The disposition made of the case of Dr. BRIGGS by the Presbyterian General Assembly would be surprising in any organization. It is especially surprising in a body that is supposed to be, and indeed has lately shown itself to be, an eminently-conservative body. For the effect of it is to deny a man the right of exercising a lawful calling and of earning his livelihood, and to deny this right without a trial.

Prince BISMARCK, it is said, will open his new career in the German Parliament by leading, or seeking to lead, a coalition against the proposed reduction or suspension of the duties on grain. The Prince cannot be said to have prided himself when in public life on consistency as his chief virtue.

ST. LOUIS, May 31. -- The Lucerne petition to the Vatican, asking that a policy based on strict national lines be followed by the Church among immigrants to America, originated in St. Louis. Father Phelan, editor of the Western Watchman, and a recognized authority on Church affairs, is credited with the following statement to a reporter to-night:

We find in the Bulletin of the Protective-Tariff League some interesting testimony relating to the pottery industry. It is given to the public through the Bulletin by ex-Congressman J. HART BREWER of Trenton, and as it was not laid before the McKinley Ways and Means Committee, so far as we know, we publish a apart of it.

WEST POINT, May 31. -- Every one at this picturesque and historical post is looking forward to the annual examination of the 265 cadets, which begins Tuesday. The Academic Board is all ready to meet the boys, and it is to be hoped that the boys are as ready to meet their professors in the mental trials.
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 31. -- The physicians attending Sir John Macdonald held a consultation at Earnscliffe at 11 o'clock to-night, and at its conclusion issued this bulletin:

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached a sermon at All Souls' Church yesterday that was in effect a continuation of his discourse of the week before on creeds. His subject yesterday was, "How to Read the Creed." His text, from Acts viii., 30, was, "Understandest thou what thou readest?" He said:

From Herodotus onward there is in the allusions on the part of Greek and Roman writers to the mysteries an element of fascination which these writers seem perfectly to have understood. At least Herodotus seems to enjoy putting one off by some pious remark concerning the necessity he is under to keep his mouth shut just when one is expecting a clue.

STARKE, Fla., May 31. -- The negro desperado Harmon Murray has again been heard from. Late last night he killed D.L. Alvarez, City Marshal of this place, and a negro guide named Prince Albert. The tragedy occurred about four miles from here, on the line of the Florida Central and Peninsula Railroad, and not far from Hampton station.

PARIS, May 15. -- Before entering into details of the remarkable exhibition of the National Society at the Champ de Mars, I must refer to a mistaken idea generally conceived concerning this association. It is not protected by the Government. It is a private enterprise paying a rent of $6,000 per annum. The members dwell and exhibit their own paintings under their own roof.

Holders of June interest coupons of the 6 per cent. first mortgage bonds of the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad were told yesterday when they presented the coupons at the Bank of North America that no money had been provided for their payment.

LONDON, June 1. -- A Blue book was issued to-day giving some of the correspondence in the Bering Sea matter. It begins with a telegram from Lord Salisbury to Sir Julian Pauncefote, dated April 17. Lord Salisbury says:

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 1. -- This week the "third-party" State Convention will meet here, with Gen. Weaver as master of ceremonies. June 24 the Democratic State Convention will meet at Ottumwa, and one week later, July 1, the Republicans will convene at Cedar Rapids to nominate a State ticket.
The entrance examinations at Columbia began yesterday, and will last throughout this week. About 130 men presented themselves. The professors were clad in their academic gowns.
KANSAS CITY, June 1. -- Rains fell throughout Kansas and Missouri yesterday and to-day, and to-night reports are that in all sections the Hession fly and chinch bugs have been washed away.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1. -- The State Commission charged with considering all propositions with regard to the Virginia debt met at noon to-day at the call of Gov. McKinney. This body consists of the Governor, Lieut. Gov. J. Hoge Tyler of Pulaski, Speaker of the House R.H. Cardwell of Hanover, Senators Berry of Amherst and Wickham of Hanover, and members of the House of Delegates Dabney of Albemarle and Tyler of Prince William.

Morris Park, complete and perfect in all its appointments, threw open its gates to the public yesterday afternoon, and then began its racing season. It was a successful opening, too, in every way. There was good racing, which is of the first importance. There was a good crowd for Monday, always an off day in racing, a perfect day for sport, and every appointment necessary for the comfort of the crowd.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- None of Mr. Blaine's friends in the North American Commercial Company ought to find fault with the share of the Secretary of State in the Bering Sea correspondence which has just been made public. On the contrary, the Elkins-Mills people ought to hold him in grateful remembrance for the tender solicitude he has shown for their interests.
LONDON, June 1. -- Trial was begun to-day of Sir William Gordon Cumming's suits for damages for defamation of character growing out of the famous baccarat scandal.

ALBANY, June 1. -- "We shall try to ascertain the relationship between the canal appropriations made in the last eleven years and the public interests," said Gen. McMahon, Chairman of the Canal Investigating Committee to-night.

Last week Judge INGRAHAM of the Supreme Court denied the application of the electric lighting companies for an injunction to prevent the Subway Company from cutting their cables out of the subways on account of a refusal to pay what they regard as exorbitant rentals, and for an order of the court fixing a fair rental for the use of the subways.

LONDON, June 1. -- The two very formidable men-of-war which were built in France for the Chilean Government have received their armament, Armstrong guns, Hotchkiss and Nordenfeldt rapid-firing and machine guns, and will soon sail for the west coast of South America.

One of the tin-plate factories about which some of our high-tariff contemporaries have had a great deal to say is supposed to be situated in the can factory of NORTON BROTHERS, in Chicago. One of the McKinley papers asserted a few days ago that NORTON BROTHERS were making enough tin plate to supply their own wants, or about three hundred thousand boxes per annum.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Proposals were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the construction of the protected cruiser No. 13, provision for which was made by the last Congress, as stated in the TIMES of this morning. A number of representatives of shipbuilding firms were present when the bids were opened, as well as members of the different branches of the naval service.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 1. -- By far the most brilliant and fashionable wedding ever witnessed in Plainfield was that which took place this evening, when Miss Elinor Matilda Shepard became the wife of John Doull Miller. The groom is a son of William Miller of Lancaster Gate, Hyde Park, London. The bride is a daughter of Augustus D. Shepard, one of the Vice Presidents of the American Bank Note Company.

DETROIT, June 1. -- After the reading of the minutes, the subject of young peoples' societies, which came up on an overture, was taken up. There was some lively discussion as to the liability of the Christian Endeavor Society becoming too independent, The special object of the resolutions which had been offered seemed to be the formation of Westminster Leagues to take the place of the Christian Endeavor Societies.

The monthly bulletin and pilot chart of the United States Hydrographic Office, which was issued yesterday, shows that a remarkably quiet condition of affairs has prevailed on the North Atlantic throughout the last thirty days. Only three storms have been chronicled. Fogs have been reported in largely increasing quantities, and they will probably continue to increase this month.

If all the lawbreakers and would-be lawbreakers in the city had been put on Madison Square yesterday, where they could have seen the annual parade of the police force, they might have been so impressed with the physical power of this should-be agency of law and order as to have been deterred from further wrong-doing.

A three-act play called "Miss Manning," written by Mr. Runnion, of Chicago, was acted in the Fourteenth Street Theatre last evening. It had not previously been seen in New-York, and we infer that it will be very popular. In Act I. a tale is told of a will made by a person who must have been insane. By its terms, unless the heroine is soon married, she will lose her fortune.

Mrs. Harrison, wife of the President; Mrs. McKee, and Mr. and Mrs. Russell B. Harrison arrived in New-York last evening and went to the Gilsey House, where rooms had been prepared for them. Mrs. McKee and Mrs. Russell Harrison will sail for Europe on the Teutonic Wednesday. They will be the guests while in London of Minister Lincoln, and should they visit Paris, will be the guests of Minister Reid.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- When the council's sub-committee that is investigating ex-Treasurer Bardsley's accounts met this afternoon, a resolution requesting the finance committee of councils to present an ordinance offering $5,000 for the arrest of Gideon W. Marsh, the fugitive President of the Keystone National Bank, was agreed to.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 1, via Galveston. -- The death of Finance Minister Dublan, while not unexpected, was not generally believed to be so close at hand; but it was considered in banking and financial circles here that he would probably never be able, even in the event of rallying from his last attack, to take upon himself the burdens of what is now the most onerous department of the Government.

Mr. Secretary FOSTER has not, at the present writing, decided exactly what course he will take in regard to the treatment of the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds. It is reported from Washington that he is still awaiting the opinion of the Attorney General as to his obligation, in case he extends these bonds, to give three months' notice to the holders of the extended bonds before he can call them in.

Judge Ingraham yesterday brought sorrow to the hearts of the contractors O'Brien Clark, who want to get from the city about twice as much for their work on Section 6 of the new aqueduct as is called for by the final certificate of the Aqueduct Commissioners, and whose suit to recover $732,312 is now on trial before him and a jury in the Supreme Court.

The New-Yorks are now in second place. They got there because they defeated the Clevelands yesterday and because the Pittsburgs and Clevelands lost. "Buck" Ewing thinks the team will overtake the Chicagos very soon. They are only twenty-five points ahead.

BALTIMORE, June 2. -- This was the first day of the circuit racing at Pimlico Park, and three races were decided. Three horses lowered their records, and the young mare Addie Lee Second, from Poughkeepsie, won her first race in the 2:50 class, getting into the fast list in the first heat.

At a special meeting of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club to be held next Monday evening the recommendations of the committee appointed to examine localities for a yachting station and seaside house will be finally considered. The committee examined locations at City Island, Cow Bay, Pelham Bay, New-Rochelle, Portchester, Rye, Hempstead Harbor, and Oyster Bay.

John Ewing's steady pitching, strong work in the field, and first-class batting on the part of the Giants, scored another victory yesterday. The Clevelands again were the victims. This time they didn't make it at all interesting for the ex-champions. On the contrary, the latter-played in their old style and disposed of their opponents without allowing them to score a solitary run.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 2. -- The meagre details of the shooting and killing of a negro man and the lynching of three men connected with the murder by a mob on the Grand Bay plantation in Pointe Coupee Parish, near Hermitage, has reached this city through passengers arriving from Bayou Sara.

Whatever may be the soundness of Attorney General MILLER'S opinion that silver certificates may lawfully be issued for the difference between the bullion value and the coinage value of the silver bullion bought under the act of 1890, we hope that nothing of the kind will be done. It would be a petty and shameful trick.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The following circular in regard to the redemption of 4 1/2 per cent. bonds was issued this afternoon:

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 2. -- The first State Convention of the People's Party will be held in this city to-morrow. The indications are that it will be a large and earnest gathering, and it is evident to every sagacious observer that its action is likely to lead to important results in the election next November.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 2. -- One Sunday evening four or five weeks ago the Rev. J.H. Boyce, then the alleged pastor of the Baptist church at Madalin, in the town of Red Hook, Dutchess County, had a fight in his own pulpit with some of the Trustees of the church for the possession of it. The Trustees believed he had no right there, and he was ejected.

A correspondent of the Post in Washington reports that there is a vague and not altogether comfortable feeling in the Post Office Department that Mr. WANAMAKER has been converted to civil service reform. It is not known what shape the demonstration of his conversion will take, but it is intimated that the chief change will be in the institution of an adequate system of examinations for promotion in the department.

The Twenty-fifth Police Precinct, over which Capt. John Gunner has command, enjoys the distinction of having within its boundaries a larger number of public institutions than any other precinct in the city. The station house is situated on the north side of East Sixty-seventh Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, sandwiched in between the headquarters of the Fire Department on the east and the Mount Sinai Dispensary and Training School for Nurses on the west.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 2. -- The Supreme Court rendered a very important decision to-day, reversing the decision of the lower court, in the case of the Cincinnati Inclined Plane Railroad Company against the City and Suburban Telegraph Company.

" A Lesson in Acting" is the title of a dramatic sketch written by Mr. John Ernest McCann, the poet, and Mr. Nugent Robinson, that was presented for the first time at the Lyceum Theatre last evening before the performance of "The Veiled Picture." Mr. Mantell is certainly encouraging serious native dramatists, and in that he deserves encouragement.

In the light of recent events the Rev. Dr. B.F. De Costa is likely to stand singly and alone in his opposition to the confirmation of the Rev. Phillips Brooks as Bishop of Massachusetts. There are many High Churchmen in this diocese who have taken a firm stand in opposition to Dr. De Costa's methods, and the determination of his fellow-clergymen to let him severely alone in this matter is very pronounced.

At this distance there is no reason why it should not be said that Sir WILLIAM GORDON CUMMING seems to have been ill advised in bringing a suit for slander against certain persons who had promulgated the report that he had been detected in cheating at cards. British "society" is pretty well understood and not in the least respected by serious persons either in or out of England.

In the easiest possible manner Brooklyns defeated the Pittsburg Club at Eastern Park yesterday. They hit the curves of King all over the field, and scored run after run in rapid succession. For the home team Lovett pitched good ball, and he was given excellent encouragement in the shape of gilt-edged support. The Brooklyns look the lead in the second inning and held it throughout the contest.

SARATOGA, June 2. -- This is the month of conventions and tournaments, and each day witnesses the opening of a hotel, and the gradual unfolding of the season proceeds. The Court of Appeals has started in for its Summer's work, and the two divisions are rapidly disposing of the calendar. There are about 300 causes on the new calendar, where there are ordinarily about 1,000.

It is certain that if the absolute security to householders against the raid of burglars which modern invention now affords was more widely known, there are none, especially among those preparing to leave town for the Summer, who would not gladly avail themselves of it. This protection is secured to them, and at moderate cost, by the Mutual District Messenger Company, 458 Broadway.

WEST POINT, June 2. -- The army girl has arrived here in large quantities. There is no difficulty in distinguishing her. Her habit is to get as close to the cadet, figuratively speaking, as she possibly can. Her habiliments are made on lines strictly for the notice and admiration of the cadet. One of her fads is to wear at her waist a brass buckle polished to the highest order of reflection.

ALBANY, June 2. -- That Dr. Seward Webb and his associates will run the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad through the wilderness from Malone to Herkimer if money will overcome the obstacles is apparent to all who have watched their course. Doubters who attended the meeting of the Land Board last Thursday became thoroughly convinced that the railroad people are in earnest and will stop at nothing to accomplish their object.

ST. LOUIS, June 2. -- The baccalaureate sermon delivered by the Rev. R.C. Cave of the non-sectarian church of this city before the graduating class of the Missouri State University at Columbia on Sunday has created a furor, and criticisms are being heaped right and left on the heads of the college Faculty.

About thirty members of the Ladies' Health Protective Association of New-York attended the last meeting of the association for this season yesterday at 11 West Eighteenth Street. Among those present were Mrs. M.R. Ravenhill, Mrs. M.J. Herbert , Mrs. A.O. Tiffany, Mrs. E. Wakeman, Mrs. M.E. Trautman, Mrs. C. Haley, Mrs. C. Fendler, Mrs. S. Baum, Mrs. M.S. Wyse, Mrs. M.A. Newton, and Miss T. Barcalow.

The New-York Tribune publishes a letter from Mr. JOSEPH NIMMO, Jr., who fears that wicked persons abroad who want to sell their goods at low prices, and other wicked persons at home who are trying to buy American tin plate but cannot find it, have conspired or will conspire to kill "American enterprise in its cradle."

The attention of the Aldermen was called to the Battery Park grab yesterday by Alderman John Morris of the Seventh District, who introduced the following resolutions, which are practically a reproduction of the resolution which was adopted by the Board of 1887:

It seems that Mr. HARRISON came away from Philadelphia on Decoration Day in a "huff." At the luncheon given him at the Union League Club no places were provided for his Private Secretary or for the Marshal of the District of Columbia, who, by the traditions of the White House, is regarded, for some mysterious reason, as a sort of First Gentleman in Waiting upon the person of the President.

ELIZABETH, June 2. -- The seceders from the Fulton Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Elizabethport, have determined to out loose altogether from the Newark Conference, and will organize an independent church, to be known as the Protestant Methodists. This step was taken at a prayer meeting held on Sunday night to protest against the action of the Newark Conference in supplanting Pastor W.G. Simpson by Pastor Johnson of Stapleton, S.I.

St. Thomas's Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, was filled yesterday afternoon at the funeral of Dr. Fordyce Barker. The impressive services were in accordance with the form for the burial of the dead of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and the uncommon incident of a Bishop taking part in them rendered the services the more significant.

The one hundred and tenth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York was opened in Masonic Hall, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, yesterday afternoon by Grand Master John W. Vrooman with the usual impressive ceremonies. There was an unusually large attendance, 704 lodges being represented, and the large ball was filled when the Senior Grand Beacon.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 2. -- The Grand Lodge Knights of Reciprocity is now in session in this city. This new organization was called into existence by the inroads made in Republican ranks by the Alliance, although its founder had commenced work upon its principles long before. The membership has been rapidly extending in this and other States, until now there are seven grand lodges.

DETROIT, June 2. -- In the Presbyterian General Assembly this morning the Chairman of the Committee on Worldly Amusements explained the meaning of its recommendation of judicious discipline, which it was yesterday instructed to modify. Its reference to progressive euche as reconstructed was read, after reference to the deliverances of previous Assemblies.

RICHMOND, Va., June 2. -- The Debt Commission and the members of the Oleott committee were in joint session the greater part of to-day discussing the plans of the latter for the settlement of the Virginia debt. The utmost secrecy is observed by all parties concerned as to what transpired; indeed, it is understood that those in the conference pledged themselves not to impart what took place.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- In spite of the apparent nearness of the Governments of the United States and Great Britain to an agreement to limit the catch of seals in Bering Sea, few persons here believe that the seals will get very much benefit from it this year.

GARDINER, N.Y., June 2. -- The protectionists tried to play a neat game on the Reform Club as to the discussions arranged for Ulster County. Up to the very last moment they ignored the club's challenge for joint debates.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 2. -- The Board of Public Instruction of this city, at a meeting held May 26, wholly divorced future appointments of assistant teachers in the schools under their jurisdiction from the possibility of control by political or social influences by providing that all appointments shall be made from the top of a merit list made up from records of scholarship and special fitness for the position vacated.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- At the annual meeting of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railway and the Belt Railway of Chicago, Ben Thomas, the Vice President and General Manager, was promoted to be President and General Manager. Volney T. Mallott, the retiring President, was elected Chairman of the Board of Directors. Secretary M.J. Clark and Treasurer J.E. Murphy were re-elected.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 2. -- The Premier's condition to-day is slightly improved. The bulletins issued are not so alarming as yesterday and indicate a change for the better. This fact has created a slight hope among Sir John's nearest relatives, and it is understood that Prof. Osler of the Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, will be summoned to the bedside of the dying Premier.

That tremendous test of strength, endurance, and agility, the individual all-around championship contest of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, was held yesterday on the beautiful Berkeley Oval. A.A. Jordan of the New-York Athletic Club, the champion of 1890, earned the honor for himself for 1891 after the best fight that has been made for it for several years.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- The hitch in the hospitalities extended to the President of the United States at the Union League on Decoration Day was the only topic of discussion in that august body to-day, and amid a flood of explanations was the one clear and comprehensible statement that the whole thing was run by ex-Mayor Edwin H. Fitler, President of the league, and the rest of the league had nothing to do with it.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 2. -- Those who will receive honors for excellence in special departments in Princeton College this year are:
BOSTON, June 2. -- Secretary Blaine started for Bar Harbor this evening at 7 o'clock. He is in very comfortable health, and was not so ill as was reported on his arrival here Monday.

The Board of Electrical Control met yesterday in the Mayor's office, and declared that the contract with the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company had, in the board's opinion, become inoperative. In the following resolution the Commissioners called on the Corporation Counsel to prepare a resolution which would forfeit the bond of the company:

The two meetings held in the Trunk Line Association offices in the Jersey Central Building yesterday were not productive of important results. The General Passenger Agents did nothing beyond routine work, because of the absence of representatives of the Canadian Pacific Road. It had been expected that the question of admitting the Canadian Pacific into the immigrant passenger traffic clearing house might be acted on.

LANSING, Mich., June 2. -- Charges of bribery have been preferred against Representatives Lewis Murthe of the Ontonagon district and M.J. Doyle of the Chippewa district. They are alleged to have demanded and received $50 for passing the Ironwood Charter bill through the House. The House to-morrow will consider whether or not to investigate the charges.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 2. -- Jack Simmons, a colored longshoreman, died yesterday of that fearful plague, leprosy. He was a native of Jamaica, and came here four years ago and married a daughter of a colored drayman. They separated a year ago, and the woman is quite healthy and living here.

A Mr. MILLIGAN of Pittsburg, a clergyman of the Reformed Presbyterian variety, has made a report to the Synod of his denomination denouncing secret societies. The dispatch says: "The report deals with the Mafia, and said it was gratifying that the Grand Jury at New-Orleans had made the investigation and reported as it did."

The beginning of the so-called investigation of the canals by the Assembly committee at Albany yesterday confirms the impression that the sole purpose of the inquiry is to counteract the effect of the Democratic refusal to consent to an investigation by the Senate, and to whitewash the present administration of the Department of Public Works.

Alexander Drake Button, Port Warden of New-York during the administration of Gov. Hoffman, died yesterday of paralysis, aged seventy-eight years, at his residence, 14 La Grande Avenue, plainfield, N.J. He was born in Sherburne, Chenango County, March 1, 1813, and early engaged in the manufacture of willowware at Watertown with James G. Lynde, then the Clerk of Jefferson County.

Walter Thomas Rogers, F.R.S. Litt, does not know Greek, nor Latin, nor French, nor books. He does not know English well. But he has written "A Manual of Bibliography," published by Scribner Welford, with thirty-seven illustrations, taken from Henri Bouchot's "Le Livre," and a colored frontispiece, a plate of the horrible bookbinding that Zachnsdorf commits.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- The quo warran to proceedings of the Commonwealth against Richard G. Oellers, the present incumbent of the office of City Treasurer of Philadelphia, were begun here to-day before Judges Arnold and Wilson in the Court of Common Pleas. By agreement of counsel on each side the case was submitted without argument, and a pro forma decree entered by the court declaring Mr. Oellers to have been duly elected City Treasurer.

If our readers could see from day to day, as we have seen them, the utterances of the McKinley press concerning Trust combinations, they would soon become familiar with a most curious collection of opinions and assertions relating to a question of great importance. They would see abundant proof of insincerity, ignorance, evasion, and contradiction.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 2. -- No recent occurrence in Scranton has caused such intense excitement as the presentment of the Grand Jury of Lackawanna County in court to-day indicting the three members of the Common Council of this city on charges of bribery and corrupt solicitations.

St. Louis, June 2. -- The Lucerne petition to the Vatican asking for the adoption of a policy of nationalizing the Catholic Church in America has caused a controversy that promises to take a very wide range and develop some decidedly sensational features.

BOSTON, June 2. -- The girls and women of Boston had evidently not awakened to the fun in store for them when their free gymnasium on Charlesbank opened its doors yesterday noon. It is called a women's gymnasium, but the children's playground takes in no way a secondary position.

BOSTON, June 2. -- The political situation in this State is at once complex and simple, if the statement be not considered paradoxical. So far as the Democrats are concerned it is extremely simple. So far as the Republicans are concerned it is uncomfortably complex. The Democrats, unless some unforeseen and unexpected condition intervenes, will renominate Gov. Russell by acclamation when their convention meets next September.

The committee of the Republican Association of the Twenty-first Assembly District of this city which has been sent forth to investigate the Civil Service Examining Board at the Custom House seems likely to obtain more assistance from Commissioner ROOSEVELT than it counted upon or can make any use of for the purpose it had in view.

We have already had occasion to emphasize the fact that it is only the connection of the heir to the English throne with the "baccarat scandal" that makes that scandal worth spreading beyond the limits of London society. Within these limits the guilt or innocence of Sir WILLIAM GORDON CUMMING has an interest of its own, but this must already have been satiated by the trial.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Signal Service issues the following bulletin for May: ...

ALBANY, June 3. -- Gen. McMahon and his select combination of whitewash artists have put in the regulation number of hours to-day in following out the policy which the Governor has decided shall govern the alleged investigation of the canals. They spent several hours listening to Senator McNaughton's tale of his unselfish work in behalf of appropriations for Western New-York canal improvements, and to his version of the late Senate dead-lock.

CARLISLE, Penn., June 3. -- In 1879 Capt. R.H. Pratt, manager of the Indian Training School in this city, and who had been at work in the Indian Department at Hampton, Va., arrived here with a few Indian children from the West, having been ordered by the Government to establish a school here.

In THE TIMES of Saturday, May 23, was published a portion of a letter from one of your readers in regard to the robbery of two invalids by professional nurses. I quote the following questions put by your correspondent:

Will you allow a constant reader of your paper to express an opinion or two on the ecclesiastical warfare now raging? While we of the laity have been comparatively silent, expressing our views only in private, we are by no means at peace. We are thinking, thinking, and waiting, wondering what may be the issue of the struggle.
In a championship game at Bay Ridge yesterday the Crescent Athletic Club nine-defeated the Staten Island Cricket Club team by the appended score:

It is not particularly complimentary to the Park Commissioners that those citizens who are working for the rescue of Battery Park from the grasp of the elevated railroad company should deem it advisable to refrain from calling a public meeting at Castle Garden pending the action of the Park Board, lest it should have a ruffling effect upon their temper.

Mr. Anthony Mullane faced the Giants yesterday. He used his stock of curves, drops, in-shoots, and slow and speedy balls in hopes of checking the batting of the metropolitan aggregation, but without success. The New-Yorkers hit the ball in all directions and won the opening game with Cincinnati hands down.

The point made by Secretary TRACY in his North American Review article that our country has passed to a new stage in naval construction is no doubt well taken. It was necessary to experiment at the outset, and as the second group of our new cruisers far surpassed the first in engine power, so it is a natural development that our present vessels should make a like advance.

The People's Fire Insurance Company of this city at a meeting of its Board of Directors held Tuesday last voted to go out of business, and at noon on the same day all of its risks were reinsured in the National Fire Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn. The same day a circular letter announcing the retirement and reinsurance was addressed to all the agents of the company.

A variety of schemes for lighting and ventilating railroad tunnels were laid before the State Railroad Commissioners in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday. The suggestions, which were made by lawyers, electrical engineers, masons, locomotive engineers, and cranks, related particularly to the New-York Central's Fourth Avenue tunnel.
There are now about 250 men employed in the railroad tunnel under the North River, and the completion of the tunnel from shore to shore is looked for within the next six months.

BOSTON, June 3. -- The Republican State Central Committee does not propose to let the Legislature divide the State into new Congressional districts this year if it is possible to prevent it. Secretary Wardwell has returned from a three days' fishing trip with renewed vigor and courage, and says the fight against the bill has only just begun.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Secretary of the Navy has selected the Thetis, now a the Mare Island Navy Yard, to be the vessel used in making the preliminary surveys for the proposed telegraph cable from San Francisco go Honolulu, and unless it is found that she is needed to assist in driving seal poachers from Bering Sea she will begin the survey as soon as the appropriation becomes available July 1.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3. -- The joint conference between the debt Olcott committee and the State Commission closed this morning for the present, and the members of the former returned to New-York. It is believed the result of the meeting will be a better understanding between the State and the holders of her bonds than has existed before.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Admiral McCann has sent a report to the Navy Department of the sinking of the Blanco Encalada. He writes from Valparaiso, April 29, and gives a story of the fight in the harbor of Caldera April 23, which is practically the same as the reports hitherto given. He continues as follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., June 3. -- While the opinion of the Supreme Court in the Branford contest, which was filed at New-Haven to-day, relates only incidentally to the "for" ballots, it is regarded here as finally expressing the views of the court that the prohibition votes rejected at the State election in November were legal and will have to be counted in the returns laid before the Legislature.

While it would be a difficult matter to draw a line by legislation and to enforce the enactments so as to exclude from this country all immigrants who may be considered "undesirable," a very distinct line is drawn by the present laws for the exclusion of certain classes whose presence here is not only undesirable but an unquestionable public injury.

WESTCHESTER, Penn., June 3. -- This afternoon Mrs. Blanche Woodward Young, who has been suspected having killed her husband, J. Norris Young, by poison, was given a hearing before Justice Alfred Rupert, she having been arrested this morning on a warrant issued by District Attorney E.D. Bingham. Mrs. Young was attired in a black gown and black hat.

There has been a curious decision in France upon the right of ownership in private fish; that is, fish bred and brought up and protected in private waters, but which had escapes to waters owned by other proprietors.

LONDON, June 3. -- Russell Co., an old commission house of Canton, China, with branches in this city and New-York, have failed. The liabilities are unknown, but it is said that the credit of the firm has long been worn out.

It is CHARLES II. who is reported, somewhat doubtfully, to have said that every man has his price. If he had lived in the New-York of the nineteenth century, instead of the London of the seventeenth, and had said that every Alderman has his price, scarcely anybody would have thought of disputing his statement.

LONDON, June 3. -- The same crowd of fashionable people, ladies still predominating, was found in the courtroom at the baccarat trial to-day. Lady Coleridge, the wife of the Lord Chief Justice of England, who presides at the trial, occupied a seat on the bench to the right of Lord Coleridge, in company with Ladies Clarke and Russell.

LONDON, May 23. -- For ten days the weather throughout the British islands and over a great part of the Continent has been very unseasonable. Snow, hail, disagreeable cold rain has in turns been the prevailing order. The agricultural outlook was decidedly unfavorable before this recent bad weather. The Spring was very backward, the only good weather being that of the fatter part of April.

BOSTON, June 3. -- If a continued peal of laughter from an audience, lasting from the rising of the curtain to its final drop, is evidence of the success of a comedy, Helen Barry's play, "A Night's Frolic," is certainly a great success. The Park Theatre was packed to the door tonight on the occasion of the fiftieth performance of the play here, and the enthusiasm was displayed by constant applause and roars of laughter.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3. -- Col. Ruffin, the Second Auditor of Virginia, has recently come in possession of information which leads to the conclusion that there may be forged or spurious bonds of this State in existence. Certain it is that one has recently been sent to his office about the spuriousness of which there seems to be no reasonable doubt.

Commissioner J.F. Goddard of the Trunk Line Association retraced his steps in the West Shore differential matter yesterday, and arbitrated at the Trunk Line Executive Committee meeting that the West Shore Road shall have a differential of 7 cents over the Canadian Pacific and "Soo" route. This is on a basis of $1.23 per 100 pounds of freight, first-class, with the regular rate $1.30.

Capt. Anson's team made its first appearance this year in this vicinity yesterday in a game against Brooklyn. As usual, Anson was on top at the finish. His boys played a remarkably clever game, and although the Brooklyns fought gamely they had to accept defeat. It was a cleverly-played game on both sides, and the spectators, although the result did not please them, were forced to applaud the skillful work of the victors.

In order to increase its present superb facilities between New-York and Chicago, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will, on June 7, place in service an additional fast express train between these points. The new train will be known as the "Chicago Special." It will be composed of two Pullman vestibule sleeping cars, one combination smoking car, two Pennsylvania Railroad standard coaches, and a dining car.

In response to the request of the Board of Health the Trustees of St. John's Guild have resolved that five trips per week shall be made by the Floating Hospital during the present season. This important enlargement of the work will involve largely increased expenditure to meet which dependence is placed upon a generous public's support, but it is believed that this action of the Trustees of this wholly unsectarian charity will be abundantly sustained.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Mr. Lacey, Controller of the Currency, made a statement this afternoon in regard to the Keystone National Bank of Philadelphia. He said:

DES MOINES, IOWA, June 3. -- The "Peoples' Party" Convention to-day nominated a complete State ticket. It was a fair convention, larger than the third party is accustomed to in Iowa, and in the matter of enthusiasm it was greater than it was in numbers.

It is quite possible, as intimated by Controller LACEY, that he was misled by the reports of the local Examiner, Mr. DREW, as to the condition of the Keystone National Bank in Philadelphia. It is equally possible that the real desire of the Controller of the Currency was to protect all interests involved impartially. But it is plain that there has been singular neglect somewhere.
Can it be possible that the inhabitants of this city are to be still further subjected to the outrages and nuisances inherent in elevated railways?

The Hon. Charles Foster, Secretary of the United States Treasury, has come to town on an errand full of business. He will meet nearly all of the leading New-York bankers -- the heads of national banks -- at the Sub-Treasury this morning for an informal talk relative to the proposed extension of Government 4 1/2 per cent. bonds at 1 1/2 or possibly 1 per cent. interest.

JACKSON, Miss., June 3. -- Never was there such a crowd here as to-day at the unveiling ceremonies of the Confederate monument. The city was in holiday attire. Flags, bunting, and streamers were seen in every direction. Thousands of United States flags were displayed in every place. They were the principal decorations. Occasionally a tattered Confederate battle flag was to be seen and some few new ones.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 12, 1891. -- Shortly after the arrival of the Russian squadron in Kobe, the Czarowitch, with Prince George of Greece, visited Kioto, the ancient capital of Japan, where elaborate preparations had been made by the Japanese Parliament to welcome their Imperial Highnesses.

RICHMOND, June 3. -- The work on the machinery of the new battle ship Texas threatens to be seriously handicapped by a strike at the Richmond Locomotive Works. Over four hundred hands have ceased work and refuse to return unless the management discharges all unskilled laborers.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 3. -- The arguments in the Tilden will case were resumed to-day before the Second Division of the Court of Appeals. Ex-Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins concluded his argument for the appellants the Trustees.
The circular issued by Mr. FOSTER, the Secretary of the Treasury, on the 2d inst., with reference to the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds that fall due in September, contains the following:

The morning session of the Masonic Grand Lodge yesterday was taken up with the election of officers. With the single exception of the Junior Grand Warden, the elections were by a show of hands. There was, however, a spirited contest for that office, which was waged in a fraternal spirit and was largely a question of locality, the three contestants hailing from different sections of the State. Rochester won the prize.

Miss Amy Fay gave at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon what she was pleased to call a "piano conversation." Such an appellation would lead one to suppose that Miss Fay was possessed of the power to make the piano talk; but it seems that the title of her entertainment is not intended to convey any such meaning. Miss Fay prefaces her piano performances with brief talks about the composers and the compositions in hand.

The Tammany Committee on Organization met last night in the Wigwam and settled two Tammany family quarrels according to the orders of Richard Croker and company. Croker and all the lesser Tammany bosses were there. Croker came in a little late, and the crowd cheered him, as a matter of duty, because it was the first meeting of the committee he had attended since the last campaign.

The Masonic Grand Lodge which has been in session in this city sines Tuesday closed its labors yesterday, and adjourned to meet again next year. On the recommendation of the Committee on Jurisprudence the United Grand Lodge of Victoria was given official recognition.

The Withers Stakes, for three-year-olds, and the Debutante Stakes, for two-year-old fillies, are the features of the day's sport at Morris Park to-day, the entries and weights for the several events being as follows:

TRENTON, June 4. -- The Supreme Court dealt a blow to-day fatal alike to their hopes and to the expectations of the convicted ballot-box stuffers of Hudson County. The court to-day on appeal overruled every point interposed in their behalf and declared that they must undergo their sentences.

In the easiest manner imaginable the Chicago team won from the Brooklyns yesterday. Anson's men hit the ball hard and often and were never headed from start to finish. The Brooklyns played poorly in the field, failing to take advantage of many opportunities to check base hits. Anson's men played that steady game for which they are famous. Score:

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 4. -- Secretary and Mrs. Blaine arrived here this afternoon, having spent the last two days with Senator Hale at his home in Ellsworth. The Secretary was driven immediately to his cottage, the Stanwood.

The three political shepherds of Ohio -- one of whom boasts that he wrote the wool schedule of the new tariff and put into it the tricky clauses that have excited the anger of the manufacturers -- are now pursuing a Consular officer who has had the hardihood to oppose their policy of exclusion.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The young men who make a living by getting news for the Wall Street agencies were exercised to-day over the manner in which Director H.H. Porter of the Rock Island Railroad "scooped" them on the very important matter of the reduction in the Rock Island dividend.

After a contest of the most brilliant character, the New-Yorks won their sixth consecutive game yesterday, defeating Cincinnati by a score of 4 to 2. The Giants played without an error and the visitors were only charged with one misplay. From start to finish both nines stubbornly contested every inch of ground and the spectators were treated to a first-class exhibition of ball playing.

ST. LOUIS, June 4. -- There has been considerable complaint at the tightness of the money market in this vicinity. A tour of the banking and financial institutions of the city brought a variety of expressions, and, while most of the banking officials were unwilling to be quoted as saying a money stringency exists, all agreed that there is little or no money to be had for speculation.

Nathaniel Smith, aged 101 years 5 months and 3 days, died at the residence of Mr. George Noon, at Hempstead, L.I., on Wednesday night. The deceased was the oldest resident on Long Island. He was born at Turtle Hook, now Uniondale, on Jan. 7, 1790. He lived under the Administration of every President of the United States, from Washington to the present time.

There was a big crowd at Morris Park yesterday in spite of the wintry touch to the weather. It was a good day for fast time, however, for in the opening dash of five and one-half furlongs La Tosca knocked to pieces all records for the distance, covering it in 1:04 1/4, which is nearly two seconds faster than the record made by Hanover at the Sheepshead Bay track just two years ago this month.

The four-act romantic drama called "The Louisianian," by Mr. Edward M. Alfriend of Richmond, Va., that was performed at the Madison Square Theatre yesterday afternoon, does not compel much thought. It is very much like many other plays of its kind. It is all on the surface. It does not contain a new idea, and what merit it has is purely theatrical.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Chauncey M. Depew was entertained by the Whitechapel Club to-day. The Doctor was dragged from the Auditorium Hotel with Mr. Baillie, Mr. Depew's companion on his Western trip. The club rooms, fronting on an alley, wore a pleasant and homelike appearance. The gaslights were wagging in the skulls which are used as globes.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 4. -- There was not much surprise in Washington to-day when it was learned that the Itata had been surrendered to the United States authorities at Iquique. Some such conclusion to the incident has been expected ever since ex-Mayor Grace's visit to this city, when it was generally understood that some sort of promise for the surrender of the fugitive vessel was made on behalf of the insurgents.

OTTAWA, Ontairo, June 4 -- The first installment of the papers in the matter of the negotiation between the Governments of Canada and the United States on the subject of commercial reciprocity was brought down to the House of Commons by Sir John Thompson yesterday, the remainder being retained pending instructions from the Imperial Government.

Wall Street worked up a great deal of excitement yesterday over a transaction in stocks which involved only 200 shares, but which was sufficiently out of the usual run to set the Stock Exchange by its ears. W. Strother Jones of Jones, French Maury, and" Eddie" Wasserman of Wasserman Brothers played the leading parts in what some of the brokers were inclined to call a farce and others a more serious matter.

Mr. Amberg's creditors held a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Amberg Theatre building. They sat behind closed doors, but after the meeting William Steinway said that an arrangement had been agreed upon whereby the theatre would be kept open with Mr. Amberg as manager.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Announcement has been made of the approaching marriage of Gen. John M. Schofield, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Army, to Miss Georgia Kilbourne of Keokuk. The ceremony will take place June 18 at the bride's home. Over 4,000 cards will be sent out.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- A gigantic deal, negotiations toward which have been carried on for the past week, was perfected this evening at the Auditorium. By the papers which were signed the Whisky Trust has at last acquired outright the only remaining important anti-trust establishments in the West, the great Chicago distilleries owned by H. Schufeldt Co., and the Calumet Distilling Company.

BOSTON, June 4. -- The Massachusetts House to-day passed to be engrossed, by a decisive vote, the bill of the committee for the reapportioning of the State into Congressional districts. The tactics of the opposition failed utterly, and the popular branch refused, by a vote nearly as large as that of last week, to refer the matter to the next General Court.

Mr. FOSTER met a score or more of New-York financiers yesterday and talked over the financial situation with them. He assured them that the question of what is the best course to pursue in regard to the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds maturing in September was purely a business question, and that there was no "politics" in it, which is an assurance that, if it be not uncalled for, is not absolutely convincing.

RICHMOND, Va., June 4. -- It is believed that Hugh R. Garden and his associates will at once endeavor to get the English holders of Virginia bonds to agree to give more terms in the settlement of the debt. To place their clients in possession of all the information Mr. Garden and the members of the committee obtained here, they will possibly send one of their number to London.

BALTIMORE, June 4. -- Sir William Gordon -Cumming has a brother in Maryland. He is Mr. Alestar P. Gordon-Cumming, and is the proprietor of a two-hundred-acre farm near Sykesville, in Carroll County, where he lives with his wife, formerly Miss Ames of Washington. About fifteen years ago he came to the United States, and finally settled in Carroll County.

Many pleasing and original designs were yesterday displayed on the walls of four large rooms at the School of Mines, Columbia College, and visitors to the fourth annual exhibition of the Department of Architecture were more than pleased at the variety and almost uniform excellence of the drawings.
A nine has been organized in connection with the St. George Athletic Association. Clubs having open dates can secure games by communicating with Secretary Stein, 207 East Sixteenth Street.

ALBANY, June 4. -- The legislative tailors who are now fabricating a robe of spotless white for the form of Edward Hannan, Superintendent of Public Works, sewed on a few more buttons today. Being untrammeled by fashionable restrictions, they are not worrying over the fit of the garment. So long as it is "roomy" and the color is correct, there will be no complaint from the Executive Chamber whence the order for its manufacture comes.

UTICA. June 4 -- The "Utica centre of the tinplate propaganda" is in a state of high glee. That "carload" of tin plate arrived Tuesday morning. It was forwarded to Charles Millar Son by P.H. Laufman Co. Of Apollo, Penn. This "carload," as THE TIMES has been informed, was the fruit of a visit of P.H. Laufman to Utica a couple of months ago.

BOSTON, June 4. -- In the 200 years that have elapsed since "Essexes have married Suffolks," as Dr. Holmes quaintly puts it, there has not been a more notable union among the old families which represent New-England's bluest blood than that to-day of Miss Elizabeth Copley Crowninshield, daughter of Gen. Casper Crowninshield, and Mr. George Lee Peabody, youngest son of Mr. S. Endicott Peabody of Salem.
Secretary Foster learned yesterday, by conferring with New-York bankers, that they do not favor his proposition to refund 4 1/2 per cent. bonds at a lower rate than 2 per cent.

ALBANY, June 4. -- "Who is John D. McMahon of Rome!" was the question asked of a prominent Utica man visiting in this city. The query related to one of the two counsel employed by the Assembly Committee investigating the canals. The Utica man was acquainted with Mr. McMahon, and the details of his reply were interesting.

The joyous Portuguese writer who rendered a lasting service to the gayety of nations in his learned essay on "English as She is Spoke," probably derived his knowledge of our language through the complicated media of a Portuguese-French and a French-English Dictionary, and the latter we suspect to have been the same one employed by the compiler of BASCHET'S "Catalogue Illustre" of the Paris Salon.

ALBANY, June 4. -- The statement that Paymaster Frederick C. Ward, who lies critically ill at his home here, was nearly $10,000 short in his accounts caused widespread interest, because of the popularity of Mr. Ward and his quiet mode of living. William C. Van Alstyne, a brother-in-law of Mr. Ward, says that on the day of the accident the money in the pay car was scattered about and handled by a number of persons.

ATCHISON, Kan., June 4. -- The appointment by the President of Chief Justice Albert H. Horton of Kansas to be one of the Judges of the new Spanish and Mexican Land Grant Court, which, it is said, will be officially announced from Washington in a few days, revives recollections of the Ingalls and Horton feud.

KERHONKSON, N. Y., June 4 -- The third of the series of joint tariff debates being held by the Reform Club in Ulster County took place at Modena last evening. In spite of a pouring rain the hall was filled with an audience mainly Republican, and the contest was the hottest so far of the series.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4. -- The last day but one of the week of examination at the Naval Academy comes to an end, even as all preceding days have ended, notwithstanding that some of the graduating class, with an extravagance of English that may be permitted to a man bred for fighting rather than composition, have declared that the week will never end.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The first twelve-inch steel gun made in the United States has been completed at the Watervliet Arsenal, West Troy, N.Y., and shipped to the Sandy Hook proving ground for testing. This is the largest steel gun ever built in this country.

WATERVILLE, Ma., June 4. -- Six or seven hundred hotel men, through 125 representatives, to-day forged the second link in the chain which will make Maine Democratic next Fall and cause a great political upheaval. The secret ballot was the first. Millions of money and hundreds of brainy business men to-day pledged themselves to secure the repeal of the State prohibitory law.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 4. -- The athletic enthusiasts of Cornell University are to-night discussing a five-column article entitled "Are Inter- collegiate Athletics to Stay at Cornell?" by Prof. Burt G. Wilder, which appeared to-day in the Ithaca Journal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- The report of the expert accountants who have been investigating the accounts of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley was transmitted to City Councils this afternoon by Mayor Stuart. The report shows that on the 21st of May, according to the books of the City Treasurer's office, there was on hand $32,317,608.50 belonging to the city.

Mr. Lodge has been having a miserable time of it the last two weeks, while he has been engaged in an unsuccessful attempt to persuade the Republicans of the Massachusetts Legislature to favor a gerrymander of his district. Mr. Powers, the Chairman of the Redistricting Committee, a Republican, has stoutly opposed Lodge's demand that his district should be made hopelessly Republican.

The leaders of the Chilean insurgents appear to have concluded that the better part of valor was discretion, and to have decided to surrender the Itata to our Government. There is little doubt that there was an understanding to that effect before the arrival of the vessel at Tocopilla, and according to the telegraphic reports the surrender has now been effected at Iquique.

Eleven o'clock is the hour set for the continuation of the hearing to-day by the Park Commissioners upon the petitions for the revocation of the permit under which the elevated road occupies Battery Park. This will be the third hearing in relation to the matter. At the presentation of the case to the Commissioners two weeks ago several citizens spoke for half an hour, and speakers on the other side consumed about two hours.
Happily, the manual of bibliography which Walter Thomas Rogers, F.R.S. Lit., has cribbed from poor Giuseppe Ottino is not at all an American book.

Nothing can induce the McKinley papers to enlighten their readers as to the enormous cost to the people of the experiments which NIEDRINGHAUS and one or two other persons are making in their sheds, and of the tin-plate clause in the McKinley bill. It is nobody's business, some of them say. We quote from the New-York Tribune of the 23d ult.:

Capt. Ward finnlly won a game from the Chicago team yesterday. The victory was due to the excellent work of Lovett, who pitched in great form. He kept the luts down to one double and two singles. He was given good support, Hutchison also pitched well, but his fielders were unsteady.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Gen. John M. Schofield, Commander of the Army of the United States, visited Army Headquarters this morning, and smilingly admitted to Gen. Miles that the report that he was soon to be married to Miss Georgie Kilbourne of Keokuk, Iowa, was true. The wedding will be solemnized at Keokuk June 18.

LONDON, June 5. -- Among the early arrivals in court this morning at the baccarat trial was Lord Middleton, who took this course of showing a moral support of his brother, Sir William Gordon Cumming. The Prince of Wales, affable as ever and as faultlessly dressed as all the other principals in the Queen's Bench panorama, was also among those who arrived and took their seats before the official opening of the court.

WEST POINT, June 5. -- By to-morrow afternoon the first class men will be happy. Prof. Clous is now confident that he can finish the examination on law by 4 or 5 o'clock in the afternoon. In that case the four years' service of the Class of '91 will have ended, and the boys will receive more freedom than they have had in many a day.

PAr:Is, June 5. -- The Archbishop of :Paris, assist,d by the Cardinal Archbishop of Lyons and the Bishops of Versailles, Orleans, and Chartres, to-day opened the magnificent Basilica of acre C(ur on the summit of Montmartre. The work, which was begun as a votive offering after the France-Prussian war, is s$ill unfinished. It has occupied seventeen years in buildin and has cos$5,000,o00.
YORKTOWN, Va., June 5. -- The United States ship Concord arrived here this evening, after a week's trial of her guns and engines at sea.

LONDON, June 5. -- The bill providing for the issue of an order in Council prohibiting the taking of Seals in Bering Sea by British subjects, though a Government measure, met with the opposition of Mr. Alexander Staveley Hill, who sits for the Kingswinford division of Staffordshire and who has represented Conservative constituencies in the House of Commons for many years.

The report of Admiral McCANN upon the sinking of the Blanco Encalada at Caldera has put in a very clear light what the torpedoes accomplished in that battle. It now appears that not only was the hapless armor-clad moored, but that no guard boats were stationed to warn her of the approach of an enemy, no torpedo net was in place, no guns were in readiness.

BALTIMORE, June 5. -- Alestar Penrose Gordon Cumming, a brother of Sir William Gordon Cumming and a resident of Maryland for the past twelve years, was interviewed by a correspondent of the Herald at his residence, The Clovers, in Carroll County. He said:

SARANAC INN, June 5. -- Dr. Seward Webb's Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad is at close quarters with the State, and a few days at most will show whether he proposes to respect the law relating to the wild lands owned by the State, to break or defy it, to evade it, or ask the courts to take it out of the way.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 5. -- Regular army officers attached to Gen. Merritt's headquarters here and others interested in army affairs are excited over current rumors to the effect that some very material changes will take place in the army within a short time. It is said that the military divisions of the Atlantic, the Missouri, and the Pacific are to be broken up and that their present commanders will be assigned to department commands.

BISMARCK, N.D., June 5. -- Nothing that has taken place for several months has so attracted public attention as the quarrel between Gov. Burke and Commissioner Helgesen. The Grand Forks Herald, the leading Republican paper, edited by George B. Winship, makes this the occasion for open warfare and scores Gov. Burke unmercifully.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., June 5. -- The tariff joint debate here to-night was one of the most interesting and important or the series arranged by the Reform Club. It opened with the Hon. Isaac N. Cox as Chairman. The others had been held in almost purely agricultural localities, but this place, although the centre of an agricultural region, is also a manufacturing town.

Coroner Hanly held an inquest yesterday in the case of John Wolf, the peddler who was stabbed in the groin by George Kaiser, May 30, at 503 East Eighteenth Street, and who died the following day at Bellevue Hospital. A verdict charging Kaiser with the killing of Wolf was rendered. Kaiser was committed to the Tombs.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 5. -- The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America in session here unanimously adopted this afternoon the report of the joint commission on the proposed union with the Reformed Church in the United States. The form of constitution providing for a Federal Synod of the Reformed Churches was approved and referred to the Classis of the denomination for approval or disapproval.

BOSTON, Mass., June 5. -- For years disgruntled taxpayers of Cambridge have been wont to express themselves in uncomplimentary terms in regard to Harvard College, which they say is of no benefit to the city, but, on the contrary, a drawback to its progress, occupying as it does a great area of land covered with valuable buildings upon which no taxes are collectable.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The account which came from San Francisco yesterday of the naval engagement in Valparaiso Harbor, stating that the insurgent cruiser Magallanes sailed under the guns of the Government forts and almost annihilated the Government torpedo boats is received with incredulity at the Navy Department.

The Park Commissioners concluded their hearing yesterday on the question of revoking the license under which Battery Park is occupied by the elevated railroad. The argument has been by no means confined to the main question, which is whether the railroad company has any legal right in the park and whether the Park Board has the power to compel it to vacate.

The trouble in the Arcanum Building and Loan Association of Brooklyn, due, it is claimed, to the absence of Secretary Joseph Ashforth and an apparent defalcation of about $10,000, assumed an official shape yesterday, when C.R. Hall of the Banking Department of this State notified the managers of the concern that there was a shortage in accounts of $10,200.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 5. -- Vacancies in the Faculty of Brown University and the extended facilities planned will result in the engagement of several new professors for the next collegiate year. The men have been recommended by the Executive Committee, but have not yet been formally engaged, but from official sources it is learned that the appointments will probably be as follows:

The Canadian Pacific Railroad will make no change just yet in its present reduced freight rates from New-York to Chicago, in consequence of the differential of 7 cents allowed the West Shore-Canadian Pacific combination by Commissioner J.F. Goddard. General Manager George Olds of the Canadian Pacific was in town yesterday, but he had nothing to say when the subject of Mr. Goddard's decision was mentioned to him.
LONDON, June 5. -- R.C. Duncan of Washington, D.C., who is charge with attempting to murder his wife near Bottws-y-Coed, North Wales, was arraigned for a hearing to-day and was committed for trial.

Secretary Foster of the Treasury had a busy day of it yesterday. After breakfasting with Thomas C. Platt and Senator Hiscock, and taking in with his breakfast largo doses of machine politics, he received a number of visitors, among whom were Titus Sheard, R.F. Pettigrew, Cornelius N. Bliss, Jacob M. Patterson, Henry W. Curtiss, and George A. Halsey.

The Union Theological Seminary Trustees took action yesterday which seems to indicate that a complete severance of its present relations with the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church is not far distant. In the language of one of the Trustees after the meeting was over, "the Union Seminary has stood by its guns.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- It pays to be related to President Harrison. The latest evidence of the President's adherence to this simple rule is furnished by the payment of $8,329.93 to Mrs. Elizabeth L. Harrison, widow of the President's brother, Archibald I. Harrison, Lieutenant Colonel of the Twenty-seventh Indiana Regiment of Volunteers.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 5. -- A committee composed of W.C. Barry of Rochester, N.Y., N.H. Albaugh of Columbus, Ohio, and I.L. Watrous of Des Moines, Iowa, representing the American Nurserymen's Association, left here to-night for Chicago to have the plan of the Horticultural Department of the World's Columbian Exposition entirely changed. Today's meeting was a sensational one.

Chauncey Vibbard of this city, in his day the foremost railroad man in America, and who is regarded to-day as "the father of railroads," died yesterday at Macon, Ga., in the eightieth year of his age. He had not been in good health for a year, and was staying in Macon, with his son-in-law, A. Craig Palmer of the Covington and Macon Railroad Company, to escape the soverity of the Northern climate.

BUFFALO, June 5. -- Who has given orders to shelve William F. Sheehan? That is a question all Democrats are asking themselves to-day, and it came about in this way: The Courier, the recognized party organ of the Democracy, with a leaning to the Cleveland side of the house, said this morning, with double heads and large type:

The suggestion that, inasmuch as the acquisition of St. Nicholas Mole has been checked it may be well to revive the old project of annexing the island of St. Thomas, is not very likely to be adopted. One great trouble both with the St. Thomas and the Samana Bay negotiations of a quarter of a century ago was that they contemplated annexation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Gen. Fisher, receiver of the Spring Garden National Bank, will tomorrow cause the arrest of Ephraim Young and Nelson F. Evans, two of the Directors of the broken bank. The charges upon which the men will be arrested are aiding and abetting in the fraudulent transactions which brought about the wrecking of the Spring Garden bank.

ALBANY, June 5. -- The place of the late William L. Muller on the State Board of Claims was filled to-day by the appointment by Gov. Hill of Hugh Reilly, District Attorney of Albany County. This appointment has been in pickle for some time, and it created no surprise in political circles. Assistant District Attorney Andrew Hamilton was appointed by the Governor to the vacancy created by Reilly's advancement.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., June 5. -- The Mohonk Negro Conference at its closing session to-day adopted the following recommendations for which, it suggests, the friends of the negro North and South should labor in unison:

The hearing before the Park Commissioners upon the application of citizens who want to save Battery Park was concluded yesterday after a session lasting something over three hours. It was thought that the representatives of the elevated road had said all that they wished to say at former hearings, at which they used the greater part of the time.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Anthony W. Evans, a naval veteran, arrived in this city from the Soldiers' Home at Erie to-day. He joined his wife and little girl at 1,910 North Fourth Street, and he will at once proceed to try to get work to keep the wolf from the door.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5. -- Collector Phillips recently secured a list of whalers that had obtained large quantities of whisky at Honolulu and then sailed for Alaska. Revenue cutters Rush and Bear have been instructed to overhaul these whalers. All whisky, except small quantities for medical purposes, will be seized, in order to keep liquor away from the natives.

BOSTON, June 5. -- For three innings to-day Viau pitched well, when the Bostons began to bat freely and he grew wild. In addition, the fielding of tho visitors was not up to the mark. and so the home team had an easy victory. Attendance. 1,560. Score:

Now that the Itata is in the custody of our naval officers and virtually in possession of the Government, there is some question as to the exact nature of her offense and of the penalty to be visited upon her. It is said that she was not seized at San Diego for any overt act in violation of the neutrality laws, but on suspicion.

By easy stages the Giants are gaining on Chicago in the League race. Yesterday they won another game from Cincinnati, and as Anson's band of pennant winners dropped one to Brooklyn, to-day the New-Yorks are only two games in the rear of the leaders. In other words, they are within hailing distance of the leaders, and are liable to jump into first place in a few days.

A dispatch to the St. Louis Globe-Democrat from Mexico says that "the Chihuahua smelter has been bought in the interest of English capitalists who have contracts for a supply of lead ores from Sierra Mojada." They will begin to ship the ores as soon as a railroad now in process of construction shall have been finished.

To-day at 3:30 o'clock Civil Engineer R.E. Peary of the navy will leave this city for a journey toward the north pole by way of Greenland. He will take his departure on the dirty and greasy little whaling steamer Kite, which arrived here three days ago, and which now lies at the foot of Baltic Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Peary, who is a young and very attractive woman, will accompany her husband on this perilous voyage.

Joseph Murray, Superintendent of the Custom House, has taken a hand in the business of writing letters to D. Morgan Hildreth. Chairman of the committee of the Twenty-first Assembly District Republicans which is investigating charges against the Civil Service Examining Board at the Custom House set forth in resolutions presented to the district association.

As we have before remarked, the question whether Sir WILLIAM GORDON CUMMING has been cheating at cards furnishes a very small part of the interest with which his suit for slander against certain persons for saying that he had done so as followed in England and in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The only dispatch received at the Navy Department to-day from Admiral McCann at Iquique was one correcting the statement as to the location of the Itata when the arms were transferred to her from the schooner Robert and Minnie. This transfer, the dispatch says, took place off San Clemente Island, a few miles from the coast, instead of off San Diego Harbor.

PARIS, May 26. -- It cannot reasonably be expected that every one of the eight representations of M. Antoine at the Theatre Libre will bring forth a chef d'oeuvre. I think his best friends would scarcely recognize in "Nell Horn," the five-act drama of M. Rosny, any interest further than the much-used Salvation Army incident, and this has long grown familiar to Parisians.

The "Act to provide for ocean mail service between the United States and foreign ports and to promote commerce" was approved March 3, 1891. Thus far the Postmaster General, so far as known, has entered into no contracts with American vessels for the transporting of the United States mails to foreign ports. The reasons are obvious after even a cursory consideration of the requirements contained in the act mentioned.

BOSTON, June 6. -- A largely attended meeting of the Alumni of Phillips Academy, Andover, was held at the Tremont to-day. Judge Robert R. Bishop was called to the chair. It appears that the Academy is in need of funds for the prosecution of certain improvements in several of the departments and for the enlargement of others. In fact, it needs to be re-endowed with about half a million dollars.

The unveiling of the statue to Mr. J.S.T. STRANAHAN in Prospect Park, which took place yesterday, called out sincere and well-deserved tributes to that gentleman. It is not usual to pay honor to a living man in this way, but there is ample reason for the exception in this case. In a very important sense Prospect Park is the work of Mr. STRANAHAN.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 6. -- Filed away in the office of the United States District Attorney for Kentucky, awaiting the decision of the United States Supreme Court, are five indictments against Banker Edward H. Horner of 88 Wall Street, New-York. Horner was the agent of several foreign lotteries. He sent circulars through the mails advertising his lotteries, and was caught up with.

It is seldom that a woman loses anything in the pocket of her own dress, but such a thing actually happened to a very clear-headed and methodical young woman whose residence is in Baltimore, but whose comings and goings encompass nearly every civilized quarter of the globe. Some time ago Mrs. C. missed her pocketbook, containing a considerable sum of money.

WEST POINT, June 6. -- Among the recommendations the Board of Visitors is likely to make in its report, which will be prepared next week, is one to double the number of cadets. Ever since the first meeting of the board this question has been discussed. Officers of the post agree that with their present facilities, 500 cadets could be cared for as comfortably as the present number -- 265.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 6. -- The Attorney General has given an important opinion in regard to the anti-trust law of the last General Assembly. That law provides that the Secretary of State shall address inquiries to all the corporations organized under the laws of or doing business in the State, as to whether they are violating the provisions of the act by unlawfully combining or merging their corporate existence in any other company.
It is just six years ago that I first traveled the coast from Gorrans Haven to Zoze Point.

The Corporation Counsel's office in Brooklyn so dislikes William J.
