Gaynor, merely because he won the Ziegler water case, that it was used on Friday to promulgate false statements about a decision of the Court of Appeals which, if they had been true, would have absolutely destroyed the value of $1,000,000 worth of bonds now held by individuals, estates, and trust companies.

Beginning with this sixth month of the year, upward of 500 meetings have already been arranged for the light-harness performers, a programme unparalleled in the history of the sport. The scores of nurseries in every State yield youthful aspirants for honors at the trotting or pacing gait in such profusion that tracks and trainers have multiplied proportionately to meet the demand and furnish engagements for the equine horde.

Capt. John Faunce, for fifty years connected with the Revenue Marine Service of the United States Government, died a his home, 67 Atlantic Street, Jersey City, Friday, in the eighty-fifth year of his age. His death was sudden. Friday was the fiftieth anniversary of the signing of his commission as an employe of the Revenue Marine Service, he having been appointed June 5, 1841.

Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court has handed down a decision refusing to vacate an assessment for personal taxes upon $150,000 invested by Edward Luckemeyer of Paris in the firm of Scherer, Schramm Vogel of this city. The assessment was sought to be vacated on the ground that Mr. Luckemeyer was indebted to the firm in the sum of $374,500.

The determination of President LOW and the Trustees of Columbia College to place the Law School of that institution upon the basis of a university department has been the occasion for an unseemly amount of personal feeling and bitter discussion. It was a part of the general plan of broad development for the chief institution of higher education in this city and in the line of progress in its work.

The sixth annual Spring games of the cadets of St. Paul's Cathedral School, Garden City, L.I., were held yesterday afternoon. The attendance was larger than usual. The weather was beautiful for outdoor sports, and the events on the programme were interesting and well contested. Several school records were broken.

There are few places in Europe about which the world at large knows so little as the eastern portion of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, with its startling contrasts between the abject poverty of the peasantry on the one hand and on the other a wealth in which barbaric and medieval magnificence are often strangely blended with the quintessence of nineteenth-century civilization and refinement.

The market was well supplied during the earlier days of last week with strawberries of good variety and of good quality, but toward the close of the week they became scarcer, with the result of increasing prices, and large shipments of Western Maryland berries for the Saturday's market. Consequently, to-day the people of this city may eat at moderate cost some of the finest strawberries grown in America.

LONDON, June 6. -- Brandon Thomas and Weedon Grossmith, two extremely clever young actors, who will be remembered with Rosina Vokes in America six years ago, began to-night the novel experiment at Terry's Theatre of an entertainment comprising three distinct little comedies, timed for 8, 9, and 10 o'clock respectively, each written by one or the other, and presenting both in most characteristic roles.

With the opening of the outing season the attention of the philanthropic is once more called to the "Little Mothers' Aid Society." It is hardly more than a year old, but presents a record of wise and beneficent charity of the kind that pays, which any older society might well be proud to acknowledge. But its work is peculiar, reaching a class that is helped by no other charitable organization.

OTTAWA, June 6. -- Sir John Macdonald, Premier of the Dominion, died to-night at 10:15 o'clock. He never rallied from unconsciousness and passed quietly away. The bulletin sent out by the attendant physician, Dr. Powell, early this morning announced that there was no change worthy of comment to be discerned in his patient's condition, and that he had passed a night of heavy sleep.

In his annual report to the members of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchanged President Charles G. Wilson says that for the year ending May 30 the Exchange has prospered. In the department devoted to trading in railroad stocks the clearances of the transactions of the year aggregated 75,806,990 shares. The system of clearing is declared to be an unqualified success. In a prophetic vein Mr. Wilson says:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 6. -- James A. Bradley, the New-York manufacturer, the founder and original owner of this famous prohibition resort, stirred up a hornets' nest at the last meeting of the Board of Borough Commissioners, of which he is the President, by announcing to his colleagues that he would not permit the electric lights to burn all night on his board walk and beach pavilions.

BRUNSWICK, June 6. -- The Commencement parts have been assigned as follows: Salutatorian -- Cutts; Speakers -- Cilley, Croswell, Chapman, Dyer, Fish-Nelson, E.H. Newbegin, Smith, and Horne. The programme for the week is as follows:

LONDON, June 6. -- These dispatches, having for years reflected a derisive attitude toward the British tendency to sit down and rest every few days, I hasten to say that for once the accustomed Saturday holiday comes as a genuine boon to mankind. Although we must take up our cross again next week, it is a great blessing to have even a single day's respite from the scandal of the baccarat trial.
KINGSTON, N.Y., June 6. -- The Rev. Octavius Applegate, Jr., of Newburg, who was recently ordained, has accepted the rectorship of St. John's Episcopal Church at Ellenville, Ulster County.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 6. -- George W. Dupre, one of the editors and proprietors of the Daily Evening States, and Dr. S.R. Olliphant, President of the State Board of Health, had an impromptu duel this afternoon, during which Dupre received a wound in the jaw.

The franchise which the Rapid-Transit Commission will presently offer for sale is believed to be, all things considered, the most valuable that the city of New-York will ever have at its disposal, and it is believed that it will not be obtained short of a sharp competition and a good price. Some idea of the enormous tide of travel awaiting the new system may be deduced from the statistics of travel in the past.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 6. -- A curious case, involving a rich man's anxiety to arrange a marriage for his daughter and a lawyer's rascality, is on trial in the civil court here. It is the suit of A.L. Robelot against Anatole Brieugne and Aristide Gelpi.

BALTIMORE, June 6. -- Jacob Bonnett committed suicide in Druid Hill Park last Wednesday. He was the trusted financial agent of a great many confiding Germans, and was the controlling factor in various building associations. His character as a devoted church member and conservative citizen was well-established, and the fact of his self-destruction created general astonishment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 6. -- When Daniel N. Lockwood was elected to Congress last Fall, he announced himself a candidate for Speaker. Now Daniel N. Lockwood takes part in the Courier-Sheehan-Seheu row by announcing himself a conditional candidate for Governor.

BERLIN, June 6. -- If popular discontent were allowed to manifest itself on free lines against the Government's decision to maintain the corn duties, Germany would be ablaze with demonstrations. Since Chancellor von Caprivi surprised the country, including the agrarian party, with his declaration that the existing tariff must remain until, at least, new treaty negotiations with other nations were arranged, the dissatisfaction among workingmen has become exasperation.

Mayor Grant had his day's outing at Morris Park yesterday afternoon. "Dick" Croker, his political creator, was on hand to see that he enjoyed the sport. "Ed" Stokes was there to lend assistance in case any was needed in looking after the Mayor, and ex-Register John Reilly was there to take a hand in affairs if there should be any trouble among the politicians.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 6. -- The Trustees of the Newport Land Trust Company, which owned the most valuable part of Easton's Point just beyond the bathing beach, are developing plans for the material improvement of that section. In addition to five cottages already erected, there are now under construction thirteen cottages, some of which will be ready for occupancy this season.

Concerning the purchase with the Chantrey bequest of Calderon's "Saint Elizabeth of Hungary" the severest things are said to the Royal Academicians. The Saturday Review likens the introduction of a naked Saint Elizabeth to the French pictures in which nudity is out of place because under the circumstances depicted it would be indecent for a woman to appear without her clothes.

ST. LOUIS, June 6. -- The cornerstone of the new City Hall, a structure that will cost a million and a half of dollars, was laid at 3 o'clock this afternoon under the auspices of the Masons. The Grand Lodge of the State and all of the subordinate lodges of the city were represented, having marched in a body from Masonic Hall.
There are two kinds -- the NATURAL and the IMITATION.

ST. LOUIS, June 6. -- There has been an exceedingly bitter fight beneath the surface between the German Catholics and other Catholics over the preparations for the celebration of the golden jubilee of Archbishop Kenrick. The celebration commemorative of the semi-centennial of the elevation to Bishopric of that venerable prelate will be on a grand scale.

The Mayor of Philadelphia has written to the President of the United States a personal and official letter which, we should say, must give to Mr. HARRISON food for much reflection. The author of the letter is a Republican, and, being a Philadelphia Republican at that, it is needless to say that he is incapable of writing anything that can disturb Mr. HARRISON'S peace of mind unless he be compelled.

The Pastime Athletic Club held its fifteenth annual picnic and games at the Empire City Colosseum yesterday. About 500 people were present to enjoy the dancing and other amusements provided. The games started at 3 o'clock and lasted until long after dark. The referee was J.E. Sullivan of the New-Jersey Athletic Club. The events were as follows:

BALTIMORE, June 6. -- After the delay in the racing at Pimlico yesterday it cleared sufficiently to go on this afternoon, and all the classes but one were taken up and finished. None were of special moment, but there was a sensation to wind up the meeting. There had been an investigation of the stake race which was begun on Wednesday and was a mixed affair of nine hosts.

Just one game divides the New-York and Chicago Club for first place in the League race. This state of affairs was brought about yesterday, when the New-Yorks won their eighth successive game and Chicago was beaten by Brooklyn. The Giants have gained steadily on the Western aspirants for championship honors since their return home and the probabilities are that they will be in first place before long.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Mr. Cleveland's opponents are still trying to make capital out of the failure of the Kentucky Democratic Convention to pass a resolution indorsing the ex-President, and, if their organs are to be believed. Kentucky wants anybody but Cleveland for the Presidential candidate next year.

The Republican managers have been watching the progress of affairs in the Seventh Senatorial District during the past week with far more than ordinary interest. They see in the present condition of the Democratic forces in that district every indication that they can gain a State Senator there this year, and there is certainly a fair foundation for their hopes.

ALBANY, June 6. -- The Forest Commission has not yet begun suit against the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company for trespass, although it is well known that the company's surveyors have cut down many trees on the State hatchery lands in Township 20, Franklin County. Under the law there would seem to be no reason to doubt that the company could be made to pay dearly for the damage it has already caused.

As June 20, the date of the New-London races, draws near, interest in the prowess of the six competing college crews increases day by day. Each boat has its admirers, and each man is making the most of the short time that remains to win for himself and his crew the merit of that admiration. Columbia is the first crew to reach New-London for preliminary practice.

The departure of Mr. PEARY'S party marks the practical beginning of a series of expeditions which during the present year and the next should greatly extend our knowledge of the arctic regions. The most elaborately prepared of these expeditions, and the one latest in starting, will be the Norwegian enterprise of NANSEN, which aims to reach the pole by trying the ocean route, as the Jeannette did.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 6. -- Roger Q. Mills of Corsicana, Texas, who aspires to be Speaker of the next National House of Representatives, came to town this morning, as he claimed, on private business, which he said would keep him here several days. He however put in the afternoon at the races and left for Washington on this evening's train.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 6. -- From the present aspect of things political in this vicinity and over a greater part of Northern Ohio, the Hon. Charles Foster, Secretary of the Treasury and boss wire-puller of all the politicians of Ohio, has pulled down a hornets' nest about his ears that will result in somebody getting seriously stung before the 15th day of next November.

BOSTON, June 6. -- Hitherto the Methodist Episcopal Church has escaped from the turmoil which now so generally characterizes the ecclesiastical world. To be sure, it has had its controversy over the participation of women in its government, but that has simply caused division of sentiment on questions of polity and has not affected vital doctrines.

It will be safer and better for the Attorney General of the State to waste no time in getting promises from Dr. SEWARD WEBB or his representatives. The builders of railroads are notoriously among the most aggressive and enterprising of created beings. With them possession is nine points of the law, and they trust to the delays and uncertainties of the law itself for the other point.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6. -- The largest crowd that has ever visited this classic town came to-day to witness one of the finest games of baseball ever played on the Princeton diamond. Every train brought in hundreds of people during the day, including one special train run from New-York in two sections. It is estimated that 5,000 people were on the grounds when the game began.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6. -- Harvard rowing is in a very unsatisfactory condition just now, and things have begun again to look pretty gloomy for the crimson's crews. The 'Varsity crew seems fated with set-backs, accidents and disappointments, and the most recent of these circumstances has come in the shade of an injury to Capt. Perkins that will prevent his rowing before the crew leaves for New-London to begin work on the Thames.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., June 6. -- The season at the Thousand Islands may be said to have fairly begun. Already much activity is noticed along the river in preparation for what is expected to be one of the most successful seasons ever enjoyed. Much is expected from the more efficient train service of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad under the management of the New-York Central.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The marriage of Miss Sophie Wilkins De Suzzara Verdi, daughter of Dr. Tullio Verdi, to Mr. Alfred Jerome Weston of New-York, took place this evening in St. Paul's Church. The Rev. Alfred Harding, rector, officiated.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of the university is to be preached by the Rev. J. Stewart Stone at St. Mary's Episcopal Church to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, June 6. -- Newspaper news in this section has received an important contribution in the removal of the office of the Dispatch into a handsome new building at Smithfield and Diamond Streets, across the way from its old quarters. The new structure has a frontage of 100 feet, and is 120 feet in depth. It houses one of the finest newspaper plants in the country.

" The ladies of the White House congratulate Mr. Mansfield upon the success of his charming play," was written on a card which was sent to Don Juan at the close of the performance at the Garden Theatre last Tuesday night. The play begins the fourth week of its career tomorrow evening. The temperature of the theatre has been lowered by artificial means, so that the house is perfectly comfortable on the warmest nights.
It is beginning to be accepted that Summer stay-at-homes in New-York are not the most-to-be-pitied of mortals. Here is an experience which a man tells:

Laurence Oliphant's name was not extensively known on this side the Atlantic. A book which perhaps might have made it so, "The Tender Recollections of Irene Macgillicuddy," though written by him, was not issued at first under his name, and his books of travel had enjoyed much greater popularity in his own land than here.

When a yachting outfit first came to be a necessity in the Summer wardrobe, it was the correct thing to copy the rig of the jolly tar. Now seafaring young women look higher for a model, and turn themselves out as faultlessly gotten-up naval officers.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- The Summer season is close at hand, but the Summer season in Chicago is not the dull and unprofitable one that it is in many other cities. The best attractions are put on here during that period. A.M. Palmer's, Augustin Daly's, Daniel and Charles Frohman's companies play profitable engagements, and the annual spectacular extravaganza at the Chicago Opera House coins money for four months.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 6. -- The programme for the seventy-ninth Commencement of Hamilton College will be as follows:

As the annual examinations at the United States Military Academy have just been concluded, thousands of schoolboys and others throughout the country are deeply interested in the subject of West Point. There is, perhaps, not one in ten of them who has not cogitated at some time or another or who is not now cogitating whether he would be an ornament to the army and could not distinguish himself as an Indian fighter.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The consideration of the recommendations in connection with the constitution of the Federal Synod of the Reformed Church (Dutch) in America and the Reformed Church (German) in the United States which were adopted yesterday at the Synod of the latter body, now in progress at the First Reformed Church, was the special business for to-day's session.

A suit of more than usual interest was decided in the Supreme Court for Westchester County, at White Plains, last week, by Mr. Justice Barnard. The action was for ejectment to recover possession of 145 acres of land under water, surrounding City Island, in the East River, and constituting a strip of land under water nearly three miles long by 400 feet wide.

In the last seven years there have been found in the asylums and almshouses of this State and sent back to their homes in Europe 1,374 lunatics, idiots, or otherwise disabled paupers who had been shipped to this country by associations, cities, or towns that sought in this way to avoid the expense of supporting them.

SARATOGA, June 6. -- Warm days and cool nights -- typical June weather -- is what the so journers here have been enjoying since the first of the month. Cottagers are taking possession of their Summer homes, the boarding houses and small hotels are filling, and the population is gradually increasing and will continue growing until the Sunday nearest the 15th of August, which period is considered the apex of the season.

IQUIQUE, Chile, June 6. via Galveston. -- An interview with the officers of the Itata to-day confirms the news that the arms and ammunition were not embarked at San Diego, Cal., but were transferred from the American schooner Robert and Minnie to the Itata many miles from the coast.

The mounted searchers went up the road along which Bell and I had come, and the sound of their excited voices could be heard long after the tramping of the horses' hoofs died out. After a short consultation we decided to stick to the road for the present. It certainly led northward, and the walking along it was preferable to blundering blindly through the woods and across half-cleared fields.

Among those who are to be guests of the Hotel Earlington at Richfield Springs the coming season are Commodore John S. Dickerson and family, Judge Rufus B. Cowing and family, Col. John R. Fellows, Mr. M.P. Breslin and family, Mr. W.H. Gelshenen and family, C.D. Pearce and family, and a long list of other New-York people who know the Earlington to be a good place to go to.

LENOX, Mass., June 6. -- New-York people have been coming up to Lenox in large numbers this week. Many of them say that they came on earlier than they expected to on account of the hot weather of the past week, while others have come on early so as to get settled in their cottages before the Turnure-Lanier wedding.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7. -- Six years ago W.G. Oliver, a farmer, living about six miles southeast of Corning, in Adams County, was mysteriously missing. On search his team was found tied near the bank of One Hundred and Two River, and not far off lay some of his clothing. As he was in serious financial straits, it was supposed that he had committed suicide, but dragging the river failed to locate his remains.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 7. -- Just at the present time the secret political societies of Kansas are making no end of trouble. They control the politics of the State and have gotten themselves and the parties to which they are auxiliary into such a tangle that the wisest heads acknowledge that they do not know how to proceed.

Gen. O'BEIRNE, the Assistant Superintendent of Immigration at this port, tells a correspondent in Washington the following story about the shipment of paupers from England to this country by way of Canada:

ANNAPOLIS, June 7. -- In a day or two the events of examination week, which always furnish the officers and their families with interesting topics of conversation, will have ceased to be engrossing, and the Summer routine will be taken up by the instructors.
-- The Putnams expect to issue the third volume of the Talleyrand memoirs some time in July.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 7. -- The political situation in this State is somewhat peculiar and decidedly alarming to the Republicans who have always assumed to be leaders in their party. The Alliance has become a new and much-feared element in the political warfare of the State, an element that refuses to be ridiculed out of existence, and, so far, has not been argued into the much-desired nothingness.

ALBANY, June 7. -- To-morrow the committee which has undertaken, at Gov. Hill's bidding, to "vindicate" the canal management and the Sheehan brothers will resume its work in this city. If the present arrangement holds, another adjournment will be taken Tuesday for a week to enable Gen. McMahon to attend the annual meeting of the Directors of the National Soldiers Home at Dayton, Ohio.

If the office of President of the United States is to be set up as the object of a deal or dicker, it is obvious that the man who shall lend himself to such a transaction is one whom the public cannot trust, and that he is therefore one unworthy of the nomination.

WEST POINT, June 7. -- The army girl went to church to-day in furs. A breeze from the northeast with walrus teeth took possession of the post from an early hour and drove the fair maidens to Winter wraps and the matrons indoors.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 7. -- The country is plunged in mourning. Canada's greatest statesman is dead. Throughout the vast Dominion to-day the tolling of church bells indicated the grief of the entire nation.

In the current number of the proceedings of the Royal Artillery Institution, Capt. G.J.F. Talbot, R.A., contributes along article on a subject that greatly interests officers of the American Army and Navy. He gives the first authentic account of the armor-plate trials that recently took place at the Ochta Naval Polygon at St. Petersburg.

During the present year the appointment of young men from civil life to Second Lieutenancies in the army, which, save for a single exceptional instance, has been discontinued for a very long time, will be renewed and carried to a remarkable extent. The reason is to be found in recent legislation which resulted in the retirement of scores of officers on the active list, in addition to those affected by previous laws.
An "inspired" editorial in the United Service Gazette on the weakness of the English Navy as compared with that of France, concludes as follows:

The three political shepherds have another grievance to talk about with Secretary FOSTER. Three or four months ago several bales of common goat hair were imported by a merchant. At that time goat hair was supposed to be on the free list, as it had been before the enactment of the McKinley tariff, and these bales were admitted free of duty.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 7. -- Complete returns of yesterday's election in this city show that the Republicans have elected their entire city ticket by majorities ranging from 436 for Mayor to 919 for City Treasurer. They have also secured control of the City Council by a vote of 8 to 5, an exact reversal of the present political complexion of that body.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Pursuant to the authority invested in him by the act of Congress approved March 3 last, for the safe transportation and humane treatment of export cattle from the United States to foreign countries, Secretary Rusk has issued a series of regulations for vessels engaged in such transportation. These, in substance, are as follows:

The Street-Cleaning Aid Society, organized recently to do what it could to bring something equivalent to cleanliness out of the uncleanliness that characterizes New-York's streets, is making noteworthy headway. Working on lines that are practical beyond all contradiction, though perhaps not as comprehensive and radical as many might desire, the society is slowly but surely overcoming some existing evils.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7. -- Baccalaureate Sunday of Princeton University's one hundred and fifty-fourth annual Commencement was celebrated to-day, and, although it was rainy, the town was filled with strangers. On the ringing of the bell in the ivy-covered tower of Old North College the students were marshaled by Prof. Tibley, and, preceded by the Faculty, clad in the academic cap and gown, marched to Marquand Chapel.

The discoveries of the Health Department concerning the condition of a large herd of cows at Carmel give new force to the suggestion we have repeatedly made that the dairy herds from which the milk used in this city comes should be carefully inspected by persons who are able to detect the presence of bovine tuberculosis.

LONDON, June 7. -- There was a moderate demand for discount during the past week. Quotations were 3 for three months and 2 1/2 for short. The Bank of England reserve yesterday was 18,000,000, a further amount of 2,250,000 coming from Australia and New-York. Even with the contingent of gold withdrawals by Russia the monetary position is strong and the future well provided for.

Although for reasons that any admirer of the late Mr. HENRY BERGH will appreciate, ex-Speaker REED is not likely ever to assume in person the role of the "man on horseback," his moral fitness for it should make him an object of interest to a certain faction in Paris, where he is now spending his time.

Yesterday morning at the 11 o'clock mass at the Roman Catholic Cathedral the Archbishop spoke on the Pope's encyclical letter, the authorized English version of which arrived in this city from Rome Saturday afternoon. The cathedral was crowded, informal announcement of the text of the Archbishop's remarks having been given out late Saturday night.

At least four large trout, each weighing more than two pounds and a half, and one of them turning the scales at three pounds, have been caught in the Beaverkill this season. All were caught below Shin Creek or Lew Beach, and only one between that point and Westfield Flats. The writer had the good fortune to capture the fish last spoken of.

PARIS, June 7. -- The race for the Grand Prize of Paris, of 100,0001, for colts and fillies foaled in 1888, distance about one mile and seven furlongs, was run to-day and won by M. Edmond Blanc's ch. c. Clamart, by Saumur, out of Princess Catherine. The same owner's b c. Reverend, by Energy-Reveuse, ran second, and M.H. Delamarre's ch. c. Clement, by Vigilant-Clelie, third.

Last evening the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of the University of the City of New York was preached by the Vice Chancellor, the Rev. Henry M. MacCracken, at the University Place Church. Dr. MacCracken was assisted in the services by the Rev. J.B. Steel, D.D., rector of the First Presbyterian Church of this city. The subject of the sermon was "Front Places."

The Rev. Dr. Burrill of the Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, preached a sermon on the "Inerrancy of the Scriptures" yesterday, in the course of which he gave some bitter thrusts at the higher criticism.

Miss Laura Jean Libby, the novelist, has become interested in two convicts, one of whom, George A. Harrison, is serving an eighteen-year sentence in Sing Sing for burglary, and the other, named Reilly, is in Auburn Prison for a similar offense. Miss Libby is going to Albany to present in person the cases to the Governor.

This is the question all Canada is asking to-day. The death of the old chieftain removes the one barrier to the beginning of political changes of so far-reaching a character as to be of supreme importance to the Dominion and to interest in no slight degree both the United States and Great Britain. It leaves the party he has controlled so long and so absolutely in a state of confusion and anarchy.

ST. LOUIS, June 7. -- The retreat of the Passionist Fathers just completed at Normandy, eight miles from St. Louis, and named the Retreat of Our Lady of Good Counsel, was dedicated to-day with impressive ceremonies.

Mrs. Grover Cleveland has been driving back and forth daily for two weeks between Joseph Jefferson's residence and Tudor Haven, the ex-President's new Summer home on the shore of Buzzard's Bay. Tudor Haven has been undergoing extensive alterations, and in the meantime Mrs. Cleveland has been the guest of Joseph Jefferson. She has been busier than a bee superintending the things in and out of doors at her new Summer home.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Harrison and the State Department people are hard at work preparing the agreement for a close season for the seals in Bering Sea, so that the document may be all ready for the signatures just as soon as the Seal Fisheries act finally passes the British Parliament. The greater part of yesterday, up to a late hour last night, was spent by the President in this work.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 7. -- Nothing has occurred recently so gratifying to the Foraker wing of the Republican Party as the embarrassment of Gen. Grosvenor, the Chairman of the Immigration Committee, who was to spend a few months abroad at the expense of the Government. The utterances of the ex-Congressman were decidedly emphatic in referring to the demands of foreign-born citizens, and have created a sensation.

LONDON, June 7. -- The thoroughfares of London were strangely silent to-day, owing to the absence of 'buses. There was a plentiful supply of cabs, however, and Londoners accepted the discomfort of the situation with good humor, the weather being fine, but on the resumption of business to-morrow morning there promises to be some hearty grumbling. John Burns and his colleagues were active the whole of last night organizing pickets.

In the small inland city of Barranquilla, in South America, there recently lived an odd little old man, whose business was that of money lender. The pawnbrokers' well-known sign of three gilt balls was never seen in front of his establishment, but instead there was a curious inscription, which, translated, read "The cold dead hand."

LANSING, Mich., June 7. -- There is intense excitement here to-night, and the sessions of the Legislature in both Senate and House to-morrow evening are looked forward to with interest. The Detroit Free Press this morning came out with a two-column article declaring that the Detroit Tribune's allegations of bribery brought against Senator Friedlander by Mayor Solomon of Au Sable are utterly false.

WEST POINT, June 7. -- THE TIMES has already spoken of the old-fashioned and antiquated ordnance at West Point. It is a remarkable commentary on the enterprise of the Government that an institution, admittedly the first of its kind in the world, is without the modern implements for the instruction of its students.

Once more the wisdom of giving the public a chance to enjoy the privileges of the Metropolitan Museum of Art Sunday was demonstrated yesterday. It was a cool and lowering day on which, one would naturally think, but few would go abroad expressly for the purpose of visiting the Museum. But in spite of this fact there were nearly as many as there were on the previous Sunday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 7. -- The Republican State Convention will be held in Columbus June 16 and 17. It promises to be an exceptionally large and a most lively one, and candidates for places on the State ticket are unusually numerous. With the exception of the head of the ticket, Auditor of State and Supreme Court Judge, the fight will be close and exciting. Candidates will be nominated for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Auditor of State.

Diary of a Pilgrimage, and Six Essays. By Jerome K. Jerome. One hundred Illustrations by G.G. Fraser. New-York : Henry Holt Co. 1891. -- Mr. Jerome writes little plays -- and when we go to see them we are apt to wish we were at home with one of those fanny books of his in hand, one of those books which London reviewers find excruciatingly jocose.

This is not the time in the history of the Democratic Party for it to engage in making new political combinations. We do not believe that there is any other Democrat who can lead the party to success next year but Grover Cleveland. We believe that the nomination of a Western man will lose to the Democracy at least seventy-one Electoral votes in the Middle and Eastern States.

PASADENA, Cal., June 7. -- An electric railroad, it is announced, is soon to be built from Pasadena to the summit of the Sierra Madres Mountains, directly back from the city. Prof. T.S.C. Lowe, the banker scientist, is promoter of the enterprise, which has long been talked of, to accommodate the travel to the peak, which is almost great enough now to be a paying investment, and that over a hard and circuitous trail.
My attention has been called to an editorial article in THE TIMES of June 7 making a personal attack upon me in connection with the administration of the Columbia College Law School.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 8. -- B.M. Clark, Postmaster of Old Jefferson, Rutherford County, and proprietor of a store at that place, was assassinated last night. The deed has created great excitement at Old Jefferson, and the Sheriff and citizens are searching for the murderer. Mr. Clark, who was twenty-eight years of age and very popular, had spent the evening at the residence of Miss Susie Wade.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- When Mr. Matthew Stanley Quay called at the White House to-day it was with no fear that he would be told again to call some other day, as the President was too busy to talk with him. That was Quay's experience the last time he had undertaken to see the President, but this time he had received assurances that he would not be snubbed.

It was Welch's turn yesterday to show that his arm has not lost its cunning. He did so. In the nine innings the Pittsburgs only made five hits, and barely escaped a "whitewash." Welch was in first-class form, and he sent the ball whizzing over the plate in a manner delightful to behold.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 8. -- It is expected that Wednesday next, the day on which Sir John is to be buried, will be marked by a general cessation from business, and memorial services will be held simultaneously with the time of the funeral in the churches throughout the cities and towns of the Dominion.

Rudolph G. Lexow, banker and broker at 906 Third Avenue, corner of Fifty-fourth Street, made an assignment yesterday to Maurice Meyer, giving a preference for $100. Mr. Lexow did business under the style of R.G. Lexow Co., his brother, Charles K. Lexow, having formerly been a partner, but withdrew some time ago. The business was started in January, 1884, R.G. Lexow also sold European drafts and steamship tickets.

LONDON, June 8. -- Sir William Hart Dyke, Vice President of the Committee of Council on Education, in the House of Commons to-day introduced the Government's long-talked-of Education bill, and it passed the first reading.

If the Board of Aldermen is going to express itself upon the propriety of having Battery Park occupied for railroad purposes, the time to do so is manifestly before and not after the Park Board has acted upon the question before it. The object of such an expression should be to accomplish something in behalf of the public, and it will be of no use when the question has been decided.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 8. -- In the great dining hall at Earnscliffe the remains of its master lie this morning. The casket stands on a pedestal in the centre of the room, and all the appointments are most imposing. The hangings are of violet and white. When all was ready the metallic casket containing the body was carried down stairs from the room in which the Premier passed away.

According to our Washington dispatches this morning, Mr. FOSTER said yesterday that he was in favor of the extension of the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds due Sept. 1 at 2 per cent. He said that "such a course would raise the credit of the Government and at the same time enable the national banks to increase their circulation, a thing greatly needed after the recent heavy shipments of gold."

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 8. -- The failure of G.B. Merritt Co. here also involves the firm of Merritt Finger, grocers and commission merchants. Another chattel mortgage on the goods and chattels of George B. Merritt Co. has been filed in the Ulster County Clerk's office. It is in favor of Noah Wolven, the Postmaster of the Kingston Post Office, for $10,000 advanced on a note.

The latest accounts of the condition of the Jewish exiles from Russia make the cruelty with which the movement is being carried out more than ever evident. According to the statements in the dispatches to the English press the outrages perpetrated by the guards on the road are simply indescribable. Many of the women and children perish on the journey to the southwestern provinces.

LONDON, June 8. -- In the House of Lords to-day, Lord Salisbury moved the second reading of the bill to enable her Majesty, by order in council, to make special provision for prohibiting the catching of seals in Bering Sea by her Majesty's subjects during the period named in the order.
There are two kinds -- the NATURAL and the IfITTION.

ST. LOUIS, June 8. -- Dispatches from several points along the Red River in Texas indicate that that stream is on the rampage. At Gainesville it is above the high-water mark, and information is to the effect that the rise was very rapid and unexpected and many people barely escaped with their lives. All communication with the Indian Territory has been out off and it will be some time before the damage can be repaired.

Secretary J.M. Rusk of the Department of Agriculture was in New-York yesterday. He came from Washington to attend to some minor matters relating to the inspections of meats which are designed for export. He returned to Washington yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, June 8. -- This was the sixth day of the trial of the suit brought by Sir William Gordon Cumming against Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Lycett Green, and Mr. Berkeley Levett, for damages on account of alleged slanderous statements made by them in regard to baccarat playing at Tranby Croft, near Doncaster, in September last.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Several offers for the extension of 4 1/2 per cent. bonds were received at the Treasury Department this morning. One was of $600,000 at the rate of 2 per cent. This came from a private citizen. The others were at any rate the department decided on. They were all from Western banks.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Ever since Mr. Maxwell was voted out of the office of Superintendent of Insurance by the Senate, at the instigation of Gov. Hill, there has been a quiet pruning going on among the clerks in the Insurance Department. The civil service rules stood in the way of making any appointments except those of a confidential nature.

Having disposed practically of their case before the Park Commissioners, the citizens who are leading in the movement to save Battery Park are turning their attention to the Board of Aldermen. They do not see any reason why the Railroad Committee should defer action upon the resolution sent to it last week.

Railroad men both East and West are in a state of perplexity over the West Shore-Canadian Pacific differential. It is apparent that Commissioner Goddard's decision allowing the West Shore Road a differential of 7 cents on St. Paul freight business over the Canadian Pacific pleased nobody. The West Shore people have not yet taken the trouble to say whether or not they will accept the differential allowed.

ST. LOUIS, June 8. -- Gen. John McNeil dropped dead in his office here this evening. He was Superintendent of Station E of the St. Louis Post Office. He was apparently in good health and returned yesterday from a meeting of the Loyal Legion in Kansas.

You will greatly oblige me, and the family which I represent, if you will have published in your paper the letter of which I inclose a copy. The letter explains itself. It was handed to Miss Donlevy, the Secretary of the so-called "Woman's Memorial Fund Association," on Thursday, May 28, the Secretary refusing to give Mrs. Thompson's address, and on the 30th Miss Donlevy sent word that the letter had been received by Mrs. Thompson.

There will be a special meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment at 11 o'clock this morning for the purpose of hearing what the United Charities Association has to urge in behalf of an application for an appropriation to establish a free lodging house, the first, if successful, of a system of such institutions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 8. -- In his last report of the condition of the wheat in Kansas prior to harvest, which has already begun in the southern tier of counties, Secretary Mohler of the Kansas Board of Agriculture says:

A golden wedding reception was given last night to the Rev. and Mrs. Alfred Pinney in the chapel of Emanuel Baptist Church at Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn, by the young people of the congregation. For fifty-five years the Rev. Mr. Pinney has preached the Gospel, though not for many years has he had a settled charge.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- The great sensation to-day in the Keystone Bank and City Treasury scandals, before the Councils' investigating committee was the appearance of Postmaster General John Wanamaker, who has been generally supposed to have used his official position to prevent the closing of the rotten bank until firm could draw out their own deposits.

QUEBEC, June 8. -- Fire broke out yesterday in the wooded regions of the north shore of the St. Lawrence, and spread with such rapidity that the whole of the Laurentide Mountains were ablaze before night. Captains of schooners trading up the Gulf report that while sailing up seven or eight miles from shore their decks were covered with live embers, so that they had to make for the south shore.

The elevated railroad octopus is making a bold and determined effort to obtain from the city gratuitously special privileges to which the law does not entitle it, and which it is against the public interest to grant. Jay Gould is not too modest to ask for what he wants, nor too scrupulous to take it without asking if the opportunity offers.

The usually calm and rather stupid Brooklyn Aldermen had another quarrelsome session yesterday. The long-winded message from Mayor Chapin and the acceptance of an invitation to a circus caused them to long for some excitement, and they got so much that Alderman Coffey, who presided, became disgusted and left the chair.

ALBANY, June 8. -- The Edward Hannan vindicating combination encountered an obstruction to-day which was not down on the cards. It ran short of witnesses of the variety it requires in its business and was forced to take another holiday in order to give the Sergeant at Arms an opportunity to corrall a sufficient number to enable it to proceed.

There is need of a general co-operation of the citizens and the public authorities in this city in order to get clean streets. The people have been so long accustomed to slovenliness in this matter that they need to be educated on the subject of cleanliness, and the authorities have been so long addicted to negligence that they need some spur to activity.

In issuing the order to the Government agents in Bering Sea to stop the operations of the North American Commercial Company for the season as soon as 7,500 seals have been killed, the President has not only performed a wise and humane act but has arrested before its culmination a scandal that would have seriously impaired the good repute of his Administration.

The turbulent little republic in the West Indies has given another illustration of its inability to govern itself peaceably. Haiti once more steps to the front and demands attention for an abortive insurrection, which appears to have been attended with more than usual fatality.

The regular meeting of the New-York Presbytery took place yesterday afternoon at the lecture room of the Scotch Church, West Fourteenth Street. It had been expected that the committee appointed to conclude on some method of procedure in the case of Prof. Briggs would make its report so that the trial for heresy could begin at the October session of the Presbytery, which is the next one.

Fire was discovered at 6:30 o'clock last evening in the cellar of the dry goods store of Krueder, Kline Krueder, 765, 767, and 769 Broadway, on the southwest corner of Ninth Street. The place had been closed for the evening. Smoke was seen coming through the cellar gratings by a fireman passing the store. The flames were contined to the cellar, and were soon extinguished.

Some new move is about to be made in the Long Island Water Supply scandal, for Mayor Chapin and Controller Jackson submitted a long statement in regard to that malodorous job to the Brooklyn Aldermen yesterday for no other apparent reason than to explain away, if possible, the recent Court of Appeals decision to the effect that the purchase of the company was illegal.

WEST POINT, June 8. -- Senator Manderson and Congressman Burrows returned to day from their visit to Vice President Morton just in time to see the cadets under the direction of the engineer officer, Capt. George McC. Derby, and Lieuts. Lucas and McKinstry, construct the ponton bridge. It was the only military exercises of the day.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Class Day at Princeton is considered by all visitors to the Commencement exercises the gala day of Commencement week. The beautiful day gratified every wish of the young graduates and made their happiness complete, as most of their exercises are held in the open air under the ancient elms and around the old historic cannon.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 8. -- The statutes in this State regulating the appointments of Commissioners by the Governor for the different departments of State supervision and control, in the event of vacancies occurring at a recess of the General Assembly, are as diverse as the duties of the offices for which the selections are to be made.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9. -- This was Class Day at Vassar, and the Class of '91 had charming weather for its festivities. The attendance was large, the decorations appropriate, and the display of dress beautiful. The officers of the class are Martha T. Allen of Red Bank, N.J., President; Eleanor H. Haight of Poughkeepsie, Vice President; Martha E. Rickert of Chicago, Ill., Secretary, and Henrietta A. Houston of New-York, Treasurer.

By superior field work the Brooklyns won another game from the Cleveland Club at Eastern Park yesterday. Both sides batted hard, but the local club made the fewer errors. With the exception of the fifth inning Caruthers pitched a pretty game of ball. At that point, however, the Clevelands made it rather lively for him. They hit the ball in all directions and scored 7 times before the side was retired.

There is to be a Territorial election in Utah in August and there are indications that the people are abandoning their old division as Mormons and anti-Mormons in politics and organizing on the lines of the regular parties. Last October the Mormon Church formally withdrew its sanction of polygamy as an article of religious faith, and it promises to disappear as a factor in politics.

Figuratively speaking, the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge was the scene of a warm conflict yesterday between the new and the old Presidents of the company, with their respective allied forces. In the morning, when President Wagstaff, armed with his new authority, entered the bridge office at Washington and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn, he encountered a big obstacle that effectually prevented him from immediately entering upon his new duties.
" I cannot understand the carelessness of people." This remark was made by a leading New-York chemist who was just making an analysis for the Board of Health.

It is announced from Washington that the statement just issued by the Treasurer of the assets and liabilities of the Treasury will be the last in the present form. The objection to the statement as it stands is a perfectly intelligible one. It is that it shows that the net cash balance in the Treasury is $3,999,000 and no more.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Within the next twenty-four or forty-eight hours Mr. Stephen B. Elkins and the other business friends of James G. Blaine in the North American Commercial Company will undoubtedly learn that their backer in the Cabinet has definitely failed to secure for them the coveted chance to kill all the seals they could find this year.

At this distance of space the strangest thing about the "trial of Sir WILLIAM GORDON CUMMING," as everybody persists in calling it to himself, is that after the verdict the crowd persisted in cheering the plaintiff, who was supposed to have been disgraced by the verdict, and in hissing the defendants whom it was supposed to vindicate.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9. -- Since the State election in Kansas last year a large element in the Farmers' Alliance and People's Party have been acting on the supposition that the Democratic Party was merely a tail to their kite and that in 1892 it would join in with the new reform movement and make the defeat of the Republican Party a certainty. This proposition did not please the leaders of the Democracy in Kansas.

PROVIDENCE, June 9. -- Three races for trotters were decided in ten heats at Narragansett Park this afternoon. The track is in bad shape, the soil being loose and uneven, so that the horses are handicapped several seconds. For all that two young trotters entered the 2:30 list, and Dynamite lowered his record to 2:23 12 in the fast class.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The first exercises of the morning were the exhibition of drawings in the Engineering and Graphics Department in the School of Science and later a microscopic exhibition in the Histological Laboratory in Nassau Hall. The reading of theses by a selected number of the graduating class of the John O. Green School of Science took place this morning in Chemical Hall.

The Board of Aldermen showed a disposition yesterday to set itself right before the people of this city on the Battery Park question. It was made plain that there is to be no dallying with the resolutions offered last week by Alderman MORRIS and referred to the Railroad Committee, and the committee was instructed to make its report at the meeting next Tuesday.

A six-foot young man, garbed in corduroys and sombrero, arrived in Jersey City at 9:25 o'clock last evening on a Pennsylvania Railroad train. A splendid setter dog followed him obediently. The young man was John D. Sargent, the keeper of Robert Ray Hamilton's old ranch in Montana, one of the last persons who saw that unfortunate man alive and one of those who saw and identified his body after it was dragged from Snake River.

A decision has just been rendered by Judge Benedict of the United States District Court, Eastern District of New-York, which is of interest to yachtsmen, as it was brought by Commodore Robert Center of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and owner of the cutter Medusa to test the question whether yachts have an equal right of way in the waters of the United States with vessels engaged in business.

WEST POINT, June 9. -- Life at this spot is proceeding under high pressure nowadays. Girls are pouring in in droves, making the capacity of the hotels insignificant; tennis consumes part of the morning, baseball or strolls up to "Fort Put." or down "Flirtation" and drills the afternoon, and hops every evening are tending to gild life for the youngster and leave memories that will never be obliterated.

LA CROSSE, Wis., June 9. -- The State Farmers' Alliance met in convention in this city this morning, the prime object of the gathering being a discussion of the project to organize all farmers' societies under one head. The convention was presided over by Col. C.M. Butt, President of the State Alliance. One hundred and fifty delegates were present.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9. -- Ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley to-day pleaded guilty to seventeen bills of indictment which were found against him yesterday by the Grand Jury.

The amusement and satisfaction with which the public has read of the capture of the bridge by Mayor GRANT would be unbounded but for the evident distress of the Brooklyn Eagle. Angry and confluent blotches of language broke out upon the editorial page of that journal toward sunset yesterday, indicating extensive inflammation in its vocabulary laboratory.

ALBANY, June 9. -- The fact that plans have been prepared for a connection between Dr. W. Seward Webb's new Adirondack Railroad and the Canadian Pacific indicates two things. First, that the proposed road through the Adirondacks is not to be built for pleasure travel into that forest region alone, and, secondly, that the Canadian Pacific-Vanderbilt alliance is to be made still closer.

Mr. William J. Gaynor returned to the attack in the Brooklyn Water Works scandal again yesterday in order to reply to Mayor Chapin's latest statement in defense of his official conduct. In the course of his reply Mr. Gaynor said:
NEW-HAVEN, June 9. -- The Scientific School students who are to read theses at Commencement are as follows:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 9. -- The Syracuse Courier of to-morrow will propose the nomination of Major Alexander H. Davis of this city for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic State ticket next Fall. The Courier will say:

CHICAGO, June 9. -- E.D. Thayer, the aged President of the Brandon National Bank of Brandon, Vt., after transacting some business in Omaha, left that place for Chicago on Friday with a small band sachel containing $40,000 in notes and mortgages. While he was in the dining car en route the bag disappeared, and he has been unable to get any trace or it since.

The agreement for a close season for sealing in Bering Sea is said to be ready for signature, and the British Minister at Washington has the assent of his Government to its terms in advance. It is likely to be promulgated to-day, and with as little delay as practicable the revenue cutter Corwin will start for Alaska with such supplemental orders as the agreement makes necessary.

LONDON, June 9. -- The famous baccarat trial has ended, and, with a verdict for the defendants in his suit for slander, Sir William Gordon Cumming now rests under the stigma of cheating at cards. The trial has lasted seven days, and from the beginning has been attended by large crowds of fashionable people, including very many ladies.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The trial board that recently conducted the unsatisfactory test of the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius has submitted to Secretary Tracy its proposals for the second test that will soon take place. After suggesting that suitable permanent sights be fitted to the guns, the board asks that the best and latest valves be used, and that the vessel then be sent to Annapolis to have its guns ranged accurately.

The one hundred and thirty-seventh annual Commencement of Columbia College, including its Medical Department, was held last evening in the new Music Hall at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. Upon the stage were the President, Faculty, and Trustees of the college, representatives of other universities and colleges, and distinguished guests, while the great auditorium was crowded beyond its seating capacity with the families and friends of the graduating students.

ORANGE, N.J., June 10. -- Orange society turned out in force to-day upon the occasion of the commencement of the tennis tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. Numbers of pretty girls surrounded the courts, and every good play was greeted with applause.

ALBANY, June 10. -- The investigation of the accounts of ex-Warden Brush of Sing Sing, which Gov. Hill has caused his appointee, Warden Brown, to set on foot, is likely to cause David a good deal of trouble in the future. The present indications are that it will give rise to a hubbub that the Democrats will have trouble to quiet in the coming campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The June report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture makes the area in Winter wheat, as compared the breadth harvested last year, 111.5; Spring wheat, 103.4; barley, 107.1; rye, 101.5: oats, 97.9. The condition is: Winter wheat, 96.6; Spring wheat, 92.6; barley, 90.3; rye, 95.4; oats. 85.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 10. -- At 12 o'clock to-day, pursuant to a call by Henry Watterson and J. Stoddard Johnston, the two leading Democratic newspaper men of Kentucky, a conference of about one hundred Democrats from all parts of the State assembled here to take steps toward organizing an opposition to the adoption of the new Constitution.

The managers of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad have made no concealment of their dissatisfaction with the allowance of a seven-cent differential to the West Shore-Canadian Pacific route to the Northwest.

For many weeks we have been trying to draw from several of our high-tariff contemporaries the proof of their repeated-assertions that the Sherman Anti-Trust law was rapidly destroying all the Trusts and similar combinations. They have steadfastly refused to bring forward the evidence. We shall now assist them. We have found a case in which this law has been used for the discomfiture of a combination.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- The one hundred and forty-fourth annual Commencement exercises of Princeton University were held in the First Presbyterian Church to-day. The Trustees, Faculty, Alumni, and undergraduates assembled in front of old Nassau Hall and marched in procession to the church. President Patton presided, while the Board of Trustees occupied the platform to his right and the Faculty on his left.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10. -- There was another gay and brilliant throng of visitors at Vassar, this being Commencement Day. The chapel was without adornment. The strains of Dr. Ritter's march upon the organ announced the coming of the procession of Trustees, Faculty, Alumnae, and candidates for the degrees, and when all were seated President Taylor invoked the Divine blessing.

LONDON, June 10. -- Echoes of the baccarat scandal suit still fill the air. The Solicitor General, Sir Edward Clarke, who argued the case of Sir William Gordon Cumming, is ill and thoroughly exhausted to-day. He has lost the use of his voice, and is obliged to retire from an important case in which he was retained for to-day.

LONDON, June 10. -- Sir William Gordon Cumming was married this morning in the fashionable Holy Trinity Church at Chelsea to Miss Florence Garner of New-York, daughter of Commodore William Garner. Lord Thurlow gave the bride away. Major Vesey Dawson of the Coldstream Guards was the best man. The Rev. Robert Eyton officiated.

The proceedings had yesterday by the Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church at Pittsburg seem to convey a salutary lesson to Presbyterians who are not classified by any prefix. The Reformed Presbyterians are perhaps better known as the Covenanters and it is their pride to maintain the conclusions arrived at by the French logic of JOHN CALVIN with the Scottish tenacity of JOHN KNOX.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Cincinnati made it three straight from the Phillies to-day. Mullane, as usual, was exceedingly effective, only three hits being made off his delivery. Thornton also pitched ball that would have won an ordinary game. Attendance, 2,552. Score:

WEST POINT, June 10. -- Some of the best shooting ever seen at West Point took place this morning at the seacoast battery. It was by members of the second class, in detachments commanded by cadets of the graduating class, under the general command of Lieut. William W. Galbraith, Fifth Artillery. The guns used were two of the old fifteen-inch smooth bores, three eight-inch converted rifles, and a thirteeninch mortar.

BOSTON, June 10. -- Two bills in equity were filed last Monday in the United States Circuit Court for the District of Massachusetts against the West End Street Railway Company of this city, one by the Sprague Electric Railway and Motor Company and the other by the Edison General Electric Company, for alleged infringements of patents held and controlled by the plaintiff corporations.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 10. -- Shortly after day broke this morning those who failed yesterday to obtain an opportunity to view the face of the dead Premier for the last time began to gather at the entrances to Centre Block, awaiting the opening of the doors. As the hours rolled on and the time appointed for the commencement of the funeral ceremonies approached, the excitement increased to a great extent.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 10. -- The State Convention of the Prohibition Party held here to-day was attended by 118 delegates, representing fifty counties. A complete State ticket was nominated and an organization was perfected for an active campaign. Temporary Chairman Turney was loudly cheered when he said that with the liquor vote divided between three parties there is no reason why the Prohibitionists should not carry the State.

The three-aet farce called "A Night's FroXle," an adaptation by Augustus Thomas of a German piece by Von Moser called "The Woman Who Has:Been to Paris," was performed at the Union Square Theatre last night by Helen Barry and her company for the benefit of Mr. Hopkins, the Treasurer of the house. There was the usual Summer night audience, comprising many actors.

Beginning Wednesday, July 1, and continuing six weeks, there will be held at Plymouth, Mass., a Summer School of Applied Ethics. The prospectus, which will be followed soon by a larger programme, shows three departments, including a department of Economics, in charge of Prof. H.C. Adams of the University of Michigan, who will deliver eighteen lectures on the "History of Industrial Society in England and America, Beginning with the Middle Ages."

The little room in the Custom House in which the Civil Service Examining Board has its headquarters was crowded and hot yesterday from the time Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt met the investigating committee of the Twenty-first Assembly District Republicans until, three hours later, he adjourned the session to this morning at 11 o'clock.

Senator James L. Push of Alabama was at the Hoffman House yesterday. He had just come from the West Point Military Academy, where, as one of the Board of Examiners, he had been for a week looking into the affairs of the institution and aiding in the preparation of reports on its condition. He was very enthusiastic in his good words for the institution.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Fire broke out at 10 o'clock this morning in the fuel room on the fifth floor of Campbell Co.'s cotton mill at Manayunk, a suburb of this city, and before the flames were gotten under control the building and its contents had been damaged to the extent of $250,000. The burned structure was seven stories in height, 510 feet long and 50 feet in width, and contained 450 looms.

The rival bride Presidents, Col. Wagstaff and ex-Mayor Howell, had another inning yesterday, the outcome of which was decidedly in favor of the gentleman whom Tammany put in control of the great highway between the two cities on Monday last.
LONDON, June 11. -- Sir William Gordon Cumming has resigned from all the clubs of which he was a member.

Our neighbor, the New-York Tribune, on April 24 published in its editorial columns some interesting assertions about the condition of the domestic tin-plate industry. We could not overlook the following remarks:

At the Church of St. Francis Xavier yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, Miss Gertrude Tack was married to Joseph Austin Farley. A large number of invitations had been sent out and nearly 1,500 guests were present. At each end of the chancel rail were immense urns of white flowers.

The process of educating the people of this country on the tariff question has been going on for the last three years, and has made great progress toward a general understanding of the effect of that particular form of taxation. But there is equal need of educating the people on the subject of State and local taxation.

ROCHESTER, June 10. -- Two of ex-President Grover Cleveland's nieces, the daughters of the Hon. I.T. Yeomans, were married to-day at Walworth, Wayne County. Mrs. Yeomans, the brides' mother is the ex-President's sister. Mr. Cleveland was present, and Mrs. Cleveland was expected to be be among the guests, but she found it impossible to attend and sent her regrets by her husband. Miss Rose Elizabeth Cleveland also sent regrets.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The marriage of Miss Mary Mauro to Lieut. Philip F. Ryan, United States Navy, occurred at noon to-day in Epiphany Church. The ushers were Naval Constructor Steel, Ensign Witherspoon, United States Navy; Mr. Giesy, Mr. Little Hale, and Mr. Jack Biddle. The groom's best man was Mr. Ryan.

ALBANY, June 10. -- When Henry L. Sprague of New-York, of counsel to the Adirondack and St. Lawrence Railroad Company, told the Commissioners of the Land Office, on May 28, that the company had acquired title to Township 20, Franklin County, he was a trifle wide of the mark. He should have said that the company had secured all the rights the Upper Saranac Association could give it to the lands in question.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 10. -- Mr. C.F. Saylor, Chairman of the committee appointed by the Young Men's Republican Club of Des Moines to convey to the Hon. J.S. Clarkson the congratulations of the club upon his selection to the Presidency of the Republican National League, has received a reply of acknowledgment, dated at Paris. Referring to his election to the Presidency of the league. Mr. Clarkson says:

CANANDAIGUA, June 10. -- Miss Kate M. Raines, the youngest daughter of Congressman John Raines, was married this evening to J. Harold Kessler of Tonawanda. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J.R. Green, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church, at the Congressman's house in Gorham Street. It was a quiet affair, only relatives of the contracting parties being present. W.R. Van Zandt of Philadelphia acted as groomsman.

Lawyer Edwin M. Wight delivered at the Park Department yesterday his brief, showing that the use of Battery Park by the elevated road is illegal. The brief covers substantially the points previously submitted to the Commissioners by Mr. Wight at last Friday's meeting, supplemented by his interview in THE TIMES. It amplifies the proposition that the powers of the Park Commissioners over the parks are powers delegated to the Commissioners, not inherent in them.

LONDON, Jun 10. -- The now famous appeal of the Bishop of Lincoln, the Right Rev. Edward King, D.D., against the decision of the Archbishop of Canterbury, in regard to charges made against the Bishop of Lincoln of having offended against the established ritual, came up for first hearing to-day before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council.

Civil Service Commissioner ROOSEVELT had another session with the committee of the Twenty-first District Republicans at the Custom House yesterday, and went, with perfect candor and in much detail, into an examination of the methods of administering the civil service rules. On the face of it there is something in this proceeding calculated to make the ordinary official hold his breath.

If the Twenty-first District Republicans who are investigating the Civil Service Examining Board of the Custom House obtained any comfort from yesterday's, hearing they must have found it in something which did not appear on the surface. As on the day before, Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt did not let the investigation lag.

LONDON, June 11. -- A lengthy circular note addressed to the European powers by the Chilean Provisional Junta, the Government representing the insurgent party of Chile, was published in England and on the Continent to-day. In this note the Chilean Junta appeals to the powers to recognize the insurgents as belligerents.

Students, with their friends, sisters, and relatives, crowded the Metropolitan Opera House last night to see the members of the Class of '91 of the University of the City of New-York graduate and receive their diplomas. The Rev. Dr. John Hall was unable to be present to preside, and Vice Chancellor MacCracken conferred the degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- About the 1st of July a general order will be issued by the Secretary of the Treasury directing all officers of the United States Revenue Marine to provide themselves with the regular navy uniform. The new order makes optional the "full dress" and "social dress" and mandatory the "special full dress," "dress," "undress," "service dress," and navy overcoat.

It wouldn't sound nicely to repeat in print what horsemen said yesterday anent the Messrs. J.A. A.H. Morris and their action in the Throg's Neck Stakes for three-year-olds. It was a high-price selling race, and in the list of entries sent out to the press on Wednesday night a very evenly-matched lot of commonplace horses were named as starters, each having a fair chance to win.

The defeat of the Lodge faction in Massachusetts in its attempt to prevent a fair redistricting of the State for the election of Representatives in Congress is a matter for congratulation to all honest and decent Republicans. We regret the inevitable inference that must be drawn from the fact that it cannot be a matter for congratulation to Mr. CABOT LODGE.
TROY, N.Y., June 11. -- What in many instances might have proved a successful swindle has been attempted on the bank of D. Powers Sons of Lansingburg.

ALBANY, June 11. -- The University Convocation of this State will be held this year in the Senate Chamber July 8-10. Chancellor George William Curtis will welcome the members at 10 o'clock A.M. July 9, and President D.J. Hill of Rochester will render the report of the Convocation Council. Then Prof. O.D. Robinson of Albany will give the necrology report.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Following is a copy of President Harrison's reply to Mayor Stuart's letter of June 5, in which the latter submitted copies of resolutions of City Councils requesting all information in the possession of the National Government regarding the affairs of the suspended Keystone National Bank:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 11. -- A political sensation has developed at the Commencement at the Agricultural and Mechanical College. Gov. Jones is ex-officio President of the Board of Trustees, and Commissioner of Agriculture Kolb is a member. Kolb was defeated for Governor by Jones in the last convention, and he is already in the field as the Alliance candidate to succeed Jones next year.

A meeting of representatives of insurance companies doing a general agency business was held yesterday at Sherry's in Fifth Avenue, to receive the report of a committee appointed at a meeting in May to formulate a plan of limiting the commissions of agents to 15 per cent.

The Camorra of Naples and the Mafia of Sicily exist in Apulia (Adriatic provinces of Southern Italy) under the name of Mala Vita, (Evil Life.) It is an organized association, with iron rules. Its object is theft, robberies, and assassinations. It has a council of administration, which divides the profits of the Mala Vita Society from thefts, robberies,

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 11. -- Judge Arnold, in the Court of Common Pleas, to-day delivered an opinion not only of great interest to lawyers and conveyancers but to the myriad title-insurance companies which have sprung up all over the Commonwealth within the last few years.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- The one hundred and thirty-fifth annual Commencement of the University of Pennsylvania took place to-day in the Academy of Music, when degrees were conferred in the arts, philosophy, science, law, veterinary medicine, dental surgery, and divinity. Bishop Perry of Iowa led the opening prayer, the Bachelor's oration was by Philip E. Howard, the law oration by Russell Duane, and the valedictory by Samuel R. Colloday.

The regular meeting of the Northern Pacific Directors set down for next Thursday has been postponed indefinitely, many of the Directors being out of town and no special business being under consideration. President Oakes is now on the line of the road in the Pacific Northwest and Henry Villard, the Chairman of the Board of Directors, is in Berlin. Both are expected to be in this city before the July meeting.

It is a little difficult clearly to grasp the meaning of the discussion going on in the German Parliament as to the suspension or reduction of the duties on grain, because, as in our own country, there is so much partisan politics mixed with the consideration of the Government policy. It looks very much as if Chancellor CAPRIVI had arranged to have his hand forced in this matter.

BOSTON, June 11. -- Gov. Russell again proved his devotion to the principle of civil service reform to-day by the promotion of one of its strongest advocates from the Superior to the Supreme Court bench, Judge James M. Barker of Pittsfield.

Judge McAdam of the Superior Court has given an interesting opinion in a newspaper libel case. An order was procured for the examiration of Vincent A. Witcher, the plaintiff in the suit, but Witcher's counsel objected to the questions which were put to him touching his career in the war of the rebellion. The matter was submitted to Judge McAdam, who decided that the questions were proper.

PROVIDENCE, June 11. -- There was a better attendance at Narragansett Park for the third day of the Circuit Meeting, but only one of the three races was at all interesting. This was the 2:45 class, for which Colonel Kipp was backed at $50 against $25 for Addie Lee II., and $10 for the field. Colonel Kipp was unsteady for two heats, which Addie Lee won without trouble.

PITTSBURG, June 11. -- Father S.G. Mollinger, the famous priest physician from Mount Troy, Allegheny, hasn't been summoned to the Vatican by the Pope as has been reported. He is not going away next Monday, and when he does go he is not going to Rome.

BERLIN, June 11. -- An Associated Press correspondent to-day met Herr G. Goldberger, the well-known Jewish financier, Director of the International Bank of this city, a member of one of the most aristocratic clubs, and Consul General for Belgium in this city, who was recently expelled from Russia, apparently in a most unwarranted manner.

Charles Fisher, the distinguished actor, died at 2 o'clock yesterday morning at his home, 952 Sixth Avenue. He had been ill since he went to Europe a year ago with Mr. Augustin Daly's company, with which he was for a long time connected. He was unable to continue work during the company's season in Europe last year, and remained abroad until five weeks ago.

ST. LOUIS, June 11. -- The last session of the Assembly passed an act prohibiting the sale of pools on all sporting events that occur outside of the State. In other words, while it permits the sale of pools and bookmaking on races run in St. Louis, Kansas City, and elsewhere in the State, it is an offense when this is done on events in any other State.

KINGSTON, Ontario, June 11. -- The remains of Sir John Macdonald were committed to their last restingplace to-day in Cataraqui Cemetery. The entire morning was spent if viewing the remains in the City Hall. Twenty thousand persons, in double line, passed the bier. The procession was over two miles long, and occupied over forty minutes in passing a given point.
BOSTON, June 11. -- The Legislature was prorogued to-day after a session of 157 days.

CARLSBAD, June 11. -- Mr. P.D. Armour of Chicago is here at present with his invalid wife, on account of whose health he came to Germany. Mr. Armour said he had just received a long dispatch from his home stating that ground had been broken at Toleston, Ind., for the new stock yards in which he, Mr. Morris, and Mr. Swift are interested.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Navy Department has prepared an outline programme of the first part of the Summer manoeuvres of the squadron of evolution. Early in July all the ships are to go to Boston, where fleet exercises will occupy ten days. Then about the middle of July the squadron will go to New-York, where the same programme will be gone through with.

ALBANY, June 11. -- The Court of Appeals, in denying the application for a reargument of the appeal in the murder case of the people against Jugiro, appellant, takes occasion to rebuke the overzealous counselors who have conducted it, and to read a warning to the legal fraternity in general. The opinion of the court is per curlam, and is in the form of a memorandum. It reads as follows:

Four months ago the New-York Life Insurance Company issued a printed statement to its Spanish-American policy holders, signed by the Director General of that department, Joaquin Sanchez, stating that Julio Merzbacher, the company's Spanish-American agent, had retired from business because of ill health. Simultaneously with that announcement Merzbacher disappeared from the company's offices and from his apartments at 34 Wes Twenty-fifth Street, and his whereabouts since that time have been unknown.
