The petition of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Street Railroad Company for leave to extend the dangerous and disfiguring trolley system through Coney Island Avenue and Fifteenth Street, from Franklin Avenue, along the southwest side of Prospect Park to the Plaza at Ninth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, had a hearing yesterday before the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, at a special meeting in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce in this city.

ORANGE, N.J., June 11 -- At the second day's play in the Orange tennis tournament to-day, in the finals of the gentlemen's doubles, Clarence Hobart and R.R. Perkins of the New-York Tennis Club defeated the players from Princeton College, W.V. Johnson and W.H. Condict, in three straight sets. Johnson did the best work for Princeton, while Hobart played in fairly good form.

ALBANY, June 11. -- To-night the Governor, through his newspaper organ, indulges in what he terms "pro-convention talk." He starts off with the declaration that "there is a strong probability, amounting almost to a certainty" that the Democratic ticket will be successful, and then remarks that it is not to be wondered at that much speculation should have been indulged in as to who the Democratic candidate for that great office will be.

BALTIMORE, June 11. -- The exercises connected with the conferring of degrees at the close of the fifteenth academic year of the Johns Hopkins University were held this afternoon in Mount Vernon Place Methodist Episcopal Church. The candidates admitted to the degree of Bachelor of Arts were:

Very few people either in or out of England can have anticipated the judgment of England upon the connection of the Prince of WALES with the Cumming case. Of all highly-civilized nations England is the one in which snobbery has struck the deepest roots. The feeling about titled persons among English snobs is by no means "that generous loyalty to rank and sex" which BURKE described as a chivalrous sentiment.

Gov. HILL'S organ at Albany appears to be trying to prepare the way for the acceptance of the third-term idea. At all events, it discusses the present Governor as among the possibilities as a candidate at the next election, and argues that the precedents are in favor of rather than against such a nomination.

WEST POINT, June 11. -- The line at dress parade was thin to-night. The cadets stood in single line formation. Behind the companies stood the members of the first class with side arms only. It was their last dress parade at West Point. To some it was the last parade to be seen here in many years. The ceremonies were different from those of other nights and were simple and impressive.

I read with much interest the communication from "D" in regard to the snakes seen in delirium tremens. "D" settles the matter for himself, and it is at least gratifying and comforting to see that he has analyzed his own sensations so well and that he states malaria to be the cause.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 12. -- The Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church of New-York City, since the death of Dr. Howard Crosby, has been without a pastor. The salary paid to the pastor has been $8,000. It has been rumored that the Rev. Dr. J.G. Van Slyke of this city has received an intimation that he might expect a call to fill the vacancy.

After a night's reflection the Vice Presidents of the New-York Life Insurance Company, who, in the absence of President Beers, are in charge of the company's affairs, decided that it would be best to make public a statement of the amount of Julio Merzbacher's defalcation, the story of which was told exclusively in THE TIMES yesterday.

The Alumni Association of the University of New-York held an important meeting last evening at the University Building, Washington Square. The business of greatest interest transacted was the nomination of an alumnus to be a member of the University Council. This was the first time that this privilege had been accorded the Alumni Association.

A fish story that is a fish story was told yesterday by Pilot Keely, who brought in the steamship Caledonia, and the tale is corroborated by officers of that vessel. Many instances are recorded where ships have come to grief by collision with the monarchs of the deep, but it remained for the little pilot boat Actaea to reverse the ordinary current of events and kill a whale by a blow from her knife-like prow.

NEW-HAVEN, June 12. -- The Yale crew went to New-London this afternoon for the final practice on the Thames before the race with Harvard. The new launch went in the morning and the shells were sent on the steamer Ivernia.

" Bouncer" Greenhlage of Massachusetts has been telling people down his way that the "stimulus of defeat is a grand good thing for a party." It is difficult to see in what way his party has profited by the defeat administered to it last Fall, but the next dose may produce the remedial effect which Mr. Greenhalge admits the Republican organization stands in need of.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 12. -- A strange and interesting story comes from Lancaster County, S.C., and is well vouched for. When Sherman's army was passing through central South Carolina on his memorable march to the sea, the officers of the Bank of Camden collected all the cash and jewelry deposits in its vaults and carried them to a place near Hanging Rock, in Lancaster, to bury them, for fear they would be confiscated.

The proposal largely to increase the number of cadets at West Point, while it has been under consideration for some time, undoubtedly derives a special stimulus just now from the fact that many young men from civil life are to be appointed to vacancies in the army this year. Still, as we have already pointed out, this is too exceptional an occurrence to base an annual increase in the membership of the Military Academy upon.

The attractiveness of the Central Park "Zoo" was unexpectedly increased yesterday afternoon by the arrival of twenty-three full-grown sea lions and an infant sea lion from the southern coast of California. They are the property of Capt. I.R. Mullett, who for years past has furnished zoological gardens and menageries with live animals, but they are held by the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company.

The Board of Health of this State may learn something from the example set by the Board of Health of New-Jersey, which has undertaken an inquiry concerning the presence of tuberculosis in dairy herds and the measures which should be taken to prevent the sale of milk in which the germs of consumption are carried.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The Directors of the World's Columbian Exposition to-day refused to confirm several of Director Davis's nominations of Department Chiefs. They rejected Walter S. Maxwell to be Chief of the Horticultural Department by a vote of 25 to 8, and refused to confirm Melville E. Stone as Chief of the Department of Foreign Affairs.

At its meeting on Tuesday the Board of Aldermen made a considerable show of public spirit and instructed its Railroad Committee to report on Tuesday next the resolution denouncing the occupation of Battery Park by the elevated railroad. Yesterday the committee met and retired into an "executive session," and when it emerged to the light it appeared that a public hearing upon the resolution had been decided upon for Tuesday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

It is not surprising that an attempt to prosecute DE LESSEPS should now be made in France by some of the Panama shareholders and bondholders who were induced by him to throw away their money, but it is scarcely probable that he will be brought to account. Many persons living beyond the sphere of his influence, in America or elsewhere, do not understand how he was able to avoid prosecution some years ago.

The First Battalion of State Naval Militia held its final drill for the season on board the United States frigate Minnesota, at the foot of West Fiftieth Street, last night. The exercises consisted of work by the First Battery at the howitzers, Second Battery at cutlass drill. Third Battery at the infantry manual of arms, and Fourth Battery at great-gun drill, (nine-inch smooth bores.)

LONDON, June 12. -- Dispatches from Shanghai announce fresh excesses upon the part of the anti-European element in the population of China. Attacks upon the Christian missions in the interior continue. In one case the Chinese troops sent to repress the rioters sided with them and made matters still worse.

Potomac, having pulled up lame in his work, will not go to Chicago to run for the American Derby, Strathmeath and Pessara will be sent on, however, to try conclusions with Kingman. Mr. Dwyer will send Kingston on if the proposed race at a mile and an eighth, with $5,000 added, is made up.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- The deeper the expert accountants probe into the affairs of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley the more apparent the rascalities of the man become, and the enormous sums which he made away with are daily added to. Yesterday the accountants reported to Mayor Stuart that they had discovered a grave discrepancy in Bardsley's accounts with the State. To-day they presented Mayor Stuart with the following statement:

The suppression of competition in an industry tends to retard or check the development of it by the use of improvements. When the history of the Harrow Trust was disclosed in court a few weeks ago it was shown that the twenty manufacturers had bound themselves not to make use of new inventions for a long term of years.

LONDON, June 12. -- The official London Gazette this evening announces, under date of June 10, that the name of Sir William Gordon Cumming has been removed from the list of officers in the army, as her Majesty has no further occasion for his services.

NORFOLK, Va., June 12. -- A suit will be instituted in this city in a short time by two young women to recover fifteen acres of land in one of the principal residence portions of the city, worth about $300,000. The titles to the property have been examined by most of the prominent lawyers of the city and have been pronounced good.

RICHMOND, Va., June 12. -- The Edwardses of King William County, this State, allege that they have discovered complete documentary evidence which will sustain their claims to the New-York estate of Robert Edwards, valued at $205,000, now in litigation.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- In an interview here to-day, Henry P. Wilson, a Republican politician of Indiana, declared that Judge Gresham would be a candidate for the Presidential nomination in 1892. "The Judge is not doing any brass band work," said Mr. Wilson, "but he is quietly feeling his ground. We have it from pretty good sources that he could have the Illinois delegation.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., June 12. -- Again the protectionists have defaulted when challenged to debate the tariff question publicly, this time in Ulster County at the meetings arranged by the Reform Club of New-York City. They responded to the challenges of the club last week for six meetings in Southern Ulster by sending Gen. George A. Sheridan to meet Congressman John De Witt Warner.

The coming test of ship armor, which is to take place on the new naval ordnance proving grounds at Indian Head, will be of great interest and importance in several ways. In the first place, it will be a trial of American-made guns, plates, and projectiles, thereby differing from the famous competition of last September, where all the armor and all the shells were foreign.

It was a serious set-back for the public credit of the city of Brooklyn to receive no bids for the proposed issue of 3 per cent. bonds for the extension of the bridge terminus and for the development of Ridgewood Park. Bonds of this city bearing only 2 1/2 per cent. have been sold at par. and Brooklyn 3 per cents have heretofore been taken at 6 to 8.64 per cent. premium.

OTTAWA, June 12. -- Everything indicates that Sir John Thompson, Minister of Justice in the late Ministry, will succeed Sir John Macdonald as Premier of Canada. Although the Conservative members are divided in their allegiance, Lord Stanley's choice will not result in any split in the party. A feeling now prevails that the future will be imperiled if all personal ambitions and local demands are to be satisfied.

As the fishing season advances two reports come in. From the fresh-water resorts good luck is mostly the word. From the salt-water headquarters of information the word is not so encouraging as to game fish. The more common varieties, such as the flounder, blackfish, and sea bass, are apparently as plenty as in former seasons.

One result of the fraudulent methods displayed in attempting to foist the property of the Long Island Water Supply Company upon the taxpayers of the city of Brooklyn was seen yesterday when Mayor Chapin and Controller Jackson failed to obtain a single bid in answer to advertisements offering $800,000 worth of gilt-edged 3 per cent. bonds for sale.

Dominick Leonard, a well-to-do contractor of Flatbush, L.I., was found lying in the roadway in Rogers Avenue, near Linden Street, about 9:30 o'clock Thursday night suffering from a pistol-shot wound in his left breast. He died a few minutes later without being able to explain who shot him.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The Chicago Opera House was packed last night at the opening performance of the fifth annual extravaganza, entitled "Sindbad; or, The Maid of Balsora." The piece made a decided hit. One of the most remarkable scenes ever shown on any stage is the shipwreck, where a full-sized ship is made to disappear beneath the waves. Fred Dangerfield designed the scenery.

St. John's Guild is about to begin its beneficent midsummer hospital work and makes its annual appeal for funds to maintain and increase that work. Its general character is well known to the charitable people of this city. A thousand or more of sick children with their mothers are taken down the bay on the floating hospital to get the benefit of sea air, good food, and medical attendance for one day.

JOHN WANAMAKER'S written history of his relations with the Keystone Bank is a good thing to keep on file. The looting of the bank is still under investigation. There will be, quite likely, further exposures and further arrests. BARDSLEY, the Treasurer of Philadelphia, is too insignificant a scapegoat for all the sins that are to be expiated in his person.

Advices from Albany are conclusively to the effect that the recent query in the Eagle, Will Albany County become a Hill asset? will have to be answered in the negative. The answer grows out of the past facts in politics there and of the unchanged honesty and firmness of character of the Democratic leaders of that Democratic community.

Some of those who have for months suffered from the wretched service of the Brooklyn Bridge hope that the new management will give them some relief. Those who are obliged to cross the bridge during the early hours of the morning, after 1 o'clock, are pretty certain that benefit of some sort must accrue not only to New-Yorkers but to Brooklynites as well, as a result of Mayor Grant's capture of the bridge.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 12. -- The patients of Father Mollinger, the priest-physician, are now counted by thousands. The priest made a statement from the steps of the Troy Hill schoolhouse to-day. He said no preference would be shown any one. Rich and poor were equal in his eye, as they were in the sight of the Creator.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 12. -- James B. Scott Co. import more tinned plate than any other firm in Pittsburg. The members of the firm are "McKinley Republicans to the backbone." It is a little surprising, therefore, to hear a wail from them about the outlook for that industry in this country. B.F. Jennings of the West Penn Steel Works is a tin-plate enthusiast. In an interview yesterday he said:

An apparently innocent little motion, made before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, caused the scandal that has arisen from the Stewart millions, ever since the distribution of them came before the courts, to burst forth with renewed vigor. The action was taken by ex-Judge Horace Russell, counsel for Henry Hilton and Charles J. Clinch, as executors of the will of Cornelia M. Stewart.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- During the recent Commencement Week among the more important class reunions was that of the Class of '41, which celebrated its semi-centennial. Among the members present were Judge John C. Biddle. Mr. J.H. Bruyere, Judge Dodd, the Rev. Theodore L. Cuyler, D.D.; Prof. J.T. Duffield, D.D.; Eugene Lawrence, the author; J. Lonn, Esq.; the Hon. E.W. Scudder, J.H. Voorbees, Esq.; Y.S. Ward, M.D., and Mr. Eli Whitney.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Census Office has issued a bulletin on the subject of statistics of petroleum production, prepared by Mr. Joseph D. Weeks, special agent. The statistics show that petroleum was produced in eleven States in 1889, namely, Pennsylvania, New-York, Ohio, West Virginia, Colorado, California, Indiana, Kentucky, Illinois, Kansas, and Texas.

The Massachusetts Legislature, which has just adjourned after being in session nearly half the year, prepared the way for an interesting experiment in the direction of what in Boston they call "nationalism," or, at least, a local application of the same principle. A law was passed authorizing cities and towns to supply gas or electric light for public and private use, if their people desire to adopt that policy.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 13. -- All speculation as to Sir John Macdonald's successor has been disposed of. The Hon. J.J.C. Abbott, a member the late Ministry without portfolio and Goverment leader, is now engaged in the task of forming a Ministry. His selection will, generally speaking, meet with approval throughout the Dominion, except in the Province of Quebec.

Chicago is going to have the World's Fair, but the New-York Giants are using all their endeavors to prevent Cook County from securing the baseball championship. With that purpose in view they whipped Anson's Colts yesterday, and are now two games ahead of the Western cracks. By long odds the largest crowd that ever witnessed a contest on the diamond field saw the game.

NEW BRUNSWICK, June 13. -- It is singular that all the prizes open to Rutgers Senior and Junior Classes were captured by '92. It has just been announced that the prize in Roman Law has been awarded to Harry K. Davis of Hagaman's Mills, N.Y.

The story of Julio Merzbacher and of his enormous thefts from the New-York Life Insurance Company grows more interesting as new facts and fresh irregularities are brought to light. The statement made in yesterday's TIMES that the amount of Merzbacher's defalcation would exceed half a million dollars and approach a million is a statement of fact, susceptible of proof.
ST. LOUIS, June 13. -- Senator George G. Vest this evening talked most interestingly with THE TIME'S correspondent on national politics. He was asked what he thought of Cleveland, and replied:

By far the most successful real-estate season for years in the New-York market is about to close for the Summer vacation. There was never a time when so many persons were interested in real estate as buyers in the market as there have been in the last three months, nor was there ever a time when so many dealers devoted their attention to suburban property.

SARATOGA, June 13. -- The weather here has been on its good behavior since the opening of the spring buds. Although the days are warm the air is clear and dry. The altitude of this village, the bracing atmosphere, sand plains, and mineral springs lengthen life. Statistics show that there are nearly 500 persons in Saratoga Country over eighty years of age.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 13. -- H.H. Yard, the friend of Gideon Marsh, the fugitive President of the Keystone Bank, is still in Trenton awaiting requisition from the Governor. District Attorney Graham is actively engaged, however, in preparing the necessary formalities, and Yard will soon be a prisoner in this city.

June has come in the country, and even to the inhabitants of the city wilderness of brick and mortar she contrives to tell something of her story. The vines on churches and houses are in tender, luxuriant leaf, and in many of the tiny courts which metropolitans call yards clambering rose vines, thick with blossoms, relieve the glaring fences and impart a refreshing floral touch to the limited landscape.

The five Judges whom President Harrison has just appointed to constitute the Court of Private Land Claims will find a large budget of business on their desks as soon as they have qualified, officials from Washington recently in this city say.

The imported French stallion Aerolithe was skipped to Col. Scott's Erie stock farm yesterday, where he will take the place of Rayon d'Or in the stan. He was secured by Tattersail's of New-York for Col. Scott. The same gentleman's French filly Rostmond is to be bred to the Duchess of Montford's famous stallion Barcaldine, sire of the famous English horses Mimi and Morton, winners of the recent classical races Epsom and Ascot.

In the course of the coming week the relative merits of the much-discussed forty-six-foot yachts ought to be pretty well settled. Tuesday the Atlantic Yacht Club will start the Summer's fun between the new candidates for honors. The Nautilus, Mineola, Uvira, Sayonara, Gloriana, and Jessica have been entered, and others will doubtless be on hand when the preparatory gun is fired at 10:30 A.M.

In April, 1492, while Columbus was making arrangements for his first voyage, a patent was prepared and signed by Ferdinand and Isabella granting to Columbus powers extraordinary and supreme over all lands met with in his travels. The terms of this patent were as follows:

I never met Gen. Taylor until after his inauguration as President. The following Winter I received a letter from Major W.W.S. Bliss, dated at the White House, inviting me to visit him. The Major and I were from the same town (Lebanon) in New-Hampshire. We were at the Academy together. He entered West Point and was graduated with the highest honors.

Now that President WAGSTAFF of the bridge promises to study the problem of better accommodation for late travel, there is another point of interest to those who use the bridge cars at night that we should like to see him take up. It is the special kindness that seems reserved by the train hands and guards for drunken loafers, and those not always men at that.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 13. -- The farmers of Vermont are not so eager to get the bounty on maple sugar as it was represented they would be. There was a good deal of eloquence expended in telling what a big thing the bounty would be for them, but it looks now as if all this eloquence was wasted. As far as appearances go the farmers are indifferent about the bounty.

There has been a strange disposition shown by the officers of the New-York Life Insurance Company to treat the Merzbacher defalcation as a mere business incident, and not a very serious one at that, inasmuch as they think it will involve no permanent loss to the company, instead of regarding it as a crime in which the public has a higher concern than any one who may have suffered a mere pecuniary damage.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- President Harrison's adherents here have read, with more interest than they will confess, the story about the anti-Harrison Republican Conference, held Thursday night in Indianapolis. They profess to be not at all disturbed about it, but those who know something about the political situation in Indiana do not really regard the meeting as the unimportant thing they call it.

NORWICH, June 13. -- The following programme of exercises has been arranged by the Connecticut Society of Sons of the American Revolution for "Brother Jonathan Day" at Lebanon Green next Monday, when the restored War Office of Jonathan Trumbull, Connecticut's Revolutionary War Governor, is to be formally presented to that society:

BETHLEHEM, Penn., June 13. -- About June 1 the '92 Epitome, Lehigh's annual, made its appearance. It is the finest number that has yet been published. Some of the more notable features of the book are fine views of the campus and buildings, a photograph of Dr. Chandler, with short sketch of his career, and the several fraternity cuts.

The General Term of the Superior Court will shortly be asked to pass upon the decision of Judge Dugro, rendered the other day in the teat suit of William Palm to recover a fifty dollar penalty from the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company for a charge of 14 cents in excess of the fare allowed by law between the Grand Central Station and Morris Park.

Mrs. Orr begins this memoir of Robert Browning with a refutation of a story, current in his lifetime and revived after his death, that Jewish blood coursed in his veins, active support of which was obtained from his known interest in the Hebrew language and literature and his friendship for many members of the London Jewish community. Browning's paternal stock was all Anglo-Saxon.

HARTFORD, June 13. -- A session of the Senate will be held here on Monday, when the report of the Committee on Appropriations and Expenditures will be made. Senator Seymour of Norwalk is at the head of the committee. From present appearances the report will not open the way for removal of the financial difficulties in the State departments that will arise on the 1st of July.

BOSTON, June 13. -- The eyes of the thoughtful have been turned toward Andover Seminary this week, for it was natural to expect that the Commencement exercises of an institution which some now believe, and many in the past have believed, to be heretical would furnish material for comparison with the deliverances of the recent Presbyterian General Assembly at Detroit and of the professors and Directors of Union Seminary in New-York.

It is a wonder that anglers of modest means have not been made insane by the bewildering display of pretty things that are now sold in the tackle stores. It requires a will strong and immovable to abstain from absolute bankruptcy upon visiting such stores. The object of the tackle man seems to be to dazzle and bewilder by an artistic arrangement of the various bits of tackle necessary and ornamental.

BALTIMORE, June 13. -- The new Revenue Marine steamer Galveston will be ready for an official trial, it is expected, in the course of the coming month. The Galveston is the handsomest revenue cutter yet designed for the Government. In general appearance she resembles a fast torpedo gunboat cruiser. She is 195 feet in length, with lines as clean as a racehorse, high freeboard, without a break from the bow to the stern.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 13. -- The hot weather of the first part of the week caused many people to leave the hot cities and flee to the cooling breezes of the Catskills. Present indications are that the season will be an unusually good one in the Catskill region, and that it will start with a rush about July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Mayor Stuart to-day received from Controller Lacey a copy of the instructions that he has sent to Receiver Yardley of the Keystone Bank, in regard to the course the receiver shall pursue in giving information to the investigating committee of the affairs of the bank.
In the easiest possible manner the Brooklyns won from the Cincinnati team yesterday. Duryea's pitching was hit hard, while Lovett's work was of a steady character. Score:
NEW-HAVEN, June 13. -- The following awards of scholarship prizes in the academic department at Yale were made this morning:

What this baseball year has still in store nobody ventures to predict, but it can hardly furnish another such scene as yesterday's, when enormous shouting throngs gathered on the two grounds side by side at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, and for more than three hours paid tribute with flags, horns, whistles, and human throat power to the fascination of the sport.
DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., June 13. -The Water Gap in June, with its rustic pathways and arbors, its artistic little lakes, and its wealth of roses everywhere, reminds one of a well-kept park.
There are two kinds -- the NATURAL and the IMITATION.

The New-York Canoe Club could not have had any more favorable conditions as far as weather was concerned than those which were present at its regatta yesterday. The wind was neither too heavy for the flitting little craft, nor yet was it so slight as to allow them to drift about at the mercy of the swift-running tide.

SEATTLE, Washington, June 13. -- There is much exploring going on in Alaska and the Northwest, and the Government of British Columbia is doing its full share. A.L. Poudrier, who has charge of the British Columbia explorations, is now at Victoria, confined to his room with inflammation of the blood-vessels caused by exposure in the snowy mountainous district in which he was working.

PEEKSKILL, June 13. -- Nine years ago, July 1, 1882, the State Camp of Instruction was set in motion at this point by Adjutant General Fred Townsend. The organization which first occupied the camp -- which, under the able administration of Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter, has become the military post of the State of New-York -- was the Twenty-third Regiment.

The only feature which at the present time appears at all likely to elevate proceedings at the State Camp of Instruction the current season, which begun yesterday, out of the ordinary prosaic rut, is the attention to be given to instructing in signaling the rank and file of the organizations of the National Guard ordered to Peekskill.

PATERSON, N.J., June 13. -- The very unusual ceremony of "healing" a Mason was performed here last night, with the assistance of a most distinguished gathering of Freemasons of high degree. A Paterson man was some time ago initiated into the mysteries of Freemasonry in Ireland. Subsequently he applied for admission to Ivanhoe Lodge in this city and was refused admittance.

There will be no scarcity of fruit in the markets of this city this week. Peaches are beginning to come from Florida and North Carolina. So far they have been, excepting the Peulos from Florida, small, green, and generally worthless. Yesterday, however, there were a few Hale's Early, which, although in bad condition, indicated that some very nice peaches of early varieties may be expected from these sources.

As a result of this letter Merivale had received a telegram from Thornton about a week afterward asking him to take rooms at the inn, and on the same evening he was at the village station waiting for the London train.

LONDON, June 13. -- The Sullivan interest, not to say clique, offended because Augustus Harris did not choose Sir Arthur to compose the music for "Kenilworth," has been mollified by the fact that the Queen has "commanded" that the "Golden Legend" be performed at the Royal Albert Hall on July 9 at a concert to be given in honor of the visit of Emperor William of Germany to England.

A new club must be added to the already long and constantly-growing list of New-York clubs, the new-comer being known as the Patria Club. The club field is already pretty thickly populated, but the aims and objects of the latest addition to the club list are absolutely unique, and it will have its chosen field all to itself.

There has seldom been a week so given over to weddings in the city and suburbs as that which has just closed. With the exception of Friday there has been seemingly one continuous procession of brides and bridegrooms up and down the aisles of the principal churches every day, and the wedding bells have not ceased to ring in the steeples for an hour of late.

BERLIN, June 13. -- Undaunted by the overwhelming majority which supported Chancellor von Caprivi on the cereal duties question in the Landtag, the members of the Freisinnige party last evening held a mass meeting, at which the party leaders, amid fervent acclamations, announced their intention of prosecuting more vigorously than ever the anti-grain duties law agitation.

Next to the device of abusing the opposing counsel, one of the commonest ways to bolster a weak case is to destroy with the greatest ferocity charges that have never been made. In the legal profession this trick is known as setting up a man of straw in order to knock it down. It sometimes succeeds before a jury, but rarely, and it never succeeds with a Judge.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Augustin Daly's company has drawn crowded houses to Hooley's Theatre at every performance this week, and has given a very enjoyable rendition of "The Last Word." Ada Rehan, John Drew, and James Lewis shared equally in the generous plaudits of the audience, and the other members of the company were not forgotten. "The Last Word" was new to Chicago.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 13. -- Within the last few days the prospect of Cornell being successful in the coming races has taken on a far brighter aspect. Two weeks ago Courtney found that his men were not living up strictly to training rules and were getting in bad trim. He had to give them a severe reprimand, and this general stirring up was not without its effect.

There has been organized in this city a body to be known as the University Settlement Society of New-York. The names of over fifty of the most highly-respected gentlemen in the community are already on the membership roll, and it is desired to enroll all college men. The one object of the society is "to bring men and women of education into closer relations with the laboring classes for their mutual benefit."

We do not know just how widely acknowledged an authority upon baccarat is M. Ludovic Billard, Licencie es Sciences, whose "Breviare du Barcara Experimental" may be found at the Astor Library, or how his "Gospel" regarding the famous game compares with that of Dormoy or Badourean; but it has been said that M. Billard was the first person to whom the term "King of Baccarat!" was applied.

BRISTOL, Tenn., June 13. -- Last Sunday morning between 2 and 3 o'clock a man entered the house of John Warren, an official on the Norfolk and Western Railroad, and assaulted his wife. The man's tracks from the house were discovered leading down to Scranton Street toward Main.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13. -- College work is about ended and another year goes into the past. The last month has been given over to examinations, and during that period the sound of the "grinding" has been low within fair Harvard's walls. Ninety-one's class day bids fair to be a most successful one, and its coming gives interest to a brief description of the development at Harvard of this important event in college life.

The Moderation Society has all its plans completed for furnishing free ice water to thirsty New-Yorkers during the Summer months. The big water tank on wheels known as the "perambulating fountain" will start on its regular daily tour through the down-town streets to-morrow. The tank will hold a hundred gallons of water, and four tons of ice will be used daily to keep the water cool.
One day last week there was launched in the East River at Astoria a novel craft in the shape of a steam cabin yacht which was built in very peculiar circumstances.

The season for art has closed in New-York with an abruptness and a completeness characteristic of our atmosphere and people. One week sees two large exhibitions and a host of smaller shows open; the next has hardly a roomful of pictures at an art dealer's. The sudden heats of June discourage even the latter, and he retires into the country for rest and recreation or takes steamer for the other side.

Street costumes in which gay colors predominate never can be in the best taste, but they have become so common as no longer to attract special attention. Promenade toilets which once would have subjected their wearers to unpleasant comment are worn without criticism, their conspicuous character only serving to invite attention to their beauty of coloring, perfection of fit, general air of elegance, or whatever may be the peculiar characteristic.

LONDON, June 13. -- Nothing has happened during the week to depose baccarat from its proud place as the leading issue in the minds of the British public. Although these dispatches from the beginning have laid stress upon the inevitable political and social consequences to the Prince of Wales as the most important thing about the whole case, these consequences are already far graver and wider in scope than could have been anticipated.

Sir JOHN'S personal popularity and his adroitness enabled him to retain his hold of power in the face of charges of corruption that would have been fatal to a weaker man, and the factions that he bound together in not always very harmonious co-operation for the support of his Government, under a leader less feared if not less respected, will be likely to develop an awkward and disruptive habit of quarreling.

The one particular reason why so many politicians believe that Mayor Chapin knew all about the impending revolution in bridge affairs and yet staid away from that important meeting is that the youthful Mayor has never been very deeply in love with Howell and his method of conducting business. Even before he was elected Mayor, in 1887, and while he was yet in charge of the State Controller's office.

READING, Penn., June 13. -- Snakes seem to have overrun many parts of the Schuylkill Valley this season, more than they have done probably since the first settlements were made by the pioneer colonists. Blacksnakes are the most plentiful, but a large number of copperheads and rattlesnakes and some other varieties have also made their appearance.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 13. -- Forty-eight A.B.'s, the largest class that ever graduated from the university, and twenty-five Ph.D.'s received their degrees at the fourteenth annual Commencement Thursday. The growing influence of the university is attested by the strong demand for graduates. Men in some of the departments have been called to important and lucrative places who have not even finished half the work necessary for a Ph.D.

The enormous musical activity of this country is unknown in Europe, and, in spite of many systematic attempts to publish it, the music lovers of this country have small knowledge of it. This is unfortunate. It is a pity that unmusical persons cannot be made to understand that the West is not engaged in cultivating the comic opera, the badly-performed opera is English, and the brass band.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., June 13. -- A party of gentlemen who have just returned from a fishing excursion up Kettle Creek tell a startling adventure which happened to a woodsman living in the Black Forest named Ben Hurd, last Thursday. The region close to where Hurd lives escaped the ravages of the forest fires late in the Spring, and for that reason is infested with wild animals which sought refuge there from the fires.

Charles Frohman arrived in New-York on the steamship Furst Bismarck yesterday afternoon. He has several contracts with French playwrights which will interest theatregoers when they are fulfilled here next season.

In a recent article in the American Angler of this city on "Hints on Black Bass Fishing," Dr. James A. Henshall says that the black bass has become the most important game fish in America. It is distributed all over the country and a man by traveling may fish for it practically the year round. Dr. Henshall says:

RICHMOND, Va., June 13. -- The Grand Camp of Confederates has unanimously adopted resolutions with a view of securing a Southern history for the children of the South. It was declared that the children in the South must be taught the lessons of the war of the Confederacy.

The annual ejectment of its graduates by the United States Military Academy has been going on for some eighty years or more without compelling the attention of the general American public. Indeed, only twice within that time have the external circumstances been such as to command more than a passing notice from the journalist of the time.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 13. -- Seven crews have arrived in town for the great series of races, and three more are to follow. It will be by all odds the greatest rowing year that New-London has ever seen, and the presence of so many crews on the river is strongly reminiscent of 1875, at Saratoga, when in the great intercollegiate race of that year eleven crews went off at the word.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 13. -- Seven crews have arrived in town for the great series of races, and three more are to follow. It will be by all odds the greatest rowing year that New-London has ever seen, and the presence of so many crews on the river is strongly reminiscent of 1875, at Saratoga, when in the great intercollegiate race of that year eleven crews went off at the word.

RICHMOND, Va., June 13. -- The Grand Camp of Confederates has unanimously adopted resolutions with a view of securing a Southern history for the children of the South. It was declared that the children in the South must be taught the lessons of the war of the Confederacy.

The annual ejectment of its graduates by the United States Military Academy has been going on for some eighty years or more without compelling the attention of the general American public. Indeed, only twice within that time have the external circumstances been such as to command more than a passing notice from the journalist of the time.

Mr. Saintsbury has taken the lesser lights in English literature between the two dates mentioned in his title, though the term "lesser" ought not to be used without a due consideration of its value. There were, as there always must be, during a period of eighty years, some greater suns, but the smaller stars kept up the heavenly balance.

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- In the midst of the chaos in Republican circles over the failure of Secreretary Noble and those acting under his instructions to capture the Missouri delegation in the National Convention for Harrison, Chauncey I. Filley is working a very nice little scheme.

The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage was full of business yesterday morning at his big Tabernacle, on the corner of Clinton and Greene Streets, Brooklyn. To begin with, there were no fewer than thirty lusty-lunged youngsters to be baptized. This hard work performed, the doctor took his place in the pulpit and delivered a sermon directed against those whom he termed "raging reptiles of ecclesiastical controversy."

The alleged smuggling of sundry articles of apparel and ornaments by officers of the Omaha, which is now at Mare Island, will doubtless be "worked" for all and more than it is worth by those who are opposed to the transfer of the Revenue Marine to the navy, although the connection between the two subjects is rather fanciful.

Mr. JOSEPH NIMMO, Jr., appears to use the greater part of his time in preparing arguments for publication in defense of the new tin-plate duty and other features of the McKinley act, although incidentally he draws the salary of a Federal officer. We have already noticed some of his curious assertions.

The baseball war of last year seems almost like a dream to everybody in the metropolis after the great crowd that saw Saturday's game at the Polo Grounds. When the New-York teams were consolidated many a crank held up his right hand and swore never to attend another baseball game. But that has all been forgotten now, and never has New-York possessed crazier cranks than at the present time.

ITHACA, June 14. -- Commencement Week at Aurora opened to-night with the baccalaureate discourse delivered before the graduating class of Wells College and a large number of residents of this city and strangers by President Edward S. Frisbee, D.D. Dr. Frisbee took for his text the words: "It is written, man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God."

The Republicans of Iowa must be bewildered as they take in the advice given them by outsiders for the running of their campaign this Fall. On one point all of the self-constituted guardians agree; the demand is unanimously made for an old-fashioned Republican majority -- one like the majority of 1880, for instance -- but as to ways and means there is a great divergence of opinion.

PEEKSKILL, June 14. -- Camp life was made pleasant to the members of "Ours" to-day by the doing away with the customary requirements for Sunday. The morning inspections, held from time immemorial at military posts, whether regular or volunteer, were dispensed with, and following close upon this the announcement was made that there would be no church services, in consequence of "Ours" not possessing the essential adjunct of a Chaplain.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 14. -- Eugene St. Cyr, a good-looking Frenchman, apparently about thirty years old, committed suicide by asphyxiation early this morning at the West End Hotel, one of the most fashionable hostelries along the Jersey coast.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- United States District Attorney John R. Read said to-night, in regard to the statement of Controller Lacey, that he (Lacey) supposed him to be in full possession of knowledge of the criminal acts of Marsh:

QUEENSTOWN, June 14. -- The Cunard Line steamer Servia, Capt. Dutton, which left New-York June 6, arrived here to-day. The Captain reports that at midnight of Thursday last he sighted the Inman Line steamer City of Richmond, Capt. Redford, from New-York June 3, bound for this port and Liverpool.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The official announcement that the Governments of the United States and Great Britain have agreed to prohibit the killing of seals in Bering Sea for the rest of this year has not yet been issued, but it is asserted on excellent authority that the agreement has been signed and its promulgation is expected at once.

Flat contradictions from the lips of the executive officers of the New-York Life Insurance Company were yesterday's developments in the case of the defaulter Merzbacher -- a case that bids fair to involve in an unpleasant scandal the names of those occupying high places in the company's affairs. Messrs. Beers, Tuck, Welch, Merzbacher, and Banta are all telling different stories.

We shall not be prepared to believe, before the agreement for a close season for sealing in Bering Sea has been made public, that President HARRISON has insisted upon excluding the provision for a joint commission to inquire into the condition of the sealing interests in that quarter. It is true that investigations have been made heretofore by agents of our Government, but their reports have been conflicting and one has been quoted against another.

The closing exercises of the school for religious instruction connected with the Temple Ahawath Chesed, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, took place yesterday afternoon. Simon Herzig, Chairman of the School Board, delivered an address. The Rev. Dr. Adolph Huebsch medal, the Lasker medal, the Eisner medal, and the Schwartz medal were awarded respectively to Rosa Bullowa, Irving Blatt, Florence Miller, and Samuel Stein.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 14. -- It is officially stated to-night that the Hon. J.J.C. Abbott is making satisfactory progress in forming a new Ministry, and that he will be able to make an announcement when Parliament resumes its sittings Tuesday.

BERNE, June 14. -- A terrible accident occurred on the Moenchenstein and Bale Railway to-day, through the collapse of a bridge beneath a heavily-loaded excursion train. The train was crowded with people on the way to attend a musical fete.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES, through its correspondence from Annapolis and West Point, has done good work for the services in directing attention to the parsimony which imperils their usefulness by compelling the instructors at our two war schools to use old hulks and obsolete guns as models in teaching naval and military science.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 14. -- The recent demonstration by the officers of the revenue cutter Lot M. Morrill, Capt. Baldwin, of the practicability of an inland passage for coast-defense vessels along the Carolina coast, has attracted much attention among the public men of the South to the feasibility of defending this portion of the coast line more securely.

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- The "City Hall gang" have sadly hoodwinked the people of St. Louis about the cost of the new City Hall now in course of construction. When the cornerstone was laid last week it was stated that so many thousands had been saved up to date in the contracts let that there was a moral certainty of the building being completed at a far lower cost than the original estimate.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 14. -- It has been said again and again by the opponents of slavery that the people of the South lived in constant fear of negro insurrections. While this belief had no foundation in fact, still it is none the less true that there were always in certain localities certain fierce spirits among the slaves who wanted only an opportunity to rise in arms against their masters.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 14. -- The celebrated assessment laws of this State, including those sections providing that a man who failed to pay his tax in any one year should be kept from the poll lists the following year and thereby disfranchised for that time, were repealed at the last session of the Legislature, but their departure is being attended by highly sensational features.

The opponents of the Hon. J.J.C. ABBOTT, the new Premier of Canada, have unearthed the fact that in 1849 he was one of the signers of a manifesto in favor of the annexation of Canada to the United States, and will try to use it against him. As that was more than forty years ago and Mr. ABBOTT was then a comparative youth, this will hardly prove an effective weapon.

A1 is the common, every-day expression of the English-speaking race for denoting superlative excellence. Its origin and true meaning are to be found in the annals of Lloyd's Register. It is an interesting bit of history.
WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Controller Lacey has made the following statement of his proceedings in regard to the Keystone National Bank of Philadelphia:

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 14. -- Pennsylvania's attitude upon the Republican Presidential nomination next year is the subject of a great deal of discussion. A careful reading of the newspapers of the State discloses the fact that popular sentiment has not taken shape in favor of any one candidate. It goes without saying that Secretary Blaine is Pennsylvania's "favorite son" over all comers any time he is avowedly an aspirant for the high office.

The State Central Committee's address to the Democrats of Kentucky is published below in full. It has been prepared in accordance with the plans of the committee and the candidates as arranged at the conference on last Thursday evening. The paper is as follows:

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- It can at last be definitely stated, on the authority of Secretary Noble himself, that he will not resign his seat in the Cabinet. Whatever may have been his intentions up to last night, (and it has been believed here that he intended to resign,) when he had a conversation with Joseph B. McCullagh, editor of the Globe-Democrat, his mind is now clearly made up.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14. -- The first rescue of the season took place at the foot of South Carolina Avenue this afternoon in view of hundreds of people who crowded the Ocean Boulevard and the beach. The man whose life was in jeopardy was Harry Devine, a young Philadelphian, who came down this morning for a day's pleasure and who started out alone for a plunge in the surf.

It is noticeable that within the last two weeks a number of applications have been made to the Boards of Freeholders in various parts of New-Jersey for riparian franchises by the owners of river fronts. The cost of dock rights on the river fronts was a trifle up to a year ago, when the State Riparian Commissioners advanced the prices manyfold.

The call for the Republican County Convention of Warren County, to meet week after next, on Thursday, June 18, to select delegates to the Senatorial convention, opens the legislative campaign, and opens it in a most significant fashion. Senator Emerson, who represents the Nineteenth District, is a candidate for re-election, and is a pronounced Platt-Hiscock man.

The attempt to prosecute M. DE LESSEPS draws interesting comments from persons connected with the canal company's projects. M. CHARLES DE LESSEPS professes to believe that the proposed prosecution, if carried through, "would help to realize his father's plans for the completion of the canal."

Railroad freight rates have reached a point -- the hot-weather point -- where New-York shippers can get almost any rates they like. While the principal lines in the Trunk Line Association keep up the appearance of sticking to the regular tariff, freight agents are not letting any shipments escape them because of the unwillingness of shippers to pay schedule rates.

Postmaster Van Cott has for a long time been endeavoring to improve the mail service between this city and Harlem. He has now completed arrangements for substituting for the present hourly delivery between the down-town Post Office and Harlem a half-hour service, and there is great rejoicing among the merchants of the annexed district over the promised change.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15. -- Three of the new mortars for the United States Government, each weighing fourteen tons, created a counter spectacle to the Barnum circus parade in the streets to-day, as they were drawn on an eight-horse dray from the builders' iron foundry to the river front for shipment to the proving ground at Sandy Hook. To-night they are resting ingloriously upon the mud on the bottom of Providence River.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -- Ninety-one bade farewell to its Rochester friends this afternoon in the Rochester University Class Day exercises at the Lyceum Theatre. When the exercises began at 2:30 o'clock the Lyceum was filled with friends of the graduates and of the university, Dr. Hill, President of the university, occupying one of the boxes.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The joint agreement between the United States and Great Britain for the prohibition of seal killing in Bering Sea has at last been promulgated, and now each Government stands pledged to prevent the reckless slaughter of the seals, which has so nearly ruined the great industry acquired by the United States with Alaska.

Big Arisen prides himself on having a record making team this year. If the Captain's claim is a just one, truly the Giants must be regarded as record-breaker. They leave beaten the Western experts in three successive games, and now, with lead of three game, are in a fair way to win championship honors.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon telegraphed to Capt. C. L. Mooper, commanding the revenue steamer Corwin, as follows:

PITTSBURG, June 15. -- The misguided sufferers who fancied that they had but to be blessed by Father Mollinger to be relieved of their afflictions are now returning in carloads to their distant homes. Many go away crippled in body, ruined in pocket, and in despair instead of hope. The reaction is so great that the sight the disappointed present is most touching.

Between 7:40 and 7:45 P.M. yesterday, second alarms were sent out for stations 247 and 139, the first fire being at 339 Stanton Street, a five-story building. It started in Charles Miller's tailoring shop on the top floor, and swept through it and the fourth floor, occupied by S. Englander Brother, tailors. About $2,000 damage was done. The other fire was at 261 South Street.

SAN. FRANCISCO, June 15. -- The United Stages revenue cutter Corwin, now about to start for Bering Sea, is one of the famous vessels of the Revenue Marine. She has seen more active service and received harder knocks than any United States vessel afloat. Under the command of Capt. Michael A. Healy the Corwin has made no less than seven arctic cruises, the little vessel going 1,200 miles beyond Bering Straits into the Arctic ocean.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- At a meeting of City Councils this afternoon, a communication was received from W. Redwood Wright, the recently-confirmed City Treasurer, offering the American Surety Company as his bondsmen. The surety was approved and an ordinance to that effect will be passed on Thursday, when Mr. Wright will take possession of the office.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Lighthouse Board has issued advertisements inviting bids to be opened June 30 for four lightships, to be known as Nos. 51, 52, 53, and 54, and to be stationed respectively at Cornfield Point, Long Island Sound; Fenwick Island Shoal, off the New-Jersey coast; Frying Pan Shoal, off the North Carolina coast, and Martin's Industry, off the Georgia coast.

It would be a mistake to attach much importance to the "hearing" before the Board of Aldermen upon the proposition to put the elevated roads out of the Battery. It is a matter for regret that the Aldermen should have any shadow of power in the premises. NAPOLEON'S saying, cynical of men in general is entirely accurate of New-York Aldermen in general: "There are only two levers for moving them -- inretest and fear."

ITHACA, N.Y., June 15. -- Commencement gayeties began here to-night with the Glee Club concert and Sophomore cotillion. The town is filled with guests from all over the country. The hotels and boarding houses are crowded, while in the twenty chapter houses are installed pleasant parties of matrons and maidens. Almost every fraternity in college has held or is holding a reception.

Henry C. Payne of Milwaukee was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Mr. Payne is a member of the National Republican Committee. During the last campaign he was Chairman of a sub-committee which had charge of the work in the Northwestern States, including Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota, the Dakotas, Montana, and Washington, and he has kept himself informed as well as he could on the political situation in these States since the last campaign.

The mode of automatically releasing horses from their stalls in fire engine houses forms the basis of suits against this city and Brooklyn, involving claims aggreating at least $750,000, for alleged violations of a patent taken out by Robert Bragg of California in 1876.

The agreement for a closed season for sealing in Bering Sea was proclaimed by the President yesterday, and instructions were sent by Secretary FOSTER to the Collector at San Francisco and to the commander of the Corwin, with the necessary orders for the Rush and the Bear and for the officers at the Pribilof Islands for carrying into effect the terms of the agreement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- Sevill Schofield of the firm of Sevill Schofield, Son Co., the Manayunk woolen manufacturers, against whom judgments were entered on Saturday to the amount of $41,000, called at the office of his attorney to-day, accompanied by the representative of the judgments, and executed an assignment to his son, J. Dobson Schofield, for the benefit of his creditors.

LONDON, June 15. -- The Hon. Edward Stanhope, Secretary of State for War, replying to-day in the House of Commons to a question put by Mr. William Summers (Gladstone Liberal) in regard to the baccarat scandal, said that Sir William Gordon-Cumming was the chief person who had broken faith, because he did not report the case to his commanding officer.

BERNE, June 15. -- The total number of people who lost their lives yesterday by the collapse of a railroad bridge on the Moenchenstein and Basel Railroad is now placed at 120, with hundreds more or less injured.

PEEKSKILL, June 15. -- The Peekskill girl gave the camp a wide berth to-day. Yesterday she was here in profusion, but even the most ardent admiration for the "bold sojer boy," even though all wool and a yard wide, cannot be guaranteed proof against the overpowering torridity of the first working day of "Ours."

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, June 15. -- At 9 o'clock this morning the jury in the case of the State against Corp. Frank Parkison of the Seventeenth Infantry for murder returned a verdict of manslaughter. The twelve men retired at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening and balloted continuously till to-day. It was a trial in which the testimony was all circumstantial, and for the most part highly sensational.

The sloop yacht Amelia was run into and sunk by the tugboat F.W. Dovoe just before midnight Sunday on the Hudson River, opposite One Hundred and Twelfth Street. Two of the pleasure party aboard the yacht were drowned. The pilot is under arrest charged with homicide.

The New-York Jockey Club's June meeting was brought to a close yesterday in a decidedly unsatisfactory fashion, the programme being the poorest offered to racegoers since the close of Jerome Park's gates. The fields of horses contesting in the several races were too small to be dignified by the title of fields, which was due to the fact that most of the horses had gone to the Coney Island Club track.

One result of the trial of Sir WILLIAM GORDON-CUMMING has been to put British snobbery to a more severe test than it is likely often to experience. The goings-on of royalty have often been very trying to loyalty, but those of them that were most trying have been known only by the loose gossip of the clubs and by society journalism.

The Jewish Ministers' Association of America began its thirteenth convention yesterday afternoon in the Temple Gates of Heaven, in East Fifteenth Street. Its President, the Rev. Dr. Gottheil of the Temple Emanu-El presided, and facing him were twenty-five ministers from Brooklyn, Boston, Philadelphia, Buffalo, New-Haven, Rochester, Pittsburg, Newark, and this city.

HARTFORD, June 15. -- The Senate, by a party vote, this afternoon referred the House resolution ordering the suspension of the specific appropriation law to the committee appointed on April 27 to examine and report on the present condition of appropriations and finances. The Republicans voted solidly for the suspension of the act, the Democrats, on the other hand, arraying themselves with equal solidity against the measure.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Chairman Finley and the management of the Chicago and Alton Railroad cannot agree. This has been demonstrated every few days for about two months, but has never been so clearly set forth as it is in the opposing pronunciamentos of the two parties on the question of the Alton's liability under the agreement for refusing to restore passenger rates between Kansas City and St. Louis and St. Louis and Chicago.

The output of domestic tin plate has fallen off in the office of the Cleveland Leader, as well as in the columns of certain other McKinley papers. On May 21 the Leader said, in an editorial paragraph relating to a meeting of "the tin-plate manufacturers of the United States":

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 15. -- The body of Eugene St. Cyr, the suicide whose dramatic death took place Saturday evening at the West End Hotel, is at the Morgue awaiting identification. Dr. Schweig of New-York, to whom St. Cyr consigned his body for scientific purposes, telegraphed to-day that the man was a stranger and that he declined to receive the body.

The Executive Committee of the People's Municipal League met at 31 Nassau Street yesterday afternoon. Horace E. Deming was the Chairman, and others present were Samuel H. Ordway, J.G. Agar, Gustav Schwab, William S. Opdyke, Percival Knauth, J.J. Chapman, and J. Noble Hayes.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 15. -- J.K. Emmet, the comedian, died at Cornwall this morning at 11:15 o'clock. He was in poor health when he arrived at Cornwall about ten days ago, and the symptoms of pneumonia developed about a week ago. He was in charge of a nurse, the village doctor visited him daily, and at last a New-York physician was called in consultation. He failed, however, to rally from the disease.

ALBANY, June 15. -- Two years ago Controller Wemple appointed Edward J. Shanahan voucher clerk in his office. The position of voucher clerk is included in Schedule B of the civil service rules, and the applicant must, under the law, submit to a competitive examination, Shanahan was not required by the Controller to take the examination until the Controller was threatened with a suit, Shanahan then went before the examiners and passed.

The very serious nature of the charges made against the men and methods that dominate in the high offices of the New-York Life Insurance Company appears to have thrown the office of that company into a state of confusion yesterday. Apparently the charges were of sufficient importance to warrant extraordinary precautions in the matter of visitors, for First Vice President Tuck and second Vice President Welch were both too busy to be seen.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- The crew from the University of Pennsylvania will be here tomorrow. Just when the Cornell eight will arrive is not known, but it will undoubtedly be before Thursday. The Cornell men will make the Crocker House their headquarters. Courtney, their coach, has never lost a race with the Cornell crew, and he is said to have no fear of the result this year.
The Brooklyns won a close and interesting game from the Cincinnati team at Eastern Park yesterday. Five persons in the free seats were overcome by the heat. Score.

The distinction of being publicly hissed fell yesterday for the first time to the lot of the Prince of WALES. Although he was not hissed in person, but by proxy, as it were, in the form of the tune named for him, this is a demonstration that will probably affect the Prince more than all the strictures of the press.

The statement made in THE TIMES yesterday that charges of a most serious nature were preferred three years ago by Cashier Theodore Banta of the New-York Life against one or more of the executive officers of the company was discussed in financial circles yesterday as a matter of great importance.

PEEKSKILL, June 16. -- The plaintive, wail of the whippoorwill, which was heard last night, and the shrill whistle of "Bob White," which broke the stillness of the early morning, gave encouragement to the occupants of the camp that the sweltering weather from which officers and men suffered would undergo a change before the day's close.

AURORA, N.Y., June 16. -- Aurora, one of the most charming villages on Cayuga Lake, is wearing this week its holiday dress. Wells College, with its fair maidens who represent at least sixteen States, is celebrating its twenty-third Commencement. The college buildings, situated on rising ground just south of the village, in a location of beauty almost unsurpassed, are in their neatest trim.

The trial of Col. KING in Memphis for the murder of D.H. POSTON promises to enrich the court reports of Tennessee with more exact definitions of certain terms than have yet obtained legal sanction in the South. The defendant was testifying on Monday concerning his use of weapons upon certain persons in the course of his rather eventful life.

NEW-LONDON, June 16. -- The Thames is at present the training ground for seven college crews, the Yale 'Varsity and Freshmen, Columbia College 'Varsity and Freshmen, Harvard 'Varsity and Freshmen, and the University of Pennsylvania.
HAMILTON, N.Y., June 16. -- At the annual meeting of the Trustees of Colgate University, held to-day, the following communication was received from the President of the board:

Big Amos Rusie, the muscular Hoosier and star pitcher of the Giants, proved to be more than a match for Mr. Anson and his team of championship aspirants. He did not allow the visitors to score a run yesterday, so skillfully did he pitch, and they were only credited with two hits. These were of the scratch order, so that the Chicagos failed to make a clean hit throughout the contest.

Senator Charles F. Manderson of Nebraska same to New-York from West Point yesterday. As a member of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs he has been looking over the academy there. He is at the Windsor Hotel.
In the course of some remarks about the Sugar Trust the Cleveland Leader, which directly represents Mr. MCKINLEY, gives this information to its readers:

LONDON, June 16. -- The popular crusade against the Prince of Wales shows no signs of abating in strength or bitterness. After the lecture delivered last night at Carnarvon Wales, by Mr. Henry M. Stanley, the band played "God Bless the Prince of Wales." The Welshmen, however, no sooner heard the first strains of the familiar air than they raised a storm of hisses which almost drowned the noise of the band.

It was reported yesterday that the committee of the Union Club appointed to select and secure a site for a new clubhouse had been impressed with the availability of the block of land on the east side of Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets, known as the Marble Block, which belonged to Mrs. Mary Mason Jones, who died two weeks ago.

The population of London, according to the census of 1891, is 5,633,330. This is "Greater London," including the suburban districts, and shows the metropolis to contain more people than Ireland (4,706,162) by almost a million. The result has come only in part by the growth of London, for "the most distressful country" has, during the decade, lost nearly half a million, (468,674.)

A jury before Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday gave John Barkley a verdict of $1,928 against Charles Seaton. Barkley is a truckman, and carts bullion for banks. In 1889 he took 131 bars of silver, to carry from the American Exchange Bank at Broadway and Cedar Street to the steamship Umbria. On the way to the steamship two of the bars were stolen.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- The report of the expert accountants, showing in detail what ex-City Treasurer Bardsley did with the $445,000 that he embezzled from the school fund, was submitted to Mayor Stuart yesterday and by him forwarded to Councils' investigating committee to-day. The report is as follows:

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, N.Y., June 16. -- Two thousand or more people who came here to-day to see 50,000 cubic yards of rock in P. Callahan's limestone quarry displaced by one enormous blast, according to the programme laid down by Mr. Callahan, were sadly disappointed. Instead of one blast there were three, and although thousands of tons of rock were torn from the side of a big hill the effect was not at all wonderful.

It is evident from the correspondence which led up to the agreement for a closed season for seal taking in a part of Bering Sea that the British Government was constrained, in consequence of the delays which have heretofore occurred in the negotiations and of the lateness of the season, to yield about every point which it suggested for the purpose of making the arrangement completely effective.

I beg the courtesy of your columns for the purpose of a personal explanation. I observe in this morning's paper that your reporter states that, at an interview with Vice President Welch and myself at the office of the New-York Life Insurance Company on Saturday afternoon, I denied that I had ever known anything about any investigation of certain charges made by Mr. Banta.

The man who makes the Summer weather --the nice, hot Summer weather -- dealt a sledgehammer blow at the record yesterday and nearly smashed it to pieces. The thermometer at Hudnut's toiled patiently up and down until, at 3:30 o'clock P.M., it registered 99. Sweltering thousands observed the figures with interest and discomfort and tried in vain to recall a day when it had been so hot.

BOSTON, June 16. -- When the sulkies made their first appearance of this season at Mystic Park to-day there was a much firmer track than the one they whirled over last week at Providence. It was much too hot for comfort, and the two contests passed off quietly.

The recent disclosures in Philadelphia have caused great tumult in the columns of the Manufacturer of that city, a journal published by one of the two high-tariff organizations in this country. We take the following from one of the Manufacturer's articles on the subject:

Interest at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday again centred and was absorbed in the Battery Park grab, which occupied the attention of the board during twenty of the forty minutes that the meeting lasted. The subject was introduced by Alderman John Morris, the mover of the anti-grab resolutions two weeks ago, who offered the following:

ALBANY, June 16. -- The great canal investigation farce which Gov. Hill's stock company is billed to present this Summer for the benefit of the canal ring was resumed this afternoon. None of the Republican members of the company was present, and Chairman McMahon had only three assistants, all Democrats.

The Republican Convention that met at Columbus, Ohio, yesterday, will be remembered for some time for two things -- for having bowed out of public life the venerable and eminent JOHN SHERMAN, and for having put in nomination for Governor of the State WILLIAM MCKINLEY, the representative par excellence of the policy on which the party was badly defeated in 1890 -- for it may safely be assumed that Mr. MCKINLEY will be nominated to-day.

Fire in the village of Casselman, Ontario, yesterday, destroyed the sawmills of the Casselman Lumber Company, six houses, immense piles of lumber and the stables in connection with the mills. The losses are $40,00 on the mill, $70,000 on lumber, and $5,000 on horses and stables. The total loss is $115,000 and the total insurance $70,000, in the Caledonia, Phoenix, and Western Companies.

The twenty-sixth annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club was sailed yesterday and was remarkable for the introduction of forty-six foot yachts as a distinct class into the yacht racing annals of this country. They made a great race, and the new Herreshoff boat Gloriana ran away from all of her competitors in the handsomest style. Even the boats of those famous designers, Burgess and Fife, wore left far in the rear.

There are one or two points in the criticism of "J. 3:[. 0." to my theory of "Snakes" whi0b I wish to set right. The rest -- vie., transcendentalism and hypnotism -- he knows the facts of Just as well as any one, for there being but few facts in either of these "fads" there ls but little for any one to know.
The principal winners at the meeting of the New York Jockey Club which closed on Monday were the following owners:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16. -- Columbus has been overflowing with politicians to-day. The crowd of delegates and friends of candidates was swelled by an influx from Washington calculated to suggest the suspension of business at the national capital. The scene about the hotels, from the early hours of the morning, was one not likely to be forgotten by those participating in the struggle.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, June 16. -- The Rutgers Commencement meeting of the Board of Trustees was held this morning. There was a large crowd at the grounds to see the exhibition drill of the cadets. The Junior exhibition was given in the Opera House in the evening. Notwithstanding the heat the ladies and their escorts turned out in large numbers, and the speakers were fairly showered with bouquets.

Tenny is no longer king; no longer a public idol. The supposed to-be invincible King of the Turf of 1891 is uncrowned. A princeling among the heroes of the turf, that sort of Henry of Battenberg among the equine aristocrats, Loantaka, dethroned the King in yesterday's race for the Suburban, the great tourney of the year for handicap horses.
Young Mr. HARRISON'S Illustrated News-paper gives prominence to "two important suggestions" for the settlement of the silver coinage question:

CHICAGO, June 16. -- R.W. Dunham Co., grain and stock commission men, petitioned the Circuit Court to-day for the appointment of a receiver, and the business was placed in the hands of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank. At the same time proceedings were instituted in the county court by Moses Born, who charged the firm with fraudulent practices and asked that an assignee be appointed.

Miss Julia T. Beers of New-York City, a member of the graduating class of Mount Holyoke Seminary, Massachusetts, was driving with her mother on Monday at Mount Holyoke, when the horse ran away. Both ladies were badly injured.

It is a sad truth that great intelligence in the practical application of scientific knowledge does not necessarily involve common sense, as is shown by the talk of MR. WERNER VON SIEMENS, the German electrician, reported in our Berlin dispatch. This gentleman, discussing the project of a German World's Fair in 1896, declared that "the European nations are becoming aware they must consolidate commercially as against American aggression."

The Police Commissioners took the first step yesterday toward carrying out the provisions of the police matrons law adopted at the last session of the Legislature, by designating ten of the police stations in this city for the detention and temporary confinement of females while under arrest and awaiting arraignment at the police courts.

Folks who sail up the Hudson River rarely fail to notice the roofs and tower of the big stone manor house rising above the trees on the summit of a rocky hill that climbs abruptly almost at the water's edge directly north of the long line of black railroad piers and sheds at Hoboken. Inquisitive strangers to the metropolis are sure to ask what that place is, and they rarely get a satisfactory answer.

The Commencement exercises of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn took place last evening in the Academy of Music in the presence of about 2,500 people. President David H. Cochran presided, and, after the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott had made an address, he presented the diplomas to the thirty-three graduates.

RED BANK, N.J., June 16. -- Seabright was visited this afternoon by a most destructive fire. It broke out at 4:30 o'clock in A.S. Buckalew's livery stable, and in four hours' time the business portion of the village, the fishing settlement, and many houses were in ashes, and 300 families were rendered homeless.

Folks who sail up the Hudson River rarely fail to notice the roofs and tower of the big stone manor house rising above the trees on the summit of a rocky hill that climbs abruptly almost at the water's edge directly north of the long line of black railroad piers and sheds at Hoboken. Inquisitive strangers to the metropolis are sure to ask what that place is, and they rarely get a satisfactory answer.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 17. -- The thirty-fifth annual Commencement of Seton Hall College took place this afternoon. The attendance was very large. Thomas A. Tole was honor man and Francis J. Haggerty was the salutatorian. These degrees were conferred:

The stories of wholesale slaughter of malcontents in Port au Prince were supplemented yesterday by others of an even more atrocious nature. In Haiti's capital the alleged insurrectionists were killed outright, in the outlying towns they were subjected to lingering torture. Jacmel, a little town on the southwestern coast, furnished six of the victims.

When David B. Hill's three agents who compose the State Civil Service Commission rode over the wishes of the Regents of the University of New-York, they locked horns with no mean antagonists. As a result of the board's action in declaring the Regents' inspectors subject to the competitive classification and naming July 2 as the date when examinations would be held, the Regents have declared formally that they will have no officials of this sort.
