NEW-BRUNSWICK, June 17. -- Rutgers College's one hundred and twenty-fifth Commencement was held to-day, the President, members of the Faculty, Trustees, and students marching in a body from the campus to the Opera House, which was filled. The orators and their themes were: M.C. Sears, Blooming Grove, N.Y., "Collegiate Institutions," and valedictory addresses; F.H. Cook, Bound Brook, Master's oration; E.C. Bryan of Skekemoko, N.Y., German salutatory.

Heat and humidity got up early yesterday morning and started in to make a day of it. They were highly successful up to 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and it can be only conjectural what triumphs they would have achieved had not a thunder storm checked their distressing career.

Enough has been made known regarding the methods of the New-York Life Insurance Company to make a thorough investigation of its affairs and a complete change of management necessary if public confidence in the institution is to be restored. If this is done, and done promptly, the policy holders of the company, which is carrying a vast volume of insurance, aggregating over $500,000,000, will have no occasion for alarm.

The latest device to which Mr. FOSTER, the Secretary of the Treasury, has given his mind is the issue of certificates against the $20,000,000 fractional currency now lying unused and unusable in the vaults of the Treasury. He hesitates because he does not feel quite sure that such a step would be legal, and he will, it is said, ask an opinion of the Attorney General on that point.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 17. -- The thermometer took a big drop very suddenly to-day, and extra precautions were taken by the oarsmen at Cale's Ferry to avoid catching cold. A severe storm of wind and rain, which did some damage in the upper valley of the Thames, passed over this place about 2 o'clock, but this city got only the edge of it.

Some of MCKINLEY'S lieutenants in the West complain that the new tariff laws are not strictly enforced at the great ports of entry on the Atlantic coast. When the Ohio wool grower growls at the falling price of his wool he is told by the three famous political shepherds in his State that importers are treated with too much respect and leniency at the Custom Houses.

BOSTON, June 17. -- Boston's team celebrated the anniversary of the battle of Bunker Hill here to-day by administering two defeats to the gilt-edged club from Brooklyn. The local players won both in the easiest possible manner. They did not do much hitting, but that was unnecessary, as the Brooklyns fielded in a most slovenly manner.

The Berkeley Athletic Club held its first annual members' field meeting at the Berkeley Oval, at Morris Dock, yesterday afternoon, but had its fun seriously interfered with by that implacable handicapper, J. Pluvius. The shower which came along at 2:30 o'clock converted much of the track and infield into good old-fashioned mud, and kept the one hundred visitors waiting for an hour in the railroad stations.

SALISBURY, Conn., June 17. -- This ancient town honored her soldier dead to-day by the dedication of a handsome monument to their memory. For several weeks past the residents have been making preparations for the event, and to-day, when the morning dawned clear and bright, there was life and bustle at the first peep of day. There was barely a house in town without its decoration of flags and bunting.

Chief of Police Hood of Kingston, N.Y., went to South Rondout yesterday, in company with Deputy Sheriff John Miller of Cortland County, and arrested Lewis B. Harkins, Principal of the public school there. Harkins is charged with a serious offense on complaint of the Superintendent of the Poor of Cortland County.

Gen. GROSVENOR of Ohio has been appointed an agent of the Treasury Department to go abroad to promote the interests of the World's Fair. Exactly what he is to do for the Treasury Department in that matter is not specified, but that seems to be regarded as less important than getting him out of the country during the State campaign in Ohio.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 17. -- Two hundred of the citizens and leading business men of Long Branch assembled in Castle Hall to-night in response to a call to perfect arrangements to assist in providing for the destitute families of Seabright. Mayor George W. Brown presided. The subscription of money reported was over $1,000, and it is expected by to-morrow night to have over $5,000 subscribed.

The sale of J.B. Haggin's thoroughbred yearlings, was begun at the salesroom of Tattersalls of New-York, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, last evening. The handsome salesroom, brilliantly illuminated with electric lights, held a goodly number of horsemen, and some fifty ladies listened to Mr. Easton's efforts to secure bids for the younsters offered to the highest bidder.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- A rather foolish rumor has been set afloat to the effect that Third Vice President Springer of the Atchison Road may soon meet the fate that befell Traffic Manager Leeds of the Missouri Pacific. Mr. Springer's crime is having disregarded an order of Commissioner Midgely to discontinue divisions of through rates with the Indiana. Illinois and Iowa Road on traffic from the Missouri River to the seaboard.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 17. -- The annual meeting of the University Alumni was held to-day. These officers were elected: Dr. George H. Fox, '67, President; Walter S. Hubbell, '71, Vice President; George H. Smith, '81, Secretary; Herman K. Phinney, '77, Treasurer; Executive Committee -- Luther M. Hair, '77; Albert H. Harris, '81; Fred J. Smythe, '84.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Lloyd Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Woodruff of Brooklyn, to Frederick Blake Holder of Boston, yesterday afternoon, was one of the largest of the season in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed at 4:30 o'clock in the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, Clinton and Lafayette Avenues, by the Rev. Dr. T.B. McLeod, the pastor, in the presence of nearly 500 guests.

KEOKUK, Iowa, June 17. -- To-morrow will be a gala day for Keokuk society, made so by the nuptials of Gen. John M. Schofield and Miss Georgia Kilbourne. The arrangements for the wedding are about completed. Many prominent persons will be present, among them relatives and friends from Washington and New-York. The ceremony will be performed in St. John's Church at noon with the Episcopal ritual.

The expressions of the temporary Chairman of the Ohio Republican Convention on Tuesday and those of Major MCKINLEY yesterday give much too favorable an idea of the real feeling of the convention on the important question of finance and currency. This was embodied in the platform, and was as follows:

The Board on Geographical Names, which consists of certain officers of the Coast and Geological Surveys, the Engineer Corps, the Lighthouse Board, the Hydrographic Office, Smithsonian Institution, and Post Office Department, has adopted a good rule in getting rid of many needless instances of the possessive case in names of places.

The storm in Brooklyn yesterday delayed but did not stop the memorial services over the tomb of the martyrs in Fort Greene Park. The crowds fled to adjoining shelters and then marched back to the park, accompanied by the Grand Army men, the Old Brooklynites, the Daughters of the American Revolution, and a large number of school children.

PEEKSKILL, June 17. -- "Ours" maintained its reputation to-day as a weather breeder. One of the unwritten laws of the Camp of Instruction runs in this wise: "When the Twenty-third occupies the military post at Peekskill, look out for hurricanes, rain, hail, and thunder and lightning."

When the iron steamboat Cetus left the Coney Island pier last night, a nasty, damp breeze was blowing, and most of her passengers took refuge in the cabins and on the middle deck. She was the last boat for the city, and when the gang plank was drawn in probably seven hundred passengers were aboard.

AURORA, N.Y., June 17. -- This has been Commencement Day at Wells College, and Aurora had many more visitors than yesterday. The Trustees held their annual meeting at 10 o'clock, but there was not a full attendance. Among the absentees was Mrs. Grover Cleveland, who was made Trustee in 1887. Gen. William H. Seward of Auburn, a well-known friend of the college, was elected a member of the board.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 17. -- The reports of the fire that raged here last night were not exaggerated. On the contrary, the experiences of the cottage owners and storekeepers and the destruction among the poor have not been fully described. The homeless ones would have fared much worse but for the charitable cottage owners and hotel proprietors who came to their relief and threw open their doors to them.

ATCHISON, Kan., June 17. -- Irrigation will be given a thorough test in Western Kansas this season. The abundant rains that have fallen this Spring have not lessened the enthusiasm of the people a particle. In every county companies have been organized and work is actively going on.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 17. -- The Kansas Farmer will to-morrow publish a report of the condition of the crops as sent in by correspondents from all counties in Kansas. In making a summary, the Farmer says:

The publication in THE TIMES yesterday of certain charges alleged to have been made three years ago by Cashier Theodore Banta against William H. Beers, President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, brought to a climax the widespread popular interest that has been awakened in the affairs of that company. Particularly among financial men were the charges as printed in substance in THE TIMES read with avidity.

Arguments for and against the application of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Railroad Company for permission to use the trolley electric system as a motive power were heard by the State Railroad Commissioners in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday. Commissioners Rogers, Rickard, and Baker were present. Mr. William N. Dykman of Brooklyn appeared for the railroad company and Assistant Corporation Counsel Arthur C. Salmon of Brooklyn spoke against the application.

" Brag," it is said in the old adage, "is a good dog, but Holdfast is a better." The Republicans of Ohio, with the evident consciousness of opening the campaign of 1892, started out yesterday with "Brag" and left "Holdfast" to follow as he chooses. They took Major MCKINLEY for their candidate and McKinleyism for their platform, and with ill-concealed indifference left Senator SHERMAN to his fate.

ALBANY, June 17. -- Very weary is the Hannan-Sheehan vindication committee to-night. Its members feel much as the Indian did who tried to lasso the locomotive -- somewhat "broken up." The committee started out this morning with the avowed intention of proving William F. Sheehan to be a political saint. Incidentally, it proposed to "do up" George P. Smith of Tonawanda, who has made pretty serious charges against Mr. Sheehan and Attorney General Tabor.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday dispatched important letters to Corporation Counsel Clark and Commissioner Gilroy relative to the proper status of certain men now employed on the new aqueduct. At the last meeting of the Committee on Construction, City Auditor Lyon, on behalf of the Controller, stated that the Finance Department would not approve the bills of those men who were employed by the Aqueduct Board to "maintain" the aqueduct.

The weather of the last two days is a sufficient admonition that nothing that can be done, either by public or private means, to mitigate the discomforts of those who are compelled to remain in town during the Summer can be excessive. The free public baths, which are not all in operation as yet, ought to be opened at once, and it is questionable whether others ought not to be added.

A real question has been found for the Aldermen to consider in connection with the occupation of Battery Park by the elevated railroad. The question is raised whether the Park Commission has any power over the parks except for their care and preservation as public pleasure grounds, and whether it did not violate its trust in permitting the encroachment of the railroad.

PEEKSKILL, June 18. -- Fifteen minutes of battalion drill represented the amount of military work performed by the Twenty-third Regiment to-day outside of guard and sentry duty, not from lack of disposition, but because of meteorological obstacles.

We have read a complete report of Senator SHERMAN'S speech at Columbus, and we find in it not a word about his law for the suppression of Trust combinations. During the weeks when he was supporting this measure in the Senate, at times he assailed all Trust combinations with most vehement and passionate denunciation, and in October last he assured the people of Ohio that the act had already had a beneficial effect.

Of late sensible and practical persons have been brought much nearer than such persons have ever been brought before to a belief in the feasibility of aerial navigation. Meanwhile, incidents continue to be reported that show the perils of the air to be much more frightful and much more imminent than the perils of the sea.

There was a full meeting of the Directors of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company in this city yesterday, at which the financial situation was fully discussed. For some time past there has been talk in Wall Street about this road being in financial straits. The possibility of a receivership has been suggested, and publicity has been given to reports concerning the alleged surreptitious sale of a large block of preferred stock.

Advices receives from Haiti yesterday indicate an astonishing condition of affairs in that land and increases the wonder that foreign powers maintain diplomatic relations with a country where international law is so little respected.

An incidental point of some interest in connection with the effort of Brooklyn street railroad companies to get permission to introduce the trolley electric system is the question whether church property is to be included in obtaining the consent of property owners. It was contended yesterday by the counsel of one of the companies that only property assessed for taxation should be included.

About 2,900 members of the Produce Exchange cherished a grievance against fate yesterday. There had been a fight, a real fight, between two of their brethren, and they hadn't seen it. Sporting blood has been at an ebb on the Exchange those many months, and the heart of the average broker longs for a "scrap" of the good old kind in the days when a floor committeeman, to retain his popularity, had to be near-sighted.
Commencement exercises of the College of the City of New-York were held last night in the Academy of Music. The hall was crowded to the doors.
The average man can draw but one moral from all this talk about the Merzbacher hypothecation -- that too large a share of life insurance premiums goes for salaries and commissions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 18. -- Reports from Kansas to-day in regard to wheat were more discouraging than they had been since the chinch-bug scare. The continued wet weather has just begun to affect matters, and is lending part of its gloom to the farmer and the grain man.

ST. LOUIS, June 18. -- It is practically settled that the Telegraphers' Brotherhood and the Order of Railway Telegraphers will amalgamate, and as one order will be taken into the Federation of Railway Employes. There has been very strong opposition to this, and this opposition at one time went so far as to threaten injunction proceedings.

Commissioner Rogers and his associates on the State Board of Railroad Commissioners sat in the Chamber of Commerce Committee Room yesterday morning and listened to arguments for and against the application of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company of Brooklyn for permission to use the trolley electric system as a motive power instead of horses.

In sixteen hours New-York people passed from a torrid midsummer temperature into rawness and dampness like that of early April. Men who almost roasted Wednesday donned their topcoats yesterday and turned up their collars to keep off the chill of a cold air and a dirty Scotch mist. The drop of the mercury from Wednesday afternoon to 6 A.M. yesterday was 37.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- The joint committee of the trades unions of this city have decided to send a letter to President Harrison asking that in all work done by the Federal Government in connection with the World's Fair the eight-hour day be recognized, all disputes settled by arbitration, and not less than the recognized minimum scales of wages for the various trades recognized in this city be paid.

An attempt is apparently being made to put new life into the New-York Cable Railway Company, which was practically knocked out by the Court of Appeals, which declared that its charter was incomplete. Secretary Charles E. Gildersleeve called at the County Clerk's office yesterday with a certified copy of an amended certificate of incorporation, the original of which he had filed with the Secretary of State.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- The question of dividing competitive traffic on a percentage basis and thus accomplishing the results formally obtained by pooling is agitating the Transcontinental Association, which is in session hero. At a meeting of the passenger department to-day a report was received from a special committee recommending a plan, but after much discussion action was postponed until to-morrow.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., June 18. -- The special train bearing the President, his family, and his party arrived at Cape May Point at 5:15 o'clock this afternoon, coming by way of Trenton. The train was drawn over the Delaware Bay and Cape May Railroad from Cape May City by two dummy engines, and consisted of a baggage car and the Pullman coach Cleopatra.

Curious things developed at last night's meeting of the Republican County Committee held in Grand Opera House Hall. To all intents and purposes the notorious political charlatan, Frederick S. Gibbs, was taken back into full fellowship in the County Committee. Nominally, Gibbs has no standing in the Republican Party, but last night he sat with his new delegation to the County Committee when it was welcomed back.

ALBANY, June 18. -- This has been contractors' day with Gov. Hill's light-comedy aggregation now performing in this city. A dozen or so bronzed and horny-handed individuals, most of them Democrats who have been successful bidders for canal contracts in the past, have related their experiences and attested to the immaculate character of the canal management.

The lumber dealers have taken a most important step to protect themselves against organized labor and boycotts. A plan has been formulated by the Lumber Dealers' Association which will be of great assistance to the weaker members of the trade in case of such a disturbance as that through which it has just passed. The plan is the outcome of the consultations of the Committee on Organization of the association.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 18. -- The Cornell crews, which arrived here by steamer this morning, are thoroughly disheartened. They left Ithaca yesterday morning in a special car over the Delaware and Lackawanna Railroad. They had one shell with them which was new last year, and which the Freshmen were intending to use in the race with the Columbia Freshmen Saturday. They fastened the shell up under the roof of the car on the outside.

Robert T. Jones, who murdered his father-in-law and two brothers-in-law in Edgefield County, S.C., was sentenced to twenty-one years' imprisonment yesterday. On his sixth trial he was convicted of manslaughter.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 18. -- This has been a dreary day for the unfortunates who were burned out by Tuesday night's big fire. Last night an easterly storm set in and continued all night. To-day the cold ocean wind was accompanied by a drizzle which will probably last through the night.

Commander George A. Converse, commanding the United States steamer Enterprise, has been directed by the Navy Department to hold himself in readiness to be detached from the command of the Enterprise on or about July 10 and receive an assignment as President of a permanent Torpedo Board. The board will consist of three members.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 18. -- Premier Abbott, in reply to the charges made by the Liberals that he signed an annexation manifesto in 1849, and is, according to Conservative principles, a traitor, says:
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The following is a list of persons selected for examination for appointment to the army from civil life:

According to the Washington reports, the actual net cash in the Treasury, by to-day's statement, will be exhausted, and a deficiency of $600,000 will be shown. This is according to the old form of statement, which does not include the fractional currency or the money in the national bank depositories.

NEW-HAVEN, June 18. -- The Directors of the Yale University Alumni Fund Association have issued their first annual report. This association was established at Commencement last year to enable the graduates of the university to contribute small sums, to be applicable to any uses of the university, but principally to meet ordinary college expenses. The number of members now in this association is 385.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 18. -- The twenty-third annual Commencement of Cornell University took place in the armory at 9 o'clock to-day. Gartland's Orchestra of Albany opened the exercises with an overture. The speakers from the graduating class and their subjects follow: "Ibsen;

The whitewashing farce of the Assembly Committee at Albany becomes more and more wearisome. A while ago the committee summoned a lot of members of the Legislature who had proposed or favored canal appropriations, and asked them if these were for improper purposes or had been improperly expended.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 18. -- Bernard Glaudi, the Gascon butcher who was convicted of attempting to bribe Tales Juror Henry B. Atwood, was to-day sentenced to one year at hard labor. Glaudi's is a queer case. He protests his innocence and disclaims all connection with the defense, and even put Detective Collings, the State's mainstay, on the stand to prove that he was never in O'Malley's office.

BOSTON, June 18. -- Trinity Church was the scene of a charming wedding this afternoon. A wedding which not even a pouring rain and the general atmosphere of gloom and depression attendant upon it could rob of its brilliance and grace. The occasion was the marriage of Miss Catherine Burr Porter of this city to Mr. Henry H. Porter of New-York.

BINGHAMTON, June 18. -- State Treasurer Elliot Danforth is profoundly interested in politics at the present time, and he is keeping an eye upon his political fences throughout the State. Until three weeks ago he evidently thought he had a walk-over, and that he would be re-elected without much effort. But the candidacy of George F. O'Neil of this city for the office of State Treasurer has put a different appearance on Danforth's prospects.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 18. -- The story recently told by THE TIMES of the elopement of Flora A. Eccleston, the fifteen-year-old daughter of Farmer Devillo Eccleston of the town of Guilford, with Warren McVittie, one of her father's farm hands, and of the midnight marriage of the fugitives at Norwich by Judge Nash, has a most deplorable sequel.

The Paris papers continue to discuss at length and with much feeling the "Quadruple Alliance," which they make out by adding England as a secret ally of Italy, according to the story attributed to Prince NAPOLEON. That unfortunate person seems to be an exception to the rule that dead men tell no tales, for tales on his authority have fairly swarmed in the French press.

In his address to the convention at Columbus Mr. McKINLEY was compelled to notice the protests of those who have pointed out that his promises concerning the tin-plate industry have not been fulfilled, and who are unwilling that the people should be taxed many millions of dollars to encourage the manufacture of tin cups for McKinley dinners and of a few boxes of tin plate to be shown in the windows of McKinley newspaper offices.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Secretary Foster's selection of Mr. H.J. Shulteis as an additional member of the Immigration Commission is meeting with considerable criticism, as the appointment was made at the solicitation of the Federation of Labor, and Shulteis is understood to be entirely in sympathy with the most radical ideas of the leaders of that organization as to the employment of foreign labor in competition with American workingmen.

President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company, who is now abroad, is coming home to aid in straightening out the affairs of his company. He was in Paris yesterday, and in the course of the day his son-in-law, Dr. Henry Tuck, received a cablegram from him stating that he would sail for New-York next Wednesday.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 19. -- At the conclusion of the regular Commencement exercises at the Texas State University last night, Gov. Hogg stated that he had a pleasant duty to perform, which was to present to the university in the name of the donor a valuable collection of ancient coins and medals presented by an old Texan and friend of the university living in New-York.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Acting Secretary Spaulding said to-day that the Government will certainly appeal from the decision rendered in the case of Meyer Dickinson at Philadelphia against the Government for refund of duties paid on bat materials. The amount involved in the question is about $20,000,000, and the Government has already refunded nearly $2,000,000.

In the final hearing on the Battery Park question before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday Mr. THOMAS BARRETT urged, with a good deal of force, the point that the Park Commissioners are trustees of the city for the care and improvement of the parks as public pleasure grounds, and have no power over them for any other purpose unless it is specifically granted and defined by law.

The bridges of the Lake Erie and Western Railroad, between Crandall and Farmdale, Ill., were destroyed Wednesday night by a cloudburst which flooded Farm Creek Valley. Several trains had narrow escapes.

The proposal to call the new 838-ton practice cruiser now building by the MOORES at Elizabethport the George Bancroft is likely to meet with general approval. The vessel is for the use of the naval cadets, and certainly the academy at Annapolis is more indebted to Mr. BANCROFT for its establishment than to any other man.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Census Office will soon publish a report on the mill and forest industries of Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota, comprising what is known as the "White Pine Group." The bulletin shows that the aggregate increase of "mill products," as compared with the census reports of 1880, is 29.66 per cent. in quantity and 75.92 per cent. in value.

ST. LOUIS, June 19. -- The Order of Railway Telegraphers finished up the work of its convention and adjourned to-day. In addition to the officers elected yesterday, there were elected to-day: Grand Junior Telegrapher -- S. Worth, Canada; Grand Inside Sentinel -- R.P. Wetmore, Texas; Grand Outside Sentinel -- H.F. Werle, New-Jersey.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- It was Class Day at Harvard to-day, but for the first in five years, a cloudless sky, with brightly-shining sun, was not present. The hearts of the Seniors sank within them as they watched the pouring rain of yesterday, and the dark sky and threatening clouds of this morning seemed determined to spoil the festivities.

The Coney Island Jockey Club is very unfortunate in having the worst kind of weather for its meeting this year. This weather is probably accountable for the poor fields in the past few days, but better sport is promised this afternoon. Three stakes, the Surf, for two-year-olds, the Tidal, for three-year-olds, and the Sheepshead Bay Handicap, are on for decision, and all will certainly be productive of good sport.

A graphic story of shipwreck and rescue, which reads like a chapter from the sea tales of Clark Russell, was told yesterday when the German steamship Sophie, with fourteen survivors of the bark Exile, arrived in port. Under command of Capt. Pearce, the bark sailed from Pascagoula, Miss., May 10, bound for Amsterdam.

It was hard work to get up any enthusiasm over the races at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. The weather was all against it -- chilly, damp, and penetrating. Showers fell at intervals, and the track was so heavy that a number of entries were scratched. As there were good fields in four of the six races, there was a lively bit of speculation on these.

People who have followed the varying fort tunes of the struggle between the American Casualty Insurance and Security Company of Baltimore and the Fidelity and Casualty Company of this city find much to interest them in the news from Baltimore, printed in yesterday's TIMES, that the Maryland Court of Appeals has sustained the Insurance Commissioner of the State in his refusal of a license to the New-York Company.

The glorious uncertainties of the national game, as baseball managers are wont to term unexpected defeats, were demonstrated on the Polo Grounds yesterday when the Philadelphia players gave the Giants a severe drubbing. The Quakers left their native heath with the worst wishes of the community. They had lost about a dozen straight games, and they came over here to face the mighty Giants with fear and trembling.

The decision of the Court of Appeals that a bank is hold rigidly responsible for wrongful payments upon forged orders has been recently conspicuously discussed, but an equally striking decision holding a savings bank guiltless under more blameworthy circumstances has escaped attention. In the Bedell case the bank was misled by the check's being genuine.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 19. -- The work of clearing up the debris of Tuesday night's fire was begun to-day, but no building has been commenced owing to the storm. Last night the tents were unoccupied, and the homeless people for the second time lodged in the hotels and cottages. More tents arrived to-day, and some of them were pitched on the beach.

The native party in the Sandwich Islands, whose rallying cry is "Hawaii for the Hawaiians," is again astir, it appears, under its old leaders, ROBERT W. WILCOX and BOYD, and is suspected of plotting to seize Queen LILIUOKALANI and hold her in duress until she promises to put none but Hawaiians on guard, or, rather, in office.

The trotting match which was set for Thursday, but postponed on account of unfavorable weather, was decided yesterday at the Fleetwood track. The match was for $200 a side, mile heats, best three in five, between H. Phillips's bay mare Kitty O. and John O'Neil's bay mare Maggie P. On Thanksgiving Day last the mares met in a match for $250 a side, when Kitty O. won somewhat handily.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 25. -- The difficulty in the trial of Tsuda Sanzo, the Japanese police constable who wounded the Czarowitch, is that no article in the Penal Code of Japan removes his crime from the category of an ordinary murderous assault. The one hundred and sixteenth article of the code says:

CHICAGO, June 19. -- About thirty acres at the World's Columbian Exposition will be given over entirely to State buildings. This area is situated in the extreme north end of the exposition grounds. This part of the park has for a number of years been highly improved. The space immediately in front of the Fine Art Palace has been divided into a sort of semicircle.

PHILADELHIA, June 19. -- The State of Pennsylvania, through Attorney General Hensel, made a formal demand upon Mayor Stuart to-day, as the representative of the city of Philadelphia, for $622,013.11, that amount being due the State from taxes collected by ex-City Treasurer Bardsley and by him embezzled.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 19. -- Every few days something occurs to indicate the powerful political forces at work beneath the surface of affairs in St. Louis. To-day it is the semi-official information that a clean sweep is to be made in the Street Department. Street Commissioner M.J. Murphy has, in accordance with orders, set to work to reorganize his department strictly in the interest of Mayor E.A. Noonan.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 19. -- Col. L.B. Bell, one of the leaders of the Cherokee Nation, and the man who first collected rents from the invaders of the now famous Cherokee Outlet or Strip, was in the city to-day. Col. Bell is not only a shrewd and very influential politician, but is one of the wealthiest men in the nation.

It is no wonder that the Prince of WALES should be reported to resent the lecture that has been read to him by his self-confident nephew, the Emperor of Germany, upon his gambling transactions. He has probably been much fatigued already by the expostulations of the Baptists and Methodists of the United Kingdom, who have not let go a single occasion of remonstrance since the Cumming suit was tried.

PEEKSKILL, June 19. -- All night long the rain poured down, and this morning the camp was about as desolate and dreary a place as could well be imagined. A Scotch mist hung over the grounds and everything was cold, wet, and disagreeable. Nobody cared to look at the thermometer, and everybody declared that it was "as cold as Greenland."

The closing hearing before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen on the Battery Park matter attracted a number of speakers yesterday, and the character of the proceedings showed some abatement of the reluctance to appearing before this committee that citizens have heretofore felt, and a desire on the part of citizens to treat the pending resolutions as though really serious and important results might follow their adoption.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The North American Commercial Company of San Francisco, lessee of the right to take fur seal on the islands of St. Paul and St. George in Alaska for the period of twenty years from May 1, 1890, have filed a protest with the Acting Secretary of the Treasury, against a close season.

The verdict against the Government in the Philadelphia hat trimming case, if it should be finally sustained, will be a pretty serious matter, as a good many million dollars may be recovered for duties paid under the ruling of the Treasury Department in excess of the legal rate. These rulings, which raise the rates of duty and are afterward upset, have two serious drawbacks.

The little athletic entertainment in one round, in which Messrs. William C. Hawk and Harry L. Daniels took part, in the reception room next door to the room of the Arbitration Committee of the Produce Exchange, is not likely to be forgotten soon. Yesterday the Complaint Committee gave a hearing in the case, and Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock it will come before the Board of Managers of the Exchange.

There was a rumor yesterday that a compromise had been arrived at between E.W. McClave and his associates and the Union Ferry Company by virtue of which Mr. McClave and those behind him had agreed to cease to prosecute their suit to have the recent May-Englis appraisal of the ferry company's property declared extravagant and void.

The North American Commercial Company has entered its protest against the assent of the United States Government to the closed season for sealing in Bering Sea, and has given notice that it claims to be indemnified by the Government for its losses, not only this year, but last year, in having the number of seals that it was permitted to take under its contract cut down.

CLEVELAND, June 19. -- To-day's game was one of the most exciting and best played of the season. Cleveland tied the score in the ninth on Davis's single to left field. A scratch hit to right field by Pfeffer sent Anson in with the winning run after two men were out. Anson got to first on Denny's wild throw. Score:

YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 26. -- The news of a serious outbreak among the Chinese at Wuhu, on the Yang-tse-Kiang River, about three hundred miles above Shanghai, has just been telegraphed here. On the 12th a Chinese mobiled by a few fanatical Buddhist priests, attacked Catholic mission buildings, burning them, and then proceeded to sack the foreign settlement.

A suit brought by Julia A. Schwartz against Peter B. Sweeny To recover $230 for show cards printed in 1890 was put on trial before Judge Pryor and a jury in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, but as the trial was not finished within the hour allotted to short-cause cases the case was put back on the regular calendar.

LONDON, June 19. -- Dispatches received here from Melbourne state that the latest advices from Samoa are to the effect that Chief Mataafa, accompanied by a body of natives, had started for Mahe, the centre of the intrigue which is known to exist against the sovereign rights of King Malietoa Laupepa. It is believed that this movement upon the part of Mataafa will lead to further trouble.

Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS of St. Louis, who is now in New-York, will be glad to learn that since he came to this city the Philadelphia Press has greatly enlarged his tin-plate factory. We assume, of course, that this has been done at the expense of our contemporary, and that no part of the cost will come out of the owner's pocket.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Evidence of the rottenness in the affairs of R.W. Dunham Co., the insolvent Board of Trade Commission firm, is daily accumulating. The investigation now on foot in the County Court will, it is claimed, not only show suspicious real estate transfers and questionable deals, but transactions on the part of one of the members of the firm which are not legitimate.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., June 20. -- Commencement week was a very pleasant one, though the warm weather Monday and Tuesday maple the Class Day and Commencement exercises trying. Last Friday evening the different societies had their annual suppers. The Delphic Literary Society during the forepart of the evening listened to the final competitive debate for the Underwood prize for Improvement in Debate.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- To those persons who know the real state of affairs on the Pribilof Islands, the protest against the close season for seals, sent to the Secretary of the Treasury yesterday by Blaine's friends in the North American Commercial Company, appears to be both impudent and ludicrous.

BUENAVENTURA, June 2. -- What is there generally known of the Southern portion of the Republica de Colombia, South America, outside of prosy consular reports? I will venture to assert very little indeed, either geographically, politically, or commercially. Yet this country, heretofore so neglected and unobserved by the European as well as the American world, is undoubtedly destined to become a most important factor in the growing commerce of the United States.

The report that Republican politicians in Minnesota are organizing low-tariff clubs throughout the State to counteract the defection of tariff reformers from the party, following close upon the bold adoption of McKinleyism in Ohio, indicates that it is going to be a difficult matter to hold Republicans together on the tariff issue in the Northwest in the next national campaign.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Augustin Daly's company of comedians finished this evening the second week of one of the most prosperous engagements it has over played in this city. The extreme heat of Monday and Tuesday had a perceptible effect on the attendance, though the audiences were large even on those nights; but during the remainder of the week Hooley's was crowded to the doors in every part.

A purveyor of club sensation has started a rumor to the effect that a club exclusively for born and bred New-Yorkers was soon to be established in this town of clubs. The all-around clubmen, who cam generally discount the club news of to-morrow, pronounce the rumor a myth, and vow its author captured it in dreamland instead of in clubland.

If the American Commonwealth had been constructed, as many of us seem to think that it was, to fit the principles brought over from Paris by THOMAS JEFFERSON, it might be a matter of surprise that our people trust so much to that vague entity, the Government, and are so little able or ready to provide efficient machinery for protecting their own rights.

PEEKSKILL, June 20. -- The experience of the Brooklyn pilgrims with the Peekskill sharks was one not likely soon to be forgotten. Between the camp ground and the Roa Hook dock, where the excursion steamer was lying, extends a long stretch of sand and loam, hardly rising to the dignity of the ordinary country lane, but which a great many indifferently-informed people persist in calling the "military road" of the post.

Kings County expects to play an important part in both the Republican and Democratic State Conventions this Fall, and the local managers of both parties are talking confidently about having a candidate on the State ticket. The warring Republicans have buried the hatchet very deep indeed, and old-time enemies are parading about in one another's company in a way that would usually be regarded as conspicuous.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 20. -- The recent heavy rains have made the leaves a brighter hue and carried delight to the farmers whose crops have suffered from the dry weather. Next Wednesday all the hotels will be opened and the season fairly started. The Court of Appeals will adjourn Thursday and each of the Judges will literally go home for a vacation.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 20. -- If indications are to be depended upon and the opinions of practical farmers are worth anything, the peach crop of the Delaware Peninsula this year will be one of the largest on record. The total failures of the past two years promise to be succeeded by a crop that will, to a very considerable extent, make amends for the losses that these failures have imposed.

Lucy looked across the table at me with a face of blank horror. "Oh, Vernon!" she cried "what are we ever to do? And an American at that! This is just too ghastly!" It's a habit of Lucy's, I may remark, to talk italics.

INDIANA, Penn., June 20. -- When the grizzled veterans of Indiana Post, No. 28, G.A.R., on Tuesday laid to rest their comrade Thomas Sylvanus, they buried a soldier whose life had been of more than passing interest.

There has been a good deal to keep educational circles in Queens County in a continual state of ferment, beginning with Mayor Patrick J. Gleason's onslaught on Principal A. Hall Burdick last year. This senseless meddling of a political demagogue with educational affairs had a demoralizing effect on all the schools in Long Island City, from which they have not yet fully recovered.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., June 20. -- Great excitement was caused here this afternoon when it was learned that Benjamin F. Young, a merchant of Kansas City, Mo., had brought suit against Mills B. Weed, trustee of the F.R. Weed estate of this city and a prominent citizen and banker, charging him with fraud in certain transactions concerning the estate, of which Young is a creditor to the extent of about $30,000.

Students of the University of Notre Dame honored Augustin Daly yesterday in a manner which college boys usually reserve for the boss football player of the season. And Mr. Daly returned the compliment with a distinction which he has sparingly granted to Shakespeare's birthplace and other historic spots that can be counted on one's fingers.

Says the Brattleborough (Vt.) Reformer: "The Boston Herald the other day sent a request to all the Democratic papers of the South, where the anti-Cleveland feeling is said to be rising so high, for a diagnosis of sentiment in their respective localities. Out of nineteen replies, representing every one of the States, all but three reported in favor of Cleveland and only one for Hill.

LONDON, June 20. -- All at once the belated Summer has burst upon England, and such a heated spell has prevailed this week that the cabled reports of the weather in New-York read as if written here. As a result, no one thinks now of anything save sitting under the shade trees surrounded by cooling drinks.

BOSTON, June 20. -- It has just become known that there was some unpleasantness between the court and the bar at the recent session of the United States Circuit Court in Concord, N.H. The trouble started the first day the court was held.

Some of the Farmers' Alliance County Commissioners in Kansas have issued an order that, in the assessment of property for taxation, horses in the various townships shall be made to average $18 a head, mules $18, and cattle $4.50. In certain large towns horses and mules must be assessed at $28 and cattle at $8 a head.

CROTON LANDING, N.Y., June 20. -- A handsome young woman, apparently about twenty years of age, committed suicide this morning by jumping from Shell's brick wharf at this place. Later in the day the body was identified as that of Dolly Davis, a soubrette.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 20. -- The most noticeable features of the Commencement at Wesleyan this year will be the absence of any Class Day exercises, owing to the failure of the class to find among its number persons both willing and able to take the places. Those who could would not, those who would the class did not want. So, instead of the usual exercises, and orchestra will play on the campus in the afternoon.

" Marriages are made in heaven." The saying has never proved more strictly true than in the case of Sister Rose Gertrude, who set out fifteen months ago on her self-imposed mission of love to the Molokai lepers. Full of fervor and enthusiasm for the cause in which good Father Damien had lived and died, the fair young sister went out, well prepared to begin her work at once.

PARIS, June 20. -- The Haitian Minister here has received a letter from the Haitian Secretary of State, dated from Port au Prince, saying that on Corpus Christi Day, May 28, President Hippolyte was attending the religious ceremonies in the Cathedral of Port au Prince, when a band of desperadoes, headed by "an obscure General" named Sully-Guerrier, attacked the prison, forced open the doors, and liberated the prisoners therein confined.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 20. -- Efforts are being made to establish a naval militia in Baltimore similar to the corps organized in New-York and Boston. Considerable correspondence on the subject has passed between the Secretary of the Navy and Gov. Jackson. Those interested have received assurances from the Navy Department that the corvette Wyoming is at their disposal.

The fact that the horsemen searched the cabin convinced Bell and myself that we were not the men they were looking for, but this assurance did not make the prospect look brighter. Our situation and appearance were not in our favor, and that our captors were not prepossessed was evident from their oaths and scowling faces.

" A foreign country," it has been said, "is a kind of contemporaneous posterity." There is one sense, at least, in which this saying is true. It is not given to the ordinary mortal to be accurately informed as to posterity. It is nearly equally difficult to have a clear and complete idea of a foreign country.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- The following members of the Senior Class will be graduated with honors in the several departments named: Mathematics -- Frank Marshall Barber of Rhode Island; Arthur Collins Graves, William George Wright, and George Hermann Wright of Connecticut; Charles Herbert Young of Illinois. Latin -- F.M. Barber, C.H. Young. Greek -- Isaac Wayne Hughes of North Carolina.

The Seawanhaka Corinthians went out yesterday for their twenty-first annual race. It was not a first-rate day for a race, but it was better than many that the club has had within the last ten years. The wind was light at first and unsteady in the early afternoon, but later became a good sailing breeze. There were twenty entries for the race and just half as many starters.

A one-wheel cycle, eight feet high, that a greenhorn can learn to ride in a minute, and then write his name in the dust with it in fifteen feet of space, not to mention a speed capacity of two miles in sixty seconds on a good track, is the astonishing invention which Victor Beranger of Worcester, editor of Le Courrier de Worcester, claims to have produced after two years of hard work.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20. -- The catalogue of the officers and members of the Harvard Law School Association has just been issued. It contains two very handsome illustrations, one of Dane Hall, the old Law School building, the other of Austin Hall, the new Law School building.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 20. -- A collision occurred on the Illinois Central Railroad last night five miles above the city in which four men were killed and six were seriously wounded. A south-bound freight train had switched off at Sauve to let the vestibule mail pass. The signal was given to close the switch, but the switchman misconstrued the order.

The posting for sale on the rostrum of the New-York Stock Exchange of the seats of Harry Markoe of Philadelphia and Cyrus W. Field, Jr., of this city recalls two brief financial careers that have very closely imitated the proverbial ascent of the rocket and descent of the stick.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 20. -- There has been some excellent work done at the Lexington track this week. On the last working-out day the weather was favorable, being warm and dry, and the track, while somewhat hard and dusty, was quite fast. Many spectators were present, and the efforts of the horses were watched with much interest.

It is said that the London ROTHSCHILDS, the financial agents of Brazil in Europe, took occasion to remonstrate with President FONSECA on the wild financial measures of the provisional Government, and to express the hope that the reorganized Cabinet would follow a conservative course and endeavor to restore Brazilian securities to their former quotations.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 20. -- The courtroom was crowded this morning when Frank M. Taylor, Jr., the editor and proprietor of the Long Branch Record came to the bar to answer to a charge of contempt of court. Editor Taylor published last week an article reflecting upon Judge J. Clarence Conover, alleging that he had prostituted his office in the interest of Gov. Leon Abbett.

SOUTH HADLEY, June 20. -- Commencement week opened with a perfect June Sunday. The baccalaureate sermon was preached in the morning in the village church by Dr. Reuen Thomas of Brookline, Mass., from the text, First Corinthians, viii, 1, "Knowledge puffeth up, but love buildeth up," the theme being "The Intellectual Life."

A portion of the first subdivision of the Courtlandt Palmer estate at Dobbs Ferry, the property of the Dobbs Ferry Land and Improvement Company, was sold at auction yesterday afternoon. Sixty-four lots were sold for $61,275, averaging about $950 a lot, which was a price that exceeded the expectations of the owners.

The distinguished and universally-respected Allen G. Thurman was asked by the Williamsport (Penn.) Sun to consent to an interview upon the leading political questions of the day. This request Mr. Thurman was unable to grant, his physical condition being such as to preclude his meeting a representative of the paper or writing with his own hand a statement of his views.

PARIS, June 7. -- We are certainly devoted now to the so-called tailor suits for morning and afternoon wear. The great worker of this miracle -- and a very hard Parisian struggle it was for him, too -- is Redfern. Consequently, in spite of many luxurious and prosperous, if more recently established houses, Redfern remains the dictator of the fashion laws of each new season.

ST. LOUIS, June 20. -- Poolsellers have determined to fight tooth and nail against the law which compels them to confine their operations entirely to races which take place within the borders of Missouri. The law goes into effect next Wednesday, and its enforcement would deprive the poolsellers of a great part of their revenue.

NEW-HAVEN, June 20. -- The undergraduate life of Yale's Class of '91 has almost ended, and the few days that remain will be taken up with the closing exercises. The members of the lower classes have nearly all departed for the Summer vacation, while a few from distant States linger only for the races at New-London.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- The strawberry crop through this section of the Connecticut Valley has been destroyed by the excessive heat that prevailed during the first three days of the week. On Sunday there was every prospect of a large supply, but the fruit for the most part has been dried up by the sun and will not pay for picking.

BOSTON, June 20. -- Gen. Neal Dew, the Prohibition hero of Maine, arrived in Boston this evening by water line. He was met on his arrival by James M. Marden, Secretary of the City Prohibition Club, and from the wharf was escorted to the residence of Samuel B. Shapleigh in Allston, where during his stay in Boston he will be entertained.

WEST POINT, June 20. -- It seems that, after all, the Academic Board is not a unit on the proposition to increase the number of cadets. The Board of Visitors, which apparently believed in the efficacy of the plan, left here with new light on the subject which the public has not yet seen. The matter is one which certainly requires the most thoughtful consideration.

An article in the May number of the Review of Reviews is an account of Pope Leo XIII, at home, written by a journalist at Rome "who is privileged to have constant access to the presence of the Holy Father." The following are a few extracts from the article which has been published simultaneously in England, America, and France:

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Judge Acheson filed an opinion in the United States Circuit Court to-day overruling the plea made for the Reading Railroad Company in the suit of John Lornie, the millionaire Scotchman, for the payment of interest on the third preference income bonds. The complaint was that interest should have been paid upon the house on the ground that it was earned.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 20. -- Some months ago S.M. Inman of the firm of S.M Inman Co., whose long experience, big business, and close connection with the great markets enable him to speak with much weight on the cotton subject, pointed out the great danger of overproduction. It appears now that the effort to reduce the acreage did not succeed to the extent hat was anticipated, and the situation is anything but encouraging.

" Boodle" Alderman DUFFY will have to look to his laurels. When he set out to bring suit to recover the share of "boodle" of which he alleged that he had been defrauded it was thought that impudence could hardly go further. DUFFY had a cold reception in the courts, and so far as heard from he has not yet "recovered."

Another Corporation Counsel's opinion upon the legality of the use of Battery Park by the elevated railway is likely soon to be added to the legal record of this grab. The resolution offered by Alderman John Morris at last Tuesday's meeting of the Aldermen asking the opinion of the Corporation Counsel has been referred to that official by the Railroad Committee, to whom it was referred.

A movement is on foot to establish a circus in New-York which shall continue all the year around, and, with a building and grounds of its own, become one of the permanent amusement places of the city. The plan is to form a corporation, to be known as "The New-York Circus Company," with a capital stock of $250,000, divided into shares of $100 each.

Frank Jenkins, the man who was drowned by the sinking of the sloop yacht Amelia, which was run into by the tugboat F.W. Devoe in the Hudson River off West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, shortly before midnight last Sunday, was found yesterday floating in the water off West Ninety seventh Street. He was forty-eight years old, and was the proprietor of an art embroidery establishment at 185 Spring Street.

Some of the children of John Battin, an eccentric and wealthy old man who formerly resided in Elizabeth, N.J., are worried because of their father's absorbing interest in the Christian Alliance. Mr. Battin is eighty-one years old. He accumulated a comfortable fortune by his labors as a civil engineer, and his sons and daughters fear that the Christian Alliance people are likely to get all of his property away from him.

While the busy men of affairs in New-York are engrossed in their absorbing duties another and smaller class is prowling about in every directions "seeking the sights." Few objects of interest escape them. They know all the corners of the Park, they are on speaking terms with the baby hipopotamus and its neighbors, they have seen all the ships at the navy yard, and they know the attractive suburban additions by heart.

In a recent description of the underground electric railways in London, Arthur Warren, the correspondent of the Boston Herald, reinforces the statement of their advantages to which the London correspondent of THE TIMES called attention some time ago. After showing the disadvantages of the old style of tunnels near the surface with steam as a motor and foul gases as a concomitant, he goes on to say:

The biggest canoe regatta ever sailed in New-York waters took places yesterday in Gravesend Bay off the grounds of the Marine and Field Club. It was the first joint regatta of the canoe departments of the Marine and Field Club and the Manhattan Athletic Club, and this joining of forces proved so successful that the experiment will undoubtedly grow into a regular annual fixture in New-York conoeing.

The arrangements made for a series of naval manoeuvres during the coming Summer make demands upon the new naval militia which fully demonstrate the value placed upon that auxiliary body by the authorities at Washington. For the first time an organization of citizens will have opportunities for drill aboard our new war ships.
John W. Bookwalter owns 60,000 acres of land in Nebraska. He proposes to work a revolution among the farmers of Nebraska.

TOPEKA, June 20. -- In the course of the so-called Commercial Convention, recently held in Denver, there came to the surface a scheme as iniquitous as it was great. It was the out-croppings of a fully-matured plan to secure from the Government 15,000,000 acres of public land, not for the benefit of the masses, but for the enrichment of a few men who have been working quietly with this end in view for years.

One of the most remarkable, as it was one of the most agreeable, features of the week's tour of the Twenty-third Regiment at the State Camp of Instruction was the almost entire absence of "talking tactics." When the officers of the regiment got together in a social way "shop" was not discussed, nor were they given to seeking after "fine points."

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20. -- The outlook for the season improves every day. All the private boarding houses and all the hotels, except the Ocean House, are open, and the hotel keepers report a fair business. The Ocean House opens this week, and permanent and transient visitors are arriving frequently and in large numbers. The Casino is open throughout, and in about two weeks the morning concerts and semi-weekly dances will begin.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 20. -- The widow of Sir John Macdonald, Canada's late Premier, is asserting her individuality and displaying a deep interest in the party for so many years led by her husband. She is certainly a remarkable woman. Many people insist that one-half of the late Premier's strength in the country as a politician and statesman was due to her advice.

In the month of May, 1800, the veteran teacher of penmanship, Allison Wrifford, was passing by the door of the lobby leading to the floor of the House of Representatives at Washington. I give what follows in his own words as narrated to me forty years later.
The London Times publishes a long letter from Mrs. Templeton (formerly Mrs. Laurence Oliphant) respecting her late husband's relations with the prophet Harris, in which she says:

BOSTON, June 20. -- The Executive Committee of the Republican State League met this noon at headquarters and voted to appoint Major J. Henry Gould a State organizer of league clubs; also to raise the funds necessary to pay expenses and look up the subject of permanent headquarters for the league. Assistant Secretary Shattuck reported on the condition of thirty-five clubs in the State with 10,000 members and others to hear from.

A hundred women of the little town of Summit, N.J., have been quietly accomplishing some good results the past few years. During that time they have banded together as a Village Improvement Association and by vigorous, well-directed work have brought about a remarkable change in the appearance of the place.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- The Grand Jury to-day found two true bills against Henry H. Yard charging him with conspiracy with ex-City Treasurer Bardsley to unlawfully use the public funds. Yard was arrested in Trenton last week on the charge on which he was to-day indicted, and is now under heavy bonds to answer to it in court.

The writing of this history must have afforded Mr. Lodge excellent diversion from the vicissitudes of politics. A few years ago he obviously found agreeable employment in writing his biography of Washington in the American Statesmen Series, one of the estimable volumes in that estimable series, and now he has turned to a theme that was probably still more agreeable to his mind and tastes.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 20. -- The Rev. Charles Lemon of the graduating class of Colgate University has been engaged by the First Baptist Church of Oneonta, N.Y., to take charge of its River Street Mission.

Two important applications for permission to use the trolley electric system as a substitute for horse power on street cars are under consideration by the State Board of Railroad Commissioners. The Messrs. Rogers, Rickard, and Baker have heard a great deal of testimony for and against the trolley system, and they have promised to give their official decisions in the two cases with all due diligence.

There is pending in one of the courts of Kansas City a legal contest over the appointment of a curator of the estate in Missouri of Mrs. Elizabeth Thompson. The amount of the estate in Missouri is only about $20,000, and there is nothing of special interest in the application except as it recalls the career of one of the most deservedly notable women of America.

BOSTON, June 20. -- Quinn's muff in the fourth inning to-day, with O'Brien's home-run hit, enabled the visitors to take the lead, and Griffin's muff in the ninth put the Bostons one run ahead. The game was won by batting, the tieing and winning runs being earned. The last part of the game was played in a fine drizzle. Attendance, 2,385. Score:

The Musical Courier, like many persons who love the noble art of music, is troubled with searchings of the heart as to the outcome of the next operate season. In view of the remarkable scarcity of news, it is not strange that there should be some anxiety. No one seems to know what is going to happen, and the atmosphere is simply purple with rumors.

The story of the enormous fortune accumulated by Mr. Cunliffe Lister (one of the "birthday peers") is one of the romances of "Fortunes made in Business." "Going one day into a London warehouse, he came upon a pile of rubbish. He inquired what it was and was told that it was waste silk. 'What do you do with it?' he asked. 'Sell it for rubbish,' he was told."

A little calm has followed the photographic boom that has pervaded the city for three weeks back, and the amateurs are giving more time to outdoor excursions. Many are getting ready for their Summer trips to the mountains and seaside, and are gathering together their outfits. The societies have mostly adjourned till Fall, and the amateur conventions and meetings have been finished.
The following general rules concerning retirement are in force in the British Navy:

BERLIN, June 20. -- The formation of a great central European customs league is an accomplished fact acknowledged by the official circle. The exchange of communications between Germany, Austria, Hungary, Italy, and Switzerland has resulted in the basis of an agreement which became known here to-day.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A private letter received from Santiago, under date of May 14, contains much interesting information concerning affairs in Chile, of which the following is an abstract: ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 20. -- Prof. E. Stone Wiggins, the weather prophet, writing to the press, says the prevailing drought throughout Ontario and many Western States is caused by the existence of telephone wires and wire fences.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- In replying to-day to the demand of Attorney General Hensel that the city pay over to the State some $600,000 collected by ex-City Treasurer Bardsley, City Controller Thompson said that the city cannot recognize the claim of the State, as Bardsley was the State's fiscal agent. In conclusion, the City Controller significantly says that other discrepancies have been discovered for which the State is liable to the city.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 20. -- The training ship Monongahela sailed to-day, and it is expected that she will reach Fayal, Azores Islands, July 10.

There was a commotion in one of the largo dry goods stores up town last Thursday morning. It was caused by six or eight hysterical shop girls, and was observed by two customers who happened to be near the linen counter. The commotion was started by the discovery of a croton bug on the counter. The girl who discovered it quietly brushed it off on the floor, whereat another girl started to step on it.

The machinery for the big armored cruiser Maine will be ready for assembling aboard ship in thirty days. This statement was made yesterday by N.F. Palmer, Jr., President of the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company. All the parts for the Maine's engines have been completed. The engines have been fully erected at the works of the company.

For a dull, heavy, wearisome market, that of the past week beats the record. It was so profoundly uninteresting that the Street seemed to welcome a slight sensation in the renewal of gold exports, and it enjoyed a genuine surprise in yesterday's bank statement. Otherwise there was nothing. An attempt was made Monday to impart some life to the market. The Gould stocks became conspicuously strong, Cordage rose, some other stocks sympathized.

The greater part of the interest in real estate in last week's market was furnished in suburban sales at the lower end of Brooklyn, on Long Island, and on Staten Island. All of these sales were pretty well attended, and the prices realized were quite fair. A great deal of the property offered was bought by people residing near it, who evidently had their minds pretty well made up about its value.

The National Executive Silver Committee was in session at the Hoffman House yesterday, and when its deliberations were concluded last night an address to the country was given out. In addition to the preparation of this address, the committee discussed ways and means of carrying the gospel of free coinage into those parts of the country where believers are now scarce.

Herr Most became an inmate of the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island for the second time yesterday under the sentence passed upon him in December, 1887, for convening an unlawful assembly. The delay in the execution of the sentence was due to appeals, the last of which was decided against him a few days ago. His term will last for one year, with two months off in case of good behavior.

It appears that when the indictment against Secretary GIBSON of the Whisky Trust was quashed in Chicago the defenders of combinations designed to suppress competition in important industries were not finally deprived of an opportunity to air their arguments and doctrines in court. The quashed indictment was one found by a Federal Grand Jury.

The Call expressed the opinion some days since that the agreement between Great Britain and the United States to stop seal poaching came too late to do much good this year. The American lessees, being a responsible company, can be compelled to limit their catch to the number allowed by the agreement, but it is not clear how the irrepressible poacher is to be reached.

LONG BRANCH, June 21. -- In its Trenton dispatch two weeks ago THE TIMES exposed the main features of the rumored scandal which accuses J. Clarence Conover, the presiding Judge of the Monmouth County Court at Freehold, of having prostituted his judicial functions to affect the result of the annual township election at this place last month.

Insurance Superintendent PIERCE stated on Saturday that he thought the official investigation of the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company would begin today, but it is probable that the officers of the company will try to get a postponement until President BEERS has returned. Mr. PIERCE further stated that he had instructed Deputy SHANNON to overhaul the company's books and records and make the examination as complete as possible.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 21. -- Notwithstanding the stormy weather, there were hundreds of people here to-day to view the ruins of the recent fire. Farmers from far up in the country drove down with their families to spend the day, and some of them brought either food or clothing for the needy.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 21. -- Max Freeman, the United States Deputy Marshal who came here last week to investigate the rumor that Gideon W. Marsh, the fugitive President of the Keystone Bank, was hiding in a cottage near Como, is confined to his bed and may die from the injuries received early yesterday morning at the hands of two men, one of whom he declares was Marsh.

About six hundred veterans of four regiments of Wisconsin cavalry and four of infantry attended the reunion in Madison yesterday. On account of the rainy weather the old soldiers were forced to spend the morning in the Capitol, where they related stories and recalled the horrors of the war. H.D. Weaver of St. Paul walked up to Gen. Harnden of Madison, and, handing him an old paper, inquired if he recognized it.
" Is the next train for City Hall or South Ferry?" asked a belated traveler of the ticket chopper at the Twenty-third Street station of the Third Avenue elevated railroad a few nights ago.

With pleasant weather there should be a lot of good sport at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club this week. There are no stakes on for decision to-day, but to-morrow the Mermaid Stakes, for three-year-old fillies, at a mile and an eighth, and the Coney Island Stakes, for all ages, at the same distance, will be run, as will the Zephyr Stakes, for two-year-olds, at three-quarters of a mile.

PARIS, June 6. -- The Comedie Francaise, in addition to a second hearing of Lemaitre's "Mariage Blane," gave to the critics this week two plays in prose, each of one act. The "Rosalinde," of Messrs. Thiboust and Aurelien Scholl, takes us back to powdered wigs and fascinating mouches. It is a bright and sparkling dialogue between two rival lovers of a singer.

The French Line steamship La Bretagne came up to her dock late yesterday evening several hours over her schedule time of arrival. The vessel had lost one blade of her propeller, and to this mishap her late arrival was due.

LONDON, June 21. -- The position of the Queen in English politics is usually supposed to be generally passive. In foreign politics she has been known, since the "Life of the Prince Consort" threw some light upon the business life of royalty, to be greatly interested. But with internal English politics she has hitherto been credited with interfering little.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 21. -- A criminal case has just been terminated in Council Bluffs which has attracted considerable attention, because it has been in the courts fourteen years. The case was a criminal prosecution against Jonathan Jones, a farmer, who killed a neighbor named Roberts in 1877. He was arrested for the act and prosecuted relentlessly by influential friends of the dead man.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 21. -- President Franklin Carter delivered the baccalaureate sermon at 10:30 o'clock this morning at the ninety-seventh Commencement of Williams College. The graduating class marched in with caps and gowns and took their seats in the front of the church. The Rev. G.H. Gutterson of India assisted in the service.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 21. -- There are two intermittent Presidential booms that break out in Indiana with more or less vigor, according to the influence of the men who put them in motion. These booms belong one to each party. The Democratic boom is the Isaac P. Gray spook, and the Republican boom is the occasionally scotched but never killed boom for Gen. Gresham.

A pamphlet recently published by the Health Department contains the laws relating to marriages and the duties of persons authorized to solemnize marriages in this State. It was found necessary to make this information public because it had become a prevailing idea that notaries public and other officials were authorized to unite persons in wedlock.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- Thirty-two Italian laborers fled from Contractor Warpley's camp, at the Chain of Rocks, early yesterday morning, leaving their baggage behind them in their flight. They report a reign of terror there, due to a feud among the men and a diabolical attempt at assassination last night.

We gave to our readers yesterday morning the substance of the address issued by the "National Executive Silver Committee." It is not so wild a document as some that have come from the same source; its authors seem to feel the real confusion that prevails in the minds of their followers and to hesitate to put forth a very definite proposition as to their "demand."

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 21. -- The President, with his guests, attended service this morning at Beadle's Memorial Chapel, Caps May Point. The sermon was preached by the Rev. N.L. Upham of Philadelphia. The President spent the afternoon at his cottage. He intends to return to Washington Tuesday.

Thomas Jefferson Lowry, chief of the Faculty of the engineering department of the State University, is one of Missouri's talented, homely, bright, and sparkling sons who not only honor their State but work for her advancement. "Tom" Lowry, as everybody calls him, is a graduate of the Class of '70 in the college of which he is now a member of the Faculty.

Those who are in a position to know the inside facts regarding the New-York Life Insurance Company and its present difficulties express a great deal of disapprobation of the course pursued by Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce in delaying the examination of that company's affairs for a week or even for a few days.

Our Berlin dispatches yesterday morning spoke of the commercial alliance of Central Europe as something seriously believed in in Germany. It is apparently one of the "fads" of the young Emperor of Germany, who seems to look on commercial and financial revolutions as no more beyond his sphere of influence than military and political affairs.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- Early in last November one of the most prominent cotton dealers in St. Louis went around among his friends and told them that cotton was cheaper than it had been in ten years at that time of the year. It was then about 11 cents a pound in New-York. Under the advice of this gentleman, a syndicate was formed to purchase 10,000 bales of May cotton in Liverpool.

PARIS, June 21. -- Inquiries among the United States Consuls in France concerning the disposition of the manufacturing classes in their districts toward the Chicago Fair are not very encouraging. Oscar F. Williams, Consul at Havre, says: "I hear much talk about the exhibition, and there is much good feeling toward the enterprise, but it is too early to look for either energy or apathy."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 21. -- An excursion train of fifteen cars, which left this city this afternoon on the Nickel Plate Railroad, jumped the track near Dover, Ohio, and seven cars were wrecked. The train was loaded with street-railway employes and their families who were going to Oak Point, a pleasure resort on the Lake Shore.

The contemptuous tolerance with which the Bonapartist banquet in Paris was treated by the French Government must have impressed all foreign observers with the strength of the Government as well as with the weakness of the Imperialists. The banquet was eaten and the oratorical guests were permitted to say their several "says" as if what they might have to say affected the French Republic no more than what they might have to eat.

William Ennis, a bartender; James Mulrooney of 318 Monroe Street, Lizzie Harkins of 335 East Thirty-third Street, and Thomas McKeon were arrested Saturday afternoon and held in Essex Market Police Court yesterday for alleged complicity in the assault upon Martin Engel, the politician who was injured Thursday in McKeon's dive in Hester Street, Engel is not expected to live.

The new Circuit Court of Appeals, created by Senator Evarts's bill passed at the last session of Congress, is, according to Chief Justice Fuller of the United States Supreme Court, a measure that will so facilitate litigation as to win for Senator Evarts the esteem of the bar. The Chief Justice was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, having come on from Washington to enjoy a brief stay with friends here.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- President Harrison's friends are both amused and indignant over the astonishing claim put forward by Mr. Blaine's follower to the effect that with the help of a special wire into the White House the Secretary of State took an active part in the final negotiations which resulted in the close season for seals in Bering Sea.

The friends of the President are said to be resentful of the efforts made to transfer the credit for the successful conclusion of the negotiations for a closed season in Bering Sea to Secretary BLAINE. The representation that the Secretary of State at Bar Harbor was in close communication with the White House "by wire" is said to be sheer nonsense.

Early on a recent morning a party of 170 men started from Llanberis to search for the body of Griffith Pritchard, the Snowdon guide who perished in a snowstorm on the 25th of March, while descending from the summit. Pritchard reached the top in safety, but was advised not to attempt the descent, as there was every indication or a storm.

The present generation of Brooklynites is beginning to wonder if any member of it will live long enough to see the new Federal Building completed. So many vexatious delays have occurred since the cornerstone was laid that ordinary delays attract no attention, but now it is calmly announced that the formal occupancy of the building may have to be postponed for a year, perhaps two years.

CLEVELAND, June 21. -- The wisdom of postponing the date of the Democratic State Convention becomes more apparent as the season goes on. The Republicans enter the field early and thrash over the old straw about Democratic extravagance and the like, while the Democratic leaders are reserving their heaviest fusillades until later in the canvass, when more interest is taken and the effect will be more marked.
