INDIANAPOLIS, June 21. -- Ex-Senator Joseph E. McDonald died here at 11:35 o'clock this evening, of cancer of the stomach, after a long illness.

" The Wilsons are to Hull very much what Bismarck was to the Germans before his fall," says the Pall Mall Gazette; "something to be wondered at, something to be proud of, something which seems to bear the charm of success; often disliked for its overbearing roughness, often admired for its heroic audacity, and always standing out as an interesting and gigantic study of character.

We earnestly direct the attention of our high-tariff contemporaries to a bit of interesting news that comes from Canada. It will be recalled that while the McKinley bill was pending in Congress and throughout the Congressional campaign of last Fall the McKinley press and the makers of the McKinley tariff vehemently denied that protected manufacturers ever sold their goods in foreign countries at prices lower than the prices demanded and obtained for them at home.

ALBANY, June 21. -- Affairs in the office of the Secretary of State would seem to be running somewhat loosely since Diedrick Willers resigned the office of deputy. How it is possible for anybody to "sequestrate" some of the most valuable records without anybody knowing anything about it is for the present deputy to explain.

The statement that a South Carolina Congressman will introduce a bill next Winter providing for the rebuilding and occupation of Fort Moultrie, on Sullivan's Island, is certainly suggestive. It is a curious fact that neither Fort Moultrie nor Fort Sumter, nor indeed any point in Charleston Harbor, is occupied by a garrison to-day.

LONDON, June 22. -- Sir George Baden-Powell, K.C.M.G., member of Parliament for the Kirkdale Division of Liverpool, and Dr. G.M. Dawson of the Canadian Survey Department, have been appointed agents under the modus vivendi in the Bering Sea seal question, decided upon between the Government of the United States and the Government of Great Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22.-- Thornton was unsteady in the fourth inning to-day, when he sent two men to first on being hit with pitched balls, and the visitors did some hiting, all of which resulted in 4 runs enough to win the game. Clarkuon pitched a good game and was admirably supported. Attendance 2,706. Score:

The refusal of the Trunk Line Association to allow a differential on Northwest freight business to the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad equal to that allowed to the West Shore has aroused President Samuel Sloan's fighting blood. He declares, with characteristic bluntness, that if he cannot get what he is entitled to by asking for it, he will reach out and take it.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- A meeting of the traffic managers of the Western and Northwestern roads was held at Chairman Midgely's office to-day to consider the situation as affected by the disturbance of west-bound rates from the seaboard. Their protests against the reductions of the Canadian Pacific, which led to the present rate war, have called out an invitation to them to attend a conference of trunk line representatives in New-York.

BOSTON, June 22. -- General Manager Howard of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company said in an interview to-day: "I think it would be a good idea to sell our preferred stock to the common shareholders, but the amounts of money we need at various times for construction purposes are almost too small to be divided among the holders oft $20,000,000 of common stock.

Do our esteemed contemporaries of the McKinley group ever recall, with a smile or a chuckle, the good things they said a few months ago? Let us hear from the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette its present opinion of the following remarks which were published in an editorial article in that journal on Nov. 1, 1890:

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 22. -- This fashionable Summer resort is filled to overflowing with detectives, professional and amateur, drawn here by the rumor that Gideon W. Marsh, the fugitive Philadelphia bank President, was hiding in the vicinity. They apparently hope to get a chance at the $6,000 reward offered for his capture.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Under the authority conferred by the last Naval Appropriation act, which contained the following item -- "Naval militia: For arms and equipment connected therewith for naval militia of various States, under such regulations as the Secretary of the Navy may prescribe, $25,000" -- the following regulations have been prescribed by Secretary Tracy:

PARIS, June 22. -- The committee of the Chamber of Deputies appointed to inquire into Panama Canal matters has declined to consider the numerous requests which have been made with the view of soliciting the French Government to intervene in the company's affairs, and to enable it to finish the work commenced at Panama.

Attorney General Hunter of Illinois began quo warranto proceedings yesterday against the Chicago Live Stock Exchange. He claims that the Exchange is acting beyond its powers in trying to fix the minimum rate of sale on the yards' market.

The People's Party made its introductory bow to this city last evening, its sponsor being Branch No. 6 of the Citizens' Alliance. The introduction was made by Senator Peffer of Kansas. Everybody was invited to attend the mass meeting at Cooper Union to greet the creation of the recent Cincinnati Convention.

Lawson N. Fuller got up a very breezy rapid-transit meeting in the interest of his friend Jay Gould on Washington Heights last night. By a liberal distribution of circulars headed "Washington Heights Up in Arms," and with the aid of a youthful, but effective brass band, he induced about 250 men, women, and children to assemble in the Athenaeum, a cool and commodious frame structure in One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, near Tenth Avenue.

OPTAWA, Ontario, June 22. -- Dr. G.M. Dawson, who has been appointed one of the British Commissioners in the Bering Sea arbitration, is one of the best-known geologists in America. His services to Canada professionally have been valuable, and his name is intimately associated with several important national explorations. He comes of distinguished stock, being a son of Sir William Dawson, the veteran scientist and Principal of McGill University, Montreal.

Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce, Deputy Superintendent Michael Shannon and Chief Actuary John S. Paterson of Albany formally entered upon their duties as investigators of the New-York Life Insurance Company Yesterday morning. Ten days had elapsed since the publication of the first story regarding the company's affairs, and ample time had been offered the officers of the company to prepare for the investigation.

Out of the 1,213 young women from private, public, and parochial schools in the city who took the examination for entrance to the Normal College during the first week of June, 624 passed. It has usually been customary to admit only those candidates who answered 75 per cent of the examination questions, but as only 400 reached that mark, the standard of scholarship was lowered to 71 per cent.

The Corinthian Yacht Club's annual race was sailed yesterday under the most satisfactory yachting conditions. There was a steady, fresh wind from start to finish, a comparatively smooth sea, and a bright sky. The race had a new element of interest from the fact that the Burgess boat Sayonara, which has not heretofore raced, started in the forty-six-foot class.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 22. -- The Democratic State Convention will meet here to-morrow. Chairman Fuller, who is early on the ground, says there will be just enough Democratic farmers left at home in the First District to milk the cows. The rest will be at the convention. It will be a farmers' convention -- not farmers by telephone, but regular every-day tillers of the soil.

Capt. John Montgomery Ward was right in his element yesterday. He was more pleasant and sociable than usual. This might have been because he foreboded victory. It was the fifth time this season that he and William Buckingham Ewing had met and shaken hands, and truly did "Johnny" get ample revenge for the three defeats his team had sustained at the hands of Ewing's Giants.

The calendar of that high-grade criminal court, the Court of Oyer and Terminer, was remarkable yesterday for the names upon it. They were Charles P. Clark, Wilson G. Hunt, E.H. Trowbridge, William D. Bishop, Nathaniel Wheeler, Henry C. Robinson, Edward M. Reed, Joseph Park, Chauncey M. Depew, Henry S. Lee, William Rockefeller, and Leverett Brainard.

AMHERST, Mass., June 22. -- Commencement has begun in earnest and the town is crowded with visitors waiting the inauguration of President Gates, the semi-centennial celebration of Gamma Chapter of Psi Upsilon, and all the class exercises of '91. It promises to be the gayest Commencement Amherst has ever had.

It is a fundamental principle of Democracy that the people rule, and that by the untrammeled exercise of their suffrages they choose delegates to give expression to their principles and to select candidates for office in their name, and that they elect representatives to do their will in public office. Nothing could be more in conflict with this principle than "boss" rule and "machine" methods in party management.

The Cherokees must be gradually waking up to the fact that the United States Government is a safer party to contract with for the use or purchase of their surplus lands than irresponsible cattlemen. Last year they tried to collect the rent due for the Cherokee Outlet from the syndicate that leased it, and after a month's delay were told that it was unfortunately out of funds.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Department of State has been notified that the British Government has appointed Sir George Baden-Powell and Mr. W. Dawson agents for that Government to visit Alaska and collect information respecting the seal fisheries.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- Capt. Cook took the Yale oarsmen out two at a time in a double shell this noon and went to work to eradicate individual faults. While one held the rudder lines and the other pulled the stroke oar. Cook himself took the bow oar, where he could watch the movements of his pupils. Then the stroke oar and the man in the coxewain's seat changed places, and so on.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 22. -- A delegation of eight from the Trustees of Williams College held a special session this morning and afternoon in Hopkins Hall. The members present were Francis L. Stetson of New-York, President Franklin Carter of Williams, Charles A. Davidson of New-York, John E. Bradley of Minneapolis, the Rev. Robert R. Booth of New-York, Henry M. Hoyt of Philadelphia, Derrick L. Boardman of Troy, and James White of Williamstown.

The case of Harry L. Daniels against William C. Hawk was tried before an admiring throng of Produce Exchange brokers in the Managers' room of that institution yesterday afternoon. The judges were the Managers, and, after hearing a good deal of testimony relating to the why and wherefore of the assault upon Mr. Daniels, they decided to suspend Mr. Hawk for two weeks.

The "panic mongers who are trying to destroy the credit of the Government in the hope of partisan advantage" by talking about the "impending bankruptcy of the Treasury" have been roundly denounced of late by patriotic Republican newspapers. They can endure the denunciation without personal inconveniences, since they have no persons and no bodily existence, being, in short, mere myths and fancies of the Republican imagination.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 23. -- The North China Daily News, in its account of the Woo-Hoo riots, says it had been reported for several-days that a mob of Chinese had determined to loot and burn the property of Jesuits at Woo-Hoo. It was rumored that eight children had been killed and their eyes taken out to make medicine for the Jesuit Fathers.

There seems to be no room for doubt now that the Administration is seriously considering the policy of coining the bullion bought under the act of last July into standard dollars. We say "seriously," but we are sure that none of our readers will suspect the Administration of considering the really serious feature of such a policy. It is, nevertheless, well to keep that feature in mind.

The Health Commissioners have codified all the regulations for the management of the hospitals of the department, and at their meeting yesterday approved them. The code willbe so exhibited hereafter that patients, physicians, nurses, and emoloyes may see it,

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- John Bardsley, ex-City Treasurer, who several days ago pleaded guilty of embezzlement of public funds, was brought from prison to court for sentence to-day, but on motion of District Attorney Graham sentence was suspended indefinitely.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 23. -- Dr. John Winans, a well-known physician at Lyons Farms, near here, died to-day from injuries received by a fall, it is supposed, from a cherry tree in his garden. He was found yesterday lying unconscious under the tree against which a ladder had been placed. He was taken to his house, but he never revived. At 1 o'clock he died.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 23. -- Prof. Thomas H. Garside, the detective, is sick of Spring Lake, and will get away from the beautiful resort as soon as the pair of crutches he has ordered arrives. He will then recuperate in a Philadelphia hospital, whence he hopes to come out all right in a week or two. He adheres to his former story and says it is true in every particular.

At his home in Fostoria, Ohio, Secretary FOSTER makes the following remarks about the farmers: "This district is a large wool-growing one, and for years the flock-masters have gone down in their pockets to pay the expenses of DAVID HARPSTER and others in Washington. I, like other Republicans, have listened to their plea for protection for their wool, and we have done our best for them."

CHESTNUT HILL, Penn., June 23. -- Miss Mabel Cahill and Miss Grace Roosevelt both played some excellent tennis here to-day. The event was the fourth annual tournament for the ladies' championship of America in lawn tennis.

The State officers at Albany could not keep the secret of the theft of valuable documents from the office of the Secretary of State, although their well-defined plan to recover them enjoined discretion.
" Major Gen." William F. Kelly and "Adjutant Gen." C. Stevens O'Mahony are preparing for another annual encampment of the Irish-American Military Union of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- In the light shed upon Secretary Blaine's attitude toward the efforts to save the Bering Sea seals by the full correspondence, recently published in the British Blue Book, a copy of which has just reached this city, the friends of that eminent statesmen will do well if they refrain from claiming for him any of the credit for the close-season agreement now in force.

AMHERST, Mass., June 23. -- Another gay Commencement Day has passed, in which '91 Class exercises took a prominent part. At 8:30 A.M. Junior Class winners of the Lincoln prize gave an exhibition before a large audience. This was followed by ivy exercises, the orator being C.R. Hyde of Brooklyn, N.Y., whose subject was "The Era of Reform."

Ex-President Michael Coleman of the Department of Taxes and Assessments was selected yesterday by Department Superintendent Michael Shannon to take charge of the work of appraising the real property owned by and mortgaged to the New-York Life Insurance Company. Mr. Coleman began his work at once. He will select such assistants as he may need and will occupy a desk in the company's office while his investigation continues. The

Big Amos Rusie scored another victory for the New-Yorks yesterday. With his strong right arm he sent the ball over the plate with rare speed and accuracy and completely puzzled the hard hitters of the Brooklyn team.

The Atlantic Yacht Club had almost as many starters yesterday in its special race, originally intended for forty-six footers only, as it had in its annual regatta. The race was arranged for a four-hundred-dollar cup offered to the new class by Vice Commodore David Banks. Since last Tuesday, however, W.W. Kenyon offered a cup for the thirty-five footers, and then Commodore Lawton came forward with an offer of a cup for the twenty-five footers.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 23. -- The meeting of the Alumni Association of the Wesleyan University was held this morning and the following officers were elected: President -- W.T. Elmer of Middletown; Vice Presidents -- F.S. Hoyt, W.P. Hubbard, F.K. Hallock; Recording Secretary -- Prof. W.N. Rice; Corresponding Secretary -- Prof. M.B. Crawford; Treasurer -- G.W. Burke: Memorialist -- L.O. Kuhns. Two Alumni Trustees were elected as follows: The Rev. Dr.

ALBANY, June 23. -- Gov. Hill is getting ready to close the mock investigation of the canals which has been occupying public attention for three weeks. His programme from the first has been precisely the one THE TIMES predicted he would adopt.

Rear Admiral David B. Harmony hoisted his broad pennant aboard the Lancaster yesterday at 11 A.M. As the little piece of blue hunting bearing his two silver stars floated out from the Lancaster's mizzen-royal truck a salute of fifteen guns boomed forth a greeting to the third-ranking Admiral of the navy. "All hands" on the Lancaster were called to muster at 10:55.

The widow of Edwin Forrest died in this city a week ago yesterday, and Thursday two carriages followed her body to a village cemetery on Staten Island. No notice of her death was published. A clergyman was called in -- the Rev. Dr. Peters of St. Michael's Church, in Ninety-ninth Street -- to read the Episcopal burial service, and when that was over she was borne quietly to the grave.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 23. -- The new time table and through connection of the Canadian Pacific Railroad with the American railroad to Puget Sound went into operation yesterday. The passengers from the East for Washington points now leave the Canadian Pacific at Mission Station, going over a branch line to Sumas City at the boundary, and thence over the Ballingham Railroad to New Whatcom.

Word comes from Albany that the Court of Appeals has sustained the General Term's reversal of the conviction in the Court of General Sessions of Thomas F. Wynn, the right-hand man of "Pete" De Lacy, the "boss" of the New-York City poolroom keepers.

PEEKSKILL, June 23. -- The Seventh has worked hard to-day, in skirmish, battalion drills, two guard mountings, both formations being in double time, dress parade, with accompanying board and schools of instruction. The usual amount of fun has been indulged in off duty, but strict attention to business has characterized the ceremonies of the day. "Steady improvement" has been the report from General Headquarters.

The quarrel at the German Hospital between the young physicians and the Superintendent has for its outcome a tragic case demanding investigation at the Coroners' office. A week ago last Sunday evening Dr. William W. Strew of 213 East Seventy-seventh Street, a specialist in mental and puerperal diseases, was summoned to 334 East Seventy-seventh Street, where he found Mrs. John Freeman, who was suffering from a bad ease of puerperal fever.

The discrepancies in the accounts of current affairs in Chile, as they come respectively from BALMACEDA'S Government and from the Congress Party, have had precedents enough in previous wars; but a special reason for contradictions in this case is the Chilean President's extreme anxiety to prevent foreign recognition of the insurgents as belligerents, and the latter's comprehension of the importance of that recognition.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 23. -- The Premier laid on the table of the Senate Chamber a big bundle of documents just before the Senate rose last night. It was a message from the Governor General, transmitting more papers relating to the extension and development of trade between the United States and Canada, including Newfoundland.

A fire which did $35,000 damage and filled the lower part of the city with dense smoke was discovered at 10:40 o'clock last night on the fourth floor of the six-story brick building occupying the acute angle at the intersection of Hudson and Reade Streets, and fronting 100 feet on Hudson Street and 50 feet on Reade Street.

SALT LAKE, Utah, June 23. -- It has been argued, in opposition to the organization of national parties in Utah, that the People's (Mormon) Party was not sincere in the dissolution that has been effected, that it is simply a scheme of the Church to secure Statehood, secure offices, and govern in the interest of the Mormons.

Having given most careful consideration to the articles in your valuable paper upon the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company, and believing that a paper of such high standing as THE TIMES would not make such statements without having the very best grounds for so doing, I think it becomes absolutely necessary that the policy holders should take united and prompt action in the matter.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 23. -- At the Yale field this afternoon 3,000 people watched the baseball game between Yale and the University of Pennsylvania. It was a small crowd compared with the one which usually witnesses a Commencement game, but Harvard was out of it from choice and rather than disappoint the Alumni, the University of Pennsylvania team was induced to play, under the promise of a large guarantee. Although Yale

BOSTON, June 23. -- The leather firm of Alley Brothers Place, 54 South Street, has assigned. Its liabilities will probably reach $500,000, and the assets are claimed to be $600,000. The assignees are W.A. Rust of the Freemen's Bank and William A. Knowlton.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- As has already been stated in THE TIMES, the Bureau of Naval Ordnance, with the approval of the Secretary of the Navy, proposes to constitute a board of torpedo experts, which will be charged with the whole subject of auto-mobile torpedo armament of the vessels of the new navy, taking all the details of this work off the hands of the Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance.

The Gordon riots were not accepted in England as a reason for turning all the Roman Catholics out of Great Britain, yet it is now seriously argued that the anti-Semitic risings justify the removal of the Jews from Russia.

Until within a year or two a Democratic Convention in Iowa has been one of the most unimportant political assemblages which were to be seen anywhere in this country. The party was in a hopeless minority in the State, and its procedures were matters that did not concern the party outside of the State borders, and that did not much concern the party even within those borders.

ALBANY, June 24. -- Dr. Seward Webb has been posing as a friend of the Adirondacks so long that a great many people have become possessed with the idea that the construction of his road through the heart of the wilderness would really work to the preservation of the forest. These people will discover some day that they have been badly fooled.

The unveiling of the statue of HENRY WARD BEECHER in Brooklyn yesterday was an occasion that might well make one ask whether anything is so durable as admiration for the good in human character. Mr. BEECHER was a man about whom for long years in the city of his home there prevailed the most violent disputes.

Tammany has suddenly developed weak knees. Its Committee of Twenty-four met in the Wigwam yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock and took very remarkable action in reference to the prevalent stories that the organization is full of dissensions. The leaders, extraordinary as it may seem, resolved that they were dwelling in the most perfect harmony and that they had confidence in Richard Croker.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 24. -- The Chancellor's address was delivered to the students of Union College this morning in the State Street Methodist Episcopal Church by Senator Charles T. Saxton. Senator Saxton was given an enthusiastic welcome when he arose to address the audience. He had chosen for his topic, "A Higher National Life."

Tammany has its clutches on the aqueduct at last. Curiously enough, it is Controller Myers -who says he is not going into Tammany -- who is now responsible for giving the Wigwam a grip on the new water supply before it is entirely completed.
The body of Daniel Lenihan, an old and well-to-do New-York merchant, was buried Tuesday beside that of Mrs. Lenihan in Woodlawn Cemetery.

The accession of Senator GEORGE to the Farmers' Alliance ideas as expounded in the Ocala platform is made with a very important reservation, that, namely, of the Sub-Treasury and warehouse schemes which were proposed in that platform. To all practical intents these exceptions may be said to embrace the substance of the Ocala declaration.

The law of Directors' responsibility makes no advance in the case of the New-Haven Railroad Directors. In default of evidence that Mr. DEPEW and Mr. BRAINERD and Mr. ROCKEFELLER and their associates personally participated in the issue of orders that the cars of the New-Haven Road should be heated by stoves, in violation of the law of this State, the court directs the jury to hold them guiltless of any misdemeanor.

The recent reduction in the crew complements of the various vessels of the white squadron has lost to the flagship Chicago eighty seamen. This reduction has been made in order to fill up the quotas of numerous vessels going in commission. There is no trouble in enlisting men. The law, though, limits the force of the navy to 8,250 seamen.

In seasons gone by Keefe was the idol of the New-York baseball public. His appearance on the field was always greeted with delight and his name on the score card was synonomous with victory. But in this, as in other instances, the whirligig of time has wrought changes. To-day Rusie is the pitcher plenipotentiary of the Giants, and Keefe, to express his position charitably, has taken a back seat.

NEW-HAVEN, June 24. -- In an interview tonight Mr. Richard L. Trumbull says that Balmaceda's declaration that the people are overwhelmingly on his side is a falsehood, made out and circulated for effect in America.

It is due to Secretary BLAINE to say that the official papers laid before the Dominion Parliament by the Governor General confirm what had already been admitted unofficially, the good faith in which Mr. BLAINE had warned the Canadian Commissioners, before they left Ottawa, that their visit would be useless, because the President wished to postpone negotiations until Autumn.

ALBANY, June 24. -- The work of the Hannan-Sheehan vindicators is nearly at an end. Yesterday several witnesses endeavored to discredit the recent testimony of Senator Sheard concerning the bill appropriating $20,000 for a vertical wall at Ilion, and to-day the Senator came down with a batch of documents proving his honesty in the matter, which he succeeded in having spread upon the record.

Arthur G. Hastings of England was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Christine Hedenburg at the residence of John McCowan, Clinton Avenue, New-Brighton, S.I. The Rev. Mr. Hutchins of Brighton Heights Reformed Church was the officiating clergyman.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 24. -- Webb's Park, a picnic resort in the suburbs of this city, was the spot selected early this morning by a pair of desponding lovers for committing suicide together.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, June 24. -- By the renomination of Horace Boies for Governor to-day the Democracy of Iowa began a campaign that will probably put an end to Republican rule in the Hawkeye State. The State Convention met, dispatched its business in an orderly manner, and adjourned, but the impetus given the party by the splendid work done here to-day will be felt until election day.

Charles Sattler, who manages and probably owns the horse King Alta, although he ran in the name of one Olt, a barber at Smith McNeil's Hotel, wanted the first race run at Coney Island on Wednesday investigated. He telegraphed to that effect to the stewards of the club from Gloucester, N.J., yesterday morning after he had read what the newspapers printed about the running of the race.

RICHMOND, Va., June 24. -- Mayor J.T. Ellyson and other members of the committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to confer with Mrs. Jefferson Davis with regard to the removal of her husband's remains here returned from New-York to-day. Mr. Ellyson and his associates say that their visit to Mrs. Davis was of the most agreeable character.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Acting Secretary Grant has just approved the recommendations made by the Fortification Board at its recent meeting in New-York. They include an allotment of $2,818 for the completion of the Woodbridge wire-wrapped gun. The construction of this gun was commenced two years ago, but work upon it was stopped because of the lack of funds.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Gen. Greely, the Chief Signal Officer of the army, issued an order to-day reorganizing the several divisions of the office and separating the business of the Weather Bureau from that of the Signal Service proper, so as to facilitate the transfer of the Weather Bureau to the Department of Agriculture July 1.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 24. -- A prominent railroad man said to-day that in a few days he expected to see filed in the Secretary of State's office certificates of incorporation of the New-Jersey Extension Railroad Company, with a capital of $2,000,000, to run from Newark, N.J., to the Poughkeepsie Bridge, by way of Lodi Junction and Hillsdale, Bergen County, N.J., and Tappan, Rockland County, N.Y., via the West Shore Road.

Three Chilean delegates from the constitutional Government of that country arrived yesterday on the Pacific Mail steamship City of Para. They are Senator Pedro Montt, Jose M. Santo Cruz, and Antonio Baras, Secretary of the embassy. The visitors were driven immediately to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where they will remain during their stay in this city.

Our poverty in vessels for station service is illustrated by the fact that Admiral BELKNAP, desiring to concentrate his entire force near Shanghai to protect the foreign missionaries, has only for that purpose the Alliance and the Monocacy, third rates, of about 1,370 tons displacement each, the latter being a paddlewheel vessel, and the Patos, of 420 tons, armed with seven howitzers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The investigating committee of Councils which has been engaged for the past week in examining the books of the Keystone Bank met gain this afternoon. Robert Yardley, receiver of the Keystone Bank, was the first witness.

The victory won by the Columbia Freshmen at New-London yesterday over the Freshman crews of Yale and Harvard will far more than counterbalance their defeat by the much older and heavier Cornellians last week. Their time, too, as the best on record for Freshmen, makes the triumph the more famous.

The falling off in the attendance at the Coney Island Jockey Club races this Summer is a matter of comment by those who have been used to seeing great crowds at this beautiful track in the past. It is a cause for grumbling among the bookmakers who pay $100 a day for the ring privileges, and of professed surprise to the managers of the track.

Senator Shelby M. Cullom of Illinois said yesterday, very modestly, but with a frankness unusual a year before a national convention, that he was not averse to being a Presidential candidate next year if circumstances were favorable.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 24. -- The important feature of the exercises of Commencement Week of Michigan University to-day was the address of ex-Senator Thomas F. Bayard of Wilmington, Del., before the Alumni and students of the Law Department. My Bayard was introduced by Judge Thomas M. Cooley and immediately commenced his address.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 24. -- The death of Lieut. Gov. Joseph W. Alsop, which occurred at Fenwick this morning, has removed the last chance which the Democrats possessed for securing the State offices during the current two years. Dr. Alsop's demise annuls the quo warranto against Gen. Merwin of New-Haven and leaves him in undisputed possession of the Lieutenant Governorship.

Irving Scott, President of the Union Iron Works of San Francisco arrived in this city on Tuesday from the West. He is on his way to Washington to consult with the Secretary of the Navy on matters connected with the big war ships now building at the Union Iron Works for the United States. These vessels include the new 10,000-ton battle ship Oregon, a new 5,600-ton armored cruiser, and the coast-defense battle ship Monterey.
HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., June 24. -- A good deal of the time of the first day's session of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the New-York State Press Association was given over to the lawyers.

PANAMA, June 16. -- Latest news from Iquique, the Congressionalist capital, states that no improvement is observable in business, and things generally are very dull. No business is done for money and only notes payable to bearer are in circulation. But all these have suffered serious depreciation with the exception of those issued by the representatives of Mr. North, which are received everywhere.

QUEENSTOWN, June 24. -- A man named Meyer of Chicago, Ill., a passenger on the White Star Line steamer Majestic, from New-York June 17, which arrived here this morning, became insane on Thursday last, and afterward died at sea. His body will be taken to Liverpool.

PITTSBURG, June 24. -- To-day's session of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers was fraught with more than ordinary importance. A number of Pittsburg iron manufacturers who took exception to the scale presented to them last week asked the privilege of laying the matter before the general body.

There was a piping breeze blowing over the Hudson yesterday for the twenty-third annual regatta of the Columbia Yacht Club. It came from the northwest at first, but afterward settled down in the north, and it made the Corinthian yachtsmen chary of topsails. There were thirty-nine entries, but only seventeen starters, as follows:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 24. -- The youths from Columbia, thanks to grit and a forty-to-the-minute stroke, not only defeated the Yale and Harvard crews to-day, but broke the world's record for a Freshmen crew over a two-mile course. Their peculiar, rapid stroke is just fitted for a two-mile race, and could hardly have been pulled under more favorable conditions of wind and current.

The policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company are under great obligations to THE TIMES for its determined, persistent, and fearless demand for an honest investigation into the financial condition, management, and business methods of their company. There must not be any whitewashing. If there is, it will not only destroy, sooner or later, the great corporation involved, but shake public confidence in life insurance as a beneficent institution.

The Institute for Artist Artisans, at 140 West Twenty-third Street, of which Prof. JOHN WARD STIMSON is the founder and Superintendent, has closed its third year. With this it reaches a crisis in its affairs that appeals loudly to the civic pride of all New-Yorkers. It is by all odds the best, most democratic, most thorough and promising art school in the country.

PEEKSKILL, June 24. -- The quiet observed by the Seventh, particularly after taps, has been a mystery and a surprise to the old timers. There is nothing in the history of the regiment to equal the conduct of the men, and nothing in the camp to explain the remarkable change in the Seventh of two years ago and the Seventh of to-day.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 24. -- Among the reform measures passed by the last Legislature was one creating a Police Commission for the city of Wilmington, with the idea of making the police force a permanent, non-partisan organization. The law provided that the Police Commission should be composed of one Democrat and one Republican, to be appointed by the Governor and the Mayor of Wilmington who should be chosen at the recent city election.

CHEROKEE, Iowa, June 24. -- The terrors of the Johnstown flood were in part repeated in this place to-day. Seventy-five houses have been carried out of sight in a Niagara-like torrent. How many lives have been lost is yet a matter of uncertainty.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Further experiments were made this afternoon by Col. Dyrenforth of the Department of Agriculture, on the outskirts of Washington, in testing the feasibility of exploding balloons, charged with gases, at a considerable height in the air, with the object of discovering the practicability of exploding dynamite in like manner, and its effects in producing rain in case of droughts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24. -- The Democratic State Central Committee met here to-day for the purpose of selecting a place and fixing a time for the holding of the State Convention. The full committee was present and the best of feeling prevailed. The greatest confidence was expressed in Democratic success in November, despite the work of the stranglers, who have lost most of their followers during the past ten days.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Orders were issued at the Navy Department to-day directing Assistant Naval Constructors John G. Tawresey and William Vansant to return home from Greenwich, England, and report their arrival to the Secretary of the Navy.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker to-day issued the following order relative to promotions in the Post Office Department:

The beautiful grounds of St. John's College at Fordham never presented a more exhilarating and picturesque scene than they did yesterday, when was celebrated the golden jubilee of the foundation of the institution in 1841, and the forty-sixth Commencement of the college, these events being signalized by the unveiling of a fine statue of the late Archbishop John Hughes.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 24. -- The Commencement exercises of the ninety-seventh year of prosperity and progress at Williams College were held in the Congregational Church this morning. The graduating class, led by President Carter, entered and took their places in the forward part of the church. All were attired in the neat Oxford caps and gowns, which are fast coming to be the significant features of Commencement in so many American colleges and universities.

The Board of Rulings of the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations, it is expected, will meet in this city to-day or to-morrow to talk over the Chicago and Alton boycott, and incidentally to prod the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy for paying commissions on passenger business.

HANOVER, N.H., June 24. -- The Alumni Association of Dartmouth College held its annual meeting in the old chapel this afternoon. The gathering was the most remarkable ever held here, because of the fact that the principal business was the discussion of Alumni representation on the Board of Trustees and the adoption of means for its accomplishment, which fact attracted the largest number of Alumni ever in Hanover at one time.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 24. -- A sad drowning accident, the first of the season, occurred at West End, just south of Takanassee Lake, this afternoon. The tragedy was attended by two courageous attempts at rescue, one of which was successful.

A multitude of people of all climes, creeds, and conditions of life crowded into the little park in front of the gayly-decorated Brooklyn City Hall yesterday afternoon to witness the unveiling of Sculptor J.Q.A. Ward's heroic statue of Henry Ward Beecher.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 25. -- The body of youn Frederick Brokaw, son of Isaac Vo ]3rokaw, who was drowned lst evening while heroically endeavoring to save the life of .nnto Doyle, now lies at his father's cottage on Ocean enuo, south of Tkanaesoe Lake, whore messages of cOndolence and sympathy are hourly arring.

NEW-LONDON, June 25. -- There is considerable doubt to-night as to whether the Yale-Harvard race will be rowed in the morning or in the afternoon to-morrow. The Yale men say they are anxioug to row in the morning, and it certainly is to Harvard's interest to do so. The official announcement is that the race will be pulled off at 11:30 A.M., provided the water is in satisfactory condition.

Mr. L.L. POLK, the President of the Farmers' Alliance, has a striking and suggestive article in the current number of the North American Review upon the prospects and the hopes of the organization over which he presides. This article has been elicited by a critical consideration by Col. GEORGE E. WARING, in a previous number of the Review, of the organization in question.

HARTFORD, June 25. -- The Rev. Frederick L. Stevens, who has been pursuing a special post-graduate course at Yale University during the past year, has been removed to the Insane Retreat in this city in a condition of hopeless dementia. Mr. Stevens has been one of the most enthusiastic of Lieut. Toten's disciples in the university, and adopted his theories respecting the destruction of the world.

William B. Moran of Detroit was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Three years ago he was a candidate for Lieutenant Governor of Michigan on the Democratic ticket, and he is counted one of the safe advisers of Don M. Dickinson and other leaders of the party there. He said very emphatically that ex-President Cleveland was the choice of the Democrats of Michigan for the Presidency in the next election.
Among the candidates at the recent civil service examination for positions as foremen in the Brooklyn Fire Department were Edward J. Norton, E. N. Shaute, James Brennan, and Thomas Hofferan.

PARIS, June 25. -- A meeting composed of about six thousand bakers took place in this city to-day. Several speakers addressed the bakers assmbled, and it was resolved to strike immediately. The bakers are in arms against thr Registry offices, and insist as the offices shall be suppressed.

There is a really serious discussion going on in the press of Paris of the question of a possible entente with Germany. The threatened commercial alliance of the Central European powers avowedly in response to the high protectionist policy of the French has, for the first time, awakened the great manufacturers to the danger of commercial isolation.

LONDON, June 25. -- The Earl of Cadogan (Conservative) in the House of Lords to-day moved the second reading of the Irish Land bill. In doing this he said he did not doubt that some of those on the Government side had objections to several of its provisions. They would, he said, support its main principles. He believed the bill would assure increased prosperity in Ireland.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Green cattle sold very badly to-day at the lowest prices of the season. Some 1,754- in cattle of very fine quality, but too heavy, sold at $6.80, to be slaughtered in New-York for the English market. Plenty of common 1,100 to 1,350 in cattle offered at $4.75 received no bids. Prices generally 5@10c lower.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- As a result of the recent examinations at West Point, 99 out of a total of 146 applicants have been admitted to the United States Military Academy to form the new class Cadets who have been turned back from last year's class, and who will join the new class in September next, will probably swell the total membership to 110.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The question as to whether Bank Examiner Drew of Philadelphia used ordinary prudence and diligence in the matter of the Keystone National Bank of Phtla6elphia ts now being tnvestigat by officers of the Treasury Department, ana ms longer continuance in otee will deDend on the result of the Investigation.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 25. -- The Journal is receiving reports from all quarters of unprecedentedly high water in the streams, injury to railroad property, loss of bridges, and destruction of crops along the rivers. The Floyd River is out of its banks and people have been compelled to make hasty departures to higher ground. The waters are receding this morning and the worst is now over.
AMHERST, Mass., June 25. -- The seventieth Commencement of Amherst College occurred to-day in College Hall before a large audience. The order of exercises was as follows:

Four per cent. tax certificates of the city of Brooklyn, running three years, ought to be a good investment; but Controller JACKSON'S advertised offer to sell $1,000,000 of the certificates brought bids for only $300,000. Two weeks ago $800,000 of 3 per cent. Brooklyn bonds were offered for sale, and not a single bid was received.

After the publication of Lieut. WYSE'S report concerning the extension of the Panama Canal concession and of his estimate of the sum by the expenditure of which the canal could be finished, the Central Committee of Panama Canal shareholders in Paris decided to appeal to the Government for help.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 25. -- The graduating exercises of the Senior Class of Bowdoin College were held to-day. Degrees of A.B. were conferred upon fifty-one graduates. Degrees of M.A. in course were conferred upon 17 and out of course on 12 graduates. Sumner Increase Kimball received the honorary degree of D.Sc. The Alumni Association elected James McKeen, '64, President; S.B. Carter, '66, Vice President; George T. Little, '71, Secretary and Treasurer.

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 25. -- There was a Inutiny to-day on board the steamer Batavia, manned with Dutch sailors. Five of the crew had deserted from the ship and word was sent to the police statlon asking the police to capture them. V,'hile the police officers were looking for the sailors the latter returned to the steamer of their own accord, but under the influence of liquor.

SARATOGA, June 25. -- Saratoga opened up practically for the season to-day. All the great hotels flung wide therir doors to recieve and welcome guests. The United Stated begun its business this morning just as if it had been in full operations were seen spon the plazzas in Millionaires' Corner, and the hotel toward evening began to assume its wonted Summer aspects.

PHILADELPIA, June 25. -- The new movement of independently-inclined Republicans against boss rule and bad party nominations took on definite shape to-day at a meeting of the Pennsylvania Club, when the Citizens' Republican Association was formally organized About fifty gentlemen attended the meeting, which was secret, and they wore unanimous in agreeing that the time had come when the better element of the party must assert itself in the State and city against prevailing methods.
" The license of Edward H. Garrison is hereby suspended."

I have just seen the statement of your London correspondent of June 20 concerning the appeal for a new trial made by the vile adventuress calling herself Gladys Evelyn! As your correspondent appears to be entirely ignorant of the real facts of the case, and as I cannot believe you would willingly wish to propagate falsehoods, I claim a statement in your paper.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 25. -- Around Elmirs the greatest interest eentres In the question of who w/ll be the candidates for Governor. From sources so well informed that there can b no quest/on of the accuracy of the Information comes the news that Senator Fasaett will probably be the Republican cantlldate The Senator Is now in the STate of Washington, and, so far, has not accepted or declined ih6 Chairmanship of the State Republican Comnliteo.

A number of well-known musical people and newspaper men met in in one of the parlors of the Brunswick Hotel yesterday afternoon in response to invitations to a musical reception by an automatic piano company. Two upright pianos were in sight, and when the hour arrived at which the musical programme had been scheduled to begin no performers had put in an appearance.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 25 --Dr. J. F. Groenevelt, native of New-Orleans, and an Assistant Surgeon in the Marine Hospital Service, is sick with yellow fever at Chandeleour Island, in Mississippi Sound. He was ordered to the station the Government three weeks ago from New-York, where he had previously been stationed. Soon after his arrival he became ill, and his siokness was found to be yellow fever.

History didn't repeat itself with Mr. Lovett, the crack pitcher of the Brooklyn Club. A few days ago he astonished the baseball world by "Chicagoing" the Giants and retiring them without a safe hit, an achievement of which no other pitcher in the profession can boast. He faced the big Giants again yesterday, and every crank in Brooklyn pinned his faith on the Bridegrooms.

Among the educational institutions of this city there is none so popular on Commencement Day as the Normal College. To this fact generous testimony was given again yesterday by the numbers atending the twenty-second annual Commencement. The capacity of the hall of the college was again overtaxed, and many who sought to attend were turned back from the doors, unable to get within sight of the platform.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Commissioner Morgan of the Indian Bureau has received a telegram from Superintendent Collins of the Moqui Pueblo Indian School at Kean's Canon, in Arizona, in which he states that the Indians threatened to kill the whites and forcibly take their children from the school, and asks that military reinforcements be sent to the school.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Advices Intercontinental ]Railroad CommisSion from Chief Engineer Shunk show that the two civilian surveying parties are now well advanced on the Work of surveying the country in the vicinity of Quite, Ecuador, for the proposed ralJroad between lorth and South nerlca. The two parties left Quzto iay 25, one working south lnd the other going north.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Navy Department has received a report from Admiral McCann on board his flagship, the Baltimore, dated Iquique, Chile, May 25, as follows: ...

The Bowdoin College scientific expedition, which starts from Rockland to-day in the schooner Julia A. Decker, is interesting not only as an addition to the current plans of arctic investigation, but also as an example of practical work by college students. Of its eighteen members, headed by Prof. LEE, the instructor in biology, nearly all are undergraduates.

A gust of wind, accompanied by hailstones and big drops of rain, visited Morrisania yesterday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock. A big black cloud had been noticed advancing from over the Hudson River, but no such uprising of the elements was expected as followed its arrival.

Tony Hamilton, the cleverest of all the jockeys in the colored division, had a bad tumble in the third race at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday and a narrow escape from serious injury. He was riding Portchester, the favorite in the betting and the horse that would undoubtedly have won the race but for the accident. The race was at a mile and an eighth, and seven horses started in it.

Police Captain Killilea of the Thirtieth Precinct seems to need the attention of an oculist. He says that he has been unable to detect any third-track construction in Ninth Avenue, although he professes to be always on the watch for it. He reported to his superiors yesterday that he spent several hours on Thursday riding over the road between stations within his precinct, but he could see nothing illegal going on.

LONDON, June 26. -- The arrangements for the reception and entertainment of the German Emperor and Empress are now nearly completed. Attended by Gen. von Hahnke, Gen. von Wittich, Baron Lucanus, Count Eulenberg, Baron von Marshall, and Countess Brockdorff, they will arrive in the Thames on board the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, Saturday, July 4, and will be met by some members of the royal family.

ALBANY, June 26. -- There was no slip of Gov. Hill's programme at the meeting of the Forest Commission to-day. At the previous session two names were unintentionally overlooked. To-day they were found. In order that matters should proceed as Hill willed, Chairman Cox was provided with type written copies of the action that was to be taken.

Although the rumors of mismanagement in the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company have been surprising in the enormity of the sums of money they involved, it was apparent yesterday among the policy holders of the company and financial men generally that the new defalcation of $125,000 reported in yesterday's TIMES had lifted the total amount of the defalcations beyond their realization.

Entries for the New-Jersey Athletic Club's games at Bayonne, N.J., July 4 close to-day with Walter Scott, 241 Broadway. These events, open to club members only, are: 75-yard dash, obstacle race, two-mile steeplechase, 440-yard run, 220-yard hurdle, running high jump, 880-yard run, running broad jump, and one-mile walk. The prizes will be gold, silver, and bronze pins.

BOSTON, June 26. -- An agreement for judgment for $22,500 for the plaintiff was entered this forenoon in the Superior Court in the case of Silas H. Gardner of Brockton against the Old Colony Railroad Company. Mr. Gardner was one of the victims of the accident at Quincy last August, and at that time sustained a concussion of the spine which, it is understood, will make him an invalid for life.

Judge Beach of the Supreme Court yesterday refused to grant the application of Edward McCrystal for an injunction to restrain the examining board of the First Brigade of the National Guard from re-examining Thomas F. Kerr. Kerr and McCrystal were both candidates for the Captaincy of Company K, Sixty-ninth Regiment. Kerr got the most votes, but failed to pass the examination. Then it was proposed to re-examine him.

From a political point of view, which is the only point of view from which it is a legitimate subject of public comment, the marriage of Mr. PARNELL comes too late. Of course, in the view of the Catholic Church, the marriage is not properly a marriage, and PARNELL has already discovered that the Church is a power to be reckoned with in Irish politics.

PARIS, June 26. -- A dispatch from Buenos Ayres says that the dissension in the ranks of the Union Civica is increasing, and that the supporters of Mitre and Uriburu for the Presidency threaten to secede.

ALBANY, June 26. -- It was by sheer force that Gov. Hill's canal "investigating" committee hung together to-day. There were but three members present, Messrs. Gallagher, Osborne, and Gould, the latter presiding. The paid attorneys were in their places, and big Sergeant at Arms Redmond occupied one of the chairs heretofore filled by a committeeman.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 26. -- A scaffold collapsed here to-day at the foundries which the Worthington Hydraulic Pump Company is constructing at Elizabethport. Two men were almost instantly killed, two badly injured, and four slightly hurt.

The renewal of troubles in Samoa comes at a time when our Government has no war vessel available to send there, although the Charleston on her return from Iquique may be used for the purpose. The present difficulty arises from the attitude of Chief MATAAFA, who led the native revolt against the Germans when they deposed and banished King MALIETOA.

ST. LOUIS, June 26. -- Postmaster John B. Harlow has just returned from Washington, where he has been in attendance on the House letter-box conference. While there he put in some good work with the Post Office Department, and, as a result, will begin some reforms of a radical nature.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 26. -- The Times-Democrat's Galveston special says: "About 11 this morning, during the prevalence of an electrical storm which passed over the city, a bolt of lightning descended, striking and exploding the powder house of the American Powder Company, containing 2,000 kegs of powder. The concussion caused the Hazard Dupon and Laflin Rand Powder Companys' house to explode and also the fire works magazine of Victor Cortinos.

The phases of the Chicago and Alton boycott are multiplying and the fight is increasing in interest among railroad men. Current events are bringing into more conspicuous view than ever before General Passenger Agent Charlton's well known characteristics as a fighter. He yesterday addressed the following communication to Chairman Finley of the Western Passenger Association:

There is no denying the fact that the athletic victories of college undergraduates excite more interest among the Alumni of the various institutions of learning, as well as among the public generally, than any achievements in learning or literature that may be reported. They excite a keener, if not a more widespread, interest than the plans and methods of education that are pursued at the various universities, real or so called.

It was a bad day for jockeys yesterday. Hamilton was the sufferer at Sheepshead Bay, as detailed elsewhere. At Washington Park, Chicago, Britton, one of the most successful jockeys in the West, was thrown from his horse, Miss Dixie, and received severe injuries. Last night he was being cared for in a hospital, suffering from concussion of the brain and other injuries, which, it is feared, may prove fatal.

BERLIN, June 26. -- Among the sculptures which attract particular attention at the Berlin International Art Exhibition is a colossal bronze group, "America Awakening Her Sons to Fight for Liberty." Columbia, seated in the centre, places her hands upon the heads of a farmer and a hunter. The latter, already alert, grasps his rifle and seems to scan the horizon for the approaching foe; the husbandman is slowly awakening.

Dr. John I. Northrop, the young tutor at Columbia College who was so seriously burned by the explosion of alcohol in the cellar of the School of Mines, Thursday, died yesterday morning at the Presbyterian Hospital. This sudden and fatal outcome of the accident was not apprehended Thursday night. At the same time Dr. Northrop's injuries were so serious as to make the case a doubtful one from the first.

St. Louis, June 26. -- Another move was made to-day in the direction of converting the municipal Government into a political machine for Noonan. Action was taken by Street Commissioner Murphy that is causing a great deal of comment. Murphy is nothing if not loyal to Noonan, and it is this loyalty that is responsible for to-day's action.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 26. -- The ship Palestine, from Tacoma, struck on the bar this morning and sunk almost immediately. The crew was saved. The Palestine, commanded by Capt. McCartney, was a vessel of 1,400 tons, and was nine days out from Tacoma with 2,500 tons of coal for the Southern Pacific Company.

BOSTON, June 26. -- The forty-six-footers Alborak, Beatrix, and Oweene are now hauled out at Lawley's, being fitted for the annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club, which takes place on Monday next. The Alborak will have two tons of lead put on her before launching, making twenty-six short tons of lead on her keel. She is being pot-leaded.

PEEKSKILL, June 26. -- The Seventh's last day in camp was the most satisfactory of the tour. Contrary to expectation, Thursday night was as quiet as the first night in camp. Only one giant cracker was exploded, an event that brought Col. Appleton from his quarters at 2 o'clock this morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 26. -- Sheet-iron manufacturers who want to make tinned plate are now declaring that the tariff won't save them. They are going to try to get their industry started by cutting down wages. Representatives of mills East and West have been having an important conference with a special committee of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers concerning the scale for 1891-2.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The Philadelphias surprised the local public to-day by defeating the Brooklyns. They won their victory principally through the efforts of Cassian, a youngster from New-Britain, Conn., who occupied the box and performed capital work. He also made one of the hits which helped the home team to win. Cassian was put in on trial, and if he keeps up to-day's work he will certainly be a fixture on the team.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., June 26. -- This section was visited this afternoon by a terrible wind and rain storm, in the course of which lightning struck in many places, tearing up trees and spreading destruction in every path. The Patterson Coal Company's new breaker, which was rapidly nearing completion, collapsed, and the crash was heard for a distance of two miles.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 26. -- The Princeton University scientific expedition started to-day on its trip in the interest of the United States Fish Commission. Among the members of the expedition are Prof. William Libbey, Prof. Rockwood, and Dr. Thompson of the Princeton corps of instructors, and Prof. McNeil, formerly of Princeton, now of Lake Forest University.

Fully 10,000 people of all sorts and conditions thronged the breezy pleasure grounds of Battery Park last night and for several hours enjoyed music and fresh air, both in abundance and free to all. Music by Bayne's Sixty-ninth Regiment Band was one attraction that served to populate the cool retreat, and the opportunity of inhaling life-giving breezes fresh from the Atlantic was another.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 26 -- Edward T. Rowell, alias T.C. Kellogg, the sharper who secured $1,635 from two banks here in May last and $750 from the National Bank of St. Augustine by means of forged cashiers' "O Ks" on personal checks on Charlotte, N.C., was brought here to-day after a three-weeks' chase. He was arraigned in court this afternoon, pleaded guilty, and received a sentence of two years in the penitentiary at hard labor.

Since the collision in the tunnel occurred many interviews with Mr. DEPEW have been published, in which that genial after-dinner orator has set forth curious and more or less entertaining observations relating to car stoves, the persecution of railroad Directors, and other matters suggested by the killing of six persons, the burning of two of them by stoves carried in violation of law, and the legal proceedings that followed.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Provisions were active, very nervous, and very irregular to-day. The newspapers contained the report of a yellow-fever case in quarantine at New-Orleans. The statement, on the heels of the uncomfortable interview by the Government microscopist at the stock yards, put the trade in a very uncomfortable frame of mind. Before the report was denied or explained pork dropped 10c a bbl; lard and ribs, 2 1/2 5c.

A number of race horses comprising the stable of H.I. Thornton and those which run under the name of the Islip Stable were disposed of at auction in the seddling paddock at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday morning by Auctioneer William Easton. The two-year-old colt Happy John was the pick of Col. Thornton's lot, and after some spirited bidding he was secured by Mr. Charles Smith of Philadelphia for $2,700.

In the obituary of Prof. William Edward Weber, published in THE TIMES of to-day, I do not see any statement of a very important feat of his. Before the discovery of electric telegraphy, and when various theories were advanced as how to employ electricity in the transmission of messages, it was he and the famous astronomer and mathematician, Gauss, who first achieved success in electric telegraphy.

OTTAWA, June 27. -- Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, has decided to retire from public life. The evidence adduced before the Parliamentary committee of inquiry into the management of the Department of Public Works has implicated the Minister and his department in one of the gravest scandals ever unearthed in Canada.

A correspondent of the London Standard, writing of the recent capture and release of tourists by brigands in Southeastern Europe, says in a letter from Constantinople that when the Orient Express came into the station at that city on June 3, bringing Herr Freudiger, engineer of the train which was attacked by the brigands, he was the object of quite a little demonstration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 27. -- Two hundred Onondaga County farmers assembled in convention here to-day to promote their interests by political action, but not by a third party organization. The Hon. Wallace Tappan of Baldwinsville presided. A number of lively speeches were made this morning and a platform of principles was adopted this afternoon.
" Except in the matter of waterfalls, Yosemite isn't in it when compared with the great King's River Canon," said Artist C.D. Robinson.
The following, taken from the Chicago Advance, has been going the rounds of the prohibition press:

E.A. Bastianelli, a traveling salesman for a Broadway cloak house, has instructed Attorney Edward C. Stone, 280 Broadway, to begin a suit against the corporation of Atlantic City, N.J., to recover damages for slander and false imprisonment, of which, he alleges, Mrs. Bastianelli and their two children were the victims.

POVIDENCE, R.I., June 27. -- The announcement that ex-President Cleveland was to be a guest of the Commercial Club served to bring together this evening one of the most brilliant companies that has ever gathered about the club's board. Mr. Cleveland, accompanied by Richard Watson Gilder of the Century, arrived in the city about 6 o'clock.

The recent death of Sister Marie Euphrasie of the Little Sisters of the Assumption was surrounded by such sad and unusual conditions that I beg a little of your valuable space to give a few of the details.

BALTIMORE, June 27. -- The trial trip of the new revenue steamer Galveston to-day is considered a success. She sailed in the morning with a party from Washington and Baltimore and went down the bay below Annapolis. She is a beautiful vessel, the largest in the Revenue Marine Service on the Atlantic coast, and will carry a complement of forty-two men.

There were many well-pleased participants in the opening of the Brighton Beach Hotel yesterday by Thomas E. Cable. Extensive improvements to this hotel have been made since last season. The music hall has been furnished with upholstered chairs, and Anton Seidl's famous orchestra will play there every afternoon and evening. The bathing facilities connected with this hotel are very fine.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27. -- Gov. Campbell is warmly commended for the stand that he has taken against the ringsters of his own party, and if he should suffer defeat in the struggle this year because of it he will have gained a victory over his traducers that will inure to his honor and the lasting benefit of the Democratic Party in this State.

Napoleon's bulletin of the battle of Waterloo, or Mont Saint-Jean, has never yet been published in England, in the opinion of the United Service Gazette, which gives the following translation, taken from the correspondence of Napoleon I.:

I think that some of your readers might be interested to know that the Mr. Fox referred to by Mrs. Sutherland Orr in her "Life and Letters of Robert Browning," (reviewed in your issue of May 27,) the earliest friend and critic of the poet, was the same Mr. Fox who, in later life, represented the borough of Oldham in Parliament for fifteen years.

ORANGE, N.J., June 27. -- The Rockaway polo team defeated the Westchester County Club team on the Essex Country Club field, in West Orange, this afternoon and won the Government Cup, now held by the Meadsbrook team. The teams were composed as follows; Rockaway -- J.D. Cheever, No. 1; J.E. Condon, No. 2; Foxhall Keene, No. 3, and R.T. Frankie, in goal.

There's many a lesson of prudence and economy that the latter-day politicians might study with profit and envy, and the lesson of cruel morality that the latter-day politicians happily avoid, in a curious volume of forgotten lore that a TIMES'S reporter stumbled across in Counselor Harry Winfield's law office, in Jersey City, a few days ago.

The upper part of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, at Forty-fourth Street and Broadway, was destroyed by fire at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and Col. Frederick Kupper's "boys" say they don't care how soon their new armory, at Thirty-fourth Street and Fourth Avenue, is finished. Such a disaster as that which occurred yesterday was prevented many times before, as the building has often been on fire, and this is the third outbreak since December.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 27. -- The Newburg Canoe and Boating Association regatta was set down for to-day. The entries in all classes were large, and it looked as though it would be the grandest regatta here in years. The prizes were costly silver cups, and the entries were from the Sing Sing, Yonkers, Croton, Great South Bay, and Fishkill Yachting Clubs.

Your article entitled "Everybody Should Work," in which are suggested methods by which the marines in the United States Navy should be turned to better account, leads me to a brief description of the services of the marines in the British Navy.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, June 27. -- The annual tide of Summer visitors has begun to rise and the Richfield season bids fair to be a busy one. The village has had its annual coat of Spring paint and has been rebrushed and renovated. There have been a few changes and improvements, but on the whole it will be the same old Richfield.

The week's stay of the Seventh Regiment at the State Camp of Instruction, which closed yesterday, will go on record as a red-letter event in the history of the organization. Estimated from a strictly military standpoint, it may safely be asserted that the tour was the most productive in practical results of any heretofore undertaken by the command at Peekskill.

It was very like old times at the race track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday. The clubhouse was the headquarters during the day of a couple of hundred horse owners and clubmen, among whom the principal topic, aside from efforts at guessing the probable winners, was the prospect of racing at Monmouth Park this year.

BOSTON, June 27. -- The Journal this evening has a special dispatch from Montreal which tells of the attempted suicide in that city of a man who claimed to be Dr. J.R Robinson of Boston by cutting the veins of his right arm in a cell at Police Headquarters this morning.

The scarcity of fruits and the fact that Southern planters did not pay much attention to the cultivation of vegetables made the South a difficult country for fugitives like Bell and myself to pass through. The only way we could get food in mid-July was to come into direct contact with the people, for though we now and then made a raid on a hen roost, the supply was uncertain and the risk very great.

BOSTON, June 27. -- The policemen attached to Station No. 16, on the Back Bay, seldom have a chance to distinguish themselves. This morning, however, shortly after 1 o'clock, one of them arrested a young fellow giving the name of John J. Sullivan, and found that he had in his possession some $400 or $500 worth of property belonging to Edward J. Lowell of 40 Commonwealth Avenue.

Lieut. TOTTEN, Professor of Military Science and Tactics, writing from "Yale University" under the date "First Day of Commencement Week," rejoices that his "testimony has gone forth with no uncertain ring," and points out that never before could there have been such facilities for reaching the entire Anglo-Saxon race at once as have been afforded to him "by the Associated Press under stress from GOD."

AUSTIN, Texas, June 27. -- The Superme Court to-day rendered a decision in the famous railway case from Valrade County brought by Attorney-General, now Governor, Hogg, and involving the question whether the railroads are entitled, under the Constitution of 1876, to land grants on account of siding and switches. The court below gave judgment for the State.

SARATOGA, June 27. -- All the hotels are open and the village is full of visitors. The Court of Appeals adjourned on Thursday and will not reconvene until the 5th of October at Albany. The court broke up at 2 o'clock, and within two hours afterward the Judges and the attaches of the court were on board the cars and homeward bound.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 27. -- The Arthur Kull Association of Elizabeth held its eleventh annual rowing regatta this afternoon on the Arthur Kills. Northerly winds blew a gale during most of the time, making the usually smooth water so rough and choppy that good racing was out of the question. Crews considered themselves lucky not to be swamped.

Mr. Story deserves our gratitude for his fine article on Michael Angelo, for it is written with true fervor and with the truest judgment of the man, his aspirations, and his many-sidedness. Of all the great characters of the Renaissance, Michael Angelo, born in 1474 or 1475 at Caprera, was the greatest.

La Touraine, the splendid new boat of the French Steamship Line, was sighted off Fire Island yesterday morning at 6:30 o'clock. Five hours later she made fast to her pier, completing her maiden trip from Havre to New-York in 7 days 4 hours and 32 minutes.

The coming to the front of new writers of short stories, like Mary E. Wilkins and "Octave Thanet," has somewhat overshadowed the fame of the older writers. But Elizabeth Stuart Phelps and Harriet Prescott Spofford have borne a goodly share in the evolution of the short story and its establishment as a literary fact.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27. -- Gen. John Beattie, who is one of the best-known Republicans in Ohio, and a man never afraid to utter his convictions, roasts Fire Alarm Foraker in two and a half columns of the strongest denunciation ever printed. Of Foraker's speech nominating McKinley, he says:
" And so, after the first act, Deshayes and I went into the foyer -- "
The shipment of live cattle and sheep from the eastern seaboard of the United States to Great Britain is one of the recent modern industries in which our business men have taken a profitable lead.

ST. LOUIS, June 27. -- There is war among the architects over the plans for the new Union depot. The company has invited competition, the terms of which are that the architect whose plans are accepted will get 2 1/2 per cent. of the estimated cost of the depot, which will be $400,000. That will be $10,000. He will get no more than that if the building costs more.

TROUVILLE-DEAUVILLE, June 14. -- Parted merely by a thread of water supplied by the little river Touques, this twofold seaside resort is a house divided against itself. Each has a wide stretch of sands for bathers, a casino, hot baths, hotels, and public works. If Trouville has the biggest caravansary. Deauville has a race course.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 27. -- The season in the Catskills can now be considered to be fully opened. The old Catskill Mountain House opened last Saturday, the Grand Hotel Wednesday, the Laurel House Thursday, and the large Hotel Kaaterskill to-day. There is great bustle and stir at the West Shore Railroad station in this city, and the Ulster and Delaware Railroad is carrying many passengers.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27. -- Three prominent American politicians are doing big fishing just at present up in the wilds of Canada. They are Senator John R. McPherson of this State, ex-Senator George F. Edmunds of Vermont, and ex-Senator Wade Hampton of South Carolina. Mr. Edmunds and Gen. Hampton are the guests of Mr. McPherson The Jersey Senator owns an entire river in the Dominion.
BOSTON, June 27. -- The reports of student insubordination at Phillips Exeter Academy recently published are corrected by the editor of the Exeter Gazette. He states:

HARTFORD, June 27. -- During the last six months a committee consisting of Prof. John J. McCook of Trinity College, A.E. Burr of the Hartford Times, Judson H. Root, Charles E. Gross of the law firm of Hyde, Gross Hyde, and William B. Clark. Vice President of the AEtna Insurance Company, has been investigating the system of out-door alms which has for years made Hartford the paupers' paradise.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 27. -- The line of action to be pursued by the City Council's Committee on Licenses was revealed this morning. Although the State law and city liquor ordinance conflict, the committee's action shows that a bitter fight will be waged against fifty-seven saloon keepers, who refuse to obey the provisions of the ordinance.
I read in THE TIMES of Monday, June 22, the following:
In changing from money (coin) into bars, (merchandise,) do gold and silver loose anything in importance, usefulness, or dignity?

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., June 27. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker came down to-night to enjoy the sea breezes over Sunday. He was met at the station at Cape May Point by Mrs. Reid, who is at present occupying his cottage. The Postmaster General is not looking so well as he looked last Summer. He appeared to enjoy the prospect of his brief rest.

LONDON, June 27. -- This has been a busy week for society, and its three most prominent attractions have been well attended and much enjoyed. These Meccas of the social world of London were the Royal Academy conversazione, the Inner Temple's performance of Ben Jonson's "Masque of Flowers," and the triennial Handel festival at the Crystal Palace.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $142,421,400, as follows: Currency 6s, $7,957,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $22,638,450; 4 per cents, $111,825,950.

Architecture for religious buildings in America has always suffered from the limitations imposed by a simple form of ambition. This ambition has been to equal, if we could not surpass, what the peoples of Europe have accomplished. But the attempt meets with various complications.

A remarkable quality of Mr. Frothingham's mind is intellectual disinterestedness. This is eminently the quality of Unitarians the world over; it is to this, in fact, that Unitarianism most tends to lead its followers. Admirable as the quality is, it does not possess much of the power that enables men to make their way in the world.

BRUSSELS, June 27. -- A letter from Rome received here to-day says: "There has been received in Rome a memorial addressed to the Cardinals endeavoring to enlist their aid in the scheme of colonizing European priests in the United States, as heretofore fully described in these dispatches. It boldly asserts that the European Governments must exert themselves to retain their influence over their emigrants to the United States.

The fleet gray couriers of morning are chasing away the night's deep shadows. In the East the first upshooting of the dawn proclaims another day's advent. All about, beyond the sentinel trees that file behind the stony breastworks that man has made to shield this noble preserve from trespass, the greatest city of the continent lies asleep, and all so still that naught from it distracts the peacefulness of this pastoral scene.

Mr. Thomas Stevens of bicycle fame tells in this volume of a ride of 1,100 miles through the heart of Russia. Mr. Stevens's adventures are novel ones. It is all commonplace enough for an American to go to St. Petersburg and, provided with passports, to take the train to Moscow, and thence by rail or in post carriages to make his way through Russia.

This season will be remembered long for its use of lace in quantities and qualities unknown before. The amount of lace sold here in New-York alone at the retail counters would seem to be almost beyond computation. The delicacy of the fabric compels the purchase of so much for one costume that the woman who would be satisfactorily belaced must invest in a fabulous number of yards.
