During the fortnight that the statement of the Bank of England as to the assets and liabilities of the BARINGS has been before the English public, it has produced an impression less and less satisfactory. By that statement the assets were in excess of the liabilities by some $16,000,000. But the value of the assets was estimated at the prices current Oct. 31, 1890, as given in the original statement.

HOLSTEIN, Iowa, June 27. -- Yesterday occurred a most destructive storm. The lightning and hail in abundance have done irreparable damage in this section to crops and cattle. The district stricken by hail is three miles west of here and is three miles wide and ten miles long. Barley is almost totally destroyed. Wheat and oats are damaged.

In the course of a year Thomas Boese, the Clerk of the Superior Court, who is a recognized authority all over the country on naturalization matters, receives about a thousand letters of inquiry in regard to passports and the rights of naturalized American citizens in case of temporary return to their native country. His replies frequently save his correspondents considerable trouble.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- To-night at Hooley's Theatre Mr. Daly and his New-York Comedy Company said farewell to Chicago for one year. Their season just ended has been the best financially they ever played in this city, and the receipts for the three weeks, it is said, have exceeded those of any similar period in the career of the company.

The third annual camp at Cheesequake of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association was opened yesterday. Many of the clubs of the association in this vicinity had laid plans for a cruise to the camping grounds, but on account of the high wind and the rough water in the bay some of them had to abandon their plans.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27. -- The Jersey State officers are tired of answering questions about an alleged decision of the State courts regarding poolselling at race tracks. Letters have been received from all over the country asking for the text of the opinion. At the suburban races near New-York last week it was announced that the Court of Errors and Appeals had delivered an opinion that would permit the opening of Monmouth Park this season.

There is a show of opposition in certain quarters to the nomination of Mr. Cleveland as the Democratic candidate for President in 1892; but a large majority of the Democratic voters of the country believe that he is the one man and the only man who can lead the party to victory. There is not a Democratic newspaper of any standing or influence in any part of the country which is opposed to him.

ALBANY, June 27. -- Ex-Alderman William Doyle of Newburg, whom Gov. Hill has made Assistant Secretary to the Forest Commission, has long been a hanger-on at the sessions of the Legislature. Once, through the good offices of Judge George Green of New-York and Jersey Bridge fame, Doyle's name appeared on the list of newspaper reporters as the representative of the Newburg Register.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 27. -- A decided conflict of orders has arisen over the disposition of Chinamen who have violated the Exclusion act and have been seized in this country. To-day United States Commissioner John E. Pound of this city sent back four Chinamen to Canada in violation of the Treasury Department orders to hold them for departation to China.

A missionary journal, published in France, has devoted a series of articles to the progress of the Roman Catholic faith in India during the present century. In 1800 the number of Catholics in India was estimated at 475,000, and of this number no less than 290,000 were to be found in the Portuguese province of Goa. In 1850 the number of Catholics was 986,000, and in 1890 they had increased to 1,701,337.

HOW THE CHINESE GET SQUARE WITH Us. -- It is as possible to "slit the thin-spun life" with a stiletto as with a broadsword, and in the most finished periods a Chinaman finds himself quite able to express either withering contempt or remorseless hate. But he has other ways also of giving vent to his ill humors.

Mayor Chapin is working industriously on his fast-approaching campaign, and Secretary Phillips, who is paid by the city to do the legitimate work of the office, is kept busy night and day distributing to the voters copies of the Mayor's various explanations of his conduct. Thousands of copies of the last message in the water-scandal matter were sent out in this way, and on June 22 Secretary Phillips mailed several thousand copies of the following:

" Washing as it is; washing as it should be!" was to be the watchword of the laundresses of London on Sunday, June 14, when they were to demonstrate at Hyde Park in favor of their inclusion in the Factory acts. As the estimated number of washerwomen in the metropolis exceeds 100,000, says the Daily Telegraph, "it is expected that the gathering will be a formidable one in point of numbers.

Gen. FRANCIS A. WALKER, whose skill in analyzing statistics and extracting their significance is well known, has contributed to the forum an interesting study upon what is shown by the mere figures of the census as to the colored element in our population, and he shows that, contrary to a very common assumption, it is a constantly-diminishing factor, even in the States where it is most at home.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 27. -- It is now well understood in political circles that Associate Justice McEnery will be the lottery candidate for Governor. This was surmised when the Supreme Court recently rendered a decision requiring the Secretary of State to submit to the people a proposed constitutional amendment renewing the lottery charter for twenty-five years on payment of $1,250,000 a year.

At a private gathering in London a lady who supposed herself to present a remarkably youthful appearance said to Douglas Jerrold, "I cannot imagine what makes my hair turn gray; I sometimes fancy it must be the essence of rosemary with which my maid is in the habit of brushing it. What do you think?" "I should rather be afraid, Madam," said the witty dramatist, "that it is the essence of Time!"

ITHACA, June 27. -- A few weeks before the time for nominating city officers last Spring the Republican wire-pullers, seeing no hope of carrying the election, resorted to strategy and advocated a non-partisan movement in city affairs. The Republican daily in this city was so given over to non-partisanship that it generously published a long list of Democrats that would doubtless fill the city offices acceptably to both parties.

The advance copies of the fifth annual publication of Brassey's Naval Annual have been issued. Some of the material of this publication is drawn from English and foreign service journals, periodicals, and leading English and French newspapers, but the greater part of it consists of the compilation of official reports and a collection of data relating to progress in naval construction, machinery, ordnance, armor, organization, administration, personnel, education, and training.

I have noticed the article in THE TIMES of to-day in regard to a conveyance of Staten Island property supposed to be stolen from the State archives at Albany. An examination of the early history of our State, I think, will show most conclusively that the document referred to has never been in the archives at Albany since the Revolution, and I may say, since 1777, and did not come unlawfully into Mr. Wilkelow's possession.

The drowning season opens sensationally. It is a thousand pities that brave young BROKAW lost his life so vainly, but his death may not be a wholly empty sacrifice if it deters other bathers from like rashness. The entire party appear to have been swimmers, and the two who were drowned sank while a boat was coming and only a few feet away.

The identity of the young woman who was found drowned in the Hudson River at Croton on Saturday morning a week ago was established last night when two young women went to the undertaking establishment in Tarrytown while Coroner Sutton was holding his inquest in the case. They asked to see the body, and said they had just arrived from New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 27. -- Quite an exciting and romantic criminal career was temporarily suspended by the sentencing to-day to terms in the Parish Prison of Willie Marlin and Edward Dixey. The first is seventeen years of age and is from Parkville, Mo. Dixey is twenty-one, and is from England. About two years ago fate found both youths studying for the ministry in a theological institute in Missouri.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- In the course of the investigation of the affairs of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley in connection with Glendinning Co., the law department learned that the bankers, who were depositors in the Fourth Street National Bank, had on May 22 received a Clearing House due bill from that institution for $30,257.58.

Congressman Hilary A. Herbert of Alabama, accompanied by Major W.W. Screws, editor of the Montgomery Register, with a party of ladies, is at the Hotel Lincoln. Mr. Herbert has been for many years a member of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, having been its Chairman during the Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Congresses, and the ranking member of the Democratic Party on that committee during the Fifty-first.

It undoubtedly is the dull season in amateur photography, but no one would suspect it who, on a fair Saturday afternoon, watches the young men and women who pass into the Park or ascend the stairs of the elevated stations with their little boxes jauntily secured by straps thrown over the shoulders. They are starting out on picture-taking excursions.

PEEKSKILL, June 27. -- After a most successful week the Seventh Regiment finished its tour of camp duty to-day, and was relieved by the Forty-seventh and Thirty-second Regiments of Brooklyn. During the night an old-fashioned north wind bounded into camp, driving the sentries into their overcoats and necessitating the tightening of many tent ropes.

At the tenth annual games of the Kings Country wheelmen at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, A.A. Zimmerman of the New-York Athletic Club won the one-mile ordinary championship of America. It was quite a surprise, as nearly every one of the 2,000 spectators present conceded a victory to Champion Murphy. Zimmerman rode a good race, and won by about ten yards from C.M. Murphy of the Kings County wheelmen.

The Dauntless Rowing Club was gallant yesterday and held a Ladies' Day Regatta on the Harlem. The boathouse at One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue was crowded with the fair friends of the members, who watched the different events with the greatest interest and cheered the winners with much enthusiasm.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 27. -- The Rev. David J. Evans, assistant rector of Holy Trinity Church, New-York, has accepted the appointment of rector of Grace Episcopal Church at Middletown, N.Y., and will enter upon his new charge Sept 1. He is a graduate of Oxford University, England.

When Mr. PEFFER addressed the toilers of New-York last week he spoke in behalf of "the millions of suffering farmers of this country." He declared that "one-half of the farms of the country are mortgaged for more than they are worth," and that the State of Kansas would not fetch enough to pay its indebtedness if put up at auction.

WATERTOWN, June 27. -- The season for catching the gamy black bass in Northern New-York waters opens well this year, and anglers are looking for a good Summer's sport Many frequenters of the Lake Ontario and St. Lawrence River bass ground are predicting that more fish and bigger fish will be taken this year than for many seasons.

The reported effort to enlist the Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church at Rome in a scheme for colonizing European priests in this country for the purpose of counteracting the influence of its institutions upon the faith of immigrants shows that the liberalizing tendency of life here is fully appreciated by some of the authorities of the Church.

MANCHESTER, June 27. -- The visiting team of the Manhattan Athletic Club of New-York competed this afternoon with the crack athletes of England at the English amateur championship meeting, held here. This meeting is the principal athletic event of England and is held under the auspices of the Amateur Athletic Association of Great Britain.

Now that Mr. Morgan has taken his wonderful Gloriana off to Newport, there to remain in obscurity until the Newport races begin, yachtsmen are finding nothing more profitable and pleasant than to compare notes taken on one or more of the five races in which that remarkable craft led all her competitors.

The author of this pamphlet rests her theory on the postulate that music represents motion. She says: "Painting, sculpture, and music find their models all in the same world of real phenomena, but neither one nor the other can represent a body or any other phenomenon in its entirety. The deep-seated popular prejudice that painting and sculpture can represent bodies helps to obscure also the function of music.

NEW HAVEN, June 27. -- J. Avery Gould of Aurora, N.Y., '92, Sheffield Scientific School, the stroke of this year's Yale crew, has been chosen Captain of the crew for next year. Gould Balliett, Simms, and Paine were the only available men for the position.

Not counting the Jumonville affair, which, nevertheless, cuts quite a figure in French history and literature, the first regular conflict delivered by Washington was the battle of Fort Necessity, in the Great Meadows, now styled the Glades, of the Allegheny Mountains. A document, yellow and stained with the accidents of a century and more, has recently been found in Virginia which tells another story of the disappointments of the brave.

With the gracious and pressing needs of the various fresh air funds making themselves felt, suggestions for Summer bazaars are in order. One held recently in suburban town was a dolls' loan exhibition. The idea was original with one of the bright young townswomen, and its development was crowned with such a measure of success as to warrant its wider announcement.

July is the month when outdoor life is found most attractive, and those who take pleasure in the study of the gem-studded heavens will find many favorable conditions beneath the grand sky roach under which to pursue their observations. The planets, the moon, and the Summer stars make the July nights, whether at seashore or mountain resort, as beautiful as a dream.

ROCKLAND, Me., June 27. -- The Bowdoin scientific expedition, in charge of Prof. Leslie R. Lee, started to-day for its arctic cruise on the steamer Julia A. Decker. The vessel is a trim craft, 87 feet in length and 23 feet beam. She is in command of Capt. Spear, who takes the expedition to Halifax, where sores will be laid in, and where the final details will be adjusted.

In the interesting sketch of Col. John Watson's life published in THE TIMES of June 14, as illustrating the good stuff the family is made of, allusion should have been made to two of his nephews who were shot in battle, Col. George Pratt and Lieut. John W. Watson, both of whom gave up their lives for their country.

The five years' term of office of President JOSE MANUEL BALMACEDA of Chile expires on the 18th of September, and the election of his successor was at the latest accounts going on. Of course, in such circumstances, the continuance of the policy of the present Government must be looked for.

TRENTON, June 28. -- Some of the incidents attending the refusal of Judge J. Clarence Conover to issue a license for the sale of liquor to ex-Assemblyman John Kennell, on the State camp grounds at Sea Girt, give fresh flavor to the license scandal at Long Branch, which THE TIMES of last Monday morning explored for the information of interested Jerseymen.

It is a matter for surprise that Count TOLSTOI in his search for objects on which to vent his superb indignation did not strike wine and tobacco before he came to soap and marriage; but he has finally reached these somewhat familiar evils, and treats them with the unqualified scorn and detestation that all things human appear to awaken in his mind.

PARIS, June 16. -- The most absurd project on hand is the Meyerbeer celebration on Sept. 5 -- just when everybody is out of town. In the hot July months of former years, when warm weather could be reasonably expected, a respectable crowd might be attracted, but in the Fall, with school holidays and shooting, only Cook's tourists are on hand.

After some hesitation, presumably to be ascribed to a variety of causes -- the amount of practical station work exacted this year, the drills in Southern waters earlier in the season, the lack of men for crews, or perhaps some personal considerations as to squadron commands -- the Navy Department now seems disposed to go ahead with the proposed practice manoeuvres on the Atlantic seaboard, which have long been under consideration.

FALMOUTH, Ky., June 26. -- The Hon. John Young Brown, Democratic candidate for Governor, spoke here to-day to a large and enthusiastic audience. His exposition of Democratic doctrine was as masterly as his dissection of Republican heresies was withering and keen. In closing his great speech. Mr. Brown broke silence as to the question of the new Constitution. On this point he used the following language:

CHEROKEE, Iowa, June 28. -- The work of caring for the homeless has been systematized, and they are now quartered in the Masonic Temple, Knights of Pythias Hall, and Grand Army of the Republic Headquarters. All the public buildings have been placed at their disposal. Cots fill the spacious halls, and every effort is being made to make them comfortable.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 28. -- Col. H.S. Benjamin, the pioneer investor and business partner of Capt. N.D. Moore, the discoverer of the Gogebie Iron Range and for several years a bonanza king, took "the poor man's oath" before Court Commissioner Hugh Ryan this evening to escape the jail limit under an execution against his body. Col. Benjamin has been under the action of the execution since June 8.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28. -- It is said that President Harrison, as he passes through this corner of Pennsylvania on his way to and from the seaside, shades his eyes and averts his face. The story may well be true. His party in Pennsylvania two years and a half ago gave him 80,000 majority; now it is wondering if it can elect its local ticket.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 28. -- All of Elberon and West End was in mourning to-day, and evidences of grief were displayed on every hand. Flags on the hotels, cottages, and churches were flying at half-mast, and the usual extensive traffic that is carried on along Ocean Avenue was perceptibly hushed. It was the day of the funeral of Frederick Brokaw, who lost his life to save a drowning girl.

With the advent of the warm weather the season for "lost children" has fairly opened, and from this time forth until Winter sets in Sergt. Kelleher, who has charge of the Bureau of Information at Police Headquarters at night, will be kept busy receiving and recording stray little ones and delivering them to their parents or friends when they call to claim them.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The details of the coming naval manoeuvres cannot be given until Admiral Walker has prepared his programme and submitted it to Secretary Tracy. In the preparation of this programme the Admiral is left entirely free, his only instructions being to give the manoeuvres such character as will tend to the development of the problem of defending the cities of New-York and Boston and the seacoast of Long Island and New-England generally.

The principals in the primary schools of the city are up in arms over some of the questions asked at the recent examination. According to the rule formulated, under ex-Supt. MacAlister, the examination questions for all the schools are made out by the Superintendent and mailed to the principals on the morning of examination.

PARIS, June 28. -- Under prompting from Cardinal Richard the other leaders of the Episcopacy in France have united in opposition to Cardinal Lavigerie's policy in support of the republic, and a new party is forming called the Union de la France Chretienne. The organizing committee includes the principal Conservative Senators and Deputies.

LONDON, June 28. -- Money was abundant during the week, and there was no demand for discount, which was quoted at 1 1/2 3/4. The Stock Exchange continues lethargic. Apart from the steady current of investment buying of high-class stocks, nothing is doing. Dealers concur in the opinion that speculative business is at its lowest ebb. Never before has such a prolonged period of inaction been experienced.

The July payments of interest and dividends in this city are the heaviest of the year. Upon July 1 interest matures on a large portion of the national debt, and the Government will pay the quarterly interest on the 4 per cents (so far as payment has not been anticipated) and also $1,938,705 semi-annual interest on the Pacific Railroad bonds, known as the "Currency 6s."

This is a fish story. Unlike a good many others, it is true. Being true, we give the names of the gentlemen who will back it up, and they are Messrs. F.H. Packard and Charles H. Davis, both of Lewiston. They have been at Moosehead, up by the wild lands of the Northwest Carry, at the Seboomook House, and Saturday, June 13, at supper the proprietor said: "We'll have chowder to-morrow."

The changes that take place in the progressive cities of America are quite remarkable. In the West especially a decade often makes a city. What was a mere hamlet finds itself in this brief period of time transformed into a busy, populous community, with hotels, street cars, electric lights, and fine stores and dwellings. The progress is usually slower in the East, and in the South there is, in many cases, no progress at all.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 28. -- An event unusual in the history of churches and church pastorates was celebrated in this place to-day. The Rev. Amasa S. Freeman has just completed the forty-fifth year of his pastorate of the Central Presbyterian Church of Haverstraw, and an appropriate celebration of the anniversary was held by that clergyman and his people.

It is to be "American night" at Palmer's to-night, so named by Manager Askin in honor of the fiftieth performance of "The Tar and the Tartar," both the author and composer of which are Americans. The theatre will be gayty decorated within and without with American flags, potted plants, and cut flowers, and Digby Bell and his companions on the stage will introduce a number of new features to the performance.

Interesting experiments designed to show how great an influence may be exerted upon vegetation by electricity are said to have been made recently in Russia, where the growth of radishes, carrots, and other vegetables was greatly accelerated by the application of an electric current, at first to the seeds and afterward to the soil in which they had been planted.

PRINCETON, June 27. -- The members of the Examining Committee have announced that there have been more applications for admission to Princeton University for the coming year than ever before. There are seven places of examination which have not been heard from, but the returns from the other local examinations show a total number of applicants (including those who took their preliminaries and those for full admission) to be 452.

Ex-Assemblyman Delcour S. Potter of Glens Falls has written the Daily Times of Glens Falls, to say that the recent enactment by the Legislature of Michigan providing for the election of Presidential Electors by Congressional districts recalls to him the attempt to pass such a law in this State in 1880.

The paper of Dr. BRIGGS in the current number of the North American Review is sure to attract a very wide attention from the position of its author. It repays that attention, as every reader of it must admit, by the force and clearness and candor of its utterances. It is noteworthy that Dr. BRIGGS argues the question like a highly-informed but disinterested and impartial observer.

The Boston Beacon (Republican) tells Massachusetts Republicans how to redeem their State. It says: "The coming campaign will be a campaign of argument. The Democratic Party has a corps of young men thoroughly drilled and equipped for effective campaign oratory. Russell, Williams, Hoar, Quincy, McNary, McDonough, Corcoran, Crosby, are all brilliant campaigners.

A fight occurred last evening on the excursion barge Meyer, at One Hundred and Fortieth Street and North River, while the County Corkmen's Association was returning from a picnic. During the row Jeremiah Cronin, a liquor dealer of 76 Oliver Street, was struck on the head with a tumbler by Michael Burke, a loborer, of 417 Tenth Avenue, and received a severe scalp wound.

Darwin J. Meserole, the young broker who put two bullets through the heart of Theodore Larbig on Saturday night in the apartments of "Dovie" F. Comstock, 378 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned before Police Justice Tighe yesterday morning, and was remanded without bail on a charge of murder. He gave his age as twenty-three years, and his residence as 460 Washington Avenue.

The peculiar complexity of the relations created for some business men by our absurd tariff laws is seen in the recent strike of the employes of JOHN JAMES DOBSON of Philadelphia. This enterprising firm is known to have contributed largely to the legislation for the protection of American labor, which has consisted largely in taxing very heavily the workingmen generally to enable employers like the Messrs.

The new heavy ordnance rifles of the United States Navy are tested to withstand a pressure of twenty-five tons to the square inch. In actual service the guns are not subjected to a pressure of more than fifteen tons to the square inch. The ordnance regulations require pressure gauges to be used at stated intervals during a cruise.

The demand for more men in the navy has resulted in a decision to reduce the crew complements on the Coast Survey and Fish Commission vessels. Fifty men will be taken out of the Coast Survey and thirty out of the Fish Commission. They will be ordered aboard cruisers about to go in commission.

CHARLESTON, West Va., June 28. -- Harve Mullins, the leader of the notorious Mullins gang of moonshiners, who have been making whisky and committing murders and other crimes in McDowell County for several years, has been arrested, with Pile Cooper, one of the gang.

Our Philadelphia dispatches this morning throw some new light on the movement for "reform within the party" in Pennsylvania. It appears that the gentlemen engaged in this praiseworthy and very necessary effort are to some extent a part of the thing to be reformed and were active in support of DELAMATER'S nomination last year.

BALTIMORE, June 28. -- The speed of twelve knots an hour attained on the official trial yesterday of the new revenue cutter Galveston is not deemed satisfactory by members of the board. The Galveston, though not built for high speed, was expected to attain at least fourteen knots. The defect is attributed to the wheels.

It was in 1885 that Italy adopted the policy of encouraging ship building and navigation by bounties. A law of Dec. 26 of that year provided that for the next ten years a bounty of 12 cents per net ton would be paid from the National Treasury to owners of steam and sailing vessels alike for every 1,000 miles.

There was a good deal of sound sense in Mr. CLEVELAND'S remarks to the Commercial Club of Providence as to the interest and duty of business men in politics, and there was, as there is apt to be in all that he says on such occasions, a simple earnestness that always leaves a strong impression.

ST. LOUIS, June 28. -- Charles Erskine of Kansas City tells a story of the oppressive methods of the Gould railway management, and he produces documentary evidence to support his statements. He is President of the Rocky Branch Coal Company, which owns and operates a coal mine situated in Lafayette County, Mo., near the town of Higginsville.

At the meeting of the locomotive engineers, to be held in Cape May during August, an interesting paper will be read by H.H. Dantzer, formerly an engineer on the Reading Railroad, but now a contractor in West Philadelphia. The paper will deal entirely with the wonderful manner in which engineers on railroads, steamboats, and the masters of mammoth machinery ascertain accurately and instantly when anything goes wrong with the machinery under their control.

I have lately visited a bench show. I enjoyed my visit. I like dogs. As I went up and down the benches I saw various ecolesiastic similes. I think that we Congregationalists are well typed by he Newfoundland dog; large, vigorous, dignified, with common sense; good for land or good for water; good for heat or good for cold; true and tried.

This will be a record-making day for the Aldermen, and those who have any regard for their political future will take care how they vote on the Battery Park resolutions. For several weeks the people of this city have waited patiently for their elected representatives to express the opinion that the use of a public park by a railway company should be prohibited.

At the Tattersall's salesroom last evening William Easton sold at auction the yearlings of the Hon. W.L. Scott's Algeria Stud Farm. They were an exceptionally good-looking lot, and, as there was a good attendance of prominent horsemen, bidding was lively and the sale a decided success. The full brother to Chaos was the pick of the lot, and, as he was a grand looker, he caused some spirited bidding.

The city of Buffalo has a new charter, and it has also a Citizens' Association whose main purpose is to promote the nomination and election of capable and honest men for municipal offices irrespective of party. Last week this association held a meeting and provided for the appointment of a Committee of One Hundred, "representing as nearly as possible all political parties and all shades of public opinion."

QUEBEC, June 29. -- Dufferin Terrace, the favorite lounging resort of an evening of the youth and beauty of Quebec, was the scene of a shooting affray to-night between two well-known society men. Capt. Kane, an ex-officer of the British Army, for nearly a year has been much displeased at attentions paid to his wife by C.P. Storey, a young Englishman holding a good position here.

HARTFORD, June 29. -- As soon as the Senate was ready for business this afternoon the Executive Secretary appeared on the floor with a communication from Gov. Bulkeley, being his first pose since Judge Hall's decision last week fixing his legal status in the Capitol. There was a ripple of excitement as to what attitude the majority would assume toward the Governor's representative, but none of last Winter's scenes were repeated.

Prince GEORGE of Greece shows good sense, on his own part or on the part of somebody else, in assuming an incognito as part of his traveling outfit in this country. It would have been churlish, of course, for him to repel a demonstration upon the part of his fellow-Greeks in Chicago, but he has at least escaped the awful hospitalities of Aldermen.

For the first time since the appointment of Judge Tappen as Commissioner of Public Parks the Commissioners are inspecting conjointly the parks below the Harlem River. The inspection began yesterday. Commissioners Gallup, Dana, and Tappen met at the Arsenal in Central Park at 9 o'clock and arranged the route for the tour for the day. Commissioner Straus is on the other side of the ocean.

There seems to be a disposition at Washington to apply the contract labor law in a manner to make it ridiculous. A public-spirited Chicago man has imported a couple of Japanese jinrikishas and had two natives of Japan accustomed to that sort of thing brought over to propel the vehicles. His purpose was to place these in a public park and have them used in carrying children about for their amusement free of charge.

PEEKSKILL, June 29. -- The second day of the Brooklyn regiments' sojourn in the camp of instruction has been as lazy as the clouds that have been drifting from Anthony's Nose across to old Dundenberg since the Third Battery detachment fired the morning gun. Up on the big drill plateau there has been just air enough stirring to make every one feel comfortable, and the work done has just about corresponded with the breeze.

BREMEN, June 29. -- The German-American Petroleum Company, which is the corporate form here of the Standard Oil Company, is fast subduing competition in Europe, as it did in America, absorbing and assimilating what it cannot easier destroy. Its last acquisition is the leading Bremen firm of oil importers, Albert Nicolas Schutte Son.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Prince George of Greece arrived in Chicago this morning from Omaha. He was accompanied by Capt. Lahmer of the Russian Navy and one servant. The Prince is traveling incognito, and registered at the Auditorium as Count Foistor. At the station he was met by a delegation of the Grecian Benevolent Association, which escorted him to the hotel.

ROME, June 29. -- The Catholic world here is endeavoring, in order to mitigate the economic crisis, to promote, in the European capitals, Catholic banks, which, working in connection with each other, would form a kind of international syndicate. In order to attain this end the argument of Boutoux is advanced, alleging the necessity of withdrawing the capital, resources, and finances of the Catholic world from what is now practically an absolute Jewish control.

It appears that the Philadelphia Press was assisted by the Albany Journal in the benevolent work of enlarging Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS'S tin-plate factory in St. Louis during his visit to this city. "Already the St. Louis Stamping Company," says the Journal, "is engaged in the manufacture of tin plate and giving employment to 350 persons."

Advices received from Haiti by down-town merchants yesterday indicate but little change for the better in the affairs of that country. The report that Hippolyte had been assassinated was discredited, but there seemed to be no doubt that his enemies were numerous and working against him in deadly earnest.

Apparently Mr. LEECH, the Director of the Mint -- who joins to some exceptional qualifications for his work an unfortunate tendency to give out general opinions on the conduct of the Treasury -- has been only slightly sobered by the experience and observation of the past two months. In the Post's Washington dispatches yesterday he is reported as giving the following statement as to the forms of currency in our happy country:

It is an interesting evidence of the very great influence of the German race upon modern affairs that English statesmen nowadays not infrequently use German terms to express a meaning that it would seem to be perfectly easy to express in their own tongue. Recently, for instance, Lord SALISBURY was visited by a deputation requesting the calling of a conference to draw up a plan of federation for England and her colonies.

LONDON, June 29. -- The Times to-day, referring to the fact that sixty delegates from the tin-plate working districts of Wales are going to the United States in order to inquire into the prospects of profitable employment there, and to the statement made that American agents in London are buying the latest improvements in tin-plate machines, as well as offering double wages to tin-plate workers, says:

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- A staff correspondent of the Republic has just returned from a trip to Iowa, where he made a careful investigation of the political situation. He found everywhere the greatest enthusiasm and confidence among the Democrats and quite the reverse among the Republicans. The correspondent concludes his article with this:

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- Ten innings were required to determine the game here to-day between Philadelphia and Brooklyn, and the latter won in a most brilliant manner. Esper, who pitched for the local club, held the Brooklyns down for five innings. In the sixth, however, the visitors began to find the ball, and thereafter they made matters extremely interesting for Mr. Esper, and at the same time kept his colleagues in the outfield very busy.

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- Douglass McCollum passed through the city to-day on his way to New-York. He has spent three months in the Kaweah Colony, in Tulare County, Cal. In the course of a long interview he said:

George S. Rice, Chief Deputy Engineer of the new Aqueduct Commission, is going to Boston in the employ of the Rapid Transit Commission of that city. He has not yet been officially notified of his selection by the commission, but expects to receive the notification to-day. The appointment will be for seven or eight months, at a salary at the rate of $10,000 a year.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 29. -- At 10:45 A.M. the first whistle for the annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club was blown from the judges' steamer, anchored off Half-Way Rock. Courses V and D were hoisted, and at 11:15 the whistle for the first-class schooners was blown. The Merlin was away first, followed by the Mayflower.
The moral teachings of the latest Brooklyn tragedy are stern and Puritanic, but uncommonly wholesome.

BALTIMORE, June 29. -- The firm of H. Straus, Brother Co. (Levi and Joseph H. Straus) made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors to ex-Judge William A. Fisher, Simon Rosenberg, and Henry L. Straus. Ex-Judge Fisher is the firm's lawyer. Mr. Rosenberg is a member of a prominent banking firm, and Henry L. Straus is a lawyer and a son of Levi Straus of the assigning firm.

LONDON, June 29. -- The body of James McHenry, the well-known Erie Railway litigant, was exhumed June 20, by order of Home Secretary Matthews, and was subjected to a careful post-mortem examination, after which it was reluterred, the stomach, however, being retained by the Government officials. A veil of mystery surrounds the affair, but it is believed that the object was to verify the death of Mr. McHenry, in view of the Erie litigation.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Ohio Republicans in Washington are awaiting, with more anxiety than they care to express, the outcome of the expected visit here of Messrs. Powderly, Devlin, and Hayes of the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor. These persons are understood to be now on their way to the capital from Ohio, accompanied by some of the Republican leaders of that State.

Substantial progress is making in the work of constructing the Broadway Cable Road. From Fifty-ninth to Forty-third Streets, with the exception of a few short sections left open in order not to incommode traffic, the roadway is practically completed, and it is expected that the horse cars will be run over the new tracks between those points in the course of the coming week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- Contrary to the general impression, Postmaster General Wanamaker did not appear before the investigating committee of Councils this afternoon to explain the apparent discrepancy between his previous testimony relative to his ownership of Keystone Bank stock and facts subsequently developed by the books of the bank.
BOSTON, June 29. -- The Boston Journal tomorrow will contain the following editorial announcement:

The congregation of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New-Rochelle, one of the largest of the Roman Catholic parishes in the neighborhood of New-York, is in a sadly-divided state just at present over the course which has recently been taken by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas McLoughlin. It is about a year since the church building was struck by lightning and burned to the ground.

" How does it feel to be the winner of a twenty-two-thousand-dollar stake?" was a question that Ex-Assemblyman David Gideon had to answer several hundred times yesterday afternoon after his colt, His Highness, had won the Great Trial Stakes for two-year-olds at the Sheepshead Bay track.

The question of making provision for the exiled Jews of Russia is occupying the minds of other wealthy and philanthropic men besides Baron Hirsch. Prominent among these is Dr. Paul Friedman. Dr. Friedman is a gentleman of Jewish descent, a native of Berlin, and at present a resident of that city, though he has spent the greater part of his life in London, where he has earned the reputation of a litterateur.

In THE TIMES Sunday morning it was stated that the loan business done by the New-York Life Insurance Company under its present management was notoriously the business of a ring, through which transactions could be had only upon the payment of heavy percentages and upon the "consideration" of those appraisers of the company whose recommendations were vitally essential to the making of the loan.

NEWPORT, June 29. -- The spectacle is presented just now of one of the leading Admirals in the United States Navy engaged in the serious endeavor to usurp the prerogatives of a senior Admiral. Were it not for the fact that the drills and manoeuvres of the new vessels of the navy are being seriously handicapped by this attempt at usurpation, the whole affair might be looked upon as a delicious piece of comedy.

There is something painfully ludicrous in the distress of the Ohio Republican leaders over the demand of the Knights of Labor that Superintendent MEREDITH of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing be removed from office because he discharged a number of plate printers for good and sufficient cause who happened to be members of that worshipful organization the Knights of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The following address, signed by Rudolph Blankenburg, John T. Bailey Co., George Wharton Pepper, George Burnham, Charles Heber Clark, the Rev. Stephen W. Dana, the Rev. W.N. McVickar, John H. Converse, the Rev. Charles Wood, the Rev. S.D. McConnell and 136 others, was made public this evening:

Owing to the quashing of all the indictments against Secretary GIBSON of the Whisky Trust, except one, in Chicago last Saturday, it may be that the professional and other advocates of Trustism will have no opportunity to give their doctrines and arguments an airing during the trial of this man in a criminal court.

Turning aside for a moment from the business of revealing and interpreting Administration policies and politics, Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper has this word to say about what it calls "that insurance squall":

The Chicago and Alton Road has stirred up more trouble for the Eastern trunk lines by its reduced passenger rates from Chicago to St. Louis and Kansas City. The reduction went into effect yesterday. It knocks off $2.50 from the regular Alton rate from Chicago to Kansas City, and by so doing reduces the through rate from New-York to Kansas City $1.75 below the scheduled trunk-line rate.

LONDON, June 30. -- The Telegraph's St. Petersburg correspondent declares the harvest in Russia this year is likely to be the worst on record. He draws a narrowing picture of the results of the continued drought.

WESTPORT, Essex County, N.Y. June 30. -- One of the most disgraceful appointments made by the Harrison Administration is that of Edwin B. Low as Postmaster in this village. It was opposed almost solidly by the respectable Republicans of Westport on the ground that Low's reputation for honesty was bad and his habits so intemperate as to render him totally unfit to discharge the duties of the position.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- ExSenator Ingalls made his debut as a lecturer at the National Chautauqua, at Glen Echo, near this city, to- day. His subject was "The Problems of Our Second Century," and his effort was listened to by a large audience.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- New-York's players increased their lead here to-day, as they won and Chicago lost to Pittsburg. Rusie's work won the game.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- During the past ten years the Consulting Engineer of the United States Revenue Marine Service has been Mr. Charles E. Emery of New-York. Mr. Emery enjoys the title of "engineer expert." The practical marine engine work of Mr. Emery appears to have been confined largely to the machinery of revenue cutters. It was not until the beginning of the present year that the efficiency of these designs was officially questioned.

A disgraceful row took place at a meeting of the Long Island City Board of Health last night. Mayor Patrick J. Gleason took part, and it resulted in the serious injury of Alfred B. Nelson, a prominent citizen, and the bruising of a number of others. Mr. Nelson's shoulder was dislocated and he is probably otherwise injured, as a result of an attack made on him by Mayor Gleason.

LONDON, June 30. -- It is now said that James McHenry, the well-known financier and old-time Erie Railroad litigant, whose body was exhumed June 20 by order of Home Secretary Matthews, was insured in England and the United States for over $5,000,000. The insurance companies, it is added, suspect That Mr. McHenry committed suicide by poison, thus rendering void the insurance policies on his life.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 30. via Galveston, Texas. -- Dispatches received here from Guatemala say that the candidates for the Presidency of the republic presented by the political clubs and the press are Gen. Jose Maria Reina Barrios, Manuel Eliseo Sanchez, Lorenzo Montufar, Francisco Lainfiesta, Gen. Henriquez, and Gen. Basilio Arrogave.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- Twelve heats were trotted and paced at Belmont Park this afternoon, and favorites captured all three of the classes for the beginning of the midsummer circuit. The 2:50 class developed a promising youngster in Audobon, a four-year-old colt from a stock farm near Poughkeepsie. He won very easily, placing his record below the 2:30 notch.

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 30. -- In all the figuring that has been done of late years to establish a shorter route between the American Continent and Europe, there is one principle which has not always been kept as clearly in mind as it should have been. Traffic flows in the easiest channels and not by the shortest ways unless other things are equal.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The immigration into the United States from 1820 to 1890 is the subject of a special report which has been prepared by Major Brook, the chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department. No official record was made of the influx of foreign population to this country before 1820, but the immigration from the close of the revolutionary war to that time is estimated at 225,000.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Considerable surprise was expressed by officers of the Navy Department to-day when it was announced that Acting Rear Admiral McCann's flagship, the Pensacola, had been ordered to the Mare Island Navy Yard for repairs, and that Admiral McCann had been ordered home by mail steamer, leaving Acting Rear Admiral Brown in sole charge in Chilean waters.

The rapid strides made in the development of naval artillery during the last few years has had a marked effect on the armaments assigned to recently-commissioned war ships. In no particular, perhaps, has this been so noticeable as in the general tendency to place rapid-fire guns in the primary batteries. Prior to 1888 the rapid-fire gun was, per se, a function of the auxiliary batteries.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The formal transfer of the Weather Bureau from the War Department to the Agricultural Department, under an act of the last Congress, will take place to-morrow. Gen. Greely will then relinquish the duties as Chief of the Bureau, and Secretary Rusk will assume them on behalf of the Department of Agriculture.

The special race of the Larchmont Yacht Club for sloop yachts measuring from 50 to 60 feet, sailing length, was sailed yesterday in a one-reef breeze. The yachts covered by this designation are nearly all included in the new forty-six-foot class. There were only four entries for the race, Commodore Chester C. Munroe's Clara, Capt. Bayard Thayer's Sayonara, Capt. August Belmont's Mineola, and Capt. W. O'B. Macdonough's Jessica.

Certain persons have undertaken to mislead the public as to the conditions under which block tin may be produced in this country. The Philadelphia Inquirer publishes a short essay on this subject from a contributor who appears to be regarded by our contemporary as an expert witness. He says:

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 30. -- A clearly-defined case of hydrophobia is that of Reuben Drew, a prominent farmer, seventy-six years old, who died in convulsions at his home, eight miles west of Fort Wayne, yesterday, after terrible torture.

PITTSBURG, June 30. -- The Monongahela Presbytery of the United Presbyterian Church to-day decided to receive into full communion the Revs. O.B. and E.M. Milligan and the Rev. J.A. Barnet. These are three of the young ministers whose liberal views recently led to the approval of their suspension by the Reformed Presbyterian Synod.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The monthly pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean for July will be issued from the Hydrographic Office of the Navy Department to-morrow. It gives the weather forecast for July as follows:

LONDON, June 30. -- George Dance and Edward Solomon's new opera, "The Nautch Girl; or, The Rajah of Chutneypore," was produced at the Savoy Theatre to-night in the presence of a brilliant audience, and judging from the manner in which it was received, the indication is that the piece will have a success fully equal to that of some of Gilbert and Sullivan's works.

ROME, June 30. -- The inhabitants of a large portion of the province of Verona were awakened last night by a series of severe earthquake shocks. They rushed out of their houses in the middle of the night and ran into the open fields. In several cases the walls of houses collapsed, and in others chimneys fell through the roofs or large cracks in the walls.

Owing to the inability of Mr. R.P. Huntington, Jr., to be present, the finals in the doubles of the national tourney at the Staten Island Cricket Club grounds, at Livingston, S.L., were not played yesterday afternoon. They will be contested to-day, commencing at 3:30. Only one match of the consolation contests was played yesterday, but the large number of spectators witnessed a close and exciting battle from start to finish.
By the decisive vote of 16 to 8 the Aldermen at yesterday's meeting declared themselves against the Battery Park grab. This is the way the lines were finally drawn:

By a vote of 16 to 8 the Board of Aldermen has given expression to the voice of the people upon the occupation of Battery Park by the elevated railroad. It would perhaps be more accurate to say that the voice of the people was expressed by sixteen of the Aldermen and the voice of the Manhattan Railway Company by eight.

In the discussion of the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company yesterday, the most general topic was the cable message which President William H. Beers is alleged to have sent from London Sunday to the company's officers in this city, which was printed in yesterday morning's TIMES. The general tone of comment on the cablegram was unfavorable to President Beers.
" This is a trust-killing tariff, men and brethren," said the New-York Tribune yesterday, and it added the following remarks:

PEEKSKILL, June 30. -- Comparatively few persons know what a really out-and-out good time the State militiamen have on their Summer camping trips. There is but one man in this camp of 800 men who does not believe that if what the militiaman's life actually is were generally known the ranks of every regiment in the service would be filled to the waiting list.
ALBANY, June 30. -- The State Board of Health bulletin for the month of May contains these remarks:

BRIDGEPORT, June 30. -- A New-York politician, bearing assurances from Gov. David Bennett Hill of a touching solicitude for the welfare of certain Connecticut Democrats, is making a leisurely tour of the State. The news that he will carry back to Albany when his inspection trip is over will be much less cheering to Mr. Hill than to some other folks. He has struck a frost.

Prince George, the athletic young son of the King of Greece, arrived in this city from Chicago last evening. He descended from the New- York Central drawing-room coach Branksmere in the Grand Central Station a few minutes before 9 o'clock, and immediately found himself the chief object of interest in an enthusiastic crowd of about a thousand persons.

ISLAND OF NAVASSA, West Indies, June 20. -- All is quiet once more on Navassa Island. The company's bark, the Albemarle, sailed to-day for Baltimore, taking away all the discontented workmen. The long vigil of the Kearsarge is over, and she has gone home.

The "Proceedings of the United States Naval Institute" for the quarter ending June 30 contain six papers. The initial subject is treated by Lieut. R.C. Smith. It deals with "Disposition and Employment of the Fleet; Ship and Squadron." This essay was honorably mentioned in the recent prize essay competition. Naval Constructor David W. Taylor has a paper "On a Method for Calculating the Stability oil Ships."

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Ohio Republicans who have been worrying over the attitude of the Knights of Labor toward McKinley have gained little comfort from the visit here of the Executive Committee of the Knights. The thing is evened up, however, from the fact that the Knights got no comfort at all to-day.

BALTIMORE, June 30. -- The insurance on the stock and fixtures in the coffee roasting house of E. Levering Co., which was burned out Sunday night, amounts to $92,500. Of this, $82,700 was on stock alone, $9,800 on machinery. The policies were placed as follows:
BOSTON, June 30. -- J.M. Hill, the well-known theatrical manager and restaurateur of New-York and Boston, has failed. The liabilities are said to be very large. Several attachments have been issued.

Last Friday night Alexander Weisse and a well-dressed woman, whose name is unknown, took a room at the Cosmopolitan Hotel, South Beach, S.I. They gave their address as 67 East Third Street, New-York. On Saturday Weisse paid the bill and the couple left. Monday Landlord Walsh got a letter from Weisse saying that he had left a package at the hotel which he wanted kept until it was called for.

The cornerstone of Brooklyn's newest political organization, the Bushwick Democratic Club, was laid yesterday at the corner of Hart Street and Bushwick Avenue, and all the local Democratic politicians graced the scene with their presence. Then about 300 of the more prominent ones walked over to Arion Hall in Wall Street, near Broadway, and disposed of one of the finest banquets that has been given in Brooklyn in many years.

The "citizens' movement" carried the day in the Portland (Oregon) municipal election. It had no machinery, no patronage, no corruption fund, no claim on party loyalty, and no claim to personal allegiance, the Oregonian says, but won on its merits by virtue of a popular uprising against bosses and ring rule. At the polls the voters entirely ignored the great national issue, and put their ballots in for honest and intelligent government of their city.

Among those who signed, in February, 1890, the memorable New-England petition for free iron ore and coal and a duty of only 24 per cent. on scrap iron and scrap steel -- a petition which was described by the New-York Tribune as a "tricky free-trade attack upon the tariff" -- were certain manufacturers of tacks whose factories are in Congressman ELIJAH A. MORSE'S district in Massachusetts.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 30. -- The Freeholders of Union County, N.J., have had a sample of the rapacity of Hudson County (N.J.) politicians during the last few days, as represented by the Board of Freeholders. Applications for licenses to build docks had been made to the Union County Board by George P. Wetmore, the Mechanics' Land and Building Company, the Bayonne Improvement Company, Frank H. Lindner, and Solon Humphrey.

During the Monmouth Park meeting at Morris and Jerome Parks the management will make a feature of the free field, to which no admission fee is charged. Mutuals, straight, place, and one-two-three, at $2 a ticket will be sold in the field, the income to the club from this source being a sufficient paying investment to offset any loss of patronage of the grand stand.

An article by Dr. Sigmund Munz in Blackwood treats of "The Pope and his Writings." The poet-Pontiff has told the story of his life in Latin distichs while he was Bishop of Perugia, and he has published numerous other poems in Latin and Italian. Here is a picture given by the writer of the poet-Pope:

It is noticeable that the recent riots in China seem to have started from a source like that of the former ones in Corea -- the spreading of a rumor among ignorant people that the missionaries were killing the native children in order to "make medicine" of them. Given the prevalence of such a notion, it is perhaps only surprising that the fury of the mob was not more destructive and uncontrollable.

ST. LOUIS, June 30. -- The political machinery at the City Hall seems to be getting into first-class working order. Street Commissioner Murphy is carrying out his idea of politics in office to the letter, and no alien or non-voter can escape, unless he is satisfied to indulge in a little deceit.

The Board of Health yesterday took decisive action to compel all physicians and midwives to obey the Sanitary Code and report all births at once to the Health Department for record. February last there were recorded 399 deaths of children six months of age and under, and from the examination of the returns of births on file it was found that there was no record of the births of 119 of these children.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 30. -- The Rosedale cricket team of Toronto, Ontario, met a team picked from the various teams in the Metropolitan District League to-day on the New-Jersey Athletic Club grounds here. Each played one inning and will finish the match to-morrow on the same grounds, starting at 11 A.M.

The address of the reforming Republicans of Pennsylvania, which we published yesterday morning in full, hardly goes far enough. They show the evil ways into which their party has fallen. They point to Mr. QUAY as the leader who, more than all others, is responsible for this state of things.

When Michael F. Dwyer paid $25,000 for Potomac at the closing-out sale of the racing stable of the late August Belmont a great many people thought it was an injudicious purchase. "Potomac will not stay over a distance of ground," said these doubters, "for the St. Blaises will not train on." But Mr. Dwyer apparently know what he was doing.

The President's proclamation is not much more than an official notification to whom it may concern that the United States has adopted an international copyright law. Of course, the acknowledgment in the proclamation of the rights of British authors is important, and will give American publishers a confidence in making contracts with those authors that they have never felt before.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- Welch pitched a remarkably strong game against the local club to-day, but nevertheless the latter won. The victory was due to poor field work. Only two hits were charged against Welch, but in spite of that fact the Quakers scored four runs, which were sufficient to win the game.

Brighton Beach race track, reconstructed, revivified, with new life and blood in its management and with a new purpose, that of giving as high-class and as thoroughly-honest racing as on any race track in America, throws open its gates to the public to-day with as good a racing programme as has been offered at any race track this year.

The Supervisor's room in the Brooklyn Court House was filled to overflowing last night when Coroner Rooney and a jury began the inquest in the case of Theodore Larbig, who was killed by Darwin J. Meserole in Mrs. Dovie Comstock's fiat Saturday night. Many of them were old men, like City Controller Jackson, who were present to show their friendship for Gen. Meserole, the prisoner's father.

Kaiser WILHELM'S Summer outing, which brought him as far as Amsterdam yesterday, has come later this year than in former seasons, and a difference more noteworthy is the general recognition now of the fact that his annual "swinging around the circle" is for personal rather than political purposes.

To the few friends who saw Manager J.M. Hill yesterday that gentleman appeared as bright and cheerful as in his palmiest days. He expressed great confidence in his ability to extricate himself from the embarrassments which now surround him, and declared that by the 1st of January he would not owe a dollar in the world.

The State Superintendent's examination of the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company is progressing slowly. Deputy Superintendent Michael Shannon reports that he has a force of twenty men at work, and that they are getting along at a commendable rate, so rapidly that Mr. Shannon begins to think that his examination will conclude before the end of September.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., July 1. -- St. James's Episcopal Church celebrated its one hundred and fiftieth anniversary yesterday by the unveiling of a memorial tablet in honor of the Rev. Dr. Richard Mansfield, who was rector from 1748 until his death in 1820, a period of seventy-two years. This rectorship is said to be without a parallel in the history of the Episcopal Church.

Alexander Weisse, an advertising agent of the New-Yorker Herold, a German evening paper, who had been missing for several days, and who had written to friends that he intended to commit suicide, carried out his intention yesterday morning; but before taking his life he made a desperate and brutal attempt to murder the young German girl, Minnie Staeding, who had been his companion for several months.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The following is an authoritative explanation of the change in the form of the debt statement and the reason therefor:

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Before his departure for Europe Senator-elect Calvin S. Brice sent to Mr. Lawrence Garner of this city, the Secretary of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, copies of the letter prepared by him to invite the co-operation of the Democratic National Committee members and the State Committees in the work of the approaching Presidential campaign.

New-Yorkers have become so accustomed to look for nothing good from their Board of Aldermen that the Battery Park vote of yesterday comes as a positive shock. The board, by a vote of two to one, declares itself for the present free from the evil influence of Jay Gould, and mildly registers its opinion that his nuisance ought no to be permitted in public parks.

The Republican Convention in Iowa yesterday assumed an attitude of boldness and confidence. It retracted nothing and dissented from nothing that the party has done in the State or in the Nation. Notwithstanding the overwhelming, reverses of last Fall, it gave its full approval to the McKinley tariff law, with special commendation of the delusive reciprocity provisions, and even went so far as to defend the extravagant appropriations of the last Congress.

The scheme of the aqueduct contractors for getting several million dollars from the City Treasury in excess of what was due them under the contracts has received a serious set-back from the decision of Judge INGRAHAM dismissing the suit of O'BRIEN CLARK. He holds that they are entitled to pay for the work called for by their contracts, certified to by the engineers as done in accordance with the contracts, and to no more.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 1. -- The irrepressible conflict came up in the Republican State Convention to-day. It was in the form of an effort of a vigorous and compact minority to throw off prohibition, the millstone that is dragging the party down to its death in Iowa. The bosses made a desperate effort to keep the struggle under the surface, but failed.

To accommodate people desiring to remain in the country over the Fourth, the Erie will run three special trains Friday afternoon, July 3. The first will leave Chambers Street at 12:50 P.M. and Twenty-third Street at 12:40 P.M., running to Paterson, Ridgewood, Suffern, Tuxedo, and stations on the Newburg Branch. The second train will leave Chambers Street at 1:40 P.M. and Twenty-third Street at 1:40 P.M., stopping at Rutherford, Passaic, Paterson, and River Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 1. -- Gov. Bulkeley did not swerve a hair from the caucus nominations in making the County Commissioner appointments this afternoon. Most of the old Commissioners were left out, and new men will decide on the liquor licenses in November. The appointments will be operative until the third Wednesday of the legislative session in 1893. In detail the appointments by counties are:

The trial of the suit of Aqueduct Contractors O'Brien Clark to force the city to pay twice over for work done on Section 6 of the new aqueduct, which was begun about six weeks ago in the Supreme Court, before Judge Ingraham and a jury, was brought to an abrupt termination yesterday. Monday Joseph H. Choate finished his argument in opposition to a motion to dismiss the complaint.

Insurance Superintendent PIERCE made a capital beginning of his investigation of the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company by appointing Mr. MICHAEL COLEMAN to appraise the company's real estate. He could not have chosen a man more competent for the work. This is the first important official duty MR. PIERCE has been called on to perform since his appointment.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The President to-day issued the following proclamation:

AMSTERDAM, July 1. -- The flotilla escorting the Emperor of Germany and his party arrived here to-day, accompanied by the Dutch squadron under Vice Admiral de Josselin de Jong. This squadron consists of the cruisers Koningin Emma der Nederlanden, 3,400 tons; Vangalen, 2,160 tons, and Johan Willem Friso, 3,400 tons; the steel-protected cruiser Sumatra of the Dutch Colonial Navy, three armored rams, and several armored monitors.

LANSING, Mich., July 1. -- The Legislature passed a new election law to-day, final concurrence being effected on the House and Senate amendments. The bill is an adaptation of the Australian system. It provides that the tickets shall be printed by County Commissioners, composed of the Judge of Probate, County Clerk, and County Treasurer.

The annual cruise of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club begins to-day with the special race for forty-six and twenty-five footers at Oyster Bay, in Long Island Sound. The fleet rendezvoused there yesterday afternoon, and a meeting of Captains to determine the direction, duration, and regulations of the cruise was held last night on board the flagship Miranda.

BALTIMORE, July 1. -- The cablegram from Rome to-day stating that the Pope had refused Cahensly's demands for national Bishops in this country, was read by the Catholics of Baltimore with a delight that they did not try to conceal. They considered it a plain fight against the predominance of the Irish in the episcopal offices of the Church in the United States, and they were worked up by the agitation to an unusual degree.

LONDON, July 1. -- The Prince and Princess of Wales will not meet the Emperor at Port Victoria, near Sheerness, as previously announced. The German Emperor will be met upon landing there by the Duke of Connaught, the Duke of Edinburgh, and the Duke of Clarence and Avondale. The Prince and Princess of Wales will await the arrival of his Imperial Majesty at Windsor Castle.

LONDON, July 1. -- The total number of people who were carried by the City and South London Railway Company during the month of May was 427,917. The week-day average was 13,050 and the Sunday average was 8,862. The total receipts from these passengers amounted to $17,100. It should be borne in mind that this line leads from nowhere to nowhere.

The present Summer will see a continuation, to some extent, of the policy of holding joint encampments of regulars and State troops, which the War Department has favored, and, to the best of its ability, carried out during the last few years. The Nineteenth Infantry, Col. CHARLES H. SMITH, has been authorized to participate again with the Michigan National Guard in their encampment.

The Sugar Trust, under its new form as the American Sugar Refining Company, is in for some more litigation. Judge Bernard of the Supreme Court at Poughkeepsie on Tuesday granted an injunction restraining the company from paying a dividend before July 11, when the case will come up for another hearing. James A. Taylor is the plaintiff in the action.

Chairman BRICE of the Democratic National Committee has made a timely appeal to the Chairmen of the several State Committees of the party to promote the organization of Democratic clubs to meet the work of the clubs of the Republican League. One of the chief advantages which the Republicans have had in the past is the thoroughness of their organization and the skill and persistency which have characterized its management.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Gen. Thomas O. Osborne, who recently returned to this city after a residence of many years in Chile, expresses his opinion that the stories of barbarous cruelty by President Balmaceda, as told in recent dispatches, are correct.

The designs of France in Asia are deduced with great freedom from the report that French troops have occupied a dependent State of Siam, Luang Probang by name. The British publicists in particular are always on the lookout for schemes that interfere with the vested interests of Great Britain in India and threaten to promote the nefarious, if not positively sacrilegious designs of Russia in that quarter.

RICHMOND, Va., July 1. -- Gov. Simon Bolivar Buckner of Kentucky is in the city, on his way to Frankfort, the capital of his State. The Executive of the blue grass Commonwealth is a strong Cleveland man. In an interview with a reporter he said:...

ALBANY, July 1. -- The garment which Gov. Hill's canal-management tailors have fashioned for Superintendent of Public Works Edward Hannan is ready for him to assume. To-morrow he will take the stand, and that will end the farcical examination into the conduct of the State canals.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 2. -- In obedience to the dictates of the local Republican politicians, led by Fred E. Bach, Senator Higgins's private secretary, the Republican members of the Levy Court have voted to place on this year's tax duplicates the names of about 4,000 poll taxables, principally negroes, whose names do not appear thereon.

ALBANY, July 2. -- The canal investigation farce came to an end to-day, and now all that remains to be done is to prepare the thousands of folios of testimony and write the report of the "inquiry." Chairman McMahon announced that the committee would stand adjourned, subject to the call of the Chairman, and said later that the committee would not come together again until Fall.

PARIS, July 2. -- The inquiry into the mal-administration of the Panama Canal Company, which is proceeding before M. Prinet, Conseiller a la Cour d'Appel, will probably be of a most protracted and comprehensive character, if it is really meant to make it thorough. The de Lesseps clique is not now the mighty power it was, but it has still wide influence in high political quarters and throughout the press.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago Junction Railways and Union Stock Yards Company was held in Jersey City yesterday. Nearly $10,000,000 of the stock was represented and the proceedings were so harmonious that Mr. Depew almost imagined that he was attending a meeting of the New-York Central Directors.

Wednesday four tramps were driven from a train at Greycourt, near Goshen, N.Y., where, after a chase, they were arrested on suspicion of having robbed a lad named McCabe at Haverstraw a week ago. McCabe said yesterday that they were not the men who had robbed him. They were held on the charge of vagrancy.

The early bird got the worm again yesterday morning, the bird in this case being the holder of Sugar Trust shares who cashed his check for dividends as soon as he received it. At 11:30 o'clock an injunction, served on the officers of the Western National Bank, upon which the checks were drawn, stopped further payments.

Mr. Alfred Roosevelt, who is in the banking business at 33 Wall Street, this city, was very seriously injured while attempting to board a moving train at Mamaroneck Station on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad at 8:14 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. Roosevelt has been a resident of Mamaroneck about a month, having taken a lease for the Summer of the old Mitchell homestead, which belongs to the estate of Charles Osborne.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 2. -- Joseph Baum Co., shoe dealers, filed confessions of judgment in the Circuit Court to-day for $87,300. The firm composed of Joseph Baum and Joseph Levy. The names of the parties who got judgment against the firm by consent, with the amounts of the judgment, are as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2. -- The malignant attacks that have recently been made by the organs of Mr. Lawrence T. Neal have brought about such a revulsion of public sentiment that many of Mr. Neal's personal friends regard the time for his open withdrawal as a Gubernatorial quantity at hand if he would not further create a division in the ranks of the party.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- It begins to look as if Chairman Finley and the Chicago and Alton Road would never arrive at an understanding. In a brief note to General Passenger Agent Charlton to-day, Mr. Finley informed that official that the reason his name had been omitted from the late excursion-rate circular was because of the status of the Alton under the agreement, as defined in a recent decision.

PEEKSKILL, July 2. -- A rainy day in camp is generally dismal beyond description, but it wasn't the case to-day with these Brooklyn militiamen, who seem bent on upsetting expectations. Yesterday, with half a week gone and everybody expecting an unusually good showing in the drill, the work was disappointing.

Mr. FOSTER'S changes in his monthly statement are, to say the least, exceedingly untimely. It is a very bad time to make alterations in your books when your business reputation is subjected, justly or not, to suspicion, and when you know that an investigation is sure to be made into your affairs by persons none too friendly and clothed with ample authority to get at all the facts.

There has been another and an extraordinary reduction of the price of tin plate in Helena, Mon., or at least in the office of Mr. RUSSELL B. HARRISON'S Helena Journal. On May 7 he said in his paper: "The competition of our own manufacturers has brought down the price of tin plate to a figure as low as was ever known in this city."

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Gen. Hyde of the Bath Iron Works of Bath, Me., was at the Navy Department to-day to see Secretary Tracy about the contract for Protected Cruiser No. 13, for which his firm was the lowest bidder. Bids were opened June 1, but the Secretary has not yet been able to decide whether to award the contract to the Bath works or to Cramp Sons of Philadelphia, the next lowest bidders.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., July 2. -- About three weeks ago Mrs. Perry Knorr, acting as agent for a corset manufacturing company, left her home, saying that she was going to Ashland to take a few orders. Taking her sample and order book she started over the mountain on foot, expecting to visit several of the houses on the way.
The name of the New-York Life Insurance Company was coupled with a new defalcation yesterday. An Associated Press dispatch from San Antonio, Texas, made the following announcement:

ALBANY, July 2. -- The examination for Inspector of Academies, under the Board of Regents, advertised to be held in the civil service rooms here to-day, did not take place. Five persons presented themselves for examination. They were informed that there was some uncertainty whether the position of Inspector of Academies under the Regents still existed and were advised to make inquiry at the Regents' office.

The rejuvenated Brighton Beach Racing Association began its thirty-day meeting at the track by the sea yesterday afternoon, some 5,000 people going to see the sport in spite of the threatening weather. Seven races were on the card. James Rowe, formerly trainer for the late August Belmont, made his bow as a starter and succeeded in satisfying the public and owners by the way in which he handled the flag.

The new lake formed in the Colorado desert of Southeastern California has now attained such a degree of permanence that the people of that region have felt justified in giving it a name, thoughtfully christening it Lake Mulvihill, in honor of the local railroad Superintendent, who is anxious lest his tracks should be washed away.

There has not been much said about it, and the Racing Associations do not care to have it too well known, nevertheless these organizations which run the big tracks about here, and which depend upon a liberal patronage to earn their big dividends, are quietly but effectually preparing to drive the proprietors of the city poolrooms out of business.

There is something humiliating in the way the demands of the Knights of Labor have been dealt with by the Treasury Department with reference to the discharged plate printers in the Bureau of Printing and Engraving. These men were discharged for good cause, and that should have been the end of them, so far as the Government service is concerned, as it would have been with any clerk or officer of higher grade.

Legal war, to be fought to the bitter end, has been declared between Mme. Anna Grangier, one of the fashionable modistes of this city, with a branch business in Paris, and Mrs. Richard C. Kerens of St. Louis, wife of one of the most prominent citizens of that city, who is Secretary of the St. Louis World's Fair Committee and President of the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas Railroad.

Last Tuesday morning the New-York Tribune for the first time in many weeks ventured to publish a few remarks about Trusts and the tariff in its editorial columns. We shall not assume that the recent notable growth of Trusts and similar combinations had escaped the attention of our neighbor.

It seems now to be definitely settled by Mr. HARRISON that Pension Commissioner Raum shall remain in the office for which he has proved his unfitness in so large a variety of ways. The theory is that there can be no scandal in this Administration so long as it is not acknowledged, and that none must be acknowledged unless the courts compel it.

The judgment in favor of Eugene Lethbridge against the city for two and one-half years' salary at the rate of $1,000 a year was affirmed yesterday by the General Term of the Superior Court. In January, 1887, Lethbridge was suspended by the Commissioner of Public Works, in which department he was employed. On the trial of his suit to recover from the city, it was held that the Commissioner had no power to suspend.

Lovers of rowing throughout the country have manifested considerable interest in the People's Fourth of July Regatta; which is to take place over the national course on the Schuylkill River to-morrow. The best amateurs in the country are entered in the different events, and the contests ought to be close and interesting.
