The special race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club for forty-six and twenty-five-footers, at Oyster Bay, on Long Island Sound, yesterday, proved to be an event of surprises. First of all, the Mineola, which nobody supposed could win, even by a narrow margin, beat the Sayonara very handsomely and with plenty of time to spare.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Whatever opinions the politicians and spoilsmen of both parties may have of civil-service reform and the merit system, they have learned that since the present Civil Service Commissioners took office they cannot make reckless and unwarranted attacks upon the law and the system without being called to account.

Warrants were issued last night for the arrest of Patrick J. Gleason, Mayor of Long Island City; Stephen P. O'Hara, Clerk to the Board of Health, and P. Bannan, W. Fredericks, J. Evans, and L. Wokal, members of the board, charging them with assaulting and resisting an officer. A specific charge of assault was also made against Mayor Gleason by Deputy Sheriff Samuel H. Anschell, and another warrant was issued for Gleason.

PARIS, July 2. -- Prince Dolgoroukoff, recently Governor of Moscow, Russia, died in this city yesterday of Bright's disease. He had recently overtaxed his strength by traveling direct from Venice to Paris, and this undoubtedly precipitated the fatal attack.
The Association magnates say that they are going to place clubs in Brooklyn and Pittsburg nest season. This is probably a move to get under the cover, the national agreement again.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 2. -- The second day's session of the New-Jersey State Teachers' Association has been an interesting one. President E.H. Cook of New-Brunswick presided. The first paper read was entitled "Manual Training as Distinguished from Technical Training," and was prepared by Charles H. Ham of New-York City.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 2. -- About 100 sporting men and a large number of other spectators attended the live-pigeon shooting match at Hollywood Park this afternoon. The match was shot just south of the Hollywood Hotel. To shelter the spectators from the wind and rain, Proprietor Frederick Hoey had several large tents erected. He also provided refreshments.

No American can read the accounts of the fuss that has been made in England over the expected visit of the German Kaiser without a feeling of the comedy of the whole performance. England is so much a modern nation in these things that the same impression must prevail there, though it is only the audacious Mr. LABOUCHERE who has thus far ventured to give it public utterance.

Warden Brown of Sing Sing Prison said to a TIMES reporter yesterday that he had everything in readiness to carry out the execution of the four men sentenced to die by electricity in that prison some time in the course of next week. The electric chair and plant were put in perfect order when it was expected to be used on April 20.

Three sessions of court were held yesterday by Recorder Smyth, who is presiding over the trial of Ameer Ben Ali, alias "Frenchy," for the murder of Carrie Brown in the East River Hotel, and so much progress was made that probably by to-night the jury will have brought in its verdict if it agrees on one. The defense was presented yesterday.

Ex-Congressman James Kerr was at the Gilsey House Wednesday. He is Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee of Pennsylvania, and he has already given some thought to the precise nature of the campaign that will be made there next Autumn. Details will be discussed and a date for the convention fixed at a meeting of the State Democratic Executive Committee, which Mr. Kerr said will be held July 9 at headquarters in Philadelphia.

ROME, July 2. -- Dispatches from Naples give meagre details of a terrible accident which occurred yesterday on Mount Vesuvius, by which a Brazilian traveler lost his life. Another Brazilian was rescued with difficulty.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 2. -- A special dispatch received by the Times says the water around Salton is now within 2,000 feet of the main track. It came in 200 feet in two hours yesterday. If it continues to come in as it has been doing; it will wash out the Southern Pacific track in three days. The deepest water found was three feet and the shallowest in the current fourteen inches.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The climax in the suit of Phoebe Couzins to retain the Secretaryship of the Board of Lady Managers of the World's Fair was reached this afternoon in Judge Blodgett's court. The case had been on hearing all day and Col. Robert Rae, attorney for Miss Couzins, was just closing an eloquent appeal on behalf of his client. He wound up by saying: "Let justice be done though the heavens fall."

LONG BRANCH, July 2. -- The season at this place has opened, and certain doubts which lately clouded the air have been dissipated as the sea mist is under the morning sun in August. Not long ago the population (the permanent clam-digging population) of this interesting seaside resort was sad and solemn. The women had veils on their hearts and the men were wearing bands of crape around their souls.

Count VON MUNSTER'S denial "that the late Emperor WILLIAM had ever intended to dismiss Prince BISMARCK" was probably not made in the form in which it has been cabled. The Count could not have known the Emperor's intentions in this respect. What he probably denied was that he himself had said that the Emperor had expressed such an intention.

BOSTON, July 2. -- The suit of Maurice Fitzgerald, a priest, against Archbishop Williams, came up in the Suverior Court to-day on motion to replace it in the docket fom which it had been stricken, under the seven years limit. This action is one to recover about, $6,000 on an alleged contract for salary for services rendered and income from the church a Foxborough, of which, parish the plaintiff was pastor.

ALBANY, July 2. -- Controller Wemple for the last few weeks has received many personal communications asking for information regarding the advertisement of Charles E. Forsyth and William W. Browne of Buffalo, who have an office in the Law Exchange in Niagara Street in that city, offering lots in Piseco Lake Park, 30 by 125 feet, for $5 each.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

A special meeting of the passenger department of the Central Traffic Association will be held in Chicago to-day to decide whether the Eastern lines shall pro-rate with their Western connections on the basis of the reduced rates between Chicago and the Missouri River. The Chicago Railroad Association will issue a supplement to the quarterly rate sheet, quoting new rates to the territory beyond the Missouri River in consequence of the reduction.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 2. -- After a hotly-contested trial, lasting eight days, Austin J. Camp of Moravia was convicted this evening of kidnapping his daughter, Mrs. Ada Baird, and having her confined in the Utica asylum charged with lunacy. The commitment papers were issued by Judge Underwood of Cayuga County, on a certificate made out by Dr. Henry E. Allison of the State asylum, this city, and Dr. Harter of Moravia.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The following circular making provision for the continuance of the bonds of the 4 1/2 per cent. loan was issued this afternoon:

JOHN BARDSLEY, late Treasurer of the city of Philadelphia, was yesterday sentenced to fifteen years' solitary confinement in the Eastern Penitentiary and to a fine in a sum equal to the amount of his embezzlement of public funds. Unless there is enough political influence concerned in the crooked financial transactions in which the City Treasurer and the Keystone National Bank were involved to secure a pardon, this virtually means imprisonment for life for JOHN BARDSLEY.

After a game of the most brilliant character the Brooklyns lost again to Boston yesterday. Eleven innings were played and the Bridegrooms failed to make a mis-play of any kind. They played an errorless game in the field and did not have a wild pitch, a passed ball, or even a base on balls charged against them.

Justice of the Peace Rusch of Hoboken has given out the story of a romantic wedding at which he says he officiated yesterday morning. According to his story a couple, young and handsome, drove madly up to his office shortly before 9 o'clock and asked to be wedded.

CHIGAGO, July 3. -- Cleveland's players made three home runs against Chicago to-day, but failed to win. The hits were made when the bases were empty, and in consequence availed but little. On the other hand, Piefier's double and triple were made just when they were needed. Score:

It seems to be the misfortune of the Democratic Party to breed mischief makers just at the time when it would have the best chance of success if its politicians would only pull together. There does not seem to be the slightest doubt that Gov. CAMPBELL of Ohio will be renominated, and his character and record are likely to win to his support all independent voters and many Republicans.

THE HAGUE, July 3. -- The imperial party arrived here this morning and were received at the railroad station by the Ministers, municipal authorities, and diplomatic corps. There was a guard of honor at the station, which was profusely decorated with flowers and exotic plants.

Driven from New-Jersey, the State of its birth, by the peculiar politico-legal complications regarding racing in that State, the Monmouth Park Racing Association has to begin its twenty-first annual meeting to-day at Morris Park, in this State. The city was flooded with dodgers yesterday announcing the racing dates at Morris and Jerome Parks.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Two trotting classes and the 2:16 pace comprised the card at Belmont Park to-day, where the sport went on after a delay from Wednesday caused by rain. In the 2:29 class the winner appeared in Trim, a trotter from Tennessee, who got the first heat in 2:21 1/4, nearly 10 seconds below his former record.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The birth of a girl baby in the family of the Chinese Minister has been the subject of general rejoicing at the legation for ten days. The tiny maiden is kept in the strictest seclusion for the first month of her existence, in accordance with the laws of the Celestial Kingdom, which also require the seclusion of the mother for the same time.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 3. -- The appointment by the President to-day of Beniah Watson of Dover, to be United States Attorney for the District of Delaware, is another disposal of a public office as a reward for party services and fealty to Senator Anthony Higgins. The appointee is a member of the Kent County bar, but he has been far more conspicuous for his political work than for his legal achievements.

The controversy in which the head of the Treasury Department has allowed himself to be entangled with the Knights of Labor is a most extraordinary and humiliating affair, and has sprung from the smallest kind of demagogic politics. Seven plate printers were discharged by the Chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing for good and sufficient reasons.

Catherine Brown, an Irish immigrant, who was a passenger by the City of New-York, was so affected by seasickness in the rough weather which that vessel encountered that she became temporarily insane. The Barge Office authorities gave her in charge of Father Callahan, the Missionary of Our Lady of the Rosary. She will remain in his care for a week, and will be allowed to land if she regains her mind within that period.

PITTSBURG, July 3. -- Trouble is expected at Duquesne, ten miles up the Monongahela River, where the employes of the Allegheny Bessemer Steel Company, of which Andrew Carnegie is the principal stockholder, quit work yesterday because the company refused to recognize the scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers.

CHEESEQUAKE BEACH, N.J., July 3. -- There is a tired lot of canoeists in the camp of the Atlantic Division, American Canoe Association, to-night. There have been races from 9 o'clock in the morning until 6 o'clock in the evening. There was a crowd of visitors from Perth Amboy, South Amboy, and the country roundabout, but a larger crowd is expected to-morrow, when the racing will be finished.

The pleasing tale of the man who cut off his nose to spite his face is beginning to have a deep interest for Alfred Skitt. Mr. Skitt is the Superintendent of the Fourth and Madison Avenue Surface Railroad. Some time ago, under pressure of strong public opinion created by THE TIMES, the Park Commissioners secured an appropriation to build a transverse surface road through Central Park at Eighty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A telegram received here to-day from Iquique, Chile, by Senor Montt, the Congressional Envoy to the United States, says that the steamer Malpo arrived at that place to-day with a complete cargo of arms for the Congressional party.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The contractors of the railway tunnel under the Hudson River have obtained from the War Department permission to fill up the river with clay in order to be enabled to prosecute the work nearer to the present bottom of the river. On June 18 Messrs. A. Pearson Sons, contractors, in a communication to the War Department, said:

SAN FRACISCO, July 3. -- Advices from China by steamer are to the effect that trouble is expected at Kinkiang and that residents are sending their valuables to Shanghai. The annual festival was held May 27 in spite of a proclamation forbidding it. This was the date fixed by the threatening placards for the hostile demonstration against foreigners.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 3. -- Statistics of the wheat crop of the Pacific Northwest for the year ending June 30 have been completed by principal wheat dealers and shippers here, and the result may be considered accurate and reliable. The total surplus of Oregon and Washington and a portion of Idaho tributary to this coast amounted to 550,000 tons, or 18,333,000 bushels.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 3. -- A mad dog ran through Washington Valley three weeks ago and bit so many other dogs, cows, and horses that wholesale slaughter had to be committed by the farmers to prevent an epidemic of hydrophobia. Four dogs owned by Andrew Collens of Glenside Park, on the road leading to Westfield, were among those bitten.

The national flag acquires a new star to-day, and therewith a much-needed approach to symmetry in the collocation of all its stars. About a year ago Idaho was rejoicing in the prospect of admission to the sisterhood of States on the Fourth of July, and so of uniting an annual celebration of that event with the recurrence of the national holiday.

BOSTON, July 3. -- The creditors of Emile Marqeze Co., wholesale boot and shoe dealers in New-Orleans, with a purchasing house at 102 Pearl Street, Boston, held a meeting this afternoon at the cities of Ball Tower, attorneys. Mr. Tower made a statement regarding the firm's affairs. Mr. Marqeze, he said, had been in business many years.

LONDON, July 3. -- The Earl of De La Warr in the House of Lords to-day, speaking of the recent fire on the steamer City of Richmond, asked whether regulations which would prevent inflammable substances from being carried in passenger ships could not be enforced.

Secretary Foster inherited from the Wisdom administration, along with other things, a large-sized commotion in the Custom House in this city, which had been fomented by a lot of ambitious special agents of the Treasury Department. Unable to reconcile the reports of the special agents with the protests of New-York business men, Secretary Foster began a little investigation on his own hook.

ST. LOUIS, July 3. -- Mrs. R.C. Kerens, who has been sued by the New-York modiste, said concerning the matter to-day: "She has attempted to extort money from me, and failing to do this she attempts to create a scandal.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3. -- The political situation in Ohio was never more complicated than at present, nor was there ever before as many unknown quantities, all of which are likely to prove factors in the contest this year and any one of which may determine the result of the election.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 3. -- The North American Phonograph Company of New-York have begun legal proceedings to seize every Edison phonograph now in Canada that has been obtained under an American lease. It is understood that a number of parties are illegally operating in Canada, and under the terms of the leases the machines are subject to seizure by the company and the leases canceled.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 3. -- The suit of the Attorney General of the State of Missouri to set aside the ordinance of the city granting a permit to Charles Schweickardt to sell intoxicating liquors in Forest Park, on the ground that such a permit is contrary to law, against public policy, and harmful to the people, has been decided against the Attorney General by Judge Klein.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- The Herald will publish to-morrow morning a long article giving the results of the expedition which it sent out a month ago to find, and mark with a monument, the spot at which Christopher Columbus first landed on the shores of the New World, Oct. 12, 1492.

The Richmond State, referring to the statement that a distinguished Virginia Congressman, although himself unfriendly to Cleveland, had declared that he had found the people of his State much more strongly in favor of the ex-President than he had expected, says: "It can be safely estimated that a poll of Virginia Democratic voters to-day would show three-fourths for Cleveland.

The statement published in THE TIMES last Thursday, calling attention to the fact that the Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company are just beginning to realize the position in which they are placed by the recent exposures of their company's methods, appears to have quite coincided with the views of nearly everybody who is in a position to know the sentiments of those gentlemen.

Alfred Roosevelt, the young New-York banker who was injured while trying to board a moving train at Mamaroneck early Thursday morning, died yesterday morning at 2 o'clock. The terrible shock, followed by the amputation of his right leg, was more than his system could stand.

BERLIN, July 3. -- Interviews with coal oil dealers in Berlin, both at wholesale and retail, show a very general opinion that the Standard Oil Company, having absorbed the big importing houses, will now try to gain control of the jobbing trade and then of the retail business in Germany. Every step is taken in exact conformity with the law, and the remedies to be proposed are likely to prove only temporary and ineffectual.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 3. -- It is settled beyond a doubt that President Harrison will spend the Fourth of July at Cape May Point. He arrived here at 3:85 this afternoon by special train, and will remain for at least a month. Mrs. Harrison, Mrs. Dimmick, Mrs. Parker, and the McKee children drove over to Cape May City to meet the President and Mr. Parker, who accompanied him.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- There will probably be two exhibits of women's work on the Columbian Exposition grounds. One of them will be prepared by the Board of Lady Managers. The second is to be arranged by the Women's Christian Temperance Union. Josephine R. Nichols of Indianapolis has filed an application for space for it to-day. Flags, banners, books, and other things will be shown, all prepared by women.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 3. -- In the course of a lengthy interview printed in the Globe-Democrat this morning, ex-Congressman Niedringhaus said he had positive knowledge that twenty-two firms in the United States are making preparation for the manufacture of tin plate, but that his establishment is the best equipped of any and was already at work.

Imprisonment for life was the message the jury had for Aamer Ben Ali, or "Frenchy," in the Court of General Sessions last night after two hours' deliberation. The courtroom was packed to the doors when the jury came in. A low murmur of surprise ran over the crowd when the foreman announced "Guilty -- guilty of murder in the second degree."

A new assocdation of prominent down-town business men, known as the Importers mad Traders' Club, has been organized, with a clubhouse In the five-story bulldin at 13 Cedar Street. The idea of forming the club was conceived by a number of the larger tobacco dealers. The scheme met with favor, and soon 200 entlemen, mostly importers, subscribed as members. Membership in the club is not conlined to any class of business men

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Secretary Foster has gone to the mountain home of "Steve" Elkins to spend the Fourth of July, and perhaps to clarify his political vision in the atmosphere of West Virginia. He leaves behind a pretty mess as the result of his efforts to "square" the controversy in the Bureau of Engraving and Printing so as to help McKinley in his campaign for the Governorship of Ohio.

Next Friday night's meeting in Battery Park will be a great event. There is no special organization yet, but everybody is waiting for it eagerly, and, without a set programme or any out-and-dried action laid out, it may be fairly expected that the people will be heard from. The crowd and the enthusiasm are surely to be counted upon, and the rest may be left to inspiration.

Mr. B.F. JONES of Pittsburg, once Chairman of the Republican National Committee, undertakes to answer, in the Tariff League's Bulletin, the question "Why I am a Protectionist," and one of his five reasons is "because, as has been demonstrated, the effect of protection is the cheapening of products." By competition in the home market? Probably that is what Mr. JONES would have added if his space had not been limited.

The evidence seems to be conclusive that the appalling collision at Ravenna yesterday morning was due to the gross carelessness of those whose duty it was to guard and protect the passengers on the vestibule train. Two trains on the same road were on their way to this city from the West. The leading train was a vestibule express of eight cars, and a fast-freight train of twenty-four loaded cars was following it.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 3. -- Two freight trains collided on the New-England Road last night between Osborntown and Bradleys, six and a half miles west of Waterbury. They were the best-equipped trains on that road -- the Boston freight, east-bound, and the fast freight for New-York. The Boston freight was thundering down the grade at twenty-five miles an hour.

LONDON, July 3. -- Before the Emperor left Rotterdam to-night the latest phase of the official programme for his reception in England had not received his approbation. Since the first draft was submitted to him he has busied himself with upsetting arrangements from the moment of his arrival at Port Victoria to the date of his farewell on the 13th.

In enforcing the postal laws hundreds of cases are investigated by the Post Office authorities which are not brought to the attention of the courts, and in which no punishment is asked for. There have been technical infractions of the law, but without guilty intention upon the part of the violators.

R.L. Trumbull, the representative of the Chilean Congressionalists, who was arrested for planning the Itata runaway, and who is now in this city, said yesterday that he had received a cablegram announcing the capture of Huasco. It stated that Balmaceda's forces simply ran away at the first attack, "as they always do," continued Mr. Trumbull.

BAR HARBOR, July 4. -- Moving in and getting settled -- this is about the most exciting news at Bar Harbor just now, and the weather has been the right sort for such exercise. The chilliness which, despite blazing hearth fires, makes hotels dreary does not much affect cottagers, whose houses are generally built in a way that might make them fairly comfortable habitations all Winter.

MONTREAL, June 29. -- When the Allan Line steamship Montevidean arrived in port early this morning the officers gave an account of thrilling voyage. The Montevidean left London for this port on June 13 with 2,000 tons of general cargo. The passage was an uneventful one until the steamer got a little eastward of Cape Ray on Wednesday last. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon a dense smoke was noticed coming from No. 5 afterhold.

A TIMES reporter went down to South Beach, Staten Island, yesterday to take a look at the "Irish Standing Army in America," which has been organized by the "Irish-American Military Union" to be the nucleus of a host that some day shall cross the water and fight battles to make old Ireland free again. The army is at Camp Wolfe Tone, which is situated near the entrance to Shakels's Park.

At Brest and Toulon the recruit listens eagerly to tales of the veterans, admires the dazzling cross of honor pinned to their dolmans too large for their thinned bodies, and never asks why their features are shriveled and their eyes are yellow. He dreams of military adventures in mysterious far-off lands.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- Outdoor sports seem to be much more attractive just now than theatricals, though the few Chicago playhouses which keep their doors open during the Summer season have been very well patronized. The novelty of the week was Gillette's farce-comedy, "Mr. Wilkinson's Widows," at the Columbia.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- During the recent visit of President and Mrs. Harrison to Pale Alto, California, the latter was urged by Senator Standford to name a young racer which has since been put on the track. Mrs. Harrison protested that she could think of nothing more likely to give the horse a widespread notoriety than to call him "Baby McKee," which was accordingly done.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 4. -- Every hotel and boarding house is jammed fall of patriotic pleasure seekers to-night. The crowds began to arrive early in the week, but the arrivals to-day surprised oven the station employes. The hotels were taxed to accommodate the throngs, and it was long after midnight before the thousands of new-comers were finally disposed of.

Are we too near or not far enough off yet from the late French imperial reign to understand it properly? Mme. Carette, who, when unmarried, as Mlle. Bouvet, was closely attached to the Empress, permits us to understand some little about the Court of the Tuileries, life at St. Cloud, at Compienge, and at Paris.

The most Interesting game of the season in the amateur ranks was played on Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. The contestants were the nines of the Manhattan and New-York Athletic Clubs. Fourteen inning were played and the Manhattan boys won by a single run. The New-Yorks led in batting, but lost by poor held work. Score:

The last British consular report from Palermo contains some curious details respecting the breeding of pigs in Sicily, which in certain districts, and especially in mountainous parts, are reared in great numbers. Nearly all the small towns are overrun with them, and they are not only useful for food, but act as scavengers to the dirty streets.

In a series of well-arranged chapters, under the divisions (a) "Crimes and Punishments," (b) "The Synhedrim," (c) "The Trial," and (d) "The Execution," the author of this work brings together the interesting and curious details of criminal jurisprudence devised by the ancient Hebrews.

If any one believes such a result is impossible let him live in almost any large or small European city and make his observations there. The writer draws her conclusions from personal experiences from living in different European cities, and maintains that this transformation of worse than savage wastes into earthly paradises is not only possible, but quite practicable.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 4. -- The grounds of the New-Jersey Jockey Club were the scene to-day of the athletic sports and trotting matches in connection with the open-air festival of the Church of the Sacred Heart. Nearly every politician of note in the city was present, including Mayor Rankin, Surrogate Parrot, Assemblymen Carroll and Lane, Health Inspector Putnam, ex-County Collector Sheridan, and scores of others.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- Ward's men administered two signal defeats to Anson's championship aspirants. They made the Chicagos step from the front rank in the League race and allowed the New-Yorks to take the coveted position. In the morning game Chicago was badly beaten, but the afternoon contest proved to be a struggle of the hottest kind. Eleven innings were played, but the Bridegrooms came out on top the 1 run necessary to win.

The article in last Sunday's TIMES which gave a sketch of ocean racing for half a century brought the history of quick passages across the Atlantic to the current year, and signs are not wanting that 1891 will prove as fruitful in transatlantic record breaking as any that preceded it.
DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 4. -- The end of June was a merry season at the Water Gap, and July comes along evidently fated to be many times merrier.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Times and the Standard to-day emphasize the fact that the Emperor, upon the occasion of this his third visit to England, is the guest of the nation, as well as of the Court. These newspapers also dilate upon the friendship existing between the two nations, which, they say, amounts to a tacit alliance.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 4. -- The heavy wind and rain storm of last night did considerable damage to the handsome decorations of the city, but this was repaired early this morning and everything put in readiness for the festivities of the day in honor of the Army of the Potomac. The Weather was clear and cool.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., July 4 -- People who chose the Hotel Kaaterskill in which to pass the national holiday made no mistake. Situated more than 2,000 feet above the sea, the air was delightfully crisp, a fact highly appreciated by the four hundred guests who have been until this week suffering from the general mugginess of the climate of New-York and Philadelphia.

BANGOR, Me., July 5. -- The festivities of the night of Independence Day had just set in here when the intelligence of the death of ex-Vice President Hannibal Hamlin became known throughout the city. He died, as he has lived here for the past few years, peacefully and quietly.

The low-crowned sailor is the hat at present, with "the" heavily underlined. Although it may be best described as dashing, it is worn by young and old, well-preserved and faded, with equal assurance. No lady seems to question its suitability to herself, however sharply she may criticise its appearance upon others. The Summer outfit must include this hat, though it omit many more becoming styles.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Observing the building of iron ships may not be an ideal Summer amusement nor present as many attractive features in July as it might in October, yet there still remains an attraction in the construction of our men-of-war which draws visitors to the shipbuilding yards in spite of weather. In the Cramp yards here there are now being built four vessels for our new navy.

To people who are outside of the Republican Party, and are in no danger of being compromised by the result, the steady extension of what may be called McKinley worship in that party is a matter of interesting study not devoid of a certain irreverent amusement. There has been nothing like it in modern times except the movement that produced the ghost dances of the past Winter among the Northwestern Sioux.

The proposal to increase the authorized limit of the enlisted force of the navy from 8,250 to 10,000 men is certainly not extravagant or uncalled for. It is quite evident that we cannot go on building more and larger ships, with heavier batteries and with a greater amount of steam machinery to manage, and yet expect to keep up only the old force to man them.

LONDON, July 4. -- The Government report upon the recent influenza epidemic, the origin of that disease and kindred matters, was presented to Parliament to-day. The report was prepared by Dr. Parsons, and contains a mass of interesting evidence, but it does not solve the problem as to the origin of influenza, nor does it provide any sure prevention of the disease.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 4. -- The Rev. D.F. Bonner will be installed as pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Florida, N.Y., next Tuesday. Among the clergymen who will take part in the services are the Revs. Thomas Gordon of Middletown, James C. Forsythe of Montgomery, Robert B. Clark of Goshen, and the Rev. Dr. Amass S. Freeman of Haverstraw.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4. -- German music mingled with German patriotism to-day to make this a typical German Fourth of July. Nominally the first day of the grand Saengerfest of the Northeastern Saengerbund, the influences of the national birthday affected it so that it became in reality a patriotic introduction to the three festival days which are to follow.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 4. -- The worst wreck ever known in this part of the State, if not the worst ever known in the State, occurred about 8 o'clock this morning on the Kanawha and Michigan Railway, eight miles west of here. The passenger train for Columbus pulled out from here with two carloads of excursionists, among them the Order of United American Mechanics, who were going to Pocas.

HARLESTON, S.C., July 4. -- Cheraw, one of the oldest and most historic towns in South Carolina, has the honor of being the first in the State to return to an ancient custom of celebrating Independence Day with a big demonstration. The people from the surrounding country turned out en masse to take part in the celebration, and were joined in honoring the day by large delegations from North Carolina.

BERLIN, July 4. -- The Foreign Office is receiving, through Baron von Bieberstein, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, a series of telegrams indicating the character of Emperor William's reception in England. The spectacle in the Nore and at Windsor Castle appears to have been contrary to the expectations of the officials and the general public.

PARIS, July 4. -- The American quarter of this city was decorated with bunting to-day in honor of the Fourth. In addition, the business part of Paris which borders on the Arc de Triomphe was lavish in its display of French and American flags.

The current number of the Financial Chronicles of this city contains a sober, but very plain, article on "Treasury Statements under the New Form," which must be taken as a fair expression of the view of intelligent business men as to the curious changes made by Mr. FOSTER in the monthly statement of the condition of the Treasury.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4. -- The North Shrewsbury River Yacht Club had perfect weather for its fifth annual regatta this afternoon. The sun shone brightly, the air was dry and cool, and a brisk breeze blew from the northwest. Many boating parties were out and the river never before presented such a picturesque appearance.
" I never saw such funny writing as George's is," said the beautiful young girl, as she held an envelope up for the inspection of her married friend.

The mania for getting married which besets so many domestic servants often results in their finding themselves either widowed or deserted in the course of a few years, with a number of young children to provide for. They are generally both able and willing to return to domestic service, but that way of earning a living is barred to them by the necessity of looking after their incumbrances at home.

I had every reason to believe that my nerves were proof against shock, but when I heard the Confederate officer calling my companion Bell by name, I felt for the instant more alarmed than I had ever been before or have ever suffered since, and if I had had to respond I am very sure my voice and manner would have betrayed me.

The cornerstone of the new schoolhouse of St. Paul's Parish, in Sixtieth Street, was laid yesterday morning, and, in honor of the holiday, there was a display of bunting and American flags. The ceremonies were witnessed by about 1,500 persons, who entered the inclosure from the Sixtieth Street side, and as they did so placed a contribution for the school within a space chiseled out of the cornerstone, which hung by the gate.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 4. -- A bicycle tour has just been completed by the Misses May and Lillian Fritts, daughters of Dr. J.T. Fritts of this city, accompanied by Andrew Fritts, their brother, and John Crawford. They spent two weeks on their trip, and visited many places in Central and Northern New-Jersey and Eastern Pennsylvania.

Howard W. Perry died at Atlantic City, N.J., yesterday morning of consumption. He had been prostrated with the disease for several months. He leaves a wife. Funeral services will be held at his late residence, 13 West Ninety-ninth Street, to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock.

A most interesting and important event in the history of English commerce took place yesterday at the Mersey terminus of the Manchester Ship Canal. At Eastham Ferry -- a pretty spot much frequented, especially in the Summer months, by Liverpool holiday-makers -- the great looks were opened, and for the first time the tidal water of the Mersey was admitted into the magnificent "ditch" which next year will turn Manchester into a seaport.
ST. LOUIS, July 4. -- The Republic will print the following story to-morrow:

That was a fine spectacle which was presented to the taxpayers of Brooklyn the other day when the delegation of public school teachers marched up Willoughby Street and turned into Kerrigan's auction room in order to ask "Boss" McLaughlin to increase their salaries. Mr. McLaughlin is not a duly-elected public officer.

There was a class of ambitious teaching people before the County Board yesterday in Sacramento, and they managed to make thirty or forty blunders with a facility unparalleled and that ought to disgrace them. Of course no one person made all the errors we quote; they are the cream of all the blunders committed by the class.

The native inhabitants of Nicaragua are a very interesting people. There is a strain of negro blood intermingled with the Caribs on the Atlantic or Mosquito coast, but the Caribs are of a different race from the inhabitants of the highlands and the Pacific coast, who are either pure Aztecs or of mixed Azteo and Spanish descent.

OWEGO, N.Y., July 4. -- The ceremony of unveiling the Tioga County Soldiers' Monument was performed to-day in the presence of a great throng of people from this place and many of the towns in the vicinity. There was a great procession, comprising the Grand Army of the Republic posts from the various towns, the Twenty-sixth Separate Company, National Guard, State of New-York, and civic organizations.

There were two striking features about the Tammany Society's celebration of the Fourth of July, Senator A.H. Colquitt of Georgia and the almost inexhaustible "well" down in the Wigwam's cellar. In the vulgate of Tammany, the well "knocked the Senator clean out," and didn't have a very hard time of it, either. The Senator was the star speaker at the celebration and he made a "fluke" of it.

" She was handsome, dignified, and dressed, from her dainty French boots to the tip of her elegant bonnet, like a rich young Fifth Avenue woman," said the young matron who told the story. "Everything about her betokened refinement of a high degree, and her exquisitely gloved little hands were innocent of any incumbrance except a beautiful sunshade which she carried with the air of the accomplished daughter of luxury.

DETROIT, July 4. -- The man Dinkelspiel, whose name has been frequently mentioned in connection with the New-York Life Insurance Company's trouble, is well known in this city. Probably the best work that he ever did for his patron Beers was done right here. It occurred in February, 1890. Being a remarkably oily-tongued agent, Dinkelspiel was enabled to make the unsuspecting millionaires of this town believe that he had a brand-new thing in life insurance.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 4. -- There is a general feeling of unrest in the Republican ranks throughout the State as the first fruits of the "hold-over" conspiracy begin to be realized. The betrayal of Gen. Merwin's interests by the politicians in power has been apparent from the first to impartial observers. Now, no doubt, it is clear to the General himself.

Wollaton Hall, Lord Middleton's seat in Notts, where Sir William and Lady Gordon-Cumming are spending the first days of their honeymoon, is one of the most perfect specimens of Elizabethan domestic architecture in the country. It took eight years to build, and it was completed in 1583 by Sir F. Willoughby, the material used being Ancaster stone brought from Lincolnshire on packhorses and exchanged for the coal found on the estate.

BRIDGEPORT, July 4. -- Since 12 o'clock Tuesday night it has been unlawful to take any brook trout in Connecticut. The season, which begun April 1, has been less satisfactory than that of last year. To add to this there is a great deal of dissatisfaction among sportsmen in regard to the present trout law, because it prohibits fishing during the Summer.

LENOX, Mass., July 4. -- The weather the last week has been fine for driving, and the cottagers have all taken advantage of it. There are more four-in-hands here this season than ever before. W.D. Sloane has a coach with four fine horses, Henry A. Barclay has a new one, Albert R. Shattuck has one also, and George G. Haven has a new turnout.

The American Yacht Club held its annual race for naphtha launches at Milton Point yesterday. The start was from the clubhouse around Execution Light and return, about eight nautical miles. Over 200 members and guests of the club went to see the race, which was in charge of George W. Hall, E.S. Connor, William S. Alley, J. Howard Wainwright, and W.J. Pierce.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 4. -- The Seventy-second Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers from Philadelphia dedicated their monument this morning. It is a bronze zouave, with clubbed musket, and stands in the "Bloody Anglo" near the stone wall.

The author of "Italy and Her Invaders" was of all persons probably the one most competent to write a history of Theodoric which would add something to public knowledge of that extraordinary son of the northern wilderness who, for more than a generation, was King of Rome. Theodoric was an invader of Italy who came in behalf of civilization.

John Henry Newman was certainly one of the greatest ecclesiastics which the Church of England produced in the generation just passed away. He has left an indelible mark upon Church history as a preacher, a controversialist, a scholar of large attainments, and a poet of no mean ability.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Chilean Minister resident here has received a telegram to the effect that the Government of Chile has declared that all ships going to the ports declared closed with provisions, forage, or coal will not be received in ports under Its Jurisdiction, and that ships destined to ports to the north Of these wlll only be received after giving such guaran~ tee as the Government may demand.

The new Naval Torpedo Board, consisting of Commander CONVERSE and Lieuts. DRAKE and McLEAN, will at once have a very important work to perform in superintending the construction, trial, and installation of the Whitehead and Howell torpedoes ordered for our war vessels. With one hundred of the former and thirty of the latter contracted for, the equipment of the new vessels with automobile torpedoes, from time to time postponed, will soon be accomplished.

BALTIMORE, July 4. -- The Carroll divorce case, which will be tried in the Autumn at Towson, will be a social sensation. When Mrs. Mary R. Carroll brought proceedings against her husband, John Carroll of the Caves, alleging cruelty and brutality, society was shocked, for they belong to the most fashionable circles of the city and their place in Baltimore County is one of the oldest and most noted estates in the South.

ST. LOUIS, July 4. -- The Chronicle of this city has felt the Missouri editors on their preference for Presidential candidates, and the responses show that Grover Cleveland and James G. Blaine are the favorite leaders in their respective parties. Of forty-five answers received from editors of leading Democratic papers throughout the State, twenty-six are for Cleveland and say so in very strong language.
LONDON, July 4. -- Mr. William Henry Gladstone, eldest son of the Right Hon. William Ewart Gladstone, died this morning.

Nearly one-third of the continent of Australia remains to be explored. If a line be drawn from north to south, cutting off the eastern third of the continent, it will be seen that the area thus detached contains Queensland, New South Wales, and Victoria. In the inland region, controlled by these colonies, there is scarcely anything left for the explorer to do.
Lady Burton, widow of Capt. Burton, the famous traveler and author, contributes to the London Morning Post a letter respecting her husband's manuscripts, in the course of which she says:

The Ordnance and Fortification Board of the War Department is arranging for a competitive firing test of heavy-calibre rapid-fire guns which in importance and thoroughness is calculated to exceed anything of its kind ever witnessed in the United States. The test will be made at Sandy Hook just as soon as arrangements can be effected, but instead of being of a few hours' duration it will extend over a period of six months.

The Rev. Dr. Robins, well known in Episcopal Church circles, has resigned his place as Head Master of the Philadelphia Episcopal Academy and the Trustees have elected as his successor Dr. William H. Klapp. Dr. Klapp is well known to scholars in New-York. It was specially due to his efforts that the Greek play performed by students of University of Pennsylvania was given in New-York in 1887.

" Ordo nootis abrosianae" was the quaint but significant title of the programme with which Yale's brilliant class of 1856 commemorated their thirty-fifth anniversary at the recent Commencement. Among the members to whom toasts were assigned were the Hon. A.J. Bartholomew of Southbridge, Mass., the Hon. Chauncey M. Depew of New-York, and the Rev. Dr. Wolcott Calkius of Newton, Mass., who appear in the "Ordo" after this fashion:

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 4. -- The drenching rains that fell the first part of the week caused another let-up in training. The track Thursday was fit to go on, however, and a number of the horses were given slow miles.
NYACK, July 4 -- Many well-known persons from New-York and Brooklyn are now flocking to this place for the Summer, and the large hotels are rapidly filling up. Among those now here are:

Sitting at his desk in his cozy office adjoining President Depew's room in the Grand Central Station last Friday, Mr. Harry O. Duval delivered a modest, but spirited, littled Fourth of July oration as follows: "Yes, I am going to Europe on the 22d of this month on the steamship City of Paris. I choose the Inman Line because it is an American line and is backed by American capital and enterprise.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 4. -- Whatever inflictions are in store for the American people, they may console themselves with one reflection -- Henry C. Bowen's Fourth of July greatest show on earth and aggregation of political curiosities will not trouble them much longer. It is doubtful if it over troubles them again.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 4. -- At the annual meeting of the Laurens County Alliance at Laurens, S.C., yesterday they had a lively time and the meeting came near ending in bloodshed and riot. The occurrence is made one of especial interest by the fact that United States Senator J.L.M. Irby was one of the principals in the difficulty.

The relation of the Southern Alliances to the new third party, recently born at Cincinnati, in which, under amplifications of the Ocala platform, it is proposed to unite the elements of the Labor Party with the agrarian interests of the country, is one that must have a strong bearing upon the success of the plans formulated at the last meeting, at which the self-styled People's Party of Progress had its nativity.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 4. -- June has passed, and Richfield finds itself in the full glory of Summer business.

The fruit-canning season opened a few days ago, and the members of the new canning combine are cogitating over their prospects. A few facts are patent to all. The fruit crop is large and the quantity of canned fruit put up this year will be larger than last year if the prices offered by canners are sufficient to call it out.

On the New-York side of the East River and not more than a half a dozen blocks above the bridge are the three largest sectional dry docks in the United States. To the eye of the inexperienced in marine matters the docks present a mass of huge rafts, curiously jumbled up together, and topped off by rows of little houses perched thirty feet up in the air.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 4. -- The annual regatta of the Hopatcong Canoe Club is the chief event of importance in the Fourth of July celebration here. The cups offered are presented by Mayor Howard, P. Frotheringham, and Manager Brockway of the hotel. Henry Altonbrand offers a silver cigar case for the sculling match.

The annual picnic and games of the Sixty-ninth Regiment were given in the Empire City Colosseum yesterday. The largo grounds were comfortably filled with the militia boys and their escorts, and to the time of Bayne's band they danced and made merry until a late hour. In the afternoon the athletic contests took place. The results follow:

It has just leaked out that the Major -- Major McKinley, of course -- had a terrible nightmare the morning after the Taxeators' banquet in this city. The Major, bound to show his patriotism, doubled up on the Chicago sausages.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 4. -- President Harrison's Fourth was scarcely a holiday. It was well and pleasantly spent. In the morning he walked up the beach with his grandchildren, and afterward returned to his cottage, where he witnessed some very harmless fireworks set off for the benefit of the McKee children.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 4. -- The season has passed the budding stage -- is almost at the bloom. All the hotels are open, the Kensington and Hotel Balmoral being the last to fall in line, and all have a reasonable quota of guest. The June record has been an unusual one. Twice within ten days the Windsor has been filled to its utmost capacity -- something unknown heretofore in June at any Saratoga hotel.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 4. -- Howard Wilson and Patrick McCourt were terribly maimed, and Jennie Feller, a little girl, was badly injured by the premature discharge of a cannon in this city this afternoon. The two men and a number of fellow-members of Plainfield Engine Company No. 2 had been dragging the cannon about the streets and firing it ever since 3 o'clock in the morning.

A correspondent of the London Daily News writes: "The Liberal cause in Sussex has sustained a real loss by the death of this distinguished lady, which took place on the 11th inst. Although women do not exercise the Parliamentary franchise, Mme. Bodichon's influence was neither limited nor indirect. So far back as 1877 ill health had compelled a too-active social worker to lead a retired country life.

There is a pensive head of Banville, with hair of Absalom, by Gavarni; another, superb in the learned tolds of a white mudler, painted in 1868 by Alfred Dehodenoq. The most precious, the one so affectionately drawn by Georges Rochegrosse, is white, beardless, hairless, with a double bump on the forehead, and rhythmic lines of light at the eyes. He might have posed for Pierrot that he idealized. He wore a skull-cap of black silk.

The undertaking of encamping two regiments of infantry at the military post was successfully accomplished the last week. It is five years, almost to a day, since the experiment was first essayed of requiring two regular organizations of the line to perform a tour of field duty simultaneously at the State Camp of Instruction. That was in 1886, and the experiment was not crowned with brilliant success.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., July 4. -- This resort is rapidly recovering from the ravages of the fire of last August, which destroyed the hotel, store, chapel, pavilion, milk depot, meat market, and several fine cottages. Nearly all have been rebuilt, except the hotel, which probably will not be completed for occupancy this season.

ORANGE, N.J., July 4. -- The annual club tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Montrose began at 10 o'clock this morning. A large crowd was in attendance and the playing was good. Following are the scores:

" Never perhaps since washtubs were invented (in the opinion of the London Daily News of June 15) have the laundresses of London had just such a time of it as a great number of them had yesterday in Hyde Park. 'Oh! what a day we are having!' cried one frisky matron, and that seemed to be pretty much the feeling of the great majority of them.

The State Railroad Commission has granted to the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company in Brooklyn the right to adopt the trolley system of electric propulsion on a part of its line, where the required consent of property owners has been obtained, and has refused it to the Brooklyn and Coney Island Road, on the ground that the consent of a sufficient number of property owners has not been obtained.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 4. -- Joseph Jefferson, the actor, has made an astonishing find on the Summer place which he has purchased here near that of ex-President Cleveland. In laying out the grounds and making alterations it became necessary to remove a sandhill of large size. The workmen, while doing this, found the skeleton of a man that filled them with astonishment from its great size.

CINCINNATI, July 4. -- Now-York's Giants celebrated the Fourth in great style hers to-day. They won two games from the Reds, and as Chicago was whipped twice by Brooklyn, are once more in the lead. Both games were well attended and at times excitement ran high. "Buck" Ewing was advertised to catch, but he didn't. He contented himself by greeting his Cincinnati townsmen.

Thirty thousand people or so assisted at the opening of the Monmouth Racing Association's Summer meeting at Morris Park yesterday. It was, with the possible exception of Memorial Day at the same track last year, the largest crowd ever brought together in the inclosure. What our ancient Grecian friends were in the habit of referring to as the "hoi polloi" made up the bulk of the pleasure seekers at the track.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 4. -- The annual Fourth of July rush for the Catskills began Thursday, and a large number of tourists was taken to resorts in the range by the Ulster and Delaware Railroad. The Albany day boat on that day had 250 persons aboard who came over on the ferryboat, and extra cars were run on the West Shore Railroad.

It is the fortune of few yacht clubs to be blessed with such delightful weather as that which beamed upon the Larchmont Yacht Club yesterday on the occasion of its twelfth annual regatta. It was neither too warm nor too cold; it blew neither too strong nor too light, and it blew unremittingly from start to finish, as all good weather, viewed from the tiller of a racing boat, should blow.

The season having set in for the great annual pilgrimage of invalids as well as pleasure seekers to our health resorts, it seems to me an opportune time to offer a suggestion through your columns which many persons may find productive of advantage to themselves.

LONDON, July 4. -- The Emperor William arrived at Port Victoria, near Sheerness, this morning. He was enthusiastically received by the crowds assembled to witness the landing of the imperial party. All the British war ships anchored about Sheerness fired salutes of twenty-one guns.

LONDON, July 5. -- Emperor William rose early at Windsor to-day and took a short ride, returning to breakfast with the Queen and the royal family. Immediately afterward he started in a carriage for the Victoria Barracks, accompanied by the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Connaught, and the Duke of Clarence. The Emperor was in the undress uniform of the Corps Garde, bedecked with Prussian orders, and wore a plumed helmet.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 5. -- Life in the Camp of Instruction to-day has been an unmixed joy for the New-Yorkers and their rural comrades in arms, for there has been a minimum of instruction and an overwhelming preponderance of pleasure. The weather has been exhilarating to a degree, and, after the rain, the turf is wonderfully green for midsummer, and the inclosing hillsides are as fresh as can be.

Sundry belated British Columbian vessels have just started for Bering Sea, and are credited with the intention of getting as many sealskins as possible there before being formally notified by the cruisers to leave the forbidden waters. It is doubtful whether they will run any such risk. They go with knowledge of the modus vivendi agreement and the British Order in Council based upon it.

CAEN, June 22. -- Nosing about an old town like Caen, where the architecture of three widely different epochs appear again and again patched together in the same edifice, one is disposed to regret the great period before the religious wars and the revocation of the edict protecting the Protestants. Here are the traces of the sumptuously decorated homes of burghers who were lovers of art and wealthy withal.

A set of four plain, solid silver buttons for neckband and wristband can be bought in a range of price from $2 upward, and they are the daintiest and most serviceable of the many designs offered for selection.

The rapid-transit question continues to crop up at various times and in various lights. The elevated railway people, balked in their endeavor to annex the best part of Broadway and the whole of the Boulevard, throw cold water on the electric underground scheme whenever it is discussed, and curiously they are backed up by one or two of the daily papers.

The Indianapolis Journal, which represents Mr. HARRISON at his home, has not forgotten what Mr. WANAMAKER said about tinware last September. The following remarks are taken from an article in the Journal of the 30th ult., relating to tin plate:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 5. -- The opening exercises in the new beach Auditorium took place to-day. They were in commemoration of Independence Day, and were interesting throughout. The meetings were in charge of the Rev. S. Edward Young, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church of this place.

The most vivid account of the remarkable escape of twenty passengers from death last Thursday night near Rosebud is given by E. Benninghoven of Chicago, who was in the Pullman that plunged into the Yellowstone. He boarded the train at St. Paul for Helena. For two days before reaching Rosebud the Pacific express on the Northern Pacific ran through a violent storm, and reports came to the passengers of heavy rains along the Yellowstone.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Some of the enterprising citizens of Washington are making preparations to secure the next annual gathering of the Grand Army of the Republic in this city, and have begun a movement for the construction of a hall in which 6,000 or 7,000 persons can find sitting accommodations.

Mr. Moule has many claims to close attention for whatever he may have to say of the great Asiatic land and race of which in this volume he write For thirty years he lived among the Chinese as a missionary. Towns like Ning-Po, Hang-Chow, and Shanghai are the towns in which his labors were put forth and he rose to eminence as Archdeacon of Mid-China.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, New-York, July 5. -- The guests of the Kaaterskill had THE NEW-YORK SUNDAY TIMES served at breakfast this morning, and it was not a late breakfast either. This was something very unusual; in fact, it has not happened since last Summer, but it will be a common occurrence from now until the end of the season.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 5. -- The Chilean transport Itata and the cruiser Charleston arrived in port at 9:30 yesterday morning, direct from Iquique. The Itata entered the harbor and anchored in the channel, while the Charleston remained outside the head. The Itata was at once boarded by revenue officers. The Itata and Charleston came direct from Iquique, being out twenty-three days.

NEWARK, July 5. -- Whatever doubts about the musical or financial success of the Saengerfest festival may have been entertained, were all dissipated to-day. Such a jam of humanity Newark has never heretofore seen. From early morning until late tonight the streets running from the stations to the Caledonian Park were lined with shouldering but good-natured people.

TRENTON, July 5. -- "If Abbett were before the people to-morrow," said a conspicuous Warren County Democrat to THE TIMES'S correspondent a day or two ago, "he would lose Warren by an overwhelming majority."

The second-class protected cruiser Intrepid for the British Navy has been launched from the yards of the Glasgow Engineering and Iron Shipbuilding Company. The Intrepid is a sister ship to the Indefatigable and Iphigenia. She is 300 feet long, and has 43 feet and 8 inches beam. Her displacement is 3,600 tons. Her speed is estimated at twenty knots ah hour.
BALTIMORE, July 5. -- The Sun will print the following to-morrow:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 5. -- The July report of the Kansas State Board of Agriculture, as given out by Secretary Martin Mohler to-day, gives the first official figures of the probable yield. It is as follows:

During the week ending last Saturday, according to the observations at the Central Park Meteorological Observatory, the total amount of rainfall was .40 inch; barometer, mean, 29.824 inches; thermometer, mean, 68.8; maximum, 79; minimum, 59. During the week the wind traveled 975 miles.

In an editorial in your issue of July 2 you treat of the police in relation to the "excise," and unthinkingly do us an injustice. We are accustomed to seeing in the daily papers of all political parties criticisms of the police of all sorts, some deserved and some not, but your editorial was apparently written with serious purpose, and correcting your misapprehension may assist in furthering your good object.
In his address to the people in Mr. BOWEN'S park at Woodstock on Saturday Mr. DEPEW said:

There resides at the little town of Port Allen, in West Baton Rouge Parish, a family of five living generations, housed beneath one roof, with a history dating from the beginning of the present century. The founder of this family in this country, Owen Gasque, was a Frenchman by birth and resided in Paris until about the year 1812, when he emigrated with his family to the United States.

To-morrow morning Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City will appear before Judge Manley in the police court to answer to the serious charge of assaulting a police officer while resisting arrest during the fracas in the Board of Health room a week ago. The charge is the most serious that Gleason has over bean arraigned on.

DETROIT, Mich., July 5. -- The citizens of Detroit have assured the success of the Silver Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic in this city the first week of August beyond peradventure. This has been done by the subscription by citizens of $110,000 to date, with other subscriptions coming in on call. Over 200 brigade and regimental organizations have been assigned to free quarters for the holding of their individual camp fires.

In an interview with Mr. F.A. SCHROEDER, ex-Mayor of Brooklyn, that gentleman defines his position with regard to the State policy of his party and the next nomination for Governor. He plainly says that if he is to be a candidate there must be a great change in the conduct of the party on the liquor question, and as he expects no such change he is not bothering his mind with the nomination.

ST. LOUIS, July 5. -- The movement to educate the Jewish immigrants who come to this city has been set on foot under the direction of the Jewish Alliance, which to-day reorganized. At a meeting held this evening Jacob Furth, Moses Fraley, Isidor Busch, and others made stirring speeches, reviewing at length the condition of the Russian Jew. It was decided that the thing he most needed was information.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 5. -- The New Jersey Bureau of Vital and Labor Statistics had devoted much time in the course of the past year to a consideration of the question of farm values and the extent of agricultural depression as shown by the abandonment of farms and other statistics. The report on the subject has been prepared by Statistician Fischer of this city and will be published in the forthcoming report.

PITTSBURG, July 5. -- The commonest item in the police news of Pittsburg is the raid of a "speak-easy." A speak-easy is an unlicensed saloon. In Pennsylvania it is the illegitimate child of the Brooks high-license law.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 4. -- The persistence with which the Hoosier keeps in politics is remarkable. A good deal of the political gossip that goes out of this town is rubbish, but so important did Indiana suddenly become at the nomination of Gen. Harrison that his election has only tended to keep things warm in his old stamping ground.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The following official announcement was to-day issued from the White House with respect to the death of the late Hannibal Hamlin:

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6. -- Lying probably at the point of death at East Buffalo is Thomas Sullivan, a New-York Central switchman, who lives at 137 Bridge Street, Oswego. The New-York Central yards at East Buffalo were dark last night when Sullivan's train was entering Buffalo. A stranger was riding on top of a car, and when Sullivan walked out upon the roof, the unknown man grappled with him and a terrible struggle took place.

There are very few heads so cool as to be quite unaffected by the enthusiasm of the surrounding crowd, even though they know it not to be very well founded. It was scarcely to be expected that even sensible Englishmen should not more or less lose their heads in "the tumult of acclaim" that was raised to welcome the Emperor of Germany.

The fact that Theodore Thomas is about to leave New-York to take up his residence and continue his musical labors in the city of Chicago undoubtedly caused many of the numbers in the Madison Square Garden last night to attend the first of his series of concerts in that popular resort. The Madison Square Garden has now become firmly established in the favor of the public.

There is a light card offered for the second day of the meeting of the Monmouth Racing Association at Morris Park to-day, though the stake events should make interesting contests. These are the Hopeful Stakes, for two-year-olds, at three-quarters of a mile, in which Merry Monarch and Airplant will meet, the former conceding two pounds to the latter. The Messrs. Morris bring out a new candidate for stake honors in Barefoot, a son of Longfellow.

Henry Farmer, who made a considerable mark in the musical world, at least in England, died in Nottingham June 25 last, in this seventy-third year. He was the composer of the popular Farmer's mass in B flat, a work which is frequently but erroneously attributed to his nephew, John Farmer, composer of the cantata, "Christ and His Soldiers." Henry Farmer was born in Nottingham, England, May 13, 1819.

The Board of Aldermen held a special meeting yesterday and received the assessment rolls for 1891. The total increase above the figures of last year on real and personal property is shown to be $88,878,948. The statement has been referred to the Finance Committee, which will fix the tax rate. The books will remain open in the office of the clerk of the board for ten days for inspection.

CINCINNATI, July 6. -- Two to one was the score of to-day's game. The Giants had the smaller number, and to their disgust left the field beaten after they had an opportunity of increasing their lead over Chicago. New-York's strong-armed boy Rusie pitched, but the defeat cannot be attributed to any poor work on his part. On the contrary, he acquitted himself in a most creditable style.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Controller of the Currency is out this evening with the correspondence between himself and Bank Examiner Drew, relating to the Keystone Bank scandal, ending with a request for Mr. Drew's resignation. Sincere regret is expressed by Mr. Lacey that the department should be obliged, through want of confidence in Mr. Drew's watchfulness, to dispense with his services.

Judge Brown of the United States District Court yesterday handed down a decision settling the blame for the collision between the French line steamship La Champagne and the steamship Lisbonense, which occurred Dec. 7 last, outside of Sandy Hook. The French line filed a libel against the Lisbonense for $106,000, and the owners of the Lisbonense filed a cross libel for $25,000.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- In pursuance of the provisions of the Copyright act approved March 3, 1891, the Secretary of the Treasury has prescribed the following regulations:

NEW-ORLEANS, July 6. -- The first cyclone that has visited Louisiana in the memory of the living generation struck Baton Rouge at 6:30 o'clock this morning, wrecked the steam tug Smoky City, demolished 100 houses, blew down the second and third stories of the penitentiary, killed ten convicts, and wounded thirty-five others. Of the wounded, five are not expected to live.

The American Furniture Manufacturers' Association is holding an exhibition of the latest styles of furniture, both domestic and foreign, at the American Institute Building, in Third Avenue, near Sixty-third Street. The association was organized last March, and has 115 members, who are among the leading manufacturers in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Superintendent of Census Porter has given out a defense of his figures which shows that it costs more per capita to run the local government of New-York than any other city in the country. He says that, if this bulletin is incorrect, the fault lies with the City Controller, as would appear from the following copy of a letter which he addressed that officer in April last:

NEWARK, N.J., July 6. -- The musical part of the great German Saengerfest was ended to-day in a furore of enthusiasm. After such a day as yesterday it was hardly within the probabilities that the festival could reach a higher pitch of excitement and artistic interest. But the crowds of yesterday were outdone to-day, and the demonstrations of enthusiasm were even more pronounced.

Three condemned murderers in the Ohio Penitentiary at Columbus, have just missed escaping from the prison. They cut through the stone floor of their ceil to an air flue. Their work was discovered a few hours before they expected to attempt to escape.

Austin Corbin, President of the Long Island Railroad Company, yesterday addressed a communication to the Common Council of Brooklyn, asking permission to construct an elevated railroad from a point on Atlantic Avenue, near Vanderbilt Avenue, to the Flatbush Avenue station of the road. The resolution was referred to the Railroad Committee without discussion.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 6. -- "What's a battery, boys?" asked a member of the Provisional Battalion of his companions on guard duty this morning. But even if that question were typical of the military knowledge of the country members of the National Guard, which it is not, it could be readily pardoned in consideration of other and more important qualities that the militiamen of these separate companies possess.
President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company arrived at this port, yesterday afternoon on board the North German Lloyd steamship Eider.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The crack filly Vaucluse, two years old, by Vauxhall, dam Jessie Hatcher, a stake and purse winner as well on the Western circuit this season, has been sold to Henry McDaniels, the well-known young trainer, for $2,000, by Joseph Desha of Cynthiana, Ky.

Kaiser WILHELM saw the lads of Eton yesterday parading not as students but as soldiers, and was well pleased with their drill and martial bearing. Perhaps, recalling the famous saying of one of England's greatest soldiers, he might have liked to see them on the cricket field, to judge of their probable pluck, alertness, and spirit in battle.

FREEHOLD, July 6. -- The evidence is daily multiplying that the breach between Gov. Abbett and the United States Senate is growing in Monmouth County. The opposition is earnest, sagacious, and has no lack of courage. One of the best known lawyers in this part of the State said to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day:

SING SING, July 6. -- The four miserable murderers who are to die in the electrical chair this week are still alive. Warden Brown, the newly-appointed head of Sing Sing Prison, deliberately made a false statement when on Sunday he told a half hundred newspaper correspondents that the murderers would be put into the chair at daybreak to-day.

LONDON, July 6. -- The Emperor of Germany arose at an early hour this morning, and, after a light breakfast, he left Windsor Castle on horseback, accompanied by the Duke of Connaught and a brilliant staff, with the intention of visiting Eton, England's most popular college school.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The leading Democrats of Pennsylvania are to hold a conference in Philadelphia July 10 to arrange a plan of campaign for this Fall. Ex-Representative Maish of Pennsylvania, who has been here a day or two, says that the trend of public sentiment throughout the State is such as to make it entirely probable that Quayism may receive another stinging rebuke.

ST. LOUIS, July 6. -- The Peralta-Reavis land claim comes to the front with the regularity of Biela's comet, but more frequently. A few days ago it was telegraphed from New-York that Mr. J. Addison Peralta-Reavis would press his big suit and that Mr. Collis P. Huntington was one of his backers. Several prominent New-York lawyers were also mentioned as being "behind" the enterprise.

RED BANK, N.J., July 6. -- It is almost certain that the Rev. Joseph V. Jowitt will retain his position as rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Middletown. A few months ago a feeling arose in the parish against the rector, and a number of the leading members of the parish threatened to leave if Mr. Jowitt was not removed from the charge by the Bishop.

President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company did not proceed to his son-in-law's home in Seabright Monday night as he said that he should. The statement that he would go there was made so as to avoid reporters. Immediately after leaving the Eider's wharf he proceeded direct to his residence, 26 East Forty-eighth Street, in this city, accompanied by his faithful friend and Trustee, W.F. Buckley.

Ever since the Lorillard Stakes was established in 1881 it has been one of the rich prizes of the year for the three-year-old division of thoroughbred racers, and it has generally proved a battle royal among the cracks. It brings with it something more than the dollars, a sort of guarantee that the horse that puts it to his credit is one of the best, if not absolutely the best, of his year.

Roswell Miller, Chairman of the Western Traffic Association, has called a meeting of that body, to be held in the Windsor Hotel, this city, next Tuesday and Wednesday. Although this is the regular quarterly meeting of the association, it is regarded as likely to be productive of important results. There are some things in the Western railroad situation that need immediate and heroic treatment.

SING SING, July 7. -- The four condemned murderers, Slocum, Smiler, Wood, and Jugiro, about whose execution under the new law so much talk has been made that the eyes of the entire county, if not of the whole civilized world, have watched the issue, because the very existence of the new law itself depended upon it, were legally put to death here this morning inside of an hour and twenty-five minutes.

PARIS, July 7. -- Agents of the Chilean Congressional Party state that advices from Chile warrant the confidence that the Congressional troops will occupy Santiago within a month. They resume the campaign amply provided with rifles and field guns. It is probable that the plan of the Congressional Generals is to land between Valparaiso and La Serena, crush the main body of the Balmacedist's, rouse the people, and make a combined movement on Santiago.

SING SING, July 7. -- Dr. A.P. Southwick and Dr. Daniels of Buffalo came from the prison entrance at 3:20 P.M., in time to catch the train for New-York ten minutes later. They had been at Auburn when Kemmler was executed, and Dr. Daniels had assisted at the autopsy then. He had since conducted a series of scientific investigations into the effects on the vital organs of this mode of taking life.

It does not follow because Judge Ross of the United States Circuit Court in California has dismissed the libel 'against the schooner Robert and Minnie that the Itata cannot be held. The meagre reports seem to indicate that the ground of Judge ROSS'S decision was that the schooner itself was not fitted out with arms and munitions to aid in war upon Chile.
" I cannot understand the carelessness of people." This remark was made by a leading New-York chemist who was just making an analysis for the Board of Health.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 7. -- Owen Murphy, the fugitive politician, who figured prominently in New-York fourteen years ago, became entangled in giving evidence to-day before the Parliamentary committee, now engaged in investigating the boodle charges preferred against Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, and the Hon. Thomas McGreevy, M.P.

NEW-YORK. Police Justice Hogan yesterday gave orders to Sergt. Coombs of Jefferson Market Police Court to drive away from the court all runners for lawyers found soliciting custom from prisoners and poor people who came to make complaints. Mrs. Lizzie Robinson, a colored woman, had gone to Jefferson Market Police Court to attend the examination of Pierre Barguet, who was charged with having assaulted her daughter.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7. -- Something has happened to the Seventy-first Regiment. All through the uneventful week that the two Brooklyn regiments were in camp grumblers met with but one reply from every side: "Just wait till the Seventy-first gets here if you want to see the fur fly. They are the boys for keeping the pot boiling." Expectations were raised high to the only end, apparently, that the collapse might be greater.

During my absence in Europe there have appeared in your paper a series of defamatory articles and editorials relative to the New-York Life Insurance Company and its officers and Trustees. These articles and editorials are full of falsehoods and are manifestly malicious, and were undoubtedly instigated by persons having a personal animosity toward the officers of the company and desiring to do the company and its officers injury.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The Phillies won to-day's game in the fifth by bunching four of their seven hits, assisted by sacrifice hitting and good base running. Both Stein and Thornton pitched good ball, but Anson's men scattered six hits through as many innings. The weather was very chilly, with a high wind blowing. Attendance, 1,100. Score:
