HONGKONG, China, June 3. -- To-day the last and only one of the great American firms, Russell Co., which have since the beginning of the century been intimately connected with the development of the foreign trade of China, closed its doors.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 7. -- The American Philological Association began its twenty-third annual meeting to-day in University Hall, Princeton. Clarence H. Young of Columbia College read a paper on "Erchia, the Home of Xenophon." In the absence of Dr. E.G. Sihler of New-York City, his paper on "Notes on the Roman Census in the Republican Era" was read by Dr. A. Gudeman of Johns Hopkins University.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 7. -- At the session of the American Institute of Instruction to-day the general subject was a liberal education. Introductory to the discussion, Miss Lucy Wheelock of the Chauncy Hall School, Boston, read a paper on "The Foundation as Laid in the Kindergarten and Primary School." No rule is necessary, she said, for little children, but the Golden Rule.

ST. LOUIS, July 7. -- The information has been given out with a great flourish of trumpets that the Hon. F.G. Niedringhaus, the tin-plate patriot, had recently made a large purchase of pig tin from the Temeseal Mining Company of Pomona, Cal. A reporter seeking information was given a pleasant welcome by Mr. Niedringhaus, who expressed a willingness to answer questions.

There seems to be no doubt whatever that the infliction of the death penalty in Sing Sing Prison yesterday by means of the electrical current was entirely successful. Although the witnesses provided for by the law were put under a pledge of secrecy by Warden BROWN regarding the details of the executions, nearly every one of them was induced to state that death in each case was instantaneous and consequently painless.

BOSTON, July 7. -- To-day the laddies of the naval battalion took their first lesson in gunnery on modern ships, and although it is impossible to make crack gunners out of such material in a day and without ammunition, still the men took hold of their work with a will, and showed their armory training by the readiness with which they handled the big ships' guns.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- The Inquirer to-morrow will contain an interview with Senator Quay. When asked whether he had read the recent address of the Independents he replied:

ST. PAUL, July 7. -- St. Paul was full of Alliance men to-day, who had come to the city to assist Mr. Donnelly in forming a People's Party, after the plan mapped out by the Cincinnati Conference, or to inquire why the Alliance State Central Committee was not recognized by the Sage of Nininger.

At a meeting last night of the committee of the Middle States regatta which is to be rowed on Friday and Saturday next, all the entries were received. The meeting took place in the Marlborough Hotel, and was largely attended. Judge Tighe of the Varuna Club of Brooklyn created some excitement by announcing that he did not believe that Hedley, the winner of the Fourth of July senior single, was an amateur.
" How is ex-president Grover Cleveland now regarded by the German-American voters of this city?"

While the recent anti-foreign riots in China have been numerous and violent, it is remarkable how few lives have been lost in them. There is a statement, which perhaps may yet need verification, that a British missionary and a customs officer were killed at one place; but there have been noticeably few injuries to persons among so many to property.

Judge Beach of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision in favor of Daniel Frohman, Henry C. De Mille, and David Belasco, in the suit brought against them by Miss Fannie Aymar Mathews to recover $100,000, representing the profits from the play "The Wife." Miss Mathews alleged that Belasco and De Mille got their play from her play, "Washington Life."

CHICAGO, July 7. -- A scheme has been devised by somebody within the Farmers' Alliance by which it is proposed to withhold this year's crop from market until the farmers can get their own price, or at least a price considerably above the average. The plau is unfolded in a circular of advice issued through accredited official channels to all members of farmers' organizations in the United States.

NEWARK, July 7. -- The great national Saengerfest closed this evening. The day began with a street parade, but the awarding of the prizes in the afternoon was the chief attraction. Major Carl Lenz was the spokesman of the judges, and a bevy of young ladies in white graced the platform from which he made the announcement to the thousands of listeners gathered on the floor of the pavilion.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 7. -- To President Harrison this day has been a mixture of crabs, picnic, Indian appointments, minor Post Office appointments, and beach promenading. The business routine of the last few days was broken into by a family excursion this morning to Sewell's Point, and from there through the water ways for crabbing.

LONDON, July 7. -- The Emperor of Germany was somewhat fatigued with his exertions of yesterday, and, consequently, slept later this morning than is his custom, and did not take his usual early morning ride.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- As a result of correspondence between the Navy Department and Adjt. Gen. Porter of the State of New-York it is now officially announced that Fisher's Island has been selected as the place and July 25 as the date for the drills of the New-York naval militia.

In their discussion of the questions involved in the hat-trimmings case, our high-tariff friends have cruelly neglected and even discredited their pet doctrine that tariff duties are paid by the foreign manufacturers. This is the case in which certain importers sue the Government to recover duties collected in excess of the rate which, the importers assert, was fixed by the tariff law of 1883.

The request for Bank Examiner DREW'S resignation on account of alleged infirmity of memory seems to be causing a good deal of surmise in Washington. In reporting on the condition of the Keystone National Bank in January, Mr. DREW made its assets and liabilities exactly balance and showed it to be in an apparently solvent condition, when he had, in fact, omitted the tidy sum of $544,851.46 from the list of its liabilities.

Brig. Gen. Curry and Sheriff Worley returned to Seattle, Washington, yesterday from the mining camps Black Diamond, Franklin, and NewCastle, where they had gone to request the miners to lay down their arms without forcing the Governor to declare martial law. It is thought that their efforts were useless. A committee agreed that the guns should be given up, but the agreement will probably not be adhered to.

WASHINGTON., July 7. -- There does not seem to be any clearing up of the mystery which surrounds the Keystone Bank affair, and there probably will not be until Congress takes hold of it and makes a vigorous prosecution of the investigation. The Administration has evidently adopted that policy of silence and secrecy which has long been so successfully practiced by Quay.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 7. -- In an article on Presidential possibilities, Henry Watterson makes the following guesses and suggestions regarding the Democratic ticket for next year:

BOSTON, July 7. -- The Democracy of Barnstable County are certainly not among those who can be suspected of starting anti-Cleveland boomlets, for they are at the present time actively engaged in preparations for a grand reception and banquet to the ex-President, and, perhaps, also to Mrs. Cleveland. The invitation was extended and accepted some time ago, and Saturday, July 25, has been selected as the date.

LONDON, July 8. -- The funeral of W.H. Gladstone, eldest son of the great English statesman, took place to-day at Hawarden. The procession of mourners was headed by the dead man's father and by Herbert and Henry Gladstone, brothers of the deceased.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The Western Passenger Association closed its monthly meeting to-day without touching upon the questions that have risen on account of the differences between Chairman Finley and the Chicago and Alton Railroad. A special meeting of the managers has been called for next Saturday morning to consider this matter and if possible to bring about a settlement of the difficulty.

There is one element in the Ohio situation on which the Democratic managers will do well to keep a sharp eye. It is the German vote. It is usually taken for granted that this vote will always go against "sumptuary legislation" and the party suspected of favoring it, whatever other issue may be raised.

There can be no question among Irishmen in Ireland or among Irishmen in America that the result of the election at Carlow is quite final and decisive, as respects the pretension of PARNELL to lead the Irish Party. Carlow was recognized as a Parnellite stronghold, insomuch that PARNELL is said to have owned that if he were defeated there he would have no political future.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 8. -- As a result of the decision of the Supreme Court Friday last in ousting the recently-elected Democratic Town Council of Lincoln on the tissue-ballot issue, the Republicans stormed the Town House yesterday afternoon, forced the doors, and elected officers. Town Clerk Smith refused at first to give up the records pending the production of the certificate of election of his successor.

The disabled steamship Servia was towed from the anchorage off Robbin's Reef to the Cunard pier early yesterday morning. As soon as landed, the vessel's passengers hurried to the office of the Cunard Company, 4 Bowling Green, and the agents of the line were kept very busy with them for a time.

John Ruphano was held for trial yesterday in the Harlem Police Court on a charge of stealing $33 from Albert Moore of the "Midnight Bell" company. Moore did not want to press the charge, but Justice White compelled him to do so. The police have discovered that Ruphano is the son of a rich silk manufacturer of Amsterdam, Holland, and that he left home in consequence of questionable conduct there.

BOSTON, July 8. -- Very much the same exercises were gone through to-day by the State's Jack tars as on yesterday. At 9 o'clock the divisions reported aboard their respective ships as named yesterday, but the plan for having the militia officers take command was abandoned, as both officers and men needed more drilling in their duties before being left to themselves.
AUBURN, N.Y., July 8. -- James C. King, sentenced for life in 1874 from New-York for murder, was released from Auburn Prison to-day on a special commutation granted by Gov. Hill

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Western roads are much exercised over their loss of the hard-coal traffic from Eastern mines, which has been almost completely monopolized by the Missouri Pacific. During the two months from May 1 to June 30, the shipments of coal from the East to Omaha and beyond aggregated 462 cars, of which 454 cars went over the Missouri Pacific Road, leaving eight for all the other lines.

The committee of the City Councils of Philadelphia has resolved to reopen the investigation of the Keystone Bank rascalities, and has sent word, among others, to Mr. WANAMAKER and Mr. MCKEAN of the Ledger that it wishes to have them appear before the committee to-morrow afternoon. It is hoped by the committee that these gentlemen especially will respond to this notice and not compel the committee to issue formal subpoenas.

The arrival at San Francisco of Chief NANPIE of Ponape will probably serve to interest Americans in the prolonged struggle of his people against the Spanish rulers of the Carolines, and this, indeed, is said to be the object of his visit. Of course our Government cannot interfere in the affairs of those islands for such a purpose as the protection of the natives.

The trial of one-legged John Cooney for murder in the second degree for shooting Benjamin Keenan in Greenpoint on the night of March 11 was concluded yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions. The principal witness for the prosecution was Owny Keenan, a brother of the dead man. Keenan testified that the shooting was deliberate and unprovoked.

Several times a year the intelligent observer has occasion to wonder whether there are any respectable inhabitants of Long Island City, and whether a scrutiny of its Directory would result any more favorably than did that of Sodom on a famous occasion. The latest forensic appearance of that malodorous suburb is one of the most curious.

PITTSBURG, July 8. -- Hard hitting at opportune moments won the game here to-day for New-York. Both Baldwin and Welch were hit hard, but the former got the worst of it by long odds. The Giants started in to bat in the opening inning, and they kept banging the ball in all directions throughout the game.

Four members of the National Commission to Europe in the interest of the World's Columbian Exposition, which consists of the Hon. Benjamin Butterworth of Ohio, Solicitor General; Major M.P. Handy, Promoter General; the Hon. A.G. Bullock of Massachusetts, Fred W. Peck of Chicago, and Judge Lindsay or Kentucky, were at the Gilsey House yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8. -- Ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley was to-day transferred from the county prison to the Eastern Penitentiary, and there began to serve his fifteen years' imprisonment for misappropriation of public funds. When sentenced on Thursday last, Bardsley's request for a few days' respite in which to settle up his business affairs before starting in on his long penitentiary life was acceded to by District Attorney Graham.

To-morrow night's mass meeting in Battery Park was sanctioned by the Park Commissioners yesterday, and nothing now remains but to lay out a programme. Everything else necessary to success has been assured. There will be good speakers, there will be a crowd, and the people will at last be given a chance to make themselves heard on the subject of grabbers.

The Board of Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company held its regular meeting yesterday at the company's office, with the venerable President Beers in the chair. Little was discussed save the very unfortunate and disquieting plight in which the company has been placed by reason of the recent criticism of its management.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8. -- A large audience witnessed the opening of the Twenty-ninth University Convocation of the State in the Senate Chamber of the Capitol this morning. Prominent educators from all parts of the State and from colleges of other States were present. George William Curtis, Chancellor of the University, delivered an address of welcome.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8. -- The annual regatta of the New-Haven Yacht Club, sailed over the club course to-day, was marred only by inclement weather. The feature of the day was the presence of yachts representing the New-York Racing Association, some of which were entered in the race.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- There is a fear on the part of some of the officers of the Government that the seizure of the Itata is going to cause more trouble than was anticipated. Even those who were most anxious for the pursuit and capture have abandoned the idea that the vessel can be held.

The large depot of the Sixth Avenue Railroad Company on Sixth Avenue, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, was in danger of entire destruction by fire yesterday. It was saved from this fate by the excellent work of the firemen.

A thread that may lead to the unraveling of an extensive scheme of forgery was picked up by Pennsylvania Railroad officials in Jersey City yesterday. Some of the railroad company's checks for the payment of the salaries of the employes are drawn on the Hudson County Bank. On Tuesday one of the tellers in the bank discovered that two of the cheeks for May that reached his hands bore the same number.

LONDON, July 8. -- The second day of the Henley regatta was remarkable from the fact that the oarsmen pulled through a series of most depressing, heavy downpours of rain, which were accompanied by much thunder and lightning. Consequently, there was a small attendance of spectators, but the oarsmen kept at it in spite of the weather.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8. -- The Camp of Instruction was treated to a genuine novelty to-day, and an interesting one, too. It was a reconnoissance by the corps of engineers attached to Company B, and it is quite a departure in the work of the National Guard.

ST. LOUIS, July 8. -- The story sent out from Chicago concerning a scheme said to have been concerted by the Farmers' Alliance for holding back wheat is denounced by those who ought to be thoroughly posted as an absurd scheme of Chicago speculators to bull the wheat market. Nobody here attaches the least importance to the matter.

The reopening of Jerome Park as a theatre for the racing of thoroughbreds occurred yesterday. It was not a tremendous success in any way. There were no drags on the lawn at the foot of the hill and no crowd assembled in the clubhouse, where years ago it was the proper thing for the social butterflies to meet and exchange gossip.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8. -- The American Philological Association resumed its literary work this morning at 9 o'clock in University Hall. The evening trains brought considerable additions to the already large number of professors from prominent colleges and universities, making the present the most successful gathering in the history of the association.

A young man whose identity has not been established took a novel way last night to end his existence by plunging into the sewer through the manhole in front of 200 East Twenty-sixth Street, near Third Avenue. His body was was washed away by the strong current rushing through the sewer toward the East River and was not recovered.

CINCINNATI, July 8. -- A little after 10 o'clock to-night came an alarm of fire, calling a relay of engines to the great building occupied by A.E. Burkhardt Co., manufacturers and wholesale and retail dealers in furs and fur goods. The building is at the southeast corner of Elm and Fourth Streets. It is the property of William A. Goodman, banker and financier.

The burning of the Sixth Avenue car stables might have been a serious public disaster before the building of the elevated roads reduced the street car lines from their previous rank of a public necessity. As it is, the main effect of it upon the public mind will be to increase the general wonder that the horse railroad companies should have been so slow in substituting for horse power more economical modes of traction.

A serious altercation took place on an East River ferryboat yesterday afternoon between two well-known professional and club men of this city, resulting in considerable injury to one of the combatants. The men engaged in the affair were Dr. Fraser C. Fuller of 47 West Fiftieth Street and ex-Judge Leicester B. Holms.

Senator R. Frank Pettigrew of South Dakota said at the Firth Avenue Hotel yesterday that his late colleague in the Senate, Judge Gideon C. Moody, might possibly be one of the Judges of the new Circuit Court of Appeals created by the last Congress. He had the indorsement of many well-known men and was one of President Harrison's warm friends.

Commissioner Goddard for a couple of hours yesterday listened to arguments for and against the Lackawanna's application for a differential on freight business to the Northwest. The Erie, New-York Central, Lehigh Valley, West Shore, Grand Trunk, and one or two other roads were represented in opposition to the Lackawanna's application.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Board of Visitors to Annapolis, through its Secretary, Lieut. Alexander Sharp, has made a report to the Secretary of the Navy upon the results of its visit to the Naval Academy last June.

A large crowd of horsemen was at the Tattersall's sale building last evening, when a draft of thoroughbred yearlings was sold at auction by William Easton. For the thirty-three head from the famous McGrathiana stock farm of Milton Young the auctioneer secured bids aggregating $48,950, an average of $1,425, one of the best ever made for the farm.

Is the Itata, now that she has been brought back to San Diego at great expense of time, money, and energy, to prove a white elephant on the Government's hands? Since the decision in the case of the Robert and Minnie it is more than ever doubtful whether she can be held for violation of the neutrality laws.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 8. -- A few rotten grapes have been discovered in vineyards in the fruit-growing district of Ulster County. The fruit growers are purchasing large lots of special paper bags into which the clusters of white and other fancy varieties of grapes are placed and are thus preserved from the stings of bugs while ripening.

LONDON, July 8. -- The Emperor and Empress of Germany, after having breakfasted with Queen Victoria to-day, drove to Frogmore and visited the royal mausoleum The imperial party afterward lunched at Windsor, and were than driven to Cumberland Lodge, where the silver wedding of Prince and Princess Christian of Schleswig-Holstein was celebrated.

BANGOR, Me., July 8. -- The funeral services of ex-Vice President Hamlin occurred this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock. At 10:30 A.M. the body was escorted from his late residence to the Unitarian Church by a guard of honor from B.H. Beal Post, No. 12, G.A.R. The body lay in state from 11 A.M. until 2 P.M., and was viewed by thousands of people who came from all sections of the State.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 8. -- A political "shakeup" resulted from a meeting of Bayonne's City Council last night. The dead-lock over the election of salaried officials was broken, and an almost clean sweep of old officials was made. Most of the retiring Republican officials are succeeded by Democrats.

Those of our readers who gave attention to the letter of Mr. WILLIAM H. BEERS, President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, purporting to deny charges which have been made against the management of the company, must have been surprised at the meagre character of his denials.

BOSTON, July 8. -- John Stetson has made a large purchase of property on Commonwealth Avenue, and work is to be begun upon a block of six brownstone residences, four stories in height. The one at the corner, which is to be occupied by Mr. Stetson himself, will be a magnificent structure, and will make one of the finest residences in the city.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, July 8. -- The radical indorsement of prohibition by the Republican State Convention has caused the biggest revolt in the Republican ranks ever known in this locality. The Democratic press is busy announcing the names of Republicans who intend supporting Horace Boles for re-election. These include merchants, bankers, professional and laboring men.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 8, via Galveston. -- El Partido (Liberal) has received dispatches from Guatemala announcing that a revolt has taken place in the district of Quezaltenango and that the uprising is gaining in force.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 8. -- An interesting case is to be tried here next Monday before Vice Chancellor Robert S. Green. Over twenty years ago the Monmouth Beach Association bought nearly all the property lying between Seabright and North Long Branch It was bounded on the West by the Shrewsbury River and on the east by the ocean.

A.B. George and W.T. Young of the Manhattan Athletic Club returned from England yesterday on the steamship Majestic. President Cart of the Manhattan Athletic Club said there was no truth whatever in the printed statements that these men had returned in advance of the team because of dissatisfaction with their reception or discord in the team.

BUFFALO, July 9. -- Drs. A.P. Southwick and Clayton Daniels, two of the official witnesses of the electrical executions at Sing Sing, returned this morning and were interviewed by a Commercial reporter. Dr. Southwick said: "The executions were a success in every way. There was not the slightest hitch. Electric execution has come to stay. These executions have demonstrated that the method is humane."

A romantic tale of love on the ocean blue was told yesterday by the officers of the Thingvalla when that vessel arrived in from Christiansand. Christian Skov emigrated to this country several years ago from Denmark. He went to Portland, Oregon, where he engaged in business. He was very successful and several months ago concluded to revisit his old home.

It has come to the knowledge of THE TIMES that Slocum, the murderer, one of the quartet executed by electricity at Sing Sing, made a full confession. The story of the confession, now that the man has paid the penalty of his crime, is interesting only as it brings out a very peculiar phase of his trial and defense.

Clarence Hobart and R.P. Huntington, Jr., played a great match in the finals of the tournament of the Westchester County Club yesterday afternoon. Hobart won after a hard fight, which reflected honor alike on both victor and vanquished. It took four sets, three of which were exceedingly close, to decide the supremacy, and the play was watched by a large crowd of spectators.

The Committee on Rules of the United States Senate will meet at the Fifth Avenue Hotel next Monday to discuss some matters which come within its jurisdiction and must be attended to in advance of the coming together of Congress next December. The committee comprises Senators Aldrich of Rhode Island, Sherman of Ohio, Harris of Tennessee, and Blackburn of Kentucky.

Jewelers and especially manufacturers of and dealers in silverware are having just now an object lesson on the tariff that is not calculated to heighten their estimation of the protective policy saddled on our Government by Major McKinley and his associates. In their trade a great deal of what is known as silver tissue paper is used to wrap silver and other articles liable to tarnish by contact with the air.

Senator Isham G. Harris of Tennessee is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He said to a TIMES reporter yesterday that he had been so little in his own State of late that he did not feel competent to give an exact statement of the political situation there or to say accurately what were the sentiments of the people and the leaders on the leading topics of interest.
ST. LOUIS, July 9. -- A staff correspondent of the Republic, who was sent to Bar Harbor to ascertain the condition of Mr. Blaine, sends his newspaper the following:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 9. -- Much talk has been caused in the southern outskirts of this city by the reported elopement of the Rev. George Washington Comer, a local preacher, and Mrs. George Washington Tappen, the wife of a Park Avenue farmer. Tappen's place is near Campbell's clubhouse, in Middlesex, just beyond the line of Union County.

The attention naturally concentrated in this country on the recent starting of Mr. PEARY'S expedition to Greenland allowed to pass with less notice another very interesting exploring expedition to the same region which set out within a day afterward. Lieut. RYDER left Copenhagen with a small party for the purpose of examining the eastern coast of Greenland during the present Summer and also in that of 1892.

There appear in this morning's TIMES two small items of news which have no apparent connection, yet which, when viewed in the light of certain additional facts, are linked at least by a chain of suggestion. On Page 1 appears a statement of the pardon by Gov. Hill of James C. King, a New-York murderer, imprisoned under a life sentence.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9. -- The Republican State Central Committee wrestled with the question of selecting a campaign committee until after midnight, and, as anticipated, Foraker was the force behind every move. Probably for the first time in the history of the Republican Party in this State were the candidates on the State ticket kept out of the room in which the committee held its meeting for the purpose of electing a campaign committee.

It may be maintained, with some plausibility, that no German is entitled to complain of English bores. Nevertheless, sympathetic hearts will go out to the Emperor of Germany after their possessors have read the reports of the things he has undergone in London, and which are probably quite new in his experience.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- A former resident of Tennessee, now residing in this city, who was intimately acquainted with Andrew Johnson when he was the most conspicuous figure in Tennessee, makes the following statement in connection with the controversy which has arisen between Editor McClure of Philadelphia and John G. Nicolas as to who was President Lincoln's choice as a running mate on the ticket of 1864:

ATLANTA, Ga., July 9. -- Great changes are, it is reported, to be made in the management of the Alliance Exchange of Georgia. The scope of the Central Exchange at Atlanta is to be greatly enlarged. Co-operative Alliance stores are to be established in every county in the State. The whole machinery, so it is alleged, is to be supplied by a New-York syndicate.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- In order that the Government of the United States may be fully prepared with all necessary technical information respecting the actual state of the Bering Sea seal fisheries and the effect of the depredations of sealers in the probable event of early arbitration of the United States in those waters, the President has decided to send two agents to Alaska to Rather the necessary information.

PITTSBURG, July 9. -- Little Galvin has a big right arm and he used it to good advantage to-day. He kept the Giants down to eight hits and 4 runs, and his club won a game from the leaders. Chicago came out ahead to-day, and Anson is now only fifteen points behind.

Not even Mr. Withers, with all his enthusiasm for anything and everything that has Monmouth Park's name attached to it, would call yesterday's races at Jerome Park a successful day's sport. The card was a light one, the track was heavy and holding, there was nothing like a crowd, and an utter absence of enthusiasm. But there was music by the band.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 9. -- An important meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee will be held here to-morrow, at which it is proposed to make a complete change in the manner of organizing the committee, and preparations will be made for perfecting the party organization and entering upon the work of the next campaign.

Toward the frozen North Prof. Albert S. Bickmore will journey this Summer in search of facts and illustrations with which to enrich his lectures to teachers, in the American Museum of Natural History, next Autumn. Each year in the early Summer an imposing procession of icebergs passes down along the coast of Labrador. It is Prof. Bickmore's intention to be there to see that procession this year.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Census Bureau has issued a bulletin on the distribution of population in accordance with altitude. It appears that in the area below 500 feet is included nearly all that part of the population which is engaged in manufacturing and in the foreign commerce of the country, and most of that engaged in the culture of cotton, rice, and sugar.

BOSTON, July 9. -- Judge Dunbar, in the Superior Court, to-day ordered the defendant to file a brief on or before Aug. 7 in the case of the Texas Standard Cotton Oil Company against the Prudential Fire Insurance Company. This is a suit on a policy of insurance, and the defense is that the President of the defendant company, Samuelson Heidenheimer, now deceased, set fire to the property burned in order to get the insurance.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Last year the Bingham House Stake for pacers was won at the Driving Park by Dallas after a hot contest of eight heats, but this afternoon Lady Sheridan landed the event off-hand and in moderate time.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 9. -- The third boat of the double-screw-propeller type made for the Hoboken Land Improvement Company was to have been launched at T.S. Marvel Co.'s yard this afternoon. There was an immense crowd of spectators present, many of them from New-York and Brooklyn.

It is announced that Col. R.G. DYREN-FORTH, who is at present rain-compeller-in-chief for the Agricultural Department, instead of removing to Kansas his air-explosion apparatus, has gone to Texas, and there will seek some sequestered spot, "where the noise will not disturb any one," and conduct exhaustive experiments.

Mr. LYNDE HARRISON of New-Haven is quite a prominent Republican in the State of Connecticut, and he has written a sharp letter to Mr. JOHN A. PORTER of Hartford in which he exposes, but does not clearly explain, the partisan trick whereby three of the Democratic candidates elected to State offices last November have thus far been kept out of office.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 9. -- Controller Staub has not yet decided concerning the State departments which are to receive orders on the State Treasury for funds during the lack of specific appropriations. The law relating to each department is now being considered under the advice of counsel, and the decision will not be reached until next week.

On behalf of Hermann Stursburg Co., agents of the American Petroleum Company of Rotterdam, which owns the steamship Chester, Messrs. Wing, Shoudy Putnam yesterday filed papers in a libel suit before Judge Benedict, in the United States District Court at Brooklyn, for salvage for towing the Servia to port.

NEW-HAVEN, July 9. -- References have been made in dispatches to THE TIMES to the unhappy situation existing in high Republican circles in Connecticut. Strenuous efforts have been made to cover up this unpleasantness, and there have been vociferous denials upon the part of Republican politicians and newspapers that any disturbance whatever existed.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 9. -- After a night of wild rain, this morning's sunshine and cheerfulness were a genuine and great surprise. The ocean, which yesterday was tossing and covered with white caps as far as one could see, was this morning as calm as any river, and the light breeze, which continued through the day, succeeded only in stirring up the most pitiful apologies of waves.

The stock market stays becalmed. Not a thing of interest or importance happens. The Granger who has an idea that Wall Street is wicked and ought to be punished would feel quite content could he drop down into the Stock Exchange district just now. He would find there none of that famed luxury and opulence which his wild Western fancy has always insisted on gilding the speculative centre with.

Some days ago the first commercial sale of bar tin produced at the mines of the San Jacinto Estate in California was reported by the San Francisco newspapers. The quantity shipped from San Bernardino County and sold in San Francisco was seven tons, and the owners of the mines were confident, it was said, that they would be producing the metal twelve months hence at the rate of 2,500 tons per annum.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9. -- The announcement that the wife of Gen. James Watts de Peyster had commenced a suit for a bill of separation from her husband created much surprise among the people hereabout. The couple have been married fifty years and both are over seventy years of age. The wife's story charges cruel treatment during many years, and some of the details as related by her are very damaging.

The steamship Theresina, which arrived here Wednesday afternoon from Para, Brazil, brings news of an attack made on that city early in June by a tribe of Indians from the interior under the leadership of a French half-breed. The Indians laid siege to the town for six days, and created so mush consternation that everybody was under arms night and day and business was practically suspended.

ALBANY, July 9. -- The opening of the second day's session of the convocation of the Regents of the University was marked this morning by an increased attendance. The discussion of the co-ordination of university, colleges and academy was opened by ex-President White of Cornell University.

Senator HARRIS of Tennessee expresses the belief not only that the people of his State are in favor of the free coinage of silver, but that the "great body of the Democratic Party" is in favor of it. In support of the latter part of his belief he refers to the vote in the Senate. That was a very poor indication of the position of "the great body of the Democratic Party."

The New-York Life Insurance Company yesterday took the first step in the prosecution of its one-million-dollar libel suit against THE TIMES in the course of which the company of course expects to clear itself of the charges of gross mismanagement in its affairs.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Mr. John G. Nicolay, Lincoln's private secretary, has to-day addressed the following letter to A.K. McClure, editor of the Philadelphia Times:

The gray building in Battery Park where immigrants are landed seems to have lately become a clearing house for old-world tales and romances. To the long list there was yesterday added another when the steerage passengers of the Obdam were landed. Among them was a tall, distinguished-looking, middle-aged man, whose appearance attracted much attention.

" Hannibal Hamlin died with the impression that Abraham Lincoln was his friend, and desired his renomination for the Vice Presidency at the Baltimore Convention in 1864." This remark was made to-day by a gentleman who is well known in national politics, and who is engaged in preparing for publication his personal recollections of public men during the past thirty-five years.

BOSTON, July 10. -- The battle of Deer Island, down the harbor, to-day was the most exciting event of the week's mimic war. The island was captured at noon by an armed force which landed under the very guns of Forts Warren, Independence, and Winthrop, corralled a few hundred pigs and cattle, drove off the troops stationed there to defend the island, and had Boston's chief reformatory institution, with its thousand inmates, at its mercy.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The July returns to the Department of Agriculture show some improvement in cotton condition during the month of June. The general average for the whole breadth has advanced three points, standing at 88.6. This is three points below the July return of last year, and one above that of 1889. In but four seasons since 1874 have the July returns been so low.

Last night's mass meeting in Battery Park will be remembered among the really great events in that historic spot. The voice of the people was heard. It declared against the invasion of the public pleasure grounds. The vehicle of its expression was an assemblage as earnest, as loyal, and as public spirited as ever met in this city.

Having demonstrated to its own satisfaction that the tariff duties on products controlled by Trusts ought to be increased, even when they are already prohibitory, our high-tariff neighbor, the Tribune, tries its hand at plate glass. In its news columns it describes "a new plate-glass factory" at Irwin, Penn., and adds this comment in its editorial columns:

It is probably just about as good fishing at the salt-water resorts of this vicinity as it will be this Summer. There will be times when the weakfish will bite better and a run of more and larger bluefish will delight the anglers, but, taking all the fish into consideration, there are about as many varieties represented as may be expected or will be met with.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 10. -- The closing session of the university convocation to-day was devoted to the subject of university extension. The discussion was opened by Prof. Herbert L. Adams of Johns Hopkins University. He thought that by introducing university extension to the teachers of the normal schools the nerve centres of education would be strengthened, and its effect be more widely distributed.

Commissioner GILROY of the Department of Public Works seems to have another fight with the Steam Heating Company on his hands. That corporation appears to have reverted to the idea that it can do what it pleases with the streets of this city without asking permission of any public authority, and has proceeded to make excavations without a permit.

Ex-Collector William H. Robertson, who was one of the delegates to the convention which nominated Lincoln and Johnson, was met by a TIMES reporter in White Plains yesterday and asked if he could throw any light on the controversy concerning Lincoln's choice for a candidates for Vice President on the ticket with him.

The Allen, gambler, Republican political heeler, and keeper of places of resort for people of questionable character, lies hovering between life and death at 246 West Forty-third Street. He was a quick fighter, but he ran across an Italian who was quicker than he and received several stab wounds, one of which, it is feared, will prove fatal.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- The camp was the scene of a most unfortunate occurrence early this morning. While attempting to run the guard at 3:30 o'clock, Private Seaman Wilkes of Company I, Seventy-first Regiment, came into violent collision with the Corporal of the Guard, Frederick W. Westervelt, and had a bayonet jabbed through his leg just above the knee.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 10. -- A circular containing about five thousand words has lately been circulated among the farmers of this State, presenting reasons why they should hold their wheat until the scarcity of that grain should cause the price to reach high figures, possibly $2, and then to place it but slowly on the market.

The new railroad route to Boston by way of Long Island is an assured fact. Mr. Austin Corbin explained yesterday that a contract had been signed by himself as President of the Long Island Railroad and representatives of the New-York and New-England Railroad, the Housatonic Railroad, and the Housatonic Terminal Company, creating the Long Island and Eastern States Line.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Assistant Secretary Nettleton has written a letter to the Acting Superintendent of Immigration at New-York in regard to the reported intention of diverting the stream of expatriated Russian Jews to this country.

The record of borings in Broadway, upon which Engineers Worthen and Parsons have been engaged for the purposes of the proposed underground railway for a month or so, has been completed and the engineers are considering the final plans for the construction of the road. Mr. Parsons said yesterday that the results of the borings were, in the largest degree, satisfactory.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 10. -- The executors of John Guy Vassar appeared before the Surrogate to-day, preliminary to a final accounting. The room was packed with lawyers, about all of whom are interested in the final results. Sixteen or seventeen of them are to receive about $8,000 each. Mr. Lown filed the executors' accounts, which cover fifty-eight pages.

NORFOLK, Va., July 10. -- James S. Van Vrankin, Paymaster's clerk in the General Storehouse of the Norfolk Navy Yard, and H.H. Coston, a clerk in the same department, were arrested to-day for the alleged stealing of composition metal and other goods from the Government to the estimated value of several thousand dollars.

The recent order abolishing the three military divisions and causing all the military departments to report directly to Army Headquarters is a natural sequence of the preliminary arrangements made a year ago, and furnishes another illustration of the skill with which the present commander of the army carries out his projects of administration.
LONDON, July 10. -- The Rev. Charles H. Spurgeon has grown extremely weak. He passed a restless night, the inaction of the kidneys exhausting the brain.

ST. LOUIS, July 10. -- The acknowledged tinplate authority of St. Louis is Charles Knight, tin and sheet iron buyer of the Excelsior Manufacturing Company, one of the principal manufacturers of tinware in the West. He has a national reputation as being one of the best-posted men in the country on tin plate and its manufacture. In an interview Mr. Knight said:

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- The sub-committee of the Finance Committee of City Councils that is inquiring into the failure of the Keystone National Bank and the affairs of ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley held a protracted session this afternoon. The main witnesses were Robert M. McWade, city editor of the Public Ledger; William V. McKean, editor in chief, the same paper, and Postmaster General Wanamaker.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 10. -- Everything was propitious to-day for the outing planned for President Harrison. The water was smooth and inviting, the weather delightful, and the revenue cutter Hamilton in good trim for a Summer day's picnic cruise. Collector Cooper came ashore early to welcome his distinguished visitors and take them aboard his vessel, but a secondary and more personal reason was a desire to take a dip in the surf.

ST. LOUIS, July 10. -- The prospect of Democratic success in Iowa grows brighter, and all travelers from that State, Republicans as well as Democrats, are only so many bearers of glad tidings of a great Democratic victory. F.W. Lehman, the recently-appointed General Attorney for the Wabash Railroad, who resides at Des Moines, and has long been recognized as one of the ablest champions of Democracy in that State, said to-day: ...

CHAMBERLAIN, S.D., July 10. -- Reports have just been received here of the way the Sioux on the Lower Brule Reservation celebrated the Fourth of July. For weeks the Indians had been preparing for the occasion. Every Indian on the Lower Brule Reservation was at the agency.
The following special order was issued yesterday to the First Battalion Naval Reserve Artillery in anticipation of the battalion's cruise with the white squadron:

Yesterday came and went with no more denials from President Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company, and those of his friends who so earnestly scouted the story of his having speculated in Wall Street are beginning to think that there was some truth in the statement after all. If there was no truth in it, would not President Beers have hastened to deny it long ago?

CLEVELAND, July 10. -- Brooklyn lost a game here by 1 run to-day. Lovett was unsteady and was hit hard at times, while Gruber pitched first-class ball. The visitors indulged in some poor base running in the eighth inning, when they had a chance to win.

The closing of nearly threescore lobster canning establishments on the French shore of Newfoundland by the British naval commander will naturally be a trying experience for that region, especially as about a thousand fishermen and other persons are thrown out of employment. But this result has, of course, all along been expected, since it was only necessary to await the formal issue of authority for the purpose under the recent colonial legislation.

SHANGHAI, China, June 11. -- The organized Chinese mob which, June 8, destroyed the Roman Catholic mission establishment and killed two foreigners at Wusieh, a large city on the Grand Canal, 100 miles from this place, is rapidly growing in numbers and is slowly making its way toward this city, taking in, on its line of march, all the foreign settlements along the Yang-tse-Kiang River.

The chief source of popular discontent in this country for years has been the growth of corporate power and its defiance of public authority and popular rights. It is this more than anything else that has produced the various movements intended to effect radical changes in legislation and disturb the existing order of things.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Workmen are engaged putting in the foundations for several World's Fair buildings at Jackson Park, and the work of construction will be pushed energetically from now on. The Illinois Central Railroad and the Directors have come to terms on the switching charges. The Central folks consented to reduce their charges 25 per cent. on what is designated by them as local business, as distinguished from switching business.

OTTAWA, July 10. -- The Parliamentary inquiry into the charges of corruption made against Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, is the sensation here. Thus far several public officials have been implicated, but no further proof has been brought against Sir Hector except the testimony of Owen E. Murphy, the self-confessed briber, who admitted that he absconded from New-York.

The spirit and devotion cannot be too highly praised of those Hebrews of New-York who, ever since the movement for the expulsion of Jews from Russia began, have endeavored to take care of their exiled coreligionists who arrived at this port. Their efforts have been wonderfully successful.

Two weeks ago we published a dispatch concerning the pitiable condition of the Rev. FREDERICK L. STEVENS, who had suddenly become demented. Mr. STEVENS is a graduate of the Yale Theological Seminary. After completing his course in that institution he prolonged his studies in Europe. Upon his return from Germany, one year ago, he decided to pursue his work for a time in the graduate department of the university.

I believe that it is nonsense to talk or suggest the name of any man except Grover Cleveland for the Democratic candidate in 1892. His defeat in 1888 was the result of treachery and rum. I deem him more available than ever. He will carry this State and be chosen without question. He is a statesman and an independent, liberal gentleman.

When Col. Daniel S. Lamont lifted the function of private secretary almost to the dignity and importance of a Cabinet officer during President Cleveland's Administration, he disclosed new possibilities to humbler private secretaries, and awakened in the public mind a more exalted conception of the character and scope of a private secretary.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 11. -- Herman Bohme was arrested here Thursday night, and Friday was arraigned in the police court for trying to kidnap his own child. He emphatically denied the charge, which was made by the boy's grandmother, Margaret Guemple, of 17 Centre Street, this city.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 11. -- With an atmosphere suggesting arctic rigor and a humidity desolate and drear, the early part of the past week did not offer conditions favorable to the full enjoyment of island attractions. But this inclemency has given way to sunny skies and welcome weather, and the change has brought about a vast increase in the population of the Thousand Isles.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11. -- Frederick Hawkins, the muscular sculler of the Manhattan Athletic Club, is still the champion amateur oarsman of the country. For a week past there has been a difference of opinion on that subject. Last Saturday Hawkins was beaten at the People's Regatta on the Schuylkill, and for a week the Philadelphians boasted of having the premier sculler in the person of Edwin Hedley, a new member of the Vesper Club.

A handsome new astronomical clock has just been constructed by Tiffany Co. of this city for the Union League Club of Philadelphia. Every year the Art Association of the club is accustomed to make a gift to the club, either of a work of art or some decorative work for the clubhouse. This year it was decided to present a cloak and one that would be a credit to the club.

BALTIMORE, July 11. -- If the Democratic State Convention were held next week Frank Brown would get at least three-fourths of its votes for the Gubernatorial nomination. Many of the county delegations have not yet been elected, but so strong is the apparent sentiment in his favor that nothing could defeat him.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 11. -- Merry parties, riding, driving, or bicycling, have been passing all the week. Members of a dozen bicycle clubs have made headquarters of the Kittatinny House. The members of the Brooklyn Canoe Club were registered over Sunday. Their canoes were launched at Milford, bound for the Lower Delaware. Outing is in full play.

The poetical proclamation of Lamartine affirmed that the French Republic was for peace and not to make war against other forms of government elsewhere; but it was not its armed interference that the courts of Europe had to fear. Its army was in Algiers, its improvised Government had no experience of public affairs. It was its example that was dangerous.

New-York as a Summer resort has won another champion in Lloyd I. Seaman. All through the Spring he and his family were planning to have a restful Summer in the country. They wanted a place not too far distant to keep Mr. Seaman from business and yet removed from city sights and sounds. A house at Greenwich, Conn., hit their fancy as about the thing needed, after looking about somewhat.

Toward 6 o'clock the other afternoon, just when the now comparatively few residents of that neighborhood were homeward bound, a half-grown Italian boy chattering and crying by turns, was making his way slowly through Fiftieth Street, not far from Sixth Avenue. He stopped often, looked up and down in a bewildered way, and talked and gesticulated, ending each tirade with a burst of tears.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 11. -- The political event of the year in Pennsylvania will be the fight for a Constitutional Convention in behalf of ballot reform. The Legislature, at its recent session, passed an act-giving the people of the State the right to vote for or against a Constitutional Convention at the next election, and at the same time to elect delegates who will serve in case the convention should be held.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 11. -- The week at Hopatcong has been interesting for its outdoor events. At the annual regatta of the Canoe Club the trophies were won by Mr. Frotheringham and the Rev. Dr. Gessler, Mr. Frotheringham winning in two trophy events.

Since the days of the Puritans church music in this country has undergone a radical change. For the first two centuries in New-England psalmody was the only form in which music existed. Metrical psalmody originated with the Reformation. It was first used by Luther in the year 1517. Knowing the power of music over the feelings, he used it to band together his followers and inspire them with his own zeal.

It was at the time when Mexico, in its impatience of rulers under ordinary designations, was consenting to be more or less controlled by a military official whom the public knew as the Governor, and by a subordinate, a privileged jidus Achates known to the people as the Lieutenant. It was also the year in Mexico when the fashion in sombreros was in the direction of the lowest crowns.
BOSTON, July 11. -- The last will and testament of the late Hannibal Hamlin has been filed for probate in Bangor, Me. It was executed while he was serving his last term in the United States Senate.

It was said when there were Kings that women, Kings, and thieves are at home everywhere, and now Academicians may take the place of Kings in the adage, for only an Academician would have had the faith in himself or the fatuity to write of Mme. de la Fayette after Sainte-Beuve and Taine and not failed.

Before the racing at Morris Park yesterday, Col. S.D. Bruce sold the Woodburn thoroughbred yearlings at auction, securing for the thirty-five animals sold a total of $39,275, an average of $1,122. They were as fine a lot as has been seen in the East this year, and the competition for their possession was lively. The breeding of the youngsters and their purchasers are as follows:

BAR HARBOR, July 11 -- There has been large increase of Summer population hero since last week. All the regular cottagers that are coming have come, save two or three prominent ones still lingering in Europe. Whose who are not coming have rented their places, and few desirable homes remain untenanted. The shopkeepers continue jubilant over the good business that continues, and the cooks are kept busy catering.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 11. -- Two important features of the session of the new School of Applied Ethics this week were the second of Prof. Felix Adler's series of lectures on the problem of unsectarian moral instruction, and the lecture by Prof. Robert Ellis Thompson of the University of Pennsylvania on "Ethics, and Patriotism."

HARTFORD, July 11. -- Editor Porter's answer to Judge Harrison's charges against him of political dishonesty is still under advisement. The Judge's charges were so clear and explicit and so capable of refutation, if false, that Republicans here not blinded by partisanship are astounded that two days have been allowed to pass without a reply from the man who is accused of the most disreputable of political offenses.

BERLIN, July 11. -- The papers of this city overflow with accounts of the popular triumph of Emperor William in London. The semi-official papers, in commenting on the reception, adopt a remarkably guarded tone, and avoid all reference to an alliance with England as an accomplished fact. These papers simply re-echo the Emperor's speech at Guildhall.

Horace Greeley, who used to make stump speeches in this region, always said Pike County was "noted for its Democrats, rattlesnakes, and bad whisky." Things have changed since Horace's day, and while some Democrats and "rattlers" still remain, plenty of Republicans can be found here, and the whisky one gets in this well-provisioned clubhouse is as good as one could wish for.
SCHOOLEY'S MOUNTAIN, N.J., July 11. -- Among the guests registered at the Dorincourt are:

" Tom" Richardson, charged with being the robber of Islip, L.I., has not yet been captured, although the village authorities, aided by many of the townspeople, small boys, and dogs, have scoured many miles of the wooded country in the vicinity in the last few days, hiding places of the much-dreaded disturber of the public peace having been found in the shape of two or more caverns.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 11. -- The Examiner this morning announces the discovery of an enormous cavern in Josephine County, Oregon, about twelve miles north of the California line, and about forty miles from the coast. The Examiner's exploring party which visited the cavern reached it by way of Grant's Pass, Oregon, on the line of the Oregon and California branch of the Southern Pacific Railway.

Science has dealt a good many blows to art and literature, but during recent years science has made the life of painters miserable by casting doubts on the immortality of pictures. It has become a nightmare to artists, this fear lest the pigments with which they prepare their paintings shall suffer some internal change and alter their colors to the point of a complete ruin of the picture.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 11. -- The commission to revise the judiciary system and the public laws will be ready to report, in regard to the former only, at the coming session this month of the General Assembly. The commission consists of William G. Roelker, Joseph C. Ely, and Henry W. Hayes, with Isaac H. Southwick, Jr., as Secretary.

Although hundreds of thousands of years have certainly elapsed since that epoch when primeval man occupied. Western Europe in company with the reindeer and other animals which have in these later days retreated to the arctic, so much has been ascertained by science respecting him that one can actually look back through the ages and behold this remote ancestor of the human rate as he lived and pursued his daily avocations.

The third annual regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club, off the clubhouse at Cos Cob Harbor, Conn., was a marked success yesterday. There were twenty-seven starters in the race, twenty-five of which, at least, stuck it out to the end and came across the finish line in good shape. Had the day opened with a little more wind there would have been still more contestants.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 11. -- The camp of the Seventy-first is over and the regiment has made a record for itself. The tour just ended has been for that regiment beyond all question the most brilliant and successful in its history. The men went home this afternoon feeling that their regiment had as great a future before it as it had a splendid war record behind.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 11. -- James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park and one of the largest property owners, is enraged at the tactics employed by the illicit beer sellers who peddle their contraband beverages to customers in this prohibition resort. Asbury Park has a special charter, granted on March 4, 1874. which prohibits the sale of liquors within the limits of the town.

Kindly permit me to say a few words through your columns relative to the recent disturbances connected with the Moqui Indian village of Oreibi, apropos of the excellent editorial on the subject in to-day's TIMES.

The orders directing Lieut. GODFREY H. MACDONALD to organize at Fort Bennett a troop of Indian cavalry, made up with the band of Chief HUMP as a nucleus, give a suggestive idea of some of the objects and advantages of the new policy on this subject, HUMP was one of the leading disaffected Sioux last Winter and was believed to have had a great influence in keeping up the troubles.

LEVNKA, Fiji, Jan. 5. -- Slung under the iron beams of the steamer stateroom in which I am writing, while a flood of tropical rain roars upon the deck overhead, are a bundle of savage spears -- long and elastic in the shaft, tipped with shell of needle-like sharpness, and barbed with rows of pointed bone, from two to five in number, extending about two feet from the end.

JACKSON, Miss., July 11. -- The United States Senatorial campaign, which up to date has been the hottest one ever occurring in this State, now looks as if it is virtually settled, and that George and Walthall will be their own successors.

The recently published Canadian documents touching reciprocity leave the case almost exactly where it was before. It is evident that Mr. BLAINE did not commit himself or our Government to anything whatever, and he seems to have been in the right in his complaint that it should have been alleged or believed in Canada that our Government was responsible for the failure to carry on negotiations looking to reciprocity with Canada.

PARIS, June 30. -- The fashion news being very slight in spite of the elaborate descriptions of the special publications, one has leisure to gossip about other things, and Paris, usually given over at this season of the year to the cirque d'ete and to the Neuilly foire -- of which I shall have more to say presently -- is most interesting to the lounger.

CLEVELAND, July 11. -- Brooklyn lost again here to-day. The visitors played in poor luck throughout, while fortune seemed to favor Cleveland. The game was witnessed by a very large crowd and on account of the closeness of the scores was of a very interesting character.

BALTIMORE, July 11. -- To-day's Catholic Mirror contains a five-column letter from J. Thomas Scharf, the local historian, attacking ex-Gov. William Pinkney Whyte and Bishop Paret of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Maryland for their remarks at the unveiling of the monument to Cecil Calvert, the Founder of Maryland. It is all about the old question of religious toleration in Maryland.

My acquaintance with Mr. Thackeray was not intimate. I had met him but once previous to his coming to America to deliver for the first time his lectures on the "Four Georges." In fact, I should hardly consider it worth while to make any reminiscence of him the subject of an article but for a droll occurrence which happened in my presence in which he was the conspicuous figure. But of this presently.

A writer in an American magazine claims that his countrymen speak better English than the English themselves. Controversies of this kind can seldom be decided, because it is next to impossible to secure an impartial judge. The improvements that have been made across the Atlantic in the tongue of Raleigh and Shakespeare would not constitute an important list.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 11. -- Bright, breezy weather, just the sort to make outdoor life enjoyable, prevails here. The crowd of visitors is growing larger every day. The country roads are gay with the many handsome equipages of the city visitors, and equestrian exercise has all its old-time popularity.

The mysterious F.C. McLewee, who now claims the ownership of a lot of horses purchased some time ago, as then announced, for a son of Ebret, the brewer, is in trouble. Two of the horses running in his name were starters in the Hackensack Handicap, which was run at Morris Park yesterday. They were Rey del Rey and San Juan, the former being ridden by Murphy and the latter by Doggett.

LONDON, July 11. -- The Emperor of Germany remained at the state ball given at Buckingham Palace until 3 o'clock this morning. At 8 o'clock he arose, breakfasted, and attended to business with his secretaries. Just before noon, accompanied by the Empress and by the Dukes of Edinburgh and Connaught, the Emperor enjoyed a ride in Rotten Row, after which he inspected the Yeomen of the Guard.

ALBANY, July 11. -- Nearly all the members of the three State Boards of Medical Examiners were present at the conference held in the State Senate Chamber to-day. The object of the meeting was to compare views in regard to the details of State examinations in medicine which must be passed by every person who wishes to practice in this State after Sept. 1 next.

There can scarcely be any dissatisfaction in the Protestant Episcopal Church with the confermation, which is now assured, of Dr. PHILLIPS BROOKS as Bishop of Massachusetts. The opposition to his confirmation came from sticklers for the enforcement of the rules of the church, for some of which Dr. BROOKS as a Presbyter has shown little regards.

We are in possession of a letter written by Gen. Longstreet to a friend in Atlanta, Ga., in which, referring to a recent public statement that Ben Butler will assail Gen. Grant in his forthcoming book, the gallant old Confederate General says: "As Grant is dead and gone, I suppose Butler feels no sort of apprehension from the small arms that may be opened on him from other sources.

" Once upon a time" it was an accepted decree of fashion, then more autocratic than now, that every woman who wished to "be anybody" must own at least one good silk dress. Since there never lived a woman with vanity so dead that she did not propose to be somebody if she could, there were few even of the most limited wardrobes which did not include the "one good silk."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 11. -- The Commercial Gazette Springfield special says the Neal and Campbell factions in that city this afternoon both claim to have elected delegates. It says that the convention was a howling mob of such a character as was never before seen in that city. The Campbell men were most numerous, and in the caucus previous to the convention had carried everything their own way.

The general high average of the 1891 season at the State Camp of Instruction was maintained the last week by the Seventy-first Regiment, Colonel Frederick Kopper commanding, and the Second Provisional Battalion, consisting of the Fifth, Thirteenth, Seventeenth, and Thirty-eighth Separate Companies of Infantry, under command of Capt. Thomas Miller, Jr.

FLORENCE, S.C., July 11. -- The fact that South Carolina sent no representative to the greatly mixed up convention at Cincinnati was a plain evidence that the Alliance and the third party were dead issues in this State. The Alliance as a factor in politics has been practically extinguished. It has died of inherent weakness in every organ of vitality.

LENOX, Mass., July 11. -- The weather has been delightful the last week for boating, driving, tennis, and other outdoor sports. The mercury has hardly touched 75, and the rain has laid the dust on the country roads, and the latter part of the week everybody has been out enjoying a ride, drive, ramble, or other opportunity to spend a delightful hour.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 11. -- The Rev. D.C. Forward, late of the Onondaga Baptist Association, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Baptist Church at Homer, N.Y.

During the last three months the Board of Charities of this State has sent back to their homes in Europe thirty-five paupers who had been shipped to this country by town officers, "benevolent" societies, or relatives or friends. At this rate the number of such persons sent back during the entire year will be smaller than usual. Last year it was 165, in 1889 it was 229, and 323 was the number for 1888.

PITTSBURG, July 11. -- The National Tube Works Company of McKeesport, which is controlled by Boston people, will be reorganized under the laws of New-Jersey. The new company will include, besides the National Tube Works Company, the Monongahela Furnace Company, the Republican Iron Works, and the Boston Iron and Steel Company, all of which have been formed by the Tube Works Company.

NORFOLK, Va., July 11. -- There is believed to be no truth in the rumor that forty men had lost their lives by the wrecking of the big caisson recently built for the lighthouse to be constructed at Cape Hatteras. A telegram was received here Thursday to the effect that the caisson had been wrecked during a short, sharp blow Wednesday night.

It is hardly conceivable that the Park Commissioners of this city, with one ignoble exception, should have any other desire than to restore the beautiful park which overlooks the bay at the lower end of Manhattan Island to the people for their exclusive use as a place of healthful recreation, provided it is demonstrated to them that both the law and popular sentiment are against its further occupation for railroad purposes.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich, July 11. -- Nearly a week ago a small brush fire started in the western part of Detour Township, Chippewa County, and to-day there is a raging forest fire, embracing all the country from Lake Turon to Lake Superior. Yesterday the fire kept up close to Detour Town; the residents became frightened and packed their goods for transportation by boat out on the waters of the lake.

In a secret conclave of representative Farmer's Alliance men from all parts of the country, held recently at an out-of-the-way hotel in the vicinity of this city, there was concocted a daring financial and commercial scheme which it is intended to foist upon the farmers of the country, and which rivals in its visionary character and magnitude the Sub-Treasury scheme.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 11. -- The Rev. E.P. Nicholson of Philadelphia, who some weeks ago informally accepted his election as Bishop of Milwaukee, to-day sent a letter of formal acceptance. He will be installed in his own church in Philadelphia.

NYACK, July 11. -- There have been many arrivals at the Summer hotels in this place this week, the most of the guests being well-known persons from New-York and Brooklyn. The cottages, the occupants of which live in one of those two cities during the Winter, are now all filled.

WATCH HILL, July 11. -- The drop in the temperature the last few days made light overcoats acceptable, and the southeast storm kept the hotel guests indoors. The population is large for the early part of the season, and the cottagers, especially, put in an early appearance, most of them having been here since the middle of May.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- The Chicagos held the lead in the championship race for just twenty-four hours. It made them so nervous that this afternoon they surprised 9,331 spectators by putting up the worst game they have played this season. In consequence Chicago's baseball cranks are in mourning to-night, for they realize that if Chicago is to win the pennant Anson must have the lead when the next Eastern trip begins.

The most exciting days of Summer yacht racing in these waters have come and gone. There will be nothing more of an enlivening nature until the New-York Yacht Club's annual cruise, which begins Aug. 3, save the race of the Cherry Diamond Yacht Club, July 25. The American Yacht Club's race Monday and the New-Rochelle Club's race Tuesday were the only events of the week.

LANSING, Mich., July 11. -- The Legislature that adjourned a few days ago made a pretty large contribution to American political history in the law providing for the selection of Presidential Electors by Congressional districts. Based on the vote of 1889, this system would give to the Democrats eight Electors and to the Republicans six, there being twelve Congressional districts in the State under the redistricting accomplished by the Legislature and two Electors at large.

" Col. McClure and Col. Nicolay are both undoubtedly correct in their statements of fact in their controversy over Mr. Lincoln's feelings as regards Mr. Hamlin at the time of the Baltimore Convention in 1864," Gen. Daniel E. Sickles said in the course of an extended interview to a TIMES reporter yesterday.

The annual praises in all the newspapers of the advantages of New-York as a watering place have become objects of derision even to their authors. A perspiring person longing to be a hundred miles away and enumerating his compensations does undoubtedly recall the philosophic fox of AESOP in his reflections after he had failed to reach the grapes.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Provisions were dull to-day. There was some selling of ribs on foreign account. September pork opened at $10.47 1/2, sold up to $10.52 1/2 and down to $10.45, and closed at $10.50. September lard opened at $6.50, sold down to $6.45, and closed at $6.47 1/2. September ribs opened at $6.40, sold between $6.37 1/2 and $6.45, and closed at the opening figure.

Two Parliamentary papers were published in London on June 23 containing the correspondence that passed between the Vatican and the Court of Great Britain with regard to Mgr. Ruffo Scilla's mission on the occasion of the Queen's jubilee, and the Duke of Norfolk's special mission to the Pope to express the Queen's sense of his Holiness's courtesy, and also to congratulate the Pope on the fiftieth anniversary of his entering on the sacerdotal office.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The following is the weather crop bulletin issued by the Weather Bureau:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11. -- The Newport season is well under way and the city is very lively, as the presence of hundreds of cottagers can make it so without any very extensive entertaining or outdoor attractions. With the present week the round of social gayeties and festivities has begun, but only upon a moderate and quiet scale as yet.

HOTEL AMPERSAND, July 11. -- The season has fairly opened at this resort, and that the Ampersand is as popular as ever has been demonstrated by the number of guests here. The additions to the hotel gives the house accommodations for 250 persons, nearly doubling its capacity.

During the intensely hot weather in June our fox terrier was taken violently ill, with every sign of rabies. At least, it seemed so to us, terrified as we were, although the attack was very sudden. Fortunately for "Dick," we knew that madness does not come without a couple of days' warning and a noticeable change from usual health and habits.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11. -- Forty-four counties in Ohio to-day elected delegates to the Democratic State Convention which assembles in Cleveland next week. So far as heard from, Gov. Campbell has practically carried all these counties, which will give him a representation in the State Convention of over 650, leaving his chief opponent, Neal, about 125, with a few scattering votes for Virgil P. Kline of Cuyahoga County.

CHRONOLOGY CONSIDERATIONS. -- Egyptian chronology carries as much further than the chronology of India. Menes is supposed to have reigned 4000 B.C., and, if we do not admit a division of the empire among different royal dynasties the date of Menes might be pushed back even further, to 5600 B.C.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 11. -- Much alarm is felt over later reports from Eastern Colorado and the western line of the State, indicating that the grasshopper plague may possibly reach the cultivated portion of this State before the corn is out of danger. The grasshoppers began hatching out nearly three weeks ago, and were at first supposed to be confined to a limited extent of country.
NEW-ORLEANS, La, July 5. -- A few days ago the political campaign in this State was opened by the anti-lottery wing of the Democracy at the Grand Opera House.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 11. -- The first time in years every cottage at this Summer resort is occupied and by a very desirable class of cottagers, and the hotels have never had so successful an opening. Those who have complained of the slow growth of Cooperstown as a Summer resort are at least able to console themselves with the knowledge that its growth, though slow, has been sure and steady.

Among the republics of South America Chile for more than half a century has been practically free from revolution. Her people, compared with other peoples of the Southern continent, are unusually independent and stable of character, and they possess a strong national spirit. The political executive power is lodged in the hands of a President, chosen by an Electoral College for a five-years' term, who, under the Constitution, is ineligible for re-election.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 11. -- The Summer season in the Catskill Mountains is supposed to open in the first week in July, and it did so this year, although the prevailing cool weather has not driven people to the mountains in the crowds that usually make the pilgrimage about "the Fourth." Nevertheless a goodly number are already in their Summer homes.

Since you have seen fit to publish so much regarding the so-called troubles of Mr. Jowitt, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Middletown, I feel sure your reputation for fairness will give these facts equal publicity. Mr. Jowitt has many warm friends in Red Bank and Middletown who have felt the injury done him by published accounts of his troubles.

The gowns prepared for Lillian Russell's re-entree as the Grand Duchess at the Casino to-night are said to be marvels in construction and arrangement of colors. Four changes are made during the opera. The plot is laid in 1720, but there is no great attempt made to follow the traditions of the times in regard to the gowns.

LORELEY, Md., July 12. -- This was the first big day of the encampment of the Maryland National Guard, and thousands of people came from Baltimore and other points to see the sights and enjoy the occasion. It is one of the largest encampments in the history of the State, the total number of men being about 1,500, under five commands.

A few days ago certain high-tariff papers began to discredit the lists of reductions of wages which were published in THE TIMES last Spring. Why they should have postponed their denials until this late day we do not know, unless they hope that the facts have been forgotten by some to whom their remarks are addressed.

" Since the evil days of Boris Godunoff, who first legalized serfdom, before the dynasty of the Romanoffs was seated on the imperial throne, hunger and famine," says the St. Petersburg correspondent of the London Daily Telegraph, "have never been yet so intense or so widespread as they seem destined to become in the year of grace 1891.

The experience of certain manufacturers of chocolate in San Francisco, as related in the Tribune, throws some light upon the new conditions under which refined sugar is now made and sold in this country. It appears that by a combination of the refiners in California the price of domestic refined sugar has been fixed at 5 1/2 cents a pound.

ASPEN, Col., July 12. -- A railroad accident occurred at Aspen Junction, eighteen miles west of Aspen, on the Midland Road, at 11 o'clock last night.
