A special train of baggage car and one passenger coach was returning to Aspen from Glenwood Springs. The passenger coach contained about thirty passengers, mostly Aspen people.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12. -- From fifty-three reports on crop prospects in Western New-York received at R.G. Dunn Co.'s Mercantile Agency from points in the counties of Seneca, Tompkins, Cayuga, Monroe, Wayne, Yates, and Ontario, the Democrat and Chronicle makes the following estimate of the general outlook:

BOSTON, July 12. -- A large number of people visited the white squadron in the harbor to-day. Admiral Walker went to South Woodstock, Conn., Saturday, to visit his wife and children, who are stopping there during the Summer. The squadron leaves for New-York at 1 P.M. Monday. Three deserters are reported from the Boston and five from the Atlanta.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 12. -The coming weeks will witness an invasion of Georgia by the third party Alliance leaders of the West. Their coming is stirring up the antagonism of Democrats who are beginning to see what it all means. The great rallies will be in Americus Tuesday next, and at Atlanta, Athens, Hogansville, and Rome on the days following.

The good people of Pamrapo, N.J., are in a state of excitement such as has never before been known in that picturesque section of Bayonne City. This condition of affairs is occasioned by a series of burglaries extending over the past month, which, for daring of design and neatness of execution, would do credit to some of the most noted cracksmen that figure in Inspector Byrnes's criminal history.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 12. -- A glorious day the boys of the Twelfth Regiment had for their first day in camp, and a glorious day they made of it. Saturday night was superb, just warm enough for life under canvas. The regiment consequently enjoyed a night's rest that entirely took away the fatigue of the trip up and the putting of things in ship-shape for the week. They devoted to-day entirely to enjoyment.

It is reassuring to learn from Senator ALDRICH that his special committee is likely to reach a favorable conclusion regarding the proposition to abolish secret sessions of the Senate except in cases where the majority, by an open vote, may order them. The Rhode Island Senator says that it is his belief that a majority of the Senate would favor such a change.

Perhaps the greatest service the officers of the New-York Life Insurance Company can now render to the policy holders is to sue THE TIMES for exposing their misconduct. We should then have an honest, full, and thorough investigation. I fear, however, that the advertising card published in all the daily papers announcing their intention to do so is only a silly game of "bluff" to mislead the confiding public.

The New-York Life is out with a dodger -- a glaring lot of misstatements about the work of William H. Beers. The sheet in question is built up of figures tending to the laudation of the company's President. The heading of this famous circular is as follows: "This is what the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company has done during the past twenty years under the guidance of its President, William H. Beers.

ABBEVILLE, S.C., July 12. -- National Alliance Lecturer J.F. Willet was one of the earliest organizers of the Farmers' Alliance. Last Winter, at the National Alliance meeting at Ocala, he was elected National Lecturer. Since that time he has traveled 14,000 miles, passed through fourteen States, and organized three State Alliances -- Iowa, Ohio, and New-York.

That the American Legislature should, in a moment of enthusiasm and self-forgetfulness, have passed an act that may some day enable English authors to get copyright in the States was in itself a sign of great good will; another goes omen is that American publishers do not disdain to come over and "hang out their shingle" in the protecting shade of the British lion.

LONDON, July 13. -- The Telegraph says that, in the course of an audience at Buckingham Palace yesterday, the German Emperor said: "Tell everybody that I am most delighted with my welcome in England. It has been a reception which I might have expected only in my own country, and not outside of it."

CHICAGO, July 12. -- A gentleman now in this city who can throw a great deal of interesting light on the Nicolay-McClure controversy is Major Ben C. Truman. Years ago he was a compositor in the office of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Then he became proof-reader, reporter, correspondent, and editor, and finally he abandoned the newspaper for a more lucrative business.

Congressman John C. Tarsney of Missouri, who is at the St. James Hotel, told a TIMES reporter yesterday that the next Congress would pay its respects to Mr. Commissioner Raum of the Pension Office in a way that would be decidedly different from the whitewashing investigations which have recently been given that official.

It is currently reported and generally believed that the persons who have assumed the management of Democrats in New-Jersey will attempt to cast the vote of this State for Gov. Hill in the National Democratic Convention. It is probable, from all the signs of the times, that they will oppose the nomination of Grover Cleveland.

The employes of rival restaurant keepers, who had different ideas about working on Sundays, had a war of words and fists in Sixth Avenue, near Twenty-third Street, yesterday at about 1 o'clock. They were the employes of O'Neill's chop house, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, and of Bristol's restaurant, just above, in Sixth Avenue.

Our latest advices from South Carolina show that the Farmers' Alliance in that State is undergoing a very decided change from what it was a year ago. Our readers will remember that Gov. TILLMAN has accepted a proposition for a series of debates with the most popular of the Alliance lecturers on the question of the Sub-Treasury scheme.

Two committees of the United States Senate expect to hold sessions at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-day -- the Committee on Rules and the sub-committee which is conducting the tariff investigation. Senator Aldrich of Rhode Island is Chairman of both. He has called the Committee on Rules to meet at 10 o'clock and the sub-committee to meet at noon.

RICHMOND, Va., July 12. -- The conference held here Wednesday by the Hon. J.T. Ellyson, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, with the leading members of the Farmers' Alliance was intended to pave the way to a thorough understanding between the leaders of that organization and those of the Democratic Party about the issues of the coming legislative campaign.

That fraud vitiates every contract is a legal maxim that no one ever thinks of disputing. It was with this fact in mind that the decision in the race at Morris Park on Saturday was made. All bets were declared off, because in racing law a fraud had been committed by the McLewee Stable management in having San Juan pulled to allow Rey del Rey to win the Hackensack Handicap.

ST. LOUIS, July 12. -- The fifteenth annual convention of the National Trades Assembly, No. 133, Knights of Labor, will begin its session in St. Louis to-morrow morning. This is a large body, and comprises all the glassblowers of the United States and Canada. The members have in contemplation changes and demands that will bring about a revolution in the trade.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 12. -- When the name of Buzzard's Bay was read July 4 in the Tammany Hall gathering to celebrate the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, everybody who heard it, no matter how slight his knowledge of geography, knew that it was the Summer home of ex-President Cleveland, and some of them knew that it is in Massachusetts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12. -- The friends of Gov. Campbell do not disguise the fact that the Democracy of Cleveland have played a confidence game upon the Governor and the State Central Committee. At the time the committee met in Columbus, a few weeks ago, the representatives from Cleveland were on hand to secure the convention, and dwelt upon the fact that Cuyahoga County would have no Gubernatorial candidate.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 12. -- The political tide has set in strongly for the Democratic Party in Iowa. Recruits from the Republican Party were never so numerous, and they include many prominent men. Among them is Capt. Langstaff of Dubuque. He is one of the prominent Republicans who are this year actively working in the interest of Gov. Boies, and against prohibition and its blighting influences.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 12. -- P.W. Barney, Superintendent of the Lake George and Champlain Transportation Company, lost his life near the Kenesaw, Fourteen-Mile Island, on Lake George, to-day.

Eugene Miller, a German, forty-five years old, who was arrested Saturday night charged with passing worthless checks on Harlem business men, was arraigned before Justice White, at the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, and was remanded for examination.

A modicum of interest attaches to the report of an address delivered by the new Texas Senator, Mr. HORACE CHILTON, the other day at Cameron, the shire town of one of the counties of his State, for the reason that it contains the first public utterances upon the leading questions of the day made by Mr. CHILTON since he became Senator.

The Philadelphia papers have, as was to be expected, proclaimed Mr. WANAMAKER'S "refutation" of the charges based on the interviews with BARDSLEY and on the books of the Keystone Bank to be complete. It is hardly that. It is, indeed, little more than a general denial, with some explanation that could be accepted as proof only on cross-examination and after careful investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Representative Herbert of Alabama is in Washington on his way home from New-York, where he has been since the Tammany Fourth of July celebration, in which he took part.

The ultra silver people, who are just now straining every nerve to commit the Democratic Party in Ohio and elsewhere to their pet theory of free and unlimited coinage of silver, are counting on an effect upon the Republican Party that may be quite contrary to the one actually produced. Their purpose and hope at the present time are to "bulldoze" the Republican leaders.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 13. -- The advance guard of what promises to be the largest and most exciting Democratic State Convention in the history of Ohio is rapidly coming in to-night. By to-morrow night the spacious hotel accommodations will be tested to the utmost capacity.
BERLIN, July 13. -- Mr. Walter Damrosch has left Berlin for Bayreuth. He expects to spend the entire month at Bayreuth to study the rehearsals and performances of the Wagner operas.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 13. -- The Twelfth Regiment and the four separate companies now in camp are in great luck. There has not been an hour since their arrival here when the weather has not been as perfect as men could wish for. Only those who have lived in the open air by day and under canvas at night can appreciate what that means.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Under ordinary circumstances the Giants are hard to beat, but with Amos Rusie in the box they are well-nigh invincible. This is the conclusion that the Chicagos arrived at to-night. This afternoon the New-Yorks won their second game of the series with the team captained by Adrian Chrysanthemum Anson, and they left for Cleveland to-night, after having caused sadness to reign in Cook County.

For several years successive Boards of Visitors at the Naval Academy have given attention to proposed changes in the academic course, particularly as to the best method of dividing its work among the six years which constitute it. They have naturally taken their views more or less from those which prevail at the Navy Department and at Annapolis itself in the Academic Board, as well as among officers of the navy in general.

The second week of Theodore Thomas's engagement at the Madison Square Garden began last night. The audience which gathered to do homage to the famous conductor and his orchestra was one of gratifying size. More than that, there was every evidence that the audience was thoroughly well pleased with the performance. The programme was one of those delightful arrangements of good music which Mr. Thomas excels in making. It consisted of the following excellent numbers:

The railroad Presidents and eminent financiers who compose the Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association will meet at the Windsor Hotel, this city, this forenoon at 11 o'clock. Nearly all of the members of the board were in town last evening, but they were full of characteristic reticence concerning the purposes of the meeting.

LONDON, July 13. -- The Times to-day, in a long article on the World's Fair, reviews the growth of the importance of Chicago, and says that it is not doubted that the exhibition will in many respects surpass all exhibitions previously held.

Dr. Charles R. Gill, who was years ago a well-known physician of Brooklyn, died suddenly under rather peculiar circumstances on the steamboat James W. Baldwin while on her trip on Sunday night from Kingston to this city. The doctor was just seventy years old. Owing to ill health he gave up practicing as a physician over twenty years ago.

BOSTON, July 13. -- The question of the supervision of immigration in this State is settled. The State Board of Lunacy and Charity held a meeting to-day and voted to accept the suggestions made by Secretary of the Treasury Foster upon this subject. The suggestions provide that an employe of the State Board of Lunacy and Charity be appointed as Commissioner of Immigration at the ports of Massachusetts, to serve without pay.

Of the nine members of the Board of Bridge Trustees who attended the meeting called for yesterday afternoon five were accredited to New-York and four to Brooklyn. The former were President Wagstaff and Trustees Barnes, Hillsbrand, Lawrence, and Wormser, the latter Mayor Chapin, Vice President Howell, Controller Jackson, and Trustee Barnes.

A number of well-known and philanthropic residents of this city have secured articles of incorporation for "The Industrial Christian Alliance," an unsectarian body, the avowed purposes of which are to restore the fallen and helpless to self-respect and self-support, and to give industrial and religious training to neglected children.

PARIS, July 13. -- The French naval manoeuvres in the Gulf of Lyons ended to-day in the whole fleet attacking Toulon. Ministers Ribot and Barbey, the military attaches of the American, British, and German Legations, and many Senators and Deputies witnessed the attack. Torpedo vessels and shore batteries defended the roadstead against sixty war ships, headed by a steel barbette which was extremely formidable.

LONDON, July 13. -- At the breakfast given to-day at the Holborn Restaurant in honor of the United States and British Colonial delegates to the International Congregational Council, which formally opens here tomorrow, Mr. Alfred Illingworth, member of Parliament for West Bradford, presided. Mr. Illingworth, in welcoming the delegates, said that the Liberals were pledged to disestablish the Welsh and Scotch Churches, after which the English Church would be attacked on all sides.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Proposals for entering into one of the largest contracts awarded by the War Department in recent years were opened today in the office of Gen. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance. They were in response to advertisements inviting bids for building 25 eight inch, 50 ten-inch, and 25 twelve-inch breech-loading, rifled, built-up steel guns.

The Silk Association of America is hard at work upon what it is satisfied is a case of extensive undervaluations in silks. Some months ago merchants in the silk trade discovered that China and Japan silks, and especially silk handkerchiefs, were being sold at prices which were lower than the cost price of landing such goods in this country.

It is growing more and more uncertain what the real basis of the third party movement is to be by the time the national campaign of next year opens. It has been supposed that such a movement, if it is to acquire any considerable volume, would proceed from the Farmers' Alliance, but it is difficult to say what the distinctive issue of that organization is.

BOSTON, July 13. -- The white squadron has gone. Anchors were hoisted shortly after noon to-day, and the fleet steamed down the bay, accompanied by scores of craft, large and small, the flagship Newark leading the way.

The Aldermen will talk again to-day about saving Battery Park. Their meeting promises to be the most interesting held by that body while this subject has been under discussion. They will be asked to go much further than before. Alderman John Morris and his friends think that they have waited long enough for a reply to their request for an opinion from Corporation Counsel Clark.

The gowns which Marie Wainwright is to wear in her role of Amy Robsart in "Kenilworth" have been completed under the direction of Mrs. Kelly at O'Neill's, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street. They are wonders of the dressmaker's art, as well as exact reproductions, as far as can be obtained, of the costumes of the day in which Amy lived and died.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Senator John E. Kenna, who left this city to-night for West Virginia, goes home confident that the Democrats are getting ready to win a great national victory in 1892. He says:

BOSTON, July 13. -- About a month ago, as it has lately leaked out, a few Massachusetts Democrats climbed the hill leading from the Delavan House to the Capitol in Albany and paid their respects to Gov. Hill. They met in the city, they asseverate, by chance, but they acted in concert as far as the visit to the Executive Chamber was concerned.

The Cleveland Leader, which is the newspaper that represents Mr. MCKINLEY in Ohio, published on the 12th inst. a long editorial article entitled, "Who Pays the Duty on Tin Plate?" It is a remarkable discourse, as we shall show, and we are inclined to think that it will not make any votes for the Leader's candidate in the Ohio campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Walter L. Griffin, United States Commercial Agent at Limoges, in a report to the Department of State, says that the National Millers' Association of France has just issued an estimate, founded on very carefully collected data, of the probable wheat harvest of France and Europe for 1891.

Unhappily our legislation has reduced naval architecture in this country to the adjunct of a manly sport. Before the war and the substitution of iron for timber had driven our shipping from the seas the steady advance made by American designers and shipwrights had come to form one of the most remarkable chapters in the history of shipbuilding.

President Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company has been doing business in his office for one week, presumably with the object in view of relieving that company from the serious imputations that have been made against it. Yet, in spite of the issues at stake, the policy holders of the company and the public generally have yet to learn that Sanchez has been sent for.

Perhaps the most confusing of the many confusing revelations for which the case of Dr. BRIGGS has given occasion has been contributed by Mr. RUSSELL SAGE. It appears that the eminent layman subscribed to the endowment fund of the Union Theological Seminary, and that he did so with the understanding that the seminary would be guided by the General Assembly in all matters of faith and doctrine.

CLEVELAND, July 14. -- Two strange things happened here to-day. Capt. Ewing caught and the Clevelands whipped the Giants. They did their work in the most approved style. In the first inning the local men took the lead and the New-Yorks were unable to overtake them throughout the contest.

A decision not very pleasing reading to those persons who loan money at exorbitant rates, taking chattel mortgages on personal property and household effects as security for the repayment of the loans, was yesterday handed down by Judge McAdam of the Superior Court in the case of Mrs. Lavinia Ehrgott against John S. Forgotston, who did business as the Lincoln Loan and Guarantee Association.

In its comments upon the day's business and news at the Stock Exchange one of the afternoon papers of this city said, on the 9th inst., with reference to a decline of the shares of a prominent Western railroad, that "the difficulty with" this railroad company seemed to be "its old trouble, that the inside interests are not disposed to take aggressive measures to protect their stock in the market.

Fire was discovered shortly after midnight las night in the cellars of the four-story brick tenements 268 and 270 State Street, Brooklyn. The houses were each occupied by eight families, all of whom had a narrow escape, so quick was the onslaught of the flames. From the cellar of 268 the fire made its way up the dumb-waiter shaft through the halls to the roof. The buildings were completely gutted.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14. -- H.H. Yard was brought into Common Pleas Court this morning on an attachment for contempt in refusing to obey the order of the court directing Yard to appear before the City Council investigating committee and answer questions regarding his connection with business transactions of the Keystone National Bank and with ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley.

SARATOGA, July 14. -- The first matches in the State championship contest at lawn tennis, the gentlemen's singles, were played to-day in Congress Spring Park. Mr. Stuart of the St. Augustine Lawn Tennis Club was agreed upon as referee, and it was decided that any disputed points should be settled by the Tournament Committee of the Saratoga Athletic Club.

If ante-convention indications are to be at all relied upon, Gov. CAMPBELL of Ohio will be renominated on the first ballot in the convention at Cleveland to-day by a large majority. There was no mistaking the earnestness and enthusiasm of his supporters on his arrival on the ground, and it is evident that the current ran strongly in his favor, notwithstanding that Cleveland presents a local candidate in the person of Mr. KLINE.

A form of advertisement that has proved especially alluring to the man in search of a home for his family has been that of the numerous individuals and companies which propose to furnish suburban homes on the monthly payment plan. Louis H. Schneider, whose luxurious offices in the Pulitzer Building have heretofore been an assurance of sound financial standing and prosperity with the simple-minded, has been one of the most extensive of these advertisers.

The grant of 25,000 made by the British Government to secure its official representation at Chicago is doubtless ample for its purpose. The appointment of the Prince of WALES as Chairman of the Royal Commission to superintend the expenditure of this money and to arrange a worthy exhibition of British products is an international compliment.

In view of the approaching meeting of the Ohio Democratic State Convention, THE NEW-YORK TIMES calls the attention of the party leaders in that State to an important element in the political situation there. It reminds them that the German voters "feel very strongly on the subject of the currency"; that it was they who buried the "Ohio idea" of "soft money" in 1875, and that these voters are opposed to free silver coinage.

It will be some time yet before the political conventions in this State are called, and they are not likely to be held before the month of September, but there is considerable preliminary discussion already going on, especially with reference to nominations for Governor. There is a curious difference in this discussion as it relates to the two parties.

Judge Truax, in his private chambers in the Supreme Court, yesterday held a long hearing in the case of John E. Blackman, a real estate dealer living a 113 West Sixty-second Street, this city, who has been held at Albany for the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of grand larceny in the first degree, the complaint against him having been made by Anthony Gould of Albany.

It would require an electrical expert to appraise the importance of the decision made yesterday by Judge WALLACE in a suit of the Edison Electric Light Company against the United States Electric Lighting Company. The decision is that the incandescent light used by the defendant infringes the patent of the plaintiff.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 14. -- Attorney General Tabor listened to arguments to-day in an application for him to bring an action under Chapter 400, Laws of 1890, to compel an accounting in the name of John C. Robinson, holder of Policy No. 5,809 of the New-York Life Insurance Company, by that company. Gen. Robinson is an army officer, having been in the service since 1850.

A meeting of the Indiana Democratic State Committee was held at Indianapolis last week, at which there was a full representation. Chairman Jewett says he is well pleased with the situation of the party in all sections of the State. A policy was mapped out for the Executive Committee to pursue, and all the life possible will be thrown into the political work at every place.

FLAGSTAFF, Arizona, July 14. -- A number of white men are surrounded by Navajos, and one of the worst massacres ever known in this part of the country is looked for. The scene of the trouble is thirty miles from here.

The most important thing done at the meeting of the Advisory Board of the Western Traffic Association in the Windsor Hotel yesterday was the postponement of definite action on Jay Gould's pet scheme of joint railroad agencies at competitive points. The matter came up for consideration at the forenoon session.

The fining of the sloop Flora of Seattle by the customs authorities of Victoria shows that our northern neighbors will at least co-operate in efforts to prevent the smuggling of Chinamen into the United States by the vigilant execution of their own port regulations. The secret and illegal importation of Mongolians has grown so great that the last Congress authorized the President to negotiate treaties with Mexico and Great Britain to check it.

Rain came yesterday afternoon just in time to interfere sadly with the racing at Jerome Park. It undoubtedly served to keep many from making the trip to the course; it made the track sloppy and little better than a street gutter for racing purposes, and caused a lot of owners to scratch such of their horses as were not mud-larks.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Another armor trial has just been concluded at the naval ordnance proving ground at Annapolis, and its results are fully as important as those of any in the series being made for the development of American armor plates. The object of this last test was to show what could be done with all-steel plates containing a very low proportion of carbon and treated by the Harvey process.

JOSHUA, Johnson County, Texas, July 14. -- This morning at 1 o'clock two men went to the home of George Newberry, living two miles west of Joshua, and demanded admittance. Mr. Newberry being absent, his mother supposed that it was he returning, and opened the door. The men forced their way into the house and demanded money that they supposed had been received by Mr. Newberry a few days previously.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The recent explosion of a six-inch gun on board the British cruiser Cordelia has attracted much attention among ordnance officers here. Commodore Folger, Chief of the Naval Ordnance Bureau, does not think it probable that the accident was altogether due to the weakness of the gun, though it was unquestionably of a bad type.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., 14. -- The Montclair Lawn Tennis Club had a hot day on which to begin its annual tournament to-day, but the number both of players and of spectators showed how popular the club is. The citizens of Montclair and the numerous Oranges were present in goodly numbers, and were rewarded for their trouble by seeing some excellent tennis.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 14. -- Dr. A.L. Ranney of New York City arrived here to-day from Pasque Island, where his schooner yacht Tidal Wave lies wrecked on that portion of the south shore of the island known as the "Graveyard." Dr. Ranney told the following story of how the Tidal Wave was wrecked:

Since the New-York Life Insurance Company's troubles began, frequent reference has been made to the fact that several of the Trustees of that company have for many years known that President Beers's management was, in many instances, corrupt and in violation of law. It remains to cite another instance of this knowledge on the part of a Trustee, the gentleman in this case being William A. Booth.
LONDON, July 14. -- The trial of R.C. Duncan of Washington, D.C., on the charge of attempting to murder his wife at Bettws-y-Coed, North Wales, in May last, was held at Carnarvon to-day.

The United States Electric Lighting Company, and through it the Westinghouse Company, which owns it, received a defeat yesterday in the decision against it of the suit brought by the Edison Electric Light Company on the patent for the incandescent electric lamp. Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, filed his opinion in the suit sustaining the patent and ordering a decree for an injunction and an accounting.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14. -- There is much commotion here among yachtsmen over the new enforcement of the old revenue law, which provides that all foreign-built vessels owned by Americans shall pay 50 cents for every ton of tonnage on arrival at any port outside the revenue district from which the vessel sailed.

ROME, July 14. -- The French Ambassador to-day, receiving the members of the French colony upon the occasion of the French national fete, said that he regretted the "passing malentendu between Frenchmen and Italians." The Ambassador then begged his hearers to work for the entente, which certainly would eventually bring the two nations into the path of their common destiny.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday showed more consideration for Corporation Counsel CLARK than he has shown for the Board of Aldermen. It asked him a month ago to furnish, "at his earliest convenience," a legal opinion as to the right of the elevated railroad to occupy Battery Park and the steps that should be taken to terminate that occupancy.

The Aldermen were very tender of the feelings of Corporation Counsel Clark when they met yesterday, and on the plea of wishing to refrain from any discourtesy to him they declined, by a vote of 14 to 9, to adopt a resolution offered by Alderman John Morris directing him to proceed against the elevated roads in Battery Park.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 14. -- The Democratic State Convention is fairly on. Delegates and their friends and the supporters of the various candidates have been pouring into town all day, and to-night the hotels are crowded and the streets thronged. The Hamilton County delegation, accompanied by several hundred Neal men, came in at 7:30 o'clock this morning, and immediately reported at the Neal headquarters at the Weddell.

Upward of one hundred men of the force usually employed at the Public Stores were idle yesterday. These laborers had struck because a dozen of their companions had been suspended the night before for refusing to work on trucks arriving after the usual hour of closing.

Two men were instantly killed and two more were injured yesterday while unloading dynamite cartridges for blasting from the tramp steamer G.R. Booth, lying at the foot of Richards Street, South Brooklyn. The steamer arrived from Hamburg last Friday with eighty packages of dynamite cartridges consigned to Simpson, Spence Young of New-York.

The suggested race between the Oxford and Harvard eights, to be rowed on the Thames in September, would be to college oarsmen a most interesting event. The contest between these universities twelve years ago was one of fours only, and, while the American boat was easily beaten, it is admitted that Oxford had an exceptionally strong crew that year.

Postmaster General WANAMAKER in inviting proposals for carrying the mails in "American vessels" under the Subsidy act of last March has laid out a scheme which, if carried into effect, would exhaust the resources of the Government in encouraging shipping, which its general policy so fatally discourages. This is supposing the Government to have resources not already exhausted.

The exposure of Philanthropist Schneider's peculiar monthly installment building operations has apparently come none too soon for the welfare of a good many other people. It is now said that his methods in the Reece case, an exposition of which was made in yesterday's TIMES, were followed in nearly all of his recent building operations.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Col. G.L. Gillespie, Corps of Engineers, in charge of the river and harbor improvements in New-York Harbor and its vicinity, has submitted his annual report to the Chief of Engineers. In the Hudson River the dikes between Troy and New-Baltimore have been repaired and 21,000 feet of dike along the east shore of the river at the Mull's Plaat constructed by contract.

Gov. CAMPBELL'S prediction that he would be nominated on the first ballot in yesterday's convention at Cleveland and would receive three votes for every one cast for both the other candidates came very near being verified. He received 508 7-16 votes out of a total of 700, and the fifty-six delegates who voted for KLINE joined heartily in support of the motion to make the nomination unanimous.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- The work of attaching the property of the S.R. Howell Lumber Company, which was begun yesterday at Omaha, Neb., and Atchison, Kan., by the First National Bank of this city, was completed here to-day, when C.M. Charnley, representing the bank, took possession of the property in this city on a claim for $200,000. The firm's attorney says it can pay dollar for dollar and have a surplus of $500,000 left.

Alice Rosenberg and Mary Bittner were caught Tuesday at Ridley's while, as alleged, they were shoplifting. The rooms where the Rosenberg woman lived with her husband were searched and goods that it is thought were stolen were found to the value of about $1,000. In the Essex Market Police Court yesterday the women, with Rosenberg and Samuel Saferston, were held to await further examination.

BOSTON, July 15. -- The ways of Census Superintendent Robert P. Porter are past finding out. His Census Bulletin No. 82, giving alleged comparisons of the cost of municipal government in many of the larger cities of the country, has excited a great deal of adverse comment here, and ex-Mayor O'Brien and Mayor Matthews throw discredit upon it.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 15. -- The bad feeling that exists between free and convict labor whenever they come in contact has culminated in decisive action on the part of the free miners at Briceville, Anderson County, Tenn. Some months ago the miners at that place struck, and as neither side has made concessions the mines have been idle.

St. John's Guild opened its twenty-fifth season yesterday by taking 914 mothers and children from the hot, tainted atmosphere of their tenement homes on an all-day trip in the invigorating ocean breezes of the lower bay to the seaside hospital of the guild, near New-Dorp, on the south shore of Staten Island.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15. -- Ex-Senator Thurman was called upon to-night by THE TIMES'S representative and found in the best of humor and comparatively free from the rheumatic grips and darting pains to which he has been so long subjected. Judge Thurman was reading the proceedings of the convention with the keenest interest and was manifestly pleased with the work, as his first words after the salutation, "How do you do!" were:

Apparently Controller MYERS leaves Census Superintendent PORTER without any excuse for error in his permanent tables and statements of municipal finances regarding the "ordinary" and the "administrative" expenditures of government of this city. There is no reason for doubting the accuracy of the Controller's figures, but it is difficult to understand the enormous disparity between them and those of the Census Bulletin, if an honest effort was made to secure correctness in the latter.

ST. LOUIS, July 15. -- The State Democratic Committee held a fully-attended meeting to-day for the purpose of electing a new Treasurer. J.H. Finks, a banker of Salisbury, Mo., was chosen. State Senator Jasper Burks was selected to a vacant seat.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 15. -- The Democrats of Ohio have named their ticket, and the most interesting and important political contest of the year has formally begun.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15. -- If Gustav Blum had communicated with his friends instead of hiding himself for three weeks in a New-York hotel he would be alive to-day and the head of his old jewelry firm, with renewed prospects of success. In this city he had a number of moneyed intimates who would have been glad to put him on his feet.

An incendiary fire yesterday morning destroyed the block extending from the Central Hotel to the electric light station in Altoona, Penn. The guests of the Leonard House escaped with their effects, but the building was gutted. The loss will be about $2,500, with no insurance. Other losses are: Besant Henneman, wholesale grocers, $15,000, insurance 7,000; George F. Street, hides and leather, $13,000, insurance $5,100; James C. Watts Co., commission merchants, 5,000, insurance $2,000.

Controller Myers sent his answer yesterday to Superintendent of the Census Porter in refutation of the bad showing that is made for New-York City finances in Census Bulletin 82. The letter is accompanied by sheets of figures giving details of the city's financial history for the year 1889 in two forms, one according to the bookkeeping system of the Finance Department and the other in line with the comparison adopted in Bulletin 82.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Postmaster General to-day issued the advertisement of the mail lettings under the Postal Aid bill passed by the last Congress. It invites proposals from steamship companies for carrying the American mails to foreign countries, in vessels of American build, of the best construction, and of the highest speed in their respective classes, over routes minutely described.

ABERDEEN, S.D., July 15. -- The matter of the appointment of an administrator in the estate of Mrs. May Dayton came up in the County Court yesterday. Ex-Attorney General Hahn of Minneapolis represented James C. Reed of New-York, the son, and Attorney Luze of Aberdeen Lyman C. Dayton, the husband. After some wrangling, the matter was continued until Sept. 14, though a special administrator of the Dakota property will be appointed.

The Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art some time ago appointed a special committee "to extend the museum collection of casts," and that committee last Winter issued a circular, in which the general objects and scope of the work were set forth. It was shown what had been accomplished by the Royal Museum at Berlin and other institutions in making up by casts for their deficiency of original works which were unprocurable.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15. -- The joint meetings of the New-Jersey and Pennsylvania State Dental Societies were opened here to-day. A resolution was adopted favoring the holding of a dental convention in Chicago during the World's Fair.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 15. -- For two days the thunder has been roaring about the mountain tops that overshadow this tented city. The weather has been such as one can only experience in the mountains. Black rain-laden clouds have every now and then rolled over the camp and heavy showers have kept the soldier boys on a continual jump, fastening down their tents and getting themselves and their effects under shelter.

SARANAC LAKE, July 15. -- The opinion prevails here that Dr. W. Seward Webb has somewhat modified his idea of crossing the State lands. As now proposed, the line will extend from Malone to Wolf Pond. The roadbed is laid to within a short distance of the State lands, which it was proposed to enter. From this terminus the track can be extended to Wolf Pond without waste of distance.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 15. -- Mrs. Mary Collins died here last night at the age of 101 years. She was born in Ireland.

JACKSON, Miss., July 15. -- The Democratic State Convention met in Representatives' Hall to-day and was called to order by J.S. McNeilly. R.H. Thompson of Lincoln was elected temporary Chairman, and T.M. Henry and B.E. Wilson temporary Secretaries. The organization was afterward declared permanent.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 15. -- Controller Staub, who has been in consultation with counsel here during the week in regard to the different State departments and institutions which can be supplied with funds in the absence of specific appropriations, left for his home in New-Milford this afternoon. He stated, as he was starting for the train, that the matter had been settled.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- In spite of the fact that Gov. Campbell was renominated against the wishes of the Democrats who voted for Hamilton County in the Cleveland Convention, it is evident to-night, from the tone of Republican comment here, that the candidate of the Democratic Party is regarded by Republicans as not only a dangerous opponent of Major McKinley, but that he is reasonably certain of an election.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- It was rumored to-day that E.H.R. Green, son of Mrs. Hettie Green, intended to buy a newspaper in Chicago. Mr. Green was seen in regard to the matter at headquarters in the Clifton House, and said:

While the Chippewas of Minnesota have an intelligible cause of complaint, if it be true that a large sum promised to them in cash is to be paid in plows and cattle, yet the sensational reports of a threatened outbreak among them must be received with caution. The settlers have more than once of late raised the outcry that the Chippewas were on the warpath.

The white squadron is here. At 6 o'clock last evening every vessel in the fleet was swinging to her best bower in the North River. The seven cruisers are lying in a line stretching all the way from the foot of West Twenty-third Street to the foot of West Sixtieth Street.

CLEVELAND, July 15. -- New-York won here to-day It was a close game, however, and the Giants came out ahead by making a grand spurt in the seventh inning. Both Rusie and Viau were hit hard. Capt. Ewing watched the game from the players' bench. He thinks that he will be able to play regularly hereafter.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 16. -- A letter from Durango, Mexico, says that Sunday, July 5, the cornerstone of the new Methodist Church was laid there in the presence of the American residents and a throng of Mexican converts. The American Consul was present, and the Revs. Gilmore, A. De Leon, and R.C. Elliot officiated. Several Catholic priests were among the spectators who crowded the streets.

Capt. J.F. Anderson of the firm of Anderson Barr of Brooklyn, was in New-York yesterday, having just returned from the point off Cape Hatteras, where had been engaged in an attempt to sink the big caisson, which he designed to be the foundation for the lighthouse for which the Government appropriated $500,000 two years ago.

In putting out a tenemen-thouse fire early yesterday morning, at 69 Ludlow Street, the firemen broke a gas-pips in the cellar. The fumes of the escaping gas overcame Assistant Foreman Lawrence Reilly, who quickly recovered, however, upon being removed to tho air. Then an employe df the Consolidated Gas Company, Thomas Gmilivan, went Into lhe cellar to mend the break.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Ernest Dale Owen of Chicago claims big damages in a suit begun today in the United States Court against John T. Boyd, the Nevada Bank of San Francisco, John O. Steinberger, and L. Osborne. The plaintiff asks $2,300,000 for trespass. Mr. Owen is trustee of the estate of the heirs of Jose Ygnacio Rouquilla, who was once a rich Mexican grandee.

ATCHISON, Kan., July 16. -- W.R. Smith, attorney for George W. Howell, member of the firm of Howell Brothers, the lumber company which failed yesterday, has made a statement concerning his client's affairs. Mr. Smith says the failure was caused in part by the failure of the Jeffersonville Lumber Company, which was a heavy debtor of the Howell mill at Jeffersonville for $400,000, no part of which has ever been paid.

The British device of inquiring into the labor question by means of a royal commission that should represent all "shades of thought" on the subject does not seem to be very successful. Lord DERBY, the Chairman of the commission, had yesterday, for at least the second time, to "clear the room," though in this case the necessity of that extreme measure was not obvious.

We notice that some curiosity is expressed by several of our contemporaries as to the fortunes of ex-Senator HENRY W. BLAIR, who started for China some time ago and then returned to Washington because the Chinese Government had caused it to be known in that city that his room was preferred to his company.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., July 16. -- At 4 o'clock this afternoon the fiercest electrical storm ever known here, accompanied by a gale lasting more than five minutes, destroyed a number of buildings, and in the collapse of one of them five lives are known to have been lost. Perhaps as many more bodies lie under the ruins.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Col. D.C. Houston, Corps of Engineers, officer in charge of the river and harbor improvements in Long Island Sound and its tributary waters, has submitted his annual report to the Chief of Engineers of the army.

To outsiders Grinnell, Iowa, is chiefly remarkable as being the scene of the dreadful cyclone that wrought such havoc in this peaceful community nine years ago. Some forty lives were sacrificed in that fearful disaster and thousands of dollars' worth of property was destroyed. The average Grinnell citizen loves to tell about this cyclone; it is an event in his life never to be forgotten.

The Philadelphia Press gives the following as the explanation of Mr. WANAMAKER'S 625 shares of the Keystone Bank stock: "One certificate for 625 shares was regarded by the brokers as too large to be easily negotiated, so they sent it back to the bank for three or four smaller certificates for the same amount.

Eighty-eight half-pound cases of opium were sealed with the Government seal at the Custom House yesterday. The lot was seized by Special Agents some time ago at the establishment of of Wing Who Chong, at 34 Pell Street, on the supposition that it had never paid duty. A day or two ago the case was tried, and the Chinaman won it.

Judge Mayham of the Supreme Court has filed an interlocutory judgment overruling the defendant's demurrer in the suit of George B. Gallup against August Belmont and others, associate members of the American Kennel Club of New-York. The club is made up of forty-five kennel, dog, and live stock associations all over the United States.

The Boston Herald (Independent) says that while it may not be profitable to speculate upon an event so very unlikely to happen as the failure of the Democrats to nominate Mr. Cleveland for the Presidency, it will venture the prediction that if Mr. Cleveland is rejected it will be William C. Whitney and not David B. Hill who will be taken up.

LONDON, July 16. -- The Foreign Commission of the Columbus Exposition, consisting of Major Moses P. Handy of Chicago, Mr. A.F. Bullock of Massachusetts, ex-Congressman Butterworth of Ohio, Judge W. Lindsey of Kentucky, and Mr. F.S. Peck of Chicago, arrived at Southampton to-day by the Hamburg-American steamship Columbia.

SEA GIRT, July 16. -- To-day was the big one among the National Guard campers here. The Thursday of the camp is always notable for being Governor's Day. This Thursday was notable as being the two Governors' day. Gov Hill of New-York was on hand to divide the honors of the occasion with Gov. Leon Abbett of New-Jersey.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16. -- Gov. Campbell arrived home from Cleveland this morning, and at once resumed his duties at the Executive office. He was the recipient of hundreds of congratulatory telegrams from all parts of the country, predicting his success in November.

Mr. PORTER of the Hartford Post has made a reply to the letter of Mr. LYNDE HARRISON addressed to him a week ago, in regard to the action of the special committee on the canvass of votes of the Connecticut House of Representatives. Mr. PORTER'S reply is devoted mainly to personalities and to questioning the veracity and the motives of Mr. HARRISON.

The long expected happened Wednesday night as the outcome of the bitter fight in the Hoboken Turtle Club over its expelled Treasurer, Capt. Alonzo T. Decker. At a dinner given by Mr. Decker to about thirty friends it was decided to establish a new club in opposition to the old Turtle Club, one which shall have a house in this city open all the year round, as well as a country villa for dinners.

HARTFORD, July 16. -- Editor Porter of the Post to-day made public his reply to the attack by Judge Lynde Harrison of New-Haven upon the House Elections Committee, of which Mr. Porter was a member, for its action in the matter of State officers. It is written in vigorous style and denies in detail statements made by Harrison.

Prof. F.W. TAUSSIG presents in the Quarterly Journal of Economics a clear and interesting discussion of the theory which determines the rates charged for transportation by railway companies. Doubtless the practice has grown out of the exigencies of traffic without much reference to scientific theories, but the principles which have determined it, whether consciously or unconsciously to the managers, may nevertheless be deduced with some approach to accuracy.

KANSAS CITY, July 16. -- The First National Bank of Wyandotte or Kansas City, Kan, suspended business to-day and is in the hands of Bank Examiner. J.D. Wilson, President of the bank, is very reticent concerning the cause of the failure and the condition of the bank. He does say, however, that the assets are $200,000 and liabilities $100,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 16. -- Thirteen men were removed from their places in the Capitol to-day to make room for that number of Sheehan and Hill heelers. Their removal is not the worst of it. In addition every man is charged with violation of rules or dereliction of duties.

Jerome Park had more of a crowd within its inclousure yesterday than on any day since the Monmouth Park Racing Association began racing there. The weather was none too hot for comfort, as there was a good breeze, and as the racing was of a fair quality those in attendance had a pleasant afternoon's outing. Four of the races were won by favorites, the other two going to rank outsiders -- Temple and Peralta.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 16. -- The members of the Catholic Church of St. Agnes, recently erected in this town, proposed to hold a fair early in August for the benefit of the church, and the Rev. John H. Fox, rector of the Seabright Catholic Church, communicated with the Women's Christian Temperance Union, asking the use of their temple here and offering to pay the usual rental therefor.

PITTSBURG, July 16. -- It required fifteen heats to decide the three events at Homewood Park to-day, and the monster crowd that thronged the grounds was well repaid for patronizing the trotters and pacers. The track has improved considerably and was quite fast, five horses improving their records, including Strader H., Abbie V., and the pacers Bavelli, Min Young, and Frank Dortch.

ORANGE, N.J., July 16. -- There is loud complaint among the Italians imported recently into this city to work on the sewers, They say that they paid a padrone named Costro $2 each for their employment on his assurance that their wages would be $1.75 per day. When they reached here they discovered that they would receive but $1.25 per day.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Senor Montt, the representative of the Chilean Congressional party here, has received the following telegram from Iquique, Chile, dated yesterday, from Errazuriz:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Census Superintendent Porter has replied to Controller Myers, but his talk about the request and tabulated statements is so evasive and hostile as to encourage the opinion first formed by many persons -- that the statistics concerning the cost of maintaining city governments were intended, in the case of New-York, to give that city a disadvantageous position beside all the other cities of the country.

To-day the Shoals are given up to the Laightons and their Summer guests. They are the sole owners of the entire group, and their great hotels and the adjoining cottages represent a property of half a million dollars. The Laighton family is closely identified with the isles. About half a century ago Thomas Bell Laighton was defeated in a New-Hampshire election.

The second and last session of the Medical Congress at Prohibition Park, near Port Richmond, S.I., was held yesterday. The attendance at the morning, afternoon, and evening meetings was small, but the papers read were interesting and the discussions were animated. President N.S. Davis of the American Medical Temperance Association of Chicago, Ill., who presided Wednesday, was again in the chair.
BOSTON, July 16. -- The Oweene has won the two-hundred-and-fifty-dollar cup for forty-six-footers in the one hundred and thirty-seventh race of the Massachusetts Yacht Club.

The application of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad for a differential on freight business to St. Paul, similar to that allowed the West Shore in connection with the Canadian Pacific route, has for the second time been denied. The matter was recently referred by the trunk line Executive Committee to Commissioner J.F. Goddard for arbitration.

In THE TIMES Wednesday morning it was said that the New-York Life Insurance Company had adopted a new system of computing its assets. Besides being new, the system referred to is easily seen to be dishonest. In the case of that $110,000 worth of Third National Bank stock, which appears under two quite different cost values, an instance of this form of pliant bookkeeping was shown.

Mrs. Lizzie Mussbaum, the wife of Joseph Mussbaum, a German plasterer, living at 242 East Eighty-fifth Street, was terribly burned last evening by the explosion of a can of benzine, and her husband was also seriously burned while endeavoring to extinguish the flames. Mrs. Mussbaum was using the benzine in a bedroom, and it is supposed that the fumes of the benzine took fire from a burning gas jet.

CLEVELAND, July 16. -- Cleveland won another game from the Giants to-day. As Chicago won from Boston, the New-Yorks left here to-night second in the race. The contest to-day was marked by heavy batting on the part of the local men. They gauged Keefe several times and hit his curves hard and often.

LONDON, July 16. -- At the session to-day of Committee A of the Royal Labor Commission, Mr. Hubbard, Chairman of the committee governing five of the largest docks, and employing nearly 10,000 men, was examined.

A Chinese leper was discovered yesterday by Sanitary Inspector Dillingham running a laundry at 403 Fifth Street. Singular to relate, the health authorities, having nowhere to place him, were obliged to allow him to continue running his laundry. The leper's name is Chin Hop Sing, and he has been in this city about a year and a half.

LYNN, Mass., July 17. -- Lynn had another taste of fire to-night, and at 10:30 it looked as if the firemen had more than they could cope with. Fire broke out in the third story of Blake's brick block, corner of Union and Mulberry Streets, at 9:50, and in twenty minutes had spread to the five-story block adjoining, owned by Strout Brothers, and threatened the entire street for a distance of 200 feet.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Cheap works of art are to be barred from the World's Columbian Exposition. The fine arts display, Chief Ives thinks, will be the finest ever collected, certainly the finest ever gotten together in America, and in order to make it all that it ought to be strict rules for the admission of exhibits have been laid down.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 17. -- President William Weihe of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, who came here to endeavor to settle the trouble in the Niedringhaus Rolling Mill, talked to a reporter in an interesting strain to-day.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 17. -- Frank Patterson, the manager of the Grand Opera House at this place, was arrested to-day by Detective Callahan of Newark, charged with passing a worthless check on Erasmus Munch of Newark. Patterson was arraigned before Justice Wyckoff and was placed under bail for a hearing next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- There is great activity to-night at the cavalry armory on New-York Avenue. The Washington Troop is completing the arrangements for the march into Virginia, which, in company with a detachment of Troop A of New-York, it is to begin to-morrow morning.

In the course of the revelations concerning the New-York Life Insurance Company's affairs there has been frequent reference made to the fact that following the Banta investigation $250,000 was loaned Trustees who sat on that committee of inquiry. It is now learned from an authoritative source that the sum referred to is only about one-fourth of the total loans made to the Trustees following that whitewashing.

PARIS, July 17. -- The rebuff which the Government received yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies, when it was decided by a vote of 286 to 203 to discuss the interpellation of M. Laur, the Boulangist Deputy, who asked the Government to explain the manner in which the Alsace-Lorraine passport regulations were enforced, has caused a great deal of excitement throughout France.

The Indianapolis Journal is one of the high-tariff papers that are now trying to make their readers believe that there were no reductions of wages in large manufacturing concerns last Winter and last Spring. This latest manifestation of McKinleyism shows that the followers of MCKINLEY will stop at nothing.

The scene of racing shifts from the winding track at Jerome Park to the hills and dales of Morris Park, where an excellent card of seven races is down for decision. The stake fixtures are the Tyro, for two-year-olds, for which a dozen starters are named, and the Midsummer Handicap, at a mile, for which ten horses have accepted the weights.

Humid weather is good fishing weather as a rule. Salt-water anglers say so and the freshwater-bait casters agree that it is just right for the big black bass. Weakfish, especially, are fond of the warm, muggy days, and take apparent delight in biting at such times. So it was no surprise when the news came up from Prince's Bay that the weakfish were abundant and that large catches were being made.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Chief of Engineers of the Army has received the annual report of Major Milton B. Adams, Corps of Engineers, in charge of the improvement of the St. Lawrence River, of Ogdensburg Harbor, of harbors on Lake Champlain, and of Grass, Great Chazy, and Ticonderoga Rivers, New-York, and Otter Creek, New-York.

The inquiry made in the House of Commons as to whether the starting of so many new lobster-canning factories on the French shore of Newfoundland had not been undertaken with a view to getting compensation for having them closed by the Government suggests a peculiar form of colonial enterprise.

There is going to be a shaking up of the dry bones at the Public Stores. The recent strike of the laborers employed there has hurried something which otherwise might have been delayed for some time. As matters now stand there is every chance for a new set of officials at the head of the establishment.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 17. -- The Princeton College geological expedition of 1891 starts from New-York City Monday. The students who have been selected for the work are Arthur William Butler, '92, Yonkers, N.Y., Treasurer; Imlay Benet, '92, Brooklyn, N.Y., Quartermaster; Edwin Augustus Stevens Lewis, '91, Hoboken, N.J.; Richard Coulter, Jr., '92, Greensburg, Penn.; James Frederic Hosford, '92, Kinderhook, N.Y.; Cyrus Church Jefferson, '92, St. Paul, Minn., and Robert Alston Stevenson, '92, Lewistown, Penn.

The outrageousness of Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER, Superintendent of the Census, must have become rather wearisome even to those who profit by it, either personally or politically. It has been very signally illustrated in his controversy with the Controller of this city respecting the rate of municipal expenditures for New-York.

ATCHISON, Kan., July 17. -- Many bankers and lawyers representing Eastern creditors of S.R. Howell and George W. Howell and the several firms with which they are connected have arrived here. The First National Bank of Chicago still has possession of the property, but a fight is inevitable and both sides are getting ready for it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 17. -- Congressman John Dalzell, who wants to be President of the organization, will fight in convention the action of the Executive Committee of the State League of Republican Clubs in deciding to exclude all clubs not on the roll in 1890 from the Scranton meeting. Mr. Dalzell said to-day:

The trial of Stephen P. O'Hara, official bond clerk to the Long Island City Board of Excise, on the indictment charging him with exacting $250 over and above the regular license fee from John A. Sonntag, was continued before Judge Garretson in Long Island City yesterday. The story told by Sonntag on the witness stand impressed everybody as truthful. It was not contradicted by the defense.

Just as the sun was slipping down into the ocean last evening, the Hon. John Simpson, who bosses the Republicans down in the Sixth District, sauntered into the corridor of the Oriental Hotel at Manhattan Beach, nodded to Thomas C. Platt, tossed a smile to Stephen B. Elkins, shook hands with Russell B. Harrison, said "halloa!" to Bernard Biglin, and immediately afterward dropped into a state of dire disappointment.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Census Office issued to-day a bulletin in regard to the gold and silver production of this country in 1889. After speaking of the impossibility of getting trustworthy information of the multitude of individual prospectors, the bulletin says:

A funny little race was run yesterday afternoon on the Sound off New-Rochelle. It was extensively advertised with maps and red ink as a special handicap race for naphtha launches under the management of the Cherry Diamond Yacht Club, but it turned out to be a little scrub affair, with a minimum of management and a good deal of uncertainty among the contestants at the end as to who had won after all.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 17. -- This being the next to the last day of camp life that the boys of the Twelfth Regiment and the four separate companies from Yonkers, Troy, Rochester, and Whitehall will see for two years, they made the most of it. From morning until night they were going, and when taps sounded they were as tired a lot of men as can be imagined.

Ex-Mayor William R. Grace said yesterday that the complaint in the suit that Guillermo Bogardus of Lima, Peru, had begun against him, M.P. Grace, and Charles R. Flint, by the filing of his complaint in the United States Circuit Court, had not yet been served on him or his attorneys, Coudert Brothers. Mr. Bogardus had, however, been threatening for about three years to bring one.

The jubilation in London on Thursday over the passage of the Copyright act in this country was undoubtedly sincere, and it was undoubtedly justified by the facts. The keynote of the proceedings of the Society of Authors was struck by the message of TENNYSON, beyond question the first English man of letters.

There has been considerable talk among railroad men about Jay Gould's attitude toward the Western Traffic Association since the Advisory Board of that body declined to carry out his wishes with regard to the joint agency scheme at the meeting in the Windsor Hotel last week. President Cable of the Rock Island Road is credited with having led the opposition to Mr. Gould in that meeting.

DETROIT, Mich., July 17. -- Between 4,000 and 5,000 people witnessed the first day's racing of the twelfth annual meet of the League of American Wheelmen at the Driving Park this afternoon. The day was an almost perfect one, save for the wind, which was dead against the riders in the stretch The event of the day was the riding of Banker and Brinker of the Buffalo Athletic Club for the half-mile tandem record.

The bright, clear evening, thoughts of fresh breezes from over the bay, and of promenades along the sea wall, and the prospect of hearing good music brought one of the largest crowds to Battery Park last night that has gathered in that historic spot in the course of the Summer.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, July 17. -- President Scott of Rutgers has selected the subjects for prizes for the three upper classes. The Freshman list will be, as usual, two entrance examinations, one $100 and a scholarship, and the other a scholarship and $50.

Cornelius N. Bliss, who has been so generally talked of recently as the probable Republican candidate for Governor, absolutely refuses to have his name considered in that connection. It has been apparent within the last few days that the leaders hereabout would select him to present to the convention. To head off any such course, he sent the following self-explanatory letter to Horace Russell yesterday:

S.C. Millett will play W.A. Larned this afternoon in the final singles of the Montclair tennis tournament. In the doubles Larned and W.V. Johnson will be opposed to J.F. Hobart ant R.R. Perkins of the New-York club, and in both of these contests close matches may be looked for.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 17. -- Col. L.F. Livingston, President of the Georgia State Alliance, publishes in the Evening Journal of to-day a modification of the Sub-Treasury plan. Coming as it does in the midst of the meetings being held by the Alliance, which have a national character, the declaration is taken to mean a good deal.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 17. -- A deputation of sealing men waited upon Sir George Baden-Powell and Dr. Dawson on board the steamer Danube yesterday and presented a memorial setting forth the loss sustained by the prohibition of sealing. They stated to the Commissioners that they had not received any official notice of the closing of Bering Sea, and consequently they had continued to prepare for the season.

Anything at all that tends to bring our navigation laws into ridicule and contempt ought to be welcomed by intelligent patriots. For that reason the official ought to be congratulated who has exhumed a statutory requirement that "an undocumented" yacht shall be compelled to pay "light money" to the extent of 50 cents a ton whenever she enters any port outside the revenue district in which she is owned.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 17. -- The white Republicans in this State, who have been out of politics since the overthrow of their party in 1876, encouraged by divisions in the Democratic ranks, are coming to the front again. A secret meeting was held in Columbia last night which was largely attended, and the coming campaign was fully discussed and numerous plans were decided upon.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 17. -- President Harrison to-day held his first public reception by the shore. While the reception was public, it was really intended for a special party, and but few others attended it. The steamer Republic brought a large party from Chester, mainly composed of the Third Pennsylvania Cavalrymen, with their wives and families.

There was a very large audience at the Madison Square Garden last evening. Whether it was because Mr. Thomas's programme was very pleasant to hear or because the naval celebrities from the white squadron were to be present and be interesting to see it is impossible for any one except a mind-reader to tell.

SARATOGA, July 17. -- Ex-Senator Warner Miller of Herkimer is at the United States Hotel. He is in this region on private business, and will leave for his mills in the Adirondacks in the morning. When asked about the letter of Cornelius N. Bliss, he said:

The Cincinnati Commercial Gazette unwisely ventures to make a few more remarks about tin plate. There is a "theory," it says, "that tin plate is now higher than it was," but "facts do not bear out the assumption." Where was that theory when the Commercial Gazette was explaining that the advance in price was due to the exactions of "The Welsh Trust"?

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The contracts for educating Indian children in Catholic schools for the current year are being made by the Indian Office directly with the schools instead of through the Bureau of Catholic Indian Missions, as heretofore. The amount awarded to the Catholic bureau for this purpose last year was $360,000. The amount given to the individual Catholic schools this year will aggregate more than $400,000.

PITTSBURG, July 17. -- Homewood Park's good luck did not desert it to-day, for the weather continued clear, and the third big crowd of the week came to see the farewell appearance of the Grand Circuit fliers. The announcement that Nancy Hanks would try to beat Sunol's record helped to draw, but Dobb did not consider the mare ready for such an effort, and decided only to show a fast mile.

The good shooting of Miss LEALE at the Bisley Range suggests the possibility of a rush of her sex into this form of competitive sports. It is obviously one more easily taken up by women in general than some that require greater muscular strength, in which, nevertheless, not a few of them have excelled.

In the Summer of 1861 there began in the upper counties of East Tennessee a reign of terror. In many respects there is no fairer region on earth than is found in the beautiful valleys of the Holston River. The country is peculiarly picturesque end enchanting. But for many years the clouds of ignorance and prejudice hung over the lovely land, and its people suffered on all sides in consequence of the teachings of leaders.
LYNN, Mass., July 18. -- The following is the additional insurance upon last night's fire:

Bell and I had been in the swamps, woods, and mountains for thirty-seven days, but immunity from recapture did not abate our vigilance; indeed, as we neared our own lines and came within sound of the Union guns we became more careful and eager than we were even on that stormy night in June when we eluded the guards at Millen.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 17. -- John Jager, who runs a large Polish boarding house here, was committed to jail to-day on a charge of stealing $400 from Stephen Subun, a boarder. On July 2 Jager called at Police Headquarters and said his place had been entered by burglars and $975 taken, of which $575 belonged to him and the rest to his boarders.

HANOVER, N.H., July 18. -- As Miss Christie Warden, accompanied by her mother, her sister Fannie, and Louise Goodell, was returning on foot to her home, situated one mile from the village, at a late hour last night, Frank Almy, about thirty years of age, jumped into the road in front of them and seizing Christie by the arm, said: "I want you."

LONDON, July 18. -- The feature of the week's session of the International Congregational Council was the speech of the Rev. Dr. Walker of Melbourne condemning Unitarianism, which, he said, was making tremendous headway among Congregationalists. Dr. Walker said he would rather drift toward the Church of England or the Church of Rome than toward Unitarianism.

While our inconsistent but entertaining neighbor, the Tribune, is trying to apply to the table-glassware industry its doctrine that existing Trusts should be destroyed and the making of new ones should be prevented by an increase of tariff duties already prohibitory, it may find time to look hastily at certain developments in the oatmeal industry.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 18. -- Chancellor E.H. Snow and Prof. E.A. Popenoe, who were commissioned to look into the grasshopper scare in Eastern Colorado and Western Kansas, have finished their work and sent in the result of their investigations from Arriba, Col. They say in part:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 18. -- The lovely weather that still prevails here tends to keep Richfield's little world out of doors, and evening entertainments are scarcely given a thought. Driving is the popular recreation. J.H. Schults, Jr., of Brooklyn has one of the largest stables here. Frank Beard and C.M. Clark have another large stable, including several racers who always win the County Club's running purses.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 18. -- The Rev. A. Lincoln Shear of Athens has accepted a call from the Central Congregational Church of Chelmsford, a suburb of Lowell, Mass. He will preach his farewell at Athens on Sunday, and on the next Sunday, by special invitation, in Winthrop Congregational Church in Boston.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., July 10. -- For the past year the name of Dick Bassett, the only inhabitant of a little island in Grand Traverse Bay, has been quite prominent in leading newspapers throughout the country. The stories that have been told of him have been interesting and romantic, but wholly unlike his real life.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- A number of United States Senator Quay's close political friends asserted publicly to-day that Quay will resign the office of Chairman of the Republican National Committee at its next meeting, which, it is said, will be held in this city in September.

The customary relief of the British fleet in North American waters by new assignments of vessels and crews for a tour of duty there has apparently been made the occasion for slightly strengthening it. The total number of vessels may remain the same, but the new armor-clad to serve as flagship will be larger and more effective than the present one, and so it is with substitutes among the unarmored cruisers.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July l8. -- It has been a delightful though uneventful week at Cooperstown. The weather, though at times a trifle warm despite the cool lake breezes, has on the whole been charming, and the gayeties, while not on an extended scale, have been sufficiently numerous to occupy the idle time not taken up by Cooperstown's standing pursuits -- boating, driving, and fishing.

A recent departure in obtaining extra draught for furnaces on steamships without the use of blowers or other devices has been successfully tried on the Scot of the Cape Mail Line. This vessel has been furnished with smokestacks 120 feet high above the grates. The increased draught is equivalent to a water pressure of three-fourths of an inch. The vessel's peed is nineteen knots.

NORSEMEN IN IRELAND. -- It was in Dublin Bay, in the year 851, that the divided currents of seafaring aggression met, after making between them the circuit of Great Britain. Not without much eddying of battle and red spray of slaughter was their coalescence effected, little to the advantage of their common victims. During fifty-six previous years the Norwegian first-comers had had the harrying of the country all to themselves.

There is something queer in the way the big men of the Republican Party in this State take to their heels at the suggestion of their names for the nomination for Governor this year. A while ago Mr. DEPEW was all the talk, but Mr. DEPEW has gone abroad, and is said to have refused to be a candidate before he left.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Provisions made a sharp advance to-day though it was all lost before the close. Quite a professional short interest had been developed during yesterday's decline, and this was forced to cover because of the very light receipts of hogs at the yards. Pork was relatively stronger than lard at all times.

The experiences of yesterday and a week ago would seem to indicate pretty plainly that the Monmouth Park Association is sadly in need of new blood or new life in the management of its affairs. A week ago there was a muddle over the Rey del Rey-San Juan race that will not soon be forgotten. Yesterday there was another muddle over the fifth race for which there seemed to be no good excuse.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- There is absolutely nothing new to record in the theatrical annals of the present week. All the down-town playhouses have settled into the easy jog of Summer runs, and while all have done an excellent business, nothing worthy of note has occurred.

The importance of the hay crop to the prosperity of the country is very great, but when a considerable portion of it is raised in the neighborhood of Wall Street the brokers don't find much prosperity in it for them. A large and flourishing growth of grass might now be seen about the Stock Exchange, or might be so far as any business doing there would interfere with its growth.

AMERICAN WORKMEN. -- Every one agreed that the American skilled artisan puts forth more physical effort and produces more work in a given time than the English workman or the workman of any other manufacturing community. This fact struck me and many experienced directors of works most forcibly.

A writer in the Christian Union, commenting on the sad drowning of brave young BROKAW, is undecided as to whether the athlete's parents are to be commiserated or congratulated on his loss. This writer is of the opinion that a stigma would have rested on the name of BROKAW if the young man had not plunged into the surf to save the drowning servant.

MANCHESTER, July 18. -- The team representing the Manhattan Athletic Club of New-York made its farewell appearance in this city to-day previous to its departure for home. The Americans secured three of the events and a second place.

Near the head of a long canon in Southern Oregon there is a great cave. Two openings give access to it. These openings look like small fissures in a big limestone bluff. This limestone extends for miles. It looks as massive and solid outside as any mountain in the world, but it is honeycombed like a pile that has been exposed to the teredo for years.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 18. -- The Canadian cattle trade is perhaps on the whole the most important interest in the country. Last year it amounted to $8,000,000, the number of head carried being 130,000, giving an average of $60 each. This trade had its origin fifteen years ago, when 200 head were shipped on the European.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 18. -- Owing to its proximity to the Cuban ports, New-Orleans is monopolizing the importations into this country of West Indian sugar.

New-Yorkers who are fond of comparing their city with London will find an unusually fertile field of analogies and differences in what is called the "day" census of London. Both the American and British national censuses are residential. That is, they are supposed to show where people have their homes.

ASBURY PARK, July 18. -- The hot wave that swept over the big cities this week sent thousands or persons shoreward, and Asbury Park received its share of the pleasure seekers. Everything has been lively about town and the prospects for a profitable season are much brighter than they were last week.
ALBANY, July 18. -- Controller Wemple continues to show his contempt for the civil service law and to violate its provisions.

Year after year athletes break records, and naturally the question suggests itself, When is this record making going to stop?
