In all classes of athletics -- running, walking, jumping, vaulting, putting the shot, throwing the hammer and weights, and rowing -- the young men of to-day as a rule are far superior to the muscular chaps of half a dozen years ago.

MOLD ON JAM. -- One of the forms most familiar to us ill home life is the Mucor mucedo which attacks our jam. I saw pretty specimen of this a couple of years ago, when visiting a country house in Shropshire. I was called into the storeroom of my hostess to condole with her on the moldiness of her jam.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 18. -- There is a prospect that the campus of Princeton College, which now embraces over two hundred acres, with great natural advantages in elevation, woodland, and streams, will soon be properly mapped and developed. Provision will not-only be made for building sites, but these natural advantages will be preserved and utilized, making the campus in its entire extent a handsome park.

A possum hunt in the heart of the city possesses the charm of novelty. Early on Thursday morning, when the streets in the vicinity of Washington Square and University Place were filled with persons on their way to work, a great commotion was caused by yells from a man who was seen tearing wildly down University Place, preceded by a strange looking little beast with its ears flattened down.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 18. -- The ball last night at the Grand Union Hotel, given by Col. Woolworth to the ladies and gentlemen of the Lawn Tennis Association at present in this city, was thus far the event of this season. Col. Woolworth's young wife received those who came. The costumes of the ladies were beautiful and the display of diamonds dazzling.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN ALFRED'S TIME. -- As might be supposed, the earliest book that is assigned to the child is the Latin grammar. Boys' Latin grammars for several centuries were mere text books compiled from the larger works of Donatus and Priscian, and they were commonly known by the name of "Donates" or "Donets," a term which occurs in "Piers Plowman."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 18. -- The Baptist Church at Hamilton, N.Y., has invited the Rev. Cornelius S. Savage of Ogdensburg to fill its vacant pastorate. He was graduated from Brown University and the Rochester Theological Seminary, and has filled his present charge at Ogdensburg for five years.

THE ENGLISH THEATRE, AS A CHINESE SEES IT. -- "When an actor first appears upon the stage he must remove his cap and incline himself toward the seated audience as a mark of courtesy. The audience then dram upon their hands to signify their approval An actor who has gone off the stage must appear again, and by bowing toward the audience express his thanks.

RED BANK, N.J., July 18. -- The farmers of Monmouth County will make big profits this year. Last year was a fair one, but it was as nothing compared with the present season. The prices generally are high, and the crops in most cases are large. The cherry crop was immense, and despite the abundance of this fruit the prices ruled high.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 18. -- The trotting season is now on in Kentucky and the trainers in and around Lexington are making use of every moment in the preparation of their horses. While very little extra fast work has been done this week, all the candidates for race and 2:30 honors have been worked out with more than usual care.

The annual club book of the American Yacht Club made its appearance last Thursday. Between its cream-colored covers there is a world of information for yachtsmen, and in point of quality -- that is to say, arrangement -- as well as quantity the little volume has no superior in its line. By way of a frontispiece there is a first-class view of the clubhouse and club grounds at Milton Point.

WATCH HILL, July 18. -- This pretty peninsula had an unusual attack of fog the earlier part of the week, it coming and going two or three times a day, and the unusual phenomenon was not regarded with the warmest admiration by the hotel guests who wanted to go yachting, or by the weather-seamed tars who run pleasure boats. The hotels are filling up, however.

Some very ugly and wry-faced rumors concerning the management of the New-York Life have been filling our ears of late. Moreover, they have great persistency, are not light and feathery, but heavy and leaden.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 18. -- Official advices from England confirm a recent intimation by cable that the Imperial Government will indemnity the Canadian sealing schooners for losses sustained by the adoption of a close season in Bering Sea. This decision on the part of the home authority is regarded as a good one, as it will tend to allay the popular outburst of British Columbia occasioned by the unexpectedness of the recent international agreement.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Mr. Edwards, the American Consul General here, has invited all the American Consuls in Germany to a conference in this city with Herr Wermuth, the Imperial Commissioner, to the World's Fair to be held in Chicago. The Consular body will also meet the American committee which is now in England. Numerous public receptions are being arranged to be hold during the presence of the committee in Germany.

George F. Parker, who is reported to have committed suicide in his London lodgings Thursday night, was well known to the police in this city. His photograph in the Rogues' Gallery, No. 1,729, shows a face strongly in contrast with the average run of low-browed, heavy-jawed faces that abound in this collection of criminals.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- The Hon. W.A. West-Erskine of Adelaide, South Australia, who is in this city on his way to Europe, thinks the labor question is bound to cause great trouble in Australia. Referring to the trouble with the striking shearers in Queensland last Spring, he said it amounted to a veritable revolution.

THE EARLY HOME OF THE EMPRESS JOSEPHINE. -- Just outside the little town of Fort de France, stretching down from the quaint, narrow Rue Victor Hugo to the purple blue waters of the bay, lies a spacious grass-grown square, set round with spreading tamarind trees and bathed all day in the glorious sunshine of the tropics.

The movement in favor of Pattison is a movement in favor of an impossible candidate. The Democracy of the Union would not consent to the Governor's nomination at this time, no matter how much success the men who are engineering the scheme might have in securing delegates in this State. The fact must not be overlooked that, when the next President shall be inaugurated, Gov. Pattison will have served out but half of his term.

Just before A.M. Palmer took down the historic name of Wallack from the unfinished theatre at Broadway and Thirtieth Street to make room for his own name, two gentlemen, unquestionably New-Yorkers, were passing down the opposite side of the street.

The death of no one man, not even of John C. Stevens, the first Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club, and fifty years ago the most active and able promoter of yachting in this country, nor yet of George Steers, the first distinctive yacht designer this country produced, has ever so thoroughly arrested the attention of the yachting world or caused such widespread and genuine regret among American yachtsmen as the death of Edward Burgess.

LIVERPOOL, July 18. -- A terrible accident occurred this morning along the line of the Manchester Ship Canal. A train passing along the railroad running near the canal fell over the embankment near this city, killing eleven men who were working under the heading. In addition to the men killed, many other workmen were injured.

NEW GRAND HOUSE, SUMMIT MOUNTAINS, N.Y., July 18. -- There was another rush of mountain travel up the Hudson to-day. It was lucky for the steamboats and mountain resorts that the severe rainstorm which has been raging all the afternoon did not begin till late in the morning, for if it had travel would have had a black eye.

With Jay Gould sick with the neuralgia, C.P. Huntington out of sorts with malaria and rheumatism, and John D. Rockefeller under treatment for nervous prostration, it is not to be marveled at that Wall Street men ask, "Are our great financiers breaking down?" Within the past six months the respective Presidents of two big trust companies have been advised that they must either abstain from business cares or retire from all association with common humanity.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 18. -- The yellow fever at Chandeleur Quarantine Station, twelve miles off the Mississippi shore in the Gulf of Mexico, is reported as spreading. It was brought there by a vessel from Rio de Janeiro, and there have been ten cases, with two deaths. Additional supplies of sulphur, charcoal, and other disinfecting materials have been shipped to the island from New-Orleans.
ST. LOUIS, July 18. -- The Hon. U.S. Hall, President of the Farmers' Alliance of Missouri, says:

DOGS ON MONEY. -- There is an important group of about forty coins containing outlines of dogs, which deserve careful study. The interest of some of them is mainly mythical, as with Laelaps, the hound of Actaeon, presented to Cephalos by Procris; or with the dog of Segeste, which symbolized the river Crimisus. But there are enough to show how extensive were the operations of the dog fancier in early times.

Grammar School No. 20, in Chrystie Street, near Delancey, must have been built over an old churchyard, judging from the great quantity of human bones unearthed in the cellar of the building in the last week. The boiler room and furnaces are in the cellar of the school. Extensive repairs were ordered to the apparatus there during the Summer vacation and work was begun last Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Commissioner Morgan has received, under date of July 8, a letter from Father Chappelle, the Vice President of the Bureau of Catholic Indian Missions, in reply to that sent by the Commissioner giving notice that the Indian Office declines to enter into a further contract with the Bureau for the Education of Indian Children.

A recent dispatch from London states that German military aeronauts have gone to the island of Heligoland to experiment with captive balloons, with a view to making use of them for naval purposes. The first experiments by the German Government in the employment of captive balloons for such purposes were made last September on board the gunnery practice ship Mars.

The cool, dim shadows of early dawn still clung to the leeward side of things as old Cap'n Joel made sail on the little sloop. A mild breeze came up from the southward and stirred into lazy life the vagrant patches of mist that hung here and there on the surface of Great South Bay. Away out in the solitude of water the lighthouse on Fire Island loomed faintly against the rosy sky.

Moliere had the hatred of men of the the-tre for book men, an explicable hatred: the more learned readers the less pleased theatregoers. The book men have given their wittiest, profoundest, and handsomest works in praise of Moliere; Was there over nobler revenefulness!
NIAGARA FALLS, July 18. -- There is an unusually large number of guests at the International Hotel. Among those registered are:

LONDON, July 18. -- Mrs. Sarah Newell Atkins, who has been engaged in literary work upon American newspapers and who has also acted in several theatres, has obtained a divorce here on the ground of cruelty and adultery. Mrs. Atkins is the daughter of a lawyer of San Francisco, Cal.

It is well known that the cruiser Philadelphia, flagship of the North Atlantic squadron, will be ordered in the course of a few days to proceed to Halifax. From Halifax, it is said, she will take a run over the fishing grounds, and then proceed up the St. Lawrence River as far as Montreal.

BOSTON, July 18. -- The fight within the ranks of the Republican Party on the question of the Gubernatorial nomination is still far from settlement. There is no decided preference on the part of the leaders or even of the voters. Crapo has made some gain, but he is handicapped by the too frequent use of his name. He has been a candidate constantly since 1883. His name has become tiresome and almost offensive.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- The case of Henry H. Yard, charged with contempt of court, in not appearing before the City Council's committee of investigation, was up again before Common Pleas Court to-day, but was not finally disposed of. The decision of the case hinged on whether or not the writ of certiorari taken out by Yard's attorney was a supersedeas and stayed further proceedings in the lower court.

Fresh-water fishing resorts near the city are much fewer than those on the coast or the saltwater tideways and rivers, and the angling is just about as uncertain for the most part. There are, however, many who love to go out on the fresh-water lakes and rivers, and for their information a few places where there are known to be some fish will be given in this article, as well as directions for reaching them.

The trouble experienced in getting good firemen for the navy was never so great as it is at present. Firemen are not only reluctant to enlist, but the great majority of those who do apply are of an inferior grade. The trouble in this respect is not confined to the United States Navy. Last week's dispatches announced that the British Admiralty, in sheer despair, had had to call on the marines to do firemen's duty.

Mr. Neilson does not pretend to trace back to the beginning trial by combat. Its origin was, "Might is right." The strongest savage exercised his brute strength in the dawn of the world, and, when he killed his weaker adversary, established the justice of his cause. In a modified form, when two Englishmen come to fisticuffs to settle a difficulty or popinjay German students swing and slash schlaegers, primeval ferocity once more establishes its sway.
This letter was received on Friday by George L. Betts, a stenographer, of 33 Wall Street:

The dinner to CLARKSON at Coney Island on Friday night does not seem likely to have any tremendous political effect. If it does, it will be of the boomerang kind. "Boss" PLATT'S jubilant introduction of the guest as a man who has "cut off many heads" was one of those maladroit performances that men are liable to who lack moral sensibility and assume that others are as callous as themselves.

As a constant reader of your manly, straight- forward, and ever able paper, I wish to send a word from the West on the subject of the Treasury and its statements. There is a desire here to keep track of how the funds of the Government stand, but it can't be done by a frequent change of method of putting the figures before the public.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 18. -- The warm weather of this week made the keepers of resorts in the Catskills smile. There was a large influx of boarders, and boats and trains reaching this city were heavily laden.

NO OBSTRUCTIVE WIRES IN PARIS -- It should be noted that the question how to dispose of wires -- a question that makes so vast and so continually recurring an agitation in all American cities -- never comes up at all in Paris, and is seldom mentioned in any European city. There are absolutely no obstructive wires in Paris.

We had heard a great deal in general about the "other concerns" that, like the Tribune's mythical tin-plate establishments, "had glutted," or were about to glut, the markets of this country with their great output of tin plate. We had chased them along every road to which the index finger of enthusiastic correspondents had pointed as their established home, and found them, like castles in Spain, to fade into thin air.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., July 18. -- Increased passenger traffic to the Thousand Islands has arrested the attention of another steamboat line. The Lora of Rochester has been added to the Lakeport and St. Lawrence service, and her initial trip was made last Tuesday. She is owned by George A. Buck and C.S. Stowell of Rochester, F.W. Wheeler of West Bay City, and John Morrow of Cleveland. She has been running between Buffalo and Cleveland.
LONDON, July 18. -- The Cobden Club, at a meeting last night, adopted a report which declares:

Very remarkable is the news that comes from China. Within a short space of time, less than a month, the foreign missions at Nanking, Wuhu, Tang Yang, Kin Kiang, and Wusueh have been raided by mobs and burned. Ching Kiang, Hart Kow, Soochow, and even Shanghai have been threatened with attack.

PARIS, July 18. -- The Chamber of Deputies today approved the remaining clauses of the tariff relating to the temporary free admission of certain imports. The entire new tariff measure was then passed by a vote of 387 to 110.

A little further investigation of the operation of the McKinley tariff on importations of tissue paper demonstrates that the increased duty was only another legalized job at the expense of the poor consumer. The former tariff was 25 per cent. ad valorem; the McKinley act increased it to 15 per cent. ad valorem and 8 cents per pound. On the lower-priced papers the increase amounted to over 130 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has prepared a statement of the probable production of sugar during the current fiscal year, of which the following is a summary:

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 18. -- The post changed hands again to-day. The Twelfth Regiment of New-York and the First, Fourth, Sixth and Ninth Separate Companies of Rochester, Yonkers, Troy, and Whitehall, which have occupied the camp for the week past gave up their tents this afternoon to the Eighth Regiment of New-York and the Seventy-fourth Regiment of Buffalo.
PARIS, July 18. -- The Chamber of Deputies today rejected the proposal made by M. de Freycinet, President of the Council and Minister of War, to grant the sum of $120,000 to the Ecole Polytechnique.

ANTIQUES AND FORGERIES. -- Good gems of the period of Phidias are rare; there is an excellent one, of a lady reading, in the British Museum. The Romans took to making regular collections of gems, dactyliothecae. Julius Caesar and Marcellus dedicated such collections in temples, which also served the purpose of museums.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 18. -- There is not an empty cottage at Hopatcong. Each of the pretty villas about Mount Arlington Park and the surrounding hills is as gay as a city house in midwinter season. The cottagers and guests alike are very fond of the water, and spend much of their time afloat. Mrs. Crooks of San Francisco gave a launch party early in the week for her daughters.

The seizure by the Dominion cruiser Dream of several American fishing boats belonging to Eastport is a reminder of the almost total eclipse thus far during the present season of what used to be a fiery and menacing dispute in that region. Instead of the many arrests of American fishing schooners which created so much excitement a few years ago, the season has passed until now in profound quiet all along the Dominion coast.

Earl De La Warr, in the House of Lords, wanted to know whether her Majesty's Government could not make some regulations to prevent inflammable substances being carried on board passenger ships. Lord Ravensworth interposed a protest against stringent rules being enforce which might increase rather than diminish the causes of accidents at sea, inasmuch as such restrictions did not exist in the case of foreign vessels.

Writing of the death of Mr. W.H. Gladstone, the London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian says: "His nature was essentially modest and retiring. He almost studiously concealed what was in him, and habitually did himself much less than justice. His mind moved slowly; he had no rhetorical gifts, and his utterance was naturally guarded and deliberate.
The following letter was received by an employe of the Times from his father, and is of such general interest that we give it to the public:

The Farmers' Alliance in Maryland seems to be working very much as it worked in South Carolina before the election of TILLMAN. It is not working as a third party or for an independent ticket, but is seeking to control the action of the Democratic Party. It has a favored candidate for Governor, but he is a Democrat, and the Alliance intends to secure his nomination by the Democratic Convention.

The North River, from Twenty-third to Forty-second Street, presented a stirring sight yesterday. At an early hour an admiring throng began to line the water front, and it gazed with curious eyes at the stately ships of the squadron of evolution, whose milk-white sides showed in sharp contrast to the dark waters of the river.

The testimony given at the inquest and the report of the State Inspector of Railroads tend to change some of the opinions that were expressed immediately after the collision on the Erie Road at Ravenna, and that seemed then to be well founded. It is clear that the rear brakeman of the passenger train should not alone be held responsible for the killing of nineteen persons, although he did not do his whole duty.

Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER'S census appears to be marked by bad work in almost every department of the investigation. The New-York Tribune has recently pointed out some inexcusable blunders in the work relating to the products of California. The Engineering and Mining Journal, an accepted authority in its field, now asserts that the bulletin relating to the production of lead and zinc is not what it should be.

BALTIMORE, July 19. -- "Can Senator Gorman afford to allow the Alliance to dominate State affairs even if his own election is assured?" This question is raised by the Baltimore Sun, and the answer is left to its readers.
The Philadelphia North American has the following highly original statement:

A dispatch published in THE TIMES yesterday from Rochester with reference to the fares which may legally be charged by sleeping car companies was the first intimation that there is a State statue which fixes the maximum charge for berths between points in this State at 80 cents.

PARIS, July 7. -- M. Antoine has finished his season at a very late hour, and he has seen fit to postpone all the sensational novelties until another season. The Theatre Libre will still hold court at the Menus Plaisirs during the theatrical term of next year, but after that a move to the Vaudeville is contemplated.

Saturday morning THE TIMES briefly alluded to President Beers's system of blacklisting the policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company. The particular case referred to happened in Kentucky. Since its publication another case has come to light here in this city, and the experience is that of a gentleman whose reputation is well and favorably known.

Whatever one eats, the material of which goes to compose the body is made to grow by the light and heat of that heavenly orb. Upon its effulgence the plants depend for their development, and upon things vegetable all animals must rely for food. Thus it may be said that every man or woman represents a certain quantity of stored solar energy.
PARIS, July 19. -- The press is generally satisfied that M. de Freycinet will not resign the Premiership. The Siccle says:

A young man named Robert Howe, or De Ford, was a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday upon a charge of having stolen a quantity of diamonds and jewelry, claimed in all to amount to $10,000. He had as an accomplice, it was alleged, a young woman, whom the detectives of Inspector Byrnes's staff are now searching for.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 19. -- When seen at his home in Beaver to-day, United States Senator Quay talked very frankly concerning his attitude on the Republican National Committee Chairmanship.

The architectural aspect of New-York City is in a state of perpetual evolution. In its history yesterday is hardly remembered, and of the day before we have only the faintest recollection. It is always essentially of to-day. Building after building has gone down, and at no very distant period the "Story of a New-York House" will be a matter of ancient history.

The much-talked-of clambake constructed by "Bab," as every racing man calls Capt. W.R. Babcock, was served at Morris Park yesterday to a crowd that was both hungry and enthusiastic before it sat down to the bake -- enthusiastic only when it had finished. "Bab" made a reputation among horsemen a year ago when he served one of his famous bakes at the Linden track, which had not then been turned into farming land.

The report of mob violence in China which has recently reached San Franciso evidently refers to the original outbreak at Woo-Hoo, which had already been fully described. The only addition of consequence is a confirmation of the fact that two foreigners were killed there, one being an English customs officer and the other a member of the Methodist mission.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Gazette publishes to-day an extraordinary paragraph touching some of the startling stories about Mr. Blaine's recent bad health. "A friend of Secretary Blaine" is quoted as saying:

The refusal of the State Board of Normal School Regents yesterday to grant a certificate to Dr. Searles of Oshkosh to his son who died a few years ago calls fresh attention to a case that is without precedent. Dr. Searles's son attended the normal school at Oshkosh in 1887, and his scholarship not being up to the standard, President Albee refused to grant a certificate.

John Thomas Clarke is a sailorman who makes a living and manages to save a little something as steward of the handsome yacht Vito, owned by Lawrence Brown of Narragansett. His savings after his last pay-day left him with $150 in his pocket. Clarke had great confidence in real estate about Yonkers, so Saturday he left the Vito and went up to Yonkers.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 19. -- The Picayune's West Point (Miss.) special says: "A suit involving property worth over $100,000,000 will shortly be filed in the courts of New-York City, and Col. H. Clay King of Memphis and Mr. T.C. King of this city, his brother, are deeply interested in that suit. It will also be of great interest to a large number of people in Tennessee, Mississippi, Arkansas, and Texas, relatives of these gentlemen.

A new distinction has been conferred upon the influenza epidemic. In London was issued a fortnight ago a Parliamentary report on the experiences of Englishmen under the prevalence of that disorder during the years 1889 and 1890. The tendency of the English mind to take serious views shows itself in this report, which is an exhaustive and painstaking public document, illustrated with maps, tables, and diagrams.

We give in our Cleveland dispatches this morning a report of the views of several members of the Committee on Resolutions of the Democratic Convention as to the free-coinage resolution. It is clearly the opinion of those who were in a position to know that the resolution was adopted as a matter of expediency.

BAIREUTH, July 19. -- The Baireuth performances always begin at 4 in the afternoon, and last until about 10, with two one-hour intermissions for rest and supper. Accordingly, this afternoon at 3 a procession of carriages and pedestrians lined the way from the town to the hilltop, where the Wagner Theatre is situated conspicuously, commanding a fine view of the mountain scenery.

Ever since the Fall of 1886 the Democracy of this State has been fed on the phrase "I am a Democrat." At the time it was first uttered it created a great sensation in certain quarters of the Democratic Party, particularly in those sections where the office seekers were hungriest and most rabid. Its object was purely a sinister one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19. -- It has been known here for several days that the friends of Senator Sherman were seriously disturbed by the unseen but formidable hand of ex-Gov. Foraker, in not only the make-up of the State Committee, but in the various Senatorial districts.

TRENTON, July 19. -- James Smith. Jr., the head of the Essex County machine men, is probably beginning by this time to see that his recently-published diagnosis of the Presidential sentiment of the New-Jersey Democracy was not an entirely accurate one. He was rash enough to declare that there is no marked public feeling in the State in favor of the renomination of Mr. Cleveland. But then he said it with a reservation.

The collection of souvenir spoons in the jewelry stores has recently had two new ones added to its number. One of these, which has been completed, is the George W. Childs spoon, so called in honor of the publisher of the Public Ledger, whose portrait it bears. The other, which is nearly completed, is known as the war spoon, because it is to be ornamented with counterfeit presentments of Gens. Grant, Sherman, and Sheridan.
The following interesting account of a recent occurrence in Naples is abridged from the report printed in the Naples Pungolo:

Benjamin R. Spelman, Jr., recently cashier of the Twenty-sixth Ward Bank, Brooklyn, has disappeared, and an examination of his accounts shows that on leaving the bank he was short at least $3,000. On account of intemperate habits he had been requested to resign, which he did May 30. He then went to Albany, and has now disappeared from that city.

Charles P. Thompson, a Danish sailor, who lodged at 79 Washington Street, killed himself with a pistol some time Saturday night on the lighter Cuba, at the West Twenty-first Street dock. His body was sent to the Morgue.

Three little children, all with curly hair and all wonderfully clean compared with the crowd of tramps and petty criminals who were crowded about them, were in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. Their eyes were bright and they were apparently as happy in the dirty, ill-smelling place as if they were on a picnic.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 20. -- Political circles are excited over what is regarded as an open rupture between Sherman and Foraker. The latter is quoted as having denounced the conduct of the Senator's friends as impertinent, and is known to have sent a very pointed message to the Senator himself.

BOSTON, July 20. -- The British bark Olive Mount, Capt. Foley, hence for Satelo, Ga., was discovered abandoned and on fire last night, twenty-five miles east of Scituate, by the tug William Sprague. The fire was extinguished by the tug and the vessel towed to this city. The bark is damaged about $2,000.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 20. -- The crisis in the labor troubles at Briceville came to-day at about 11 o'clock, when the miners and a crowd of sympathizers from the country surrounded the camp of the State militia, captured the troops and convicts, marched them off to the station, put them on a train, and shipped them to Knoxville.

BOSTON, July 20. -- Dr. James W. Babcock, assistant physician at the McLean Asylum in Somerville, has been appointed Superintendent of the State Asylum at Columbia, S.C. He was born in Chester, S.C., thirty-five years ago.

The Committee of One Hundred, appointed to look after the preservation of the Battery and other parks as pleasure grounds for the people, will soon be called together for organization. Such delay as has occurred is to be explained simply. All the members of the committee are busy people, and such time as has been given to the movement has been voluntary and at some sacrifice.

Pauline L'Allemand, one of the prima donne for the Casino next season, arrived from Europe yesterday. Her first appearance in that house will be made on Aug. 17, in the role of Fantasca, in Johann Strauss's opera entitled "Indigo." Miss L'Allemand was seen at the Casino yesterday afternoon while busily engaged in rehearsing the music for the new production.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 20. -- Bergen Point Lawn Tennis Club of this city opened a prize tournament for club members here to-day. The Avenue A courts were in prime condition, and the contestants had Several spirited encounters. Miss Anna W. Voorhees, Charles S. Coleman, and Sidney L. Smith were the committee. Entries vare divided into three classes, with allowances.

WURTSBOROUGH, N. Y., July 20. -- The people in Sullivan and Orange Counties to-day commemorated the battle of Mamakating, better known as the battle of Minisink. The history of the event is substantially as follows: In October, 1778, Col. Joseph Brant, the Mohawk Chieftain, incited by the Johnstons and bloodthirsty Tories, made his first attack on the inhabitants of this portion of the country, killing the Swartwouts and others and carrying away much plunder.

ST. LOUIS, July 20. -- An application for a pro-forma decree of incorporation, filed by the Deutsche Oesterreichischer Unterstutzuage Verein von St. Louis, a proposed Austrian Society, was filed in the Circuit Court and referred to Col. Patrick Dyer for reference. Attorney Dyer made his report to-day. He recommends that the decree be refused, and gives his reasons to the court as follows:

MONTREAL, July 20. -- Dispatches receives in this city to-day reported that the Donaldson Line steamer Circe was ashore at East Cape, about the most southern part of the island of Anticosti. The report caused a good deal of talk among merchants and on 'Change, as the Circe was bound from Glasgow to Montreal, having left the former port July 11.
PARIS, July 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. P.D. Armour of Chicago arrived here to-day from Carisbad.

ELIZABETH, July 20. -- The Street Commissioner, acting under orders from the City Council, will to-morrow open First Street, the main business thoroughfare of Elizabethport, across the Central Railroad coal tracks.

A largely-attended public meeting was held in Battery Park last Friday night, with the consent of the Park Commissioners of New-York, to protest against the occupation of that pleasure ground by the elevated railroad and to demand that the structure be "promptly removed." A committee of one hundred was appointed to carry on the crusade for the rescue of the park from the clutches of the Manhattan Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The announcements concerning Quay's resignation do not change the situation very much from what it was last Winter before the Republican leader made his general denial to all the accusations of the press and the speech of "Bob" Kennedy of Ohio.

Racing will be resumed at Jerome Park this afternoon with seven races on the card for decision, and all with light fields. The features will be the Colleen Stakes, for two-year-old fillies, and the Barnegat Stakes, for three-year-olds, Potomac and Montana being announced as starters in the latter. The probable starters in the several events are as follows:

FORKED RIVER, N.J., July 20. -- There is great fishing now in Barnegat Bay. Many persons from New-York, Jersey City, Newark, and other places in this State were on the bay yesterday, and catches of 75 to 15O weakfish to the boat were by no means uncommon. One party from Jersey City, consisting of five men and two boys, took over 200 weakfish.

BAIREUTH, July 20. -- Max Alvary, of all the artists to-day assembled at Baireuth the most popular in America, is rapidly becoming the most popular Wagnerian tenor in Germany. He lives in a charming villa near the Wagner Theatre, and from his windows commands a grand view of the Franconian Mountain. His rooms are adorned with trophies of his vocal triumphs in a dozen German cities.

A crowd of horsemen that filled the salesroom of Tattersall's assembled last evening to see the sale of the Fairview yearlings, the property of Charles Reed Sons. It was a good lot of youngsters that were offered, and the bidding for them was very lively in several instances. The thirty-seven animals sold fetched a total of $55,950, an average of $1,512, much better than even Mr. Reed had expected.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 20. -- The Central Bank of Kansas City, Kan., failed this morning. The collapse was due to the failure of the First National Bank, which was taken charge of by the Bank Examiner last Thursday. The liabilities are $35,000; assets, $65,000. R.W. Hilliker is the President and cashier of the bank. The bank was organized under the State law.

The Secretary of the Republican Club of Massachusetts recently sent a circular letter to members of the club in which in roundabout way he asked what the Republican Party of Massachusetts should do to be saved -- on what issues it should go to the people this Fall. Replies have come in from most of those to whom the circular was sent.

The "boss" method of regulating party affairs is so prevalent and so persistent among the Republicans of Pennsylvania that it threatens to create serious trouble in the State League of Republican Clubs, which is supposed to be auxiliary to the regular party organization. The meeting of the league is to be held at Scranton next month and a President is to be chosen.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 20. -- The Times of this city will to-morrow print a dispatch from Philadelphia containing much information concerning Gov. Pattison's political plans, secured from undoubted Democratic authority. The dispatch says:

Two members of the Republican National Committee -- A.L. Conger of Ohio and R.G. Evans of Minnesota -- were in this city yesterday. If the States which they came from indorse the sentiments that they uttered, there is a remarkable unanimity on several interesting questions in the Middle, West, and the Northwest.

It was daylight when most of the visiting Turners went to bed in Brooklyn yesterday morning, and yet there was no sign of the fact when they gathered at their several appointed rendezvous for their grand parade a few hours later. They were in four divisions, formed in the side streets out of Bedford Avenue, west of Broadway, Brooklyn.

PEEKSKILL, July 20. -- Gov. Hill gave the camp a surprise this afternoon, and as a consequence one member of the Second Battery is in the hospital, badly wounded by the premature explosion of one of the twelve-pounder Napoleons with which the salute to the commander was being fired, and another is suffering severely from burns and a lacerated and contused arm.
A correspondent of the Evening Post makes the following statement:

Another thing that is reported to affect the mind of the President greatly when considering the case of his unfortunate Postmaster General is the ardent devotion manifested toward him by Philadelphians. We are not surprised at this devotion, and we are far from thinking that it is solely the fruit of Mr. WANAMAKER'S liberal advertising.

Charles S. Thompson, a resident of Hartford, Conn., and a member of a well-known family in that State, committed suicide at the United States Hotel yesterday by putting two bullets in his head, one just under the ear on the left side and the other in the left temple.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 20. -- The finals in the Englewood tennis tournament, postponed from Saturday, were played off on the club courts this afternoon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 20. -- District Attorney Stephens of Denver reached this city this evening, having been detained in Chicago on business. He talked quite freely, but denied that his visit to Providence had any significance in connection with the Barnaby murder case. He has come East for a social visit, and will stop at Block Island and other Eastern Summer resorts. He will probably remain East for a month to come.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 20. -- The annual regatta of the Lake Yacht Association took place to-day off Ontario Beach. The first-class start was as follows: Vreda, Onward. The Oriole was in this class, but did not start. The Onward had scarcely crossed the line and was getting under sail when her topmast was carried away. She was undaunted, however, and bravely kept on her way.

Through his lawyers, Bristow, Peet Opdyke, J. Edward Simmons, as a receiver of the American Loan and Trust Company, applied yesterday to Judge Barrett of the Supreme Court for permission to pay a dividend of 35 per cent. to the preferred creditors of the company. W.J. Lardner was there to represent the Attorney General. Judge Barrett took the papers.
Up to a late hour last night Martin B. Waller, the Secretary and Treasurer of the Long Island Brick Company, had not returned to Greenport, although President Sage said he expected him.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 20. -- To-day's developments in the mining troubles at Briceville have caused all the immediately available military in the State to be called out by Gov. Buchanan, and to-night not less than fourteen companies of the National Guard, well armed and equipped, are hurrying toward the scene by special train.

The present squabble in Samoa seems to differ from former "political crises" in that island in not having been instigated by foreigners. The American, German, and British Consuls have united in a proclamation sustaining the monarch de facto, and that is the best evidence we can have that he is also a monarch de jure.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 21. -- To-day in the Ocean Grove Sunday School Assembly has been devoted to reviews and examinations. Mrs. B.B. Palmer conducted an exhaustive review in her boys' and girls' class, and as a result eleven passed, fourteen received honorable mention, and thirteen were recorded perfect. The children will receive their diplomas to-morrow.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 21. -- The fifth annual meeting of the New-York State Hotel Men's Association assembled this morning in the Grand Union Hotel. President W.D. Garrison of the Grand Union Hotel, New-York, presided. Among those present were the Hon. J.H. Bagley, Jr., of the Prospect Park Hotel, Catskill; W.G. Leland of the Hotel Bennett.

There is something rather ludicrous in the rumpus which some of the good people of St. Paul., Minn., have created over the sparring exhibition which a local athletic club has arranged to take place to-night. As we understand the matter, it is to be an exhibition match between two pugilists with gloves, in which neither of the conbatants is likely to be much hurt.

It is probable that the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred appointed to save the public parks as pleasure grounds for the people will shortly be called together for the purpose of issuing a statement by which the public may be informed generally of the course to be pursued by the committee in fighting the elevated road in Battery Park.

Something of a sensation was created in Wall Street yesterday by the announcement that the St. Paul Railroad had been obliged to borrow of New-York banks something like $2,000,000 in order to meet current interest due on its bond indebtedness. The Street was surprised that officers of the St Paul Company did not attempt to deny the report.

A big crowd gathered in front of THE TIMES Building, on the Park Row side, about 7 o'clock last evening to watch a man flourishing a dusting brush in one of the plate-glass windows on the street floor. A policeman saw that something was going on and elbowed his way through the crowd.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 21. -- The Governor's office at the Capitol was besieged at 10:15 o'clock this morning by a mob of 500 people. It was the same crowd that last night swarmed over the lawns and trampled down the flower beds in their frenzied rush. They wanted to see Gov. Merriam, and without ceremony pushed through the outer offices to where sat the Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Army officers are watching with interest the conflict between the striking miners and the State militia in Tennessee, apprehending that the failure of the latter to cope with the miners may result in a call upon the National Government for troops. In this case it would be difficult for the War Department to meet the demand in time to secure the protection of the convict miners.

By just one run Ward and his men won from the New-Yorks yesterday. On account of the closeness of the scores the game, at times, was interesting, but it was not well played by any means. On the contrary, some stupid work was done by both teams, and the errors were numerous. One misplay by D'Rourke in the last inning gave the Brooklyns the winning run.
St. Louis, July 21. -- Affairs at the Niedringhaus Rolling Mill are at a standstill. The striking workmen are still out and many of them are seeking employment elsewhere.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- A dispatch from Milwaukeee says: "A meeting at Elkhart Lake, a few weeks' acquaintance, and an elopement terminated in the marriage in this city of Miss Alene Loeb of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Count H.F. von Blucher, a son of Prince Blucher von Wahlstatt and a great-grandson of the old Marshal Blucher who turned the tide of battle at Waterloo.

The statement that the owners of the site of the famous Valley Forge camp, of Revolutionary memory, are about to sell it is once more repeated. It has seemed strange to some persons that there should not be enough local patriotism or interest in Congress to purchase it and hold it as a public park.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 21. -- President Harrison received this morning one visitor who could not be classed with the usual callers at the Executive Mansion. An old countryman was the guest, and he was received with all the courtesy which would have been extended to a Senator.
ST. LOUIS, July 31. -- Col. Joseph K. Rickey has received a letter from Leland Stanford, in reply to one sent by the Colonel. The letter is dated Menlo Park, Cal., July 1. Senator Stanford says:

The racing card yesterday served to bring to Jerome Park neither a large nor an enthusiastic crowd. The races promised nothing out of the ordinary. That fact and the intensely hot weather prevented any show of enthusiasm, had there been anything to enthuse over, which there wasn't. No one was excited over anything except just at the close of the last race.

Some of the stockholders of the American Loan, and Trust Company, who have no prospect of getting anything out of the assets of the wrecked concern, propose to ascertain whether the Directors cannot be held personally responsible for losses due to their negligence. With this view they will bring suits to recover, through the receiver, provided the latter's counsel advise that there is ample legal ground to proceed upon.
We are surprised to find the following in the editorial columns of the Chicago Inter Ocean of the 18th inst.:

T.J. Keefe, for many years the crack pitcher of the New-York Club, was yesterday released. His work has not suited the management this season, and as he has been drawing a big salary, it was deemed advisable to let him go. This news will be received with regret by the lovers of baseball in this city. Keefe has been a big favorite here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21. -- The fight for the Senatorship is now on, and both the Foraker and Sherman factions are charging each other with precipitating the fight and making it one of the issues of the State campaign. The friends of both Foraker and Sherman have not been so thoroughly stirred up since the result of the election which retired the Governor, temporarily at least, from political life.

It appears that the scheme of local self-government for Ireland which has so often been promised since the Salisbury Government came in is really contemplated, and that a bill embodying it is to be introduced at the next session. It is also announced that the bill will be in effect an extension to Ireland of the laws already enacted giving greater power to the local governing bodies in England and Scotland.

In the affectionate admiration of the people of the South STONEWALL JACKSON occupies a place next to that of ROBERT E. LEE, and it is not surprising, therefore, to find the unveiling of VALENTINE'S bronze statue of the hero of Chancellorsville and many another battle made the occasion for enthusiastic tributes to his memory.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 21. -- Six hundred troops are now at Knoxville, but they will not be sent to Briceville, and the miners are masters of the situation. The authorities are anxious to send the troops forward, but it has been decided that they have not the power.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- The Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association, published to-day, contains the exact figures of the production of pig iron in the United States in the first half of 1891. The total production of pig iron in the United States in the first half of 1891 was 3,371,925 gross tons, against 4,560,513 gross tons in the first half of 1890, a decrease of 1,188,588 gross tons, or 26 per cent.

The First Battalion of Naval Reserve Artillery of the State of New-York had its first taste of actual naval work yesterday afternoon. The men had been ordered to report aboard the old frigate Minnesota, now tied up to the wharf at the foot of West Fiftieth Street as a receiving ship, for what is called the "cutting-out" drill, and promptly at 5 o'clock all hands made their appearance.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21. -- The body of Peter Van Riper, which had been buried in the Old Hook Cemetery, near Westwood, was disinterred to-day, but as the relatives were satisfied with the autopsy made at the time of the death, it was reinterred without further examination.

LEXINGTON, Va., July 21. -- This is the thirtieth anniversary of the first battle of Mauassas and Lexington, and this village, the home of Stonewall Jackson, is crowded with visitors to witness the unveiling of a statue in honor of the distinguished General. The streets and public buildings are beautifully decorated, and the decorations of the houses are profuse.

The delay of the Insurance Department in giving Mr. MICHAEL COLEMAN official notice of his appointment as appraiser of the real estate of the New-York Life Insurance Company in this city indicates, we suppose, a disposition on the part of the department to look further, at the risk of faring worse.

Major John W. Powell, director of the United States Geological Survey, was in New-York yesterday, and gave a TIMES reporter some interesting facts about the new lake which has recently been growing in the Colorado Valley just above the Gulf of California.

With a bloom on his cheeks and a sparkle in his eyes that told of good health and royal good humor, United States Minister to Greece A. Loudon Snowden returned to his native Philadelphia yesterday. He arrived in New-York last Wednesday, and until yesterday had been staying with his sister, Mrs. Wainwright, at Rye, on Long Island Sound.

Fourteen young women, dressed just alike, and so strikingly costumed as to attract the attention of all who saw them, walked up Park Row Monday night shortly before the hands on the City Hall clock indicated midnight. They wore blue dresses trimmed with white, sailor jackets with big white collars, and jaunty straw hats with blue and white bands.

Collector Erhardt returned from his outing yesterday and sent to the heads of departments in the Custom House a letter instructing them to send him lists of the men who could best be spared and of those whose pay can be reduced. "In making these recommendations," he said, "you will be governed by the record of the incumbent as to efficiency, long service, industry, and attention to business."

" This is a Trust-killing tariff, men and brethren," said the New-York Tribune a few days ago. Since that amusing assertion was made we have invited our neighbor's attention to several new Trusts in protected industries, and especially to those which have been formed by manufacturers who procured an increase of duties in the McKinley tariff.

The Washington Heights Taxpayers and Real Estate Speculators' Association marshaled its forces for a raid upon the Rapid-Transit Commission yesterday. When they had all been rallied and counted they proceeded to the office of the commission, where they found the Commissioners prepared to receive them. Charles E. Runk, the leader, opened the ball.

Mrs. J.C. Carson, the septuagenarian widow of a Hudson River steamboat magnate, is the latest victim of the humbug female mediums. Mrs. Carson is a well-preserved and benevolent old lady, whose home is at Newburg, N.Y. Her husband, who was at one time Mayor of that city, died three years ago, and she moved to New-York for a change of scene and took up her residence temporarily in a flat up town.

PERKSKILL, N.Y., July 21. -- The gratifying intelligence was made public this morning, on the authority of Post Surgeon Bruce, that the crisis in the case of Private Robert Reid, the member of the Second Battery who was injured yesterday while assisting in firing the salute in honor of Gov. Hill, was passed, and that the injured man was in a fair way of recovering.

The Parnell Leadership Committee met last night at Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street, and after a rather stormy session adopted a set of resolutions severely condemning the interference of the clergy in political matters in Ireland. The committee, it is said, represents those Irish organizations in this country that believe Ireland must be freed at any cost.

It is already evident that the Republicans are much more pleased with the silver plank in the Ohio Democratic platform than are the Democrats, either in or out of that State. It is likely to induce the Republicans to try to keep the tariff question somewhat in the background and to push the silver question to the front, confident that they will gain thereby.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 21. -- Among the early callers on Senator Sherman this morning was ex-Gov. Foraker. According to the former the meeting resulted in a pleasant exchange of views on the coming Senatorial contest. There is another account of the conference, coming from the ex-Governor himself, which puts the matter in an entirely different light.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 21. -- Last April, Lieut. E.J. Glave and Jack Dalton started from here to explore the interior of Alaska. Glave was in Africa with Stanley, and with the expedition for founding the Congo Free State, and Dalton is an experienced Alaska prospector. In 1890 they were with the Frank Leslie expedition and explored the country between the Yukon and the south coast, getting north and south.

That must have been a very interesting interview between JOHN SHERMAN and ex-Gov. FORAKER at a hotel in Cincinnati yesterday, of which the dispatches only tell us that it "lasted fifteen minutes." A good deal can be said in fifteen minutes, and if Mr. SHERMAN undertook to express his opinion of Mr. FORAKER within that time it seems safe to say that the expression was not so ambiguous as most of his recent public utterances.

Several Republican politicians at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon were discussing the business which would probably come before the meeting of the Republican National Executive Committee at Philadelphia next week, when the statement was made that there would be two resignations passed in together.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, (Tuesday,) July 21:

There is a good-sized row on hand in the Cooperative Building Bank, which is a national building and loan association, and, according to statements made in the Supreme Court yesterday, before Judge Barrett, the concern is in danger of being dissolved by its officers. The trouble is all over Henry W. Allen, who has a ten years' contract with the bank to act as its agent for New-York State in the getting of new business.

SHANGHAI, China, June 18. -- The riots against the missionaries throughout the valley of the Yang-tse Kiang River still continue at intervals, but no lives have been lost other than those of the ringleaders of the mobs who were caught by the Chinese Mandarins and suffered decapitation for their offense.

SARATOGA, July 22. -- The Summer meeting of the Saratoga Racing Association begins to-morrow with a good card and a good lot of horses, the Western and Eastern horses meeting here for the first time to-morrow. Racing will begin at 11 o'clock as usual. The entries and weights for the several races are as follows:

The new Greek benevolent society, the Athena, met last night at the Hotel Pearl, 475 Pearl Street, to perfect the organization that was effected at the first meeting a week ago. Fully one-tenth of the thousand Greeks in this city were present, and it was evident from the start that the new enterprise had back of it an abundance of earnestness and enthusiasm.

his mom-nng an immense o box, made by'l -:'he order of the Oommissioners of Chrftles and ' Correction for the prorvtion of bodies at the I korgue, will be put tose, nd fifteen unclhned bodies will be plaed In it until the time for their removal to Potter's Field.

A tall, thin young man named Esper is a member of the Philadelphia Club. He has a strong left arm, and he used it to advantage against the New-York batsmen yesterday. So skillfully did he handle the ball that the Giants only made four safe hits and did not score a run. In consequence, Harry Wright's boys won another game and placed the proud and haughty Giants in second place again.

The crew of the British ship Coringa, which arrived from Chilean ports yesterday, report having some exciting experiences in Pisagua. The voyage which has just been completed cost Capt. Dodge, the commander of the vessel, his right arm, and other members of the crew received injuries which they will not soon forget.

Recruiting in the rural districts and smaller towns for the regular army has now become an established policy, and presumably illustrated posters showing the farmer's lad how he would look if dressed up in Uncle Sam's uniform, and setting fourth the advantages of military life, are doing good service in the agricultural regions.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 22. -- "I expect to be re-elected," said Gov. Campbell of Ohio to-day, "with or without the vote of Hamilton County. There is still some dissatisfaction there, but it is quieting down. It is chiefly among the German element, and they are rather sluggish about changing votes.

BOSTON, July 22. -- The Safety Electric Light Company of this city, which has for the past few mouths been making experiments with a primary battery for electric lighting, has so far perfected its battery as to put it to several practical tests that seem clearly to demonstrate its commercial value.

PARIS, July 22. -- A correspondent here has been making inquiries of the Chambers of Commerce in France as to the present feeling concerning the McKinley tariff and as to whether this feeling will affect the French exhibit at Chicago.

One of the most serious of the charges which Cashier Theodore M. Banta preferred against President William H. Beers of the New-York Life four years ago was that of paying large sums of money for blackmail to prevent exposures of the company's methods, and directing that such sums be charged to the cash account in order to avoid their inspection by the Auditing Committee.

The card for to-day's races at Jerome Park show a decided improvement over that of yesterday, and should result in some excellent sport. The Elizabeth Stakes, for three-year-old fillies, and the Harvest Handicap at a mile and a quarter, in which but four horses have accepted the weights, are the fixtures. The probable starters and the weights are as follows:

The old "Dinsmore claim" served to make yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment interesting. This claim is a relic of Tweed's time, and is for printing and advertising claimed to have been done for the city. Interest has swelled the $70,962.94 originally asked to $130,000. There are several claimants, and they got the last Legislature to pass a bill authorizing the Board of Estimate to pay the claim if it was due.

The Rapid-Transit Commission decided yesterday upon another route for a rapid-transit road, which will be in effect an east-side branch of that previously laid out through Broadway, starting from Fourteenth Street and following the line of Fourth Avenue under ground to a point near Forty-second Street, and then curving to the west and following Madison Avenue to Ninety-sixth Street.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 22. -- The Farmers' Union of Bienville Parish has made opposition to the lottery a prerequisite to admission to the Alliance. Lincoln and other parishes have followed this example. It will be done throughout the State, the intention being to make the Alliance a thoroughly anti-lottery organization.

COPENHAGEN, July 22. -- The Berlingske Tidende, semi-official daily newspaper of this city, publishes the following, which it says is the text of a letter from Prince George of Greece to his father. The letter is dated from Kobe, Japan, on the bay and near the city of Hiogo. It says:
WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Lieut. John F. Meigs, United States Navy, has been ordered before the Retiring Board for examination as to his fitness for retirement from active duty.

Some graceless scamp has been misusing the stationery of the Department of Justice, for surely no Attorney General of the United States, not even an Attorney General from Indianapolis, would address a Federal District Attorney in such slovenly and vulgar language as is used in a letter received yesterday by United States District Attorney JOHNSON of Brooklyn, bearing the signature, presumably forged, of Attorney General MILLER.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 22. -- Southampton's maids and matrons turned out en masse to-day to see the continuation of the tennis tourney. The thinning out of the competition made the remaining matches more likely to be close and exciting, and so the day's play proved. The courts and weather could not be improved upon and the committee's arrangements were most satisfactory.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 22. -- Delegates from the five clubs composing the Kill Von Kull Rowing Association met here to-night and completed arrangements for their twelfth annual regatta. They represented the Staten Island Athletic Club, the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne, the Arthur Kull Association, and Alcyone Boat Club of Elizabeth, N.J., and the Bayonne Rowing and Athletic Association.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 22. -- The second annual reunion of the Thirty-fifth New-Jersey Volunteers took place here to-day. About eighty survivors of the old regiment that marched with Sherman from Atlanta to the sea were in attendance, among them being Gen. Wager Swayne of New-York, the brigade commander. A letter of regret was received from Gen. Sprague.

ASBURY PARK, July 22. -- Mayor James A. Bradley is after the cigar dealers and druggists who refuse to keep their stores closed on Sunday. Last week the Mayor served notices on the druggists, barbers, and cigar dealers, directing them to close their stores at 10 A.M. Sundays. A number of the merchants obeyed the edict, but the barbers' shops, drug stores, and cigar stores on the beach were open all day as usual.

Soon after day had dawned over Jersey City yesterday, and while it was quiet along the docks and in the ferry houses, many strong men went to the foot of Pavonia Avenue and with much ado began rolling numerous kegs from the warehouse to the decks of two steamers and two barges that lay at anchor there.
The Board of Control yesterday gave a hearing to the parties interested in the Caldwell-Bergen squabble, and at the conclusion of the hearing sent out this as the outcome of the investigation:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 22. -- It is pretty generally conceded to-night that there is little fear that blood will have to be shed in the mining region. Gov. Buchanan reached the city this morning from Nashville, and as soon as he had breakfasted began his work to smooth the tangled skein.

The champion organ of this generation is clearly the Chicago Inter Ocean. There is hardly an issue of the paper that does not afford an example of what every decent journal should at all costs avoid. Its latest is the following:

STARKE, Fla., July 22. -- Willie Dowling was shot and killed and his father, Joseph Dowling, perhaps fatally wounded by George Futch this morning about 2 o'clock about thirteen miles west of Starke. The cause was an old feud. From a man just in from the scene of the murder THE TIME'S representative learned the following additional particulars: The trouble occurred at the house of Ancrum Adkins during the progress of a country dance.

BAIREUTH, Bavaria, July 22. -- To many Baireuth pilgrims the chief interest of this year's festival has centred in "Tannhauser," (Paris version,) as this is the first one of Wagner's four operas, ("Rienzi," "Dutchmann," Tannhauser," and Lohengrin,") as distinguished from his seven music dramas, (the Nibelung Tetralogy, "Tristan," "Meistersinger," Parsifal,") that has been sung at Baireuth.

In the Richmond County Court yesterday Wilson A. Cleveland, Postmaster at Dongan Hills, S.I., was tried on a charge of attempting to bribe School Trustee John Kadlitz. The charge grew out of an old and bitter fight between two factions of the citizens in Public School District No. 3 of Southfield over the erection of a new school building.

The spirit of trades unionism is strong among the female Knights of Labor. They have determined to push the propaganda of Knighthood as Mohammed spread Mohammedanism with a book in hand and a sword in the other. They do not exactly intend to kill working girls who refuse to join a union, but they will do something much to the same purpose, as they will deprive those infidels of the society of male Knights.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Republicans in Washington who have been somewhat familiar with the men who have been conspicuous in their party for ten years or more have wondered today at the appointment of Mr. De Witt C. Wheeler of New-York to be Superintendent of the Custom House. The position pays a salary of $1,400 a year.

BOSTON, July 22. -- Nutt Island, off Hough's Neck, was the scene of an interesting spectacle to-day. The old war ship Brooklyn was set on fire and, while the flames ate away the old vessel, the imaginative spectator saw a romance of American history finished before him.

Controller Jackson of Brooklyn made public a long statement yesterday designed to show that Census Superintendent Porter had erred when he classed Brooklyn in his Bulletin No. 82 tenth in the list of first-class cities, and as expending $17.84 per capita. According to Controller Jackson's figure the administrative expenditures are $9.85 per capita, and Brooklyn should stand third on the list.

It is nonsense for Commissioner BEATTIE to talk about West Street being cleaned as well as it can be under the circumstances and to plead that it is torn in places and that the pavement is uneven. This affords no excuse for the absolute neglect which has prevailed for weeks, according to the testimony of tenants and property owners, confirmed by the most casual observation.

Potter and Patten are out. Not only are they out as between themselves, which is a matter of sad significance where such eminent men are concerned, but Patten is also and separately "out" on his own hook, which is a solemn thing for Peter Patten, and a source of some sorrow at the headquarters of the Royal Oak Benefit League, of which Patten was until recently the Supreme Commander.

Hans S. Beattie, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, is deluding himself with the belief that the streets are as clean as they can be made under existing circumstances. He is enjoying this belief very much indeed. His delusion is his joy. The fact that many of the streets of the city are deplorably, disgracefully, and inexcusably dirty cannot penetrate the thickness of Mr. Beattie's delusion.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23. -- The German-American Republican Association has adopted the following:

BOSTON, July 23. -- The Brooklyns made a gallant fight here to-day, but the odds wore against them and they lost again. With their crippled team they were no match for the local club. They played a fairly good game, however, and several times the followers of the Bostons grew restless.

LONDON, July 23. -- The inquiry into the mental condition of Mrs. Mary Cathcart, a wealthy lady of Wooton Lodge, Staffordshire, on the petition of her husband, Mr. James Taylor Cathcart, which has been going on for some time past before Mr. Bulwer, Q.C., Master in Lunacy, and a special jury, in the Royal Courts of Justice, resulted to-day in a verdict to the effect that Mr. Cathcart was of sound mind.

Having made a snug profit, estimated at $50,000, by importing a large quantity of tin plate before the imposition of the high duty for which he voted, Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS of St. Louis now seeks permission to import workmen from Wales who shall carry on the experiments he began some time ago in a little Shed adjoining his kitchen-ware factory.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23. -- A sensation was caused here to-day by the publication of the fact that a bundle of letters written by Justice Field and Francis J. Newlands, Senator Sharon's son-in-law, and bearing on the peculiar, procedure in the Sharon case, were in the hands of Mrs. Sarah Mitchell, the landlady of Newlands's confidential manager, Charles Livingstone.

" I say, old fellow, look at those blisters," was the remark made by one member of the Naval Reserve to his mates as they returned to the receiving ship Minnesota last night after practically five hours of work with the white squadron -- five hours of harder work than any one of them has done for many a year. "I went into this thing for exercise," he continued.

The unterrified Democracy of Kings County dined at the Brighton Beach Hotel, Coney Island, last evening. The event was a tribute by the Brooklyn Aldermen to their returning President, John McCarty, who recently resigned in order to make himself eligible for the Democratic nomination for Senator, to succeed John C. Jacobs.

About seven years ago Daniel E. Donovan and Heman Clark constructed a mile section of Erastus Wiman's Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad. When they came to divide the profits they felt so well pleased that they agreed with Mr. Wiman to complete his railroad for him. The contract was taken out in the name of H. Clark Co., and work was begun in the Fall of 1884.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 23. -- State Controller Wemple, through a palpable error in the construction of the law creating and governing the State Board of Health, appoints two clerks in that office who act as registrars of certain vital statistics. Recently he arbitrarily removed two anti-Hill clerks, Charles Huddleston and Thomas Lawler, from the office of the Board of Health and appointed two Hill men to succeed them.

The Grand Jury yesterday handed down an indictment against Charles O'C. Hennessey, the city editor of the Daily News, charging him with violating the law forbidding the publishing of the details of executions by electricity, by having published in that paper an account of the executions at Sing Sing July 7 of Harris A Smiler, Joseph Wood Schiklok Jugiro, and James J. Slooum.

The return to Victoria of vessel after vessel of the sealing fleet, led by some that were conspicuous in past years for breathing out threatenings and slaughter against such Yankee revenue cutter officers as might venture to cross their rails, indicates a general submission to the modus rivendi arrangement and an abandonment of seal hunting in the prohibited waters.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- The following appeal and plan of action with regard to Russian-Jewish immigration was to-day issued by the Jewish Alliance of America:

NEW-ORLEANS, July 23. -- Probably the last of the bribery cases was tried in the Criminal Court to-day. It was that of Emile Bagnetto, a first cousin of Tony Bagnetto, one of the supposed leaders in the assassination of Chief Hennessy. Emile scarcely associated with Tony although they lived near each other. He was as much American as the other was Sicilian.

You have taken such deep interest in the fight against the Battery Park grabbers that I venture to expose to you an injustice done to the residents in the neighborhood of the East River Park, at the foot of Eighty-fourth to Eighty-sixth Street, and trust you will lend your good assistance in bringing the matter to public notice by giving this a space in your highly-regarded paper.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23. -- Ocean Grove is all worked up over an alleged attempt of the Rev. Aaron E. Ballard to abduct his two-year-old daughter. Mr. Ballard is the Vice President of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, and is also the Postmaster of that resort. He is the President of the Pittman Grove Camp Meeting Association, and is the State temperance agent of the New-Jersey Temperance Alliance.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 23. -- This morning the miners' committee left Knoxville for Coal Creek with the decision of the Governor that if the convicts were allowed to be placed in the mines from which they had been evicted by the miners, the militia would be withdrawn and the Legislature would be convened in extra session for the purpose of taking such action as it saw fit on the convict lease system.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Secretary Rusk is in this city in consultation with friendly Republicans, and the inference is plain that President Harrison wants the Illinois delegation to the National Convention in 1892.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- A special dispatch from Omaha, Neb., says: "The muddle growing out of the unseating of Gov. Boyd in favor of Thayer, by the Supreme Court, is being thickened by active preparations of the Alliance and Democratic Parties to have Gubernatorial candidates in the field this Fall, though the Supreme Court has virtually declared that Thayer holds over until next year at the regular election.

Appraiser Cooper has scored a decisive victory over his enemies. A few weeks ago they were prophesying that he was sure to lose his office in a short time, and so certain did they seem that their statement was well founded that Mr. Cooper's many friends among the business men of the city took pains to see to it that both sides of the ease were presented to Secretary of the Treasury Foster.

Clarkson's missionaries, who have been going about the State in the interest of the Republican League, had a hard time of it yesterday at Long Island City. They went out to meet the Queens County Republican Committee to "awaken enthusiasm" in the breasts of the committeemen. The reception awarded them was so different from what had been expected that the meeting was a great many removes from beings a "howling success."

ROME, July 3. -- It is stated on high authority that the Holy See will not give its consent to the projected American Review, which it was announced was shortly to appear at Rome under the title of the Roman Messenger. The Journal was to make a special feature of articles solely devoted to the various religious questions in the United States.

PITTSBURG, July 23. -- The Rev. John R. Paxton, D.D., of New-York is taking life easy during the hot Weather on a farm in this county remote from newspaper men. A Pittsburg reporter found him in his retreat yesterday, however, and secured from him some positive views on the outcome of the creed Controversies that are now agitating the Christian world.

The Giants had an opportunity of regaining first position yesterday, but they failed to take advantage of it. Chicago was beaten by Cincinnati, and, if the New-Yorks had won from Philadelphia, they would have gone into first place. Philadelphia won again, and the Giants are still floundering in second place.

PARIS, July 23. -- Horrible scenes have been witnessed during the past week on and about the Place de la Roquette, the place where criminals are executed by the guillotine. Crowds of the lowest classes have assembled there every evening, and have passed the night in the vicinity eagerly waiting to witness the execution of the murderess Berland and her accomplice, Dore.

Nino young people of this city wore the contestants in a Demorest gold modal contest at Prohibition Park, Staten Island, yesterday. The contest was under the management of Mrs. C.F. Woodbury of this city, the general superintendent of this temperance work, and the judges were Erastus Wiman of Staten Island, H. Frances Jones of Philadelphia, and F.N. Clark Of Springfield, Mass.

Mr. STEINWAY, Chairman of the Rapid-Transit Commission, is quoted as saying: "We shall not adopt the Greathead tunnel system. That is especially applicable to deep tunnels, and our roads are to be as near the surface as possible." We can hardly believe that this represents the decision of the commission as to the Broadway route.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 23. -- Mr. Frederick Law Olmsted, the landscape gardener, has prepared plans for transforming the old college grounds together with the large tract of land known as the Potter farm, which was recently presented to the University, into one immense park.

There was a very odd fire in the laundry in the basement of Mrs. Rosa Hyman's house, 48 East Fifty-eighth Street, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Smoke had made its presence in the house known two hours before, but its source was not discovered until the time named, when a mattress and the trunk of a servant who had left it when she went to another place where found blazing in an alcove.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 23. -- It now being a recognized fact that there will be two candidates for Senator, Sherman and Foraker, in the event of the Republicans carrying the Legislature, with a bare possibility that Secretary Foster may be brought out if the heat between the two loaders is a dead one, has been sufficient to add interest to the already very remarkable condition of affairs political in this State.

Members of the Manhattan Athletic Club who have organized the Manhattan Athletic Club Lawn Tennis Association held a meeting last evening at the clubhouse to perfect an organization. A constitution and by-laws were adopted, one of the features of which is that members of the association who may play lawn tennis in championship tournament anywhere in the country shall do so as representatives of the association.

BOSTON, July 23. -- The arrangements for the reception and dinner to ex-President Cleveland at Sandwich Saturday next are now nearly completed. A special express train, carrying the Governor, with the members of the Executive Council and the staff who accompany him, will leave the Old Colony Station at 9 A.M. This train will carry the other invited guests, but will also be open to all purchasers of excursion tickets.

LONDON, July 23. -- The United States Minister, the Hon. Robert T. Lincoln, at the Foreign Office to-day introduced the Foreign Commissioners of the Columbian Fair (ex-Congressman Butterworth, Mr. F.W. Peck, Major Moses P. Handy, and A.F. Bullock) to Lord Salisbury, the British Premier. Lord Salisbury expressed pleasure at meeting the Commissioners, and inquired into the prospects for the Chicago Fair.

DETROIT, Mich., July 23. -- The whole system of the Detroit street railways, over eighty miles in length, has to-day been purchased by Waller, Cook Wagner, corporation lawyers, of Wall Street, representatives of a New-York and Boston-syndicate, for $5,000,000. This will probably end the raging street-railway war in Detroit.

No political significance whatever could be attached to the gathering of the Steckler Committee of One Hundred (anti-Tammany) at Manhattan Beach last night. Not all of the members of the committee were on hand to enjoy the social features of the evening, but enough were present, including members of the committee and Steckler sympathizers, to make the affair satisfactory to the Stecklers.

Tenny and Longstreet are finally matched for a race at a mile and a quarter, and Mr. M.F. Dwyer will now have a chance to find out just how good his horse is at the distance.
