The match was arranged at Jerome Park yesterday afternoon by Mr. Galway, representing the Monmouth Park Association, and it will be run at Morris Park, if there is a good day and track, on Wednesday of next week.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 24. -- The camp-meeting grounds were in possession of the Woman's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Church to-day. Almost every woman who is prominent at all in missionary work in the State of New-Jersey was present, while many from other States took part in the sessions.

PANAMA, July 16. -- Roberts from Chile state that provisions are still scarce and high in the ports held by the insurgents. At Santiago and Valparaiso, held by the Balmaceda party, trade is being carried on on a very small scale.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction are busy at present making improvements in the institutions under their control with money appropriated by the Board of Estima to Extensive alterations are being made around Bellevue Hospital. The bulkhead is to be pushed about sixty feet out into the river and the space filled with stone and earth.

The river barge Merchant, conveying an excursion of the Knights of Pythias from Green-bush, was run down by the steamer Drew of the People's Line, about ten miles below Albany, Thursday night. The accident was fortunately attended with no fatalities, but the excursionists had a very narrow escape.

Mayor Chapin's refusal to reappoint Horace E. Dresser, a Republican, and William P. Ferguson, an anti-Chapin Democrat, to the Brooklyn Board of Education was a fruitful topic of conversation yesterday. Everybody thought Chapin had blundered. Mr. Dresser said:

The "opinion" written by Mr. OWEN in response to Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS'S inquiry as to the legality of importing workmen from the tin-plate factories in Wales under contract to work in his kitchenware factory at St. Louis appears to be regarded with some surprise and dissatisfaction in the Treasury Department.

It is never safe for foreign observers to estimate the significance of English "bye-elections." They are in almost equal danger of attaching to these casual and sporadic manifestations of local opinion too little importance and too much. The value of the personal or the local equation is really not to be ascertained, and it is this fact that makes the English discussion over them alike unprofitable and unending.

While the exercises and drills of our war ships in Boston and New-York waters have been causing unusual satisfaction through the evidence they have given of the existence of something like an effective modern American Navy, foreign nations have been carrying on, or are about to carry on, naval manoeuvres on a somewhat larger scale.

The last has not been heard of the Simon silk undervaluation case. As stated in THE TIMES of July 14, the silk manufacturers and importers have taken an active hand in the effort to acquaint Secretary Foster with the facts in the case. They were by no means satisfied with the results of the special agents' conspiracy to prevent Appraiser Cooper from removing an officer whom they thought unfaithful to his duty.

The plea has been made for Controller WEMPLE in regard to his appointment of WALDRON as a clerk in his office, and of SMITH as a registrar in the Health Department, that he did not think that either of the offices in question was in the competitive lists under the civil service law. Chief EXAMINER REILLY puts it very mildly in stating that the Controller "erred in his understanding of the law."

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The Columbia Oil Company, with an immense plant at 44 to 54 Erie Street, with branches at Memphis and Owatonna, Minn., after the brief existence of six weeks, collapsed this morning. Judge Blodgett appointed Sidney A. Stevens of this city receiver.

The Providence and Stonington Steamship Company has made a special rate for the benefit of those persons was may wish to go to Fisher's Island in the course of the week beginning today, to witness the target practice and manoeuvres of the squadron of evolution and naval reserve militia. The rate from this city to New-London and return is $2.50, and to Fisher's Island $3.

There can be no question that the Republican press of the country is treating Quay with great cruelty, and it is really refreshing to come across an acknowledgment to this effect in so good a Republican paper as the Philadelphia Inquirer, which, after reminding Quay's critics that they "could not do too much" for him after the Harrison victory, goes on to say; "Quay is the same man to-day that he was in 1888.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 24. -- Despite a heavy storm before the performance and a light downpour during the presentation, "As You Like It" was successfully given on the lawn at the Hotel Kenmawr this evening. The attendance numbered about 1,000, representing the highest circles of Pittsburg society.

AMSTERDAM, July 24. -- At Leyden to-day a ceremony of great interest to the United States was the unveiling in St. Peter's Church of the memorial erected there in honor of the Rev. John Robinson, pastor in Holland of the Pilgrim Fathers, and one of the passengers on the Mayflower who settled in Plymouth in 1620. It was witnessed by a number of Americans now traveling in Europe.

OTTAWA, July 24. -- The boundary line between British Columbia and Alaska has never been fixed. It was defined by a treaty between Russia and Great Britain in 1825, but practically exists only on paper. Since the United States acquired Alaska successive efforts have been made to secure the appointment of an international commission intrusted with the task of locating the line, but the negotiations never amounted to anything.

ST. LOUIS, July 24. -- F.G. Niedringhaus of tinplate notoriety was in a much better humor when called upon to-day than he has been since the strike at his rolling mill was begun. He had read in the Republic, here, THE TIMES'S report from Washington concerning the decision of Commissioner Owens, under which he can import alien labor, and expressed surprise at its publication, evidently thinking the matter a secret.

The white squadron remained at anchor in the North River yesterday, and there were no drills except those of the regular seamen of Uncle Sam's navy. The members of the naval reserve, who had gone home the night before thoroughly fatigued by their arduous and unusual labors, staid at home and prepared for their cruise which begins to-day.

Of all the State elections of the present year no other is likely to compare in importance and in political effect with that in Ohio. This seems to be fully appreciated by the Administration at Washington, and there are many indications that the Federal power will be exerted to the utmost to influence the action of the people in that State.

Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, has under consideration the testimony in the proceedings to condemn such of the property on the block bounded by Barrow, Washington, Christopher, and Greenwich Streets as the owners refused to sell at Mr. John Lindley's price for the purposes of the site for the new Appraiser's Stores.

Seven races with good fields of horses are to he run at the Morris Park track this afternoon. The three fixtures, the Passaic, for all ages; the Stevens, for three-year-olds, and the Sapling, for two-year-olds, will have exceptionally good horses among the contestants, and rare good sport is a certainty. The probable starters for the several races and the weights the will carry are as follows:

Controller Myers was not at his office yesterday, and his assistants were somewhat agitated by charges that worthless bonds had been acsepted on certain asphalt street-paving contracts. Deputy Controller Storrs said that the charges amounted to nothing; that the city was amply protected on all its asphalt contracts, not only by bonds, but by the retention of 30 per cent. of every contractor's money.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 24. -- Glen Hazel, a pretty little lumbering hamlet fourteen miles from Ridgway, Elk County, may soon be the scene of a race war. During a drunken row between lumbermen and Italians employed in grading an extension of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Horace Fisher, a jobber, was fatally stabbed in the abdomen by Paolo Passuzzi.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Assistant Engineer B. C. Bryan, who is in charge of the machinery of the torpedo boat Cushing, has preferred charges against Lieut. Cameron McR. Winslow, the commanding officer of that boat.

Jockey Martin Bergen appeared in the saddle at Jerome Park yesterday and was accorded the warmest kind of a welcome, for his sudden reappearance was an agreeable surprise to all. Bergen was at Saratoga on Thursday and was not expected back here, as it was announced that Mr. Gideon had taken his horses to the Saratoga track.

The three days' conference and school of methods of the Women's Christian Temperance Union opened yesterday at Prohibition Park, Staten Island. It is conducted by Mrs. Ella A. Boole, the Corresponding Secretary of the New-York State Women's Christian Temperance Union. There will be three sessions each day, at 9 A.M. and 2 and 7:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Among the acts of the last Congress was one creating the Sequoia National Park in California. One of the purposes of this park is to preserve the magnificent trees that grow to almost marvelous dimensions within its boundaries.

All accounts agree that HIPPOLYTE has become much more intolerable in Haiti than his predecessor ever was and that an uprising against him is imminent. Such an uprising would put Port an Prince in a state of riot that would endanger the lives and property of foreign residents, many of whom seem to be prudently escaping.

After three successive defeats the New-Yorks finally won a game yesterday. They defeated the Philadelphias, but it was only after a desperate struggle. The visitors stubbornly contested every inch of ground, but they were finally forced to give way in the eight inning, when Buckley made a timely hit for two bases, sending in a couple of runs.
Near the village of Peapack, Somerset County, N.J., there resides Mrs. Sarah Heath, who passed her one hundred and second birthday yesterday.

For months the McKinley papers in Ohio have been teaching the curious doctrine that the foreign manufacturers pay the tariff duties imposed by the McKinley act. They have repeatedly asserted that this is true with respect to the duty on tin plate. But now they see that the people will not swallow this, and that they must foremost of these devotees of McKinleyism is the Cleveland Leader, which is the mouthpiece of MCKINLEY himself.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 24. -- An intimate personal and political friend of Senator Brice, and one who represents the Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, has visited all of the northern and northeastern counties of the State since the Cleveland Convention for the purpose of ascertaining the actual facts in reference to the alleged hostility to Gov. Campbell in a number of counties in that section of the State.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 24. -- A Gainesville, Fla., special says: The wildest dime novel seems to be outdone by the exploits of the negro outlaw and murderer, Murray. He is now appearing in the new role of highwayman.

BALTIMORE, July 24. -- Officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company pronounce without foundation the "report" printed in a New-York evening paper, "that President Mayer of the Baltimore and Ohio will soon meet the controlling interests of the Ohio and Mississippi Road in London for the purpose of arranging terms for the lease of the Ohio and Mississippi to the Baltimore and Ohio."

BALTIMORE, July 24. -- A Cape May special to the Baltimore Sun says: "At the next meeting of the Catholic hierarchy of the United States a letter of thanks will be sent to the Pope in the name of the Bishops of the country, thanking him for having rejected the petition of Herr Cahensly and his associates.

It is a fact somewhat interesting, but not altogether surprising, that the most notorious of the defaulters and other swindling agents of the New-York Life Insurance Company have been, in each and every instance, personal friends and intimate companions of President William H. Beers. If a man is known by the company he keeps, the singular coincidences of bad companionships ought to militate severely against Mr. Beers.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 24. -- Secretary of the Treasury Charles Foster arrived in the city to-night from Cave May, where for the last two days he has been in conference with the President. He will leave for Washington early to-morrow morning.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Capt. E.L. Huggins of Gen. Miles's staff, who has been on an official visit at the Indian agencies in the Sioux Reservation, returned to army headquarters yesterday after an absence of three weeks. Capt. Huggins visited Fort Bennett and Cheyenne River Bgencies and the sub-agencies along the Cheyenne River.

PEEKSKILL, July 24. -- The last working day of the tour of the Eighth and Seventy-fourth Regiments has also been the busiest of the week. Just before daylight this morning the clouds opened and the rain came down in torrents. It stopped the early company drills and sent the men scurrying in double time to the mess hall to avoid a soaking at breakfast call.

SARATOGA, July 25. -- The rain of the first two days of the racing meeting was a damper on the spirits of the Summer visitors. There were not many magnificent turnouts and equipages en route to the track because of the bad weather, and people had to go in covered vehicles Thursday and Friday.

A great deal of talk is being heard just now about the era of good feeling that prevails among local Republicans. The trouble is that it is all talk. The old Nathan-Woodruff lines are just as tightly drawn as ever, and the adherents of the two factions are as bitterly opposed as they were during the Daggett scandal of a year ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 25. -- The Czar and Czarina and the Queen of Greece paid a visit to-day to the French squadron. Admiral Gervais received his imperial visitors on board the war ship Marengo, while the guns of the fleets at Cronstadt belched forth a royal salute. The visitors afterward inspected the Marceau, another of the visiting war vessels.

Mr. Russell undertook to write this volume with some reluctance. He had stood in an official relation toward Mr. Gladstone and had enjoyed social intimacy with him; hence, he could not consent to embellish his pages with traits and incidents the knowledge of which had been thus acquired.

THE DECLINE OF INDIAN TASTE. -- Certainly in Southern India art has not been improved by the introduction of modern and European art. Southern India, especially the Madras Presidency, is now the centre of tinselly manufactures of worthless, hideous goods, sold at exorbitant prices. Color and shape, quality and workmanship, are a mixture of bad Indian and bad English or French work.

Very strange is the adventure through which a postman named Boudon has just passed at Nimes. He had taken a registered letter to one Faure, a shoemaker, and was about to leave the house when the man closed the door, pulled a revolver out of his pocket, and, rushing on Boudon, threw him down and bound him securely.

BLOCK ISLAND, July 25. -- The fogs that have hung over Block Island here for the last week or so have gone, and the Summer visitors are making the best or good weather. The hotels are filling up, and the young men are beginning to put in an appearance by every steamer, much to the joy of the young women. To-night there were balls at all the leading hotels.

DALLAS, Texas, July 25. -- At 12:40 this morning a fire broke out in J.B. Cowan's wholesale liquor house on Commerce Street, opposite the Grand Windsor Hotel, wherein were stored, it is estimated, about 700 barrels of whisky. A few minutes later flames burst through the roof, and at the same time they seemed to fill the inside of the building.

The widow-marriage question is still causing much commotion in India; but there are signs that the old extreme views on this subject are passing away. A curious meeting of the Senoy or Gaud Brahmin community has been held in the Thakordwar Temple, in Bombay, with the object of excommunicating the family of Dr. Bhanddarkar in consequence of the recent remarriage of his widowed daughter.

LONDON, July 25. -- The sole novelty for the week, so far as theatricals are concerned, was "Miss Decima," the operatic comedy, which was presented for the first time in English on Thursday night at the Criterion Theatre. As already cabled, "Miss Decima" was adapted by Frank Burnand from the French, and it was well received.

Among the passengers on the steamer Normannia, which arrived yesterday, were Mr. and Mrs. Potter Palmer, who have spent the last three months in Europe. It is already known that Mrs. Palmer received a cordial reception abroad as President or The Board of Lady Managers of the Chicago World's Fair. In talking of her trip yesterday she said:

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 25. -- The Summer city was painted yellow instead of red to-day by the women suffragists. They came from all over the country, each one wearing a yellow ribbon and a smile of the blandest kind. The Chautauqua management devotes one day in the year, to the discussion of political equality and the advocates of the doctrine send their leading representatives here.

RED BANK, N.J., July 25. -- A match at continuous pool, 200 points each, for $100 a side, took place last night at the Union Hotel between Mr. Loney, a New-York expert, and John Leonard of Red Bank. There was a large crowd present and considerable money was bet on the match, Loney being the favorite.

In Sacramento thirty years ago, before the Pacific railroads were built, there was a little store in which gimlets, nails, and hammers were sold by the firm of Huntington, Hopkins Co. They were impecunious tradesmen battling with adverse fortune, yet out of that shop came the C.P. Huntington whose millions are famous to-day and the Mark Hopkins whose millions were famous on the Pacific slope before he died thirteen years ago.

Camerists have had a little diversion the past week bombarding the naval vessels at anchor in the North River. The young photographers are always glad to have the war vessels come to port. There seems to be a sort of fascination in photographing them. Seldom have they had a chance to take snap shots at so many, however, or had them bunched in such easy reach.

One of the most interesting, although at the same time one of the smallest, denominations of Christians in the United States has recently come particularly before the public by reason of the wholesale suspension of fifteen of its ministers for alleged failure on their part o fulfill their vows of allegiance to the doctrinal standards of the Church.

There was general satisfaction throughout New-England last Wednesday when it became known that "Charlie" Prince's Beatrix had won the Eastern Yacht Club's race off Marblehead. Mr. Prince is said to be a good Democrat, and much of the fervor that emphasized the popular enthusiasm in Marblehead is attributed to this fact.

Mrs. Jessie Benton Fremont and her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Benton Fremont, have taken possession of the beautiful home at the corner of Hoover and Twenty-eighth Streets presented to them by a committee of ladies. Lieut. Fremont, his wife, and child are members of the household for the present. There is also a trusted servant, who has faithfully followed the fortunes of the family for twenty-six years.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 25. -- Hopatcong will count this season among her best. There are several thousand visitors at the lake and near it, and every day is filled with pleasurable excitement. The handsome new railroad station, "Mount Arlington," will be opened for use this week. The New-Jersey Central Railroad has greatly improved its station and grounds at Nolan's Point.

A GALLIC FIND IN DENMARK. -- An antiquarian find, which will excite interest all over Europe, has lately been made in Roevemose peat bog, near Hobro in Jutland, Aalborg Amt The objects are all of silver, the principal piece being a very large basin, on which have been fastened plates of silver hammered out with figures of men, women, and animals.

TORONTO, July 25. -- A special cable dispatch to the Globe from London says: "The sudden arrival of President Van Horne of the Canadian Pacific Railroad Company in London, coupled with the fact that Mr. Chauncey M. Depew is also here, attracts attention in city circles. An official statement, made in reply to inquiries, is that Mr. Van Horne is only here on private business, but the statement meets with little acceptance.

The Mail and Express cannot be said to be good to its friends. In a conspicuous place in its columns it displayed yesterday the following head lines: "FOSTER Talks: Major MCKINLEY, He Thinks, Will Have 75,000 Majority in Ohio." But when we get down to what the Secretary of the Treasury, who is irreverently called "FOSTER," really said it was as follows: "Personally Major MCKINLEY was very popular throughout the State.

Evidently the Governor and Attorney General of Tennessee accepted the assurances of the miners of Coal Creek Valley with a great deal of satisfaction as relieving them from a serious dilemma, but it must strike persons outside of that State that the power and authority to establish and maintain the status quo seem to be on the wrong side.

The general public has heretofore known Prof. Ordronaux chiefly as an expounder of medical jurisprudence and as all authority in questions of insanity. The present volume shows, however, that he has extended his researches, and to good purpose, to the history and the results of constitutional legislation.

Lenox, Mass., July 25. -- A round of small dinner parties, musicales, tennis, the meeting of the Mahkeenac Lake Boat Club, and some informal dancing parties have made up the entertainment in Lenox this week. Of course, everybody has been out driving, for the weather has been extremely pleasant. The temperature has been low, and there has not been a rainy day.

The pearl fishing craze in Wisconsin, which was at its height in numerous rivers a year ago, seems to have ended as speedily as it came. Pearls were found in the clams in many rivers, but none of any particular value was found except in Sugar and Pecatonica Rivers, in Southern Wisconsin. Not only has the stock of pearls been exhausted, but the clams have been practically exterminated.

Wherever there has bean activity in the market the past week, it has been at the expense of prices; but there has not been much, and it was mainly confined to two or three stocks. The absolute lack of speculative vitality is producing its natural effect in developing a general sagging tendency. Good news fails to lift prices, and bad news makes them a little heavier than they were before.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Previsions had a considerable fluctuation to-day, the tendency being upward, and yet it was not a big market, the operators being chiefly of the scalping sort. There was some sharp buying of ribs by Wright and Ryan, and fair buying of product by the Anglo-American. The manufacturers the sellers of Thursday and of Friday, were not offerers of product.

PEEKSKILL, July 25. -- When the Twenty-second Regiment marched into camp at 2 o'clock this afternoon and relieved the Eighth and Seventy-fourth, the superb appearance of the command, which paraded close upon 600 of all ranks, and thus, at the very outset of the tour captured the record for attendance, elated everybody.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 25. -- The Rev. Henry Boggis has been installed as pastor of the Reformed Church of Woodstock, Ulster County.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- There has been sent to President Harrison a letter signed by several members of the Kaweah Colony Corporation of California resident in New-York City, Brooklyn, and other cities, calling his attention to the conduct of Special Agent Andrew Cauldwell of the Land Office.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Acting Commissioner Wilson has made a preliminary report to the Secretary of the Treasury of the operations of the Internal Revenue Bureau during the fiscal year ended June 30. The total collections from all sources during the year were $146,035,376, an increase of $3,440,680 as compared with the collections during the preceding fiscal year.

DURING RAMAZZAN. -- About thirty or, forty women, in their house attire, but wearing the long white veil draped round the head, face, and shoulders, wives, daughter, sisters, servants, slaves, and children -- white, brown, bronzed, and black -- were ranged in kneeling rows, their foreheads touching the ground, their attitude the embodiment of self-abasement, in presence of the one indivisible God they adore.

SARATOGA, July 25. -- There was a big crowd at the track here to-day expecting a good day's sport. But the heavy track caused a lot of scratches, and the fields were as small as those that Jerome Park visitors are accustomed to. The two stake races proved of little interest, as but two started for the Alabama, and Sallie McClelland won without any difficulty from her only opponent, Santa Anna.

Although designed for American schools, the edition of "Polyeucte" made by Prof. Alcee Fortier would not be disdained by those to whom the more ambitious labor of Petit de Gulleville is familiar. Prof. Fortier's commentary is accurate, brief, and exhaustive. It has a pleasant, classical, literary flavor, the flavor of another epoch peculiar to the work of French scholars who live out of France.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 25. -- Last season's craze for music seems to have revived with greater energy than ever. When the Summer visitors here are not riding or driving they are trying to master the intricacies of the musical scale on all shapes and varieties of instruments. Banjos, guitars, mandolins, and flutes have ardent disciples, and the long-suffering piano is in constant trouble.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- That Chicago is the headquarters of a padrone system is said to be established beyond a doubt by evidence in the hands of the Government authorities. An Italian named David Fallone, residing at 337 South Desplains Street, is accused of being the guiding spirit of the conspiracy to evade the alien contract labor law.

Why do we attain a certain size and weight of body and then cease to grow? Why is one person limited in stature to a few inches while another stretches up several feet? Why is it that one at maturity weighs not above fifty pounds and another attains a weight ten times as great? These are all questions of growth, and some marvelous examples are recorded.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 25. -- Extremes meet at Bar Harbor this Summer. Days that chill the marrow and days that make the perspiration ooze seem to chase each other alternately. The hotel keepers' prayers appear to have been heard, for we have had some broiling weather, but somehow people have lingered about getting here to the hotels.

The Manchester Ship Canal embankment at Ellesmere Port collapsed at an early hour on July 12, and the Pall Mall Gazette gives the following account of the affair: "Some few days since the Eastham section of the canal was filled by the waters of the Mersey, preparatory to its opening for traffic as far as Ellesmere Port.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The Treasury Department is informed that large quantities of grain from the Province of Manitoba are shipped via Duluth, Minn., under transit entries made for the purpose of facilitating the re-entry of the grain into Canadian territory. It is said that, at the time of shipment from Manitoba, the destination of the grain is unknown and can be determined only on arrival at Duluth.

LONDON, July 25. -- The United States Commissioners to Europe for the Chicago Exposition, who left London for Paris last night, are in a state of high delight with the flattering and enthusiastic reception they have met with in England. From the moment of their landing at Southampton, ten days ago, they have been the objects of the unceasing solicitude and courteous attentions of all that is best and most distinguished in the London world.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 25. -- The dress-reform movement has invaded Chautauqua with a vengeance. A big meeting was held yesterday, and so great was the interest manifested that the President, Mrs. Emily Huntington Miller, decided to have a "secret conference" to-day, still further to look into the matter.

THE AFRICAN BUFFALO. -- There are several varieties of the Buffalo proper, but all are remarkable for their formidable horns and almost invulnerable heads. When the sportsman has occasion to go forth to battle against a wild buffalo on foot, he will do well to study what Sir S. Baker has written on this subject:
CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 25. -- News has been received by telephone from Hamilton of a collision of trains at Middletown, attended by serious loss of life.
FIRE ISLAND BEACH, N.Y., July 25. -- The average temperature here the last week has been 70 and visitors have enjoyed capital bluefishing. The Surf Hotel has 260 guests, among whom are:

In view of the recent excitement caused in this city by the discovery of a case of leprosy in a Chinese laundry, and as every case occurring is made a pretext for stirring up a very strong popular feeling against the unfortunate sufferers, the following views and experiences of Dr. E.V. Brendon, a physician now practicing in the city, will be of interest.

LONDON, July 25. -- The members of the United States Immigration Commission, with the exception of two of their number remaining in Liverpool to continue investigations there, have returned to London.

Spiritualists have of late been holding camp meeting near Chesterfield, in Indiana, where they became so enthusiastic over the "manifestations" of spooks that they determined to establish a Spiritualist college, the building of which is to begin during the coming Autumn. Mr. CARROLL BRONNENBERG gave a number of acres of land to serve as the college grounds, and headed a subscription for the erection of the college proper with $1,500 in cash.

NEWBURG, July 25. -- The old neighbors of Warden Brown of Sing Sing Prison say that when he made the trade with Gov. Hill, whereby he was appointed Warden in return for his services in building up a following among the Democrats of this end of Orange County which he would use for Hill on call, he played a big bunko game on David.

STONINGTON, July 25. -- The members of the First Battalion, Naval Reserve Artillery, are a tired lot of men to-night. They have been at sea all day and have been broken into the routine of life aboard a man of war. They have stood their watches, done duty as guards, as men at the wheel, had several kinds of instruction, eaten in mess as cadets at Annapolis do, and have had a general awakening.

THE TWO FOES OF THE TURK. -- The Turkish Government has no friends, and two irreconcilable foes, Russia and the Arab race. The hatred of Russia, which has lasted all through modern history, is well understood in England; but the hatred of the Arabs, owing to the seclusion of Arabia, and to the preconceived notion, which is absurdly false, that all Mussulmans pull together, escapes the general attention.

G.H. Lewes said in 1867: "Spain once furnished Europe with plots and situations as Paris does now; and early in the century there seemed a prospect of revival for the Spanish drama. But these hopes have died out. * * * The national drama has almost ceased to exist."

In denouncing the prohibition policy in Maine the President of the Pharmaceutical Association of that State declared that "it has grown, like a fungus, on the body politic, stimulated by a Combination of dark-lantern societies, with demagogy, fanaticism, political intimidation, and intolerance of individual rights."

WHAT IS GAMBLING? -- Is playing "snap" en famille on Christmas Eve for nuts, gambling? Is buying with a penny the millionth chance of obtaining a gilt three-penny piece in a prize packet, gambling? Is diving for half-crowns gambling? With due respect for those who differ from us, we say, it is not.

PARIS, July 25. -- A report which prevailed in this city to-day to the effect that an attempt had been made to assassinate Mme. Carnot, the wife of the President, by means of an infernal machine, was utterly incorrect, in that the attempt was not made on the life of me. Carnot, but of the wife of a prominent member of the French Cabinet.

Many apple trees in London suburban gardens are in danger of extinction. This is a thousand pities, because the apple tree, apart from the attacks of caterpillars and some liability to American blight, not only lives and grows in London gardens, but will bear abundant fruit. Up till the past four or five years it has been quite common to find fairly well loaded apple trees in hundreds of London suburban gardens.

When Prof. George Davidson of the Davidson Observatory and the Coast and Geodetic Survey was shown the Paris cablegram saying that an old lady had just died at Spa, leaving 100,000f. as a prize to the astronomer, French or foreign, who within ten years shall be able to communicate with any planet or star, he read it through slowly once, then he read it twice more rapidly.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 25. -- Mr. Harrison has passed another busy day. He has been called upon by Chairmen of colored Republican clubs and by the much-discussed Postmaster General. His son has come to visit him again, and his grandson has appropriated the family carriage for a ride. He has bathed, he has sat upon his cottage porch, and he has worked diligently in the intervals of these other lighter occupations.

In his clever and tactful speech to his "neighbors" of Barnstable County at the reception and dinner tendered to him at Sandwich yesterday, ex-President CLEVELAND avoided all political, questions and controversies, merely making a pressing plea for tolerance and patriotism among citizens of opposing parties and referring to the embarrassing position in which ex-Presidents are liable to be placed.

A RUSSIAN DIPLOMAT. -- Many anecdotes of Gem. Ignatieff's cunning in diplomacy were current in Constantinople. I am not sure that I did not have the following from his own lips. The late Sultan Abdul Aziz, if not absolutely mad, was sufficiently eccentric to cause constant irritation, not only to his Ministers, but to the foreign Ambassadors.
There was a lonely husband wandering through the Adirondack pines last August, and there was a wife too busy to be quite so lonely who ought to have been with him and was not. Here is the story:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 25. -- Mrs. Mollie Cave was shot and mortally wounded by her husband, Charles Cave, at 3,937 Finney Avenue, at 9:30 o'clock this morning. After inflicting fatal wounds the man turned the weapon on himself and sent two bullets into his abdomen.

There were recorded at sanitary headquarters last week 1,001 births, 235 marriages, and 947 deaths, and the following cases and deaths of contagious diseases were reported: Typhoid fever, 41 cases, 10 deaths; scarlet fever, 117 cases, 18 deaths; cerebro-spinal meningitis, 1 case, fatal; measles, 165 cases, 16 deaths; diphtheria, 58 cases, 24 deaths, and smallpox, 1 case.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 25. -- One of the most important industrial deals of the year was consummated here to-day. The Eastern Reaper Works, the largest agricultural implements works in the world, covering forty-six acres, and ranking next in size to the Krupp Gun Works in Prussia, was sold to a syndicate of prominent capitalists of Cleveland, Chicago, and New-York, to be used for the manufacture of railway cars and supplies of all kinds.

The winds that fan the heated multitude at Coney Island each evening in the Summer months and the waves which tumble among the bathers on the beaches there are playing curious pranks with the great sandbeds which form the beaches and the ocean bottom for miles out. They scour the shining sand up from the bottom and whirl it away to lodge in other spots.

A match race for $300 was trotted at Fleetwood yesterday between Andrew Miller's blk. g. Larry Boy, 2:29 12, and M.H. Bernheimer's b. g. Lightfoot, 2:38. Larry Boy was the favorite, but was very unsteady in the first heat, finishing on a run a length behind Lightfoot, who reduced his record six seconds, to 2:32. The next three heats and the race were won by Larry Boy in 2:35 12, 2:32, and 2:36 14.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 25. -- Gov. Nicholls and his friends have already opened the Gubernatorial campaign, although the election will not be held until April, 1892. The entire fight will be upon the lottery issue. Gov. Nicholls is charged with being very desirous of leading the anti-lottery faction and becoming a candidate for re-election, while his predecessor, ex-Gov. Samuel McEnery, is probably the strongest man on the lottery side.

BOSTON, July 25. -- It is evident that the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions feels an impatience to which it is not willing to give expression in regard to the long delay of the Department of State in arriving at anything that oven suggests definite action regarding the affairs in the Caroline Islands, in which it is directly and deeply interested.

The Squier Whipple Company has been formed with a view, it is said, of extricating the firm of Squier Whipple of 146 Broadway, west side builders, contractors, and architects, from their difficulties. Nine dwellings and lots at the southeast corner of Riverside Avenue and Eighty-second Street, valued at $300,000, have been transferred by Mr. Albert C. Squier to the new company.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., July 25. -- Lieut. Gov. Jones addressed the Niagara County Farmers' Club at their annual picnic to-day at Lake Island Park, Wilson, on Lake Ontario. There were fully 5,000 people present, of which a fifth were Canadians, who came over from Toronto. Mr. Jones, with Thomas V. Welch, Superintendent of the State Reservation at Niagara Falls, were guests of Mr. Barnes of Philadelphia at his cottage.

ALBANY, July 25. -- The term of the Hon. William L. Learned as Justice of the Supreme Court, Third Judicial Department, expires with the present year. The district is largely Democratic, and as courtesy in the past has awarded the nomination to a person residing in the same place as his predecessor. It is considered that Albany will be honored with the nomination.

There used to be a great deal of "metropolitan" satire in the New-York newspapers about "provincial" Boston, but even the authors of this satire were well enough aware that Boston was in many respects a city to be envied, and even to be made a model of by New-York. There there was abundant public spirit and local pride. Here there was none at all.

A correspondent, who asks us not to publish his letter, writes us to ask why, in our judgment; "the use of both gold and silver, at a proper ratio, would not be at once safe for all interests and to the great advantage of the debtor class now cruelly oppressed by the enhancement of the value of gold."

BERLIN, July 25. -- Emperor William, responding to inquiries as to the accident which befell him on Thursday evening last on board of the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, by which his right leg was injured, telegraphs that his ankle was hurt, and that he will require to use his foot sparingly for some time.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 25. -- There was brought to an end this morning a plot to rob the American Savings Bank at East Fifth and Walnut Streets. The most notorious culprits having a hand in the scheme were Samuel Cooper and James Dimmitt, who has frequently appeared in police court as defendant in various criminal cases.

The peach crop of Georgia has this season been a very light one, and the keeping quality of the fruit from there, which two years ago was phenomenally good, is this season but slightly better than that of the peaches from Maryland. There were a few Troth's Early from Caroline County, Md., last week, from a very early section.

NEW-LONDON, July 25. -- The "white squadron," which has served to make the Summer season interesting to the hotel boarders at the Pequet and Fort Griswold Houses, left Tuesday. The good weather, which took the naval vessels off, also cleared the river of a large fleet of yachts and sailing craft of all descriptions that had gathered there to wait for the fog to clear from the Sound coast.

The work under notice gives the main facts in bacteriology, tells of the life history of bacteria and allied organisms, and gives the best accepted theories as to the role these organisms play in nature's economy, treating particularly their action and relationship to fermentative, putrefactive, and disease processes.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25. -- This has been busy week among the trotters in Kentucky as well as elsewhere. Regular meetings were held in Richmond and Eminence, and yesterday there was an extra day's trotting at the Lexington track. The sport has been good at all points and a number of now 2:30 performers have been brought out.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 25. -- Washington Rock, situated not far from here, is one of New-Jersey's historical places, the centre of some of nature's greatest beauties, and at the same time a standing evidence of the difficulty of raising public monuments.

THE GOOD FATHERS OF THE GREAT ST. BERNARD. -- The exercise of untiring, unceasing hospitality toward all travelers, without any distinction as to nation or religious belief, is the special vocation of these good monks. They often minister to several hundreds daily, and during the Winter season (which often lasts over eight months) their hourly task is one of great self sacrifice.

Holders of real estate in this city are taking comfort out of the fact that to all outward appearances they are much better off than those investors who have chosen railroad securities as a lodgment for their money. Business in real estate is certainly dull. That is to be expected at this season of the year. There is, therefore, nothing abnormal in this condition.

The State must pay its lawmakers more liberal salaries to obtain good material. Senator John J. Linson of Kingston, Ulster County, one of the strongest men, mentally, in the upper house, has declined an offer for renomination on the ground that he cannot afford to represent the State in the Legislature. The Ulster district will lose an able and upright representative.

I observe in your paper of July 20 and in many other papers articles upon the "Mystery of Cotton Fires," which are becoming more and more frequent, especially on shipboard. I think the solution of the mystery is not far to seek. American cotton is treated more barbarously, more unsuitably, more wastefully, and more dangerously than any other great staple of any kind -- or than any other kind of cotton in the world.

Sarah Bernhardt has arrived at Sydney and has been received with extraordinary honors. The Mayor went to meet her and an official "pronounced a discourse." Tragedy queens have their liabilities as well as their privileges, and the discourse was followed by an official reception. The harbor was decorated as if for a regatta, and the town was illuminated at night.

The body of Levi L. Brigham, who since 1868 had been a member of the Union League Club, was found yesterday morning in the water off Stillwell's Club House at Gravesend Beach. There is little doubt that Mr. Brigham committed suicide. He had been sorely in need of money for some time, and an attempt to raise some Wednesday had failed.

Visitors who are the least interested in the fine arts never fail, when seeing the Louvre at Paris, to marvel at the size and splendor of the Crown diamonds which are shown in a case vigilantly watched by a guard. When noble persons are in financial straits they sell the family diamonds, at least so the good old British novel tells us.

If the servants and employes of any one of the big clubs in this town were marshaled in dress parade the array would be a decidedly imposing one, and the size of the small army would surprise anybody who had not had occasion to become familiar with the workings of the larger New-York clubs.

Thus far we have had few "Summer snaps" in New-York this year, perhaps because the weather has been unusually cool. Things theatrical are often so oddly managed. Many of the theatres, however, will reopen in August, which is likely to be the hottest month of the Summer.

SARANAC LAKE, July 25. -- This village of 800 inhabitants, made up principally of invalids attracted by the sanitarium and guides, has three churches, and another, a Catholic edifice, will soon be built. The churches built are Episcopal, Methodist, and Presbyterian. The latter is the most ambitious, being the newest, with stained glass windows of the latest pattern.

The Buda-Pesth correspondent of the London Times recently telegraphed: "The deaths of three Hungarian Cardinals within six months has left the most important sees of the kingdom all vacant together. No new appointments have yet been made for the Archbishoprics of Gran and Agram, and now the Archbishopric of Kalocsa has been deprived of its diocesan by the death of Cardinal Louis Haynald.

MME. GEOFFRIN. -- Like most Frenchwomen, she had the gift of making phrases. When Rulhiere had read in her salon a work upon Russia which she feared might involve him in difficulties, she offered him a sum of money to burn it. The author waxed wroth at the insinuation implied, and broke out into an eloquent assertion of his courage and independence. She listened patiently and then, in a quiet tone of voice, said:

CARBON EATERS. -- Take an ordinary soda- water siphon, with or without a wine- glassful of brandy, and empty it till only a few drops remain in the bottom Then the bottle is full of gas, and that gas, which will rush out with a spurt when you press the knob, is the stuff that plants eat -- the raw material of life, both animal and vegetable.

The Cherry Diamond Yacht Club's advent to the racing arena is not what might be termed a shining success. Its naphtha launch races a week ago developed little more than an extensive advertisement for a certain make of naphtha launches, and its races yesterday, through unfortunate management, few starters, and a lack of wind, were a complete failure.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 25. -- It has been a week of pleasant days and musical evenings at the Water Gap, with a little rain, but not enough to do more than freshen up the mountain air. Tuesday evening there was a carnival of music on the river. The steamer Kittatinny carried the Water Gap Cornet Band, and in smaller boats were a zither club, two banjo clubs, and a host of singers.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 25. -- The Summer season in the Catskills generally opens on the last week in June and first week in July, and a goodly number of persons are in their Summer homes and more are expected in August. The railway station at Kingston is a very busy point, for through it 90 per cent. of those who go to the mountains must pass.

The "procession" of royalties to the city on Friday was a wretched failure. They went irregularly, Just as chance ordered, and much later than they were expected, and while some had escorts, others had none. The carriages were very shabby, and none of them was drawn by more than two horses. The royal stables certainly did not show to advantage on this occasion.

HAIRDRESSING IN QUEEN BESS'S TIME. -- When Elizabeth came to the throne and inaugurated the golden age of head-dressing, she adopted some highly remarkable coiffures, and the ladies of her circle, who, like not a few of the men, put their whole fortune on their backs, followed her initiative, and even went the length of dyeing their hair to make it approximate to the decidedly "sandy'" hue of her Majesty's.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 16. -- Now that the Mexican Southern Railroad, following the line of the road of the same name projected by Gen. Grant, is, in a few weeks, to be opened for public traffic from Puebla to Tecomavaca, a distance of 224 kilometers, a brief account of the history of this line will be of interest.

LONDON, July 25. -- The eldest daughter of the United States Minister, the Hon. Robert T. Lincoln, has been engaged to Mr. Charles Isham of New-York, who was formerly Mr. Lincoln's private secretary. The wedding will take place in London some time during the coming Autumn.

LANDOR AND HIS WIFE. -- Landor's domestic unhappiness was too well known to be ignored; and I have known him refer to the circumstance occasionally, but I never heard him utter a word of blame. He said merely that "life was rendered impossible to him in Italy." I have heard him regret when contrasting other and more congenial marriages, that he "unfortunately was taken by a pretty face."

BAYONNE, N.J., July 25. -- A revival of interest in amateur rowing was manifest in the twelfth annual regatta of the Kill von Kull Association, held this afternoon. While there were some unfavorable conditions at he outset, the regatta passed off successfully. Fully three thousand people saw the races. With two exceptions each of the five events was stubbornly contested.

BOSTON, July 25. -- Boston put up the worst game of the season, and as a consequence the Giants won with ease. Clarkson attempted to puzzle the Giants with his slow drop balls, but the visitors took kindly to them.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 25. -- Gov. Boies's letter of acceptance of the Democratic nomination was given to the public to-day. Like all of his public utterances, it is a clear and lucid document, leaving the reader in no doubt of its author's position upon any question touched upon by the Democratic State platform. It is as follows:
-- Prof. Tyndall's health is improving to such an extent that he is preparing for the press a volume of essays, addresses, and reviews, to be issued under the title "Fragments of Science."

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 26. -- A few minute red spots which the tell-tale microscope told were blood had as much as anything to do with convicting Dick Frames of the crime of manslaughter here yesterday. The trial had been in progress for a week in this city and attracted widespread attention from the mysterious and horrible nature of the crime.

The cornerstone of the new edifice of St. John's German Evangelical Lutheran Church at Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in Milton Street, near Manhattan Avenue, was laid yesterday afternoon with interesting exercises. Fully a thousand Germans of Brooklyn and many from this city were present. The auditorium floor of the church was occupied by the 800 members of the church, the clergymen, and the Social Quartet Club, which assisted in the services.

A few days ago a gray-haired, wrinkled old woman passed through this city in the cars. More than sixty years ago this woman married George Irving, an industrious young mechanic. They lived together in one of the towns in the northern part of the State a few years, happy and contented. Then trouble came, and, in a moment of anger, the couple separated.

ST. LOUIS, July 26. -- The wool growers are beginning to ask why their clip of wool this year is worth, on an average, from 2 to 5 cents less per pound than it was last year. They want to know why the McKinley tariff has not increased the price, as they were promised it would.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 26. -- In June, July, and August three-fourths of the practical work of the United States Naval Cadets is done at sea, while the other fourth is confined to the Steam Engineering Department at the Academy. The latter work is progressing in the steam-engineering buildings to-day, and a more interesting spot could not be found in these now comparatively, deserted grounds.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 26. -- The Rev. Theodore B. Roth, pastor of the Church of the Redeemer at Utica, N.Y., has declined to accept the proffered post of President of Tbiel College at Greenville, Penn. He will remain with his present charge.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 26. -- President Harrison attended service at the Beadle Memorial Presbyterian Chapel this morning for the second time this Summer. He reached there just in time for the 11 o'clock service, having walked up from his cottage. His sisters, Mrs. Eaton and Mrs. Dimmick, accompanied him. The three occupied the pew always reserved for the President's family.

NEW-HAVEN, July 26. -- Grave fears are entertained that Hugh Dailey, for many years Prosecuting Attorney of this city and one of the most prominent Republican politicians in Connecticut, has been drowned with two companions in Long Island Sound.
Charles A. Ball, a prominent young, Republican of Allegany County, has been mentioned as the possible candidate for Senator from the Twenty-seventh District to succeed J. Sloat Fassett.

The customary Summer visit of the North Atlantic squadron to Halifax has been made this year by a very modest force, consisting only of the Philadelphia and Petrel, under Admiral GHERARDI. They will remain but a few days in the Dominion port before proceeding to the annual delectation of Bar Harbor by their presence.

Racegoers can have a day's rest to-day, unless they wish to chase the elusive dollar at the Brighton Beach track, where the game which they follow would go on forever, in spite of wind or weather, if the law did not confine the proprietors to a limited number of days' racing yearly.

An admiring crowd gathered about the boxes containing the snakes at the Central Park Menagerie yesterday, and they saw some rare, as well as very poisonous, creeping creatures whose habitats are in the tropics. The snakes are the property of Prof. G.R. O'Reilly, who for the past sixteen years has paid much attention to snakes and knows about all there is to know about them.

HALIFAX, July 23. -- The Philadelphia reached here this afternoon, two days out from New-London, Conn. Much delay was experienced because of slow running during a heavy fog, the revolutions of the engines being limited to forty per minute. The Petrel started with the Philadelphia, but she, deeming herself too small to be run into, kept up her full speed and reached Halifax several hours before the flagship came in.
PARIS, July 26. -- The identity of the person or persons who sent the infernal machine received yesterday by Mme. Constans, the wife of the Minister of the Interior, has not yet been discovered.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The energetic and talented ladies who record the doings of Washington society for the metropolitan newspapers are at present engaged in a gentle discussion as to which one of them is entitled to the credit of suggesting that Mrs. McKee and Mrs. Russell Harrison ought to make a European trip.

Through the peculiar construction of the mutual life insurance company it has come about that an attack upon the management of one of the leading New-York companies by THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in the avowed interest of the policy holders, is to be resisted in the courts by such management at the expense of the policy holders; in other words, the company is to pay the expense of fighting a movement in behalf of the company.

PEEKSKILL, July 26. -- There was one officer of the Twenty-second Regiment missing from the church parade this morning whose absence was sorely felt. This was Lieut. Col. King, who in the course of the night before had joined the ranks of the sick, along with Col. Camp; but with this difference, that while the disability from which Col. King is suffering is distressing, it promises no to be of long continuance.

Public interest is centring in a large degree about four little children who are in Boston for the purpose of being educated. Robbed by severe illness in their infancy of three of their senses -- sight, hearing, and speech -- these little ones show an intelligence that would shame many another child who has full possession of its faculties.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 26. -- Desertions from the Republican Party have become so general in Iowa that the leaders are trying to conjure up some way to stem the rising tide in favor of Gov. Boles, which promises to overwhelm the party with a defeat the magnitude of which threatens to equal a political revolution.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 26. -- A.L. Conger of Akron, Ohio, a near relative of Senator Conger and Postmaster Conger, and a manager of Republican conventions for years past, arrived here yesterday and called on Mr. Blaine. The call was quickly returned by the Secretary and his son Emmons, who sent some time in conversation with him.

LONDON, July 26. -- Money was more plentiful during the past week, and discount was easy at 134 for three months and 34 for short. Since the opening of the week, when discount rates touched the official minimum and an advance of the Bank of England rate appeared imminent, the monetary outlook has rapidly changed. On Wednesday Russia returned 750,000 gold to the Bank of England, with the prospect of sending more.

HARTFORD, July 26. -- The resignation of Clinton B. Davis of Haddam as Chairman of the Democratic State Committee has been decided on and will be in the hands of the Secretary, J.H. Swartwout of Stamford, in the course of a few days. Mr. Davis has occupied the Chairmanship for the last three years. His resignation, however, has been under consideration for months, and the formal announcement will not cause surprise among the party managers.
Miss Georgiana M. Stisted recently sent some interesting reminiscences of her uncle, Sir Richard Burton, to Temple Bar. Below are a few extracts:

The Theatrical Protective Union met yesterday afternoon at Florence Hall in Second Avenue. The committee that had been appointed to look after Raymond and Ross, two constructors of scenery who were said to have been brought from Canada by a theatrical manager, in violation of the contract labor law, reported that those men had left the city, and that only union men were working on the scenery for that manager.

We notice a disposition on the part of some of the Democratic and Independent friends of honest money to warn the Eastern Democratic leaders not to take too active a part in the Ohio campaign, because the Democrats there have declared in favor of free coinage of silver, and thus made advocacy of their cause risky.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26. -- District Attorney Graham has in his possession documentary evidence of great importance bearing on the Bardsley case. It was furnished to him by Mayor Stuart's experts -- Faunce and Brown -- but it is the opinion of both City Solicitor Warwick and Mr. Graham that the interests of the city and the ends of justice will be best served by withholding the information from the public for the present.

People may differ from Mr. Goldwin Smith, but the clearness of his style and his excellent English are at once conspicuous. He has a capital way of settling things, and seems pleased when he can so put them in direct opposition to your otherwise conceived opinions, and it may be generally conceded that Mr. Goldwin Smith is quite often as right as wrong.

Sea Girt camp on Thursday last witnessed two of the biggest local political planets in conjunction. They met on the same plane; they scintillated their mutual rays into and from their respective orbits. Each had its own accompanying set of satellites, each shining with the reflected light of the leading star, and not one venturing to lay claim to any but a reflected light -- of a very sinister hue at that.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 26. -- Sealing is certainly stopped in Bering Sea and all the Victoria fleets are now on the way home. The entrance to Bering Sea is effectually blocked, and is now patrolled by five American and two British war vessels. The latter are the Nymphe and the Pheasant, and the United States vessels are the revenue cutters Bear, Rush, and Corwin and the gunboats Thetis and Mohican.

ON BOARD THE NEW-YORK STEAMER STONINGTON, FISHER'S ISLAND SOUND, July 26. -- The stanch New-York man-of-war Stonington is riding quietly at anchor in Fisher's Island Sound, just off the Mansion House at the island. The green shores of New-London Harbor stretch away to the northward, while to the eastward the hotels of Watch Hill peep around a corner at the solemn figure of the old Ram Island Lightship.

A letter dropped on the floor at her home in Wayne Street, Jersey City, by Miss Lillian Meyers, one of the daughters of Louis Meyers, a day or two ago, led to revelations. It began: "My dear little wife," and started an inquiry as to the writer's right to call the young woman by that term of endearment.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 26. -- John B. Smith of Rutgers College, who is the State Entomologist, has been collecting information regarding the "rosebud," which is now causing so much destruction to vines, fruit, and trees in New-Jersey, and the Agricultural College experiment station will soon issue an important bulletin on the subject.

SYRACUSE, July 26. -- A curious combination traveled through this town last week, making a political trip over the State. It consisted of two members of Assembly -- one Republican, Hamilton Fish, Jr., of Putnam County, and one Democrat, Percival Farquhar, one of the Tammany automatons from New-York.

The curtain that lately fell, in the current European drama, on the visit of Kaiser WILHELM to England, with abundant suggestions as to its possible influence on Continental politics, has already risen on the next scene -- that of the reception of the French fleet at Cronstadt and St. Petersburg.

ST. LOUIS, July 27. -- The trouble between the German priests and other priests growing out of the denunciation of the Cahensly memorial seems to have reached a climax. Father Phelan, editor of the Western Watchman, the most influential Catholic paper in the West, has been pouring hot shot into the German Priests' Society in such a merciless manner that they have turned on him.

BOSTON, July 27. -- The Bostons and New-Yorks met for the second time to-day. Inability to hit Staley was the cause of New-York's defeat and their errors aided the Bostons very materially in increasing their run-getting.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 27. -- The Grand Duke Alexis banqueted the officers of the visiting French squadron last evening on board the Russian flagship Asia. The utmost cordiality prevailed.

It is a notorious fact that over 50 per cent. of the business of the New-York Life Insurance Company is done in foreign countries. These countries, rightly enough, exact security for their subjects, and as a consequence very large sums of money are tied up in foreign deposits, sums that are absolutely beyond the control of the company's management, as they are deposited with the Governments and are liable to instant confiscation

Stories of Richmond Terminal were many in Wall Street yesterday. It was a day of rumors about the company, and every fresh tale of woe was followed by a little more weakness in the quotations for its securities. For some time there has been a general notion that some "insider" was getting rid of his holdings, and yesterday the rumors took the shape that he was in a desperate financial tangle.

A curious story comes from Washington in regard to trouble that Secretary FOSTER has had with a couple of his Assistant Secretaries, each of whom wished to appoint his son as private secretary. Mr. FOSTER refused to give his consent. Then these two worthy officers arranged a "combine" by which each appointed as his private secretary the son of the other.

From the Portland Oregonian (Rep.) comes a new view of a matter which is exciting much comment just at present. "It matters very little to anybody," it says, "whether Senator Quay resigns as Chairman of the National Republican Committee or not. This committee has no functions of importance to perform. It has only to call the next National Republican Convention and to preside over its temporary organization.

NEW-HAVEN, July 27. -- Hugh Dailey road obituaries of himself in the newspapers this morning and then officiated as usual in the police court as prosecuting attorney. It was just daybreak when the rescuing party, consisting of James H. Austin and his nephew, George A. Austin, after an all-night search up and down Long Island Sound, found the disabled catamaran Typhoon, to the side of which Mr. Dailey and his two companions, Messrs.

QUEBEC, July 27. -- The Allan Line steamer Grecian has arrived here with the fourth engineer, two seamen, two cattle owners, and eight cattlemen of the ill-fated steamer Circe, which was wrecked at East Cape, Anticosti. When the Grecian passed Heath Point the Circe was broken in two or three pieces and became a total wreck.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27. -- The new rapid-transit street-car line management suffered a short tie-up to-day. The consolidation with the Essex Passenger Railroad Company was effected toward the close of last week, and Superintendent Akerman announced a new time schedule for the men employed on the company's lines.
CHICAGO, July 27. -- Prof. Mark W. Harrington, the new chief of the United States Weather Bureau, made an important announcement while here to-day on his first tour of inspection.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Secretary Foster has directed Mr. Dumont, the Supervising Inspector General of Steam Vessels, to convene the Board of Supervising Inspectors of Steam Vessels in extra session in this city Monday, Sept. 28, for the purpose of making "a series of experiments with such line-carrying projectiles and the means of propelling them as may be submitted."

Gen. James S. Clarkson, President of the National League of Republican Clubs, has prepared something in the form of a circular which the officers at headquarters began sending out yesterday "to the Republican clubs of the United States." It gives directions for carrying on the work. It reads like a primer. Some of the club principles as laid down will strike those who receive the circular as being too elementary for effective campaign work.

PARIS, July 27. -- The execution of young Berland and Dore, two accomplices of Mere Berland in what is known as the Courbevoie murder, took place this morning on the Place de la Roquette in the presence of the usual crowds of people. It took 300 foot policemen, 250 infantry soldiers, and 100 mounted policemen on duty about the guillotine to keep the unruly spectators in order.

While a reserve of trained gunners is provided for our war ships in the new movement for a militia reserve, the navy has an urgent need of another class of men, for the adequate supply of which there is no immediate prospect. These are trained firemen, who have become all the more important from the high class of machinery now used.

If the politicians of one party could nominate the Presidential candidates for both, that "party of the first part" would have a pretty easy time of it. It would be likely to nominate for the opposing party a man whom it considered easy to beat, or, in case it missed its calculation in that respect, a man with whom it could make the best bargain.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The firing last week at Sandy Hook of several shots from the new twelve-inch gun built by the Ordnance Department of the army was in no sense a test of the gun, but of brown prismatic powder imported from Europe. The charges of powder were small and army officers considered the performance so slight a test of the gun that no importance was attached to it.

Immigrants arriving at this port after September will find in the new landing place on Ellis Island a vast improvement over the present terminal station at the Barge Office. The new building is rapidly, nearing completion and the contractors of the work expect to have it ready for occupancy early in September.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- News from Omaha, Neb., is to the effect that Nebraska Railroad managers are actively engaged in an effort to defeat the law of the recent Alliance Legislature, which goes into effect Aug. 1, making eight hours a day's work. All the companies have prepared instructions to their employes declaring that they will be employed and paid by the hour after Aug. 1.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 27. -- The Democratic editors of this State have been in session to-day. The meeting was attended by the leading men of that party from all sections of the State.

The visit of the French squadron to Russia seems to give point to the extreme queerness of the present political situation in Europe, which may be said to be an alliance of the satisfied against the dissatisfied nations. It would not be unfair, at least, to describe the Russo-French alliance as a Cave of Adullam, since Russia is undoubtedly in debt and France is undoubtedly discontented.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 27. -- The University of Pennsylvania has just come into possession of several handsome bequests through the untiring energy and industry of Prof. Francis N. Thorpe, who is now lecturing at Chautauqua. Prof. Thorpe received advices from the benefactors to-day, which makes it possible to give a detailed account of the new school, the success of which is now assured.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27. -- In the Special Term this morning was argued an interesting motion in the case of Edwin Booth, the actor, against Elsworth L. Striker and Horace C. Russ, proprietors of the Long Point Hotel, on Seneca Lake.

SARATOGA, July 27. -- This is what is called an "extra" day at the race course, because there were no stakes on for decision. Still, as the weather was pleasant and the track in fairly good condition, there was excellent sport, and the largest crowd of the season was on hand to enjoy it. The details of the races are as follows:

At last Mr. HARRISON and his Attorney General have discovered that there is a Federal Anti-Trust law. Having been enacted, if we may believe the repeated assertions of the Republican papers, "to redeem the pledges of the Republican Party for the suppression of Trusts and similar combinations," it is strange that it has escaped the attention of Mr. HARRISON and his assistants for so long a time.

BERLIN, July 27. -- Prof. Koch has left to Drs. Bottkin, Pfuhl, and Kitasato all further research into the cure of tuberculosis, and will devote his whole time to the supervision of the Bacteriological Institute.

Frederick A. Obey was murdered near Floral Park, L.I., Sunday night. William Covert and George Becker, both well-known residents, are under arrest, charged with being the assassins. Obey was unmarried and twenty-four years of age. Until recently he was employed at the Queens County Insane Asylum at Mineola and latterly as a carpenter on the new hotel building at Hyde Park.

Our predictions concerning the fate of Superintendent OWEN'S learned "opinion" relating to the proposed importation of workmen under contract by Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS may soon be fulfilled. Mr. OWEN assumed that he had been empowered to interpret the statutes without taking the advice of the law officers of the Treasury Department or consulting any of his superior officers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 27. -- Attached to the north-bound morning passenger train for Coal Creek was an extra coach containing fifty convicts to work in the mines at Briceville. They were in charge of State Warden Joseph Turney, who was accompanied by Col. William Ferman of Nashville and four guards.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 27. -- The action of the Mississippi Democratic Convention at its meeting on July 15, when it pronounced so strongly against the Sub-Treasury scheme, appears to have killed that measure in the State. The campaign for United States Senator is being conducted mainly on that issue, Messrs. George and Walthall, the sitting Senators, opposing the Sub-Treasury plan, and Messrs.

The cabled accounts of the frightful railway accident in France show once more that, in Europe as well as in this country, the excursion train is the most prolific source of danger. The number of fatal accidents occurring on board these trains, or by reason of them, is out of all proportion to their number or to the accidents that occur in the course of the regular traffic.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 27. -- On July 5, 1890, the steamer Eleanor of the Maine Steamship Company collided in the East River at Hell Gate with two barges in tow of the steamer Idlewild. The barges had on board Lafayette Council. Independent Order of Foresters, of this city, and their friends, who were going on an excursion to a grove on Long Island Sound.

Several members of the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee, which is to meet to-morrow, were in New-York last night, and their presence created a good deal of talk as to the business which will come before that body. A. L. Conger of Ohio, who had just come from an interview with Mr. Blaine at Bar Harbor, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, as was J. Sloat Fassett, the Secretary of the committee.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- "Blocks-of-Five," Dudley was recently interviewed by a reporter, to whom he frankly admitted his preference for Mr. Blaine as the next Republican candidate for President. He was sanguine about Mr. Blaine's chances of nomination.

We can account for the varying moods and contradictory opinions of the New-York Tribune only upon the hypothesis that our neighbor exemplifies in journalism that curious creation of STEVENSON known as Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. It was the malicious and wicked Mr. Hyde that published on Saturday last in the Tribune's Washington dispatches and editorial columns some remarks about trade with Mexico and the effect of the McKinley tariff on the smelting industry.

There is an office holder up in Fordham who is not in love with some of the duties and responsibilities of his office. He is Mr. M. Donohue, and he is the keeper of the public pound at 2,354 Arthur Avenue, his establishment for carrying out the functions of his office being connected with his residence. He complained yesterday over the generally unsatisfactory situation in which he found himself.

ON BOARD NEW-YORK STEAMER STONINGTON, OFF FISHER'S ISLAND, July 27. -- The hard work of the First Battalion Naval Reserve Artillery began to-day. The men were turned out at the regular hour, 6 A.M. They went on deck to discover that the Newark and Concord had arrived and were at anchor with the squadron.

Late Saturday night the final negotiations between Manager Daniel Frohman and Henry Arthur Jones, the English dramatist, in regard to Mr. Jones's play, "The Dancing Girl," were concluded, and Mr. Frohman secured the American rights to the piece. This will be the new play in which E.H. Sothern will appear during his coming season at the Lyceum, which will begin the last of next month, probably on the 24th.

Fresh from their victories over the British athletes the Manhattan team arrived home yesterday morning on the Gallia. The Cunard pier was thronged with the friends of the young men of muscle, and they gave the boys a grand welcome home. Those who arrived were: Manager Eugene Van Schaick, Mortimer Remington, C.L. Nicoll, C.A.J. Queckberuer, Luther Cary, H.L. Hallock, and H.L. Dadman.

Among the bits of information given by Mr. DEPEW in his London interview is the statement that the issue between the two parties in the next Presidential campaign, so far as silver is concerned, is to be as follows: The Republicans will hold "that we shall coin only silver produced in America.

CORTLAND, N.Y., July 27. -- After suffering hours of agony, George Frieze, farm hand, died early this morning. Frieze was employed on a farm about two miles south of this village, and among his other duties was that of milking the cows each morning. The cows, after being milked in the evening, were turned out in large pasture lot, where they grazed during the night.

Opposition to the erection of a huge gas tank in One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, just west of the Boulevard, has united the residents of that vicinity in a common bond of sympathy. Persons who own handsome residences, and other persons who are interested in the various public institutions near by, are deeply concerned at the prospect of having their attractive neighborhood marred by a noisy and ill-smelling gas works.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The published accounts of the reported defeat of the Chilean Congressional troops at Huasco and Vellenar having been received at the Congressional headquarters at Iquique, Chile. Mr. Errazuriz, the Minister of Foreign Affairs there, has sent a cablegram to Messrs. Montt and Varas, the Congressional envoys at Washington, authorizing them to reiterate the contradiction they have heretofore made of the truth of such statements.

The plans of the new armory to be erected at Fourth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, which have been approved by the Building Bureau, were submitted to the Armory Board by Architect Thomas yesterday. The issuance of $350,000 in bonds to raise the money with which to pay for the construction of the armory was then ordered. The board decided to advertise for bids in gross.

Chilean, Peruvian, and Argentine newspapers received in this city give interesting details of the struggle of the Chilean factions. La Patria, the organ of the revolutionists at Iquique, gives this account of the looting of Tocapilla, a small seaport, by marines from Balmaceda's ships on June 10:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- Advices just received from China give particulars of fresh depredations by the Chinese against the missionaries. The latest attack was made at Yankao on June 29, when the Catholic Mission was methodically looted, the crowd passing things from hand to hand in a chain. The buildings were afterward set on fire.

In the easiest possible manner the Philadelphia Club won from Brooklyn yesterday. At the end of the sixth inning the scores were even, but in the seventh and eighth the Phillies added 7 runs to their number, and, in consequence, distanced their opponents. It was a game marked by numerous errors on the part of Brooklyn. Caruthers, was hit hard, but the earned runs gained off his delivery were very few.

PARIS, July 27. -- The official reports received from St. Mande, near Vincennes, the scene of the collision between two excursion trains loaded with passengers returning from a musical festival at Fontenoy, show that 43 people were killed outright and that 104 were injured by the accident. Six people died after being extricated from the ruins, making the total number of dead so far 49.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 27. -- Ida M. Haight, wife of Webster C. Haight, a member of the Dutchess County bar, has sued for a bill of separation on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment. The parties were married in Millbrook, June 5, 1876, and have a daughter four years old. He owns a farm in the town of Washington, and they lived happily until he contracted intemperate habits.

Seventeen "ocean parties" have new been taken to and from the People's Seaside Home, West Coney Island, under the direct management of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, which has its offices at 79 Fourth Avenue, and about 10,000 parents and children have already received the benefit of fresh air, surf-bathing, and substantial meals.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day made the following changes in the office of the Collector of Customs at New-York:
