Pending the adoption by the committee of insurance men appointed by President Blagden of the Board of Underwriters of New-York of some plan of formal co-operation among the fire insurance companies doing business in the metropolitan district to do away with rate-cutting and place fire insurance once more on a profitable basis, the Continental Fire Insurance Company has originated a scheme and offered it to the insurance people for their adoption.

The little back room at Excise Headquarters, Third Avenue and Bond Street, contained a curious assemblage yesterday, drawn together to participate in the trial of Louis H. Franchi, keeper of the notorious dive at Bleecker Street and South Fifth Avenue, where "The" Allen, the reputed proprietor, was nearly stabbed to death by an Italian a short time ago.

BOSTON, July 28. -- The Russian Jews who came here on the steamer Kansas and are detained at this port by the requirements of the new immigration law told, in an interview through an interpreter yesterday, of the persecutions which drove them from Russia. The crowning piece was the burning of their hamlet, which was thus described:

The coal showers at the home of Edward Miller, 406; West Fifty-first Street, have ceased. The mystery has been solved, and the culprit is the little sixteen-year-old servant, Lizie Rau. She made full confession, and Mr. Miller apologized to the police for not believing them when they said she was the cause of the trouble.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 28. -- Samuel Barclay, aged seventy, was shot and instantly killed by James Burdine, aged forty, in Jessamine County, near here, at 6 o'clock this morning. Burdine has been cultivating Barclay's farm in tobacco, and the two men were unable to agree in settling their affairs. This morning Barclay went to the house of Burdine and, stopping at the yard fence, called for him.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Census Superintendent Porter to-day sent the following letter to Controller Myers in regard to the disputed figures of census bulletin No. 82:

Rain began falling just in time yesterday to keep people from going up to Jerome Park in very great numbers. Yet, with the improvement in the card, there was a better attendance than there has been as a rule. Once at the track, there was an agreeable surprise in store for the lovers of racing, for no rain had fallen there and the track was as dry as one could wish it to be.

The Rapid-Transit Commission, through its Chairman, has made public the following letter, containing a protest against what has been interpreted as a discrimination against the Greathead Subway and Tunnel Company:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 28. -- August Imbert and Grace Ruger, who eloped on a sloop two weeks ago, and who were arrested in New-York and brought here, were taken before Recorder Morsehauser to-day. Imbert was charged with abduction and the girl with being a disorderly person. The Recorder told them they could have counsel if they desired, and then the case was put over until to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The New-York Herald, which has been attacking the plundering pension agents with great vigor, has now taken a turn in its Washington columns, and has made an attack upon Major Ainsworth, the Chief of the Records and Pension Division in the Surgeon General's office.

The axe, which has been so long hanging over the heads of the Custom House clerks and messengers, has fallen at last. At least, to-day everybody may know who are doomed to go and who are to be kept at their old posts in the Custom House. Collector Erhardt yesterday received the letter in which Secretary of the Treasury Foster told where the reductions in the expenses of the Custom House must be made.

The size, the growth, and the resources of Arizona were discussed from various stand-points last night over the coffee and cigars that followed a complimentary dinner given by Walter S. Logan to the Hon. John N. Irwin, Governor of Arizona, and Herbert H. Logan of Phoenix, Arizona. The dinner was spread in the dining rooms of the Marine and Field Club at Bath Beach, and there were about one hundred gentlemen present.

CUMBERLAND, Md., July 28. -- A meeting of the Directors and stockholders of the West Virginia Central Railroad was held at Piedmont, West Va., to-day. At the stockholders' meeting ex-Senator Henry G. Davis, the President, proposed for adoption the contract with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company for a western connection at Bealington, and it was adopted.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The Board of Ordnance and Fortification, recently in session in New-York, has adjourned to meet Saturday of this week, when Gen. Schofield, now on his way East on his bridal tour, will attend the session.

LONDON, July 28. -- The Foreign Committee of the Columbian Fair Commission ended its stay in England to-day with a luncheon at the Savoy Hotel, where the Americans entertained the British Commissioners and others previous to departing for the Continent. The whole of the Savoy Hotel was devoted to the use of the Americans and their friends, and from the summit of the building waved the American flag.

The recrudescence of the Know-Nothing spirit in Massachusetts has been attested by the nomination of an "anti-Catholic State ticket" under the auspices of the "Patriotic Order of the Sons of America." It would be easy doubtless to underrate the significance of this demonstration of sentiment, but then it would be equally easy to overrate it.

It now appears that the unpleasantness in Ohio fomented by FORAKER involves not only Mr. SHERMAN but Mr. FOSTER, and even more intimately Mr. HARRISON. FORAKER accuses Mr. SHERMAN of dragging the Senatorial question into State politics and endangering the success of Major McKINLEY.

PLATTSBURG, July 28. -- The Republican Fourth Judicial Convention will assemble at Malone to-morrow, and it promises to be one of the hottest fights ever seen in Northern New-York. The terms of Judges Joseph Potter of Whitehall, who is sitting on the bench of the Second Division of the Court of Appeals, and of Charles O. Tappan of Potsdam, expire.

Although the Republican State Committee will meet at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Thursday for the purpose of determining the place and time of the State Convention, which will nominate candidates for State offices to be filled this Fall, only two or three members were in town last night. As a matter of fact, the Republicans have all seemed to run to apathy since the letter of Cornelius N. Bliss declining the Gubernatorial nomination was published.

NEWARK, N.J., July 28. -- A dastardly attempt at outrage and murder occurred shortly before 7 o'clock this evening in Badger Avenue, within a short distance of Lyons Farms. Miss Sophia Fredericks, a respectable girl of twenty years, was on her way to her home at Lyons Farms, when she was suddenly confronted by Henry Warner, a stalwart fireman, twenty-four years of age, who made an indecent proposition.

The firebugs still continue to alarm the residents of Flushing, L.I., and the Fire Department was again called out Monday night to a fire on the Van Bergen place, now occupied by Mrs. Eliza Young of New-York. The firebug had attempted to fire the house by placing a ball of pitch pine through the window of the laundry, which adjoins the house.

In an interview with a reporter of Kate Field's Washington, Gov. CAMPBELL says that the silver question cannot be an issue in Ohio to such an extent as the tariff. "While the Democrats declared," he adds, "after a fashion, for free coinage, yet it was upon a very close vote, and the sentiment of the party is much divided in this State.

Census Superintendent PORTER'S reply to Controller MYERS with reference to municipal and county expenditures is quite characteristic. He thinks that the figures of Bulletin No. 82 cannot with propriety be changed, because in a foot note it is stated that county expenditures are included and because they are not stated in the Controllers reports.

Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper and Secretary Briton Richardson of the Silk Association of America went to Washington on the 3:20 train yesterday afternoon to place before Secretary of the Treasury Foster a statement of the fasts connected with Examiner Wiswall's suspension and the frauds in the silk division of the Appraiser's Stores.

President Kramer of the American Association clubs made the following announcements yesterday: Contracts approved -- With Cincinnati, Charles W. Marr; with Columbus, William H. Clark, L.G. Twitchell; with Louisville, S.H. Larocque, Charles Bell, Hugh Jennings; with Washington, Harry F. Mace, George F. Lohman, C.M. Smith, W.H. Quarles, F.J. Foreman, M.J. Slattery, E.M. Daily, John Freeman, Elmer E. Sutcliffe, Tobias C. Griffin, Danniel Shannon, Edward H. Eiteljorg.

" G.H.W." -- Stone's History of New-York is authority for the following information concerning "Saint" Tammany and the Tammany Society or Columbian Order: Tammany was an Indian chief of the Delaware Nation, who probably lived in the seventeenth century. He was very friendly to the whites and wielded great influence among his people.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 28. -- After having been twice postponed on account of the weather, the meet of Central and Northern New-York wheelmen under the auspices of the Watertown Cycling Club, was held in this city to-day. The track was not in the best condition, and no records were broken. The winners of the various events were as follows:

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 28. -- Every day brings now developments in the evidence tending to prove the serious charges made against the various departments of the Government of gross irregularities and contract boodling. The feeling against the Government is increasing daily, as fresh scandals crop up in almost every department of the public service.

JACKSON, Miss., July 28. -- The subjoined letter shows more clearly the inside workings of the committee that whitewashed Macune at the Ocala Convention than anything yet published. It was given by the person to whom it is addressed to W.S. McAllister, Assistant Alliance Lecturer of this State, at Fort Worth, Texas, during the anti-Sub-Treasury League meeting:

ATLANTA, Ga., July 28. -- Stephen A. Ryan is in Fulton County Jail under an order of Judge Gober, of the Superior Court, adjudging him in contempt in falling to turn over to the receiver of the firm of John Ryan's Sons certain assets supposed to be in his possession. On the 25th day of May the doors of the famous mercantile house of John Ryan's Sons were closed.

The McKinley newspapers continue to tell their readers that bar tin could not now be produced at the California mine if there had not been inserted in the McKinley act a paragraph imposing a duty on imported bar tin two years hence. To them every part of that act is sacred, and no one but "an enemy of his country" can question the wisdom of a sentence or a word in it.

The present condition of negotiations for "reciprocity" with Venezuela is a curious instance of the working of the famous clause in the McKinley tariff law. It is the boast of Mr. BLAINE'S friends, and of those of Mr. HARRISON as well, that under this clause the United States would soon get great concessions from the South American Governments.

ST. LOUIS, July 28. -- Business was never brisker at the poolrooms and bookmaking establishments than to-day. Returns were received from all the race tracks. The gamblers who conduct these resorts, the sports and dupes who patronize them, and the rowdies and criminals who congregate about them, were in great glee.

PEEKSKILL, July 28. -- Everybody was ready to turn out at revielle this morning, for the night had been cold, so cold, in fact, that four and five thicknesses of Quartermaster's Department blankets proved insufficient for comfort. The early company drills in skirmish exercises warmed the men up, however, and sent them to breakfast at 7:30 o'clock with ravenous appetites.

Some women have been using an official broom on that section of the city which lies within Twenty-seventh and Forty-second Streets and Seventh Avenue and the North River, and as a result the streets are kept much cleaner than they used to be. These women are the officers and members of the Street-Cleaning Aid Society, and, as their main office is within the limits of the Twentieth Police Precinct, they decided to begin work there.

BOSTON, July 28. -- The best playing of to-day in the Longwood tournament was unquestionably done by E.L. Hall of New-York, who defeated R.D. Wrenn in a close five-set match, and later F.S. Mansfield in three straight sets. Hall was clearly at his best and in good form, and, including his defeat of Hovey yesterday, has beaten three of the "Hub's" best players.

Archbishop John Ireland of St. Paul was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He said he did not care to express himself on the recent action of Indian Commissioner Morgan in refusing to recognize the Catholic Indian Bureau in making contracts between the Government and the Catholic Indian schools.

Mr. James Cox, the accountant and translator of 51 New Street, this city, who disappeared from his home July 18, is still missing. His friends say there were no reasons of a financial nature why he should absent himself. In the Knickerbocker Trust Company are securities to his credit representing a sum that ought to keep a man in a cheerful mood.

The figures quoted in THE TIMES last Sunday, showing how the cost of some of the bonds of the New-York Life Insurance Company have been altered by President Beers in order to conceal bad investments, have led to other examinations of those famous financial exhibits, which bring to light new facts.

Mr. C.P. Huntington said yesterday that the death of Mrs. Hopkins-Searles will in no way affect the management or policy of the Southern Pacific Railroad properties, although Mrs. Searles was a very large holder of Southern Pacific stock. The important interests held by her first husband, Mark Hopkins, passed to her and now they will all go to Mr. Searles.

BOSTON, July 25. -- A young man named Dunning met the Bostons here to-day and played against them as a member of the New-York team. Dunning has been a member of the Manchester Club all Summer and he gained some prominence in New-Hampshire baseball circles. Somebody told Manager Mutrie that he was just the man that he wanted to take the place of the great Rusie.

ALBANY, July 28. -- The session laws of 1891, making 750 printed pages, have just been sent out from the printer. This is much earlier than usual. On these 750 pages are found 49 asterisks. This number is fewer than usual.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department to-day issued a review of the foreign commerce of the United States during the fiscal year ended June 30, giving also a comparison of the imports and exports of the past nine months, during which the new tariff law has been in effect, as compared with the corresponding nine months of the preceding fiscal year. It says:

At the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Tuesday July 28, William Kennelly, under a foreclosure, Augustus O. Brown, Esq., referee, sold a plot of land, 46x102.2, on East 79th St. norteast corner of Madison Av, for $39.150, to Dix Phyle.

ON BOARD NEW-YORK STEAMER STONINGTON, FISHER'S ISLAND, July 28. -- To-day the gay young tars of the naval reserve began to do something like the real pulling of triggers. The men reported aboard at the usual hour and after getting shaken down into their places the bugler sounded "Quarters," and the naval reserve crews aboard the Chicago, Newark, and Atlanta went to their posts.

A delegation of Harlemites, chiefly residing in the neighborhood of Pleasant Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth and One Hundred and Sixteenth Streets, appeared before the Board of Health yesterday to protest against and demand the abatement of the nuisance caused by the works of the Standard Gas Company, which occupy the East River front from One Hundred and Fourteenth to One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

NEWARK, July 28. -- One of the most daring attempts at robbery that have been made of late years in this city was tried at the office of the New-Jersey Oil Company, at 86 Liberty Street, this afternoon. Charles F. Chichester, a resident of Brooklyn, and William Parsons, two of the bookkeepers in the service of the works, had just returned from lunch.

Tenny and Longstreet did not settle the question of superiority at the Morris Park track yesterday, as they were expected to, because the track was too heavy for them to race over and make anything like a trne contest. No decision to postpone the race was made until after the owners of the horses had carefully inspected the track shortly after 1 o'clock.

ASHLAND, Penn., July 29. -- A fierce fire is raging in the Lehigh Valley Coal Company's Packer Colliery, near here. The fire has been burning several hours and has gained considerable headway. It has climbed to the tower on the surface, which, in a short time, was reduced to ashes.

BOSTON, July 29. -- Thirty Russian immigrants en route from Liverpool upon the steamer Norseman of the Warren Line, which arrived to-day, have been refused permission to land by the customs authorities. They are deemed likely to be a public charge.

Phillip Goerlitz, a builder of 125 East Forty-seventh Street, had a judgment entered against him yesterday for $1,040 in favor of A.S. Nichols Co. Mr. Goerlitz has placed all his property in the hands of John Goerlitz and Anthony J. Dittmar as trustees for the creditors.

The resignation of Mr. ERHARDT as Collector of the Port of New-York is practically notice to the country that in the present organization of the Republican Party, with its actual spirit and purposes, there is no room in the public service under its control for a man of integrity and even fair independence.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 29. -- The Mayor and municipal authorities this evening met Admiral Gervais and the other French officers at the quay and escorted them to the Town Hall, where a banquet was given in honor of the visitors. All the vessels in the harbor and the houses along the route to the Town Hall were profusely decorated.

Thomas B. Reed of Maine the autocrat of the last House of Representatives, arrived in the city late yesterday afternoon on the steamer City of New-York. He received a "courtesy permit" to hustle through the Custom House his numerous trunks full of his foreign acquisitions. He wore a black frock coat and black trousers, his only decoration being a smart "Lunnon neckcloth."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 29. -- John W. Coons, formerly Deputy Auditor in Indiana, was sent to Washington by Gov. Hovey several weeks ago to learn why the State had not been paid $46,000 due on the old war loan claims. He instituted an investigation which has resulted in the discovery that there is really $300,000 due Indiana, and assurances have been given by the Government officials that the amount will be paid.

Messrs. QUAY and DUDLEY have resigned their offices as Chairman and Treasurer of the Republican National Committee and with them their membership in the committee, and the Executive Committee has accepted the resignations with professions of regret. Of course there will be no official explanation of the reasons which induced this action, and it is a matter of conjecture whether it was really due to external pressure or internal prompting.

The young men who have been drumming up passengers for the special train to the Syracuse Convention of Republican Clubs next week are not so happy now as they were several days ago, when there were no signs of any trouble and the work they were doing promised them lots of fun and fame. There are unpleasant omens now.

Over two thousand persons, among whom were many ladies, gave Congressman Roger Q. Mills of Texas a hearty reception at Prohibition Park. Staten Island, last night, where he made an address on "The Democratic Creed." When be advanced to the front of the platform the crowd cheered and applauded and handkerchiefs were waved.

POUGH KEEPSIE, N.Y., July 29. -- An order has been issued by Judge Barnard to show cause why the Hudson River Shoe Company should not be dissolved and a receiver appointed. The order is returnable Oct. 31. In the meantime ex-Postmaster William M. Ketcham has been appointed temporary receiver, and an injunction has been granted restraining the creditors of the corporation from bringing any actions to recover claims.
CHICAGO, July 29. -- Congressman Holman of Indiana, who is here, declares that Harrison will be renominated, and that it is absurd to think of Elaine as a candidate.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 29. -- A.D. Van Sciver, who is by occupation a paper hanger, and Millionaire Charles Hyde, who is, as he announces on his letter heads, a "President of Banks," are having a suit in chancery which may ultimately involve several other persons, besides the city of Plainfield, the borough of North Plainfield, and the counties of Union and Somerset. Just now, however, Van Sciver and Hyde have the floor all to themselves.

NORWALK, Conn., July 29. -- A month or two ago Lieut. Henry Matheis of Company F, Fourth Regiment, Connecticut National Guard, was charged by a Sergeant and private of his company with falsifying the shooting scores, and in consequence thereof a court of inquiry was held. Matheis was found guilty, his commission revoked, and he was discharged from the service of the State.

Mr. ALBERT SHAW, in the July Century, begins a series of studies on "The Typical Modern City" with a paper on Paris. He entertains, as every intelligent person must who knows the city, great admiration for many of the results of its administration, and he finds its system, though too much centralized and "humiliating" to the Parisians, on the whole very effective.

NEW-YORK. Frederick Hirt, aged twenty-five years, of 412 East Fifteenth Street, was held in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday for stealing a watch from Frederick Arnold of 315 Avenue A. While on his way to prison Hirt was recognized by ex-Assemblyman Philip Wissig, Chief Clerk of the Harlem Police Court, as the man who robbed him of a gold watch at Brommer's Park on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 29. -- The announcement of the resignation of Collector Erhardt was a surprise to everybody here except Secretary Foster. He was surprised only because the resignation had been made six weeks ago and not made public, because the President desired to name his successor at the same time that the resignation was announced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 29. -- Collector of the Port Phelps has ordered the seizure of a cargo of nails which recently arrived here on the ship Steine Donnard from New-York via Liverpool. The nails are valued at $35,000, and were shipped from New-York to Europe and then transshipped to San Francisco on account of the cheaper rate.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29. -- The fourteenth annual meeting of the American Paper Manufacturers' Association was held in the Grand Union Hotel to-day. The session began at 11 o'clock, with President W.A. Russell of Lawrence, Mass., in the chair. William T. Barker of Boston was the Secretary.

LONDON, July 29. -- Lord Salisbury, in his speech at the Lord Mayor's banquet to-night, reviewed the labors of the present session of Parliament. He said hard and valuable work had been done, and that the obstruction formerly hindering legislation had almost disappeared. He rejoiced at the passing of the Education bill, as calculated to support the system of religion which the people loved.

A rumor was in circulation yesterday that Jay Gould and his son George had resigned from the Directory of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Company, and that Mr. Gould was selling his stock. A few months ago he said that he held about 100,000 shares.

BALTIMORE, July 29. -- The Democratic politicians of the State are assembled at the Carroll ton Hotel in this city to-night, preparatory to the State Convention which will be held in Ford's Opera House to-morrow. Senator Gorman is on hand. The convention will nominate candidates for Governor, Attorney General, Controller of The Treasury, and Clerk of the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The count of the farm and home transcripts, made in accordance with the mortgage collection clause of the Census act, has been completed by the Census Office. The figures are subject to slight modifications. There were returned by the enumerators 2,491,930 farms and homes occupied by owners which are incumbered by mortgages.

F.C. Whitney, manager of "Wild America," and C.E. Blanchett, also of the organization are in New-York. Mr. Whitney goes to Washington to-day to take steps for patenting a number of stage novelties, and after attending to this work will start for Australia, to rejoin the show. He says that the business of "Wild America" on its tour around the world has been simply phenomenal.

Ten innings were required to decide the game between Brooklyn and Philadelphia yesterday, but Ward's men came out on top. It was a most interesting contests. Several times the leadership alternated, and the players of both teams seemed to play with rare vim and determination.

LIVERPOOL, July 29. -- It was the intention of the consignees of the American "whaleback" steamer Charles W. Wetmore to dispatch that vessel to-day to New-York with a cargo of machinery. Their plans were disarranged by the sudden death of the commander of the vessel, Capt. Saunders, who died in his berth some time during the night.
It is seldom the case that a newspaper brings upon itself such utter and complete humiliation as the Philadelphia Press succeeded in doing by making the following statement:

PHILADELPHIA, July 29. -- Donato Toce was arrested to-day on a warrant charging him with obtaining money under false pretenses. The warrant was sworn out by Pietro Miraglio, who is acting in the matter simply to make a test case. Scores of others, it is said, are awaiting the result in order to determine their own action.

Gov. BUCHANAN of Tennessee has decided to call a special session of the Legislature to consider the question of convict labor, to begin on the 17th of August. The labor organizations of the State are likely to engage in a concerted movement for the repeal of all laws authorizing the leasing of convicts to outside employers of labor, and it is not probable that the demand will be resisted.

Within a few days Joel B. Erhardt will cease to be Collector of the Port of New-York. His resignation has been sent to the President, and in it he asks to be relieved of the duties of the office Aug. 1. The President accepted his resignation yesterday, and designated Senator J. Sloat Fassett as his successor.

The reported failure of fully one-half of the twenty-four candidates from civil life to pass their examinations for Second Lieutenanties in the army is a very practical reminder that leave to compete is not equivalent to appointment, and also that the standard for the lowest commissioned grade in the army is higher than many fancy it to be.

CLEVELAND, July 29. -- The fastest average time for three miles in harness was made here this afternoon by Hal Pointer, who paced the heats of his race in 2:10 3/4, 2:10 1/4, and 2:10 1/4. A crowd of nearly 8,000 people saw this great performance, which proved the champion's supremacy over the California-bred mare Yolo Maid, who has only been beaten once before.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 29. -- The debate on the tariff resolutions in progress for ten days back concluded at 4 o'clock this morning, when the Dominion Parliament voted down Sir Richard Cartwright's amendment in favor of unrestricted reciprocity with the United States. The Government's majority was 26, the vote standing yeas 88, nays 114.

The report for June, just issued by the Bureau of Anthracite Statistics, is not pleasant reading. Agreed output for that month, 3,250,000 tons; actual tonnage, 3,780,242; 530,000 tons more than agreed upon. And yet the June agreement was "on honor" and as strong as a verbal contract could be made. We know that the May output was 840,000 tons and the April 810,000 tons more than the amounts which were fixed as a maximum.

The Yaqui Indians who are now giving Mexico so much trouble are the tribe that under CAJEME and his predecessors endeavored for years to maintain their independence. They are found in the northwestern part of the republic, in the region back of Guaymas, and many of them have shown much capability of civilization.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 29. -- Twenty members of the Georgia Legislature, members of the Penitentiary Committee, arrived here last night. They are on their way to the Dade County coal mines, in the mountains of Northwest Georgia. As is generally known, these mines are worked by leased convicts, and are operated by a company of which ex-Senator Joseph E. Brown is President and principal owner.

Mrs. Flora Adams Darling has washed her hands of the Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and, with a parting salaam of defiance to Mrs. Roger A. Pryor and William O. McDowell of New-Jersey, has gone off with her friends to organize a rival society, to be known as the Daughters of the Revolution.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 29. -- Burglars in petticoats are the latest novelty, and the two Milwaukee women who undertook to practice the profession were flat failures. Both burglars are respectable married women. Mr. and Mrs. James Robinson live at 112 Sixth Street. Mr. Robinson is a railroad engineer and was out on the road Monday night.

Capt. Joseph A. Thompson of the clipper ship J.F. Chapman was arrested on the arrival of his vessel here yesterday morning by Deputy United States Marshals Van Buskirk and Grant. He was taken before United States Commissioner Shields, and held in $'2,500 bail for examination to-morrow on a charge of cruel and inhuman treatment preferred by Eric A. Eklund, the ship's carpenter.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 29. -- Gov. Buchanan to-day announced that the Legislature would be called to meet in extra session Aug. 17, and that the whole penitentiary question would be referred to the body, including the regulation of the penitentiary, the erection of a new State prison, the removal of the main prison from this city, the management by the lessees, and the regulation of convict labor.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 30. -- An affray took place in the saloon of James Liddy, the pugilist, at Elizabethport, to-night, in which William McAdams, Liddy's brother-in-law, was nearly killed by Liddy, his bartender, Jim Finlan, and John Liddy. McAdams has several serious wounds on his head, and his skull, the doctor fears, is fractured.

PEEKSKILL, July 30. -- The Twenty-second Regiment girl is impervious to weather. Were it not for this fact, the military post would have been a dreary and desolate place indeed to-day. For while the members of the regiment and of the battalion were perforce compelled to keep close to quarters on account of the rain, she pervaded the camp.

The Democratic Convention of Maryland, held yesterday in Baltimore, was an altogether harmonious gathering, all rivalries for nominations having been settled in advance of its meeting. Mr. FRANK BROWN, the candidate for Governor, owes nothing to the party managers. He was shrewd enough to win the favor of the farmers and to pilot the Alliance into the Democratic camp, and thereby he made his nomination by the convention inevitable.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Advices from Omaha are to the effect that President Cable of the Rock Island celebrated his victory over Jay Gould to-day by crossing the Union Pacific Bridge in his special car, and that the trains of that company will begin running regularly into Omaha to-morrow. The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul commenced using the bridge to-day.

The Republican State Committee met yesterday under somewhat depressing circumstances and decided to call the State Convention to meet at Rochester on the 9th of September. No particular reason could be given for holding the convention at Rochester, except that Assemblyman PARSONS pleaded that it would help him in his Senatorial fight against MCNAUGHTON.

The appointment of Mr. FASSETT to the place made vacant by the resignation of Mr. ERHARDT only confirms what was very well known before, that the resignation of Mr. ERHARDT was practically compulsory, and that it was forced to make room for the appointee of Mr. PLATT. When Mr. ERHARDT declares that "the office is no longer independent, and I am, and so we separated," he put the same fact in a vivid form.

The ruling of the Treasury Department by which a drawback of 99 per cent. of the tariff duty on imported tin plate used in the manufacture of "kitchen or house-furnishing goods" is allowed when these goods are exported, is announced just in time to relieve the minds of Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS and other makers of kitchenware.

BOSTON, July 30. -- Russian Jews who arrived on the steamer Norseman yesterday, many of whom are detained by the Immigrant Commissioners, have pitiful stories to relate of the cruelties perpetrated upon them by the Russians. One lad, who refused to give his name for fear of being apprehended and returned, said he came from Slabotky.

CORTLAND, N.Y., July 30. -- The convention of the Knights of Pythias resumed its session here this morning. The convention decided to hold the next meeting at Troy on the fourth Tuesday of July, 1892. Officers were elected as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Senator Fassett was resting this afternoon after his two days of work in the Republican National Executive Committee and preparatory to his trip to Cape May, whither he had bean summoned by a dispatch from the President. He left for Philadelphia by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad at 8:10 o'clock this evening, and will be at Cape May Point early to-morrow morning.

The indictment of an evening newspaper for violating the law against the publication of the details of executions was an injudicious and unfortunate procedure. Now an important and responsible newspaper has been indicted for the same offense, and it is to be expected that the law will undergo a searching judicial examination.

In the campaign of last Fall the McKinley papers "pointed with pride" to Mr. SHERMAN'S so-called Anti-Trust law. They asserted that the Republican Party had "redeemed its pledges for the suppression of Trusts," and declared that the law had already become "effective." Some of them coolly told their readers that the great Trusts were already going down before this statute.

Much unfavorable comment has recently been aroused among the owners and manufacturers of patent medicines and other proprietary articles by a swindle which is being practiced more and more upon them and the public by some retail druggists.

It is now generally believed in Connecticut that the chief object of the cabal exposed by Mr. LYNDE HARRISON was to secure the defeat of Senator HAWLEY for re-election in the hope of being able to replace him by MORGAN G. BULKELEY. This is in the line of the attempt to defeat Mr. SHERMAN in the interest of FORAKER.

ST. LOUIS, July 30. -- The controversy growing out of the decision of Judge Claiborne that the law closing the poolrooms is unconstitutional has assumed a decidedly sensational phase. Charges and countercharges are made that would lead an unenlightened person to think there was not an honest or decent man in public office or in the legal profession in the city.

RED BANK, N.J., July 30. -- An exciting race for the Neptune Club challenge cup was sailed this afternoon. The cup, which is an elegant silver trophy, was presented to the North Shrewsbury Yacht-Club two years ago by the Neptune Club of the Highlands. It can only be sailed for on the North Shrewsbury River.

Apparently Mr. HARRISON'S Administration prefers that whatever is scandalous in its experience shall be investigated by the Democratic House. It has been accumulating a number of tasks for that body that will be taken up, we may be sure, with entire alacrity, with as much impartiality as such work usually commands, and with opportunities for making party capital for which the gentlemen in power are to be thanked.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- United States Senator Quay arrived in the city from Washington at 7 o'clock to-night. He was accompanied by his son Dick, Frank Willing Leach, and Parker L. Walter, editor of the Pittsburg Chronicle Telegraph. The party was driven at once to the Continental Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Senator Fassett's nomination to be Collector of the Port of New-York came so soon after the resignation of Quay and Dudley from the National Committee that it was almost inevitable that the two circumstances should be spoken of together to-day. If the appointment had been made conditional upon the reorganization of the committee with Quay and Dudley excluded the bargain could hardly have been carried out more promptly.

The gathering of Republicans at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday resembled a political funeral. A pall seemed to hang over the rotunda of the hotel when the State Committee was assembling. Everybody was disposed to discuss the change made at the Custom House by the substitution of Senator J. Sloat Fassett for Col. Joel B. Erhardt for Collector of the Port rather than the coming State campaign.

JAMAICA, L.I., July 30. -- The inquest on the death of Frederick A. Obey, who was murdered in front of Wick's Half-way House, near Hyde Park, L.I., Sunday night, was begun in Miller's Hall, Hyde Park, to-night by Coroner Everett of Jamaica. The accused men, William Covert and George Becker, were present in charge of Constables Ashmead and Murphy.

BALTIMORE, July 30. -- The Democrats of Maryland held a thoroughly harmonious convention in Ford's Opera House to-day, and all the nominations were made without opposition. While the convention leaves a number of disappointed would be candidates in its wake, yet all their fights were made before the body was called to order, and all the nominations were made by acclamation.
ROME, July 30. -- The Holy See has just appointed an extraordinary commission of Cardinals to reorganize the Catholic missions.

There is something comic in the announcement that two Italians and a German have been arrested for sketching the forts at Como, in Lombardy, presumably for the use and behoof of France and Germany. There is an ancient and obsolete superstition about the sketching of military works for which many a picturesque tourist has suffered.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 30. -- A dynamite bomb is about to be exploded under the divorce law of South Dakota by the position taken by Judge Aikens, that the spirit of the law must be complied with, which will result in Mrs. J.G. Blaine, Jr.'s, failure to get a divorce. The general public seems to be unaware of the facts pertaining to the ease with which divorces are granted in this new State.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 30. -- Three hundred representatives of the People's Party assembled in State Convention in this city to-day and took important action in the matter of organizing for the coming campaign. T.W. Ferre, President of the State Alliance, was made Chairman, and a half dozen editors of country papers in sympathy with the party were made executives. Plans of organization were then discussed and adopted.

The few seizures of schooners that have been made in Bering Sea this Summer add interest to the sealing controversy, particularly in regard to the proceedings that may be taken against these vessels. The San Francisco schooner said to have been brought to by the Thetis in prohibited waters would, of course, be subject to our own statutes, now for many years in operation.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 31. -- If the predictions of the Hydrographic Office are verified, the month of August will be very favorable for transatlantic ocean travel, and some unusually quick passages may be expected. The monthly pilot chart for August will be issued to-morrow, and it will show that the steamship routes are almost entirely free from ice, whereas usually the 1st of August finds the ocean off the Grand Banks thickly studded with bergs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- In a long letter to Auditor General McCamant, ostensibly asking for information and instructions before bringing suits for delinquent mercantile taxes, City Treasurer Wright shows up in a startling manner the iniquitous mercantile tax system. In the course of his letter he says:

The statement that the Eastport boats are taking advantage of the presence of the revenue cutter Woodbury openly to fish in British waters must be taken with allowance. The whole point at issue is as to where the boundary runs, or rather as to whether a certain ground occupied by the half dozen boats seized recently by the Dominion cruiser Dream is within British limits.

Even the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, a Republican paper which has been a mouthpiece for Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS in the discussion concerning tin plate, deserts him when it comes to the question of importing workmen under contract to take the place of strikers in his rolling mill and kitchenware factory.

A pleasanter day for racing than the Monmouth Park Association had yesterday could not be asked for. The weather was perfect, the track in good condition, and the races were well fought out as a rule. As favorites won five of the seven races, there was general satisfaction among those present, a number that did not in any way tax the capacities of the track.

In attempting to excite popular sympathy in his behalf, President Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company has drawn a parallel between the life insurance corporation and the savings bank corporation in respect to the alarm that is felt alike by the policy holders of the one and the depositors of the other when the integrity of the institutions which they are interested in is assailed.

PEEKSKILL, July 31. -- Gilmore's classical concert last night proved to be considerably more than a rare musical treat. It worked wonders. Everybody plodded to the mess hall through the most violent thunderstorm of the season, whose lightning accompaniments paled and put to blush the electric lamps, with which the camp grounds is studded in plentiful profusion.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- All day long the corridors of the Continental were crowded with politicians of high and low degree, all anxious to get a word with Senator Quay, and all anxious to discover if possible what the silent statesman's next move would be. The first arrival at the hotel this morning was State Chairman W.H. Andrews.

OTTAWA, July 31. -- There were more sensational developments before the "boodle" investigating committee to-day. A chain of evidence has been woven around Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, and his resignation will be sure to follow. A report submitted by the expert accountants appointed to examine the books of Larkin, Connolly Co., with whom the Minister had confidential relations, shows a serious state of affairs.

HORNELLSVILLE, July 31. -- There is fun ahead in the Twenty-ninth Congressional District Democratic Convention. Charles F. Peck, who nominated David B. Hill in the convention which selected him as the Lieutenant Governor with ex-President Cleveland as the head, some time ago began laying pipes for the nomination by the State Democratic Convention for Lieutenant Governor.

Big fish have been the feature of the angling this Summer. When the trout began to bite freely in the Spring, anglers not only noticed that the average was excellent, but also that the occasional large one was a "whopper." Several trout weighing over two pounds apiece were taken in the Beaverkill region. A two-pound trout is a large one for this State.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- William M. Smith, assignee of the Bank of America, (which closed its doors in April, 1890,) this afternoon filed his first account in the Prothonotary's office. The account shows receipts amounting to $118,047.78, and expenditures $73,431.20, leaving a balance of $44,616.58 for distribution among an army of about 4,000 depositors, whose claims stand undisputed.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- President Harrison has detailed Lieut. McCarty Little, one of the brightest officers in the navy, to go to Spain at once to superintend the construction of the facsimile that is to be made by the Government of the caravel Santa Maria, in which Columbus sailed on the greatest voyage of the ages, for exhibition at the World's Fair.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 31. -- William W. Van Voorhees, who was arrested at Avelon on Saturday by Sheriff Nichols on a charge of fraud, and was released on Monday, has disappeared. He was managing partner of George W. Stetson Co., commission merchants of 69 Wall Street, New-York, and formerly the President of the Harlem National Bank.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 31. -- In response to Treasurer Wright's request for books and papers in his possession belonging to former Philadelphia City Treasurers, Auditor General McCamant this afternoon forwarded the following letter to Mr. Wright:

The story published yesterday morning to the effect that the Messrs. Dwyer were interested in the purchase of a tract of land near New-Brunswick, N.J., where they proposed to establish a track for Winter racing, has no foundation in fact. It was stated that the equipments of the Elizabeth track would be transferred to the new plot of ground, and that there would be no more racing over the New-Jersey Jockey Club's track.

In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, Capt. R.H. Bowman of Los Angeles, Cal., appeared against R.D. Mountdore, a banker and broker, of 510 Fifth Avenue. The complainant claims that he forwarded $1,000 to the defendant, pending his arrival in this city. When he asked for his money July 10, he was told that he would have to give fifteen days' notice.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 31. -- J.R. Sovereign, Labor Commissioner of Iowa, has filed his biennial report with the Governor. The statistical portion of the report embodies in tabulated forms the experiences of more than 3,000 farmers as submitted by themselves. The portion of the report which deals with production is interesting. Mr. Sovereign says:
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Spanish reciprocity treaty and the diplomatic correspondence in regard to it were made public to-day. The following is the President's proclamation:

CHICAGO, July 31. -- The trial of John Stakely and Dennis McCurdy, indicted for conspiracy, resulted to-day in a verdict of guilty. Instead of a penitentiary sentence, which was possible, the men were fined $100. The defendants are railroad conductors, who were instrumental in causing a four days' strike in the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad in November last.

Most railroad men have an impression that the boycott against the Chicago and Alton Road is practically at an end in consequence of the refusal of the Grand Trunk Railway system to persist further in the warfare. It is true that the Alton has not suffered much from this ineffective boycott, but other Western railroad interests have been put to much inconvenience and extra expense because of its operation.

It is not in the least surprising that a rumor should get abroad that Mr. WANAMAKER is to "retire" from the Cabinet. Mr. WANAMAKER has of late been making an exhibition of himself as a witness which is naturally adapted to convert him into a dead weight upon any social, industrial, or political enterprise in which he may be conspicuously engaged.

The committee of the Grand Jury to which the duty of inquiring into the unclean condition of the streets of this city was assigned showed a great deal of tenderness for Commissioner BEATTIE and reserved its reproaches for the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for not allowing him sufficient funds with which to do his work properly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31. -- The Senatorial lines in Ohio are being tightly drawn between Senator Sherman and ex-Gov. Foraker, with Secretary Foster in the background as the beneficiary of the Sherman contingent in the event that the latter fails to secure a majority of the Republican members of the Legislature. The result of the Hamilton County Convention yesterday has alarmed the Sherman managers and discouraged their plans for the immediate future.

Nothing is more curious in the whole business of the official persecution of the Jews in Russia than the difficulty of getting accurate information about it. The "rumor" that the Russian Government had suspended the execution of the edict of expulsion could not have gained currency if the question were of any civilized nation.

LONDON, July 31. -- Messrs. Dillon and O'Brien's repudiation of Parnell, though a foregone conclusion, has profoundly depressed the Parnellites, who relied upon a belief that both would suspend a public announcement. Mr. Parnell sought, through private communications made on the eve of their release, to resume negotiations, but neither responded to these overtures.

The fifteenth Summer school of the American Institute of Christian Philosophy will be held this year at Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J. It begins on Tuesday, Aug. 4, and continues ten days. The Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems, pastor of the Church of the Strangers of this city, will preside and deliver the anniversary address. The annual sermon will be delivered by the Rev. Dr. S.D. McConnell, rector of St. Stephen's Church, Philadelphia.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 31. -- When the steamer Elm City was off Bridgeport on her way from New-York at 10:30 o'clock last night with about thirteen hundred members of the New-Haven Catholic Total Abstinence Society on board, fire broke out directly above the boilers and beneath the floor of Stateroom 47.

The Guaranty Loan and Trust Company of San Francisco has, to say the least, a peculiar method of transacting its business. Its agents in this city are a firm known as "Sharon Co.," who have an office at 712 Broadway, and it is through this concern that any one who desires to "make a loan" is obliged to apply.

Mr. Erhardt, who has resigned his place as the Collector of the Port of New-York for the excellent and uncompromising reason that there was nothing else for him to do, is endeavoring to put himself in the light of a hero and a martyr. This is highly absurd on Mr. Erhardt's part, though in that respect it is characteristic. The Republican Party honored him with an office of great trust and responsibility.

About a week ago Rusie, the big pitcher of the New-York Club, injured his hand and it was feared that he would not be able to play for some time to come. He urged Capt. Ewing to allow him to play yesterday, and he went in to face the Brooklyns.

NEW-LONDON, July 31. -- The last day of the navy and naval reserve at Fisher's Island was clear, bright, and sunny. In the forenoon races were pulled between the naval reserve boats, in which the third division won, and between the Chicago and Newark barges, in which the former won.

El Monitor, a Spanish daily newspaper of Taos, New-Mexico, gives a description of Dudoso, the young son of the famous Apache outlaw, Geronimo. This phenomenally wicked youngster lives with some cowboys at Duncan, Arizona. He was captured when he was nine months old in the Dudoso canon, and war dubbed with its name.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Three Republican Congressmen have resigned their membership on the Committee of Resolutions, in letters of formal withdrawal now before the State Committee. They are F.W. Rockwell of Pittsfield and Gen. Cogswell and Joseph Walker of Worcester. Mr. Rockwell has recently been chosen Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions for the next Republican Convention, and his withdrawal in particular was unlooked for.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Secretary Tracy has finally decided to award the contract for building Cruiser No. 13 to Cramp Sons of Philadelphia, although the Bath Iron Works of Maine were the lowest bidders. In explanation of this action the Secretary has put his reasons on record in the following letter:

ST. LOUIS, July 31. -- Thomas Hackett, Deputy Building Commissioner, was to-day summarily dismissed from his position. This dismissal reveals a queer chapter of municipal government. The dead-lock between the Council and the Mayor over the latter's appointments has resulted in a committee being set to work investigating the departments.

The city will have to pay for some rather peculiar work done several years ago in the reguulating of Clifton Street, between St. Ann's and Union Avenues, unless the decision handed down by Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday is reversed. Proceedings to have the assessment for the improvement reduced were brought by H.P. De Graft, a property owner, through Truman H. Baldwin, on the ground of fraud.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31. -- The will of Mrs. Hopkins-Searles, disinheriting her adopted son, Timothy Hopkins, and leaving her $70,000,000 to Searles, created a big sensation in railroad and other circles. If one-quarter of her railroad interests had been left to young Hopkins, then the Stanford and Crocker faction could easily have purchased the balance and thus secured control.

By far the larger part of the revenues of the United States Treasury are collected from duties on imported merchandise. The greater part of these duties are collected at the port of New-York. The Custom House in this city is the most important business agency of the Government, requiring for its proper management a high degree of business experience and skill, sound judgment, absolute integrity, and a good deal of firmness.
CLEVELAND, July 31. -- There was a brilliant close of the Grand Circuit meeting here this afternoon the four contests being decided in thirteen heats, and only one favorite winning.

We suppose that the obligation of honesty, the duty of carrying out pledges that are made deliberately and voluntarily, will hardly be repudiated by any considerable number of intelligent Americans of this generation. It may be, and often is, disregarded by a certain number, but even then it receives the recognition that vice pays to virtue, in hypocritical pretense.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The Rev. A.A. Zabriskie, former pastor of the Flatbush and Glasco Reformed Churches, but now of the Free Reformed Church of Grand Street, Jersey City, has accepted a call to Manhasset Church, Great Neck, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States notes to secure national bank circulation, $146,089,650, as follows: Currency sixes, $8,700,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $16,772,850; 4 per cents, $114,674,950; 2 per cents, $5,942,050.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- The old wreck recently discovered by the diving class of the torpedo station promises to become an especial object of interest. It lies completely buried in mud and stone on the west side of the torpedo station, within a couple of hundred feet of the island.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- With outstretched hands and faces contorted with mingled sorrow and anger, over one hundred poor Italian laborers surrounded the closed doors of the "Banco Popolare Italiano," 726 South Seventh Street, to-day and clamored for the return of their hard-earned money. Their appeals were in vain.

Notice was printed yesterday that the Board of Directors of the Western National Bank had called a meeting of the stockholders of the bank to be held on Sept. 1 at noon to consider and decide upon a proposition for a reduction of its capital.

As the days go by even the memory of noted events grows dim, and in the flight of years less than a half century is time sufficient to render extremely uncertain a knowledge of things that were deemed of minor importance. That this is true is demonstrated by the inability of many men, even Confederate soldiers, to describe accurately the flag under which they fought.
There are charming things told about the Americans in this book, and they are not less true than the vexing ones.

The ravage of the "yellows" among the Delaware and Maryland peach orchards is proved by the character of the peaches which came from there last week to have been much more serious than even dreamed of by those who most dreaded the disease.

NYACK, Aug. 1. -- There has been a big rush of city people to this place this week and the hotels and boarding houses are filled to overflowing. Among the latest arrivals from New-York and Brooklyn are:

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 1. -- The Water Gap has a fresh air fund among its institutions. There is a handsome roomy house on the slope of Mount Minsi to which twenty-five children from the city are taken every two weeks. It is supported by subscriptions from guests.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The following is the weather crop bulletin issued by the Weather Bureau:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Seven times a year, and always in the Winter, Spring, and Fall, a queer flag is flung to the breeze in Washington. To him who sees it for the first time it may suggest piracy, but to those who know it the black gridiron on a white field is suggestive only of good cheer and innocent merriment. This cross-barred and severe-looking flag is that of the Gridiron Club.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 1. -- To-day Detroit is already in full bloom for the twenty-fifth reunion of the Grand Army of the Republic, the triumphal arches and the decoration of public buildings and business houses excelling in artistic beauty, variety, and extent any similar preparations in honor of the veterans. This is the verdict of all the past commanders who have attended all the reunions of the army.

An exciting fight between a man and a bear took place at South Beach, S.I., Friday evening. Gilholm Issohes was patrolling the beach with an immense performing bear, weighing fully 500 pounds. At Mrs. Miller's hotel a large party of bathers came out of the water and began tantalizing the bear.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 1. -- The gay season here has been quiet up to date, but now it has begun, and Bar Harbor is in for it till well on in September. To add the last thing needful, the two lagging war ships Philadelphia and Petrel that have loitered at Halifax since the Enterprise came in last Sunday made their appearance Friday noon.

Several Brooklyn Republicans of prominence have been complaining to the local papers because it was stated in this column a week ago that the much-talked-of era of good feeling among the various factions of the party was a myth, and that the adherents of Nathan and Woodruff were as bitter in their feelings of antipathy as ever.

The members of the Manhattan Athletic Club's European team are enjoying a rest after their trip. Several of the boys have gone to the Catskills and are the guests of Capt. Cornell, while Luther Cary, the great sprinter, has gone to his home in Chicago. The boys will start in to train again in a few weeks to get in readiness for the Metropolitan championship contests which will take place on Sept. 12.
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- The Goodwood races and the Ministerial banquet have sounded the death kuell of the London season, and next week the holiday exodus will be in full swing.

The Summer boarder is abroad in all her glory. One uses "her" advisedly, for somehow the male adult rarely poses as the Summer boarder. He stands it over Sunday, perhaps, but a consecutive fortnight of undiluted Summer boarding-house life would, as he tells his neighbor in the smoking car as they are being whirled from the city on Saturday, put him in Bloomingdale at the end of it -- and his neighbor agrees with him.

The removal or the wooden walls or the old emigrant station at Castle Garden has brought into view already a portion of the structure of the old fort which occupied that historic spot in the Battery for many years and has given to the Battery an appearance more closely resembling the pictures of it that have been handed down than it has enjoyed within the memory of the present generation.

PEEKSKILL, Aug. 1. -- The glory of the State Camp of Instruction has departed, and for a year to come the military post of the State of New-York at Peekskill-on-the-Hudson will be given over to the elements and the care of Military Storekeeper James Hughes, official representative of the Ordnance Department.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Aug. 1. -- Engine Maquam running wild, collided with a through freight going west on the St. Johnsbury and Lake Champlain Railroad, near Danville, this noon. The engineers and firemen all stuck to their engines and were all badly hurt. Engineer Leslie of the Maquam had his leg and arm broken and received internal injuries and burns. His recovery is doubtful.

The art of great-gun making in the United States, which has made slow progress since the time when the Rodman and Dahlgren cast-iron smooth-bores reached their best development, was given a most substantial encouragement yesterday by the action of the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications in awarding the contract for 100 big coast-defense guns.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The first annual tournament of the Cortland Wheel Club, held at the Cortland Driving Park this afternoon, was a success. Clubs from New-York, Brooklyn, New-Jersey, Rochester, Rome, Utica, Buffalo, Ithaca, Syracuse, Binghamton, Wappinger's Falls, Boston, Norwich, and other cycling circles were represented.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Dispatches received here from Zanzibar state that the tribe of Somalis, which recently made a treacherous attack upon Athale, an Italian coast station in southeast Africa, in latitude 3 north, was repulsed after a sharp struggle, during which thirty men were killed on either side.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The San Domingo reciprocity treaty and the diplomatic correspondence concerning it were made public to-day. The following is the President's proclamation:

" The great Northwest must have an outlet for its commerce through the great lakes -- an outlet deep enough to allow ships of ocean tonnage to pass from Duluth to tidewater, thereby saving hundreds of millions of dollars in charges for loading and unloading her products. She must have this, I say. She demands it; she has the political strength to back the demand, and the issue will be brought, and brought quickly."

It is a pleasure to hear the Hon. John N. Irwin, Governor of Arizona, talk about the Territory of which he is the executive head. He believes in Arizona thoroughly and is able to give good reasons for his belief. At the Murray Hill Hotel last evening in the course of an informal talk he remarked: "Arizona is the sanitarium of America.

It was to be expected that Parnellism would die hard in Ireland, but it will scarcely be pretended by anybody but PARNELL himself that it is not at last dead. The defection of DILLON and O'BRIEN and of the owner of the Freeman's Journal may be said to leave him without an organ or a friend, that is a friend whose support will do him any good with the Irish people.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 1. -- The event of the week was the german at the Spring House. It was the first real, genuine, full-dress hop of the Summer, and invitations were very much in demand. Mrs. Robert Tailer wore a handsome gown of white satin, with jetted waist, cut decolletee, trimmed with thread lace, and diamond ornaments.

Old residents in Great Barrington remember when, nearly fifty years ago, Mrs. Searles was Mary Frances Sherwood, daughter of William Sherwood, Principal of a boys' school in New-York. She was a pupil in the Kellogg Terrace School, conducted by her aunts, Sarah, Mary, and Nancy Kellogg, and belonged to a coterie of pupils whom the young men regarded with admiration and certain feelings of awe.

Joaquin Sanchez, the Director General of the Spanish-American department of the New-York Life Insurance Company, has at last been heard from. Sanchez is the man who is said to have discovered the shortage in the accounts of his partner, the defaulter Merzbacher, and he it is who was ordered by President Beers to get out of the jurisdiction of the State with the tell-tale books of the Spanish-American department.

The Giants lost to Brooklyn on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and are now in third position. They are led by both Chicago and Boston now, and altogether are in a bad position at this stage of the race. Chicago, as usual, won, and now holds a good lead.

There seems to be no sort of check upon "boss" methods in the Republican politics of Pennsylvania. There is to be a convention this month for the nomination of candidates for State Treasurer and Auditor General, but on Friday last Senator QUAY was in consultation with politicians in Philadelphia with a view to agreeing upon the candidates to be nominated.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 1. -- The appointment of a committee to secure a reform in the system of taxation in Waterbury has directed public attention to the gross inequalities in the assessment of taxable property in Connecticut. Since 1851 the law has required that all property, real and personal, should be listed at its "fair, market value."

Those who saw the Emperor's luggage brought ashore at Port Victoria will remember the iron safe which formed part of it. In this safe was the large collection of jeweled snuff boxes, silver cigarette cases, diamond breastpins, signet rings, , which the Kaiser brought with him for distribution among the members of the Queen's household and many other officials with whom he was brought in contact during his visit.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 1. -- The cross-examination of P. Larkin was concluded before the Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day. He said he had never known where the $25,000 granted by the firm went, but he understood it was used for election purposes. Mr. Oster said that the Hon. Thomas McGreevy would be examined on Tuesday.

The call for the meeting of the Democratic State Committee for Wednesday, Aug. 12, at 10 A.M., at the Hoffman House has renewed interest in the speculation as to what sort of an attempt Tammany will make to prevent the County Democracy from being represented in the State Convention.

Since the close of the articles in THE TIMES describing some Southern prisons and giving the story of the escape or Tom Bell and myself from Millen, Ga., a few old prison comrades who know me as the writer of these reminiscences, have urged me personally and by letter to complete them by telling what became of my brave companion.

Throughout the month of August the sun hurries away toward the south and the days shorten. More than nine degrees in northerly declination separate the first and last days of the month. The sun's rising hour this morning was 4:57, while its corresponding hour on the same day last month was 4:33. At the close of the month the rising hour will be 5:26.
The following remarks in the Christian Union show that our worthy contemporary is not familiar with the lectures delivered by Lieut. TOTTEN before the students of Yale University:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The Hotel Kaaterskill, New Grand, Catskill Mountain House, Laurel House, and several others of the large hostelries in the Catskills now count their guests by hundreds. The old Catskill Mountain House is in the midst of its sixty-ninth season. Although many other resorts have been opened in the range, it retains its popularity.

LAREDO, Texas, Aug. 1. -- This morning the particulars of the fight between smugglers and the customs guards from New-Laredo, which took place a few days ago, were received in the city and announced a most fatal affair for the guards. The party of smugglers consisted of twenty-five or thirty desperate characters, who had in their possession a large lot of contraband articles.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The moist weather of the past week precipitated an epidemic of the blues among the hotel guests, but to-night everybody is in good humor and participating in the amusements at the hotels and on the beach front. The usual weekly full-dress hops took place at the big hotels. Over in Ocean Grove the demure visitors put in the day and evening listening to temperance lectures by noted cold-water advocates.

Your last Sunday's edition contains a criticism of my plan for promotion in the navy, published in your issue of July 19, to which I should, like to reply. The writer, who subscribes himself * * *, has evidently not understood the working of the proposed measure. He states that there will be no result for about ten years, and no serious result for perhaps fifteen.

Mr. Stephens has already become known here as the author of a new history of the revolution in France, of which the first part only has yet appeared. In that work he has aimed to lay before the public a history which shall not only be based on the old material, but on the new, of which a large mass exists representing the accumulations since Carlyle wrote.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- A greater number of professors than usual from the university are spending their vacations in scientific investigations and research in the interest of the geological and biological departments as well as for their own personal advancement in that special branch of study.

Mr. Fassett was at the Custom House yesterday, and there he had an interview with Collector Erhardt. He reached the Custom House with Deputy Collector Burr and one or two other friends about 10:30 o'clock. The talk of the incoming and outgoing Collectors occupied about two hours.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is right about Quay. Quay is not the product of accidental generation in Pennsylvania; he does not come without the conditions that produce Quays. They will continue to produce them unless there is a radical change in the party from which the Quays proceed. And when the Quays do leave office in the party the responsibility for them is not ended with their withdrawal.

Since the midsummer tournament for the harness racers began at Pittsburg three weeks ago there has been no lack of sensations. In the matter of speed the honors go to a pacer, the performance of Hal Pointer at Cleveland last Wednesday being the most notable instance of a horse sustaining an extreme flight for three miles.

WOMELSDORF, Penn., Aug. 1. -- The wild woman who roamed over South Mountain near this place years ago, it is reported, has made her appearance again. One of a party from this place while picking huckleberries says he saw her.

The list of the steamship routes which our Post Office Department desires to encourage by offering handsome sums of money for carrying American mails to foreign countries has recently been made public. An examination of them in detail shows some interesting facts:

Americans and Englishmen never read plays -- at least, the present acting ones. An unimaginative public does not care a snap for the accepted printed drama. It has not been trained to such mental efforts as understanding a dramatic situation in cold type. It may be that the modern English or American play is not worth the reading.

G.M. Walcott, Jr., was arrested by the United States authorities Tuesday charged with a wrongful use of the mails. The warrant states that he sent an envelope of unusually large size bearing in great red letters the words "Collection Department" to Robert Madison "with the intention of injuring him and bringing him into disrepute."

Your editorial article of a few days ago frankly and kindly put the query whether this institute was to continue. As the date draws near for a decision, will you kindly allow me these few words, which, from my somewhat public record and the publicity of the interest, seems only appropriate?

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Though there has been nothing new in the world of music and the drama, already may be heard the sounds of preparation for the coming season. Monday night the first "Fall opening" will take place at the Grand Opera House, when Thatcher's Minstrels and Rich and Harris's farce-comedians will offer "Tuxedo," in which minstrelsy and farce-comedy are combined.

All Europe and America were groping in darkness until the Oxford professor threw his powerful light on the Jewish question in Russia. In former years, when passengers had to cross the desert from Suez to Cairo, in Egypt, in omnibuses, some strange sights wore enjoyed. One of these was to see suddenly a black cloud, composed of thousands of vultures and birds of prey, setting up an unearthly screech.
Our recollection of the history of leasing convict labor in Tennessee since the war is only a matter of memory; we have no records or documents to refer to.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1. -- One of the finest trains that ever traveled westward will be that over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to-morrow, the destination of which will be Detroit, where those on board go to attend the annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. The train will be divided into two sections, and both are composed of brand-new vestibuled cars just from the shops.

It was in 1856 that Mr. Motley published his "Rise of the Dutch Republic," and it was in 1860, when he was forty-six years old, that he published the first two volumes, concluded in 1867, of the "History of the United Netherlands." These works gave to their author an imperishable name as a historian, by which he took rank with Prescott.

Michael Fortunato, the boss of "Little Italy," was arrested yesterday and brought before Recorder Smyth on a bench warrant, having been indicted again by the Grand Jury. The complainant against him this time is Mrs. Elizabeth Muchardo. Fortunato's sister lived in his house with her husband. In the family was also Mrs. Muchardo.

TRIER, Aug. 1. -- The "Holy Coat of Trier," the garment supposed to have been worn by the Saviour, will be exhibited at the cathedral here for six weeks, commencing Aug. 18. Fully 2,000,000 pilgrims are expected to visit Trier during that time. An earnest and long controversy has been waged regarding the genuineness of the relic.

Some of the passengers from the Orient steamer Chimborezo arrived at Granton, near Edinburgh, July 17 by the Norwegian steamer Britannia, from Bergen. The Chimborazo is the English tourist steamer which ran on a rock in the Toft Sound, Norway, and which afterward proceeded on her return voyage and reached Bergen, as already reported. A correspondent of the London Daily News writes from Edinburgh:

PARIS, July 14. -- It is not often that the Comedie Francaise gives a new play at this season of the year. Usually the Summer months serve to revive old plays, in which the young troupe of pensionnaires have an opportunity to show their talent. Upon the occasion of the production of M. Paul Ferrier's "Article 231," M. Got heads the cast.

DANVILLE, Ill., Aug. 1. -- Our little city is all torn up over a contest between the Street Railway Company, of which ex-Congressman J.G. Cannon is the head, and the municipal authorities. The city is paving Main Street, and Mr. Cannon's company is laying tracks for an electric street railroad. Mayor Beard and the other officials of the city object to the manner in which the railroad is being constructed and so notified the company.

Before the racing at Morris Park yesterday, Col S.D. Bruce sold twenty-one head of yearlings at auction for a total of $5,540. Jay Gould and Russell Sage are unique among the millionaires of this town in having new or no club affiliations. So far as is known, "The Wizard of Wall Street" belongs to but one club, the American Yacht Club. His side partner is still less of a clubman, having kept out of clubs altogether. With these exceptions, the millionaires of Gotham are emphatically clubmen.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The Republican County Convention for Seneca County, held at Romulus to-day, was one of the most exciting in the political history of this section, resulting in a bolt and two conventions. Only one convention is held in the county, there being only one Assembly district, to elect State, Judicial, and Senatorial delegates.

FONTAINEBLEAU, July 15. --Midsummer is the season for Fontainebleau town, for about the time that the President arrives come the strangers, and also the Parisians, who still find here many cafes, much military, and no little hint of the pomp that used to accompany the Napoleons when they ruled France. Trumpets blow and sentinels appear where sentinels were not a month before.
What are you waiting for?"

Boston, Aug. 1. -- The Hon. Albert Nason, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts; Lucius Turtle, General Manager of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, and John F. Goddard of New-York, Chairman of the Trunk Line Association, were recently appointed referees to construe the traffic contract between the Boston and Maine and the Concord and Montreal Railroad.

While it hardly becomes our protectionist friends to complain of the selfishness of the English in opposing the efforts of the United States to secure reciprocity arrangements with Spain and other countries, it is to be said that such opposition is not creditable to the English. Not only the theory but the very audible boast of the English Government is that all it wishes for its trade is a fair field and no favor.

The question that is often put to the amateur photographer is "What camera shall I buy and where shall I get it?" Unless the amateur has some particular dealer to recommend, or some special camera has hit his eye, he is forced to give an evasive answer, and can only recount some of the cameras that are known to be standard.

Only one convention is held in the county, there being only one Assembly district, to elect State, Judicial, and Senatorial delegates.

Trumpets blow and sentinels appear where sentinels were not a month before.

The question that is often put to the amateur photographer is "What camera shall I buy and where shall I get it?" Unless the amateur has some particular dealer to recommend, or some special camera has hit his eye, he is forced to give an evasive answer, and can only recount some of the cameras that are known to be standard.

TOPEKA, Aug. 1. -- Flushed with success, the Kansas Alliance has thrown off all disguise and proposes to carry everything in this State at the Fall elections. That it can do this, or nearly so, now seems to be a reasonable certainty. The Republicans are badly demoralized, while the Democrats have practically lost their organization.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- The shares of the Deutsche Bank, which on Saturday last were quoted at 150, closed to-day at 140. The frauds on the bank perpetrated by its clerk, Franck, and the broker, Schwieger, have excited the whole financial world to a degree unknown since the embezzlements of the two Directors of the Leipsic Disconto Gesellschaft.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- That the inducements thrown out by building and loan associations are having their effect among the patrons of savings banks is demonstrated by the statements just made to the State Superintendent of Banking by the twenty-five savings banks doing business in the city of New-York. For the six months ended July 1 there has been a falling off in the aggregate resources of these banks of about $800,000.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 1. -- The Board of Trade reception to Admiral Walker and the officers of the squadron of evolution took place to-night in the armory of the Third Regiment Connecticut National Guard. The building was ablaze outside with Japanese lanterns and a general illumination and the interior was lavishly decorated with flags, bunting, flowers, and plants, and never before looked as well.

ST.
