LOUIS, Aug. 1. -- The Municipal Electric Lighting Company has the contract for lighting the city streets at a price that is well known to be a losing one on every lamp, and for some time business and financial circles have been agitated over reports that the company was about to abandon the contract and forfeit its bond of $50,000. These rumors have taken a very wide range and assumed a variety of phases.

Very little comfort is to be derived from the Grand Jury "presentment" of Friday in regard to the condition of the streets of this city, which continues to be altogether bad. The committee of the Grand Jury whose report was submitted to the court as a "presentment" must have made an extremely superficial examination of the matter, and its report is in some respects ridiculous.

A decision has been made by Albert Stickney, to whom was referred the suit brought by Maria H.P. Wright, the widow of Dexter R. Wright, of New-Haven, Conn., against Thomas B. Sexton and others, to recover a large estate at Bay Shore, L.I. Mr. Stickney finds in favor of the defendants, fully establishing their title. The property consists or 600 acres on the shore or Great South Bay, and is worth about $200,000.
" How was the Calumet and Hecla discovered, you ask. Here, Capt. Duncan, you tell this man what he wants to know."

A small tract of Crown land in Pall Mall was recently leased for a term of eight years at an annual rental of 1,525, amounting to 8s. 6d. per foot of the area, which is nearly equivalent to a selling price of half a million sterling per acre. The plot of ground is 60 feet by 59 feet, and is situated nearly opposite the Travelers' Club.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 2. -- Oliver Hurd was arrested to-day on a charge of passing counterfeit money. On him were found samples of notes ranging from $1 to $20, some United States, some Canadian. Years ago the prisoner served a term in Dorchester, and during the past eight or ten years he has been operating throughout the Provinces in the bogus-money line.

Thomas L. Smart, a Fulton Street engraver, was passing through Howard Street late on Saturday night, when he was asked the time by a gang of young men. He showed a handsome gold watch in replying to their request, and passed on. Then he discovered that he was being followed. At Crosby Street, meeting Michael Costello of 57 Spring Street, he asked Costello to show him to a car.

BRADFORD, Penn., Aug. 2. -- Potter County is alarmed over the ravages of a worm that is destroying the foliage and killing off the hemlock timber. About five days ago it was noticed by lumbermen that the tops of the heavy timber on the mountains were turning brown, as if the trees were dying. The trees looked exactly as if they had gone through a forest fire or were withering up for lack of irrigation.

We give in our dispatches from Concord, N.H., this morning some interesting details of the sentiment of Republican politicians in that State regarding Mr. HARRISON and the recent resignations of QUAY and DUDLEY. It is well known that there is a considerable and active body of the political enemies of Mr. HARRISON there.
PARIS, Aug. 2. -- The Chicago Fair Commissioners were interviewed here yesterday, just before starting for Berlin. Mr. Peck said:

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Discount during the past week was quoted at 1 1/2 for three months and 1/2 for short. There was no demand. Money is plentiful. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2@1 3/4. Gold continues to be in active demand for Germany, but the influx into the Bank of England for the week exceeds the efflux, while there is 250,000 due from Australia.

ELMIRA, Aug. 2. -- Rash indeed would have been the prediction, ten years ago, that Thomas C. Platt was ever again to occupy a position of trust and responsibility in the Republican Party and to become the dictator in State politics. It was believed that after his ignominious retirement from the United States Senate in May, 1881, Platt was "as good as done for."

SQUADRON OF EVOLUTION, NEW-LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Last week saw the completion of what bids fair to prove a very momentous departure in the training and development of our sea forces. It has long been recognized that a country with our military instincts is at least safe from invasion. Nearly every boy desires to become a soldier.

There seems to be very good reason for belief that the Monmouth Park Association is suffering from a boycott, and that the boycott is responsible for the comparative failure of the series of meetings that are being held at the Jerome Park track. The association cannot get horses to run for the rich purses that are daily offered for horse owners to compete for.

The Liverpool correspondent of the London Standard of July 20 writes the following account of the recent disaster on the ship canal at Manchester: "An appalling disaster occurred early on Saturday morning on the Ince section of the Manchester Ship Canal, resulting in the death of ten men and serious injury to four others.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The fact that a little newspaper in Hoboken has joined the caravan of those that have served forewarnings of trouble, if he attempts to pervert the political sentiment of the State, upon Gov. Leon Abbett, has aroused a good deal more comment than a newspaper of its size might be expected to arouse.

It is to be regretted that in this delightful book Mr. Saintsbury, save an occasional mention of Balzac, fails to treat of him. But to Dumas he gives full justice. The fact is that Balzac is a literary phenomenon hard to explain. Mr. George Moore is a Balzac fanatic, but too noisy a one for our liking.

Mr. MCKINLEY and the statesmen of China to the contrary, it must be admitted that commerce is by far the greatest of all civilizing agencies. The condition as to civilization of any nation can be very fairly judged from the statistics of its commerce, foreign and domestic, while the civilization of the world at large can be told with even more accuracy from the statistics of international commerce.

While foreign countries have long been experimenting with the nitrate or so-called smokeless powders, both in small arms and field pieces, and, indeed, in several instances long ago, regularly adopted them for service purposes, our military and naval authorities have hitherto followed more slowly in that direction.

In one important particular the Police Department differs from every other department of the City Government, in that it has its own Treasurer and disburses its own funds, audits the pay rolls of its employes and the bills incurred for supplies, , and pays them monthly without recourse to the Controller, the fiscal officer of the municipality. In this it is unique.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 2. -- E.S. Hammond, District United States Judge, has handed down his decision in the famous case of R.M. King, the Seventh-day Adventist. King was convicted a year ago of Sabbath-breaking by plowing on Sunday in Obion County. He appealed to the Supreme Court, and the sentence was affirmed.

BOSTON, Aug. 2. -- For some time there has been trouble in the Twelfth Baptist Church Society, (colored,) whose church is situated on Phillips Street. The church has been without a pastor for several months, and a call on behalf of a portion of the members was recently extended to the Rev. Henry H. Harris, a former pastor.

Preliminary to a meeting of the Committee of One Hundred appointed to save Battery Park for park purposes, Lawrence J. Callanan of that committee has written an answer to the pamphlet recently addressed by Erastus Wiman to "certain citizens" of this city. It is as follows:

Some of our high-tariff friends are alarmed because the contract-labor law promises to prevent the importation of workmen under contract by Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS of St. Louis. This manufacturer of kitchen-ware has been very useful to the followers of MCKINLEY, and they want to stand by him.

There has just been published by the Treasury a statement that is extremely valuable and interesting to all who care to know the operation of the law of 1890 for the purchase of 4,500,000 ounces of silver per month. This statement shows the "monthly receipts from customs at New-York since January, 1889, and the percentage of each kind of money received."

As stated in THE TIMES of yesterday some one shot and instantly killed Thomas McLoughlin of 135 West Sixty-seventh Street, in front of the brownstone flat, 416 East Eighty-ninth Street, Saturday night, at about 10:30 o'clock. An hour and a half later the police arrested William Hallisy, a brother-in-law of the murdered man, in the rooms where he lives, 420 East Eighty-ninth Street, on the charge of having committed the deed.

A barn on the city farm at Fitchburg, Mass., was burned yesterday, with a large quantity of hay, a pair of horses a pair of oxen, and farming tools. Frank Miller, head farmer, was smothered while trying to save the horses, and his body was burned to a crisp. Loss, $4,000, no insurance.

The eyes of Congregationalists in particular and Protestants in general have been turned toward London during the last two weeks noting the deliberations of the first International Council of Congregationalists. Thanks to the letters and cablegrams sent to the denominational journals and to the English newspapers brought by the last mall, it is possible at this early date to get a very accurate impression of what was said and done.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The services to-day have been more largely attended than over before this season. The camp grounds at the hours of Auditorium worship were crowded, while at the early services hundreds were compelled to remain outside around the windows of the young people's temple and the Tabernacle.

A friend places in my hand a statement concerning the enormous force exerted by the growth power of plants, of which he has some doubt, and suggests that some comment thereon might be acceptable. According to this statement fungi are found in the old silver mines of Mexico which take on numerous forms, frequently of immense size.

The smuggling of Chinamen into the United States, which used to be an industry chiefly prosecuted on the British Columbian and Mexican frontiers, is now evidently carried on more or less along a great part of our Canadian boundary. The evidence of the illicit importation of Chinese laborers at Lewiston, on the Niagara River, is just now attracting special attention; but the same thing is noted at Ogdensburg and has long been observed at Detroit.
THE TIMES of July 12 called public attention to the fact that one Julius Merzbacher, a trusted employe of the New-York Life Insurance Company, was a defaulter for a large sum of the Company's

The staid apartment house, the Percival, 230 West Forty-second Street, was last night, the scene of an attempt at murder that is likely to prove successful, Charles E. Goodwin, a commercial agent, who is connected with the wine firm of Goodwin Ricord, having been shot in the abdomen by Bertram C. Webster, the horse owner and bookmaker.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 2. -- The Mexican Railway Company lies just receivedfournew locomotives from Glasgoxv. The road between this city and Vera Cruz is not in good condition, being affected In many Dlaces by heavy x'aina.

In the columns of THE TIMES this morning the charges made four years ago by the cashier of the New-York Life Insurance Company against the President and officers of the company come for the first time under the public eye.

There will be a "conference" of Prohibitionists on Staten Island this week. Several representatives of the Farmers' Alliance and the Cincinnati People's Party have been invited to be present and give their views regarding a "fusion." So far as can be gathered from an address issued by the National Committee of the Prohibitionists, fusion means nothing more nor less than absorption by the Prohibitionists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The officers connected with the Assistant District Attorney General's office of the Post Office Department have succeeded, it is believed, in rendering abortive the attempt of the Home Fascinator Company of Montreal, Canada, to victimize many credulous Americans. This concern, it is stated, publishes a monthly journal called the Home Fascinator, alleged to be devoted to useful knowledge, romance,

The Hudson County Jockey Club will begin their midsummer meeting at the Guttenberg track on Monday next, racing at Brighton Beach being brought, to a close to-morrow. Instead of racing six days a week, as intended, they will probably race only on Mondays and Fridays. This will be done if the Monmouth Park Racing Association will give up Fridays to them, and the clash of dates thus avoided.

A wedding of an international character will be celebrated to-morrow at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Pickering at Beechwood, near Langhorne, Bucks County, Penn. The bride is the only daughter of Major and Mrs. Samuel Comfort, guests at the Hotel Marlborough, this city, and the groom is Crookshank Pasha, Director General of Prisons of Egypt. Over 600 invitations have been sent out. Beechwood is a handsome country house, the home of Mrs. Comfort's sister.

One of the best programmes yet offered by the Monmouth Park Racing Association is that for to-day at Jerome Park. There are seven races on the card for decision, for the sixth race of the book programme failing to fill the seventh race for two-year-olds was divided. The fixtures are the Red Bank for two-year-olds and the Palisade for three-year-olds, for both of which fair fields are named to start.

The strike of the pavers, rammers, and chippers which was ordered by District Assembly No. 49 in several streets was extended yesterday morning. It was decided to make the pavers in Hubert Street, who were allowed to work Saturday, also go out. Secretary McNair of No. 49 started up town to Twenty-third Street, where the pavers had gathered to get the order to strike.

The St. Louis Republic makes a cruel suggestion for the guidance of Attorney General MILLER and District Attorney REYNOLDS of St. Louis in enforcing the so-called Anti-Trust law. Some weeks ago we published the history of the making of the Barbed Wire Trust, a new combination operating under a chartered organization known as the Columbia Patent Company.

We find in the market reports of the Toronto Monetary Times of the 31st ult. the price of pig lead quoted as follows: "Lead per 100 pounds, pig, $3.60 to $3.75." This is the price in Toronto and Montreal of pig lead which is produced in this country and sent to the Canadian market.

NEWARK, Aug. 3. -- Sam Sing, the Kearny laundryman who was reported to be suffering with leprosy, has published an appeal to the public for its aid in protecting himself against the libels of his heathen enemies. He says that two years ago his Chinese persecutors, in the same line of business with himself, caused an article to be put in one of the Newark papers accusing him of being a leper.

Abraham Backer, a man interested in many lines of business and one of the biggest and best known money lenders and note brokers in the city, failed yesterday. His assignment was made to Benjamin F. Einstein of Townsend, Dyett Einstein, lawyers, of 247 Broadway. His liabilities are put at the very large total of $4,000,000.

BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- The indications point strongly to a lively meeting of the Republican State Committee Wednesday. The meeting is called to elect a Chairman and two members of the Committee on Resolutions, the vacancies being caused by the resignation of Congressmen F.W. Rockwell, William Cogswell, and J.H. Walker.

A most destructive fire occurred on Staten Island last evening. The electric plant of the Richmond County Light and Power Company was burned, and the entire populous territory on the island, except Port Richmond, was left in darkness. One of the company's employes was severely burned.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 3. -- Architect Cady of New-York is preparing plans for a new building for the Sheffield Scientific School, work upon which will be begun this Fall. For several years it has been apparent that the facilities of this department of Yale were inadequate to its needs, but with the large increase in the number of incoming students in September it has become an absolute necessity that the quarters be enlarged at once.

A fire started yesterday morning in David Boyd's packing box factory, 199 Wooster Street, near Bleecker. The upper floors of the building are occupied by Michael Schwartz, manufacturer of jewelry boxes, and Joseph New, wood turner. The fire was extinguished. The total loss is estimated at $5,000.

Still another is added to the list of reputable Republicans who decline to take the nomination for Governor this Fall. Mr. JAMES W. WADSWORTH, who worthily bears an honored name, had been looked upon by the younger Republicans as a candidate whom they could support with a clear conscience and with a good deal of enthusiasm.

The Kaweah colony, which, in defiance not only of Secretary NOBLE but of Capt. DORST'S troop of cavalry, persists in cutting timber within the limits of Sequoia Park, is not wholly without excuse for its course. Of the two acts of Congress setting apart the lands constituting the new park, one makes no exception to the rule requiring the removal of trespassers, while the other seems to recognize existing lawful settlements.

The six hundredth anniversary of her independence which Switzerland is now engaged in celebrating makes our own Republic seem very modern and juvenile by comparison. Undoubtedly the Swiss Confederation of to-day is a very different affair from the league for defense which the three cantons of Uri. Schwvz, and Unterwalden formed at the beginning of August, in the year 1291.

Charles E. Goodwin, who was shot in his apartments at the fashionable Percival flats, 230 West Forty-second Street, on Sunday night, died at 2:15 o'clock yesterday morning at Roosevelt Hospital, Bertram C. Webster, race-horse owner and bookmaker, who for many years has been a conspicuous figure among the sporting fraternity and who fired the shot that killed Goodwin, is still at large.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 3. -- Attorneys representing the New-York bondholders of the San Antonio and Aransas Pass Railway to-day filed an amended petition in the Forty-fifth District Court. The object is, if possible, to obtain a rehearing of the case and a reversal of Judge King's recent decision whereby the local creditors were given preference over the bondholders.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The annual baby parade took place this afternoon on the beach promenade. The parade was under the immediate supervision of Mayor James A. Bradley. The line of march formed at the Asbury Avenue Pavilion, and, headed by the full band of the United States steamship Trenton playing "Rock-a-Bye Baby," proceeded up the promenade and countermarched, returning in files of four.

The position of leadership of the Republican Party in New-York to which Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT has now attained, by grace of the President, naturally suggests a comparison between him and the public man who last held a similar post, ROSCOE CONKLING. There was a time when their names were intimately connected.

Controller, Myers renewed the census controversy with Superintendent Porter yesterday when he sent another long letter to Mr. Porter. It is a reply to Mr. Porter's letter of July 28, in which he asked to be informed as to the aggregate expenditures of the city in 1889 for county purposes, and also the amount expended for parks, bridges, and aqueducts, for construction of new ones in distinction from amounts for maintenance of the old.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3. -- Some days ago, when questioned by THE TIMES'S correspondent, Mr. F.G. Niedringhaus denied that, he intended to send an agent to Europe to employ workmen for his mills. Notwithstanding this it is positively learned that General Superintendent William Harris of the Niedringhaus Roller Mills and Tin Plate Works of this city left Saturday night for New-York, whence he will sail for a business trip to England and Wales.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 3. -- The Republican candidate for Governor of Ohio came to Pittsburg from West Virginia to-day. He says his visit has no significance and that he will return to Canton to-morrow and prepare for the work of the campaign. He seemed to have no cares to-day as he attended a circus performance in the afternoon and in the evening witnessed a display of fireworks.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 3. -- Gov. Pattison on Saturday last sent the following letter to Secretary of the Treasury Foster:

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Fire involving a loss estimated to be at least $700,000 broke out at 7:30 o'clock this morning in the large retail dry goods and notions store of Siegel, Cooper Co., southeast corner of State and Adams Streets. The blaze started in the exchange room on the first floor and spread through the inflammable stock with the greatest rapidity.

BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- Ex-President Cleveland presided to-night at a meeting in the little town of Bourne for the preservation of the fishing in Buzzard's Bay, which is rapidly becoming completely destroyed by the working of seines, pounds, and weirs on the line of the bay. Fishermen in rough clothes rubbed elbows with Summer cottagers who, doubtless, had been attracted by the knowledge that Mr. Cleveland was going to preside.

Yesterday was the three hundred and ninety-ninth anniversary of the sailing of COLUMBUS, and to-day the three hundred and ninety-ninth anniversary of his dropping the Andalusian coast on his fateful voyage of exploration.

" The question of fusion between the Prohibition and the Farmers' Alliance or the People's Party will undoubtedly enter into the discussion which we expect at the Prohibition Party conference to be held on Staten Island this week," said John Lloyd Thomas, Secretary of the National Prohibition Committee, to a TIMES reporter yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- Mr. William Walter Phelps the United States Minister, to-day accompanied Messrs. Handy, Bullock, Butterworth, Lindsay, and Peck, comprising the Foreign Committee of the Chicago Columbian Exhibition, to the office of Herr von Boetticher, Secretary of the Imperial Home Office and representative of the Chancellor.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Frank B. Sturges of the law firm of Owen, Gray Sturges, to-day assumed the temporary receivership of the Schuyler Steam Towboat Company. This corporation succeeded the old Schuyler towing line last year, then the oldest line of towboats on the Hudson River. It has been apparent for some years that the big boats of this company were too expensive to operate.

The mystery enveloping the murder of the young woman whose body was found on Sunday morning at Glendale, just outside the Brooklyn city line, is as profound to-day as it was at the outset. The fact is now evident that Sunday was allowed to pass without any attempt to trace the murderer, although an experienced detective might then have found important clues on the ground where the body lay.

President Brayton Ives of the Western National Bank made a statement yesterday in which he gave a further explanation of the reasons which had led the Directors to advise a reduction in the capital of the bank. After speaking of the reasons which were explained in yesterday's TIMES, he added.

It is a very curious letter which Mr. BLAINE'S intimate friend "JOE" MANLEY has written and caused, or allowed, to be made public. The substance of it is that Mr. BLAINE is in excellent health and "will go back to Washington this Fall a much more vigorous and healthy man than he has been for years."

It is scarcely conceivable that the Russian Government will withhold its cooperation from the committee of Hebrews who are trying to make the forced migration from Russia of their co-religionists as easy as possible. To refuse this co-operation would be to show a perfectly wanton malignity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- The following notice has been sent to C.T. Yerkes, P.A.B. Widener, William L. Elkins, C.R. Cummings, Sidney A. Kent, Thomas Dolan, and W.W. Biggs by Secretary C.K. Wooster for the Chicago Gaslight and Coke Company:

The Fourteenth Street Theatre has begun its new season with triumph. "A Fair Rebel," a play written by a novice, Harry P. Mawson, and acted by a company that contains scarcely an actor, excepting Maurice Pike, who is known to this public, will crowd the house as long as it is kept on view. At the second performance last night there was not a seat to spare and all the standing room was occupied.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 4. -- To-day's municipal election resulted in a sweeping victory for the Democrats. Last year the City Government was composed of six Republican and three Democratic Aldermen. This year the entire body will be composed of Democrats. John J. Larkey, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, received a majority of 915 over Thomas F.O. Marvin, the Republican.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 4. -- The Old Colony Distillery Company of this city, of which Adolph Woolner of Peoria, Ill., is President, and Nathan I. Nathan of this city is Secretary and Treasurer, is in pecuniary difficulties. An assignment will probably be made within a week. Attachments to the amount of $168,700 have already been levied.

Henry Bartels, a young bartender, fell gasping behind the bar at Theodore Feldstein's saloon, at 266 Grand Street, at 6 o'clock last evening, was carried up stairs yet alive, but speechless, and died on a lounge a few minutes after. The police reported that he was killed by electric shock. There are several reasons for doubting this statement.
BUFFALO, Aug. 4. -- The Grand Circuit races made their appearance here this afternoon, and but one favorite won, Happy Bee having a hollow victory in the 2:29 class.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 4. -- An event of this week here will be the celebration of the golden wedding of John and Isabella Beecher-Hooker Wednesday afternoon. Nearly two thousand invitations have been sent out to persons in this country and Europe. The affair will take the shape of an old-fashioned tea party. There will be all the old-time friends of the Hooker and Beecher families and the grandchildren of the two families.

The anti-railroad movement is gaining in extent and earnestness among the residents of that section of Eleventh Avenue through which the New-York Central's freight trains run. There has been a steady increase in the membership of the West Side Citizens' Association, and already preparations are under way for an open-air public meeting to be held in the vicinity of Forty-second Street and Eleventh Avenue on Friday evening, Aug. 14.

Yesterday was a bad day for the Ohio wool barons, for the Board of General Appraisers decided two cases against them. They were cases in which the barons took a deep interest, and over which they had spent much time in the way of "agitation" in favor of American "protection."

At a meeting of the officers and Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company yesterday it was decided to take measures to stop the food of adverse criticism against the company. These measures resolved themselves into the publication of a portion of the report of the special committee appointed in October, 1887, to examine the charges made by Cashier Theodore M. Banta against the officers of the company.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- George W. Williams, a colored lawyer of Boston, Mass., who some time ago visited the Upper Congo country, and who wrote letters to King Leopold of Belgium severely criticising the methods of the Congo Free State officials and also those of Mr. Henry M. Stanley, died at the Palatine Hotel at Blackpool, a town in Lancashire, to-day.

Senator VEDDER succeeded in getting the convention at Jamestown so made up that opposition to his renomination was hopeless, and he was yesterday made a candidate once more by acclamation. A little comfort may be drawn from his pledge that he will not seek the nomination again, but he thinks his work of "reforming" the tax laws is not finished.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 4. -- Chester, S.C., is in a state of great excitement over a duel which took place on one of the principal streets last night between a prominent lawyer and a newspaper editor. E.B. Sligh, a lawyer and a very active Democratic politician, some weeks ago applied to the President for the Chester Postmastership, and published a card declaring himself a national Republican.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- Harvard will have a new dormitory next Fall. Last Spring J.H. McNamee, the bookbinder of Harvard Square, came to the conclusion that a handsome and elegantly-appointed dormitory would not lack for occupants. So during the last few months he has been erecting a building after the plans of George F. Fogarty of Cambridgeport.

LAFAYETTE, La., Aug. 4. -- The Farmers' Alliance of the State of Louisiana met in convention at 11 o'clock to-day. The visitors were welcomed to Lafayette by Judge John Clegg. He thanked God that the farmers had come forward with a demand for the abatement of the lottery evil. He urged farmers to stand together with the people in ridding the State of the incubus.
SHANGHAI, China, July 3. -- The question of the future status of the Kingdom of Corea is now probably the most exciting in the political affairs of this section of the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The following circular was issued to-day by Acting Secretary Willetts of the Department of Agriculture:

The Senate Committee on Naval Affairs made no arrangements yesterday for the inspection trip to the navy yards of the country, which has been talked of, because no quorum was present. Senators Cameron of Pennsylvania, Butler of South Carolina, and McPherson of New-Jersey were on hand. Word was received from Senators Stockbridge of Michigan and Blackburn of Kentucky saying that they would be here to-day.

The effort to readjust the politics of Utah upon the lines of the national parties of the country seems to have been fairly successful as shown by the election of Monday. The old Mormon or Church party was abandoned, and the Mormons were divided between Democrats and Republicans. The old anti-Mormon, or so-called "liberal party," persisted in making separate nominations, which were supported chiefly by Republicans.

The report of the committee of the Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company upon the charges made by Cashier BANTA in 1887 is almost a model of its kind. Still it does not equal its great prototype, the Connolly report of November, 1870, which must always stand unmatched in the literature of daring exculpation.

DETROIT, Aug. 4. -- This has been a proud day for the Grand Army of the Republic. It has witnessed the grandest parade in the history of the organization, and has made the twenty-fifth, or "silver," encampment an occasion of magnificence and grandeur surpassing the fondest dreams cherished by its humble founder, Dr. Stephenson of Illinois, twenty-five years ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4. -- Gen. William H. Hubbard, one of the executors of the late Mrs. Mark Hopkins-Searles, is a member of the party of Wabash Railroad officials now in the city. The dispatches have announced that Timothy Hopkins would probably contest the will. Gen. Hubbard says this statement could not have been made authoritatively, as Timothy Hopkins was in Japan when Mrs. Searles died, and will not reach San Francisco until Aug. 12.

Bertram C. Webster, ex-bookmaker and owner of race horses, who shot and killed Charles E. Goodwin, a fashionable, well-connected, and well-educated young man, in the latter's apartments in the Percival, 230 West Forty-second Street, Sunday evening, is still at large. The police will not acknowledge that they have any clue to his whereabouts.

An agreement was arrived at yesterday between the employers and the unions in the pavers and stone handlers' strike by which the men will resume work this morning, unless something unforeseen should happen.
CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Before he leaves the seashore this season it is now assured that President Harrison will be able to claim a Summer residence in the "borough" of Cape May Point.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- At the meeting of the Western Passenger Association to-day, the old question of special party rates for the benefit of traveling theatrical companies was revived. The proposition was to make a rate of 2 cents per mile for parties of ten or more, but to establish a form of ticket that would prove a reasonable safeguard against the abuse of the privilege.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4. -- Three and a half miles from the pretty little village of Clarence lives Joseph Eckhart, a well-to-do farmer, estimated to be worth $25,000. Last Tuesday forenoon Joseph and his wife were gathering in the crops. Following the old German custom, the farmer's wife did duty as a field hand, and in that duty she received injuries resulting in her death.

NAHANT, Mass., Aug. 4. -- O.S. Campbell was defeated to-day in the first round of the Nahant tournament by R.P. Huntington. Campbell seemed unable to play this morning, but in the afternoon defeated P.S. Sears in two straight sets. A beautiful day greeted the opening of the tournament, and players and spectators were early on the ground. The feature of the day was the strong play of Clarence Hobart of New-York.

The chief significance of the Kentucky election lies in the indication it affords of the strength and the tendency of the Farmers' Alliance in the South, and it seems to show that the farmers in that section will continue to support the Democratic Party in both State and national politics. There was a People's Party ticket in Kentucky, but its support was relatively insignificant.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 4. -- The annual report of the President of the Dominion Millers' Association, which is in session here, estimates the wheat crop of the Dominion at 55,160,000 bushels, a reckoning which allows 22,180,000 bushels for export.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 4. -- The latest returns show that the Democratic State ticket carried in yesterday's election by about 25,000. Returns are in from 80 out of 119 counties, and these give Brown (Dem.) a net plurality of 27,707. The remaining counties in 1887 gave a net Republican plurality of 2,580.

The declaration that may be made in regard to the currency by the Democratic Convention of this State is likely to be of more than usual importance. New-York is relied upon to furnish for the next Democratic candidate for President a larger number of Electoral votes than any other State in the Union.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 4. -- The great grain business which New-Orleans is doing this year is beginning to point the moral of its own story. The Illinois Central, the Mississippi Valley, and Louisville and Nashville Railroads are bringing in large cargoes of wheat and other grain for export. The freight rates favor New-Orleans, and it has been demonstrated that this city can be made the grain port of the country.

" What difference does it make whether it is Secretary Noble at the head of the Interior Department or some other man appointed by Mr. Harrison?" asked Senator James L. Pugh of Alabama yesterday at the Gilsey House. "I pay no attention to these rumors of changes in the Cabinet," he continued, "because whoever may be the head of the departments, their affairs will go along in about the same lines.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 4. -- In the Senate to-day the bill for the revision of the judiciary system was carried over to the January session by a vote of 13 to 12, the deciding vote, that of Democratic Leader Champlin of New-Shoreham, coming just in time, as the Senator arrived at the Chamber late.

The card for the races at Jerome Park is the best so far as the number of entries go of the year. Firenzi, the queen of the turf, will make her first appearance this year in the second race, a dash of 1,400 yards, in which, however, she will have but a commonplace lot to defeat. A steeplechase over the short course will be a feature of the day's sport.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Advices have been received here which give another illustration of the bitter hostility against the Jews in Russia. This last instance of the virulent feeling against Hebrews occurred at Elisabetgrad, a fortified town of 56,000 inhabitants situated on the Ingoo River, 130 miles north of Kherson.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday appointed Hugh J. Connell, Dr. Cyrus Edson, and Michael Gavin Commissioners de Lunatico Inquirendo to determine the mental condition of Elizabeth McNeal, otherwise known as Lulu Wallace, who has been insane since the Spring of 1890. The woman owns the property at 237 East Forty-fifth Street, and has personal property valued at $30,000.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- To-day Judge Barnard appointed James W. Hinckley receiver of the property of the firm of Clark O'Brien of New-York aqueduct fame, the firm being John O'Brien, Heman Clark, and John Mooney. The appointment was made upon the application of the First National Bank of Rhinebeck, O'Brien and Clark being made defendants.

A decision of great interest and importance to owners of property in Broadway, between Fiftieth and Fifty-fourth Streets, has been rendered by Herbert B. Turner, referee in the ejectment suit brought by John E. Blackman against Charles Riley. Blackman is just now languishing in jail in Albany awaiting the action of the Grand Jury upon a charge of swindling.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Capt. James E. Stuart yesterday arrested Henry E. Barlow, a mail carrier of the Chicago Post Office, and solved the problem as to who has been robbing the mail of Montgomery Ward Co. for the last year. Lapp Flershem, Montgomery Ward Co., the Chicago Supply Company, and a number of other local business houses have been complaining for many months past of the loss of mail.

LAFAYETTE, La., Aug. 5. -- The Farmers' Alliance is in session with closed doors; but enough has transpired to disclose what will be the policy. The third-party movement will be voted down, and the Alliance will submit the name of President Adams as its choice for Governor to the Democratic State Nominating Convention, yet to be called.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The members of the Board of Freeholders of Monmouth County, headed by Director J. Henry Heyer, met the officers of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, at Highlands of Navesink this morning to lay out the right of way over the Shrewsbury River for the new bridge for the Southern Division, and to grant the right of way along the base of the highlands to Atlantic Highlands.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 5. -- This has been a day of rest for the yachtsmen of the New-York Yacht Club fleet. With the exception of the owl and gamecock races, there has been little or nothing done. Every one was tired after yesterday's hard thrash to windward, and even the owners of the Mineola and Jessica, who have a private match in view, declined to do any work.

" Give the Kansas farmers two more crops as good as their present one and they will be out of debt," said Martin Mohler of Topeka, Secretary of the Kansas State Board of Agriculture, to a TIMES reporter yesterday at the Grand Central Hotel.

The Park Commissioners at their meeting yesterday listened to arguments on the application of the New-York Central Railroad Company that the Third and Madison Avenue bridges over the Harlem be kept closed from 7 to 10 A.M. and from 4 to 7 P.M., so that trains can be run more rapidly over the Fourth Avenue railroad bridge.

It is more than probable that the letter published in the Figaro of Paris and attributed to BISMARCK is a canard of the kind that wings its way with great frequency through the columns of that enterprising journal. Yet the sentiments of the alleged letter are very likely those of "the statesman out of a job."

Loantaka, winner of the Suburban, and Firenzi, the peerless and the winner of some of the most famous turf battles of the decade, were both among the starters at the Jerome Park races yesterday, and the fact that they were such served in great measure to bring to the track a somewhat larger number of people than usual.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 5. -- The report of the Ohio State Board of Agriculture on the condition and prospects of crops in August contains the following information:

BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 5. -- City Treasurer Nathaniel W. Trask roundly lectured Mayor William C. Farr for treating him unfairly while the City Council was in session last night. The scene occurred in the lobby, and the Mayor quickly fled to the hallway, where the indignant Treasurer continued to denounce the city's chief executive in emphatic but civil language.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 5. -- The golden wedding reception of John and Isabella Beecher Hooker was held between 3 and 9 o'clock to-day at the City Mission rooms, which were tastefully decorated with flowers and hung with pictures representing the different members of the Hooker and Beecher branches of the family. Mr. and Mrs. Hooker received seated on a raised platform draped with evergreens, beneath which were the dates, in rustic lettering, 1841 --1891.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The east-bound mail train of the Ogdensburg and Lake Champlain Railroad, due here at 6:50 P.M., collided with a returning Sunday-school excursion train just east of Champlain Station at 6:50 this evening, killing four persons and fatally injuring ten or fifteen more. The mail was on the main line and about to side track to let the excursion pass, when the latter rushed down the grade under full head.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The twenty-first annual convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America was formally opened this morning in the Academy of Music. The Right Rev. Bishop Cotter of Winona, Minn., President of the union, called the convention to order. After prayer by Bishop Keane, Bishop Cotter introduced Cardinal Gibbons.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 5. -- The first collision between the strikers and non-unionists at the Vesuvius Iron Works of Morhead Brothers occurred this afternoon. It was not unexpected, and that it did not result in loss of life was due entirely to the presence of mind of two men.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The annual meeting in School District No. 3 was held here last night, and it resembled in many respects an Indian war dance. The trouble in the district which has been a bone or contention for years is as to whether a Catholic parochial school must be supported by the taxpayers of the district or not.

The Marquis de Leuville, whose bankruptcy is noted in yesterday's London dispatches, achieved wide notoriety, through his engagement to Mrs. Frank Leslie, a circumstance which gratified the inordinate vanity and love of advertising, which is the chief and controlling characteristic of the man. He is an Anglo-Frenchman, having been born in England in 1841, and at the time of the announcement of his engagement to Mrs. Leslie, March, 1884, he was reputed to be wealthy.

Those prophets who are looking forward with confidence to the time when transatlantic passages will be made in five days, will find much gratification in the performance of the White Star liner Majestic, which yesterday completed one of the most remarkable voyages ever made. Steaming over a course of 2,777 miles, the racer accomplished the distance in 5 days 18 hours and 8 minute.

DETROIT, Aug. 5. -- The next encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic will be held at the national capital. This was decided to-day on the first ballot, and although the partisans of Lincoln, Neb., feel disappointed, there is a general resolve by the veterans from all quarters to make the encampment at Washington one worthy of the capital of the Union.

Two of the State Assessors representing the Board of Equalization are on their customary annual visit to this city to examine into the matter of assessments for taxation. It has become quite the custom for the Board of Equalization to add more than $100,000,000 to the real estate valuations of this city and distribute the benefit among other counties by way of reductions, showing special favor to counties which have representatives on the board.

The mysterious Glendale (L.I.) murder, from present appearances, gives promise of going down into history as one of those inexplicable crimes that every once in a while startle mankind and baffle detective skill. There is much that is startling about this crime, but so far there has been no detective skill employed on it.

There were two attractions a Prohibition Park, at Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday. One was the all-day session of the National Temperance Congress and the other, nearly as continuous, was the kissing game going on at the same time out in the grove adjoining the big meeting place of the cold-water people. The kissing game was the more attractive, naturally, to the young men and women.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- J. Henry Jahke, Jr., aged twenty-six years, died early this morning from the effects of a blow from a piece of lead pipe in the hands of his father, J. Henry Jahke, a prominent and wealthy German butcher residing at 3,929 Baring Street, West Philadelphia.

There is something like a state of congestion at the Appraiser's Stores. Business there is booming, and, as a result, the stores are so crowded with goods that it is almost impossible for the force to attend to its duties. Yesterday there were 10,865 packages there, and they were so much larger than the usual run that they took up fully as much room as would be required for 14,000 of ordinary bulk.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The Republican League Convention approached a fizzle so closely that many of the delegates left town to-day before the proceedings were half over. The number in attendance by no means approached that which was expected, and the absence of prominent Republicans whose names have appeared as delegates was the subject of much comment.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 5, -- At the Sixth Senatorial District Convention to-day in Portsmouth there was a very close contest between the Foraker and Sherman Republicans. It was, in fact, the first convention in which the lines were closely drawn, and it resulted in the nomination of D.D. Phillips, a strong Sherman man, by a vote of 28 to 27.

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- The Republican State Committee had a breezy meeting to-day to fill the vacancies created by the refusal of Congressmen Rockwell, Walker, and Cogswell to serve on the Committee on Resolutions at the State Convention this Fall. Chairman Burdett presided, and the meeting opened with a statement by him of the object of the gathering.

It takes a great deal to impress Mr. F.B. THURBER when he is on the subsidy trail, and still more to repress him. Yesterday at the breakfast to the officers of the white squadron he listened calmly to Rear Admiral WALKER'S statement that we are yet, with all our efforts, a long way from a navy that could cope with those of other powers.

The man who had ears to hear was not very long in finding out yesterday that financial men and insurance men throughout the city attached little weight to the statement put forth by the Board of Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company exonerating the management of the company from the crimes and misdemeanors attributed to that management by Cashier Banta.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 5. -- The Peoples' Party Convention was called to order at 2:30 P.M. by H.F. Barnes of Tiffin, Chairman of the State Committee. There were about 400 delegates present. After prayer by the Rev. Joshua Crawford the Chair read letters of regret from prominent people in sympathy with the movement.

ALBAY, Aug. 5. -- An examination of the condition and affairs of the Flour City Life Association of Rochester, N.Y., has just been completed by officers of the State Insurance Department. Superintendent James F. Pierce has informed Attorney General Tabor that he is satisfied "that this association has been conducting its business fraudulently, and has failed to comply with the provisions of the general assessment insurance law."

WORCESTER, Mass. Aug 5. -- George H. Hosmer of Boston, the well-known professional oarsman, who has for the past two or three seasons traveled with the "Dark Secret" theatrical company, and James A. Ten Eyck of this city rowed a three-mile single scull race at Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon for $250 a side, an added purse of $100, and the championship of 7 New-England.

It is noticed by political observers that the Elmira Advertiser has promptly and conspicuously copied, and by implication indorsed the Wellsville Reporter's article in favor of Ball for Senator. It has not even referred to the presentation of Assemblyman Acker's name by the Republicans of this county, nor to the editorials in the Corning Journal and Hornellsville Times in favor of Mr. Acker.

The "color line" promises to cause no little trouble in the Grand Army of the Republic. In his address before the national encampment yesterday Commander in Chief VEAZEY virtually declared in favor of establishing a separate department in Louisiana and some other Southern States for the colored posts, while the Judge Advocate General expressed the opinion in his report that there cannot lawfully be two departments covering the same territory at the same time.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The hand of the political boss of New-York is being felt in the western part of the State, and the Pratt-Hiscock clique are now laying their pipes for the renomination of Van Gorder for State Senator. To-day the first move was made, disclosing the plan of operation that has been on foot for some time.

The project of introducing athletic competitions into the National Guard of New-York, under State auspices and supervision, has at last taken a shape which seems likely to meet the views expressed by the military authorities. In general, the plan adopted is that which has made the system of rifle practice so successful, popular, and useful in increasing the efficiency of the troops.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Cortland County since it became a county has always been Republican all the way from 800 to 1,200. Occasionally -- and only occasionally -- a Democrat managed to slide in, but never has the Democratic Party been favored with a better opportunity than in the coming election in November.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Parliament was prorogued to-day to Oct. 27. The Queen's speech closing the session, after alluding to the amicable relations between Great Britain and the other powers, made a brief reference to the treaties that had been concluded with Portugal and Italy regarding territory in Africa. Continuing the speech said:

We recall nothing more amusing in the labors of the expounders of McKinleyism than the attempt of Mr. McKINLEY and his newspaper organ in Ohio to convince wavering voters that the Standard Oil Trust, the makers of canned goods and "the owners of buildings," will cheerfully pay the duty on tin plate.

General Passenger Agent Charlton of the Chicago and Alton Road and Chairman Finley of the Western Passenger Association had a fresh tilt in Chicago yesterday. The Chairman again presented the bill for $259 against the Chicago and Alton for its proportion of the expenses of the Association for the first half of June, 1891, and urged its prompt payment in order that proper credits might be shown in the regular monthly statements.

The President of the State League of Republican Clubs, in his address before the convention at Syracuse yesterday, said that it was not the object of the organization to nominate or even to suggest candidates for office, but to elect them. He intimated that its purpose was to promote harmony in the ranks of the party, to excite enthusiasm, and to get out the vote.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 5. -- The Coroner's verdict in the Erie Railway disaster at Ravenna on July 3 is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- About 200 Pennsylvanians, members of the Pennsylvania State Club, and all office holders, of course, sweltered in an upper room in the Grand Army Building to-night in order to testify to their devotion to Quay and Robinson and their indifference to the fact that the Administration has just put Mr. Quay out of the National Committee and would like to keep Mr. Robinson from the Presidency of the Pennsylvania League.

WILLEMANTIC, Conn., Aug. 6. -- The chapters relating to the political controversy in this State which has been in progress since the general election in November, will become more interesting as the facts are disclosed. THE TIMES'S correspondent is able to give at this time fasts concerning Gen. Merwin's position that have not heretofore been made public.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- It is not believed here that the articles published by the Vossische Zeitung and the Tageblatt condemning the idea of Germany taking part in the Chicago World's Fair on the ground that, owing to the McKinley law German manufacturers will be unable to find any market for their goods in the United States, will have much effect upon manufacturers and others who study the trade statistics of the two countries.

The mystery connected with the six-year-old, blue-eyed boy whom Clarence A. Chute says he picked up in the woods near Stamford, Conn., will be investigated by Mr. Gerry's Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Mr. Gerry is away, and pending his return the boy has taken possession of the headquarters of the society, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, and is running affairs to suit himself.
Yesterday was a busy day at the Barge Office. Many immigrants were landed from various steamships, and among the arrivals were several whose stories are interesting.

The report that a formal treaty of alliance between France and Russia has been signed at St. Petersburg seems to be fairly well authenticated, but it is not very important. A treaty of this kind becomes waste paper when it no longer represents the sentiments or interests of the contracting parties.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- The fiery spectacle known as "The Last Days of Pompeil" has been suspended on account of a lack of patronage, which can be directly traceable to the unpropitious weather that has prevailed during the entire Summer.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 6. -- Immediately after the meeting of the Grand Army Encampment this morning the election of a Commander in Chief was declared the first business. There were four candidates -- John Palmer of Albany, N.Y.; A.G. Weissart of Milwaukee, Wis.; W.P. Smedbery of California, and S.H. Hurst of Ohio.

The early risers of Corona, L.I., were startled yesterday morning by the discovery that the White Caps had been out the night before and hung in effigy William F. O'Neil, the proprietor of the principal hotel in the town, to the telegraph wires crossing the main street and but a few yards from the hotel and railway station.

Capt. Ewing saved his team from defeat yesterday. The Pittsburgs gave the Giants a hard fight and the score was even in the tenth inning. Two men were on bases when the New-York's Captain grasped his bat. He drove the ball to right field for two bases, sent in as many runs, and the game was won.

President Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company found an interesting parallel yesterday between the condition of his company and that of the Flour City Life of Rochester, which, it was announced, Superintendent James F. Pierce had pronounced guilty of fraudulent methods. Questionable practices of various sorts have been reported concerning this company, and specific charges, fourteen in number, have been finally preferred against it by the examiners.

Once more an order of the Treasury Department has played havoc with the business of the Custom House brokers. This time the interests are of a magnitude which was not approached in previous cases when the mandates from Washington came along to make unhappy the lives of those who have to deal with the customs officers of the port.

NAHANT, Mass., Aug. 6. -- The Nahant tournament is finished, and Clarence Hobart is the winner. By his defeat of Campbell this afternoon Hobart has won five matches without suffering a single defeat. R.P. Huntington comes next, and will take second prize with a record of one defeat by Hobart. The third place goes to Campbell, who was beaten by both Hobart and Huntington.

We do not know what view Secretary FOSTER may take of the law, but we hardly see how he can modify his order that consigned goods must be entered with a statement of cost. The law seems to be extremely clear and explicit. Our Government undertakes to levy a tax on the market value abroad of goods.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6. -- The particulars of a heated encounter in the clubrooms of the Liederkranz, between Rabbi Sonnensohein of the Temple Israel, and Fred Wiederholdt, Vice President of the society, have just come out. It was last Sunday night, and the billiard room of the club was a blaze of light and was swarming with members playing billiards and sipping beer and chatting.

If the action of the People's Party Convention at Springfield, Ohio, is to be taken as an indication of the course of the ultimate third party, whatever it may be called, in national politics, it is likely to relapse into the relative insignificance of the Greenback Party and the Greenback-Labor Party of the past.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6. -- The Missouri World's Fair Commission met in the State Capitol yesterday and organized. Mr. N.D. Gentry of Pettis County was made President and Nathan Frank Vice President. No permanent headquarters were selected. Mr. Frank is not at all pleased with the organization. He fully expected to be placed at the head of the commission, and has shown his disappointment by saying some severe things.

Judge Benedict, in the United States District Court, yesterday handed down a decision that will be hailed with joy by all American yachtsmen who own yachts made abroad, and who have feared that in accordance with the order of the Secretary of the Treasury they would have to pay "light money" of 50 cents a ton every time they entered an American port.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Aug. 6. -- The announcement of a speech by Roger Q. Mills of Texas brought crowds to the city to-day from near and far. Large delegations were present from Cedar Rapids, Burlington, Muscatine, Davenport, Marengo, and other cities of Eastern Iowa. A band of music furnished a rallying point for the crowd.

HOTEL AMPERSAND, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The opening of the new baseball ground of the Hotel Ampersand was celebrated to-day under considerable excitement. A hotly-contested game with Paul Smith's was played amid great enthusiasm, and witnessed by a large crowd of people from both hotels. It was a banner day for the Ampersand nine, as they defeated the champions of the Adirondacks by a score of 19 to 5, as follows:

MADRAS, Aug. 6. -- Though the monsoon set in some time ago in some parts of India, dispelling all fears of a failure of the crops in that portion of the country where the rains had fallen, there has been no rainfall in the Chingleput and North Arcot districts in this Presidency, and all hopes of averting a famine have been abandoned. The heat is unprecedented.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6. -- It was a lovely morning when the fleet of the New-York Yacht Club pulled its ninety anchors out of the New-London harbor mud and bustled about preparatory to starting for Newport. The wind was east-southeast and very light, and the tide was flood.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The following are the entries for the national regatta for amateur oarsmen to be held here Aug. 18 and 19 next:

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Seventy-two in the shade, or rather on the piazza, makes a pleasant temperature for dancing, and the 800, more or less, of the participants in the ball at the Long Beach Hotel danced steadily to-night from the first number at 10 o'clock. There were some very handsome costumes noticeable.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The Directors of the Pan-American Transportation Company will continue in session some days here. Instead of twenty steel steamships being immediately constructed by the company, it appears now that it is intended to use a portion of the first $1,000,000 which the Treasurer says is almost paid in, in the purchase of second-hand vessels of the second grade.

A dilapidated team of horses, a sorrel and a bay, attached to a large open car of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, was stopped by Superintendent Hankinson and Officer Gay of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals early yesterday morning. The bay was lame, sore, and emaciated, and hardly able to crawl along, and the sorrel, a mere apology for a horse, was in about the same condition.

What was lacking in the attendance at the second day's session of the Second National Temperance Congress yesterday in Prohibition Park, Port Richmond, S.I., was made up in the success of the meetings morning, afternoon, and evening. There were barely 200 persons scattered about in the front seats of the auditorium, but there was an active interest in all the papers, and the discussions were unusually animated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6. -- United States steamer Charleston arrived here yesterday. The Charleston left here May 9 to go in pursuit of the Chilean insurgent steamer Itata, and returned with that vessel to San Diego, Cal., July 4. After remaining at that port nearly three weeks the Charleston steamed north, stopping on the way at Rodondo Beach, Santa Barbara, Port Harford, and Santa Cruz, large crowds visiting the cruiser at each point.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 6. -- It was exactly 9:15 o'clock this morning when Temporary Chairman Cavanaugh called the People's Party Convention to order by pounding with a brand new sledgehammer upon the anvil that stood upon the flag-bedecked block at the front of the stage. The report of the Committee on Permanent Organization was the first business in order.

Comes the Lewiston (Me.) Journal, Republican, remarking: "The reason why foreign commerce increases under a protective policy is that the country is more prosperous because it is diversifying its industry and keeping everybody at work at good wages, and this increased prosperity enables the people to buy more of articles that we don't produce."

Hannah Robinson was the name of the murdered woman whose body was found at Glendale, L.I., last Sunday morning. Of that fact there is no reasonable doubt. Her identity was established by the independent testimony of two families. She was an English servant in the family of the Rev. Thomas W. Martin of Hewletts, L.I.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6. -- Auckland advices of July 14 to 16 are to the effect that a great flood and something like a tidal wave prevailed at Melbourne on July 13. The waters in the harbor rose above the level of the surrounding towns, and several small vessels were wrecked. The floods were the most severe since 1862, and the course of the Yarra River presented a scene of desolation for miles.

The recent declaration of Commissioner GREEN B. RAUM that matters have been moving much too slowly in his bureau, and that he is going to "hurry through and dump 350,000 original cases upon the various pension agencies before the year is out," may have excited some doubt, not indeed of his desire to make this dump, but of his ability to find the material to work up so rapidly.

We hope that while Judge LAWRENCE is filling the Republican papers of Ohio with dissertations on wool, he will not overlook the following remarks of Mr. THOMAS DOLAN in a letter written on the 27th ult.:

The announcement that a receiver had been appointed for the firm of O'Brien Clark, the aqueduct contractors, was as much of a surprise to a couple of the members of the firm as it was to the business men down town and the friends of the contractors. Mr. Clark hurried down to the office at 49 Wall Street yesterday from his home in Port Chester, and brought his wife along with him.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 6. -- The young gentlemen who have been trying to be politicians for the last two days in this city, under the name of the Republican League, wound up their affairs to-day at noon. The only business to be done was the election of the minor officers and the announcement of the Executive Committee, which has been absorbed by the grasping tentacles of the Thomas C. Platt machine.

The recent article by Matthew Marshall has been occasioning a good deal of comment among those persons who serve as Directors in companies which make a business of financial dealings. Mr. Marshall intimates that some unjust criticism has been bestowed upon Directories in view of the miserable collapse or certain institutions in this city and in Philadelphia.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Coroner Stewart of Port Byron held an inquest this afternoon upon the bodies of the victims of the West Shore collision near Montezuma. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict finding Conductor Tobin and Brakeman Connolly of the freight train guilty of criminal negligence. Both men have fled.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Aug. 6. -- District Attorney John N. Vanderlyn of Ulster County began the preliminary examination in the Stanton poisoning case at Milton, Ulster County, yesterday. Dr. Snow, who attended Stanton; the Rev. E. S. Bishop, pastor of the Milton Methodist Episcopal Church, and Earl Stone, principal of the village school, were examined, in addition to Stanton himself.

New facts are constantly coming out which throw light upon the political controversy in Connecticut, of which the chief result thus far is the retention in office of men whose terms expired at the beginning of the present year and the exclusion of those whom the people elected to succeed them.
MILFORD, Mass., Aug. 7. -- Miss Huldah Arnold is celebrating her one hundredth birthday to-day. She was born in Leicester, Mass. Her health is good and her faculties well preserved.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 7. -- President Harrison is perturbed over the situation in Pennsylvania. He has recently sent for Minister Smith and for Gen. A. Louden Snowden, American Minister to Greece. Snowden paid a second visit to Harrison, and lunched with him in his cottage yesterday at Cape May Point. He talked freely to a TIMES correspondent of the situation, saying:

The results of the ball games yesterday no doubt pleased Capt. Anson. He won his game in Boston and the two clubs chasing him for first place -- New-York and Boston -- were beaten. As a result, the Cook County team has increased its advantage decidedly.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Work at the grounds of the World's Columbian Exposition has progressed very favorably in the last week, and those in charge are fully satisfied with the results. The foundation of the Woman's Building is almost completed, and the erection of the superstructure -- the first permanent thing of the kind on the ground -- is now under way.

An accomplished adventuress, who gave herself out as a Countess, has escaped the clutches of justice, after having swindled elaborately her servants and some tradespeople. The c called Countess began by engaglngamarried couple to wait on her in her hotel. These persons were to receive u10 monthly for their services, and naturally xvere enchanted at the prospect of such splendid wages.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- A strong Dress Reform Club has been quietly launched in this city. Secrecy for the present was the word, but as the organization is made up exclusively of women, this part of the programme was, of course, a failure.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Capt. Lawlor, on board the American dory Sea Serpent, which started from Boston on an ocean race with the Mermaid, another dory, officered and manned by Capt. Andrews, arrived at Coverack, near Lizard Point, on the English Channel, at 6:30 A.M. Wednesday. His recital of the incidents of the trip shows many narrow escapes from death.

The Illinois Court of Appeals has added another decision to the long list of those which declare the illegality of combinations or agreements designed to suppress competition in an industry. The case was that of MORE DUNDAS against BENNETT, EDWARDS PETIT, both the plaintiffs and the defendants being members of the Chicago Law Stenographers' Association, which had fixed certain prices for shorthand reporting and copying.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7. -- Parliamentary committees are still engaged investigating the charges of bribery preferred against Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, and his political friends. At this afternoon's sitting there were more developments. The intimate relations existing between the Minister and the Hon. Thomas McGreevy, M.P., were fully established.

Sarah Coleman, the wife of William Coleman, was found dead yesterday afternoon in a shanty on the vacant lot at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The shanty is numbered 72, and there is a little candy store in the front part of it. The lot belongs to John D. Crimmins, and the Colemans have lived there two years, rent free, on consideration of taking care of the premises.

Last month a large, airy farmhouse in Monmouth County, N.J., in perfect condition, was rented by the Reed Alumnae League's Fresh-Air Mission. The house was newly and thoroughly furnished and then offered free of any expense -- and all transportation charges from New-York and back paid by the league -- to St. Chrysostom's Nursery in West Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Rear Admiral McCann was in the Navy Department to-day and had a long talk with Assistant Secretary Soley and Commodore Ramsay, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation. He made no official report in addition to those he had already made from his flagship, but the whole course of events and the present situation in Chile were discussed at length, and the Admiral gave his views, based on his personal observations.

There are very good prospects that the reorganization of the Washington National Bank will be carried out. For one thing, the collections of debts owed to the bank have been better than most people interested expected they would be. All the depositors have been paid off, and the Directors who advanced money to assist in meeting these claims as speedily as possible have been repaid.

It is clear enough that Senator Stanford of California is "willin'." Asked, the other day if he would accept the Republican nomination for the Presidency, he said: "I am not a candidate myself, and I don't propose to be. It will be time enough to determine that matter when the nomination comes, if it should come; but I have no idea that it will be offered to me.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 7. -- Though E. Barksdale, the Democrat Sub-Treasury candidate for the United States Senate against Senator George, is still conducting a vigorous campaign, assisted by Clark Lewis, the Alliance candidate for Walthall's place, and says he thinks he has good prospects of being successful, the contest is generally conceded to be practically settled.

News is received from Saratoga of the death of the once famous thoroughbred gelding, Procter Knott. He was the champion two-year-old of 1888, made so by the winning of both the Junior Champion and the Futurity, which no other horse has done as yet. He was by Luke Blackburn-Tallapoosa, she by imported Great Tom, was bred at the famous Belle Mead farm, and foaled in 1886.

Every reflective person who has read the report of the entertainment given by the merchants of New-York to the officers of the White Squadron must have been struck with a certain sense of confusion if not of incongruity. It was not easy to see what was the precise public significance of this public function.

WASHINGTON, AUG. 7. -- Unless the members-elect in sixty-seven Congressional districts in different States are diligent in hunting up as many young men who desire to enjoy the benefits of an education at the West Point Military Academy, there is danger that the new class at that institution will begin its studies in the Fall very far short of the number for which Congress has made provision.

LAFAYETTE, La., Aug. 7. -- Having completed the details of its combination with the Anti-Lottery League for the support of a fusion ticket in the Democratic State Convention, the Farmers' Alliance returned to its routine work and elected its officers for the new year. Farmer Adams was unanimously re-elected President, but Lecturer Guice, who headed the opposition to the "combine" and advocated a third party, was defeated for re-election.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Not since the most flourishing part of the Presidency of Dr. McCosh have so many handsome university buildings been under process of erection as at the present time. Students who left Princeton in June will find on their return at the opening of college that at least four new buildings will have graced the university grounds.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Steps have at last been taken to suppress the notorious concert saloon of Joseph B. Miller, which, under the name of the Elkwood, has established itself in what was formerly one of the quietest and most respectable parts of the city. A bitter legal struggle is certain, however, before the closing up of the place can be effected.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The mystery surrounding the case of the woman whose body was found in the Hudson north of Highland last Tuesday grows deeper. To-day Drs. Lamoree and Preston of Highland made an autopsy. They found no water in the lungs, and they therefore declare that the woman was dead before she entered the water.

The graduate of twenty or more years ago, who had not kept well up with the changes at Harvard, was surprised on Commencement Day, as he watched the ceremonial, to see two young gentlemen appear to take the degree of Master of Arts in course, who had but a few minutes before, taken the preliminary degree of Bachelor of Arts -- in course also -- as members of the Class of '91.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- Calvin Page arrived home from Dakota to-day with his two daughters, having recovered them from the Chlute band of Indians, in whose custody they have been for the past twelve years. In 1870 Mr. Page and his wife, who had married against the wishes of their parents, went West. stopping for six months at St. Joseph, Mo.

The failure of Abraham Backer assumes a new phase in the light of a legal action which was brought in the Supreme Court yesterday. The action is begun by Myers Brothers of Savannah through their lawyers. Guggenheimer and Untermyer of 46 Wall Street, and alleges the wrongful conversion by Abraham Backer of about $72,000 worth of securities belonging to the plaintiffs.

After manipulating the stock of the Union Pacific Railroad to his heart's content in the stock market, Mr. Gould permits the announcement to be made that a syndicate of capitalists has been formed to provide such funds as may be required to take care of the Union Pacific's floating debt. The syndicate includes Mr. Gould, Russell Sage, Sidney Dillon, the Messrs.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- For twenty-two years and six months Dr. James H. Hoose has been Principal of the State Normal School here. It is the leading normal school in the State, and not once during his principalship has his ability as an instructor or disciplinarian been questioned. However, several times attempts have been made to remove him.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Much excitement was caused in the Whitechapel district this morning when a rumor was rapidly passed from mouth to mouth that the dreaded "Jack the Ripper" had again appeared and committed one of the butcheries that have made his name a household work in this most ill-favored portion of London.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7. -- There was almost a clearance of the Grand Circuit card this afternoon, a smart shower which fell shortly after 6 o'clock being the only obstacle to a conclusion. The unfinished 2:23 class was decided first, Nightingale landing two more heats, while Honest George was not in a trotting mood.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Republican Association in Philadelphia has issued another address to the people, in which it advances a step further toward independent action than it has done before. This organization is made up of avowed Republicans who seek to reform their party from within.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7. -- The unpleasantness within Republican Party councils is very far from settled. In fact, the troubles grow more and more acute each day. A committee constituted by "Gov." Bulkeley to read Judge Lynde Harrison out of the party has somehow failed of its purpose.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 7. -- At the opening of the Grand Army of the Republic Encampment this morning the first business was the report of the Committee on the John A. Logan and Phil Sheridan Monuments. The Logan Monument Fund now reaches about $65,000 and is closed. For the Sheridan monument they have $50,000 in hand.

The absurd assertion of Judge LAWRENCE and of prominent Republican papers in Ohio that the price of Ohio wool has fallen because the manufacturers have wickedly "conspired" to boycott it and to substitute foreign wool for it in their mills calls from the American Wool Reporter a reply of considerable length, from which we quote the following:

Salt-water anglers, with about all the customary grounds of complaint, have settled down to fishing, and, as a rule, in consequence, have had fairly good luck in the main. It is always easy to find something to growl about, and more time is spent, in trying to think up some reason why the fish do not bite than in earnest efforts to find the fish themselves.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 7. -- An execution for $100,000 was issued to-day against William E. Schmertz, at the instance of William Loeffler. Mr. Schmertz has for many years been President of the Third National Bank, the head of the largest shoe manufacturing company here, and has been identified with many other important financial interests.
Col. W.R. Morrison of Illinois, a member of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Wednesday. He is on his way to Illinois for a Summer vacation.

Two captures have been made in Bering Sea by the revenue cutters, but they do not seem to be very important, A British schoonen from Victoria was taken by the Rusk, not in the act of catching seals but with the evident purpose of continuing her sealing cruise notwithstanding the warning to desist, and was turned over to the British cruiser Nymphe and taken to Unalaska.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 7. -- Ashton G. Bean, Chief Coin Teller of the Sub-Treasury in the Custom House, by some clever detective work succeeded in capturing this morning a thief who has made several raids on Uncle Sam's money recently. Mr. Bean had noticed the disappearance of several small piles of coin from his desk. Once a bag containing $62 in battered nickels disappeared, another time $10 in quarters.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 7. -- An employe of the cotton mills at Wesson, Miss., arrived to-day, bringing an account of an affair in that town early this morning. For the last two months two white women have been working at Wesson. The came from the North and were known as Agnes Reardon and Mamie Haspel. They were watched, and it was found that they often visited a cabin outside of town.

The announcement that there are now 5,500 countrymen of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS on the Atlantic Ocean, who started from his birthplace last week to rediscover America for themselves, suggests that the flow of Italian immigration to this country has not been materially checked by the recent unpleasantness in New-Orleans.
