The complaints of commuters on the roads that cross the Harlem River at Fourth Avenue are frequent and earnest, and they are entirely justified. They might and probably would be seconded by all the owners of suburban real estate on the lines of the Central, Harlem, and New-Haven Railroads.

ST. Louis, Aug. 7. -- The law enacted by the last Legislature, imposing upon foreign corporations doing business in Missouri the same requirements as to taxes as are made with domestic concerns, has driven the St. Louis branch of the Atlas Tack Company to Chicago. This concern was incorporated under the laws of Massachusetts, with headquarters at Boston.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 7. -- Commissioner Nesbit of the Agricultural Department of Georgia makes the following statement for August:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- When George Butler opened his butcher's shop at Washington Avenue and William Street, Belleville, Tuesday morning, he found that the meat had been hauled from the refrigerator and the money drawer had been relieved of its cash. Three boys and four dogs were asleep on the floor. The noise of his footsteps aroused the boys and the dogs, and all seven made frantic efforts to escape.

Mr. Charles D. Kellogg, Treasurer of the Bartholdi Creche, on Ward's Island, acknowledges the receipt of the contributions in aid of the creche amounting to $264. Further contributions are needed. Free transportation is now given at increased expense to the creche. Dispensary physicians find the creche of immense benefit to drooping infants and their overtaxed mothers, who find rest and recuperation in the shaded grounds and fresh breezes.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- Col. E.B. Glasgow has written to Joseph H. Walker a letter describing the meeting of the Republican State Committee last Wednesday, and setting forth his stand in the discussion. Mr. Walker is at New-Hampton, N.H., at the present time. The letter reads:
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- A Blade special from Columbus Grove gives Cashier T.U. Maples's statement as follows:

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Cyrus Stickles and Jennie Bogart were arraigned here to-day on charges of bigamy. On Oct. 12, 1873, Stickles married Clara F. Crampton, who was looked upon as the belle of Dover. Three daughters were the result of their union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Navy Department has received, under date of Unalaska, Alaska, July 11, a long letter from Commander C.S. Cotton of the United States steamer Mohican, commanding the United States naval force in Bering Sea. The Mohican arrived at Unalaska on the 8th of July from Departure Bay, Vancouver Island, from which port it sailed on June 27. The following extracts from the letter are given:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The offer of the Treasury Department to the holders of 4 1/2 per cent. bonds, to exchange these obligations for new bonds bearing 2 per cent., will, it is believed at the Treasury, be very generally accepted. One-half of the national banks have notified the department that they will make the exchange, and nearly $11,000,000 of the $23,000,000 held by the banks has been sent in for this purpose.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 8. -- A story has been circulated in this city to-day that Adolph Woolner, Jr., President of the Old Colony Distillery Company, has disappeared from New-York, and that detectives are searching for him with warrants for his arrest on charges of fraud. Woolner owns a controlling interest in the local distillery, and he is represented as a partner of Herman A. Curiel in the United Growers' Company of New-York.

A case of commercial perfidy and business disaster which promises to haunt the memories of several hundreds of merchants in all the large cities of the North for many years to come is that of "Steve" Ryan of Atlanta, Ga. Ryan is a young Irishman of convivial habits, somewhat below the average stature, of slender frame, and with but the rudiments of an education.

It is stated, on what ought to be good authority -- that of the Postmaster General -- that Mr. WANAMAKER will not resign, and that he "still enjoys the President's confidence and friendship." Doutless Mr. WANAMAKER is correct in both these statements. That he will not resign is a matter as to which his own evidence is necessarily conclusive.

As time passes and the art of angling becomes more of a science, it is gratifying to see that the bait fishermen are being treated with more respect by their brethren of the fly rods, and that just appreciation is being given of the skill necessary to make a good bait caster and successfully lure the trout or bass to the worm or minnow.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 8. -- The Farmers' Alliance of Louisiana closed its annual session last night at Lafayette and then held a banquet, which lasted until after midnight. The third-party element showed itself very sore over the combination of the Alliance with the anti-lottoryites.

A gentleman who arrived in this city yesterday from Southampton, and who recently was in Berlin, states that the exposure of Mr. Beers's methods has been extensively commented on by the press in that city. As a direct result, he says, there has been great excitement, and the business of the New-York in Germany and Austria has practically come to a standstill.

The discovery of the old standard yard and certain other weights and measures supposed to have been lost or destroyed by the fire by which the Houses of Parliament were consumed, in 1834, is of little real interest, seeing that the duplicates escaped that catastrophe. Even the metallic documents which for more than fifty years have laid among other lumber in the Journals Office were long ago replaced by perfect copies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- In the Circuit Court to-day Charles W. Rigdon filed a bill to restrain the Chicago City Railway Company from increasing its capital stock $1,000,000 and from purchasing bonds of the Chicago and South Side Rapid-Transit Railroad to that extent.

We are glad to observe that the People's Municipal League of this city professes to exert itself through a committee in behalf of the cause of ballot reform during the coming State canvass. The object is to secure the adoption of the genuine Australian ballot and the prohibition of all others, by which means alone the reform can be made complete.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The history of the origin and extent of the understanding between France and Russia remains and, it is to be hoped, will remain a secret. No one knows whether the alliance was formally concluded either before or during Admiral Gervais's visit to Moscow, or even whether any written treaty is contemplated by the French and Russian Ministers.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- Two agents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, J.R. Holman, and J. Baker, were charged to-day in the District Court in South Boston with forging and uttering false applications for insurance and fraudulently obtaining $500 from the company. They have been in the employment of the company for some time, and up to within a short period have been looked upon as trustworthy.

The wonderful feats of Flavius Taylor, the boy mind reader of Glasgow, Ky., continues to astonish all those who see him. Though only nineteen years of age, he has shown his power of mind reading in a manner that would do credit to a Bishop or other person of like fame.

New-York gained slightly on Chicago yesterday. Anson's men were beaten in Boston and the Giants won on the Polo Grounds. The latter contest was a close and interesting one. For eleven innings the result was in doubt, but in the twelfth the Giants made one of their characteristic dashes, scored three times, and won.

The late Gen. B.F. Kelley, "Old Ben Kelley," as he was affectionately known by his men, was one of the silent heroes of the war. Major Davis, the army officer who has charge of the publication of the rebellion records, told me that Kelley made less history for the amount of fighting he did than any general officer in the service.
LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A balloon accident occurred to-day at Leeds by which a balloonist and parachutist named Higgins was killed and a young woman, a Miss Devoy, had a narrow escape from death.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- A special to the Evening Dispatch from Lima, Ohio, says: "One of the boldest bank robberies and murders ever perpetrated in this section of the country occurred this morning at Columbus Grove, a town of about 2,000 people, twelve miles north of here. Cashier T.J. Maple had just opened the Exchange Bank, of which his father is proprietor, and laid out about $3,000 near the cashier's window.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8. -- The Masonic Savings Bank assigned to-day to the Germania Safety Vault and Trust Company. The capital is $250,000 and the deposits $1,000,000. The statement of July 1 showed resources, bills receivable, $817,992; bonds and stocks, $119,980; real estate, $40,858; call loans, $162,237; due from banks, $23,397; cash, $68,927; suspended debt, $19,326; furniture, $1,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 8. -- Angry disappointment, bordering on indignation, was expressed on all sides by the leading spirits of the Grand Army posts here when the news was received that colored veterans must be given free recognition and admission to the order. The greater part of the officers of the white posts are ensconced in comfortable berths in the Custom House, and there the indignation over the action of the national body was greatest.

It is proverbially easy for men to be liberal with other people's money. No taxes or debts are paid so promptly and cheerfully as those which come out of estates in charge of others than the owners. No claims are so easily allowed as those that are made upon property in the hands of trustees or administrators who suffer no loss by their payment.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8. -- Gov. Pattison was in the city a few hours to-day. Considerable interest was manifested in the Governor as a Presidential possibility, but he was very reticent and not inclined to distribute any information on the subject, unless it was pulled from him by main strength.

I read in your paper a letter from Mr. George Vickers, in which he dilated upon the charming scenery about Rock Point, at the mouth of the Wicomico Bay, where it empties into the Potomac, in Charles County, Md. I can testify, from personal observation, that the picture sketched by Mr. Vickers was not overdrawn.

SING SING, Aug. 8. -- Coroner Sutton continued his investigation to-day at Croton Landing into the shooting affray between Orville M. Anderson and I. Newton Baker, by which the latter received three severe wounds. Eugene Barton testified to having been given the two pistols by John See after the shooting, See having received them from Chester Fisher, who in turn took them from Anderson and Baker in the road.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 8. -- The Star's Topeka (Kan.) special says: "The most remarkable set of resolutions which the Alliance has yet sprung on the public comes from Elk County. Several whereases tell the condition of the people, and announce that the loan companies and the banks have refused to loan any more money in Kansas. Continuing, the resolutions say:

A correspondent writes us, asking that we shall give an accurate statement of the net available cash in the Treasury. We regret that we cannot do it. There are no statistics made public by the present Administration that enable us to get at the facts sought by our correspondent. Under the system prevailing before Mr. FOSTER took office such facts were readily known with substantial accuracy.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 8. -- The questions which will come before the Legislature at the extra session to begin the last day of this month are already engrossing the attention of laboring people and politicians all over the State. By the careless enrolling of a bill at the regular session the election laws were rendered inoperative. This error must be corrected, and under the Constitution the State must be redistricted and the Senators and Representatives reapportioned.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 8. -- A Key West special to the Picayune says: "Chief Officer Boyd of the Morgan steamship Eldorado arrived here this morning on the revenue cutter McLane, with dispatches reporting his vessel ashore on the Bahama banks."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a bulletin giving statistics of the Roman Catholic Church and all other Catholic bodies historically related to it, which are represented in the United States, viz., the Greek Catholic Church, (Uniates,) which acknowledges the sovereignty of the Pope; the Russian Orthodox Church, the Greek Orthodox Church, the Armenian Church, the old Catholic Church, and the Reformed or Converted Catholic Church.

There is nothing about the Union Pacific Company to-day which has not been known for months to the few. There is a great deal more known about it to the many. Therein consists largely the difference in the speculative position of the stock; and it may be added, of the bonds also. The market the past week has hinged considerably on the movements of Union Pacific.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The fleet of the New-York Yacht Club is now at anchor in the commodious harbor once called Holmes Hole, now rechristened Vineyard Haven. The run from Newport to this place was not exciting. The yachts started out in the morning with a north-northeast wind, which died out soon after noon and caused a lot of drifting.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Gen. J.S. Clarkson, the new Chairman of the Republican National Executive Committee, arrived at 4 o'clock this afternoon in response to a call from President Harrison. He cane on the New-York train and registered at the Stockton. After registering he took a carriage and was driven over to the President's cottage at the Point.

At the election for Commander of the Division of the Atlantic I.O.O.F., held at the office of the Grand Secretary in this city yesterday afternoon. Gen. James O. Woodward of Albany, N.Y., was unanimously elected for the full term of four years. The Division of the Atlantic is the largest jurisdiction in the order. Every officer entitled to vote, both in the United States and Canada, was either present or represented at yesterday's election.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- This popular Summer resort was thrown into a fever this morning by a fire alarm. The Cooper House, the leading hotel, was found in flames, and long before any of the lazy Summer guests had thought of rising from bed -- 8:30 A.M. Like all villages of its size, Cooperstown has primitive fire-subduing facilities. By the rarest good fortune no lives were lost.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 8. -- The Rev. J.L. Evans has accepted the pastoral charge of the Congregational Church at Nepaug, in New-Hartford, and will engage in his work there Sept. 1. Mr. Evans has been settled in Massachusetts, and comes to Connecticut from that State.

It is announced that Ja Ja, once Chief of Opobo, is dead. It will be remembered that Ja Ja was deposed by the English Government some years ago, and that his case attracted a good deal of attention in the House of Commons and in the English press. The work of deportation from Opobo was intrusted to Mr. H.H. Johnstone, who subsequently defended his action in the columns of the Pall Mall Gazette.

The Athletics of Red Bank and the New-Amsterdams of Navesink played a game at the latter place yesterday. At the end of the eighth inning the game was stopped on account of darkness, the Athletics winning by a score of 22 to 9. The batteries were: Athletics -- Steinberg and Parsons; New-Amsterdams -- Johnson and Conner.

Capt. Andrews of the dorey Mermaid, which started to race across the ocean with the dorey Sea Serpent, was spoken by Capt. Moore of the Johnston Line steamer Queensmore, now at this port, July 26, and sent the following letter to Boston through Capt. Moore: "We are now in the great life and heat distributing element of the North Atlantic, and are drifting toward the regions of the never-setting sun.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- John H. Lacid, a prominent farmer of the town of Bethel, Sullivan County, has been received for treatment at the New-York State Homeopathic Hospital for the Insane in this city. He is a victim of the horrors of Andersonville Prison. He served in the war of the rebellion in the Fifteenth New-York Regiment of heavy artillery and was captured by the Confederates and lodged in prison at Andersonville.

The greatest event of the season's yachting was that which occurred Friday at Newport when in the Goelet Cup races the Herreshoff wonder Gloriana won her sixth victory. The result was a foregone conclusion. No matter what the conditions of weather might be, everybody felt in his bones that Gloriana would win. She met every expectation.

CARLYLE AND BORES. -- Carlyle did not know how to put up with bores. "The art of being savage to those people," or "such things" -- as he would have designated them -- which Scott so signally lacked, was possessed by him in its perfection. What he could "least endure," we are told, was being bored.

APOCRYPHAL TRAVELS. -- The "Voyages and Travels of Sir John Maundeville" appeared in the latter part of the fourteenth century. Its quaint and quasi-ingenuous narrative of an adventurous English knight's wanderings in the East quickly won it a popularity which was not a whit diminished by the monstrous extravagance of its fictions.

DU MAURIER. -- On page 140 of Punch, Vol. II. for the year 1860, is to be seen Du Maurier's first drawing, unsigned, which represents a number of humble artists (including Mr. Whistler) entering a photographer's studio. From that day forward he became one of the bulwarks of the paper, his fecundity rivaling that of Keene, Leech, and others.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The services here to-day were conducted by the leaders of the Interdenominational Bible Conference, of which Dr. L.W. Munhall of Philadelphia is the Director. The large number of arrivals on Saturday added to the crowds which usually attend the Sabbath services, and the attendance at the meetings was the biggest of the season.

That veteran advocate of free-silver, Gen. A.J. WARNER, has issued a manifesto to the voters of Ohio on the free-coinage question. He evidently knows where the weak point in his pet theory is. The danger comes from "the imbecile cry that under free coinage the miner will be permitted to take 80 cents worth of silver to the Mint and get a dollar for it."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Mrs. H.J. Langdon of Oroville, Cal., who has for eighteen years been a contractor for carrying the United States mails, is on the warpath. She wants Postmaster General Wanamaker's scalp, and if she reads the signs aright she will get it.

BAKSHEESH. -- There are not many words, even among those of foreign extraction, of which the orthography offers no less than thirteen alternatives. We have, however, the authority of the great English dictionary now issuing (very deliberately) from the Clarendon Press for declaring that baksheesh is one of the few which enjoy this privilege.
The annexed letter, which I have just received from Admiral Walker, may be of interest to you and the public. If so, will you kindly publish in your Sunday edition?

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 8. -- Trotting has been in progress at Danville and Columbia this week. Large fields and good sport ruled at both places, and several new performers were added to the list. There has been a decided improvement over last year in the Kentucky trotting races, and they are being patronized more generally than formerly.

In 1835-6 Henry W. Longfellow, then in his twenty-eighth year, made his second trip to Europe to air his German at Heidelberg, the better to fit himself for the office of Professor of Modern Languages, to which he had been appointed at Harvard. Before leaving he was offered by Lewis Gaylord Clark, the editor of the Knickerbocker Magazine, a letter of introduction to Bulwer.

The authorities at Bellevue Hospital are very indignant over the action of the German Hospital officers, who hurried a dying man from their institution to Bellevue, where he died seventeen hours after admission.

THE BEGINNING OF THE CUNARD LINE. -- In December, 1835, Dr. Lardner, in the course of a lecture which he delivered at Liverpool declared that a scheme of steam transatlantic voyages was "perfectly chimerical," and that men "might as well talk of making a voyage from Liverpool to the moon." Dr. Lardner, after all, only gave utterance to what was a prevailing impression.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The cottagers who remain here have been having a pleasant, though quiet week. The young people have had much pleasure in private theatricals, boating, tennis, and driving. Many of the older visitors are at the seashore.

Sam Jones, the revivalist, conducted the first of a series of meetings which will continue through this week at the National Prohibition Park, on Staten Island, yesterday. His first appearance drew a crowd of perhaps four or five hundred persons. He talked for over an hour, and his sermon abounded in incidents told in his comic style and striking comparisons which frequently caused laughter.

The rain-compelling emissaries of the Agricultural Department, headed by Gen. DYRENFORTH, have now reached that remote region in Texas which they have deemed desirable for their experiments. Accordingly, we may possibly look for the mystification of the nearest local weather sharp by the reversal of his predictions, the production of deluges out of dry skies, and the forcible overthrow of all the accumulated lore and stock signs of the Signal Bureau and its observers.

TELEPATHY. -- A young married lady related to me the following remarkable experience of this kind: Shortly after her marriage she had accompanied her husband to India. It was toward the end of the mutiny, and she was separated from him -- he being about forty miles away, and, as she believed, in great personal danger.

HARRISVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The present season is one of the best ever known at the Adirondack resorts reached by the Carthage and Adirondack Railroad. The weather for the past two weeks has been of the right sort to make life in the woods enjoyable, and every camp, cottage, and hotel has had a full complement of guests.

THE SLIPSHOD MUSE. -- Slipshod versification is now hardly possible. Rhymes are criticised with a severe care which has something ludicrous in it, and furnish, in the absence of the critical power now so unhappily rare, materials for many lines of useful copy. Such lines as "You trample our beds of ranunculus, While you 'Tommy-make-room-for-your-uncle' us," seem to excite connoisseurs to a kind of delirium of praise.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 9. -- State Deputy Game Warden L.K. Buntain of this city fatally shot David McIlvain, whom he caught, with four others, seining in Mad River, near Harshmanville, about midnight. Buntain had heard that a party had gone up the river to seine contrary to the State law, and, at the request of Ben F. Seitner, member of the County Fish and Game Protective Society, accompanied him to the spot, both being disguised.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Had not the question of the successful establishment of the School of Applied Ethics been previously settled beyond any doubt, it would have been concluded distinctly with the last week. For, while the course has been carried on quite evenly at a high standard, the gradually-spreading knowledge of its character has considerably increased the attendance and the general interest in the later development.

This is champion week, always one of the most important in the yearly meetings of the Monmouth Park Association. But, unlike champion day of past years, the two stakes, the Champion and the Junior Champion, will be run on different days. First comes the Junior Champion, which is to be run over the Morris Park track to-morrow.
ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Eugene Tyler Chamberlain to-day assumed the position of editor of the Albany Argus, succeeding Myron A. Cooney, who held the position seven years.

BARBIZON, July 20. -- A seven-mile walk through the woods to the northeast of Fontainebleau takes one through a region wilder and less frequented than most sections of the forest. No house breaks through the leafy vistas. Alternate sunshine and showers offer the woodlands in their most varied moods and at the same time bring out the most varied perfumes.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 8. -- One of the season's social events was the dance given at the Kittatinny House Thursday evening to the guests of the house and a select number of invited guests. The big house was prettily decorated, and its ballroom banked with ferns. A supper was served after the dancing.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- M. Ribot, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, will go to Lausanne at the end of this month on a vacation, during which he will meet, either at Lausanne or at Lucerne, the Russian Foreign Minister, M. de Giers, who is also about to make a holiday sojourn in Switzerland.

BAR HARBOR, Mo., Aug. 8. -- Whatever the state of the Blaine boom elsewhere, it certainly can get little stimulus from the Secretary of State himself. He is living a passive life under the shadow of Mount Desert and preserving an almost perfect isolation. So many stories, exaggerated one way or the other, have been printed about the Secretary of State's physical condition as to make him an object of curiosity to every visitor here.

Thomas Carey, a laborer, who lives in West One Hundred and Forty-third Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, committed suicide by jumping into the North River from the dock at the foot of One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street at 1:30 o'clock Thursday morning last. A watchman on the dock who saw him leap overboard threw him a rope, but he refused to take it and was swept away by the current and drowned.

A SYDNEY LUNCHEON. -- We do not exactly long for the Port Lincoln oyster of South Australia, which sometimes measures a foot across, and which, fried in bread crumbs and butter, is as much as an able-bodied man can consume at a sitting. Fortunately oysters are found in every sea except, perhaps, the Baltic, for some two billions are eaten annually in Europe alone.

The National Line steamship Europe, which sailed from this port Wednesday last, yesterday came "limping" back, with two blades of her propeller gone. The commander states that Thursday night, when about 450 miles distant from Sandy Hook, one of the blades was lost. The propeller of the steamship is fitted with four blades, and, apprehending no accident to the remaining three flanges, the vessel continued upon her course.

The railroad officials say that they could not estimate the value of Mrs. Searles's interest in railroad properties. They were valued at $20,000,000 when Mark Hopkins died, but they might be worth more now. Herman Shainwald is well up in property values and he gave some interesting figures concerning the San Francisco share of her estate.

ODEBOLT, Iowa, Aug. 8. -- The bankers and money lenders have come to the rescue of "Farmer" Wheeler and his seventy-thousand-dollar farm, mortgaged. They say in a published statement that $10,000 of this mortgage has been paid off, leaving only $60,000 still unsatisfied. Probably this statement is true, although there is nothing on the county records to show it.

PARIS, July 23. -- The leave-taking of the Chamber of Deputies was disturbed, and the serenity of Minister de Freycinet ruthlessly perplexed by the sudden appearance of a small bombshell. It was thrown, too, from the groundwork most sacred to M. de Freycinet. Whatever opinion his friends and enemies may have of the President du Consell, they all agree as to his unexpected efficiency and popularity as the Minister of War.

A most peculiar and fatal accident occurred in Brooklyn yesterday forenoon, by which John Uniack and his little four-year-old child were almost instantly killed. Uniack was a driver for the Nassau Gas Company, and had been in the employ of the company for seventeen years. For the last three years he had driven a fine, big gray horse called Harry, of which he had become quite fond.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 9. -- A conflict is threatened here between Contractor Redding of Perth Amboy and the Pennsylvania and Western Union Companies. Only the presence of the police to-day prevented hostilities beginning, as the contractor announced his intention of cutting all the railroad and telegraph wires at Bayway Crossing and forcing his way over the crossing with a big French-roof house despite the opposition of both companies.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Deputy Superintendent of Banking Cyrus Stewart has taken occasion to criticise the deductions made from the savings bank reports for July 1 and printed in THE TIMES last Sunday, and to assert that the statement that some of the money savings of people are being diverted to building and loan associations is not the fact. Mr. Stewart says:

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- There was a plethora of money during the past week. Discount was quoted at 1 1/2 for three months and 1/2 for short, with no demand. A small drain of gold continues toward Germany. There is nothing to indicate large immediate withdrawals from the Bank of England from any quarter. Though discount houses are obliged to work at absurdly low rates for short bills, six-months' drafts are not regarded with favor.

The figures of attendance at the State Camp this year present some suggestive features. The highest honors in this particular among the regimental organizations go to the Twelfth, which had about 86 per cent. of its members present. The Twenty-second follows, with over 85 per cent., and then the Thirty-second and the Eighth.

One of the worst sections of the tariff law is that relating to hosiery. For over seven years the consumers in the United States had paid a protective duty of 40 per cent. upon all their imported hosiery, although the United States had no infant hosiery industry that needed protection. The average importations in that time grew from about $8,000,000 annually to about $12,000,000, foreign value.

The Constitution of the United States frowns upon titles and orders of nobility, yet there are many native-born Americans whose dignities range from the humbler orders of knighthood to the exalted rank of Princes. I am not now alluding to heiresses who have been raised to the peerage by marriage. These instances are already familiar to the public.

" I see the spirit of Sawando, a dusky Indian girl, daughter of the Chief of the Blackfeet, from the far West. Upon her head is a band of feathers with red ribbons, and in her ears are rings of gold. The color gleams brown through her dusky cheeks, and she beckons as if she would talk with some one. I see her lips move. She speaks.
Rutebeuf was the Villon of the thirteenth century; Verlaine is the Villon of the nineteenth century.

The recent splendid performance of the White Star liner Majestic, which unexpectedly and considerably lowered the record between Queenstown and New-York, has given a new impetus to transatlantic steamship races. The City of Paris is now speeding on her way to this port, and it is reasonably certain that the displaced champion of the Inman fleet will do her level best to regain her lost prestige.

A pathetic tale is that of Mary Ellen Johnson, the Liverpool "bigamist," whose technical offense against the law has been purged by a sentence of one day's imprisonment -- or practically no imprisonment at all. In 1872, according to the uncontradicted statements of counsel, this "middle-aged, respectably dressed person" had the misfortune to marry a foreign sailor, who lodged with her for two years.

She was a Delsartean poem -- the lines all curves, the movement all rhythm. Her light-brown hair was wound high in a Greek coil and bound with silver chains -- a double fillet of tiny links through which a stray curl or two escaped. Her gown, a modified Empire, was of pale-blue silk shot with silver and draped with silver fringe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Immediately after the Fall elections, and probably by the second week in November, the Speakership contest will have begun in this city. Mr. Mills has already given notice of his intention to open headquarters about that time, and it is to be assumed that the other aspirants for the honor of presiding over the Fifty-second Congress will be here as early as the member from Texas.

The tenth volume of Mr. Ford's edition of the writings of Washington brings the dates down to 1785 and sees the great man released from the responsibilities of office. The opening pages find him still at headquarters in Newburg and the last show him at Mount Vernon, rejoicing in the pleasure of living on his own acres and beneath his own rooftree.

READING, Penn., Aug. 8. -- A ninety-five-year-old citizen of Salisbury Township was awakened the other night by his faithful dog, while walking around his yard sound asleep, clad only in his nightrobe. The aged somnambulist on returning to the house found that he had crawled out of his chamber window and dropped to the ground without sustaining a scratch. He is as lively as a cricket and assists actively in farm work.
Outside was the dreary dripping of the Autumn rain; the fitful soughing of the win wind.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The Republicans are not alone in their troubles in this city and county. "Billy" Tracy, the Hill loader and a member of the State Committee, will have to do some hard work to retain his own scalp, according to present indications, for the anti-Tracy Democrats are hot after him under the lead of Valentine Fleckenstein, who served President Cleveland's Administration in the capacity of Postmaster, and was afterward City Treasurer.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The rainstorm last Tuesday put a quietus on all the sports of the day, which included a bicycle tournament and a church fair. The ladies of St. John's Episcopal Church had their ice cream and sandwiches, pin-cushions and table-scarfs, all ready to look appetizing and ornamental, but they had to save their treasures until to-day for public inspection.

Attempts have been made recently to show by the hat-making industry that a high tariff has been beneficial to American workingmen, and it has been asserted that protection has maintained the wages of hatters in particular at a standard which nothing else could possibly have accomplished. As a matter of fact, no business is better calculated to demonstrate that tariffs are powerless to keep the compensation of labor up to a high point.

The chief characteristics of a midsummer "first night" are heat and noise. The heat cannot be helped; patent cooling machinery does very little to ameliorate its effect when there is a great crowd. The noise is made by the actors, who are sure to form a large proportion of the audience and to have friends on the stage.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Ex-Bank Examiner William P. Drew to-night forwarded to Secretary of the Treasury Foster a detailed statement of his work in connection with the Keystone National Bank. The statement is in vindication of himself, and deals with the action of Controller of the Currency Lacey in asking for his resignation, owing to his omission in his January report of the condition of the Keystone Bank of the Clearing House loan.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 8. -- The fourteenth State in the United States will celebrate the centenary of its admission into the Union, at Bennington, Aug. 19, when the monument commemorating the battle of Bennington will also be dedicated. It was only after a struggle of twenty-six years that Vermont succeeded in so firmly establishing her independence that Congress was compelled to vote her admission as the first State received after the formation of the Union.

TRENTON, Aug. 9. -- The coming convention of the liquor dealers of the State may take up some serious and interesting political problems. The dealers are to meet in Jersey City the first week in September, and even more than heretofore their meeting is anticipated with impatience and misgivings. It is an open secret that they do not like the legislation of last Winter by which Abbett put them under his heel.

BREAKFAST IN A HAREM. -- A plate of broth before each guest; in the middle a big red tray, containing tumblers of water and syrup, and small plates filled with sweets, caviare, sardines -- all kinds of hors d'oeuvre, in fact, which are plentifully patronized. I am seated next to the Pasha's daughter.

CHINESE POST OFFICES. -- It is not to be imagined that a veritable nation of shopkeepers like the Chinese would remain, owing to the refusal of their Government to convey their correspondence, destitute of a postal service. They have, indeed, a very complete system of their own entirely independent of the State.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The week at New-Jersey's pretty lake has been one of un-interrupted gayety. It will be fittingly ended to-night by a brilliant water carnival, in which nearly every boat on the lake will participate. They will assemble at 8 o'clock at Kenmore, near Chincopee Cove. After the display there will be a ball at the Breslin. The hotel arrivals of the week have included many prominent New-Yorkers.

When the Massachusetts "world beaters" returned from their triumphal tour through Great Britain, in the course of which they met and vanquished the crack military shots of the British Volunteers, singly and collectively, the experts of the Twenty-third Regiment tried in every way to get on a match with the acknowledged champions, but without avail.

The wrangle in which a good many veterans of the late war have been engaged since the reductions in the force at the Custom House went into effect has produced a lot of correspondence, but it is doubtful if any letters of more interest have passed than those exchanged by Collector Erhardt and Major Joseph W. Kay, Acting Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Veterans' Rights Union.

At a recent meeting of the Boston Waiters' Alliance a committee was appointed to draft a list of grievances and a schedule of wages. Yesterday the committee forwarded this schedule to Secretary W. Wallace Waugh of the Massachusetts Hotel Proprietors' Association:

THE RIVAL DOCTORS. -- An old chronicler tells the following quaint story of a couple of physicians who were attached to the household of Louis IX. One was called Deroldus, and was afterward Bishop of Amiens; the other, whose name has not been preserved, let us designate the Salernitan, because he was a native of Salerno.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Politics in Wayne County are becoming interesting, and to a casual observer on the outside it would seem that the Democrats are doing their level best to make the path of the enemy as smooth as possible.

IN SEARCH OF THE ACOUSTIC PRINCIPLES. -- A few years ago about fifty earthenware pots or vases were found built into the internal surfaces of the walls of Leeds Church in Kent, so placed that it was impossible to assign any other purpose to them than of an intention that they should assist in some way the transmission of sounds.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- One hundred and twenty-five friends of the Rev. Dr. R.L. Burtsell, largely composed of the members of the Church of the Epiphany, in New-York City, attended St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here to-day. The occasion was the twenty-ninth anniversary of Dr. Burtsell's ordination to the priesthood.

" Cousin" Ben Folsom, Consul at Sheffield, is recovering from an illness which at one time seriously threatened his life. Mr. Folsom returned to America last Spring to visit his aged mother, who is ill of consumption in Southern California. While there he was attacked with pneumonia. Upon his recovery he sailed for Europe and suffered a relapse.

It has for some time been known to scholars that the lost treatise of Aristotle was not the only treasure which recent Egyptian researches have given to the learned world. In the pages of more than one specialist journal partial accounts have from time to time been given of a scarcely less wonderful discovery which we owe to the energy, skill, and good fortune of that remarkable explorer, Mr. Flinders Petrie.

The prosecution of BERTRAM C. WEBSTER for the killing of CHARLES F. GOODWIN promises, from the indications so far given and from the utterances of counsel, to be marked by some unusual features. Without in anywise presuming to prejudge the outcome of the judicial proceedings, it may, perhaps, be worth while to call attention to these features because of their bearing on the law and the customs in vogue for the punishment of homicides.

LENOX, Iowa, Aug. 9. -- When the Cedar Rapids Convention nominated "Farmer" Wheeler the first step in an important political deal was consummated. The second was the nomination of George Van Houten for Lieutenant Governor. Wheeler's patriotism was of a kind that kept him in Europe during most of the period of the civil war.

The French census returns were published yesterday and our Paris correspondent sends us some of the most important figures. The population of France is now 38,095,150, while that of the United Kingdom is 37,740,283, so that we have come within 354,867 of our great neighbor. At the beginning of the present century France had twenty-seven millions to the sixteen millions of these islands.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The most successful season that Cooperstown has ever known reached its height this week, and the destruction of the Cooper House by fire this morning was a genuine calamity. The house had been crowded all the week, among the guests being Admiral Braine and family of Brooklyn and from New-York the following:

With half a dozen notable exceptions, the Presidents of the leading New-York clubs are comparatively unknown outside of their respective social and business spheres. Club politics are unlike "political politics," so to speak, and, as a rule, the Presidency of any big club rarely goes to a man not possessed of particular qualifications for the office.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- A petition bearing nearly 1,300 names was presented to the New-Brunswick Board of Education this week asking for the reinstatement of Prof. Ellis A. Apgar, the City Superintendent of Schools, who was removed by the board a month ago. The members of the board seem to find it hard work to get a Superintendent to suit them.

Leland Stanford was born in Watervliet, very near to the present western boundaries of the City of Albany, March 9, 1824. He began to practice law at Port Washington, Wis., in 1849. A fire in 1852 destroyed his law library and determined him to remove to California, where three brothers had preceded him.

There is a perceptible diminution in the stream of travel to England and the Continent. For the present time in the season there were many vacant staterooms in yesterday's fleet of outgoing steamships. Following is a complete list of voyagers carried by five of the principal liners:

Several things have happened during the past week to substantiate the truth of the story in THE TIMES to the effect that Hugh McLaughlin and Gov. Hill have had a falling out. One was the refusal of all the local politicians to deny it, and another the orders received in the office of 3one of the Democratic organs to ignore it "until further notice."

Mr. Charles T. Yerkes, now in London, is credited in the World of yesterday morning with this statement: "If any money has been taken from the treasury of the Gas Trust Company unlawfully, it must be the New-York party who did it, as they have been in control for over a year past."

Secretary Gibson of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen has announced the entries for the annual regatta which is to take place on the Potomac Aug. 18 and 19. Both Hawkins and Hedley are to meet in the senior singles. The latter says that he is in good condition and hopes to be able to offset the victory gained by the Manhattan Athletic Club crack at the Middle States Regatta.

I have read carefully the articles published in THE TIMES of the trials and tribulations of the men who escaped from Libby, and the description of prison life is not exaggerated one iota, judging from what many others have told me of their experiences in different prisons. My Captain was a prisoner at Charleston, and I have heard him tell his story many times.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Carlton Hall, which has been utilized for this Summer's Presbyterianism at Cape May Point, was this morning well filled with a congregation which was highly appreciative of Dr. Graham and his sermon. The solos were well sung, the choruses were enthusiastic, the discourse was eloquent, but the President wasn't there.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The long-delayed "season" has arrived at last, and to-night the hotels, boarding houses, and even the cottages are crowded. All day long the trains brought down big crowds of visitors, and it was almost midnight before all the new-comers were provided with accommodations for the night.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Attorney General William H.H. Miller, direct from his home, at Indianapolis, was a late arrival at the Continental Hotel this evening, and retired immediately for the night. He will go to Cape May to-morrow morning to meet an appointment with President Harrison.

The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, the headquarters of which are at 79 Fourth Avenue, is prosecuting, with its accustomed vigor and success, an excellent fresh-air work. Its management is ably presided over by Mr. John Paton, whose heart is in the work.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- 0n Sunday, Aug. 15, the Rev. Isaac Clark of Northampton, Mass., a former pastor, will preach in the Wurts Street Presbyterian Church here. Mr. Clark has recently accepted a professorship in the Howard University, at Washington, D.C.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- One of the most picturesque and attractive cottages on the river is Bonnie Castle, the favorite resort of the late Dr. J.G. Holland. Situated on one of the most prominent points near Alexandria Bay, and perched high above the water's edge, it commands a charming view out over the river in either direction and forms a delightful setting in the general landscape.

It is interesting to note the unanimity of opinion among editors of the religious newspapers of the country on the subject of the retirement of Messrs. Quay and Dudley from their places as Chairman and Treasurer of the Republican National Committee.

THE APPRENTICESHIP OF A MATADOR. -- Well, on that Sunday I was at first a failure! I went in the procession with the rest, then with the others I got my capa; but when the bull rushed at me, instead of running away, like the rest, I wrapped my capa about me, and, just as his horns were touching me, I moved aside -- not half a pace.

In their attempts to support that provision of the McKinley act which imposes a duty on tin, the metal, two years hence, our high-tariff contemporaries are making some very amusing remarks. Some of these expounders of McKinleyism profess to believe that there can be no market in this country for the metal except in tin-plate factories.

The action of the State of Kentucky, whose voters on Monday last adopted a new Constitution, removes forever the continuation or renewal in the future of one of the most pernicious evils whose baneful influences ever disgraced a Commonwealth. For seventy years lottery in its worst form has been legalized in Kentucky, and under the sacred sanction of the State its branches have grown and extended throughout the Nation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- The Directors of the Chicago Gaslight and Coke Company are in great glee. C.L. Yerkes is the cause of it. His explanation, cabled from London, of his connection with the bond-selling scheme is regarded with satisfaction by the Directors.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 9. -- The Browns played like a lot of amateurs this afternoon and were not in it at any stage of the game. McMahon had them at his mercy and they couldn't have hit a balloon with a barn door any way. The visitors' play was full of ginger and they had no trouble in touching up both pitchers. Attendance, 12,000. Score:

Major Richmond, a prominent Iowan, who has always been a Republican, is out with a card announcing that this year he shall vote the Democratic ticket. In the course of his letter he says: "I cannot understand how a body of intelligent men will meet in convention and frame such a platform as that adopted by the Republicans at Cedar Rapids, knowing, as they most certainly do, the sentiment of the people on this question.

A sad calamity took place on Sunday night at the chemical works situated close to the edge of the River Tyne, at Friar's Goose, the eastern extremity of Gateshead. A man named Heslop was following his employment as laborer on what is known as a condenser in the form of a large chimney built of stone, and between 80 and 90 feet in height.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 9. -- The largest prehistoric work in this State heretofore described, and of which the Smithsonian Institution has published a complete report, is Fort Aztaian, near Lake Mills, so named from the pyramidal mounds found there, which greatly resemble those found in Mexico. But without doubt the most stupendous and elaborate system of defensive works in the State are found in the vicinity of this city.

There is something almost grotesque about the naivete with which some of Mr. BLAINE'S friends and admirers explain his strength with the party. "He opposed the McKinley bill," remarked one of them, the other day. "He was against the Force bill. He has never gone wild on pensions. He has large interests in the South, and believes in its regeneration.

READING, Penn., Aug. 8. -- Eight-year-old Willie Rothenberger is the object of great wonder and interest to the doctors here on account of his strange and instantaneous recovery from a prolonged case of epilepsy. He is the son of Jacob H. Rothenberger, a street-car conductor, living at 213 North Tenth Street.

Although surrounded by no such commercial pomp and circumstance, the cashier of a country bank is quite as important a man among his own rural constituency as his higher-salaried brother officer in the city. The village bank is frequently the financial centre of half a country, and the man who presides over its destinies comes to be regarded as oracle and authority for fifty miles around.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 9. -- Eighty yachts of the New-York Yacht Club and the smaller clubs which are following along with Commodore Gerry's regular squadron are about the Vineyard to-day and others are still arriving. The victories of the Mineola, Marguerite, and Mischief in their respective classes are the talk of yachtsmen to-day.

Michael Dulko, who keeps a beer saloon in the basement of 224 Second Street, was shot by Officer John Foster of the Thirteenth Precinct, while resisting arrest for violation of the excise law yesterday. His injuries, it is thought, will prove fatal. Dulko is a Slav, thirty years old, and with his wife Mary and one child, lived in the tenement over the saloon, which was the scene of the shooting.

Depending from nails driven into an old shutter and covering a space of not more than four square feet, the whole contained within an Ann Street store, one may see such a quantity and such a variety of queer cast-off things, composed wholly or in part of metal, that if he has the penchant for curios, he may spend a solid hour without exhausting the charms of the panel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Capt. Brooks, Superintendent of Foreign Mails, has just returned from Vienna, where he was in attendance as a delegate to the International Postal Convention. There were, he says, delegates present from every civilized country except Natal and the Transvaal. He believes that by the time of the next convention, which meets here in 1897, every civilized country will be in the Postal Union.

The real estate market last week was very dull. Not only real estate trades, but real estate dealers as well were scarce in this vicinity. Advantage was taken of the anticipated stagnation by many of the leading operators and dealers to enjoy a holiday, and the Exchange in consequence was for several days about as lively as a Summer resort in midwinter.

YUMA, Arizona, Aug. 9. -- Reports continue to come in from the earthquake region at the head of the Gulf of California. Two Cocopah Indians of the tribe that live near there arrived yesterday. They tell a thrilling story. Early Thursday morning hundreds of mud volcanoes, thirty miles off, burst into a violent eruption. The air grew denser and many infants were suffocated.

Owing to the short time remaining in which to prepare exhibits for the proposed exhibition by the Society of Amateur Photographers at the American Institute Fair, it has been decided to abandon the undertaking, which will give the members more time to get exhibits ready for the Boston Joint Exhibition in 1892.

A Post-Express reporter had an interesting talk with Prof. Ward on the subject of the mastodon remains just discovered at Oakfield. "A man came to me yesterday," said he, "and showed me a rib which he said he had dug up. It was certainly a mastodon rib. He said he was going to dig for the rest of it, but I doubt if he finds very much more.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Milton Rainford, a comedian of the old school, died this morning in this city at 1,031 Vine Street. For many years his was a familiar figure on the Eastern and Western stage, and he played prominent roles in leading stock companies when there was attached to engagements in such organizations much more importance than there is to-day.

Application was made to Judge Coffey late yesterday afternoon for an order revoking the special letters of administration on the estate of Mary F. Hopkins-Searles, granted to Public Administrator Freese, last Monday. The application was based on a telegram from Methnen, Mass., addressed to Attorney Craig of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 9. -- When ex-Congressman Harrison Kelly published a letter several days ago repudiating the Republican Party and going over to the People's Party, it created a great deal of surprise among the old-time Republicans. A recent explanation, however, clears the matter up, and shows that there was method in his madness.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The cool and rainy weather has made it uncomfortable in the mountains this week, but the trend of travel is yet to and not from the Catskills, and hotels and boarding houses are entertaining thousands of guests. Postal clerks on the Ulster and Delaware Railroad on one train handle 219 packages of letters and 52 sacks of papers daily.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Last night James McElroy was found murdered in an areaway beside his boarding house, at 14 Passaic Street, by Andrew Wells, the proprietor of the house. The man's skull had been badly crushed, and his face was horribly disfigured. The deed is laid to Joseph Smith, a Brooklyn Bridge policeman, who was here visiting his aunt, Mrs. Wells.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- It was learned to-night that the young woman whose body was found in the Niagara River at Lewiston on Friday was Cora Farthing of this city. Whether it was a case of murder or suicide is still in doubt, though her family believe it to have been the latter. A reason has been discovered for either. She was in trouble and unmarried.

Bazaar promoters -- and their name is legion at this season -- are beginning to realize that expensive trifles beautiful to look at, but of no use and as ornaments very perishable, do not obtain the ready sale of former times. There was a time when the patrons of these affairs expected no equivalent for their money, regarding their expenditures merely as they disguised gifts.

WATERTOWN, Aug. 8. -- The appointment of Senator J. Sloat Fassett to the Collectorship of the Port of New-York, with the accompanying implied notification that Thomas C. Platt can hereafter be regarded as boss of the Republican machine, has not had an inspiring effect on the Republicans of Northern New-York.

READING, Penn., Aug. 8. -- The midsummer snake crop is unusually large in the Schuylkill Valley this year, and within the last fortnight no end of rattlers, copperheads, vipers, and blacksnakes have been seen and killed. Farmers' wives and daughters just now are chary about stepping around their yards and shrubbery lost they should tread on the coil of one of the reptiles.

CAFE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 10. -- In addition to the usual Monday morning exodus from all seashore resorts there was this morning a special departure from Cape May that leaves the White House by the sea in what might also be termed a lonely condition.

An interesting rifle competition has been arranged to be held, under the auspices of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association, at the State Rifle Range. Sea Girt, beginning on Monday, Aug. 24, and closing the following Saturday. It is proposed to make this an annual event, and, if it is carried out on the lines laid down by the projectors of the scheme, it can hardly fail to be very popular with military riflemen.

BARNESVILLE, Md., Aug. 10. -- The colored camp meeting which has been going on here for four weeks, and which has been attended by colored persons from all parts of this and other States, was the scene of a bloody fight yesterday while the crowd was waiting for the evening train to convey them to their homes. A party of negroes engaged in a dispute over some cigars, when one of them.

Cable advices from San Salvador are that the United States mail steamer City of Panama, belonging to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, has been seized officially by the Salvadorian Government for violation of the port regulations. The seizure took place Aug. 9, at the Port of La Libertad. Should the confiscation be enforced, it will cause great delay in the delivery of the mails.

Commissioner BEATTIE does not propose to make any mistake by not asking for enough money to carry on the work of the Department of Secret Cleaning next year. He has put in a modest estimate of its requirements at $2,653,233. His estimate for this year was $1,717,774.51, and he promised that if that amount was allowed he would keep the streets clean or give up the job.

Yesterday was the hottest August day on record, and the records have been kept for twenty-five years. It came within 2 also of being the hottest day of the year. The day was preceded by a sultry night, in which but little comfort was secured by the unfortunate denizens of the populous sections of the city. In the tenement districts especially the suffering was intense.

The McKinley papers continue to mislead their readers concerning the consumption of tin, the metal, in this country, the effect of the now tariff upon the production of the metal, and other kindred subjects. Their purpose is to make their readers believe that there can be no market for the metal here except in tin-plate factories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The August returns to the Department of Agriculture make the condition of cotton 88.9 for the whole breadth, practically the same as last month. The improvement during the month has been confined to sections of South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, and Arkansas. In other portions of the cotton belt there has been a decline in condition.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The St. James Gazette takes a very gloomy view of the condition of British trade, and to-day there appears in its columns an article commenting in a pessimistic manner upon the outlook for the manufacturing and other industries of Great Britain. It says:

Unsteady pitching on the part of Terry and poor fielding lost a game for Brooklyn yesterday. The latter led in the batting, but made errors at critical moments. Terry's work was of such a poor character that it was necessary to put Caruthers in the box. Score:

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 10. -- J.O. Wynn, the State business agent of the Farmers' Alliance of Georgia, was this morning announced to be a defaulter to the amount of $20,000. All day new deficits have been discovered, until now it looks as if the shortage will go beyond $40,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Alfred Downing, President, and N.H. Tolman, Vice President, of the National Capital Savings Building and Loan Association of North America were arrested today by Post Office Inspector Stewart, charged with using the mails for fraudulent purposes. It is charged that the men who have been conducting this association have swindled thousands of people from every State in the Union, and have taken from $200,000 to $600,000 and given nothing in return.

The police authorities of Stapleton, S.I., are interested to a mild extent in the unraveling of a story of a mysterious drowning case told by Capt. Charles Loomer of the stone barge Active, now lying at Staple's Dock, in that town. This dock, from the fact that it extends out into the stream something like 1,100 feet, is known to the residents of the locality as "the long dock."

Although no quorum of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs has appeared in response to Senator Cameron's call for a meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, it is as good as settled that the committee will make an extended trip to the navy yards along the New-England coast. A member of the committee told a TIMES reporter yesterday that Secretary of the Navy Tracy had invited the committee to go on the white squadron.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The expectation that the Catholic University would become a centre around which would be located the various Catholic orders is gradually being realized. The Paulist Fathers occupy the old Middleton House, within the boundary of the university grounds, and the young men who are being educated by the order attend the university lectures.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Beattie has prepared his departmental estimate for 1892 for submission to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to be considered in the arrangement of next year's budget. He asks for a total of $2,653,233, which is more than was ever asked for before for street-cleaning purposes and more than a million dollars more than was allowed for 1891, which was $1,584,250.

The Rapid-Transit Commission appears to be determined to confine its decision in regard to the construction of an underground railroad in Broadway to a choice between two plans, neither of which fulfills the promise of the resolution adopted when the route was laid out. It was then declared that the tunnel was to be "at such a depth below the curb line as not to disturb the surface or endanger building foundations."

We have already referred to the attitude assumed by Mr. ex-Speaker MILLS in Iowa regarding the relative importance of the silver question and the question of tariff reform to the Democratic Party, of which he is so prominent a representative. Mr. MILLS, not only in his public speeches, but in his intercourse with the leading Democrats, declares, without reserve, that "the silver question will have to be kept out of the national canvass next year."

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The President to-day appointed Richard Cotts Shannon of New-York Minister to Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Salvador. This is the new South American mission created by the last Congress.

The saloon keeper Michael Dutko, who was shot by Patrolman John Foster of the Thirteenth Precinct Sunday while resisting arrest, died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning from the effects of his wounds. The police officer was arraigned by his Captain before Justice Duffy at the Essex Market Police Court and remanded to the Coroner's care.

The new uniform regulations for the Revenue Marine, it is expected, will be issued during the present week. The nature of the changes have already been given at length in THE TIMES. In brief, the new regulations present, with but few exceptions, the line uniform of the navy. Recently a few of the unprogressive officers of the Revenue Marine have taken occasion to air in service papers their disapproval of the coming regulations.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 10. -- The Republicans have another party row on their hands. Gov. Fifer has asserted his independence, it seems, in the exercise of his official duties, disregarding the wishes of Candidate Cullom and some of his friends. A split in the Cullom-Fifer faction of the party is the result.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Acting Secretary Nettleton has received a letter from F.G. Niedringhaus, President of the St. Louis Stamping Company, in reply to the letter of the Secretary of the Treasury of the 30th ult. in regard to the importation of skilled labor for the tin-plate industry. Mr. Niedringhaus says:

The Custom House kaleidoscope, in which Custodian De Witt C. Wheeler and Janitor Edmund C. Lee appear in varied relations, took another turn yesterday. On Saturday it had shown Mr. Lee triumphant and the custodian in full flight for the refuge that the Collector's office grants. Yesterday it revealed a triumph for Mr. Wheeler and the janitor's energies confined to a telegraph office, through which communication is kept up with the Public Stores.

Several members of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Democratic Clubs came to the city yesterday in anticipation of the meeting of the committee which will be held at the Hoffman House to-day at noon. From their remarks in the hotels last evening the meeting will be an interesting one, and will in its discussions cover the political situation in nearly all parts of the country.

Considerable interest has been manifested in Vera Cruz over the seizure by Mexican revenue officers of the American bark William Kern for smuggling. The capture was effected at Tuxpam, an important seaport north of Vera Cruz. The William Kern has been accustomed to put in an appearance at this port three or four times a year with a cargo of merchandise, and it was rumored that she did a large contraband business.

TOPEKA, Aug. 10. -- The wheat harvest of Kansas is producing better results than the most sanguine anticipated. The Agricultural Department predicted 60,000,000 bushels, and the President of the Alliance estimated 42,000,000 bushels from the returns made by thrashers. It is now estimated that there will be 70,000,000 bushels, machine measure.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 10. -- Judge W.A. King of the Fourth and Fifth Judicial Districts of Texas, in whose court the San Antonio and Aransas Pass receivership is vested, says that if the Railway Commission makes its indicated cotton rate he will order a foreclosure and sale of the road, which will have the effect to shut out the home credit and place the road in the hands of the New-York bondholders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The Department of State has received a copy of the following imperial decree of China, issued June 12 last:

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The result of the continuation of the Republican caucus battles in this county to-night reveals the fact, as predicted in THE TIMES this morning, that Senator Fassett has gained an overwhelming victory over all opposition, and will have a large working majority in the convention next Saturday.

Although the Democratic State Committee will meet at the Hoffman House at 10 o'clock Wednesday, none of the members was visible at the up-town hotels after 8 o'clock last night Chairman Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy, and Speaker of the Assembly William F. Sheehan arrived from Albany on the limited train over the New-York Central Road at 7:30, and were met by Police Commissioner James J. Martin.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The seventeenth annual session of the International Congress of Hygiene and Demography opened in St. James's Hall, in this city, this afternoon. At an early hour this morning the royal yacht left Portsmouth for Cowes, Isle of Wright, the object of the voyage being to bring to England the Prince of Wales, who was to preside at the congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Mr. Lacey, Controller of the Currency, said to-day he had read Mr. Drew's letter to the Secretary, in which he defends his official action as Bank Examiner in connection with the Keystone National Bank.

We do not hear that the United States District Attorneys in Ohio or Western Pennsylvania are sitting up nights to make cases against Trusts under the Sherman law. That curious letter of instruction from Attorney General MILLER does not appear to have caused any excitement in their offices.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker and National Chairman Clarkson came up from Cape May Point this morning. Gen. Clarkson proceeded at once to New-York to keep an appointment at the Hotel Plaza, which Mr. Wanamaker said was of an entirely private and personal nature. The Postmaster General is looking bronzed and hearty from his brief outings by the sea.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Two good-looking young men, wearing patent leather shoes and white silk vests and carrying canes, were arraigned before Judge King, in the police court, this morning. They were William Wilson and Lincoln Whiting. Both boarded at 286 Seventh Street a week ago. One night they went through Thomas Hunt's trousers and took $100.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 10. -- The great heat wave has passed over North Dakota, and farmers to-day express the hope that the grain is not so badly blighted as at first feared. All points reporting from west of the Missouri say the damage has not exceeded 7 or 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The newspapers of Lima, Peru, contain elaborate accounts of the removal of the remains of Francisco Pizarro, who led the conquest of Peru, from a vault under the altar of the cathedral at Lima to the chapel of the Viceroys, in the same building. The remains were subjected to a careful examination and the body was found to be admirably preserved, although it is 350 years since Pizarro died.

The name of Mr. STARIN is now to be added to the long list of reputable Republicans in whose sight the net of fowler PLATT is spread in vain. This will be regretted by Mr. PLATT most sadly, because Mr. STARIN has not only capacity, and reputation, and popularity, but he has much money, which he always expends with a liberal hand for an object that he regards as worthy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- An important inquiry in regard to the effect of the tariff on prices is now being conduced by Col. Carroll D. Wright, Commissioner of the Department of Labor, who will probably have his work far enough advanced to be able to make a report to Congress early in the session.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 10 -- The hottest day of the year witnessed the beginning of the annual tennis tournament here. A large number of entries had been received and play was started promptly this morning by Referee O.S. Campbell. S.T. Chase, the Western champion, appeared in excellent condition and it is thought will win the tournament.

This is Junior Champion day, and Morris Park will be crowded this afternoon to see the battle of the royally-bred youngsters for the prize of $27,000 and the nominal championship of the T.Y.C. Eighteen youngsters are named to start for the prize, and the race on paper promises to be one of the best of the many good ones of the year.

COTTAGE CITY, Aug. 10. -- The New-York Yacht Club had a grand race to-day. It was the finest event of the cruise up to date. A strong west-southwest wind swept down Vineyard Sound and the sea was smooth, so that there was a splendid opportunity to try the merits of the yachts. The course was also favorable for a test of speed in various points of sailing.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 10 -- The Michigan crop report for August gives the average yield of wheat per acre, as estimated by correspondents as follows: In the southern counties, 17.96 bushels; in the central counties, 13.10 bushels, and in the northern counties, 11.31 bushels. The present estimated yield for the southern counties is 1.69 bushels higher, and for the central counties it is 7 bushels higher than that of July 1.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- Mr. A.J. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, in a speech delivered at Plymouth to-day, outlined his ideas of Irish local government. He repudiated what he claimed to be Mr. Morley's unjust and unfair suspicion that the Government's proposed measure for Ireland was a small Home Rule bill. Mr. Gladstone, the speaker declared, was not as sailed with such a suspicion when he proposed a similar bill in parliament.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 10. -- A cloud of mosquitoes descended upon this city on Sunday night. The telegraph operators were driven from their keys and the lights had to be put out in many residences. People living in the suburbs suffered the most. The insects penetrated everywhere.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, LAKE CHAMPLAIN, Aug. 11. -- "Who in the world was 'Will' after whom this borough and point were called?" is the natural question which every one will ask. The answer to it makes a very interesting chapter in history. Just before the outbreak of the Revolutionary War an Englishman of fortune and position, William Gilliland, came over to settle and to develop the country.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11. -- F.G. Neidringhaus was called upon to-day and asked for an explanation of his letter to the Acting Secretary of the Treasury at Washington. He said:...

The Board of Park Commissioners will meet to-day. It may be that the meeting will be an important one to the thousands of good citizens who are engaged in the effort to get the Commissioners to order Jay Gould's elevated railroad off Battery Park, upon which it squatted under a temporary permit from a preceding Board of Commissioners.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 11. -- Sir Hector Langevin's sudden determination to resign has caused a big sensation here. His step was completely uneqpected. It is said that the Hon. Thomas McGreevy will also resign. The resignation of Sir Hector Langevin has proved to be a veritable bombshell in political circles. It was totally unexpected at this stage of the proceedings, and is the absorbing topic of conversation here.

It is doubtful that there ever has been hotter, stickier, nastier weather than the people of this city have suffered during the past three days. There are not adjectives enough in the Dictionary to describe the uncomfortableness which New-Yorkers have experienced since the present hot wave struck them. They have suffered under a duplex burden of heat and humidity which has seemed almost unbearable.

According to Mr. CARLISLE, who has been interviewed at Narragansett, the Alliance or third-party movement is not to play an important part in next year's campaign unless CLEVELAND and HARRISON, "both anti-free coinage men," should be nominated by their respective parties. In that case, he thinks that there would be a third ticket in the field which would inflict greater losses upon the Republicans than upon the Democrats.

The meeting yesterday of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Democratic Clubs showed, through the reports submitted from various States, that the organization of these clubs has been quietly spreading throughout the Union in the last two years, and awakening new interest among the people in the political issues to which the Democratic Party is devoted.

The award of the contract for one hundred high-power coast-defense guns to the Bethlehem Iron Works was the natural result of the legislation on the subject. The appropriation required that the guns should be furnished "at prices deemed fair to the manufacturer and to the best interest of the United States."

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- The great activity displayed by the State Civil Service Commission two months ago in the matter of the inspectors under the Regents of the University seems to have prostrated the board. Since that time but little if anything has been done. During the season of inactivity the heads of departments have taken advantage of the situation, and the civil service law has been openly violated.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- The Sub-Committee of City Councils that has been investigating the affairs of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley and the Keystone Bank met this afternoon after a recess of a month. Lawrence E. Brown, an expert accountant, who has been engaged in an examination in the interests of the city of the books of John Bardsley and the Keystone Bank, was the first witness called.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 11. -- Attorney General John P. Stockton to-day forwarded a brief to the Secretary of War at Washington bearing on the controversy between Gov. Abbett's State Riparian Board and the Federal Harbor Commission, as to the proper place for the location of the solid filling line on the New-York Bay shore.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- The Farmers' Alliance met here today in its third annual convention. Fifty delegates, representing sixteen of the twenty-three counties of the State, were present. President Hugh Mitchell of Port Tobacco presided, with T. Canfield Jenkins of Pomonkey Secretary. Reports showed that since last year the number of the Alliances in Maryland has increased 100 per cent., and the membership has increased 300 per cent.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11. -- The Rev. James Hughes of this city, who is the first Catholic Chaplain to be assigned to duty in the National Guard of the State, has been a distinguished figure in the Hartford Diocese since 1852, when, at the age of twenty-two years, he received the appointment of Vicar General from Bishop Bernard O'Reilly, who was his uncle.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 11. -- When the Electra fired her gun and sent up signals which announced that the fleet was to get under way for this fine old whale all city, not a breath of air distributed the deep, green waters of Vineyard Haven. It was the deadest kind of a dead calm, and the rays of the August sun came down with pitiless severity on the heads of the waiting yachtsmen.

VIENNA, Aug. 11. -- King Alexander, the boy ruler of Servia, who succeeded to the throne upon the abdication of King Milan, arrived here at a late hour last night from St. Petersburg, where he has been visiting the Czar. A large number of officials were awaiting him in the station, while outside a crowd numbering 10,000 persons had gathered to get a view of the youthful ruler.

Both John Ewing and Luby pitched excellent ball yesterday. The Chicagoes got only four hits off of Ewing, while the Giants only secured five off of Luby. It was a game marked by brilliant field work, but weak batting, and was not of a character that is calculated to please the patrons of the sport. There was, however, a redeeming feature -- the Giants won. John Ewing's work was highly commented upon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- There were two elaborate society events to-day. The first was a large reception given by ex-Gov. and Mrs. George P. Wetmore at their beautiful villa, Chateau sur Mer, from 4 to 6 o'clock this afternoon. The reception was held in a large red tent erected on the broad lawn front of the cottage.

Our reports from the leading wheat-growing States, which we published yesterday, indicate that estimates of the new crop heretofore made were not too large. It is now believed that the crop in Kansas will be 70,000,000 bushels, a quantity considerably in excess of the Government's estimate.

The Navy Department has adopted a series of regulations to govern the employment of foremen, mechanics, and laborers at navy yards, which are designed to more effectually carry out the letter and spirit of Sections 1,544, 1,546, 1,754, and 1,755 of the Revised Statutes. The regulations are to go into effect Sept. 1 next. The sections referred to provide substantially as follows:
