NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 11. -- The State Alliance met to-day in the hall of the House of Representatives with about one hundred and fifty delegates, representing unions in all except twelve counties. Gov. Buchanan delivered an address of welcome, in the course of which he said: "This farmers' uprising is crude, it is true, but it has genuine evils to combat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11. -- Senator Leland Stanford is giving aid and encouragement to thousands of Southern negroes, who are establishing large colonies in California. It is expected that 50,000 negroes will become residents of the State within the next twelve months. In view of these facts the politicians are alarmed, as the colonists are quite likely to bewilder the shrewdest political manager on the coast.

For four hours the Executive Committee of the National Association of Democratic Clubs sat behind closed doors in one of the Hoffman House parlors yesterday and discussed the political outlook in various parts of the country. In that time reports were read from the Chairman of the State Central Committee or the Vice President of the association of clubs in every State in the Union.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 11. -- Good progress was made in the tennis tournament here to-day. The second round of the singles was finished and the doubles and consolation matches were begun. S.T. Chase, the Western expert, was successful in all his matches, and to-morrow plays L.R. Parker, the Yale expert, to determine which will reach the finals in the top half of the draw.

Mrs. Mary Bright, a colored woman, was a prisoner yesterday in Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with theft. It was said that she entered the rooms of Garwood Baker, at 60 West Twenty-fifth Street, and stole $300 worth of clothing. The police say that Mary has stolen a great deal in the Sixteenth and Nineteenth Police Precincts.

At a meeting of the Board of Health held yesterday afternoon it was decided to call the attention of the public to the following circular concerning sunstroke, first issued by the board in the Summer of 1882:

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Charles H. Brinkerhoff, Charles F. Baldenecker, David L. Cardozo, John A. Dougan, and David T. Jennings are Trustees of the Excelsior Mutual Aid Society of New-York which has just been incorporated. The object is to exercise charity and render aid to needy and distressed persons. Medical and legal advice is also to be furnished worthy persons.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- Senator Quay, fresh from his Beaver home, arrived at the Continental Hotel this morning, where he was soon joined by Collector Cooper. The ex-Chairman of the State Committee sat down, and they were busy for fully an hour discussing the coming Republican State Convention, its platform and candidates.

The events of the last two days in Wall Street have left a peculiar impression there that, if Jay Gould desires to get up a syndicate to take care of the Union Pacific obligations for the next three years, he will have to come home and attend to the matter himself. The New-York and Boston men, to whose hands the scheme was intrusted, seem to have failed to put it on its feet.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- For the purpose of studying the actual effects of the McKinley bill, as far as such effects could show themselves within the comparatively short time since the law became operative, the Associated Press correspondent has visited some of the most important industrial centres of Germany, such as Leipsie, Chemnitz, Plauen, Greiz, Nuremberg, and Frankfort.

A wreath of laurel, from which fluttered ribbons of crimson and of silver, was bestowed upon Theodore Thomas in the large hall of the Liederkranz Club house in East Fifty-eighth Street last night. Upon the silver ribbon in letters of gold was inscribed: "To our honored guest and member, Theo. Thomas. From the German Liederkranz, Aug. 11, 1891."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 11 -- The convention of the Southern Lumbermen's Association, which opens in the Polytechnic Building to-morrow morning, promises to be the largest and most important meeting of its kind ever held in the West. The most important subject to be touched upon is the uniform gauge question. In building it is very often necessary for contractors to purchase lumber from two or three different firms for the same premises.

Senator Cameron and the other members of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs waited at the Fifth Avenue Hotel all day yesterday, not knowing when they were to begin their trip of inspection aboard the white squadron. Last evening Rear Admiral John G. Walker, commanding the squadron, called on them, and said he proposed to start shortly after noon to-day.

If we take as correct the old description of the Bourbons as those "who forgot nothing and learned nothing," it applies very closely to the Republican Party of to-day and not at all to the Democratic Party of to-day. Thirty years ago the cases were reversed. When the Democratic leaders were wedded to the ideas that had their source in slavery.

Engineer William Barclay Parsons of the Rapid-Transit Commission was in Philadelphia yesterday in consultation with Consulting Engineer Joseph M. Wilson on the details of his plan of construction of the Broadway-Boulevard line, and Chief Engineer William E. Worthen refused to give any information about the plans upon which he is engaged.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Much gossip has been occasioned in the American colony here by an action brought by Mrs. Walter Berkeley Crane, formerly Miss Alice Cooper of New-York, but more recently of Paris, who is seeking in the divorce division of her Majesty's High Court of Justice to procure the annulment of her marriage.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The people here were mystified this morning when they found that the shores of a small lake west of the town were all thickly lined with dead fish. In some unaccountable manner all the fish in the lake died during the night, and the bodies of thousands of them lay along the edge of the water. The people are much puzzled to account for the strange happening.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 11. -- Senator Carlisle, who is here with Senators Aldrich, Harris, and Allison as a member of the Senate Sub-Committee on Finance, in discussing the political situation yesterday, said: "The Farmers' Alliance is a gradual atrophy, which indicates that the organization will not, in all probability, be a serious factor in the election next year.

In preparing his estimate of the cost of cleaning the streets of this city next year, which calls for the monstrous appropriation of $2,653,233, Commissioner BEATTIE says that it is made in accordance with the recommendations of the report of the Advisory Committee on Street Cleaning and the Mayor's letter in answer to that report.

Owing to the excessive heat all work in the Brooklyn Navy Yard was stopped at noon Tuesday and yesterday. Three seamen on the cruiser Bennington, one seaman on the cruiser Atlanta, and several navy yard workmen have been prostrated by the heat in the past thirty-six hours. The matter is greatly delaying the cleaning of the bottom of the Atlanta.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12. -- Timothy Hopkins, the disinherited son of the late Mrs. Hopkins Searles, arose very early at the Palace Hotel this morning, and began reading his large accumulated mail. He was besieged with visitors, and to an early caller he said he must go through his correspondence carefully before he could say a word of positive information concerning the situation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug 12. -- The political situation is somewhat altered by Sir Hector Langovin's resignation of the portfolio of Public Works. The latest and best authenticated rumors are to the effect that the resignation was not only forced by the new Premier, Mr. Abbott, but that it was the result of a real desire upon Sir Hector's part to have done forever with political life.

Commenting on the ways of bluejackets, a naval officer recently gave an illustration of the characteristics which distinguish a sailor from his fellow-men. In 1885, he said, there was something like $13,000,000 in sliver dollars in the New-Orleans Mint which the Treasury Department wanted transferred to the national depository in Washington.

" This is only one of the outrages which consignees of foreign goods are subjected to by the customs officials in this city," Mr. L. Contaseau, proprietor of Contanseau's Foreign Express, said to a TIMES reporter as he displayed a piece of work by Customs Inspectors, which he characterized as "reckless vandalism."

BOSTON, Aug. 12. -- James Russell Lowell died early this morning at his home at Elmwood, Cambridge. Exactly what caused Mr. Lowell's death is not at present known, but it is understood that gout brought on liver trouble and led to other complications too great to be resisted by a man of Mr. Lowell's age and feebleness.

The Russian ukase forbidding the exportation of rye will have the most far-reaching and important consequences. To us rye is of less consequence than almost any other cereal, being grown mainly for the purpose of being distilled into whisky. In Eastern Europe, however, it is the most important of breadstuffs, being the food of the people and the staff of life to a considerably greater extent than wheat.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Work on all of the great buildings for the World's Fair was stopped Tuesday night by Chief of Construction Burnham. All of the contractors received orders to take their men off and not put them to work again until they received written orders. The contractors were told that slight modifications would be made in the building plans, and that they could go to work again in a day or two.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Business was brisk in the President's cottage to-day. Mr. Harrison had not time even to take a surf bath, and Mr. Halford was at the Point later than his usual hour. Even after the industrious secretary had left his chief, the latter sat at his little desk in the corner of the reception room and toiled earnestly.

HANOVER, Ind., Aug. 12. -- A novel wedding took place on Monday in Bergadines Woods, west of the village, where a partly of gypsies have been encamped for several days. The principals were John Lynch, at one time a prosperous butcher of Philadelphia, and Jennie Van Zeklin, a genuine nomad, who was born on the road in England nineteen years ago, and who was recently chosen at Elyria, Ohio, Queen of the Gypsies.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12. -- The navymen are having a fine time here target shooting. Companies from the three ships came on shore again to-day and drilled for a couple of hours.

A terrible stormblast, wind, lightning, and rain, coming together and with little warning, struck the excursion streamer Crystal Stream and the barge Republic as they lay at the dock in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday afternoon, and in the wreck that followed fourteen people were killed almost instantly. Many were seriously injured, the number being variously estimated at from twenty to sixty.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Edward Pardridge to-day was assuring his Board of Trade creditors that his indebtedness to them would be paid in the morning through the Clearing House -- a remarkable position for Mr. Pardridge to be compelled to take. Anybody who has known this enormously rich dry goods man has probably never imagined that his speculative dates would ever be closed out under the hammer.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- In the election held in Walsall, Stafford County, to-day for a member of Parliament to succeed the late Sir Charles Forster, a Liberal, in favor of home rule, who died on July 26, Alderman Holden, the Gladstonian candidate, defeated Mr. F. James, the representative of the Conservatives. The result of the voting was as follows: Holden, 4,899; James, 4,361; Holden's majority, 538.

The feature of the day's sport at Jerome Park this afternoon will be the race for the Champion Stakes, at a mile and a half, in which Firenzi, Riley, and Raceland will meet, Kingston starting in the Orange Stakes, in which he has a practical walk-over, instead of making a fight against two such good horses, at the distance, as Riley and Firenzi.
Hugo Eitel, sixteen years of age, the son of Emil Eitel, a saloon keeper of 2 East One Hundred and Tenth Street, is a victim of hydrophobia.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12. -- John Devlin of the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor is in the city for the purpose of putting an end to the big beer boycott. The Brewers' Union has been conducting a boycott on the Anheuser-Busch and Lemp breweries for some time. At attempt was made recently to adjust the difficulty, but it failed.

CASTLE OF CRAIG-Y-NOS, WALES, Aug. 12. -- Adelina Patti threw open her new theatre to the world to-night. The occasion added another to the successes of her life, and marked their culmination. From morning until midnight it was a continuous festivity, ending in the brilliant performance in the theatre. Everything passed off as arranged; there was not a hitch or an untoward event.

Secretary Lawrence Gardner of the National Association of Democratic Clubs remained in New-York yesterday, and in the course of the day had interviews with several local politicians. He also discussed with George Hazzard, the Chairman of the Democratic Committee of Washington, the proposed excursion of Democratic leaders through the Northwest.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- Senator Quay returned to the Continental Hotel this evening from New-York. The members of his family, who have just returned from a tour through Europe, did not stay over, they bidding their father good-bye at Broad Street station and continuing on their journey to the Senator's home at Beaver.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 12. -- The Farmers' Alliance Convention to-day tried its hand at diplomacy. The resolution to indorse Frank Brown, the Democratic nominee for Governor, was up as unfinished business. Most of the delegates were in favor of voting for it, but a few independents prolonged the debate and tried to persuade the convention that it would not be politic to formally indorse a man who had neglected to indorse the Alliance.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Regret was expressed throughout the business community to-day at the announcement of the death of Mr. George Jones. Especially was this the case with the older residents who had known Mr. Jones personally when he carried on business here. They had naught but praise for him for his pleasant, cheerful nature, for his integrity and business methods.

BELVIDERE, N.J. Aug. 12. -- Two negroes were arrested to-day on suspicion of having committed the Hope murder. One of them was afterward discharged, but the other was hold for identification. The negro gives the name of Wilson and says his home is in Philadelphia.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Julius Marcus, a New-York broker, spent to-day in Connecticut, looking into the affairs of the Old Colony Distillery Company of this city, which, was recently attached by the United Growers' Company of New-York for $150,000. He wanted to secure requisition papers from Gov. Bulkeley, but the Governor is not in the State.
LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Bret Harte has written concerning the death of James Russell Lowell, the American poet, as follows:

OFF BIMINI, BAHAMA BANK, Aug. 11, via Key West Aug. 12. -- The stranded steamship El Dorado still holds together, and the weather so far has been favorable. The signs point to moderate northeast winds and a smooth sea.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The massive loving cup, the first prize in the tennis tournament here, was worthily won by Richard Stevens of the St. George Cricket Club to-day. Stevens defeated L.R. Parker, the expert from Yale, after a hard fought match. Parker had previously unexpectedly beaten S.T. Chase, the Western champion, after a close contest.

The recent test at Sandy Hook of emmensite as the bursting charge for shells will direct increased attention to this form of using the high explosives in projectiles. A seven-inch shell filled with emmensite, which is far more powerful than gunpowder, was fired safely from a gun of that calibre, and when a proper fuse can be obtained for such shells they will have a decided prospect of taking their place among service projectiles.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The canoeists at the annual meet of the American Canoe Association have had bad weather for the past two days, but the prospects are for better weather, and the calling of the first races on Thursday. The storm on Tuesday night wrecked the large tent at headquarters and thoroughly wet some of the tents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Work at the Pension Office is almost at a standstill. It is stated on good authority that in the last twelve days not a single original pension has been issued. Practically the entire force is engaged on miscellaneous business, the cleaning up of arrears of correspondence, and other odds and ends, but no certificates are going out.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 12. -- The streak of bad luck for favorites which has characterized the summer trotting circuit continued to-day, as Hal Pointer was the only one of four to pull off his engagement.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- William Jeffrey of Oceanport, a son of Milford Jeffrey of Oceanport, was killed here last night. The young man was anxious to get an education and this season, to earn money, accepted a position as night watchman on the Oceanport drawbridge. His mangled body was found on the drawbridge this morning.

CARLTON, Minn., Aug 12. -- A hurricane demolished a Chippewa Indian village at Sawyer yesterday. It was accompanied by a great hail storm which destroyed all the gardens and grain fields between Sawyer and Big Lake. Many Indians were injured, but none killed.

It was hot last night, and, though a refreshing August breeze blew over the city from the south, the old settler who had not spared himself in pioneer days would ordinarily have been tempted to stay at home in neglige. But he did not remain on his wide porch, neither did his wife nor his children. They were seen, something less than seven hundred strong, at Col. Chase's house cooling.

J. Sloat Fassett took the oath of office as Collector of the Port of New-York yesterday, and to-day will find him in full possession. He spent most of his time at the Custom House yesterday, appearing in the Collector's office at 10:30 o'clock. Deputy Collector Burr, who is expected to be close to the new administration, was with him.

Just one inning was enough to settle all doubts as to the result of the game between New-York and Chicago yesterday. It was the second. At that point the Chicago fielders made errors, the New-York batsmen made base hits, the official scorer tallied 6 runs, and Anson was beaten again.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The Rev. Dr. George H. Goodsall of New-York City laid the cornerstone of the chapel of the First Methodist Episcopal Church at Avenue C and West Thirty-first Street to-night. The pastor, the Rev. C.S. Ryman, and the Rev. W.W. Knox of the First Reformed Church of Bayonne assisted at the services.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 12. -- C.A. Pillsbury was interviewed this morning in regard to the recent dispatch in which Congressman Baker quotes Mr. Pillsbury as saying that under normal conditions the farmers should receive $1.50 per bushel for their wheat. Mr. Pillsbury said that if it was not for short selling -- gambling in wheat -- it would be worth $1.25 to-day.

As the season advances the crowds grow larger and larger to witness "Paris -- From Empire to Commune" at Manhattan Beach. Every Thursday evening, in addition to the spectacle, a special programme of fireworks is prepared, and these special displays have been received with such favor that they will be continued to the close of the season.

But little important business was transacted on the north side yesterday. Most of those in whose hands it belongs were away from town, and the district took on, as its principal citizens had, a holiday expression. The occasion was the tenth and last annual excursion and clambake of the Schnorer Club, and nearly 600 citizens of the north side and Harlem participated.

London, Aug. 12. -- The English newspaper press is much disturbed over the announcement that the Russian Government has decided to prohibit the export of rye. The general feeling is that, although Great Britain will not be affected to such an extent as Germany and Austria, she will inevitably suffer to a great degree from the prohibition.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The ukase forbidding the export from Russia of rye and rye meal of every kind and brand, which was published in the official journal at St. Petersburg yesterday, has created an enormous sensation in this city. The ukase came as a complete surprise to the dealers in grain here.

By the survivors of his own generation Mr. LOWELL will be mourned and remembered as a representative American. What his relative standing in literature may be fifty years hence it is not for his contemporaries to divine. To them his literary work seems curiously uneven, some of it very slight, some carelessly, almost indolently, executed, and a considerable portion confused and overloaded by the teeming fancy and the great wealth of association of the author.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The fleet of the New-York Yacht Club, diminished in numbers but still full of racing spirit, arrived here this afternoon. The run from New-Bedford was a brisk one, the breeze being good from start to finish. It brought the yachtsmen back to their favorite anchorage early in the day, and gave them an opportunity to rest before to-morrow's race.

Some details have been given in our Albany dispatches of the way in which State officers are taking advantage of lax administration of their office by the Civil Service Commissioners. The easiest and most common form of evading the law is for the appointing officer to make a "temporary" appointment. Either this temporary appointment is indefinitely continued or the appointee is "transferred" to some other position.

A refreshingly cool breeze early in the afternoon, followed by a windstorm and just a dash of rain, made things very comfortable for the people who went to Jerome Park to enjoy the racing yesterday. The racing was nothing out of the ordinary, except that the favorites were slaughtered one after the other in a fashion that made the talent wince, particularly after their hard day at Morris Park Tuesday.

Coroner Louis W. Schultze held the inquest yesterday in the case of Charles E. Goodwin, who, on Sunday evening, Aug. 2, was shot in the Percival apartment house in West Forty-second Street. The time appointed had been 10:30 o'clock. The jury, the witnesses, and the lawyers were all present at that time, but the Coroner was not. He was just three-quarters of an hour late.

A memorable event took place yesterday afternoon at the rectory of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church at Bedford Village, Westchester County, the occasion being the twenty-fifth anniversary of the rectorship of the Rev. Lea Luquer over that parish. A large number of the parishioners, who arc mostly farmers, assembled on the spacious lawns or broad verandas of the rectory to congratulate the rector.

The publication in yesterday's TIMES of the correspondence that passed between ex-Gov. Chamberlain and Cashier Theodore M. Banta of the New-York Life Insurance Company regarding the charges preferred by the latter four years ago against the management of the company has served to arouse the policy holders to a new realization of the perils that beset their interests so long as those interests are in the hands of President William H. Beors.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 12. -- The Georgia Legislature went into joint session to-day to receive the Mayors and General Councils of the cities of Savannah and Atlanta, who had come to ask the Legislature to back up Savannah's claim for a three-million-dollar appropriation from Congress to improve the channel of the Savannah River.

Senator M.S. Quay, who came to New-York yesterday to meet his son and daughter on their arrival from Europe, stood in the Fifth Avenue Hotel which several newspaper men asked him questions. He was in a smiling mood, but maintained his well-earned reputation for keeping silent on such points as had anything to do with politics.

The doctors at the Presbyterian Hospital concluded yesterday that seventeen-year-old Hugo Eitel was suffering not from hydrophobia, but from fear. Last night they took the straps away that had bound him down, and left his movements free.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 13. -- To-day has been beautifully clear, and while cooler than yesterday, still warm enough to make the water a very grateful resort. The President sought to drown his official cares in the salt sea as well as to take a little of that rest that he is supposed to be courting here, and went bathing a little before 1 o'clock.
PARIS, July 29. -- The Salpetriere, the prison hospital of Paris, is to-day the most interesting spot in Europe to those whose duty it is to lessen the physical suffering of the human race.

Capt. Roberts of Guilford, Conn., through Lawyer George R. Cooley, has asked for and obtained from Judge Torrance an order of notice on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad to show cause next Tuesday why they should not be enjoined from building a bridge over West River in that town. The railway company had a posse of Italians at work on the bridge Wednesday hastening the work and they struck.

An odd suit has just been brought against the Mount Morris Electric Lighting Company, and an injunction will be asked for to compel the company to discontinue the use of a couple of arc lights placed under the windows of a flat in Harlem.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 13. -- Capt. E.L. Zalinski of the Fifth Regiment of United States Artillery was found to-day with his battery at the Presidio barracks. Capt. Zalinski's name is a familiar one to the readers of THE TIMES in connection with the development of the pneumatic dynamite gun, though it should be known that the Captain practically severed all connections with the Dynamite Gun Company over a year ago.

The announcement of the death of the senior owner of THE NEW-YORK TIMES is much more unwelcome than unexpected. He was nearly eighty years old, and the bulletins from his sickroom foreshadowed the result.

The death of George Jones removes the last landmark of the notable journalists of New-York who achieved national or world-wide fame a generation ago. Bryant of the Evening Post, Bennett of the Herald, Greeley of the Tribune, Raymond of THE TIMES -- these were names identified with metropolitan journalism forty years ago, and several of them date back a full half century.

BOSTON, Aug. 13. -- An Augusta (Me.) special says: "The sensation in investment circles is that an investment concern in which many people in this section are interested has gone out of business. Its headquarters were in New-York, and through an agent various sums were picked up here. One man put in $10,000, and another mortgaged his property and invested his all. Clerks and professional men were caught.

MELROSE, Minn., Aug. 13. -- One of the most terrific hailstorms ever witnessed here passed over this place yesterday. Thousands of acres of the finest wheat in this county was knocked down in a few moments, many of the farmers losing all their crops, even corn and potatoes. Large fields of wheat looked as if they had been gone over with a land roller and then dragged.

Firenzi, queen of the thoroughbreds, added to her laurels yesterday by once more winning the Champion Stakes of the Monmouth Park Association. She won it once before, in 1888, when the "brown whirlwind" Kingston ran second to her, but was beaten in her first attempt to capture it, the year previous, by the great Hanover, both being three-year-olds at the time.

A GREAT LOSS TO JOURNALISM -- New-York journalism suffers in the death yesterday of Mr. George Jones an incalculable loss. As editor and proprietor of THE TIMES Mr. Jones exercised great influence upon the course of public affairs, and this influence was directed by honest convictions as to the men and measures upon which THE TIMES was called upon to comment.

In the death at Poland Springs, Me., this morning of George Jones after an illness remarkable for its display of reserve vitality, the profession of journalism sustains an irreparable loss. That loss is all the more poignant that Mr. Jones, in the sturdy manliness of his honest nature, never permitted his abilities to be fulsomely exploited or his forceful personality to receive adulation.

The New-Yorks had an opportunity of taking second place yesterday, but they failed to do it. They were beaten by the tail enders, while Boston lost an eleven-inning game to Cleveland. The Chicagos have apparently struck another winning gait, as they took a game from Brooklyn without much trouble.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The President, upon recommendation of the Civil Service Commission, has made important changes in the rules governing the classified service. Under these amendments all promotions hereafter made in the classified service will be upon strictly competitive examination, conducted under the direct authority of the Civil Service Commission.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13. -- Two stage-struck girls, Misses Julia and Alice Baily, have caused a great social sensation by eloping with and marrying two men in the theatrical line. The girls are sisters, and their father is John J. Baily, chief bookkeeper for the Moffett West Drug Company. The family is very well known, the father having been for years Actuary of the Mercantile and Public School Libraries.

The death of George Jones, for the past twenty years the editor and principal owner of THE TIMES, means that the metropolis has lost one of her most worthy citizens. This is much in these hours of moral bankruptcy and doubt. The city is great in the greatness or her citizens, and the passing away of the worthiest is a common misfortune.

One of the most remarkable features of Gov. Chamberlain's letters of advice to his client, Cashier Banta, regarding the letter's exposure of the New-York Life's mismanagement is the fact that those letters, although written four years ago, apply as directly to the matters at issue to-day as they applied to those at issue then.

The most distinguished leader of American literature and the most typical impersonation of modern methods in American journalism have to-day passed to that bourne whence no traveler returns -- James Russell Lowell, the poet, critic, and diplomatist, and George Jones, the proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, having died this morning.

The deplorable accident to an excursion barge on the Long Island coast by which a number of lives were lost and a still larger number of persons were injured on Wednesday afternoon brings very emphatically to public attention the fact that there is no official inspection of this kind of craft and no effective regulation of their equipment and use.

The death of George Jones, the proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, at Poland Springs, Me., is announced. He would have been eighty years old next Sunday. He was of slight figure and frail health, but of dauntless will and unfailing perseverance. It is difficult to discriminate between his character and that of the journal he has long controlled, and of which he was one of the founders.

Sometimes we suspect that our high-tariff friends, who contend that the owners of the San Jacinto tin mines in California cannot do business profitably without the aid of the prospective duty of 4 cents a pound on bar tin, have been misled as to the composition, or nationality, so to speak, of the company known as the San Jacinto Estate, Limited.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 13. -- The failure of W.E. Schmertz was followed to-day by surprising developments. The first was the appointment of D.E. Wheeler as receiver for the Standard Plate Glass Company, whose works are at Butler. This concern is one of the largest in the country. Its capital stock is $750,000, and the stockholders are the leading businessmen of Pittsburg.

Mr. George Jones was one of those editors who was entirely satisfied to have his personality absorbed by his newspaper. More than that, he was anxious that it should be so. When THE TIMES was praised, that gave him great delight; whereas, on the other hand, it was always an annoyance to him to have an utterance of THE TIMES quoted as George Jones's opinion.

Lamothe Cadillac, one of the early Governors of Louisiana, sententiously declared: "No boat could ever be run up the Mississippi into the Wabash, the Missouri, or the Red River for any commercial or profitable purpose. As well," said he, "try to bite off a slice of the moon." According to his judgment the rapid currents of these streams and their extreme crookedness formed insurmountable obstacles to their utility.

The ordering of the war ships Charleston, Mohican, Marion, and Alert from Pacific waters to China, will leave in the Pacific squadron the Iroquoia, Pinta, Pensacola, San Francisco, Thetis, and Baltimore. The Omaha, now at Mare Isl- and Navy Yard, could be got in readiness, it is declared, in a fortnight, though just where her crew would come from no one in naval circles seems to know.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- At the national headquarters of the Farmers' Alliance to-day considerable discussion and comment was caused by the published accounts of the flurry in wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade, and the statement that it was due to the Farmers' Alliance circular. Editor Dunning of the National Economist took occasion again to reiterate the denial that the Alliance was in any way responsible for the circular.

BAR HARBOR, Mo., Aug. 13. -- Gayety on board the war ships still continues. There is another dinner to-night on board the Despatch. Nearly all the party who were on board last night, including Mrs. Sheridan, the Carneys, and Marquis Imperial, are there to-night again. To-morrow Admiral Gherardi holds a large reception on board the Philadelphia, which will include the Canoe Club people, who hold their reception to-morrow also.

At the regular weekly meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday, bids for dredging in the North and East Rivers were opened. The Morris and Cummings Dredging Company received the contract to do the work on their bid of 20 cents per cubic yard.

The Eagle several days ago announced the serious illness of George Jones, the owner and, with Henry J. Raymond, the founder of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. To-day comes the news of his death at Poland, Me., where he was stricken down with a complication of disorders, incident to old age, shortly after his arrival at that place a few weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Little work will be done on the World's Fair buildings for some time. The blunders in computing the strains on the buildings have been found to be much more serious than was first supposed. All of the expert engineers in Chief Burnham's office are now reviewing the engineer's estimates of strains on the building.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 15. -- In no State has the process of irrigation been attended with better results than in Washington. The Cascade range divides the State into two parts, with radically different temperatures. West of the mountains there is a heavy forest. The air is cool in Summer and the Winter is a rainy season, with scarcely any frosts.

Dr. G.F. Becker of the United States Geological Survey and geologist in charge of the Division of California, is en route to Washington, after having inspected the work of the three surveying parties under his direction, to attend a meeting of the International Geological Association. "We have been working for several years," said Dr. Becker, "on the gold-bearing districts of California, between parallels 37 1/2 and 40.

George Jones * * * was a man of considerable tact, of unflinching courage, and dogged tenacity of purpose. He was a good judge of men and keenly appreciative of faithful service. No New-York newspaper has had in all its departments so large a proportion of old employes as THE TIMES.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- The death at New-Windsor on Sunday last of George Ryerson, aged eighty-three years, closes a notably strange and eventful career. Martin and George Ryerson, brothers, were born more than eighty years ago in the then small hamlet of Paterson, N.J. When grown to manhood, Martin, the elder, went West and became one of the leading business men and millionaires of Chicago.

George Jones, in the course of his long and creditable career, did two pre-eminent acts of service to his time. One was his part in exposing the Tweed Ring and arousing the public to the enormity of its stealings. That alone will cause this city to honor his memory with a lasting sense of gratitude. Its recognition will be a part of the duty of American historians.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 13. -- The State took a hand in moving the convicts from the branch prison at Briceville to-day, when the State Board of Prison Inspectors issued an order for the immediate removal of all the convicts, the lessees being given the option of returning them to the main prison here or taking them to some other branch.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 13. -- A Unalaska correspondent writes that in a cruise in the vicinity of the seal islands, one British war ship had seen and warned one sealer, the Pheasant five, the Mohican five, and the Alert two, besides those warned by the Thetis. Many of these had to be fired on to make them halt, and only one schooner succeeded in getting away.

J. Sloat Fassett, the new Collector, had a pretty busy day yesterday. He was at the Custom House from 10:30 o'clock, and between receiving callers, swearing in some of the officials who hold confidential relations with the Collector, and saying good-bye to Col. Erhardt he had his hands full. There are many people in this town who are paying the new Collector a great deal of attention these days.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- The Grand Duke Alexis has left this city for Vichy. The enthusiasm evoked by the visit of the brother of the Czar has lost none of its force by the personal contact of the Parisians with the tall, fine-looking Russian Admiral, and upon every occasion when he has shown himself to the public he has received greetings that have amounted to ovations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The State Department is still without any detailed information about the seizure of the Pacific mail steamer City of Panama at La Libertad, and Assistant Secretary Wharton said this afternoon hat the department would take no further action until Minister Pacheco had reported the result of his investigations and of the protests he has already been directed to make.

SIMLA, Aug. 13. -- Another illustration of the swift punishment which England inflicts upon those who violate her rights or infringe upon her dignity in India was given to-day at Manipur, when two of the leaders of the massacre of British officials in March last met their death at the gates of that capital.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- "Linden Gate," the Newport Summer estate of Henry G. Marquand of New-York, was the scene of a pretty event at noon to-day. It was the marriage of his daughter, and the first society event of the season. The bride is Miss Mabel Marquand and the groom Henry Galbraith Ward, a well-known New-York lawyer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- When Timothy Hopkins arrived in this city on Tuesday night it was his purpose to proceed at once to Methuen, Mass., to contest the probate of his foster-mother's will. But his attorney got his ear and he looked over his mail. Disappointment awaited him there. Only coldness characterized the letters, both of Searles and of Butler, Stillman Hubbard, but Hopkins did not start East.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 13. -- The World's Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations opened its second day's proceedings this morning. "Spiritual life in our association and the dangers that threaten it" was the first topic under discussion. The subject was introduced by the reading of a paper in English by the Secretary of a London association.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 13. -- The principal testimony in the examination of the charges of brutality toward Federal prisoners kept in the State penitentiary at this place, which was held in the Federal court to-day, was given by a colored attorney named Davis from Pine Bluff. Davis was convicted for forging pension papers and serves a short sentence.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 13. -- News of the revenue and naval fleet which is chasing the seal poachers to the far north has reached this city in letters from officers of the Thetis. The vessels are so far to the north that the regular Alaska mails do not reach them, and so letters come irregularly and by chance.

George Jones, the proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who died at Poland Springs, Me., yesterday, is associated in the popular mind with Horace Greeley, Henry J. Raymond, the elder Bennett, and Thurlow Weed, because he was of their time and engaged in the same business, but he was not an editor in the sense these men were.

About 1,000 cloak makers, cutters, finishers, and pressers, who worked for the firms of Julius Stein Co. of 507 Broadway, and Freedman Brothers of 332 Canal Street, went out on strike yesterday in obedience to the orders of the Consolidated Board of Cloak Cutters and Operatives. Several cloak cutters in the employ of Benjamin Caspary, in Broome Street, also struck.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 13. -- R. Dudley Frayser, President of the Security and the Memphis City Banks, Secretary of the Memphis City Railway, principal owner of the Public Ledger, and one of the most prominent and wealthy citizens of Memphis, was this afternoon chloroformed and robbed at the Gayoso Hotel by a man giving his name as John A. Morris and his residence as New-Orleans.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 13. -- Ex-Congressman Scott's condition is slightly improved. Dr. Brand, his physician, says: "I am confident Mr. Scott will recover, though his recovery will be necessarily slow. He has passed the turning-point and the chances are greatly in his favor."

Information was allowed to dribble through semi-official quarters yesterday that the conferences that have been going on for the past two days in the interest of the Union Pacific Road have borne fruit. The assertion was made by a Union Pacific Director last night that a powerful financial combination had been formed to take care of the Union Pacific until that road could work its way out of its present troubles.

George Jones was less known outside of the profession than any of the editors of the leading newspapers of New-York, but every newspaper man in the country knows what he has done for THE TIMES and for journalism. Horace Greeley, Henry J. Raymond, the two James Gordon Bennetts, Charles A. Dans, Whitelaw Reid, Col. Shepard, and Joseph Pulitzer are names familiar throughout the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- The special race for forty-six-footers, with which this year's cruise of the New-York Yacht Club terminated, was sailed here to-day. The prizes offered were three -- $500 in money or a cup to the first, $150 to the second, and $50 to the third. The entries were the Gloriana, Mineola, Sayonara, Uvira, and Jessica.

The comment of the English journals on the death of Mr. LOWELL shows how deep a hold he had taken on the affections of Englishmen. That Englishmen of letters should hasten to pay a tribute of respect to the writer whose service to literature was so great and varied is natural, but the words of TENNYSON reveal...

After the celebration of the beautiful service for the dead of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in All Souls' Church, at Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, this forenoon, the body of Mr. George Jones will be borne to its final resting place in Woodlawn Cemetery.
George Jones was the real founder of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. * * *

The name of George Jones, proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who died yesterday, in the eightieth year of his age, is associated with the names of two of the greatest of American newspaper editors -- Horace Greeley and Henry J. Raymond -- and very worthily associated, for in his own sphere Mr. Jones was no less successful and useful than his early friends, though he was not a writer.

George Jones of New-York, who died at Poland Springs yesterday, was identified with metropolitan journalism for forty years. His connection with THE TIMES began when it was founded by Henry J. Raymond, in 1851. Mr. Jones was a man of sturdy character and sterling worth. What he believed he believed through and through, and advocated with the greatest earnestness and sincerity, whether it conflicted with his interest to do so or not.

A gentleman who has been visiting the White Mountains says there is a good deal of talk touching important litigation concerning part of the "Switzerland of America," including Mount Washington, Mount Clinton, Mount Pleasant, and Mount Webster. Gen. Benjamin F. Butler and his New-York partner, Benjamin Patterson, have just commenced a suit for the recovery from the present possessors of a large tract of White Mountain property, that property being designated as "Bean's Purchase."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 14. -- The 6 o'clock express on the Reading Railroad collided with the up freight at Egg Harbor City this evening, resulting in the injury of several passengers on the express, two probably fatally. The two trains met on the cross-over switch, and, until an investigation is made, who was at fault cannot be ascertained.

According to the census bulletin on the social statistics of cities, it costs only 8 cents per capita of the population to clean the streets of Chicago, while it costs 71 cents to clean those of New-York. If this is taken to represent the relative cleanliness of the two cities, what a fearful condition must the streets of Chicago be in!

I trust you will permit me to add my humble note to the full chorus of praise and lament which the death of Mr. George Jones is calling forth. I am sure he gave me a measure of his confidence and esteem when living, and I would bear tribute to his worth when dead.

The examination of Abraham Becker on the complaint of Justice Hardin of Savannah, charging him with appropriating $12,000 worth of securities, was held in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, and it ended in Justice O'Reilly's holding him in $15,000 bail for the Grand Jury. The complainant and defendant were represented respectively by Lawyers Untermeyer and Dyett.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The State Department to-day received a telegram relative to the Pacific Mail steamer City of Panama from Minister Pacheco at Guatemala City, Guatemala, in which he says:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 14. -- A special from Ellsworth, Minn., says that the most terrific windstorm that ever passed over this section of Minnesota struck Ellsworth at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and left the town a pretty complete wreck. A dark cloud with a greenish tint along its edges came swirling in from the northwest and crushed pretty much everything in its path.

Mr. THOMAS DOLAN'S remarks about the price of wool have not been well received in Ohio. Mr. DOLAN is the President of one of the two large and powerful high-tariff associations in this country, and what he wrote a few days ago was this:

DETROIT, Aug. 14. -- The twenty-third annual regatta of the Northwestern Amateur Rowing Association was opened to-day at Des-Chree-Sho-Ska Island over the same course the Mississippi Valley Amateur Rowing Association used Wednesday and Thursday. Heavy rain during the morning limited the attendance somewhat, but when the first race was called the course was in good condition, although the heavens were overcast. One of the features of the day was Edward Hanlan's exhibition.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 14. -- The question of granting certificates to nuns, or Sisters of Charity, authorizing them to teach in Texas public schools, having been referred by the State Superintendent to the Attorney General for an opinion, he replied to-day, holding that nothing in the Constitution or laws of the State disqualified such persons from receiving certificates if otherwise qualified.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 14. -- The fourth meeting of the Grand Trotting Circuit ended here to-day, the final beats being decided over a slippery track, as rain came late in the afternoon.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Both the Republicans and Democrats of this city have already formed clubs and are holding weekly meetings. In addition to the interest which centres in the Gubernatorial contest there are several important local offices to be filled for which there are many aspirants in both parties. It is believed an earnest effort for harmony will be made by the Republicans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- Miller Purvis of Morrow County, this State, an active laborer and lecturer for the Farmers' Alliance, and a life-long Republican, is in this city to-night, and in an interview laid particular stress on the fact that the Farmers' Alliance and People's Party were separate and distinct organizations.

BRIDGEPORT, Aug. 14. -- The property of Sir Titus Salt, Bart., Sons Co., (Limited,) of this city, was attached yesterday by United States Marshal Strong of this city. The amount of the attachment is for $6,000. The suit is brought at the instance of Abram Ambler and five other men, who claim they were brought to this country in violation of the contract labor law.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 14. -- Early this morning Hugo Heinrich, a young German, shot himself in front of the residence of a young lady who had refused to marry him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Chilean Congressional Envoys in Washington have received advices from Chile which confirm the statements that President Balmaceda had removed all the Judges in the country and had appointed other persons to their places. The Judges removed include the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and his six Associate Justices, the Judges of the Courts of Appeal, and all the District Judges.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The nomination of Congressman Leslie W. Russell for Judge by the Fourth District Judicial Convention yesterday, has added new complications to the Republican fight in the Twenty-second Congressional District. Already there are several candidates in the field for the Congressional nomination, it being expected that Mr. Russell will resign, and that his successor will be chosen at the coming election.

The New-Haven Club disbanded last night, as far as New-Haven is concerned, and may disband for good, as the negotiations for the transfer to Providence are not promising. Providence will support a good ball club if it holds its own in the pennant race, and if Providence people would take the New-Haven Club, name it Providence, and let it have New-Haven's standing, it might live the season out.
Mr. J.W. Reinhart, Vice President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, was in this city yesterday on his way to his home in Boston. Speaking of his road, he said:
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- The condition of Uncle Sam's Treasury occupied the attention of Secretary Foster and Senator Sherman at a conference here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 14. -- Sensation follows sensation in the cases of official corruption. To-day the Senate Committee on the Bale des Chaleur Railway unearthed facts that go far to inculpate even Premier Mercier of the Province of Quebec, and which, it is believed, cannot but lead to the Lieutenant Governor calling on him for an explanation, failing which dismissal from office must follow.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 14. -- The crop reports from Middle and Southwest Alabama this week are very much mixed, and some difficulty is found in drawing any satisfactory conclusion from them. In a general way it may be said that the rainy season is over and the sun has come out very hot. The plants, being very humid, have been scalded by the heat, and the leaves are withering.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14. -- Major Mann Page of Prince George, the President of the Farmers' Alliance of this State, is here to-night on his way to Charlottesville, where he will speak tomorrow.

Lieut. J. Truckwell of the Royal Engineer Volunteer Corps of the British Army arrived in this city yesterday direct from Chile, and sails to-morrow for England, where he will at once place himself in communication with the British Government concerning the condition of affairs at the seat of war. Lieut. Truckwell was seen last night by a TIMES reporter, and was induced to speak unofficially on the latest developments of the war.

John Ewing's clever pitching coupled with timely hitting on the part of Whistler, Conner, and Glasscock, won a game for New-York yesterday from Cincinnati. As Chicago was whipped in Brooklyn, both Boston and New-York gained on the leader. Both are now within hailing distance of Anson and he is liable to lose first place before he starts westward.

The reports about the health of the Emperor of Germany are mainly significant as showing the extreme tension of European politics. The Emperor has wrenched his ankle severely, and is to that extent disabled for the time, and this disability is extended by frightened correspondents to a long list of fatal diseases of body and even of mind.

Creditors of Munger, Thomas and Co., investment brokers at 173 Broadway, who managed the American Trust Company of Fort Worth, Texas, are looking in vain to find the men. Those who have called at the New-York office have been unable to gain any definite information, as the doors are still closed by order of the Sheriff.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14. -- A woman claiming to be the widow of Peter Kitwood, who had charge of the Bethel Mission, and who was believed to be an unmarried man, has put in a claim to Mr. Kitwood's estate. Capt. Kitwood, as he was known, left considerable property, which he divided by will among various persons, but never mentioned wife or children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a bulletin on the social statistics of cities, which was prepared under the direction of Dr. John S. Billings, Expert Special Agent of the Census Office. Data are given with regard to streets, street lighting, water works, sewers, police, and fire departments of fifty of the larger cities in the United States which have furnished the information asked for.

The Boston Journal calls for information. It asks somebody "to be so kind as to explain to us how it happens, if the American tin-plate manufacture is a myth, that we are importing these increased quantities of pig tin from the Malay Peninsula, instead of first having it manufactured into tin plate for us by the British." "An early answer is solicited" adds our contemporary in Boston.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 14. -- A stop has been put to the actions of Joseph Battin, the rich and eccentric octogenarian of this city, who wanted to give all his worldly possessions to the New-York faith curists. Mr. Battin was so infatuated witch their views that he abandoned his home in this city, cut loose from his relatives, and went to live with the Rev. Mr. Simpson in New-York City.

Comedian Nat Goodwin again is head over ears in domestic trouble. This time, according to the story told by his wife and her attorneys the role he has filled is anything but a creditable one. There are always two sides to a story, though. Goodwin refuses to give much of his side, though he does not deny the story of his wife.

The Brooklyns played a strong game both at the bat and in the field yesterday, and won easily from the Chicago Club. It was an uninteresting game. Both Luby and Nicol pitched poor ball and the Chicago fielders made numerous errors. Nicol is a young left-handed pitcher secured by Anson in the West. He bids fair to show good form before long.

The private affairs of Martin Gunning, an old tinsmith who died last April having accumulated a snug little fortune, will probably get a thorough raking over in the courts. After the death of Gunning, two women appeared on the scene, each of whom declared that she was his lawful widow and therefore entitled to her share in the estate. One was Catherine Gunning and the other declared that she was Sarah Gunning.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 14. -- Only $1,100 was expended by the People's State Central Committee last Fall in a campaign which elected five Congressmen, eighty-four legislators, a United States Senator, and a majority of the county tickets. This Fall the committee has decided to expend $10,000.

Things were topsy-turvy on the Produce Exchange yesterday. It was a day for the bulls and they made the most of it, but that was not where the reversal of the usual conditions came in. The chief novelty lay in the fact that rye, generally considered an inferior grain, not only climbed up to an equality with the more aristocratic staple, but gave signs of a willingness to pass it.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- In the case of the people against Orville M. Anderson, Judge Barnard to-day filed the following decision:

A dozen years ago the extreme kindness and generosity of the late Mr. George Jones to a gentleman on the staff of THE NEW-YORK TIMES called forth a "round robin" of thanks. To this Mr. Jones made a characteristic response in the following letter:

The death of Mr. George Jones, who for more than twenty years had controlled and directed the business management and editorial policy of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, removes one of the two remaining newspaper men of those who made the great journals of the metropolis. Horace Greeley, the elder Bennett, Henry J. Raymond, and George Jones were four of the great journalists who have had an incalculable influence upon the American newspaper. * * *

Amateur photographers who have returned recently from Summer trips are well loaded down with negatives as the results of their labors. They claim that the Summer has been an excellent one for photography. The weather has been favorable and the light excellent.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Anglers are unanimous in testifying to the excellent fishing that this season has thus far afforded. One of the most singular catches of the Summer is that of Mr. W.K. Greene of Amsterdam, N.Y., who hooked a nine-pound pickerel while trolling from the stern of a steamer. J.F. Maynard, another Summer visitor, succeeded in landing a fine pickerel that tipped the scales at seventeen and a half pounds.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The season here is at its height and the hotels are crowded. There is a hop nearly every night at some one of them, and cottagers are doing their share in the way of entertaining. Receptions were given this week by Mrs. Lawton, Mrs. Hanson, Mrs. Manning, and Mrs. Nathan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Quay and Clarkson have been so long associated together on the National Republican Committee, and have been so often mentioned in connection with the leading events of the campaigns in which both have been workers, that Clarkson has won some of the reputation that has been largely due to the Chairman whose place he has now taken.

The New-York Yacht Club will probably have many more annual cruises, but none of them will be more successful and more enjoyable than that one which has just closed. The weather has been at its best, the cups have been fairly won, and the races have served to bring together an unusually fine fleet of yachts. No yachtsman could ask more.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The intense heat of the early portion of the present week induced many persons to seek the cooling breezes of the Catskills. The Ulster and Delaware and Stony Clove Railroads found their rolling stock taxed to the utmost to accommodate the increased traffic, and the month of August will be a prosperous one for the hotels throughout the range.

Wide divergent as were the paths they trod, the activities in which they engaged, the talents which commanded their success, the deaths of James Russell Lowell and George Jones occurring on the same day emphasize some points of similarity between the men. They represented different types, each one of the best types of American manhood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $148,016,900, as follows: Currency sixes. $8,885,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $9,869,650; 4 per cents, $116,411,850; 2 per cents, $12,850,400.
The death of George Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES removes not only the oldest newspaper man in that city, but the man who had seen the largest continuous newspaper service. * * *

The press of the country, without distinction of party, has cordially done justice to the civic virtue and the personal courage shown by Mr. GEORGE JONES during the attack upon the Tammany Tweed Ring. It is, we believe, proper for THE TIMES briefly to revert to another occasion on which he displayed qualities no less honorable to himself and of equal value to the press, with consequences to the country of the most lasting importance.

The annual games of the Xavier Athletic Association were held at the club grounds, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Willis Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The events were hotly contested, though a long rainstorm put a damper on the enjoyment of the spectators, but poor shelter being afforded.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15. -- The work of the State Decennial Board of Equalization is completed, and the people of Ohio and the country have a chance to study the changes in realty values in Ohio in the last ten years. This board is the final court of adjudication in the matter of property valuation for the purposes of taxation in the State.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15. -- Nearly forty years ago a young blacksmith, not having been over-successful in the California gold mines, built a small smithy in the sparsely-settled town of of San Francisco. At the outset the young smith contented himself with making horseshoes, repairing mountain wagons, and doing such odd iron work as the citizens of San Francisco demanded.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 15. -- In that section of Texas known as "The Bloody Peninsula" another murder has occurred, and one of the most noted desperadoes of Northern Texas has another notch on his six-shooter.

The belief is freely expressed among leading authorities on small arms that the Lee magazine gun will be the one finally adopted by the United States Government. So far, the Small-Arm Board, in session at Governors Island, has given the best part of its attention to the Krag-Jorgensen, Manlicher, Schmidt, and a small-calibre Springfield.

In the death of George Jones, the venerable editor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, American journalism has lost one of its early landmarks. Jones was a boyhood associate of Horace Greeley in Vermont, and went to New-York many years ago, and was employed on the old Tribune. Afterward Henry J. Raymond and Mr. Jones together established THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The matches of the National Rifle Association, open to teams of military riflemen from the several organizations of the National Guard, seem likely to be more than ordinarily interesting this season. The prize meeting begins at Creedmoor Tuesday, Sept. 1, and will cover the five days up to and including the following Saturday.

It has been many a year since the Produce Exchange had a short session marked by the excitement displayed yesterday. From the opening of business to the close the market was on the jump. Prices seemed to be bound to go up, and there were few brokers, except the chronic bears, who cared to guess where the advance was going to end.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 15. -- The postponed regatta of the Corinthian Navy, Long Island Sound squadron, was sailed in Hempstead Bay to-day under the auspices of the Hempstead Harbor Club. It was the first regatta hold by the club, which is a new one, and was largely attended. The start was off the new clubhouse, and the course twelve and an eighth miles for the larger boats and eight miles for the smaller.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Among those most badly injured in last night's collision at Egg Harbor between an express train and a freight on the Reading Railroad, was Thomas Hartman, engineer of the express. Hartman had both legs broken in jumping from his engine. He was brought here and gave the following account of how the accident occurred:

The call for the Republican primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Rochester Sept. 9, will probably be issued by the County Committee's Executive Committee early this week. As the Republican machine in this city is in T.C. Platt's hands, the great majority of delegates who will be sent to Rochester will be ready to do as they are told and vote as he dictates.

The New-Yorks barely escaped a defeat yesterday. As it was, they didn't win, but made the game a draw. In order to accomplish the latter they had to score a run in the last inning, and for a time it looked as though Cincinnati would win another game. Anson's men won in Brooklyn, and as a consequence are still in the lead.

One of the handsomest and most interesting buildings in the city is the new Hotel Renaissance, in West Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue. It is an example of the French Renaissance style of architecture, and is light and airy in all its features and mechanical treatment. But it is a type of the Renaissance with pronounced American interpretations, as might have been expected, seeing that the owner and builder is Mr. David H. King, Jr.

The Tribune prints this morning the news of the death of two Americans who have won distinction in widely different fields. One of them is James Russell Lowell, poet, scholar, and diplomatist. The other is George Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who for more than twenty years has controlled the policy and dictated the course of one of the great and influential journals of New-York City.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Hopatcong is at present the liveliest inland place in New-Jersey. There are 5,000 persons at or near the lake. During the day the water is dotted with puffing launches, splashing paddle steamers, and small craft of every description. At night there are fires glistening in a hundred camps along the shore.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The new ball team which is to represent New-Brunswick in the New-Jersey League, with the Plainfield Crescents, the Somerville West Ends, the Westfields, the New-Jersey Athletic Club, and other nines, has announced its first game for next week, and the members are prepared for a hard fight against the city ordinance which prohibits ball playing and kindred sports within 500 yards of any private residence except with the owners' consent.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 15. -- This has been a week of very pleasant weather, and, although rather warm through the day, the evenings were delightfully cool and the nights cold enough to require a blanket to keep one comfortable.

At a little shop in Broadway, where a popular actress leaves five-hundred-dollar orders, there is displayed such a fascinating assortment of the Summer girls gloves that even the prosaic, matter-of-fact young woman who couldn't be a Summer girl if she tried is tempted by them. It is an injustice to sneer at the Summer girl as a pictorial creation existing chiefly for the benefit of newspaper paragraphers.

Two men who have won their way to prominence and an enduring place in American history by the use of the pen have passed away from life. They are James Russell Lowell and George Jones. A sketch of the life and work of each of these noted men is given on the second page of the Advertiser this morning. * * *

By some very clever detective work on the the part of Post Office Inspectors Jacobs and Hartshorn, George Jacobs, also known as E.C. Davis, Thomas G. Collins, Edward Bechtold, J.H. Burney, S.A. Johnson, and several other names, was lodged in Ludlow Street Jail yesterday on the charge of having worked the green-goods game.

By the deaths of James Russell Lowell and Editor George Jones, this country is deprived of the influence and example of two justly-distinguished men, whose characters, as especially indicated by sincerity and pertinacity of purpose, were cast in the same mold. * * * In the character of Editor Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES is to be found also the sincerity and tenacity that Lowell's career constantly displayed.

Jean Marie Guyan, who died in 1887, aged barely thirty-three, was possessed of remarkable powers. While almost a lad, a work of his on the utilitarian moralists showed the peculiar bent of his mind, which was toward solving the leading problems of sociology. In the volume under notice, which treats of education, he, like Plato, tried to draw "a distinct line of demarcation between the morality of impulse and the morality of thought."
" What are these figures in plaster of paris?" The Count came forward with a smile and said:

The death of George Jones has recalled public attention to the first great battle against corruptionists in American politics. The story of the Tweed Ring and its overthrow has become, in these days of rapid history-making, almost an ancient story, yet it marked an epoch in the record of American journalism and politics which will always have surpassing interest.

A significant feature of the real estate market for more than two months past is that nearly all the foreclosure sales have resulted in the property being bought in by the mortgagee, where the sale was not postponed for want of a purchaser or because the mortgagee did not feel like taking his chances in such a desperate market.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 15. -- The New-York customs authorities, in recent interviews, charge the Custom House here with negligence, particularly in the matter of the admission of Chinamen not entitled to enter the country. It is possible that the same strict scrutiny exercised at Northern ports is not in vogue, not because the local officials are less vigilant, but because of their insufficiency of number and resources.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 15. --The Picayune's Havana special says: "The merchants of Havana are studying the new treaty with much care and interest, holding meetings which are attended by the principal importers. While they admit that the treaty is most favorable to the sugar-making interest, it leaves the important article of Cuba's product, tobacco, under the same onerous duties existing in the United States for so many years, and still further augmented by the McKinley bill.

Bank Detective Francis R. Kelly saw Chauncey Johnson, an old-time bank thief with a national notoriety, sauntering around inside of Drexel's banking house, at Fifth and Chestnut Streets, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. As Johnson was slipping out of the door Detective Kelly accosted the old fellow with "How do you do, Chauncey? What's up!" "I guess you're mistaken this time," Johnson replied, coolly.

Sensational reports have been circulated of late about cruel practices in the State prison at Clinton. Such reports affecting prison discipline get abroad every now and then, and are almost sure to become greatly exaggerated and to create false impressions. In this case they are believed to have come from a discharged keeper, and in other cases they have been derived from discharged convicts.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 15. -- At the World's Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations to-day the topic, "The Association Secretaries -- Their Work, Their Position, the Best Means of Training Able, Consecrated Men to Fill this Important Position," was opened with papers in German by Herr Helbing, District Secretary at Elberfeld, Germany; in Swedish by Karl Fries, Secretary at Stockholm, and in English by Edwin F. See, Secretary of the Brooklyn (N.Y.) Association.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 15. -- The Water Gap's season is nearing its height and the big hotels overlooking the river are overflowing. The Kittatinny House gave a ball this evening as a climax to a delightfully lively week.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- This city is having a very decided building boom, and it has led to a system of better street paving. Four of the principal streets -- French Street, Hamilton Street, Livingston Avenue, and Union Street -- have been paved, while in the heart of the city new pavements have been laid in Peace and Church Streets.

BOSTON, Aug. 15. -- A new theatre is to be built on the site for many years occupied by the well-known Maynard stables, on the northerly side of Court Street, owned by the F.G. Fullam heirs. Work on the excavations will begin Monday morning. The building will be among the largest theatres in the city, 150 by 80 feet, besides utilizing a three-story brick building in the rear for dressing rooms and mechanical department.

George Jones, publisher and senior proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, is dead. He had reached the advanced age of eighty, and for a number of years past his health had been infirm. He was a devoted worker, and to the last would never yield up the management of his business. He had a favorite son, Gilbert, in whom he had unbounded confidence; nevertheless he loved to be about the business office daily.

The disappearance of the buffalo has been the fruitful occasion of much unreasonable sentiment. Men who never saw a buffalo except in a menagerie are especially given to lamentation. An Eastern paper recently gave up a column or more to one of the mourners, probably a woman, who srrowed with much satisfaction, because of the disappearance of large game from the face of the earth.

Mr. Beers still preserves his silence, apparently unable to utter a word in defense of the charges against him. His agents, who purchase the columns of newspapers, have temporarily ceased their labors in the face of Gov. Chamberlain's irrefutable opinion that the Banta charges were not examined with a view to eliciting the truth.

Even a very busy man can discharge the duties of a club President, but satisfactorily to fill the position of Secretary of any large club a man most have plenty of spare time and a willingness to devote it gratis to his club. The Presidency of a club is generally a sort of honorary office; the Secretaryship is nothing if not a working office.

If there is a death trap at Jewell's Wharf, foot of Fulton Street, Brooklyn, the public should know it. Especially should all who contemplate making a Summer-day excursion starting from that wharf be fore warned of their danger.
LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Arrangements are maturing for the annual exodus of the dramatic and musical world of this city to America.

During the past week the English-speaking world has suffered a severe loss in the persons of the Hon. James Russell Lowell and Mr. George Jones -- two men whose literary work entitles them to the grateful admiration of all who are interested in freedom, good government, and the harmonious advancement of civilization.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- This has been the banner week of Richfield's season. The hotels and cottages are full and the purses of the landlords are filling. It has also been the banner week in the way of amusements. On Saturday afternoon and evening the ladies of the Episcopal Church held their postponed fair, clearing about $1,000.

Foresters' Day had its third annual celebration yesterday at the hands of the Association of the Ancient Order of Foresters of America. The celebration took the shape of a street parade, in which the Courts of Forestry of the City of New-York and visiting courts from various parts of the United States, including all branches of the order, participated.

CAMP WATSON, NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 15. -- The Connecticut Brigade arrived in the thoroughly rain-soaked camp this afternoon. The weather was about as cheerless as possible all through, the forenoon, a dreary easterly storm prevailing, but occasional intermissions in the rain enabled the troops to get to the tents in comparatively good condition.

BOSTON. Aug. 15. -- The Democratic State Committeee sent out to-day its call for the State Convention of the party, to be held in Mechanics' Hall, Worcester, Sept. 29, at 11 A.M., for the purpose of nominating candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and other State officers, and four delegates at large and four alternates to the next National Democratic Convention.

READING, Penn., Aug. 15. -- The Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers has suffered an unusual number of crushing defeats this season in the iron centres of Eastern Pennsylvania through its attempt to introduce a new scale of wages for the coming year. Eight hundred of its members at Steelton have been sacrificed in a strike pronounced by President Weihe to be unauthorized.

Frank White, who calls himself an ex-light-weight champion pugilist, does not like the idea of policemen carrying night sticks. He has written a long letter about it to the Police Commissioners. He says that a night stick in the hands of an excited policeman is a very deadly weapon, and that many persons get battered faces and scars for life because of the sticks used when they ought not to be.

Ceramics is the name given to those productions of the potter's art that assist in forming the famous collections which now and then startle the world as objects of beauty and price. Though still examples of the same art, our plates and dishes are not dignified with that newly-coined word. These objects of like porcelain, when made to serve, are china.
" Mr. Faulkner, I have news for your," said the Iviza Vice Consul entering the room in which the other was seated at a table over some brandy and water and an ancient periodical.

The manager and proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES died at Poland Springs, Me., yesterday at 4 A.M. * * * This eminent man is known to the people of the country solely as a journalist. He was for a time associated with THE NEW-YORK TIMES when the late brilliant and popular Henry J. Raymond was its leading spirit and director.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- This has been a lively and busy week in society circles, and those who are deepest in the social vortex of pleasure have been severely taxed to find time for all the brilliant events. The leading affair, not only of the week, but of the season thus far, was the magnificent ball given by Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Vanderbilt at Rough Point.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The crowd of Summer visitors has taken complete possession of Asbury Park, much to the delight of the hotelkeepers and merchants, who are expected to make enough money in three months to keep them for the remaining nine months of the year. It is estimated that the population of the Park at the present time is over 75,000.

The three Guianas, which have all had protracted boundary disputes -- prosecuted, perhaps, with the more vigor since none of the three had a great deal of territory to spare -- seem now to be nearing the end of their troubles on this score. French Guiana and Dutch Guiana some time ago took the sensible course of referring the dispute over their joint frontier to the decision of the Czar.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The Rev. H.R. Keats is conducting revival meetings at Highland in a tent.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Canon Farrar had announced that services in memory of James Russell Lowell would be held in Westminster Abbey to-morrow, but the plan was abruptly changed and the services were held to-day. Many of the Americans in the city who were desirous of attending the services had no knowledge of the changed arrangements, and consequently they were not present.
