Few men who were known so little outside of the sphere of their business and social relations have exercised so much influence in shaping public opinion and in making political history as the late George Jones, who died yesterday, aged eighty years. Since the death of Mr. Baymond, in 1869, Mr. Jones had been the chief owner of the great newspaper, THE NEW-YORK TIMES, with which his name will always be connected.

The reports of Commander REITER of the Thetis and Capt. COULSON of the Rush to the Navy and Treasury Departments respectively show that they have had a busy time in warning the poachers away from Bering Sea. The Thetis has been especially industrious, and was credited even several weeks ago with having boarded twenty-eight vessels.

In reading in last Sunday's TIMES Richard B. Kimball's interesting account of Bulwer, I was reminded of an incident that happened in Parliament in July, 1855, which illustrates the great novelist's good humor and quickness of repartee. A kinsman, Mc-Hillingtleetcazley, member of Parliament for the North Riding of York from 1832 to 1862, had taken me into the House -- strangers' gallery -- and was showing me the celebrities.

A bull combination has done much more in the way of lifting the market the past week than seemed possible ten days ago. It is all professional, of course, but that goes for little, since all movements of the market are professional in their initiation. Public support may or may not come in later; but it never does come in at the start.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The expected struggle between the opposing factions of the Republican Party in Chemung came to a close at Horseheads this afternoon. The greatest interest centred in the result, and the historic convention village was crowded by Republicans long before noon, some of whom had not taken part in convention or caucus matters for many years.

The goldenrod is blossoming in the field and by the country wayside, and in town the merchants are advertising the first Fall dress goods -- two infallible signs that midsummer is past. To-day is high-water mark at the Summer resorts -- from now on the season rapidly wanes -- and people are beginning to think of the homecoming and making plans for Autumn and Winter activity.

" Perhaps it would be as well, Alonzo, not to dwell so constantly upon these personal matters. To be sure, there is an interest -- occasionally even a thrill -- connected with them which one does not feel in more intellectual subjects. Yet, notwithstanding this fact -- perhaps on account of it -- I'm convinced that the exercise of the reflective, rather than the emotional, faculties tends to develop mind."

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 15. -- The fifth annual State Convention of the Farmers' Alliance closed its session yesterday at Morehead City. Every one of the ninety-seven counties was represented. Eleven hundred delegates were present and a large number of Alliance men who were not delegates.

The statistics of the Census Bureau winch relate to the larger cities of this country are open to great suspicion on the score of accuracy in the individual cases, but in the comparisons between different cities they are most misleading, and from them scarcely any fair inference can be drawn.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The Bayonne Rowing and Athletic Association's fifteenth annual club regatta, held this afternoon on New-York Bay, was a gratifying success. A light westerly breeze prevailed, but did not disturb the water until a shower arrived, just before the last event.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A dingy little brown-red building standing on piles on the beach outside the board walk near the foot of Sixth Avenue arouses the curiosity of thousands of strangers here each season. Its occupant is none other than the war artist, Theodore R. Davis, whose cartoons and sketches during the days of the rebellion helped to give Harper's Weekly a great war record.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15. -- To-day came nearer to being a "black Friday" for the speculative wheat trader on this market than probably upon any other occasion in the history of the grain business of this city. The wheat market has been a wild and exciting one all the past week, but to-day undoubtedly eclipsed any and all previous days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- The session on the Board of Trade to-day was one of the wildest ever known on the floor. Greatly to the consternation of the bears, December wheat touched $1.08. They had been partly prepared for the boom Friday, but when the bulls took hold again and sent prices up once more they were dumfounded. Such jumps in the figures had not been seen since the days when Hutchinson was operating.

There was published a few days ago a long letter in defense of the Mckinley Bariff, written by Mr. JOHN L. WHEELER of Red Bank, N.J., who appears to have been invited to express his opinions for the reason that he was regarded as a protectionist of some prominence in his State. Speaking of wages, Mr. WHEELER said: "The potters of Trenton have accepted a reduction of 10 per cent."

The marriage of Core Belle Fellows of this city to Chaska, the Sioux Indian, created something of a sensation nearly four years ago. Miss Fellows, the daughter of a department clerk in this city, became a teacher of Indians and was assigned by the Indian Office to the Sioux Reservation. In that vocation she met her fate in the person of Chaska. They were married.
LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Throughout the length and breadth of England this week there is but one word on the lips and in the hearts of educated people; that word is Lowell.

Among the objects recently deposited in the Museum of Archaeology of the University of Pennsylvania are two minute Japanese carvings and a small black lacquered shrine, about two inches in height, containing three carved images of Japanese deities. These objects, which were obtained from Japan for the museum by Mr. C.H. Kajiwara, a Japanese gentleman at present residing in this city, are peculiar to one of the temples in his native province.

Postmaster VAN COTT has vigorously supported every suggestion that has been made during his term for increasing the efficiency of the mail service in this city. It is certain that, with our present methods of assorting and distributing the mails, the present Post Office is very far from being a central point.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The intense heat of the last week has been the most remarkable that has ever been known in Lenox, where cooling breezes are always in order. The mercury climbed easily to 92 in the shade and the rays of the sun were scorching, so much so that the cottagers found it practically impossible to drive about.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 15. -- This has been another busy week with the trotters throughout Kentucky. There was racing at Sharpsburg, Nicholasville, and Campbellsville. The Nicholasville meeting was by far the best of the season, the 2:19 class of Tuesday being the best race trotted anywhere in the United States this year.

The Uniformed Company of Exempt Firemen of the City of New-York will leave next Wednesday to attend the annual meeting of the State Exempt Firemen's Association at Herkimer. The company wilt meet at the Veteran Firemen's headquarters Wednesday evening at 8 o'clock. The line of march will be through Fourteenth Street, to Eighth Avenue, to Forty-second Street, and through Forty-second Street to the Weehawken Ferry.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Miss Emma Krug of 312 Fifteenth Avenue has commenced suit to recover $5,000 for breach of promise from Frederick Sachs. The young man is in the coal business with his father and is said to be well-to-do. Ever since he made Miss Krug's acquaintance a year ago he has courted her ardently, and they finally fixed upon Wednesday last as the wedding day.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- Henry F. Coxe, the young Philadelphia inventor, who attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat in the woods at Glen Summit, Penn., Thursday night, is now an inmate of Kirkbride's lunatic asylum, hopelessly insane. Mr. Coxe is only thirty-five years of age, and has been married about eight months.

Christian Wilson, alias Sylvester Wilson, alias W.S. Franklin, who has had a criminal record of over fifteen years as a swindler, abductor of young girls, and bully, is under arrest, as was stated in yesterday's TIMES, on a charge of abducting Elizabeth Sunderland, a sixteen-year-old girl of Binghamton. The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has undertaken to prosecute the charge against him.

There will be a great abundance of peaches in the market all this week. The quality will range from exceedingly low to as good as ever before grown. They may be had at wholesale at from 25 cents to $2 per basket. The peaches which were shipped here from Maryland last week were largely of good quality.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Secretary Foster made the following statement to-day in regard to the refunding operations and the financial situation generally:

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Despite positive assurances to the contrary, it was generally hoped that the Cabinet meeting announced for this afternoon would resolve on some reduction in the corn duties. It was hoped that the influence of Minister Miquel, who still strongly urges a reduction would have the effect of persuading his colleagues to consent to such a measure.

The trouble that is reported from the colony of Russian refugees in New-Jersey illustrates a difficulty and a danger in dealing with these refugees that seem to be general and that are likely to become chronic. The story of this difficulty is that many of the refugees were dissatisfied with the treatment they have received from the trustees of the Baron Hirsch Fund.

John H. Gray, who said that he lived at 226 East Forty-ninth Street, Saturday night attempted to pick the pocket of William A. Jones, a banker from Cleveland, who is stopping at the Victoria Hotel, of $50 as he was getting off a Blue car at Broadway and Seventeenth Street. Mr. Jones chased the thief across Union Square, where a park policeman arrested him.

When in July of last year Congress passed a law for the purchase of 4,500,000 ounces of silver bullion per month, it directed that these purchases should be paid for in Treasury notes of denominations not less than $1 nor more than $1,000. These notes were made a full legal tender for all debts public and private, except where otherwise expressly stipulated in the contract.

A hostess, whose influence with the Four Hundred should certainly carry weight, even outside that august body, has set the excellent fashion of refusing to allow any servant in her employ to accept tips from guests. She argues, with great good sense, that the custom is not only a burden and nuisance to visitors, but it is an indirect imputation upon her liberality as a mistress.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- A local paper says: "The object of the law creating the new United States Circuit Courts of Appeals, which was intended to relieve the Supreme Court's crowded dockets, may be defeated by a little clause in the law which United States District -- Attorney Milchrist discovered yesterday when looking over the latest Federal statutes.

SHANGHAI, China, July 21. -- The Yang-tse River still continues to rise, and has already caused a great amount of suffering to the peasants in its valley. The rice fields have been completely flooded, thousands of acres being submerged and the rushing water carrying the grain along with it. A famine is feared unless the water rapidly recedes, which does not seem at all probable just now.

The unenviable notoriety that President William H. Beers has brought upon the New-York Life Insurance Company by his mismanagement is producing its natural results in a steady falling off of business, and the greatest anxiety among policy holders. The last mail from South America brought newspapers containing full reprints of THE TIMES'S articles.

India is dark, wonderful, mysterious. China is reserved, dignified, forbidding, but Japan is a coquette -- bewitching, fascinating -- truly Le pays de revanants. He who has lived there and gone to other lands is haunted by the ghosts of the Japanese days and tortured for years by an irresistible desire to return to those enchanted shores whose charm is as subtle as it is indescribable.

If Bartholomew Callahan, a middle-aged tramp, who lay mortally wounded at the Chambers Street Hospital yesterday, tells the truth he was wantonly shot down in a cowardly manner in West Street at 3 o'clock yesterday morning by one of two men or whom he could give no description of value to aid the police of the Second Precinct in searching for his assailant and his companion.

Smoke has always been an element of importance in both land and naval warfare. It has often served as a screen behind which one of the combatants could manoeuvre for attack or retreat. Whenever it is an advantage to one side it is an obstacle to the other. Evidently, then, it has a tactical value. It should be utilized as far as possible.

The works in progress outside the tract of the city walls between Porta Salaria and Porta Pinciana continually bring to light some interesting object which recalls their attention to the study of ancient Rome. Quite recently a fine half-sized statue of Hygia (unfortunately headless) was disinterred.

The revelations made in the course of an action against an insurance company at the pre sent Manchester assizes have forced into the public notice as hideous a traffic in human life as ever disgraced a civilized country. Gambling in lives has in many Lancashire towns, but chiefly in Blackburn, long been a lucrative occupation.

The promoters of the Gubernatorial boom of Mayor Alfred C. Chapin of Brooklyn were delighted yesterday to discover that William F. Sheehan of Buffalo, Speaker of the State Assembly, had paid an incognito visit on Friday night to Hugh McLaughlin at Greenport, L.I.

There are described by various writers as having been at some time growing in America -- all of which have had names given to them -- some two thousand varieties of apples. As a matter of fact, no apple comes from seed exactly like its parent. Every seedling apple has, therefore, an individuality of its own, to a greater or less degree.

The project of using petroleum as fuel for war vessels, and particularly for harbor defense and torpedo craft, has again been under discussion, and the advantages and disadvantages of this substitute for coal are once more compared. It is admitted that the cost of oil is greater, that special stations would have to be maintained for fueling, and, above all, that the advantage in point of safety is very greatly on the side of coal.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16. -- The desert lake in Southern California will be permanent. There is no longer any doubt about it. The latest reports from Salton are that the water is slowly but surely rising at an average rate of three-fourths of an inch per day. This makes the amount of water now in the Salton basin 4,460,544,000 cubic feet.

After life's fitful fever Jules Gros, journalist, composer of comic songs, and sometime President of the shadowy Republic of Guiana, in South America, has died at Vanves, a southeastern suburb of Paris. Gros was an indefatigable globe trotter, and in the course of his peregrinations had taken notes which, when published in Paris, obtained for him due recognition from the Geographical Society.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 16. -- When the Legislature, last Fall, passed an act providing for the ceremonies attending upon the dedication of the Bennington Battle Monument and the centennial celebration of the admission to the Union of the State of Vermont, they probably realized in small measure the great proportions which the celebration would assume.

The famous West End of Coney Island, on a hot Sunday afternoon, is a most enjoyable place as compared with Schutzen Park, Union Hill, N.J., as it was yesterday and as it probably will be for three days to come. The Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein is holding a festival there. So apparently are the great majority of all the crooks, thieves, blacklegs, and confidence men who are at present fortunate enough to be out of jail.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 16. -- The International Labor Congress, or, as it is now called, the International Socialist Workmen's Congress, opened here to-day. Mrs. Aveling and numerous English trade union delegates are in attendance, despite the fact that but few English delegates were expected.

The recent appointment by the Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic of Frederick Phisterer to the position of Adjutant General is in violation of the constitution, bylaws, and rules and regulations, and extremely against the welfare of the order, and the reasons, among others, are as follows:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- As a Swede in the employ of Muskin Co., fishermen, was walking along the beach about 11 o'clock to-night, he discovered the body of an unknown suicide just north of the fishing grounds. At that place the boats are hauled high up upon the beach, and are made fast by a hawser from the bow of the boat to the bluff.

Capt. Cross of the Thirty-seventh Street Police Station had twenty-four young men, the youngest only seventeen years old, before Justice Hogan at the Jefferson Market Court yesterday on a charge of gambling. He, with Detectives Hay and Barrett, had raided the saloon of Harry Hegellman, at 246 West Thirty-second Street, and found all the prisoners there engaged in playing that festive species of poker known as "penny-ante."

Over and over again it has bean written that in Japan is to be settled the most remarkable of social problems. On an old order of civilization a newer is to be established, and the change is not forced on a people, but self-imposed. How the graft will work no one can tell. The difficulties are many, and not the least are the racial or purely anthropological ones.

TRENTON, Aug. 16. -- Seven or eight years ago a party of audacious speculators conceived the idea of seizing the reef of rock extending from Ellis Island south for several thousand feet to the lighthouse off Staten Island for commercial purposes. The rock was to serve as the foundation for a neck of artificial land that was to stretch along the Jersey front of New-York Bay.

According to the correspondent of the Brooklyn Eagle, describing a visit of Mr. SHEEHAN to "Boss" McLAUGHLIN, the latter gentleman is in the market and ready to put up the Kings County Democracy at a price to be named. Here is the summary of the "Boss's" position, as made by this friendly and presumably well-informed writer:

One of the best pieces of property that the city owns came to it by the economy that regulated the spending of money appropriated for police purposes by Messrs. James Bowen, John G. Bergen, and Thomas C. Acton. It is the marble structure in Mulberry and Mott Streets, over the main entrance to which, at 300 Mulberry Street, is the legend "Central Department of Metropolitan Police," and which has come to be called Police Headquarters.

We have already remarked upon the chance that the failure of the harvest in Russia might come to have a marked effect upon American politics in ameliorating the condition of the farmers who compose the Farmers' Alliance, and consequently in brightening their views. This effect will be very much increased by our own crop prospects.

" There are not so many odd characters around old book stores as there used to be," remarked William H. Stuart, the brother of the Mayor, in the letter's bookstore the other day. "They appear to have fallen off, but I don't know why nor where they have gone. However, nearly every book lover has his peculiarities, and we see much of them.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- During the past week business in the money market was simply in a state of stagnation. The discount rates were 1 1/2 for three months and 3/4 for short, with nothing doing. Germany has been an active buyer of gold, but not enough so to alter the position. The enormous total of bankers' balances weighs down the market and continues prolong a period of unhealthy ease.

A good story of a little episode at Sing Sing Prison has just leaked out through the usual channels, although Warden "Dead-Line" Brown has made it a rule to discharge any and all keepers or guards at that institution caught in the act of giving reporters information.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Gov. Robert E. Pattison of Pennsylvania was one of the distinguished visitors at the camp grounds to-day. He occupied a seat on the Auditorium platform at the several services and took an active part in the singing.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 16. -- Quay's manipulation of the Blaine boom in Pennsylvania for the purpose of regaining his own lost prestige is regarded in this State as an ingenious piece of political strategy. Ever since the nomination and defeat of Delamater Quay's power has been on the wane, and it needed an unusual tonic to restore it.

All is not exactly harmony at Baireuth, hitherto the metropolis and temple of higher Wagnerism. Down to the present year the members of the Wagner societies in various parts of the world have not only had a certain number of free invitations to the festival performances, but also, as they state, have enjoyed the first right to purchase tickets.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- There is war among the veterinarians. It has all come over the determination of "Dr." Hawk, Chief of the Federal Cattle Bureau in this State, to slaughter a lot of cows in this city. He had condemned the animals either as being infected with pleuro pneumonia or as having been subjected to the infection.

A number of undertakers in this city are in a state of indignation against a young Hebrew who, as an agent for the Jewish Times, has been going about among them soliciting advertisements and at the same time making false representations. His argument to the undertakers whom he visited was that the members of synagogues and of the Jewish societies were displeased with the way in which the Jewish undertakers were doing their business.

In a bright and readable letter upon American theatrical matters published in the London Stage, John Glendinning, who came here with the Kendals, says: "With regard to accent, we can each afford a good-natured smile at the other's peculiarities. An American, however, professional or otherwise, never drops an aitch. In very many cases they try to cultivate the 'English accent,' and often with laughable results.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The proposition to organize a naval militia force in the City of Chicago has raised a very nice point in international law. The arrangement of April 28, 1818, between the United States and Great Britain as to the naval force to be respectively maintained on the American lakes, after specifying the force to be maintained provides that no other vessels of war shall be there built or armed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Association of Agricultural Colleges and Experiment Stations ended its meeting last evening with a banquet at the Shoreham in honor of Prof. Warrington of Rothamsted, England. Assistant Secretary of Agriculture Willets presided.

The last genuine relics of the First Napoleo have now been transferred from the Louvre Museum to that of the Hotel des Invalides. They comprise an authentic "Redingote grise," which cost 160f. at Lejeune's, and the "Little Hat," which was blocked by Poupard Co., and was afterward worn by the Emperor in the campaign of 1814.

The death of George Jones, the proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, at Poland Springs, Me., is announced. He would have been eighty years old next Sunday. He was of slight figure and frail health, but of dauntless will and unfailing perseverance. It is difficult to discriminate between his character and that of the journal he has long controlled, and of which he was one of the founders.

-- Mr. Bartlett has in preparation the ninth and final edition of his "Dictionary of Familiar Quotations." The list of authors now reaches 850. The eighth edition appeared eight years ago and the first thirty-six years ago. In the new edition Mr. Bartlett will drop the first three words from the sub-title, "An Attempt at a Collection of Passages, Phrases, and Proverb." He rightly thinks the work is no longer "an attempt."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17. -- The Des Moines and Northwestern Railway, a narrow-gauge road running from this city to Fonda, and the Des Moines and Northern, running from this city to Boone, were consolidated to-day. Under the new deal the road will be known as the Des Moines Northern and Western Railway, and the company is capitalized at $6,500,000.

The latest mails from Japan bring the news that six large and powerful Chinese men-of-war recently visited Yokohama and made a marked impression on the Japanese. The Chinese squadron was composed mostly of war ships built under contract in England. The whole force was under the command of Admiral Ting, who had for his flagship the Ting Tuen.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- The assignment of the Fire Extinguisher Company of America, per John Lucas, President, to A.T. James, entered at the Prothonotary's office yesterday, marks the winding up of a scheme by which a number of prominent men of this city and elsewhere are financial losers in various amounts.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The St. Petersburg agent of Reuter's Telegram Company has been furnished with an "inspired denial" of the report that a secret treaty has been concluded between Russia and France. It is declared that neither Admiral Gervais or any other French or Russian representative has signed or concluded verbally any convention between France and Russia.

The gamblers' paradise at Schuetzen Park, Union Hill N.J., was again in full bloom yesterday, and 20,000 Plattdeutschers who flocked into the pleasant grove to attend the second day's games of their great Volksfest Verein were fleeced as they were never fleeced before.

This is Omnibus Day, and there will undoubtedly be a great crowd at Morris Park to see the race at a mile and a half in which eleven of the best three-year-olds now in training are named to start. Three stables, those of J.A. A.H. Morris, F.C. McLewee, and Byron McClelland, will each be represented by two candidates for the twenty-two-thousand-dollar prize.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The record of the court-martial in the case of First. Lieut. James A. Swift of the First Cavalry, late of the Signal Corps, has been sent to the President, at Cape May Point. Lieut. Swift was tried by general court-martial at the Washington Barracks on charges of indebtedness, and it is understood the court found him guilty and sentenced him to dismissal from the army.

There was inaugurated in this city yesterday an experiment which promises under tactful management to become an enduring success. It was the opening of the first "people's bath" by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- The Council's sub-committee to investigate the affairs of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley and the Keystone Bank met this afternoon. Some weeks ago Gov. Pattison was requested to appear before the committee and testify as to the alleged payment of interest to Bardsley by the Chestnut Street National Bank, of which Mr. Pattison was President prior to the time of his election as Governor.

While the Insurance Department of the State of New-York is engaged in investigating the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company the policy holders in that company are in a measure debarred from taking any action against the Beers ring, which has for years been using their money either recklessly or for its own advantage.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- At last the two crack yachts. Gloriana and Beatrix, have come together on even terms, and the Herreshoff creation is a winner, as her many admirers have hoped and believed she would be. Not only is the Beatrix beaten by her formidable opponent, Gloriana, but also by another of the fast forty-six-footers, the Oweene.

A reputable and responsible mercantile firm in this city recently found it necessary to insure three parcels of property against fire. Through a broker named C.W. Peasley, doing business at 18 and 20 Liberty Street, a member of this firm obtained three policies for $2,500 each, in what he was led to believe were three first-class French fire insurance companies.

In the latter part of March and for some time in April Mr. ROOSEVELT, Civil Service Commissioner, was engaged, by the direction of the commission, in investigating charges of violation of the law and of the civil service rules in the Baltimore Post Office. His report to the commission is just made.

That QUAY and CAMERON are now advocating BLAINE "for revenue only" is an open secret in Pennsylvania. The latest cheme pro posed is to have the State Convention to-morrow put BLAINE before the country as a candidate. It is declared by QUAY'S friends that his taking up the Blaine "boom" has already "restored him to his old place as the ideal leader of his party in the State," and this scheme would confirm his power.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. I. Townsend Burden gave a ball to-night which was one of the principal events of the season. About 300 guests were present, including the leading cottagers, officers of the white squadron, members of the Naval Committee, and representatives of the foreign legations.

Since the impression got abroad that the Brazilian Government was offering special inducements to farmers to settle in that country, the office of the Brazilian Consul in this city has been overrun by applicants for free passage to Brazil. A large proportion of these applicants were Russian Jews, and comparatively few of them were fit to become farmers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- To-morrow will witness here the largest gathering of amateur oarsmen probably ever gathered together on one occasion, to participate in the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Scullers and Oarsmen. Crews from all the important rowing associations in the country are represented, and if the weather be fair and the water smooth, the contests will no doubt be stubbornly waged from start to finish.

Among the profuse eulogistic utterances that have followed the demise of George Jones, late proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, to his grave, one note runs through all and is worthy of the man and the occasion.

Louis Goodheim, who was eighty-two years old, killed himself yesterday by hanging at the Hebrew Home, in One Hundred and Sixth Street, near Ninth Avenue. He went there in 1884, and had suffered such agony from an ailment that he told his brother, who visited him recently, that if he had a pistol he would shoot himself.

Elliott Roosevelt, a brother of Theodore Roosevelt, is insane, and, upon the petition of Theodore, Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court. yesterday appointed Peter B. Olney, Edward V. Loew, and Dr. Cyrus Edson a commission to legally pass-upon his condition in order that a committee may be appointed to take charge of his person and estate, He is now in the Chateau Suresnes, near Paris.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 17. -- Stephen Acor, a young private of Company A, of the Fourteenth Regiment, N.G.P., this afternoon arrested Elmer Bruner, who has been so much wanted since Thursday for the murder of Farmer Samuel Reese, near Ebensburg. The Acor family live close to the Bruner household. To-day Bruner came to young Acor and wanted him to tell Mrs. Bruner her son wanted to see her.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 17. -- A burglars' syndicate or trust now exists, according to high police authorities. In fact, there are said to be about a dozen of these syndicates, and the next move will be to consolidate them. The facts leaked out through the arrest of a noted criminal a few days ago on suspicion. In his day he was one of the most noted bank robbers of the East.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 17. -- The old English aristocratic families of Kingston have been stirred by a romantic elopement in high life. The marriage took place at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Kingston, Friday. The bride was Miss Sophie Tupper Cameron, daughter of Major Gen. Cameron, Commandant of the Royal Military College at Kingston.

In the opening yesterday of a bathhouse in a crowded part of the city, the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has given a hint to the municipality which it is to be hoped that the municipality will not be slow in taking. This bathhouse is placed where it is accessible to a large number of persons who have no facilities for bathing on their own premises.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The New-Jersey Federation of Trades held its annual session here to-day. President Samuel Meller of Trenton presided. Mayor Beridge in behalf of the city welcomed the thirty-six delegates in attendance. Addresses were made by President Meller, J.P. McDonnell of the Paterson Labor Standard, and Samuel Gompers of the American Federation of Labor.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- As the time for holding the Democratic Convention for Ulster County comes nearer, what is called the "anti-Parker boom" begins to develop itself. Judge Alton B. Parker of the Second Division of the Court of Appeals, whose political fortunes have been so greatly improved by having gained the favor of Gov. Hill, has for many years been the acknowledged loader of the Democratic Party in Ulster County.

The green-goods swindler who was arrested Saturday by Post Office Inspectors Jacobs and Hartshorn got into more trouble yesterday, being put under arrest when he was brought before United States Commissioner Shields on a warrant procured on behalf of Anthony Comstock.

The death of Mr. George Jones, the founder and chief proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, deprives America, and, indeed, the world, of one of its most honest, useful, and independent journalists. THE NEW-YORK TIMES, which has from the time of its establishment down to the present been under the control of Mr. Jones, has proved one of the most enterprising and influential of American journals.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Despite the disappointment of Saturday, caused by its postponement on account of rain, the garden party to-day and this evening was a complete success. In point of numbers and richness of the toilets of the ladies, it was pronounced the most successful ever given at the Grand Union Hotel. Five hundred beautifully-dressed children appeared beneath the flags of all nations and the foliage upon the lawn and platform.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The War Department has received the report of Lieut. Col. R. Loder, the army officer who made an inspection of the annual encampment of the National Guard of the State of New-York held at Peekskill from June 13 to Aug. 1. An abstract of his report is as follows:

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 17. -- Less than fifty candidates and delegates are here for the Republican State Convention, which meets Wednesday, and it promises to be rather a tame affair, unless considerable enthusiasm is injected into it between now and the hour of meeting. All the candidates, except Gen. Gregg of Reading, are on the ground, as are also Senator Quay, Chairman Andrews, and others.

The Russian Czar has officially decided on the new rifle to be adopted by the Russian Army. The arm will differ from the French rifle in calibre by .01 part of an inch. This information was received yesterday by cable by the Government authorities in Washington. The fact was simultaneously cabled to Lord Salisbury and the French Minister of War from Russia.

The disposition of the players of the Cincinnati Association Club is as follows: Kelly goes to the Boston American Association team as Captain and manager; Milwaukee will get Canavan, short stop: Carney, first base; Dwyer, pitcher, and Seery, left field. Washington wants Marr. right field; Mains, pitcher, and Vaughn, catcher. The rest of the players are not yet disposed of. Frank Bancroft of the Cincinnatis will manage the Milwaukee Club.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 17. -- Civil Service Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt's report was a galvanic shock to the Republicans to-day. They had so many emotions touched that they could not be induced to discuss the matter for publication. The general sentiment, however, was that the document was merciful to the leaders, and that it made up for that by its severity to the subordinates.

J. Sloat Fassett, the new Collector of the Port, was at his desk in the Custom House yesterday, fresh from his convention at Elmira, and smiling whenever anybody asked him about it. The Collector received a communication from Washington, which told him of his formal appointment as custodian of the Custom House, the Public Stores, and other buildings under the jurisdiction of his office. This was merely a bit of red tape.

Greater excitement than had been seen before in years prevailed on the floor of the Produce Exchange during the first hours of trading yesterday. It centred about the wheat pit, where there occurred the astonishingly rapid and wide fluctuations in prices, but there was also much excitement in those places where corn and rye were bought and sold.

WASHINGTON, AUG. 17. -- The first session of the third general meeting of the American Chemical Society now being held in this city was called to order this morning by the President, Prof. George H. Barker. It was preceded by a meeting of the Washington Chemical Society, which was called for the purpose of welcoming the visiting organization.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 17. -- Notwithstanding the Alliance leaders insist that there is no politics in their order, the deepest interest is manifested by the politicians in this State in the action of the State Convention, which will meet here tomorrow. The line of policy adopted at this meeting may have an important bearing upon the campaign in the State this year.

The death of George Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, it is announced, will not change the policy of the paper in the least. It will still go on as a Mugwump, living off the rentals of its building. -- Kansas City Journal.

A well-dressed young man who gives his name as Ed Scott and who says that his father is a wine merchant, is plying a very petty swindling vocation in the vicinity of the tennis court in Central Park. The inadequate police protection practically grants him immunity from arrest.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The canoe races were resumed this morning. The first was the record paddling race of half a mile, the start being called at 10:48. No time was taken, on account of the confusion at the finish. The entries were more numerous than usual and they were as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- "The Lost Paradise," Henry C. De Mille's new play, was produced here to night for the first time on any stage by Charles Frohman's company. A large and fashionable audience was present. In a general way the play follows the lines of "The Middleman." The first act is too verbose. The second and third acts are strong.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 17. -- A most serious state of affairs political exists in this country at the present moment, and the combined fleets of the powers may be called upon at any moment to take effective action. The smoldering fires caused by the agitation against foreigners among the populace have repeatedly broken out into flame, but without, until quite recently, revealing the strength of the volcano which is threatening a most disastrous outbreak.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17. -- The racing programme set for Saturday, but postponed because of the rain, was run off here to-day, two stakes being decided. These were the Beverwyck, at a mile and three-sixteenths, and the Congress Hall, the latter at heats of three-quarters of a mile.

BERNE, Aug. 17. -- A railroad accident, by which thirteen persons were killed and eighteen seriously and thirty slightly injured, occurred yesterday at Zollikofen, on the Paris-Simplon line. An excursion train, crowded with people on their way from the country districts to this city to take part in the centenary fetes now in progress here, had just pulled up, preparatory to being side-tracked so as to let the Paris express pass.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 17. -- The local political situation is becoming worse and worse each day. Interest is confined principally to the Police Department, and if things keep on it is not unlikely that the present efficient police of the city will be completely demoralized. The old Board of Police Commissioners are after Chief Ryland's official head.

While crossing the ocean on his homeward voyage for Europe Mr. THOMAS B. REED made some remarks about reciprocity which have been published by the gentleman to whom the were addressed, the editor of the Chicago Advance, a well-known religious journal. Said the leader of the Billion Congress:

In an article concerning the wool-growing industry the Bulletin of American Protective Tariff League said last week: "The McKinley bill has done something to remedy the suicide policy of excessive importations of wool." Even in Ohio the wool growers cannot be deceived by such talk as this.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Those who witnessed Saturday's scenes on the Board of Trade and had no inkling of the condition of the market thought the climax of excitement had been reached, but the most conservative old-timers proclaim that such a day as to-day never before transpired in the history of the board. This is equally true of the excited crowd.

The more the subterfuges by which the Republican conspiracy in Connecticut for keeping out of office the Democrats who were elected last November are examined the more shameful they appear. The whole fabric of fraud, except so far as it related to the office of Governor, rested upon the rejection of the so-called "double ballots."

RED BAY, Labrador, July 13. -- In the northern part of the continent of North America, between the parallels of 50 and 60 north latitude, lies the peninsula of Labrador, which country, though it is in exactly the same latitude as the British Isles, and is nearer to them than any other point on this whole continent, is at present almost wholly unknown to civilized man.

Mr. FOSTER and his immediate advisers in the Treasury are very much annoyed at the partial failure of the scheme to extend the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds. The Secretary puts a bold face on the matter and declares that he will be entirely ready to pay off the $30,000,000, the holders of which have not as yet consented to the extension.

An attachment was yesterday granted in the Supreme Court by Judge O'Brien against the property in this State of Sylvester Young in a suit brought by the Guarantee Company of North America to recover $20,000. Young belongs in Louisville, Ky., where he was in the employ of the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Company.

Although the centenary of STARK'S famous victory over the redcoats was duly commemorated at Bennington in 1877, yet an occasion for a renewal of the celebration, and, indeed, for a far more imposing display of patriotic enthusiasm, has now been furnished by the completion of the lofty monument that marks the battlefield.
WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The record for the six-mile unlimited sailing race at the meet of the American Canoe Association to-day was as follows:

There is nothing in the least convincing in Corporation Counsel CLARK'S opinion regarding the power of the Park Commission to allow a railroad to be constructed and maintained in Battery Park, but the Board of Aldermen felt bound to accept his construction of the law and to act in accordance with his opinion.

Desiring to obtain the opinions of a representative Republican and protectionist in North Dakota concerning the McKinley bill, one of our contemporaries has procured from T.K. LONG of Bismarck a letter in which he makes the following remarks about wool:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The nineteenth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, representing clubs from all parts of the country, was held here to-day on the Potomac River. The races in the main were well contested and at times were close and exciting. While the time made in some instances was slow, it was, taken as a whole, good and above the average.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The Presidential train stopped here at 4 o'clock this afternoon. There were about 600 people present at the West Shore station, and the President made the following speech:

The attorneys of the New-York Life Insurance Company after forty days' deliberation, which has undoubtedly been profound, yesterday served upon the attorneys for THE NEW-YORK TIMES the complaint of the former against THE TIMES in the one million-dollar libel suit, notice of which was served in July, July 9 to be exact.

BOSTON, Aug. 18. -- Cambridge was visited this morning by a destructive fire. The Damon Iron Works, situated at the extreme end of the causeway of the West Boston Bridge, are a mass of ruins. The building, which was a two-story wooden structure, had a frontage on Main Street of 250 feet, with a depth of 150, and was 300 feet long on the border of Broad Canal at the northerly side.

L.C. Krauthoff, President of the Western Association, and John W. Spear, President of the Kansas City Club, arrived in Denver Monday night. They have been prowling around the Yellowstone region and met an adventure. To reach some magnificent scenery it was necessary to undertake a seventy-five-mile stage-coach ride. This is what Mr. Krauthoff says about it: "While journeying along, the stage suddenly stopped with a jerk that piled us in a heap in one corner.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18. -- The Ottawa Free Press prints a special from Washington to the effect that Premier Abbott has asked Mr. Erastus Wiman of New-York to co-operate with Sir Julian Pauncefote, British Minister at Washington, in promoting the negotiations for a reciprocity treaty between Canada and the United States.

HELENA, Mon., Aug. 18. -- Prince Russell Harrison is making a noble effort to get his State in line to support his father in the Republican National Convention of 1893, but he appears to be having a serious time of it, with chances rather against his succeeding. Somehow the Montana Republicans are very little inclined toward Harrison; he does not seem to possess the qualities which far Westerners most esteem in public men.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The Putnam Phalanx of Hartford, Conn., Major O.H. Blanchard, ninety-one men, officers and privates, with the Moodus Druin and Fife Corps, arrived at 8 P.M., and were escorted by the Saratoga Citizens' Corps to Congress Hall, where they will remain until Friday and take part in President Harrison's reception. The storm marred the street parade this evening.

The notorious Peter B. Tarpey, editor and politician and school teacher and "Pat" Gleason henchman in Long Island City, has been served with a copy of a complaint to be presented to the State Superintendent of Public Instruction on Aug. 28 as the basis for a petition that "Profeessor" Tarpey's license as a teacher shall be revoked.

A crowd that thronged the visitors' gallery at the Produce Exchange yesterday expecting to see a repetition of the stormy time of the day before, in the wheat pit, waited an hour or two and went away disappointed. The brokers took the day to recover from the tremendous activity of Monday, and there was a disposition to await developments, without trading much.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 18. -- A resolution was passed to-night by the Alliance State Convention which may prove a snag in the coming campaign in Virginia. As related in THE TIMES several weeks ago, despite a plank in the platform opposing it, the first legislative candidate in Virginia indorsed by the Alliance was a salaried railroad attorney.

HOMER, La., Aug. 18. -- John Ramsey and a negro were waylaid and killed Sunday evening about three miles from this place by unknown parties. Ramsey was in town nearly all day, and late in the evening started for his home in a wagon, accompanied by his brother Sam and a negro man and woman. About a half mile from his home he was fired upon.

The judgment of the Baltimore Sun is that the "oligarchy of office holders and office seekers" pictured by Mr. ROOSEVELT in that city is not confined to the Republican Party. It says that there is one branch of it depending on the Federal spoils and another relying on the State spoils, that each aids the other, and both have "a common object -- to despoil."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- Another brilliant society event of this great social week was the big ball given to-night by Mr. and Mrs. George Peabody Wetmore at their villa. Between two and three hundred cottagers were present. The floral decorations were very artistic. The principal decorations were confined to the ballroom.

The main parlor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel was yesterday the gathering place of a distinguished assemblage of owners and managers of the steam coasting vessels of the United States. The occasion was the twentieth annual meeting of the National Board of Steam Navigation, and there were representative men present from the leading cities of the country from Portland, Me., to Cincinnati and New-Orleans.

While the Rapid-Transit Commission has been busy trying to settle upon a proper plan of construction for the various lines of railroad thus far laid out, the engineering corps has, incidentally, while assisting in the more difficult work, completed the surveys and staked out the continuation of the west side route from Fort George, the point to which it was definitely carried by the commission's report, to the Yonkers line.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- President Harrison and party passed through here at 3:02 this afternoon on the West Shore Road. At the station in this city John A. Sleicher introduced the President to over 1,000 citizens, to whom Mr. Harrison spoke as follows:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18. -- The fight between the State and the lessees of prison labor is on. The convicts at the Briceville coal mines, after being sent back to Knoxville by the free minors and returned to the mine by Gov. Buchanan, were a few days ago ordered by the State Board of Prison Inspectors to be removed because of the bad condition of the mine and inadequate accommodations.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18. -- The general Western branch, situated in Kansas City, Kan., of the English and American Mortgage Company of London, England, was taken possession of to-day by the United States Marshal, under an attachment in favor of the Bank of Commerce of this city. The complication arose as follows: The branch offices drew a draft on the home office in London for $46,000.

Two newspaper detectives brought a "green goods" case to Acting Superintendent Byrnes yesterday. It was that of a Zincite (Jasper County, Mo.) miner, George Williams, whose imagination was fired by "you know" circulars, and he was chosen by several comrades to go to New-York and get all the "green goods" he could for $265. His contribution to the pool was only $15.

TRENTON, Aug. 18. -- The utter insincerity with which Gov. Abbett's Riparian Board is treating the State's shore owners in the matter of the seizure of the reefs off their holdings at Communipaw and Bayonne -- a project which is now under discussion between the Governor and the Federal authorities -- is shown by some disclosures made to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day by some gentlemen connected with the State Board.

Collector J. Sloat Fassett is already experiencing some of the difficulties incident to the position he occupies. The place hunters are doing their best to make his life miserable, and now the clerks of the Custom House are grumbling because there is a prospect that they will have no vacations this year.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The fleet of French war vessels which has recently been visiting Cronstadt was off Dover this morning. The fleet was slowly steaming down the Channel, and will arrive in the Solent, between the Isle of Wight and the mainland of England, to-morrow.
At the meeting of the American Association yesterday the Milwaukee Club was admitted to membership in place of Kelly's Cincinnati team.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The first race of the Cherry Diamond Yacht Club for the gold cup offered by the Manhattan Athletic Club was sailed here to-day by the Mineola and Jessica. The Nautilus did not start. The Jessica crossed the starting line first, but the Mineola took the lead almost immediately and kept it to the finish, crossing the line more than fifteen minutes ahead of the Jessica.

The main interest in the yachting season that is now drawing to its close has been in the contests of moderate tonnage, and consequently of moderate cost of building and operating. This is in itself a very encouraging fact. Especially, the interest of the season has centred in the performance of the Gloriana, which has shown herself superior to all the cutters and to all the centreboard boats that have been brought against her.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The red-hot fight for control of the Twenty-third Congressional District took a new and decidedly interesting turn to-day.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 18. -- Delegates to the Republican Convention which is to meet to-morrow and nominate candidates for State Treasurer, Auditor General, and eighteen delegates at large to the proposed Constitutional Convention, have been arriving all day, and tonight the town is filled with enthusiastic adherents of the various candidates.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18. -- The Executive Committee appointed by the Fort Worth Farmers' Alliance Convention, with U.S. Hall, President of the Missouri Alliance as Chairman, has issued a circular to the "Members of the Farmers' Alliance and Industrial Union, and to the Farmers and Laborers of the United States," calling a convention of the members of these bodies who are in accord with the resolutions passed at the Fort Worth meeting.

The removal of Police Sergeant Osborn of the Yonkers police to the small sub-station at Bronxville, known as the Fourth Ward, has created a great deal of ill feeling among the business men of that city by reason of the irregular and peremptory manner in which it was done, and is characterized by some as an "underhanded piece of procedure."

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 18. -- At Albany the President received in his car a committee of citizens of Troy, led by Gen. Joseph B. Carr. When Troy was reached the train moved with difficulty through the throng. It was the noisiest demonstration of the day. As soon as order was secured, Gen. Carr introduced the President, who said:

We are bound to say that in some respects the attitude of some of the New-York bankers toward the Secretary of the Treasury with reference to the extension of the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds is not altogether what it should be. If the Secretary's own skirts were clear, if he had from the first acted in a straightforward and businesslike manner, we think he would have some reason to complain.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 18. -- At the meeting to-day of the International Socialist Workmen's Congress a committee reported in favor of pledging workmen of all countries not to support a candidate for a public position unless the candidate announces himself as being prepared to advocate reforms for the benefit of labor and the protective legislation demanded by workingmen.

The game of politics, as it is played by Mr. PLATT, is a cruel sport. He regards with cold-blooded indifference the betrayal of confidence, the wreck of noble ambitions, the disappointment of cherished hopes, and the ruin of honorable careers. No fat Roman Emperor ever looked on the anguish of a Christian martyr with smaller sympathy.

After two days of costly experience, the guileless Plattdeutschers, who are having their annual open-air carnival at Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, decided that there was actually a good deal of gambling going on, and that unless something was done the girls would have no jewelry left to set off their charms, and that Mynheer would have no money left to spend legitimately.

If there ever was anything corresponding to poor old Polonius's "tragical-comical historical" drama, it is the piece now being played with Mr. Br. BLAINE as its chief point of interest. The latest contribution to it comes from RUSSELL HARRISON'S paper in Montana, the Helena Journal, in an article quoted in our dispatches this morning.
ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- The Albany Citizens' Committee met the President at Selkirk. They were James Ten Eyck, Col. A.E. Mather, John G. Myer, James M. Warner, Henry C. Nevitt, and William Barnes.

The Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad made a financial arrangement yesterday which is said to be satisfactory to a majority of the floating-debt creditors, but which may encounter spirited opposition from at least a portion of the minority. The purpose of the meeting was to provide for an extension of the company's floating debt for a period of three years.
LEEDS, Aug. 18. -- At a meeting of the Leeds Millers' Association to-day it was decided to make a further advance in the price of flour of 1s. 6d.

President Harrison and some of the party that has been summering with him at Cape May were in Jersey City for a half hour yesterday. Their advent, brief stay, and departure occasioned no excitement whatever. The President was on his way to Bennington, Vt., where he is to be the central figure at the dedication of the great monument to commemorate the battle of Bennington.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 18. -- Messrs. George and Walthall now have 93 legislative votes, which is 3 more than they need to secure their re-election to the United States Senate. Barksdale, the Sub-Treasury candidate, has only 30 votes. This leaves 55 votes unaccounted for. It is hardly possible now for Barksdale to have more than 55 votes on joint ballot, while it looks as if George and Walthall will have over 120.

KEY WEST, Aug. 18. -- The revenue cutter McLane, Capt. Chaytor, arrived off this port this morning with the crew of the wrecked steamer El Dorado. The crew had abandoned the ship during the hurricane of Aug. 15. The wrecking schooner Cora, with a large quantity of damaged cargo, was also brought in tow from the Bahama Banks.

The excitement in the wheat pit of the Produce Exchange had all died down yesterday, and there were frequent pauses in business. Early cable reports said that foreign markets were excited, and this had a tendency to increase trading here. A little later the cables reported a general desire to sell, and the market dropped a peg.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 19. -- In the presence of the dignitaries of the Nation and State, and participated in by the Chief Magistrate of the country, the dedication ceremonies of the Bennington Battle Monument and the centennial of the admission of the Green Mountain State into the Union were celebrated here to-day.

Col. Elliott F. Shepard laid the cornerstone of the new building for his Mail and Express yesterday at noon. The ceremonies were characterized by much loud rejoicing and display of religious fervor. A big free lunch was a conspicuous feature of the occasion and one which was by no means overlooked by the crowd of Col. Shepard's friends and others who had gathered on his invitation.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- The Temps, commenting on the visit of the French fleet to Portsmouth, expresses pleasure at the cordial tone of the English press, and says: "The visit to Portsmouth is a natural compliment to the visit to Cronstadt, showing that all three powers desire to preserve peace and to re-establish an equilibrium in Europe without binding the hands of either."

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 19. -- When Chairman Andrews called the Republican State Convention to order at 10:40 o'clock this morning everything moved with beautiful precision for a while. He had just told a friend that the people were running this convention, and somehow the right people seemed to know just what they were expected to do. Secretary Frank Willing Leach read the list of delegates as though he knew it by heart.

It would be interesting to know what damages the New-York Life Insurance Company claims in its suit against THE NEW-YORK TIMES. This action has been commonly known as "the million-dollar libel suit," and there is a statement in the complaint that bears out this understanding. But there are other things in the complaint that make it exceedingly doubtful just how much will satisfy Mr. William H. Beers and his associates.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 19. -- The British delegates to the International Socialist Workmen's Congress held a meeting to-day to consider the committee's report, presented to the congress yesterday, in favor of pledging workmen of all countries not to support a candidate for a public office unless he announces himself prepared to advocate reforms for the benefit of labor and the protective legislation demanded by workmen.

A panic was caused in the five tenement house 165 Chrystie Street at 1:30 yesterday morning by the discovery of a fire in the basement. The place where the flames first made their appearance is occupied by Shire Gottlieb as a coal and wood store, and the damage done is estimated at only $400. The smoke was thick and suffocating, however, and it had filled the building before the cry of fire aroused the occupants.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The fashionable residence quarter was thrown into excitement early this morning by the daring exploits of a masked burglar. He gained entrance to John G. Mills's house on Upper Madison Avenue through the bathroom by way of a ladder which was found near by.

The Hon. A. Lee Knett of Baltimore, formerly Assistant Postmaster General, was at the Hotel Marlborough yesterday. He was accompanied by his wife, and said he was on his way to Sharon Springs for a short vacation. He spoke of the political situation in Maryland at some length, when a TIMES reporter asked him what were the features of interest in the coming State campaign:

Major -- not Major -- Gen. -- James W. -- not James S. -- Wadsworth now declares through a number of superserviceable friends and newspapers that it was all a mistake and that he will take the Republican nomination for Governor if it is tendered to him unanimously. In the meantime Sing Sing is singing the praises of Col. R.A. McAlpin.

Some of the Tammany people in the Eighth Senatorial District have developed a desire to nominate Col. Alfred Wagstaff, President of the Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, for the Senate. None of the heavy-weights of the Tammany bosses in the district has yet-publicly given his sanction to the boom, but there has been enough talk about the matter in the Senate district to set people wondering.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Two of the three events for the second day at Hampden Park were disposed of before dark this afternoon, the 2:25 trot going over until to-morrow after two heats.

Martin Engel, the well-known Republican leader of the Eighth Assembly District and the chief supporter of the notorious "Silver Dollar" Smith, is, as he walks about among his friends to-day, about as strong a living illustration of the perfection of the surgeon's art as one would care to meet.

Scores of Tammany men have recently become very chilly toward the organization, because they hold it responsible for the passage of a law at the last session of the Legislature, which was a very good bit of legislation for the residents of this city, but which happens to affect their pocketbooks. The person held immediately responsible for this law is Mr. Percival Farquhar, the Tammany Assemblyman from the Third Assembly District.

Although it was an off-day in the racing world yesterday, there was a good crowd at the Jerome Park track to see a decidedly commonplace programme run off. There were six races on the card, and the chief of these was a steeplechase, at least it aroused the most enthusiasm. It was the last race of the afternoon, and nine horses started in it.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 19. -- The war vessels of France were signaled at 1:45 P.M. to-day. They were steaming slowly toward the Solent. The Marceau was leading the fleet; then came the Marengo, the Furioux, the Requin, the Sur Coup, the Lance, and two torpedo boats. The latter were almost engulfed in the rough Channel sea, which formed a part of Britain's welcome to her warlike visitors.

As there is a possibility that the Delaware Handicap will be a walk-over for Reckon this afternoon, the Monmouth Association announces an extra race for maiden two-year-olds at four and a half furlongs in order to fill out the day's sport. The entries and weights for the several races that are closed are as follows:

OTTAWA, Aug. 19. -- To-day's boodle developments surpassed any of the disclosures hitherto made. They show that the taint of corruption affects high Federal officials as well as prominent members of the Quebec Administration. Three committees were in session all day. It would be difficult to state which elicited the most demoralizing state of affairs in public life.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 19. -- The annual State Alliance Convention met to-day. It had not been in session fifteen minutes before President Livingston and Gov. Northen clashed. Col. Livingston swept the convention in a whirlwind. Just after he had called the convention to order the Rev. J.G. Gibson arose.

The death of LOUIS PAULSEN is a most striking reminder that a great era of chess playing has passed away. In spite of Mr. STEINITZ, it may fairly be maintained that it was the greatest the world has ever seen. There is more knowledge of chess now extant in the world than there was a generation ago.

It is not unlikely that importers of music, pictures, including etchings, photographs, , and a large contingent of lovers of these things who are not dealers will unite in a protest to the Secretary of the Treasury against the ruling which instructs the customs officers to confiscate these articles when sent through the mails from foreign countries.

A great effort was made at Harrisburg yesterday for harmony in the Republican Party in Pennsylvania, and an uncommon degree of self-restraint was exhibited by the leaders in order to secure it. This shows at least that something has been learned from experience. QUAY and MAGEE met without being at swords' points and without carrying any contest into the convention.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 19. -- The following are the losses and insurances in yesterday's fire:

There is little significance in the rest of the platform except in its treatment of the silver question and ballot reform. The approval of the McKinley tariff, the Fifty-first Congress, and the pension extravagance was to be expected. The silver question gave the platform makers some trouble. They undertook to settle the difficulty by diluting free coinage with protection, and carrying the Pennsylvania idea of protecting home industry into the currency.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The first sailing race of the American Canoe Association to-day was for the trophy won by Ford Jones last year on the seven-and-a-half-mile course. To-day the course was nine miles. The total number of entries was limited to fifteen, and twelve of them were the best twelve of the winners of the unlimited race already sailed. The entries were as follows:

The marks of respect paid, last week, to the memory of the late George Jones, proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, had been earned by a long life of great activity, which had been crowned by the attainment of its object. He had devoted himself to the creation of a great newspaper, and he had made THE NEW-YORK TIMES, a journal the equals of which could be counted on the fingers of one hand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The medal of honor conferred by the Government upon the men who rendered conspicuous gallantry during the rebellion has just been sent to James G. Grindlay of Utica, now employed in the State Controller's office at Albany.

The United States gunboat cruiser Bennington sails to-day to hunt a storm off Cape Hatteras. The Bennington is under the command of Commander Royal B. Bradford. With him is the official Board of Inspection and Survey of the Navy Department in Washington. This board is ordered to inspect the ship during the coming ordeal.

A convention of a singularly interesting, if melancholy, character is that of the deaf-mutes now in progress at Lyric Hall, in Sixth Avenue, near Forty-first Street, in this city. It is the fourteenth annual convention of the Empire State Association of Deaf-Mutes. Nearly 200 members are in attendance, about one-third of them women and girls.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- The great match of the second round of the national tennis tournament was the contest to-day between Richard Stevens of Hoboken, N.J., and V.G. Hall of New-York. Hall finally won, but only after a close and exciting exhibition of good tennis, in which Hall played as well as ever in his life.

It is a singular fact, which perhaps hardly accords with prevailing impressions, that for several years there has been a progressive decrease in the number of public school pupils throughout the country, as compared with the population. That is to say, while there has been no absolute retrograde, and, indeed, even a slight average gain, yet this gain is very much less than the gain in population.

The situation in Germany seems to threaten a much more vigorous and sustained attack upon the corn duties than that which the Chancellor has thus far resisted with success. It is evident that Germany has not this year raised enough rye to supply the domestic demand, and it is equally evident that the principal source of foreign supply, that of Russia, is for the present cut off.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Lieut. Gov. Jones is nothing if not a shrewd advertiser. He takes advantage of every opportunity to advertise himself and his scale works. During the Summer months there are a great many visitors to the Capitol. Gen. Jones knows this, and it occurred to him that the opportunity was most excellent for advertising purposes.

Welch pitched for the New-Yorks yesterday, and they lost another game to Boston. The latter is in excellent form and playing remarkably fine ball. In the opening inning the visitors measured up the curving of the New-York pitcher, and they batted out 3 runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The action of the Navy Department in ordering the Pensacola from the Mare Island Navy Yard to Honolulu, is commended by naval officers and others who have kept informed as to the progress of events in the Pacific and appreciate the necessity of keeping a naval force at the Hawaiian Islands constantly.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn, who is ill at the home of his relatives, the Schieffelins, in this place, is very much improved to-day. Dr. Fanning, who is attending him, says that his patient is doing splendidly, and if he continues to improve in the present manner he will probably be well enough next week to remove to his home in Brooklyn. The Mayor is in good spirits.

That Andrew D. White, ex-President of Cornell University and ex-United States Minister to Germany, has been decided upon as the Republican candidate for Governor by Thomas C. Platt and the other Republican bosses who will dictate the business of the Republican State Convention is to-day the opinion of the Republican politicians of this city.

Recruiting ought not to be difficult nowadays for the French Navy. When Jack has such junketings as those at Cherbourg, Cronstadt, and Portsmouth this Summer he may well appear fond of his day and his calling. It is an inspiring reflection, also, that the French bluejackets are ready to fraternize alike with Russian and with British tars.

The country owes a debt of gratitude to President HARRISON for his statement at Albany regarding the currency, in response to the welcome of Gov. HILL. It seems to us a statement to which no' exception can be taken. It is careful, simple, and, within the lines determined by the President, explicit.

The reports from Europe unsettled the wheat pit at the Produce Exchange yesterday and made business very lively at times during the day. The bulls had the best of it in the scramble. European cables told of unsettled weather and apprehension of political action growing out of present complications and of the prohibition of export by Russia.

A good deal of light is needed to inspire confidence in the character of the insurance business done by Mr. H.A. Richardson of 17 Whitehall Street. Mr. Richardson says he is prepared to furnish that light, but he does not furnish it. His explanations are of the kind that do not explain.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 20. -- "Tom" Watson, whose card writing and speechmaking have won for him a good deal of notoriety, feels about as blue to-day over Alliance developments as does Gov. Northen. Watson was one of the smart young lawyers who early saw a good deal of political outcome in the Alliance movement, and he worked his knowledge with such good effect that he is now a member of Congress.

Judge O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, on the application of James G.D. Burnertt, granted an injunction to restrain Commissioner Heintz from carrying on improvements in One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street, which, if finished as planned, would place a stone culvert over the Mott Haven Canal. There is at present a drawbridge over the canal at this point, but the traffic on the canal does not make it necessary to open it very often.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The first regatta of the season and the most successful one ever held on Cayuga Lake, was participated in by seven of the fastest yachts on the lake over the course at Shelldrake to-day. The morning opened with a stiff breeze from the north and at 11:34 the yachts were started. Jacob Cram had entered his English cutters Violette and Kitz, and they started first and second respectively.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Corn traders were sure this morning that Hutchinson and his New-York bull outfit were trying to sell. It was the thing the whole trade had been watching for -- an attempt on the part of the corn clique to unload. September sold from 69 cents to 66 1/2 cents, and the close was a little groggy at 67 1/4 cents.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 20. -- The Ohio campaign is not formally on and the Republican Presidential Convention is a year away, but the former is already warm and for weeks the candidates to come before the latter have been discussed. Blaine has always had the strong aggressive following in Ohio, and that this old guard is wide awake and in the fight was made apparent by two things to-day.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20. -- The people of Saratoga were a good deal surprised this forenoon to find that President Harrison had actually been in the town and driven through a portion of it in a coach from one railway station to another, accompanied by President Lohnas of Saratoga Township and the Reception Committee. He took the train for Mount McGregor without any delay.

" About this time," as the almanacs used to put it, we may reasonably expect hurricanes in the West Indies. The violence and duration of these cannot possibly be estimated beforehand, but the "hurricane months" are seasons of great anxiety. Sometimes the storms spend their force at sea, and it is impossible to predict upon what land they may alight.

James W. Ridgway is to be promoted from the Kings County District Attorneyship to the Brooklyn Mayoralty, if Democratic votes can do it. The powers that be -- Hugh McLaughlin and the "Big Four" -- have decided that the only Democrat to make the run next November is Mr. Ridgway. This is almost official.

That is a very amazing story which is told about the riot at the Plattdeutsche Volksfest in Hoboken. In itself the riot was of no great consequence. In its beginnings it was one of those exuberances that, are liable to occur when a crowd of merrymakers assemble, especially if the merrymakers be all of one nationality, and that nationality foreign to the community in which the merrymaking is held.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20. -- Premier Abbott announced in the Senate to-day that the Government had decided to appoint a royal commission after the session to investigate the wholesale irregularities in the civil service. He hoped they would be able to adopt a system under which those improprieties, although not absolutely preventable, since human nature must always be human nature, may be reduced to a minimum and checked with greater facility than under the present system.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 20. -- A legal contest will be made by Nathaniel W. Trask to recover the office of City Treasurer, the most desirable position in the gift of the City Council. William D. Salter has just come into possession of the office. Mr. Trask gave up the books under protest in the presence of witnesses.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20. -- There was a good crowd at the track here this afternoon, and some more than ordinary sport. The fun began with a dash of three-quarters of a mile, and Prince Royal looked to be so sure a winner that the books refused to lay against him. He won as he pleased. But Mr. Dwyer's candidate, the costly coward Bolero, could not win the Spencer Handicap, in which he was a starter.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- John F. Foster, who is confined in the State prison, has invented what is called a wonderful marine engine. The convict this morning explained its merits. He said there were no eccentrics used, and that the engine was reversed without slacking speed by means of a button, but that on a large engine a treadle would be used.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20. -- The most important action to-day of the Farmers' Alliance State Convention was the indorsement by that body of the whole Ocala platform. They not only indorsed it in its entirety, but added: "And we further demand of our Representatives in Congress that if they cannot agree to these demands (Sub-Treasury bill and all) that they give us something better or as good."

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 20. -- The squadron of evolution sailed for Bar Harbor at 9:30 this morning. This makes a stay of but twenty-four hours at Boston. It was expected that the squadron would go to Portsmouth, N.H., in order to avoid Admiral Gherardi, but, to the surprise of every one, the white squadron sails direct to the place where the North Atlantic fleet is assembled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The Blaine boomers here were disappointed because the indorsement of the Maine statesman by the Pennsylvania Convention was not more emphatic. Still, they argue that it was sufficient. The reason why it was not more emphatic is generally attributed to Quay's intense desire for harmony in the convention.

Miss Coghlan will have to try again. "Dorothy's Dilemma" is not a good play. The black horse and the dragoon's uniform fail to make it even a mild success, and there is nothing else in the piece to do it.

It was another hard day that racegoers had at Jerome Park yesterday, and all but one of the good things on the card went wrong. That one, that was the savior of the plungers, was Beck. He was the single favorite that won a race during the afternoon, and consequently the plungers had a hard time of it.

When General Passenger Agent Scull of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad made an excursion rate from Cincinnati to Atlantic City of $16 without authority of either the Central Traffic or the Trunk Line Associations he stirred up the passenger department of the Erie Road with a sharp stick. W.C. Rinearson, General Passenger Agent of the last-named road, regarded the action of the Baltimore and Ohio as unjustifiable and prejudicial to the interests of the Erie.
