MILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The Jabberwock Cup, donated by the original Jabberwock, George A. Warden of Ohio, was sailed for at the American Canoe Association meet to-day. The record was this:

BRUSSELS, Aug. 20. -- The International Socialist Workmen's Congress to-day discussed a report from a committee on international combination, advising the formation of national instead of international committees, and resolving that, although strikes are sometimes necessary, they are often unsuccessful, and workmen ought to take every precaution before striking.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 20. -- Admiral Gervais, in command of the French squadron now visiting England, accompanied by seventeen of his senior officers, landed at Osborne Bay this morning and were conveyed in the royal carriages to Osborne Palace.

In our estimates published on the 12th inst. of the quantity of wheat that could be spared for foreign consumption from the new crop in North America, the probable surplus in Canada was mentioned as being about 20,000,000 bushels. This was in accordance with the indications of official reports up to that time.

If the two Russian cruisers now in Bering Sea to protect the seal fisheries of their Government from encroachment should encounter and arrest the British Columbia schooners reported to be trying their luck on the Russian side of that sea, some interesting questions in international law might be brought up.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- The sub-committee of City Council investigating the affairs of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley and the Keystone Bank met this afternoon. The report of the expert accountants was submitted. The report deals principally with the overissued stock of the bank, but does not materially change the aspect of the affairs of the bank as already made public.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The garment known as the Holy Coat was exposed to view this morning in the cathedral at Treves. Two Knights of Malta, in full costume, with drawn swords in their hands, stood on each side of the shrine inclosing the Holy Coat case, which was surrounded by tall lighted candles in handsome candlesticks, and surmounted by a large gold cross.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- Philadelphia presented a crippled team to-day, and New-York won hands down. Ewing's men made 5 runs off Esper's pitching in the first inning, and when Kling was substituted in the third they opened on him for 6 runs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- The American Wheel Company, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of wheels and vehicles, is insolvent. Noble C. Butler has been appointed receiver, and has possession of the different plants of the company. The total assets are given as $4,105,000, and liabilities $1,800,000. Stringency of the money market and inability to secure extension of obligations caused the collapse.

THE TIMES has an editorial article on the subject of the step taken by Mr. George Jones in 1884, when for the first time his newspaper opposed the nominee of the Republican Party for the Presidency. A reference to this event -- a very important event both for the party and for the newspaper -- was made in the Evening Post's sketch of Mr. Jones's life.

HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 20. -- Frank C. Almy, the murderer of Christie Warden, was discovered in Mr. Warden's barn this morning. Charles E. Stewart, a student at Dartmouth College, found him in the hay by prodding with the long handle of a shovel. When he punched the hidden man a bullet was fired up at him through the hay on which he stood.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The wheelmen shattered two world's records to-day. The weather was hot, and the racers gloried in it. W.F. Murphy of the New-York Athletic Club reduced the mile safety record to 2:25 4-5, and A.A. Zimmerman of the same club rode the last quarter in competition in 0:30 4:5. The summaries follow:

There is some force, if not much novelty, in the suggestion made by a prize fighter to the Police Commissioners that policemen be taught to rely more on their fists than on their night sticks in cases of emergency. Several years ago Inspector WILLIAMS, then a Captain, tried to accomplish something of the kind by means of the organization known as the Police Athletic Club.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Times this morning publishes long extracts from Count von Moltke's history of the war of 1870.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The weather clerk again favored the tennis players to-day, and the players favored the spectators with some very fine tennis. The results of the day showed one great surprise in the defeat of R.P. Huntington, Jr., by S.T. Chase, the Western champion. The match throughout was a brilliant exhibition of skillful tennis, and Chase covered himself with glory by his victory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- A thoroughly- disappointed crowd was that which gathered to see the long-talked-of match between the two fast mares Nancy Hanks and Margaret S. The latter was wholly unfit to race, and after she had been beaten in 2:20 1/4 and 2:19 she was withdrawn. A smart shower that came up prevented Doble from sending Nancy Hanks a mile against her record, 2:12 1/2.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 20. -- A delegation of eleven sheet-iron rollers from Philadelphia, headed by Fred Simmons, Samuel Caldwell, and Peter Wible, reached here yesterday, having been engaged by W.F. Neidringhaus while he was in Philadelphia. The men saw an advertisement in a local paper there, and, answering it, were informed, so they allege, by Mr. Neidringhaus that Pittsburg wages were in force here, and they inferred that the Pittsburg scale had been signed.

The unanimity with which the foreign policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company have joined in the protest against the company's mismanagement at the hands of President William H. Beers, shows more conclusively than any other argument how useless it will be for Mr. Beers to continue his career at the company's head.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A general session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was held to-day at the Columbian University Building. Prof. Goodale of Harvard University, the retiring President of the association, in his valedictory address on the possibilities of economic botany, said that if all our present cereals were swept out of existence our experiment stations could probably replace them by other grasses within half a century.

The People's Municipal League of this city has set out upon a campaign to secure real ballot reform in this State by the adoption of the "blanket" ballot. Its subcommittee on electoral reform has issued a statement setting forth the defects of the present law and the advantages of the proposed change, and the mere statement is convincing and hardly needs the support of argument.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- The dead body of Clark Woodman, one of the wealthiest citizens of Omaha, Neb., and an influential Director in the Linseed Oil Trust, was found this afternoon in his room at the Grand Pacific Hotel. The general supposition is that the death was that of a suicide.

Mr. Frank Mullen's saloon roosts on the rafters of Tweed's old Knickerbocker Hotel, fronting the plaza, and leans lovingly against the south wall of Judge P. Henry Dugro's big unfinished twelve-story Hotel Savoy, at Fifty-ninth Street. Judge Dugro's hotel is very tall and Mr. Mullen's saloon is very small, and is almost obscured behind advertising signs that Mr. Mullen rents out at a high rate per month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The Acting Commissioner of Immigration at New-York recently recommended to the Treasury Department that on the removal of the immigrant station to Ellis Island, a portion of the Barge Office premises now used for immigrant business be set apart for occupancy by the Free Bureau of Labor, which is now maintained at Castle Garden by the German and Irish societies of the City of New-York.

The two Committees representing the League and Association, which will have the work in hand of closing the yawning chasm that now separates them, have been appointed. The personnel of the committee, which will consist of three from each association is not positively known, but this much can be stated: Chris Von Der Ahe is Chairman and Mr. Brush of Indianapolis is a member.

The shareholders in Samuel Allsopp and Sons, Limited, cannot be complimented on the manner in which their cause was presented at yesterday's annual meeting. Still less can they be congratulated on the result. There was abundance of wild hitting, but there was no concentration of force on any definite and vulnerable point.

Clarkson was hit hard and often yesterday by the Brooklyn players, who won from the Bostons by a one-sided score. Young Hemming pitched another good game. He kept the hits well scattered and filled his position admirably. The fielders gave him good encouragement in the shape of clever support.

The most conservative life insurance men in this city, while taking no part in the warfare that is being waged against President Beers's management of the New-York Life, have not hesitated within the last month to state through the mouths of their agents that the whole business of life insurance is being injured by Mr. Beers's attitude toward the policy holders of his company.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- Additional details received here this morning from St. Pierre, the capital of the Island of Martinique, which was visited by a terrible hurricane on Tuesday night last, show that the facts already published are not only in no way exaggerated, but that they did not tell the full story of the disaster. The number of dead was originally estimated at sixty, with hundreds of injured.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 21. -- A few minutes after 12 o'clock noon to-day President Hall of the Farley National Bank posted a notice on its doors that the bank, by a vote of the Directors, had agreed to suspend payment temporarily, the cause stated being inability to raise money to make good paper drawn by others discounted by the bank and protested in New-York.

The revision of the regulations for the examination of candidates from civil life for commissions in the line of the army is in the direction of securing greater fitness for the particular work required. The weight hereafter ascribed to a certain percentage of proficiency shown in mathematics will be greater than for an equal percentage of proficiency in history, and twice as great as for the same percentage in constitutional and international law.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 21. -- A heavy storm had raged throughout the night, and the wind had raised a sea which was far from being pleasant to the crowds of amateur sailors who were ready to put off from the shore in swarms of yachts and excursion boats. The French war vessels, which had come from Osborne Bay to Spithead, had not anchored in position at 10:30 A.M.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Receiver N.C. Butler of the American Wheel Company has filed his bond and begun the work of disentangling the affairs of the corporation. Several of the stock-holders of that company are already in the city, and others will be here to-morrow, when a conference will be held, at which, it is expected, some satisfactory plan of settlement will be arrived at.

Newton Squire, the chief clerk of the Clearing House, who was arrested Thursday in a civil suit brought by Homer Lee of the Homer Lee Bank Note Company and locked up in Ludlow Street Jail in default of $300 bail, furnished the required bail yesterday and was released. The complaint against him made by Mr. Lee charges him with converting a certificate representing 100 shares of the stock of the Homer Lee Bank Note Company.

When Mr. FASSETT was appointed Collector of this port he admitted his entire ignorance of the business of the Custom House and its requirements, and since his appointment his time has been chiefly spent elsewhere. He has devoted very little time to studying the requirements of the business of the great establishment placed under his charge, and can hardly have made much acquaintance with the details of its operation.

The 300 passengers carried by the Netherlands-American steamship Obdam on her last eastward voyage from this port had a thrilling experience with a mutinous crew. On the second day out the entire engine-room force mutinied, and for two hours the vessel drifted helplessly upon the seas. The second act in the ocean drama was an ineffectual appeal to the men to resume their duties by the engineer officers.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21. -- Two fast miles by Hal Pointer, the victory of Henrietta in the 2:17 class, and the long battle for the Springfield Stake were the features of the last day of the Grand Circuit meeting here.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 21. -- The Executive Committee of the American Canoe Association has elected Charles V. Winne Commodore and William B. Wackerhagen Secretary and Treasurer for the coming year. Mr. Winne is popular in business and social circles in Albany, and is the Captain of the Mohican Canoe Club. He will throw life and energy into the association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the World's Fair, Director General Davis nominated for Chief of the Department of Machinery L.W. Robinson. Mr. Robinson is a Chief Engineer in the United States Navy. At present he is President of the Examining Board of United States Naval Engineers at Philadelphia.

AMHERST, N.S., Aug. 21. -- It is confidently asserted in well-informed circles that a proposal is under consideration by the British and United States Governments to advance the sum necessary to finish the Chignecto Ship Railway, for the former to furnish two-thirds and the latter one-third. The sum of $3,600,000 has already been spent on the work, and there is required for its completion about $1,500.000.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has taken prompt steps to carry into effect the recent arrangement as to promotions in the departmental service at Washington. He has begun a series of conferences with several of the most capable and experienced officials of the various departments (Treasury, Post Office, and War Departments) upon the details of the application of the system.

D ES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 21. -- An item of news that will interest army circles comes from the far-off isle of Japan. There is tinge of romance about it that does not detract from its interest. It relates to Major G.R. Wasson, who for several years was a resident of this city and who left it nearly a year ago.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 21. -- The Republican machine of this State has always been run in the interest of Gen. Harrison when he wished to grind that way and it will work for him next year. He will, if he desires a renomination and is not overwhelmed by the Blaine movement, have the delegation in the next National Republican Convention.

The investigation which the chemists of The Board of Health have been making along the east branch of the Croton River during the present week indicates that the drinking water of this city is constantly subject to every kind of pollution that the presence of inhabitants with their industries near the sources of supply is calculated to produce.

The story of the discussion that took place at the meeting of the Dock Board on Thursday between President Post and Commissioner Cram attracted much attention yesterday. The trouble between the two members of the board arose over the contemplated building of the new dock at the foot of Vesey Street. It has been the custom heretofore to assign the work of dock building to a contractor.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Promptly at 7:30 this morning President Harrison, with his overcoat on his arm, walked from the Arkell cottage alone to the front of the Hotel Balmoral at Mount McGregor, paused a moment to look across the valley, half shrouded in a cloud of mist, and, entering the hotel, joined his selected companions for the day's fishing excursion. An early breakfast had been prepared, and all sat down together.

It must be a consolation to good President Harrison to know that there is one Republican paper in the country which is not edited by a Blaine maniac. That paper is of course "Prince" Russell's, the Helena (Mon.) Journal. In it the Prince stands up for his father with a faithfulness like that shown by the youngster on the burning deck some years ago.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Although high waves were running this morning, yet the canoeists crossed the lake, ten miles to Burlington. The water was too heavy for canoes and the three races were not called until afternoon. The first was the sailing race, in which these were entered:

ST. LOUIS, Mo. Aug. 21. -- The Post-Dispatch this afternoon said that a scheme is on foot by which the militia of all States will be put under national pay and supervision. It was started by officers of the regular army at the encampment of the State militia, at Camp Wickham, the other day, and circulars and personal letters concerning it are now flying thick and fast about the country.

The American Protective Tariff League has repeatedly shown in its weekly journal its liking for Trusts and similar combinations, and sometimes has sharply attacked certain Republican journals for professing to believe that the party was in earnest when it denounced Trusts in the national platform of 1888.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- The New-Yorks had a soft snap here to-day. They won the game with comparative ease, and are once more within a point of their Boston rivals. Chicago, however, continues to win and still holds a good lead.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 21. -- The British delegates to the International Socialist Workmen's Congress at a meeting to-day adopted resolutions in favor of the abolition of piece work and in favor of calling the next congress the International Workers' Congress. At to-day's session of the congress debate was resumed on the report on international combination, and the amended resolution offered yesterday was passed, with the exception of the last clause.

Collector Fassett was at the Custom House yesterday for the first time since Tuesday. Soon after his arrival in the morning he called several of the heads of divisions into his private room, one at a time, and a messenger locked the door so that nobody could disturb the conference. Just what was said at these conferences none of those present would say.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 21. -- In conversation with a newspaper man yesterday morning. Gen. Alger remarked on the handsome reception accorded President Harrison "If Blaine had been here how the people would have crowded to hear him," exclaimed the General. "It is wonderful what a powerful attraction his name has.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- In conversing with Admiral Gervais, when she received him on board her yacht, Queen Victoria said: "I am delighted with the spectacle and pleased that the weather has permitted me to inspect your ships. I hope you will have a good voyage home."

HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 21. -- Judge Samuel W. Cobb of the police court, with Attorney General Barnard and Solicitor Mitchell, accompanied by citizens, went to Almy's room in the Wheelock House this morning to conduct the preliminary examination of Christie Warden's murderer. Almy, in reply to Attorney General Barnard's questions as to how he felt, said that he had not had any sleep and had been in pain all night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A large number of papers, for the most part of a technical character, were to-day read before the several sections of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. A few, however, were of popular interest. A paper entitled "An Experiment in Human Stirpiculture," was read before the anthropological section by it author, Anita Newcomb McGee.

" I will yet be heard from in connection with my concessions from the Chinese Government. Just wait a while and, in spite of all the newspapers have said against me, I will yet have something to show that I had a valuable property in my railroad and banking franchises in China. I am not through with those enterprises yet."

Some light has been thrown upon the readiness of Senator QUAY to resign from the Republican National Committee by the action of his convention at Harrisburg and by his evident manoeuvring to place himself at the head of the Blaine movement and put himself in a position to be a power in the next National Convention of his party and to take the lead in the campaign of 1892.

A letter received by the Methodist Episcopal Missionary Society from the Rev. John Walley, in charge of the mission at Wuhu, China, gives ome interesting details concerning the recent lot at that place. He says, under date of May 19:

More light is thrown upon the tin-plate champion's essays on wages by something that occurred in St. Louis last Wednesday. After he discovered that it might not be possible for him to import sheet-iron rollers under contract without interference from the Treasury Department, he engaged eleven sheet-iron rollers in Philadelphia, through the agency of a high-tariff newspaper, and on Wednesday these men arrived in St. Louis.

More light is thrown upon the tin-plate champion's essays on wages by something that occurred in St. Louis last Wednesday. After he discovered that it might not be possible for him to import sheet-iron rollers under contract without interference from the Treasury Department, he engaged eleven sheet-iron rollers in Philadelphia, through the agency of a high-tariff newspaper, and on Wednesday these men arrived in St. Louis.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21. -- What promises to be a novel and interesting feature at the Chicago World's Fair will be a hospital ward exhibit. Mrs. Mary Cummings, late of London, England, and one of the best trained nurses in St. Louis, has been put in charge by the World's Fair Directory. Mrs. Cummings intends to make the exhibit worthy of the occasion.

Many anglers prefer the dog days in which to fish in salt water. They know that the weakfish generally bite better at this time of the year, and that for the most part they settle over oyster beds or in favorite channels to look out for food. The sea bass and the blackfish also have no prejudice against the warm days, and are ready to take any food that comes along.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- Since the day when THE TIMES recently published an account of the differences existing between Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi, commanding the North Atlantic fleet, and Acting Rear Admiral John G. Walker, commanding the squadron of evolution, fragmentary statements on the same subject have from time to time appeared in these columns.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- A few weeks ago the Nationalists of this city gave the public a new sensation by petitioning the City Council to establish a "fuel department." They asked that the city should open a coal yard from which to supply an purchasers with coal at cost price. The public received the announcement of the scheme with a general smile of incredulity.

It seems hardly probable that the action of the Geographical Congress at Berne recommending the adoption of the Greenwich meridian as a universal prime in the reckoning of longitude and time will be followed by very practical results. Seven years ago an international conference at Washington, assembled with a special reference to the consideration of this question, made the same choice, yet it failed to be accepted by the nations there represented.

Residents of and visitors to the Adirondack region are encountering a very disagreeable manifestation of autocratic power this season. They are being warned off land which for years they have been in the habit of traversing, and they have been threatened with arrest if they dared to fish in lakes and streams which from time immemorial have been practically open to the public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $149,306,450, as follows: Currency sixes, $9,025,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $5,855,000; 4 per cents, $117,850,150; 2 per cents, $16,576.300.

" What do yon think of a nitro-glycerine picnic?" writes a young woman spending the Summer in Western New-York. "I was invited to such a one last week, which turned out to be the shooting of an oil well -- a much less ominous-sounding affair. We started early in the morning, three carriage loads of us, almost all Summer visitors from Detroit, New-York, and Washington, to whom the sight was a great novelty.

ESKDALE, Cumberland, Aug. 6. -- Wordsworth's and Coleridge's country has been mightily be-painted on canvas and Bristol boards since the days of the lake poets, and to such an extent was this carried that the Lake District foreshadowed the fate of the Hudson River Valley by becoming available no longer for the landscape artists.

The last performance of "The Grand Duchess" will be given at the Casino to-morrow evening. Johann Strauss's operatic burlesque called "Indigo" will be produced Tuesday night. "Indigo" has already been performed here in French and German, but never before in English.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 22. -- This has been another week of good trotting in Kentucky. The races were in progress at Maysville and Lebanon. Next week they will be going on at Lexington and Springfield. The races here are expected to be equal to anything yet seen on the Grand Circuit this year, from the fact that all the horses that have shown well in Kentucky this season will start during the Lexington meeting.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- The agitation of young Lamare, the educated lad of nineteen who is leading the turbulent wine growers in the champagne districts, is the outcome of endeavors upon the part of the large wine companies to acquire and unite the small vineyards, with the object of localizing and stamping out phylloxera.

SARATOGA, Aug. 22. -- Los Angeles had a walkover for the Morrissey Stakes, at a mile and five-eighths, here this afternoon, and so sure were the managers of the track that La Tosca would have another for the Pocahontas Stakes, at a mile and three-sixteenths, that they added another race, so that the people could not complain that they did not get their money's worth.

Many readers of THE TIMES have been anxiously watching its columns for the last few days for an answer to the question implied in the edition of that Journal on the 8th inst., to wit: "The national significance of the public functions participated in by a few of the officers of the white squadron, and the public men of New-York in particular, and of all our sea coast towns in general."

While surveying parties are examining the routes by which it will be possible to connect the railroads of Mexico with those of Chile and the Argentine Republic, and Russia is about to make a road across Siberia to the Pacific, it is not surprising that the eyes of engineers should turn to the virgin soil of Central Africa and to the vast regions there which cannot forever remain undisturbed by the railroad builder.

The Doorbell (timidly.) -- Ting, ting! Yellowplush, (in an armchair before the fire reading the Morning Post.) -- "Yesterday, at St. George's Church, Hanover Square, by the Lord Bishop of Lawn, the Lord John Fitzwhiskers to Amelia Frances Annabel the lovely and accomplished daughter of Samuel Botts, Esq., of Portland Place. After an elegant dejeune at Lord Tufton's mansion in Cavendish Square the happy pair set off -- "

NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 22. -- Once in every twelvemonth the State of Connecticut mobilizes its active militia at this point. This force, the National Guard, is organized into a single brigade, comprised of four regiments and two separate companies of infantry, and a battery of artillery. To each of the infantry regiments there is attached a signal corps and a machinegun platoon.

SIASCONSET, Mass., Aug. 22. -- For short, the natives of Nantucket call this fanny old fishermen's hamlet "'Sconset." It is over 200 years old. It is fifty miles from New-Bedford, and is the point of Uncle Sam's domain the furthest out in the Atlantic Ocean. By swimming due east two thousand and odd miles I could reach Spain. I haven't tried it yet, but fishermen tell me so. Fishermen never lie.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The David B. Hill method of carrying caucuses has been fully exemplified in this city this week. Democrats who believe in fair play are disgusted with the action of the Hill heelers, and the local Democratic organ, the Oswego Palladium, characterizes it as discreditable and injurious to the party.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The weather this week has been more than beautiful; enough rain has fallen to keep the dust down, but not enough to make the roads muddy, so that driving has been very enjoyable.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The great Ocean Grove Camp Meeting is the loadstone that has attracted monster crowds to the Twin-Cities-by-the-Sea this week. To-day's arrivals were very large, and it is estimated that there are nearly one hundred thousand persons in the two resorts. There were lively scenes on the beach and at the hotels to-night.

One of the most sensational duels of modern times was the meeting between Gen. Boulanger, the youngest, and at that time the most famous, General of the French Nation, and M. Floquet, Prime Minister of France. The place of encounter was at Neuilly-sur-Seine, on the morning of July 13, 1888, on the grounds of the Comte de Dillon, a short distance from the capital.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- During the six years between 1882 and 1888 the expenditures of the seven great European powers on armies and navies amounted to no less than 974,000,000. Since 1888 it is estimated that the average annual expenditure has increased by one-fifth. In 1882, when, with the exception of England's small troubles in Egypt, the whole world was at peace, serious negotiations were begun with a view to a general disarmament.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 22. -- The visiting Frenchmen and their entertainers passed a comparatively quiet day. Numbers of the French naval officers witnessed the military review by the Duke of Connaught and inspected the dockyards and various other objects of interest, while others visited London.

The bulls have had a market to their own satisfaction the past week. It was so buoyant in the early part of it, that the large realizations failed to make a serious impression on prices. Trading diminished, but quotations have held so firmly that the closing prices of yesterday were very near to the highest of the week, and showed substantial advances over the closing of the previous Saturday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 22. -- Six suits were filed in the Federal Court to-day against N. Hoffheimer of New-York, formerly of Louisville, who is charged with fraudulently importing and tampering with whisky shipped to Bermuda. The object aimed is the confiscation by the Government of the whisky now held by Surveyor Collier pending the final decision of the question.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- Out along the dusty Boulevard Bineau, runs a tramway; and, as if the road was not good enough, they are making it more modern and new. Fresh stones are being laid and nothing is lacking but electricity to render it thoroughly in tune with all the modern improvements. Along this uncomfortable highway, are cottage homes on both sides, shaded by real trees, in miniature gardens.

The speech with which Major MCKINLEY opened his canvass in Ohio yesterday is calculated to make the Democratic leaders regret that they put the free-coinage plank in their platform. The Ohio Napoleon evidently knows the strategy of the original NAPOLEON, who said that the secret of success was to force the fighting where you were strongest and the enemy weakest.

The exclusive announcement in THE TIMES that the Brooklyn Democratic leaders had decided to nominate District Attorney Ridgway for Mayor was a surprise to a great many of the "boys," and at first they were inclined to scout the idea, but now they have all fallen into line. They are singing Mr. Ridgway's praises to the skies and are preparing to bet unlimited sums on his election.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22. -- Major McKinley formally opened his campaign for Governor at Niles to-day with the largest first meeting of any campaign in the history of the State.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 22. -- The gayety here continues, and entertainments the past week have been numerous. Mrs. Carman gave a moonlight drive a few evenings ago, and Mr. Beard also entertained a party in the same way.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The seventh heat of the stake race was won by Happy Bee this forenoon, ending this event in favor of the speedy four-year-old. The fliers continue their engagements at Hartford, at Charter Oak Park, where they will be occupied during the usual fair days, beginning Tuesday.

The "demonstrations" of the French squadron in Russian and British waters belong to a recent international condition which is intrinsically very strange. They are literally "demonstrations" meant to impress other and possibly hostile powers with the strength of the nation that makes them; and this is the motive that underlies the superficial courtesies of the occasion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- To-day was an off day in the national tennis tournament. It was sort of preparatory to the great matches of next week. P.H. Hovey beat M.D. Smith, but had another hard five-set match to do it. Valentine G. Hall defeated C.T. Lee, the New-England champion. Hovey is now in the finals, while Hobart and Hall are one round behind and will contest on Monday to decide which shall meet Hovey.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Simply to see the fire engines going at full speed and to enjoy the excitement incident to a disastrous conflagration, three boys, whose ages range from nine to thirteen years, have set fire to nine warehouses in the business section of the city during the past four weeks. This morning the juvenile incendiaries were arraigned before Magistrate Milligan.
The demand for American screws is so great in England and Germany that a screw company of Providence has established a branch factory in Leeds. England, and will put up another on the Continent.

The office of the President of a big club is one of honor; that of the Secretary is one of work; that of the Treasurer is one of work and responsibility combined. In the case of most clubs the Treasurer has nearly, if not quite, as much work to do as the Secretary, and, besides that, he is responsible for anywhere from $10,000 to $500,000.
" It is said that Arabian horses have deteriorated, Count. Can it be true?"

Mrs. Martin had seen something of the world beyond England before she departed for the land in which she gathered the material for this instructive and sprightly volume. Incidentally, we learn that she had been in Brazil and the West Indies, and that some knowledge of Africa had been obtained in Egypt, where, all unconscious of what was before her, she once visited an ostrich farm belonging to the Khedive.

Mayor Gleason of Long Island City has once more gotten himself into trouble by acting contrary to the city's charter, and his well-laid scheme to gain for himself voters for the coming Queens County election has been exposed. Gleason stock has been on the wane for a long time. Nobody has realized this better than Gleason himself.

The Beattys were quite a large family in the Fall of 1861. Their home was, and had been for three generations, in Beatty's Creek -- "Betty's Crik," the people down there call it. This creek is an unmapped and not at all an affluent tributary of the Tennessee, rising in the heart of the Cumberland Range, just south of the Kentucky line.

Repeated proddings beneath President Beers's official ribs have finally induced that somewhat reticent gentleman to come to the front with another "statement," this time through the mouth of the New-York Life's attorney, who also, as it happens, is one of the company's Trustees. The statement in question was carefully prepared under Mr. Beers's direction, and the Evening Post kindly loaned its columns to furnish the desired publicity.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Hon. Elbridge T. Gerry of Yew-York. City gave $200 and Mrs. J.S. Wright $300 toward completing the Episcopal Church at Griffin's Corners, Delaware County.

CHEROKEE, Iowa, Aug. 22. -- Gov. Boies opened the Iowa campaign here to-day in the presence of a great crowd of people. The day was cold and raw, which prevented an outdoor meeting; consequently a great many who had come to town were unable to hear him, for the opera house, large and commodious as it is, could not contain over half the crowd which massed itself about its doors and struggled for an entrance.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Keefe pitched winning ball for the Phillies against his old comrades to-day and New-York was beaten. It was a long-drawn-out game, full of accidents. Bastian started in to play short stop for the Phillies, but was hit on the finger the first time at the bat and retired in favor of Morelock.
Quite a large number of belated tourists took passage for Europe on yesterday's fleet of outgoing steamships. Following is a complete list of those who sailed:
BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Commissioners appointed by the Court of Chancery have partitioned the real estate in this city which the late Rufus Story bequeathed to his four surviving children.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 22. -- The body of Capt. William Renton, who, take him all in all, was the greatest of the Washington pioneers, was buried in this city recently. The occasion was an important one, for the death of Capt. Renton may be said to close the chapter of pioneer history in this State, if not indeed, in the Union.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- There is no abatement in the excitement arising from the agitation in regard to the duties on grain imported into Germany. Gloomy reports as to the prospects of the harvest in the provinces continue to be received. Everything confirms the belief that the Winter of 1891-2 will be one of the worst, so far as food is concerned, on record.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 22. -- The Southern Pacific Railroad and Steamship Company has withdrawn its line of steamers which heretofore made weekly trips between New-York and Galveston during the cotton season, and will have them ply between New-York and New-Orleans.

According to that entertaining and ingenious writer, Mr. FRANCIS GALTON, an almost infallible method of identifying human beings has been developed. The proposed method is the examination and registration of the marks upon finger tips, which Mr. GALTON explains in the current Nineteenth Century.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company is projecting plans for the building of a branch from the main line near Drakesville to the south end of the lake. At present the hotels are reached by stage and steamers making three-mile trips to connect with the trains. It is probable, too, that the railroad company will secure Bertrand Island, a wooded tract of fifty acres, as a terminus.

It is doubtful if there ever was a year in the history of the midsummer trotting circuit when so many good things went wrong as during the campaign now in progress. Public form has proved an expensive criterion in the last few weeks, and up to the close of the fifth meeting the big speculators had received enough hard blows to knock them clear out of the betting ring.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 22. -- Marvin Smith of Montville, should he live until next Tuesday, will be 107 years old. He was born on Aug. 25, 1784, in Montville, and has always lived there. For over 100 years he has dwelt within two miles of his birthplace. He has been twice married. His first wife, Anna Newton, who was the mother of his children, was born in 1784 and died in 1844.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 22. -- A week ago an old soldier in Rush County of the name of Sergt. Henry Embree had a well dug. At the depth of twenty feet he found well-preserved vases and articles of earthenware, which he now keeps as a memento of past ages. Rush County is in Western Kansas, in the treeless part of the State, and has been, as far as the memory of man reaches, a desert.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 22. -- Several months ago the Sentinel, the organ of the protectionists, devoted a large amount of space to an account of a visit of a number of local business men to a manufactory where, it was claimed, a large business was being done in the manufacture of worsteds and diagonals such as are used by merchant tailors in the finest qualities of men's clothing.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Lenox has been rather quiet for the last week or two, but it will awaken to renewed life when the cottagers return from the seashore, where many of them have been the greater part of this month. Plans are now being made for the annual tennis tournament, which is to be held this season earlier than usual.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The Newport season has reached its height this week. Not that there will be no more entertainments, outdoor sports, and social festivities, but that the last week has been marked by a larger number of such events than any previous week of the present season or than any of the coming weeks will show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Treasury Department has in contemplation early and important changes in the composition of the revenue cutter fleet. The past and present work of the service, officials say, has made it imperative that many of the vessels be replaced by a new and more efficient type of craft, and to this end Congress will be asked during the coming Winter to liberally appropriate for the pressing needs of the service.

Among the concessions obtained from the Czar as the result of Mr. Arnold White's recent mission to Russia on behalf of Baron Hirsch there were two which will probably have considerable effect on the situation with regard to the persecution of the Jews in that country. The first is the practical abolition of the costly passport system.

Properly to characterize the late Summer millinery of this season the word picturesque would have to be written in capital letters. The outdoor life, more generally approved each year, is especially favorable to the development of the picturesque in millinery. The long list of open-air sports calls for, or at least permits, headgear of such surprising tendencies that it is impossible to imagine what vagary may be next brought out.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Never before in the history of the St. Lawrence as a resort have such crowds been seen on the river as this week. The hotels are filled to overflowing, all the boats have carried their full complements of passengers, and a more successful season could not be hoped for.

ELBERON, Aug. 22. -- Col Jones of the famed Elberon Hotel was talking over his reminiscences of notable men whom he had met a few days ago, and eventually, of course, his conversation drifted around to the death of President Garfield. His narration of the circumstances that lodged the suffering President on the Jersey sea coast is somewhat at variance with the generally accepted version.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Democrats of Jefferson County held their district conventions in this city to-day and elected delegates to the State Convention, at the same time giving the boom of Roswell P. Flower, which was started in this city a few months ago, a substantial lift.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- With the exception of the election of officers next Tuesday, the work of the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science came to an end to-day.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Aug. 22. -- Nicholas Williams of Beaver Meadow, this (Carbon) county, relates a thrilling escape that he had from angry bear on Quakake Mountain before daylight on Wednesday morning. He was slowly driving up the incline between Weatherby and Beaver Meadow in the darkness, when his horse suddenly stopped short and sniffed suspiciously at a dark object on the roadside.

J.S. Roddy, the Princeton student who accompanied the Manhattan team to Europe, arrived home last week. He is not satisfied with his performances on the other side; he had a delightful trip, though. July 15, at the games of the Manchester Club, he sprained the sinews of his leg and was warned by his physician not to take any athletic exercise for a year.

We fear that it is in the malicious spirit of the "deadly parallel column" that our neghbor, the Evening Post, discusses with so much elaboration the question whether the Mugwumps would be allowed to support Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE for Governor, and the further question whether, if they persisted in doing so without permission, the "regulars" would not deem that an excuse for defeating him.

The announcement that the indictment against Dr. BRIGGS for heresy is substantially completed will interest all persons within the communion of the Presbyterian Church and a great many thousands without that communion. The questions involved affect the Presbyterian Church scarcely more than they affect every other orthodox Christian body.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The anti-Hill spirit which was expected to develop in the Democratic County Convention held at Horseheads this afternoon was crushed out before reaching the convention, although there was a strong undercurrent in that direction.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22. -- The Pacific Union Club, an aristocratic organization and one of the leading clubs in the West, is reveling in a scandal which is to-day the talk of the town.

In the maze of conjecture and uncertainty as to the cause of the terrible calamity in Park Place yesterday the fact that the wrecked building was a flimsy construction of the Buddensiek order appears with tolerable clearness. A building of good material solidly put together does not crumble and collapse utterly, even under the shock of a severe explosion, as this Park Place edifice plainly did.

The regret that we should say that the Democrats would feel in giving Major MCKINLEY a chance to make the silver issue prominent must be all the keener as they perceive-how weak he is on the issue of the tariff to which they ought to have shut him up. The moment he touches that he has to take the defensive, and his defense is feeble.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Railroad men unite in saying that the present season has been the most successful in the history of the Catskill Summer boarding region. Last Saturday 1,100 persons were taken into the mountains by the Ulster and Delaware Railroad, and on the Saturday two weeks previous the number was 1,720.
The first championship games of the Long Island Amateur League were not very successful. Only a few hundred spectators were present, and the events, as a rule, were poorly contested.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The delegates to the Republican State Convention elected from the First Oneida District to-day are James S. Sherman, Charles S. Symonds, William M. White, Hugh F. Thomas, J.R. Swan, William H. Gloher, Charles Philo; alternates, James Miller, William H. Roberts, Daniel McGuicken, F.D. Haak, Jr., N.M. Pierce, Patrick Griffin, C. Dewing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- A crowd estimated at 80,000 was at the Garfield Park track this afternoon to see the race for the ten-thousand-dollar stake which Kingston had been sent on from the East to win for his thoroughly-confident owner, M.F. Dwyer. The race was at a mile and an eighth, and Kingston, ridden by Tony Hamilton, carried 124 pounds.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 22. -- Hancock Neagle, Justice of the Peace in this city, has a relic which he prizes highly -- the autograph of the late President Chester A. Arthur, cut into a board when Arthur was a student at Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., in 1853.

PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 23 -- Post Office Inspector Brown has been in this city for several days, and the outcome of his investigations will probably result in the dismissal, if not the arrest, of Postmaster Hugh Mulholland. Serious charges have been made against the Postmaster, and the indications are that these charges are far from groundless.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23. -- The doubt that arose a day or two ago about President Harrison's coming is not yet settled. Evidently Secretary Tracy and those who wanted the President to come find him less easy to move than they had counted on. The Secretary early in the week told his friends that the President was coming.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- It is not expected in navy circles here that Rear Admiral Gherardi will be ousted from command of the North Atlantic station as long as he insists upon his right to serve out his three years.

A pamphlet bearing the title "The American Question in Haiti" has made its appearance in this city. It is by John D. Metzger -- at least his name is on the title page. He speaks highly of himself in his book, but declares that the articles on the Haitian question published in the New-York papers "deserve very little attention."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The extraordinary eagerness with which the "Big Six" of the Plainfield Common Council has pushed through the project to give a water works franchise to J.M. Low Co. of Kingston N.Y., has all along been viewed with great suspicion by the public, and it is expected that the litigation that is soon to be begun in the matter will bring to light some highly interesting developments.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23. -- President Harrison has spent another delightfully quiet day at the Grand Union Hotel. He remained in his room all day and received very few visitors. Several persons asked for him, but of the may that called few were invited in. The President read most of the time, and he was charmed to be allowed to enjoy the seclusion of his own room.

The friends of the present management of the New-York Life Insurance Company must feel, after reading Mr. Hornblower's statement, which was referred to in yesterday's TIMES, that it has done the company more harm than good. It has certainly placed Mr. Beers, who is Mr. Hornblower's commander in chief, in a more unenviable attitude than that which he formerly occupied.

Representatives from all the German Schuetzen Bunds of New-York and Brooklyn met yesterday afternoon in the New-York Saengerbunde Hall, 12 St. Mark's Place, to consider the arrangements for the great international shooting festival which it has been decided by the German societies to hold in this vicinity in 1892. The meeting, which numbered close upon one hundred delegates, was presided over by Capt. Adolph Ludwig, the President of the United Association of Schuetzen Bunds.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Aug. 23. -- Don Bruce, City Marshal, was shot and fatally wounded last night by Charlie Hawkins, a desperado, who was lynched by a mob a few hours later. Hawkins was in a quarrel when Bruce requested him to cease his disturbance. Hawkins fired three shots at Bruce, each bullet taking effect. He fired twice more, but missed, and started to run, with Bruce following.

F.D. Beatley, the young Superintendent of the Rockaway Beach Gas Works, is missing, together with the books and papers and, it is alleged, $300 of the corporation's funds. He went away about ten days ago and all efforts made to trace him have failed. He is about twenty-five years of age and has been in the firm's employ since the Spring.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 23. -- Friday night the body of a well-dressed man was found floating in the river near the city and taken to the morgue. This afternoon it was recognized as the remains of George J. Osborne, Superintendent of he Milwaukee company's elevators at Minneapolis. Mr. Osborne disappeared nearly week ago and an investigation into his affairs was ordered.

In order to allay public suspicion, and in order to permit its agents in America and elsewhere to deny the accusations which THE NEW-YORK TIMES is heaping upon the head of President Beers, the New-York Life Insurance Company has brought a libel suit against THE TIMES for $1,000,000 damages. The news of this suit has been received in America with considerable merriment.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 23. -- Harper Brothers' Circus, billed for two performances at Thompsonville Saturday, came to grief in the evening. The performers struck about 8 o'clock for back wages. It was announced that there would be no performance and money would be refunded. The crowd became excited, cut the guy ropes, set the tent on fire, smashed seats and wagons, and cut up harness.

TRENTON, Aug. 23. -- The revolt against the bosses and their figurehead -- Mayor Haynes -- in Newark must make Gov. Abbett and his clique feel very uncomfortable. This revolt has three distinct and marked phases. People will not have Haynes because, in the first place, he is Haynes. They have had enough of Haynes as a personality all by himself.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 23. -- A fearful cloudburst broke over Pottsville this afternoon, and the water poured down in torrents for an hour. The thunder and lightning were awful, the latter doing considerable damage.
RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The race between the Nahli, owned by Washington E. Connor, and the Enigma, owned by Frederick Oakes, took place yesterday afternoon, in Sandy Hook Bay.

Our cable dispatches yesterday morning gave a most striking statement of what would be saved to Europe by a reduction of one-half in the military force and expenditure of the chief powers. For the past nine years alone, it would have amounted to $2,400,000,000, while nearly 3,000,000 men in the prime of youth would have been restored to labor and production.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23. -- The negroes of this section are again excited over a scheme by which they are to be transported to Liberia. The author of the present movement is the Rev. Benjamin Gaston of Monrovia, Liberia. He arrived in Atlanta three weeks ago, held a meeting at Scheltz Hall, and unfolded his scheme. Gaston explained that he only asked for the sum of $15,000 to carry over the first load of negroes.

We suppose that there is still surviving in the minds of some Republicans the impression implanted by the Tribune that Mr. LOWELL as a diplomatist was deficient in the "American" spirit. If any there be who retain this view, we commend them to the comments of the London Spectator of Aug. 15, on the occasion of Mr. LOWELL'S death. It says:

The competitive trial of six-pounder rapid-fire guns, arranged by the Navy Department and soon to take place, is made doubly interesting since all three of the inventions invited to contest are American, while a substantial reward is offered for success in a Government contract for fifty of the pattern that furnishes the most desirable results.

The more the Rapid-Transit Commission's change of purpose in regard to the underground railroad in Broadway is considered, the more unaccountable it seems. When that route was decided upon it was declared that the "general plan of construction" below Forty-second Street was for a tunnel at such a depth that the surface would not be disturbed nor the foundations of buildings endangered.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- St. Louis cotton factors do not fear the formation of a cotton trust by the Alliance. That organization's scheme is said to have been originated by Mr. E.M. Stoeber, a prominent farmer near Columbia, S.C., and is in brief to organize trust, companies in every county in the cotton belt, each with a capital of $20,000 or $30,000.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 23. -- The people of Schuylkill County, and especially of Pottsville, are looking forward with daily quickening interest to the coming of October. For on the first day of that month here will be unveiled a monument to the valor of the volunteers who went from this region to fight for the Union, a memorial of such of them -- and they were many -- who were destined to return never again.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- A thousand things are said and thousands more will be in explanation of the action of the Republican Convention at Harrisburg. But the main sense of it lies on the surface, and he who runs may read. The disasters of last year have weakened Senator Quay to such a degree that he is now struggling to keep his hold on the party.
Please answer the following questions and oblige a New-York Life policy holder.

The latest semi-official report from Bar Harbor is made by Senator HOAR, who says: "Mr. BLAINE seems about as he has for some years past, in all respects." Like the Delphic oracle and Bunsby's aphorism, the value of this report depends much on the interpretation and application of it. There are "respects" in which Mr. BLAINE "for some years past" has "seemed" to Senator HOAR an active but very disagreeable person.

Dreadful as were the first details of the destruction of the Taylor Building in Park Place, the lapse of nearly forty-eight hours has not served to modify or make them one whit the less shocking. That 100 people met a horrible death when the structure, numbered from 68 to 74, fell to the street and caught fire is almost beyond the possibility of a doubt.

The tired firemen had not had a chance to recover from the exertions they had been obliged to make at the Park Place disaster when another lively fire called them to prompt action early yesterday morning. This fire also had its fatal results, as it caused the death of the Assistant Foreman of Engine Company No. 27, James H. Shute, one of the oldest and best firemen in the department.

The appearance of the second of these two volumes gives occasion for a renewal of one's regrets at the poor health of Mr. Leslie Stephen. It was he who began this biographical enterprise, and to him we are most indebted for the success with which it has been now carried forward to a volume which must be about the central milestone on this long biographical journey.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- The committee appointed at the New-York convention of the National General Service Corps to formulate a plan of organization and draft by-laws met today in the Army and Navy Veterans' Hall, at Eighth and Vine Streets. The committee was composed of delegates from the divisions of the General Service Corps of Philadelphia, the commands from Fort Hamilton, New-York; the Newark (N.J.) Command, and the Phil Sheridan Command of New-York.

Mr. George Jones, the proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who died on Wednesday of last week, in Maine, at the age of eighty, was not in the literary sense of the word, a great editor. He rarely, if ever, contributed to the editorial columns of his own paper, yet he most closely controlled its policy, its political course, and its journalistic tone.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- Gov. Campbell was quite comfortable to-day, although he spent a sleepless night. He still has a high fever at times, but is very hopeful of a change in his condition to-morrow. He is anxious to leave the city for a week or ten days to visit the seashore, expressing the opinion that salt-water air will soon restore him to his former good health.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Camp-meeting Sunday has come and gone. The crowd that participated in the meetings was the largest ever on the camp ground, and the services were unusually impressive. The day was cool and pleasant. The big crowd already on the ground was augmented by thousands of visiting farmers and residents of near-by coast resorts and towns.

Probity, astuteness, and courage were the distinctive qualities of the late Mr. George Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Those whose memories go back forty years can recall the news-vender of Albany on the old "Museum" corner. In two years from that time Mr. Jones established THE NEW-YORK TIMES and put into it his best life and work.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 23. -- The affairs in Choctaw County, where in the fanatical family of Robert Sims has come in conflict with the United States, promises to become of unusual prominence, by reason of the belief on the part of Sims's followers that Sims is the temporal manifestation of their God.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The political cauldron in this county is boiling, and from present indications there will be a sharp fight between the two great political parties. As far as the Prohibition Party in this county is concerned, it does not amount to much. For several weeks an organizer has been at work endeavoring to proselyte the farmers, but the work has been fruitless.

OFF BEMINI, Bahama Banks, Aug. 24. -- The revenue cutter McLane left Key West in spite of the predicted brewing of a hurricane by the signal officers, having in tow the wrecking schooner Cora, with coal for the Merritt tug. Supplies were taken on the McLane for the officers of the wrecked schooner El Dorado.

A political contest of unusual interest and of more than merely local importance for the office of Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation has resulted in the-choice of JOEL B. MAYES, the present incumbent, over D.W. BUSHYHEAD and G.W. BENGE. As usual, fraud is charged; but should Chief MAYES make-good his claim, as he is likely to do, being elected on the face of the returns, he will serve a third successive term as Chief.

NEWPORT, Aug. 24. -- Mrs. William Astor gave a grand ball to-night in honor of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Jr. It was a very elaborate affair, fully equaling, if not eclipsing, any other event of this most brilliant social season. The cottagers, of course, all responded to their invitations and enjoyed the Astor hospitality, dispensed with that lavishness which is characteristic of the family.

Almost in the same locality that the Cunard steamship Servia broke down on her recent voyage from this port, the Hamburg-American liner Suevia was passed Saturday, with two blades of her propeller gone. It is a singular coincidence that the first news of the Suevia's mishap should be brought to this city by the vessel whose serious accident in the same locality caused so much excitement.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24. -- By just 1 run the Giants won the game here to-day. Cincinnati hit Ewing hard enough to win any ordinary contest, but New-York came in with three hits in the seventh that scored 2 runs and won the game.

Since THE TIMES began its exposures of the notoriously bad business management of President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company frequent reference has been made to the company's investments in the Plaza Hotel, at Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, and the Yosemite Apartment House, formerly Holbrook Hall, at the southwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Sixty-second Street.

But little testimony of value concerning the cause of the disaster in Park Place has been added to that which was available yesterday morning. The evidence still tends to show that the building, already dangerously weak and greatly overweighted, yielded readily to the slight shock of what appears to have been an explosion of gases in or near the front part of the basement.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES continues the daily exposures of crookedness in the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company as if no libel suit for $1,000,000 damages had ever been brought by the company, and one is led to believe that THE TIMES has pretty good proof for what it publishes. According to its reports, statements to which President Beers swore are false in nearly all details, and have been so for many years.

The latest official analysis of the water brought to New-York by the Croton Aqueduct has revealed so much contamination that it has determined the Board of Health to make a further examination of the Croton Basin. Of course it is essential to the health of the city that this examination should result in removing the causes of the contamination.
SIR: I have read your report of an interview with Mr. Hornblower, in the Evening Post of today, respecting the Banta charges against Beers and their investigation four years ago.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24. -- Interest in the suit brought by J.E. Goodwin, a sub-lesse of convict labor at the Briceville mine, to enjoin the State Board of Prison Inspectors from carrying out their order for the removal of the convicts from the mine, is very strong. Judge McAllister will render his decision in a day or two.

The Monmouth Park Racing Association will resume racing at Jerome Park this afternoon, it being the last day of the Monmouth meeting at that track, as to-morrow is one of the New-York Club's dates. A good card is announced, and, if the rain does not entirely ruin the track, there should be some good sport, particularly if Firenzi starts in the Monmouth Handicap.

The United States gunboat cruisers Bennington and Concord have completed their forty-eight hours' inspection trial. The Concord is lying off Twenty-third Street, North River. She sails to-day for Bar Harbor to rejoin the squadron of evolution. The Bennington is in the lower bay. She is expected at the navy yard either to-day or to-morrow.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- It was hard to tell this morning which created the most excitement at the American Canoe Association's meet, the single paddling race for ladies or an accident which overtook one of the members yesterday.

The people of Newark have had to choose between river water polluted by the sewage of a neighboring town and water from wells polluted by the sewage of their own city. Under advice from the local Board of Health, many of them have ceased to take river water from the city mains and have procured supplies from wells which for long time have not been used.
BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Col. W.W. Dudley was interviewed to-day by a Post reporter. Here is a sample of the conversation:

READING, Penn., Aug. 24. -- At Hamburg, this county, at noon to-day 701 Antwerp carrier pigeons, which were received from New-York several days ago for a grand tournament between Hamburg and New-York and surrounding cities, were released. Owing to the oppressive weather they flew rather slow at the start and separated into two flocks.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24. -- Premier Abbott in the Senate this afternoon announced that the Canadian Government, with the approval of the imperial authorities, had decided to allow American live cattle to be slaughtered within the Dominion. For several years past, he said, American cattle had been shipped in bond in considerable numbers through Canadian territory between one point and another within the United States, as between Detroit and Niagara.

So much has been said in the New-York papers of late with regard to impurities in the city's water supply and the non-observance of the laws made for its protection that it seems only just that some plea be made in behalf of those who are so unfortunate as to possess homes along the streams and water courses chosen by the great metropolis for her water supply.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Search is being made by detectives for Ellen Brunn and her little daughter, who disappeared from their home in this city June 17. Ellen is the wife of a Swede, head gardener for Charles W. McCutchen of Washington Park, North Plainfield. She came home from a trip to New-York on the day named in a state of intoxication.
Secretary Crickmore announces the following weights for the Jersey Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, for three-year olds, to be run at Morris Park on Thursday afternoon:

The very distinct utterance of President HARRISON at Albany last week on the currency question has had one consequence which was, perhaps, not unintended, and which is interesting. It has given rise to considerable discussion in various quarters as to what position Mr. BLAINE may feel inclined to take on the same question.

Assistant Secretary SOLEY'S complacent dismissal of Rear Admiral GHERARDI'S report concerning the extraordinary behavior of Rear Admiral WALKER at Port au Prince as a mere discussion of "the question of the regulations applicable to their respective squadrons in the situation then existing at Port au Prince" is, of course, not final.

TORONTO, Aug. 24. -- A hint is given in the Dominion Government organ here to-day of a scandal, brewing for some weeks, concerning the Customs Department. It says rumors are current that a little coterie of officers in some departments have been securing goods at the expense of the country by means of falsified invoices.

Trading in wheat was less active at the Produce Exchange yesterday than during the last days of last week, the total transactions amounting to but a little over 4,300,000 bushels. There was a report of frosts West and another of unsettled weather abroad, both of which had some effect on the market. Heavy clearances were reported and a decrease in the visible supply.

An important meeting of the shareholders of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company was held in Montreal yesterday, under the Presidency of Mr. Van Horne. Among those present were Lord Mount Stephen, Lord Elphinstone of England, G.K. Harris of Boston, and Gen. Samuel Thomas of New-York. The first business before the meeting was a proposal on the part of the Canadian Pacific Railway to take over the Lake Temiscamingue Colonization Railway.

WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 23. -- Nobody in this neighborhood was at all surprised the other day when reading his newspaper he came upon a half dozen lines with "Joe" Manley's name under them, in which the announcement was made that the undersigned proposed to be elected to Congress in 1892 to succeed the Hon. Seth L. Milliken.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24. -- The steamship City of Rio Janeiro arrived to-day, twenty-five days from Hongkong and seventeen days from Yokohama.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- James Connolly, Chief Factory Inspector, said to-night to a TIMES reporter that he examined the Taylor Building two years ago, and that it had been inspected twice since then by one of his assistants, McKay.

READING, Aug. 24. -- The storm which prevailed throughout this section last night did nearly $500,000 damage in Berks County alone. Its fury was unprecedented. Public travel in the country districts is virtually at a standstill. At least forty country bridges are washed away and the roads are lying full of splintered trees. The Lebanon Valley Branch of the Reading Railroad between this city and Lebanon is badly crippled.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 24. -- The Republican editors of the State held a meeting here to-day for consultation in reference to political work during the present campaign. A minority of those present were strongly in favor of standing stiffly by the McKinley tariff and make that the distinct issue. But a large majority favored the pushing of the fight against the free coinage of silver, which the Democratic Party has indorsed in its platform.

The Executive Committee of the Liquor Dealers' Central Association will meet at 52 Union Square at 3 o'clock this afternoon to make the preliminary arrangements for the State convention, which will take place in the Lexington Avenue Opera House Sept. 1, 2, and 3. This convention will elect new officers, and the Presidency will come to New-York City or Brooklyn by rotation.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- It is learned to-day from reliable sources at Bar Harbor that Admiral Walker has in effect forbidden any of the officers of his white squadron visiting vessels in Admiral Gherardi's North Atlantic fleet. The two Admirals are now in Bar Harbor, and, by virtue of his rank, Admiral Gherardi is in command of the combined forces.

Wilhelm Dietzel, a packer in the employ of Bawo Dotter, 30 Barclay Street, was present in the Petersen restaurant at the moment of the explosion. He was fortunate enough to escape. He was seen yesterday at Bawo Dotter's, attending to his usual duties, though still somewhat indisposed by the shock he had experienced. He gave the following account of his experiences:

The "swimming championships" of the Amateur Athletic Union will be held on the Hudson at Nyack next Thursday. They will be under the management of the Manhattan Athletic Club and the Nyack Rowing Association. Among the entrants are the best-known amateur swimmers of the country, with the exception of Alexander Mefferts, the mile champion of the United States and Canada.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- The State Central Committee of the People's Party met here to-day and elected George F. Washburn of Boston permanent Chairman and E. Gerry Brown permanent Secretary. A thorough State organization was effected. It was voted to put a State ticket in this field this Autumn. After an extended debate a platform was adopted.

The extreme tension of the relations of the European powers is shown in the facility with which reports intrinsically incredible are set going, and the gravity with which they are taken up and discussed by men and journals ordinarily serious. This is one of the commonest results of a period of great excitement, national or international.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- This has been a day of receptions for the President. The pleasing inactivity of the Sabbath gave him a much-needed rest, and he appeared fresh and hearty this morning.

If the shade of Monte Cristo went to the Union Square Theatre last evening, the suspicion must have entered his mind that his own adventures and character were rather lacking in the striking and sensational. "The Black Mask" makes them seem tame.

That is a queer dispatch which comes to us from St. Petersburg by way of the London Standard, and which sets forth that the Minister of the United States at the Russian capital, following instructions from Washington, has "requested an interview with the Minister of the Interior to discuss the question of the emigration of Russian Jews to America."

There are a good many Democrats in the State just now who are becoming very doubtful of Speaker William F. Sheehan's chances of getting the nomination for Lieutenant Governor. These Democrats like Mr. Sheehan personally, but they are afraid that he would find it very difficult to be elected and would handicap whomsoever might be at the head of the ticket.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 25. -- THE TIMES'S accounts of the Gherardi-Walker differences have points of interest connected with them not generally known to the public. One of the last acts of Acting Rear Admiral John G. Walker, while serving as chief of the Bureau of Navigation, was to bring about the present general order making it impossible for any naval officer serving on board ship to communicate with the Secretary of the Navy direct.

Whatever may be the conclusion as to the cause of the terrible disaster in Park Place which careful expert investigation may justify, there is already one lesson taught by it which we commend to those who think the greatest interests of the community would be much better administered by the "Government" than they are now by private individuals.

Lovers of art in Rome will be gratified by the announcement that the Italian Government has prohibited the proposed sale of the Borghese collection of pictures and statuary for the benefit of the creditors of Prince BORGHESE. Lovers of art in this country, and especially in this city, will be correspondingly depressed by this announcement.

The hitch in the financial scheme by which the enormous floating debt of the Union Pacific Railroad is to be extended for three years is believed to be due to uncertainty concerning Mr. Jay Gould's purpose in the matter. That unfathomable financier is expected to reach home from the West next week, and soon after his arrival, it is predicted, Union Pacific affairs will begin to move.

CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., Aug. 25. -Jude Stewart to-day rendered his decision in the long-contested equity suit between the liberal and radical factions of the Church of the United Brethren in Christ. This contest grew-out of the adoption of a new constitution at the General Conference in York in 1889. A portion of the church objected to the clause permitting members to unite with secret societies.

The Central Liquor Dealers' Association met at 52 Union Square yesterday afternoon to lay the preliminary plans for the convention of the State Association to be held in the Lexington Avenue Opera House Sept. 1, 2, and 3. This convention will elect a President and other officers. Under the rule of the association the Presidency comes either to New-York or Brooklyn this year, and Tammany, of course, wants to gobble the office.
TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 25. -- The Globe fears the recent scandals unearthed at Ottawa will seriously affect Canada's credit in the English money market. It says:

Firenzi's name was the loadstone that brought to the Jerome Park track yesterday the largest number of people that have been on the course this year. The famous mare was named as a starter for the Monmouth Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, in which she had the top weight and was asked to give a lot of weight to everything else.

It seems to be certain that Mr. PLATT has selected Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE, ex-President of Cornell University, as the Republican candidate for Governor of New-York. There is nothing strange about this announcement. Mr. WHITE is a highly-respectable man, and highly-respectable men who are willing to accept the nomination, even without paying for it, seem to be in such demand this year that Mr. PLATT cannot afford to let one of them go.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 25. -- "Where is Col. H.M. Taylor?"
OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 25. -- Lord Stanly, the Governor General, has received the following memorial from British Columbia sealers, addressed to Lord Salisbury, respecting the Bering Sea question:

A large gray wolf is skulking somewhere in the Bowery or that neighborhood, and dogcatchers who may think him a prize worth having had better be careful. Wolves can bite at the rate of at least two bites a second.

BEDFORD, Penn., Aug. 25. -- William F. Harrity, Secretary of the Commonwealth, will leave Bedford Springs Thursday next, after a stay of three weeks. When questioned this morning as to the probable outcome of the approaching Democratic contest for State officers, Mr. Harrity said:

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 25. -- Jay Gould, accompanied by his party, made a flying trip to the mining camps of Eureka, about 100 miles south of here, yesterday. He was the guest of the Bullion Beck Mining Company, down whose celebrated mine he made a trip. He was quite interested in what he saw, and asked many questions concerning the output, value of product,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A "peace conference" between the representatives of the National League and the American Association of Baseball Clubs was begun here to-day. The conference is being held for the purpose of thoroughly discussing the troubles now existing between the two associations and to endeavor to agree upon a compromise programme that will insure the prosperity of the national game. The following are the representatives of the two associations at the conference:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 25. -- The news telegraphed from Granada to the United States to the effect that there had been riots there Sunday, that the Chief of Police and six men had been killed, and that three important personages were to be expelled from Nicaragua, with the warning that they would be shot if they returned, is correct.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The "communication" of Rear Admiral Gherardi to the Secretary of the Navy concerning the occurrence at Port au Prince has never, it is declared at the department to-day, been called to the attention of the Judge Advocate General, and no action of any sort has ever been taken on it. The department refuses to consider the communication as a report of breach of discipline.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 25. -- At Castleton the train began moving while the President was speaking, and a shower of bouquets of roses, goldenrod, and sweet pea blossoms were thrown atter him. At Rutland Gen. Veazey and Aldace F. Walker of Chicago joined the party. The train reached Brandon at 11 o'clock, and ex-Govs. Ormsbee and J.W. Stewart, G.G. Benedicts and C.S. Forbes of St. Albans entered the car.
