If Emma Abbott's spirit could have spoken at the auction sale of her operatic wardrobe yesterday, it would have protested against the awful sacrifice of her pretty things. The wardrobe bore every evidence of luxurious taste and extravagant expenditure, the 137 numbers under which the items were comprised having cost over $200,000.

The following changes in the staions of the hospital stewards are made:Hospital Steward James Fields will be relieved from duty at Fort Meintosh,Texas,and will proceed to Columbus Barracks,Ohio,to relieve Hospital Steward Frank Wagner:Hospital Steward Wagner,upon being thus relieved,will proceed to Fort Bills,Texas,for duty.Hospital Steward William Bock will be relieve from duty at Fort Bidwell,California, and will proceed to Watertown Arsenal,Massachusetts,for duty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 25. -- Advices from Singapore state that the steamer Namchow sailed for that port with 800 Chinese coolies for the Penang market. The officers were Chinese, with the exception of half a dozen Europeans. While at sea cholera broke out among the Chinese. The sick were crowded into the cabins, where a Presbyterian minister and one lady passenger has taken refuge.

MIDLAND, Midland County, Texas, Aug. 25. -- The public has already been informed of the preliminary experiments which have been made by Gen. Dyrenforth's "rainfall" expedition on the Chicago ranch, near this station. Gen. Dyernforth expresses himself well satisfied with the experiments here, but no one else can be found who has implicit faith in the rain-making process.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 25. -- Sir John Thompson to-day presented an important return in reference to the correspondence between the Canadian and Imperial Governments in reference to the Canadian copyright laws. The bulk of the return is composed of the full text of Sir John Thompson's memorandum to Lord Knutsford written in London in July of last year.

The advertisements and circulars of a company which asserts that it has the exclusive right to sell Bell telephones "for export" to South America, Central America, Mexico, and the West Indies, throw some light upon the actual cost of these telephones and the price for which they can be sold profitably.

It is pretty well decided that the Committee of One Hundred appointed at the Battery Park mass meeting in July will begin work in earnest in about a week. Sufficient replies have been received from members of the committee in regard to the advisability of an early meeting to warrant those who issued the circulars making this inquiry in calling such a meeting as soon as arrangements can be conveniently made for it.

At last we hear again from BLAIR. Since the Chinese Government expressed a desire that he should not visit China in an official capacity Mr. BLAIR has remained in Washington, where he has drawn at least a part of the salary which he hoped to enjoy for some years. He now emerges from his seclusion to assert that he was the author of the "reciprocity policy" as set forth in the McKinley bill.

Mrs. Ida F. Lederer, the daughter of Richard S. Newcombe, who eloped with George W. Lederer, the theatrical manager, appeared before Acting Probate Clerk Jackson, in the Surrogate's office, yesterday to file her petition asking that Ira Leo Bamberger be appointed as her guardian ad litem in her proceedings to contest her father's will.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- President Harrison left Saratoga by the Delaware and Hudson Road at 8:30 o'clock this morning on a special train. The party consisted of the President private Secretary Halford, Secretary Proctor, Vice President E.C. Smith of the Vermont Central Road, C.D. Hammond, Superintendent of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad; Howard Cole, E.F. Tibbetts, and the press correspondents.

The bids for the new torpedo boat, which are to be opened to-day, will, it is hoped, show that a considerable number of builders are willing to compete for it. The requirements as to speed are, of course, much in advance of the estimates made for the Cushing, which, although a fast craft, can already be looked back upon as our first experiment in boats of this class.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- It has been many years since Monroe County has seen as hot a political convention as that held to-day at Pittsford by the First Assembly District Democrats. The Hill and anti-Hill men were out in full force, with reinforcements from this city, and the struggle for supremacy began as soon as the delegates entered the convention hall.

The Board of Health yesterday considered the report of Chemists Edward W. Martin and Alfred L. Beebe, who have been investigating the Croton water supply, including Reservoir "I" and the east branch of the Croton River and its tributaries, to a point one mile above the village of Croton Falls.

The Porrett family, consisting of Michael Porrett. Margaretta, his wife, and Josephine, their daughter, was taken into custody yesterday, and it is hoped that as a consequence a very prosperous counterfeiting business has been broken up. The Porretts lived in Eighth Street until a short time ago, where Porrett was ostensibly a boot and shoe maker.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 26. -- President Harrison spent last night at the house of ex-Gov. Smith in St. Albans. He arose early, and before his host and the other guests were stirring he was out of doors strolling over the grounds, through the graperies, and upon the lawn in company with the gardener. After breakfast he visited the St. Albans creamery and thence was driven to the station.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- "Walker's pull" is the chief topic of discussion in navy circles. The publications in THE TIMES have created renewed interest in the subject -- for this "pull" has been the bane of the navy for many a day -and awakened a hope among officer's who are not in with Walker and benefited by his "pull" that, public interest being aroused, there may come some relief.

The last shovelful dirt of was removed from. the Park Place ruins at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and Battalion Chief Reilly of the Fire Department said that all the ground had been gone over thoroughtly. Sixty-one bodies have been taken out. The number is far below that of those that are certainly known to be missing.

It was an off day at Jerome Park yesterday, and it was also the last day of the Monmouth Park Association's meeting at the saddlebags track. Their unfortunate season's racing will close to-day at the Morris Park track. No stake events were on yesterday's card, and there was little in the programme to excite enthusiasm. All five of the races on the flat were short distance races, and were in the nature of consolation races.
Following are the weights for the three principal handicaps at the Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, which begins on Saturday next:

A great many stories were told in Wall Street yesterday and as many guesses made about the future movements of Douglass Green, who was until nearly two years ago a member of the firm of Green Bateman of this city and a well-known stock broker.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26. -- It was Rusie against "Cyclone" Crane to-day. Both pitched well, but the home players did poor work in the field and at the bat and were defeated. The whole New-York outfield distinguished itself, Tiernan, Gore, and O'Rourke making sensational catches of long flies. Score:

The Directors of the Roselle and South Plainfield, Newark and Roselle, Newark, Jersey City, Newark and Western, Newark and Passaic, Jersey City Terminal, and Edgewater Railroad Companies met in Collins Corbin's office, Jersey City, yesterday, and discussed a proposed agreement for the consolidation of those roads. A decision was arrived at, and the actual merger or consolidation will be effected to-day.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- All the delegates to the Republican State Convention so far chosen are for Charles H. Allen of Lowell for Governor. Melrose, the home of Speaker Barrett, which, people had been led to believe, was his own pocket borough, has to-night elected six Allen delegates to the State Convention. Mr. Crapo did not get as much as a single delegate.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 26. -- About a year ago, Benton Turner, who has been in constant litigation with the State for years past, over the title to Adirondack lands, offered to sell to the State his interest in the northeast quarter of Township 18, Great Tract No. 1, comprising the town of Brighton, Franklin County. This offer was rejected.

The new Atlantic liner State of California arrived in port late Tuesday night, completing her maiden voyage from Glasgow. The vessel belongs to the Allan-State Line, and was launched Jan. 29, 1891. The new ship is a handsome addition to the transatlantic passenger fleet, and will no doubt become a favorite with the traveling public.

It is entirely natural that the gentlemen interested in the disbursement of the Baron Hirsch Fund for the relief of the persecuted Russian Jews should seek to obtain a reversal of the decision by which some four score of these unfortunates are debarred from landing from the steamer Marsala. But we do not see that Superintendent O'BEIRNE could have done otherwise than he has done.

The fancied security in which Battery Park grabbers have reposed during the last few weeks is likely to be rudely disturbed as soon as the Committee of One Hundred shall organize for work. Members of the committee are impatient for the meeting to be held next week, and conferences are frequent with reference to the date of meeting.

The Summer meeting of the Monmouth Park Racing Association will be brought to a close at the Morris Park track this afternoon, and the horses will then move to the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club to meet those that have been racing at Saratoga during the past six weeks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- The Pacific Short Line will be offered for sale at public auction next Tuesday under foreclosure proceedings by order of the United States Circuit Court. It is expected that there will be a sharp contest for the possession of the property, as several companies are known to have had a covetous eye on it for some time and will make the most of this opportunity to secure it.
The Aqueduct Commissioners adopted the following resolution yesterday, offered by Commissioner Cannon, in relation to the Croton water supply:

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 26. -- The Republican State League Convention met here to-day. Fully 500 delegates are in attendance. The work before the convention was the election of officers and preparation for the campaign throughout the State this Fall.

We give considerable space this morning to a dispatch from Seattle, Washington, analyzing the sentiment of the Democratic Party of the new State toward Mr. CLEVELAND and Mr. HILL, and with reference to the issues on which the great contest of next year is to be fought out. The report is well worth study for various reasons. It is not yet two years since Washington was admitted as a State.

POUGHPKEPSIE, Aug. 26. -- There was a better attendance at the second day's meeting of the New-York Breeders' Association to-day. In the race for two-year-olds, Benton Wilkes trotted the middle half in 1:11. The hottest contest was between Glyceria and Bush. The talent plunged on Bush at the start, and stuck to her even after Glyceria won the first heat in 2:22 1/4, and finally went dead broke on her.

The Congress of Geologists now in session at Washington is a body of much more than usual eminence, and the Americans who are taking part in it count on some very interesting results from its meetings. It was formally opened yesterday, and Prof. J.D. DANA of Yale University and Prof. HALL of this State were elected honorary Presidents, while Prof. J.S. NEWBERRY was chosen President.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- Oliver S. Campbell holds his title as champion tennis player of America. To-day he defeated Clarence Hobart, the winner of the All-Comers, in one of the closest and best championship contests which ever took place here.

MIDLAND, Texas, Aug. 26. -- The party of scientists who, under the direction of Gen. R.G. Dyrenforth, came to this place about three weeks ago to try to produce rain by a series of powerful explosions, have virtually completed their experiments in this part of the country, having had every facility afforded them through the public spirit of Mr. Nelson Morris.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Aug. 26. -- The President's train arrived at 4:30. The town was beautifully decorated. An escort was in waiting, consisting of a platoon of police, Company D, Vermont National Guard; Palestine Commandery, K.T. Cantons; Knights of Pythias, St. Jean Baptiste Society, Odd Fellows, Frost Camp, Sons of Veterans; Chamberlain Post, G.A.R., and visiting comrades.

There is really nothing to be said about the decision requiring Mr. W.K. VANDERBILT to pay $30,000 duty on a foreign-built yacht that has not in effect been said often before. It is only the novelty of the case that makes it noticeable. A steam yacht is undoubtedly a "manufacture of iron," if she be built of that material, and the tariff undoubtedly levies a duty of 45 per cent. on manufactures of iron.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 26. -- The Georgia Legislature will not indorse the Ocala platform. This is the result of a series of secret caucuses which have been held by the Alliance members of the Legislature.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 26. -- Faustino, the son of Sydney, who trotted as a yearling in 2:35 and as a two-year-old in 2:24 1/2, further added to his fame here to-day by winning the five-thousand-dollar stake for three-year-olds, and lowering his record to 2:17. This record is surpassed at the age, only by Sunol and Axtell. His performance gives him the fastest three heats ever trotted by a stallion in a race.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- In the northern parts of the British Isles a furious gale is raging. At Sheffield the large marquees erected for the fair were wrecked and their contents seriously damaged. In addition, a church situated near the Sheffield fair grounds was blown down, and throughout the district a great amount of damage was done to trees, crops, and buildings in course or erection.
CORTLAND, Aug. 26. -- The Cortland County Republican Convention held here yesterday unanimously nominated James H. Tripp of Marathon for the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the construction, exclusive of armament and of torpedoes and their appendages, of a steel, twin screw, seagoing torpedo boat, of not less than 120 tons displacement. This is torpedo boat No. 2.

Domestic and business troubles and a naturally despondent nature resulted in the suicide yesterday, in his office at 23 Murray Street, of Alfred H. Hildick, who has been for many years an importer and commission merchant in the hardware business. Hildick was sixty-eight years old and lived at the Bristol, 15 East Eleventh Street.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 26. -- The convicts leased by the Tennessee Coal Mining Company, and employed in the coal mines at Briceville, East Tennessee, until the Board of Prison Inspectors stopped their work last week, will be kept at Briceville, but not permitted to work until the Chancery Court so decrees.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- The postponed naval review took place this morning. The vessels started at about 10:30 A.M. for Baker's Island, about eight miles off. All the ships took part except the Despatch and Enterprise, which were reserved for invited guests, and sailed around among the manoeuvring vessels. The steamship Olivette and, at noon, the steamer Sappho, both took out the crowds.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 26. -- The Democracy of the State of Washington has just made what amounts to a formal declaration of its choice of Cleveland for President. The announcement has been made in an editorial in the Seattle Morning Telegraph, the State organ of the party.

The big twelve-inch breech-loading rifle at Sandy Hook was yesterday given another test before a large number of assembled artillery experts of the army. The object of the test was to try a second sample of brown prismatic powder, expressly furnished by the Dupont Powder Company of Wilmington, Del.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Hill and the canal management were laid under the sod in this city last night and James H. Shanahan, the representative of anti-Hillism and tariff reform in this county, was vindicated. The fight was made against the patronage of the canals, represented by Superintendent of Section 3, Robert Owens, and the Hill administration represented by Judge Zeral Westbrook, Deputy Controller, and ex-County Judge H.V. Borst, all of whom live here.

The attention of the Bureau of Buildings is now being called to many buildings that are considered to be unsafe. The Superintendent of the Bureau received more of such complaints yesterday morning than on any day in the history of the bureau. In fact, the letters made a stack over a foot high.

The firm of Lipsker, Munk Crohn was up to two days ago actively engaged in the manufacture of jewelry at 44 1/2 Maiden Lane. To-day the junior partners of the firm are lamenting the unexplained absence of their senior, and casting up accounts in order to determine to what an extent the sudden disappearance of Mr. Jacob Lipsker has involved them in indebtedness.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- It is not likely that Mr. Proctor will retire from the Cabinet before November, when he will receive his appointment to the Senate.

HARTFORD, Aug. 26. -- There was some royal sport at Charter Oak Park this afternoon, when the heats in the 2:20 stake were divided, till at dark there was no decision, though eight had been trotted Little Albert and Nightingale alone remain for the final heat to-morrow, as they were tied in the fourth heat, so that Abbie V., who had also two heats, is out of the race under the amended rules.

The policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company, who may be assumed to be more interested in the pending exposures of William H. Beers's mismanagement than any other class of persons, find themselves confronted with one question upon which their views of Mr. Beers's incompetency or competency must depend.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 26. -- Mr. J.S.B. Thompson, now Superintendent of the Virginia Midland and Washington and Ohio Divisions of the Richmond and Danville system, with headquarters at Alexandria, by an order issued to-day is appointed assistant to General Manager Green, with headquarters in Atlanta. He will have general charge of the distribution of equipment, both passenger and freight. Mr. T.O. Troy is appointed to succeed him in his late position.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- The fourteenth annual meeting of the American Bar Association, the first held in New-England, was opened this forenoon in Horticultural Hall. Nearly 200 members were present. After President Baldwin had called the assemblage to order, a welcome was extended to the visitors by the Hon. John Lowell, the President of the Boston Bar Association.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- There was a large meeting of representative Democrats in Columbus to-day for a conference relative to the conduct of the campaign. Nearly all the candidates on the State ticket were present, as well as a number of legislative and county officials.

The Greek Catholics (of the Oriental rite which permits of a married clergy) have become quite numerous in this country. There are large settlements of them in New-York, Pennsylvania, and the West, especially in Minneapolis. The Greeks have endeavored to establish for themselves a separate jurisdiction, independent of the Catholic Bishops in whose dioceses they were.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- Oliver S. Campbell, the singles champion of America, won to-day, with his partner, R.P. Huntington, Jr., the doubles championship of the United States from Clarence Hobart and Valentine G. Hall, last year's champion team.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 27. -- The frost of last night was severely felt in nearly all parts of North Dakota, and the present outlook is very gloomy. Said an agent of one of the elevator companies this morning: "There is no doubt, from reports just at hand, that the frost of last night was most disastrous, and I fear there will be more frosted wheat this year than ever before.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- David Christie Murray, the novelist, made his debut as an actor at the Globe Theatre this evening in a play entitled "Ned's Chum." The play is a good one, and there is every indication of its success. The scene is laid in Australia. Murray takes a strong character part, in which he acquitted himself with the ease and self-possession of an old actor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- A San Francisco special dispatch says: "To Sarah Bernhardt belongs the credit of projecting the most audacious theatrical scheme on record. The idea is a tour of the world on a specially-chartered steamship of not less than 3,000 tons, carrying the company, scenery, and, incidentally, freight to help defray the expenses, which would be nearly $1,000 a day.

OFF BEMINI, Babama Islands, Aug. 25. -- Great excitement prevails here. Some British subjects attempted to haul down the American flag from the staff on the steamer El Dorado and run up the British ensign in its place. They were summarily dealt with. A heavy southeastern gale is blowing, and many ships ran for a harbor during the night.

It seems probable that the defeat of the insurgents in Chile is decisive and final. They appear to have staked all their hopes upon the event of the battle in which they have not only been defeated, but in which their whole land force is reported to have been captured. The news has been so contradictory since the beginning of the insurrection that judicious persons have read the dispatches with much incredulity.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Aug. 27. -- When President Harrison looked out upon the morning from his chamber in the house of Mr. Franklin Fairbanks, at St. Johnsbury, the clouds were hanging low and rain was falling heavily. At 8:30 o'clock when the Presidential train started from the Boston and Maine station at St. Johnsbury for Rutland, about 500 people cheered the President on his departure.

The Saratoga Racing Association closed its last meeting yesterday, and now the track passes into the hands of G.F. Walbaum and his associates of the Guttenberg track. The day's races resulted as follows:

The Westchester County Fair this year promises to be of more than local importance. That county has become so closely identified with New-York County, better known as New-York City, through the existing propensity of residents of the latter to seek suburban retreats in the former, that it has been decided this year to make the fair as much of an event to them as it is to Westchesterites proper.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Husbandman, the organ of Lieut. Gov. Jones, published here, but soon to be removed to Binghamton, the Lieutenant Governor's home, has some very severe criticisms on Roswell P. Flower and the party machine that is carrying his nomination in this week's issue. Following a double-column portrait of Gen. Jones is the following double-leaded display-headed statement:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 27. -- Last Tuesday evening one of the boxes at the Grand Avenue was occupied by a party that attracted a great deal of attention. It included three persons. The most conspicuous figure was a tall, slender man of peculiarly pale and striking physiognomy, clean shaven, and apparently not more than thirty years old, with hair like a crow's wing. He was irreproachably dressed.

The pious Mail and Express, in the citations from the Scripture with which it adorns its columns daily, sometimes hits upon a phrase that is not without pertinence to its own party conditions. Yesterday the text was: "And ye have made void the Word of GOD because of your tradition." Now it happens that the Republican Party, if ever a party was, was founded on what is regarded by Christians as the "Word of GOD."

Passengers on the Belt Line Car No. 69 had an exciting experience yesterday morning while riding along Tenth Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-second Streets. The horses took fright a an engine and ran madly down the avenue at full speed, dragging the car at a terrific rate over the pavement a portion of the way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The evil complained of in the order relating to correspondence between officers on shipboard and the Navy Department lay in its application while Acting Admiral Walker was Chief of the Bureau of Navigation. The order has never been revoked, but it appears not to have led to any usurpation of authority by the present chief of the bureau.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 27. -- There was an unpleasant surprise in store for the Giants here. They came prepared to win three straight, as Manager Mutrie put it, but they failed to carry off the opening game, and barely saved themselves from the mortification of a "whitewash."

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Aug. 27. -- North Dakota railroad shippers have practically completed arrangements which assure to this city the handling of much of the crop of North Dakota under the new inspection laws of that State. Heretofore 8,000,000 bushels of elevator capacity here has been under Minnesota inspection.

Assistant Secretary Rorke of the Coney Island Jockey Club last evening announced that the list of starters for the Futurity Stakes of $75,000, to be run on Saturday, would probably be made up of the following, the weights to be carried being figured up to last evening:

The overcrowded condition of the Flatbush Insane Asylum, where 1,400 patients are crowded into a space intended for 900, and where even the damp cellar has to be used to accommodate the unfortunates, was the subject of an official complaint to the Kings County Board of Supervisors yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 27. -- A dispatch from Tampico received here says that the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railroad to-day completed its road to that point. The road connects on land with the Southern Pacific and other American roads, and expects also to enter into water comsetition between Tampico and New-York and New-Orleans as soon as Engineer Carthell has the jetties sufficiency advanced.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- The Times to-morow will print a remarkable letter to the Hon. A.K. McClure from Abe Buzzard, the notorious Welsh Mountain outlaw, now serving a long sentence in the Eastern Penitentiary. In the course of his letter the outlaw says:

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The charges made in ex-Keeper John Brophy's story of cruelty and inhuman treatment by officers in Clinton Prison are to be officially investigated. Secretary Round of the Prison Association has not made public his report on the examination he conducted some time since, and Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop desires that he first give it to the newspapers when it is ready.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 27. -- The Georgia Legislature to-day was a body in which brimstone seemed to burn. Scarcely had the Chaplain said "Amen" when Mr. Wright rose to a question of personal privilege. He said:

Hugh Duffy, Morgan Murphy, John Fitzgerald, "Hardy" Richardson, John Stricker, Paul Radford. Thomas T. Brown, and John O'Brien yesterday signed contracts to play with the Boston Reds of the American Association for the season of 1892. Brown will receive an increase over last season's figure.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 27. -- The racing here to-day was something phenomenal, for the 30,000 people present saw fourteen miles trotted or paced no one being in slower time than 3:21 3/4. Nancy Hanks, in the five-year-old class, put to her credit the three fastest heats ever trotted in a race, and reduced her record by two seconds and a half, and Roy Wilkes paced the three fastest heats to the credit of a stallion.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 27. -- The News and Courier is after the Census Bureau. It will say, editorially, to-morrow:

TORONTO, Aug. 27. -- The result of the census of Canada, just published, is very disappointing to the friends of the Conservative Government at Ottawa, who were confident of a much bigger increase, and some think the showing will yet be the death blow to the high protective policy inaugurated by Sir John Macdonald, and which Premier Abbott declares he is determined to maintain while in power.

On the arid Staked Plains of Texas, where for three years rain has been a rare and fleeting phenomenon, there have fallen during the past three weeks nine showers and one hard rain. The passage from practically no rain at all to an average of a rainfall every other day during several weeks is striking enough to call for some explanation.

There was plenty of food for reflection on the part of certain police officers in the action taken yesterday by the Police Commissioners at their regular meeting. On the strength of a recommendation from Acting Superintendent Byrnes several rather important changes were made in the disposition of several members of the "force."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 27. -- Ex-Assistant Cashier Charles Lawrence of the Keystone Bank has written a statement of the methods which were used to deceive ex-Bank Examiner Drew. Lawrence is now in the Eastern Penitentiary serving out his term of seven years for complicity in wrecking the bank. The letter is as follows:

Ex-Mayor Philip Becker of Buffalo is evidently a candidate for Governor on the Republican side in dead earnest, for he has been appealing to Brooklyn Republicans to take him up as their second choice. His preliminary campaign is being run by Senator Laughlin, who thought Jacob Worth was the proper man to write to in Brooklyn. Here is his letter:

In the annual report of President Roswell Miller of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, just issued, a decrease of net earnings for the year ended June 30 is shown amounting to $94,886. The gross earnings for that period were $27,504,244, the operating expenses $18,366,500, and the net earnings $9,137,724. The increase of gross earnings was $1,098,516 and the increase of expenses $1,193,402.

We give in our news columns the plain facts in regard to the curious story published in two of the morning papers yesterday, in which Mr. Secretary FOSTER was described as having played a trick upon the bankers of New-York and got $12,000,000 of their gold from them before they knew it.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- For several weeks the friends of Isaac H. Maynard, who holds the position of Deputy Attorney General, have been mentioning his name in connection with the position of Attorney General on the Democratic State ticket this Fall. When questioned as to the matter, Mr. Maynard told THE TIMES'S reporter that he expected to be tendered the nomination, and intimated that he expected to be on the ticket.

Mr. Stevenson's hero considered "Americo-Parisienne" an adjective of "knotted horror," but it applies happily enough to the new impersonators of Mr. Wilkinson's widows. Gillette's clever adaptation of Bisson's "Feu Toupinel" has returned to Proctor's Theatre, and last night Georgie Drew Barrymore and Emily Bancker encountered most successfully that awful mystery of two marriages by one man in two cities at the same hour.

Richard Barry, a customs official, boarded the revenue cutter W.E. Chandler yesterday afternoon and went to Stapleton, S.I., to take possession, in the name of the Government, of the steam yacht Conqueror, belonging to Frederick W. Vanderbilt.

Reports from the Southern States of damage to the cotton crop by worms were again received yesterday at the Cotton Exchange. The cables from Liverpool reported that the market there was affected by similar reports, and a general feeling was prevalent that the damage from this cause might be serious.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The wheelmen's camp meeting, under the auspices of the Asbury Park Athletic Association, was opened this afternoon. The camp is conducted on a semi-military plan, the tents having been loaned the association by the State. The greater part of the day was spent in pitching the tents and arranging the preliminary details for the meet.

COLUMBUS, O., Aug. 27. -- The opening gun of the People's Party was fired to-night, the orator of the occasion being John Seitz, candidate for Governor, assisted by a few of the lesser lights of the organization.

There are few things in life more depressing to see than a person to whom a sense of humor has been denied "trying to be funny." The victim of the double affliction of this privation and of an unconsciousness of it chooses the most unmirthful topics for his merriment and bestows upon them a most unmirthful treatment.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 27. -- Col. William J. Vannort of Kent County was nominated for Governor to-day by the Republican Convention, but he owes his candidacy to Harry M. Clabaugh of Carroll County, who had a majority of votes before the nominations were made, but feared that the farmers would defeat him if nominated.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Very heavy rains have prevailed for several days, and a storm almost amounting to a deluge set in this morning, and still continues at Glasshouse Lake, ten miles east of the city. The water overflowed the banks, and a great volume sped on with almost resistless fury in the direction of Slater's Corners and Averill Park.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- Cross Road Cottage, at Beverly Farms, the charming Summer home of Mme. Celestine Eustis, was the scene of a notable gathering this forenoon, the occasion being the marriage of Mr. Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., of New-York and Miss Louise Mary Eustis of Washington, D.C., granddaughter of W.W. Corcoran. Contrary to general expectation the wedding was very unpretentious, all display being dispensed with.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27. -- Mr. Owen Scott of Bloomington, Ill., a prominent politician and member of Congress for the Fourteenth Illinois District, speaking of the Presidential possibilities for the coming election said:

MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., Aug. 27. -- It is reported that a tremendous sensation is about to explode in this section of the Cumberland Mountains. The public is familiar with the details of the lynching of Frank Rassimus, formerly of Cincinnati, during the early part of July last. Rassimus's friends have been raising funds from societies all over the country and have had detectives at work ferreting out the names of those who composed the lynching party.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 28. -- A special to the Transcript from Georgetown, Ky., says: "At 3 o'clock this morning a mob of 150 men came into town, and, taking the negro murderer of Frank Hughes out of jail, hanged him to a tree."

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 28. -- The reported probability of the selection of ex-Gov. Pearson C. Cheney of Manchester by President Harrison to succeed Secretary Proctor of Vermont at the head of the War Department arouses no enthusiasm among the Republicans of this State. Indeed, the ex-Governor never had any strong hold upon the popular heart, or upon the masses of the party.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28. -- The State Legislature will meet in extraordinary session next Monday for the consideration of the convict lease and other important questions.

There is nothing in the newspaper literature of the day to compare with the" round unvarnished tale" which THE NEW-YORK TIMES told on Friday last of the honorable life and public services of its founder, George Jones. The beauty and force of the narrative were heightened by its perfect simplicity, and must have made a good impression upon a thoughtful and discriminating public.
LIMA, Aug. 28. -- An engagement took place early this morning between Balmaceda's troops and the forces of the insurgents at Vina del Mar, in which the insurgents were completely victorious.

The campaign of the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred against the Battery Park grabbers will begin next Thursday night, when the first meeting of the committee will be held at the Hotel Brunswick. Arrangements for the meeting were completed yesterday. There is no doubt that it will be successful, and that the movement to save the public parks of this city as pleasure grounds for the people will start in with a very favorable beginning.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 28. -- Rain was falling at 7 o'clock this morning, and the prospects were unfavorable for the demonstrations at Proctor and Rutland in honor of the President. Gradually, however, the clouds broke and there were patches of blue sky visible, but the muddy streets and muggy atmosphere rendered the general conditions uncomfortable.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- The Republican State Committee met to-day to complete arrangements for the State Convention. Chairman Burdette presided, and there were twenty members present. One gentleman from each Congressional district was chosen to serve upon the Committee on Resolutions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- There is a general feeling of gratification among officers of the navy who are not indebted to a "pull" for preferment that public interest is being aroused against the practice of favoritism in the service.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 28. -- The Hon. B.D. Wood, Chairman of the Executive Committee on the Improvement of the Western Waterways, by authority vested in him by the Cincinnati Convention held in September, 1889, has issued a call for a convention of the people interested in the improvements of the western waterways, to be held in Evansville, Ind., Wednesday and Thursday, Oct. 14 and 15.

QUEBEC, Aug. 28. -- Capt. Nygaard, of the Norwegian Dark Prince Eugene, which reached port to-day, reports that on the 16th inst, on the Banks of Newfoundland, he picked up a boat containing six Portuguese fishermen who were in a starving condition, having been three days without food. While attending their nets a thick fog came on and they were lost from their vessel

* * * As greatness goes, George Jones was one of the characters that mankind in self-respect ought to admire. He was the inspiring cause of THE TIMES, a newspaper which, in spite of some shortcomings, is really the most admirable journal in this or any other country.

Frank P. Arbuckle, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of Colorado, and whose home is in Denver, is in the city. When seen at the Hoffman House last night by a TIMES reporter he had some very interesting things to say on the political situation out West.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 28. -- This was the closing day of the seventh annual meeting of the New-York State Trotting-Horse Breeders' Association at the Hudson River Driving Park, and the attendance was larger than on any of the preceding days. The racing to-day was made quite exciting because of split heats in the Village Farm Stake contest, the fight being very warm between Dinehant's Alcyone, Jr., and the mare Bonhommie from Summit View Farm.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28. -- The idea of having the Bayreuth opera festival in 1893 during the World's Fair period reproduced in Milwaukee has to-day received a fresh impetus through a dispatch by Anglo Neumann, the great impresario and the founder of the Wagner theatres in Europe, who wires the Milwaukee Herald that the idea is a brilliant one and that the plan proposed, with some slight modifications could be carried to a successful issue.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The results of the flood in this section yesterday are far more serious than at first supposed. It is now certain that several lives have been lost. Those familiar with the devastated district would hardly recognize it. Meadows have been converted into lakes, highways have partially disappeared, while the great mass of debris everywhere to be seen marks the work of the flood.

At 2 o'clock this afternoon a dash of five and a half furlongs over the straight track will begin the Autumn meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, which will continue daily until Sept. 12. Shortly after 3 o'clock the richest turf prize of the year, the race for the Coney Island Futurity Stake, valued at about $75,000, will be run at three-quarters of a mile.

Lake Tchad has become for the moment the centre of interest in Africa, not only because of the competition of France, Germany, and England in exploring its neighborhood and opening avenues of trade there, but chiefly because of the disasters which have lately befallen the expeditions directed thither.

The following item, being a paragraph that appeared in Mr. Theodore W. Banta's letter published in THE TIMES of to-day, requires some explanation, as I am mentioned therein. If Mr. Hornblower referred to me as a witness before that star chamber committee he has made a statement that is wholly inaccurate. I never testified before it or had any knowledge of its sitting.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Some new facts keep leaking out about the corn deal. The more that comes out about it, the more substantial the manipulation looks. When people began talking about the September deal it was the general theory that the New-York deal amounted to possibly 5,000,000 bushels. Everybody now is inclined to double that figure.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 28. -- It was a close game here to-day between New-York and Pittsburg, but the later won. From the fifth to the ninth inning the score was a "tie," but in the ninth the local players scored one run and the Giants scored another defeat. Rusie pitched good ball and tried hard to win, but fate was against him.

VALPARAISO, Aug. 28. -- Battle fought near this city this morning., Government forces badly beaten. Heavy loss on both sides. City surrendered to opposition, but in hands of Admirals, American, German, French, and English fleets, for good order. No communication with Santiago. Opposition forces now entering the city.

The next vessel to be launched for our navy will probably be Cruiser No. 9, which, it is understood, will be named North Point, after the battle fought in Maryland during the war of 1812. She and her sister ship, Cruiser No. 10, are under construction at the Columbian Iron Works, Baltimore. They are 2,000-ton steel vessels, with a length of 257 feet, an extreme breadth of 37, and a mean draught of 1412.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- The State Normal School will open Wednesday next. It will not be without trouble. This trouble was augmented to-day by the resignation of Bruce Smith of the local board. This, with the death of Henry Brewer, leaves two vacancies in the board. Mr. Smith has resigned solely because the other members of the board influenced Superintendent Draper to remove Principal Hoose.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The bones of the Frank J. Griffith, the first steamer that ever plowed these waters, were buried in the lake here to-night with imposing ceremonies. Crowds of visitors came up from Newark and Elizabeth, and sixteen steamers full of guests from the lake hotels surrounded the object of the evening's celebration.

Without any apparent motive and without giving any previous signs of insanity, a young painter named John Baxter, living on the top floor of the four-story tenement 321 East One Hundred and Sixth Street, deliberately shot and killed his wife, his two small children, one a girl of five, the other a boy of two and a half years, and then himself, late Thursday evening.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The London Gazette (official) announced to-day that Queen Victoria has issued a commission to the President, Vice President, Treasurers, and members of the Council of the Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce. This is the royal commission which is to supervise the representation of Great Britain at the Columbian Fair at Chicago.

For some weeks the National Provisioner, which represents the interests of packers and others who use large quantities of tin cans, has been making an inquiry concerning the manufacture of tin plate in this country. "We have advocated," says the Provisioner, "the use of American tin plate, by all means, providing it was in quality not inferior to the imported article."

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 28. -- Monbars is a world beater. This afternoon the sensational two-year-old by Eagle Bird-Lady Maud, by General Knox, and with a record of 2:21 3/4, was brought out to beat the two-year-old stallion record of 2:20 3/4, held by Regal Wilkes. The ribbons over the stallion were held by the redoubtable Budd Doble. The first quarter was made steady and firm in 0:36 1/2.

Editor Post: I note in Saturday morning's Post an article on "The Reciprocity Policy" and a reference in it to the "Blair amendment" to the Tariff bill of 1883, (H.R. 5,538.) See Congressional Record, page 2,986, Feb. 20, 1883, which the Chicago Evening Post, I take it, conceives to be the essence of the idea of reciprocity.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- Judge Don A. Pardee of the United States Circuit Court for the District of Louisiana, sitting in Chambers hero to-day, granted an application for the appointment of a receiver for the New-Orleans and Northwestern Railway. C.H, Hammond of Kansas City and W.D. Jenkins of Natchez, Miss., were appointed joint receivers. The application was made by the bondholders and stock, holders of The railway, who were represented.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- What looks like an effort to shield an embezzling city official occurred at the meeting of the Common Council last night. City Clerk H.B. Cook has for some time been accused or being short in his accounts, and figures have been presented showing that he had failed to account for some of the city's money.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- The chief event in World's Fair circles this week was the discovery by Commissioner Do Young that less than eight acres of room was available for exhibits in the building for manufactures which was designed by George B. Post of New-York. This was not anywhere near enough space.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Aug. 28. -- It is now evident that James G. Blaine, Jr., will fight the divorce suit to be brought by his wife, who now resides in this city.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 28. -- Mrs. Lawrence Algernon Kingsley, nee Carrie Laura Dickerson, of New-Haven, Conn., is still in the St. Louis jail, and is likely to stay there for several days. She is the very pretty young woman who gained notoriety through her escapades with the peculiar young man who has been passing here and in other cities as a nephew of Lord Harrington.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- This city was visited by a cyclone yesterday afternoon. Buildings were unroofed, trees wore uprooted, walls demolished, and much havoc caused. The three-story building at the corner of Bowery and Lexington Streets, owned by Frederick Millering, was struck by the whirlwind. The roof was torn from its fastenings and blown 200 feet away.
Sing, Muse, the destructive wrath of EDWARD F. JONES, of Lieut. Gov. JONES, of JONES who pays the freight.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 28. -- The cotton crop throughout Middle Georgia sustained heavy damage Tuesday night. The entire stretch of country along the line of the Macon and Augusta Road and the region comprising the Eighth Congressional District was visited by heavy rains. The rainfall was 5.40 inches in ten hours.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 28. -- The second of the midsummer series of races of the Corinthian Yacht Club for a two-hundred-dollar trophy for forty-six-footers and a one-hundred-dollar prize for each leg was sailed to-day with the same five entries as contested in yesterday's race. To-day's race also counts as a leg in the contest for the five-hundred-dollar gold cup offered by the Cherry Diamond Yacht Club, previous logs having been sailed off Newport.

Congressman John De Wilt Warner, Chairman of the Reform Club's Tariff Reform Committee, in speaking of the political outlook yesterday, said: "As to prospects this Fall, Iowa, Ohio, and New-York seem to be the storm centres. All looks favorable for clinching Iowa to the Democratic position in which she lately placed herself.

The Commissioners to whom Rhode Island has intrusted the erection of a new State House have begun their work in a very commendable way. The common practice has been to invite designs from anybody who may choose to prepare them at his own expense and submit them to inexpert judgment.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Saturday. Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes will reach his eighty-second birthday. No quotation could be made that would more thoroughly show forth Dr. Holmes's chief characteristic, that of unfailing good humor and cheerfulness, than the piquant one of his own, "It is better to be seventy years young than to be forty years old."

The presumptions of innocence which the friends of President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company have generously accorded him since the present exposures began must have suffered a severe blow in the letter which Cashier Banta has written, and which was printed in THE TIMES yesterday morning.

A very beautiful astronomical phenomenon will occur on the evenings of Sept. 4 and 5. Wolff's comet, which is now faintly visible in the constellation Aries, will pass over or occult some of the smaller stars of the Pleiades. At its nearest the comet will only be a few minutes north of Aleyone, the brightest star of the group.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 29. -- Major William Tillman, until recently a member of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners of Louisville, cashier of the defunct Falls City Bank, and social leader, is gone, and with him a large share of the bank's money. Until two months ago should a stranger have asked to see the model business man of Louisville Major Tillman would have been pointed out without hesitancy.

BAR, HARBOR, Aug. 29. -- The North Atlantic squadron ships have gone and the squadron of evolution is still in the bay, and after the exciting gayeties of the week Bar Harbor is trying to swing round to its normal Summer gayeties. The departed ships, however, have left a void behind them, and this will be increased by the departure of the others next week.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- The Rapid-Transit Commissioners have been guilty of making a proposition so redolent of Philistinism that the electric current might be expected to come down upon them from the overhead wires and lay them low. They protest that the Common occupies valuable space that is well-nigh indispensable to the thoroughfares of the city.

TIEN-TSIN, China, July 15. -- American newspapers frequently have random notes on the prospects of railways in China, and it is generally said that there is strong opposition among the people of this country to foreign innovations of all kinds, and to railroads in particular. It is recorded that there are strong superstitions about the sacredness of graves and many other reasons which cause the populace to rise against the introduction of the "fiery dragon."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- No doubt Mr. Wanamaker is a good organizer. Next to his high capability as a tradesman, with his apprehension what people will want to buy at each particular moment, is his ability to organize and systematize the processes of business affairs.

The preliminary examination before Acting District Attorney Gunning S. Bedford as to the cause of the collapse of the Taylor Building was concluded yesterday. The testimony procured will be used at the Coroner's inquest. Mr. Bedford says that the investigation has been of great value.

The latter part of August always sees a tremendous effort to predict the fashions of the future. While still new and beautiful things are being brought out for Summer wear, the restless, investigating spirit which characterizes the modern woman impels her to pry into the hidden vanities which do not as yet belong to her.

HARRISVILLE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The shooting season, which opened on the 15th, has so far been a good one on this side of the Adirondacks. Deer are reported to be very plenty in these parts, and sportsmen have had better luck than usual during the past two weeks. One party came out of the woods on Thursday and reported three deer killed in a single night on one of the Oswegatchie lakes.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- Orders have been issued by the Government calling upon the agricultural district officials to report as to the condition and the probable yield of wheat and rye. These reports are to be made before Sept. 8. Further reports concerning the potato crop are called for, and these must be in the hands of the Government before Sept. 20.

It was only three years ago that yachtsmen were boasting of the prowess of the Fife cutter Clara. In 1884 she sailed twenty-one races in English waters, and took seventeen first prizes and one second prize. In 1885 she came to this country and began by defeating all her competitors. In 1886 she started eleven times and took the prize in her class in every race.
MANHANSET HOUSE, Long Island, Aug. 29. -- Among the recent arrivals at the Manhanset House are the following:

ISLE OF MAN, Aug. 15. -- Half a battered skull emerging from the Irish Sea represents the outlines of the Isle of Man, whether charted on the map or seen from a distance. Its fame in the remotest ages agrees with its gruesome shape, and as it comes into history in later centuries the supernatural clings to it, while its record of human action has many a chapter that is sinister.

UTICA, Aug. 29. -- A person earning to Oneida County to look over the political situation ought to provide himself with a quantity of disinfectants, for nowhere in the State, or, perhaps, in the country, is a city so thoroughly abandoned to and controlled by the very worst elements of society as is Utica. How the people have endured this condition of affairs so long is a mystery to the average stranger.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Despite the closing of the races and the departure of the President, the season at Saratoga is still vigorous. There are a great many persons in the hotels, and the cottages are full, and the round of gayety prepared for the coming week equals anything we have had heretofore.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 29. -- A secret conference of prominent colored Republicans was held here yesterday, inspired by J.W. Townsend, who is a recorder in the General Land Office at Washington. Thursday night Townsend made a long speech in the colored church, reflecting on Republicans generally and the Administration in particular for not bestowing more patronage upon the colored race:

Having been asked by friends frequently for advice for their boys in handling guns, I send you a digest of same. Perhaps, as the shooting season will now be on soon, you might think them worth publication:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The stay of "The Lost Paradise'' at the Columbia, which ends to-night, has been too short. Had the great success of Mr. De Mille's play been foreseen several months ago, it might have been possible to have secured longer time in this city. The piece might probably be kept on the boards from now until after the holidays.

If money be the root of evil, envy is the root of industrial discontent. The laborer is at war with his employer chiefly because he envies the apparently excessive rewards of his employer's investment and labor. The rewards are apparently excessive because hitherto there has been a plentiful lack of all exact information as to what employers' profits are.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- Bright skies and a clear, bracing air greeted the "Autocrats of the Breakfast Table" when he sat down to his table at his Beverly Farms home this morning. Every one connected with the household greeted him with a cheery good morning and congratulations that twelve more than the allotted three score and ten years had been so kindly allowed to him, and that the prospect for yet other years was good.

The Century Club very rarely gets into print, but it has emphatically become one of the clubs of the town since it removed to its new home on Forty-third Street. It has always been an important organization front an artistic or literary standpoint, and now that it has a home outclassed by that or scarcely any other New-York club, it has come to rank as one of the half dozen leading metropolitan clubs.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Back come the cottagers to Lenox by scores from Newport, Bar Harbor, and other seaside resorts along the Atlantic coast. They are attracted here always the 1st of September after the resorts begin to wane elsewhere, and the months of September and October this year will be even livelier than they have been in previous seasons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Nothing in regard to yesterday's battle at Valparaiso was received at the headquarters of the Congressional Party in this city until late to-night, when the envoys received the following dispatch:

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Late last evening a meeting of the Democratic leaders of Cortland County was held in this village to prepare for the election of November. The Democrats realize that while the county is Republican the split in the majority party may result in Democratic victory. This is not alone true regarding the county ticket, but the member of Assembly stands within their reach.

SPIRIT LAKE, Iowa, Aug. 29. -- Gov. Boies delivered his second speech of the campaign here this afternoon. He was accompanied here by his daughter, Miss Boies; his niece, Miss Barber of Waterloo; Adjt. Gen. Greene and Mrs. Greene of Cedar Rapids, and members of his military staff and several of their lady friends, having come direct from the encampment of the Second Regiment of Davenport.

Word came yesterday of the death Friday at North Scituate, Mass., of Father Kemp, who was well known throughout the rural settlements of New-England from thirty to forty years ago as the manager of Olde Folke's concerts. He organized a small company which traveled through the rural districts every year giving olde folke's concerts.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 29. -- The famous Edwards claim for many million dollars' worth of property in New-York City is still an interesting subject of discussion here. Referring to a recent publication in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch of an interview with Dr. Chancellor, Mr. Harry L. Edwards, a young lawyer of this city, says:

ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- The Democratic Assembly District Conventions were held to-day. The only contest was in the Fourth District, being over the delegates from the Third Ward of West Troy. The contest was made by the Hill faction under the lead of Police Captain Boyle, but the regular delegates were seated. Resolutions indorsing the candidacy of Roswell P. Flower for Governor were adopted.

HARTFORD, Aug. 29. -- By the favorable turn in the weather the track at Charter Oak Park was fit for racing to-day, and the Grand Circuit programme was ended, despite the loss of a day. It was bright and cool and about 2,500 were present.

The statements made by Cashier Banta in his letter to THE TIMES are still an absorbing topic of conversation among insurance men and all who are interested in the standing of the New-York Life Insurance Company. Never in the history of life insurance in this country has there been so portentous a scandal or one affecting so many interests.

When the best performers from the East and West come together in the Summer tournament known as the Grand Circuit it requires more than one test to show the relative merits of the horses. In the slower classes especially there are always new developments, and the first two or three encounters are pretty sure to keep all the speculators guessing.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29. -- The proudest man in Central New-York to-day is John S. Kenyon, Clerk of the State Senate. His young daughter returned yesterday from a visit to the Adirondacks, at Sternberg's, in St. Lawrence County, and brought a buck which she shot. It was a creditable piece of work for a young girl who had never before handled a Winchester.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29. -- The great political question in this county and in this Senatorial district, comprising the counties of Onondaga and Cortland, is, "What is Jim Belden's game?" "Who is Belden's candidate for Senator?" the average Republican asks. Three men are in the field, one from Cortland, Rufus Take-It-All Peck, and two from Onondaga, Assemblyman Howard White and Lawyer Ceylon Lewis, both of this city.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Mr. Andrew D. White has been in the city the past two days, the guest of his brother, Horace K. White. He came to Syracuse for the purpose of consulting with his relatives and friends in relation to the Republican nomination for Governor. This morning Mr. White conferred with his cousin, Assemblyman Howard G. White, Congressman J.J. Belden, Senatar Francis Hendricks, and other prominent citizens.

Here is another story which I offer to the consideration of the correspondents who have been complaining lately that I am too hard on the Church of England. In the diocese of Exeter there is a living held by the son of the patron. This man is a more or less hopeless lunatic, but with lucid intervals. Periodically he retires into an asylum.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The annual shooting competition of the Division of the Atlantic, United States Army, comprising teams from all the posts east of the Mississippi River, has just closed at Fort Niagara, at the mouth of the famous old river. The shooting has been exceptionally good and has continued incessantly for the last two weeks, with the exception of two days, when the wind and rain storm interfered.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The hotels and boarding houses in the Catskills are yet in prosperous activity. It seems safe to predict that they will be kept open later than usual to accommodate the large contingent of visitors who will linger to see the mountain sides and hillsides a blaze of glory and to enjoy the splendor of Autumn foliage.

The prospect for Fall business in real estate was certainly never better than it is now, and there have been few years in which it was so bright. Every dealer is looking forward to as much business as he can master during the ensuing three or four months. Nearly 1,500 lots of property are already booked for sale at auction during the month of September.

Three plays new to this city will be produced at prominent theatres to-morrow night. Of these, "The Dancing Girl," by Henry Arthur Jones, is the one about which the most curiosity has been excited. It was current at the Haymarket, Beerbohm Tree's theatre, in London, nearly all last season, and will probably be played there, to the exclusion of other pieces, most of this Fall and Winter.

The Russian Government is at last beginning to realize the gravity of the situation created by the failure of the crops in Western Russia. On Tuesday an imperial ukase was issued forbidding the export of "rye, ryemeal, and every kind of bran from the Russian ports in the Baltic, the Black Sea, and the Sea of Azof, or over tide western frontier, this measure to come into force on the 27th inst."
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The restless visitors who hurried away from Long Branch early this year have not only missed the greatest events of this season, but of any season.

It is hardly probable that the leaders of the dress reform crusade themselves expect the radical measures which they suggest to be adopted in their entirety. That they will succeed in simplifying woman's dress and abolishing some of its exaggerations and serious evils many women hope and believe and are ready to aid in their accomplishment by precept and example.

One evening last week my young comrade entered my office after an absence of three days. The youth smiled wearily as our eyes met, and said, as he unslung his creel and stood his rod in a corner: "I am pumped out. I have had a time, such a time, catching trout. Look!" he exclaimed as he unstrapped and opened the creel. It was packed full of dressed fish.

WELLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The little village of Wellsburg, six miles below Elmira, on the Erie Road, is wild with excitement to-night. Gas has been discovered issuing from a well which was originally put down to secure good water. Last night a stream of gas was flowing from the pipe sunk in the ground on the village lot of C.E. Van Buskirk, which an expert says would illuminate the whole county.

-- The Three Miss Kings. By Ada Cambridge. New-York : D. Appleton Co. -- Take three Australian women, born and bred in the bush, whose names are Elizabeth, Eleanor, and Patty, transport the entire female bevy from the wilds to cultured Melbourne, set them up there, marry all three, and you have the task the author has committed herself to.

The sun hastens off toward the equator very rapidly throughout September, and on the 23d -- at 3:06 in the morning, to be exact -- astronomical Autumn begins. The sun rises at 5:27 Sept. 1, whereas it rose at 4:32 on the corresponding day of August. Its hour of setting is 6:33 on Sept. 1, as against 7:35 on the same day of August.

The disposition to do business over the curbstone is apparently not confined to the New Street brokers. Reputable down-town merchants, contractors, and mendicants seem to be laboring under the impression that the city should grant them full scope in the public thoroughfares rent free. Most of the down-town streets are now so hampered with obstructions that pedestrians are obliged to exercise both ingenuity and dexterity in order to make their way from place to place.

The political outbreak in Nicaragua described in the papers of this city last Wednesday does not come as a surprise to any one acquainted with the state of political feeling in that country. On the contrary, it was apparent to the most casual observer who accompanied the Nicaragua Canal Expedition to that country last Spring that serious trouble was brewing between the two parties that contend for the control of the Government.

The trials of the new twelve-inch rifled breech-loader at Sandy Hook confirm the impression that one of the urgent wants of the Ordnance Department is better powder. The gun is undoubtedly good, but the highest initial velocity it has yet reached is only 1,860 feet per second, and about 100 feet more should be attained without going beyond 38,000 pounds pressure.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 15. -- To have loitered two months in England may atone, in some degree, for the popular offense of having gone around the world, for of all the forms of infatuation affecting this generation, the most unreasonable is the mad desire to get from place to place in a given time. For purposes of intelligence, a bale of goods would do equally well and perhaps make the journey a little quicker.

THE TIMES deserves the sincere thanks of every honest man in the United States for its outspoken exposure of the deplorable state into which the American Navy has fallen. Our navy has a history of which any nation might be proud. The war of 1812 was a series of splendid victories for us, of many humiliations for England. Our civil war revolutionized the naval architecture of the world.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29. -- The Wild Hunters' branch of the Mutual One-Year Benefit Order of this city is no more. Thirty hard-working Germans and men of other nationalities in the humble pursuits of life have been made its victims for several months, and they refused to stand it any longer.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 29. -- The Smoky City team didn't encounter any difficulty in defeating the big New-York aggregation hero to-day. In the opening inning the local players took a big lead, and held it throughout the contest.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 29. -- Ezra Comfort of Delphos, this State, who joined the Owens integral co-operative colony in Mexico about a year ago, has returned from that land of promise with a story of suffering and distress. He was an enthusiastic member of the colony that was formed to go to Topolobampo, believing that he had found the solution for all his troubles in co-operation.

Mr. Irving M. Scott, General Manager of the Union Iron Works of San Francisco, arrived in this city last week from Europe. Mr. Scott, whose name is familiar to the readers of THE TIMES in connection with war-ship construction on the Pacific coast, has been abroad for the purpose of observing the latest features in ship designs.
Will you allow me space to plead, in a few words, the cause of a wise and noble educational institution, in which THE TIMES has shown by repeated commendations its interest?

It has become manifest to Englishmen as well as to Anglo-Indians that British rule in India is now in a more precarious condition than it has been since it was established, with the single exception furnished by the Sepoy mutiny more than a generation ago. The anxiety felt upon the subject is shown by the frequent meetings of the Indian Council, and it is reflected in the columns of the best-informed English journals.

Make way for His Highness! The champion. Sir Matthew, made so by his victory in the Junior Champion, is dethroned. There is but one champion, there can be but one, and his name is His Highness. Sir Matthew made no attempt to defend his spurious title. Matt. Byrnes knew there was no use in his trying to do so, and he wisely avoided the battle.

Early in September, 1872, I was staying for a few days at the Falls of Reichenbach, at the foot of the Grimsel Pass and at the beginning or the ascent of the Grand Scheidegg. Excursions to the "High Alps" were at an end. Snow was beginning to fall there, and the peasants were driving down their cows and goats from the upper chalets.

George Washburn, Captain of the Thirty-first Precinct, is one of the tallest men on the police force, has curly gray hair, weighs more than 250 pounds, and was so much of a veteran that after the Commissioners retired him as a sexagenarian he proved his army record and fought his way back into the department through the courts.

Both the Opera Comique and the Gymnase will be opened for the Fall and Winter next Tuesday night. At the Opera Comique the first piece will be "Le Reve," by Zola, Gallet, and Bruneau. The play at the Gymnase will be "Mme. Agnes," a comedy in three acts, by M. Julien Berr de Turique, which is soon to be followed by a revival of Daudet's "Numa Roumestan" reduced to four acts.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Pedestrians on the east side of Riverside Avenue last night saw a man whom they supposed to be drunk lying close to the fence in front of John L. Wheeler's property. The man's back was braced against a short locust tree, one leg was drawn up under him, and his head leaned toward the sidewalk. He was first seen at 7:45 by John Marchment, a young Englishman.
COHASSER, Mass., Aug. 29. -- "Down the Jerusalem Road! See the houses of Crane, Robson, and Barrett! All aboard!"

" Cabbe-Roquebrune is a medieval cluster of houses presided over by the ruined castles of the Lascaris," says a letter from Nice in the London Times, "and it gives a spot of human interest in that lovely prospect, swimming in light and colors, that the indolent look up to from the terraces of Monte Carlo or the promenades of Mentone, and the enterprising attain to.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 29. -- In spite of the sunshine this morning, the weatherwise residents pointed out various signs of a coming storm. Mrs. Harrison and her home party, however, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. John W. Buckman, went on a crabbing expedition from Sewell's Point. The party started about 10 o'clock and reached home again about 3.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, Lake Champlain, Aug. 29. -- Thursday marked the end of the three weeks' meet of the American Conoe Association, and a very successful meet it was, too. The site of the camp was all that could be desired, save that the Commodore's tent and the headquarters were too far away from the main camp.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Half dozen well-contested clay-pigeon matches were shot by members of the New-Jersey Shooting Club this afternoon. An unusually large number of marksmen participated in each event, and the scores of the prize winners were high. In several cases there were ties, but they were not shot off. Tie men divided prizes of shells. The summary shows the birds broken by winners:
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- David B. Hill and Edward Murphy, Jr., were given a smashing blow to-day by the Democrats of Montgomery County.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The season of 1891 is drawing to a close. While the hotel registers continue to show large numbers of visitors, the cottagers are preparing to take their departure. Many have left this week, and more will go in the next few days. However, the hotel population will not decrease materially for several weeks.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 29. -- The Boston and Maine Railroad's answer to the complaint made against it before the Inter-State Commerce Commission by Senator Chandler is attracting considerable attention throughout this State and on the part of railroad men in Boston. It has been published in full in the Boston newspapers and in the leading journals of New-Hampshire.

The death of Mr. WINDOM caused the first change in the Cabinet of Mr. HARRISON. That was followed by a purely political -- and personally political -- appointment, that of Mr. FOSTER. There was no effort to conceal the motive of this selection, perhaps because any effort would have been useless. Mr. FOSTER was not a financier.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The police authorities have succeeded in putting a stop to numerous burglaries which have caused much annoyance. Considerable of the stolen property has been recovered and restored to owners, some of whom objected to prosecuting the cases. A boy named Reynolds, fifteen years old, has been sent to the Reform School.

Some of the Littlefield church ladies had fallen into the way of saving "Poor Mrs. Maxwell," a habit so misleading that a stranger who might have heard Mrs. Maxwell mentioned with this unfortunate qualifying word would naturally have been led to suppose that she was in some sort an object of charity, a person who made a perpetual drain on the sympathies of her friends.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 29. -- By the death last week of the Clerk of Clark County, Ind., one of the most peculiar, yet most thriving, industries of Jeffersonville, the county seat, just across the river from this city, was temporarily paralyzed. This industry is nothing more nor less than the tying of nuptial knots for eloping couples from Kentucky and elsewhere.

The news brought in by the scouts did not demoralize Capt. Hugh Beatty or his men. They did not expect to get out of Tennessee without a fight, and if it had to come there could be no better time nor place. A great fire had been lighted near the spring, but it would be fatal to remain about the light with the enemy in the outer circle of darkness.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- In the two Democratic District Conventions held in this county to-day the anti-Hill faction had the best of it. The feeling against Hill and his local representatives is such that at the city caucuses Warden Durston of the prison only captured one ward.

About one-third of the Australian Continent is attached to the colony of South Australia. This third lies in a belt from 450 to 600 miles wide, extending across the centre of the continent from north to south. Near the southern extremity and on the coast is the City of Adelaide, and near it are the other towns of the colony.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Summer visitors here are still trying to amuse themselves, and coaching, tennis, bowling, and strolling fill the day, while cards, dancing, candy pulls, and concerts make the evening's sport. There are still many persons here, and a goodly number are expected Sept. 1.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Rev. Frederick H. Gates of Macedon, N.Y., has accepted the call of the Baptist Church at Saugerties, and will enter upon the duties of his new charge Oct. 1.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 29. -- The proprietors of the big hotels are preparing to put up the "storm doors," for they realize that the season is about over. The exodus from the Park and Grove began early this week, and the breaking up of the great Ocean Grove camp meeting caused thousands of guests to pack their trunks and start for their city homes.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Again the city is in peace and quietness. Once more have the "Bill" Brown heelers slunk away to their home on the river's bank at Sing Sing. Now that they are gone and that the battle is ended, perhaps it may prove an interesting question for Warden Brown to consider what he and his friends have gained by the political fight that was unnecessarily brought about.

The eleventh annual picnic and games of the Printers' Benevolent Association were held at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday. There was a large crowd in attendance and the affair proved a grand success. In the afternoon the games were contested. In past years the amateur athletes of this vicinity were allowed to compete, but this was not the case yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- There is a feeling among navy officers who want the dignity and discipline of the service maintained, that it is the duty of Rear Admiral Gherardi to prefer formal charges against Acting Admiral Walker. If this is done Acting Admiral Walker cannot escape a court-martial. It is not seen how Secretary Tracy can ignore the matter now anyhow.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29. -- Prof. W.S. Chaplin, Professor of Engineering at Harvard University, and Dean of the Lawrence Scientific School, has been elected Chancellor of Washington University, and will enter upon his duties as soon as necessary arrangements can be made for his withdrawal from Harvard, probably by the 1st of November.

The call for next Thursday's meeting of the Citizens' anti-park-grab Committee of One Hundred at the Hotel Brunswick will probably reach the members of the committee to-morrow, and this will end the preliminary arrangements for the meeting. From the number of responses at hand from members of the committee it is confidently expected that the meeting will be well attended, and there is no doubt that it will be an earnest and business like gathering.

Gaetano Russo, the sculptor of Rome, has written to Cavalier Carlo Barsotti, the editor of Il Progresso Italo-Americano, that the work upon the Columbus statue which Editor Barsotti will present to this city on behalf of the Italian population, is progressing in the most satisfactory manner. Some description has already been given of the statue itself, the newspapers having printed it, some of them illustrating it when the sculptor's design was accepted.
DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 29. -- The hotel people at the Water Gap are preparing for a busy September season. The present prospects indicate that the month will be as gay as August has been.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 29. -- A storm is breaking in the Kansas Alliance, which bids fair to disrupt that organization. The President has given notice that he will not countenance those who are now presenting all sorts of wild schemes, financial and otherwise. The Sub-Treasury plan advocates have organized a fight upon him and will attempt to break his power at the annual meeting next month.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- The new dancing school for girls, conducted under the auspices of Sir Augustus Harris at Drury Lane Theatre, is pronounced to be a success. Mme. Phasey is instructor of these young ladies, ranging in age from sixteen to twenty years, who, in order to be admitted to the school, have to enter into a contract for three years; beginning at a salary of $2.50 per week.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- The Globe this afternoon, commenting upon the capture of Valparaiso and the consequent utter downfall of Balmaceda, says that the Congressional victory gives the Espiegle affair a much more serious complexion, adding:

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30. -- The Alliance in this State is having serious trouble within its circles that may have a calamitous ending for that organization.
