At this time it looks as though disintegration had begun, which means disaster to the People's Party. Alliance members are not responding as freely as heretofore with their assessments, nor are they paying their regular dues.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Gen. Joseph T. Torrence, President of the Chicago Elevated Terminal Railway Company, returned to-day from an inspection of railway terminals in the European cities. He says he is now convinced that the elevated terminal is the only solution of Chicago's railroad problem.

Fire broke out Saturday night in the three-story frame building in San Francisco, occupied by A. Lusk Co., canners, and the California Automatic Canning Company. The total loss amounts to $100 000 divided as follows: Automatic Company. loss on machinery and stock, $70,000, insured for $37,000; A. Lusk Co., loss on machinery and stock $20,000, oil building, $10,000, fully insured.

ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- The annual report of the State Forest Commission has just been received from the printer. As an appendix is a catalogue of maps, field notes, surveys and land papers of patents, grants, and tracts situate within the Forest Preserve, which was prepared by J.B. Koelteritz, C.E. This is considered a very important document. The report, in speaking of trespasses, says:

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 2. -- Tsai Tien, Emperor of China, grandson of the Emperor Tao Kuang, nephew of the Emperor Hsien Feng, and first cousin of the Emperor Tung Chih, known since his selection of the imperial purple by the name of Kuang Hsu, was, by English reckoning, twenty years old yesterday, and has reigned in his own name for nearly two years and a half.

Mrs. Harriet E. Beach, the unfortunate wife of Editor Beach of the Scientific American, the woman who fell into the snares of Ann Odelia Dis Debar, and was, on the certificate of two physicians, committed to the Bloomingdale Asylum by Judge Beach of the Supreme Court, has written a long letter to the Governors of the New-York Hospital, discharging thereby, as she puts it, her duty to her country and her fellow-sufferers.

SENECA, Mo., Aug. 30. -- A temperance crusade is in progress here, with odds in favor of the crusaders. Col. C.J. Helt, the temperance lecturer of Decatur, Ill., under the auspices of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, has for ten days been stirring the people up by a series of forcible lectures.

MIDLAND, Texas, Aug. 30. -- The rain-making experiment inaugurated by the Government, and which has been operating on the Morris Ranch, twenty-five miles from this place, is to be pushed to a final and thorough test regardless of what operations or results of the Dyrenfurth party have been.

The question has been frequently asked, How did President William H. Beers manage to obtain so complete a control of the New-York Life Insurance Company? What influence did he possess that enabled him to continue his depredations throughout a period of a dozen or fifteen years without exciting the antagonism of those whose business it was to watch him and protect the interests of the company's policy holders?

SHANGHAI, China, July 31. -- The recent additions made by the Chinese Government to its already large navy have caused much uneasiness among Japanese statesmen, and have brought forward prominently the suspicions which Japan always feels for China as its ever-threatening enemy. This feeling has been further augmented by the dispatch of a large Chinese Iron-clad fleet, under Admiral Ping, to visit the various seaport cities of Japan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Senor Montt late last night received the following cablegram:

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30. -- So many conflicting statements have been made regarding the effect of the prohibition law in this State, as well as its enforcement, that a personal inspection of its working has been made by THE TIMES'S representative in twenty counties. The result of this tour, taken in connection with the knowledge obtained from members of the Legislature last Winter, forces the belief, primarily, that prohibition in Kansas is a permanent fixture.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30. -- J.M. Cammack, the brother of the New-York millionaire, who disappeared mysteriously three weeks ago, is thought to have been murdered. On Friday Manager Thorn of the Grand Hotel received a letter of inquiry from another brother, G.W. Cammack, who lives in Illinois. To-day a second letter was received from him in regard to the missing man.

It is scarcely to be expected that the forestry associations, however strenuous their efforts, will be able to make way against the tide of progress which is rapidly converting the timber lands of this country into farms and city lots; but it is not unreasonable to hope that the tendency toward the substitution of slate and metal roofing for the pine shingle of our fathers may be at least temporarily cheeked if not altogether overcome.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The probability that the Congressional Party in Chile will soon be in complete and undisputed control of the Government of that country has once more made the Itata a subject of discussion, and there is considerable speculation as to whether the new Government will demand the payment of heavy damages by the United States for interfering with the delivery of the arms carried from the United States in that vessel.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 30. -- An accidental capture of a notorious boarding-house thief who is wanted in several places in Pennsylvania was made here to-day at the Union Station by Detectives Hutchinson of Belvidere and McClallen of Hacketstown. The officers were working up the recent murder of Theodore H. Freeze at Belvidere by a negro, and were on their way to New-York and Jersey City.

It is announced that Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE, after consultation with his friends and family, has telegraphed to Senator HISCOCK that, while he is not a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor in the sense of seeking it, yet he will accept it if it be offered to him unanimously and if the platform shall be such as he approves.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- There is an unprecedented homeward rush of Summer travel down the Hudson. The first train from the Catskills down the Ulster and Delaware Road Saturday morning brought 500 tourists, and the same number were brought down the Catskill Mountain Road to Catskill Landing. After that every mountain train was packed.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Aug. 30. -- A gloomy day, with rain in the morning, was the President's experience here to-day. The house party was a pleasant and comfortable one, and Mr. Harrison showed his thorough content at being again with his family. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Cale and Russell Harrison were additions to what may be called the resident family.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- The Ohio campaign can now be regarded as opened, so far as the Republican Party is concerned. They have commenced their work under the most favorable conditions, the bright and sunshiny weather having contributed largely to the success of the gatherings that have greeted Major McKinley and listened with marked attention to his discussion of the tariff.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 30. -- The regular monthly cotton crop report for the Memphis district, which embraces West Tennessee, North Mississippi, North Arkansas, and North Alabama, to be issued to-morrow by Hill, Fontaine Co., will say:

Officer Michael Mahoney of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station has a penchant for argument that has earned for him the title of the "lawyer cop." What he does not know about the law he thinks is little and worthless. Officer Mahoney has a great antipathy for street peddlers. He arrests them whenever he gets a chance, and makes it his business to get the chance often.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- There is trouble everywhere. The builders are beginning to look about with anxious eyes, for appearances indicate that long before the swallow's flight and prior to the Winter rains -- succeeding to the Summer rains -- no one will be on hand to finish the countless residences and apartment houses springing up like mushrooms all over our city.

In the death of Mr. George Jones New-York journalism loses a man who has done it honor. Mr. Jones has not been the creator of a policy, but be has been an example of incorruptible principle. It was his good fortune in life to be endowed with the energy and intelligence which lead to wealth, rather than with wealth itself.

SHANGHAI, China, July 31. -- A disturbance, which it was feared might lead to serious trouble between England and Holland, has this month been amicably adjusted. For several years the boundary line between the English and Dutch possessions in Borneo has caused much hard feeling among the settlers of both countries living near the disputed lines, which has on several occasions almost broken out into open fighting.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union, Delegate George K. Lloyd submitted a set of resolutions in regard to the Park Place disaster. He said that several of the Building Inspectors knew little or nothing about buildings. The father of Senator Cantor, he said, was a fair specimen of the lot. He was a Building Inspector, but by trade he was a shoemaker.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30. -- An Elkton special to the Sun says: "The worst fire in Elkton for years started at 4:30 o'clock this morning on the south side of Main Street, and for a while threatened to destroy some of the principal business places of the town.

There is a Brooklyn small boy whose highest ambition is to tie cans to the tails of such wandering ours as happen his way. The capture of a victim and the subsequent spectacle of the animal striking up a record-breaking gait to escape from the rattling addition to his anatomy is a thing from which the average small boy, and this one in particular, generally succeeds in extracting much enjoyment.

MOBERLY, Mo., Aug. 30. -- William Foyer, a resident of Moberly, the United States prisoner who was so mercilessly whipped in jail at Denver, Col., has been brought home. To THE TIMES'S correspondent he told the story of his brutal treatment.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30. -- There are breakers ahead for Senator Preston B. Plumb. Members of his party are very much dissatisfied with his course, and his old friends are at a loss to understand him.

Important developments in the affairs of the Union Pacific Railroad are expected this week. A meeting of the recently-appointed financiering committee, of which J. Pierpont Morgan is the head, will be held to-day or to-morrow in this city. It is probable that the outcome of the meeting may be of greater significance than the mere putting into effect of the scheme for carrying the floating debt.

KIEL, Aug. 31. -- The new Chilean war ship Presidente Pinto has coaled and is now ready for sea. It is reported that she will soon sail with the view of shipping war material from the Armstrong vessels outside the three-mile limit.

The Sultan's abject submission to the demands of the Czar touching the passage of the Dardanelles is a curious illustration of the change that a generation has wrought in European politics. Forty years ago demands not more imperious than those to which the Sultan has now yielded became the cause of a European war, in which England, France, Italy, and Turkey were arrayed against Russia.

CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Hamilton Fish, Jr., had full control of the Republican County Convention which met here last Thursday. Last year a Patterson politician, William A. Towner, made a bitter fight against Fish, but was badly beaten. It was believed that Platt was at the bottom of Towner's revolt. This year, however, Fish has had no opposition within the lines of his party.

It was a very agreeable surprise to the managers of the Coney Island Jockey Club to see so large a number of people at the track as were there yesterday. Monday is usually an off day, and anything like a crowd is never looked for. But the card was an exceptionally attractive one, for though there was no particular star event, there was a fair quality of starters named for each one of the races.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore of the American Museum of Natural History got back from Labrador last Saturday. With him came many photographs of icebergs, Esquimaus, and other natural and human products of that almost unknown northern country, together with a great quantity of notes and other material for the lecture on "Food Fishes from the Sea," which is to be the concluding one of the professor's Fall course of lectures to teachers.

The yearlings of the Peytona, Hurstbourne, and Ferncliffe studs were sold at auction by William Easton at the Tattersalls salesrooms last evening, and as a rule fetched small prices. There was a good attendance of horsemen, but the lots were generally of unknown quality and in such poor condition that bidding was slow and no fancy prices were realized.

MEDINA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- To-day a terrific hailstorm extending over most of the fruit belt of Orleans and Niagara Counties did immense damage. The hail came with terrible force, outing the fruit and foliage badly. Grapes were practically ruined in many places, and pears, apples, and other fruit were damaged to an extent which it is feared will seriously affect the crop.

An exhibition "turning-over" of the big 9,000 horse power engines for the armored cruiser Maine was given yesterday at the shops of the builders, N.F. Palmer, Jr., Co. of this city. The exhibition was in itself a complete novelty, the engines being run as they stood in the shops by a set of compound pump engines geared on to each shaft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Official corroboration of Balmaceda's fall reached the State and Navy Departments this morning. Acting Secretary Wharton received the following cablegram dated Valparaiso, Aug. 30, 9:30 P.M.:

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 31. -- The proposed removal of the Hon. W.L. Scott to Newport was not effected to-day. His illness took a more alarming turn this morning, and physicians decided it unsafe to make the attempt. There is no doubt Mr. Scott is dangerously ill. Dr. Pepper, the Philadelphia physician who came here Friday, was called away Sunday upon important consultation and has not yet returned.

Two more bodies were found yesterday in the ruins of the Taylor Building on Park Place. They were readily identified. One was the body of Neuman Goldschmidt, twenty-nine years old, of 417 East Seventy-ninth Street, foreman for Rosenfeld Co., the gold paint manufacturers; the other was that of Samuel Blitz, twenty-seven years old, of 263 Houston Street, an employe in the same establishment.

While revising their tariff our neighbors in Mexico have had in mind our recent legislation with respect to imported sliver-lead ores and the opportunity to lay the foundation for a tariff trade. Our dispatches show that in the new tariff, which will become operative on Nov. 1, the duties on a considerable number of products have been largely increased.

Everybody must admit that trades unions have, upon the whole, conferred benefits upon the general mass of workmen in the trades in which they have been organized. The extent of these benefits depends upon the honesty and judgment with which the unions have been managed, and where these qualities have been wanting to their management, there are cases in which the union has inflicted injuries instead of conferring benefits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Officers of the navy continue to discuss with great interest the Gherardi-Walker case, and they wonder whether it is to be allowed to pass without adjustment in a way at once just to Admiral Gherardi and beneficial to the service.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- At 8 o'clock this evening several oil cars in a Central Hudson freight train left the east-bound track, owing to a defective truck, a mile east of the Schenectady station. The entire four tracks were completely blocked, and it was three hours before west-bound trains were able to go forward.

It is a curious case that is presented by the claim of the owner of the racehorse Huron for "second money" in the Futurity Stakes, for it is a claim on behalf of an animal that was admitted to the race only in obedience to the order of a court, and that was not officially recognized as being in the race, and was not officially placed, though it is not disputed that he finished second.

Col. David E. Austen of the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, is going on a month's yachting trip to-morrow, so he sent a letter to Mayor Chapin yesterday, handing over the care of the new armory to him and making a few more complaints about the loose way it is being constructed. In the course of this letter he says:

The examination on the charge of mutiny preferred by Capt. Williams of the four-masted ship Frederick Billings against three of his sailors, Edward Clark, James Heath, and Thomas Hayes, was begun yesterday before United States Commissioner Hitchcock. Capt. Williams gave his testimony, which did not differ from the story of the trouble on board the Billings when she came into port last week, and the hearing was adjourned until this morning.

The first convention of the season -- and it is one that will be watched by the politicians with interest only second to the forthcoming conventions at Rochester and Saratoga -- will convene in the Lexington Avenue Opera House to-day, when the delegates of the State Association of Retail Liquor Dealers assemble. That it will be a lively affair is beyond question.

Our neighbor, the Evening Post, is still uneasy about the Itata. Without knowing anything about the case one way or the other, the Post became a desperate partisan of the Chilean insurgents at the time the Itata escaped from San Diego, and it is now sorely troubled lest the victorious Congressional Party should bring in a bill for damages against the United States for pursuing that vessel and bringing her back within our jurisdiction.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- Gov. Hill has brought his disreputable methods to bear in Albany County. Failing to secure representation in the Fourth Assembly District Convention Saturday, Hill, through his canal heelers, Garside, Harden, and Simmons, immediately issued a call for primaries in the Fourth District, which were held this evening.

The National Rifle Association begins today its annual prize meeting, which will last through the week. Usually no Dyronforth has bean needed in the surrounding regions on these occasions, the regular September assemblage of the marksmen at Creedmoor affording an assurance of torrents of rain such as explosions of gas balloons or dynamite could not easily accelerate.
A tall, well-dressed man, with blue eyes and a beaver hat, drove up in a coupe to the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Sunday and approached Clerk W.M. Dunn with an air of great familiarity.

Acting Rear Admiral Walker, the commander of the white squadron, has brought great reproach upon the United States Navy by his treatment of Admiral Gherardi. THE NEW-YORK TIMES says that when the white squadron steamed into port at Bar Harbor the other day Admiral Gherardi ran up the signal on his flagship, the Philadelphia, "Anchor at your discretion."

Secretary Foster's rosy announcement of Saturday, to which the Administration newspapers gave prominent space, that a syndicate of bankers in this city had agreed to send him on his yachting trip to-morrow in a state of elation by absorbing from $5,000,000 to $6,000,000 of the 4 1/2 per cent. bonds at 2 per cent. miscarried yesterday, and Mr. Foster must console himself during his vacation with thoughts of what might have been.

Gov. Hill's programme for the New-York State Democracy this year may, after all, be subject to revision. Caucuses and county conventions thus far held do not reveal that entire satisfaction with his management that is visible when a partisan machine is in perfect running order.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 31. -- The extraordinary session of the Forty-seventh General Assembly began at noon to-day. Interviews with Senators and Representatives from Middle and West Tennessee seem to indicate that the sentiment of their people is against any change in the prison system that would be attended by an increase in the rate of taxation.

Despite the drawbacks which might be expected to attend the introduction of Indians as soldiers into the regular army, the work seems to be meeting with much success. What is remarkable is that some of the aborigines, who have usually been reckoned among the more intractable bands, show particularly good results in their military training.

Dr. Walter Beebe, the assistant chemist of the Health Department, who has been making an inspection of the middle branch of the Croton River, made a preliminary report to President Wilson of the department yesterday. It was determined by President Wilson not to make this report public until the analysis of the samples of water taken from the river has been completed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31 -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day, Judge Acheson handed down an opinion in the case of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the Northern Central Railroad Company, and the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad Company against the Allegheny Valley Railroad Company, Townsend Whelan and James B. Murray, Trustees, and others.

HARTFORD, Aug. 31. -- In the Town of Bloomfield, at an early hour yesterday morning, Henry Frederick Bushenhagen, aged sixty-nine years, and his wife, Emily, aged seventy-one, were murdered. Not content with killing them, the murderer frightfully mutilated their bodies and then threw them into an old well.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- Newport has seen many grand entertainments this season and they have all had excellent weather, so that the guests did not confine themselves entirely to the houses, but were at liberty to stroll about the spacious lawns, and, in fact, this feature was encouraged, and separate music was had at the large balls for promenading upon the lawns.

ROME, Aug. 31. -- The attitude of the Italian Government with reference to the next conclave, and the discussions of the same question in the Italian papers, continue to produce a deep and lively impression in enlightened ecclesiastical circles. The leading Cardinals are much impressed with the passionate interest manifested by Italian politicians in insisting on the necessity of holding the conclave at Rome.

BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- The new Harvard bridge across the Charles River will be opened to the patient public to-morrow morning at 8 o'clock. After all the delay and litigation, it is deemed best to have no formal ceremony, apart from quietly knocking down the fence on the Cambridge side, which has long been the only barrier to teams.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 31. -- The annual shoot of the Dominion Rifle Association commenced this morning. It was just 8:25 o'clock when Sergt. Dunnett discharged the cannon as a signal to begin, and in five minutes afterward the popping of the rifles was heard all along the lines.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31 -- As usual, Buffalo will present a candidate for a State office at both political conventions. Ex-Mayor Philip Becker will appear in the Republican gathering at Rochester as Buffalo's candidate for Governor, and Speaker William F. Sheehan at the Democratic assemblage at Saratoga as Buffalo's candidate for Lieutenant Governor.

Women with children, nurses, and hand-baggage, men with valises lengthened by umbrellas and canes shoved under the straps so as to occupy the easements of three seats, and young women clad in dusters ad russet complexions and shoes, were plentiful in elevated trains yesterday and a sign to the most unobservant that the tide of Summer travel had once more turned homeward.

Some of our contemporaries have been publishing with much apparent satisfaction the substance of certain assertions made three or four weeks ago by the Philadelphia Press, which undertook to show how the price of tin plate would have been affected by "a duty high enough," if such a duty had been imposed some years ago.

The announcement of Special Census Agent IVAN PETROFF that the population of Alaska has actually decreased during the last ten years comes as a surprise. The falling off in Nevada from the census of 1880 is, to be sure, far greater than in Alaska, while Vermont has not quite held its own.

The Treasury Department has decided to appeal to the courts from the decision of the Board of General Appraisers concerning the doubling of the high McKinley duties on carpet wool. It will be recalled that by the McKinley tariff the duties on the two grades of wool of the third class, or carpet wool, were increased from 24 12 per cent. and 30 12 per cent. to 32 per cent. and 50 per cent., respectively.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 1. -- J. Scott Ferguson, attorney for James A. Chambers, the well-known window-glass manufacturer, said this afternoon that his client had determined to make an assignment for the benefit of creditors, and would probably do-so on Thursday. All bu one of Mr. Chambers's creditors have consented to an extension, but as that one holds paper for nearly $200,000, it was considered folly to hold the others off.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 1. -- The studied persistency with which Jay Gould shuns California is something of a marvel to those not knowing the strange character of the Wizard of Wall Street. Three times within the short space of two years he has been within 300 miles of the State line, but neither business interests nor the solicitation of personal friends could induce him to take a trip to San Francisco.

A resident of Croton Falls, writing to THE TIMES concerning the pollution of Croton water, suggests other sources of corruption than the sewage from towns and the small amount that he admits may escape from barns and farm buildings. He points out that the low water in the Sodom Dam Reservoir has exposed much ground from which the condition of the entire bottom may be argued.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- There have been many inquiries to-day at the State Department as to what message has been sent from Chile by the Minister of the United States, Mr. Egan, concerning the overthrown Government of Balmaceda, to which he had been accredited by Mr. Blaine and Mr. Harrison. Up to a late hour in the afternoon Assistant Secretary Wharton had not received a word from him.

There is one phase of current politics the treatment of which by the Republican State Convention will be watched with much interest. It has been semi-officially announced that Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE, former President of the great university at Ithaca, will be the "unanimous choice" of the delegates as candidate for the office of Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Secretary Foster's monthly debt statement, which presents the assuring figures of a net cash balance of more than sixty millions printed in black type, would, if recast according to the form of statement made out by Mr. Windom in February, 1890, show a net cash balance available for all demands of about thirteen millions of dollars.

Theodore M. Banta has been yielded up by the Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company as a sacrifice to the vengeance of President Beers. The Trustees came to their President's rescue at a special meeting called for that purpose Monday afternoon. Mr. Beers lost no time in dismissing Mr. Banta when authority to do so had been given him.

Four races were on the card for decision at the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday that should have brought to the track an enormous crowd. These were stake races, and a high class of horses were named as competitors. Yet the attendance was very small for a stake day, no more than there used to be on an off day being present.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The three St. Lawrence County Assembly District Republican Conventions were held to-day. The convention for the First District was held at Gouverneur. George R. Malby of Ogdensburg was renominated for member of Asssembly. The delegates to the Congressional Convention were instructed to support Gen. N.M. Curtis of Ogdensburg for member of Congress.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The Democratic primaries held here at noon to-day were the most exciting in the history of the city. The fight was between the Hill forces, organized and led by State Committeeman Samuel A. Beardsley and the local canal ring, and the anti-Hill men, who favor Walter Ballou of Boonville for State Committeeman. The result was a victory for Hill, but it was a dearly-bought one.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The Board of Charities and Police, composed of the Democratic Mayor, (Wadsworth,) and two Republican Commissioners, last night dismissed Chief of Police Davis and discharged the Superintendent of Charities, William Anderson. The changes were made as the result of a deal by the Mayor and Commissioner T.K. Smith after Commissioner Lewis, who was ignorant of the deal, had left the room, supposing all business had been disposed of.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 1. -- City Clerk H.B. Cook for months has been charged by a local paper with being a defaulter. His accounts were examined two years ago and he was paid 27 cents which the committee said was due him. He resigned in July, and demanded an examination of his accounts since the time he took office, five years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- This week the Grand Circuit cracks are at the Philadelphia Driving Park, and they made a fairly good beginning to-day. The weather continues heavy and dark, but the rain held off and two events were finished. The 2,20 class proved rather surprising, as Play Boy, the favorite, got the first heat, but got demoralized after that, so that Pocahontas Prince gathered in the money.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- The Lee-Riddle wedning at Glen Riddle to-night was the occasion of a brilliant gathering. The ceremony took place at 7 P.M., at a small Presbyterian Church about a hundred yards from the Riddle mansion. The Rev. T.J. Wylie of the Broad Street Presbyterian Church officiated.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 1. -- The convention of the Twenty-fourth and Twenty-sixth joint-Senatorial District, which was held in this city to-day, was in many respects the most interesting contest of the kind that has taken place in Ohio this year. The district is composed of the five Republican counties of Ashtabula, Geauga, Lake, Portage, and Summit, and the normal Republican majority is 8,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- City Treasurer Wright to-day took another and highly important stop looking to the correction of the gross abuses he has found to have been connected with the collection of the mercantile taxes. On July 30 Mr. Wright addressed a letter to Auditor General McCamant in which he informed him of the alleged methods that had been employed by the mercantile appraisers and suggested heroic remedies.

Patrolman John J. Sherman of the Twenty-sixth Precinct was murdered yesterday by Noah Richards, a negro, whom he was placing under arrest for disorderly conduct. The officer's throat was cut by the negro and death was almost instantaneous.

We predicted two or three weeks ago that our high-tariff contemporaries would soon cease to talk about ex-Congressman NIEDRINGHAUS, and to hold him up before the people as the tin-plate champion, but we did not expect that Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS himself would become silent. Our prediction as to the action of our high-tariff friends has been fulfilled, and in addition the champion appears to have gone into seclusion.

It is high time for a thorough overhanling of the navy in its higher ranks if half the stories are true concerning the conduct of Rear Admiral Walker with reference to his senior, Rear Admiral Gherardi.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 1. -- The examinations for admissions of the naval cadets to the United States Naval Academy will commence to-morrow. The programme is as follows: Wednesday, English studies; Thursday, arithmetic and algebra; Friday, re-examination in English studies and algebra; Saturday, re-examination in arithmetic.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Superintendent of Census Robert P. Porter is revising the final census reports at his cottage here on Fifth Avenue. He expects to have the first 500 pages of the compendium of the eleventh census ready for the Public Printer by Sept. 15, and then he will return to Washington.

The September pilot chart of the Hydrographic Office was received at the branch office in this city yesterday. The tracks of all the storms during August are plotted upon it, and the wonderful recurvature of the West Indian hurricane which devastated the Island of Martinique is shown.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Secretary Tracy returned to this city last night, and this morning, after he had had a long conversation with Assistant Secretary Soley, it was learned that Mr. Tracy would to-night go to Cape May to see the President, and that he would probably discuss with the President the Gherardi-Walker controversy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 1. -- The General Assembly now in extraordinary session got to solid work to-day, passing several bills on second reading and referring them to committees. Some of these will be reported for action in a day or two and then the discussion will begin.

SING SING, Sept. 1. -- The Democrats of the town of Ossining had their primary election this evening in Sing Sing, and, as anticipated, it was the liveliest ever held in the town. The polls were in a long, narrow store, which was suffocatingly hot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Capt. Anderson of the Sixth Cavalry, the Acting Superintendent of the Yellowstone National Park, has submitted to the Secretary of the Interior his report for the last fiscal year.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept. 1. -- There is a well-defined movement now under way for the creation of a new State, to include all of the old Indian Territory. Congress at its next session will be asked to pass an enabling act authorizing the formation of a State Government to control all of this vast region.

The story of the train robbery on the Denver and Rio Grande Railway is evidently one that could be told only of a remote and comparatively unsettled country. It is quite true that such a crime might be committed on almost any railroad in the country, but in the more populous States the chances of escape would be so small that it is not likely desperadoes could be found desperate enough to attempt its commission.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The State Board of Equalization met to-day in the office of the Secretary of State, the absent members being Assessor Wood, Lieut. Gov. Jones, and Speaker Shechan. Assessor Williams submitted the report of the State Board of Assessors, as follows:

Mrs. Benjamin Harrison arrived in this city from Cape May, N.J., at noon yesterday, accompanied by George W. Boyd, Assistant General Passenger Agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, Mrs. Boyd, and Mrs. W.E. Dimmock. They were met at Jersey City by Russell B. Harrison, and the whole party went at once to the Gilsey House.

Coroner Hanly's investigation of the Park Place disaster was commenced yesterday in Part I. of the General Sessions Court. There was an interested crowd present all day, including a number of the widows and children of the victims of the disaster. Assistant District Attorneys Townsend and Bedford were present to assist the Coroner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- The "tie" game of yesterday drew a large crowd to the grounds to-day. It was expected that Anson's colts and Mutrie's aggregation of aged players would play another good game. But they didn't. On the contrary, the Chicagos had things their own way, and won as they pleased.
CANON CITY, Col., Sept. 1. -- Seven men "held up" the east-bound Rio Grande train No. 4 last night near Cotopaxi. The highwaymen compelled the flagman at Texas Creek to flag the train.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 1. -- On the second day of the rifle practice the meteorological conditions were favorable for high scoring. The light was a subdued one, steady and dull, so dear to the hearts of prize shots, and as a result some high scores were registered. What little wind there was did not interfere with good shooting. It was steady from the left front and of moderate speed.

BALTIC, Conn., Sept. 1. -- The town of Baltic has appointed a Board of Trade to look after the sale of the mammoth Baltic mill property. The property is a part of the A. and W. Sprague estate that failed in 1873 for $19,000,000. All of the mill rights outside of the Baltic Mill Company have since been sold at auction, and are now operated by different Providence companies.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Sept. 1. -The Republican County Convention was held to-day. The name of Andrew D. White was favorably mentioned for Governor. No other name was suggested. The delegation goes unpledged and uninstructed.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 1. -- Although the Democratic State Convention is but two days off, there are few surface signs that 4GS delegates are to meet and nominate a State ticket. Not one-tenth of the delegates are here yet, and but two candidates, Charles W. Raymond and A.L. Tilden, the Erie County farmer who is permanently domiciled here as Deputy Secretary of the Commonwealth.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Sept. 1. -- There was a disastrous wreck on the Tell City Branch of the Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis Railroad near Tell City, Ind., yesterday morning. A mixed passenger and freight train from Lincoln jumped the track, and, after riding the ties for nearly a hundred feet, rolled over and down the high embankment.

A congress of delegates some 800 in number from various German Catholic societies is now in session at Dantzic. It has set on foot a scheme for an international congress of Catholics for the purpose of promoting the restoration of the temporal power of the Pope. This is a subject about which an immense amount of perfectly sincere zeal can be excited.

John O'Neil, who has been known for years as a desperate character in Baltic, Conn., was severely thrashed by Alexander St. Longe, a stableman, yesterday, while attempting a murderous assault on St. Louge's employer, Richard I. Brophy, a hotel keeper.

If a Victoria telegram to the Herald may be trusted, Russia has at last committed herself in the dispute over Bering Sea. Heretofore Russia, while formally asserting her exclusive jurisdiction, has diplomatically closed her eyes to all intruders, leaving to her co-tenant, the United States, the burden of defending their common interest and title.

Mr. BEERS has at last committed the fatal blunder which his guilty conscience and his astuteness have hitherto prompted him to avoid. He has dismissed Cashier BANTA, the only honest man in any place of responsibility or authority under the roof of the New-York Life Insurance Company's building.

The story of the opening day of the ninth annual convention of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association of the State of New-York, which met in the Lexington Avenue Opera House at noon yesterday, is briefly this: Mayor Grant, fearing the attitude of certain liquor dealers toward Tammany Hall, went before the convention and put himself and Tammany squarely on record in favor of the sale of liquor in restricted hours on Sunday.

ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- The State Board of Equalization is composed of ten members -- the three State Assessors (Williams, Wood, and Ellis) and the State officers -- Secretary of State Rice, Lieut. Gov. Jones, Speaker Sheehan, Controller Wemple, Attorney General Tabor, State Treasurer Danforth, and State Engineer Bogart. All but the last named belong in the interior counties.
ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- Less than 400 persons, including delegates, women, and children, attended the opening session of the State Convention of the Prohibition Party of New-York to-day.

From information received in this city yesterday from reliable sources it is learned that a "personal" contract was made some months ago between President Balmaceda of Chile and the Armstrong Armament Company of England for the furnishing of batteries and stores to the Chilean cruisers Presidents Pinto and Presidente Errazuriz.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 2. -- Six men stopped Train No. 1 on the Southern Pacific Railway at 3:25 o'clock this morning and held it until 5 o'clock twenty miles west of Langtry and one mile from a sidetrack called Samuels, which is about twelve miles from the Rio Grande.

It was evident, when the Pope issued the encyclical on Labor that has attracted a world-wide attention, that the encyclical had not only been very carefully prepared, but that it was a part of a general policy. The policy was framed with the view of retaining and increasing the hold of the Church upon the people.

The liquor dealers slapped Tammany in the face yesterday. They rejected Morris Tekulsky, who was put forward by Tammany interests, and elected Robert W. Oliver of Brooklyn, a henchman of Hugh McLaughlin, to the Presidency of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association.

BATH, Me, Sept. 2. -- The white squadron, Acting Admiral Walker commanding, anchored in the stream opposite this city at 7:30 o'clock to-night. It was received with an Admiral's salute of fifteen guns. Mayor Twitchell and the Reception Committee met the fleet six miles below the city and tendered the Acting Admiral and the officers the freedom of the city.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- As was expected, the opening of the State Normal School this morning was not without incident. Trouble has been brewing ever since Dr. Hoose was removed and Dr. Cheney appointed as his successor. The former has had his claims backed by the people, and the later has found firm support in the local board, through whose instrumentality Dr. Hoose was removed.

The affairs of the Union Pacific Railroad attracted additional attention yesterday from the fact that an impatient creditor sold out its collaterals and reimbursed itself for a loan made some time ago. The "impatient creditor" is believed to have been a Canadian banking institution. The house through which the selling was done was W.H. Goadby Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Some of Admiral Walker's friends in Washington have suddenly taken the mood of the navy to heart, and are loud in their complaints that the continned agitation of the subject of the Admiral's "pull" is hurting the navy. There is no doubt that there is something hurting the navy, but it is the deplorable condition of affairs in the North Atlantic, and not the printing of the facts.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 2. -- On Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. F.D. Beatley arrived here from Bay shore, L.I., and stopped at the Tremont House. Yesterday the bride, whose name was Alice Wicks, penned the following telegram to George L. Wicks, her father, who is a prominent citizen of Bay Shore:

A quarrel in the management of the Harlem Library has brought to the notice of the inhabitants of Harlem -- and to most of them apparently for the first time -- that there is such an institution. A very queer institution it must be, seeing that, with a collection of 16,000 volumes, it has but forty-two subscribers.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 2. -- The Orange Mountain Land Company, which failed last year, is to be revived. Articles of incorporation were filed at the County Clerk's office in Newark to-day for the Orange Mountain Cable Company, with capital stock of $350,000, $1,000 paid in, and of the Orange Heights Land Company, with capital of $250,000, and $1,000 paid in.

FONDA, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The third day of the Montgomery County Agricultural Association's fair, now being held at Fonda, was an unqualified success. The most attractive feature was the joint debate on the tariff this afternoon between the Hon. J. B. Chapman of Kansas, representing the Reform Club, and the Hon. D.G. Harriman of the American Protective Tariff League. County Judge John D. Wendell was selected as Chairman and timekeeper.

The second day of the prize meeting of the National Rifle Association at Creedmoor yesterday was chiefly of interest to individual shooters and the large number of spectators who followed the progress of events closely from beginning to end. The Barney Walther Team Match, the principal event of the day's card, had but, single entry, and was put over until to-day, when it is to be finally contested.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The bottom figures in the war on west-bound lake and rail rates was reached yesterday in a special commodity tariff of 27 cents on dry goods (first-class) from Boston to Chicago and Milwaukee, put in effect by the Fitchburg Railroad and Anchor Line.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The marriage of Miss Mary Lincoln, eldest daughter of the United States Minister, Robert T. Lincoln, to Mr. Charles B. Isham of New-York took place at 2:30 P.M. to-day at the Brompton Parish Church.

Considerable attention was given in March last to the charges against John R. Morrison, who was formerly a deputy in the Street-Cleaning Department, of extortion, and the necessary papers were put in the hands of the District Attorney. Recently there has been considerable curiosity as to what had become of the case.

Gen. MILES is credited with opposition to "consolidating the State troops and forcing them into what would practically be a standing army of 100,000 men, placing them under the control of whoever may be Secretary of War." The allusion is to the plan recently spoken of at Camp Wickham in Missouri, under which the National Guards of the various States are to be enrolled as National Guards of the United States.

The famed O'Brien Association of the Eighth District and Assemblyman John E. Brodsky have fallen out, and a great fight is on in the Eighth in consequence. There was a meeting of the association last night at the Grand Street headquarters, at which "Silver Dollar" Charles Smith demanded Brodsky's books as Treasurer.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 2. -- The recent census of the Dominion, showing the extreme smallness of the apparent increase in population during the past ten years, formed the subject of a motion of want of confidence in the Government, moved by Sir Richard Cartwright in the House of Commons this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- That very irreverent editorial in the Washington Post about "Steve" Elkins is said to have given Editor Frank Hatton an uncomfortable hour to-day. Hatton did not know it, but at the time the editorial appeared Mr. Kerens, Elkins's old and familiar friend, was in this city in hiding at one of the hotels under an assumed name, or without having gone to the trouble of registering at all.

Ellen McGovern, a tall, raw-boned woman, forty-one years old, was shot in the left breast yesterday by Patrolman John Fay of the Fifth District Court while attempting to prevent the arrest of her husband. When the ambulance arrived the woman held a cloth over her wound with one hand while with the other she knocked down three men in rapid succession. The combined energies of four men were necessary to put the woman under subjection.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Cold, threatening weather did not prevent the attendance of more than 700 farmers and farmers' wives at the joint tariff debate at the Whitney's Point Fair this morning between the Hon. Mark D. Wilber, representing the Reform Club, and John Ford, representing the American Protective Tariff League.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The indulgent public, and that part of it particularly that is inclined, by reason of its great faith in the truthfulness of its party leaders, to accept without question the reports of the Secretary of the Treasury, may believe fully the explanations that are being sent out to-day to supplement the scanty debt statement of yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 2. -- Since the beginning of the year the question of a successor to Pope Leo XIII. has come to be much discussed in clerical circles. The renewal of the triple alliance and the downfall of Signor Crispi, as well as the interest attaching to the policy of the present Italian Cabinet with reference to the next con clave, have helped to precipitate discussion.

The troubles in the Knox Presbyterian-Church, Second Avenue and Seventy-second Street, over the appointment of a pastor to succeed the Rev. Dr. D.G. Wylie have resulted in a split in the congregation. Thirty-six of the most influential members of the church, from whom the greater part of the financial help came, have for their letters, and twenty or thirty more will follow the example.

It is not at all wonderful that a demand should rise up from the Indian Territory for the conversion of that Territory into the State of Oklahoma. Nor is there any reason to doubt that the demand comes, at least in part, from the bona fide settlers who experience a bona fide disgust with the Government of the Territory.

The people of the State of New-York have always looked upon Lieut. Gov. JONES as a joke, a rural joke, not always funny, yet to be classed as harmless; and in this disposition Mr. JONES has appeared heartily to join. Indeed, knowing himself as he does, it is not easy to see how the Lieutenant Governor could ever take himself seriously.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day issued the following circular in regard to the continuance of 4 1/2 per cent. bonds:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- After carrying everything before him through six weeks of the Grand Circuit, Hal Pointer came to grief here to-day. His defeat was due to illness which overcame him as the race progressed, and he was not able to start in the last heat. The Judges rendered a most extraordinary decision in declaring bets off, as there was not a suspicion of anything crooked, and the favorite was beaten on his merits.

Investigations will be undertaken by the Democratic House of Representatives next Winter, we presume. During their two years of control the Republicans exhibited all the insolence of their great power and all the imprudence of their party character. The odor of scandal several times became distinctly perceptible to the public nose.

Postmaster General WANAMAKER'S circular request to Postmasters at county seats to visit and inspect at their own expense and report on all the Post Offices in their respective counties is drawing down upon him a good deal of sharp criticism, especially in his own State, and from the papers and the Postmasters of his own party.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2. -- Cleveland gained another easy victory to-day. The Brooklyns couldn't bat Viau, while the curves of Inks were not of a deceptive character. He was not hit hard, however, but the support given him was responsible for 5 of the 8 runs scored by Cleveland. The local players handled the ball in faultless style. Score:

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Anson won to-day, and he performed the act in the most approved style. In the opening inning the Colts touched up the curves of big Amos Rusie in a manner calculated to make him believe that his arm had lost its cunning. They continued the onslaught for three innings, when Rusie thought that he had enough and the heavy-weight battery retired.
The naval administration of Mr. HASON, which at one time gave such promise of good works, will pass into history under the shadow of a scandal of its own creation.

THE DALLES, Oregon, Sept. 3. -- As a result of yesterday's disastrous fire about one-third of this city is in ashes and not less than one thousand people are homeless. Eighteen blocks are totally consumed. The Vogt Block, Opera House, Methodist, Baptist, and Congregational Churches; Gibbons, McAllister Co.'s large implement warehouse, and stores of Fillion Brother, E.P. Fitzgerald, and F.C. Nicholson, together with 500 or 600 residences, are but a mass of ruins.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept 3. -- More harmony prevails among the Republicans of Ulster County this Fall thus far than has been known before in many years, but it is expected that when the County Convention is held the Cornell-Coykendall-Sharpe feud will again manifest itself. This, which appears to politicians outside of Ulster County as a political feud, is, in reality, a family quarrel, and had its origin over a quarter of a century ago.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 3. -- Two of the representative yachts of the North Shrewsbury and the champion of the South Shrewsbury raced at Fair Haven this afternoon. They were Herman B. Duryea's Twilight. Clinton R. James's Undine, and Frederick Oakes's Enigma. The entrance fee was $25, the first yacht to be awarded $50 and the second to have her entrance money.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3. -- The Harrison Administration faction has been beaten at every point in the internal affairs of the Republican Party of this State. The climax came to-day, when the State Central Committee met to select its Chairman. All the leading Republican politicians were present, including Assistant United States Treasurer George T. Wellington, who was the champion of the Administration's interests.

Two hundred and eighty-two years ago to-day HENDRIK HUDSON steered the Half Moon past the salt swamp which is now the Battery and entered the river which was to bear his name and on which he was the first civilized navigator to sail.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- A rather remarkable discovery has just been made by Dr. C.L. Sleich of this city. He was conducting experiments with a view to determining how weak a solution of cocaine would prove efficacious as a local anaesthetic in minor surgical operations, when he stumbled upon the fact that simple water injected under the skin with a syringe rendered the flesh at that point insensible to pain.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3. -- The Giants finally won a game. By superior batting they defeated the local club here to-day. The New-Yorks used three pitchers in the game. Big John Ewing played for one inning and retired in favor of Clarkson. The latter pitched until the sixth inning, when Capt. Ewing thought it advisable to call on Rusie, who finished the contest.

VIENNA, Sept. 3. -- Emperor William of Germany, accompanied by Chancellor von Caprivi, at Horn this morning met Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria, who was accompanied by the King of Saxony, and the entire party, surrounded by brilliant military suites and escorts of cavalry, proceeded on horseback to the headquarters at Gopfritz of the Austrian Army engaged in the manoeuvres.

The investigation yesterday of the Park Place disaster was very interesting, although the conclusion to which the evidence pointed had been reached before. The testimony of the representative of the architects showed that the building was at the time of its fall, and had been for long time before its fall, very seriously overloaded.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 3. -- A Christenson, State Manager of the Wells, Fargo Co. Express, was in the city to-day and left on the westbound afternoon train for Samuels, the scene of Tuesday night's robbery of the Southern Pacific passenger train. He is accompanied by Superintendent J.P. Long of Morris's Detective Agency.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 3. -- The announcement is made to-day that the Sultan has dismissed from office the Grand Vizier and President of the Council, Kiamil Pasha.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept 3. -- This has been the big day at the Monmouth County Fair. It was designated in the official programme as Governor's Day, and an immense crowd gathered, but a telegram was received from Gov. Abbett, saying that he was detained by important business. This afternoon the races were once more the chief attraction.

The French war manoeuvres now going on are the most extensive that have been undertaken in the present generation. Four corps are participating -- the Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, and Eighth -- the two former acting as an invading army, under Gen. GALLIFET, and the others as a defensive army, under Gen. DAVOUST.

The convention acted wisely in confining its declarations in the main to State issues. The delegates showed their appreciation of Mr. CLEVELAND'S services and national leadership by their hearty cheers when his name was mentioned, but the platform did not refer to him, and there was no reason why it should refer to him. The demand for tariff reform and tax reduction is in line with the position of the party throughout the Union.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- There was a lively time in the Republican First Assembly District Convention held here to-day. The delegates were overwhelmingly Platt-Hiscock, and the machine ran everything for the Administration. The Crowley-Journal faction was nowhere, and the few delegates who represented that side might just as well have staid at home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- There is no doubt whatever that "Dick" Kerens and "Jeff" Chandler hope to see "Steve" Elkins made Secretary of the Interior, if they can induce President Harrison to transfer Secretary Noble to the War Office. At all events, Elkins feels sure of a Cabinet place, extraordinary as that assertion may appeal.

The Young Men's Benevolent Association and the railroad employes of this city found that both had obtained Sulzer's Harlem River Park for their picnics Sept. 5. The Benevloent Young Men went before Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday and asked that the railroad employes be restrained by an injunction from appearing at the grounds to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Sept 3. -- A dispatch from Omaha, Neb., says that in railroad circles yesterday it was rumored that receivership papers for the Union Pacific Railroad would be filed before night. John M. Thurston, General Attorney for the line, when questioned merely said that nothing would occur that day. Further he wound say nothing. All other officers declare their ignorance of the whole matter.

Artois Minnaugh, a carpenter, living near Montreal, recently received a letter from New-York stating that the writer would give him $2,500 in negotiable counterfeits for $300 good money. Minnaugh determined to accept the offer and came to this city on Wednesday and met, as he says, a tall, good-looking young man at the Grand Union Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- The baby trotters played a prominent part in the Grand Circuit racing at Point Breeze to-day and all excepting the yearlings trotted the heats below 2:30. Three stakes were competed for, the largest, worth $5,000, going to Bermuda Boy rom Illinois. He won easily, as did Position in the three-year-old event. The race for foals of 1887 was better contested, the favorite, Greenlander Boy, failing to get a heat.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- Two Republican District Conventions were held here to-day, and only served to complicate matters relative to the choice of State Committeeman. Both delegations to the State Convention are for Thomas C. Platt.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- After a factional fight, the most exciting in the history of Onondaga County politics, the Hiscock-Hendricks faction to-day won the first battle in the contest to retain control of the State Senatorship for the Onondaga and Cortland District. They captured by a substantial majority the city caucuses which elected delegates to the Senatorial convention to be held next Saturday.

While the advance of about 50 per cent. in the price of fruit jars is due in part to an increased demand for them and to the fact that the output of the factories in the last manufacturing season was below the average, the following paragraph which was published a few weeks ago in the Iron Age should not be overlooked:

The Republican primary elections, at which delegates were chosen to the Republican State Convention, were held in all the Assembly districts of this city yesterday, with the exception of the Twenty-fourth. The delegates in the Twenty-fourth will be elected to-day. There were no contests except in the Seventeenth District, where Stephen N. Simonson and his followers made an unsuccessful fight against the regular machine, of which George Wanmaker is leader.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 3. -- A great deal of uneasiness has been occasioned among the owners of Minnesota iron lands by the filing of a sensational suit to-day involving over $2,000,000 worth of iron land north of Duluth. The suit is brought against Robert W. Jameson, lately County Attorney of Minneapolis, by the Mountain Iron Company of Duluth, and involves State Auditor Bierman.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- The Suffolk Trust Company, chartered in 1887 by the Massachusetts Legislature, and authorized to do a general banking business and a mortgage loan business, has been notified by the Savings Bank Commissioner to pay no more money on the Western portion of its business. The Western farm loans, most of them in Kansas, have failed to satisfy expectations.

All the interest in the third day of the prize meeting of the National Rifle Association at Creedmoor centred in the contesting of the President's match, which was to determine the personality of the member of the National Guard and the United States Army and Navy who was to enjoy the distinction of holding the place of champion marksman of the combined services for the coming twelvemonth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- All information received from Chile to-day at the departments was comprised in the following massage received from Admiral Brown, dated Valparaiso, Sept. 3:

There is a strong possibility that the British Government will be called upon to make good the damage done to a portion of the valuable cargo of the steamship El Dorado of the Morgan Line, which met with disaster recently in the Bahamas, by the wreckers of the Bahama Islands.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 3. -- A glance over the four hundred and fifty-odd delegates to the Democratic State Convention who slowly gathered in the Opera House this morning showed that the body was mostly composed of men new to State Conventions. There were plenty of veteran Democrats in Harrisburg, but they came mostly as lookers-on.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 3. -- The annual matches of the Dominion Rifle Association were concluded here to-day. The following is the result of the competitions for the President's Prize and the Caron Sharpshooters' Trophy:

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- The Dartmouth Alumni, who have for a quarter of a century struggled for Alumni representation, have encountered difficulties even at the last stage of ultimate success. The Nominating Committee was made up of men who realize the needs of the college, and in sending in the list of nominees took pains to place first in order the men whom they thought best fitted for the needs of the college.

The removal of Mr. Banta from his position as cashier of the New-York Life Insurance Company is the chief news of the week in the matter of the notorious New-York Life scandals. The Trustees met on Monday and voted, with three "whereases" and a "resolved," that Mr. Banta should be immediately ejected. The special pleasure of evicting Banta was delegated to the President.

KIEL, Sept. 3. -- Extensive experiments have been commenced at Friedrichsort with the view of protecting the forts at that place and elsewhere by a series of submarine mines against a possible attack from the sea. As a result of these experiments merchant vessels passing Friedrichsort are obliged to take a pilot on board, and they will have to continue so doing until the mines are removed.

A four-and-a-half-inch navy protective deck plate was subjected yesterday, at Sandy Hook, to the pounding of a twelve-inch rifled mortar. One shot of the mortar's 628-pound projectile proved so effective as to cause all further firing to be declared unnecessary. The plate used was of Bethlehem cast steel, fabricated on the same plane as the plates now in general use aboard war ships.

It does not require much stimulation to set people in Europe to thinking upon the chances of war. The anniversary of Sedan and the coincidence of it with the Austrian manoeuvres, in which the Emperor of Germany will take part, have set people all over Europe to talking and writing upon the prospect. The contrast of tone between the German and the French press is very marked.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- The Committee on Platform of the Prohibition Convention reported at the beginning of the session to-day, and the platform was adopted without amendment. It denounces the Legislature for failing to provide for the submission of the prohibition amendment, and scores the National Administration for attempting, through the State Department, to "foster American breweries" in South America.

The Coroners' inquest into the cause of the Park Place disaster was continued yesterday. Much important evidence was brought out, and it mainly tended to show that the overweighting of the building had caused the collapse.

Another meeting of the Board of Control is to be held at the Coney Island track to-day. It is possible that some sort of action in the case of Garrison will then be taken. The board will also receive a letter from Mr. Ed Corrigan's attorney, A.H. Hummel, asking it to revoke the order of expulsion from the Eastern tracks that was passed on Futurity day.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 4. -- The largest seizure of smuggled goods made by the customs officers of this port for five years was completed to-day. The French steamship Marseilles of the French Transportation Company is one of the largest vessels that plies between Bordeaux and New-Orleans. Her Captain is Henry Mollier, whose wife lives in this city, keeping a millinery store on Boudon Street.

In the last number of this paper we made the statement that President W.H. Beers had lost $500,000 of the policy holders' money, speculating in stocks in Wall Street. Has anybody heard this statement denied! We haven't.

A few weeks ago the organ of the American Protective Tariff League began to publish diagrams showing that the price of cotton cloth was lower nine months after the passage of the McKinley bill than it had been six months before the bill became a law. At the same time it was pointed out that the duties had been increased about 10 per cent.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- The injunction issued by the Supreme Judicial Court against the Suffolk Trust Company has made things so unpleasant for other concerns that an effort will be made to modify the injunction in court to-morrow morning.

The firm and vigorous manner in which the Philadelphia Ledger takes its stand on the side of good government and the Democratic ticket this year in Pennsylvania is extremely creditable to that journal, and is full of meaning as to the situation. It requires a great deal of provocation to make the Ledger veer from its course of faithful support for the party with which it has been so long and so honorably connected.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 4. -- The strongest kind of language has been used by Republicans here to-day and the Federal office holders have been excoriated unmercifully. It is the general opinion that, in their efforts to fix things for Harrison in 1892, they have disgraced the party and completely demoralized its organization. Col. William J. Van Nort persists in his determination to withdraw if Mr. Wescott accepts the Chairmanship of the State Central Committee.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 4. -- The wholesale grocers of Hutchinson, Wichita, and Salina are having a hearing before the Board of Railroad Commissioners upon their complaints of excessive freight charges on carload lots of sugar. The rates complained of are as follows: New-York to Hutchinson, 77 cents, of which 36 cents is charged from the Missouri River to Hutchinson; San Francisco to Hutchinson, 1.01.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 4. -- This city is wild with excitement and joy to-day. The people are assured of peace now, for Harmon Murray, a noted desperado of this State with twelve murders to his name, was killed near Archer this morning by a young negro named Hardy Early.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- One year ago Elbert W. Rose was robbed of a horse and wagon valued at $600. Three months ago a sister of Rose saw the horse on a street in Newark, N.J., and the sale of the horse was traced to Philadelphia, Penn., where a firm named Kyle, Berry Co. had purchased it from Allen Raymond Wright, a former resident of this city.

It was a tame day's sport at the Coney Island track yesterday, without any particular sensation other than the constantly-recurring defeats of the favorites, but this has become common that it passes without much notice. Reilly in the third race and Pagan in the sixth were the only two to come to the rescue of the players of favorites.

Whatever may be the result of the New-York department's investigation, the Board of Trustees of the New-York Life Insurance Company has already been brought before the bar of public opinion and condemned. The evidence so far adduced proves conclusively that the members of the board are unfit guardians of policy holders' interests.

A gentleman long familiar with Mr. A.D. White said to me recently: "Mr. White is a man whom politicians regard as a scholar and whom scholars regard as a politician." The remark was not original, though its application may have been. A review of Mr. White's public career will show that his appearance in politics has often been as disastrous to his party as unfortunate to himself.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- The legislative committee appointed to investigate the State Treasurer's office met here this morning. Gov. Pattison testified that while he was President of the Chestnut Street National Bank the State had a deposit there of $100,000. The deposit had been entirely unsolicited. No interest was ever paid on it and no favors had been shown to any one by reason of it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4. -- The steamer Gaelic brings particulars of a storm which visited Kobe on Aug. 16, the violence of which is without parallel since 1871. The town experienced what was probably the outer edge of a typhoon, but not its full force. At 8 o'clock the storm was raging with terrible violence and the sea pouring in volumes over the bund.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- The National Commission of the World's Fair has been in session here this week. The only business of importance which it has transacted was the passage of a resolution, with only three dissenting votes, providing that Congress be asked to loan the fair $5,000,000, to be returned out of the first money received at the gates.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The Second District Democratic Convention for Oncida County was held at Clinton to-day. The following delegates were chosen; To the State Convention -- John D. McMahon, James L. Dempsey, C.B. Scoville. To the Judiciary Convention -- W.T. Shields, H.G. Wiggins, L.P. Fuess.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Representative William H. Hatch of Missouri has been in Washington to-day, and he arrived just in time to receive from Secretary Rusk of the Department of Agriculture a letter advising him of the removal by Germany of the embargo on American hogs and hog products.

The younger men of the navy who have its interests at heart are thankful to you for the kind of light that you have let in on the absurd position in which the service has been placed before the outside world. But there is much yet that has not been written and the half has not been told.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- To add to the general discomfiture of the Republicans, it is now asserted that William Livesey of Harrisburg, ex-State Treasurer and at present cashier of the Treasury, cannot be found, though every effort has been made to subpoena him to appear before the Legislative Committee appointed to investigate the scandals in connection with the administration of the State Treasurer.

A collision occurred at the Brooklyn terminus of the East River Bridge at 9:15 o'clock last night in which three persons, a man and two women, were seriously injured. One of those injured may die. The injured were John Fitzpatrick, a fireman, of 2 Canton Street; Mrs. Frank E. Carpenter of 102 Reid Avenue, and Mrs. William C. Bolton, the wife of the President of the Bolton Drug Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4. -- The Los Angeles express was held up by two masked men a few miles south of Modesto at 8:45 o'clock last night. The robbers boarded the train at Ceres and compelled Engineer Neff and Fireman Wallace to extinguish the headlight and fill the boiler with water. They then made them get down and go to the express car and ordered it opened.

Inspector Byrnes was notified by telegraph yesterday morning of the arrest in Detroit, Mich., of Sidney Old, who was up to last June secretary and cashier for Fisher Renwick, shipbuilders of Newcastle-on-Tyne, England. Old, who came to this country early in July, and has since passed under the name of Samuel Owens, is charged by his late employers with embezzling a large sum of money.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 4. -- One of the most exciting scenes ever witnessed in the State Legislature occurred in the Senate to-day. It was brought about by the discussion of a resolution offered by Mr. Alexander. The resolution reviewed the disturbance at Briceville in July, the intimidation of the authorities and law-abiding citizens by a mob, and the release of the convicts in the mines at Briceville and Coal Creek.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Secretary Tracy, according to all accounts that come from the Navy Department, regards the discussion of the awkward relations between Admiral Gherardi and Acting Admiral Walker as ridiculous, and intimates that he does not propose to do anything about it.

Austin Corbin, President, and Benjamin Norton, Vice President of the Long Island Railroad; William H. Starbuck, President of the Housatonic Railroad; J.L. Macauley, a Director of the Housatonic and the New-York and New-England Roads, accompanied by two or three other gentlemen, made an inspection yesterday of the work now in progress which will unite the three roads named in a through line from Brooklyn to Boston.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The suggestion of the name of Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy for the nomination for Governor by the Republicans is not looked upon with favor by the leaders here. That there is some reason for the announcement from Rochester that Gen. Tracy might be named is shown by the fact that fully a week ago a prominent State official stated that Gen. Tracy was to be the Republican nominee.

The Spanish steamship Habana ran into the Iron Steamboat Pier (1 North River) yesterday morning a little after 11 o'clock. Her bow was stove in from the water line to about eight feet above it, while all the beams on the pier were smashed. The damage to the pier was very slight, as it is entirely of stone, save a few heavy beams that act as a guard.

An inspection of the pilot chart of the North Atlantic for this month shows a dangerous state of affairs on the commercial highway between this port and those of Northern Europe in the matter of derelicts or abandoned vessels now drifting in those waters. Two of these wanderers lie in the course of vessels between this port and the Grand Banks.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The liveliest disturbance in the Republican Convention will proceed from the Chemung delegation. The spouting geyser of the Yellowstone will be as nothing to it. Chemung is the home of Collector Fassett. Emulating the example of his worthy preceptor, Mr. Platt, Fassett has been battering the party in this Senatorial district out of shape with a club. He has made himself obnoxious to many of the best Republicans.

Ever since the Custom House fell into the control of the Harrison Administration there have been complaints on the part of merchants having business to transact with it that they have been subjected to grave annoyances and delays in getting their goods into the Appraiser's hands and out of the stores after they had been examined and appraised, but complaints have never been so numerous before as they are now.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 4. -- Shortly before 2 o'clock this afternoon George Roney drove away from the City Hall en route for Atlantic City, N.J., having been suddenly changed into an ex-Director of Public Safety. He had become convinced that he could no longer remain a member of Mayor Stewart's official family, and during the morning he had written his resignation.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4. -- By a single run the New-Yorks won here to-day. Cleveland started off with a lead of 2, but the Giants steadied themselves and prevented the local club from scoring after the opening inning. John Ewing pitched a fairly good games, and he was well supported.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 4. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Richard Cartwright's motion of want of confidence in the Government in connection with the census returns was defeated by a vote of 81 to 103.

How very loose is the tie that binds the so-called "People's Party" together is shown by the extremely varied treatment accorded in different parts of the Union to the Sub-Treasury idea. This was put forward in the Ocala platform not merely as a cardinal principle of the Farmers' Alliance, but as the one to which all others were to be subordinated.

The quarrel between authors and publishers is as old as Grubb Street, and it is not probable that the article of a New-York publisher in the September Forum will convince any author with a grievance that the relations between the two are equitable. There are, however, some minor infelicities in the relations of writers for the periodical press and their editors which it may do more good to discuss.

According to the latest reports, Brooklyn has a candidate in the field for the Governorship nomination of each party -- Mr. CHAPIN for the Democratic and Gen. STEWART L. WOODFORD for the Republican. Were it possible that the two should be named, it would make a very pretty fight so far as Kings County is concerned.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The most brilliant social event of the season was the fancy dress ball at the Breslin Saturday evening, but its gayety, by no means spent, has been continuing all through the week. There have been a dozen lunch parties and innumerable minor entertainments in and about Mount Arlington Park. The arrivals of the week have in-

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- In this city and in Paris musical and dramatic affairs show signs of a renewal of activity. The Hereford festival takes place next week, and it will be followed by the popular Birmingham festival. These two important events will release the vocalists and players, who will then prepare for the London Winter season.

The waiters of Philadelphia have joined a movement to form a national organization which will exact better pay and better treatment from their employers. For months past John Mea, a Frenchman, has been traveling from one large city to another organizing branches of the Waiters' Alliance. Recently a large number of local waiters met in response to a call and decided to organize.

Though immediate interest in the Lesseps canal may be lost for the moment, the general lay of the land, the characteristics of the people in the immediate vicinity of that short cut the commerce of the New and Old World is to pass through, will always be worthy of consideration.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Sept. 5. -- Pocono is still a crowded resort, with September guests rapidly filling up all the vacant space at the hotels. Wednesday the Pocono Mountain House gave its annual banquet, always held Sept. 2. Thursday evening there was a brilliant musicale in which the New-York participants were Mr. W. Oakley Raymond, Miss Lee, Mr. Steele, and the Misses Hoge.

Labor Day will be taken advantage of by many associations which indulge in outdoor sports for the enjoyment of their specialties. As Decoration Day is utilized in the Spring for games and athletic events, Labor Day is fast becoming just as popular in the Fall for such events.

The sanitary statistics of last week showed that the health of the city is good.
