There were recorded at Sanitary Headquarters 1,061 births, 426 marriages, and 736 deaths, and the following cases and deaths of contagious diseases were reported: Typhoid fever, 38 cases, 10 deaths; scarlet fever, 67 -- 13; cerebro-spinal meningitis, 7 -- 7; measles, 56 -- 5, and diphtheria, 52 -- 22.

In his address before the British Dental Association, of which he is the President-elect, Mr. J. SMITH TURNER, or, as he would be called in this country, Dr. TURNER, starts out with the assertion that there can be no doubt of the serious deterioration of modern teeth. It is more and more the case that people come to the dentist with teeth incapable of doing their proper work.

The fact that the body of Leonard W. Jerome -- once the best known and most popular of all New-York clubmen -- had been quietly laid away in Greenwood Cemetery without funeral rites was discussed among his old friends with much feeling and some bitterness yesterday.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 5. -- This has been a phenomenally productive year from one end or the State to the other for all sorts of farm produce. The tobacco growers hereabouts have never had so profitable a season, the tobacco crop being enormous and of particularly fine quality. Of wheat and other grain there has also been a prodigious yield, and cord promises to exceed the record of any crop in the last decade.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- One of the elements of discord in the Democratic Party in this part of the State has been the tactics of William F. Sheehan. Emulating the example of his preceptor in politics, David B. Hill, who to-day holds the two offices of Governor and United States Senator, Sheehan is also desirous of holding two billets in the party -- State Committeeman and the Lieutenant Governorship.

RONDOUT, Sept. 5. -- Fruitmen in the Hudson River Valley are almost discouraged. The peach crop, which was expected to return a remunerative reward, has not thus far paid the expense of shipment. The fruit has been large and of characteristic flavor, yet the markets have been so glutted that the price per basket returned by the sales agent has put the producer in debt.

Even the long-suffering taxpayers of Long Island City are confounded at the audacity of Mayor Gleason's Board of Assessors, which has completed the labor of designating how much each citizen shall be mulcted for the support of the gang for the next twelve months. No less than $5,000,000 has been added to the assessment roll since last year, making an advance of 50 per cent. on the assessable property in a single twelvemonth.

Spanking the hydrophobia out of a boy with a wooden splint is not exactly in accord with established usage and traditions, but the experiment is, nevertheless, meeting with gratifying success at the Presbyterian Hospital. The subject of this novel and not entirely painless cure is seventeen-year Hugo Eitel, the son of Emil Eitel, a saloon keeper at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Fifth Avenue. Young Eitel is weak-minded and suffers from heart disease.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The conferences between Chancellor von Caprivi and Count Kalnoky, the Austrian Prime Minister, at the Maires Schloss, near Schwartzenau, have ended in their advising the English Government not to be in a hurry to take any diplomatic action in connection with the Dardanelles incident. The tone of the official press here indicates distinctly that the Government is averse to joining England in any hasty remonstrance against the Porte's agreement with Russia.

The third volume of Mr. Seilhamer's valuable history of the growth of the drama in America treats of the years 1792-7, inclusive. It is the largest book of the series thus far, and, with its index, contains 427 pages. Its record ends abruptly, and the author adds a note by way of explanation.

The rumors that have appeared from time to time within the last few months that David B. Hill was making an attempt to control the organization of the Democratic Party of the State of New-York have been confirmed by events which have transpired within the past few days, not only in this county but in other sections of the State.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 5. -- Col. P.P. Brannon, one of the fugitives from the wrath of President Ezeta of the Salvador Republic, who figured so prominently in the collision between the Salvadorian authorities and the Captain of the Pacific Mail steamer City of Panama the other day, was formerly a resident of Scranton, and has many relatives, including a wealth brother, engaged in the wholesale dry goods business, still living here.
As an illustration of the red-tape system of the Navy Department which makes it so easy to "drown" official communications the following case may be cited:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Whether or not the Congressional Junta has been recognized as the de facto Government of Chile cannot be officially learned at the Department of State, as the Acting Secretary refuses to make any statement whatever on the subject. Nevertheless, there is good reason to believe that, acting upon Minister Egan's information that the authority of the Junta is supreme in Chile, Mr. Egan has been directed to open relations with it.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 5. -- The Autumn season has fairly commenced and September promises to be the liveliest month that the Lenox people have ever had. The cottagers have all returned from Newport, Bar Harbor, and other seaside resorts. More have come on this week than ever came here before during the first week of September.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- John Lyons mysteriously disappeared from this city nearly a quarter of a century ago. He reappeared yesterday almost as mysteriously.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Commencing tomorrow, the Rev. J.K. Wardle of Hudson will occupy the pulpit of the St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Kingston, during the month of September.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 5. -- The little City of Elizabethtown, Ky., is greatly excited to-day over the order of the court, virtually putting the city up at public auction, to satisfy an old judgment held by Philadelphia people.

In the Austrian manoeuvres now going on bicycles are said to be playing a conspicuous part by the carrying of dispatches. When the suggestion was made some years ago that the velocipede might become a substitute for the horse as a dispatch carrier in military operations it seemed to some people rather comical.

It has been the policy and the practice of the United States from the time King George III. gave a tardy recognition to John Adams up to now to send some one from our ablest men as representative to the Government of Great Britain.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Not half the story of how Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy carried the caucuses in this city and defeated Shanahan for State Committeeman has been told. He came here in person, followed by a gang of Troy thugs under the immediate supervision of ex-Assemblyman James Ryan. William Hathaway discovered them in Cushing's, an out-of-the-way hotel on the flats near the gates of the Edison Company's works.

FRESCO, Cal., Sept. 5. -- Before the election by which the McKinley Congress was chosen, the necessity of increased tariff protection for the vineyard industries of California was one of the favorite texts of every high-tax organ in the State. That lusty infant, the business of growing raisin grapes, was especially the object of intensely sympathetic concern among the advocates of enrichment by taxation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 5. -- The Government to-day suspended two French Canadian clerks, named Talbot and Neonne, for embezzling public moneys. They ordered dry goods at a leading store, and, making a false invoice, charged the amount to the Public Works Department, where they were employed.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Dutch steamer Dubbeldam, Capt. Potjer, from Amsterdam Aug. 26, for New-York, has put back to Plymouth with her rudderhead damaged. She has 53 cabin and 353 steerage passengers. She reports that from Aug. 26 to Aug. 30 she encountered strong westerly winds and heavy seas.

As is well known to many of THE TIMES'S readers, the town of Ashfield, Mass., is the Summer home of several men of national reputation, among them George William Curtis, Charles Eliot Norton, and G. Stanley Hall.

Capt. David Wilson's Second Battery went campaigning on Long Island yesterday, and made the day memorable by capturing a ferryboat. The command left its armory early in the morning and started for the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry. It was bound for Garden City where it is to have an outing until the 10th of the month.

The Board of Commissioners of the Western Traffic Association closed its session in Chicago yesterday, having heard all the testimony and arguments in every case scheduled for consideration. When the question of commissions to be paid by transcontinental lines on emigrant business came up, Commissioner Finley produced the letter from Chairman Farmer of the Trunk Line Passenger Association requesting a conference in New-York on that subject Sept. 11.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- The flower show held in Horticultural Hall from Tuesday to Friday evening was a most appropriate reception of September, and a throng of visitors were in attendance to honor the new-comer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- The close of the first week in September finds Newport still well filled with cottagers and very gay socially. Only two or three of the cottagers have yet closeed their Summer homes, and those have done so only because of the regular custom of spending the Fall months at other places where they have country residences.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- The Crapo Republicans, although they decline to be quoted, claim that the prospects of their candidate are good and that much quiet work is being done. As to what this is, however, they are very reticent, and are adverse to anything being said that will provoke bad feeling in the party ranks.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 5. -- According to their own accounts, since their return home, the distinguished men who have recently visited Bar Harbor came here solely for pleasure, though some admit that they did desire to see Mr. Blaine and get a personal impression of the state of his health. Gen. Alger, as reported, seems to think he is all right and will return to his place in the Cabinet by Oct. 10.

The news from every portion of the State -- it is useless to conceal it -- indicates that an important strategic struggle is in progress within the camps of the Democratic Party. From Amsterdam, Auburn, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Newburg, and a number of the rural counties our advices, public and private, are that the Democracy is divided into two elements, each struggling for mastery.

Some of the members of the Young Boys' Camping Club of Harlem write to THE TIMES asking for some points about camping out. They also ask to have some places suggested where such pleasure can be indulged in. They also wish to know what rifles it would be best to take along. This sounds a little formidable, and the query about the rifles savors of expectation of big game if not of an Indian expedition.

The Park Place disaster has certainly opened the eyes of the people of this city to a realizing sense of the necessity of doing something to prevent a repetition of such a horror. The Building Department Inspectors are likely to have their hands full for some time investigating reports of overweighted and rickety structures.

An industry which is not mentioned in the tariff schedules or the free list of the McKinley bill -- the manufacture and sale of so-called "unclaimed estates" -- has recently been affected seriously by new conditions. In the last twenty years the profits of this industry have been diverted to England, although the operations of those engaged in it have been carried on in this country.

MARYSVILLE, Cal., Sept. 5. -- Despite the fact that an injunction has been rendered by a United States court against hydraulic mining in California, the Sacramento Valley, the richest and most fertile portion of the State of California, threatens to be eventually ruined unless the United States Government enforces the provisions of the recent injunction.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 5. -- To that American who cares to learn, by observation, something of the trailic of the great lakes that lie between the United States and Canada, there is no lake port from which he can make a more advantageous or a pleasanter start than the City of Cleveland. For several reasons. Cleveland is, to begin with, an attractive town.

Union Pacific and "arctic" frosts together were responsible for the reaction which occurred in the stock market last week. The "arctic" business came from Chicago, and if all the stories told were true there was excellent skating in the corn belt Wednesday and Thursday. But the stories were not true. It was a little cold in the corn region, but the dip was followed by much warmer weather and no damage was done.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Beginning to-morrow night, "Sindbad" enters upon the last week of its unprecedented run at the Chicago Opera House. The Opera House has always been a record breaker in the matter of long runs, especially with Mr. Henderson's own productions, but neither "The Arabian Nights," "Blue Beard, Jr.," nor "The Crystal Slipper" has equaled, either in consecutive performances or in attendance, the wonderful record of "Sindbad."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5. -- Millions of small red spiders have attacked the fruit orchards in and around the town of Lodi. The pest is far worse than a plague of locusts. The spiders first made their appearance about ten days ago, immediately after a season of very hot weather. The ground is red with the insects, and great damage to crops is the result.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Already the politicians of Monmouth County are laying their plans for the coming Assembly campaign. The convention to nominate the candidates will be held some time next month. The hardest fighting ground, from present indications, will be the Third District, which includes the Townships of Shrewsbury, Middletown, Raritan, and Holmdel.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The Seabright Coaching Club held its second annual floral parade here this afternoon during the lull in the rain. Mrs. Fitzgerald, the wife of Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, who managed last year's parade, again had charge, and it is to her chiefly that the success of the affair is due.

The Republican delegates who meet in convention on Wednesday will, as is claimed by the organs, undoubtedly manifest a good deal of "harmony." There will be the usual crop of local squabbles between contesting factions in a few of the counties. But the purpose of these will be rather to secure recognition from the State Convention for purely local uses.

Complaints have been frequent lately that the block indexing system employed in the Register's Office, since the new law went into effect on the 1st of January, has not been working with the accuracy that is absolutely necessary to the security of titles to real property in New-York City. Mistakes of so serious a character as to imperil the title of the legitimate owner have been of startlingly frequent occurrence.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 5. -- The House to-day adopted a resolution introduced by Mr. Cochran, expressing the desire of the Forty-seventh General Assembly that the convicts in the State Prison should not be leased hereafter. Fifty votes were cast for and 36 against the resolution.
An article entitled "The True Arabian Horse," signed by "Dinah Sharpe," appeared in your issue of Aug. 23. It has been cut out and sent to me by gentlemen in the East and West, also from Canada.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 5. -- Secretary Hoffman of the Board of State Engineers has compiled a statement of the yardage and cost of all the levee contracts under the supervision of the board. Some of the contracts are to be paid for from the general levee fund, and others from the revenues of the several levee districts into which the State is divided.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 5. -- The Medical Practice act, which has been agreed upon by the different medical schools of practitioners in the State, was not in shape for submission to the Legislature in April. Since then it has been formulated with great care by representatives of the different schools, and will be introduced as soon as practicable after the reassembling of the Legislature in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- In the press dispatches from Chile it has been stated that the insurgent party used smokeless powder in their small arms, and much has been written about the great range of their guns and the penetration of their bullets. As they used the Mannlicher rifie it has been taken for granted by many army and navy officers that they used the German smokeless powder.

Photography on a black background is a subject that is attracting much attention from the amateurs nowadays, while the curious results obtained by double exposures in connection with it are constantly being shown.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- In November, 1886, Patrick Larkin, while employed here as a private night watchman, shot and killed a young unmarried man named David Kain. A Coroner's jury brought in a verdict that the act of Larkin was not in the line of his duty. Larkin was tried and served a short term at Dannemora for the offense.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 5. -- The week which brings the first day of September is one full of terror for the landlords of Summer hotels, as it usually brings an end to their money making. But the fatal day has come and gone and the backbone of Richfield's season still remains unbroken, though the limbs of fashion have been lost.

" The work of organizing te Pennsylvania Naval Reserve is making [ood pro'ess," says the At',ny ald A'uvy iegitcr, "in spire of the faot/that the Pennsylvania Pqaee Soolety has Issued a formal protest to the leople of hc State against its formaTAon." The society declares it to be wrong to establish sentiment in favor of a war navy.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Sept. 5. -- September at the Water Gap is a distinct season, as gay as that of midsummer and a hundred per cent. more delightful. There are people here now who return for the early Fall as regularly as the season itself and never tire of the perfect September days.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Harrisburg says:

How much M. Loti of to-day or Thorean of the past have influenced Miss Dowie cannot be precised, but the young woman who was "A Girl in the Karpathians" has entirely emancipated herself from older methods in her determination to be unconventional. Looking for the keynote in this amusing book, it might be that it was "a yearning for quiet dullness."

SARATOGA, Sept. 5. -- The Autumn days in Saratoga have opened cheerily; they began with the advent of the Knights Templar, who made a very favorable impression in Saratoga, and would have left a lot of money to charity here if Jupiter Pluvius had not felt it to be his business to sprinkle the town continuously from Tuesday morning until Wednesday afternoon.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Although the great majority of the people who have spent the Summer in the Catskills have departed for their homes, many yet remain. There is not a pleasanter month in the range than September.

A valued correspondent in another city calls our attention to the state of things in Buenos Ayres consequent on the depreciation of the currency. One of his own correspondents there, who has been largely engaged in construction for English capitalists, states that the laborers employed receive the same nominal wages, $1.40 per day, that they received when the money they were paid was worth that much in gold.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6. -- As the Republican campaign progresses in this State it becomes apparent that a strong undercurrent of anti-Blaine feeling runs through it. Major McKinley and his fellow-protectioniste have not forgotten the terrible blow Blaine dealt them in his famous letter to Senator Frye, and they will never quite forgive it.

VIENNA, Sept. 6. -- Emperor William and the King of Saxony, with their suites, wearing Austrian uniforms, visited Archduke Albrecht to-day. Archdukes Charles, Louis, William, and Rainer, were also present. The most cordial greetings were exchange. The Generals commanding the opposing forces in the manoeuvres have each received a life-size portrait of Emperor William, mounted in a gold frame.

SARANAC LAKE, Sept. 6. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb, attired in knickerbockers and sack coat of corduroy, and wearing a broad-brimmed, hat, has spent much of his time of late with his engineers, who have been surveying the route for the new railway from Malone to Herkimer. The route, as finally decided upon at this end of the line, is perhaps the most feasible that has yet been outlined.

The admirers of Paul Arene admire him passionately. The things that he relates were seen, felt, taken from life, and they are expressed by an artist. His impressions are delicate, true, faithful, surprisingly just, and they are his impressions.

The occupants of the Columbia Hotel, South Beach, S.I., were awakened at 2 o'clock yesterday morning by two loud explosions. Mr. Beni, one of the proprietors, hurried down stairs, but found all the doors leading to the barroom fastened on the inside. Finally an outside window was found open, and when the room was entered it was found that burglars had attempted to blow open the safe.

Our London correspondent in his dispatches yesterday morning gave a brief summary of the impressions received and conclusions reached during a tour of nearly two months in Russia. The primary object of inquiry in this most interesting journey was the actual nature of the measures taken in Russia against the Jews, the effect already produced, their probable development and duration, and the influence likely to be exerted not only in Russia, but in other countries.

Many of the politicians are now busy brushing up their knowledge of the ballot-reform law, especially of the amendments made to it by the Legislature this year. The more important changes that were made in the law interest them now more than ever in view of the immediate opening of the campaign.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 6. -- The unprecedented movement of grain from the West is choking the Kansas City market. There are miles of side tracks full of loaded cars, and the grain men and railroad men are working night and day to clear the jam. All of the elevators at the mouth of the Kaw are crowded to their utmost capacity.

It is by no means an easy task to build up in this country the industry of manufacturing and selling enormous "unclaimed estates," although the business of selling in the United States "estates" of the same kind that have been manufactured in England for our market exclusively has been cut down to almost nothing by disclosures concerning the character of the goods and the imperfect condition of the raw material.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6. -- Among the exhibits at the horse barns at the State Fair Grounds last week was Hiram C. Wheeler, Republican candidate for Governor. Elaborate preparations had been made for this exhibit, as the following circular, dated at Odebolt, Mr. Wheeler's home town, will show:

" Welcome to all who love liberty" is the greeting that everybody receives who attends the festival of the Swiss-Americans now being held at Washington Park. Though this inscription over the gate might be read as excluding all who do not love liberty, none of the 15,000 or more people who went to the park yesterday saw fit to read it in that way, for all passed beneath the arch and were made welcome.

About the latter part of August Orlando S. Johnson, a coal operator of Scranton, Penn., lost a team of horses valued at $1,000. Several days ago David Armistead sold a handsome horse to George A. Feld of 164 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street for $85, and another to Andrew Wick of 242 West Thirty-eighth Street for $60. Policeman Barrett heard of it and arrested Armistead.

The present attitude of the great powers of Europe toward each other is hardly encouraging to those who were lately taking rosy views of arbitration as a panacea and of the prospective coming of universal peace. If such an incident as the one relating to the Dardanelles, which should be governed by the provisions of the various treaties on the subject, is considered ominous, it must be that causes of war are easy to find.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 6. -- Tests have recently been made about sixty miles north of here on the banks of the Guadeloupe of one of the recent productions of the Watervliet Arsenal. Light Battery F, Third Artillery, under command of Major Burbank, had charge of the trial, which was very successful.

Among the group of sailors stationed at the United States Naval Academy for the instruction of the cadets in splicing, knotting, and the various forms of marline-spike seamanship is a weather-beaten, bronzed-faced old fellow with a record. His name is Richard Knowles, or, as he is better known to the fledgling officers, plain Dick.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 5. -- The Democratic State Committee will meet here in a few days to decide upon what policy shall be pursued toward the Farmers' Alliance in the legislative campaign. This question is a difficult and nice one to determine.

The interest in the matter of the New-York Life has been very materially increased within the last month by the publication in full of the Banta charges, the nature of which was not specifically known before. These charges, many of them most direct and positive in their nature, have caused even former conservative men to express an opinion that they should be thoroughly investigated.

The pretty little village of New-Rochelle has a new sensation just at present, in the shape of a controversy between the Sewerage Commission and the village Trustees and Board of Health. The outcome of the controversy seems to be of all-important interest to the inhabitants of the village, inasmuch as it concerns most vitally the health of the population.

The annual President's address before the British Association for the Advancement of Science is wont to be an utterance of exceptional quality. The President of 1891 is Dr. HUGGINS, the discoverer of carbon and nitrogen in the stars, the acutest theorist regarding the nebulae, and the magician in whose hands the spectroscope has solved problems about which earlier astronomers with their imperfect instruments could only speculate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- Representative John H. Fow was somewhat disgruntled to-day when he read in THE TIMES an article from Harrisburg in which allusion was made to the perfunctory examination to which State Treasurer Boyer was subjected by the Legislative investigating committee appointed to examine into the workings of the State Treasury and devise a plan for improving the method of auditing the accounts of the Commonwealth.

JAMESTOWN, Sept. 6. -- Gov. Hill's recent highwaymanlike attempt to seize the control of the Democratic organization in this county has recoiled upon himself with an intensity that neither the Governor nor any one else can realize without visiting here.

Three alarms were sounded yesterday afternoon for a fire which broke out at 12:30 o'clock in the rear of the first floor of the four-story brick tenement 367 Third Avenue, near Twenty- seventh Street. The lower floor of the building was occupied as a pawnshop by Aaron Spero and a second-hand clothing store run by Jacob Futoransky, and in the basement Sing Lee kept a laundry.

Mr. Harrison is like that vase which the poet declared would throw off the scent of the rose though smashed into innumerable pieces; the odor of sanctity hangs round him wherever he may be; he is always and everywhere a Presbyterian and he doesn't care who knows it. We have his word for this, or, which is the same thing, the word of the Indianapolis Journal, his organ.

After having plays d fast and loose for three months with the Gubernatorial boom of Mayor Alfred C. Chapin of Brooklyn, in order to gain time to observe the drift of Democratic sentiment throughout the State, Gov. Hill made up his mind on last Saturday that the chances were overwhelmingly in favor of the nomination of Roswell P. Flower.

During the last few days Russia has been making further efforts to Russianize Finland. The committee with whose aid the Minister of State for Finland has been preparing, measures to be submitted to the Emperor will now no longer be asked to assist in this work, and the Finnish Minister will henceforth take the advice of the Russian Imperial Ministers alone.

TRENTON, Sept. 6. -- The Hon. James Smith, Jr., the "boss" of all Essex County, returned from Saratoga to his home in Newark last Tuesday. He found the revolt against the rule of the "bosses," against the Street and Water Board's usurpation of popular rights, and specifically against the continued reign of Haynes, in full flower.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 30. -- Few people are aware that co-operation has worked very successfully in the whaling vessels of the Northern Pacific Ocean and of the Bering Sea. The men, instead of being paid regular wages, receive a percentage of the profits.

Yesterday was an anxious day for the average Wall Street man. The London stock market was open, and traders in American stocks there -- on their own account or under cable orders -- were making quotations. And what London was to do, it was pretty generally felt, would give the direction to stocks here for the rest of the week at least.

The machine-made "harmony" of the Republican Convention is naturally the subject of a good deal of comment by the Democratic papers, but it would do their party no harm in this State if they would apply the same standard of criticism to its condition. It is not true, as asserted by the Republican journals, that HILL'S control of his party is more absolute than PLATT'S control of his.

In the easiest possible manner the Brooklyns defeated the Chicagos in the opening game yesterday. They hammered the curves of Vickery to their hearts' content, and then amused themselves by knocking the pitching of Ryan in all directions. In the second inning the Bridegrooms took a lead of nine runs, and finally won by a score of 21 to 3.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Sept. 7. -- Dr. Charles E. Ballard of Saybrook, Ill., this morning killed Miss Bertha Ison, late of Baker City, Oregon, and daughter of the late Judge Luther B. Ison of the latter place, and then shot himself. Dr. Ballard came to this city last Friday and secured a license to marry Miss Ison, who came here a month ago to attend college.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7. -- The bark Royal Tar, from Australia, anchored off Quarantine yesterday morning, reporting fever and scurvy on board and the captain and first mate both dead.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7. -- The suit for injunction by carriage manufacturers against the railroads to restrain them from putting into effect a new rate of freight on less than car lots of carriages was dismissed to-day by Judge Outcalt, ha sustaining a demurrer, on the ground that this court has no jurisdiction over a matter involving the rights of so many different corporations.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 7. -- Lon V. Stephens, receiver of the Fifth National Bank, has brought suits in the United States Circuit Court against the Directors of the bank to recover $343,337.97, money alleged to have been loaned by the bank in violation of the statutes and which could not be collected by the receiver.

A radical change in the character of the operas to be produced at the Casino is announced by Mr. Rudolph Aronson. Hitherto burlesque operettas have been the feature of that house. For some time the question of giving more ambitious works at the Casino has occupied Mr. Aronson's attention. The successes in Germany and Austria have recently been confined to works which contained good music, with just enough comedy and no more.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- The National Columbian Commission reassembled this morning. The report of the Committee on Awards, recommending the appointment of a committee of eight to have charge of the awards of premiums, was adopted after being amended to make the number twelve, and referred to the committee to frame the rules and by-laws for its government.

Mr. Frederick Paulding, an ambitious young actor, who always means well, and sometimes acts very well indeed, produced at the Standard Theatre last night a real old-fashioned melodrama said to have been written thirty years ago by his uncle, William Irving Paulding, but never before performed. The fashion in melodrama has not changed very much, and, on the whole, such changes as there have been have not improved it.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Lieut. Gov. Jones and a boxing bout were counter attractions at competing picnics this afternoon. The General was announced to speak on the prison-labor question, and he did. But he not only cut the convict-labor part of his address, but prefaced it by a hidden attack on Roswell P. Flower, and concluded it with a somewhat concealed assault on David Bennett Hill.

Despite the proof afforded by the Fassett appointment that a close alliance has been formed between Mr. HARRISON and PLATT, the latter is still strongly suspected of being a firmer friend of Mr. BLAINE than of the President, and ready to serve the old love before he is off with the new. Unfortunately for both BLAINE and PLATT there is nothing in the career of either to render the suspicion unreasonable.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The utmost excitement prevails in the Village of Saugerties, in Ulster County, over the result of a Democratic caucus held on Saturday evening to elect delegates to the District, County, and Assembly Conventions. The main question at issue was as to whether Frank D. Pidgeon should remain on the Democratic County Committee or not.

The New-York merchants and importers in several different lines of trade have given THE TIMES their views upon the present and prospective conditions of trade, and their opinions are given herewith. A general consensus of the opinions expressed is that trade during the Summer months was duller even than last year, but for a week or more there has been a changed-condition that amounts almost to a revolution.

The McKinley newspapers in Ohio, aswell as the McKinley orators, have been led into a maze of contradictions about the tariff. Before the beginning of the campaign it was their habit to tell the people that the effect of a high duty was to reduce the price of the protected goods in the home market and that the duties were paid by the foreign manufacturers.

Importers of dry goods in this city discuss the delays and annoyances attendant upon the passage of their goods through the Custom House from different standpoints. Some houses have found the way through the Appraiser's department as smooth as an oiled whetstone. Other houses have found the way as rough and devious as the average pavement in a New-York street.

Labor Day was utilized by the National Rifle Association for the contesting of the fifth of the marksman's matches arranged for the qualification of members of the National Guard to receive the State decoration awarded to all those showing themselves competent to score 30 points or better with the regulation military rifle at 200 and 300 yards, five shots at each distance.

A steady twenty-five-mile breeze from the northwest, clear weather, and an open harbor were three of the many favorable circumstances under which the New-York Yacht Racing Association sailed its third annual regatta in the upper and lower harbor yesterday. This annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Racing Association has always brought out an immense fleet of sailboats from the fourteen foot open ears to a fifty-three-foot saloon schooner and big crowds of sightseers.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The proposed new law against the abuse of spirituous liquors was published in the Reichsanzeiger to-day. While it was formerly left to the different Federal Governments to grant licenses, the law is now so changed as to allow of the granting of a license only in cases where there appears to be a need for a retail liquor shop or for a saloon.

If the prognostications from Rochester are not altogether at fault, Mr. PLATT is about to take the advice given him by THE TIMES some days ago to nominate for Governor some tough young Platt man who could stand defeat and recover from its consequences. Collector FASSETT, according to present indications, is to be the nominee of the convention, and he fills the bill.

The popular and a large part also of the professional interest in the current European military manoeuvres once more centres, as last year, on the employment of smokeless powders. The old experiences of Champigny, Hanover, and Ammerstein have been renewed at Gopfritz, and while the absence of much of the noise and more of the dense smoke customary on battlefields strikes all spectators, the effect on tactical movements is a special study for soldiers.

Locking the stable door after the horse has been stolen is proverbially held not to indicate a high degree of efficiency, but it is at least less inefficient than a failure to dock the stable door after a robbery when there are more horses left in the stable. This latter degree of inefficiency has been attained by the keeper of the Jefferson Market Jail.

Fifty-five head of yearlings, drafts from the Chesterbrook, Fox Hill, and the Faustiana Studs were sold at auction by William Easton at the salesrooms of Tattersalls last evening. The consignment from the Fox Hill Stud were an exceptionally good-looking lot and fetched good prices, the eight bringing $4,100, an average of $512.

Labor Day drew a great crowd to Coney Island. The hotel clerks and policemen at Manhattan Beach said it was one of the biggest days of the year. The crowd at Brighton and West Brighton was not as large.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Navy Yard Examining Board has submitted its report of the examinations in the Washington Navy Yard. The report recommends the reappointment of all the present foremen, master mechanics, and leading men, without any exception, and it is understood that Secretary Tracy will make the appointments accordingly.

MONTREAL, Sept. 7. -- The convention of the National Electric Light Association opened here to-day at 3 o'clock, and the exhibition opened at the Victoria Skating Rink in the evening. The opening of the convention was one of the most brilliant affairs ever witnessed in Canada. There were over three hundred delegates present from all over the United States and Canada, representing capital to the extent of $300,000,000.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 7. -- It is learned to-day from sources aboard the flagship Philadelphia, now in this port, that, on Sept. 4, Rear Admiral Gherardi sent to Washington additional correspondence in reference to the Port au Prince affair.

The sailboat Truant was upset yesterday by the wash of one of the boats of the Fulton Ferry fleet. John English of 403 East One Hundred and Fifth Street and Edward Irving of 146 East One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, the occupants of the sailboat, were rescued by one of the harbor police boats. The Truant was towed to the foot of Navy Street, Brooklyn.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Sept. 7. -- In 1889 a party of railroad men, chiefly from Chicago, set on foot the project of building a railroad south from this city. The road was chartered as the McPherson, Texas and Gulf Road. Reno County subscribed to the stock of this road $92,000, and issued county bonds for that amount.

Boston, Sept. 7. -- DespJte the rain of to-daF the rowing races under the auspices of the City Government and the New-England Amateur Rowing Association took place on the Charles River. President H. W. Garfield of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen was referee, and Walter Stlmpson, President of the NewEngland Association, starter.

One of the results of the Park Place disaster has been to direct the attention of the authorities and the public to the unsafe condition of many of the old buildings in the city, and to provoke the inquiry as to where the authority, if any there is, exists to remove the menacing structures or compel the owners to put them in safe repair and condition.

Labor's official holiday found general observance yesterday with a general suspension of business and a wholesale exodus of the population to the Summer amusement resorts. Its distinguishing feature was the parades of the organized labor unions, and the feature of these parades was, as last year, the rivalry of the factions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Lieut. G.H. Harries, one of the District of Columbia marksmen who took part with the National Guard team, in the competition at Creedmoor, was the correspondent at Creedmoor for the Evening Star, in which paper he to-night reviews the incidents of the match and reiterates some of the complaints made from day to day during the progress of the week's shooting.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The games and bicycle races to-day on the New-Jersey Jockey Club grounds, under the auspices of the Union County Roadsters, drew over 4,000 people to the place, and fully 600 wheelmen from various parts of New-York and New-Jersey attended the meet.

CALCUTTA, Sept. 7. -- Gen. Alikhanoff, the well-known Russian commander and Oriental diplomat, has been arrested at Cabul, the capital of Afghanistan. He is charged with being a spy in the employ of the Russian Government.

It will not escape the notice of those who are interested in the official interpretation of the McKinley tariff that while the Treasury Department has appealed from the decision of the Board of General Appraisers with respect to the imposition of double duties on carpet wool, it did not appeal from the decision of the same board concerning the duty on boiler-plate shearings.

Labor Day, like the Fourth of July and Decoration Day, is noted for its baseball games. In all the cities that sport baseball teams two games were played yesterday, and in every instance the contests were well patronized. In the League circuit, the honors were evenly divided in New-York and Brooklyn, where Cincinnati and Chicago played, and in Philadelphia the Pittsburgs won two games from Harry Wright's men. Rain postponed the games scheduled for Boston.

The arrest in Cabul of a Russian General, disguised as a Mohammedan, is precisely what one might have expected from the recent course of events in British India. The revolts and disturbances that have lately occurred at places wide apart in India point to some general and pervading cause, and the most obvious of such causes is the ambition of Russia.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- City Treasurer Wright scored a signal victory to-day. With the evidence in his possession against the Mercantile Appraisers, District Attorney Graham was forced to admit the force of the charges and to agree to the institution of criminal prosecutions against the members of the board.

The protracted litigation between the Western Union Company and the American Bell Telephone Company bids fair to assume a still more sensational aspect. When the first-named company brought suit against the telephone company, in 1883, for an accounting and the payment of about $7,500,000, the United States Circuit Court of Massachusetts appointed ex-Judge John Lowell referee to take testimony in the case.

Several thousand persons went to Hudson Park, New-Rochelle, yesterday to witness the eleventh annual regatta of the New-Rochelle Rowing Club, Which was held on Echo Bay, an arm of Long Island Sound. The course was one mile straightaway. E. J. Oianninl was referee and 8tarter, A. D. Seymour was timekeeper, and Rear Commodore F. r,r Hausling of the NewRochelle Yacht Club was judge at the finish.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- The convict lease question is now squarely before the Legislature, and during the present week the fight will be urged with great warmth. The introduction in the House on Saturday afternoon by Mr. Davis and in the Senate to-day by Mr. Penland of a bill to repeal the convict lease law has forced the issue.

The Staten Island Athletic Club held its fifth annual Labor Day celebration yesterday on the beautiful grounds at West Brighton, S.I. The threatening weather of the morning kept many away from the opening events of the day, but the afternoon and evening were perfect, and over 5,000 people were on the grounds at one time.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 7. -- The strife between the two factions of the Republican Party in the City of Wilmington has broken out afresh. This began with the fight that prevented the confirmation of James H. Young as Collector of the Port of Wilmington, and led to the appointment of John C. Davey, colored, through the influence of Young, Congressman Cheatham, and the friends of Young and Cheatham.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- A dispatch from San Francisco says: The Southern Pacific Railroad is about to commence active operations in Oregon and Washington which will create a sensation in the railroad world. Articles of incorporation have been filed at Salem by the Oregon and California Railroad Company.

There is something highly imitative, not to say positively simian, about the endeavor of the Colored National Alliance to foment a general strike of the cotton pickers. Like all other men, the cotton pickers are discontented with their condition and desire to improve the same, and, like many white workingmen, they think they can attain this laudable object better by not working when there is a special demand for their services than by working.

The statements of the Paris correspondent of the London Times regarding the Russian loan and the obstacles it has encountered confirm the reports of our own dispatches as to the extent of the distress prevailing in Russia and its probable development. It is said by M. DE BLOWITZ that Russia requires for immediate use in relieving the actual necessities of the population of the famine-stricken provinces $60,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Collector J. Sloat Fassett was appointed to be the head of the Custom House on July 29, simultaneously with the resignation of Quay and Dudley from the National Committee, and while the mooting was in session at which the resignations were secured.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The National Columbian Commission resumed its sessions this morning. Commissioner Mercer of Wyoming presented a resolution setting forth that the question of policing the fair while open is one of great importance, and suggesting the propriety of making arrangements with the various States for sending their militia to the fair in succession to act in the capacity of guards of honor and police upon the grounds.

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 8. -- The steamer City of New-York arrived here this afternoon at 2 o'clock, having crossed the Atlantic in 5 days 22 hours and 30 minutes. This beats the record for the eastern trip, which had been held by the Inman steamer City of Paris. She made the run in December, 1889, in 5 days 22 hours and 57 minutes.

Rifle circles were interested yesterday in the charges preferred against the management of the National Rifle Association in the conduct of the Hilton Trophy and the Inter-State Military Matches shot at Creedmoor last week by one of the members of the team representing the militia establishment of the District of Columbia. The instigator of the charges in question was Lieut. G.H. Hurries, who was the Creedmoor correspondent of the Evening Star of Washington.

The Coroner's inquest into the cause of the Park Place disaster has, after five days' continuance, started a flood of export testimony, and the examination of witnesses now has passed almost entirely into the hands of the experts on the jury.

Everything seems to be conducing to render the American farmer more contented with his lot and to lessen the force of the "demands" he made upon the Government in the days of his discontent and of the organization that was created to enforce those demands. The coincidence of abundant crops and high prices is the dream of the agriculturist, which, from the nature of the case, is very seldom realized.

Mr. Sidney Dillon, President of the Union Pacific Railroad, said yesterday that the scheme for extending the floating debt of the company was progressing satisfactorily. The Trustees' agreement, which was signed last Friday, placed the matter on a solid foundation, and now it is necessary only to arrange some minor details before issuing the proposed three-year notes.

There was an important meeting of the State Fish and Game Commission yesterday at the commission's rooms in Fulton Street, at which President Eugene G. Blackford presided and Commissioners L.D. Huntington, William H. Bowman, and Henry Burden were present.

The Metropolitan championships, under the direction of the Amateur Athletic Union, are to be held on the Manhattan Field next Saturday. All the clubs of this vicinity have entered their best men, and the contests ought to prove of a very interesting character. Below are the entries:

A test was made yesterday at Fort Hamilton of a new high-explosive -- terrorite. Col. H.L. Abbott and Col. Alfred Mordecai of the United States Engineers conducted the experiments. Although neither Col. Abbott nor Col. Mordecai would say much about the test, they were convinced that this new explosive is very powerful.

The general storage warehouse of R.C. Layton, Jr.. at 63 and 64 South Street, just above Wall Street, took fire yesterday afternoon and gave the men of the down-town fire companies as stubborn a conflict as they have had for many months. It was hours before the flames were under control, and it was not until late last night that they were extinguished.

As was predicted in these columns four days ago, President Beers has availed himself of the advertising columns of every newspaper all over the country to herald his dismissal of Cashier Theodore M. Banta, and for the added purpose of glorifying himself. It would be placing the figures at a minimum if it were said that this has cost the policy holders tens of thousands of dollars.

Mr. FASSETT'S candidacy was put before the people twenty-four hours too soon. That was one of Mr. PLATT'S mistakes. Notwithstanding his pretended disinclination to abandon Mr. WHITE, Mr. PLATT has for some time been a good Fassett man, and no doubt expected that the nomination of the new-made Collector of the Port would be accomplished without much friction.

The recent occurrences at Port au Prince and at Bar Harbor are the logical outcome of some ten years of maladministration in the navy. Officers of experience in the navy have been expecting this very outbreak of insubordination whenever the proper occasion should come to pass.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Early Sunday morning residents on the main street in the centre of the quiet town of Fairfield were awakened by pistol shots and female cries for help. The excitement was at the residence of Mrs. E. Bergh Brown and was occasioned by a daring attempt at burglary. Mrs. Brown and her three daughters occupy a handsome residence.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 8. -- To-morrow morning Oliver C. Wilson, Jr., will appear before Magistrate Milligan to answer to the charge of embezzling $2,500 from the Produce National Bank at 104 Chestnut Street, of which he was paying teller.

The members of the State Board of Health came to this city yesterday. They are here to consider the matter of the pollution of the Croton water. Most of them are stopping at the Everett House. It was intended to hold a conference with the Commissioner of Public Works and other city officials yesterday, but the city officials could not attend.

NEWCASTLE, Sept. 8. -- The proceedings of the Trades Union Congress, now in session here, and representing, the interests of over 1,500,000 skilled and unskilled workmen of Great Britain, are attracting widespread attention. The Parliamentary committee's report, which has just been issued, sets forth that it is to be regretted that the Government has given a considerable balance of power to capital in the appointment of the Royal Labor Commission.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 8. -- It seems that, after all, the Republican programme is not going through as smoothly as indications last night pointed. To-day ominous and lowering clouds have appeared in the Republican sky, and all efforts of the experts have been unavailing to disperse them.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 8. -- With cloudy skies and a cold north wind as accompaniments the Hartford Wheel Club run off the first day of its fourth annual meek here this afternoon. The races were held at Charter Oak Park, and nearly 5,000 spectators gathered at the grounds to witness the events.

There were seven races on the card again today at the Sheepshead Bay track, and the attendance was accordingly large, much greater, in fact, than was expected after the great outpouring of people on Monday. The sport was good as a whole, though the speculation was light on the first race, in which twenty-one horses faced the starter for a run over the Futurity course.

FRANKLINVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- The Firs Assembly District Republican Convention of Cattaraugus County met here to-day and chose Dr. W.H. Vincent, Judge Alfred Spring, W.F, Persons, E.M. King, and L.E. Chapin delegates to the State Convention. Philip Becker was the choice for Governor. The delegates chosen to the Judicial Convention are C.P. Aernam and F.W. Higgins, who will support Judge Spring Franklinville.

Col. Story, Chief of Surveyor Lyon's staff of Inspectors, made a number of seizures yesterday which promise to interest a good many patrons of dressmakers who take trips to Paris. Last Spring the Inspectors made a specialty of looking out for the returning dressmakers, who, it was charged, did such a thriving trade in smuggling that the business of other people who paid duty was seriously affected.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8. -- The second day of the convention of the National Electric Light Association was a decided success. The exposition was running in full blast and a greater display of electrical apparatus was never seen, in Canada, at least. Besides the Edison and Thomson-Houston firms a great number of other companies have made splendid displays of electrical machinery, from an electrical ventilator to a street lamp and drilling machine.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Mr. Fassett has had the Gubernatorial bee buzzing in his bonnet for several years. As far back as 1888 he aspired to the nomination, but Mr. Platt at that time extinguished his hopes by the declaration that the Miller faction must be placated. Warner Miller was nominated for Governor at the Republican Convention held in Saratoga in September, 1888.

If Mr. FASSETT should be nominated for Governor to-day by the Republican Convention there will be a lesson in the fact from which much can be learned by various persons and by the decent Republicans generally. We do not pretend to know why PLATT should prefer FASSETT as a candidate to Mr. WHITE, and it is of no special consequence what PLATT'S motives are.

Secretary Halford has apparently superseded the boy Harrison as head hornblower for the President. It was young "Russ," it will be remembered, who informed the country that his father managed the Itata case, crushed Rudini, discovered reciprocity, and wrote "The Bread Winners," but it is Halford who announces that it was Harrison -- and not Blaine nor Phelps nor any other of the small-fry fellows -- who forced Germany to receive American pork again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Gen. William Warner of Missouri, Past Grand Commander Grand Army of the Republic, who is in this city, talks in terms of approval of Harrison's Administration. He finds that Mr. Harrison has "been growing steadily"; that he is now undoubtedly President, and that "he is intellectually the equal of any"; but Gen. Warner does not nominate him for President.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- The three individual ledger clerks of the broken Keystone National Bank -- E.L. Maguire, Charles R. Ege, and J. Frank Lawrence -- who were arrested charged with making false reports of the bank's condition to the Bank Examiner, were given a hearing this afternoon before United States Commissioner Bell.

" The Solicitor" is not so bad. It is a Cockney farce, to be sure, and the mere thought of a Cockney farce is depressing to the critical playgoer who reflects that, with the exception of Mr. Pinero, there is not an English comic playwright of the present day who has a single original idea in his head. The ideas in "The Solicitor" are as old as Plautus.

The character of JULES GREVY could be estimated with sufficient precision from the fact that he had been twice elected President of the French Republic. In this country a re-election to the Presidency signifies very little except that the person reelected has been elected before, and the first election signifies little as to his personal character and equipment.
Col. John G. Lee, a former army officer and a resident of Philadelphia, was found dead yesterday morning in his room at the Hoffman House, where he had been staying for the past five months.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9. -- W.H. Belden, chief bookkeeper for the George D. Barnard Stationary Company, has an eighteen-year-old son now serving as an apprentice in the United States Navy on the Pensacola, formerly flagship of the South Atlantic squadron, and recently stationed at San Francisco. About thirty seamen recently deserted from her on the plea that the vessel was unseaworthy.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Mercantile Appraisers Patton, Hunter, Housman, Crawford, and Bell were arrested to-day and held in $2,500 bail each to appear for a hearing on warrants charging them with conspiracy to defraud the State.

With the help of the jockeys that occasionally ride him Carroll is making a name for himself as one of the sensational horses of the year. On Tuesday, thanks to Fred Littlefield, the horse was beaten in a race over the turf track at a mile and a quarter in the very slow time of 2:18, by Snowball, a horse that would be an expensive purchase at $500.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- M. Francois Jules P. Grevy, ex-President of the French Republic, died to-day at Mont-sous-Vaudrey, the Department of Jura. For four days he had been suffering from a severe attack of congestion of the lungs, which was the immediate cause of his death.

The new Navy Department regulations affecting the employment of men at the various United States naval stations are now in full force at the Brooklyn Yard. Capt. Henry Erben, commandant of the Brooklyn Yard, said Tuesday that some 500 men had been taken on to work under the new rules. The men were mostly laborers, he said, but for all that had to prove themselves fit for duty.

President William H. Beers now realizes that his tenure of office -- at a salary of $75,000 a year as President, and a bonus of $50,000, not including traveling expenses -- is a trifle uncertain. Being a master of arts, he is using all the machinery at his disposal, such as agents and money, the former and latter all employed or belonging to the unfortunate policy holders, to secure every available proxy.

The inquest into the cause of the Park Place disaster is assuming a rather questionable phase through the evident determination of interested parties to make the cause of the catastrophe an explosion. After the bulk of the testimony had been taken from the witnesses summoned by the city officials, the burden of proof was that the Taylor Building collapsed through structural weakness and overloading.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9. -- Minneapolis millers and commission men are up in arms over the discrimination in grain rates which the railroads entering the city have recently inaugurated in favor of Duluth. To-day Duluth obtained the same rate as Minneapolis has for all points south and west of the twin cities. That means that wheat passing through Minneapolis to Duluth pays no freight charges between Minneapolis and Duluth.

The furniture dealer, George Rubel of 189 First Avenue, who was charged with taking Mrs. Jaeger's furniture because she owed him a bill of $3, was before Judge Ryan yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Essex Market Police Court. As Mrs. Jaeger did not appear Rubel was discharge.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 9. -- The Committee on Credentials convened in one of the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce as soon as the convention adjourned. There were no absentees, and it at once became apparent to the Chemung and Seneca contestants that the committee was prepared to rush the business to completion and report in accordance with the mandates of the boss.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 9. -- The convicts at Briceville will be put to work in the mine of the Tennessee Coal and Mining Company tomorrow, the Prison Inspectors having decided, after considering the new reports as to the condition of the mine, to rescind their recent order. The Miners' committee say the free miners there will take no action until after the adjournment of the Legislature.

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 11. -- A famine in portions of China seems very probable. By old residents the outlook is thought to be a very gloomy one. The first rice crop, owing to risings of the rivers, was completely destroyed in Northeastern China, and now it is thought that the continued drought will about destroy, or at least severely damage, the second crop.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 9. -- The Committee on Resolutions at this convention will not soon forget its experiences. It started in like a lion and came out like a lamb. It had opinions at the outset, but after Mr. Thomas C. Platt had reprimanded it, and sent it back to make changes in line with his ideas, it had disposed of these most effectually.

In nominating Collector FASSETT for Governor Mr. PLATT has shown that he can be logical, candid, and astute. In strict logic Mr. PLATT should have nominated himself, thereby putting the strength of his leadership to the supreme test of the suffrage. But that course would have been imprudent as well as impudent.

Mr. W.W. GOODRICH of Brooklyn is a citizen of perfectly good reputation; he is an admirable lawyer with a considerable business; he has had some experience in public life, and has had a great deal in party politics. He is entirely respectable and is respected by his fellow-citizens, whom he would hesitate a long time, in his private relations with them, to treat as gullible simpletons.

The Seidl season of popular orchestral concerts was begun at the Madison Square Garden with brilliant success last evening. Quite the largest audience of the Summer, with the exception of that at the Thomas farewell, was in attendance and welcomed Herr Seidl with enthusiasm. The band was in uncommon spirits and did its work with gratifying zeal grid intelligence.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The Prohibition State Convention, held in this city to-day, nominated the following State ticket:

The career of George Jones, veteran editor and proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, which closed in death Wednesday morning at Poland Spring, Me., is as instructive as any that has been terminated in a decade. His well-directed perseverance and his honesty of purpose have been amply rewarded, and he has passed away leaving behind him a monument, alike honorable to American journalism and his own sturdy convictions.

The decision just rendered by Judge WHEELER in the United States court sitting at Brattleborough, Vt., touching the return of Chinamen arrested under the Exclusion act, is in accordance with recent decisions of United States courts in other States. Yet it is in direct opposition to the practice of the Administration.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 9. -- The miners of the anthracite region are thoroughly aroused on the subject of the semi-monthly pay law, and largely attended meetings are of daily and nightly occurrence in the principal towns of the coal valleys, at which the enforcement of the new law is vigorously and vehemently urged.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 9. -- No more skulking behind the hedges where assassin shots can be delivered against his neighbors! Thomas C. Platt is out in the open now, where he can be reached. He has throttled all opposition in the convention, and has nominated his own ticket. Now he must elect it if he can.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9. -- The quo warranto proceedings concerning the Governorship cannot reach the Supreme Court prior to the first Tuesday in October, and then only by consent of all parties concerned. Pursuing the usual channels and precedents, the case would not be reached until the first Tuesday in December. when the regular session of the court will begin in New-Haven.

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 12. -- Information has just been receives here of an insurrection of the Chinese against the foreign missionaries at Foo-Chow. The accounts are very meagre, but state that three missionaries have been murdered a few miles from the city and their homes burned.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Stories of genius bursting full-grown from rags and a garret are more numerous in fiction than in history. Yet such is the story of Pietro Mascagni, the composer of "Cavalleria Rusticana," which is the reigning musical sensation of Europe. Sozogno, the Milan publisher, offered a prize for the best one-act opera.

Among the fastnesses of the Pocono Mountains in Pennsylvania a new railroad is being built. The surveys were completed some time ago, and now active work has commenced. The road is known as the Pennsylvania Midland. Its charter was obtained at Harrisburg several years ago, but nothing further was done for a year.

Only eleven Commissioners of the Board of Education attended yesterday's meeting, the first of the Fall season. Two of the absentees had not returned from Europe and the others were excused on account of sickness of themselves or their families. Ex-Judge Larremore, who twenty-one years ago was President of the board, had a seat beside President Hunt.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The Thirtieth District Republican Convention to-day renominated Greenleaf S. Van Gorder for State Senator.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9. -- Major James B. Quinn, United States Engineer in charge of the lighthouses on the Gulf coast west of the Mississippi, the jetties at Port Eads, and the improvement of the internal waterways of Louisiana south or Red River, furnishes an interesting report with reference to important Louisiana waterways.

Is it not time that the excavation of Broadway were completed and that street made once more a thoroughfare? Of course the work is elaborate and difficult, and it cannot be hurried beyond a certain point.

Miss Agnes Huntington, with her mother, arrived from England yesterday on the Inman steamship City of Paris, and is now occupying cozy apartments at the Grand Hotel. When the newspaper men called upon her last evening she was discovered restraining a ferocious fourteen-inch English black and tan by force of arms.

In a very few days arrangements will be completed for a test of speed between Norman L. Munro's steam yacht Norwood and Mr. Hearst's Vamoose. Since the Vamoose crossed the bow of the Monmouth on Saturday last in a race down the upper bay with the Sandy Hook steamer, Mr. Munro has been anxious for a match between the two yachts, as the Norwood has outsteamed the Monmouth, too.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 9. -- There is no State in the Union where hop growing is carried on with more success than in Washington. The industry has passed beyond the experimental stage and is steadily gaining ground. The crop is a large one this year, and well-informed men estimate the State's profit on it at about $1,500,000.

Amasa Lyon Co., a corporation manufacturing umbrellas at 684 Broadway, has become insolvent and unable to meet maturing obligations, and Judge McAdam of the Superior Court has appointed Andrew J. Nutting of Brooklyn temporary receiver on the application of the Trustees, who declare that the business has been unprofitable since the organization of the company, and future prospects do not justify hope or expectation of any profits from the business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- A local paper says: "At a secret meeting of the Board of Control of the World's Columbian Exposition held yesterday afternoon, after the National Commission had adjourned, the following resolution, in substance, was unanimously adopted:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8. -- A sensation was caused to-day by the announcement that Rabbi H. Sonnenschein of Temple Israel has resigned and will go to Germany to reside permanently. In his letter of resignation the celebrated Jewish scholar and teacher assigns ill health and expresses great regret. The resignation is accepted in similar terms, but there are rumors afloat of various kinds to the general effect that the resignation is under pressure.

ROCHESTER, Sept 9. -- Big and little Federal office holders have been jostling one another in the hotel corridors ever since this convention began to pull itself together. The two most conspicuous ornaments of this office-holding array were, of course, Thomas C. Platt, member of the commission for the location of a Government dock in Washington, and the Collector of the Port of New-York, Mr. Fassett.
Three persons were killed and two were injured yesterday by the explosion of the engine of a passenger train on the Long Island Railroad at the station at Oyster Bay.

While the British naval experts admit that this year's manoeuvres in the North Sea have been valuable as showing that less is to be apprehended than was generally supposed from the attacks of torpedo vessels, and also as illustrating the gratifying promptness with which the great armor-clads can be mobilized, some of them complain of the unsatisfactory character of the exercises as a whole.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 10. -- A telegram from Sydney to-day states that the bodies of four men and one woman have been washed ashore at Scatterie from the wreck of the bark Camellia of St. John's, N.F. The vessel was bound to St. John's from Bahia. The woman whose body came ashore was the wife of Capt. Harvey, the master of the Camellia, and her husband perished with her.

The Tammany Committee of Twenty-four met yesterday afternoon and made the final arrangements for the trip to the Saratoga Convention. Reports from the various Assembly districts indicated that about seven hundred braves would go up with the delegates. The first section of the special Tammany train will leave the Grand Central Station at 8:20 o'clock Monday morning, and will stop at Mott Haven to take on the Twenty-fourth Assembly District shouters.

If the Rochester Convention was not in sentiment heartily in favor of the renomination of Mr. HARRISON -- and some way Mr. HARRISON does not seem anywhere to inspire hearty sentiment in his favor -- it was what may be called an officially "Administration" convention. It was run by office holders to an extent that has not been seen in a number of years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The Statistician of the Department of Agriculture reports the September general averages of cereal crops as follows: Corn, 91.1; wheat, 96.8; rye, 95.1; oats, 90.7; barley, 94.3; buckwheat, 96.6. A small advance is noted in all but buckwheat. The average for potatoes is 94.8; for tobacco, 87.4.
If the eleventh census, which has cost some $10,000,000, can be at all relied upon, we find strange revelations therein.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- About twenty-five pickle manufacturers of the West held a meeting here to-day and fixed the price of pickles for the opening of the Fall trade. The small manufacturers wanted the price fixed at $3 per barrel, but the large manufacturers desired to get $4.

William R. Rockwell, a son-in-law of Charles H. Swan of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company, committed suicide at the Highland House, Summit, N.J., on Wednesday. Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell went to Summit for the Summer in June, and the latter remained there until Tuesday morning, when she suddenly left with her six-year-old son for her father's house, 39 Brevoort Place, Brooklyn.

The Jury of experts who have sat for nine days under the direction of Coroner Hanly trying to determine from a mass of conflicting testimony the cause of the Park Place catastrophe has finished its task, but has accomplished little. Their verdict, rendered at 8:30 o'clock last night, after over six hours' steady deliberation, places but little responsibility for the catastrophe.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- To-morrow will be published the articles of association which will formally launch Baron Hirsch's munificent scheme of benefaction to the poor and oppressed of his race. It takes the form of a limited liability company, called "The Jewish Colonization Association," registered, the office of which will be in London. Its nominal capital is $2,000,000, in 20,000 shares of $100 each.

The death last week of George Jones, proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, was not unexpected, for he had been a sufferer from a complication of diseases for a number of years. * * * Mr. Jones was * * * an important factor in modern journalism, for he was, in fact, THE NEW-YORK TIMES from the date of the death of his former partner, Henry J. Raymond, to that of his own.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The only question raised by the Republicans left in Rochester to-day was, "Will the ticket nominated yesterday be faithfully supported?" That was the apprehension, and the best grounds existed for it.

The full text of the grounds upon which Secretary FOSTER and Judge LAWRENCE have taken an appeal from the decision of the Board of General Appraisers concerning double duties on carpet wool, shows that these gentlemen are in perfect accord with respect to their interpretation of "the bravest and wisest of tariff laws yet framed."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- A series of tests at the naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Head Tuesday last has demonstrated that the navy has a smokeless powder which can be depended upon for very satisfactory results in rapid-fire guns.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- The banquet given to-day at Vandeuvre by M. de Freycinet, President of the Council and Minister of War, to the French Generals who are taking part in the army manoeuvres and to the military attaches who are watching them was a brilliant affair. It was apparently selected as the occasion for the French Government, through M. de Freycinet, to give utterance to its views upon the peace prospects of Europe.

The submission of the Sultan to the Russian demand for a free passage through the Dardanelles is likely to turn out a more serious matter than it at first appeared. Eleven Russian vessels have passed the Dardanelles this year, which if not strictly men-of-war were engaged in a warlike mission and were laden with military stores.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept 10. -- Under the terms of the Cape Cod Ship Canal bill, passed by the last Legislature, the so-called "Canadian Syndicate" had until midnight last night to deposit $500,000 in cash with the State Treasurer as a guarantee of good faith, and if it did so the charter now held by O.A. Shaw and Col. T.L. Livermore was to be extended. The $500,000 was not put up.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Miss Vera Ava, a wealthy Englishwoman who came to Chicago recently to raise the standard of living in the slums, is reported to the police as missing. She has been stopping at the residence of the Rev. Dr. Bolton. Last evening Miss Ava and Mrs. Bolton drove to the Catholic Church on West Twelfth Street. Miss Ava entered the building and Mrs. Bolton waited for her in the carriage.

The spectacle of twenty-three fat men in nine hacks bowling gayly along the dusty road to Dorlon's Point yesterday regaled the vision of the inhabitants of the quiet old town of South Norwalk, Conn. Over the bridge and across the marsh they went at a clipping pace, their white high hats bobbing merrily up and down, and the sound of their ponderous laughter awakening the echoes far and near.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- This was a gala day in the United States Army national shooting tournament at Fort Sheridan. The grand stand and veranda were filled to overflowing with ladies, civilians, and handsome young Lieutenants, while the range was lined with fashionable equipages, each bearing a bevy of fair spectators.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The Republican nominations on the State ticket were received in Cortland County without much expression of satisfaction. Fassett is not liked generally, and as Edward Keator, President of the First National Bank here and a prominent Republican, expresses it: "He's entirely too thick with 'Tom' Platt." Platt, in the estimation of Mr. Keator, does not bear a very good reputation in certain parts of the State.

BRIDGEPORT, Sept. 10. -- The most important meeting of the Board of Aldermen since the trouble in municipal matters started last April was held last evening. Mayor Marigold presented three veto messages, and in each instance the resolution was passed over his head, the Democrats voting solidly against the Mayor.

Interest in Fall racing matters promises to be fairly divided in the near future between the tracks, the courts, and the poolrooms. Ed Corrigan, whose colt, Huron, ran second for the Futurity Stakes at the Coney Island Jockey Club track Aug. 29, is not disposed to accept the action of the club in that and other affairs in which he is concerned.

The New-Yorks and Clevelands played a close game on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Judging from the scores, one would naturally jump at the conclusion that the contest was a very interesting one. But it wasn't. On the contrary, both sides committed costly errors, and of the 11 runs scored only 3 were earned.

PLAQUEMINE, La., Sept. l0. -- There was considerable excitement on the Dunboyne plantation to-day. A negro named Scott Austin fired a double-barreled shotgun loaded with fine shot into a crowd of Italians. Six of the Italian laborers were seriously wounded. Austin says the shooting was accidental, but there was a great deal of feeling, and the negro was taken to Plaquemine for safe keeping.

PULTNEY, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The appearance of the Marvin seamless buckskin peach in market a week earlier than usual suggests the thought that Winter is almost at hand in spite of the calendar. This peach comes chiefly from the lake region of this State, and is seldom offered for sale until all other varieties have disappeared.

The Canadians are credited with contemplating the construction of a second transcontinental railroad in their country, starting from Port Simpson on the Pacific coast and running to Fort Churchill on Hudson Bay. This would make a route parallel to the Canadian Pacific and about 600 miles north of it.

The Custom House is rapidly accumulating a large stock of Paris-made gowns. Yesterday there was an important addition to the collection in the seizure room. It came from the steamer City of Paris and was contained in a big trunk bearing the name of A.J. Parcels of Pittsburg. It was claimed, however, by Miss Mollie Jones of that city as her property.

Lewis Stein, manufacturer of garters and elastic supporters at 378 Canal Street, has sold his business to George D. Nichols and disappeared, leaving debts that are estimated at $25,000. Mr. Nichols is in receipt of a letter from him dated at Montreal Sept. 4, in which he congratulates himself on his lucky escape from American jurisdiction and outlines his future work, which seems, in plan, to be a continuation of his former methods.
