OTTAWA, Sept. 10. -- The investigation into the irregularities in the State Department, including the Printing Bureau, was resumed to-day. To-morrow or Tuesday the opposition hope to bring the charges home to J.A. Chapleau, Secretary of State. To-day's proceedings were lively. C.A. Danserau, Postmaster at Montreal, in the witness box said he knew Senecal very well.

There was published in the World last Wednesday a short interview with "the examiner in charge of the division of electricity" at the Patent Office in Washington. Part of this interview was as follows:

The denial by the Board of Park Commissioners of the application made on behalf of the Now-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company for the closing of the drawbridges over the Harlem River for certain hours morning and afternoon was based upon the following reasons, which were yesterday spread upon the minutes of the board:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The opening of the Springfield Bicycle Club's tournament was held at Hampden Park, this place, to-day. The track is a half-mile one, and time and money have made it perfect for cycle racing. The absence of any wind made records easily possible, and the racing men did not fail to take advantage of the fact. This meet bids fair to outstrip all the others. Nearly 12,000 people
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- In an interview this afternoon with Lieut. Gov. Edward F. Jones on the nomination of J. Sloat Fassett for Governor, Mr. Jones said:
The fortunes and prospects of President William H. Beers must be at low ebb when his general agents send out circulars, of which the following is a copy:

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10. -- There will be no strike of the negro Alliance men in this part of the South, but the movement came within an ace of being indorsed in Georgia. So says E.S. Richardson, Superintendent of the colored Alliance in Georgia. In speaking of Humphreys and his attempt to get the Alliance to indorse his scheme in Georgia. Richardson does not mince his words.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10. -- A conference of prominent Republicans in the Carrollton Hotel to-day resulted in Col. William J. Vannort of Kent County remaining on the ticket for Governor, the withdrawal of Charles T. Westcott of Kent from the Chairmanship of the State Central Committee, and the selection of Harry M. Clabaugh of Carroll County to take that position.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- As was anticipated in THE TIMES this morning, the dissolution of Acting Rear Admiral Walker's squadron of evolution still goes on. The Boston and the Concord were detached to-day, and as if to emphasize the fact that the department is awakening to the necessity of doing something to show that Walker's "pull" does not absolutely control the navy, the Secretary has transferred them under the flag of his rival.

HAWKESBURY, C.B., Sept. 11. -- The schooner Julia Decker arrived in port to-day, having on board the members of the Bowdoin scientific expedition. The results of the trip to Labrador have far exceeded the hopes of the projectors. Grand falls have been discovered and photographed, and, though not as high as reported, present a beautiful sight.

It is a great advance toward the employment of petroleum instead of coal for generating steam in the boilers of marine engines to find that the question is now nearly reduced to one of cost. When it comes absolutely to that point its use for some branches of navigation will be assured.

Baltimore celebrates once more to-day her battle of North Point by orations, odes, parades, and a public holiday. A few years ago there were survivors of the conflict to participate in the ceremonies, but now the affair is wholly in the hands of a younger generation, who keep it up with enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Secretary Tracy to-day issued an order intended to put in practice the system adopted in the army a year ago of ascertaining periodically the fitness of officers for their various professional duties, the intention being to enable the Navy Department to assign officers to discharge the functions for which they may show special aptitude.

Our high-tariff friends have an interesting assortment of discordant doctrines, and it requires much skill to handle them. For two or three months they have been trying to teach their readers that when tariff duties are increased the price of the protected products in the home market falls. In this task they have called to their assistance intricate diagrams and other devices.

The verdict rendered by the jury that sat for nine days trying to determine the cause of the terrible Park Place disaster is provoking a great deal of unfavorable comment. It is to the effect that the verdict amounts to nothing, and that the time of the twelve experts who sat on the jury and of the public officials who conducted the inquest might just as well have been spent fishing in Jamaica Bay.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Admiral Brown has been ordered by the Secretary of the Navy to bring his flagship, the San Francisco, from Chile to the Mare Island Navy Yard. This indicates that the department regards the new Government of Chile as on a sound basis, and that there will be no more trouble there to require the presence of more than one vessel.

The affairs of the Panama Canal Company are still the subject of discussion in Paris, although the project is dead and buried. It is not surprising that some of those who gave $250,000,000 to the company should continue to complain and to urge the Government to do something for them, but there is no indication that they will be successful.

Tammany Hall Assembly District Conventions for the election of delegates to the Saratoga Convention were held in the First, Thirteenth, and Fifteenth Districts last night, the only districts in which they had not already been held. The delegates and alternates elected were as follows:

As the cool nights arrive and the anglers are reminded that their bouts with the big fish will soon be over, there is always a rush for the fishing grounds. It is this kind of a rush that is now on, and every day there comes the familiar sight of green baskets and long poles to which a shrimp net is attached. They are seen at the railroad stations and at the boat landings.

The London Times truly says of the scheme of Baron HIRSCH for colonizing in America the Jews for whom there is no place in Europe that it is the most remarkable scheme of the kind ever attempted by practical men. There are not wanting examples to show that representatives of the Jewish race can spend money as generously as they can accumulate it shrewdly.

The Western Union Telegraph Company, which is the ally of the city poolrooms, is preparing to make a hot fight against the Brooklyn Jockey Club when racing shall begin on the track of that club next Monday. The furnishing of news to the poolrooms in this city and in the Western towns is the most profitable business that this giant monopoly has, and it will do all in its power to get it for distribution.

The feeling that has been excited by the announcement of the production of WAGNER'S "Lohengrin" in Paris is not at all creditable to the good sense of that city. Of course, Paris has its share of persons who are there called chauvinists and would here be called hoodlums, and these Parisians would be glad to mob a German opera.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11. -- About 8 o'clock this morning the janitor of the Haehnien Building, at 418 Library Street, discovered the body of Charles M. Stokes, Sr., a well-known stock broker, lying on the floor of the room he occupied as an office. There was a bullet hole through the head, and beside the body lay a revolver with one chamber empty.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- No trace has been found of Miss Vera Ava, the woman who came here some weeks ago to work for the reclamation of fallen women, and who suddenly disappeared on Wednesday evening. Concerning her identity an afternoon paper says:

Julius M. Price, artist and special correspondent for the Illustrated London News, arrived in New-York yesterday from San Francisco, and is now at the Hoffman House. He will remain a week and then continue his journey to London. He is on his way home after completing a trip through Siberia in the interests of his paper.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Prof. F.B. Putnam, Chief of the Department of Ethnology and Archaeology of the World's Fair, is rapidly getting together the materials for a grand exhibit. He began the work in February and gathered around him many able assistants, who are especially qualified for investigations in this direction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Mr. Denby, the Minister of the United States to China, in a dispatch to the Secretary of State dated Pekin, July 28, 1891, states that an imperial decree has been issued sanctioning the extension of the existing Chinese railway from Liu Hsi to Shan-Hai-Kuan. Liu Hsi is the present terminus of the road which runs from Tongshau, near Taku, on the Peiho River, to the Kaiping Mines.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 11. -- Documentary evidence very damaging to B.R. Musgrove, who tried to swindle various insurance companies by leaving a skeleton to burn in a log cabin near Terre Haute, Ind., has just been furnished by Parson Co., St. Louis, dealers in secret society paraphernalia. It was this firm which sold the skeleton to Musgrove, and the letters constitute the strongest evidence yet brought against him, substantiating charges in Traut's confession.

At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners held yesterday a communication was received from the Mayor recommending that a census of the dogs in the city be taken for the purpose of better enforcing the ordinance providing for the licensing of those animals. The board will consider the matter.

In 1879 the present Government of Canada introduced into Parliament what is now known as the national policy. This meant simply a system of protection. Prior to this date the bulk of the revenues of Canada had been obtained from customs and excise, but these had been levied from a revenue point of view rather than from a protective point of view.

The rain-making experiments in Texas, it appears, are to go on again. The farmers whose parched lands have been drenched with heavy showers following the dynamite explosions are naturally enthusiastic over the new process of artificial precipitation, and show their gratitude for benefits received by unhesitating faith in the theories propounded.

ATHENS, Sept. 11. -- A collision has taken place off Cape Colonna, the most southern point of Attica, between an Italian steamship, the Taormina of the Italian Messageries Company, and a Greek steamship, the Thessalia. The Taormina sank soon after the accident, drowning her Captain, several of her crew, and forty of her cabin passengers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- "Flower and McNaughton." The Democrats of Rochester and the friends of Senator McNaughton think that the good-natured Scotch-American is just about the man to nominate for Lieutenant Governor.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 11. -- A banquet in honor of the delegates to the International Electrical Convention, now in session in this city, was given last night at the Windsor Hotel. The banquet was tendered to the visitors by the citizens' committee, and was a great success. Nearly five hundred guests sat down to dinner. The chair was occupied by Sir Donald A. Smith, President of the Bank of Montreal and Chancellor of McGill University.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Yesterday Recorder Morschauser of this city issued a warrant for the arrest of William A. Smith of 60 Broadway, New-York, charging him with grand larceny. He is the senior member of the firm of W.A. Smith Co. of this city, doing business at 54 Market Street, this city, and also in New-York.

Adolphe Deckle, alias A.D. Meteline, who was employed as a gold plater by E.G. Bratmar, jeweler at 47 Cortlandt Street, yesterday was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court and held in $1,500 bail on a charge of having stolen a gold brick valued at $1,000 from his employer. When arrested he admitted the theft and said he had sold the brick for $460 in Providence to a man named L.P. Darling.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11. -- Attorneys representing John Lornie of Scotland and Alfred Sully and N.B. Randall of New-York to-day filed a bill in equity in the United States Circuit Court against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, the Reading Coal and Iron Company, and the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities, complaining that interest due bondholders has been diverted for other purposes.
" You put $10 in the slot and you pull out $5,000. A sure thing. Failure impossible."
EFFINGHAM, Ill., Sept. 11. -- This city was the scene of a bank robbery to-day at noon that almost rivals the exploits of the Younger brothers.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- There was a contest between the Hill and anti-Hill Democrats in their Second Assembly District Convention at Canton, St. Lawrence County, yesterday, the fight being continued at every point throughout the convention. The Hill men won. Both sides are for Flower, however, with the exception of a few Jones men.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- Miss Vera Ava, if her own testimony is to be credited, is here in the Cincinnati House of Detention. She is a rather large woman, apparently thirty-eight years old, has light blue eyes and rather closely cropped hair, well sprinkled with gray. She talks sometimes rationally and sometimes with wild incoherence.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners expected yesterday to make public the reports of the consulting engineers who have been examining the plans of construction of the Broadway Line, but the reports were not all in.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 11. -- The Pittsburg Press of this evening makes the statement that C.L. Magee has gone down to Atlantic City to have a talk with Senator Quay about Mr. Blaine's prospects for the Presidential nomination in 1892 and Pennsylvania's part in the coming contest. Much political significance is said to lie in the conference of the former rivals.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11. -- The second and last day of the Springfield Bicycle Club's tournament was run off to-day at Hampden Park. The crowd numbered 25,000 people, and the sight was one seldom witnessed at a bicycle meet. As early as 1:30 the grand-stand gates were closed, and the rest of the spectators were forced to go into the centre of the field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11. -- Late last night officers at the Southern Police Station were startled by a pistol shot just outside of the door. Rushing out, they found Officer Grant lying dead on the pavement, with a bullet hole in his head. A man was seen running away, and on being stopped Grant's handcuffs were found on his wrists.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 11. -- In the various accounts which have appeared in THE TIMES relative to the insubordinate conduct and highhanded actions of Acting Rear Admiral John G. Walker, fragmentary statements have appeared intimating that this officer, while Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, advanced himself by creating vacancies above him.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The Perth Amboy Common Council has taken steps to obtain an adequate supply of pure water. For years the city has been dependent on a plant owned by a private company, and at times the water is very muddy, and at others so scarce that during part of the day no supply can be had.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 11. -- This city was thrown into the wildest excitement by the kidnapping of William E. Bailey and R.B. Albertson, his attorney, yesterday afternoon by Detective Sullivan and his two deputies. The abduction took place at 5:30 o'clock in Second Street, when it was crowded. Bailey is a young man, whose father is a millionaire at Harrisburg, Penn.

If the Vamoose, the little steam racing yacht built by the Herreshoffs and owned by W.R. Hearst, the young San Francisco millionare, is not the fastest craft afloat, then Norman L. Munroe's little Norwood must prove it. The Vamoose yesterday ran all around the fast steamer Mary Powell, on the Hudson River, and ran alongside a passenger train on the New-York Central Railroad from Yonkers to Hastings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- An evening paper publishes an open letter from Julio M. Foster, dated Washington, D.C., Sept. 11, in which he takes Patrick Egan severely to task for his course during the troubles in Chile. After stating the well-known facts in regard to Egan's political career abroad and in this country and the fact of his appointment two months after his naturalization, Mr. Foster says:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 11. -- Chauncey I. Filley having carefully laid his plans took action last night that again placed him in control of the Republican machinery in the city. A little over a year ago the silk-stocking element unseated John McFall, Chairman of the committee, put George Bain in his place, and elected members at large that gave them control of the committee.

Day by day new and interesting facts are reaching the surface relative to the gross mismanagement of President William H. Beers and the many impecunious relatives that he has grafted on the New-York Life Insurance Company. Some years ago a cousin of William H. Beers, one Samuel Cooper, was in charge of the loan department of the company.

Thomas Dougherty, who was arrested Tuesday night on a charge of vagrancy, and who developed an epileptic fit two hours later and was taken to Bellevue Hospital after a wild struggle in a sadly damaged condition, is still receiving treatment at Bellevue.

Lizzie Walter, a German girl, twenty-two years old, obtained work in Mrs. William Malsom's family at 254 Keap Street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, and yesterday morning she was found lying on the bed in her room unconscious, while the gas poured out of a burner. On a table was a bottle, in which there remained only a few drops of paregoric.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Before the majority of Harvard men will have turned their faces college-ward this Fall the candidates for the football team will have assembled and begun preliminary work on Jarvis Field. Wednesday, Sept. 23, has been chosen as the date for the first work, when at least forty candidates are expected to be on hand.

Two new views of life in England, as depicted by modern English dramatists, were offered to New-York playgoers last week, and are to be available for study for a few weeks to come. At Palmer's Theatre a very creditable effort has been made to revive the splendor and the glory of Queen Elizabeth's time in a series of tasteful, richly-colored pictures.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. l2. -- Robert H. Humphrey, better known as "Bob" Humphrey, died at 6:15 o'clock this morning at his residence, 3,233 Rutger Street. He lacked but one month of being fifty-five years old, and was never sick before in his life until stricken down with paralysis of the spinal cord, a week ago last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- People in Washington who have watched the progress of events in the Pacific Ocean for a few years hope that the sending of the Pensacola to Honolulu marks the beginning of a policy of keeping a naval force constantly at the Hawaiian Islands.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 12. -- September leaves are turning crimson, and the "season" is well-nigh over. The chronicle of the week is the same for Monday, Tuesday, and all the other days. Driving, riding, and coaching seem to be the only things that make life worth living in these delightful days of frost and sunshine.

At the office of the State Superintendent of Insurance in this city to-day, it was said that the examination by the State Insurance Department of the affairs, management, , of the New-York Life Insurance Company was being pushed forward as rapidly as possible, under the direction of Deputy Superintendent Shannon.

THE LORNAS, LUCIES, DIS, AND BEATRIXES. -- I like my lady-loves of romance to have names that the lips and the memory can linger over lovingly -- Lorna Doone. Lucy Desborough, Di Vernon, Beatrix Esmond, and there is sweetness as well as pathos in the simple signature of Clare Doris Forey, as Clare liked to write her name, because Richard's was Richard Doria Feverel.

SLEEP. -- Sleep insures rest in its highest degree, and rest is necessary for repair, as all action, whether of mind or body, involves destruction, and without sleep and rest destruction would proceed so much more rapidly than repair that our powers would soon fail altogether, as it is probable that muscular and mental fatigue are due to the waste having outrun repair.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $150,126,600, as follows: Currency 6s, $9,367,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $1,056,900; 4 per cent, $119,000,100; 2 per cents, $20,702,600.

All the crack amateur athletes of this vicinity have been in training for some weeks past for the express purpose of winning gold medals, fame, and points for their clubs at the Metropolitan championships. These took place on the Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon in the presence of a large number of spectators. The track was in grand condition, and it was thought that some records would go under.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Many signs point to an animated dramatic season in London. It is not so much that important novelties are expected as that the long simmering feud between such poetic spirit as England possesses and that Philistine group, which practically monopolizes dramatic criticism here, has burst forth into open warfare.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The Drury Lane Theatre's annual melodrama, produced by Sir Augustus Harris under the title of "A Sailor's Knot," does not require any further notice beyond the fact that, dealing with the battle of Waterloo, it has aroused the ire of the London correspondent of the Paris Figaro, as Gilbert and Sullivan's treatment of a French subject did upon a former occasion.

The "new uniform" order to officers and enlisted men of the United States Revenue Marine has been signed by the Secretary of the Treasury. It will be ready for issue to the service during the present week. Officers will be allowed four months from the date of the order in which to provide themselves with the uniforms prescribed.

The recent conference between Gov. Hill and Hugh McLaughlin at which, it is now generally known, the latter offered to mortgage the future actions of Kings County for several years to come, and the former had to confess that he could not prevent Roswell P. Flower's nomination if he tried to, has left the Kings County Democracy way out at sea. The leaders evidently don't know what to do except to denounce Hill.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- According to the figures presented by the State Assessors, and upon which the equalization for this year was based, the real estate of the several counties of New York increased during the year $98,910,766, to sum of $3,397,234,679. The personal estate fell off $3,170,064, to $382,159,067. Of the 60 counties, 31 show increased values in personal estate over last year and 29 decreases.

The members of the National Commission to Europe in the interest of the World's Columbian Exposition arrived home yesterday by the steamer Augusta Victoria. They are Moses P. Handy of Philadelphia, Gen. Benjamin Butterworth of Ohio, Judge William Lindsay of Kentucky, F.W. Peck of Chicago, and A.G. Bullock of Massachusetts. J.W. Shragne is the Secretary of the commission.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Still in his most fantastic mood the weather clerk is fairly baking Europe now with the sultriest, the sunniest September known for many, many years. Had this true midsummer burst of heat come in the right place in the calendar, it would have been a great boon to everybody on this side of the Atlantic.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 12.--The North Atlantic squadron will scatter early next week. The flagship Philadelphia will leave Tuesday for New-York, to have her military masts replaced by wooden ones. She will stop one day at Gardiner's Bay, Long Island, for great-gun target practice. Her complement is twenty men short.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- The war begun early this Summer by Founder James A. Bradley against the illicit beer peddlers has ended. The "spotters" employed by the founder to chase the drivers of the liquor wagons have been called off, and the beer barons, bolder than ever, think they have won a victory over the founder of the prohibition resort.
" Since you were born in Poland, Count, did you serve in the Russian Army by choice?"

Three months ago yesterday THE TIMES published its first article on the New-York Life Insurance scandal. During that interval President William H. Beers has taken no direct steps to clear his name. A statement he did make, but it was wholly valueless as a document that in anywise cleared him of the many and very serious charges laid at his door.

The Fire Commissioners have received official reports on the Park Place disaster from Fire Marshal Mitchei, Superintendent of Buildings Brady, and Acting Fire Chief Reilly. They all state that the catastrophe was the result of an explosion, though there is that in Superintendent Brady's report which clearly indicates that even while he wrote of an explosion he had the theory of the collapse of the building through overweight in his mind.

MR. LABOUCHERE. -- To begin with, the House will always listen to him, and that is something. In truth, it is more than some who are in the Ministry could honestly say for or of themselves. Mr. Labouchere must once have been in the diplomatic service; at least I have heard him say so a score of times.

It were unprofitable to philosophize over the methods of Mr. Rudyard Kipling. And it strikes us that the manner in which he decks his stories, rather than the spirit of them, has attracted the attention of reviewers. It is but natural that critics should try and divine why this new man is so attractive and impressive.
She had but slept a couple of hours when some one came to rouse her.

LENOX, Mass, Sept. 12.--There were 3,000 people in Lenox to-day to see the annual tub parade. There were about fifty vehicles in line, the most there has ever been since this unique affair was inaugurated. The decorations of the carriages and the toilets of the ladies were the most elegant ever seen on a similar occasion.

There has been a good deal of photographing by the amateurs in the last week, but few events have happened offering special photographic attractions. The Labor Day, parade was not especially remarkable, and, as a consequence, the array of cameras to catch the distinguishing features was small. The day was made use of, however, for suburban excursions, and not a few amateurs took advantage of the holiday to catch views of Autumn scenery.

OBNOXIOUS ENGLISHMEN IN AUSTRALIA. -- I have never in my life known anything more offensively insolent than the patronizing tolerance which I have seen a traveled Cockney extend to a man of the colonies who was worth a thousand of him. I have seen an Englishman unintentionally insult a host at his own table and set everybody on tenterhooks by his blundering assumption that colonists are necessarily inferior to home-bred people.

" This seems impossible! It cannot be true!" Mme. Minnie Hauk exclaimed yesterday when she read the cable report regarding the prohibition of "Lohengrin" at the Paris Opera House. The famous prima donna had just arrived on the North German Lloyd steamer Elbe, coming from Paris, en route for Philadelphia, where her opera company will begin rehearsals next Monday.

Members of the New-York Mercantile Exchange are deeply interested in the balloting that will take place in the Exchange on Tuesday to decide whether the Executive Committee shall be authorized to buy in non-participating certificates of membership or not.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12. -- The identity of the woman who mysteriously disappeared in Chicago on Wednesday evening with the one who as mysteriously appeared last night in this city is fully established by a description of her given to-day by Mrs. Bolton of Chicago. There is the deep scar under the left eye, the growth of hair on a light mole, the blue eyes, and the entire description closely corresponds.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Father Kelley of the Church in Twelfth Street, whom Miss Ava accuses of complicity in her abduction, said to a reporter, in reply to her story:

The "pull" of Acting Admiral Walker is so singularly like that of a naval officer in the English service, two hundred years or so ago, that some account of a "political pull" in our great-grandfather's days may not prove uninteresting. The Earl of Torrington was England's politician Admiral -- the man who had a famous "pull."

Within a few months there has been published in Florence the autobiography of Colonel Michele Zambelli, who, during thirty-two years of active service in the gendarmerie of the Papal States, was the scourge of banditti and the most active uprooter of the secret societies into which they formed themselves. His work lay in Romagna and the outlying dependencies of the Papal States, before the establishment of the kingdom of Italy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Of the dramatic attractions presented by the theatres during the week just closed, but one was a novelty to Chicago -- "The Idler," a comedy from the pen of C. Haddon Chambers, given by the New-York Lyceum Theatre company at Hooley's. Were it not for the artistic acting of Miss Georgia Cayvan as Helen.

The condition of the real estate market fully warrants all that has been said in its favor during the last fortnight. Already there have been sales that have brought into the market men who deal heavily in real estate and who act as though they were now making purchases with a view of starting with the season at the beginning and of continuing to deal in the market for some time to come.

Bright Child -- Gran'pa, you used to live in Philadelphia, didn't you? Grandpa -- Yes, my dear. B.C. -- Well, there's something in the paper about a gravity railroad that Philadelphia is thinking about having in the park. Shall I read it to you? G. -- No, my dear. I read all about that when I was a boy. -- New-York Weekly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The much-talked-of rifle match between the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn and the National Guard of the District of Columbia was shot to-day on the arsenal range, in this city, and resulted in an overwhelming victory for the representatives of the State of New-York.

That the prize fight between "Jack" McAuliffe of Brooklyn and Austin Gibbons of Paterson, N.J., under the auspices of the Granite Association of Hoboken, which was stopped by the police, was a farce is beginning to dawn upon many of the "sports" of this city who went over to see the contest and spent their money freely.

The Palisade Boat Club of Yonkers yesterday held the races which were postponed from Labor Day on account of rough water. The first race was for junior singles, the contestants being P.B. Rosaire, W.T.C. Carpenter, C.C. Rossire, W.C. Hoff, and C.P. Marsden, Jr. The latter won by a length in 5:58.

ATHENS, Sept. 12. -- The corrected estimate of the number of persons drowned as a result of the collision off Cape Colonna between the Italian steamship Taormina and the Greek steamship Thessalia, shows that sixty-six persons lost their lives by the sinking of the Taormina. Of this number ten were saloon passengers.

HOWLING DERVISHES.--They were of all ages; fat and lean, smooth-shaven and bearded; some in rich garments, others in more sombre and cheaper stuffs. One face cut itself into my memory--that of a handsome, clear-skinned young man, with deep, intense eyes that fairly flamed, and a sinewy, graceful body.

SARATOGA, Sept. 12. -- Saratoga has put on her political dress this week, and social life is temporarily under an eclipse. It must not be understood, however, that there are no social affairs here now; on the contrary, there are many very agreeable receptions, conversaziones, and evening parties, but they are not so numerous or overpoweringly fashionable as were those of the regular season.

This is the ticket that the Democrats now expect to see nominated by the Democratic State Convention to be held in Saratoga Tuesday. Mr. Sweet, who is understood to be scheduled for the tall of the ticket, was State Engineer and Surveyor from Nov. 6, 1883, to Nov. 8, 1887, having been the immediate predecessor of the present Sate Engineer, John N. Bogart.

THE SLAVE IN ANCIENT COMEDY. -- The slave is the most important character in ancient comedy, and naturally so, as he was a universal figure in ancient life. Clever, witty, unscrupulous, braving the scourge, and even the cross to carry out his schemes, the slave is the most conspicuous person on the canvas of the comic stage.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 12. -- On the surface, the season is over here; in reality, it is the time when society people see most of each other and enjoy real intercourse. The chase after pleasure is not so apparent, but nearly every cottage is a scene of daily and nightly festivity.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The Rev. E.L. Burnet, for four years pastor of the Congregational Church at Maine, N.Y., has resigned the charge.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- There was a parade of all the troops stationed in the Cassel district today, which afforded a brilliant spectacle. The Emperor and Empress, the King of Saxony, the Grand Duke of Hesse, the Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar, the Duke of Edinburgh, Prince and Princess Henry of Prussia, Prince Albrecht, and others of high rank were present at the ceremony.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The University of Rochester opened for the Fall term on Thursday morning with sixty new names upon its roll of students. All were freshmen with one exception, a sophomore. Even if these figures showed the full strength of the class of '95, this is the largest number of new students that has ever entered the institution in a single year.

Although those wiser yachtsmen who know how to enjoy the luxury of cruising will continue to drift about among the wooded coves or rocky bays of the coast between Sandy Hook and Bar Harbor for at least another month, what is commonly called the yachting season is over. For the yachting season has come to mean the racing season, and we may now regard that as ended.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Books printed in a foreign language exclusively are admitted to the United States duty free, and the General Appraisers have now decided, in connection with an importation of pamphlets, that woodcuts beneath which there is in the foreign language a quotation from the pamphlet may be admitted free of duty, it appearing that the cuts are intended to be part of the pamphlet.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 12. -- A great green hull, above which towered two black funnels and four tall masts, lay alongside the pier at the mouth of the Cuyahoga River one recent Saturday night. Huge masses of very black coal smoke poured from the funnels, and there was a low hissing and murmuring of steam about the hatch in the hall's side through which the engineer occasionally stepped out upon the landing and back.

I am an advance agent and my duties are manifold, but the principal one is to lie. To the uninitiated this may seem easy, but do not deceive yourself. The lies which the advance agent has to tell must bear the impress of truth and ring eighteen-carat every time. To lie in this manner requires a special faculty, an inventive brain, and full control over the muscles of the face.

As a relief from the gray and gloomy Winters which are the latest development of the American climate, the ladies are seeking gay colors and cheerful tints. The disposition to wear white and all light and bright colors through the Autumn and Winter is even more manifest this year than last. White cloths and wools are being brought out in many styles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12. -- Creed Haymond, attorney for the Southern Pacific Company, who has just returned from Europe, knows more about the Hopkins-Searles will ease than any one else. From a friend who talked with Haymond, it is learned that there are fortifications about the Searles fortune of which the lawyers know nothing.

Cleveland again played two games with the New-Yorks yesterday, and the Giants won and lost. In the opening contest John Ewing was pitted against Young, and he pitched an excellent game. The visitors only made four hits, and the New-Yorks fielded in grand style. They took the lead in the opening inning and won as they pleased. At times the Clevelands played good ball.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 12. -- Chief Justice McDonald has rendered a decision in the case of the New-York Farmers' Loan and Trust Company against the Nova Scotia Central Railway, ordering the foreclosure and sale of the road. The road is seventy miles long and connects with the Windsor and Annapolis at Middleton, and runs to Lunenburg, its Atlantic terminus.

Omaha's municipal pay roll, exclusive of inspectors and employes who work by the day, aggregates $21,894.96 per month, $262,739.95 per year. This is an enormous regular drain upon the city Treasury. It is large enough to excite the suspicion that it needs reorganization, pruning, and reduction.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 12. -- The new People's Party, which absorbs the Alliance and Industrial Union Parties of Minnesota, under the leadership of Ignatius Donnelly, adopted many sensational resolutions yesterday, among the chief of which are:

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 12. -- A dispatch from Grand Rapids, Mich., states that the Michigan Methodist Episcopal Conference spent most of the forenoon to-day with the case of the Rev. J.W. Arney of Saranac, the pastor with a decided proclivity for fast horses. The committee apointed to investigate the matter reported that "Brother Arney" had not lived up to the promises made at Muskegon one year ago, and recommended that he be disciplined.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The Rev. Dr. M.B. Terry, a former pastor, now a professor in Garrett Biblical Institute, preached in the Wurts Street Methodist Episcopal Church here last Sunday.

The current number of the Financial Chronicle contains an article by Mr. WILLIAM TRUMBULL of New-Haven, a native of Chile and for forty-five years a resident there, (but not the Mr. TRUMBULL who bought the arms for the Itata, who is a cousin of the writer,) on "The Chilean Revolution."

Her face, under the shadow of the ugly bonnet, was one of extreme refinement and beauty. She looked -- as indeed she was -- thoroughbred. Katherine Villiers, in fact, belonged to one of the oldest families in England.

Jules Breton is the happiest of autobiographers. His life has been so honest, he has basked so much in the sunshine, his own work has been so thoroughly in broad daylight -- au jour -- that the shadows are but few. His existence has been an art one, and he has been among the few fortunate ones who, having a true calling for art, enjoyed the fullest opportunities to develop his natural capacities.

Says the Naval and Military Record, (British:) "One important result of the recent naval manoeuvres has been the awakening of public opinion to the dangers of torpedo-boat attack. The striking article which appeared in the Globe this week has already been noticed in these columns, and has been read with interest in naval circles.

For the second or third time the report is telegraphed from London that "Portugal is negotiating for the sale of Macao to England." On this occasion the statement is supplemented by an announcement that "if England buys Macao she will try to trade it to China for the Island of Formosa."

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Everything this week has seemed to conspire for the enjoyment of the large number of city people summering in the Berkshires. The clear, cool weather, with the mercury ranging from 50 to 70, has been delightful. The week has been full of entertainment of all kinds. There have been tennis, boating, driving, parties, two elegant balls, and a score or more of dinner parties.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen G. Clarke of New-York City arrived at the Rainier Hotel yesterday, after a two weeks' excursion on the steamer Islander along the coast of British Columbia and Alaska. Mr. Clarke told some interesting facts about his trip to a Post-Intelligencer reporter yesterday. He said:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The whole business was revealed to-day. Not only are the anti-Hill men fighting against Sheehan for the State Committee, but they are against him for anything and everything. It is all a part of a deep-laid plan to fight Hill wherever it is possible, a plan concocted by the anti-Hill element in the Democratic Party.

Mr. Sanborn's biography of Dr. Howe is not very satisfactory, and in part this is not his fault. The family of the philanthropist have in preparation an extended biography, which will include extracts from letters and journals never before printed, and of this material no use has been made by Mr. Sanborn.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Not more than half a dozen delegates, outside of those from Saratoga County, are in town to-night, but the early train in the morning is expected to swell the host.

The offer of several pieces of ground as a site for the proposed Episcopal Cathedral at Washington has been made to Bishop Paret by Washingtonians, but, as the situation of the land was considered unsuitable for the purpose, the offer was not accepted. "As yet the plans have taken no definite shape," said the Bishop yesterday, "and nothing will be done in the matter until the site has been selected and the land given.

THEY DID BATHE. -- A popular prejudice credits the Middle Ages with a hatred of water, cold or warm. "Mille ans sans un bain," cries Michelet. Few accusations are more unfounded. The Registers of the Chatelet furnish constant allusions to the public baths of Paris; there was at least one establishment in every quarter of the city, and "warm baths" were cried daily through the streets of Paris by the water carriers.

The London Daily Telegraph has taken advantage of the Parliamentary recess to open its columns to a general discussion upon intemperance. For weeks it has devoted three or four columns daily to printing in fine type letters from the public upon this subject. These letters contain personal confessions, from drunkards or the experiences of persons suffering from the intemperance of friends and relations or suggestions as to a cure.

A New-York woman, who came to town from her suburban boarding place one day last week to look for an apartment, had an experience whose recital may be a caution to other flat hunters. On her rounds she found herself at the entrance of a five-story double apartment house, and her ring brought, after some delay, the janitor's wife.

It was 3 o'clock yesterday morning before the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union came to a close, after a continuous session of seven hours. There was a wild scramble for office on the part of the athletes, and at times the scene looked much like a down-town primary. Button-holing, wire-pulling, and trading votes were all indulged in by these athletic legislators.

The Gould-Morgan plan of paying a floating debt is gaining in popularity. The Richmond Terminal people are apparently disposed to adopt it. The floating debt of the Richmond Terminal Company amounts to about $9,000,000, and well-authenticated report has it that the management of that company is formulating a plan similar to the one adopted by the Union Pacific creditors and Directors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Senator Faulkner of West Virginia, Gen. John C. Black, President of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, Representative McAdoo, Mr. James M. Beck of Philadelphia, and Mr. Lawrence Gardner of Washington, Secretary of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, will leave Washington to-morrow on a trip that may be of great importance to the Democratic Party in the West.

The persons who have believed that politics has nothing to do with morals are rudely taught now and again that morals will have much to do with politics. The patience of the average American community with rascality in the management of public affairs is a quantity that is not easily calculated.

The breeding of horses or dogs or any domestic animal to secure speed or stature or any desired quality is an art based upon principles beyond any dispute, however uncertain and disappointing the results may be. And no one doubts that the same principles obtain in regard to the human race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- After the adjournment of the meeting, in July, of the Republican National Executive Committee, Mr. Andrew Gleason, a contractor of Washington, approached Gen. James S. Clarkson and, giving him a one-hundred-dollar bill, asked him to make that the first contribution to the Blaine campaign fund of 1892.

Your interesting articles on the New-York Life have caused great consternation among its European policy holders and annuitants, all of whom are now aware of the imprudence that led them to place their confidence in a man devoid of integrity.

We notice an interesting change in the attitude of some of our high-tariff contemporaries toward the domestic tin mines. A few weeks ago they were publishing stories about the productiveness of these properties, and were asserting in their editorial columns that here was fresh proof of the beneficial effect of the McKinley tariff.

The Society of the Army of the Cumberland holds its twenty-second annual reunion at Columbus, Ohio, during the present week. When Gen. SHERMAN in 1864 began his Atlanta campaign against JOHNSTON, the Army of the Cumberland was not only larger than the Army of the Tennessee and the Army of the Ohio combined, but constituted three-fifths of his entire force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A remarkably-close and interesting game was played here yesterday afternoon between the nines of the New-Jersey and the Columbia Athletic Club. The New-Jersey boys scored all their runs in the opening inning. The local players appeared to be nervous, and before they recovered their composure the visitors had scored a lead that the Columbias failed to overcome.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Edmund Burke confessed a century ago that he did not know how to draw the indictment of a nation. A hundred years of labor-saving science and ingenuity have not operated to lighten the task. Moreover, the world's jury, grown callous to sensation and wearied with the ever-multiplying claims upon its sympathies, takes now a deal of moving.

It has been intimated that the present intention of the Navy Department is to confine its demands for new vessels during the coming session of Congress to torpedo gunboats, torpedo-boat catchers and small gun vessels. The Treasury Department also, as has recently been stated in these columns, will ask for five new revenue cutters.
QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 13. -- The Guion Line steamer Arizona, Capt. Brooks, from New-York Sept. 5 for Liverpool, arrived here to-day in a battered condition.

DENVER, Sept. 13. -- A passenger train bound toward Denver, on the Graymont division of the Union Pacific Railway, was wrecked this morning about 11 o'clock, near Bear Brook station, and twenty-three passengers were injured, five of whom will probably die.

Prof. Graham's volume, with the above title, differs from his former work, "The Social Problem," inasmuch as he considers new Socialism especially from the historical and economic side. It is in regard to contemporary Socialism, as represented by Marx and Lasalle, that Prof. Graham's contribution is useful.

TRENTON, Sept. 13. -- Gov. Abbett should lose no time in looking after his fences in Warren County. They were never in so shaky a condition. They are not quite down, but it would not require a hurricane to level them. They are only propped up with toothpicks, for his deception. While he is about it, it might not be inadvisable for him to inspect his fences in other counties of the State.

QUEBEC, Sept. 13. -- Cap Blanc, a French Canadian village lying between the St. Lawrence River and the cliffs, was to-day nearly destroyed by fire, and seventy-five families were left homeless. Several fire companies went to the scene from this city, but were able to do little on account of lack of water. The sacristy of Notre Dame Church was burned, and the flames reached the church chancel and did much damage there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Really, some kind friend ought to subscribe for a daily newspaper and have it sent to Senator Hiscock, and perhaps send along a capable reader who will save him from the fatiguing exercise of doing the reading.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13. -- The convicts in the jute mill at San Quentin struck yesterday. Nearly two hundred prisoners threw down their tools and defied the officers to make them work. The convicts demanded more and better food, more tobacco, and they wanted less favoritism shown. They also demanded to be taken before the Board of Prison Directors, where they might state their case.

A man who is spoken of as "ex-Railroad Commissioner Bartlett of North Dakota," has seen Blaine and describes the meeting in an interview with a St. Paul Pioneer Press reporter. He says: "On meeting with him I told him that I had called to shake hands with the next President of this country, but the Secretary only smiled.

We publish this morning the first of a series of letters on the Jews and Russia by our London correspondent. Early in July our correspondent entered Russia with instructions to make as careful and thorough inquiry as he could as to the condition and treatment of the Jews, the extent of the persecution which had been going on for some four months, its nature, and the motives and occasion for it.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- The points of interest here to-day were the Kenmore Hotel and the Executive Mansion. Arriving delegates made the hotel their headquarters, and then proceeded to the Executive Mansion to consult with David B. Hill.

The soil of Prospect Park is not favorable to the formation of good bridle roads through the unaided and unchecked operations of nature. This fact does not seem to be fully understood by the present managers of that park. They have left nearly half and much the most beautiful part of the bridle paths there, especially that part traversing the lovely ravine and woods below the farmhouse, for weeks without care.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- There is war between the Rev. Father Leonard, the pastor of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, and the Rev. Father McManus, pastor of the new Church of the Sacred Heart. Father McManus was sent here nine months ago by the Bishop to organize a new parish in part of the territory covered by St. Michael's parish.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13. -- Vera Ava still remains either the heroine of a romantic episode or the victim of a cruel outrage. There is a strong disposition here to regard her as Miss Dis Debar, sailing under another name. Dr. Bonnell of New-York, who knows Dis Debar, saw Miss Vera Ava, called on her last evening, and said: "This is not Dis Debar."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13. -- The British steamer China arrived early this morning from Hongkong. Yokohama, 12 days 11 hours and 55 minutes from the latter port. It was thought she would attempt to break the record made by the Vancouver Line of steamships, but she did not do so. She brings advices from China to Aug. 30.

SARATOGA, Sept. 13. -- In spite of the dissensions throughout the State, but few changes will be made in the State Committee. The organization of the party hereafter will be vested in the hands of Edward Murphy, Jr., by virtue of his control of State patronage along the canals and several influential departments, united with the support he will receive from Tammany Hall.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 13. -- It is altogether probable that the inside workings of the St. Louis School Board will be laid bare to the public, and ninety-nine people in a hundred are looking for revelations of ring rule and corruption of a sensational character. The board recently resolved to complete a new high school building, begun many years ago, provided the work could be done for $200,000.

The pilot boat Washington, minus masts and sails, reached port yesterday in tow of the E.F. Williams. The Washington, whose number is 22, was dismasted in a cyclone encountered a week ago, when she was about three hundred and fifty miles to the eastward of Sandy Hook. Only the crew of the vessel was on board at the time, the pilots having been placed on incoming steamships.
We take the following paragraphs from the news columns of the Boston Commercial Bulletin of last Saturday:

The issue of silver free coinage has visibly lost vitality and prominence during the months that have elapsed since the adjournment of Congress, but it is still sufficiently alive and troublesome to plague politicians and parties that have not the courage or the intelligence to treat it wisely.

Among the prisoners arraigned at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday was one David Lawson, charged with obtaining money under false pretenses. It seems that last Spring the officers of the German-American Insurance Company were annoyed by frequent demands for policies by people of the poorer class, whose property investigation showed had not been insured by the company.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13. -- There is unusual interest in the meeting of the Board of Directors of the Maryland Institute of Art and Design, which is to be held to-morrow evening. At the last election a colored City Councilman was elected in the Eleventh Ward, a young lawyer named Harry S. Cummings. The election was a surprise and a sensation.

There was music in the air at Ridgewood Park, Long Island, yesterday. It was the opening day of the fifteenth annual festival and agricultural and horticultural exhibition of the Schaebischer Saengerbund of Brooklyn. It is estimated that 12,000 people passed through the gates. The pavilions and tents were gay with bunting and flaunted the flags of every nation.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13. -- John H.B. Latrobe will be buried to-morrow from Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Eccleston officiating, and the funeral will be one of the largest ever seen in Baltimore. The pall bearers will be the leading men of the city, among them John K. Cowen, the chief counsel of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; President D.C. Gilman of the Johns Hopkins University.

PERRY, Iowa, Sept. 13. -- Three thousand people, a large proportion of them farmers from Dallas, Greene, and Storry Counties, heard Gov. Boies speak on the political issues of the day this afternoon. Chairman Fuller and Edward H. Hunter of the Democratic State Committee and a number of other Democratic leaders accompanied the Governor from Des Moines.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13. -- The recent upheaval in the Republican Committee was at first thought to have no special purpose beyond the removal of Chairman Bain and the restoration to authority of Filley's lieutenant, but the full significance is gradually developing. It is simply that Chauncey I. Filley proposes to control the selection of all the delegates Missouri will send to the next National Republican Convention.

The British cruiser Vulcan, a new vessel designed for a speed of 20 knots an hour, was unable on her recent trial to do more than 18 knots. In commenting on this fact yesterday Mr. Horace See expressed the opinion that the Vulcan's failure was due to the small proportion of length to beam.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Another railroad is to be opened between Omaha and Chicago, to be operated by the Santa Fe. Part of the new line is to be built, but work is now advancing.

The cornerstone of the new church of St. Joachim and St. Anne, which is being erected at the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, Mount Loretto, Staten Island, was laid yesterday afternoon by Archbishop Corrigan of this city in the presence of nearly 10,000 spectators.

Peter Brady died at his residence, 509 Grove Street, Jersey City, Saturday afternoon, having passed man's usual allotment of threescore and ten by more than thirty years. He was born in Parish Tydavnet, County Monahan, Ireland, May 15, 1790, and consequently was over 101 years old. Death was due to old age, the breaking up of the old man's mental and physical faculties having set in about two months ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Theresa Fair, the wife of ex-Senator James G. Fair, the California millionaire, died this evening at her residence on Pine Street from a complication of diseases. Her death was not unexpected.

As much of American Germany as could get into Sulzer's Harlem River Park, at One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Second Avenue, was there yesterday afternoon and evening celebrating the opening day of the Connstatter Volksfest. The festival is to remain in full swing for three days longer.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The Hon. C.A. Burr, Deputy Collector of the Port of New-York came to Syracuse Saturday and had a long interview with Senator Francis Hendricks. Mr. Burr is a close personal friend of Collector Fassert, and his visit to Syracuse at this juncture is supposed to have a political significance. Mr. Burr, on being interviewed to-night, however, said that his visit to Senator Hendricks merely of a social character.

Georgette Elodia Broadhead, who was about thirty years old, poisoned herself with carbolic acid in a hall bedroom at 459 Ninth Avenue some time Saturday night, and died early yesterday morning, just after her condition had been discovered. Although she had been in the house nearly a year, the woman from whom she hired the room knew little of her history, except that she had been a maid at the Park Avenue Hotel.
BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- The Crapo men met to-day and sent out the following address to the delegates to the State Convention, signed by John D. Long, Chairman of the meeting:

To-morrow the Republicans of Massachusetts are to hold their State Convention, and ex-Congressman CRAPO has just retrained from a sojourn in foreign parts to find the canvass for his nomination for Governor in a rather precarious condition. Mr. CRAPO aspired to the candidacy several years ago and failed to get it, and the result of the campaign which followed was the election of the Democratic candidate, Gen. BUTLER.

A very curious spectacle was presented by the races at Gravesend yesterday. The racing men appeared as the champions of law and order, bent upon preventing the violation of the statute which forbids public betting upon horse races at any other places than the race tracks themselves. They pursued this purpose, at much trouble and inconvenience and with a large measure of success.

Two more triumphs for our Naval Ordnace Bureau are simultaneously reported. One is the great success achieved by its new six-inch breech-loading rifle, having a length of 40 calibres, which has achieved an initial velocity of 2,180 feet per second without exceeding the prescribed limit of safe pressure in the chamber.

In the last few months the number of passengers killed by the collision of railroad trains moving in the same direction has been exceptionally large both in this country and in Europe. The most recent collisions of this kind in the United States were those at Ravenna, on the Erie Road, and at Montezuma, on the West Shore.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 14. -- To-day the first statement from the assignee of the Masonic Savings Bank, which went to the wall July 8, is made public, and with the statement the personal assignment of Jacob Krieger, Sr., President, and J.H. Egelhoff, cashier, is announced. The statement of the condition of the bank is not encouraging to depositors or stockholders.

The Democratic Party has always claimed, and with much justice, to be the people's party. From JEFFERSON to TILDEN, who in many regards was the descendant and heir of JEFFERSON, its leaders have professed a zealous respect for those rights that are common to all and an aggressive hostility to any class that sought more than its fair share of advantage under the Government.

" Any party which presumes to go before the country now, even indirectly, in favor of free silver coinage will invite defeat. If the Democratic Party of this State is misled into such conduct it will be a calamity. Business men won't have it. More than this, business men want outspoken opposition to such dishonesty."

President John H. Inman and several of the Directors of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Company were in earnest conference in this city yesterday over the financial needs of the various railroad companies which the Richmond Terminal corporation controls. Mr. Inman explained that the floating debts of the Richmond and Danville, the Georgia Central, and the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Roads would aggregate something less than $9,000,000.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The early report of the asserted occupation of Mitylene caused much excitement here, which was redoubled when, late this evening, another and still more startling dispatch came from Athens. It was that the Greek Consuls at Mitylene and at Smyrna have wired the Greek Government that thirteen British men-of-war landed troops and guns at Sigri on Friday, and that they have already strongly fortified that place.

SARATOGA, Sept. 14. -- Tammany's scheme to oust the County Democracy from representation in State affairs worked perfectly at the meeting of the State Committee held to-night, when it was decided by a vote of 22 to 10 to put only the names of the seventy-two Tammany delegates on the preliminary list on which the State Convention will effect temporary organization to-morrow. Last year the two New-York factions hed each 36 votes.

SARATOGA, Sept. 14. -- This Democratic Convention is confronted with a considerable number of contests. Seventeen Assembly districts, comprising twelve counties, have sent contesting delegations. These contests represent the antagonism to Hill and Hillism that has been growing rapidly throughout the State.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- The Republicans of Massachusetts will meet, by delegates, in convention next Wednesday, Sept. 16, to nominate candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Treasurer and Receiver General, Attorney General, Secretary of State, and Auditor. Incidentally they may be invited to join in a first-class "shindy." Indeed, the preparations for an entertainment of this sort have been made upon an extensive and elaborate scale.

ST. PAUL, Sept 14. -- There has been talk in general business and grain circles all the afternoon to the effect that the last million copies of the "Hold Your Wheat" circular are being circulated at the expense of the Minneapolis mills.

It may be predicted that Mr. HARRISON will soon begin to show some interest in the career and ambition of CHAUNCEY I. FILLEY of Missouri. Mr. FILLEY, who represents in the State that portion of the party which is opposed to what are called the "silk stockings," regards himself as an energetic and useful politician whose body has been permitted to lie outside the breastworks.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 14. -- The case of R.B. Albertson, the Seattle attorney, accused of concealing stolen property in connection with the Fidelity Bank robbery, was called in court this afternoon. He is a cousin of Edward Albertson, the defaulter, who has not yet been caught. Before the hearing commenced the original complaint against R.B. Albertson was dismissed and one of grand larceny substituted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The record in the court-martial case of Passed Assistant Engineer Galt of the navy, tried at the Norfolk Yard on charges of culpable negligence of duty, has reached the Navy Department. The charge against Galt was that through negligence on his part Pay Clerk Van Vracken was able to steal engineers' supplies and sell them for his own profit. Van Vracken has already been found guilty of the theft.

Stock of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company, otherwise the Whisky Trust, got a great deal of attention in Wall Street yesterday, and there was a sharp rise in the quotations for it in the Stock Exchange. In three-quarters of an hour the trading in it ran up to 10,000 shares. There was an advance at the same time of a couple of points.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 14. -- The San Francisco schooner City of San Diego reached here with 600 sealskins Saturday night from Copper Island, on the Russian side of Bering Sea. Its commander reports an eventful trip. It was warned off St. Paul Island the end of June and it made for Copper Island. There it fell in with eight other schooners, and all of them together raided the island, catching and skinning seals.

Major Livingston Mims. manager of the Southern department of the New-York Life Insurance Company, whose headquarters are in Atlanta, Ga., has just published in the Southern press the semi-annual statement for the six months ending June 30, 1891, of the company's business. The laws of the State of Georgia exact a semi-annual statement from all life companies doing business in that State.

SARATOGA, Sept. 14. -- The ticket which will be nominated at Saratoga Tuesday or Wednesday will be the ticket published exclusively in Sunday's TIMES, with the exception of the State Surveyor, which will be decided to-morrow. All through the day the wildest stories were rife that the slate was to be broken. The moment each successive arriving delegation reached here, the rumor was spread with intensifying force.

The rumor that a body of British troops had landed and taken possession of a harbor in the Island of Mytilene is probably a stock-jobbing story, suggested by the rather artificial excitement over the question of the Dardanelles. Mytilene is a fairly fertile island, with excellent ports, easily fortified and in the hands of England would form a perfect defense against any Russian attempt upon the Suez Canal, or even upon Constantinople.

By a single run the New-Yorks lost again to the Pittsburgs on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants led in the batting, but they sacrificed their chances of winning by making costly errors in the field. In this respect the Pittsburgs played a remarkably fine game.

SARATOGA, Sept. 14. -- A brigade of seven special trains, divided up into regiments of many cars each, swept up the State from New-York City and deposited thousands of Democratic politicians in this village to-day. The big procession formed in the Grand Central Station during the morning, and specials were sent chasing each other over the Central tracks at a rapid rate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- The character of the evidence for both prosecution and defense in the case of the five accused Mercantile Appraisers was pretty well outlined at to-day's hearing before Magistrate Pole, at the City Hall. The Appraisers are charged with conspiring to cheat and defraud the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and with making false and fraudulent returns.

Secretary of the Treasury Foster came to town yesterday on his way back to Washington after his fishing trip up the New-England coast and devoted himself to getting light about the Collectorship and other matters political and financial. Before the day was over it was practically settled who was to succeed Mr. Fassett at the Custom House.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 14. -- The Pester Lloyd, doubtless inspired through its editor, Max Falke, reporter of the Foreign Committee of the Hungarian delegation, to-day says that Austria-Hungary's interest in the Dardanelles question is greater than Great Britain's, adding: "Can Austria look on with complacency while Russia, finding herself barred from expanding through Bulgaria, advances by a shorter route to the goal she has in view -- the seizure of Constantinople.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Naval Constructor Hichborn and Chief Engineer Towne have returned from Dubuque, Iowa, where they went to inspect the Iowa Iron Works and to make report as to the ability of that establishment to undertake the building of Torpedo Boat No. 2, for which they were the lowest bidders.

If the Democratic leaders wish an instructive object lesson in the folly of coqueting with the silver men, the can find it in Ohio. The free-coinage resolution in the Democratic platform in that State was a weak and silly bid for the votes of the Farmers' Alliance. It was so far from expressing the views of the party that nearly half the convention voted against it and refused to make its adoption unanimous.

A summary of important changes in the Mexican tariff has been received by the Seeger Guernsey Company of 7 Bowling Green. Its interest to those engaged in Mexican trade will be apparent from the following:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14. -- The following summary official action of the Board of Directors of the Latonia Jockey Club was promulgated to-day. It has reference to the case of the spurious horse entered as Polk Badget on Sept. 7, on which occasion this horse won a race, to the dismay of bookmakers and racegoers. The following is the text of the official document, which speaks for itself:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- As the result of the publication of a letter from the Pensacola, in which that vessel was declared to be unseaworthy, the families of officers and others on board her have felt much uneasiness since she sailed from San Francisco for Honolulu last week, and a number of inquiries as to her condition have been made at the department.

The practical outcome of the remarkable run made by Vice President Webb's experimental train over the New-York Central Railroad from this city to Buffalo on Monday will be the establishment, about Oct. 1, of a fast passenger train to run westward daily between the points named.

SARATOGA, Sept. 15. -- All the big men from the metropolitan end of the State were in the frontispiece of the picture seen from the platform. By a curious dispensation of Providence, John Scannell and Edward Kearney, the Tammany delegates, were given the front seats on the left of the Chair, and Kings County had the front seats on the right.

The claim of the County Democrats for one-half the representation of this city in the convention at Saratoga may be excessive, considering the vote which the organization has been able to poll in the last year or two, but it will hardly be good politics for the convention to rule them out altogether.

It is only within recent years that a speed has been attained upon the railroads of this country that was to be compared with that reached in England, and on no line has there been a rival for the train known as "The Flying Scotchman," that runs from London to Edinburgh at the rate of about fifty-five miles an hour.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- The struggle between the Allen and Crapo forces reached the stage of bitterest intensity to-night. Every effort to effect a compromise or agreement failed. Both armies retired to rest, after a prolonged engagement, without decisive results.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A dispatch from San Francisco says: "By the last mail from Chile news was received of an attempt of John Dow, a Pennsylvanian, and Henry Merriam, an English adventurer, to seize $800,000 in bullion which was secreted in the suburbs of Santiago by Balmaceda preparatory to shipping it to Europe.

The report of Dr. Moreau Morris, the Sanitary Inspector in charge of the Summer Corps of Physicians, whose two months of service ended on the 5th inst., was received at the meeting of the Board of Health yesterday. Dr. Morris had forty-six inspectors in the corps. They paid 39,164 visits to houses in which were 335,293 families, treated 19,777 sick persons in 3,553 visits, abated 5,340 nuisances, and made 360 complaints of nuisances.

Racing at the Brooklyn track was conducted under rather depressing circumstances yesterday because of the novel conditions which existed, and to which the crowd had not been accustomed. It was entirely strange to go to a track without the faintest idea as to what kind of sport there was to be, and with no notion as to whether there were to be two starters or two dozen in a race.

Almost for the first time in the history of racing in this neighborhood, there was yesterday run a series of races within a few miles of New-York upon which no pools were sold in the city itself. What the law and the police, under the direction of Tammany Hall, have found it impracticable to do has been perfectly accomplished by the owners of a single racing association enforcing their unquestionable legal rights of property.
" Yes" said an eminent physician recently, "I do not think I exaggerate when I say that one-half of the suffering and sickness which exists among women might and should be avoided.

A representative of the Jewish Messenger has had a talk with the members of the Board of Health about what is to be done with the Russian Jews who are flocking to this city by thousands, and the views expressed by the board are given in the current issue of his paper.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- Judges Fell and Gordon, sitting as committing magistrates in the criminal court, to-day heard the evidence in the possession of District Attorney Graham against the banking and brokerage firm of Robert Glendenning Co. on the question of their criminal liability with ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley in the unlawful conversion of the public money.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Secretary Tracy to-day made the following statement regarding the policy of the Navy Department in strengthening the United States naval force in Chinese waters:

CLEVELAND, Ohio. Sept. 15. -- Two interesting Republican Senatorial Conventions were held in Ohio to-day. The one at Washington Court House, in the Fifth and Sixth Joint District, was in Foraker's end of the State, and the issu was distinctly made between the two candidates. The district is composed of the five counties of Clinton, Fayette, Green, Highland, and Ross, and is over 4,000 Republican.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15. -- The row among the Republicans of St. Louis is a pretty fight as it stands. There are two city committees, both claiming the right to run the party machinery. One of these is the "Silks," with George Bain as Chairman, backed by the Federal office holders here. The other is the "Hoodlum" Committee, with John McFall as Chairman, and Chauncey I. Filley the power behind the throne.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The hop harvest of Central New York, especially in the fruitful counties of Otsego, Chenango, Oneida, and Madison, is practically ended, and the 7,000 pickers who flocked in from outside districts to get a month's work have returned to their homes.

MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., Sept. 15. -- The reunion of Gen. Morgan's command, the Seventh Ohio Division, the first of the kind to be held at Cumberland Gap since the war of the rebellion, is now being held in this city. Though a veteran reunion of ex-Federal soldiers all ex-Confederates have been invited, and the result will be the bringing together at this point of over twelve thousand of the heroes of the late civil war.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 15. -- Gov. Emillio Rabasa, one of the most distinguished political leaders in Mexico, passed through the city to-day on his way to New-York, where he will spend about ten days. Mr. Rabasa was recently elected Governor of the State of Chiapas, which country has been the scene of more incipient revolutions and political turmoils than any other part of Mexico.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 15. -- President Diaz opened Congress this evening. In his speech he said:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15. -- The anti-third party and anti-Sub-Treasury wing of the National Farmers' Alliance met at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Not more than half of the number of delegates expected made their appearance. The convention was called to order by U.S. Hall, ex-President of the Missouri Alliance, and a temporary organization was effected by the election of U.S. Hall as Temporary Chairman and William H. Murray of Corsicana, Texas, Temporary Secretary.

SARATOGA, Sept. 15. -- When Gov. Hill reads the platform to be adopted by the Democratic State Convention he will realize more keenly than ever that his days as a political power in this State are gone. The platform will declare fairly, squarely, and unequivocally for hard money, in spite of the strenuous and persistent efforts of the Governor to tamper with it for his own benefit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Treasury Department has issued to customs officers a circular in regard to the free entry of personal and household effects under the act of Oct. 1 last.

It cannot be said that the excitement that prevails in Paris with reference to the forthcoming production of "Lohengrin" is entirely without precedent. The same excitable city furnished a partial precedent for it in the mobbing of the same composer's "Tannhauser" in 1861. But that riot, though undoubtedly an anti-Wagner demonstration, was not an anti-German demonstration.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 15. -- The Senate and House to-day transacted important business, the former passing the bill providing for the erection of a penitentiary at a cost of $320,000, and the latter tabling the bill introduced by Mr. Davis providing for the repeal of the law leasing the convicts.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Henry T. Edson, a son of Franklin Edson, ex-Mayor of New-York City, was arrested to-day on a warrant sworn out by Frederic P. Allen, cashier of the German-American Bank, charging him with grand larceny in defrauding the bank out of $5,000.

HARTFORD, Sept. 15. -- The Rev. Dr. C.D. Hartranft, President of the Hartford Theological Seminary, will resume the administration at the opening of the new year on Thursday of this week, relieving the Rev. Dr. Graham Taylor, who has been at the head of the institution during the protracted ill health of Dr. Hartranft.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 15. -- There is an interesting clash between the Judicial and Police Departments, which is likely to lead to serious consequences. Under the law creating the Police Board, the entire police force was placed under its order. The law creating the Recorder's Court provided for court officers detailed from the police force.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The Rensselaer County Soldiers and Sailors' Monument on Washington Square, Troy, was dedicated to-day. The cornerstone of the monument was laid May 30, 1890.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 15. -- Interest increases in the Iowa campaign with each passing day. The best speaking talent of both parties is now pretty well engaged and the meetings are generally well attended, but in point of attendance and interest, as well as in confidence and enthusiasm, the advantage is largely with the Democrats.

Since the Collector of Customs at the little town of Nogales, in Arizona, was so sharply rebuked by the Treasury Department he has humbly sought the advice of Assistant Secretary SPAULDING whenever new questions have arisen at his port of entry concerning the enforcement of the McKinley tariff with respect to stray cows and expatriated calves.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- At noon to-day, at All Saint's Chapel, Miss Sallie Hargous of New-York, who has been the belle of several seasons here, was married to Mr. Duncan Elliot. The event has long been anticipated with interest in society circles, as the young people are among the most popular of the Summer visitors.
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Sept. 15. -- The jury in the case of Thornton Hains, accused of murder, has returned a verdict of not guilty.
