SARATOGA, Sept. 15. -- One striking feature of the convention was the protest made by the County Democracy against the treatment it received at the hands of the State Committee, which refused to recognize it in making up the preliminary roll Monday night. Before the convention, the Counties met in caucus in the stock room of the United States Hotel and decided to "stand firm."

The old Commercial Advertiser Building, a ramshackle structure which has stood at Fulton and Nassau Streets for over half a century, was totally destroyed by fire yesterday morning. In its destruction was involved a loss of property that will aggregate a round quarter or a million dollars. The fire was caused by an explosion of benzine vapor in the shop of a tailor.

Shoald the proposed demonstration of foreign fleets against China be carried into effect, our country might contribute toward it the wooden craft Alliance, 1,375 tons, armed mostly with a few old smoothbores, and the Palos, 420 tons, carrying howitzers only. We have in Japanese waters also the venerable Monocacy, a paddlewheel craft -- but she is said to be worn out.
SOMERSET, Ky., Sept. 15. -- Harvey and Joe Gilland, the assassins of Sheriff McGargue, were taken from jail here early this morning by a mob and hanged.

The Propogateur of Saint-Pierre of Aug. 22, which has arrived here by mail, gives a harrowing account of the terrific cyclone that swept over the Island of Martinique four days before. On that terrible day there was a stiff breeze blowing from the north-northeast. In the afternoon the barometer fell rapidly, the sky darkened, and the wind rapidly increased in violence.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 15. -- At to-day's meeting of the Privileges and Elections Committee, George Cox, President of the Ottawa Conservative Association, testified that about a year ago he heard of the "crooked work" of Senecal, Superintendent of the Printing Bureau, and informed Sir John Macdonald of what he had heard.

SARATOGA, Sept. 15. -- In the upper room of the Grand Union Club house the Committee on Credentials began, at 4 o'clock this afternoon, the hearing of the many cases of contested seats. This committee was composed of thirty-four members -- one from each Congressional district in the State. This is the list:

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- While it is now admitted that a British force has not seized the Island of Mitylene, news to the effect that the island had been occupied was received from Mitylene and elsewhere by the various embassies at Constantinople and in this and other capitals. The French, Russian, Italian, and Turkish Governments and the Sultan personally received information of the alleged landing of a British force.

RIGOLET, Labrador, Sept. 1. -- Hamilton Inlet, or lonektoke, as the Esquimaus call it, is the outlet to the largest river on the Labrador Peninsula, and of great importance to commerce, Rigolet, the headquarters of the Hudson Bay Company in this region, being situated on its shores. This inlet is the great waterway to Central Labrador, extending into the interior for nearly 200 miles.

It must already be pretty plain to the Democratic leaders at Saratoga that the Democratic and independent business men of the State not only will not tolerate any declaration in favor of free coinage, but will be restive to the point of hostility under any equivocal, cowardly, or "straddling" utterance on that point.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- The Republicans of Massachusetts wanted to nominate William W. Crapo of New-Bedford for Governor to-day. Their delegates nominated somebody else. Briefly told, that is the story of the convention.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 16. -- The annual meeting of the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad Company was held this morning. The annual report of the Directors to the stockholders was presented. The total receipts were $3,091,321.83; operating expenses, $1,977,932.79; total expenses, $2,585,584.99; net earnings, $505,806.84. President Babcock made his annual report, referring to the advance stops made during the year and of further improvements contemplated.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- Several members of the Second Nationalists' Club, with a few other gentlemen interested, are on a two days' excursion to Provincetown to urge upon the occupants of Government land in that vicinity the plan of creating an immense ocean park.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16. -- Advices from Yokohama state that much activity exists in the Army and Navy Departments of the empire. Extensive increases are being made in the navy, a large number of new cruisers being built.

PIPESTONE, Minn., Sept. 16. -- A feud of long standing has existed between two highly-respected families in this county, of which William Allerton and Arthur Arrowsmith are the respective heads. Both are farmers, and each owns several thousand acres of valuable farming property in the county.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- According to to-day's reports, the President will soon turn his mind to the task of finding another Indianian or two to occupy Federal offices that are to be made vacant, or to occupy new offices that have been created by the Congress.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 16. -- "I have found the party. We are coming as fast as steam will carry us."

The trouble in the Long Island City schools is increasing. One of them has been closed, and endeavors have been made to close another. In consequence of this about a thousand children, who ought now to be pursuing their studies, are running at large in the streets, while a Principal, Peter E. Tarpy, and fourteen teachers are drawing salaries for work not performed.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- Passed Assistant Surgeon James F. Keeney, United States Navy, and Miss Mary Howes, daughter of Commander Charles H. Rockwell, United States Navy, now commanding United States steamship Yantic, were married in Chatham at noon today. The event took place in Commander Rockwell's Summer residence on Main Street, the Rev. Mr. Elmer of the Methodist Episcopal Church officiating.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 16. -- The appointment of ex-Congressman R.H.M. Davidson of the First Florida District to succeed Senator Call in the alleged vacancy in the United States Senate is the result of long deliberation and a long internal fight in the ranks of the anti-Call Democrats.

In your issue of 10th inst., under the heading of "This Commission Is a Luxury," a paragraph appeared relative to the Washington Bridge and the Harlem River Bridge Commission. Statements of similar tenor have appeared in other papers, and during the last few months numerous articles of like character reflecting upon the Bridge Commission have been given to the public.

J. Float Fassett stood up before several thousands of wildly enthusiastic Brooklyn Republicans last night and struck the keynote of his campaign. It was simply "Down with Tammany!" The Republican candidate for Governor boldly declared that for all evils in State and municipal government in New-York Tammany was to blame.

The first through train from Boston over the new route, via Wilson's Point and Oyster Bay arrived at Long Island City at 7:18 o'clock last evening. The train consisted of all vestibule cars and was made up of one combined car, two sleepers, a dining car, an ordinary coach, and one freight car. The train left Boston at 10 o'clock yesterday morning and arrived at Wilson's Point at 3:38 P.M.

The efforts made by Russia to break loose from the treaty restrictions concerning the Black Sea can be better appreciated on observing the magnitude of the fleet she is accumulating there. She has, to begin with, three 10,000-ton battle ships, the Tchesme, the Sinope, and the Catherine II., which cost her over $13,000,000.

Two political conventions, one Republican and one Democratic, met yesterday in two States -- the former in Massachusetts, the latter in New-York -- and made a formal declaration of the principles of their respective parties in regard to the currency. It is profoundly significant that these two declarations were, in almost identical language, in favor of honest money and against very form of depreciation.

Chauncey M. Depew has once more returned from a tour through "the effete monarchies" of Europe, glowing with good health and spirits and fairly bubbling over with opinions and stories regarding what he has seen and heard. He says he is glad to be home once more, and hundreds of his friends answered that they were glad to see him here again.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16. -- Tommy Nolan, proprietor of a lodging house at Fresno, is a full brother of Timothy Hopkins, who has become famous as the principal contestant for the millions of Mrs. Hopkins Searles. Nolan was very much interested to-day in recent telegrams from New-York relative to the legality of Timothy Hopkins's adoption.

There is on exhibition at Tiffany Co.'s, Union Square, the medal voted by the Prussian Parliament to Alexander von Humboldt in recognition of his services to the cause of science. The medal bears on its face the words "Alexander von Humboldt." The face is profile, and the date MDCCCXXXXVII, (1847.) On the reverse side the signs of the zodiac surrounding a wreath, within which is a group with the word "Kozmoz" above their heads.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Has Mr. "Jay Slate" Fassett's successor in the New-York Custom House been selected, and was he not already chosen by Platt before Fassett had gone through with the pleasing formality of taking possession of an office that he was not intended to hold, except for a sufficient time to enable a few ambitious Republicans to have themselves talked about as candidates for Governor.

There is a tolerably obvious moral for us in the tragic story of the floods in Spain. It seems that the first accounts were understatements rather than exaggerations, and it is now estimated that three thousand persons have lost their lives, while one town has been almost destroyed and one commune is submerged.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16. -- The Farmers and Laborers' Convention reassembled this morning at 10 o'clock. The first order of business was the question on the resolutions which were up yesterday, and they were carried by a good majority. An effort to make the vote unanimous revealed two negative voters who did not relish the resolution censuring machine.

President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company has just made his appearance in a new role, and now it will be possible for the public to judge what sort of a witness he would make if he ever gets into the witness chair in court. Since Monday Mr. Beers has been giving his deposition on behalf of his company in a suit for $100,000 for services rendered brought against by Capt. A.P.T.

The Democrats at Saratoga have done a quite inestimable service to the State in annihilating the political power of DAVID B. HILL, and another scarcely less valuable to the country by taking the most advanced and uncompromising position against silver free coinage that has ever been taken by any assembly of either party.

The Republican Convention of Massachusetts yesterday nominated CHARLES H. ALLEN of Lowell for Governor. He received the votes of 713 delegates, while 514 were given to WILLIAM W. CRAPO of New-Bedford. This is regarded in Boston as a triumph for machine methods and as ominous of party defeat this Fall.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- The ticket which THE TIMES published exclusively on Sunday was adopted at the Democratic State Convention to-day, with the exception of the unimportant office of State Engineer and Surveyor.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 16. -- Carlos J. Garcia is notorious upon both sides of the Rio Grande River. He has money, education, daring, and a violent disposition. He has been a leader of the turbulent class of Mexicans, and has a special hatred for President Diaz. In fifty undersized revolutions, municipal riots, and clerical fights, he has been the central figure upon the Mexican list of fugitives from justice.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Six thousand Knights of Pythias from all over the State gathered in Plainfield to-day and held their annual field-day celebration. People flocked to town from miles around, all business was suspended, and everybody united in making the event a great holiday. The parade of the Pythians, all in handsome uniforms, was a magnificent sight.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16. -- Ten o'clock was the hour scheduled for calling the convention to order, but there was a trifling delay that gave the delegates an opportunity to do some cheering as the big men took their seats. The rink was so crowded that the journey from the entrance to the platform was a trip of trials for those who had to make it after 10 o'clock.

MADRID, Sept. 16. -- Further distressing particulars in regard to the flooded provinces continue to be received at long intervals, each additional report showing that the extent of the disaster has in no way been exaggerated.

As we have said before, the apathy with which the Czar's bullying of the Sultan has been received in Europe is an evidence of the sincerity of Germany's desire to keep the peace. The opening of the Dardanelles to Russian vessels carrying military supplies is not a matter that directly concerns Germany, nor, indeed, any party to the Dreibund.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- There will be a big time here at the Cramps' in the course of a month or six weeks, when the New-York leaves the ways and is launched into the Delaware. Preparations are already being rapidly made for this event, and the launching cradle, so narrow and slight to the unprofessional eye, even now lies under the huge hull.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The conference between the World's Fair Foreign Commissioners and the principal officers of the Treasury Department respecting the modification of certain features of the customs regulations so as to facilitate the free entry of foreign exhibits at the fair was held at the Treasury Department this morning.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- An English officer, describing the German army manoeuvres, says: "The method of infantry attack called 'swarming' differs from the English style of advancing in extended lines. The method of the Germans is simpler. They advance line upon line, and shoulder to shoulder. This formation gives great strength, though there is a heavy expense in life, which shows that infantry is still held cheaply, and that victory goes to the biggest battalions."

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Replying to a person inquiring whether the discussion of theosophy ought to be permitted in workmen's clubs, where lectures and debates on religious subjects are tabooed, and whether such a discussion was likely to benefit workmen, Mr. Gladstone writes:

The men at Saratoga to whom the credit of the sound action of the convention on finance is essentially due are Messrs. CROKER and STRAUS of this city. JENKS and BOODY of Brooklyn, and TRACEY of Albany. Mr. TRACEY brought the inspiration and prestige of the gallant fight against cheap money in the last Congress.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Princeton College will reopen at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of Sept. 23, when the students will assemble in Marquand's Chapel to listen to President Patton's opening address. A number of new buildings have been in process of construction this Summer. The David Brown dormitory, to cost $100,000, has reached the fourth story.

HARTFORD, Sept. 16. -- With the exception of New-Haven and Bridgeport, the annual town elections in this State will take place on the first Monday in October. In New-Haven the election will not occur until December. In Bridgeport it will be delayed until the first Monday in April. In the remaining 166 towns all the offices of consequence, with the exception of Collector, will be filled by popular vote in October.

New-York may fairly claim to lead the world in the theatrical, as in many other lines of business. The most extensive enterprises ever undertaken in the way of furnishing amusements for the public have their headquarters here, and the biggest of them is under the sole control and direction of Charles Frohman, brother of Daniel Frohman of the Lyceum Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Secretary Foster today, when asked by a reporter about the financial condition of the Treasury, said:

Lawyer Leonard Bronner of 320 Broadway recently appeared for Henry C. Libby in a suit against Rosalie Hirsch and Charles E. Martin, the firm of Hirsch Martin, 109 Greene Street. On the 8th of last June Mrs. Hirsch made a co-partnership agreement with Martin. She was to put into the partnership stock and fixture said to be worth $6,000 and Martin was to furnish $3,000 cash.

Superintendent Parsons was asked yesterday for an explanation of the fact that Central Park, in the vicinity of the dairy and the marble arch end along the confines of the mall, presented a most untidy appearance. In those quarters there was a litter of discarded paper bags, newspapers, cigarette boxes, and other unsightly things.

The following letter from Lord Walsingham appeared in a recent edition of the London Times: "The work of converting the old Norman keep of Norwich Castle and the prison buildings around it to the purposes of a museum is now in progress. A meeting has lately been held at which additional subscriptions from his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales and others were announced.

It is reasonably certain that two men lost their lives by the burning of the Beach Building at Fulton and Nassau-Streets Tuesday morning. They are John Adelmann and his son Frederick. They were dealers in optical instruments, and sober, steady men, as a glance at their cozy home at 253 Second Street would testify.

There was rejoicing in New-York business circles yesterday when it became definitely known that the Saratoga Convention had repudiated the cheap money scheme of David B. Hill and had come out explicitly and vigorously for honest finance. Every important business man in the city identified with the Democratic Party was enthusiastic.
GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Sept. 17. -- It was nearly 9 P.M. when the Nebraska State Democratic Convention came to order this evening for a session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Upon the favorable report made by Naval Constructor Hichborn and Chief Engineer Towne, upon the shipbuilding facilities of the Iowa Iron Works of Dubuque, Iowa, Secretary Tracy to-day awarded the contract for building Torpedo Boat No. 2 to that establishment. This action of the department will create an interest in the navy along the interior waterways of the country.
]IDDLETO'IVN, i'q. Y., fqept. 17. -- The Prohibi tl0ulStS of the Second District of Orange County have nominated Abram T. Bquicr of this city for Assemblyman.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 17. -- The marriage of Mr. Horatio Nelson Sister and Miss Mabel De Carteret Hunt, youngest daughter of Mrs. William Morris Hunt, took place at Mizzen Top at noon to-day. Bishop Doane, who is a cousin of Mrs. Hunt, performed the ceremony. Mr. Edward Perkins of Boston, another cousin, gave away the bride.

From private letters received by a gentleman in this city, the following extracts are taken. They give the sequel to the attack on the Czarowitch of Russia, near Otsu, in Japan, last Spring, in an account of the trial and conviction of his assailant.
Mr. FASSETT is rash rather than courageous when he takes up the World's Fair as an issue in his canvass. Here is what he said in his speech at the Union League Club in Brooklyn on Wednesday night:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept 17. -- It appears that Gaiza, who is leading the attempted revolution in the State of Tamaulipas, Mexico, is not the celebrated desperado of that name, but is the editor of a weekly paper printed in Spanish and published at various points on the Texas frontier. He is a crank of the first water, and a violent opponent of the Diaz Government.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-first District met here to-day. Previous to opening for business, some friends of M.L. Wright, candidate for the Republican nomination for Supreme Court Judge, tried to secure an agreement from a majority of the delegates to adjourn the Senatorial Convention until after the holding of the Judicial Convention, which meets next week.

Big TOM BRENNAN is to take charge of cleaning the streets of New-York, and at last Tammany will have full sway over the working of the department. It is many a year since the Tammany power has had unresisted control of the work of street cleaning. When it was in charge of the Police Department the commission was bipartisan, and the patronage was divided.

The second body was taken from the ruins of Tuesday's fire, at Nassau and Fulton Streets, yesterday morning at 6 o'clock, and carried to Bellevue Hospital morgue. It was found within five feet of the body taken out Wednesday night. It is believed that there are no more bodies in the ruins.

The Rapid-Transit Commission received yesterday the report of Consulting Engineer John Bogart, the last of the four for which it has been waiting, preliminary to a decision upon the plan of construction of the Broadway Boulevard line. The reports of Engineers Octave Chanute, Joseph Wilson, and Theodore Cooper were received last week.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Capt. Thompson of the steamer Stockholm City, which arrived from London yesterday, reports that on Sept. 1 the boatswain heard some one groaning in the hold. On removing the cover of a ventilator the upturned face of a man could be seen in the lower hold. He asked in a very feeble voice for water, which was lowered to him.

As reported in yesterday's TIMES, Grammar School No. 35, in West Thirteenth Street, was closed yesterday, as it seems now, with every prospect of its remaining closed for school purposes for all time. The building is as good an example of bad work in construction as could well be found. The walls present every evidence of having been merely thrown together.

The people of Yonkers yesterday abandoned all their regular pursuits and pleasures and joined in the ceremonies and celebrations attendant upon the unveiling of the handsome monument which they have erected to the memory of the men of Yonkers who fought in the war for the preservation of the Union. Over 5,000 strangers were in the city and altogether it was a gala day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The case of the United States against John L. Rapier and the two cases of the United States against George W. Dupre will come up for argument at the October term of the United States Supreme Court. Each of these cases is an application for the discharge by writ of habeas corpus from arrest for an alleged violation of the anti-lottery legislation of the United States.

Fifty years ago an eccentric Frenchman whose brain seethed with Titanic musical fancies, who conceived combinations of instrumental and choral masses wholly incomprehensible to the multitude and astounding even to masters of his art, fled from Paris, where he felt keenly the lack of sympathy with his colossal ideas, and entered Germany.

The news became public in Wall Street yesterday that the Reading pool had been dissolved and that the stock held under the agreement had been released from the terms on which the syndicate went into business. As the case was generally understood and as it was explained by members of the pool, the syndicate went out of existence because its work had been done.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The terms made in London by Armour, representing the "Big Three," and by Winston and Depew, representing the Union Stockyards, have finally been disclosed. There are two ends to the agreement, one being that which the stockyards propose to do, the other that which the "Big Three" agrees to do.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Senator Francis A. Hendricks was to-day appointed to be Collector at New-York, in place of J. Sloat Fassett, resigned. The announcement is coupled with the explanation that the nomination had been decided upon several days ago, but its publication deferred.

A good-sized crowd greeted the Chicagos, the coming champions of the National League, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the first of the last series they will play with the Giants this season. Anson and his men were cheered as they walked on the field, but the Giants had to begin practice work without a word or sign of encouragement from those whom they had reason to suppose were their friends.

Last Winter Congress appropriated $25,000 for surveys between San Francisco and Honolulu, with a view to examining possible routes for a submarine cable between these two points. The Thetis was promptly selected to carry this measure into effect, but other duties took her to Bering Sea, and now the Albatross will make the survey.

It is not surprising that the purely partisan mind should seek to make an effective issue of the declarations of the Republicans and Democrats upon the currency. It is the habit of such a mind to find its own party right in everything and the opposing party wholly and always wrong, and if that state of things does not appear on the face of the respective platforms, ingenuity is exhausted to make it appear.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17. -- An inter-State war is impending between Missouri and Kansas over the headquarters of the general offices of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, now situated at Sedalia, Mo. President Meyer of the Sedalia Commercial Club was in the city today seeking the moral support of St. Louis merchants in behalf of this State. The facts in the case are these:

MADRID, Sept. 17. -- The municipal authorities of Almeria, capital of the province of that name, estimate that it will require 2,000,000 pesetas to repair the streets and buildings damaged by the recent floods. There was a renewal yesterday evening of the storms and floods in the Province of Toledo and more damage has been done.

If the Rapid-Transit Commission does not reach the best conclusion regarding the construction of the Broadway underground road it will not be for lack of expert advice or of taking sufficient time to consider the problem. It has now before it the reports of four consulting engineers upon the plans prepared by the two regular engineers of the board.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- A number of politicians dropped in here during the day and called at the Executive Chamber. It was the current remark, however, that in comparison with former years the representation was light. Chairman Murphy of the Democratic State Committee was closeted with Gov. Hill for half an hour this morning, and Immigration Commissioner Ridgway and Congressman John R. Fellows also came to the Governor's political funeral.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17. -- The indications are that the complete inside history of the troubles of the Grier Commission Company will be brought to the surface through the medium of a suit at law. This concern assigned some months ago and a great many charges and counter-charges were made. These accusations took such a range and were of such a character that all parties rushed into print with denials.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- A grand three-day centennial celebration was opened here to-day in commemoration of the location of old Fort Hamilton by Gen. Arthur St. Clair in 1791. The city is profusely decorated.

Twenty years ago the man who should have predicted that the elective method of choosing Judges in this State would result in a practically stable tenure for Judges of character and ability, quite independent of their party predilections, would have been looked upon as foolishly sanguine -- a sort of belated Jeffersonian.

SIDNEY, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- Gov. Campbell formally opened his campaign this afternoon in this thrifty little centre of the Western Ohio Democracy, on one of the brightest and hottest days of Autumn. The location had been chosen partly because it was surrounded by a fine farming community and partly because it is the capital of a Democratic county and has other stalwart Democratic counties to the Northwest and Southwest.

Burglars have been very active on Long Island of late, and for the last few nights have been operating quite extensively in the neighborhood of Newtown. The local authorities have been on the alert in consequence, and yesterday morning a battle took place between two police officers, which resulted in the capture of an alleged burglar.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- At Vitry-la-Francais to-day President Carnot and his Cabinet reviewed the French Army, consisting of 110,000 men, which has been taking part in extensive manoeuvres since Sept. 3, under the supreme command of Gen. Saussier. There was an enormous crowd present, and the most fervent enthusiasm was manifested by the masses.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 17. -- "Gentleman" George Ellwood, the notorious burglar, whose desperate criminal career was suddenly checked by two bullet wounds in the Frisbie residence in Hartford, and who was captured by the Worcester police, was brought to this city this forenoon by Detective Parker.

The account brought to Victoria by the sealing schooner San Diego, confirming the Geneva's previous report of a raid on the Russian islands in Bering Sea, greatly increases the importance of that affair. This new version shows that nine schooners, American and Canadian, simultaneously attacked Copper Island on one occasion, over forty boats landing, and making great havoc among the seals.

BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- Landlord Whipple held a conference this morning at Young's Hotel with a committee from the Boston Waiters' Alliance, representing the employes of Young's and Parker's. The result was that all existing grievances were amicably adjusted. The scale of wages presented by the men was accepted, and the desired reduction made in the hours of labor.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- With the roaring of cannon the second day of Hamilton's grand centennial celebration opened. Forty-four guns were fired in commemoration of the number of States now in the Union. The decorations are becoming more and more profuse until the city is hid beneath the national colors.

The Trinity Baptist Church in Fifty-fifth Street, near Lexington Avenue, is now struggling with the Chinese question. Trinity Church was one of the first in this city to attempt to do mission work among the Celestials in this city. It started out on what it thought was a practical line of work. A school for the Mongolians was established in the basement of the church.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A rather extraordinary impetus has been given to Cabinet gossip. It is stated on excellent authority that Mr. Platt and Senator Hiscock are pressing the President to appoint Representative Belden of New-York Secretary of War, and they expect that the appointment will be made.

Persons troubled with insomnia would do well to try the soporific influence of a stroll up Broadway during the progress of the work of building the cable railroad. Fifteen minutes' observation of the laborers there engaged is guaranteed to soothe the nerves and banish all recollection of a busy world. A half hour's communion with the 2,000 men employed on the road is as effective as a dose of laudanum.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 18. -- In response to the call published in the News and Courier of yesterday, about twenty-five policy holders in the New-York Life Insurance Company met at the Chamber of Commerce to-day to take some action toward making inquiry into the reports concerning the company, and to protect their own interests.

The decision just rendered by Judge GREEN in the case of the quarry worked by BUSHYHEAD and others, on the Cherokee Strip, is a hard blow to the Cherokees During several years they have resisted the overtures of the Government to purchase this tract, one excuse being that they wished first to get a judicial decision on their title to it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Within the last week preliminary arrangements for an Electrical Congress at the World's Fair have taken definite form. A committee of the World's Fair Congress Auxiliary has been appointed by President Bouney, with Prof. Elisha Gray, Chairman; Col. Robert C. Clowry, Vice Chairman, and B. E. Sunny, C. H. Summers, G. H. Bliss, and F. S. Gorton as members.

The new Temple Beth-El, one of the finest synagogues in this country, which has been erected within a year at the corner of Seventy-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue, was dedicated yesterday afternoon with much ceremony. Nearly three thousand members of the congregation took part in the consecration of their new house of worship.

MADRID, Sept. 18. -- The bodies of 1,200 victims of the flood at Consuegra have been buried. The town wears a most desolate aspect. The streets are covered with a deposit a yard deep of mud, which probably contains many corpses. A deposit of similar slime envelops the whole of St. John's Church, the furniture of which was thrown in all directions by the torrent.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 18. -- The famous Blue Point oyster beds of Great South Bay, which for more than one hundred years have been jointly owned by the "Tangier" Smith family and the Trustees of the Town of Brookhaven, have been seized by the former, to the threatened exclusion of over 1,000 oystermen, who, with their ancestors, have for many generations enjoyed the privilege of working the beds at a nominal fee.

If the city authorities can have their way about it, there will be an early decision of the municipal building site question. Little or nothing has been heard about the location and plans of the proposed new building since last Spring, when the Mayor's bill to authorize the construction of the building in City Hall Park was lost in the Senate dead-lock.

The complete effacement of the political influence of Gov. HILL by the action of the Democratic Convention has upset the calculations of two classes of politicians and their newspaper organs, and they are making desperate efforts to rehabilitate him as a factor in the campaign. The Republicans counted upon Hillism as an issue in the State canvass, and several of the leaders announced that the fight was to be made upon that issue.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 18. -- More trouble seems to be brewing in the Tennessee coal mines. Gov. Buchanan this afternoon sent the following telegram to Gov. Brown of Kentucky:

Two mounted policemen will be placed on trial before the Park Commissioners next Monday for fighting while on duty on Riverside Drive last Sunday. The names of the combatants are William O, Lyon and John Hoy. Three different charges growing out of the encounter wore preferred against Lyon yesterday. Hoy will be tried on the single charge of conduct unbecoming an officer.

The dispute about the site of the new municipal building would probably not have arisen but for the expectation that the building might be placed upon City Hall Park. Public opinion has been so decidedly declared against any further encroachment upon that pleasure ground that it has been abandoned.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 18. -- The officials of the Trinity Reformed Church in Plainfield have just learned how a wedding of twenty months ago cost them $50,000. A few years ago, during his residence at Park Avenue and Sixth Street, this city, John Goldsmith Payntar was one of the most regular attendants at the Trinity Reformed Church, and his relative, the Rev. J. Simonson, late of this city, occupied the pulpit.
ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- Snappish and cross, Lieut. Gov. Jones arrived here this evening. He comes to sign the two weeks' pay roll of the men employed in the construction department of the Capitol.

Perhaps the past few days have been more trying than any "spell of weather" that has preceded them since the beginning of the Summer. Undoubtedly they have been more trying to the people who have only just, and as they now find rather prematurely, returned from the country, particularly if these people have been among the mountains, where "humidity" has no terrors.

Of course the poolsellers do not like the breaking up of their business. Confessedly, this has been effected by the action of the Brooklyn Jockey Club in refusing to allow any news of the races to leave their track before all the races are decided and in refusing to give out before the races the names of the horses that are to start and of the jockeys who are to ride them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Minister, has called the attention of the Department of State to alleged violations of the modus vivendi respecting the maximum number of seals to be taken in Boring Sea.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18. -- The steamship Mondego, from Montreal for Dundee, is a total wreck on the coast of Newfoundland. The first intimation of the wreck came from a cattle foreman on board the steamer Joseph Hyland. He telegraphed from St. Mary's, N.F., as follows:

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York. New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company will be held in New-Haven on the 21st of next month. The report of the Directors for the year ended June 30 last, prepared for submission to the stockholders, shows:

The new Republican State Committee met for the first time yesterday and completed its organization, decided to open headquarters at once, and after a conference of the Executive Committee agreed that one of the chief issues of the campaign had already been defined by Mr. Fassett, and that it would make one of its principal lines of battle the issue against Tammany

The meeting of the Baltimore Jockey Club, to cover twelve days, will take place over the famous old track at Pimlico, where in past years the most stirring turf struggles between the equine representatives of the East and West were decided. It will begin on Monday, Oct. 19. Nearly all the prominent Eastern stables will send representatives to Baltimore.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- The second performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin" took place this evening at the Grand Opera House. The theatre was filled at an early hour. During the second act of the opera a number of globules containing a fetid chemical substance were thrown from the gallery to the orchestra. The Police Commissary gave warning that if this was repeated the galleries would be cleared.

WASHINGTON, Sept 18. -- Upon the urgent request of the Mayor and Council of El Paso, Texas, Gen. Dyrenforth made all arrangements before returning to Washington to continue the rainfall experiments there. The apparatus and material were promptly shipped, and his party went from Midland to El Paso, where they were in constant telegraphic communication with him.

ST. Louis, Sept. 18. -- A telegram was received here to-day announcing that the Thiels Agency's men had captured Edward Albertson and Fred Chandler in Oregon. Albertson is the absconding secretary and cashier of the Fidelity Bank of Tacoma, Washington. He had taken from the bank vaults $900,000 in securities and $20,000 in cash. Fred N. Chandler was a confederate of Albertson's, and a gambler well known throughout the Pacific slope.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 18. -- The Grand Jury met this afternoon to further consider the Mc Carthy-Warren fight. There was a lively discussion in the jury room, and it is said that Chairman Breedlon Smith, a prominent member of the Young Men's Christian Association, desired a special report and a sweeping denunciation of the prize ring, coupled with a recommendation that the officials stop the fight and break up the sport in New-Orleans.

The new Republican State Committee has been organized for campaign work, with Mr. WILLIAM BROOKFIELD of this city as Chairman, but it is believed that Lobbyist CAMP is to attend to the important task of collecting funds and putting them where they will do the most good. He is an adept at that kind of business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Thomas H. Mills, who was the last Republican Speaker of the House in the Wisconsin Legislature before the "great landslide" in favor of the Democracy in that State, is here. Mr. Mills, of course, thinks the Republicans are going to win at the next election in Wisconsin. He argues this way:

CARROLL, Iowa, Sept. 18. -- Gov. Boies addressed an audience of 5,000 persons here this afternoon. It was the greatest of a series of meetings that have not been equaled in the annals of Iowa politics.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 18. -- The application of Prof. Casonovitch to the Newark Presbytery for reinstatement as Professor of Hebrew in the German Theological School of Newark, situated here, will probably attract the attention of Presbyterians everywhere. The professor is the son of a well-known rabbi, and early in 1885 went to the theological school in Bloomfield as a professor.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 18. -- Senator Quay is having a hard time to secure the harmony he so much needs in Pennsylvania this year. One essential is a settlement of the bitter factional struggle that has been going on for months between Congressmen Robinson and Dalzell for the Presidency of the State League of Republican Clubs.

It is generally supposed that the work of private corporations is done without the waste and inefficiency that are so apt to characterize work done under public authority, but it is said that in the construction of the cable road in Broadway under the direction of Mr. JOHN D. CRIMMINS, the Tammany method has full swing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 18. -- The disappearance of Miss Vera Ava from Chicago and her subsequent appearance in Cincinnati have created a mild sensation at Fresno, where no less than three persons reside who are intimately acquainted with Miss Ava's career. C.L. Cook and A.W. Beveridge, real estate men, and H.W. Jackson, a lawyer, are natives of Gloucester County, England, where Miss Vera Ava was born.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Sept. 19. -- Rutgers College will open next Wednesday with several new professors and tutors and a larger freshman class than ever before. There have been a very large number of applications, some of which have been rejected, not being up to the standard.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The new Grand Hotel on Summit Mountain, in the Catskills, closed Monday after one of the most successful seasons in its history. Saturday evening the Hon. Davis Winne, a Director of the Ulster and Delaware Railroad, gave a dinner at the hotel to the officers and the other Directors of the road.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Texas, Sept. 19. -- It has been definitely ascertained that Caterino Garzia premised his men that they should assault and loot the town of Camargo, and that after a slight skirmish with seven Custom House guards whom they met near that town, Garzia and the remnant of his men retreated to the Azucan, where he told them that Ruiz Sandoval and reinforcements were to meet them.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- The first annual championship games of the Atlantic Association of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States came off this afternoon in Union Park, under the auspices of the Baltimore Athletic Club. The Atlantic Association embraces all the Atlantic coast States from and including New Jersey south of Trenton. The entries were numerous and the sport very exciting, although no records were broken.

The order of Adjt. Gen. PORTER, approving the rules drawn up by Dr. BRYANT, the Surgeon General, for the examination of recruits for the National Guard, creates a new departure in that respect. Hitherto, when in some organizations there has been a demand for men, very little obstruction has been created for candidates on the score of ill health or organic disease.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Sept. 19. -- The Delphic Literary Society held its first meeting this year last Friday night. Charles Hart, '92, was elected President; H.L. Turner, '93, Vice President; Allen K. White, '94, Secretary; Jesse H. Reinhart, '93, Treasurer; C.S. Hallowell, '93, Corresponding Secretary; F.E. Broomell, '93, Censor; P. Sellers, '94, Librarian, and S.H. Mattson, '95, and C. White, '95. Library Committee.

ROME, Sept. 19. -- The Pope to-day received, in the vestibule of St. Peter's, the first contingent of the French pilgrim workmen. The pilgrims numbered 2,000. The majority of them looked like workmen in Sunday attire. The Pope was borne into the hall seated on the sedia gestatoria. He was received with fervent acclamations by the pilgrims.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The refusal on the part of Prof. Morey to continue the instruction of the seniors in political economy will result in an improvement on the old arrangement. There has been for some time a vacant chair in the Faculty, as an endowment was given by Don Alonzo Watson for the establishment of a department of political economy, which has never been filled.

The Southern Society is slowly but surely nearing the time when the mammoth clubhouse which some of its magnates are talking about will become a positive necessity. It has, even now, outgrown its present quarters at 18 West Twenty-fifth Street, famed and famous as the former home of John Chamberlain and the Carleton Club, and has concluded arrangements looking to the annexation of the adjoining house on the west.

Hugh McLaughlin and his followers did not succeed in nominating Chapin for Governor, but they made several facts very plain to the people of this State. One was that the opposition to Mr. Flower in Kings County came, not from the people, but from the office holders, ex-office holders and expectant office holders. It was the machine, pure and simple, that was behind Chapin, and consequently against any other candidate.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 19. -- The intense heat of the past few days continued yesterday, the thermometer registering 100 to 106 at several Minnesota points. The heat was accompanied by a strong wind, and prairie fires are reported from a dozen localities. A great deal of hay in stacks has been destroyed, and three or four miles of the Great Northern Railroad track have been burned and made impassable.

The summary published Tuesday by THE TIMES of the semi-annual statement to June 30, 1891, of the New-York Life Insurance Company to the State of Georgia has caused a profound sensation among insurance men. The more they examine and discuss the matter the more does it become incomprehensible, even to them as experts.

The Republicans of this State have put themselves in a better position than their opponents in their treatment of the question of ballot reform, but the fact that they have done so is entirely due to the malign influence which Gov. HILL has exercised upon legislation and upon the counsels of his party in the last three or four years.

READING, Penn., Sept 19. -- Next Thursday the sect known as the Schwenkfelders, of whom there are only five congregations in the United States, all in the contiguous counties of Berks, Lehigh, and Montgomery, will hold their unique annual celebration, or "Gedaechtnis Tag" at Clayton, in Washington township, to commemorate the arrival of their forefathers in America at Philadelphia in 1734.

WATERBURY Conn., Sept. 19. -- The Connecticut State Board, of Health has just completed a summary of the vital statistics of the Commonwealth for the year 1890. The number of births was 17,394. The males exceeded the females by 468. The parentage statistics indicate that in 7,596 cases the children were of American parents, in 9,298 cases of foreign parents, while in 500 cases the nativity of the parents is not returned.

There was sackcloth and ashes galore at the Staten Island Athletic Club house last night. Their crack baseball club had the Amateur Athletic Union League pennant in their grasp yesterday morning, but last night it had as good as gone to the Englewood Field Club. The teams were tied, and it was the Staten Island boys' last game. Fully 3,000 people were present.

MADRID, Sept. 19. -- The workmen who have been engaged in Consuegra in removing bodies from the mud-buried streets refused to work this morning. They claimed that the stench was so severe that work was impossible. A liberal supply of disinfectants was obtained, and the men this afternoon resumed work.

Now that the political battle lines in the State are drawn and the opposing forces are rallying their armies for the big conflict, the situation here in the city takes on a peculiar interest. In some respects this will be the great battlefield of the campaign, and the local Democratic forces will meet the Republicans for the first time in three campaigns without the G.O.P. having unions with Democratic allies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The week has been notable for the production of one new play, "The Leavenworth Case," and the first production on a metropolitan stage of "Abraham Lincoln." In "The Leavenworth Case" Mr. Haworth has scored an undoubted triumph as an artist. The play in itself is too weird to be immensely popular.

The words "New-York" attached to the Custom House at this port seem to have a purely geographical meaning for the politicians at Washington into whose hands the administration of Federal affairs has fallen. It is known to them that the Custom House is situated in the City of New-York, and that imports on which duties are fixed and collected in the Custom House are necessarily imports into New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- The unholy compact entered into between the Knights of Labor leaders and the Republicans failed of ratification to-day at a meeting of the delegates to the Legislative Convention of the order. The fight of the day was over the adoption of the majority or minority report of the Legislative Committee, in which the followers of P.F. Caffrey, the signer of the minority report, came off victorious.

The nine Catholic Bishops of the New-York Province have addressed letter of thanks to the Pope for his recent encyclical on the condition of labor. The letter, dated from this city, is written in Latin. In English it would read somewhat as follows:

The Louisiana State Lottery Company, which has grown rich and corpulent since its organization in 1868 upon the dollars of millions of luckless individuals, is now making a desperate struggle for an additional lease of life. The question raised has become paramount in interest and importance to Louisiana primarily, and secondarily to the dwellers in every hamlet of every State in the Union.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- In anticipation of a possible visit from President Harrison to Boston during the stay of Mrs. Harrison at Auburndale, the Boston Chamber of Commerce tendered dinner to him, but a note received from Private Secretary Halford yesterday states that the President does not expect to visit this city at any time in the near future, and, therefore, he was unable to accept the invitation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $160,722,100, as follows: Currency 6s, $9,648,000; 412 per cents, $693,400; 4 per cents, $119,255,100; 2 per cents, $21,126,600.

The residents of the most aristocratic quarter of Astoria, Long Island City, are at present much interested in the apparently bitter personal war being waged by Richard Bamler, a well-known contractor, on Mrs. Hicks, a wealthy widow. Mrs. Hicks owns and occupies a handsome residence on Remsen Street, which was built some years ago.

" Pete" De Lacy was "called down" yesterday. Superintendent W.C. Humstone of the Western Union Telegraph Company did it. Mr. Humstone was very angry when he learned that De Lacy had told P.J. Dwyer of the Brooklyn Jockey Club that the Western Union Telegraph Company, through its particularly-petted creature the H.C. Ditmas Company, alone stood in the way of a settlement of the war now in progress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Another social sensation, to which Miss Gertrude Whiting Potter, daughter of O.W. Potter, the millionaire President of the Illinois Steel Company, is a party, was developed this afternoon. At the residence of her parents, in the Virginia apartment house, shortly after noon, she was married to Julius Clarke Daniels of New-York City.

The regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club was held last Monday week, but as the weather was bad the regatta was not much of a success, and many of the members of the club were, in consequence, disappointed. Commodore B. Frank Sutton decided to put up a number of prizes and hold what he called a "scrap" regatta, and yesterday it was sailed at Gravesend Bay.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The farce of the Mahone and anti-Mahone fight in Virginia, which always comes up toward the close of an Administration to settle the question of whom the President must deal with to get the delegation to the National Convention, has begun, and the ambitious spoilsmen are parading themselves before the President in tin armor, ready to be his champions -- for a consideration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- There is much excitement here to-night among negro politicians over the President's proclamation throwing open to settlement lands acquired from the Indians in Oklahoma. In the preamble of the proclamation the President quotes from the act of Congress as follows:

On my way to the Latin Quarter in Paris, of which I have made mention, I had a two weeks' allowance for a brief stay in London. I experienced the natural enthusiasm of youth about the historic monuments of the great city, but I confess it was the living men, the men who were then governing England, that I desired to see rather than the tombs of the dead in the famous mediaeval abbey.

More than two weeks have passed since the kite-shaped track at Independence, Iowa, was the scene of two extraordinary feats in light harness, the one being the mile in 2:06, paced by Direct, the other Allerton's performance of trotting in 2:10, and thus placing himself first among stallions at that gait. These two record-breaking efforts have been the subject or much criticism and certainly have not been received as cordially as were those they eclipsed.

PORT HURON, Mich., Sept. 19. -- All the trains arriving at Port Huron and Sarnia to-day had distinguished guests, who were to take the first official ride through the great tunnel. At Point Edward a special train with four ordinary day coaches was drawn up on the front of the station. At 12:30 P.M. Sir Henry Tyler waved his hand and the train started.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- It is just three years since the Daly troupe last came to us. At no time has the American management seen fit to advertise such coming, except in the most businesslike manner, as if the the event were a yearly occurrence, like the migration of the swallows, or the usual Summer complaints concerning "infamous Paris water."

The amount of tentative millinery put forth each season must reduce considerably the profits of the trade. Once it was only necessary to issue a limited number of styles and they were accepted immediately without question. But the ladies have become so independent that they are as little to be counted on in millinery as Mugwumps in politics.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- During the Summer vacation the committee of the Faculty who have in charge the publishing and arranging of the university catalogue have been busily engaged in preparing to have the new catalogue out within a month after the opening of college. Everything is completed except the list of students, which cannot be prepared until after Oct. 1.

News comes from England that the British Admiralty have at last awakened to the necessity for using homing pigeons as carriers of messages, and experiments on an extensive scale are about to be conducted. The Naval Intelligence Department of England is said to have some splendidly-trained birds with which trials will be made, the Scilly Islands having been selected as the homing station.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- There has been no such other object lesson in actual European politics for a decade as that which fluttered the Bourses of the world at the beginning of the present week. There was a declaration that three Consuls in the Grecian Archipelago had informed their Ministers at Constantinople that a British fleet had landed men and guns on Sigri, an island by Mityleue.

Western-dressed beef has revolutionizes the tastes and markets of the world, and has superseded in large communities, to a great extent, the local-dressed beef which, though sometimes fatter, is much higher in price and not preferred by many to the cattle of the plains.

NEVADA, Iowa, Sept. 19. -- The Republican stronghold of Story County was alive with Democrats to-day, and it happened that the relative drawing powers of Gov. Boies and Senator Allison were clearly demonstrated. Gov. Boies spoke at Nevada in the afternoon and Senator Allison held forth at Ames at the same hour.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The army manoeuvres, which have been in progress for some days, were concluded to-day with an attack of the Fourth and Eleventh Army Corps, commanded by Emperor William in person, upon the enemy, under Gen. Wittich. The Emperor left Mulhausen yesterday morning and proceeded to Volkemoda, where he assumed command of the Eleventh Army Corps.

La Bretagne, which sailed for Havre yesterday, carried the body of Marquis de Chambrun, which will be interred in France. Among La Bretagne's passengers were Count de Boisgelin, Mrs. Leonard Buet, Adolph Beanjour, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Benson, P. Chambert, L. Chardonnier, George Chivot, attache of the French Embassy in Italy; the Countess d'Hunieres, Albert Ross, Mr. and Mrs. A.F. Zarriga, and Miss Concepcion Zarriga.

On Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday the transactions on the Stock Exchange exceeded each day 500,000 shares; on Friday they rose to the height of 778,000 shares, and in the brief two hours of business yesterday they were 312,000 shares. That tells where the public is. No such volume of business has ever been done in Wall Street without the public being in the market. It is there now.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- St. Mary's Church was crowded to-day with people who were curious to witness the obsequies of Lawyer Gerard G. Riordan, who died from a dose of carbolic acid, taken in mistake for wine of cocoa.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The action of Lieut. Gov. Jones in opposing the nominations of the Saratoga Convention was not a surprise to those who know him best. His past record justified the belief that in the event he was ignored by the Democratic Party he would make matters interesting for the candidate, whoever he might be.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 19. -- New-Orleans Levee Board yesterday held its first annual meeting. The officers and engineers' report showed an expenditure during the past year of $126,895, paid out in the building, repairing, riveting and maintenance of 21.15 miles of levees, and that $14,000 was expended in building a rear levee to protect the suburb of Algiers from the Ames crevasse water.

The engineers of the New-York Central Road have about completed their preparations preliminary to the construction of the new branch from Tonawanda to Batavia in the western part of this State. This branch will be used by the Lehigh Valley Road for its coal traffic as soon as the latter's extension from Geneva to Batavia is completed.

David M. Stone, President of the Associated Press, yesterday forwarded to Mrs. George Jones a memorial of her husband in the shape of an album containing engrossed resolutions adopted by the members of the Associated Press, testifying their respect to the memory of Mr. Jones, and tendering their sympathy to herself and family.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The past theatrical and musical week has not been interesting. No novelties were presented at the theatres, and the musical world has not yet entered upon its Winter season of enjoyment.

ADEN, Sept. 1. -- If like cures like and a blue pill is good for the blues, it may comfort Americans suffering from heat to know what their fellow-mortals can endure and live. There is no place on earth which has not a "devil's cave," and in the way of "punch bowls" he is well supplied, but some eminent and accurate geographer has discovered in the Red Sea the "devil's mouth."

To the minds of some people the fact that the late Ambrose H. Monell was heavily in debt to ex-Sheriff James A. Flack, furnishes a partial explanation of how he became involved in the notorious Flack case. All through the case, Monell, then a Justice of a civil court, was the legal adviser of Sheriff Flack.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- There has been a great deal of life and excitement at Syracuse University since it opened last Thursday. The freshman class is larger than that of last year, and represents almost every State in the Union. Dr. Charles J. Little has gone to Evanston, Ind. Three new professors have been appointed -- Mace history and political science; Hargitt, biology, and Emmons, Greek.

The notion that Mr. BELDEN may be pacified in his known disgruntlement at the results of the Republican State Convention by the offer of a place in Mr. HARRISON'S Cabinet ought to be a preposterous one. It is not inconceivable that Mr. HARRISON should use a Cabinet office to purchase political support for a renomination.

The utterances of the London Standard upon questions of foreign policy may fairly be taken as representing the opinions of Lord SALISBURY'S Government. From the remarks of the Standard it is quite clear that the "picnic" upon the Island of Mitylene, though really a picnic and not an armed occupation, was, so to speak, an inspired picnic, and was intended as a political demonstration.

There is little likelihood of any large war ships being authorized to be built for the navy in the next two years. This fact is known not only to the Secretary of the Navy, but to shipbuilders in general. The coming House is a Democratic one. It has staring it squarely in the face the reckless expenditures of the Fifty-first Congress.

When one can be a mouse in the corner at a gathering of young women a vast amount of valuable information is gleaned. The dear girls do not mind in the least telling a joke on themselves, and have no hesitancy whatever in avowing all sorts of little feminine artifices, on the principle, probably, that there are no secrets among "professionals." And this is what floated through an open door the other day:

The opinion is expressed by an observer, whose knowledge of the public taste is not to be questioned, that "Niobe," the farce now current at the Bijou Theatre, is "over the heads of the people." It does not draw as many spectators in the upper galleries as an ordinary farce. This is valuable information. From it people of moderate intelligence may learn why the American theatre is what it is.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 19. -- Hamilton's grand centennial ended this evening with the finest display of fireworks ever seen in Ohio. The pieces were much larger than those used in the centennial of 1876 in Philadelphia. Thousands upon thousands of persons are here, every State in the Union and countries abroad being represented by large delegations of ex-Hamiltonians.

In many respects the most noteworthy amateur athletic event that has ever been witnessed in this country was the first annual carnival of sports held all day yesterday on the new Manhattan Field, under the auspices of the Manhattan Athletic Club. Fifteen thousand people, at a conservative estimate, spent an entire day and evening applauding the contests of strong and agile young men.

Not the least of the results growing out of the recent inter-State rifle matches at Creedmoor and at Washington, in the District of Columbia, is the influence which the enterprise and undertaking of the Twenty-third Regiment is likely to exert in the matter of the selection of teams to hereafter represent the State of New-York in the Hilton Trophy and matches of a kindred nature.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- Ceres and Pomona have held high court in Horticultural Hall this week, and their triumphal display, continuing through Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, drew out that portion of the community that is especially interested in the fine art of horticulture. The vegetables and fruits made an uncommonly fine appearance, too.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 19. -- The boat parade had to be abandoned because there were so many arrangements to be made beforehand. There are many things to do and the ladies have thought they would not be able to get things together. The last week has been extremely lively with luncheons, teas, dinners, dancing parties, and the coach parade in Pittsfield.
TROY, Sept. 19. -- Levi P. Worden of Hoosick was to-day renominated for Assembly in the Second District of Rensselaer County by the Republicans.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 20. -- L.W. Naylor, Post Office Inspector from Washington, who has been in this city for the past few days, has brought to light and is now working up the evidence of one of the most remarkable swindling schemes ever known in this section of the country.

With the sealing season practically over, attention will now be directed to the reports of the experts sent to Bering Sea by the British Government and our own to investigate the fisheries. The main conclusion reached by the two American Commissioners, Profs. MENDENHALL and MERRIAM, seems to be that the current agreement prohibiting the wasteful and indiscriminate open sea hunting must be continued for several years more to preserve the seals from extermination.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 20. -- Dr. W. H. Green, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, in his opening sermon to the students of Princeton Theological Seminary this morning preached on the subject "The Word of God." In referring to the "higher critics" and positions taken by them he said:

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- Charles H. Allen, four days ago nominated for Governor by the Republicans of Massachusetts, figured yesterday at four dinners. One was that of the Massachusetts Club, the second that of the Republican Editorial Association of Massachusetts, the third the dinner of the Commercial Club, all in the afternoon; and the fourth that of the Chicatawbut Club, in the evening.

DUBLIN, Aug. 31. -- While Home Rulers have been coquetting with Radicals and Conservatives and flying at each other's throats as Parnellites and anti-Parnellites, the City of Dublin has not remained entirely at a standstill. It now boasts of another public building to place beside Custom House, old Parliament House, and Trinity College.

The new Synagogue erected by the Hebrews of Staten Island in Richmond Turnpike, Tompkinsville, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon. Admission was by card only, and about 350 persons were present.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The spirit of the citizens of Newark is beginning to assert itself all over the State. The local struggle against the oppression of the bosses brings into bolder relief the iron-bound autocracy Gov. Abbett has established all over his empire. What Boss James Smith, Jr., is to Newark the Governor is to the Commonwealth. The imperialism which one applies to local affairs the other applies to State affairs.

Policeman Charles Schneider of the Union Market squad is in a fair way to be stripped of his badge and buttons, unless they are fastened by a thread of political influence too strong to be broken. Schneider used to be attached to the Mercer Street squad. He was there for three years, and in that time complaints for drunkenness, being off post, , were lodged against him fifteen occasions.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20. -- The Time's Rio Grande City Special says: "Two hundred Mexican troops from Mier, Camargo, and Ringosa are watching the revolutionists near Camargo. Great uneasiness is felt in Camargo. Camargo and Mier are patrolled by citizens. The soldiers are absent and the revolutionists take arms, horses, and provisions promiscuously.

The light of theosophy is waning in England, partly, it must be supposed, because that cult never really met any long-felt want, and partly because Mrs. ANNIE BESANT and Mr. BURROWS, who, since the death of Mme. BLAVATSKY, have been the most prominent of all theosophic adepts, have refused to submit their occult powers to rational investigation and such tests as non-believers wished to apply to them.

Newspapers, letters, and reports from all parts of the world indicate the profound impression produced by THE TIMES'S exposures of the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company. The excitement is not confined to any special locality. From the Atlantic to the Pacific in this country, in Mexico, Central and South America, the West Indies, Canada, and Europe, the press literally teems with the New-York Life scandals.

BUFFALO, Sept. 20. -- An astonishing revelation of German solidarity and strength of numbers was furnished here to-day. Apparently it was arranged as a fitting forerunner of the great congress of German-American Catholics which begins proceedings to-morrow. The announcement had been made that a new Catholic church was to be dedicated, but little or nothing appeared beforehand to indicate an affair of magnitude or novel significance.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The aquatic carnival last night on the river at Rahway attracted crowds from this city, and was the most brilliant event in Rahway's history. Thousands of spectators lined the river banks and docks and crowded the Monroe Street bridge, which was the turning point for the procession.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Properly to follow what has happened and is happening in Russia, not to speak of the still more impressive events to come, one must first of all realize that all over the empire the administrative power is above the law. It is by the failure to comprehend this that men even of Mr. Goldwin Smith's intellectual rank are led to write and print misleading and mischievous nonsense about Russo-Jewish matters.

The anxiety expressed in some quarters lest the well-known pro-British sympathies of the new Queen of Hawaii should lead to an attempt at the seizure of the archipelago by England seems to be rather needless. Although the death of her husband, Gov. DOMINIS, a native of Massachusetts, has perhaps left her still more susceptible to British influence, it is not to be supposed that she wishes to exchange her sovereignty for foreign vassalage.

Special dispatches from Valparaiso, Chile, to the New-York Herald, published yesterday, state that ex-President Balmaceda, of the Chilean Republic, committed suicide at Santiago Saturday by shooting himself through the temple.

If Senator SHERMAN was at his home in Mansfield on Saturday and heard the address of ex-Speaker MILLS, he must have felt that an opponent of no mean rank was contesting his State with him. Mr. MILLS with admirable candor and effectiveness approached the silver question straight in front.

The details of Brooklyn politics in both parties are pretty well known to those of our readers who have followed the subject in our news columns. Since the County of Kings presented a candidate to each party, who was with unflattering promptness rejected by the convention, the politicians in each party seem to be bound to show that their zeal is not chilled.

ROME, Sept. 20. -- A feature of the celebration in this city to-day was the public reading by the Mayor, at the Porta Pia, of a telegram from King Humbert, received by the former in reply to congratulations sent the King on the twentieth anniversary of the entry of the Italian troops into Rome.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- These are busy times in the Washington Navy Yard, and never since its conversion into an ordnance yard has there been more work in progress. All departments are working to their full capacity, and the facilities of the establishment will soon be greatly increased by the equipment of the new north gun shop, with machine tools capable of handling the biggest kind of work.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Discount rates hardened during the past week, being quoted at 2 1/2 for three months and 1 3/4 for short. The demand for gold continues for Germany and New-York, and the drain is regarded with much uneasiness. As some check upon the withdrawal of bullion for the United States, the Bank of England has raised the selling price of eagles to 76s. 9d. per ounce.

GUTHRIE, O.T., Sept. 20. -- A trip along the west line of the new Territory to-day revealed a chain of encampments, while a detour into the lands to be opened Tuesday showed that the "sooners" had taken possession. Authentic advices indicate that all through the lands of the Sacs, Foxes, and Iowas there are secreted nearly enough people to pre-empt the best lands.

QUEBEC, Quebec, Sept. 19. -- From official sources it is learned that the royal commission to inquire into the Bale des Chaleurs Railway scandal will consist of Judges Jette, Baby, and Davidson. A meeting of the Cabinet was held to-day, at which the lines upon which the commission will work were decided. The Commissioners, who, it is understood, will all accept, are to commence their labors in two weeks.

There was a spirited debate at the rooms of the Addison Literary Society, 32 East Fourth Street, last night, on the subject, "Resolved, that the civilized nations of the world should enter a protest against Russia's barbarous treatment of her Jewish subjects." Judge Henry M. Goldfogle presided. The affirmative was presented by Moses Grossman and J. Raichart, and the negative by Joseph Levison and Louis L. Schapp.

Richard Owens, homeless, and forty-five years old, was found shortly before midnight Saturday lying unconscious in front of Dennis O'Connor's liquor store, 329 East Fifty-ninth Street, between First and Second Avenues. He was bleeding from a severe cut on his head. Patrolman Tancredi of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, whose attention was called to the man, sent for an ambulance to the Presbyterian Hospital, but when the ambulance arrived the man was dead.
DES MOINES, Sept. 20. -- Candidate Wheeler has at last broken his sphinxlike silence and has told where he stands on the prohibition question.

The wisdom of putting the great national parks under the control of the regular army has received fresh confirmation from the report made by Capt. ANDERSON, Sixth Cavalry, who, with Troop I of that regiment, has charge of Yellowstone Park. This splendid pleasure ground is now in better condition than ever before.

There are many Republicans who heard with more misgiving than enthusiasm the news that their party had nominated to the office of Governor so pronounced a Platt man as Mr. FASSETT. There are some Democrats who cannot approve the nomination of Mr. FLOWER. There are Mugwumps and independent voters of all sorts and conditions to whom neither candidate is entirely satisfactory.
Allow me to hand you inclosed three clippings of some of the papers of this city, with the respective translations, which I think you will find interesting.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20. -- A sensation of no small proportions has been caused by the report, and confirmation thereof, that the teachers in the public schools have been subjected to a system of espionage. There are 1,200 female teachers in the public schools, and concerning some of them reports of improper conduct have reached the board.

PITTTBURG, Sept. 20. -- The Western Pennsylvania delegates favorable to the election of Congressman John B. Robinson to the Presidency of the Pennsylvania League of Republican Clubs will leave Pittsburg in a special train to-morrow night to attend the convention of Wednesday at Scranton. The contingent which supports Congressman John Dalzell for the place will start Tuesday morning on a train of its own.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Truxton is one of the villages of this county, and among its most attractive young ladies is Miss Minnie Johnston, who is a pronounced blonde of nineteen Summers. Miss Johnston lives between the village proper and the town of Homer. At all the Sunday school picnics and evening teas, which are the limit of the dissipation of the county, Miss Johnston was always the one most admired.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- Gov. Jackson of Maryland and Gov. McKinney of Virginia will start from Crisfield next Tuesday on a cruise over the oyster grounds of the Chesapeake Bay. In both States the salvation of the oyster industry is now a leading question, and the Legislatures which will be elected in November will be called upon to deal with it.

Mr. SHERMAN in a recent interview remarked: "Some of our Republican free-trade newspapers in the East are after us about our tariff policy, but if they will stop a moment to consider the situation they will see that in a campaign of this character the one issue cannot be dropped for the other to please any section of the country."

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court has decided that Gen. O'Beirne was wrong in detaining Beriah Baruch, who arrived on the steamer Obdam Aug. 21, from Rotterdam, on the ground that he was likely to become a public charge. A brother of the detained immigrant said that he had saved over $1,000 in seven years, and had sent for Beriah in order to set him up in the shoemaking business.

The funeral of Major Jonas M. Bundy, for many years editor of the Mail and Express, was held yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street. It was attended by a large number of well-known people who been friends of Major Bundy, and by many newspaper men who had come in contact with him in professional life.

The Republican Club held one of its regular monthly meetings last night, and there was a large crowd present. President William Brookfield was in the chair, and, in behalf of the Campaign Committee, John S. Smith, its Chairman, presented a resolution indorsing the Republican State ticket. This was carried with enthusiasm and unanimity.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 21. -- Already the hotels are full of guests awaiting the opening of the annual music festival. The three rehearsals of to-day were well attended, fully 1,700 people being in Mechanics' Hall to-night, when choruses from Handel's "Israel in Egypt," Dr. Bridge's "Repentance of Nineveh," and Victor Herbert's "Captive" were sung. The two other rehearsals were orchestral.

GUTHRIE, O., Sept. 21. -- At Oklahoma City the land office has been so besieged with claimants that the Governor has been appealed to for protection. All day yesterday the trains from the south and north came into that city loaded with men, boys, and women, all carrying bundles, which were burdensome because they did not know what to do with them.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The fourteenth biennial conference of the Unitarians and other Christian Churches began its sessions here this evening in the Town Hall and will continue until Thursday evening. The headquarters are at the United States Hotel, where the Council held its preliminary business meeting this afternoon.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 21. -- The debate on the reports of the committee appointed to investigate the charges made by J. Israel Tarts against Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, and the Hen. Thomas McGreevy, was commenced to-day in the Commons. Chairman Giouarda, Langevinite, began the debate by supporting the majority report which condemns McGreevy, who is rusticating at Portland, but exonerates Sir Hector.

The Japanese Government is already busy with arrangements for participating in the Chicago Exhibition. At the next sitting of Parliament a bill will be submitted providing for an appropriation of 695,000 yen -- about $525,000 -- to cover the public expenditures. A part of this amount will be applied to the transportation of wares from the ports of Yokohama and Kobe to Chicago, which the authorities take upon themselves without charge to individuals.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 21. -- Munchausen appears to be outdone.
