A Brooklyn couple go in bathing at Coney Island on Aug. 27 in bathing rig and are found at Jacksonville, Fla., nearly four weeks afterward. This is the experience of Samuel W. Thornton and his sister- in-law, Eva Jewell, a Brooklyn lass of twenty-three Summers.

That the Government sitting in authority at Pekin is entitled to a proper recognition of its domestic necessities and liabilities, no fair-minded person should deny. This, however, is what it rarely receives from European or American censors. Whenever riotous demonstrations are made against missionaries or other aliens residing in the interior of the vast empire, it is too hastily alleged that the supreme rulers connive at the outbreaks, if they do not secretly instigate them.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 21. -- The Olympics scored a point to-day, and it will probably perpetuate glove fighting in New-Orleans, at least until the Legislature meets again in May. Mayor Shakespeare is absent, and J.G. Clark, President of the Council and of the Pickwick Club, who is personally opposed to prize fighting, is in charge of the executive department of the city.

Assemblyman Joseph Blumenthal of the Twenty-second Assembly District wants to go to Congress in place of Roswell F. Flower, resigned, from the Twelfth Congressional District, and he is hustling after the nomination. His candidacy is in the nature of a demand on Tammany to give him the place, and he thinks he will get it. He put the matter in this way yesterday:

The delegates and alternates who were sent to Saratoga by the County Democracy, and who were denied seats in the convention, met last night in the small meeting room of the Cooper Institute. No action was taken regarding the Democratic State ticket, but that the rank and file of the Counties will support it is the only impression that can be gained by talks with representative men in the organization.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Sir James Fergusson, Bart, Political Secretary of the Foreign Office, has been appointed to the office of Postmaster General, made vacant through the death of Henry Cecil Raikes.

The future of Mr. BLAINE continues to give the more zealous friends and organs of Mr. HARRISON much uneasiness. They are especially worried over the impenetrable reserve of the Secretary of State. They say that he is exposing himself to all sorts of misunderstanding which a word from him would prevent.

Rate cutting on east-bound freight, particularly grain via the lake and rail routes, is one one of the vexatious questions which Trunk Line Commissioner J.F. Goddard is trying to settle. Mr. Goddard has been in communication with some of the Western roads for several days, with a view to securing harmony of action if possible.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 21. -- It is now estimated that 4,000 persons will attend the meeting of the Republican State League in Scranton, Wednesday next, and already delegates and their friends are thronging the principal hotels of the city.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The Sixteenth Senatorial District Republicans held their convention in this city this afternoon. Its operations were controlled by the machine, and their slogan was, "Anything to beat Tappen." Mr. Tappen is the present Sheriff of this county, and has also been County Clerk. He wanted to go to the State Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The Attorney General was to-day advised of the filling at San Diego, Cal., of a second libel against the Chilean steamer Itata for $200,000 for damages against the vessel for escaping from the United States Marshal and for expenses incurred in her recapture. He, later in the day, directed the United States District Attorney to dismiss this second libel, and the Itata will be immediately released and free to resume traffic.

The Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Association met yesterday afternoon at its headquarters, at 146 Broadway. There were present Gen. C.H.T. Collis, the Chairman of the committee; A.B. Cornell, H.L. Hotchkiss, Edward M. Knox, A.L. Sanger, and Cornelius O'Reilly.

Mr. Richard Mansfield produced at the Garden Theatre last evening a tragic play in five acts, written in metred prose by Mr. Russell Sullivan, entitled "Nero." The play is largely taken from the two modern Italian poets, except the last scene, which is little more than an amplification of the account of Nero's death given by Suetonius.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The course of events in Haiti is being watched with unusual interest from Washington just now, and it can be said, on good authority, that at the first favorable opportunity negotiations for the acquisition of the Mole St. Nicholas will be renewed. The opportunity is expected to come with the insurrection which is understood to be brewing against the Government of Hippolyte.

YONKERS, Sept. 21. -- A pretty wedding took place this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, the contracting parties being Miss Jane Baldwin, daughter of Mrs. Eben Baldwin, Jr., of New-York, and Herbert Montague Linnell, formerly of Norwich, Conn., now of Montreal. The Rev. A. B. Carver officiated. The church was handsomely decorated with goldenrod and chrysanthemums.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Mr. Mills's speech at Mansfield, Ohio, in which he swept aside the silver question as one of no importance compared with the question of tariff taxation, has commanded a good deal of attention from the Washington politicians, who have been watching the course of things in Ohio.

Inspector BYRNES yesterday delivered one of his allocutions to the Police Captains, and a very sensible allocution it was. It turned upon the relation of the police to the work of street cleaning. This relation is very important, and it has been very much neglected since the business of street cleaning was withdrawn from the Police Department, which indeed mismanaged it more shamefully than it has ever been mismanaged before or since.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 21. -- The new Alvin Theatre, erected at a cost of over $200,000 by Charles L. Davis, (Alvin Joslyn,) was thrown open to the public to-night. The attraction was Miss Pauline Hall and her company in "La Belle Helene." The house was crowded.

The white cross of Lombardy floated its red and green folds proudly over the City Hall yesterday, and the Italian colony celebrated the twenty-first anniversary of the fall of the temporal power of the Pope with a big parade and a picnic. The parade, in which 5,000 men took part, was a glorious array of uniforms of nearly all colors, representing every corps in the real Italian Army.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21. -- The first day of the seventy-second Grand Encampment of the Sovereign Grand Lodge, I.O.O.F., opened with a heavy mist enveloping the city. The hot weather of the past week gave place to a somewhat cooler atmosphere, to the great delight of the thousands of Odd Fellows who participated in the parade this afternoon.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Sept. 21. -- Allerton went another mile in 2:09 14 to-day, thus putting an end to all dispute as to the stallion championship. The quarters were made in 0:32 14, 1:04 12, 1:37 14, and 2:09 14.

The Chapin third term Mayoralty boom has died. It was started on the cars when the delegates returned from the disastrous attempt to make him Governor, and it grew from a spirit of sympathy for the young man. Yesterday this frenzy was all over. The men who have been most enthusiastic for the Mayor said that they doubted if he would accept a renomination.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- An important bank robbery has taken place in the City. The police and bank officials are trying to keep the matter as quiet as possible, so that the entire facts in the case are not obtainable at present. It is known, however, that the institution that has suffered is the London and Westminster Bank, Limited, 41 Lathbury, E.C., an important establishment having over fifteen branch houses in this city.

THE TIMES is indebted to a gentleman from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, for information regarding the New-York Life Insurance Company, and the effect produced by THE TIME'S exposures of Mr. Beers's mismanagement, The daily exposures well-nigh produced a panic -- but papers paid to publish puffs and laud Mr. Beers and company, played their usual role in Brazil.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 22.--District Attorney Graham to-day made public the now-famous McCaman-Livesey-Bardsley correspondence. It is the same correspondence with which Mr. Graham sought to establish eases against the Auditor General and State Treasurer. The letters, the authorities think, plainly show that there was collusion between McCamant and Bardsley in procuring rebates from certain newspapers for the Mercantile Appraiser's advertising.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The northeast gales which have been causing so much damage in England and Scotland have grown worse instead of calming down. The latest news received as to the damage done is that a number of coasting vessels have been driven ashore and lost between the Tyne and the Forth. At Eyemouth, near Berwick, Scotland, a large number of houses have been flooded.

CAMDEN N.J., Sept. 22. -- The taking of testimony in the Miller murder case before Master in Chancery Vroom this morning was brought to a sudden termination by the arrest of John O. Campbell, the alleged detective, on a charge of perjury, preferred by Mary Collins. A squabble ensued between counsel for Lingo and Prosecutor Jenks, but Campbell was committed to prison by Justice Cassaday.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 22. -- Ten days ago Victor and Louis M. Schlacter, brothers, doing a grocery business as Victor Schlacter Co., voluntarily assigned, with liabilities estimated at $8,000.

GUTHRIE, O.T., Sept. 22. -- The long-expected hour has arrived, and the agony is practically over. At noon to-day the west border of the Territory, some sixty miles, was a continuous line of people, there being groups of 400 or 500 every five or six miles.

The -ew-Yorks and Phtladelphtas played two nmes at The Polo Grounds yesterday and broke ovum "Smiling fickey" %Veloh pitched in the first game for the t%lants, and the way he showed up was surprising to the cranks I led %hem to ask all orr. s of questions concerning tile club's management in keeping him on the bench and not allowing him to lwirl the sphere.

PARIS, Sept. 7.--Fashion hints were never so late as now. Last Winter ran into the promise of a Summer, and we are still awaiting warm days and sunshine, with the tree boughs already in their yellow leaves, and the tedious ouvrier hard at work furnace mending and chimney cleaning.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22. -- The first dinner of the season of 1891-2 of the Democratic Club of Connecticut was held in this city to-night. The attendance included such representative men as Prof. Simeon E. Baldwin of the Yale Law School, Mayor Sargent of New-Haven, ex-Mayor Morgan of Bridgeport, President Read of the State Senate, State Senators Seymour and Holden, and Representative Callahan of this city, Gov. Luzon B. Morris was unable to be present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- It begins to look as if President Harrison was about to try the temper of the country by favoring a policy of acquisition, in the hope of infusing something like spirit into the record of his Administration.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22. -- The St. Louis Stamping Works, the great concern of the Niedringhaus Brothers, apostles and self-styled pioneers of tin-plate making in the United States under the McKinley tariff, has succeeded in importing ten Welsh workmen, but the men have not gone to work.
Efforts are making in Texas to produce rain at will by the explosion of balloons in midair; a Chicago man offers, with the approval and through the aid of Government,...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Messrs. Mendenhall and Merriam, who were sent out to the seal islands of Alaska to ascertain for President Harrison whether preceding agents of the Government who had recommended that the killing of seals at the islands be stopped had reported truly, have been at home some time, but the public has not yet been informed as to the nature of their discoveries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- S.V. White's failure was forecast on Monday by a great many people around the Board of Trade, and after the close it was whispered through the offices that unless some great stroke of good luck saved him the rich Brooklyn man would be crushed before morning. Consequently, the news of the failure, which came at the opening, did not cause as much of a shock as it otherwise would.

SALEM, Mass., Sept 22. -- The hearing in the Searles will case was opened in the Probate Court this morning. It is on petition of the executor for the allowance of the will. The executor was represented by Solomon Lincoln, Frederick Dodge, William Allen Butler, and Richard Dodge. Timothy Hopkins was in court with his counsel -- W.C. Endicott, E.T. Burleigh, and Judge J.H. Boalt.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 22. -- The remains of William L. Scott arrived in Erie to-day. The casket was taken from the station to the old Tracy homestead, in which Mr. Scott and his wife had spent their married life. The face of the deceased was very natural. The city buildings, public buildings, and private houses floated their colors at half-mast.

All those who are lovers of pretty things in millinery, dress goods, wraps, and cloaks have had an opportunity of gratifying their tastes at Ehrich Brothers', Sixth Avenue, Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets, the last few days, and can do so from now on. The firm held its Fall opening yesterday and Monday, and the opening will continue to-day. A large variety of new dress goods for evening wear is shown.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 22. -- The heat reached such a degree of intensity to-day that it was almost unbearable, and Superintendent Gilbert issued a general order closing all public schools, giving the 20,000 children a holiday until cooler weather shall arrive.

The suspension of Messrs. S.V. WHITE, CO., the head of which firm is the famous "Deacon WHITE," whatever inconveniences it may entail upon those immediately concerned, is likely to be of some value to the country at large. The immediate consequences, so far as can now be judged, do not threaten to be very serious.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- The Dix Neuriene Siecle publishes a dispatch from a correspondent in Baden giving the substance of a speech which it is claimed was made by the Grand Duke of Baden at the close of the recent maneuvres of the Southwest Army. According to this dispatch, the Grand Duke said:

It is not to be inferred from the protest and warning adopted on Monday evening by the delegates of the County Democracy to the Saratoga Convention that the organization has any fault to find with the platform or the ticket of the party. Consequently there is no reason to suppose that the County Committee, to which this document was referred, will do otherwise than give its approval to both.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- At the opening of the Unitarian Conference in the Town Hall this morning, the communion service was conducted by the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale of Boston. The hall was crowded with delegates. At 10 o'clock the conference was regularly opened by Secretary George Batcheller of Boston, who introduced the Hon. George William Curtis of New-York, the new President.

The official trial of the Howell torpedo may be looked for in the course of three or four weeks. This torpedo, an invention of Capt. John A. Howell of the navy, will be brought into a competitive test with the English Whitehead. The result of the trial will determine whether Howell or Whitehead torpedoes shall be adopted for American war ships.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- The printed list of rooms for rent outalde of the college buildings lssl)ed a year ago by the committee on the reception oi students of Harvard University, of which Prof. N. S. Shaler is Chairman, proved of such assistance to She students that this Fall a roular pamlyhlct is in course of preparation by the committee, and is expected to be ready for distribution the latter part of thls week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 22. -- The Thornton-Jewell "Munchausen" story of rescue from the sea has dwindled down to a common story of how a married man ran off with his pretty sister-in-law. Instead of being landed here from a Spanish bark, after adventures that would rival those of one of Jules Verne's heroes, the two persons came here from New-Orleans in a palace car, occupying the same berth.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 22. -- Representative Roger Q. Mills of Texas addressed about 5,000 Columbus voters to-night. There was quite a number of Republicans in the audience, and the closest attention was given to the speaker during the entire two hours of his address.

After a quarter of a century of activity, prominence, and influence in Wall Street, S.V. White was yesterday obliged to acknowledge his inability to meet financial obligations. Two millions of dollars are involved in the failure.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 22. -- The action of the Republican Party managers in this city last Fall in buying from two corrupt Democratic Tax Collectors a large number of tax receipts, and the subsequent notion of the Collectors in returning these taxables as errors and failing to turn the money into the County Treasury, is now under investigation by a committee of the Levy Court.

NIAGARA FALLS, Sept. 22. -- Mrs. Dell Rathbun of 70 Pearl Street, Buffalo, committed suicide at Cedar Island, on the Canadian side, near the Michigan Central Railway Station of Falls View, shortly after 6 o'clock this morning.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 22. -- Aug. 27 THE TIMES published a dispatch telling how the Seattle Telegraph, the Democratic organ of the State of Washington, had declared for Cleveland for President in 1892. That dispatch and the editorial comment of THE TIMES have evidently attracted wide attention in the East, for the Telegraph has received many letters and newspaper clippings commendatory, congratulatory, or critical. Several of them it has published.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 22. -- The twenty-fourth annual festival of the Worcester County Musical Association, which began here to-day, promises to be in almost every respect a decided advance from those of former years.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Kansas City last night says: "M. Knight, Freight Traffic Manager of the Wabash Railroad; S.B. Knight, Freight Agent of the Wabash, and M.B. McClellan, General Freight Agent of the Lehigh and Wabash Freight Line, were indicted by the United States District Grand Jury to-day for discriminations against small shippers contrary to the inter-State commerce law.

AFTON, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- In spite of the oppressive heat a large crowd met on the grounds of the Afton Agricultural Association to-day to listen to the joint tariff discussion between the Hon. John E. Russell of Massachusetts and D.G. Harriman of Brooklyn. From early morning the roads leading to Afton were crowded with wagons filled with tax-ridden farmers and their wives, "out for a holiday and information."

The prospects seem good that California will get several hundred "assisted emigrants" from Germany and England during the next year, yet no one objects. They are bird colonists and are coming to warble in the hedges and to eat pestiferous bugs from orchards and vineyards. Early in November the advance guard of songsters will be here.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Fire to-night destroyed the New-Jersey Athletic Club's Viking boathouse and contents, on the Bayonne shore of Newark Bay. There had been two incendiary attempts recently, and to-night's fire was of that origin. The house was worth $1,500 and was fully insured. Twenty canoes and five St. Lawrence skiffs were consumed, also equipments and property in twenty lockers.

The people living near St. James's Cathedral, in Jay Street, Brooklyn, were aroused about 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning by the cries of a lot of negroes who had discovered a bright light in the vestry. In less than five minutes there was a big crowd around the church, and two boys, John and Isaac O'Connor, went into the vestry and caught three men who had hidden themselves behind a door.

Proof copies of the new "Instructions for Infantry and Artillery, United States Navy," are at hand. The new instructions will be ready shortly for general distribution to the navy. They have been prepared under the direction of the Bureau of Navigation by Commander Charles M. Thomas, Lieuts. C.E. Calahan and W.F. Fullam, Ensign F.J. Haeseler, all of the navy, and First Lieut. L.W.V. Kennon, United States Army.

Unless something unforeseen arises the United States gunboat cruiser Yorktown, now fitting out at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for duty on the Pacific station, will be ready to start on her journey around the Horn inside of two weeks.

PITTBURG, Sept. 22. -- A special from Butler, Penn., says: "The Butler County Bank of Millerstown, owned by H.J. Hoyt, suspended payment a week ago, but has not closed Its doors. The deposits aggregate only $26,450, and Mr. Hoyt says that his assets amount to $30,000, and that, If he can obtain assistance for a few days he will be able to pull through.

Mr. George W. Perkins of the Rookery Buildings, Chicago, an agent of the New-York Life Insurance Company, is sending out circulars to that company's policy holders. Two of his circulars have been received at the office of THE TIMES in addition to Mr. Perkins's earlier circular, with a wood out of President Beers, in which Mr. Perkins asked his readers if the President of the New-York Life looked like a bad man.
Is it possible to imagine anything worse than the mismanagement of the New-York Life Insurance Company.

It is interesting to learn that the European agent of the Standard Oil Company has prepared a report in order to disabuse the German Government of the notion that that corporation is aiming at a monopoly. The agent declares that the policy of the company is "simply that of competitive commerce" and denies that it acts in collusion with the Russian producers, "or any combination to exact an artificial price."

BUFFALO, Sept. 22 -- Archbishop Katzer of Milwaukee, whose ecclesiastical promotion in America is justly or unjustly asserted to have been aided by the present German Emperor's Ambassador at Rome, was the dignitary who to-day formally opened the German-American Catholic Congress as celebrant of pontifical high mass.

NEWARK, Sept. 22. -- The children who attend the Lafayette Street public school were trooping through Prospect Street on their way to their desks, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, when their attention was arrested by the movements of three men and a well-dressed woman. One of the men drove a carriage into Prospect Street, and near the corner of Elm came to a halt in the middle of the street.

It is evident that the Republicans of Connecticut have no intention of doing anything to promote the settlement of the longstanding election dispute in that State by judicial decision. The Legislature will meet again in November, and they are credited with a determination to keep up the tactics of last Spring and to hold on to the State offices.

Sixty-two bookmakers were in the ring at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday, ready to do business on the six races that were run. They had plenty of business and could not well have helped making money, for of the favorites in the races but three. Contribution in the first race, La Tosca in the third, and Sir John in the fourth were successful, the other races going to rank outsiders in the betting.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 23. -- The indictment of another Cabinet Minister at Ottawa has intensified the growing feeling of distrust in the present Administration at Ottawa, and this feeling is not lessened by the announcement made this morning by the Globe, chief opposition organ in the Dominion, which, after remarking that the deeper Parliament digs the more numerous scandals become, says:

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Counsel on behalf of the Chilean Government to-day applied to Justice Jeune to restrain the Mail Packet Company, owning the steamship Moselle, from parting with $750,000 in bullion, brought from Montevideo recently, except to the Bank of England for storage purposes. The same counsel also asked the Justice to forbid the Bank of the River Plate from parting with certain documents referring to this bullion.

In his report to the Mayor on the contamination of the water supply of this city, Commissioner GILROY claims that the actual effect of pollution upon the Croton water is slight, and that the supply is still exceptionally pure compared with that of other cities. But this is not enough. It has been shown that causes of pollution are at work all through the Croton Valley, and are increasing almost without restraint.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 23. -- The harvest festival and industrial parade held in Minneapolis today was pronounced the most magnificent affair of its kind in the history of America. It was absolutely unique. It combined the splendor of the Mardi-Gras with the most complete exemplification of the agricultural, industrial, commercial, manufacturing, and aesthetic progress of the vast Northwest.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 23. -- As the 12th of October draws near, the date set apart for the discussion of reciprocal trade relations between the United States and the Dominion by Mr. Blaine and the Canadian Commissioners, the interest in the country at largo is again excited as to the outcome of this vital question.

The statement by a member of the Utah Commission that "polygamy is dying out" in the Territory accords with the reports of other observers and with the action of the Mormon Church. When the Church finally and publicly gave up polygamy the institution was manifestly doomed, because the leaders of any community cannot present themselves to their own people as hypocrites.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 23. -- At 6 o'clock this evening Dr. Benjamin G. Bruce, editor of the Live Stock Record, died at his home here of apoplexy, aged sixty-three years. He was a brother of Col. Sanders D. Bruce, whom he not only assisted in founding the Turf, Field, and Farm, but also in compiling and publishing the two first volumes of the "American Stud Book."

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Republican Judiciary Convention for the Fifth District resumed its session here this morning. The twenty-fifth informal ballot showed no material change from the vote of yesterday. On the twenty-eighth ballot Wright of Oswego increased his vote to 13, or six less than a majority, but on the thirty-eighth ballot he dropped to 6, and on the forty-third temporarily disappeared from the contest.

" Deacon" S.V. White's assignee, Charles W. Gould, had men at work all day yesterday on the books of the White firm, but the results of their labors were not enough to put him in a position to make any definite statement as to the condition of affairs. Mr. White was at his office for a part of the day, but he went home about noon.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 23. -- "Ninety-four in the shade, 112 in the sun," was the tale told by Twin City thermometers at noon to-day. The wind was blowing almost a gale, too, but it could not have been hotter if coming directly over the scorching sands of Sahara. The public schools are still closed, and probably will not be opened again until next week.

Many holders of policies in the New-York Life Insurance Company have asked THE TIMES to advise them whether they ought to sell their policies, let them lapse, or continue to pay the annual premiums, taking their chances of the company's utlimate rescue from the hands of its present unworthy managers.

Mr. D. CADY HERRICK of Albany has an honorable ambition to be elected to the bench of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial District of this State. There is no question that he is qualified for the place, nor is there any question that his nomination would be favorably received by the people of the district.

The offer by the American Yacht Club of a prize of $500 for a race between the Cushing, Stiletto, Javelin, Now Then, Norwood, and Vamoose was the principal topic of conversation yesterday among yachtsmen. There was only one opinion on the subject, namely, that the race, if it can be arranged, would be one of the grandest yachting events the world had ever seen.

The hearing before the Park Commissioners yesterday on the question of ousting the elevated railroad from Battery Park closed the case for the people, and the matter is now in the hands of the Commissioners for their decision. The case against the people's claim for a restoration of the park to its proper use, as presented before the Park Board, was singularly weak.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 23. -- The second day of the Searles will case opened with a big crowd present in the court room. The examination of Mr. Searles was continued by Mr. Burley.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Sept. 23. -- The Fall term of Rutgers College opened to-day with eighty-seven freshmen present and all the Faculty, including the new professors. Lieut. Smiley is here giving points to his successor, Lieut. J.J. Brereton, who for the next three years will be the military instructor, and introducing him to the students.

Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy sent a long report to the Mayor's office yesterday on the condition of the supply in the Croton watershed and the way to prevent contamination. It was in the way of an answer to a communication sent to him by Mayor Grant, which included a resolution of the Board of Health, passed Aug. 25, calling the Mayor's attention to the contamination of the water supply from various sources.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The devotional exercises of the Unitarian Conference were conducted this morning by the Rev. Mary A. Safford of Sioux City, Iowa, after which the subject of church extension was further discussed by the Rev. D.W. Morehouse, Secretary of the Middle States and Canada Conference, Rev. Dr. Horatio Stebbins of San Francisco for the Pacific Coast, and the Rev. George L. Chaney for the South.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 23. -- After a day of excitement Congressman John B. Robinson of Delaware County was chosen President of the Republican State League this evening. The vote stood as follows: Robinson, 141 clubs; Dalzell, 42 clubs, and Warren, 15 clubs, each club being entitled to three votes.

The Inman Line steamship City of New-York, which arrived at her dock last night several hours over her schedule time, brought a number of delegates to the Ecumenical Conference, which is to meet in Washington Oct. 7. A large number came by the City of Chicago last week.

There exist at present eleven vacancies in the grade of Third Lieutenant, United States Revenue Marine. Some of these vacancies have been open for nearly a year. Since the convening of a board last May and the taking on at that time of seven Annapolis graduates, no attempt has been made by the Secretary of the Treasury to fill the vacant numbers.

The notorious Gibbs, whom Platt will need in this campaign, was restored to full leadership by the Republican organization in the Thirteenth Assembly District last night. Gibbs was expelled from the County Committee a year ago on the ground that his action with Hamilton Fish and others in the Legislature of 1890 had made him a traitor to his party.

It is expected that a meeting of the Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad will be held to-day for the purpose of taking some action relative to the quarterly dividend, which, according to custom, should have been declared a week ago. A story was current in Wall Street yesterday that the dividend would either be passed or reduced from the usual 1 per cent., owing to Mr. Gould's ultra-conservatism.

PLAINFIELD, Conn., Sept. 23. -- This State, especially this section of it, is up in arms, getting ready for the town elections, which take place Oct. 5. All town officers and Election Boards for 1892 will then be elected, and each city and town will settle whether or not license to sell intoxicants will be granted for the coming year.

Commissioner RAUM, in his recent letter to Congressman ENOCHS of Ohio, reiterates that the pension mill, under his urgent efforts, is turning out 30,000 certificates per month, and that the limit he has set himself for the current year is 350,000. At that rate it can hardly take many years to use up all the available material.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- The MacQueary heresy case is at last ended. The reverend gentleman has given up the contesting of the Bishop's sentence, and accepted the alternative of resignation. A letter to this effect was to-day forwarded, and its acknowledgment by the ecclesiastical powers will conclude the case.

Work on the excavations for the new charity administration building, which Mr. John S. Kennedy is to erect for the use of the allied charities of this city, is fairly under way. The building, of which R.H. Robertson and Rowe Baker are the architects, is to to occupy the site of the old St. Paul Methodist Episcopal Church, at Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Not long ago a Republican politician who took a leading part in the last campaign, and who was then convinced that the protection issue, owing to the "unfortunate" projection by Mr. Blaine of his reciprocity plan, was no longer to be of use to the Republicans, and no longer sufficient to hold the voters, who had seen the policy practically abandoned by one of the most popular leaders.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23. -- In accordance with instructions from the Navy Department at Washington to thoroughly test the merits of the new "Zeise screw propeller," the running launch Annie, attached to the training station, was equipped with one of these latest inventions and it was given an official trial this morning.

DES MOINES, Sept. 23. -- A short time ago the Republican State Central Committee pulled Van Houten, the candidate for Lieutenant Governor, off the stump and sent him home to his Taylor County farm. It was a wise thing to do, but, driven to recklessness by the Democratic press for having candidates who cannot be trusted to discuss the issues, the committee has undone its action and has turned Van Houten loose again.

ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- Judge William L. Learned will retire from the Supreme Court bench Dec. 31, after having represented the Third District faithfully for fourteen years. To-day the Democratic Judicial Convention to name his successor was held in this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- About 800 students assembled in Marquand Chapel at 3 o'clock this afternoon to listen to President Patton's address opening the one hundred and forty-sixth year of Princeton University. More students than usual were prompt in returning. The freshmen came because they thought it the proper thing to do.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- The single-tax people of St. Louis are in a high state of indignation. Some time ago they were granted by the Mayor a general permit to hold open-air meetings, and for a time these took place two or three nights a week on Twelfth Street, near the Grant Statue, but they were not a great success.
CAMBRIDGE CITY, Ind., Sept. 23. -- At the races here to-day Nelson, the famous Maine stallion, trotted against the mile record, accompanied by a runner. He covered the distance in 2:10 1/2.

Senator ALLISON has a peculiar way of arguing to the farmers of Iowa. He is trying to convince them that raising corn is a profitable business, and that those engaged in it can afford to contribute to increase the profits of manufacturers, because the return can be figured out as equal to 11 1-3 per cent. on the capital invested.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23. -- The results of the second day of the music festival at this place have been disappointing. This is simply explained. The principal interest of the day centered in the production of "The Repentance of Nineveh," the dramatic oratorio written by Dr. J. Frederick Bridges, organist of Westminster Abbey, for last year's festival at Worcester, England. Much was expected, but little was received.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 23. -- Passengers leaving the passenger station of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Jersey City this morning were attracted by a great gathering of gentlemen, smoothly shaven, and wearing high hats, with their coats decorated with a satin badge bearing these words: "Dedication Tammany Monument, Gettysburg, Sept. 24, 1891."

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The Rothschilds, Speyers, Lazard Brothers, and other bankers all agree in their statements that further large shipments of gold are going to America. The Rothschilds dispatched an additional 100,000 to-day. The chief clerk of this house said that it was uncertain whether France would make the bulk of the gold exports or whether the burden would fall on England.

When Samuel W. Thornton and Miss Eva Jewell return from their little trip to Florida tomorrow they will be cordially welcomed to their home in Brooklyn. William Thornton, who has been managing the bakeshop and taking care of his missing brother's supposed widow, said yesterday that nothing could shake his belief in Sam's integrity and truthfulness.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 23. -- The annual meeting of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Association Saturday next promises to be the best ever held in Canada, and local athletes look for lowering important records. The interest in the games is largely international, as prominent athletes from the United States have been entered to contest thirteen of the fourteen events.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- During the last few days visitors have been attracted to a bust of Lowell by the sculptor, Partridge, who has dealt with a more than ordinarily difficult task, having missed the advantage of studies from life. Mr. Partridge visited Elmwood hoping to obtain a mask, but the objections of friends prevented this.

The members of the board recently engaged in formulating new drill instructions for the navy are deemed to be among the best infantry officers in the navy. Commander Charles M. Thomas, the senior member of the board, is conceded to be one of the ablest men in the service in the handling of a naval brigade.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 23. -- After ten days of deliberation the County Commissioners to-day resolved to pay over to the Wheeling Bridge and Terminal Railroad Company the third installment of $100,000, due on account of the construction of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Company's line from Bowerston, Ohio, by the city, payment of which to the Terminal Company the Wheeling and Lake Erie has been resisting.

The recent semi-annual report of the New-York Life Insurance Company to the State of Georgia, bearing the affidavit of Son-in-law Henry Tuck, demands some attention. An affidavit is supposed to be a solemn statement of fact, duly sworn to in the presence of a notary public. An untrue statement in such a document constitutes perjury.

Orders from the Treasury Department were received at the Custom House yesterday to resume reliquidations in the hat-trimming cases, provided the importers interested dropped their suits against the Government. This does not apply to the few articles affected by a recent decision in Philadelphia, in a raised case which the Government won.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- An effort was made to-day to ascertain positively whether the men brought here by Niedringhaus signed a contract before leaving the old country, but it was very evident that the men had all been carefully coached in what they were to say. Their statements are apparently the same which enabled them to successfully pass through the office of Immigration Inspector O'Beirne in New-York.

When a man is "Head of the Commercial Department and Controller of Corn Returns of the British Board of Trade," the real importance of his functions is so great that he may be pardoned if his successful performance of them leads him to think that he can go outside of them with equal success and authority.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 23. -- A special from Marysville, Mo., says: "Ex-Gov. Albert P. Morehouse committed suicide at his residence at 9 o'clock this morning.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 23. -- The Hon. Hervey Watterson, the venerable father of the editor of the Courier-Journal, is lying at the point of death at the residence of his son in this city. He is the sole survivor of the Twenty-sixth Congress, having been the youngest member of that body, and during the years of his active, life he was a distinguished figure in national politics.

Col. Henry S. Olcott, President of the Theosophical Society of the world, made his appearance in this city last evening, having arrived by the City of New-York from England, en route to Japan. At the Astor House he talked to the reporters in a highly-entertaining way of the occult science of which he is, since the death of Mme. Blavatsky, the foremost representative.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The devotional exercises in the Unitarian National Conference were conducted this morning by the Rev. S.H. Camp of Brooklyn. In The absence of the President, George William Curtis. Dorman B. Eaton presided. After the reading of a favorable report from the Committee on the Endowment of the Meadville Theological School, the Rev. H.N. Brown, the Chairman, read the report of the Liturgical Committee.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The religious marriage of Miss Jennie Urquhart, sister of Mrs. James Brown Potter, to M. Rene Raoul Dural, was solemnized this afternoon in the French Protestant Church of L'Etoile, in the Avenue de la Grand Armee, which edifice was built in 1874, chiefly at the expense of the Duval family. Pastor Picard officiated, and Col. Urquhart, the bride's father, gave the bride away.

The New Yorks played the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday and suffered defeat. That is nothing unusual for the Giants nowadays. They are used to it; so is the baseball public. Rusle pitched and he did splendidly. Buckley caught him in good style. But their combined effort were useless. The men back of them could not bat. Two safe hits were the extent of their stick work.

The enlargement of Plattsburg Barracks, which was authorized last Winter by Congress, and is now being arranged, will probably result in giving this post one of the strongest garrisons in the United States, and perhaps the most extensive in the East. The frank avowal of the purpose of this change is also interesting.

The agents of the Western Union Telegraph Company had more trouble in getting the news away from the Brooklyn Club's track yesterday than on any day in a long time. That they failed to secure the desired information was due to fear of arrest by the operators who hang around outside the inclosure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker has had a commission at work for some time looking into the operation of the Post Offices in the principal cities, with a view to ascertaining the needs of the offices and making the department acquainted with their efficiency, and the course that should be pursued to make them more responsive to the demands upon them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- George E. Leighton, John F. Plummer, Jesse Spalding, Rufus B. Bullock, and Joseph W. Paddock, the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railway Company, have filed with the Secretary of the Interior their annual report, as follows:...
ALBANY, Sept. 24. -- A debate has been precipitated between the Hill and anti-Hill Democrats over the wording of the silver plank in the platform adopted by the Saratoga Convention.

There was a mass meeting at West Bergen, N.J., last night in the interest of a good water supply. It was heralded with bonfires and fireworks. It was presided over by R.E. Jennings, President of the West Bergen Improvement Association. The speakers were the Rev. John L. Scudder, Major Z.L. Pangborn, W. II. Beach, and S.L Harvey.

In the article in THE TIMES of the 21st inst. entitled "With Mr. Platt in Power," you well say that many independent voters "will candidly weigh the merits and the demerits of each candidate and each party, picture forth by the light of experience and individual judgment the near and remote consequences of the election of the one or of the other candidate, and will vote in accordance with their conclusions."

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24. -- The American composer made himself heard at the music festival to-day, and, on the whole, with happy results. The afternoon concert was given over to his work. The first number was C.F. Adams's mass in C minor, which was followed by E.A. Macdowell's suite in A minor, Whitney Coombs's song, "The Heavenly Message," and Victor Herbert's cantata, "The Captive."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The net cash balance in the Treasury to-day is $43,745,458. Of this amount $17,270,302 is subsidiary silver coin, $13,699,228 is deposited in national bank depositories, and $364,835 is minor coin and fractional currency. The receipts of the Government thus far during the month from customs, internal revenue, , have exceeded the expenditures (aside from the redemption of bonds) by $2,300,000 in round numbers.

Pension Commissioner RAUM has submitted his annual report, covering the fiscal year ending with June 30, to the Secretary of the Interior. It shows that twenty-six years after the close of our last war the number of pensioners is still increasing with great rapidity and the amount of money disbursed for pensions is continually growing larger.

The Ladies' Cycling Club of New-York is a new organization whose name implies the club's intent. It held a meeting yesterday afternoon at headquarters, 108 West Fifty-ninth Street, and took into membership six more women, raising the total now enrolled to nineteen. There are no fees and no articles to subscribe to except the articles of uniform in which the club members will appear when they go out for a spin.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, Sept. 24. -- There was a large attendance at the second day's convention of Democratic clubs of Washington. Henry Drum of Tacoma was elected President and George Hazard of Tacoma Secretary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. -- Residents along the borders of the Yosemite National Park reservation are greatly enraged at the United States troops on the reservation. It is quite likely that complaint will be lodged against soldiers soon at army headquarters, either in this city or at Washington.

COSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 24. -- The Porte has sent a circular to the powers in regard to the passage through the Dardanelles of several vessels of the Russian volunteer fleet. In this communication the Porte says that for several years past vessels of the Russian volunteer fleet have been running between Odessa and Vladivostock, the port intended to be the eastern terminus of the Trans-Siberian Railroad, and situated on the Sea of Japan.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Sept. 24. -- The recent reunion at Lena, Ill., of the survivors of the battle of Keilogg's Grove, in the Black Hawk war, brings up an interesting question as to where is the final resting place of the bones of the great Indian warrior.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- At a Republican rally in Amesbury to-night, Mr. Allen, the Republican candidate for Governor, made a speech. He devoted himself to the task of showing, as he put it, "What voting for a Democrat for public office in Massachusetts means."

Mr. MATTHEW HALE'S letter to THE TIMES is an instructive and useful contribution to the discussion of the issues of the campaign. It is a contest in which the conscientious voter encounters many perplexities. It calls for a candid measurement of candidates and principles. It demands an unusually patient inquiry as to the facts, for full information is beyond question the voter's best safeguard against mistakes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 24. -- Never in the criminal annals of this State was an important murder case brought to such a sudden and abrupt termination as was that of the State against John Moran, the trial of which began in the Davidson County Criminal Court yesterday afternoon and ended this morning. Moran was charged with the murder of Miss Mary Ann Dolan at his home in this city on Jan. 26 last.

Many of President Beers's deputies have made records for themselves. That there are able and honest men in their employ, and honest agents, goes without saying, but a belief is current that the men of doubtful character have the most influence with President Beers. When, as Trustees, they occupy the position so accurately described by him as "being under his thumb," they are just where he wants them.

The blow given to the stock market yesterday by the fall in Missouri Pacific was about as plain a case of "rigging" as we have been called upon to notice in a long time. There have, of course, been instances enough of this peculiar "business," but the existing conditions have limited their extent and their effect.

Gov. Leon Abbett of New-Jersey was "in the hands of his friends" at College Point, L.I., yesterday. The occasion was the second excursion of the season given by the Dennis McLaughlin Association of Jersey City, and one of the chief objects of the outing was to advance the political standing of Gov. Abbett. According to the man who furnished dinner for the crowd there were 1,802 persons present. They came from Jersey City.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept. 24. -- The action of Secretary Noble in selecting the town site of Chandler and of his subordinates in inspecting the site and reporting favorably upon it will prove the direct cause of the deaths of dozens of men and women in that rocky, desolate place, where water is almost as scarce as in the Yuma Desert.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 24. -- The Seventy-second Regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteers, which has been permitted by the Supreme Court of this State to place a monument on ground that does not belong to it, was doubly censured to-day during the proceedings attending the unveiling of the Tammany monument.

DUBLIN, Sept. 24. -- At a meeting of the McCarthy committee in Dublin to-day, in addition to the decisions cabled yesterday it was resolved that the committee should act henceforth with the Finance Committee of the party. Messrs. McCarthy, Sexton, and Dillon were appointed trustees to receive and disburse money under instructions from the committee.

The Executive Committee of the Cowie Sprague faction of the Republicans in the Thirteenth Assembly District met last night in Alaska Hall, 292 Eighth Avenue, and indorsed the Republican State ticket. The course of the meeting indicated that with the exception of their feeling as to the State ticket the Republicans in the district were by no means harmonious.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Public interests which have been permitted to suffer all Summer without a Board of Health will now receive tardy attention. Several months ago the discovery that the old board had no legal existence was first made public by THE TIMES. The new administration moved slowly, but finally passed an ordinance remedying matters of organization.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24. -- Lieut. Col. John Upham of the Third United States Cavalry and Miss Caroline H. Williams, daughter of the late Henry and Caroline Williams, were married last evening at St. Paul's Church in this city. The wedding was a military one, and the colors used at the church and at the house, where a dinner was given later, were those of the cavalry.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The interest the people of Newark take in the contest between themselves and the bosses for the Mayoralty was amply demonstrated by the throngs that packed the big halls in which the two City Conventions met to-night. The bosses got their heelers together at Saenger Hall, on Belmont Avenue.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 24. -- In the magnificent harvest festival parade of yesterday, one of the most admired displays was that of the City Fire Department. Within less than twenty-four hours after that parade the city has been threatened with great disaster, and only after the most daring efforts of the department, and after serious injury to several of the brave firemen, was the threatened disaster averted.

The French war ship Naiade, flying the flag of Rear Admiral the Cavalier de Cuverville, arrived in this port shortly before noon yesterday. The Naiade made her appearance off Sandy Hook in the early morning. She steamed slowly up to Quarantine, underwent the usual inspection of the Health Officer, and proceeded under the guidance of a pilot to an anchorage in North River.

In a recent memorial to the Emperor of China the Viceroy, Li Hung Chang, describes the work which has been done to render passable one of the great trade highways of China. The pass reading from Nankow is one of the great thoroughfares connecting Pekin with Mongolia and the southern parts of the empire and is well known to most visitors to the Great Wall, through which the road passes.

QUINCY, Ky., Sept. 24. -- The most horrible tragedy that ever occurred in Lewis County took place near the mouth of Kinniconick Creek to-day. Thomas Carr, a farmer, aged thirty years, cut the throats of his wife and his mother-in-law. Then he cut his own throat. His weapon was a large corn knife.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sep. 24. -- The Republicans held their State Convention here to-day. It was attended by delegates from every county in the State but one, and, while the contest for the nomination for Judge of the Supreme Court has usually no significance, this was an exception.

On the evidence of Cammilla Deline, an eleven-year-old girl, who declared that she saw Joseph Preroto and his sister-in-law, Louisa Preroto, stab Antonio Rossa, the woman was taken into custody by the police yesterday. The child asserts that as she was leaving a candy store at 82 Mulberry Street she saw Joseph and Louisa Preroto steal up behind Rossa and stab him with their knives.

BUFFALO, Sept. 24. -- A clever stroke to-day marked the final session of the Priesten Verein, or German-American Clerical Union. A nonmember, and one who speaks German fluently, was taken into the meeting at its beginning and had an opportunity to see it through to close. As if to make the action still more remarkable, the outsider was an Irishman, Father O'Byrne of St. Nicholas's Church, this city.
The disappearance of two little girls in Brooklyn, under circumstances so strange as to leave no apparent clue to work upon, is engaging the attention of the people in that city and also in New-York.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Another crowded court room greeted the opening of the third day of the Searles will contest. The examination of Mr. Searles was continued.

On Wednesday a citizen took several bunches of Concord grapes to the Health Department and called attention to a green substance that clung to the stems of the bunches directly under the grapes. It was pale green and looked like paris green. The grapes were sent to Mr. Ernest Lederle, acting chemist of the board, for analysis.

The Republican managers of Ohio are more sensible than those of Massachusetts. On the 8th of October will occur the first of a series of debates between Major MCKINLEY and Gov. CAMPBELL, which promise to be among the most interesting and important incidents of this year's campaign. Both men are accustomed to debate, and have met each other on the floor of the House of Representatives.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- An interview to-day with Speaker Paige of the Connecticut House of Representatives confirms the belief, generally entertained, that there will be no settlement of the Gubernatorial controversy through the Legislature. Mr. Paige was positive there would be no break in the Republican majority in the House.

John S. Fitzgerald, who said that he was twenty-seven years old and a bookeeper and resided in Brooklyn, went yesterday into the office of James Walsh, the money broker, at 5 Wall Street, and offered for sale a bar of gold weighing 13-49 ounces. It bore the United States Assay Office stamp showing that it was 997 fine and was worth $278.03.

The Manhattan Railway Company seems to have gathered from this city and the adjacent country something like 2,000 names to a petition to the Park Board against the removal of the elevated railroad from Battery Park, and it makes a display of this motley and miscellaneous list as a paid advertisement at some little cost.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Italian celebration on Boyden Street of the entry of the Italian Army into Rome ended here to-night in a catastrophe that may cost a half dozen lives. Already three are dead and Capt. McManus says that seventeen are injured, although other reports indicate a much larger number of injured.

So far as the ordinary business man is concerned, the sworn statements of the insurance companies from year to year, or such parts of them as are published, are of little value in determining the standing or progress of the company. In fact, they are a source of vexation even to an expert, and it is only by the most laborious analysis that one is enabled to get at the true facts.

There are likely to be some important developments in Union Pacific affairs within the next few days. Unless there is an unexpected and radical change in the present situation Mr. Jay Gould will get out of Union Pacific altogether or else J. Pierpont Morgan will drop it and Mr. Gould will succeed in putting the road into the hands of a receiver.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24. -- In his attempt to set himself up as an autocrat concerning the hour at which residents of the borough of North Plainfield should retire. Borough Marshal Thomas Rutledge has suddenly found himself confronted with the opposition of the Supreme Court. Some weeks ago Rutledge found his old rival.

It is reported that there is only fifteen days' supply of water in the reservoirs which furnish New York City. This is an astonishingly small supply, and it would seem to indicate that there has been mismanagement on the part of whoever has this matter in charge.

The refusal of the Republican State Committee of Massachusetts to accept the challenge of the Democratic Committee for a joint debate of the issues of the State canvass between Gov. RUSSELL and Col. ALLEN, the Republican candidate for Governor, certainly is not an indication of confidence in the soundness of the party's position or in its strength with the people.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- The Fall term at Yale for all the departments, except those of medicine and the arts, opened with prayer in Battell Chapel this morning The usual opening remarks by the President were wanting, as President Dwight is in Europe, and will probably not return until Oct 15. The "galleries" were also disappointed in not seeing the new seniors practice their bow to the President.
MADRID, Sept. 24. -- An express train running between Burgos and San Sebastian came into collision with a combined goods and passenger train to-day.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 24. -- Under the management of the Good Templars' Lodge of Columbia, 25,000 petitions for signatures, asking the Legislature to enact a law prohibiting the liquor traffic in South Carolina, are being sent out. Each petition is accompanied by a circular letter urging the people to sign, and the names attached are those of H.F. Chrestzberg and S.P.H. Ewell, pastors of Methodist churches here, and J.A. Glenn.

The Adams Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary was filled yesterday afternoon with students and clergymen. The occasion was the opening address of the year by Prof. Marvin R. Vincent, D.D., who holds the Casir of New Testament Exegesis. Dr. Vincent is well known in this city as the former pastor of the Church of the Covenant.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 24. -- The hot, dry weather of the last ten days has had a marked effect, both for good and evil, on the cotton crop in the Memphis district, which comprises Western Tennessee, Eastern Arkansas, Northern Mississippi, and Northern Alabama. The hot sun has caused the bolls to burst with almost unexampled rapidity, and, in consequence, picking is more general for the time of year than for many seasons past.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Major Gen. Schofield has approved the new army tactics, and when they receive the approval of the Secretary of War steps will be taken at once to put them in operation. After coming from the board created to formulate them the tactics were submitted to some of the most experienced general officers in the military service.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Frank L. Smith of Galway has been nominated by the Republicans for Assemblyman in the First District of Saratoga County.

The Kickapoo Indians are probably disgruntled and disgusted at the current goings on around them. They occupy a reservation of 206,466 acres on the eastern border of Oklahoma, north of the North Fork of the Canadian. During the recent negotiations with the various bands on that border for surrendering the surplus part of their reservations, they resisted all overtures.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- A dispatch from Portland, Oregon, tells of the murder of two white men and five Indians on the Upper Yukon, in Alaska, and says one of the men was Ewing Earlscliffe, a prominent journalist of Missouri.

Prof. Henry Kiddie, ex-Superintendent of the public schools of this city, died at his home, 7 East One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, early yesterday morning, of paralysis. He had been 111 since Saturday. Hle death recalls one of the most Interesting struggles that over took place in the Board of Education.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 25. -- A Captain and twenty policemen patrolling Camp and Natchez Streets this afternoon was an unusual sight. They were there to prevent a hostile meeting between John C. Wickliffe, editor of the New Delta, and Gen. George W. Dupre, editor of the Evening States. Afterward both parties were arrested for being about to commit a breach of the peace and placed under bonds, and the police were withdrawn.

It is but three years since Russia opened her great Trans-Caspian railroad to general traffic, and yet she is now proposing to undertake the building of a still longer line. Indeed, if her present grandiose plan of a Trans-Siberian railroad to Vladivostock is carried out, she will have the longest line of railroad in the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- One day last Winter Nathaniel McKay, "the man who defeated Cleveland," invited a negro friend of his to dine with him at the Riggs House. It is not customary for all white men who have negro friends in Washington to invite them to the hotel tables to dinner, and Mr. McKay's departure from the rule aroused a prejudice that may be unreasonable.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- A murderous assault was committed by Convict Wallace in the penitentiary yesterday afternoon. He is a negro, and was convicted at Washington, D.C., of assault with intent to kill and sentenced to the Albany Penitentiary for a long term. He is a big, surly fellow, about twenty-eight years of age, and strong as an ox.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- A large pulp mill is being erected in Mechaniesville. It has reached the top of the third story, about forty feet above the ground. This afternoon thirty men -masons and hod carriers -- were working on a scaffold which extended the length of the building.

It is unlikely that the present drought will continue for many weeks, and a copious rainfall would replenish the city's water supply; but there is no certainty in a dependence upon a providential change of weather. It seems to be admitted that without rain, the present supply will last barely three weeks at the rate of consumption now going on.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25. -- The music festival came to a close to-night with a performance of Handel's oratorio "Israel in Egypt." It was the first time that this imposing work, which is usually cut rather generously, has been performed in its entirety in this city. It was prefaced by the overture to the "Occasional Oratorio," a piece of instrumental writing which in these days possesses only a historical interest.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- England and Germany have each applied for about five acres of space in the World's Fair buildings for their exhibits. The applications were made by Sir Henry Trueman Wood and James Dredge, representing the Government of Great Britain, and by Herr A. Wermuth, Imperial Commissioner from Germany.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma, Sept. 25. -Owing to the rush to the new lands opened to settlement this week, only a few of the delegates to the Oklahoma Statehood Convention to be held here yesterday put in their appearance, and the convention was therefore indefinitely postponed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The report of Commissioner Carter of the operations of the General Land Office during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1891, was made public to-day. An abstract is as follows:

A great many people who are fond of grapes were yesterday disturbed in their minds by the announcement that the Board of Health had ordered the seizure and destruction of some thirty-seven thousand pounds of that fruit. The occasion of the seizure was presented by a citizen who took to the board several bunches of Concord grapes, the stems of which were coated with a substance that "looked like paris green."

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 25. -- The following s a complete list of the fourth class, embracing all the successful candidates of the regular June and September and the special September examinations at the Naval Academy:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Nathaniel C. Barnes of Middlehope, Orange County, has a large display of grapes at the Dutchess County Fair. He cuts twenty tons of grapes every season at Middlehope, and twenty-five tons in his Ulster County vineyard. In an interview to-day, he said:
A curious story came out yesterday in Wall Street. It related to the doings of Thomas H. Stout, who sailed for Europe ten days ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Republicans of Monroe have been having a love feast this year, and have greatly enjoyed the scraps between the Hill and anti-Hill Democrats. But they must look to their guns.

A correspondent of THE TIMES sends information relating to the Barcelona office of the Spanish-American department of the New-York Life Insurance Company, and some additional data regarding its cost to the policy holders, who pay for everything.

Carmine Esposito, an Italian newsboy seven years old, whose parents live at 812 Mott Street, was run over and killed by a Houston Street car at the Bowery and Houston Street at 6:30 o'clock last evening. Antonio Esposito, the boy's father, who works in the saloon on the northwest corner, ran out to see what the excitement was about, and fainted when he caught sight of the body of the child.

Acting Chemist Lederle of the Board of Health and Assistant Chemist Weeks, with a staff of subordinates, seized and condemned 258 crates of Concord grapes early yesterday morning as they were landed by steamboats in this city. At the foot of West Tenth Street Dr. Weeks examined 4,700 crates landed from the steamer James W. Baldwin, and seized 112 crates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Persons who are favored with more of the Executive confidence than some others insist to-day that Mark H. Dunnell of Minnesota, who was not re-elected to Congress at the last election, is to be appointed a Civil Service Commissioner in place of Commissioner Lyman, when that gentleman goes out.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 25. -- Clarence Burleigh, who recently became District Attorney for Allegheny County, has a theory that law must be shown to have some terrors in order to minimize murder. To make emphatic the fact that crime will be punished he has arranged to have all the murderers in Pittsburg jail awaiting trial brought up in regular succession.

Mr. McMurray has begun his campaign in the Eleventh Assembly District. Mr. McMurray is a gentleman who was once a Republican Aldorman and who now has an organization of his own which is unique but not powerful. This association met in its clubhouse in West Thirtieth Street last night and resolved to resolve again that they were in favor of the Republican State ticket.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- The St. Louis Republic will to-morrow print an exposure of the tin plate fraud practiced in the Ohio campaign. Regis, Chauvenet Brother, the leading analytical chemists of St. Louis, at the request of the editor of the Republic, made an analysis of one of the so-called American tin medals, and make the following report:

NEWARK, Sept. 25. -- The fatal results attending the explosion of the bomb at the Italian celebration at Boyden and Nassau Streets last evening exceed all anticipations. Eight are dead, and it is believed that two or three others, if not more, are suffering injuries that forbid hopes of saving their lives. The list of the dead comprises these names:

If CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW and J. SLOAT FASSETT were wise in their day and generation they would avoid any effort to defend the action of the Republicans in the State Senate in 1890, under the dictation of "Boss" PLATT, on the World's Fair question, and do their utmost to keep that issue out of the present canvass.

The "no thoroughfare" condition so ably maintained along Broadway resulted yesterday in a call upon Commissioner Gilroy by a committee of merchants. They were W.F. King, from Calhoun, King Co.; G.C. Clark, from Tefft, Weller Co.; C.H. Webb, from Dunham, Buckley Co., and Walter Stanton, from Converse, Stanton Cullen.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- There is a very pretty little row going on here between the Administration and anti-Administration Republicans. The Harrison cohorts, it is said, are led by no less a person than Mark Hanna, who is known not only to be against Blaine, but also to be a warm advocate of the re-election of Senator Sherman.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The following is a summary of an official Pekin cablegram, received Monday and handed to the Foreign Office authorities Tuesday:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Town of Wallkill, which adjoins this city, has had five farm barns, or groups of barns and other out-buildings, burned recently under circumstances which pretty clearly indicated that the fires were incendiary.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Presbytery of Rochester held its stated Fall meeting at Nunda, N.Y., Monday and Tuesday. The matter of chief interest and importance was the Confession of Faith as revised by the committee of the General Assembly. The points in this were taken up seriatim and discussed. Several exceptions to the work of the revisors were taken and changes proposed.

The second opening of Oklahoma has not given rise to the same scandals as the first, possibly because little of the land opened to settlement by it seems to be worth forestalling. It has given rise to a scandal of another kind, which reflects rather upon the capacity than upon the integrity of the officials of the Interior Department.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The preliminary stages of the bitter feud between those relatives of the three children of the late John Duckworth who are Protestants and those who are Roman Catholics have already been recorded in the columns of THE TIMES. New developments were reached to-day. John Duckworth was a Protestant.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 25. -- A dispatch from Quebec, referring to the political situation, says: "Lieut. Gov. Angers, who is said to be harassing his Ministers into doing something that will warrant him in dismissing them, to-day demanded that the Government name a public accuser or prosecutor to conduct the case against the Ministers before the Royal Commission and refused to allow their claim to be represented by counsel at the investigation.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25. -- For the past four years "fake" dispatches have been sent from this city to all parts of the world about supposed occurrences here. Sometimes these stories have a little truth to base them on, but in most instances they are manufactured out of whole cloth.
BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The Democratic State Committee sends a challenge to Henry Cabot Lodge to meet John E. Russell in joint debate. The letter says, in part:

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 25. -- This evening's issue of Truth publishes a letter just received by Mr. James Brannon of this city from his brother, Col. P.P. Brannon, now in Guatemala, describing the assassination of Dr. Ayala, ex-Vice President of Salvador, who was shot through the heart in the City of Guatemala on the 4th of this month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Republicans of Ohio seem to be enjoying a monopoly in blunder-making in the campaign in that State, and Secretary Foster, observing some of the performances from his post in the Treasury Department, has just felt impelled to tell the McKinley managers of one mistake that they have recently introduced as a campaign issue.

The steamship City of Birmingham, from Savannah, arrived at Quarantine at 12 o'clock last night. It was expected that the Brooklyn man, Samuel Thornton, and his sister-in-law, Eva Jewell, who had the extraordinary good luck to be picked up at sea after being swept off the Coney Island bathing grounds, according to their marvelous story, would arrive on the City of Birmingham, and their friends were anxiously awaiting them.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 25. -- The Senate, after a spirited debate to-day, adopted an address to her Majesty asking that Canada be relieved from the effect of the favored nations clause in commercial treaties which exist between Great Britain and Belgium and the German Zollverein. Premier Abbott said he considered these provisions in foreign treaties were incompatible with the rights of powers subsequently conferred by the British North America act.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- Gov. Campbell addressed a large meeting, composed principally of farmers, at London this afternoon. An amusing incident was noted at the Court House, now in process of construction, where the Democratic workmen had run up a flag and placed a large rooster on the top of the building. On a large placard was printed:

The Executive Committee of the Cleveland League of the State of New-York, an organization of colored men that worked hard for the Democratic national ticket in 1888, met at the Gilbert House, 254 West Twenty-sixth Street, last night. It was stated that the organization now has 8,000 members on its rolls throughout the State.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The United States cruiser Newark arrived in the Thames River yesterday morning and anchored just below the city. The ship left New-York last Monday morning for Gardiner's Bay, L.I., where the crew was to be drilled at target practice in accordance with the regular department order.

Gov. Hill's speech to the Franklin County farmers on Thursday, in favor of reducing the rate of interest from 6 to 5 per cent., furnishes one more evidence that he did not have such perfect control of the recent Democratic State Convention as he would like people to believe he had.

It is to be presumed that everybody concerned will approve the action of Dr. MACQUEARY in resigning his ministry in the Protestant Episcopal Church, especially the Bishop and the clergy of his late diocese, who must, indeed, be particularly relieved. There was little in the trial of Dr. MACQUEARY that was in the nature of a persecution, and still less of what is called "heresy hunting."
BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- The ghost of Banquo itself could hardly rival Boston's mooted cemetery question in point of persistent rising before the public.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 26. -- The Press has been instrumental in solving a mystery that has been puzzling the authorities of Brooklyn for some days. An elderly man died suddenly at a hotel in that city. He had registered under the name of Mason, but when his effects were examined not the slightest clue could be obtained as to his residence or his friends.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 26. -- Carlos Hitchcock was arrested last night at Pittsford, nine miles from here, charged with assault with intent to kill on one William Dutelle. Hitchcock lives in Washington, where his son-in-law is engineer at the White House. He spends the Summer at his old home in Pittsford, where he owns a large amount of property, in the acquirement of which his forehandedness gained him the dislike of the village.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- If the game of European politics is a difficult one to play, it is often still harder work for onlookers to understand its progress. Last week, for example, everybody agreed that the outlook was extremely stormy, and none could see anywhere on the horizon a reassuring gleam of light.

Mr. Matthew Hale's letter in your issue of this day will be read by independent voters with the greatest interest and closest attention. It appears to me to present in a clear and most masterful manner convincing reasons why the independent voters of this State should this year support the Republican candidate for Governor.

The address of Gov. Hill at Malone, yesterday, dwelling chiefly with the matter of a reduction in the rate of interest in the State from 6 to 5 per cent. is an instructive presentation of one side of the case. The occasion, however, was non-partisan, and it must be borne in mind that with his exquisite regard for the proprieties, the Governor presented his views merely as a citizen and not as a Democrat.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 26. -- American athletes have every reason to be satisfied with the results of the eighth annual championship games of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Association, held at the Rosedale Lacrosse Grounds here this afternoon. There were fifteen events in all, two mile bicycle races being added to the list, and the first prizes in fourteen events were taken by American athletes.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The annual statement of the New-York, Providence and Boston Road to the Connecticut Commissioners, which has been received here, shows that the gross earnings for the year, including the Providence and Worcester Division, amounted to $3,051,228.69; operating expenses, $1,977,932.79; interest, rents, and taxes, $701,974.64; net income, $507,234.40; dividends, 10 per cent., $500,000; surplus for the year, $7,234.40.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 26. -- Lake Superior is eighteen feet higher than Lake Huron, and all the ships that go from below the point where the waters of Superior tumble into the St. Mary's River must climb over that long step. The flight of the water is so tumultuous, dropping as it does in one mile, that the ships that navigate the lakes cannot venture to "shoot" the rapids.

Warm weather following cold in the early Autumn creates beautiful confusion in costuming. New Fall costumes mingle with the dainty apparel of late Summer in charming panorama. The eye rests with most satisfaction upon the children. The little ones take such unaffected delight in their pretty fixings. The tiny young ladies wear an air of such entire complacence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $151,087,100, as follows: Currency 6s, $9,836,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $451,900; 4 per cents, $119,481,100; 2 per cents, $21,318,100.

" Circumstances alter cases." It is of the essence of independence in politics to consider the full effect of political action and to work for practical results in every canvass. There should always be consistency in adhering to principles, but there should be discrimination in working for their application in order to make real progress toward their ultimate success.
