KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The many city people who still remain in the Catskills are being treated to the most beautiful weather ever known in the month of September. As a rule better weather has been expected in October than in September, and this season has been a remarkable exception.

The times of which Miss Walworth writes in this volume belong to the earliest period of authentic New-York State history. In the year of this interesting maiden's birth the Dutch were still the lords of New-Amsterdam, and in the year of her death the English had learned but little of the vast western domain that was in time to become the Empire State.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26. -- Ex-Attorney General Thurston of Hawaii, speaking to-day of the projects for the annexation of the islands to this country, said:...

The Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn held its Fall regatta at Bay Ridge yesterday. A large crowd, including many ladies, assembled on the clubhouse bluff overlooking the course. The water craft afloat out on the bay, yachts big and little, steam and sailing, some under clouds of canvas, others with bare poles, made a pretty marine picture.

In the present condition of the finances of the Chicago Fair its managers have no doubt decided wisely in not making an appropriation for constructing a duplicate of the convent of Santa Maria de la Rabida. The project was rather an interesting one, and the structure which it was proposed to reproduce had an intimate connection with the life and fortunes of COLUMBUS.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The sophomore and freshman classes engaged in the Liveliest kind of a cane rush Tuesday. in which the sophomores were victorious. The battle, which was over a baseball bat, was stubbornly fought. The Faculty witnessed the rush and did nothing to prevent it. The freshmen are not satisfied and say that they will organize into squads and carry canes despite the sophomores.

Throngs of well-dressed and pretty women sat on the bluff on the grounds of the New-York Athletic Club, at Travers Island, yesterday afternoon and watched the oarsmen as they took part in the twenty-fifth annual regatta of the club. Though the races might have been managed better, nearly every one appeared to enjoy them.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 26. -- Wednesday last Capt. Smyth of the United States revenue cutter McLane was informed by Capt. Brown of the bark Formosa of New-York, now in this port, that his entire crew had deserted Tuesday night. The Sheriff, who had a warrant for the arrest of the deserters, said he believed they were on the schooner Dantzler of Pascagouia, Miss., which sailed late Tuesday night.

-- Miss Maxwell's Affections. A Novel. By Richard Pryce. New York: Harper Brothers. -- Here is a romance with a surprise in it a la "Lady and the Tiger," and the entire business of "Miss Maxwell's Affections" is managed in a clever way. The hardened reader of novels generally dislikes the heroine under whose spell every man is influenced, and yet Gertrude is of that special, fascinating sort.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- This has been a gala day for the Nyack Country Club, one of the most prominent and wealthy social organizations along the Hudson River. The grounds are dressed in holiday attire, and the handsome building to-night presents a scene of brilliancy unsurpassed in this region.

Those who are familiar with Burckhardt's great volume in German will be pleased to know of the translation, the subject of this notice. This translation has even some additions in text and notes, and Mr. Middlemore has to thank not only the author of the work for advice, but Dr. Ludwig Geiger of Berlin and Prof. Valbusa of Mantua for new matter.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 26. -- The "Latter-Day Saints," or Mormons, were the first English- speaking Americans to adopt irrigation in farming.

" What do the students of Union Seminary think of Dr. Briggs?" is a question which is often asked nowadays. A student who had taken considerable pains to ascertain the feeling prevailing with his fellows answered this question when it was put to him the other day as follows:

The real trouble in getting men just now for the cruisers Concord and Bennington is due to the cramped quarters on those vessels. Even the officers are protesting against men being sent to sea in such ships. The space between decks is so cut up and lumbered with all sorts of gear and appliances as to compel hammocks to be swung in untenantable positions.

CLINTON, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The opening of the new year presages a successful future for this institution. The freshman class is up to the average in numbers, there being forty-three registered. Of these thirty-six are regular classical students, four take the newly established Latin-Scientific course, and three take special courses.

Kingston, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Rev. Dr. R. L. Burtsell, rector of St. Mary's Catholic Church, has been presented with a handsome golden cross with a diamond star in the centre by a number of his late parishioners of the Church of the Epiphany in New-York City.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Gov. Russell's New-York speech, over which there has been so much discussion, is going to be widely circulated. The offer of the Democratic State Committee to furnish the Republican State Committee with 100,000 copies for distribution has been accepted by the latter. In fact, the latter goes a little further to show how desirous it is of giving it great publicity by asking 400,000 copies.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Henry James's new play, "The American," had its first London production to-night, before a house filled with well-known people. It was probably the most distinguished audience the Opera Comique ever held, from a literary point of view at least, and it was very prodigal with its applause; but the people, after they got out, hardly tried to disguise their disappointment.

This is really a remarkable little book. It has been charged by critics who make books as well as comment on them that the style of your journalist is necessarily diffuse, not to say verbose. Here is a newspaper man -- the title is a little above, not below, that of journalist -- who verifies Bacon's aphorism that "writing maketh an exact man."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Rev. A.S. Gardner, for many years pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Milford, Penn., and noted as a historian and an ansquarian or the Minisink Valley region, has resigned the pastorate of the church at Rockford, Ill., which he had filled for two years past. His health is impaired, and he will return East and occupy the Gardner family mansion at Sag Harbor, L.I.

On the 3d of March, 1890, the Council of the University of the City of New-York established a School of Pedagogy as one of the departments of the university. Two degrees were provided for, Doctor of Pedagogy and Master of Pedagogy.

INTERMENTS IN WESTMINSTER ABBEY. -Long before the period of the Reformation, the church was not only a royal burying place and the scene of every coronation, but also became the place appointed for royal weddings and christenings, Te Deums for victories, and national pageants. It was not until the reigns of Henry VIII. and of Edward VI. that a marked increase took place in the number of non-royal interments.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Two weeks ago to-night William F. Sheehan left here for Saratoga determined to secure the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, and also to give the place of State Committeeman to whoever he pleased. He left behind him much hot talk and a revengeful lot of men, who were equally as determined that he should not have all he wanted.

GAMBLERS' SUICIDES. -- "If we could but obtain accurate statistics, we should find that gambling was of all vicious habits, not even excluding hard drinking, the one which most predisposed its victims to suicide. Yet," continues this writer, "one does not quite see at first why gambling should so greatly predispose to suicide.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- The Republicans of Cuyahoga County held their County Convention to-day and named three candidates for the State Senate and eight for Representatives, besides a regular county ticket. The result is a surprise and general disappointment to the decent members of the party.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- A special from San Francisco says: "A romantic story comes from the Paumoto Islands in the South Pacific. William Gibson has just returned from there and says that Samuel Harris, 26 years old, who was born and reared here, and has been for five years in the islands, has married the daughter of King Tokotala, and has been made Prime Minister.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Lord Tennyson has this week signed an agreement with Mr. Augustin Daly by which he assigns to the American manager the exclusive right to produce both in America and England an entirely new work which the Laureate has just completed. It is a three-act comedy, and it is the first and only piece which Lord Tennyson has written especially for the stage.

Rumors of an important change in the management of one of the big steamship lines took substance yesterday when a tug, having on board the Hon. Carl Schurz, American Director of the Hamburg-American Packet Company; Mr. R.J. Cortis, the American agent of the line, and Mr. Oscar L. Richard, the company's passenger agent, steamed down the bay and met the Hamburg-American liner Columbia at Quarantine.

ALBANY, Sept. 26. -- Gov. Hill's champion of labor, Charles F. Peck, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, is just now giving more attention to the political duties imposed by Mr. Hill than to his office. His twenty-five-thousand-dollar office shows little return for the money expended, the report for last year being yet unpublished. The getting out of a report is all that is required of this barnacle office holder.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- For six hours, in a broiling hot sun, Lord Hawke's team and the representative Philadelphia eleven contested on the field of the Germantown Cricket Club at Manheim to-day. The result of the day's play was the completion of Philadelphia's first inning for 248, 18 less than the Englishmen made in their first inning.

The New-Yorks and Brooklyns met for the last time this season at Eastern Park yesterday. Two games were played. Ward's alleged wonders were badly beaten in both. Rusie pitched throughout the two games and was a complete enigma to the Bridegrooms. They were glad after the games were over that they will not be compelled to meet the Giants again this season.

A Fassett and Vrooman Campaign Club was organized last night at the Hotel Hamilton, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, which has for its leading spirits the "wet" element of the old Hamilton Club of Harlem. This club was once the Republican Club of the Nineteenth Assembly District, and had a large membership.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Sept. 26. -- College opened with the largest freshman class that ever entered. The number is 182, out of which 102 are without conditions. If the succeeding classes are as large in proportion as that of '95, the university will be wholly unable to provide for them.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, Sept. 26. -- The college has resumed its wonted activity, and the students, have settled down to work, while the new professors are rapidly becoming acquainted with their duties.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 26. -- The Rev. Dr. Palmer's assertion in his address at the opening of the anti-lottery campaign in this State, that even revolution would be resorted to in order to defeat the lottery, seems destined to be speedily realized. Already in many parts of the State the shotgun has been resorted to.

The New-York Life Insurance Company finds very little business on its hands in these piping times of popular distrust of its management, and for this reason it may be pardoned for seeking employment in bringing playful suits for libel against THE TIMES for publishing the news. Yesterday the company, through its attorneys, sent the summons in its second suit against THE TIMES.

Leonard A. Giegerich, County Clerk, is a man who is always in touch with the feelings of the German-American citizens on political matters. When asked yesterday how the German voters regarded the Democratic State ticket and the platform of the Saratoga Convention, he said:

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Harrison and Mr. and Mrs. McKee enjoyed a coaching trip yesterday in Mr. Henry E. Cobb's handsome tally-ho, drawn by eight spirited horses. The party comprised, besides the distinguished guests and the host and hostess, ex-Congressman Candler, ex-Gov. and Mrs. J.Q.A. Brackett, Miss Cobb, Miss Brackett.

The ice has been broken and a bicycle meet has been run by an athletic club. The Manhattan Athletic Club yesterday, on its new grounds, the Manhattan Field, held a successful meet of this character. Nearly three thousand spectators occupied the grand stand, but several times that number were expected. The track was in good condition, considering its newness.

It is said that the Republican Campaign Committee proposes to get out and circulate in this State a document demonstrating that HILL in 1888 sacrificed the Democratic Electoral ticket by giving votes for HARRISON in exchange for votes for himself. It is difficult to see what the Republicans expect to gain by the dissemination of such a document.

READING, Penn., Sept. 26. -- One of the amusing results of the tremendous apple crop gathered hereabout this season is an extraordinary scramble on the part of farmers for barrels in which to store cider, and for pots in which to pack apple butter. This apple butter is a standard Pennsylvania product, consisting of cider extract as a basis, combined with out apples, and preserved with sugar and spices.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 26. -- Passing westward some eighty miles from Madison to the Mississippi River, we found on the bluffs which intervene between the Wisconsin and Mississippi Rivers another extensive system of fortifications, consisting of numerous long mounds running parallel to each other and commanding an extensive view of the valleys and bottom lands for miles around.

The combined "ladies' day" and forty-fourth annual regatta of the Atalanta Boat Club yesterday was one of the most notable events that has taken place among the Harlem River boat clubs this season. To accommodate the guests a large double-decked barge was swung alongside the club's boathouse, and an hour before the races began 500 enthusiasts had crowded upon it. A band stationed on the barge played popular airs.

Among the children of the First Ward School, Long Island City, which has not yet been opened this Fall, who were sumoned to appear at the school on Thursday morning last was Ella L. Weeks, the twelve-year-old daughter of Nelson Weeks, Jr., of 131 Twelfth Street. The parents of the child, like those of the other children, thought the school was to be opened.

WHERE BROWNING WROTE HIS LAST POEMS. -- "What a curious place to select," was my first thought, as I stood at the door of the queer old house. I walked up twelve or fifteen hard stone steps, grasping the balustrade to guide myself in the dark, and was soon warmly welcomed by Signora Nine Tabacchi, as passing through the kitchen, I was ushered into the sitting room.

ELIZABETH, Sept. 26. -- This was a great day for the Elizabeth wheelmen at the New-Jersey Jockey Club's grounds. Their annual meet was highly successful, and was attended by fully 2,500 people, nearly half of whom were ladies. About 500 wheelmen were in attendance.

I believe it was Burgon's handsome face that first attracted me. He stood so near me at the State that I could not help talking stock of him, and so everyday become more-aware of the faultless shape of his features and the utter badness of his drawing. Being rich, friendless, and a trifle "stand-offish," he was at once invested by the other fellows with an absurd halo of mystery.

Lieut. Commander McCullom and Lieut. Wyckoff of the United States Navy have taken possession of the land recently purchased at Port Orchard by the United States for a naval station. A party consisting of Lieuts. Wyckoff and McCullom and a number of friends returned to Seattle yesterday from Port Orchard on the schooner Yukon, bringing the news of the formal occupancy of the station by the Government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26. -- The coming of Mr. Mills and other Democratic orators is likely to put the Republicans on their mettle during the rest of the political contest in this State. It seems unfortunate, however, that many of the Democratic speakers persist in the discussion of the silver question and the practical abandonment of the tariff.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- In the presence of 4,000 people C. W. Dorntge of Buffalo, at the Parkside track to-day, put up a new American bicycle record for five miles in competition, and came within fifteen seconds of the five-mile record made against time. His time for five miles was 13:57. The former record was 14:20.

PLAINFIELD, Conn., Sept. 26. -- This little town was thrown into a flurry of excitement last night at an occurrence that bids fair to terminate fatally for several of its residents. A social dance and supper were given in Union Hall by parties from Moosup. W.F. Picket, a Moosup caterer, furnished the supper.

The announcement, in THE TIMES'S cable dispatches this morning, that TENNYSON, at the age of eighty-two years, has written a new play, not primarily to be read, like all his former works in dramatic form, with the exception of the unfortunate "Promise of May," but to be acted, will cause some surprise.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- As the news of the raid of the New-York Board of Health spreads in the vineyard districts the indignation among grape-growers increases. The main shipments are from Ulster, Greene, Columbia, Dutchess, and Orange Counties. Thousands of crates are sent into New-York nightly, the Poughkeepsie Transportation Company's boat carrying the heaviest loads.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The British Minister recently made a complaint that indicated that his Government regarded the performance of the United States in postponing the agreement for a close season as a sort of "confidence game" that should not have been played by us.

MORA, Minn., Sept. 26. -- After a long and brave fight with the forest fire, the people in Kanabre County are feeling relieved. The high wind has gone down, and no further danger is anticipated in the settled portion of the county. So far as heard, no lives have been lost.

BURKE DINES WITH BARRY. -- "Sir," said Barry to the statesman, who had been his first patron, "you know I live alone, but if you will come and help me to eat a steak, I shall have it tender and hot from the most classic market in London -- that of Oxford." Burke agreed, and on the hour appointed, arrived in Castle Street.

Believing it to be the duty of every policy holder or ex-policy holder to come forward and lend a helping hand in exposing the iniquity and rascally manoeuvres of the New- York Life Insurance Company, I cheerfully contribute my mite that ordinary mortals may not be lead into its snares hereafter. Read this and decide if I am not entitled to righteous indignation.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26. -- The criminal libel suit of Prince George of Wales against R.N. O'Brien, the Dalziel Dunlop News Agency correspondent, was continued to-day. When the court assembled in the morning the room was crowded. Justice Doherty took a seat on the bench with Justice Cross, the trial Judge, yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The theatrical world, much to the satisfaction of the managers, seems destined to enjoy a renewal of the Queen's favor. Her Majesty, it appears, has expressed a desire to have several plays performed at Buckingham Palace and at Windsor Castle, and two leading London managers are hopeful of being able to secure the Queen's personal attendance at their places of entertainment during the coming season.

There is no inconsiderable amount of enthusiasm of a quiet kind disclosed by those in interest concerning the approaching field day exercises at Van Cortlandt Park. Officers and men recognize the fact that the First Brigade will then be afforded an opportunity to appear to the fullest advantage, and the general disposition is to make an appearance commensurate with the opportunities and the occasion.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 26. -- A recent visit to Clinton, a Connecticut shore town, best known as the home of Prof. B.G. Northrop, the promoter of village improvement societies, brought to light some interesting points in the early history of Yale College, which live in tradition, but are not chronicled in books. A Summer pilgrim to the pretty village discovered a modest monument on the village green, bearing on its granite base this curiosity inspiring announcement:

ARABS IN THEIR RAGS. -- The gray woolen burnouses of the Arabs are furnished with, a hood, like a monk's cowl, which is pulled over the head during the greatest heat of the day. The head is closely cropped or shaven, and covered with the many folds of the turban, which latter is wound round. again and again with a brown-colored woolen cord.

The week has been rather an exciting one on Wall Street, and the market has been much disturbed, but nothing has happened which changes the basis on which the bull movement rests. Every great movement must necessarily encounter obstacles which retard it, and must have reactions when the forward progress has been too rapid.

BEES AND BUTTERFLIES. -- The bee, in fact, is the bon bourgeois of the insect world. He attends strictly to business, loses no time in wild or reckless excursions, and flies by the straightest path from flower to flower of the same species with mathematical precision. Moreover, he is careful, cautions, observant, and steady going -- a model business man, in fact, of sound middle-class morals and sober middle-class intelligence.

President WILSON of the Board of Health is reported as saying, with reference to the seizure of "sprayed" grapes, that whenever there is a question as to the unwholesome character of a food product the benefit of the doubt should be given to the public, by which he seems to imply that the questionable food product should be seized and destroyed without settling the doubt.

Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan is a man of strong will and definite purposes. He took hold of the Union Pacific finances at the request of Jay Gould. He soon found that Mr. Gould was juggling with the property. Having identified himself with the scheme to fund the floating debt, he naturally felt that success was essential to the preservation of his prestige as a great financier.

Mr. GUSTAV H. SCHWAB, who has labored with great zeal and intelligence in the cause of ballot reform, agrees with Mr. MATTHEW HALE in thinking that the enactment of a genuine ballot-reform law will be best promoted by the election of Mr. FASSETT. We print Mr. SCHWAB'S letter to-day.

Now comes the authoritative statement that the subscription balls, known as the cotillions, which were so popular for some Winters, and whose abandonment caused such general regret in society, are to be revived, or rather are to be started under new auspices, Mrs. Newbold Morris being at the head of the committee of ladies who are to manage them.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, announced to-day the appointment of the following Executive Committee:
HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 26. -- The following was issued from the Executive Department to-day:

CHICAGO, -- A generation ago America consisted of the settled Northeastern and Southeastern States and of the great expanse of more or less wild continent behind them. Year by year, however, the population has been spreading west, and every fresh census has pushed inland the mean line of population -- the line on either side of which the population is equal.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 26. -- There were never so many people in Lenox at one time as now, and this is the testimony of the cottagers and the hotel proprietors. During the past week it has been difficult for people who have come on unannounced to obtain accommodations. The demand for rooms is increasing, and the 1st of October will find more here than at present.

A murder was committed in Port Chester, Westchester County, yesterday morning, James B. Daly being the victim of John P. Gleason. Daly was one of the firm of Daly Brothers, grocers, on Main Street. At about 9 o'clock, while Daly was alone in the store, Gleason went in there and, drawing a revolver, fired a shot at him.

Mr. Mansfield's Nero is something more than the most notable performance of this theatrical week. It is the finest example of the art of acting seen in this city since the theatre doors began to open in August. It is a work to be studied and remembered. The play itself is out of the common, but we confess we do not care so much for that as for Mr. Mansfield's acting.

Patrons of city poolrooms had a hard time of it trying to play the races yesterday. They wanted to speculate on the runners at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, but they couldn't do it because the Western Union's clever flash-light telegraph machine in the coachman's hat had been discovered and its usefulness destroyed.

THE IDEAL WAR CORRESPONDENT. -- "In my day dreams" -- I am quoting from a lecture I delivered some ten years ago -- in my day dreams, indulged in mostly when smarting under the consciousness of my own deficiencies, I have tried to think out the attributes that ought to be concentrated in the ideal war correspondent.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Just now the cadets are considerably upset over the fear that the Faculty may not permit the football team to visit Annapolis Thanksgiving Day to play the return game with the Annapolis cadets. One of the cadets said to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day:

Prof. Galloway, Chief of Pathology of the Department of Agriculture in Washington, came to this city yesterday and met a number of large fruit merchants and several grape dealers at the Mercantile Exchange. This meeting was brought about by the seizure of grapes by agents of the Health Department on the allegation that the bunches contained large quantities of a solution of copper, which rendered the fruit unwholesome, if not poisonous.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- What could be more absurd than the preliminary effervescence given to the representations of "Lohengrin"? The vast amount of preparation undertaken during the last three months has been a mystery to no one, and really the constant interference of the so-called Patriotic League is becoming obnoxious, if not dangerous to the public peace.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock this afternoon fire was discovered in the machinery storage room of the Plant Milling Company, situated at the foot of Choteau Avenue, and the flames spread so rapidly that the firemen could do nothing but save adjoining property. The building was a five-story structure, seventy-five feet front on Choteau Avenue and 100 feet deep.

Mr. Leland has taken "The Florentine Nights," "The Memoirs of Herr von Schnabelewopski," "The Rabbi of Bacharach." and Shakespeare's "Maidens and Women" as samples of Heine, and has translated them. Some eighteen years ago Mr. S.A. Stern gave the happiest of translations of "The Florentine Nights," to which he added a number of excerpts taken from other of Heine's works.

In his third letter on Russia and the Jews, printed this morning, our London correspondent takes the opportunity to lay the foundation for the explanation of the facts he has already outlined, and of those which he will give hereafter in greater detail, by tracing the origin and describing the character of the moujik, or Russian peasant, who makes up about five-sixths of the population of Russia.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27. -- A movement from an unexpected quarter has been begun against John P. Poe, the Democratic nominee for Attorney General, and unless it is checked it will probably bring about his defeat in spite of the fact that he was nominated unanimously and was considered one of the strongest men on the ticket.

County Physician A.W. Shepard of Brooklyn will hold an autopsy to-day on the body of Jacob Betzel, who died late on Saturday night in Raymond Street Jail. Betzel was arrested on Friday in Ellery Street for being intoxicated and acting in a disorderly manner, and on Saturday he was sentenced by Police Justice Goetting to ten days in prison.
A good deal of merriment was caused among the business men of this city when they read in the Detroit Tribune of Sept. 18 this, one of Beers's latest advertisements:

With fine music and an imposing procession of the clergy the silver jubilee of the Rev. Father McCready was celebrated at the Church of the Holy Cross, Forty-second Street and Ninth Avenue, yesterday. A congregation that tilled the church witnessed the solemn high mass. It was announced from the chancel that the Pope had cabled his apostolic benediction on the priest whose jubilee was being celebrated.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Discount was quiet during the past week at 2 3/4 for three months and 1 3/4 for short. Money is still plentiful, but discount houses sold out for full rates in view of a fall in American exchange and a farther withdrawal of gold for New-York. A tightening of rates is certain, though the process will be gradual, the Bank of England having an unusually large reserve.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- Not in years have the Democrats of Albany been wrought up to such a pitch as now, and unless something is done to mollify them before election day the Democratic State ticket will suffer in Albany County, and a Judge will be elected from the Third Judicial District to the Supreme Court from the ranks of the Republicans.

President Harrison's Administration has come to Thomas C. Platt's aid in his effort to elect J. Sloat, Fassett and a Republican Legislature this year. It has "pulled off its coat" and gone vigorously campaigning, thereby showing what an important bearing the Administration believes this campaign in New-York will have upon the Presidential campaign of next year.

James Norton, a Pullman trainman employed on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, while coupling cars at Eleventh Avenue and Sixtieth Street yesterday, was caught between the bumpers and will probably die of his injuries. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital.

The meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League, which takes place tomorrow at Buffalo, will afford the occasion for a review of the course of official action and of public sentiment with reference to the reform during the past year. The subject is not the less important because during that time it has not attracted as much public attention as it did during the year immediately preceding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Naval engineers are much interested in the proposed race of steam yachts at New-York, and are in hopes that it may be arranged. They have very little doubt that the torpedo boat Cushing could beat any of them if she were allowed to enter.

DES MOINES, Sept. 27. -- The coming week will be one of unusual activity among Iowa Democrats. Gov. Boies will make four speeches during the week. He will begin at Audibon Tuesday afternoon, and follow at Jefferson Wednesday, Ottumwa Thursday, Bloomfield Friday, and Iowa City Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Gov. Pattison's bold move in calling the Senate of Pennsylvania together in extraordinary session for the purpose of considering the removal from office of State Treasurer Henry K. Boyer and Auditor General Thomas McCamant created a profund sensation in political circles, and to-day nothing else was talked of in places where men congregate.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27. -- A special to the American from Knoxville says: "The penitentiary lease question will now go to the courts, in so far as it relates to the convicts who are worked away from the main prison or, rather, sub-leased. Attorney General Pickle, in an elaborate opinion, held that the convicts could not be sub-leased. Nothing of this came before the Legislature. Now, however, the question goes to the courts.

The County Democrats have a much better record and reputation of fidelity to the candidates of their party than Tammany has ever had. The treatment of the County Democracy at Saratoga was undoubtedly unjust and impolitic, but though disappointed and sore, they are not revengeful. They will support Mr. FLOWER and the State ticket.

It is interesting to know that the naval engineers in Washington are greatly interested in the projected trial of speed among steam yachts, and would like very much to enter the torpedo boat the Cushing. This vessel has an official record of twenty-four knots per hour, and the Government officers are confident that under favorable conditions over the measured course at Newport she could outsteam any of her competitors.

Census Superintendent Porter has not abandoned his scheme to turn the Census Bureau into a confessional for home owners. The indignant protests last year against some of the questions that the enumerators were required to ask about matters that most people considered none of the census takers' business seem to have left the census returns with a big blank in the columns set apart for calculating how property stood in regard to mortgages.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 27. -- United States Marshal William R. Leeds was found on the porch of his States Avenue cottage surrounded by his family, and when questioned as to the significance of Gov. Pattison's proclamation convening the State Senate in special session with a view to the removal of State Treasurer Boyer and Auditor General McCamant, he said:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27. -- A pronounced Presidential boom for Grover Cleveland is making itself felt on the Pacific coast. Ever since Mr. Cleveland gave his promise that he would visit California the people have been anxiously awaiting his coming, and should he not come the result would be general dissatisfaction. The leading newspaper of Stockton, the most prominent inland manufacturing town in California, to-day prints a long editorial article on Mr. Cleveland.

HARTFORD, Sept. 27. -- The systematic registration of vital statistics has been enforced in Connecticut since 1848. During the ten years from 1880, as shown by the statistics which the Board of Health has published this month, the whole number of births in the State was 157,064. The total number of deaths for the same period was 117,814.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 27. -- Close Hall, the Young Men's Christian Association and Young Women's Christian Association Building, is now practically completed. It was thrown open for the first reception a week ago, and there was a large gathering of the Faculty and students of the State University, who form most of the members of the associations, and their friends.

Saturday THE TIMES published part of the inner history of the Barcelona office representing the Spanish-American department of the New-York Life Insurance Company. Reference was made to Mr. Joaquin Sanchez's salary of $30,000, and to that of Son-in-law Berthelot of $10,000. No doubt $5,000 a year for traveling expenses will be allowed Berthelot. A man of his tastes must travel.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- The consecration services to-day at Trinity Episcopal Church were held by Bishop Leonard of Cleveland. When talked with on the recent deposing from the Church of the Rev. Howard MacQueary of Canton, for heresy, he said:

The Rev. Dr. William W. Page, for twenty-two years pastor of the New-York Presbyterian Church, at Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street, preached his farewell sermon to the congregation yesterday morning. The occasion brought out every member of the church and a host of other friends of the pastor, so that the seating capacity of the church was taxed to the utmost.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- William H. Kemble the well-known financier and street railway magnate, died very suddenly late last night at his magnificent residence, Marylawn, near Glenside Station, on the North Penn Railroad. He was attacked with heart disease while in bed, and died ten minutes after making known his condition.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Louis Gathman's patent for preventing heat generating in ordnance was tried at Fort Sheridan yesterday, and while the experiment was entirely informal, the new method of discharging projectiles was approved by the officers who witnessed the trial.

The statement sent forth from Peoria, that the manufacture of American whisky has been totally revolutionized by a Japanese scientist, is likely to excite some incredulity, but evidence from various quarters shows it to be thoroughly trustworthy. The inventor of the new process is a well-known chemical expert of Tokio, named TAKEMINE, whose important discovery has been frequently mentioned in Japanese newspapers.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 27. -- A special from Salt Lake City says: "Information has been received that several members of the Burlington and Missouri River surveying party, which has been running lines through the country in the Big Horn basin between Buffalo and Yellowstone Park, separated from the main body and undertook a perilous enterprise of running a line through the Big Horn Canon.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 27. -- A disguised desperado, whose voice betrayed him as "Curly" Troy, a sneak thief, given "trusty" privileges during his incarceration, held up the guard of the Laramia County Jail here this morning and quietly liberated Charles Miller, the boy double murderer, under death sentence, and Frank B. Parkisen, a soldier, convicted of the killing of a comrade and sentenced to prison for twelve years.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Groups of grape growers have assembled in all the vineyard districts of Ulster County to-day discussing the situation as to the result of the raid of the New-York Board of Health upon sprayed grapes. The D.S. Miller took about 2,000 boxes from Highland this evening for the New-York market.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The people of Newark have found time, in the midst of their fight against the "bosses," to complete their nominations for the other offices to be filled with new men next month. They are to elect, besides the Mayor, a City Home Trustee and Aldermen and School Commissioners. The Republicans have nominated Dr. Ill and the Democrats Prosecutor Crane for Home Trustee.

-- Morrina, (Homesickness.) By Emilia Pardo Bazan. Translated by Mary J. Serrano. New-York: Cassell Publishing Company. -- Mme. Bazan takes the love of a Galician serving maid for her own country as a, topic, and has with high art and perfect understanding written a psychological study of an original character.

I have read your editorial on "Our Impassable Streets" in your issue of the 20th inst., and would refer to that part of it which alludes to the condition of Broadway and the attitude of the Department of Public Works thereto. In the article referred to the entire onus for alleged delays is placed upon the Commissioner of Public Works and apparently on a hypothesis unwarranted by the circumstances.

What is to hinder regulation of the water supply by controlling the consumption and preventing waste? As a stranger, visiting this city from time to time. I have been amazed at the immense waste of water from defective or wornout plumbing. Other places have a bountiful supply of water without waste by simply measuring the water, like gas, to the consumer.

" About this time" look out for a general bleeding of Government employes by the politicians. We publish in our Washington dispatches a circular addressed by the Pennsylvania Republican State Committee to the Pennsylvanians in the Post Office Department begging for money. It it said that Mr. WANAMAKER had asked that no such circular be sent to his department, and had offered to give his check for the sum expected to be raised.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27. -- A special from Corpus Christi says: "Yesterday the rainmakers made their first experiment here and it was a complete success. Broken clouds had been floating overhead all the morning, and at 6 P.M. Messrs. Ellis, Caster, and Fairchild entered a carriage and drove out of town, accompanied by the County Engineer, who represented the Citizens' Committee.

Frank S. Collins of 65 East Sixty-sixth Street, who had spent two days in the Tombs at the instance of Edward Gilmore, the theatrical manager, went out on $5,000 bail yesterday morning. His bondsman is Williard P. Ward, 164 West Sixty-eighth Street. Gilmore charges Collins with the misuse of $5,000 given him by Gilmore to invest in a Mexican theatrical enterprise.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- It is said that if Gov. Abbett is the absolute master of the Legislature next Winter, as he was last, he will try to cap the climax of autocracy by forcing through a tax bill of the pattern of that which the people so indignantly repudiated a few months ago. The State Tax Board has not been going around the State for the fun of the thing.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Foreign Minister Ribot, at Bapaune, to-day unveiled a statue of Gen. Faidherbe. After paying a tribute to the military virtues of the General as an example to the army, he traced the phases of the republic since its foundation, and said:

There seems to be no doubt that the Board of Health has inflicted a very serious injury upon the growers and dealers in grapes by condemning as unfit for food a large quantity of grapes and by raising in the minds of thousands of persons a suspicion against the wholesomeness of all grapes offered for sale.

There is some excitement among the members of Congress Court of Foresters over the circumstances attending the burial of James McGrath of 111 Thorne Street. McGrath lived alone with his two-year-old child, and at his death Congress Court assumed charge of the funeral arrangements. They fixed Sunday afternoon for the services, and all the members of the court and the members of the Fourth District Association, with which McGrath had allied himself, prepared to attend.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The United States, through the State Department, this afternoon sent to Minister Egan at Santiago, a vigorous protest against the violation, by the forces of Chile, of the territory of the United States in the legation at the Chilean capital.

The clergy and laymen of St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, at Hoyt and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, are after the Excise Commissioners with a sharp stick. They are aroused over the action of Commissioners Schliemann and Cahill in transferring the license of a saloon to a building near the church against the protest of the church members.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- The cricket match between Lord Hawke's eleven and the team made up of the cracks from the various first-class Philadelphia teams, which began on Friday last, ended to-day with a victory for Philadelphia.

The central fact in Commissioner RAUM'S annual report is, as we have already noted, that on the 30th of June last no fewer than 676,160 pensioners were on the rolls. This is a body more numerous than the standing army of any country in the world, except Russia, and larger, even, than her field forces and troops of the reserve combined, exclusive of the local and Cossack organizations.

The elaborately detailed story, straight from the far East, describing a deep-laid Russian scheme to take possession of the inland Chinese city of Hankow may be, and probably is, fictitious; bus the political intrigue to which it calls renewed attention is undoubtedly one of the best authenticated facts of modern diplomacy.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The Inter-State Fair opened here to-day. All departments of the exhibits, especially those in the live stock classes, are full to overflowing. The novelties are two carloads of Percheron and French coaching stallions, and a full exhibit of the newly-imported brown Swiss cattle. Judging of the live stock takes place on Wednesday at 11 A.M., and all horses in show classes parade each day at 10:30 A.M.

The Kings county Democracy formally jumped into the campaign last night and pledged itself, as far as resolutions and written assurances could do it, to a hearty and enthusiastic support of the State ticket. This was done by calling a special meeting of the General Committee in the Thomas Jefferson headquarters.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- A prominent society wedding took place at the First Parish Church, Brookline, at noon to-day, when Miss Gertrude Flint, daughter of Mrs. Edward A. Flint of Brookline, and Dr. Charles Wendell Townsend of Boston were married. The church was elaborately decorated with wild flowers and ferns.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- There is trouble among the Republicans of Genesee County on account of a broken slate at the County Convention, which met at Batavia to-day. There were many delegates present, and the ticket was thought to be in fine shape to be railroaded through without a hitch.

The delegates of the Democrats of Massachusetts will meet in convention at Worcester to-day under peculiarly hopeful auspices. There is not a sign of discord or disagreement, nor the least little cloud on the prospects of the party save the fact that in times past Massachusetts has been a Republican State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- An unprovoked murder, followed by two attempts at lynching, served to throw the inhabitants of the neighborhood near the river and St. Clair Street into a wild state of excitement this morning. Cornelius J. Sullivan, known on the Western Transit Company's docks as "Boston Kelly," became involved in a quarrel with Martin Bales, a desperate young negro.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Upon the occasion of the jubilee of the Seventy-eighth Infantry Regiment at Osnaburg, Hanover, Chancellor von Caprivi made a long optimist speech upon the political situation in Europe. He said that the apprehensions in some quarters as to whether the existing state of things would be maintained were not warranted.

PLAINFIELD, Conn., Sept. 28. -- This little town is still in a fever of excitement over the poisoning cases of last Friday night. Miss Delia Dolbeck, one of the victims, is in a serious condition and will probably die. Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Johnson of Moosup are also very ill.

The rumor in Victoria that a venture-some schooner of that port is to wind up the sealing season by a visit to the Pribilof Islands is far from incredible. The four vessels of our navy and the three British war ships that have been on patrol duty in Bering Sea have left it, and probably also the revenue cutters are on their way home.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Sept. 28. -- There is no member in the Sioux Falls divorce colony who stands higher socially than Baroness de Stuers, wife of the Belgian Minister in Paris. Before her marriage she was a Miss Carey, a niece of John Jacob Astor, and her marriage was a society sensation in New-York.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 28. -- A special from Durango, Col., says: Ralph Ray, the twenty-year-old murderer of his mother, was captured Saturday evening in Canon Large, New-Mexico, by Sheriff Longnecker, and returned to this city to-day. He made a confession to the Sheriff last night, in which he gave particulars of the crime.

The firm of Von Lengerke Dietmold, powder dealers of this city, has been requested by the War and Navy Departments to make experiments for the United States Government with the view of obtaining a smokeless powder for use by the army and navy. Mr. Dietmold said yesterday that he had just sent instructions to three establishments in Europe, with which his company has connection, to commence investigations.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The third annual reunion of Company F, Seventeenth Regiment, New York State Volunteers, known during the war as "The Westchester Chasseurs," was held here today, and there were present about forty of the veterans from New-York, Brooklyn, Yonkers, South Norwalk, Conn.; Port Chester, and Morrisaula.

The Norwood is ready. She was tested this morning on the bay at 200 pounds pressure, and Mr. Reuben Riley, who had charge of the repairs to her condenser, pronounces her to be in first-class condition in every particular. She will be, ready on Saturday to accompany Vamoose and other steam yachts over the American Yacht Club's course.

ELIZABETH, Sept. 28. -- Judge McCormick of the Union County Court to-day issued an order for a special election to be held at Westfield Oct. 20 to decide whether certain parts of that township shall be formed into a borough with the name of Westfield. A petition asking for this to be done was presented the Judge by Chauncey B. Ripley, E.J. Whitehead, and other residents.

Deputy Sheriff Burke has charge of the prisoners who are taken to Sing Sing after their conviction in the Court of General Sessions. It is a position of a good deal of responsibility, as many of the men he takes to prison cells have their eyes open for the least chance to escape. They realize that it is their last opportunity to make an effort to avoid servitude.

More workmen are now employed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard than at any time since the close of the last war. The number approaches closely to 2,000. In addition there are between 70 and 80 officers and over 300 clerks and draughtsmen. In the construction department there are alone 1,300 men.

In a circular letter dated Sept. 21, addressed to the New-York Life's policy holders in North and South Carolina, and signed by Church Lane, the company's general agents for those States, an effort is made to show that the policy holders will do themselves much harm by forfeiting their policies on the strength of the present attack on the company's President.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 28. -- The O'Brien libel case is attracting considerable attention here, and the position of the accused is not improved in the public eye by his characteristic erratic conduct.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 28. -- To-night was anxiously awaited by more than three-fourths of the residents of Plainfield, N.J., from the fact that the newly-enacted ordinance prohibiting the playing of music in beer or liquor, saloons was to go into effect. Up to three months ago the citizens of Plainfield found peaceful repose after the hour when decent persons retire.

Senator Hendricks took the oath of office yesterday and became Collector of the Port of New-York. There was precious little parade about the performance, and compared with Mr. Fassett's induction into the same office it lacked the semi-publicity which was supposed to add ecist to a formal change in Custow House administration.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- This afternoon fire broke out in the oil warehouse of Phillips Cunningham at 136 North Delaware Avenue. Despite the efforts of the firemen the flames spread west to Water Street and to the rag warehouse of Jessup Moore, adjoining the burning oil store on the north.

WASHINGTON, Del., Sept. 28. -- Before an investigating committee of the Levy Court, to-day, was told, under oath, the story of how John J. Dougherty and George W. McKee, two Democratic County Tax Collectors, sold to the Republican Committee of this city a large number of tax receipts and then returned the taxables as errors. They also failed to pay the money received for these taxes to the County Treasurer.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Harrisburg says that the legislative investigating committee followed Senator Flinn's advice to-night, and concluded to go slow about acceding to Gov. Pattison's request that the Attorney General be allowed to appear before the committee and examine witnesses. "Going slow" was the order of business from first to last.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28. -- An Important budget of news arrived to-day from Shanghai, China. The riots continue in the interior and the northern provinces. At Shenpao a large crowd of bad characters surrounded a girls' school and began to throw stones. The servants of the school at first stoutly resisted, but, overpowered by superior numbers, they at last fled and the school premises were destroyed.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- J. Sloat Fassett, Republican candidate for Governor, and John W. Vrooman, candidate for Lieutenant Governor, accompanied by Archie Baxter of Elmira and a number of local politicians from the Counties of Oneida and Lewis, arrived here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Mr. Fassett and his party were enthusiastically greeted all along the route from Utica.

President ELIOT of Harvard University discusses in the October number of the Forum what he calls "One Remedy for Municipal Misgovernment." It is a serious defect of the article that the writer does not throw any light upon the means by which the remedy is to be applied. It is easy enough to point out the difficulties and the failures of municipal administration.

Will you permit me to give some reasons why I shall vote the Democratic State ticket this Fall and why I think it ought to succeed? You will excuse the dogmatic form of expression, I trust, because your space will not allow me anything more than succinct statements.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept 28. -- What is believed to have been an attempt to blow up the house of Mrs. Ann Welch, a widow, living on Meadow Street, was discovered yesterday morning. Mrs. Welch, who lives in the second story of the two-story frame building, came down stairs about 7 o'clock and saw a small block of wood lying outside. She picked it up, intending to use it to cook her breakfast.

WASHINGTON, Sept 28. -- The marble statue of Pope Leo XIII., presented to the Catholic University at Washington by Count Joseph Loubat of New-York, was unrolled this afternoon. The unveiling exercises were very simple and were participated in by Archbishop Corrigan of New-York, Cardinal Gibbons, and a large number of prominent members of the priesthood and the laity.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Monday, Sept. 28:
An incident occurred in this city recently which is worth recording as showing the entire confidence of the policy holders and the public generally in Theodore M. Banta.
THE NEW-YORK TIMES has got another big libel suit on its hands. The party that sued it for $1,000,000 has now brought another suit for $750,000. And still THE TIMES seems to be happy.

Samuel W. Thornton still persists in the story that he and his sister-in-law, Eva Jewell, were carried out to sea on a Spanish vessel, and so retold the story last night to the officers of the Mount Olivet Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn Thornton is one of the Elders of the church, and as last night was the regular meeting night of the session of the church, he asked that they hear his story.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Telegraph's St. Petersburg correspondent says: Dispatches from the interior are more alarming. The August frosts destroyed the barley crop, the staple food, in Archangel. In the extreme north the crops have been spoiled by rains. Straw from thatched roof's is utilized for fodder. Cattle are dying by wholesale on the roadsides.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Every Republican in office is fully aware of the importance of the elections in the States in the approaching contests of November, not only for the power the Republicans may recover, hold, or lose, but for the effect that the results will have upon the campaign of next year. Reflection upon the matter makes them more than usually anxious, particularly about Ohio and New-York.

Peter De Lacy was talkative on Sunday on behalf of both himself and the Western Union Telegraph Company, whom he represents in the fight which has been in progress with the Brooklyn Jockey Club. Peter had prepared to do a heap of tremendously sensational things yesterday, according to his talk on Sunday. But Peter's sensations failed to put in an appearance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Senator Quay came up from his Atlantic City retreat to-day, and the fact of his coming was known to only a few. Gov. Pattison's proclamation called him to the city, and Republican leaders from every direction visited Room 34 at the Continental as part of that political sympathy that invariably brings the leaders together when the Senator is about the city.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 29. -- Last night at 9 o'clock the door bell of Farmer Warden's house was rung by a woman who said, as the door was opened: "Here is a lady who wants to stay all night." The visitor had on a stylish hat with a veil drawn over her face and wore a long circular, reaching to the floor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The State Department is without any information relative to the reported outbreak in Guatemala City, Guatemala, Sept. 15. The latest information received was contained in a letter dated the 14th inst., the day before the fighting is said to have commenced. It made no allusion to any impending trouble.

ROME, Sept. 29. -- An imposing religious ceremony took place this morning in St. Peter's Church. For some days the Pope has been receiving bodies of religious pilgrims from various countries, and the city is filled with them. When it was announced that the Pope would celebrate low mass this morning great eagerness was manifested by the throngs of pilgrims to attend the services.

An almost absolute certainty of rain, coupled with a light racing card for the day, served to make the attendance at the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday about the smallest of the meeting. Thirty-seven horses in all ran, and these were sufficient to induce a lively lot of speculation in each of the events.

Our protectionist friends have lately exhibited signs of fatigue when any discussion of our tin-plate industry has been threatened, or even any allusion to the subject made. We do not blame them. The duty on tin plate in the McKinley bill was almost a solitary effort, not to protect an existing industry, but to create an industry that confessedly did not exist by offering large rewards to people who would go into it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29. -- The retirement from business, within the last year, of four of the insurance companies organized in this State, and the recently-rumored possible retirement of two or three of the remaining local companies, are causing sensational talk and speculation among home underwriters, as to the probable future of the insurance business.

The trial of Robert Howe and Nettle Hamburg for stealing $7,000 worth of jewelry from the store of Carl Wernicke at 10 and 12 West Twenty-eighth Street, which is progressing before Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions, grows more interesting daily. The jewelry, which was found in the trunks of the accused, consists of silverware and diamond rings and pins.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 29. -- Clem Lea was arrested at Corinth, Miss., for carrying a pistol last Winter. His defense was that he was a United States officer in pursuit of a fugitive, for whom he had a warrant. The Mayor fined him $25, and he appealed to the Circuit Court, which affirmed the finding of the Mayor and ordered Lea to pay a fine of $50.

The Democratic State campaign has begun in earnest. The wheels that will not cease running till the night of the 3d of November, five weeks from last night, were carefully oiled yesterday afternoon in the Hoffmann House by the Executive Committee of the State Committee, and the Democratic machinery is now under way.

The stock of books of John Pierce, in two small rooms of an ancient building in Nassau Street, was sold by auction by the Sheriff yesterday morning. At the beginning of the sale Commissioner MacLean, counsel for Mr. Brayton Ives, objected to the sale of several books on the ground that they were the property of his client.

The convention of the Massachusetts Democrats yesterday was united and enthusiastic in the selection of candidates for State offices and in the adoption of a perfectly sound platform. The platform and the speech of Gov. RUSSELL recognized three national issues as of "paramount importance" -- civil service reform, tariff reform, and a sound currency.

When the steamer Waesland was on her way from Antwerp to this port a child of one of the steerage passengers was taken ill with smallpox. The child was isolated as far as possible under the circumstances, and some of the steerage passengers were vaccinated. As there were 808 in the steerage, it was almost impossible to vaccinate all, as there was not enough virus on board.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention held here this afternoon gave Senator William P. Richardson a unanimous nomination for a second term. The convention did its work in a perfunctory manner, without any exhibition of the enthusiasm that might attend the selection of a candidate who is eminently fit or who had made a thoroughly creditable record as a legislator.

The French man-of-war Naiade, now in this port, serves as an object lesson showing how efficient it is possible for sailors to become as infantrymen. The Naiade carries screw of about 400 men. There are no marines aboard. This statement applies to all vessels of the French Navy. The navies of Great Britain and the United States alone employ soldiers to guard their sailors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- A foretaste of America's welcome to the World's Fair in 1893 was given to-night at the Palmer House. The recipients were the visiting Government World's Fair Commissioners from European nations, and the entertainment took the form of a banquet, the magnificence of which has seldom been rivaled -- at least in Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- Senator Quay came up from Atlantic City again at noon to-day, and was in close conference with Republican Party workers in Room 49 at the Continental Hotel until long into the night. Great secrecy characterized the proceedings.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District will meet here to-morrow. The district is composed of the Counties of Herkimer, Madison, and Otsego, but the convention is held outside of the district to secure neutral ground, as each county has a candidate.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 29. -- Gov. Campbell is making things very interesting for the Republicans in Northern Ohio this week by conducting a vigorous speaking canvass through the rural districts of the Western Reserve. He began Monday afternoon at Wellington, where he spoke to an audience that crowded the Town Hall, and discussed in a very effective way the results of the tariff on butter and cheese in that dairy centre.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Sons of Veterans comprising the Department of New-Jersey, post system, held their sixth annual encampment here this afternoon and evening. There were forty delegates present, representing the following posts: Elisworth, No. 2. of Union Hill; Hexamer, No. 5, of Newark; Custer, No. 6, of Bayonne; Joseph Weston, No. 10, of Hackensack; Marcus L. Ward, No. 13, of Newark; Isaac N. Tucker, No. 15, of Newark and Paterson.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 29. -- The Farmers' Alliance, through its Minnesota organ, the State has issued No. 3 of its sensational series of "hold your wheat" circulars, but it is not intended to reach the public until Friday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The freshman class of Cornell held its first meeting to-day and discussed the question of rushing. At the meeting in the morning President Adams appeared and spoke. He advised the class not to rush, but did not say that there was any idea of the Faculty to prohibit the customary rush which will take place to-morrow night.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Sept. 29. -- The Republican organs have been publishing glowing accounts of Major McKinley's ability upon the stump, and proclaiming that his arguments were of the most convincing sort. Some of the partisan newspapers expressed the greatest sympathy for the Governor, and regarded his entering into a joint debate with the author of a high protective tariff as madness, if not suicidal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29. -- A letter from Shanghai received to-day gives the details of a tragic and sensational occurrence in the northern province of China:

The New-Yorks and Bostons played two games at Boston yesterday. The Bostons won both, and pulled themselves up to within two points of the Chicagos. Should they win both games from she New-Yorks to-day they will take the lead, even though the Chicagos do win.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- There is no doubt that the President and his Cabinet at the meeting to-day found abundant reason for regretting that it had ever been regarded as necessary that Patrick Egan should be sent to Chile as a diplomatic guardian of the interests and citizens of the United States.

The marriage of Robert R. Selleck and Miss Cora M. Travis occurred yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mabbett Travis, at Babylon, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H.L. Glover of Moriches. Miss Mamie Travis, cousin of the bride, was maid of honor. The ushers were W.W. Freeman and G.M. Selleck of Brooklyn.

The first meeting of the new Board of Managers of the Metropolitan Associations of the Amateur Athletic Union was held last night at the Astor House. Mr. C.F. Matthewson presided. It was decided to reinstate E.V. Scheide, an insurance broker, who recently competed in some games when not registered. Committees for the year were appointed as follows:

LONDON, Sept 29. -- The dispatch from St. Petersburg to the Telegraph describing the situation in Russia arising from the failure of crops, and detailing harrowing incidents of the famine now prevailing, part of winch has already been cabled to the United States, adds that not for centuries has such widespread distress been recorded.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29. -- The financial troubles of W.H. Cheppu, the well-known bookmaker and turfman and the owner of the Meadowthorpe Stud, this city, has been the reigning sensation in Lexington financial circles for several days.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Livingston County Democratic Convention met at Avon to-day and nominated Aaron Barber of Avon for member of Assembly.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29. -- The fourth day of the trial of O'Brien, Dalziel's Montreal correspondent, for libeling Prince George of Wales during his visit here brought out some testimony damaging to O'Brien's reputation for truth. In opening, the list of subscribers to the prosecution fund was produced. It contained the names of some of the most prominent men in the city.

The feat of the Philadelphian amateurs in beating the visiting English eleven is perhaps the most creditable achievement thus far of American cricket. The visiting team is unquestionably a representative eleven, and it includes a very exceptional amateur bowler. Yet its defeat by eight wickets was entirely decisive of the superiority of the home team.

The Norwood and Vamoose were both out of water yesterday, overhauling for the great race next Saturday, and were objects of interest all day long to hundreds of persons who, notwithstanding the showers, stood with or without umbrellas looking at them first from one point of view and then from another. The Norwood was on the ways at Wintringham's yard, at the foot of Fifty-fifth Street, South Brooklyn.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The political situation in Rockland County, so far as the Assembly nomination is concerned, is exceedingly interesting and very peculiar. There are several Democratic aspirants for the nomination, among the number being Thomas Finnegan and John W. Felter of Haverstraw, and Frank P. Demarest of Clarkstown.
Mr. George William Curtis delivered the following address yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League in Buffalo:

The Brooklyns defeated the Philadelphias again at Eastern Park yesterday. Keefe pitched for the visitors and did well, all things considered. Although the Brooklyns made 8 runs, not one was earned. Errors back of Keefe gave them 5 runs in the first inning. His bases on balls and wild pitches were responsible for the rest. He never could handle the ball well in rainy weather, and yesterday was no exception to the rule.

The Kinderhook Rough Notes, in an article relating to the time when the late George Jones of THE NEW-YORK TIMES entered the newspaper business, prints two letters -- one written by Mr. Jones and the other by Horace Greeley -- which are very interesting. The Rough Notes says:

The Standard Gas Light Company had a hearing before the Board of Health yesterday, to show cause, if any existed, why the order of the board of Sept. 10, in which its works were declared a public nuisance, should not be carried into effect.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- President Scott said nothing to the students yesterday about Saturday's flag rush, and they thought they had got out of the scrape easily. The Faculty, however, considered during the day what should be done, and at chapel this morning Dr. Scott made a stirring speech. He was visibly affected.

A special committee of the National Civil Service League made a report at the annual meeting in Buffalo on the effect of the spoils method of making appointments upon the results of the last Federal census. The committee first calls attention to the pledges of the Republican Party and of the National Administration in regard to the application of the principle of civil service reform.

The staid and quiet Brooklyn neighborhood of which the Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church is the centre was stirred to its depths last night. The occasion of the uncommon excitement was the wedding of Mr. Casprr H. Harring and Miss Mary A. Whitson, for which the customary Wednesday night prayer-meeting exercises had been postponed for forty-eight hours, or until Friday evening.

During the meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, which closed yesterday, $146,274 in stakes and purses was divided between the various owners racing at the track. The money was divided among them in this way:

The Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad accepted Mr. Jay Gould's financial statement yesterday and voted to pass the usual 1 per cent dividend for this quarter. The price of the stock promptly dropped from 63 34 to 59 34, and the fact that more than 56,000 shares changed hands during the day showed that there were eager buyers as well as sellers.
BUFFALO, Sept. 30. -- As the train ran into the Central Station at 9:20 o'clock this forenoon a reporter boarded the car and asked Mr. Moore to explain the robbery.

Mr. David B. Hill is supporting the Democratic ticket in New-York, of course. What else could he do? He would have preferred to make it himself, but as he was not allowed to have his own way in everything, he is being as cheerful as possible. Mr. Hill is not the man to quarrel with his bread and butter.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 30. -- The centennial of Free Mason in New-Britain will be celebrated by Harmony Lodge of that city, Tuesday, Oct. 13. Washington Commandery of Hartford, the oldest templar organization in the United States, will take part in the festivities. The memorial address will be made by the Rev. J.T. Pettee of Meriden.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 30. -- Gen. Boulanger committed suicide to-day in the cemetery of Ixelles, one mile south of this city, on the tomb of Mme. de Bonnemain.

We remarked the other day that the political contest in this State was not one in which the conscientious voter could decide off-hand to give his support to either candidate, and that a proper discharge of the citizen's highest duty demands this year "an unusually patient inquiry as to the facts, for full information is beyond question the voter's best safeguard against mistakes."
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30. -- The following is published here this morning from the City of Mexico:

The Fall meeting of the New-York Jockey Club, the last racing meeting of the year, will begin at Jerome Park this afternoon, and a most attractive programme is offered for racegoers, there being two stakes on for decision, the Essex, for two-year-olds and the Hunter, for three-year-olds, though the latter does not promise anything sensational.

In view of the angry menaces with which China is assailed by leaders of public opinion in Europe and America it becomes necessary to inquire whether the Government and people of that vast Eastern Empire are, or are not, entitled to any consideration of honesty, justice, or humanity from what is conventionally called the civilized world.

A story of shipwreck and attendant hardships endured for weeks and a gallant rescue accomplished in an Atlantic gale was related yesterday when the Allan State Line steamship Siberian arrived in port. On board were the Captain and four men of the English schooner Little Wonder, who owe their preservation to the splendid seamanship of the officers and crew of the Siberian.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Director of the Mint, with the approval of the Secretary of the Treasury, to-day issued she renewing special instructions to the Superintendent of the Assay Office in New-York City:

MONTREAL, Sept. 30. -- The fifth day's proceedings in the O'Brien libel case was a small sized circus from start to finish. The tilts between counsel not only amused the large audience and the jurors, but kept them on the qui vive for what was coming next. Everybody expected that the defense would make a fairly strong case, but one or two of their witnesses were harder on "O'Brien" than those of the prosecution.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- When the American express train which was robbed on the Central reached this city at 10 o'clock last night. Detective Furlong of Chief Humphrey's staff was in his office over the passenger room. The conductor of the train called him and told him there were three men on the platform who had beaten their way up on the train from New-York.

C.H. Venner Co. of 33 Wall Street announced on the Stock Exchange yesterday that they had suspended. The firm has a branch in Boston, and a similar announcement was made on the Exchange in that city. Venner Co. have done a large business in investment securities, particularly water bonds and other municipal issues, and those of street-car companies, gas works,

In addition to the range-finder and telescopic sight devices of Lieut B.A. Fiske now in use aboard United States war vessels, the Navy Department is considering the advisability of adopting an electric helm and signal apparatus recently designed by this same officer.

The annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New-York began its work at St. Bartholomew's Church. Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The entire time was taken up in discussing the report of the Committee on Canons, which wishes to authorize the Bishop to appoint a rector to a vacant, church should the Vestry not supply the church within six months, the Bishop's appointee to occupy the pulpit till a rector is chosen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The receipts of the Government since Sept. 1 amount to $28,385,000, being an excess of $4,287,000 over ordinary expenditures during the same time. The additional payment of $18,000,000 during the same time on account of bond redemption, however, makes a net loss in cash for the month of about $14,000,000

Is it safe for the Norwood to make Saturday's race? Mr. Mosher, her builder, says that it is not, and that Mr. Monro has not money enough to induce him to go in her, in her present condition, while Mr. Monro, her owner, says it is safe, and that Reuben Riley, the machinist who repaired the injury to her condenser, will go in her and take the chances.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- The greatest excitement exists in political circles here over the action of the present Grand Jury, which is making an earnest effort to bring boodlers to justice. Boss Buckley and others have fled, while those who remain refuse to appear before the Grand Jury.

The exodus of Russian Jews has scarcely begun, but already the result has been to double the arrivals of Russians in the United States. In August last year less than 4,000 Russian immigrants were recorded, but this year the total is 8,418, or within a dozen of as many as the German arrivals.
THE TIMES last Friday pointed out that there was a shortage in the supply of the city's water. It was stated then that but fifteen days' supply remained on hand.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- At 2:05 o'clock this morning the fifth section of the special excursion run on account of the reunion of the Olin family at Bennington, Vt., left Kent. It was running as the sixth section of No. 4. Five sleepers, four day coaches, and a baggage car composed the train, which was crowded with Michigan excursionists.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 30. -- An adjourned meeting of the Charleston policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company was held yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce. The Hon. Charles Richardson Miles presided.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District commenced the biannual struggle here to-day. E.A. Brown was made Chairman. Nominating speeches wore dispensed with. Each county in the district has six delegates and a candidate. Two years ago 900 ballots were taken, and the convention became known as the "Three Sixes."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30. -- The twenty-second annual convention of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners was called to order at 11 o'clock this morning, in the Odd Fellows' Building, by State Commissioner C.P. Ellerb, who is President of the association. State Actuary Augustus Harvey acted as Secretary. On the call of the roll the following delegates responded:

Mr. HENRY CABOT LODGE declines to discuss the "Issues of the Campaign" in Massachusetts with Mr. RUSSELL unless he can restrict the subjects of debate to suit himself. This he claims the right to do as the challenged party. It is a rather narrow way to treat a proposition for a joint debate, to call it a challenge giving either party the sole right to choose the weapons.

The Brooklyn Eagle reviews the letters to THE TIMES of Mr. HALE. Mr. SCHWAB, Gov. CHAMBERLAIN, and Mr. THOMPSON upon the issues of the State election, and expresses the conviction, in agreement with our own, that the independents "who think to the roots of present conditions" will see their way clear to vote the Democratic State ticket. The Eagle says:

The suicides of BALMACEDA and of BOULANGER point the same moral, and that is the utter ruin that is entailed by failure in the career of a political adventurer. It is not likely that the moral will be laid to heart by anybody who embarks upon that career, because no such person expects to fail. BALMACEDA was scarcely more of a political adventurer than it seems that any Spanish-American statesman must be.

We have lately been congratulating ourselves upon the impossibility in the more thickly-settled parts of the country of such train robberies as have occurred in the West. It is just at this time that a successful attempt is made upon an express car upon the New-York Central. The attempt succeeded, just as an attempt at highway robbery might succeed at midday on Wall Street, by reason of its very unexpectedness and its apparent hopelessness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- For reasons of policy, which the public may or may not assume are wise, the State Department is preserving the strictest secrecy about such correspondence as it is having with Minister Egan, and with the result of a season of calm and confidence at the State Department in the restoration at Santiago of better relations between the government of Chile and our incompetent and irritating representative there.
