BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- The Bostons wound up the season at home by taking two more games and stepping into first place. In the first game they batted hard and fielded well, winning easily. Coughlin was hit in the spine by a batted ball in the fifth inning and gave way to Welch.

The official opening of the twenty-ninth session of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women took place last night in the prettily-decorated parlors of the hospital building, 213 West Fifty-Fourth Street. The Rev. Dr. Francis Bottome opened the proceedings with prayer. Introductory remarks were made by the Chairman and President of the Board of Trustees, Henry S. Day.

The season in Brooklyn wound up yesterday. Two games were played and the home team defeated the Philadelphias twice. The first game was very exciting. The "Phillies" appeared to have the game well in hand, when the Brooklyns unexpectedly took advantage of Thornton's wildness and won the game. Two bases on balls and two safe hits in the last inning gave the Bridegrooms 3 runs and a victory of 1 run.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 30 -- Letters received at the frontier from Guatemala state that President Barillas has ordered three journalists who had criticized his actions to immediately leave the country. The President is daily becoming more and more unpopular. The dissatisfaction among the troops, who have not received their pay for some time, is rapidly spreading.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- At the funeral of William H. Kemble to-day, there were present the most honored representatives of the circles of finance, commerce, and politics. The services at the Kemble country seat, Mary Lawn, near Glenside, Montgomery County, in the morning, were attended by a multitude of persons from far and near, the majority being Philadelphians who had been more or less intimate associates of Mr. Kemble.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Pension Commissioner Raum acts in a very curious fashion for a man who is at all desirous of commanding public confidence in his uprightness. Having been under fire for months on various charges, instead of sweeping them aside by proving them to be without foundation he has adopted the plan of attempting to throttle the accusations.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Special American Express train No. 31, due here at 3:10 A.M. to-day, was robbed between here and Little Falls. The robber brought the train to a standstill a mile east of this city by applying the air brakes by means of the valve in the car, and then escaped in the darkness.

VIENNA, Sept. 30. -- The Presse of this city to-day publishes a rumor that the Archduke Karl Ludwig, who, upon the death of the Emperor's son, Crown Prince Rudolph, became the heir presumptive to the throne of Austria-Hungary, is about to resign his title or heirship in favor of his son, the Archduke Franz.

News reached this city late last night that the side-wheel steamer C.H. Northam of the New-Haven Line, which left Peck Slip late yesterday afternoon for New-Haven, had stranded on Black Rock, an obstruction in the Sound just below College Point. The vessel had on board, it is said, about 150 or 200 passengers. She was scheduled to arrive at New-Haven about 9 o'clock last night.

" Some of the owners of farms in Minnesota and the Dakotas will get more money from their wheat this year than the farms cost them," ex-Congressman Samuel P. Snider of Minneapolis said to a TIMES reporter yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. "It is a wonderfully great crop, and the people are feeling so good over it that they have no time or inclination to talk politics."

The Buffalo Express, a good Republican newspaper and an able one, kindly reminds several journals now engaged in giving aid and comfort to the Democratic cause in this State that in former years they have sometimes spoken irreverently of Mr. FLOWER'S political ambitions.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Mr. Fassett and Mr. Vrooman arrived here between 4 and 5 o'clock this afternoon on a special train from Albany, consisting of Superintendent Vorhees's monitor engine and private car. They were met at the station by Mr. Robert H. Hunter of the Republican Committee, and escorted to the Nelson House, where a large crowd was in waiting.

If the Democratic leaders desire to curtail as much as possible the mischief to be done in the State campaign by the bad repute of Tammany, they would do well to direct their efforts to preventing the nomination of JOHN J. SCANNELL for Congress in the Tenth District. That nomination is said to be "on the cards," as they now stand.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 1. -- A circular letter numerously signed by Democratic Knights of Labor will this week be addressed to General Master Workman Powderly, protesting against the deal with Senator Quay for the labor vote. A copy of this letter fell into the hands of a newspaper man to-day. It says, among other things:

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Dispatches received here from St. Ives, Cornwall, near Penzance, and from other places give accounts of a gallant act of heroism upon the part of a crew of volunteer lifeboat men, chiefly seaside visitors, and of the rank cowardice, in comparison, of eight professional life savers.

With no extravagant interval of rest, the Philadelphia cricketers and their English guests begin a return match, for which, as before, three days are set apart. While curiosity to observe the style of the visitors may be somewhat appeased, the local interest in the contest is yet probably not much abated.

The marked activity at the Brooklyn Navy Yard still continues. The work in progress, as outlined in THE TIMES of last Tuesday, is greater than at any time since the close of the last war. The ships now fitting out for service include the cruisers Boston, Concord, Yorktown, and Bennington, the gunboat Petrel, and the corvette Yantic.
Harrison has made no such contribution.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The second day of the Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twenty-third District closed without a nomination. Three sessions were held and the number of ballots taken increased to 400, with each candidate showing the same strength as at the start.

It was red-letter day for the stewards of the Cunarder Etruria and 400 of their friends yesterday. From early morning until late at night duties "aboard ship" gave way to the excitements of their fourth annual picnic, which they held at Sulzer's, Oak Point, at the entrance to Long Island Sound.

The convention of the Protestant Episcopal Churches of the Diocese of New-York continued its sessions at St. Bartholomew's Church, Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday. Immediately upon the assembling of the delegates for the morning session, Bishop Potter delivered his annual address, which was a resume of diocesan work for the past year. After a number of ballots, the following committeemen and deputies were elected:

BRUSSELS, Oct. 1. -- It has been decided that the funeral of Gen. Boulanger will take place Saturday afternoon. Henri Rochefort will attend the funeral, which will be purely a civil ceremony. The clergy, under the instructions of the Archbishop of Malines, have finally and definitely refused to officiate at the ceremonies attending the interment of the General's remains.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- Farewell to the long club! This morning the sturdy policeman appeared in his Fall uniform, changed his light blouse for a dress coat, and swapped his white helmet for a black one, but his companion with last year's Fall suit, the long club, was conspicuously absent. The board has so ordered it.

The statement as to the condition of the Norwood as set forth by Mr. Mosher, her designer and builder, made public exclusively in THE TIMES, was much talked about by yachtsmen yesterday. There was a general feeling of regret that there should be any room for doubt that the Norwood is in first-class condition for the race.

The steamer Majestic, which arrived yesterday morning after a long and rough passage, brought Mr. and Mrs. Kendal, the famous English actors, who propose making another tour of the United States. They are now at the Victoria Hotel. Their season will open at the Star Theatre Monday, Oct. 12, with Tom Taylor's play, "Still Waters Run Deep."

Inspector Conlin, Capt. Killilea, and several officers yesterday raided the offices of James F. Sullivan, at 2,058 Eighth Avenue, which had been reported as the headquarters of a green goods gang. In a rear room were found boxes that are used by green goods men, and several of them contained green paper cut to the size of bank bills, also sawdust, soap, and stones.

NEWCASTLE, Oct. 1. -- The formal opening of the great National Liberal Federation Congress occurred here to-day. For days past, in anticipations of this monster Liberal demonstration, crowds of people have been pouring into Newcastle from all parts of England and Scotland and from many parts of Ireland. The morning trains have discharged thousands of extra visitors, although it is raising hard.

The members of the Republican State Committee were surprised and displeased when they saw in the morning papers of yesterday their call for cash, which had bean prepared only for the eyes of Federal office holders and others from whom they thought contributions could be exacted. The committee had intended to keep the circular a secret.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 1. -- When President Lincoln issued his first call for 75,000 volunteers, April 15, 1861, the National Light Infantry and Washington Artillery, two Pottsville companies, responded, with 237 men in line. They were the First Defenders, along with the Ringgold Artillery, the Logan Guard, and the Allen Rides, and to-day they turned another leaf in their history by the dedication and unveiling of a massive and magnificent soldiers' monument in Garfield Square.

According to reports which had wide circulation and a good deal of effect in Wall Street yesterday, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company is about to issue $10,000,000 or more bonds. Some rumors have it that the bonds have already been issued.

The new pneumatic disappearing gun carriage is now at Sandy Hook and awaits an official test with a ten-inch steel breech-loading rifle. The idea of the carriage is to lower the gun for loading purposes, and then throw it up to a height of several feet to put it into the firing position. The ability of the carriage to stand the test is entirely problematical.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- This was Governor's Day at the Inter-State Fair and the crowd inside the grounds was enormous, between fifty and sixty thousand. From the observatory over the grand stand, when the balloons went up and the people all stood with upturned faces, the sight was most impressive. Fully 10,000 swarmed over the infield, and the entire round of fencing to the race track was lined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The latest form that the Raum scandal has taken is certainly the most complicated and troublesome that it has yet assumed. Commissioner Raum has asked Secretary Noble to discharge three clerks, who appear to have been more or less trusted by the Secretary and to have held confidential relations with him, for doing precisely what they were expected to do by the Secretary.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 1. -- The regular Fall meeting of the Cedar Rapids Presbytery of the Presbyterian Synod of Iowa was held here yesterday, at which twenty-four clergymen and eighteen ruling Elders were present. The principal discussion of the day was on the proposed change of Section 3 of the Confession of Faith. In the subordinate standards of the Free Church of Scotland, Section 3, the one under discussion, reads as follows:

Some enterprising Brazilians of this city and Rio propose to establish a new line of steamships to run between this port and the principal ports of Brazil, to be supplemented by a line of sailing vessels to ply between Baltimore and New-Orleans and the ports of the South American republic. The projectors have already advertised for bids for four steamships of 4,000 tons burden and eight sailing vessels of equal capacity.

A private dwelling, which differs in no important respect from its neighbors, on Thirty fourth Street near Fifth Avenue, is now transformed into a small museum. Nothing outside gives warning that it is no longer a dwelling but an Art House; once inside, one discovers that here is an interior such as a fanatical collector might offer, a collector capable of gradually retiring before his own collection into the garret and out at the scuttle.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, to-day gave to the press the following report of the details attending the execution of the four murderers at Sing Sing on the morning of July 7. The report was first presented to Warden Brown of Sing Sing Prison, by Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald of New-York and Samuel B. Ward of Albany, who wore the official physicians in charge of the executions.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1. -- The closing-out sale of the Elmendorf Stud drew a large crowd this afternoon to Mr. Swigert's lovely farm, six miles from this city on the Paris Pike. Among the horsemen present from other States were J.W. Mackey of Sacramento, Cal., buyer for Mr. Haggin; James Howard, Assistant Secretary of the Washington Park Club, Chicago; Gen. W.H. Jackson and C.H. Gillock of Nashville, and Tyce Bate of Gallatin, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Commissioners appointed to represent the United States on the Intercontinental Railway Commission have submitted a report to Secretary Blaine of the progress made by the surveying parties in South and Central America on the line of the proposed road.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 1. -- Republican primaries were held in this city last evening. Candidates for Aldermen were nominated and delegates to the City Supervisor's department and Assembly District Conventions were elected.

Jay Gould at a business meeting in Wall Street fell suddenly into his chair unconscious. This report had free circulation on Wall Street yesterday, and circumstantial support was given to it. It was at the quarterly meeting of Missouri Pacific Directors Wednesday that Mr. Gould is said to have suffered thus. A stroke of paralysis some people said it was.

Two questions of great importance to the merchants of New-York were discussed by the Chamber of Commerce at its meeting yesterday, the first since the Summer vacation. One related to silver, the other to the shameful tangle at the Public Stores. President Charles S. Smith brought the former to the attention of the Chamber in his opening address, in which he said:

The acting chemist of the Department of Health has been paying a visit to the vineyards of the Hudson in company with a representative of the Department of Agriculture. He comes back with a report that where the Bordeaux mixture is properly applied it does not remain on the grapes and is not injurious or threatening to the health of the consumer, but where it is improperly applied, traces of it remain.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Mr. Gladstone to-day laid the cornerstone of a new wing of Trinity College at Glenalmond, Scotland. He looked well. He has been greatly benefited by the highland air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Secretary Foster has just issued one of his monthly novelettes under the periodical title of "Statement of the Public Debt." Taken for what it says, it shows that the Government has in hand, convenient for use and payment to anybody entitled to receive money from the Government, nearly $45,000,000.
A stout man with side whiskers and a bottle-green overcoat went up to the main gate of the Westchester County fair grounds at White Plains at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and knocked for admittance.

The report of the two physicians who had official charge of the electrical executions at Sing Sing on the 7th of July shows that the application of the current in the four cases was made somewhat experimental. In the first case the current of 1,485 volts was applied for 27 seconds, and, signs of life appearing, was applied again, after an interval of between one and two minutes, for 26 1/4 seconds.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has been sued again for libel by the New-York Life Insurance Company. In the present suit only $750,000 is demanded as damages. The first suit was for $1,000,000. Together they make $1,750,000. This is plain enough, though it might not jibe with some of President Beers's arithmetic. It is worth noting that THE TIMES keeps up its criticisms on this insurance company, or rather the management of its President.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 1. -- The Republican mass meeting summoned by the anti-Mahonite element was called to order to-day by W.A. Patie of Roanoke. Col. H.C. Parsons, leader of the movement, was made permanent Chairman, and Yardley T. Brow of Loudoun County, Secretary. The Committee on Plan of Organization recommended that a committee of 100 be appointed to take charge of the abandoned campaign.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The Democrats propose to retain their hold on the Sixteenth Senatorial District. This afternoon they unanimously renominated Senator M.F. Collins, and he has accepted the nomination. Under ordinary circumstances the district is Republican, but while the Democratic vote in Rensselaer has been increasing the Republican vote in Washington has decreased.
ANNAPOLIS, Oct. 1. -- The United States Naval Academy began its forty-seventh academic year to-day. Following is the list of officers, embracing many changes, assigned to duty in the institution:

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Legend somehow connects the name of Blanche Lebouvier with Laferriere fame. At all events the celebrity of the former has bounded into the full sunshine of Parisian success in a wonderfully short time, and the last dramatic seasons have laid their glory, in a millinery, sense, at the feet of charming Blanche.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- At the opening exercises of Cornell University to-day, President Adams spoke as follows:

The voice of the business community of New-York on questions of public policy which affect the commercial interests of the country and which equally affect all the operations of industry and trade is wont to find utterance through the Chamber of Commerce, and seldom is that utterance uncertain or unsound.
BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- The Democratic State Committee sent another letter to Henry Cabot Lodge last evening, which concludes as follows:

St. Ann's Church, Sayville, L.L, was the scene of a quiet although fashionable wedding yesterday when the nuptials of Miss Lena de Trobriand Post and Mr. Hamilton Fish Webster were celebrated. The marriage ceremony took place at noon. As the bridal party entered the church the "Lohengrin" bridal chorus was performed upon the organ.

VIENNA, Oct. 1. -- Emperor Francis Joseph arrived in safety at Reichenberg, near Prague, this morning, and with his advent the news of an alleged attempt upon the life of the imperial traveler spread all over Austria.

The decision of the Navy Department, as announced in THE TIMES of yesterday, to provide a preponderance of six-pound Hotchkiss rapid-fire guns in the auxiliary batteries of all the new war ships has been expected for several months by ordnance officers. As at present made up, the majority of our auxiliary batteries contain not only six-pound rapid-fire pieces, but three-pounders, one-pounders, revolving cannon of both the thirty-seven millimeter and forty-seven millimeter types, and machine guns.
Gov. Hill will start on a little Southern tour about the middle of next month. He has announced that he will be in Washington on the 20th, en route for Atlanta.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The main characteristics of the play in the return cricket match between Lord Hawke's eleven and the Philadelphia team, which began to-day at the Germantown Club's Grounds, was the light batting. The Philadelphians were all put out in their first inning for the small total of 56 runs.

LYONS, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Mr. Fassett, Mr. Vrooman, and Col. Baxter arrived here this morning. W.A. Sutherland, Republican candidate for Attorney General, came over from Rochester an hour later. There were 5,000 strangers in town. An audience of as many thousands listened to Mr. Fassett at the fair grounds in the afternoon, when he talked about the progress made by the tillers of the soil.

It is not easy to determine how significant of Canadian opinion is the meeting that was held in Windsor, on our frontier, last evening and that passed resolutions in favor of annexation to the United States. The meeting at least makes it plain that Canadians do no longer go in fear of being called "annexationists," a term that in times past has been used in Canadian politics with some effect as one of opprobrium.

The presentment of the Grand Jury in respect to the Park Place disaster is a very temperate, and a very sensible document. That body declines to indict anybody upon the ground that no proof has been offered that would be likely to satisfy a petit jury of such gross and criminal negligence as alone would justify that proceeding.

The keen-sighted and quick-scented gentlemen who have been looking and smelling over the drainage area whence New-York draws its drinking water report that the nuisances nauseously catalogued by their predecessors in previous years still exist. Not counting recent year-by-year additions, we know, therefore, of 6,146 special permanent nuisances, besides the unavoidable dirt of 25,000 persons and 33,000 animals.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Representatives of labor societies are coming to Chicago from all parts of the world to attend the Labor Congress during the World's Fair. T.V. Powderly has been in constant communication with the committee that has this work in charge, and will attend all of the conventions. John Burns, a labor member of the London Council and one of the foremost labor leaders of Great Britain, is also coming.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 2. -- The most calamitous fire Halifax has experienced in many years occurred last night, when wharf property extending from Cronan's south to Cunard's north was almost entirely destroyed. The flames were first discovered in Martin's planing mill, a two-story wooden building on Taylor's wharf. Just below the mill was Louis A. Wilson's shipsmith's shop, containing considerable valuable property, which soon caught fire.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The struggles for the Democratic nominations in the three Assembly districts of Monmouth County are growing fiercer every day, and the fight is-gradually narrowing down to a contest for supremacy between Gov. Abbett and United States Senator Rufus Blodgett. The First District primaries have been held, and Reuben G. Strahan and George M. Davison of Millstone Township are equally sanguine of success.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The news of the postponement of the conference on reciprocity with Canada, which reached here from Ottawa through THE TIMES of this morning, is corroborated here without much explanation, so far as the Administration is concerned. It has been expected that there would be a postponement, not perhaps until the return of Mr. Blaine, for that might be too indefinite, but until after the election.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 2. -- Gov. Humphrey has instructed the Attorney General to commence proceedings against the officers of the Missouri Pacific Railway Company for criminal negligence in causing the death of two men on the Kansas Central Railway. He has also instructed an officer to commence action to revoke the charter of the Kansas Central, owned by the Missouri Pacific, and restrain that road from doing any further business.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The third day's session of the Republican Senatorial Convention closed this afternoon with a total of 475 ballots and no choice. An adjournment was taken until Tuesday morning.

The Rapid-Transit Commission has found itself unable to come to any conclusion upon the plans of construction of the roads for which it has already designated the routes. Although over two weeks in possession of the reports of the consulting engineers, to whom the Commissioners had submitted the plans of Engineers William E. Worthen and William Barclay Parsons, they seem as far from reaching an agreement upon them as ever.

SALEM, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Additional interest has been added to the Searles will case by the appearance of Mrs. Maria E. Bresse of Los Angeles, Cal., as a contestant. Through her attorneys, Wells, Munroe Lee of Los Angeles, she has filed to-day with Register Mahoney of the Essex County Probate Court her appearance in the case and makes sweeping charges as her reason for so doing.

There will be no steam yacht race to-day; the great event is off for at least two weeks, if not indefinitely. The Norwood, on her way to New-London in charge of an incompetent pilot, ran upon Penfield Ridge, off Bridgeport, Conn., and destroyed her propeller. The accident happened at 8:15 A.M., when the sun was shining brightly and there was no fog.

We are glad Mr. FASSETT has asked the Democrats to tell him what they have done with the $2,000,000 of direct tax money refunded to the State of New-York from the National Treasury last Winter. We hope he will find out. But it is an indifferent sort of campaign issue for Mr. FASSETT or for any Republican to raise.

The text of the incendiary placards posted throughout Wuhu ought to be read by every American, regardless of whether or not he contributes to the funds of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. Nothing but the details of the document can enable enlightened readers to appreciate the heathen point of view.

Among the advanced impressionists of France the young American painter Mary A. Cassatt holds a high place; her work is always looked for with the expectation that it will prove in fair measure above the commonplace, even if it lacks something in beauty, as beauty goes nowadays.

These are dark days for the conservative Briton, who views with apprehension and alarm the Americanization of British politics. That disgusting process seems to be going on with increasing speed. That objectionable American device, the caucus, has been for some years domesticated in Birmingham, and there is now in progress at Newcastle another equally American manifestation in the form of a national party convention.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The Democrats of this city held to-night a grand ratification meeting, which was largely attended. This is the first move the Democrats have made since the campaign opened. The enthusiasm for Flower and Sheehan was apparent by the demonstration made.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Arrangements are now being made for a test during this month at the naval ordnance proving grounds at Indian Head of eight American-made armor plates. This test will be of greater importance than that at Annapolis in September, 1890, and its results will attract the attention of ordnance experts all over the world.

President Day of the New-Yorks yesterday asked Amos Rusie, the big pitcher, to sign a contract for next season. Rusie replied that he was in no hurry to attach his signature, and intimated that he had better wait. Rusie this year received $3,500 for his services, and it is thought that he wants a much higher figure for next season. Rusie may pitch to-day against Brooklyn.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- John Ball O-borne, United States Consul at Ghent, was married in this city last evening to Miss Bertha Josephine Grinnell. Mr. Osborne is the son of ex-Congressman E.S. Osborne of Wilkesbarre, Penn. He was graduated from Yale in 1888. Lieut. William A. Osborne, United States Army, was best man.
Mr. Beers's agents in their search for new business are indefatigable, and sometimes untrustworthy. Herewith is reproduced a circular letter issued by George W. Lane of Washington, D.C.:

NEWCASTLE, Oct. 2. -- Over four thousand persons were packed in the Tyneside Theatre to-night to hear Mr. Gladstone. The stage was occupied by members of the House of Commons and officials of Liberal associations, while the auditorium was crowded with delegates and other influential members of the party. Two hours before the proceedings opened every inch of standing room was taken.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2. -- Advices by the steamship Monowali say that the Island of Tanna has been visited by a hurricane and devastated by a civil war. Fierce fighting is now going on, and two villages have been wiped out of existence. In the midst of the fighting came a fearful hurricane. The German ship J.W. Gildemerston was wrecked in Dianirus Bay.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Ex-Senator O.C. Allen, who represented the Warren-Venango district with marked ability in the session of 1889, was a city visitor to-day. Talking over the political situation this evening, Mr. Allen said:
PANAMA, Sept. 25. -- Advices from Venezuela state that the Congress has passed a bill providing the guarantee of rights to individual citizens. The President has no veto power.

ROME, Oct. 2. -- A company of French pilgrims, after having been received by the Pope to-day, was visiting the notable sanctuaries of the city. At the Pantheon they manifested open disrerespect of the tomb of King Victor Emmanuel. Some of the bystanders protested vigorously, and a row between the pilgrims and the defenders of Victor Emmanuel followed.

Decidedly the most serious menace to the prospects of the Democratic Party of this State in the present canvass is the equivocal position it has held heretofore under the guidance of Gov. HILL on the subject of Ballot Reform. We regard this reform as distinctly in the interest of the Democratic Party, and it has been so recognized in many of the States where it has been adopted.

There was enough activity around the Hoffman House yesterday to indicate that the Democrats have really begun the hard work of their campaign and that it will not be very long before they have things a-humming. Roswell P. Flower, who will go to Watertown next week, received many callers at Room 311 in the Hoffman House in the course of the day.

Farmer Jay Gould of Irvington drove over to the Westchester County Fair in a buckboard yesterday. At the main gate he pulled out a long leather pocketbook containing the remnants of the Missouri Pacific dividend, which recently failed to materialize, and tried to find a bill small enough to offer to the ticket seller without danger of throwing the latter into a spasm of excitement.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- Rumors concerning the ill health of John D. Rockefeller, the Standard Oil magnate, have been revived by the return of his family to New-York on Tuesday, leaving him behind at his Summer home at Forest Hills Farm, near here.

Racing this afternoon will be over the broad and hilly stretches of the beautiful Morris Park, and the voluminous entries give promise of some first-class sport in all six of the races, two of which are rich stakes, the Dunmow, for two-year-olds, and the Manhattan Handicap, at a mile and a quarter. The entries for the several races are as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Lord Hawke's English cricketers won the match to-day by scoring 95 runs for six wickets. The Philadelphia team's fielding was not so sharp as on previous days. The score:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Naval Board appointed by Secretary Tracy to examine into and report upon the present stagnation of officers in the line of the navy, and recommend such measures as it may deem desirable to regulate promotion, with a view to the increased efficiency of the navy, has submitted its report through Capt. Phythian to Secretary Tracy. The board says:

When the Grand Jury came in yesterday to close the September term, among the indictments that it handed up was a presentment in regard to the Park Place disaster; but there were no indictments against the owners or occupants of the ill-fated building for criminal negligence. The presentment says among other things:

The Boston Journal recognizes the fact that if Gov. RUSSELL should be re-elected it would be claimed "as a triumph of the principles of the National Democracy, and it would be hailed by the Democrats of the country as proof that Massachusetts was in sympathy with their party," whereupon the unsophisticated Evening Post of this city inquires:

Four members of the Chamber of Commerce committee appointed on Thursday to investigate the delays to business through the crowded condition of the Public Stores and the apparent inability or the Government contractor to cart packages from the wharves to the stores, went to work yesterday upon the task delegated to them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- M.V. Gannon of Omaha was to-night elected President of the Irish National League of America, succeeding John Fitzgerald. Absolute independence on the part of the organization of any of the factions in Ireland or of their auxiliary bodies was the attitude assumed by the convention, as the result of a spirited struggle. John P. Sutton was re-elected Secretary and William Lyman of New-York was chosen Treasurer.

The contest between SHERMAN and FORAKER in Ohio for the control of the Legislature with a view to the Senatorial election is evidently playing a prominent part in the canvass in that State. Both these men have been giving close attention to the legislative nominations, and there seems to be a general impression that the Senator is coming out ahead.

All the beautiful novelties of the new season are coming out with a rush. Dress goods, wraps, hats, and notions are showing an embarrassing plenitude of new ideas, and every day adds something worth noting.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 3. -- During the Summer months the several classes of seamen gunners at the torpedo station here have been under instruction as regards the uses and development of smokeless powders. Various tests have been made with unsatisfactory results, and Prof. Munroe, the expert, has made repeated experiments with gun cotton, both dry and in the pulp.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A visiting Iowa merchant who has been asked his opinion about the chances of Gov. Boies in the election has spoken very confidently about the success of the Democrats, and he gives some reasons for predicting Republican defeat.

The New-York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital is one of the genuinely charitable institutions of the city. It is devoted to the treatment of children suffering from spine and hip diseases and other deformities It is situated at 126 and 128 East Fifty-ninth Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Psi Upsilon, Delta Upsilon, Phi Delta Theta, and Phi Kappa Psi Fraternities held their initiations last night. They were followed by banquets at the Vanderbilt House and Globe Hotel. The D.K.E. and Beta Thats will have their initiation next week. There has been a great deal of strife among the old society men to secure the "best timber" from the freshman class, but good feeling has prevailed.

An unusual number of large sharks has been reported during September in Long Island and Fisher's Island Sounds. To these the name of man-eater is generally applied. As a matter of fact, however, the true man-eating shark (Carcharodon carcharias) is rarely seen on our poast. This species grows to a length of twenty-five feet and to the weight of one ton, being surpassed in size only by the basking shark.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Prof. Levi H. Elwell will sail for Antwerp Nov. 25 for an absence of three months, during which he will visit the historic cities and battlefields of Greece, especially such as are connected with his instruction in Herodotus.

NEWPORT, R.I. Oct. 3. -- The first of October finds a very large proportion of the cottagers still at their Summer homes here quietly enjoying the exceedingly delightful weather which has prevailed practically without intermission all through the month of September.

FERRARA, Sept. 18. -- Imagine an old woman who has been lady-in-waiting to a Queen and has fallen on evil days. The Queen is dead, the Court is dispersed, the stables are falling to ruins, and the paintings on the walls of the palace crumbling bit by bit to decay. But the old lady retains under all her adversities an air of having once been somebody.

Nothing could have been better calculated than the course of the baseball season that has ended in securing the championship of the National League to the Boston club to revive the public interest in baseball. This interest was attacked during the season of 1890 with great persistency and success by the baseball players themselves, whose livelihood depended upon cultivating it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3. -- The contest between the boodlers and political rings and the Grand Jury is becoming very exciting. When Superior Judge Wallace fined "Dick" Chute for contempt of court Chute's attorneys took the case into the Superior Court of Judge Murphy, who discharged Chute and pronounced the Grand Jury illegal.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Rev. H.C. Longyear preached his farewell sermon at the Saugerties Baptist Church on Sunday. His successor, the Rev. Frederick Gates of Macedon, N.Y., has already arrived.

As the principal characters in the story I am about to tell are still living, and I have not received their consent to use their true names, I must take fictitious ones, but this will not detract from the general accuracy of the narrative, while it will give me more latitude in the grouping and presentation of a series of incidents quite as startling in their way as ever the brain of romancer conjured up.

READING, Penn., Oct. 3. -- This has been a phenomenal year for garden vegetables as well as for fruit and grain, and proud farmers hereabout are daily bringing in wonderfully big specimens of all sorts of products and laying them on editors' desks for flattering notices.

It is natural that the action of Russia in holding aloof from co-operating with the other powers to coerce China should provoke conjecture. The suggestion that the motive was unwillingness to augment England's influence in Asia lies on the surface, but is hardly exhaustive; while the supposition that Russia hopes that the disturbances in China will effect a diversion of trade to her new trans-Siberian railway is far fetched, not to say grotesque.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- A call has been issued for what promises to be one of the most important meetings of labor leaders ever held in Pennsylvania, and one that will probably have considerable bearing on the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor at Detroit next month.

Mr. C.J. Hubbell of this city announces that he has invented an electrical primary battery having commercially value. It is proposed to test this battery commercial of great guns. The underlying idea is to eliminate noxious fumes and prevent assimilation of the two fluids, which occurs in cells when the battery for any length of time remains inactive. The inventor announces that he has accomplished this by temporarily cutting off communication between the two fluids.

At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday a resolution was adopted that the Health Department be requested to vacate what is known as Room 38, at the Mott Street end of Police Headquarters, as the quarters are needed for police purposes. This is the outcome of the rebellion of Inspectors Steers and Conlin against their quarters in the front basement of the Central Office.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 3. -- The biggest sale of real estate in the history of Fall River has just been consummated through G.M. Hoffards Co., by the transfer of nearly $400,000 worth of land and buildings, to a syndicate composed of Robert T. Davis, Arnold B. Sanford, and others of this city, and Oilver Ames and others of Boston.

Armand Silvestre appears to the greater number of his readers as an epicure with lips dipped in the magnificently-purpled glass of Rabelais; but the poet, pupil of Banville, whom George Sand praised, "le grand poete de la Douleur et de l'Amour," is one of those for whom real life is fiction, and who are in exile when they are not in azure.

" I am fearful that we are going to have a long and very cold Winter," suggested a middle-aged man to the stranger that sat beside him in a railway car on the Harlem Road last Wednesday evening. No response came from the stranger, who wore a tired look on his face and did not appear to be sociable.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Dr. C. Irving Fisher, the head of the State hospital and almshouse at Tewksbury for the past eight years, has accepted the position of Superintendent of the Presbyterian Hospital of New-York. His salary will be far in excess of that allowed by the State of Massachusetts.

The Ulster County Savings Bank at Kingston has been compelled to close its doors and has been taken in charge by the State Banking Superintendent in consequence of long-continued embezzling from its funds by the Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer. Their peculations are said to have been going on for years without discovery by the Trustees or the Bank Examiners.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- It has been decided to adopt bacteriology as a new course for instruction at the university. In speaking of the innovation, Dr. E.M. Moore, the eminent Rochester surgeon, and Second Vice President of the Board of Trustees of the university, said: "The course has only just been decided upon by the Faculty, and consequently our plans with regard to it are still rather indifferent.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Boston has thus far indulged in no county fair this season -- save that of the redoubtable Burgess -- but the city is preparing to make good her deficiencies next week. The great fair, or exposition, that opens on Monday in Mechanics' Building is warranted to take the glory clean away from the mere gingerbread and peanut excellence of the county fair per so.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The following is the weather crop bulletin issued by the Weather Bureau:

Tart correspondence occupied the members of the Excise Board yesterday. In reply to Secretary Bruns of the Park Board, who wrote on Friday about Gabe Case's license, the board ordered the following letter sent out:

Ex-President Grover Cleveland will preside at the first meeting of the campaign, to be held in this city next Thursday evening, under the management of the Democratic State Committee, to ratify the State ticket headed by Roswell P. Flower. The largest and most accessible hall in the city has been selected -- Madison Square Garden, with its capacity for 15,000 persons.

In executive session yesterday the Police Commissioners decided to pay Martin B. Brown $3.90. per thousand for the 6,000,000 ballots which he will print for the coming election. Last year about 14,000,000 ballots were printed at a cost of $3.50 per thousand. Mr. Brown says that he lost money, and this year his first bid was $4.50 per thousand. At this year's rate the cost will be $23.400.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- A committee of the Common Council of this city is investigating the recent work of the City Assessors in the matter of the taxation of personal property. The Assessors were induced to cut down personal taxation many thousands of dollars by listening to "tales of woe" front bank officers, in which they seated the banks had lost money during the present year.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 3. -- The cottagers and their many guests have had lively week of it and are beginning to be weary.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3. -- As there is now no doubt about Allerton, 2:09 1/4, meeting Nancy Hanks, 2:09, in a race for $8,000 at the coming meeting of the Kentucky Trotting-Horse Breeders' Association, the great match is being widely discussed. Until Allerton recently stepped out in 2:09 1/4 no horse younger than nine years old had ever succeeded in placing a record of less than 2:10 opposite his name.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- A case that has baffled the most skillful detectives in New-Orleans is the incendiarism on the British steamship Chollerton, now loading with cotton for Liverpool. Four mysterious fires have occurred this week in the cotton which had been stowed on board the vessel, but by whom and how started the police have been unable to discover.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The one hundred and thirty-sixth session of the University of Pennsylvania has opened with an attendance in all departments of about 1,850 students, an increase of about 271 over last year. There was an increase in every department save the Dental School, the extension of whose course from two to three years naturally reduced the attendance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The hot weather of the last week has had considerable effect on the box-office receipts at the theatres, although several of the attractions playing here have done handsomely. There was not much novelty in the dramatic line.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- The entrance examination of the Johns Hopkins University, which went on all the week in the gymnasium, closed last night, and the results were announced this morning. Next week the work of the year will be formally begun and the session will be in full operation.

A third version of the seizure of the American schooner J. Hamilton Lewis by the Russian war vessel Aleut has now been brought by the steamer Danube. It mainly differs from the other two in the statement that a fight occurred on the Aleut's deck, arising from the fact that when the Captain of the Lewis was ordered to go aboard the Russian cruiser he took all his crew with him and they resisted capture.

The general verdict of insurance officials is that the [Banta] removal was just four years too late, and that, inasmuch as he had been retained so long, it would have been wiser to have waited a report from the department which would have vindicated the company against the charges made or confirmed their truthfulness.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- The death of Gen. Boulanger recalls the visit he and a party of other prominent Frenchmen made to this city some years ago. They arrived in New-Orleans on Thursday, Dec. 15, 1881, in a special car over the Illinois Central Railroad, and were met by a committee of citizens and the Continental Guards.

ANNANDALE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The college is to have a gymnasium erected through the efforts of the students. The undergraduates have long realized the need of a building, and have now collected a considerable amount of money toward its erection. About $1,500 more is needed, and it is expected that it will soon be raised. Meanwhile, Architect Rauck has submitted plans for a handsome building.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- Despite the reports of a small crop all the roads have been rushing cotton into New-Orleans, and the figures for September are very gratifying. Better than that, freight business was good in all departments, showing a healthy condition of trade.

AUCKLAND, New-Zealand, via San Francisco, Oct. 3. -- In the House of Representatives at Wellington, when the Land bill of the Government was under discussion, the Minister of Lands, the Hon. J. McKenzie, repeated the charge of corruption which he had heard against ex-Minister of Lands G. Richardson.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The play upon which Lord Tennyson is at work, and which Augustin Daly is to produce in New-York, is partly in blank verse and partly in prose. It is what is known in England as a "costume play," and the scene is laid in England.

The Etruria, sailing yesterday for Liverpool, took out among her passengers. Lord Connemara, J.H. Carnegie, Naval Cadets H.G. Gillmor, Laurence Spear, Henry G. Smith, and Richard M. Watt. Others who sailed by that vessel were Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Seligman and the Misses Seligman, Capt. Howard Patterson, Dr. H.A. Moxey, the Rev. R.F. Ashley Spencer and Mrs. Spencer, the Rev. E.W. Urquhart, the Rev. James E. Tracy and Mrs. Tracy.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- Gen. Ruiz Sandoval has been in this city for the past thirty days, and discusses freely the recent outbreak on the Mexican frontier. Gen. Sandoval says that although he is in sympathy with any movement that will lead to the overthrow of President Diaz, he had absolutely nothing to do with the recent revolution, which was simply a local outburst on the part of the Mexican people.

Bicyclists are already gathering for the international 142-hour contest to take place at Madison Square Garden, and some wonderful work is expected. For America there will be John S. Prince, "Senator" Morgan, Charles Ashinger, Albert Schock, and Edward McDowell; for Canada. P. Martin; for France. Jules Dubois and Charles Torrent, both now training at Bordeaux; for Ireland, M.J.O Flanagan of Tipperary County; for Scotland, John Dunlap Lumsden and Wallace Stage, already arrived in this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- The nomination of a Republican legislative ticket in this county put in the field the last important nominations in the State, and, with a few others made the same day, practically ends the preliminary fight between Sherman and Foraker over the Senatorship. Whatever is done hereafter must be in the way of influencing men who have already been nominated.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The ReV. David J. Evans entered upon his charge as rector of Grace Episcopal Church at Middletown, N.Y., last Sunday. He is of English birth, and was graduated from Oxford University. He had been for two years assistant rector in charge of a mission of Holy Trinity Church, New-York City.

It appears as if the market were safely mounting another rising wave. The last surge upward was a big one, and when it foamed over and broke, some things shot down rather alarmingly. However, we seem to be all right again. With all the demoralization caused by the Missouri Pacific incident, it was remarkable how little the general list was affected.

Of four well-marked periods in the Revolutionary War, the first, the one beginning with the resistance of John Otis to the general search warrants, (1761,) culminating with the defiance of Great Britain by the people of Boston and the Parliamentary acts of 1771, is the one which is of the greatest interest to us.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 3. -- The Dartmouth freshmen won their second game from the sophomores in the class series this afternoon by a score of 20 to 4. The features of the game were the battery work of Thornburg and Claggett, Jr., '95, and the listless playing of the sophomores. This is the first freshman team for eight years that has won a baseball game from the sophomores. Score by innings:
Those who were present on Wednesday last at the Convention of the Diocese of New-York witnessed the administration of a rebuke which was as pungent in its effect as it was dignified in form.

The number of Bermudans who visited America in the season just ended was altogether unprecedented. Some of them were to be found in nearly all the New-York hotels, and Saratoga, Niagara Falls, and most of the seaside resorts became acquainted with the Tuckers and their cousins, and the sisters and aunts of the Triminghams, the Harveys, the Whitneys, the Troths, and the Lightbourns.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- An official dispatch from Fredensborg, received in this city to-day, announces that the Czar and Czarina are expected to arrive there Tuesday. Their Majesties may remain at Fredensborg until after the celebration of their silver wedding anniversary, which occurs Oct, 28, returning to St. Petersburg via Berlin.

D. Jouaust has retired from business as a printer and publisher, wealthy, after twenty-five years of a work constantly artistic, leading among the models of literature and typography, implacable in its elevated purpose. In his determination, quite French, to become a rentier, he ceded for 300,000f. his stock, which was valued at 3,000,000f.

The Catholic Club has long had a method of keeping its members posted on matters of interest connected with the club which a good many other clubs in this town might copy with profit. This method is nothing more nor less than the publication of a monthly newspaper. To be sure, this "newspaper" bears the name of the Bulletin of the Catholic Club; but it is a newspaper, just the same, small though it is.

The latest quotation for the New-York Life scandal market is that the supply is steady and the demand firm. THE NEW-YORK TIMES has devoted itself lately to repetitions and analyses of the charges against the Beers management. Very little new material has been brought out this week.

PROVIDENCE. R.I., Oct. 3. -- Rhode Island, as one of the doubtful States, is evidently to receive the attention of the Republican managers, and they have begun early in their characteristic way. A Republican organ has been established in this city within a fortnight, and it printed for two successive days an editorial article signed by Headsman Clarkson.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 3. -- The Ulster County Savings Institution has closed its doors, and is in charge of Bank Superintendent Charles M. Preston. Expert examiners have been at work since Tuesday and have found already that the enormous sum of $463,000 has been stolen by Treasurer Ostrander and Matthew T. Trumphour, Assistant Treasurer, and it is feared the stealings will reach over that amount.

BRUSSLES, Oct. 3. -- The funeral of Gen. Boulanger took place to-day. A great crowd of people assembled hours before the time fixed for the ceremonies about the General's house in the Rue Montoyer. A large force of police was present, but they had to obtain reinforcements before they could manage the disorderly throng. They were compelled to make a number of arrests before order could be restored.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 3. -- It is pretty well known that some of Mr. Blaine's friends in this city as well as elsewhere have repudiated the recent report that a conference was lately held between Senators Hale and Frye, Mr. Manley, and others in regard to Mr. Blaine's nomination for President When Mr. Hale himself was asked about it by THE TIMES'S correspondent he declared that the whole story was a sheer fabrication.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Williams College played her first exhibition football game of the season on Weston Field this afternoon with the Laureates of Troy. The game was interesting only as it showed the new material for this season's 'Varsity team. The college boys had a complete walkover, downing the Trojans with figures of 42 to 0.

The first regular run of the season given by the Richmond County Hunt of Staten Island yesterday afternoon brought out a field of nearly thirty and several hundred spectators. The meet was at the kennels on the grounds of the Country Club, and the driveways about the clubhouse and Little Clove Road were filled with equipages of every description which were occupied by well-known society people.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The third annual report of Commissioner Taylor was handed to the Secretary of the Interior to-day. An abstract is as follows:

It had all come to pass so gradually that Beatrice Danvers could not, although she strove to, remember how it had originated. And yet the bitter truth remained. She, who had begun her early married life in a glow of confidence in the future, was now past middle age, bereft of all illusions, confessing that her life was nought but an irrevocable, irredeemable failure.

The National Provisioner continues its search for American tin plate offered for sale in commercial quantities. Some weeks ago we predicted that this trade journal would soon be denounced by the McKinley press as "an enemy of American industries." The National Provisioner now declares not only that our prediction has been fulfilled, but also that it has been called by its McKinley contemporaries "a free trade journal" and "a paper supported by British capital."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- The greatest interest was manifested by the friends of both Foraker and Sherman in the nominations made by the Republicans of Cuyahoga County on Saturday last. The delegation is worth looking after, as it will, in the event the Republicans carry it without a break, consist of three Senators and eight Representatives, a total of eleven votes in the Senatorial fight.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- M. Paul Delair, the author of "Helene," given at the Vaudeville Theatre for the opening of the regular season, is not as much of a new-comer as he may seem. The dramatic stage already owes to his pen "Garin," given at the Theatre Francais; the "Rois en Exil," adapted from Daudet's book and given at the Vaudeville, and "L'Aine," in which Coquelin has acted.

The Riverside Wheelmen held a successful meet at the Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. It was the first attempt of the club in this line, and its members feel very happy over the result. Twenty-five hundred people were present and enjoyed some spirited contests. It was expected that some trials at records would be made, but the absence of the crack riders made this impossible.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Jewish New Year began to-day, and the day was appropriately celebrated in this city. The Rev. Dr. Max Landsberg delivered a sermon at Temple Berith Kodesh on the present condition of the Jewish race, from the text: "Hitherto the Eternal has helped us." In the course of the sermon he said:

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- The political war in Monmouth County this Fall is being fought hard and fiercely. It is a well-established fact that the Abbett and Blodgett factions are fighting for supremacy. The Blodgett people deny the reports that the tall Senator is in the contest, and loudly declare that they are in the war themselves personally and that they intend to defeat Gov. Abbett.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- England has long been accustomed to these vast annual gatherings of Liberal and Radical leaders, managers, editors, and orators, of which the latest has been held at Newcastle this week. Sometimes they come and go with scarcely more public attention than is given to a big Wesleyan Conference.

The Rapid-Transit Commission has obtained from the engineers to whom the general plans of construction for an underground railroad were submitted some valuable opinions and suggestions, but these differ to such an extent as to make the task of the commission more difficult rather than less.

STAR LAKE, St. Lawrence County, Oct 3. -- Deer hunters who have visited this resort since the opening of the present season have little to complain of, for it is many years since the shooting has been so good in the southern part of St. Lawrence County. More deer have been killed here this year than at any time since the lake became a Summer resort.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 3. -- This has been a great year for Mount Baker, for no less than three exploring parties have climbed to the summit. The second one included Miss Sue Nevins, the first woman to make the ascent.

GARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Democrats of the Sixteenth District met here to-day to nominate a candidate for Senator. The convention was run entirely by J.W. Hinckley of Poughkeepsie. No man could tell before 1 P.M. who the nominee would be. Samuel J. Tilden was wanted, but last night he telegraphed Hinckley he would not allow his name to be used.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- The Rev. Louis Banks of the St. John Methodist Episcopal Church, who has done for Boston what Charles Booth, in a much more thorough way, has done for London, and Jacob A. Riis for New-York, namely: studied its slums and shed light upon its abominations, last Sunday defended the Salvation Army from the gibes of the Pharisees of Beacon Street.
The shades of evening were falling yesterday when Col. O. Sumner Teale closed the big gates of the Westchester County Fair. He closed them with a bang and locked them, and that wound up the fair.

The Police Commissioners depend in great measure for the discipline of the force upon the Roundsmen. In each precinct there are at least four Roundsmen, two to each platoon, and in a few of the precincts in which the force is very large six Roundsmen are detailed to watch the patrolmen and to see that they do their duty properly and obey the rules.

Merchants of the French islands of Martinique and Guadaloupe, especially those whose interests lie in the trade with this country, are anything but satisfied with the proposed "Tariff Douanier Metropolitan'' and the local administration of the islands. The Chamber of Commerce of Point a Pitre and the Chambre Syndicale have presented to the General Council a list of the articles which they say should be excepted from the tariff.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 4. -- A prominent young Republican politician from one of the counties in James W. Wadsworth's Congressional district tells something interesting about the Republican State Convention recently held here. This young man has been for several years one of Mr. Wadsworth's most trusted lieutenants, having stood by him when Wadsworth men in his particular neighborhood were few and far between. His story runs thus:

The drift of political talk all over the country shows that the State elections are everywhere regarded this year as a preliminary skirmish in the coming national contest of 1892. The influence which their results are to have upon the course of parties in that campaign and upon its outcome is the source of a large part of the interest that is taken in them.

It is reported in our dispatches that while the election of all the other persons nominated on the Democratic State ticket in Maryland is assured, Mr. POE, who is named for the office of Attorney General, may be defeated because he has expressed unfavorable opinions concerning "the fraternal and endowment organizations."
I do not doubt your spirit of fairness will prompt you to publish this reply, written from a Catholic standpoint, to an article in your paper of Sept. 28 under the heading of "A Surfeit of Camels."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 4. -- About 500 Poles journeyed from New-York this morning to witness the ceremony of the erection and benediction of a sacred cross, or the laying of the cornerstone of a church to be erected in New-Crestochowa, a colony to be inhabited by Poles, on the line of the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey, two miles south of Englewood. Father McCarthy officiated at the ceremony.
LONDON, Oct 4. -- Mr. Gladstone has written a letter to Mr. Scott of Manchester, in support of the latter's candidature for member of Parliament for the northeast division of that city.

A sister of Dr. Samuel O. Dixon of the Academy of Natural Sciences, and daughter of Isaac Dixon, recently walked into the establishment of a lapidary in Chestnut Street. She had on one of her fingers a very beautiful ring with three precious stones, one of which was awaterxvhlte diamond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Though the present term of Commodore Melville as Engineer in Chief of the Navy will nor expire until next January, Secretary Tracy, in order to set at rest any question as to the succession in the office, has already announced, as stated in THE TIMES yesterday, that Commodore Melville will succeed himself.

There must be something in the name of Peabody that leads its possessors to become eminent. The world knows the life story of the great philanthropist, George Peabody; Boston still has in Miss Elizabeth Peabody a lady whose works have made her famous. She is the eldest of Dr. Nathaniel Peabody's three daughters, one of whom married Nathaniel Hawthorne, and another the noted Horace Mann.

During the past month America has lost two men who have inscribed their names indelibly upon the annals of the country as minds that wielded an immense influence for good and as leaders of progress and a higher civilization.

The Acting Superintendent of Immigration at this port should take something to revive his judgment. When he applied not long ago to the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for permission to close the Barge Office on holidays and Sundays, the authority was given if the public interests would permit the office to be closed, and the decision of that question was left to the Assistant Superintendent's judgment.

The announcement of the suppression of the revolt in Yemen may be colored in the interest of the Porto, but if confirmed would only repeat the story of previous uprisings there. The district is the coast strip in Southwestern Arabia bordering on the Red Sea, north of the Straits of Bab-el-Mandeb. The Arabs have been oppressed for years by the Turkish soldiers, whose chief function is that of supporting the officials in levying tribute.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 3. -- While negro philanthropists are endeavoring to organize a Liberian movement, more practical negroes have instituted a colonization scheme that is already bearing fruit.

Shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning fire broke out in the canning works of the Van Camp Packing Company, Indianapolis, and in three hours the works wore completely destroyed. The total loss is $200,000, on which there is $149,500 insurance, distributed among eighty companies, and divided as follows: On Van Camp Packing Company, building, $16,000: boilers and engines, $2,000; stock, $74,000. On American Preserver Company, machinery, $75,000; stock, $29,000. On Dugdale Can Company, stock, $12,000.

A quantity of affidavits and other documents furnished by the special agents employed by the Government to collect the statistics of manufactures was sent to Washington Saturday to be used in prosecuting a case against the Government to recover what the agents claim is a portion of their pay.

Photographic sharpers have begun to spring up all over the country, and they are not only swindling people on promises to send portraits at uncommonly low rates and to furnish enlargements as "advertisements" for a few stamps, but they are working swindles with photographic goods. There has been a "fashionable" -- or at least to all personal appearances "fashionable" -- young man who has been visiting Newport.

NICE, Oct. 4. -- The Mayor of this city unveiled a monument to Garibaldi here to-day, in the presence of M. Rouvier, representing the French Government; Gen. Canzio, representing the Garibaldi family, several French and Italian Deputies, many notables, civil and military, and a large concourse of people.

George H. Harries of the Washington Star, a member of the Sioux Commission which Secretary Noble sent to the Indian reservations under an act of the last Congress, was in New-York yesterday. With the other Commissioners, Charles E. Pearce of St. Louis and A.R. Appleman of Columbus, he has recently come East after two or three months on the reservations.

The epidemic influenza of misinformation about the New-York election has spread as far as Springfield, Mass. The Republican of that city is down with it. But the patient has a strong constitution and large recuperative powers. If liberally dosed with facts we have no doubt it will recover sufficiently to sit up and read the returns on Nov. 3.

While Gov. Hill is placing himself on exhibition at the county fairs and endeavoring to impress the farmers, is not the suspicion taking deep root that he is determined to stab and, so far as may be in his power, to defeat the Democratic State ticket. A number of little incidents mud episodes have occurred since the Saratoga Convention that seem to betray the Governor's insincerity toward the ticket.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4. -- Every day brings new and sensational developments concerning the wrecking and plundering of the Standiford Bank, at the little town of Chrisman, Ill. The bank, conducted by two brothers named Standiford, was apparently doing a profitable business, and when its doors were closed, on Sept. 30, there was great surprise.

We notice that Mr. Beers's newspaper friends dwell fondly upon two points: (1) That the New-York Life is admitted to be solvent, therefore, there can be no just cause for complaint against Mr. Beers's management; (2) that the publicity given to the charges against Mr. Beers may cause some policy holders to lapse their policies, thereby inflicting possible injury to future widows and orphans.

We have occasionally directed attention to what may be called the official utterances of the two high-tariff associations concerning the duties on wool. The President of one of these associations, Mr. THOMAS DOLAN of Philadelphia, is a member of the Board of Managers of the other, which is known as the Protective Tariff League.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- Last Fall there were 5,362 polling places in New-York State. Of this number 1,618 were in New-York and Kings, leaving 3,744 for the rest of the State. Under the law of last Winter providing that the number of voters in a district be 400, instead of 300, a number of the counties reduced the number of polling places.
In its issue of Sept. 21, the St. Louis Globe-Democrat has the following interesting item regarding the manufacture of linens in this country:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Gov. Pattison's purpose to issue extradition papers on ex-Cashier William Livsey caused widespread comment in the city to-day, and the contemplated movement to secure this leading witness of transactions in the State Treasurer's office during the past ten years was generally applauded.

The New-York Presbytery will meet in the Scotch Presbyterian Church, on Fourteenth Street, this morning. The Presbytery will consider several questions of importance, but the greatest interest will attach to such proceedings as may be had relative to the now celebrated heresy case of Prof. Charles A. Briggs of Union Theological Seminary.

The town elections in Connecticut take place to-day, and in most of the towns the question of license or no license will figure prominently. The secret-ballot law of that State makes no provision for the license or no license vote, and a question has arisen whether ballots on that issue in-closed in the official envelopes are legal.

The keenest interest has been aroused among military men over THE TIMES'S Newport dispatch of yesterday announcing the obtaining at the Newport torpedo station on Saturday of small-arm muzzle velocities ranging from 2,850 to 2,860 foot-seconds. The velocities were gotten with a new smokeless nitrate compounded by Prof. C.M. Monroe and Commander Jewell, both of the United States Navy.

TRENTON, Oct. 4 -- This seems to be a bad year all around for the "bosses." The Republican Senatorial Convention in Burlington County yesterday was a bad blow for Gen. Sewell, the Administration manager in New-Jersey. Ex-Sheriff Hayes, who is one of the bitterest of Gen. Sewell's South Jersey foes, was given the nomination for Senator, though the General had favored the candidacy of Robert C. Hutchinson.

The incident related in Mr. Frederic's last Russian letter of the moujlk being driven away from the show window calls to mind a similar occurrence observed during a visit to the Hermitage CaLlory in St. Petersburg. Three or us lind Just cetered the doorway, when we were attracted by a group ahead who were standing silent while two functionaries in gorgeous red tunic wore talking and gasticulating in a most opphatic manner.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- The schooner Donna A. Briggs of Newport, R.I., hence Oct 3 for NewYork, with a cargo of about 150 tons of guano consigned to the Bowker Fertilizer Company of Elizabethport, N.J., returned this afternoon disabled, in tow of the steamer Orion, Capt. Hammond, which left Boston Saturday night for New York.

The contest for the local political offices to be filled at the coming election will occupy its share of attention from now until the close of the campaign. By a week from Wednesday night all the nominations will have been made. The Republican County Convention is scheduled for Thursday night of this week, the Tammany Convention for the following Monday, the Counties' Convention for the following Tuesday, and the Voorhis Convention the following Wednesday.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct 4. -- One of the Sunday papers publishes a story to-day showing crookedness among the Freeholders of the county. The Free Bridge Committee advertised for bids for some apparatus needed at the bridge. John C. Blevny offered the work and material for $11,114, William Greenfield's bid was $11,709, and J.S. Mundy's was $3,275.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4. -- Forest fires have been raging for over a week in El Dorado County, and more than forty square miles of country have been burned over. The flames spread over Greenwood Creek country and all the country to the west of Garden Valley, destroying many dwellings, barns, hay, fences, and thousands of acres of dry feed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- A boiler explosion aboard the steam tug C.W. Parker killed seven persons and seriously injured others in the neighborborhood of Archer Avenue Bridge, on the south branch of the river, about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. The C.W. Parker, in company with three other tugs, was engaged in attempting to tow the coal steamer H.S. Pickands out of the draw of the bridge when the explosion occurred.

The Rev. Dr. Stephenson, President of the Wesleyan Conference of England, who is a delegate to the coming Methodist Ecumenical Conference at Washington, addressed the congregation of Asbury Methodist Church, Washington Square, yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Discount hardened during the week past, the closing quotations being 3 for three months and 1 3/4 for short. Some houses, being convinced that the Bank of England rate would be raised next Thursday, refused paper under 3 1/4. Every department of the Stock Exchange was quiet until Friday, when Wall Street's turn for the better sharply enlivened dealings.

HARTFORD, Oct. 4. -- The no-license issue will play an interesting part in the town elections throughout the State to-morrow. The demand for prohibition ballots has been much larger than in previous Fall elections. The decision in the Huntington case, which involved the validity of no-license votes, will lead the Prohibitionists in most towns to ask for a separate box at the election for tickets on the license question.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 4. -- The Occidental and Oriental steamer Belgie arrived early this morning from China, Japan, and Hawaii. She brings advices from China to Sept. 3, from Japan to the 14th, and from Hawaii to the 26th.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- Yesterday was the day, had it been rainy, that women to the number of 200 or more were to have appeared in public in short skirts and other exceptional clothing. The matter has been talked about in female reform circles and in the newspapers, and the fact was got at that the leader in the movement here was Mrs. Evelyn Shaw Ingersoll, who is a sister of Mary Shaw, the actress.

The steamer Albatross is now about to undertake the task of surveying a route for a submarine cable between San Francisco and Honolulu. It was at first feared that the kind of wire needed for making the soundings could not be procured in this country; but that obstacle has been overcome and an undertaking that has already been delayed several months will now be carried out.

The pride of Detroit and the lakes, the E.C. Pope, was sold Saturday. The purchasers were Charles A. Eddy Brothers of Bay City and the price paid was $220,000. The E.C. Pope will hereafter make her home port at Bay City and give the people an opportunity to come down to the docks and remark with pardonable pride: "She belongs here." The E.C. Pope was built in this city last Winter.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 4. -- No sooner were the third class men here on Thursday, the day the Naval Academy opened, than they began to prepare to "haze" the plebs -- the fourth class men. Lieut. William F. Fullam, the Officer of the Day, walked into the rooms just as the ball was about to begin, and this stopped the programme. He gave them this good advice: "Young gentlemen, you had better stop this.

The Rev. John McNeill of London, whom some have called the "Scottish Spurgeon," preached yesterday morning at the Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn, before an audience that more than filled the pews.
Of the six days' racing this week, four will be at the Jerome Park track, the sport beginning there this afternoon, when the following races will be run:

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- Papers were filed yesterday with the Supreme Court by the attorneys for the C.F. Jewett Publishing Company of Boston against Gen. Benjamin F. Butler and A.M. Thayer Co., publishers, for a perpetual injunction restraining defendants from printing and issuing a work advertised to be called "Butler's Book."
This week has been dubbed "convention week" by the politicians of Westchester County, as the principal conventions are to be held in it and the fate of a score or more of candidates decided.

A receiver has been appointed for the Ulster County Savings Institution, at Kingston, and its affairs are to be wound up, in consequence of the depletion of its funds by the long-continued embezzlement of its Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer. It is estimated that the depositors will lose about one-fourth of their savings.

Lieut. Gov. Edward F. Jones came to New-York last evening to remain a month, during which time he will undergo treatment which his doctors have told him is necessary to prevent him from becoming blind, which they say would happen within a year. His family accompanied him. They have rooms at the Park Avenue Hotel. Dr. H.D. Noyes of 263 Madison Avenue is his physician.

We do not care to insist upon absolute consistency as to principles and policy in a political party; in the first place, we should not get it, and in the second place, parties, like men, are neither so bad nor so good as they might seem if judged by their course on one or two points, even when these are in themselves important.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 5. -- A court-martial was convened at the Naval Academy to-day for the trial of Naval Cadets Claude W. Griffith of Maryland and Arthur G. Kavanagh of Nebraska, both third-class men, charged with hazing Naval Cadet Butler of Ohio, fourth-class man, by tying him between two mattresses.

A fire in a tenement house at the southeast corner of Hudson and Dominick Streets early yesterday morning, which did comparatively little damage to property, caused the death of four persons and injuries to a fifth which will probably result in death.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Governor of Alaska in his annual report, devotes much space to the sealing question. After speaking of the attempts to stop depredations, he has this to say:

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 5. -- E. Barksdale of this city, in an interview in the Clarion Ledger, denies that he aspires to the Presidency of the National Alliance, as stated in a recently-published telegram from Washington. He says, further, that he would not accept the position if it were tendered to him.

The Hon. JAMES W. WADSWORTH, member of the House of Representatives of the United States from the Thirty-first District of this State, had plainly forgotten the fate of Gen. N.M. CURTIS when he signed his name as Treasurer of the Republican State Committee to the circular soliciting political contributions from Federal office holders.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 5. -- Little interest is felt in the result of the town elections, and not much effort is made to secure early returns. Twenty-one of the twenty-five towns in New-Haven which chose town officers to-day have been heard from. Eleven of them elected Republican officers and ten Democratic.

The much-talked-of Ziegler letter, an outline of which appeared exclusively in THE TIMES several days ago, was made public yesterday. It was addressed to Howard M. Smith, Vice President of the Bedford Bank, and one of the influential members of the Brooklyn Union League Club. In this letter Mr. Ziegler does not accept or decline a nomination for Mayor, for the reason that such a nomination has not been offered to him.
