RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 5.--The Third Assembly District Democratic Convention was held in the Globe Hotel this afternoon. There was a red-hot time, and John Henry Heyer of Holmdel secured the regular nomination. The Abbett and Blodget factions worked hard to secure control of the convention.

Columbia College began her one hundred and thirty-eighth year yesterday with very large freshmen classes. Many changes have taken place about the college, the most notable of which is the removal of the old building, or "Maison de Punk," as it was called. Its site is used for a new campus, in the centre of which is a large white fountain surrounded by flowers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 5. -- The Democratic State Committee launched its first thunderbolt in the present campaign in this city to-night by a rousing meeting at Music Hall, which served to introduce to Ohio Democrats City Chamberlain T.C.T. Crain of New-York. Mr. Crain made an excellent impression, quite justifying the action of the committee in inviting him to make a speech-making tour of the State.

Gen. O'Beirne, the Assistant Superintendent of Immigration at this port, whose unapproachable reputation for blundering has been greatly augmented during the period that his chief has been absent in Europe, yesterday added another one to the long list of his absurd decisions.

There was no change in the Democratic Mayoralty situation in Brooklyn yesterday. Politicians said that Chapin was still begging the bosses to renominate him and that they were telling him with constantly-increasing positiveness that he could not be elected and that his nomination would weaken the State ticket and perhaps defeat it.

The Democratic Club gave a reception last night at its clubhouse in Fifth Avenue, near Fiftieth Street, to the Hon. Roswell P. Flower. The clubhouse was crowded with well-known Democrats, and Mr. Flower, when he entered unattended save by his private secretary, about 9 o'clock, received an enthusiastic greeting. He had walked down from 601 Fifth Avenue, where he and Mrs. Flower are staying with Mrs. Flower's sister, Mrs. Schley.

Mr. Jay Gould said not long ago that he did not own a majority of the stock in any of the railroad properties that he controlled. He added, with what then appeared to be a tinge of sarcasm, that the stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Road could, if they became dissatisfied with his management, put him out of the Presidency.

The display of imported furniture by R.J. Horner Co., 65 West Twenty-third Street, is unusually handsome at present. It includes many designs manufactured expressly for the firm at foreign factories. The novelties include many charming ideas in Vernis Martin, buhl cabinets, and cabinets in ormolu and ebony, and in marquetry. Some of these are with single, some with double doors. All are delicate and symmetrical.

The announcement that Mr. EDISON has devised a new system of electric traction for street cars, by which the difficulty of using the current from underground wires and the objection to overhead wires are obviated, is of peculiar interest just now, when so much of our city is in a state of eruption and chaos from preparations for the use of cables.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 5 -- When the County Commissioners to-day formally passed the ordinance paying the third installment of $100, 000 to the Wheeling Bridge and Terminal Railroad Company under the contract of three years ago, they received a formal notice that an injunction would be served on the board to prevent carrying the order into effect.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5.--Senator Quay and his family said farewell to Atlantic City for the season, to-day, and coming to the city were assigned rooms at the Continental. Mrs. M. Ward of Stamford, Conn., accompanies Mrs. and Miss Quay, and they expect to leave for Beaver after a brief visit.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5. -- The insurance on the Baltimore and Ohio elevator "A," burned yesterday, was for $100,000 in the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of New-York. On the grain there was $182,500 insurance, divided as follows:

President HARRISON will doubtless view with apprehension and alarm the profuse thanks bestowed upon him by the leaders of the Mormon Church for pardoning one of their number. There is, of course, no reason at all why the Mormons should now be persecuted, nor any decent pretext left for persecuting them.

The scheme to improve the water route along the south side of Long Island by a canal connecting Jamaica Bay with the Great South Bay will probably now be carried to a successful issue, as the surveys recently made by the Government have shown the proposed improvement entirely feasible.

The Treasury Department has decided that Miss Agnes Huntington must pay duty on all the costumes which she imported for the production of "Captain Therese" except those which are for her own personal use. When the costumes arrived they were passed by the Inspector on the dock. Then the Special Agents took up the case and sent to Washington for instructions, the point at issue being the old "tools-of-trade" question.

With cold, calm nerves Mr. Platt's State Committee last night made the announcement that Congressman James W. Wadsworth, the Treasurer of the committee, had resigned from that office. His reason was obvious. It was because the "boodle" circular sent by the committee to federal office holders had laid him, as custodian of the funds so collected, liable for violation of the civil-service law.

The elevated railroad company has begun fighting on another line in its hope of keeping off as long as possible the day when it will have to pay property owners for the damages by its tracks and trains to their property. The first skirmish took place yesterday in the Superior Court.

One thousand admirers of the good old English game of cricket put aside all worldly cares yesterday, decked themselves in becoming holiday raiment, and went to Staten Island to see young Lord Hawke's English team play against a picked team of players selected from the various athletic organizations in this city and the surrounding metropolitan district.

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., Oct. 5. -- The Phillipsburg Bank closed its doors to-day, announcing that on account of the continued demand from the depositors it was deemed best to suspend payment and go into liquidation. The cashier stated that he firmly believed all deposits would be paid in full.

Congressman James B. McCreary of Kentucky stood in the Fifth Avenue Hotel corridor yesterday, and told a TIMES reporter of some things which he believed would be done by the Fifty-second Congress. He said that he thought the House would pass a general tariff bill, and that before the end of the first session the question of silver coinage would be disposed of.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- So far from insuring stability of rates, the heavy grain movement from the West to the East is likely to bring the demoralization that has been successfully staves off during the dull portion of the year. This of course will not be due to the increase or tonnage, but to the fact that all other outlets to the seaboard seem to be in greater favor than Chicago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- At to-day's Monroe County Democratic Convention, John J. Powers was nominated for County Clerk, Bernard Ritzenthaler for Superintendent of Poor, and Oscar P. Colby for Justice of Sessions. Alderman Tracy called the convention to order, and Charles H. Strong was elected Chairman. Both factions of the party were well represented in the convention.
The Democratic clubs of Harlem and vicinity will tender Roswell P. Flower and his colleagues on the Democratic State ticket a grand reception at the Belmont Riding Club on the evening Oct. 19.

HAVANA, Oct. 5. -- Intelligence reached this city to-day of another brutal crime committed by bandits. The outlaw Manuel Garcia, with two other bandits, made an attack upon the residence of Senor P. Hernandez, near Quivican, and killed both him and his wife. When the officer intrusted with that duty searched the body of Senor Hernandez he found in one of the pockets of his clothing a letter addressed to the civil authorities of Quivican.

ST. Lou s, Oct. 5. -- The St. Louis Republic will to-morrow print a history of the Aransas Harbor scheme in which Russell B. Harrison is concerned. The correspondent, who writes from Aransas Harbor, after having made a thorough investigation of the matter, first gives a brief history of the efforts to have a first-class seaport at Aransas, reciting the conventions held and the work done.

" Thermidor" is a drama in four acts, containing five dramatic scenes and an undue amount of narrative. It has three important personages. The thirty-odd others are of so little importance that the spectators do not even bother to learn their names from the house bill. But the three are human beings, first of all, and very interesting persons, with uncommon attributes and strong natures developed and manifested under strange circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The references in THE TIMES of this morning to the closing of the Barge Office on Sunday attracted the attention of Secretary Foster, and provoked some remarks from him as to the inadvisability of permitting a matter of discretion to be lodged with a man who is not discreet.

Commissioner RAUM has caused to be published in Chicago an account of his recent interview with the President. The Commissioner appears to spend a great part of his time in Chicago and other places far removed from the Pension Office. "The President assured me most cordially," he says, "that the office under my administration had been entirely satisfactory."

The movement which has been started by German-Americans to celebrate annually the 6th of October, or the Sunday preceding it, as "Deutscher Tag." is likely to become widespread and successful. Englishmen, Irishmen, Scotchmen, Welshmen, French, Italians, and others of our adopted citizens commemorate in their social organizations their patron saints' days or the national holidays of their respective native lands.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 5. -- John H. Parton, an American who for two years has been engaged in mining near Metztillan, in the State of Hidalgo, Mexico, arrived here yesterday. He brings information of a bloody Indian outbreak which has for some time been in progress in the district of Tulamengo, in that State.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- A great step in an art long neglected was taken this morning when the Food and Health Exposition was opened, under the superintendence of the Boston Retail Grocers' Association. The event is the first of the kind held in New-England, and will be watched with no small interest by all who wish to see the advancement of the culinary art.

Judge Lippincott, the fearless jurist who presides over the Hudson County Court of Sessions at Jersey City, gave the ballot-box stuffers another set-back yesterday, and incidentally whacked some of the officers of his court. The opportunity was given in rendering the decision of the court on the application of Thomas C. Smith and his father, Bryan Smith, concerning the elder Smith's bail bond for his son.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 5. -- BN order of the Czar, nu Court balls will be giv,n during the cominx season of Winter festlvit!6 . The me nG; Usually usad for such entertainments wilt ,.o devoted to the relief of the famine sufferers.

The announcement in our news columns this morning that Mayor CHAPIN of Brooklyn will not receive the nomination of his party for another term may be taken as conclusive. As we have already intimated, the "boom" of Mr. CHAPIN for the Governor's nomination was understood by the Democratic managers in Kings County to be a settlement "in full to date" of all claims by Mr. CHAPIN.

Several important changes in the drill of the life-saving crews along the coast have been adopted by the General Superintendent of the Life-Saving Service, and the necessary instructions are being forwarded this week to the various stations. The changes are embodied in a new and amended edition of the work on "Beach Apparatus Drill," prepared by Lieut. C. H. McLellan of the United States Revenue Marine and Assistant Inspector of United States Life-Saving Stations.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Jacob Sloat Fassett Republican candidate for Governor, accompanied by John W. Vrooman, candidate for Lieutenant Governor, and Arthur C. Wade, candidate for Controller, journeyed from Syracuse to Lockport to-day. They held a public reception at Power's Hotel in Rochester this morning, which was largely attended by citizens of that city.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, Oct. 6. -- Last night a man named Slusser, who has been clerking in McClellan's new cigar store on Main Street, was arrested on a charge of attempting to wreck No. 5, the Pennsylvania Limited, one night in the latter part of last February. This arrest discloses a fine piece of detective work and a very interesting story to Alliance people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The State Department awaits with interest the arrival of diplomatic dispatches, anticipated by the press news of the Belgic, which arrived yesterday at San Francisco from Honolulu. The news of the ill health of the Queen was a surprise, and increased the embarrassment already felt in the menace of British attempt at domination.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Alluding to the death of Mr. Smith, the Daily News says:
The bear contingent made a number of rather savage raids on the market yesterday, but they effected very little. Quotations showed a marked rebounding power.
In a speech at Xenia, on Monday night, Major McKinley is reported to have used these words:

The elevated railway lawyers are going on with their attempt to get their suits tried in three sections, as told yesterday in THE TIMES. Before Judge Beach in the Supreme Court yesterday, when a property-damage suit was called for trial, there was an informal discussion as to whether it should be tried before Judge Beach in Special Term, or go to a jury term for trial. Judge Beach adjourned the matter until Friday.

The Republican County Convention of Westchester County met yesterday in Moran's Hall, White Plains. The convention was called to order by Judge William H. Robertson, who made a brief speech commenting on the bright Republican prospects for the ensuing election. The Hon. D. Wiley Travis of Peekskill was chosen Chairman.

The movement to oust the grabbers from Battery Park and to restore that resort to the people is now to be pushed by action rather than by argument. Those citizens who have had this matter in charge feel that they have given already too much time to discussion in regard to it. They were disposed from the beginning to inform the public and public officials upon this subject and to do that work thoroughly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -There was an oldfashioned Democratic velcome to Senator Charles J. Fauikner of Wes Virginia and Conressman W. D. Bynum of Indiana at Metropull,an Hall last evening. These gentlemen arnvecl Sunday evening, in company with oxLieut. Guy. Chauncey Black o! Pennsylvania and Laurence Gardner of Washington, D. C.

STOCKTON, Cal., Oct. 6. -- The record meeting was begun on the kite-shaped track here to-day, and two world's records were lowered. Senator Stanford's two-year-old, Orion, trotted the full mile in 2:15 3/4, beating Sunol's record of 2:18, and his yearling, Bell Bird, went the mile in 2:27 3/4, breaking Freedom's record of 2:29 3/4.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 6. -- The naval court-martial trying Naval Cadet C.W. Griffith, third class, for hazing Naval Cadet H.V. Butler, Jr., fourth class, was continued to-day. Naval Cadet Butler resumed his testimony. He is evidently a conscientious youth, telling the truth, but trying not to tell one more word than is necessary.

Three Senators are to be elected in Kings County this year, and the Democrats placed their candidates in the field last night. The delegates to the Second District Convention, comprising the First, Second, Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, and Twenty-second Wards and the county towns, met at 65 1/2 Montague Street and elected Thomas E. Pearsall Chairman.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct 6. -- Prof. Paul Haupt, Chief of the Semitic department of the Johns Hopkins University, has just returned from London and Berlin, where he had a conference with noted scholars in reference to a new translation of the Bible. It is proposed to include in this translation not only the Old and the New Testament, but also the Apocrypha and the Pseudepigraphy.

At the Latonia races, just closed, the largest winning owners were W.R. Letcher, $8,756; the Hituvar Stable, $5,090; Brice Steele, $4,220; J.T. Williams, $8,220; P.M. West Co., $2,130: W.E. Applegate, $2,360; C. Porter Co., $2,370; E. Brown, $2,620; the Indiana Stable, $2,260; J.E. Pepper, $2,330; the Oakdale Stable, $2,220: P. Dunn, $2,480; W.A. Hopklus Co., $2,380; W.P. McGraue, $2,270, and White Wilkerson, $2,140.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 6. -- The Presbytery of Pittsburg, one of the largest in the General Assembly, to-day took action upon the proposed revision of the Confession of Faith. As a body it was opposed to a revision, but that step having been decided upon, it suggests the following changes in the revision:

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Republican Convention of Putnam County, held here to-day, proved a harmonious affair. This year no opposition to the rule of Hamilton Fish, Jr., has manifested itself among the Republicans, and he was renominated for the Assembly by acclamation. There had been some contests for the minor places on the ticket, but the fighting had all been done in the caucuses.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- In the civil side of the Superior Court to-day an application was filed by the State Attorney for an order restraining the Consolidated Road from using its new bridge over the West River at Guilford. The application states that under the charter the railroad is required to maintain a drawbridge there, and instead Of doing so has shut up the stream, thereby interfering with navigation.

The second day of the cricket match between Lord Hawke's team of English cricketers and All New-York's sixteen was more interesting to the inexpert spectator, if not to the expert, than the first day's play. There were more frequent changes in the batters when the New-Yorkers had their innings, and the sharp fielding of the Englishmen added zest to the play.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Republican Senatorial Convention reconvened to-day to continue the struggle to make a nomination which commenced last week. They had taken a recess Friday with a record of 475 ballots without a choice.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The Right Hon. William Henry Smith, First Lord of the Treasury, Warden of the Cinque Ports, and the Government leader in the House of Commons, who had been ill for some time past, suddenly suffered a relapse this morning and died this afternoon.

A very important real estate suit, affecting property on Long Island, was yesterday decided by Judge Bartlett, in Brooklyn, in favor of the plaintiff. It is known as the Setauket bridge case. The property affected by the suit is a parcel of meadow on Setauket Bay and the homestead of Richard Floyd, who settled at Setauket in 1665, which property is now owned by one of his lineal descendants in the eighth generation.

" This is a State campaign; only State officers are to be elected, and the issues are State issues," cry the Platt-Fassett organs and orators. But it is as impossible for them to keep National and Presidential issues out of the account as it is for a professional neighborhood tattler to refrain from repeating to every person she meets the tale or scandal that lies uppermost in her mind.

Contains, on Page 9, an account of the beginning of the trial by court martial of First Lieut. Edward S. Farrow, Twenty-first Infantry, on a charge of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentlemen in the matter of the sale of certain lots in Barnegat Park, New- Jersey.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 6. -- A band of brigands, yesterday, in spite of the recent diplomatic action of Germany and France, and of the efforts of the Porte to suppress brigandage, made an attempt to wreck and rob a passenger train.

The figures submitted to the Clearing House Association at its annual meeting yesterday were of a magnitude to puzzle even the most active imagination. It is like trying to realize the distance to the moon to try to form a clear conception of clearings for a year amounting to over $34,000,000,000, or even of average daily clearings of over $111,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Secretary Foster this morning listened to the representations made by Messrs. Gustav H. Schwab, John Gibb, and Peter A.B. Worrall on behalf of the New-York merchants who desire to have more adequate facilities in the Appraiser's Stores for the transaction of the business of the port. Mr. Constable and Mr. Sloane, who had been appointed members of the committee, were unable to appear.

No man who has filled the offices that have fallen to the late Right Hon. WILLIAM HENRY SMITH has ever been of less intrinsic account. He was very shrewd and successful man of business, and he carried into the House of Commons a good sense and a fairness that were really the only qualities that could be ascribed to him. Nobody ever became the leader of that body on a smaller intellectual capital.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 6. -- The Grashdanin announces that the officers of the Imperial Guard have decided not to drink champagne at any of the regimental banquets and to contribute the money which would have been so spent to the famine fund.

The eighteenth annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of this State began its sessions in the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday. The morning session was consumed in the appointment of committees and listening to the reports of the superintendents of the many different branches or work included in the catalogue of the union.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- After breakfast this morning Senator Quay went to the People's Bank and one or two other places where he had some private business to transact. About 11:30 o'clock he returned to the Continental Hotel and was closeted for nearly an hour with State Chairman Watres of the Republican Campaign Committee.

The Aldermen met yesterday, and John Morris of the Seventh District offered a resolution which declared that Grammar School No. 35 in the Fifteenth Ward was closed by order of the Board of Education Sept. 15, and that the two remaining schools in the ward were so crowded that the 1,200 pupils of No. 35 were unable to obtain the education provided for by law.

The report that another revolution had occurred in Guatemala appears to have been an invention; or, rather, some incident of the political canvass now going on there was magnified into an insurrection. Still there was nothing in the history of the republic to make the rumor incredible, nor has it been exceptional for Presidents of Guatemala both to succeed to power and to be overthrown by a resort to violence.

There is nothing in the present plans of the local politicians to indicate that there will be a union against Tammany on the local issues this year, but on the contrary, everything points in the direction of straight tickets for all parties and sections.

The final Government tests on the boilers for the big armored cruiser Maine began Monday on the wharf at the foot of East Twelfth Street. Four of the Maine's boilers were on the wharf, having been taken thither from the shops of the builders, the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company of this city.

Three Republican conventions were held in Jamaica, L.I., yesterday. The Queens County Convention organized, with Robert A. Davison of Hempstead Chairman. Judge Garret S. Garretson, the retiring County Judge, was unanimously nominated to succeed himself. Then came the struggle of the day. Chairman Davison stated that the nominations for Sheriff were in order, and Frank Northover of Long Island City named Theron H. Burden.

The present situation of the case of Dr. BRIGGS is that 64 delegates against 62 have voted that he ought to be tried for heresy. Among his clerical brethren, who were presumably better informed than the laymen, the majority was against forcing the issue. In these circumstances a very grave question is presented to the Presbyterian Church.

So far as the responsibility under the law of the Hon. JAMES W. WADSWORTH for his share in soliciting political contributions from Federal office holders is concerned, we do not see that he has helped his case materially by resigning the Treasurership of the Republican State Committee. We have no wish to make it especially uncomfortable for Mr. WADSWORTH.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 7. -- A seedy-looking man of forty-seven years, dressed in a rough suit of brown, and wearing on his head a faded slouch hat. That is John Parnell, the brother of Charles Stewart Parnell. While Charles has been figuring so prominently before the people of Europe and America, his brother has been tending fruit trees on a little farm near West Point, seventy-five miles from Atlanta.

In view of the increasing importance, as pointed out in THE TIMES'S Washington dispatch of yesterday, of providing at an early date for a naval defense of the commerce and seaports on the great lakes, Congress will be asked this Winter to authorize, in addition to some general plan to be proposed by the Secretary of the Navy, the building of two modern type revenue cutters for those waters.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The first session of the Lake Mohonk Indian Conference was held this morning. Opening remarks were made by the host, Mr. A.K. Smiley. Dr. Merrill E. Gates was elected President; Mr. Joshua W. Davis, Mrs. Isabel C. Barrows, and Miss Ellen H. Bailey, all of Boston, were elected Secretaries, and Frank Wood of Boston Treasurer.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 7. -- The sudden fall in the temperature made it improbable that either Hal Pointer or Direct would lower the race record in the renewal of the contest between the crack pacers here this afternoon. But the case with which Hal Pointer went the first heat to-day in 2:10 14 showed that he might have beaten his own mark of 2:09 34 if Direct could have forced him for a mile.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Complete returns concerning the town elections in this State Monday will not be accessible until the last of the week, no systematic effort being made to secure and tabulate the results. The public will view with some interest the fact that the two cities which claim the residence of United States Senators.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- A special from Indianapolis says: "Suit has been brought for the appointment of a receiver for the Indianapolis, Decatur and Western Railroad. The plaintiffs are H.E. Showers and the old First National Bank of this city. Last September Hattie E. Showers obtained a judgment for $1,500 for injuries received. About the same time the First National Bank obtained a judgment against the road for $1,400.

Part of the Democratic plan of campaign is to call the attention of the laboring classes to Mr. Fassett's record on labor matters during his terms in the Senate. Chairman Cummings of the Committee on Literature said, in speaking of it at the Democratic headquarters yesterday:

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The Daily News says: "If Parnell had died two years ago, he would have bequeathed to history the memory of a career almost unique in the perfection of triumph. He had fought the whole English Parliament a dozen years, and, triumphing in the end, could have borne down opposition, outlived hatred, crushed calumny, and made his enemies his footstool.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The equestrian statue of Gen. Grant, representing in giant proportions the "Old Commander" in bronze, was unveiled to-day in Lincoln Park in the presence of an immense crowd and with ceremonies fitting the dignity of such an occasion. High officials, close personal friends of the General, veterans of his old regiment, and a long line-of those who had served under him as Commander in Chief, paid tribute to his memory.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Charles B. Willis, the twenty-year-old son of a well-known resident of Keenesborough, Monmouth County, and Miss Tillie Post, daughter of Truman B. Post of Glenwood Avenue, this place, were determined to be married to-day, and they were married, in spite of two priests. There had been nothing especially secret about the proposed marriage.

The check to the advance in prices on the Stock Exchange has been more obstinate than some of the more ardent and sanguine professional observers were willing to believe that it could be. It has been found quite impracticable to produce what could fairly be called a serious reaction, and those who were gambling on a fall in prices have either made very little or have lost according to the degree of their confidence.

Mayor Alfred C. Chapin of Brooklyn issued his reply to the Ziegler letter yesterday, as THE TIMES said he would do, and in it he declared that he did not desire another term as chief magistrate of the city, but that he thought he could beat William Ziegler. Then he deliberately departed from the programme laid down and demanded that he should be given a chance to run again if the Republicans nominated Mr. Ziegler.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The 114th anniversary of the battle of Fort Montgomery was appropriately observed to-day at that place by the gift of a large American flag to the district school. The flag was presented in behalf of the donor by Prof. Brooks, instructor, and was received by the Rev. Dr. Galloway. Col. Caleb Huse of Highland Falls, who was purchasing agent for the Confederacy during the rebellion, was Chairman of the meeting.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Cornell's library, the pride of every Cornellian's heart, was dedicated to-day with interesting ceremonies. The building stands on the brow of the hill, just south of Morrill Hall, and commands a lovely view of the valley for a score of miles. It is built of white sandstone, with red-tiled roof, and is surmounted by a massive campanile 180 feet high, in which have been placed the chimes and the clock.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- James Marshall Wright and other Eastern Division Chairmen met Democratic State Chairman Kerr to-day, and brought along some very encouraging reports. They show that the interest taken by the Democrats in this year's campaign far exceeds that of last year. Mr. Wright said: "Every effort made to organize the Republicans appears to be a failure.

An injunction was secured in the Superior Court yesterday by Hugh O'Neill to restrain Matthew and James Baird from piling up paving stones on the sidewalk in front of Mr. O'Neill's store in Sixth Avenue, between Twentieth and Twenty-first Streets, on the north side of Twentieth Street for 285 feet back from Sixth Avenue, and the south side of Twenty-first Street for 75 feet back.

Brewers from all parts of the State gathered at the Brewers' Exchange in East Fifteenth Street yesterday to attend the annual session of the New-York State Brewers and Maltsters' Association. This association includes about 250 breweries, and its voice is practically the united voice of the brewing industry.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- The arrangements for the consecration of the Rev. Phillips Brooks as Bishop of the Diocese of Massachusetts are about completed and an official programme will be issued in a few days. The consecration will take place next Wednesday at 11 A.M., and the presiding Bishop will be the Right Rev. John Williams of Connecticut.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Senator McNaughton's determination to retire from the State Senate was stronger than any one believed. This morning he was called upon at his office by a committee, consisting of Congressman Greenleaf, Judge Lynn, and W.G. Skinner, representing the Democratic Senatorial Committee.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- The veteran publisher Patrick Donahoe said: "In the past few weeks Balmaueda and Boulanger have been placed beyond the possibility of blocking human progress. Who can say but that in the death of Parnell Providence designs to give a new birth to the Irish cause? The Irish people will forger Parnell's weakness and mourn him sincerely. Ireland will be ever grateful to him for his great services."
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Coupled with the announcement this morning that Mr. Parnell died last night was the news that Sir John Pope Hennessey, member of Parliament for North Kilkenny, was also dead.

H. Walter Webb, the Third Vice President of the New-York Central Railroad signed a contract yesterday with the Consolidated Car-Heating Company for the re-equipment of the entire Central Road with the consolidated system of steam heat. The work must be completed within sixty days.

Before Judge O'Brien, in the Supreme Court Chambers, yesterday, Julian T. Davies, appearing as counsel for Jay Gould's elevated railway company, asked that a suit against the company that had been called for trial the day before, in the special term of the court, should be sent to a jury term for trial.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The marriage this evening of Dr. Albert H. Ely of New York and Miss Maud L. Merchant of this city was a very brilliant affair. The doors of old St. Paul's were thrown open at 5 P.M., and for nearly two hours people poured into the edifice, filling the church from chancel to vestibule with the most brilliant assemblage ever gathered at a wedding in this city.

DUBLIN, Oct. 7. -- The general feeling in the leading political clubs in both Great Britain and Ireland is that the death of Charles Stewart Parnell will heal the breach which has so long existed in the ranks of the Irish Parliamentary Party.

Rain prevented the conclusion of the cricket match at Livingston, S.I., yesterday between Lord Hawke's team of English gentlemen and the All-New-York sixteen. There have been many unfortunate incidents throughout the three days' play. The weather has been unpropitious, Lord Hawke has been ill and has not played at all, and several others of the team have been out of condition.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 7. -- About 3 o'clock this morning Freight Conductor Joseph Powley of the Middle Division, Pennsylvania Railroad, residing in this city, was assaulted on his train by two unknown men, supposed to be tramps, who knocked him off the train, choked him, and after rifling his pockets of over $22 in money, made their escape in the darkness.

UTICA, Oct. 7. -- The Republicans of the Twenty-third Senatorial District are still without a candidate. Three sessions were held to-day, as usual, and enough ballots taken to bring the total number up to 815, with the last ballot the same as the first and all intervening ones, viz.: Sheard, 6; Smith, 6; Wilber, 6.

THE TIMES is a true leader. Its vision is clear and its present altitude is worthy of its great past. The editorial article, "Discrimination and Consistency," completely turns the tables on those independents who confuse local issues with State politics while insisting that the latter has no bearing on national affairs. This editorial article and Gov. Chamberlain's letter ought to be read by every doubting voter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The second Ecumenical Methodist Council met this morning in the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Church. This edifice has a larger seating capacity than any other Methodist church in the city. There were no temporary decorations to embellish tee severe beauty of the Gothic interior, and the only change made in the interior arrangements was an addition to the platform back of the pulpit to afford the necessary room for the distinguished guests.

It was a big crowd for a day like yesterday that went to Jerome Park with the certainty that rain would come to interfere with the sport. It was a thoroughly disgusted, as well as bedraggled party that came away from the track, for, with the exception of Yorkville|Belle, not a favorite won a race, and she had a narrow escape from defeat.

The trial of Lieut. Edward S. Farrow, Twenty-first Infantry, by court-martial was continued yesterday at the Army Building. It lasted from 10 o'clock in the morning until 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Col. Bacon, the attorney for Lieut. Farrow, said that he was in for fun, and he had it. He engineered any number of oratorical contests with Judge Advocate Birkhimer, and had an even share of the honors.

A jury in the Supreme Court before Judge Patterson will probably decide to-day whether a woman who told them a somewhat peculiar tale yesterday is Mrs. Agnes T. Ellinger or Miss Agnes T. Cunningham. The question is raised in a suit for a separation begun by the woman against William Ellinger, and comes up as a preliminary matter to the trial of that suit.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Great Britain and Ireland were startled this morning by the utterly unlooked-for announcement that Charles Stewart Parnell, the noted Irish leader, was dead. He died suddenly at his home, Walsingham Terrace, Brighton, at 11:30 last evening.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Jacob Sloat Fassett, Republican candidate for Governor, traveled from Lockport to-day in company with John W. Vrooman, candidate for Lieutenant Governor, and Arthur C. Wade, candidate for Controller, to Niagara Falls, thence to Tonawanda, and thence to Buffalo. They held receptions at Niagara Falls and Tonawanda.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- It is asserted by Pension Office employes, who are sure that they know, that Pension Commissioner Raum is practically out of office, and that an order was made by the Secretary of the Interior and with the approval of the President, making First Deputy Commissioner Davidson Acting Commissioner in place of Green B. Raum, suspended, and pending the appointment of his successor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7. -- San Francisco just now is in the throes of such a struggle as that by which New-York shook off the grip of the Tweed Ring. There is this difference, however: the Tweed Ring represented a single political faction, while the thieves and bribe takers who are being hunted to their holes in this city are the present or past leaders of both parties.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The State Convention of typographical unions, held in this city to-day, adopted the following resolutions in executive session:

ELIZABETH, Oct. 7. -- The Abbett and anti-Abbett factions locked horns here to-day at the Second Assembly District Democratic Convention held this afternoon. The row arose over the adoption of a report of the Committee on Resolutions, which struck out a clause that had been prepared in advance indorsing Gov. Abbett's official acts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7. -- There was considerable excitement about Gov. Campbell's office to-day, a large number of persons calling to express their sympathy with the Governor, condemning in the severest manner the malicious attacks made upon him.

After having represented the Twelfth Senatorial District, all told, sixteen years in the State Senate, Judge William H. Robertson positively declined another nomination at the Republican Convention yesterday at Tarrytown. The convention was held in the parlors of the Franklin House, and Edward B. Long of White Plains presided.

The Women's Temperance Convention was an hour late in assembling for its morning session in the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday. But once in order, its business, skillfully guided by the President, Mrs. Burt, traveled in smooth grooves. Once only was there a hitch.

As a supplement to its original libel suit against THE NEW-YORK TIMES for $1,000,000 damages, the New-York Life adds another for three-quarters of a million. If this was meant to intimidate that paper it has failed in its purpose, for the articles go on from day to day with monotonous regularity. Evidently THE TIMES is amply able to take care of itself, and doesn't scare worth a cent.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Telegrams from Liverpool, Manchester, Glasgow, and other centres through out the kingdom testify to the profound sensation caused by the event everywhere among constituencies where the Irish element is of importance, and the consensus of opinion is that it will increase the weight of the Irish vote.

The Democratic Convention of Westchester County was held yesterday in Lafayette Hall, White Plains. It was called to order by George Sanford, Chairman of the Democratic County Committee. William A. Boyd of Mamaroneck was elected Chairman, and in taking the chair made a telling speech upon the bright prospects of the Democracy in this State at the coming election.

DUBLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Freeman's Journal says: "One of the most remarkable careers of modern times has been brought to an early and sudden close. At such a moment it ill befits the Irish nation to set aside or discard the memory of the bright days when Irishmen regarded Parnell with confidence, because of his integrity, honor, and devotion.

The Brewers and Maltsters' Association of this State held its annual meeting yesterday and received a report from its Trustees which dealt somewhat fully with the position of political parties in the State on the excise question. The brewers fail to find anything in the new phraseology of the Republican platform that indicates a change of policy.

Representatives of business firms which are among the heaviest consumers of tin plate in this country met yesterday at the Fulton Club rooms, Fulton and Gold Streets, and formed an association to be known as the Tin Plate Consumers' Association of the United States. After listening to a statement of its objects one of those, present characterized the new organization as "something designed to choke off all tin-plate liars in the United States."

The Democratic Assembly Conventions were held in the twelve districts of Kings County last night and nominations were made in all but the Eleventh, where the Republicans have a majority. This convention was adjourned until tomorrow night.

We notice in the McKinley press many articles and paragraphs in which the attention of farmers is directed to the price of binding twine. The Protective Tariff League asserts that the price of binding twine was 14 1/2 cents a pound in October, 1890, when the McKinley bill became a law, and that it is now 11 cents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The presiding officer's chair at the Ecumenical Methodist Council to-day was filled by the Rev. Dr. T.B. Stephenson of London, President of the Wesleyan Conference. The session was opened with devotional exercises, an eloquent prayer being offered by the Rev. Griffin W. Wilson of England, who has achieved a notable reputation as a missionary among the Fiji Islanders.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- A dispatch from St. Petersburg to the Daily News of this city, published to-day, says that the United States Immigration Commissioners who have recently been visiting Russia were painfully impressed by the condition of the Jews. They saw, according to the News correspondent, a number of curious examples of Russian administration, of which the following instance is given:

A number of Lord Hawke's team of cricketers from England attended the races at Morris Park yesterday afternoon. Lord Hawke wasn't with them, much to the disappointment of a number of vapid young fellows from some of the Fifth Avenue clubs who have Anglomania in the worst form and dress like Cockney "Johnnies."

The Census Bulletin giving the population of the State by civil divisions shows in a striking way the tendency of growth toward cities and large towns. While by the imperfect census of 1890 it appears that the increase of population for the State was in ten years only about 18 per cent., that of cities and towns of more than 4,000 inhabitants was 38.71 per cent.

Laidlaw Brothers, the bankers of 14 Wall Street, were swindled last month out of $11,600 by a spruce-looking Englishman by means of a forged letter of credit. The firm does a large business in foreign letters of credit with tourists visiting this country, chiefly from England. Among its English correspondents is the New Oriental Banking Company, Limited, of London.

Benjamin F. Einstein, assignee of Abraham Backer, dealer in commercial paper at 285 Broadway, has, after a great deal of labor, succeeded in perfecting a plan for liquidating the affairs of Mr. Backer, by means of a trust, whereby it is expected that the creditors will be paid in full, the assets preserved, and the best possible result secured out of the property in the assignee's hands.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Hudson County's First Assembly District Democratic Convention met here to-night and nominated Thomas Magner of Bayonne. He received 12 votes, against 2 for Michael I. Fagan of Greenville Magner is a young man and a saloon keeper, who never held office.

The facility with which proxy rights can be obtained and retained in the mutual system of life insurance has now come to be recognized as fraught with great danger. In theory the idea of all members of the company having a voice in its management is most attractive; in practice it falls very far short of the actual truth.

A complaint purporting to come from attendants at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twelfth Street, near Fourth Avenue, was received yesterday at the Board of Excise, against a saloon known as "The Hole in the Wall," at 117 Fourth Avenue, which is run by Carey Welsh, and which it is claimed is the resort of bad characters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The following named Presidential Postmasters have been appointed. The offices affected all became Presidential on the 1st inst., and in each case the President appointed the incumbent of the office at the time it was raised to this class:

Two or three months ago, when the production of a few tons of tin, the metal, at the Temescal Mine in California was widely advertised, the McKinley newspapers declared that the development of this mine had been caused by the McKinley tariff. Vast deposits of ore, they said, had remained undisturbed in the earth until the enactment of the McKinley bill created a demand for the metal.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 8. -- The Eastern Inter-collegiate Football Association met at the Parker House, Boston, last night. Bowdoin withdrew from the league, which is now composed of Williams, Dartmouth, Amherst, Technology, and Stevens. The schedule is:

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The Fire Department of this city had its annual parade today. About 1,200 men were in the procession. The visiting companies were Humane Engine Company of Morristown, Harmony of Trenton, Washington of Wilmington, Del.; Neptune and Hibernia of New-Brunswick, Protection of South Amboy, Alert Hose of Plainfield, Franklin Hose of East Orange, and Westfield Chemical Engine and a large delegation from Engine No. 20 of New-York.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The Hill and anti-Hill forces, who have been engaged in the bitterest warfare for supremacy here for the last three months, met in County Convention at the village of Mexico to-day for the final conflict. The result was a fitting climax to the whole business. The convention was the largest that ever assembled in the county, and such a scene of noise and confusion was never before witnessed there.

The People's Municipal League seems to have an effective plan for promoting the cause of genuine ballot reform in the present canvass. The plan is to secure so far as practicable the nomination of candidates for the Assembly pledged to the support of the proposed amendment of the law, and to unite in their support all friends of the reform regardless of party.

The election of a Mayor in the City of Brooklyn is an extremely important matter, and, though it receives a great deal of attention from the politicians, it is not always considered from the point of view of the citizens generally. With its large and usually trustworthy majority in the city, the Democratic Party has naturally a greater responsibility for the filling of this office than its rival.

BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- The Inter-State Railway Commission, represented by Commissioner W.G. Veazey and Martin A. Knapp, gave a hearing in the rooms of the Railroad Commissioners to-day on the charge of Senator Chandler against the Boston and Maine Railroad, that the company had issued free passes in violation of the inter-State commerce law. There were about a dozen persons present.

Order was brought out of chaos in the Brooklyn Mayoralty situation yesterday, and THE TIMES is in a position to state several important facts authoritatively. One is that Mayor Chapin will positively not be renominated under any circumstances. He wrote his letter to Congressman Boody, in opposition to the wishes of the leaders of his party and in order, as he himself said, "to appeal to the Democratic Party."

MINERSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 8. -- News reached here this morning to the effect that some of the bodies of the victims of the Richardson Colliery Mine disaster had been recovered, and the greatest excitement prevailed. People flocked to the mine, and wives, children, and friends formed a circle around the mouth of the slope. The scene was a sad one in the extreme.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The Census Office to-day issued a bulletin showing the population of the State of New-York by minor civil divisions. The bulletin gives the population of the State in detail by counties, towns, cities, wards of cities, and villages, according to the official count of the returns made under the eleventh census, taken as of June 1, 1890.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 8. -- The Minnesota Farmers' Alliance pays its respects to Robert P. Porter, who made such a sorry mess of the eleventh census. President Donnelly gave Mr. Porter a "brown roast," after which the following drastic resolutions were adopted:

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 8. -- The champion stallions of the East and West met here to-day in a great struggle for the championship and a purse of $10,000. Nelson, the Maine horse, represented the East, and his erratic owner, C.H. Nelson, drove him, weighing 170 pounds when he weighed in for the race. Allerton, was also driven by his owner, C.W Williams, who tipped the scales at 165 pounds.

The Ecumenical Council of the Methodists at Washington is one of the most striking events in the history of Methodism by reason of the number of the eminent men in attendance upon it, and by reason of the vast and increasing numbers and the various nations they represent. Yet the business of this body is little more than to attest the prosperous progress of Methodism.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The Passaic County Democratic Convention was held here this afternoon to nominate candidates for Senator and for County Clerk. The convention was largely attended. The Abbett men having crowded Senator Mallon off the track, very little confidence was manifested in the success of the nominee, whoever he might be, but the nomination was looked upon rather as deciding who should be regarded as the leader of the party hereafter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8. -- The vexed question of a public building site for San Francisco has been settled at last. The corner of Seventh and Mission Streets has been chose, and the price is $1,040,000. The contract has been drawn up and approved by the Secretary of the Treasury.

The court-martial trying Lieut. Edward S. Farrow, Twenty-first Infantry, for alleged dishonest transactions in regard to property at Barnegat Park, N.J., met yesterday morning on the top floor of the Army Building. The reading of Wednesday's proceedings occupied two hours. Then the cross-examination of the witness, Christian F. Schramme, was continued.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The prosaic happenings of the Supreme Court at Elizabeth were brightened to-day by a wedding in which John, the only son and heir of the late Uncle Billy Moore, became the husband of Miss Mary Wood of New-York. Young Moore met Mary three years ago, and in a few months they were both madly in love and looked eagerly forward to their wedding day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The Mutual Protective Association, which was established in this city some time ago, has been exposed by the newspapers. The scheme is the old one of ten-thousand-dollar policies paid when they mature -- that is when the company has money enough to pay them. It was worked here a couple of years ago, but thoroughly exposed by the papers and driven out of town.

Recently a prominent naval officer has expressed the opinion that the Government is making a mistake in constructing high freeboard vessels. The utility of the cruiser is now so universally recognized by all naval powers that it is no longer considered an experiment, as the building of battle ships still is.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- The suit brought by Attorney General Watson against the Standard Oil Company to annul its charter rights was argued in the Supreme Court to-day. The argument for the State was made by John W. Warrington.

At the meeting of the Union League Club last night resolutions or regret were passed upon the death of two members of the club who were for many years honored and respected by their fellow-members, and who died recently within a short time of each other. The one was Mr. George Jones, the other Mr. Charles Watrous.

Recently an article appeared in your valuable journal headed "Proud of His Family." It was taken from the Illustrated American, and was to the effect that Jefferson Davis's first wife was the eldest daughter of "Dr Biranger" of New-Orleans, and the second daughter married Gen. Dick Taylor, son of President Zachary Taylor.

Hanging over the piano in President Beers's drawing room at 26 East Forty-eighth Street there is a painting by Rembrandt valued by the venerable President of the New-York Life at $12,000. It was given to him by his dear friend L.C. Vanuxem of Philadelphia, and it is a source of great pride to the donor as well as to Mr. Beers himself.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The following call for a meeting of the Republican National Committee was issued this afternoon:

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The Democratic Senatorial Convention for the Twelfth District, comprising the Counties of Westchester and Rockland, was held in the Nyack Opera House this afternoon. The delegates from Westchester County, as well as those from Rockland, were accompanied by many friends, so that the attendance was very large.

ADA, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- "The meeting of the Governors" will be a long-remembered event in the history of Ada and Hardin County. The little town of Ada was in gala attire to-day in honor of the great event. By noon there were over 5,000 strangers in the place, and although great enthusiasm was manifested by both parties, the rivalry was a friendly one and entirely devoid of unpleasant incidents.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Jacob Sloat Fassett and John W. Vrooman, candidates of the Republican Party for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, addressed audiences to-night at Harmonia Hall and Lincoln Hall in this city. Ex-Mayor Philip Becker accompanied them and made speeches supporting Mr. Fassett for Governor and Mr. Vrooman for Lieutenant Governor.

ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 8. -- The World's Fair Convention adjourned at 4:30 this afternoon. Seven additional counties had delegates present, making 21 counties in all with 131 delegates. The Committee on Plans and Resolutions submitted a report, which was adopted, providing for a State Directory of thirteen members, who were subsequently elected by the convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The following signals, recommended by the late International Marine Conference for adoption by all institutions for saving life from wrecked vessels, have been adopted by the Life-Saving Service of the United States:

" I am ashamed of my mother," exclaimed a fair-haired, fragile-looking delegate yesterday morning in the Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention. It was Miss Anna L. Thompson of Newburg, and she continued with a sweeping gesture and dramatic emphasis: "We are relying on ourselves, when we ought to be trusting in the Lord."

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 8. -- The bill passed by the Legislature to prevent pooling among insurance companies is a blow at the Southeastern Tariff Association, which has its headquarters in Atlanta. The bill provides for the prevention of combinations or pools of insurance companies or their agents, tending to defeat or lessen competition in the business of insurance in the State of Georgia.

The play at the Amberg Theatre last night was Paul Lindau'e German version of "El Gran Galooto,' a four-act drama of modern life by Joss Echegaray. "Galeoto," as Lindau calls it, is a social study With a tinge of pessimism that reminds one or Ibsen; but the impassioned and dramatic eloquence of the Southern poet enters into roll his Work and dominates it.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- Hambleton's Circular will announce to-morrow that the publishers have obtained definite information regarding the proposed pulley of the Baltimore and Ohio. It is proposed to ask the stockholders at the annual meeting in November to authorize the issue of $10,000,000 additional stock, to be appropriated as follows: As dividend to present stockholders, $3,000,000; to the Pittsburg and Western Road, $2,000,000; to be sold as required for extensions and betterments, $5,000,000.

TRENTON, Oct. 9. -- The County Excise Boards which Autocrat Abbett has established over the South Jersey temperance counties have aroused the wildest excitement among the people. These boards have been established mostly in the Republican counties. They are empowered to reduce the license fee if it be fixed too high by the local Excise Boards, and to grant licenses to those to whom the local Excise Boards refuse to grant them.

DUBLIN, Oct. 9. -- Thousands of persons are already flocking to Dublin to attend the funeral, and an immense crowd is expected to be present on Sunday. All the public houses will be closed while the funeral ceremonies are in progress.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- No candidate for public office in Philadelphia has ever received a stronger indorsement than one issued to-day supporting W. Redwood Wright in his fight for election to succeed himself as City Treasurer. It is signed by 124 of the most influential business and professional men in Philadelphia Fifteen of the signers are Democrats, who were invited to sign because they have always been identified with reform movements.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The Senatorial dead-lock was broken at 2:15 o'clock this morning on the nine hundred and thirty-seventh ballot, when the Otsego delegates withdrew their own candidate and cast their solid vote for John E. Smith of Madison County. The Herkimer delegates were for Senator Sheard to the last.

" By what authority do you groan?" demanded GEORGE F. HOAR of ROSCOE CONKLING in a Republican Senate caucus many years ago when the saintly Massachusetts Senator had been obliged to admit that he was the political "backer" of a certain Sergeant at Arms about to be dismissed for drunkenness. "I groaned to relieve a burdened spirit," replied Mr. CONKLING, "and I feel that I must groan again," and once more he groaned.

It is hard for Democratic speakers to suit the ideas of Republican politicians in their choice of "issues" for discussion. The latter, being determined so far as possible to keep national questions out of the State canvass, are accusing the Democrats of a willingness to talk about nothing else, and a desire to evade State issues.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- A brilliant but not numerous company at Mount Washington to-day witnessed the opening of the cricket match between Lord Hawke's party of Englishmen and the Baltimore Cricket Club. The cricketers of "My Maryland" made a very creditable showing. They have scored 52 runs for four wickets, with eleven batsmen to come yet. The Englishmen went to the bat first and scored 305 runs before they were retired.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 9. -- A special committee of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association, consisting of Col. Frederick Driscoll of the St. Paul Pioneer Press, E.H. Woods of the Boston Herald, and Major W.J. Richards of the Indianapolis News, will conduct a typesetting machine contest during the coming week in the Chicago Evening Post Building.

Three deaths occurred on board the Guion steamship Wisconsin during that vessel's stormy passage to this port. The Wisconsin sailed from Liverpool Sept. 26, during a moderate gale, and battled with heavy seas and high winds throughout the entire passage. Oct. 3 Bernt Johansen, a Swedish steerage passenger, died of pneumonia, and was buried at sea.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- One million dollars in the bonds of the City of Chicago are soon to be sold in aid of the World's Fair. This is the first of a series of five blocks of $1,000,000 each that are to be donated by Chicago to the big exposition. This afternoon the Directors adopted a resolution calling on City Controller May to sell the first block of bonds within ninety days from Nov. 1.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 9. -- Last Friday there was a dead-lock in the First Assembly District Democratic Convention which was held at Manalapan. Henry Embley of Upper Freehold was the Abbett faction's candidate and Reuben G. Strahan of Millstone was the choice of the opposing or Blodgett faction. Both sides were firm and held their ground so persistently that it was decided to adjourn the convention until to-day.

Corporation Counsel Clark sent an opinion yesterday to the Board of Police Commissioners, stating that he considered that the board had no power to increase the salary of Roundsmen from $1,300 to $1,400. He said that the power granted by the act of the Legislature to fix a Roundsman's salary had been exhausted when the board raised the salary in 1890 from $1,200 to $1,300.

We thought it highly improbable that FASSETT would oppose his master's will in the matter of the Senatorial nomination in the Twenty-third or Herkimer-Madison-Otsego District. After the first hint was made public that he desired the renomination of his friend TITUS SHEARD, and would exert his influence in that behalf, there came an ominous silence as to FASETT'S further interest in the proceedings at Utica, and his influence, apparently suffered a blight.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- County Treasurer Nicholas E. Brodhead, who was appointed temporary receiver of the Ulster County Savings Institution, qualified to-day, his sureties being the American Trust Company of New-York City. The amount of the bond is $250,000, which has been approved by Judge Fursman of Troy.

It will be Princeton's turn against the Crescents this afternoon. The new football team of the New-Jersey college, under the management of Trainer "Jack" McMaster, will face the crack Brooklyn eleven ac Eastern Park. The result of the game against Lehigh Thursday inclines the followers of Princeton to hope for big things this Fall.

CORK, Oct. 9. -- Large sensational posters have been placarded on walls, fences, and other places throughout this city. They have deep mourning borders, and bear in the centre the words, "Murdered to please Englishmen," together with verses denouncing the McCarthyltes and the United Ireland articles; declaring that Parnell was murdered, and imploring the people to remain tranquil.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- C.A. Spreckels, Rudolph Spreckels, J.C. Uhler, Charles Watson, William O. Hempstead, and Louis Spreckels will make an application next month for a charter for a corporation to be known as the Spreckels Steamship Company. The notice for the application states that the object of the company is to engage in shipbuilding and transportation business and "whatever shall be incidental to the said business."

Arrangements are rapidly being perfected for the ratification meeting which Tammany will hold in the Wigwam on Oct. 15. Those who have been invited and who will probably speak at the meeting are: Patrick Collins of Massachusetts, United States Senator Kenna of West Virginia, George Raines, who presided at the Democratic State Convention, and ex-Congressman McAdoo.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The third day's session of the Ecumenical Methodist Council opened with the Rev. H.T. Marshall of the Methodist New Connexion, England occupying the presiding officer's chair.

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 28. -- That dreaded scourge, the cholera, is rapidly beginning its annual ravages. It had been confidently hoped that as the Summer passed and few serious cases of the plague occurred, the year might run by without the fatality which has overtaken Chinese cities in past years. But within the past fortnight the disease has been gaining headway rapidly, and already seven Europeans are known to have suddenly died from cholera.

Your San Francisco correspondent states that the Tweed Ring belonged only to one political faction. If he will turn to a file of THE TIMES during its glorious fight with that Ring, he will admit his mistake. One of the crowning merits of Mr. Jones and of his paper was that in the fight with Tweed he fought men of his own party as well as men on the other side.

NEWARK, Oct. 9. -- The city papers of this evening note a suspicious circumstance in connection with the people's fight against the municipal bosses. A Director of one of the banks says that a member of the Democratic County Committee having an account at that bank has given notice that $10,000 will be drawn by him from the bank Monday morning and that the money will all be wanted in one and two dollar bills.

Jay Gould has shown, on more than one occasion, that he possesses the power to break up a meeting of the Western Traffic Association whenever he chooses to do so. He probably regards it as his right to regulate the proceedings of that body, as he was chiefly instrumental in organizing it.

Henry A. Coffin, a well-known Iowa financier and Treasurer of the Iowa Loan and Trust Company of Des Moines, died suddenly of heart disease in Ladd's Jewelry store. 3 Wall Street, yesterday morning at 11 o'clock. Mr. Coffin came to this city on Thursday with G.M. Hipple, Vice President of the Des Moines savings Bank and a Director in the loan and trust company, and registered at the Astor House.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9. -- Wholesale liquor dealers in this city are up in arms. For some time past -- in fact, almost from the time that George H. Large of Newark was appointed Internal Revenue Collector -- it has been almost impossible to get satisfactory service from the gaugers. Men have been appointed, in the interests of local politicians, who had no practical experience of the duties expected of them.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 9. -- There was a much better track for the harness races to-day, and the miles trotted and paced were all fast. The best performance was by Delmarch against time, who turned the course in 2:11 1/2, lowering his record a half second. This sensational trotter is a stallion, seven years old, and his previous record was made in a race last week at Richmond, Ind.

STUTTGART, Oct. 9. -- The funeral ceremonies of the dead King Karl I, took place at 10 o'clock. A memorial service was held in the Marble Room. The catafalque was surmounted by a handsome baldachin of black velvet, embroidered with silver. The casket was covered with a red velvet pall, heavily embroidered and fringed with gold.
Fire in the Kankakee Crystal Ice Company's house, at Waldron, Ill., yesterday, damaged the property $20,000. Fully covered by insurance.

There was solid basis for encouragement in the news that came to the Democratic Headquarters yesterday. The ordinary "encouraging" news at all campaign headquarters is born largely of the hopes of those who give it out, but yesterday's news was of the kind that is born of facts, and self-evident facts at that.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9. -- The Oliver Roberts Wire Company, one of the largest concerns of its kind in the country, made a request of its creditors to-day for an extension. The amount of its indebtedness could not be learned, as the members of the firm refused to give figures, but it was confidently said that the creditors would be paid every dollar.

The court-martial of Lieut. Edward S. Farrow, Twenty-first Infantry, proceeded yesterday at the Army Building. The session was more productive of incidents than some of the previous ones. The charge against Lieut. Farrow is "conduct unbecoming an officer and gentleman," and embraces six specifications, all alleging that he sold lots in Barnegat Park which he had no right to dispose of and that he subsequently floated fraudulent notes.
LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The following is a summary of the platform adopted at the Indian Conference to-day:

I was once a "junior" in the employment of that well-known and extensive firm, Apsley, Wellesley Co., of Cornhill. The senior partner was a friend of my father, which gave me a better position than I should otherwise have occupied; but I may say, without vanity, that I was well worth my "salt," or at all events my salary, which was by no means a large one.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- While the Republican managers deny all connection with the suit which has been brought in the State Supreme Court to annul the new Australian ballot law as unconstitutional, there is no doubt that they are very apprehensive of the new system. They undoubtedly have good cause for fear, and clearheaded observers are to be found who declare it will contribute very largely to the re-election of Gov. Campbell.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 10. -- The recent cold weather has caused considerable of an exodus this week of cottagers. The chief events of interest this week were the catboat races for the prizes offered by Mr. Edwin D. Morgan and those subscribed for by other cottagers. Both races were very successful, and perhaps the best ever held here.

This volume on the Puritan Sabbath is not devoted to faith and doctrine. On these aspects of the religious life of the New-England forefathers the writer has nothing to say. She is content to abandon a field of investigation to which many studious persons have devoted years of research that perhaps contributed more to their own satisfaction than to the substantial good of the public at large.

The Columbia College football team beat the team of the Berkeley Athletic Club by a score of 32 to 0 yesterday afternoon at the Columbia Oval. Columbia showed a great weakness in the centre. Grout of the Berkeley team did some very good kicking. On the Columbia eleven Shipman ran well, and the interference of Bandler was good, but he fumbled the ball several times.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10. -- About 400 victims of misplaced confidence held an indignation meeting to-night. They were men who had been led into joining the Annual Friend Benevolent Association, which, according to promises, was to pay $100 on each certificate or membership, and it was guaranteed that the assessments should not exceed a total of $30.

Judge Henry Wilder Allen of the Court of Common Pleas was stricken down with apoplexy and resulting paralysis yesterday in the corridor of the County Court House. He was removed to the Chambers Street Hospital, where he now is. It is thought by the hospital physicians that he has a good chance of recovery. The apoplexy affected the left side of his head, and the paralysis was confined to the right side of his body.

David A. Boody is already a member of Congress from the Second Congressional District, but will undoubtedly obey his party's call to assume the Mayoralty, should he be elected to that office, of which we take it there is no doubt. It is a diversion of his career from the path in Federal councils he had long desired, but the change can only be regarded as a promotion.

There is a somewhat curious condition of things in Brooklyn, owing to the action of the Republican City Convention, which at the last moment placed in nomination Mr. WILLIAM ZIEGLER. This gentleman's appearance in the public affairs of our sister city has been extremely interesting, but is of recent date.

" Are they pretty?" That is woman's first question about hats, wraps, and gowns at the beginning of every season. Naturally, too, since her own beauty depends so entirely upon them. Cynical and heretical? No, because the woman does not live so beautiful that bad dressing will not obliterate her beauty for the general eye, while every one knows that elegant gowning will make the homeliest woman pleasant to look upon.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- With the reopening of the Haymarket with Henry Arthur Jones's "The Dancing Girl" on Monday last, and of the St. James's with C. Haddon Chambers's "The Idler," the Autumn season of theatre business may be said to be in full swing. At the St. James's there is an after attraction to "The Idler" entitled "Moliere." It is a drama in one act by Walter Frith.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The fourth day's session of the Methodist Ecumenical Council was presided over by the Rev. Dr. William Arthur of England. Through Secretary King the Committee on Business reported several resolutions and memorials, which were held for consideration; also one expressing sympathy with the Rev. Dr. Samuel Antcliff of England in his serious illness, which was adopted.

The American Protective Tariff League publishes in its weekly paper some "average retail prices" of articles in common use, the league's purpose being to show that the prices of these articles were lower last month than they were in October, 1890. Among the articles in the list are fruit cans, tin dippers, and tin pails, and the reader is told that the prices of such wares have fallen since October last.

It has become very plain, even thus early in the campaign, that the men whom Platt and Nathan have selected to manage Mr. Fassett's affairs in Brooklyn are going to prevent, if possible, any discussion of national questions during the next three weeks. Their speakers have been instructed to let the tariff severely alone and to have nothing to say about the silver question.

The suburbs have again been blessed with a week of almost uninterrupted fine weather, and although this was rather variable in quality, with Summer on Sunday and almost wintry blasts on Monday night, the many members of the gay world now assembled in the various resorts near the metropolis have enjoyed themselves to the fullest extent in the opportunities afforded them for outdoor recreation.

District Attorney Graham of Philadelphia writes to THE TIMES concerning the statement telegraphed from that city and published here on the 4th inst. touching the rumored withholding from publication by him of letters affecting State Treasurer Boyer of Pennsylvania, H says:

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore gave the first of the Autumn course of lectures to teachers yesterday under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, at the American Museum of Natural History in Central Park. The course will consist of ten lectures on geography and zoology, illustrated with stereoptican views. Prof. Bickmore said yesterday he would give some of the results of his travels in Labrador during the past Summer.

The sixth day of the court-martial of Lieut. Edward S. Farrow, Twenty-first Infantry, proceeded yesterday morning at the Army Building. The members came in just before 10:30 o'clock, and without ostentation got to work. The popular conception of a court-martial as an occasion for "fuss and feathers" finds no support in the present trial.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10. -- The cricket game at Mount Washington to-day between the Gentlemen of England and the Baltimore Cricket Club ended in a fiasco, as far as Baltimore was concerned. They promised well in the opening of their inning on Friday afternoon, and made 52 runs for four wickets down. To-day the play began at 11:15, and the slaughter of Baltimore was fearful.

The first meeting this Fall of the Hempstead Farm Racing Association took place at Meadowbrook, L.I., yesterday afternoon. A very attractive programme had been arranged, but there was an unexpectedly small number of people who patronized the affair, and in this number were included chiefly the local Meadowbrook hunting set, which turned out bravely to do honor to the first grathering of the season.
DUBLIN, Oct. 10. -- As Mr. John Dillon, member of Parliament for East Mayo, was passing down Sackville Street last evening, he was met by arough who shouted:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct 10. -- Shortly after 6 o'clock this morning a heavy freight train of sixty cars left here going north on the Hudson River Railroad. The Poughkeepsie and Albany way freight left to go north at 6 A.M. Near Boorman's Bridge, a mile south of Hyde Park, the heavy freight train broke in two. Before the way freight train could be signaled it dashed into the rear of the broken train.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Marksmen of the New-Jersey Shooting Club faced the traps nearly five hours yesterday afternoon at Claremont. Among the two dozen competitors in the eleven prize events were nearly all the crack shots. In six of the events first prizes were won by men who did not miss a bird. They were closely pushed.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Oct. 10. -- The Athletic Association of Rutgers College is preparing for its field day exercises, and though the time is not definitely set, election day, Nov. 3, will probably be selected. Members of Christian Association teams will join hands to make the events a success.

This has indeed been a season of great abundance of fruit. Nor is the season yet past. This week it will be possible to obtain as handsome peaches as were ever exhibited in the fruit stores of this city, at prices never before so low in the mouth of October. New-Jersey and the Hudson River Valley will send the last of this season's crop this week.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- In the course of his speech at Malone the other day Gov. Hill uttered language affecting the Adirondacks that was lost at the time, because of the greater importance of his remarks touching the reduction of the legal rate of interest. Hill's Adirondack policy has been vacillating and uncertain, as every other policy he ever had to-ward the important interests of the State.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 10. -- Among the cases to be heard in the Chancery Court here on the 27th is one involving several prominent civil servants and with which one Minister of the Crown may be connected. It is a suit for divorce and alimony brought by Jessie Aldrich, wife of Frederick Aldrich, for many years private secretary to Sir Adolph Caron, Minister of Militia.

Where has the public gone? It has disappeared from Wall Street as suddenly as it came. Transactions are diminishing to about one-third of what they were, the market is narrowing, dealings are confined mainly to a few of the leading speculatives, commission houses are getting idle again. This is a rapid change from last month.

The annual games of the Brooklyn Heights Athletic Club were held at the old Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds, Eighth Avenue, Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, yesterday afternoon. The feature of the day was the hammer throwing of J.S. Mitchell of the New-York Athletic Club, present champion, who threw the sixteen-pound hammer 141 feet 3 1/2 inches, supplanting his own world's record of 139 feet 10 1/2 inches. The results were as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- A very large number of people surrounded Walsingham Terrace this morning when the casket containing the body of Mr. Parnell was taken from the house. Inside the house there was an affecting scene. The grief of the widow was most intense, and it was with difficulty that she could be persuaded to allow the coffin to be taken away. She was utterly unable, through prostration, to accompany the body to Dublin.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Gov. Hill got another set-back to-day.
