Not content with the slap in the face he received at the Judicial Convention Thursday, he took it upon himself to meddle with county affairs to-day. The County Convention was called for noon, and there was to have been no contest, except for Coroner. During the forenoon it was noised about that the friends of Andrew Hamilton would contest the nomination for District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The increase in the Asiatic squadron, ordered by Secretary Tracy in consequence of the Chinese riots, is gradually being accomplished. A cable dispatch from Yokohama announces the arrival of the Alert at that point from Bering Sea last Monday. The Charleston has already been there since Sept. 21, and the Marion, also from Bering Sea, will be due in a short time.

An old railroad conductor on a Western railway, after some irritating experiences with a couple of passengers, imparted to me in confidence this sage secret, the fruit of his ripened observation: "You may think you do, but you don't, know how many blanked fools and cranks there are until you go traveling. The most of them are always on the cars or the boats."

The Princeton football eleven made its first appearance of the season at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, when it faced the Crescent team. There was a large crowd in attendance and the New-Jersey students were warmly applauded as they strode on the field. Poe came in for the giant's share of the applause.

The Richmond County Hunt held one of the most brilliant meets in its history yesterday afternoon. There were nearly 100 gay traps filled with society people from Staten Island and this city, and a field of twenty-five. The only thing lacking was a fox. The meet was at the little village of Graniteville at 3:30 o'clock, and the throw-off was in a meadow along Richmond Avenue.

The outcome of the field day of the First Brigade on Thursday last was of the most gratifying description. Judging the undertaking in its entirety. "The fact that the men in the ranks liked it," said a Captain in a leading regiment, "is the best proof that could be offered that enterprises of the nature set in motion through the energy and enterprise of the brigade commander are what the National Guard want.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The Rev. Dr. Arthur T. Pierson of Philadelphia, well known throughout the college world by his addresses at Northfield and other student gatherings, opened the course of special sermons before the students last Sunday, his theme being "Modern Missions."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The Court of Appeals has just handed down a decision which is of unusual interest to shippers, involving, as it does, nearly all the questions between shipper and carrier. The cases of Henry Gallagher and Jennings Co. against the Grand Trunk Railway have been decided by the court of last resort, after having been in litigation for nearly ten years.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The body of William Henry Smith, late Conservative leader in the House of Commons, was removed this morning from Walmer Castle, near Deal, en route to Hambleden, near Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshira. The casket was covered with wreaths of flowers, one being from the Queen. It was inscribed: "A mark of sincere regard and gratitude for devoted services to his sovereign and country from Victoria."

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- If the public interest continues in the investigation being conducted by the Rapid Transit Commissioners into the lack of accommodation afforded by the West End Railway Company to its patrons the hearings will not end on Monday, but will go on so long as there are persons sufficiently interested in the matter to give their views.

When Abraham Lincoln, at the beginning of the war, called for troops, he asked first for 75,000 men. It was soon apparent, however, that this number was quite insufficient to quell the great rebellion, and his second call was for 300,000 soldiers. Everybody remembers what noble patriotism prompted the hearty response, and the self-forgetting rush to arms that was made by men of all classes in defense of their beloved country and its honored institutions.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 10. -- The Kansas State Board of Agriculture, in its October report, makes the total yield of wheat in Kansas 58,399,619 bushels, of which 2,202,869 bushels is Spring wheat.

The McKinley tariff having been in force for a year, we begin to form estimates of some of its effects. There are chiefly two kinds of wool, line being used for clothing and coarse for carpets. The former is produced mostly here, the latter exclusively imported. What is imported comes unwashed, rates on the cleaned article being prohibitory.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The open handicap meeting of the Worcester Athletic Club attracted a large field of amateur athletes this afternoon. The games took place at Worcester Oval, the new grounds of the Worcester Club at Lakeview. The grounds were in first-class condition, but there was no record breaking.

Lovers of billiards are looking forward to the match game between Jacob Schaefer, champion at the fourteen-inch balk-line game, and George F. Slosson, which is to take place at Chickering Hall Oct. 26. Slosson is the only man in the country now who is anything like a match for the "Wizard," and honors between them are at least oven enough to make the result of their matches interesting for betting purposes.
Congressman Amos J. Cummings does not quite agree with Mr. Fassett in what the latter has to say on the World's Fair topic. Speaking of Mr. Fassett's speech on Friday, Mr. Cummings said yesterday:

A suicide occurred in the United States garrison at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., Friday afternoon. Louis Bauer, aged twenty-four, a native of Germany, was a private in Battery C, First Artillery, for ten months. He was a quiet fellow and was popular with his comrades. Giving no intimation of his purpose, he went to the wardroom when it was vacant, took his rifle, placed the muzzle against his breast, and pulled the trigger with his foot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The Superintendent of the Life-saving Service to-night received a telegram from the keeper of the life-saving station at Assateague, Va., saying the Despatch was broadside on on the shoals and was fast going to pieces. Her officers and crew were landed safely, and are now being cared for by the life-saving men.

Preparations have been making since Spring for a "Kunstlerfest," to be held Dec. 3 at Music Hall, a festival similar in character to those arranged under the direction of the Artist Guild at Dusseldorf, Berlin, Rome, Venice, and other centres of art.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The October report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture relates to yields per acre of grain and condition of corn, potatoes, buckwheat, and tobacco. The estimated average yields are: Wheat, 15 bushels; oats, 29.3; barley, 25.8; rye, 14.4. The condition of the corn crop is 92.5; buckwheat, 92.7; potatoes, 91.3; tobacco, 93.8.

Professional play writers, play actors, and play goers formed a large part of the audience at the Star Theatre last night. It was "author's night" and the last performance of Mr. Roland Reed and his company in "The Club Friend." After the third act the players were called before the curtain. They passed in review before the spectators, Mr. Reed bringing up the rear.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- The dramatic event of the week was the engagement of Sarah Bernhardt at McVicker's Theatre. The season opened to a fair business, the house the first night being only comfortably filled with a distinguished audience. Upon Bernhardt's first appearance on the stage in "La Tosca" she was cordially, but not enthusiastically, welcomed, and it was not until the third sot that the audience warmed up.

The Brooklyn Democrats last night chose David A. Boody as their candidate for Mayor. It had been a great day for conventions in that city. In the afternoon, nominees for county offices were made, but it was the evening convention that interest was centred in as the standard bearer for Mayor was to be nominated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Mr. McKinley's agents are making a frantic effort to swell their corruption fund for this Fall's campaign by pressing the Government clerks, but, thanks to the security they feel in the civil service law and the popular sentiment, stronger than even the law itself, very few of the clerks are being frightened by the stand-and-deliver demands that are being made upon them.

The Wool and Cotton Reporter, published in Boston, refuses to procure its news about the carpet trade from the editorial columns of McKinley newspapers in that city, but goes to the manufacturers themselves. It says:
BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- The promises made by the projectors of the Food and Health Show but feebly indicated the magnitude of their fulfillment. It is the prize show up to date.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- After a long recess the Bundesrath, or legislative body representing the individual States of Germany, reassembled Wednesday. The House considered, as the first order of the day, the projected law to repress drunkenness, which, as is well known, is a pet measure of the Emperor. The fact that the initiative proposals came from the Emperor failed to commend the bill to the Bundesrath.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Wallace Vail, a Plainfield real estate broker, nearly lost his life in a singular manner at Elysium Lake, near Evona this afternoon. Contractors Dowd Rice are using a great deal of dynamite in blasting to make improvements, and Mr. Vail ventured to do some experimenting himself by touching off an old tree stump with some of the explosive.

Our high-tariff contemporaries have ceased to commend Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS of St. Louis and to advertise his business. At the beginning of the strike at his factory, when he asked the Treasury Department for permission to import workmen under contract, the McKinley press came to his defense and argued that the desired permission should be granted.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- About 2,500 spectators, including Gov. Hill and several other distinguished persons, saw the Yale-Williams football game to-day on the Ridgefield grounds. The battle was exciting, though one-sided. Yale was superior in weigh and strength, and vastly too much for Williams in the line. Heffeltinger and his big comrades were pluckily resisted, but they were usually down on the Williams backs before the latter could get a start.

" Thermidor" has been the one new play of the week. As good a play would be welcome every week. Perhaps, however, "Thermidor" is not quite as brisk and effective in action as it might have been if Sardou had finished it when he began it twenty years ago. The lingering reflectiveness of his mature years sometimes counteracts the effect of the fervor and vigor and directness of his youth.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The faction fight in the Republican Party between S.D. Coykendall and George H. Sharpe broke out in the Ulster County Republican Convention held here to-day. The strife came on the organization of the convention.

Two matters of general interest to amateur oarsmen came up last night at the meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at the Gilsey House. One was in regard to Fred Hawkins of the Manhattan Athletic Club, whose entry was rejected at the annual regatta at Washington in August, and the other was in regard to college crews at the regattas of the association.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 11. -- A monument was dedicated to-day in Bellefontaine Cemetery to mark the last resting place of all worthy members of St. Louis Lodge, No. 9, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, who desire to sleep their last sleep there.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Domestic infelicity caused Mrs. Alvin Delong of this city to shoot her husband about midnight Saturday night, instantly killing him. One of the bullets entered his left arm and the other his heart.

When we called attention to the connection of Congressman-elect WADSWORTH with the violation of the law against soliciting political contributions we had hoped that that gentleman would make some sort of explanation of his course. He has not, so far as we are aware, seen fit to do so.

This week sees the close of the racing season in this State this year, there being racing for three days at Jerome Park, with a wind-up on Thursday at Morris Park, on which day the White Plains Handicap, for two-year-olds, with a gross value of $10,000, and the Pelham Bay Handicap, for three-year-olds, at a mile and a quarter, will be run.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- If the programme arranged by the Republican bosses in their desperation is carried out, the evidence brought before the legislative committee appointed to investigate the offices of the State Treasurer and Auditor General will not be produced at to-morrow's meeting of that committee at the Continental Hotel.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 11. -- The ships of the squadron of evolution, consisting of the Chicago, Newark, and Vesuvius, went to Block Island Sound Friday for target practice. The Vesuvius towed Relief No. 17, an old lightship. Just off Montauk Point the lightship was anchored and a rightangled triangle formed, with the lightship at the apex and a boat anchored at each of the other angles.

It is useless for the promoters of missionary enterprises in China to contend that no cause exists for the aversion in which they are held by the native community. Those who affirm that the prevailing distrust of foreign religious teachers is without justification or excuse are blind to the plainest facts of history.

The testimony thus far taken at Annapolis illustrates the curious yet not unintelligible notions of honor current in hazing affairs. The cadet who was pressed between a pair of mattresses in order to present with his protruding head what might embody to his persecutors their idea of a human turtle has shown reluctance to implicate them.

We have heretofore noticed the attempts of certain prominent McKinley papers to convince their readers that the increased cost of goods which is due to an increase of tariff duties will be paid cheerfully by manufacturers and wholesale dealers, and that these manufacturers and merchants will not ask individual consumers for a cent of it.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The Neptune Township Democrats met yesterday and elected delegates to the Second Assembly District Convention, which will be held to-morrow at Matawan. The township is made up of the towns of Asbury Park, Ocean Grove, Interlaken, Avon, West Asbury Park, and West Ocean Grove. The Abbett faction locked horns with the Blodgett followers, and the township will send two sets of delegates to Matawan.

The Irishmen in Ireland seem bound to surprise every one, friend and foe in turn. On Saturday the English public was shocked at the threats of violence, and the incitements to it, by some of Mr. PARNELL'S friends on the occasion of his funeral. Yesterday the Government had taken great precautions to preserve order, and was prepared for a bloody riot.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Dispatches received from Keeper J.S. Tracy of the Assateague Life-Saving Station state that the wrecked vessel is full of water and fast breaking up.

William H. Davis, a member of the firm of Frederick W. Davis Co., iron manufacturers in Rutledge Street, Brooklyn, was drowned yesterday in the East River, being thrown overboard from the steam launch Nyack by a sudden lurch of the boat. Mr. Davis was twenty-eight years old and unmarried. He lived with his brother at 80 Penn Street, Brooklyn.

The Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue, near Fourteenth Street, was opened again yesterday after having been closed for three months to undergo a thorough renovation inside and out. The long vacation caused no falling off in the congregation, as the auditorium morning and evening was crowded and the attendance at Sunday school was as large as usual.

The Christian Inquirer, one of the leading Baptist newspapers of the country, says: "The uppermost question in society is that which relates to the destruction of the huge octopus, the saloon. Attention is turned to it just now with new interest, because the Republican party has given up its abortive attempt to handle it.

BOSTON, Oct. 11. -- The Prohibition State Committee has issued an open letter to the Hon. Henry Cabot Lodge, in which it, challenges him to a joint debate on the temperance plank of the Republican platform and Mr. Lodge's statement that the Republican Party stands ready to improve, strengthen, and enforce the temperance laws.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- To-morrow closes the most exciting municipal campaign Newark has witnessed in many years. Tuesday the struggle between the people and the bosses will culminate at the polls. An honest expression of the popular preference would defeat Haynes, the bosses' candidate for Mayor, by 5,000 or 6,000 votes.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The National League of Great Britain has issued the following manifesto:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- In connection with Secretary Tracy's recent declaration in favor of building half a dozen 1,000-ton gunboats for service on foreign stations, his remarks on this subject in his annual report for 1889 will be of interest. The Secretary then said:

Up on the west side, near the junction of Seventh and St. Nicholas Avenues, there is an apartment house in which a dozen small families are comfortably domiciled. A short distance away a general provision store is kept by an industrious German, who counts among his best patrons the families in the aforementioned apartment house.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11. -- Aside from the party issues in Ohio this Fall there are two important constitutional questions to come before the people which have almost been lost sight of in the discussions of the tariff and currency.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Because of a bitter factional fight in the Second Assembly District a remarkable convention is now in progress. According to the call, the delegates from the Second, Fifth, Seventh, and Eighth Wards of Trenton convened on Friday evening to nominate a candidate. They remained in session all Friday night trying to agree on a Chairman.

Dr. Schliemann's rule was to acquaint the world with his discoveries as soon as they were made. This was in certain respects an excellent plan, for it served to keep alive the public interest in his labors. It had the drawback, however, that he was continually compelled in his later publications to modify or contradict opinions set forth in his earlier ones.

James Hagerty, a stableman and undertaker at 156 East One Hundred and Fifth Street, has sworn out warrants against Marshal Edward P. Holahan and Deputy Marshal John B. Mulvihill, charging them with grand larceny. Last week these officers, with their assistants, went to Hagerty's stables and by force removed a couple of hearses to satisfy a mortgage.

DUBLIN, Oct. 11. -- The funeral train bearing the body of Charles Stewart Parnell reached Holyhead about 2 o'clock this morning, and the coffin was transferred to the channel steamer Ireland. The journey thence to Kingstown was made in a gale of wind and a heavy rainstorm. The coffin, in an inclosure specially arranged for it, was guarded by the committee of Parnellites.

Ex-President Cleveland presided at the great Democratic meeting in New-York City last night, and made a strong and earnest speech in which he set forth, with his usual clearness, the issues dividing the two great parties, and urged the importance of continuing aggressive work to confirm and extend the advantage gained in last Fall's elections.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- Miss Eastlake, the popular English actress, who was for many years the leading lady in Wilson Barrett's company, and who recently started on a starring tour in this country, was left at the Walnut Street Theatre last night without a cent to pay the salaries of her company. The management of the theatre attached all the box-office receipts and the scenery, which belonged to Miss Eastlake.

Boston, blissful in the possession of her bifold championship in baseball, might excusably leave to Philadelphia the task of showing what America can do at cricket. However, she is to try her fortune to-day against Lord HAWKE'S team, and perhaps will improve on New-York and Baltimore. The matches of English visitors in Boston hitherto have been rather notable for low scoring on both sides.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Discount was not in demand the past week. Quotations were: Three months, 3 short, 1 34. The abundance of money, increased by the release of quarterly dividends, delays an advance of the Bank of England rate, but the ebbing away of gold to America and the Continent may necessitate a rise any day, and, under the best circumstances, it cannot be long delayed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Secretary of War has received the report of the Board of Visitors to the Military Academy of West Point, through Major John M. Carson of this city, a member of the board and its Secretary, by whom the document was prepared. It is very elaborate and comprehensive, covering upward of 100 printed pages.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11. -- The national convention of master brewers of the United States opens in Druids Hall to-morrow morning for a three days' session. An attendance is expected of about 300 delegates. New-York will send 40 delegates; Philadelphia and Boston about the same; Detroit, 20; Cincinnati, 25, and Chicago 70.

While certain high-tariff journals in California are complaining that the English owners of the Temescal tin mine are choking off the production of the metal and are not adding anything to the seventeen tons, more or less, which were produced three or four months ago, it has been reserved for the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette to make the remarkable discovery that one of the products of this mine is tin plate.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The family event which has detained the Hon. Roswell P. Flower in Watertown for some time past took place early this morning, when his only daughter, Mrs. J.B. Taylor, gave birth to a son. The baby weighs ten and a quarter pounds.

BOSTON, Oct. 11. -- To-day the Rev. Dr. Phillips Brooks preached his last sermon as a simple minister; on Wednesday he will be consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Massachusetts. Probably it was the knowledge of this fact which drew such an extremely large congregation to Trinity Church. At the morning service all the available standing room was occupied.

Judge Henry W. Allen, who was stricken with apoplexy Saturday and taken to the Chambers Street Hospital, was better last night than he had been in the morning. The fact that he held his own for so long after such a severe stroke was said by his physicians to be a favorable indication. Notice was sent to his friends, however, at 1 o'clock in the afternoon that his condition was critical.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton returned to his pulpit at All Souls' Church yesterday. The congregation that greeted him filled the church. His sermon hinged on the consecration of Phillips Brooks as a Bishop. He said that the consecration of the foremost man in the American Church to the highest office in the Church, after an opposition unparalleled in tone and temper, naturally focalized thought upon the subject of that office.

Levi M. Bates of 254 Madison Avenue was drowned in Bowery Bay Saturday afternoon. With his son, George B. Bates, he had started in a rowboat from Port Morris about 4 o'clock and had passed Riker's Island. The sea was smooth. They had one pair of oars, each pulling one, and when near Bowery Bay, Mr. Bates suggested to his son that they change seats.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 11. -- The seven members of the secret assassination society known as "The Honest Men's Friend and Protector," who were on trial all the past week in the United States District Court, were acquitted last night. The verdict created surprise, not only in the courtroom, but throughout the community.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Superintendent J.S. Drake, Master Carbuilder L.B. Van Wagoner, and Roadmaster Laurence Doyle, the three managing officials of the New-Jersey and New-York Railroad, were placed under arrest at 2:30 o'clock this morning upon a charge of violating the Sabbath day. The complainant is J.B, Veldan, a sawmill owner at Oradel, Bergen County.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Jews of Russia called Nicholas "the Second Haman." They could think of nothing more opprobrious. The Book of Esther was, and still is, by far the most familiar of their sacred writings. Scrolls containing it, and ornamented by marginal pictures of gibbets and hangmen, are everywhere to be found among them.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- The street pavements of Philadelphia, composed principally of the antiquated, hideous, and uncomfortable cobblestone, are beyond a doubt worse than those of any other large city in the world, exciting the derision of visitors and the mortification of the natives.

These are very expensive times for the policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company. Thousands of dollars of their money are being spent by President Beers to suppress the growing revolt against his notorious mismanagement, and every means that the cunning of his agents can suggest is resorted to in the effort to secure new business in the face of immense difficulties.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 11. -- The steam barge Susan E. Peck passed here down bound at 9:15 yesterday morning loaded with 60,000 bushels of wheat from Duluth to Buffalo. When passing through St. George Flats, at the elbow, near the Can Buoy, she came into collision with the schooner George W. Adams, up bound, in tow of the steam barge Aurora.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11. -- There are surface indications calculated to lead to the impression that the real contest in Ohio is for the Legislature, although the tariff and the free coinage of silver are the issues before the people. There are but three weeks more of work on the stump, and it seems quite likely that fully one-half of the voters of the State have decided what party they will cast their lot with.

The Board of Health in Philadelphia has begun an inquiry concerning the sale of the milk of consumptive cows in that city. It appears that this action was suggested by the report of the investigation made by a committee which was instructed by the Veterinary Department of the University of Pennsylvania to test the value of KOCH'S tuberculin by experiments in which cows should be the subjects.

BANGOR, Me., Oct. 11. -- John Towne and Frederick Hubbard of the Berlin (Conn.) Bridge Company, Charles Whipple, Frank Richmond, W.H. Sargent, H.F. Clement, and William F. Bellows of Springfield, Mass., and F. Howard of Pittsfield, Mass, left here this morning for a deer hunt on Union River waters. They form a part of a club of forty-three Western Massachusetts men who hunt in Maine annually.

When Congress meets in December one of its first duties should be to investigate the colossal mismanagement of the census by Robert P. Porter. The Civil Service Reform League has shown how partisan considerations determined the selection of many of the enumerators and subordinates, and the flagrant injustice done New-York in the count has been proved; but these are really minor matters compared with the disappearance of $8,000,000, with very little to show for it.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Jacob H. Myers was nominated to-day by the Democratic Senatorial Committee of the Twenty-ninth District for Senator to succeed Donald McNaughton. Mr. Myers is the inventor of the American ballot machine, an attempt to introduce which into general use in this State has already been made.

The initial indoor athletic championship games of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union will be held at Madison Square Garden Saturday evening, Jan. 23, 1892. The Games Committee selected by the delegates of the association at its last meeting includes A. Peverelly of the Williamsburg Athletic Club, Chairman; C.C. Hughes of the Manhattan Athletic Club, and Harry Dimse of the Bank Clerks' Athletic Association.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 12. -- The annual convention of Democratic clubs of the State has been held at Spokane, and the organizers from the East, ex-Gov. Chauncey F. Black of Pennsylvania, James M. Beck of Philadelphia, Senator C.J. Faulkner of West Virginia, and Congressman William D. Bynum of Indiana, have made their tour of the State.

The Yorktown is at last on her way to Chile, and it appears that the Boston is soon to follow her, while the Petrel is getting ready for China and the Atlantic will probably be sent to some foreign station. Thus there will be not a little scattering of the modern steel cruisers that have been so long collected in this neighborhood.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Discord and bitter factional fights, which characterized the Democratic Convention in the First and Third Assembly Districts of Monmouth County, were thrown aside at the Second Assembly District Convention held at Matawan this afternoon. The smoke of the battles from the First and Third District Conventions was visible early in the fray to-day, but it was quickly dispelled and harmony reigned supreme.

The Cleveland Leader speaks of "the erroneous idea that the consumer pays the duty on imported goods." This newspaper, which is the ablest and most industrious of the organs of McKinleyism in Ohio, and which directly represents the opinions of Mr. MCKINLEY himself, admits that the price of Ohio wool to those who buy it in this country is increased by the amount of the duty on similar wool that is imported.

About thirty-five members attended the twentieth annual meeting of the American Society of Railroad Superintendents at the Hotel Brunswick in this city yesterday. The session continued through the greater part of the day, and was interesting from a technical standpoint. The President of the society, Mr. H. Stanley Goodwin of the Lehigh Valley Road, presided.

Whatever may be the course which the Federal officers on the Republican State Committee may feel it proper or safe to follow as to soliciting political contributions, we wish to make it perfectly plain to every one in the United States service that he is protected by law from any injury whatever consequent on his refusal to respond to such solicitation.

Coroner Messemer investigated yesterday the circumstances attending the deaths of Annie Murphy, John Touhey, Josephine Ryan, and Kate Dunn, who perished in the fire at Dominick and Hudson Streets last week. The stories of incendiarism and a mistake in the reading of the alarm by the men of Hook and Ladder No. 8 were refuted by ample testimony, and the jury, in giving a verdict of accidental death, praised the firemen.

It is not generally known, apparently, that the law of the State of New-York absolutely prohibits the solicitation of political assessments or contributions from all persons in the service of the State, or of any political division thereof, subject to the Civil Service act. In this regard the State law is much more severe than the Federal law.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 12. -- Seven miles below Rio Grande City, Texas, and on the opposite side of the river, the body of a nephew of Julian Flores, a suspected revolutionist, swings from a tree, with nineteen bullet holes in it. The man was arrested several days ago, and left for Victoria under a guard of soldiers. No one is bold enough to cut the body down.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- Worthless checks have reached this city purporting to have been signed by E.V.R. Thayer of Boston, payable to C.W. Page of New-York and indorsed by Page. Mr. Thayer has had no dealings with any such person, and his name is forged. Tiffany Co. appear to have cashed one for $300 and Knox Brothers one for $50.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- Lord Hawke and the English cricketers began their match this morning against the Boston Athletic Association team, the play taking place on the grounds of the Longwood Cricket Club. The weather was raw and cold, with a strong northwest wind, rendering high scores difficult.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 12. -- Soon after 8 o'clock this morning John Duffy, a well-known sporting man, committed suicide at the clubrooms 136 Common Street by shooting himself in the mouth with a revolver. He had been drinking heavily for about three weeks. Duffy entered the club soon after dark last evening and talked as usual with friends and acquaintances until a late hour, when he lay down on a lounge and slept until this morning.

QUEBEC, Oct. 12. -- The historic old sloop of war Alert came near depositing her bones today on that "graveyard of vessels," Anticosti. She was dispatched several days ago, with supplies for lighthouses, down the Gulf, but one of her crew having been seriously injured in an accident, she had to put in to Gaspe to land him.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 12. -- The Union Pacific to-day began forcible evictions and destruction of dwellings on its right of ways on the levees in Kansas City, Kan. The evicted families are "squatters" on the Union Pacific lands at the point and have lived there for years unmolested.

If the funeral of PARNELL had been made the occasion of a riotous and vindictive demonstration against the majority of the Irish members of Parliament, the results of such a demonstration upon the Irish cause would have been considerable and calamitous. It seemed entirely feasible for factionists to instigate a riot, and this was perhaps the main reason why a riot was expected.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- The legislative committee which has been investigating the relations existing between the convict ex-City Treasurer and State Treasurer Boyer and Auditor General McCamant met this morning in the sample room of the Continental Hotel to hear the Attorney General ask the newspaper proprietors of Philadelphia how much commissions they have been paying for the Mercantile Appraisers' advertising, and to whom they paid the money.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 12. -- The nine city banks of this city have agreed to form a trust, and hereafter a maximum rate of 2 per cent. interest is to be paid on city funds. The City Council has accepted the proposition, and will divide the funds proportionately among the banks according to the capital of each institution.

The critical examination to which President William H. Beers of the New-York Life was subjected by the Assembly Committee on Insurance in 1877 is troubling that gentleman not a little in these days. Hardly had his testimony on that occasion been put into type when the whole insurance community began to cry out "Perjury!" and the cry has been maintained throughout the intervening years with undiminished force.

HARTFORD, Oct. 12. -- The annual meeting of the State Board of Equalization required by the General Statutes was held here to-day, and was used to emphasize the Democratic determination not to co-operate with the Republican "hold-overs." The board consists of the Controller and State Treasurer, and is charged, among other duties, with regulating the State tax on corporations transacting business in Connecticut.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Advices from various points in Russia state that great numbers of peasants are flocking into the towns from the country districts, perishing from the want of food. At least 55,000 have passed through Tuinien alone, seeking food. Many are falling by the roadsides and dying in their tracks. The wanderers have no fuel and the cold is intense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- From some quarter, unknown here by those most interested, a dispatch, dated in this city and setting forth that the United States had reached an agreement with Germany, by which, in consideration of our continued free admission of German sugars, the German Empire would admit free the cereals from the United States, was to-day printed in New-York.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Oct. 12. -- The fast westbound express on the Central Pacific, which passed Colfax early this morning on its way to this city, was wrecked about midway between New-England Mills and Colfax. The train passed through a deep cut and out on to an embankment, which had been thrown up to preserve the grade. Engineer Estabrook did not detect anything wrong until the first two cars were derailed.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 12. -- A fair conducted by the Independent Order of Railway Conductors opened to-night in the Second Regiment Armory, and is to continue a week. An exhibition of modern railway appliances is a feature of the fair, which is expected to attract railroad managers from all over the country.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Mr. Parnell's Parliamentary colleagues have issued the following manifesto:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 12. -- It was long after 10 o'clock, the hour set for the beginning of business, when the Hon. R.B. Hayes, President of the association, called the National Prison Congress to order this morning for the third day's session. Judge Francis Wayland made an address on "How Shall the Children of Vicious or Cruel Parents be Prevented from Becoming Criminals?"

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The affidavit of Roger B. Towner, a former resident of this city, now in Brooklyn, published in some of the Sunday papers, has caused much indignation among Mr. Flower's friends in Jefferson County. Republicans and Democrats alike join in condemning the Republican Campaign Committee for having anything to do with a man who was driven out of Watertown years ago because the town was too good for him.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- The British schooner Daphne of St. John, N.B., Capt. Givan, with a cargo of lime, grounded on Devil's Back Ledge, Broad Sound, Boston Harbor, at 2 o'clock this morning, but subsequently came off and sank in deep water.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 12. -- A curious will case will come up at the next Assizes at Cornwall, near here. About six months ago a rich contractor and ex-member of Parliament named Patrick Purcell died worth about $1,000,000. Shortly after, his body was stolen from the churchyard and has never been recovered. The deceased, who was an uneducated man, left two wills and managed to bungle them up pretty well.

We greatly regret that District Attorney MITCHELL has been prevented by an accident to his person from giving attention to the law violated by Messrs. VAN COTT, HENDRICKS, and other Federal officers relating to political assessments. We beg to suggest to him that the law is so very plain and the principle involved is so very important that he might with propriety instruct a suitable deputy to take the matter in hand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The fifth day of the Ecumenical Methodist Council opened with Bishop J.W. Hood of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, Fayetteville, N.C., in the chair. Bishop Gaines of the African Methodist Episcopal Church delivered the prayer, and the Rev. Dr. C.H. Phillips of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of Washington read the Scriptures, so that the opening services of the great council were conducted by three colored men.

READING, Penn., Oct. 12. -- Aetonlshing reports of the Fail snake crop are oomin~ in daily from divers points along the Schuylkill Valley. William Reeser of this city, while riding horseback to Lebanon the other day, encountered a big black snakeln the middle of the road. The reptile Jumped at the horse, and, quick as thought, wound itself around the animal's left foreleg, causing him to rear and pitch frantically.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Secretary Tracy and Commodore Folger, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, left this afternoon for Bethlehem, Penn., where they will witness to-morrow, in the shops of the Bethlehem Iron Works, the forging of the tube for the first of the thirteen-inch guns for the new battle ships. This forging will be the largest piece of steel ever forged in America.

HELENA, Mon., Oct. 12. -- The female highway robber arrested here Friday while attempting to leave town in man's attire proves to be a nervy young woman. She is also a versatile prevaricator. Her name has been discovered from letters in her possession. Instead of being Bertie Miller, she is Helen Forstund, and her parents live not far from Spokane Falls, Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Brig. Gen. A.V. Kautz, commanding the Department of the Columbia, makes, in his annual report, some recommendations about the army. He will retire from active service in a few months, and gives that as an excuse for offering what he considers "the most valuable suggestions" that his "long service in the line of the army, which began forty-five years ago in the grade of private, can furnish."

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The cattle steamer Wells City, (British,) Capt. Gore, from New-York, Sept. 26, which arrived at Bristol, Oct. 11, encountered gales on the Atlantic which continued from Oct. 1 to Oct. 9. During this time heavy seas washed the vessel, damaging some of the cattle pens, and a number of oxen were so badly injured that it became necessary to kill them.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 12. -- Gov. Pattison to-night issued a proclamation calling upon the Senate, which will meet in extra session to-morrow for the purpose of inquiring whether "reasonable cause" exists for the removal of Auditor General McCamant and State Treasurer Boyer, to also consider whether there is cause for the removal of the magistrates and constables of Philadelphia.

Four women were injured yesterday in a fire which destroyed the rag storage and cutting warehouse of J.W. Lyons Co., 832 and 834 Kent Avenue, near Park Avenue, Brooklyn. The building was three stories high, of brick, with a frontage of 50 feet on Kent Avenue and a depth of 100 feet. It was composed of several buildings thrown together, and there was but one stairway.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Seneca County Republican County Convention was held today at Seneca Falls. J.B. Mangin was appointed temporary Chairman. After the report of the Committee on Credentials the Patterson branch withdrew from the convention. The Sweet-Mangin faction nominated W.T. Seymour of Seneca Falls for member of Assembly, Augustus McIntyre of Lodi for Sheriff, and Charles Marshall of Fayette for Justice of Sessions.

Tammany put the above ticket in the field last night. There are no surprises in it: the convention moved along precisely in the grooves laid down for it by the Committee of Twenty-four. All the Judges nominated last night are now filling vacancies by the appointment of the Governor. Coroner Hanly was the only man left off the ticket, and John B. Shea was put on in his place for Henry D. Furroy.
I feel that THE TIMES is deserving of the thanks of the insuring public for the masterly and persistent exposure of the practices of the managers of the New-York Life Insurance Company.

Henry Sanford of Bridgeport, Conn., who for thirty-five years has been an active member of the Adams Express Company, was yesterday elected its President to fill the vacancy caused by the dismissal of John Hoey. Frederick Lovejoy of this city, formerly Superintendent of the Pennsylvania division of the company, and more recently President of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, was elected Vice President in the place of Clapp Spooner of Bridgeport, resigned.

The tower of the Madison Square Garden was finished yesterday. For over a year it had been slowly roaring its head above the roofs of the city, attracting attention from far and near by reason of its size and fine proportions, and of late a powerful search light at its foot has served to direct almost universal attention to it by night.

The condition and prospects of the tin mine of the San Jacinto Company at Temescal, Cal., have recently become the subject of controversy. We have sought to discover the truth about the rate of production and the purposes of the managers. In July last there were published in San Francisco "inspired" predictions that the mine would soon be yielding block tin at the rate of 2,500 or 3,000 tons per annum.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 13. -- The school enumeration, which is now in progress in this State, will show a total, in round numbers, of 163,250 children between the ages of four and sixteen years, the annual increase having averaged 2,000 for several years past. The income of the school fund for the State fiscal year ending June 30, 1891, was $127,111.04.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The Newark Mayoralty contest is over, and Haynes, the ring candidate, has been elected by a small majority, but at midnight the figures could not be obtained. The struggle was a fierce one, and W. Lehlbach, the Republican candidate, made a good fight. Bribery was undoubtedly resorted to by the corrupt Democratic ring.

Time and the paid-for laudation of William H. Beers are marching on. Day before yesterday THE TIMES asserted that over $40,000 had been expended by the New-York Life Insurance Company for such good words from newspapers, a part of the sum having been sent to a single foreign agency to be used in offsetting criticism and securing new and laudatory articles.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- In the Second Assembly District, to-night, the Democrats nominated John Johnson. He was formerly Postmaster, was promised the appointment as Keeper of the State Prison by Gov. Abbett, who did not keep his promise, and is now Clerk of the District Court of this city. He is a pronounced anti-Abbet man.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The Presbytery of New-Brunswick late last night concluded the work on the revision as recommended by the General Assembly. The discussions and conclusions of this Presbytery are the most important of any of the subordinate ecclesiastical legislative bodies, because the entire Faculty of Princeton College, including ex-President McCosh and President Patton, are members of it.

The Farrow court-martial reconvened at the Army Building yesterday morning. The prosecution proceeded, showing Lieut. Farrow's connection with the Barnegat Park Company, and attempting to prove that such connection was incompatible with the position of an "officer and gentleman."

The Washington correspondent of the Brooklyn Eagle telegraphs that it is believed by those who have the best means of obtaining correct information that it is the purpose of the President to nominate Judge CHARLES L. BENEDICT to be Judge of the Circuit Court of Appeal, and to replace him in the District Judgeship by Mr. W.W. GOODRICH.
BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- Gov. Russell, in an interview with a representative of the Post on the silver question, said:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- J. Sloat Fassett and John W. Vrooman this afternoon addressed what was probably the largest political gathering ever held in the Binghamton Opera House. The meeting was to have been held in the Court House Park, but Mr. Fassett's physician forbade him to speak in the open air. Among other things, Mr. Fassett said:
LONDON, Oct. 13. -- A letter from Capt. O'Shea, written on the eve of the Parnell funeral, is just published here. In it he says:

The Richmond County Democratic Convention was held yesterday afternoon at Griffith's Hall, Port Richmond. There was a fight between the party leaders, who realized the necessity of nominating a clean representative Democratic ticket, and the supporters of Michael Cahill for Sheriff. The Chairman, District Attorney T.W. Fitzgerald, called the convention to order and made a strong appeal for harmony.

Ex-Supervisor George Green of the Twenty-second Ward, Brooklyn, who was arrested in Jamaica, L.I., at 2 o'clock Monday morning charged with attempted arson, was arraigned before Justice Hendrickson in the Town Hall, Jamaica, yesterday afternoon and was remanded until to-day, when the examination will be continued.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The high tide this evening cut the beach badly at Sea-bright. At this place the large pavilions of W.T. Streets and Dr. Knox were surrounded by water and both houses were washed away. The seas ran down all Atlantic and Arnold Avenues and the board walks are afloat. At Bayhead 300 feet of bulkhead and board walks were cut out and went to sea.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The residents of Sandford Avenue, an aristocratic new thoroughfare in the part of Plainfield known as Brookside, are up in arms against the private insane asylum that Dr. Justus H. Cooley has opened on the thoroughfare. The house which Dr. Cooley has appropriated to his purposes is one of the most prominent on the street.

A quiet but pretty wedding took place last evening at the Church of the Strangers, the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems officiating, when Lieut. James Wilkinson Clinton of Passaic, N.J., and Miss Grace Ethelind Warner of Stamford, Conn., were married. Lieut. Clinton is a great-grand-nephew of the first Continental Governor of New-York. Miss Warner is well known in society in this city, Stamford, Conn., and in London, where she spent a year.

There is practically no municipal election in this city this year. While the Republican leaders are trying to conduct the State canvass on an anti-Tammany basis, there is really no issue against Tammany in the city, where alone it is a power and where alone there is any ground for fighting against it.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- The cricket match between the Gentlemen of England and the Boston Athletic Association was resumed this morning on the Longwood Grounds at 11:25, the weather conditions being very much the same as on Monday, except that the temperature was a little higher. The attendance was very small.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The report of the Board of Visitors at the graduating exercises last June, which has just been made public, has excited some comment among army officers on duty at the Military Academy. The insufficiency of the present entrance examinations, to which the board refers, is generally acknowledged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Navy Department has ordered an exhaustive trial to be made of the Towne tubular boiler recently built for the ferryboat to be used at the Portsmouth Navy Yard. The trial will be made at that yard, and its purpose is to ascertain the relative value of the Towne boiler in comparison with the Thornycroft, Ward-Cowles, and other tubular boilers heretofore tested by the department.

This is the ticket presented last night by the County Democracy's County Convention, which was held in the Cooper Institute. It has one Republican, Mr. Isaacs, and one Tammany man, Mr. Pryor, upon it, and the rest are County Democrats. There was a large crowd in the hall, although there were many vacant seats. There were two drum corps in the front of the auditorium.

There has been considerable speculation since the death of the Hon. William L. Scott as to the provisions and instructions of his will. The will has no been filed at the Recorder's office, and it is understood to be the intention of the surviving members of the family not to offer it for probate, at least not for some time.

The committee appointed by the New-York Baseball Club to inquire into the charge of crookedness preferred by the officials of the Chicago team made its report at a meeting of the Board of Directors yesterday. The report exonerated the Giants from all blame, and the officers of the New-York, while they have failed to censure the Chicago officials for the groundless charges, are in a very angry mood.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Full particulars of the murder of John Whalen by William Coy have come to light this afternoon by the finding of the victim's body buried on a lonely mountain side one-eighth of a mile from Coy's house.

It is a comic illustration of the violence of party spirit in England that the first breach of harmony in the Methodist Ecumenical Council should have occurred over British politics. The delegates from the United States and other parts of the world must have looked on in wonderment to see a Methodist minister and a Methodist member of Parliament interchanging personalities that were unintelligible except to Britons.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The severe northeast wind and rain storm which has been raging for the past twenty-four hours has done considerable damage all along the New-Jersey coast, and particularly between Sandy Hook and Point Pleasant. For twelve hours the wind along the seaboard has blown from forty to fifty miles an hour and the sea has been unusually high and strong.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13. -- The fight between the two factions of the Republican Party in St. Louis grows fiercer every hour. There are now two city committees, one representing the Filley or anti-Administration faction and the other the "Silks," or that element of the party that supports Harrison.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The schooner Mary E. Oliver, Capt. Elmball, of and from Georgetown, Me., for New-York, sprang a leak while off Nauset, Cape Cod, at 5 P.M. on the 11th inst. during a northeast gale and high sea, and also broke her maintopmast. The water constantly gained on the vessel's pumps, but she was kept on her course, and anchored here about 1 o'clock this morning.

Samuel H. Willard, who for twenty-eight years previous to 1887 had been in the employ of the Holmes, Booth Hayden Company of Bridgeport, Conn., which has offices in Park Place, this city, was sued by the company to recover the amount of two promissory notes aggregating about $14,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Bishop R.H. Hargrove of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, Nashville, Tenn., preached at the opening of the sixth day's session of the Ecumenical Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Commodore Ramsay, Acting Secretary of the Navy, received a telegram this morning from Lieut. Wadeworth, Inspector Life-Saving Service, dated Assateague, saying that the Despatch is broken up forward of the engines. The upper works are washed off. Little material was coming ashore. The Yantic was off station Sunday night, but has not been seen since. There is thick weather, a heavy gale, and very high surf.

The city canvass in Brooklyn in opening in a spirited fashion, Mr. MEYER, the Republican candidate for Mayor, having introduced a wholly novel set of methods, the results of which are likely to be interesting, if not important. Mr. MEYER proposes to run his own campaign and on purely business principles.

Personal Summer experiences, a double variety apple and a box of dwarf chestnuts from North Carolina, were the chief features of an interesting meeting of the Terrey Botanical Club in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, last night. The members had come together for the first time since last Spring. President Addison Brown presided.

Secretary Whitehead of the Hudson County Jockey Club announces the following entries and the weights to be carried in the Initial Handicap, at a mile and an eighth, to be run on the opening day of the club's meeting, on Friday next:

The October meeting of the Fish Commissioners of this State was held yesterday. President Eugene G. Blackford occupied the chair, and the other Commissioners present were L.D. Huntington of New-Rochelle and Henry Burden of Troy. President Blackford announced that he had received reports that the waters of the Upper and Lower Saranac and Meacham Lakes had become infested with pickerel, which were killing off the lake trout.

DUBLIN, Oct. 13. -- The Freeman's Journal to-day bitterly deplores the announced intention of the members of Parliament who represent the Parnellite party to nurture the faction feud which has existed between themselves and party acknowledging Mr. Justin McCarthy as its leader. The Journal adds that should they continue in their determination "unending strife is in prospect if they place before the country the programme thus offered to it.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 13. -- To-night the members of the Grady Memorial Committee, with the Hon. Charles P. Northen, Chairman, left in a special Pullman car for New-York to escort Gov. Hill of that State to Georgia. On his arrival here at noon on Tuesday next the Governor will be received by a parade of the labor organizations of the city.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13. -- To-day's reports from Northern Minnesota and North Dakota as far west as the Missouri River are of the most discouraging character. It has been snowing and raining all over that section for eighteen hours, and not a wheel is turning among the thrashing machines. It is calculated here to-night that from 2,000,000 to 5,000,000 bushels of wheat will be utterly ruined.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- There was a large gathering in the Circuit Court here to-day, Judge Fursman presiding. The people were attracted by the announcement that James E. Ostrander and Matthew Trumpbour, the defaulting Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer of the Ulster Savings Institution, would be brought in.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 13. -- The unprecedented sight of an extra session of the Senate called to consider the grave question of the removal of prominent State officials, was witnessed by more than the usual number of spectators who gather at the opening of an ordinary session of the Legislature.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The eighty-second annual meeting of the American Board began here to-day. At 3 P.M. the Rev. Dr. Storrs, the President, announced that a quorum was present. He opened the meeting by Scripture reading and prayer, and the minutes of last year's meeting at Minneapolis were read. Dr. Jenkins, pastor of the First Congregational Church, in which the meetings are held, welcomed the gathering.

James O. Pandy, who crossed the ocean on La Bretagne on her last trip, told a curious story yesterday of the voyage that two ships finished just before he left Liverpool. The ships, the Lorton and the Cockermouth, left Liverpool Oct. 5, 1890, bound for Astoria, Oregon. Their voyage, of course, was by the Horn, and for 148 days the two ships kept together.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- A case on something of a parallel with the late French decoration scandal has just been concluded in this city. A pamphlet which recently appeared contained a charge against Herr Manche, the ex-Chief of the Civil Cabinet of Emperor William I., that he was accepting bribes for his services in return for procuring titles.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Elizabeth Darby, a trained nurse, twenty-one years of age, is locked up in the Delaware County Jail at Media, charged with a particularly heinous attempt at arson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14. -- A Shanghai letter says that a number of French officers and privates have been killed by the pirates in Hongkong. Hanoi advices state that a continuous warfare has been in progress between troops and large gangs of pirates. Capt. Simon, in charge of the Biendong station, started with 200 riflemen to take a fortified position north of Biendong.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- With services as solemn and impressive as have ever been witnessed in this city. Dr. Phillips Brooks, the rector of Trinity Church, was to-day made Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts.

Clarence A. Seward, Secretary of the Board of Managers of the Adams Express Company, was instructed yesterday to prepare the necessary papers in a suit to be brought against ex-President John Hoey and ex-Vice President Clapp Spooner to recover from them $195,000 and $172,333,33 respectively, these being the amounts paid to them in the deal with the New-England express companies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- C.F. Heinrichs of 43 Centre Street, New-York, was found dead in his room at a hotel in this city this morning, having committed suicide by the inhalation of chloroform. Heinrichs was an electrician, and it is supposed that despair over his inability to complete an electrical machine, a model of which was found in his room, was the cause of his last act.

From the arguments made by Harper's Weekly and those independents who have determined to vote for Mr. FASSETT because they hope through his election to secure ballot reform, a stranger to our recent legislative history would infer that we had no reform ballot act on our statute books, and that ballot reform as a whole and from the beginning was at stake in this election.

As reported, the result of the Newark election Tuesday is 199 plurality for Mayor HAYNES, who was elected two years ago by a majority of over 1,200. If the 273 Democrats who professed to be opposed to ring rule, but who persisted in voting for an "independent" candidate, had cast their votes for LEHLBACH, he would have been elected, and the power of the corrupt "bosses" would have been broken.

The local campaign in Brooklyn dragged a trifle yesterday, but the politicians were all interested in the order received by Sheriff Courtuey from Secretary of State Rice to amend his call for the election on Nov. 3 so as to include an election for Congress in the Second District, made vacant by the resignation of David A. Boody.

The last day's racing for the year at Jerome Park was that of yesterday, and there was a good crowd on hand to enjoy the sport, although it was not of the highest order, but was a regular "getaway day" programme. Yet, contrary to the rule on such days, there was a preponderance of favorites among the horses that put races to the credit of themselves and the bank accounts of their owners.

NEWARK, Oct. 14. -- The Republicans contemplate asking a recount of the vote by which Haynes was apparently re-elected to the Mayoralty yesterday. They have learned that in one or two of the precincts ballots bearing Lehlbach's name were thrown out, and they suspect other irregularities that may have helped to falsify the result.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The gale has subsided. The partial derangement of the telegraph lines retards to a great extent the collection of the full details of the storm's ravages. The losses of life and property, so far as is yet known, are comparatively small, when the extensive area and extreme violence of the hurricane are taken into consideration.

There is a very large number of persons in this country to whom the question whether the mile record will be broken this season is of even more interest than the question what disposition will be made of the charges against Dr. BRIGGS. To a considerable subdivision of this class the "kite-shaped track" at Stockton, Cal., is at present the most interesting place in the United States.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The sophomore class of the University of Rochester is under a cloud. This morning when the class entered Prof. Baker's algebra classroom, eight of the students were suspended for the remainder of the term. The suspended men left the room and seven others followed them. The reason for the suspension of the eight young men was told by one of them to-night as follows:

The Democrats of Kings County last evening gave a rousing ratification to the nominations made by their conventions for the coming elections, and cheered to the echo sentiments uttered by ex-President Grover Cleveland and other party leaders concerning the national issues to which they have pinned their faith. The meeting was held in the big Clermont Avenue Palace Rink. Full 5,000 people succeeded in gaining admission. Another thousand failed to.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- About 1,000 persons saw the Princeton football eleven defeat the Lehigh team this afternoon on the university grounds by the score of 30 to 0.

The new infantry and artillery drills adopted by the Navy Department are admirably suited to the nature of the service and to the character of the sailor. The evolutions of naval battalions and the execution of the manual of arms will lose something of their old precision and accuracy no doubt, but they will gain in directness.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 14. -- The Republicans had a demonstration here to-day and tonight. They began to prepare for it a month ago by advertising that it would be "ex-Governors' day." Having no real live Governor to talk to the people, they thought the next best thing was to get out the ex-Governors, but for some unknown reason the former Governors could not be lured from their retirement.

MAYPORT, Fla., Oct. 14. -- The private detective, S. Roebuck, arrived here nearly a week ago. He stopped at the Burrows House the first night, and after supper made known his business. He was told that one of the old residents, "Case" Norris, knew every inch of the country hereabouts, and was thoroughly acquainted with the beach from Mayport to St. Augustine.

Friends and relatives of the 600 passengers who had sailed last Saturday on the Anchor Line steamship City of Rome for Glasgow had an exciting time yesterday when dispatches were received from St. John's, reporting that the steamer had foundered with all on board off Cape St. Shotts, a dangerous point of the treacherous Newfoundland coast.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 14. -- It was the evident purpose of the leading Republican Senators last night to adjourn to-day until next Tuesday. A telegram to this effect went to Quay, and as late as noon to-day Senator Porter assured THE TIMES'S representative that this would be done. But matters assumed a new phase this afternoon.

The Fall quarterly conference of local Appraisers was held yesterday at the Appraiser's Stores. There were present besides Mr. Cooper, Appraiser of this port, Appraisers J.G. Leach of Philadelphia, C.L. Kimball of Detroit, James S. Burdsdall of Cincinnati, L.S. Metcalf of St. Louis, and Charles M. Leavy of San Francisco, and Assistant Appraiser Thomas H. Dunham of Boston.

The boisterous weather that has prevailed since the first of the month on the North Atlantic and the consequent delays of steamers have inclined the public to receive with credulity almost every story of marine disaster. A whole fleet of steamships westward bound are now crowded with returning Americans, and almost everybody has some acquaintance among these passengers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- The annual meeting of stockholders of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, operated under lease by the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, was held here this morning. The old Board of Directors was re-elected. President Whitehead, in his annual report, states that the earnings of the past year were very good, although showing a slight decrease.

The semi-annual meeting of the American Railway Association -- formerly the General Time Convention -- was held in the Hotel Brunswick yesterday. Nearly 300 members were present, representing almost all of the important railroads in the country. Col. H.S. Haines, the President of the association and Vice President of the Plant Investment Company of Florida, presided, and Mr. W.F. Allen, the Secretary, called the roll.

The Republican campaign has passed into the period of "conferences." Conferences are now, being held on the slightest provocation at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, not only in Mr. Platt's committee's headquarters, but in Oliver Sumner Teall's headquarters, which adjoin Mr. Platt's, and which are labeled "Republican Estate Committee, City Department," in very large letters.

The resolution on the silver question adopted yesterday by the Board of Trade and Transportation on the motion of Mr. OSCAR S. STRAUS undoubtedly represents the views of the business men of the country who have any views on the subject. It declares the board "opposed to any legislation providing for the coinage of any dollar which is not of the identical and full value of every other dollar coined or issued by the Government."

There has not in a long time been submitted to the American public a document more encouraging to the believers in popular government than the message in which Gov. PATTISON of Pennsylvania lays before the Senate of that State the facts on which he invites them to pass judgment as to the conduct of the Auditor and State Treasurer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- To dam Niagara has been considered one of the things which human skill could not accomplish, yet such is the means which Capt. J.S. Dunham, a well-known vessel man, would employ to procure deeper waterways on the great lakes.

Major Charles B. Throckmorton, Second Artillery, was relieved of command of Fort Schuyler on Tuesday by order of Major Gen. Howard, and was placed under arrest pending the investigation of charges preferred against him by Col. Robert P. Hughes, Inspector General of the Division of the Atlantic, and by Col. Rodney Smith, Assistant Paymaster General and Chief Paymaster of the Division of the Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- The Commandery in Chief of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States began its annual session here this afternoon. In the absence of the Commander in Chief of the order, ex-President Rutherford B. Hayes, Gen. Orlando M. Poe, United States Army, presided. The meeting of the Commandery was an executive one.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- The Commandery in Chief of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States began its annual session here this afternoon. In the absence of the Commander in Chief of the order, ex-President Rutherford B. Hayes, Gen. Orlando M. Poe, United States Army, presided. The meeting of the Commandery was an executive one.

The great attendance at the Democratic ratification meeting in the Clermont Avenue Rink last night will discourage the managers of Mr. FASSETT'S canvass more than they will be willing to confess. They have cherished some hopes, now shown to be delusive, that the Democracy of Kings County would give the Saratoga nominees only a perfunctory and lukewarm support.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct 14. -- C.T. Lee of the University of Pennsylvania defeated L.R. Parker, the Yale player, in the intercollegiate tennis tournament which began here to-day. Parker played his prettiest in the second set, but Lee won the deciding set and the match on steady play and particularly good "lobbing."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Stagg's football players from the School of Christian Workers, Springfield, Mass., played a stubbornly-contested game at the Yale field this afternoon. Stagg's eleven repeatedly broke through the Yale centre, and had the bal within two yards of the Yale goal when time was called in the last half.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Rev. J.D. Murray of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Baltimore, presided over the Ecumenical Methodist Council at the beginning of the seventh day's session. After the usual devotional exercises Secretary King, from the Business Committee, reported favorably the resolution concerning the extension of friendly greetings to the Pan-Presbyterian Council to meet at Toronto, September, 1892, and it was adopted.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- It has been a source of wonder and dismay to many Republicans in this State and at Washington that at the last election of Congressman this district was lost to the Republicans, although Charles S. Baker had carried the district twice by something like 5,000 majority, once defeating the very man who has now been elected on the Democratic ticket.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct 14. -- The political campaign is being waged with more than usual vigor in Northern Ohio this week. Saturday night three meetings, addressed respectively by Roger Q. Mills, ex-Gov. Foraker, and Congressman Jerry Simpson, were held in this city. Beginning Monday afternoon, Major McKinley has been canvassing the Western Reserve, following Gov. Campbell's Northeastern Ohio tour, but speaking at a number of smaller places the Governor had not time to reach.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The meeting of the American Board this morning was called to order by Vice President Blashford. The Rev. Dr. Cobb of New-York read the report of the committee on the paper of Dr. Alden, the Home Secretary, emphasizing the great increase in the number of men offering themselves for service and commending warmly the present management of the Home Department. (which has heretofore been the bone of contention.)

It is quite incomprehensible how Mr. BLAINE can have "improved rapidly in health" during his visit to his old home at Augusta. According to the Blaine papers he has not been ill at any time this Summer. He was well when he came to this city last Spring, well when he went to Bar Harbor, and he has been in capital health and spirits all Summer long.

When the court-martial which is considering the case of Lieut. Farrow met yesterday, the prosecution was resumed, with George W. Wingate on the witness stand. Mr. Wingate is a lawyer, and as such had notes of the Barnegat Park Company placed in his hands for collection by the People's Trust Company. There were five notes in the bunch, and Mr. Wingate described his meeting with Lieut. Farrow and the conversation they had about the notes.

On Wednesday and Thursday Herr Josef Kainz appeared at the Amberg Theatre in the title role of Schiller's romantic and historical play, "Don Carlos, Heir Apparent of Spain." The houses were large; applause was frantic; the German press of this city breaks into eulogy of Herr Kainz and hails him an actor of the first rank.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Senator Calvin S. Brice of the National Committee spent the entire day in close consultation with Col. Neal, Chairman of the Democratic State Campaign Committee. The entire State was gone over, county by country, and each of the Senatorial districts in which there was a fighting chance to win was carefully scrutinized.

A general court-martial is appointed to meet at the military prison, Fort Leavenworth. Kan., Oct. 20, 1891, for the trial of such prisoners as may be brought before it. The detail for the court is: Capts. Francis E. Lacey. Tenth Infantry, and David J. Craigie, Twelfth Infantry; First Lieuts. Frederick Von Schrader, Twelfth Infantry; Charles W. Mason, Fourth Infantry; James B. Jackson. Seventh Infantry, and John F. McBain, Ninth Cavalry; Second Lieuts. Robert L. Bullard.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15. -- The Ohio and Mississippi Railway stockholders' meeting, adjourned from last week, was held at the general offices to-day. The principal business to be transacted was the election of three Directors in place of three whose terms expired, but much interest was manifested owing to the negotiations which are said to have been completed, subject to ratification, for making the Ohio and Mississippi a part of the Baltimore and Ohio system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Acting Secretary of State sent a cable message to Minister Phelps at Berlin this morning conveying an expression of the President's condolence over the death of Count Arco Valley, the German Minister at Washington.

George Francis Train has been a friend of Sylvester F. Wilson, the manager of the female baseball clubs, who is being tried for the abduction of Libbie Sunderland of Binghamton, in the Court of General Sessions. He has attended the trial, distributed flowers, and written alleged poetry by the yard. He was wanted by the defense yesterday to testify to Wilson's good character, but he refused to obey the subpoena.

Tammany Hall last evening gave its customary ostentatious ratification to the Democratic candidates for the coming election. Fireworks, sounding brass, cheering and yelling, and speehces galore were the tiger's indorsements of the Democratic platforms. The meeting was held at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 15. -- The first home wedding for some time in Newport took place this noon at the Havemeyer cottage on Bellevue Avenue. Recent deaths in the families of both the bride and groom prevented an elaborate ceremonial. The bride was Miss Blanche Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer, and the groom was Mr. W. Butler Duncan, who is related to prominent families on both sides of the Atlantic.

The two corporations which have been chartered, one in New-York and the other in New-Jersey, to construct a colossal bridge over the Hudson River have consolidated, of course. That is what they were for. The joint concern has modestly decided to fix its capital stock at 15,000,000, and its bonded debt at $60,000,000, to be issued "for value."

War has broken out among the Directors of the Central Park, North and East River Railroad Company. This is the road which, under the abbreviated name of the Belt Line, winds around the town like an old-fashioned cowpath and goes everywhere without really going anywhere.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 15. -- The Michigan crop report for October has been issued from the State Department and shows the most gratifying condition of the 1891 crops. It is the final estimate that the wheat crop of Michigan this year is 30, 041, 130 bushels. This total is obtained by multiplying the number of acres in wheat in each county by the average yield per acre as shown by records kept by thrashers.

It seemed likely, when the Ecumenical Methodist Council began its sessions, that they would be rather dull, and that the Church was to be congratulated upon their dullness, seeing that it evinced harmony and prosperity, and that the annals of harmony and prosperity are not very interesting reading.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The convention of the State League of Republican Clubs began as a Harrison gathering and ended as a Blaine one. It was Sewell's convention. He came here last night and opened headquarters in one of the large hotels. His faithful lieutenant, ex-Judge E. Ambler Armstrong, was put to work to draft a set of prosy but strongly-flavored Harrison resolutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Rev. Dr. Donnelly of the Irish Methodist Church presided over the Ecumenical Methodist Council at the beginning of the eighth day's session. The first business before the council was the further consideration of the report of the Business Committee in response to the memorial on Methodist federation.
The smooth waters of the bay were a welcome refuge yesterday to many of the storm-tossed ships which had been battling for days with adverse wind and wave.

The New-Jersey law which Gov. ABBETT secured last Winter to give him control over the liquor interests of the State through the appointment of County Excise Commissioners seems to be causing quite a commotion down in Cumberland County. That has been a stronghold of the temperance sentiment in times past, and the Town of Vineland has been regarded as a sort of terrestrial paradise of total abstainers.

Mr. Platt's headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel had a good many visitors yesterday, including Collector Hendricks, Deputy Collector Bivor, Senator Deane, Cornelius N. Bliss, and Senator Frank Hiscock. Across the hallway Partner Oliver Sumner Teall was holding up the "city department" end of Mr. Platt's campaign with a dignity becoming the stationery he uses.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 15. -- Apprehension felt for the safety of Lieut. Russell and party, sent out by the Smithsonian Institution to survey Mount St. Elias, has been allayed by the receipt of a letter from Lieut. Russell dated Sept. 23. The party was then at Yokatel. The revenue cutter Corwin touched at that point on Sept. 1, and the party not being there then, fears were entertained for its safety.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 15. -- Harvard had more than she could accomplish to-day to defeat the representatives of Columbia in the intercollegiate tennis tournament. The Columbia team made a phenomenal spurt at a most critical time for them, and tied the score at one set all, and had a slight lead in the third, when darkness put a stop to the contest.

A suit was called to trial in the City Court of Brooklyn yesterday, which was very innocent in its apparent nature and yet which promised to disclosed some important political secrets. The action was begun by Patrick H. Flynn to eject one John Douglass from his home. Mr. Douglass is an ex-Assemblyman and a well-known Democrat.
