WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Before going West, not many days ago, Pension Commissioner Raum recommended to the Secretary of the Interior the dismissal of three clerks, who were objectionable to Mr. Raum because they had made affidavits to support the assertion that promotions are procured in the Pension Office for money, and that the son of the Commissioner had taken money for such purposes.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 15. -- The fly-wheel of No. 7 Mill, Amoskeag Corporation, burst about 9:30 o'clock this morning, tearing through the floors of the first and second stories. Eleven girls were employed in the drawing room over the steam pumping room adjoining the engine house. When the wheel burst they were carried to the basement in the debris.

The Atlanta returned from her cruise to the assistance of the wrecked Despatch last night, and came to anchor off Bedlow's Island at 6:15 o'clock. She shows the effect of the gale and heavy seas through which she passed in the twisted and broken iron railings on deck and in the broken furniture of the cabins.

Col. John B. Weber, who was appointed Chairman of a commission to investigate the emigration question in foreign lands, returned by the North German Lloyd steamship Spree yesterday. He is the Superintendent of Immigration at this port, and was welcomed back by the employes of the Barge Office who went down to Quarantine on the steamer William Fletcher to meet him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Jerry Simpson of Kansas, in an interview as to his impressions of the political situation in Ohio, said he thought the People's Party movement would show great strength in the election. He said:

The Hudson County Jockey Club begins its Fall meeting this afternoon at the North Bergen track with a programme that will compare favorably with that of any of the tracks hereabout for a month past There will be music at the track by Levy's Military Band, with cornet solo by Levy and a programme of popular music. The entries for the races are as follows.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., Oct 15. -- A pretty home wedding was celebrated at the residence of Samuel J. Adams yesterday. The contracting parties were Mr. John A. Snyder, teller of the First National Bank of this village, and Miss Satio M. Adams, eldst daughter of Samuel J. Adams.

A number of thoroughbreds, the property of Byron McClelland, Capt. S.S. Brown, W.H. Sands, the Rancocas Stable, and others, were sold at auction by Col. S.D. Bruce in the free field at the Morris Park track yesterday. The eight from the Rancocas Stable were the pick of the sale. The majority of them have performed well this year, and though they brought no fancy prices, they were disposed of at a good figure.

It is proposed to form a Buddhist society in this city. The aims of the new society have not yet been completely formulated, but the central object will be communion on the great mystery of life, and the methods to be followed will be found in the teachings of Siddartha Gautama, the great apostle of Buddhism. One of the most active promoters of the movement is Dr. Rodrigues Ottolengui of 115 Madison Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- The Manufacturers' Record reports the sale to a Belgian syndicate of 150,000 acres of coal, iron, and timber lands in Eastern Kentucky, including the Cumberland Valley Coillery Company's plants at Pineville. The total investment, including the purchase money and capital for the development of the property, is $5,000,000.

Everybody who believes that home rule for Ireland has become a political necessity for England as well as for Ireland must be glad that the Parnellite schism has become so entirely contemptible since the death of PARNELL. Nothing but a division among the Irish themselves can long delay the concession, and the less threatening the division the better.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- A terrible accident, resulting in the death of three members of the Inter Ocean staff and the serious injury of several other passengers, occurred on the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railway this morning about 11 o'clock at Crete, Ill. The dead are:

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 15. -- When the House adjourned yesterday it had before it the question of adopting the Ocala platform at the dictation of the State Alliance. This morning Mr. Trammell moved that the resolution be taken up, and called the previous question upon his substitute. Mr. Reid's substitute was first in order. He called for the yeas and nays on its adoption, and the call was sustained.

DUBLIN, Oct. 15. -- A convention of the Irish National Federation was held at Cavan to-day. There were numerous priests among the delegates. The meeting was presided over by Timothy M. Healy, the member of Parliament for North Longford.

Mr. FASSETT'S strongest claim to support as a candidate for Governor rests upon his supposed familiarity with the affairs of the State, derived from his experience in the Senate, and his ability to deal with those affairs. Neither his knowledge nor his ability is denied, but a more important question concerns his manner of dealing with public interests.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- At 12:30 o'clock to-day St. George's Episcopal Church in this city was packed with fashionable people to witness the marriage of the Rev. Octavus Appiegate, Jr., rector of St. John's Church. Ellenville, Ulster County, to Miss Ada Augusta Havemeyer, eldest daughter of Augustus Havemeyer of this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Scottish Rite of Masonry is approaching a revolution. There are two jurisdictions of the Scottish Rite in this country, the Northern and the Southern. The officers of the Northern jurisdiction are elected every three years, while those in the Southern are elected for life. The Southern branch of the order includes all that country south of the Ohio River and west of the Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The suit of the United States, complainant, against the Central Pacific Railroad Company, the Southern Pacific Company, and the Western Union Telegraph Company, defendants, has been set for hearing on Nov. 2, before Mr. Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court, sitting as a Circuit Judge. The hearing will take place in this city.

The plans for rapid transit suggested by the engineers of the commission now in session ignore almost completely what is known as the Greathead design. This is singular in view of the fact that the City and South London Railway, constructed according to Mr. Greathead's inventions and appliances, embodies the best and most modern devices for sub-surface travel and traffic and the only ones which have stood the test of actual work.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 15. -- A spark from an open grate set fire to the clothing of Mrs. Nathan A. Nash of Darien last evening, and she was burned so severely that she died early this morning. Mrs. Nash was preparing a meal, and when she became aware of the fact that her clothing was ablaze she seized here nine-months-old child and ran out to the road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Secretary Foster has just prepared a campaign document on the coinage legislation, and he gives it out to the press associations to-night with the information that he has copies for distribution at the Treasury Department. Just what reason there exists for converting the Treasury into a campaign bureau does not appear, but if it is to be the disseminator of information it ought to he accurate, which this document is not.

I am the holder of an endowment policy In the lX'ew-York Life Insurance Company. Reckoned in money, it is not a large etako In the prosperity of the company compared wtth tllat wlaich some persons hve, but it represents the frugal savings from a moderate alary for many years, and the loss or dimlnulon of the investment would be a seriuso matter to those dearest to me.

PITTSFIELD, Maas., Oct. 16. -- At a meeting of the American Board to-day two more members were, by request of Dr. Storrs, added to his committee to memoralize the United States Government upon Spanish outrages at Ponape. The committee on place and preachers for the next meeting recommended Chicago as the place and the Rev. Dr. Lewis F. Stearns of Bangor, Me., as preacher, with Dr. John K. McLean of Oakland, Cal., as alternate.

The elevated railroad company has just received a serious set-back in the shape of a decision rendered by the Court of Appeals, sustaining the judgment of the lower courts, awarding large damages in the suit of Lena Pappenheim against the Metropolitan Elevated Hallway Company for damages to property in Second Avenue between Ono Hundred and Twentieth and One Hundred and Twenty-first Streets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Of the leading railroads in the United States, 269 have agreed to return, free of charge, exhibits sent over their lines to the World's Fair. Half rates in each direction on exhibits have been granted by 25 lines, and 14 railway companies have agreed to transport exhibits free in each direction. This is the record made by Traffic Manager Joyce during the last year.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 16. -- The Democratic State Central Committee had a lively session of a dozen hours to-day, its fourth day. The anti-lottery people have been making a gallant fight, but the lottery men, with their slight majority, insist upon carrying out their programme.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 16. -- M.D.L. Shrope, editor of the New-Jersey Telegram, who was recently indicted on complaint of Mayor Johnston of Washington for publishing obscene and immoral articles in his newspaper, was tried and convicted here to-day before Judge Shultz. Sentence will be passed next Tuesday.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners seem to be rather chary of submitting their plan for an underground road for public discussion before the Board of Aldermen is asked to act upon it. It is admitted that they have reached a conclusion and that their final plan is ready, but they decline to say what it is before reporting it to the Aldermen for their "consent."

The Adams Express Company, through Henry Sauford, its President, and on the affidavit of Frederick Lovejoy, its Vice President, yesterday brought an action in the Supreme Court against John Hoey, the ex-President, to recover $712,750.57, with interest, which money he is charged with having misappropriated to his own use as a trusted manager of the company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The office of the Rochester Co-operative Supply Company in the Cox Building is closed on attachment proceedings. Several hundred people who have been paying $1 a week into the concern with the expectations of large returns in merchandise feel very glum.

From memoranda found in the trunks of Mrs. W. Minnich, the dressmaker whose trunks, containing $10,000 worth of Paris-made gowns, were seized the other day, the customs officers believe that about thirty-five more dresses of an equally costly character have been brought into this country recently, without the formality of paying duty, or are soon to arrive here.

There is trouble in the American Association -- the English company that established the Town of Middlesborough, in Kentucky. The Duke of Marlborough, generally known in this country as the husband of the former Mrs. Lillie Hamersley, is one of the most deeply interested of the English operators in the Middlesborough company.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 16. -- Miss Phoebe Couzins, the ex-Secretary of the Women's Board of Managers of the World's Fair, has returned from Chicago. When asked to-day if she intended to remain in St. Louis she said:

The greatest sale of thoroughbreds ever held in this country, and what may develop into the greatest over held in the world, was begun by William Easton, manager of Tattersall's, at the Hunt's Point sales paddocks yesterday. Forty-eight brood mares were sold for a total of $203,525, and twenty-seven weanlings, no one of them more than nine months old, sold for $72,250.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- The most dangerous, if not the most corrupt, legislators who have been sent to Albany for the past half dozen years have been known as Platt men. In either house of the Legislature the most vicious bills, the most dangerous strikes, the most flagrant corporation measures were introduced and supported by men who were in affiliation with the President of the United States Express Company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- United States Senator W.B. Allison of Iowa was at the Grand Pacific Hotel to-day and held a private consultation with Gen. James S. Clarkson. Senator Allison's presence in Chicago just at this time has set Democratic politicians to talking.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- The quo warranto suit of Luzon B. Morris against Morgan G. Bulkeley consumed a few minutes of Judge Thayer's time in the Superior Court this morning. The result is that the pendings are now in the possession of Clerk Anketell for transmission to the Supreme Court, the case having been formally reserved to-day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 16. -- The Republicans are so disgusted with the result of Tuesday's city election that the managers have openly discussed the penurious attitude of the Washington officials, especially the President, and declared that the defeat was no more than Mr. Harrison deserved.

Gov. STEELE Of Oklahoma, in his report to the Interior Department, says that if the Cherokee lands may be bought for the use of Indians at 47 cents an acre, he does not see why the Cherokees should not be compelled to sell them at the same price for the settlement of white people. There are good reasons why this should not be done, and it is singular that Gov. STEELE does not know them.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16. -- Gov. Hill of New-York to-day telegraphed President Belvin of the Powhatan Club that he will not be able to make a speech at the Democratic meeting here Monday night.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 16. -- At 9 o'clock to-night the schooner Julia A. Warr, from Calais, Me., arrived here, having on board Capt. J.J. Bowling and six men of the brig Alice of Baltimore, which was abandoned forty miles southeast of Cape Lookout Light early Wednesday morning. Capt. Bowling tells this story of the wreck:

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 16. -- The brig Arctic has arrived at Harbor Grace, Newfoundland, with the mate and eight men of the iron screw steamer Wolviston, Capt. Mitchell, which left Bristol for New-York Sept. 12, in ballast. In a severe gale on the 22d she sprung a leak and rapidly filled. She was abandoned in latitude 48 20' north, longitude 37 30'.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct 16. -- In the place of the greatest confidence that prevailed in the minds of the Republicans yesterday, doubt, uncertainty, and suspicion now dominate. The presence of Senator Brice, Chairman of the National Committee, had a most remarkable effect upon the rank and file of the Democracy, and the party managers themselves seemed enthused with new life and courage.

President William Steinway of the Rapid-Transit Commission said yesterday that the commission had finally reached a conclusion as to the plans of construction of the road which has been laid out, and would report to the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday next. He declined, however, to state what the conclusion arrived at was.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- The Board of Rulings of the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations has addressed a circular to the roads west of Chicago which the latter regard as an unwarranted exhibition of "nerve." It appears that the Western lines, while living up to their agreement to pay no passenger commissions to the agents of Eastern lines, are still paying commissions to the agents of Western roads stationed in the East.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- A band of determined-looking men gathered to-night in Odd Fellows' Hall. Most of them were strangers, and so quietly was their business transacted that not until after they had adjourned was it known that an important conference of labor leaders had been held.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- It has been intimated for some days past that William O'Brien, member of Parliament for Northeast Cork, was preparing a statement or manifesto in reply to the recent Parnellite defiances which have been scattered right and left by the leaders of that party. Mr. O'Brien's statement is given to the public to-day.

Superintendent PORTER delivered an address last evening before the American Statistical Association in Boston upon the "Organization, Administration, and Results of the Eleventh Census," the chief purpose of which seemed to be to glorify his own work in comparison with that of his predecessors and to support his pet scheme of establishing a permanent Census Bureau.

There is one chapter in the recent history of New-York politics which is studiously ignored by those who think that "Plattism" is a "national issue" and should be kept out of this election, where Tammany alone can be properly considered. We refer to the passage of Mr. FASSETT through the Custom House of the Port of New-York on his way to the nomination for Governor.

Representatives of the different railroads in the Transcontinental Association were in session at the Windsor Hotel yesterday. They talked all day about various matters of interest to the roads west of the Mississippi River, and adjourned until this morning without having settled some of the most important points.

BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- Irving A. Evans, the well-known Boston stock operator, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself at the Summer residence of Brice L. Evans, near Suncook, N.H. Despondency following unfortunate speculations is believed to have unbalanced his mind.

Medical etiquette is so awful and mysterious a topic that nobody but a doctor need pretend to understand it. Nobody but a doctor has any right to an opinion whether the naval medical service and the Navy Department have or have not been insulted by the refusal of the Pan-American Medical Congress to admit Dr. HOWARD E. AMES, a surgeon in the navy, as a delegate to that body.

It was charged by an Irish journal the other day that the Irishmen who decline to accept the death of PARNELL as a reason for disbanding the Parnellite faction are merely the agents of the secret societies. We all know what that means. It is the old policy of "outrages," which for generations made everybody outside of Ireland tired of hearing of Irish grievances, that these men are accused of reviving.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Rev. F.W. Bourne, President of the Bible Methodist Church of England, occupied the chair at the beginning of the ninth day's session of the Ecumenical Methodist Council.

March 31, 1887, President Patton of Princeton College delivered an address before the Philadelphia Society of Princeton College. The great Andover controversy was then going on, and the doctrine of future probation was agitating the whole religious world. Two persons, one of them a stenographer, reported Dr. Patton's words with great care.
BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- Harrison Loring, who for nearly forty years has been proprietor of the City Point Iron works, has made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- William Le Messurier of this city succeeded in reducing the bicycle road record between Buffalo and Rochester to-day. His time for the distance, seventy-four miles, was 4:55:00. The previous record was 5:45:00, made Oct. 29, 1889, by C.J. Iven, in the big Buffalo-Rochester road race.

Capt. Howard Forbes was not at all alarmed at being held as a hostage for Capt. Edward Campbell; indeed, he would have volunteered to fill such a position if assured that it would save the life of the unfortunate man at Camp Dick Robinson till his case could be reviewed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- It turned out another weak day in provisions. Pork at the close showed a decline from Friday of 25@30c; lard a decline of 12 1/2c; ribs a decline of 15c. The hogs, as has been the case each day this week, were over the expectations. The trade was dull. The very absence of outside speculative activity has been one reason for the week's decline.

The Boston Food and Health Show proves to be a growing institution. The increase in attractions is surprising, and the prodigality of the purveyors is constantly on the gain. As the second week of the exhibition draws to a close the stream of humanity for miles around sets toward Mechanics' Building.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Dr. John S. Billings of the United States Army is in the city to give his entire attention to the new hygiene department. This school, the building for which was liberally provided for by Mr. Henry C. Lee's fifty-thousand-dollar donation, will soon be in operation, and its Faculty and students will take up a field of research never yet entered by any American university.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 17. -- John Twohig, a pioneer citizen of this city and a banker whose wealth is estimated at three million dollars, died Tuesday, aged 85 years. Mr. Twohig had been a resident of San Antonio since 1836. He was born in Ireland, and when fourteen years of age ran away from home and went to sea.

It is likely that the Ecole des Beaux Arts will soon open its classes to women. Mme. LEON BERTAUX, the manager of the Union of Women Sculptors and Painters in Paris, is constantly finding more encouragement in the crusade which she has undertaken against the exclusion of women from the famous school. A great change has indeed come over the situation in Paris so far as the women are concerned.

One of the most varied and elaborate collections of household furniture marked the regular Fall display of the popular firm, Geo. C. Flint Co., at their warerooms, Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue. Their entire building was crowded from the time of the opening. The Flint warerooms occupy the whole of the three buildings numbered 104, 106, and 108 West Fourteenth Street, and every available inch of space was taken up for the display.

LENOX, Oct. 17. -- The mercury has gone as low as 30 the past week on some of the coldest nights, so that wood fires have been in order. It has been a great week for dinner parties. Miss Furniss gave one with sixteen covers Monday night, in honor of Mr. and Miss Woodruff of England, who have been her guests for some days past.

Thirty-eight years ago an American naval officer commanding a small sloop-of-war at anchor in the harbor of Smyrna grimly defied an Austrian fleet to remove from his vessel Koszta, a Hungarian refugee, whose only claim for American protection rested on the fact that he had declared his intention of becoming a citizen of this country.

SANTIAGO, Oct. 17. -- The anti-American feeling, which is very pronounced, reached a climax last evening in the streets of Valparaiso. A number of sailors of the United States steamer Baltimore, now in that port, were walking along the street when they were confronted by some sailors of a Chilean man-of-war. Some words passed, when a night followed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 17. -- The exhaustion of the gas fields which supplied Columbus a year ago, and the lessening of pressure at a number of points in Northwestern Ohio, are now followed by an alarming failing off in pressure in the more recently discovered St. Mary's district, which supplies Dayton, Springfield, Urbana, Sidney, Troy, Piqua, and many smaller Southwestern Ohio towns.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 17. -- This year an addition has been made to the course in experimental mechanics by giving a special study of the setting of valves. The value of this to the practical engineer cannot be too highly estimated.

The new fifty-thousand-dollar reading room and library which Mr. C.P. Huntington has presented to the Town of Westchester was opened last night with appropriate ceremonies. The building is a very pretty two-story brick affair, designed by William Anderson of Westchester. It was built two years ago by Mr. Van Schaick, who presented it to the town unfurnished.

A large and enthusiastic crowd witnessed the games of the New-York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday. The mile walk was the best event of the day. Shearman and Curtis, both of the Manhattan, were the leading contestants. Shearman managed to cross the tape a winner by half a yard.

The Farrow court-martial had a lively time of it yesterday. From beginning to end there were badgered witnesses, gesticulating counsel, and members who wanted to talk but couldn't make themselves heard. To begin with, the reading of Friday's record was dispensed with temporarily, and Mr. Bacon, the counsel for Lieut. Farrow, plunged into the cross-examination of Friday's witness, George W. Van Sicien, Secretary of the Holland Trust Company.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene A. Hoffman, Dean of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, has addressed an open letter to the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of the Diocese of New-York, in which he takes exception to the strictures on the clergy of the diocese contained and expressed in the pastoral charge of the Bishop delivered before the late Diocesan Convention.

Not content with its swindling operatious in the opera-house line in Minnesota, the New-York Life Insurance Company, through President Beers, is endeavoring in various parts of the South to secure new business before the year closes, by making frantic promises to loan money, erect buildings, form stock companies, and do everything else under the sun which promises to secure an increased volume of business.

To lay down the rule that Tammany must always and everywhere be opposed confines the independent voters of New-York to the forced and unvarying choice of supporting the Republican candidates, who in the present condition of the party are always Mr. PLATT'S candidates. In such conditions political independence loses all its substance and becomes a "barren ideality."

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Attorney General Tabor to-day gave an opinion with reference to the regularity of the certificate of nomination of Alfred C. Chapin, who has been nominated by the Democrats to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of David A. Boody from the Second Congressional District, comprising a part of the County of Kings.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 17. -- Had it not been for the Duncan-Havemeyer wedding the severe storm that prevailed here the first half of the week would have driven many cottagers away from the city. As it is there has been quite an exodus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The President visited the Washington Navy Yard this afternoon for the special purpose of witnessing the hydraulic mounting of one of the twelve-inch guns intended for the Monterey and the largest gun ever made for the United States Navy. He also inspected the new hot-blast furnace for heating jackets and hoops which is being constructed in the shrinking pit of the gunshop.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- There is hardly a city in the country where the accepted residence section or the so-called "Assembly set" is so circumscribed as in Philadelphia. And out of this condition strange results are now manifesting themselves. The Quaker City "400" that dwell in town are practically hemmed in between the Schuylkill River and Twelfth Street, between Chestnut and Pine.
I have read the letter of Mr. Matthew Hale and that of Mr. Gustav H. Schwab on the Gubernatorial question and the State election, recently published in THE TIMES, with no little surprise.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- With the little admonition from the weather clerk during the week that Winter was close at hand business at the local theatres jumped up several per cent. At several of the down-town theatres and at one or two of the up-town houses the standing-room sign was displayed at the door.

The vogue of the Kendals is undiminished. At the beginning of their third American tour with a supporting company less efficient than the one they had last year, and not to be compared with the company they had in their first season here, with an enforced sojourn in their New-York engagement at a down-town theatre, somewhat off the line of travel, they still draw great crowds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Dr. T.G. Williams of the Methodist Church in Canada presided over the Ecumenical Methodist Council at the beginning of the tenth day's session. The Hon. Charles Foster, Secretary of the Treasury, occupied a seat within the altar rail, and was an interested spectator of the morning's proceedings.

The clearing-out sale of the famous Nursery Stud of the late August Belmont was concluded at Tattersall's salesroom, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, last evening with the sale of the stallions and yearlings. The four stallions sold, headed by the most famous horse in America, fetched a total of $114,700, and the twenty-four yearlings a total of $124,550, an average of $5,189.
" Care," it is said," will kill a cat." To somewhat pervert the meaning of the phrase, a Brooklyn woman has discovered that it takes a considerable amount of care to accomplish a feline death.

ALBANY, Oct. 17.--According to the State Constitution the State Engineer of this State must be a "practical engineer." According to the loose constructionists of the Republican Party "a Surveyor" answers all requirements for this office, for in nominating Verplanck Colvin, they ignored absolutely the demands of the Constitution and selected a man whose only qualifications for the office consist in his having, during the past twenty years, made a survey of the Adirondack wilderness.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The sophomores have distinguished themselves during the past week in making life especially miserable for the new member of the Faculty, Prof. Baker of the department of mathematics. Prof. Baker succeeds Prof. George D. Olds, who was always an especial favorite with the students. This may explain, to a certain degree perhaps, the hard row that Prof. Baker has had to hoe ever since his work began here.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Doubt as to the action of the Republicans and the citizens of Newark concerning the fraudulent election of Haynes to the Mayoralty has been set at rest by an announcement made this evening over the signature of Lehlbach, the Republican candidate whom everybody believes to have been elected. The ex-Congressman says:

The attitude of the Evening Post in regard to the campaign in this State is certainly anything but consistent. The Post cannot support Mr. Flower because Tammany Hall participated in his nomination, and he is therefore "tainted" with their assistance, yet, lo and behold l it indorses Tammany's local judiciary ticket, and advises Mr. Scott to withdraw from the canvass.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Gov. Hill, accompanied by his military secretary, Col. E.L. Judson, arrived here this morning from Elmira. A band from Cortland serenaded the Governor and crowds of citizens and college men waited upon him at the hotel and shook him by the hand. Ex-Gov. Cornell, C.A. Collin, Professor of Law at Cornell, and E.C. Stewart, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, were among the callers.

The Richmond County Country Club held their jumping contest and pony races yesterday afternoon. The affair had been postponed for two weeks, with the expectation that there would be many entries by members of other country clubs. There was disappointment in this respect, but the event was, on the whole, a highly gratifying success.

Philadelphia is not the only city in which the health authorities are beginning to take, for the preservation of the public health, such action as is suggested to all intelligent persons by the recent discoveries concerning the infectious nature of the disease commonly called consumption. It will be recalled that experts have been employed there to inquire as to the sale in that city of milk taken from consumptive cows.

In your widely-circulated paper there have recently appeared extracts from the report of the Board of Visitors of the United States Military Academy for this year, reflecting on the department of modern languages and its instructors, on which, as was to be expected from ordinary human nature, comments are being made without waiting to hear from the other side.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 17. -- At 12:30 o'clock this afternoon two men entered the pay office connected with Spencer's mine at Dunmore, on the outskirts of Scranton, and after overpowering the foreman, John Brady, and leaving him gagged and blindfolded on the floor, carried off $12,760 in cash that was to be used by Mr. Spencer in paying his miners their September wages to day.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- M. Jean Jullien, the author of the new three-act play at the Odeon Theatre, is not a new-comer by any means, and he is, by all odds, the most painstaking, conscientious laborer of the new school. He directed, for over two years, the Art et Critique, whose editorial staff included several eminent names.

The representatives of the different railroads in the Transcontinental Association resumed their work yesterday morning at the Windsor Hotel. The subject which took up most of the time was the Pacific Mail Company's subsidy. Although the matter was not settled permanently, a new agreement was made which will go into effect as soon as possible, and will hold until the 1st of February.

Paris has become a new city within the last fifty years. It is now the most beautiful city in the world and the most attractive. It has always been attractive, but it abounded in deformities. But to my narrative.

The Committee on Nominations of the People's Municipal League has nominated candidates for the Assembly in seven districts and secured their "indorsement" by the Republicans or County Democrats or both, and it has "indorsed" the nominations of the Republicans or County Democrats or both in seven other districts, the test in all cases being unqualified support of ballot reform, which now means the adoption of the "blanket" ballot.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Orange Athletic Club played against the University of Pennsylvania on the Orange Oval to-day before a large number of spectators. The Orange Club was weak, only four of the regular players taking part in the contest, the others being substitutes. The regular men are holding themselves in reserve for the game with Yale next Saturday.

Since the Odd Fellows of Illinois determined to erect in Chicago a building that should literally put in the shade the building which the Freemasons began to construct last November in the same city, certain timid residents of Chicago have ventured to question the wisdom of compelling the patient crust of the earth on the shore of Lake Michigan to bear so heavy a load.

Mr. Ball wrote this autobiography in response to numerous appeals from friends and relatives who have been often entertained by stories of his life, which he has been fond of relating. It is obvious that when he at last yielded to their requests he had had scarcely any other alternative than compliance or a rupture of the family peace.

To be rich is a luxurious sensation -- the more so when you have plumbed the depths of hard-up-ness as a Fleet Street hack, a picker-up of unconsidered pars, a reporter, an unappreciated journalist -- all callings utterly inconsistent with one's family feeling and one's direct descent from the Dukes of Picardy.

Mr. John Hoey did two important things yesterday that tend to simplify the problem which the Adams Express Company has before it in relation to him and his doings. He resigned his position as a manager in the company, and he opened through his counsel, Mr. Elihu Root, negotiations with the company for a settlement of its claims against him.

The University Club's Committee on Admissions had a session the other night and elected eight men to fill the vacancies in the club's resident membership list. The growlers in the club have been in session ever since. The dissatisfaction with the committee's action rests upon the fact that some of the eight men whom they made happy with elections to membership were far from the head of the long waiting list.

DWIGHT, Ill., Oct. 17. -- Passengers on daylight trains out of Chicago on the Alton Railroad will have their attention arrested, within the first seventy-five miles of their journey, by two public institutions of world-wide celebrity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- This was the finest day's outing the Dutchess Hunt Club ever enjoyed. There was a farmers' festival at the Hudson River Driving Park, under the direction of the club, for the farmers and their families over whose grounds the club has hunted the past season. They came from Barrytown, Rhinebeck, Staatsburg, Hyde Park, Poughkeepsie, Wappingers, and other places to the number of 3,000.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Benjamin Brewster, at present the rector in charge of Calvary Chapel, 220 East Twenty-third Street, New-York, who has been called as the rector of the Church of the Holy Communion at South Orange, has accepted the call and will enter on the discharge of his pastoral duties in South Orange Nov. 1. Mr. Brewster is about thirty years old.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Henry C. Covell, the Bank Examiner who examined the Ulster County Savings Institution, and who is charged by Superintendent Preston with failing to inform the Banking Department of its true condition, was seen at his home in this city and asked if he had anything to say in reply to the charge.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Several surprises of an unwelcome nature are in store for the taxpayers of Bayonne at an early date. While the new Assessor has not yet succeeded in solving the rate problem, he has discovered that it will be unusually high. Last year it was $2.39 on the $100. An increase of over 20 cents is a certainty, and it may be more.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The prizes offered annually by the Amherst Literary Monthly Board for the best contributions from October to June have been awarded as follows: To Henry Wolcott Boynton, '91, for the best essay; to Herbert S. Nichols, '92, for the best story; to Le Roy Phillips, '92, for the best poem; to Seymour H. Ransom, '92, for the best light verse.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Cecil dynasty is now as well established in England as it was in Elizabethan days, when the founder of the family, Lord Burleigh, ruled the realm under the Virgin Queen. Mr. Balfour deserves attention on his own account, but just at the present men think most of the fact that he is Lord Salisbury's sister's son.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 17. -- The revenue cutter Corwin has arrived at Fort Townsend after four months of cruising in the northern seas. She sailed from San Francisco June 17 to enforce the provisions of the President's proclamation against sealing. During her cruise she has sailed 9,300 miles, boarded forty-nine vessels, and given assistance to two vessels in distress.

The recent series of storms which since the beginning of the month have swept over nearly the entire surface of the North Atlantic has been in severity almost without parallel in the recorded history of similar atmospheric disturbances. Each day has brought its story of another marine disaster. The coasts of two continents are strewn with wreckage.

The Fall races of the Manhattan Bicycle Club were held last night in Madison Square Garden. There were about 2,000 persons present, and at times the excitement was intense. Delegations from the different clubs in this vicinity occupied boxes and they cheered their favorites on to victory. Their well-known shouts could be heard all over the building.

The annual budget of hazing news from the United States Naval Academy, now occupying the attention of many fathers and mothers throughout the land, shows flow tenaciously this ancient custom clings to the school despite the most heroic measures to end it. In the Fall of 1883, when thirteen members of the class of '86 were summarily dismissed for hazing the members of the newly-entered fourth class.

The temperance agitation seems to be passing through another of the many phases which have attended its origin and progress. At first it aimed at nothing more than the reclamation of drunkards by inducing them to save themselves by total abstinence from alcoholic stimulants, and in its earlier programme it had the sympathy and support of all good men.

The suburban reason, which is largely dependent upon the weather for its success, received a decided set-back last week. For three entire days the wind blow with hurricane force at Newport, and entertaining and entertainment, even in the way of dinners, which are the delight of the lingering cottager at this season, were both out of the question.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17. -- Mrs. Thurman, wife of Judge Allen G. Thurman, died at 4 P.M. to-day. The condition of Mrs. Thurman changed for the worse last night. During most of the past week she had been in an unconscious state, rallying occasionally. For some time past there had been but little hope entertained of her recovery.
Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy has transmitted to the Mayor his report for the quarter ended Sept. 30, of which the following is a synopsis:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The annual report of Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles, commanding the Department of the Missouri, is mainly a historical review of the Sioux war of last Winter -- its causes, episodes, and results. In concluding his remarks on the campaign, Gen. Miles says:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- There was a great display of sentimental rhetoric by the more conservative element of the army when the progressive ones decided that the Academic Building was no longer sufficient for the needs of the military academy, and began to talk about tearing it down and putting up a modern building in its place.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The Senatorial committee appointed at the request of Attorney General Hensel to consider the evidence to be presented to the Senate in the investigation of the charges against Auditor General McCamant and State Treasurer Boyer for the purpose of ascertaining if any agreement could be arrived at by which the proceedings could be shortened, met this afternoon at the office of Rufus E. Shapley.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17. -- A decidedly peculiar case has arisen under the new Australian ballot law in this State, and is causing a great amount of discussion among members of both political parties. The Veteran Republicans in Hamilton County bolted the regular local Republican ticket and put in nomination an independent ticket.

In Mr. GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS'S letter to Mr. L.E. CHITTENDEN, expressing his hearty sympathy with the Republican Club "in this anti-Tammany campaign," though he is unable to accept the club's invitation to speak at one of its meetings, we find the assertion that "no question at this election takes precedence of the restoration of Tammany Hall to political power in this State."

During the quarter of a century that has passed since Lincoln died, the lives of him that have been written would fill a spacious corner in any library. Of books not strictly lives, and yet which are filled with events in which Lincoln was a foremost actor, enough are extant not only to fill a corner, but to make a library of no mean proportions.

Several lawyers of Queens County are bothering their brains over a real estate case which involves the title to a handsome residence which the original owner or his builder erected by mistake on another man's land. The house was built at least twenty years ago, but the strangest part of the affair is that the mistake has only now been found out.

The misfortunes which have overtaken the new Governor of British Honduras indicate that the British Foreign Office is lacking in a very important particular. It should have a health bureau for the benefit of its civil servants to tell them at what times of the year they may safely take themselves and their families to the distant parts of the world to which they may be sent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Judge Lowery of Ohio calculated that the 700 Ohio persons in office in Washington, with aggregated salaries of $500,000, would give at least $25,000 to help McKinley and protection. They have, it is understood, "paid up" only $1,000. The result of his appeal is said to be "disgusting," only fifty clerks having subscribed.

Joseph Trould, a Bohemian tailor, forty-two years old, made a desperate attempt to kill himself late Saturday night. He shot himself six times in the head with a revolver while in the yard of the tenement house, 276 East Third Street, where he occupied a furnished room. Trould is married, but his wife and their one child are in Bohemia.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- One of the vagaries of Porter's census will be the statistics relating to the manufactures of Philadelphia, which are now being tabulated at Washington. When the census of 1880 was taken, Philadelphians, who had long prided themselves on the industrial supremacy of their city, were greatly mortified to find that New-York had far surpassed them.

Yesterday was a great day for the officers and men on board the French flagship Naiade, which is anchored in the North River off Forty-second Street, for Archbishop Corrigan boarded their ship in the morning and held religious services. The Archbishop was accompanied by Mgr. Charles E. McDonnell. The services were held on the quarter deck beneath an awning built with the flags of all nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Before long the Republican newspapers that have periodically made up paragraphs about "Rebel Brigadiers" in the Congress with undiminishing zest, notwithstanding the constantly-diminishing Brigadier, will turn from the contemplation of unpleasant news concerning the election to the business of scaring their readers about the danger, in the Fifty-second Congress, of a preponderance of Southern men at the heads of the committees of that body.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- The number of deaths reported to the Board of Health last week was 214, as against 177 the corresponding week last year, showing an increase of 37 deaths, and making the death rate for the week 24.2.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- A special dispatch to a Sunday paper from Ottawa, Ontario, says: "Following close upon the announcement that the United States Government intended to abrogate the agreement entered into with Great Britain in 1817 and place a fleet of gunboats upon the great lakes, comes the report to-day that at the request of the British Government Lord Stanley had demanded an immediate report upon the defenses of the Dominion.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Just as Boss Kreuger's shrill brewery whistle permeated the atmosphere of the city at midnight of Tuesday to announce the re-election of his henchman to the Mayoralty, in spite of the people. "Barney" Ford stepped into "Fred" Feary's telegraph office on Market Street to tick the tidings of the "triumph" to Czar Abbett in Jersey City.

The arrangements for the formal opening of the latest of the chapels erected by the corporation of Trinity Parish -- St. Agnes's in West Ninety-second Street -- are rapidly nearing completion. At the last meeting of the Vestry of the parish a call was unanimously extended to the Rev. Dr. Wilford L. Robbins of Albany to become the minister in charge, and a response to the invitation is being anxiously awaited.

The Rev. Theodore L. Cuyler, who recently retired from the pastorate of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, has come out "flat-footed" for David A. Boody for Mayor. It is not often the good fortune of a candidate to have the reasons for voting for him as cogently presented as were Dr. Cuyler's reasons for supporting Mr. Boody to an Eagle reporter on Saturday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- John A. Cella, storekeeper of the Cook County Insane Asylum, was arrested last night for malfeasance in office in making false and fraudulent entries in the official records of the county. He is said to be one of the thieves who have been systematically robbing Cook County of unknown sums of money.

Dr. John Hall, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, has resigned from the Board of Directors of the Union Theological Seminary on account of the Prof. Briggs controversy. His resignation is regarded as but the first of a series of shocks that the Presbyterian Church must suffer before the present unpleasantness is settled.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Asa R. Woods, who, a few weeks ago, fondly fancied that she had come into property to the value of $240,000, has made the discovery that she is out of pocket and the victim of a bold clairvoyant.

The ground taken by Commissioner MORGAN'S annual report in favor of further reducing the Indian reservations, with a view to their ultimate disappearance and the absorption of the red men into the general body of American citizens, is not novel. His immediate predecessors looked forward to the same result as inevitable and desirable.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- The real estate speculations of George Z. Erwin and C.P. Vedder in Chicago bid fair to net them considerable profit. Erwin has been dealing in property here for some time. In February, 1889. he purchased two lots in Auburn Park, a suburb of this city, for $3,840, paying $1,040 cash down, and giving mortgages for the rest of the purchase price.

SEDALIA, Mo., Oct. 18. -- Thomas A. William son, to be hanged here Oct. 31, has made a most startling confession. He is condemned for the murder of Charles and Thomas Moore, father and son. At the time of his arrest he was a leader of the Salvation Army and a prominent character in the religious world. His confession shows that his life has been a continuous career of crime. He is forty-seven years old.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The Miller Brewing Company is in financial difficulties, but it is thought the trouble was discovered soon enough to prevent serious results. It seems that on Friday the directors met and elected Gen. Henry Brinker President in place of Frederick Miller, who had suddenly resigned.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18. -- William Evans was Secretary of the Morse Wool-Securing Company. He disappeared from St. Louis nearly a month ago under circumstances that led to an investigation of his books, and it was discovered that he was a defaulter for a large amount. The President of the company, beyond admitting that crookedness lead been discovered, refused to make a statement.

Both the Democratic and Republican headquarters were closed tight yesterday, and not even the shadow of a candidate crossed their thresholds. The corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and the Hoffman House were practically deserted, although late in the evening several political friends dropped in to see Mr. Sheehan, the candidate for Lieutenant Governor, who arrived there about 4 in the afternoon.

John Geoghegan, a young east side ruffian, who rejoiced in the sobriquet of "Tommy the Rat," and was the leader of the notorious stable gang, whose headquarters are at Avenue A and Eighteenth Street, died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning from consumption, the result of a pistol-shot wound resolved during a fight with a policeman over nine months ago.

Our neighbor, the Tribune, has borrowed from a manufacturer in Philadelphia thirty-three bars or pigs of tin that were produced at the Temescal mine in California, and it exhibits them with an affidavit asserting that they were really made of ore taken out of the earth in that State. The Tribune says:

The Rev. I. Newton Stanger, rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Harlem, announced his resignation from the pastorate of the church yesterday and its acceptance by the vestry. He did not state why he had resigned, but simply read his letter of resignation and the resolution of the Board of Vestrymen and then proceeded with his sermon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18. -- The Post Office site scandal is still the leading topic of conversation here. Since Mr. Wanamaker has cleaned his hands of the whole affair and Secretary Foster now comes forward in defense of the selected site, the wrath of the people here is turned upon "Calico Charley." Little by little inside facts connected with the site steal are coming to the surface.

The sealing season is practically ended, and its returns show a larger take, in the aggregate, than had been generally expected. The Pribilof Islands, in consequence of the limit in the modus vivendi, seem to have sent to San Francisco only about 13,000 skins, a considerable part of these being left over, at is said, from last season. This would be a falling-off of more than 8,000 from the take of 1890.

Just as the hands on the big clock in Madison Square Garden touched 12 last night fourteen young men started on a six-day journey on bicycles. The contest is of course for fame and gate money. At that hour the big building was comfortably filled, and the contestants got a rousing send-off.

The New-York Tribute has repeatedly asserted that the reports of Superintendent PORTER'S concerning several important in4ustr/es in the far ,Nes arc defective and misleading. Yesterday it published the following:

Mr. Rockhill had been a student of Buddhistic literature before he went to China, and there he used his place in the United States Legation to get in communication with certain Tibetans who were in Peking on some embassy from their distant mountainland. He had great difficulty in entering into acquaintance with these men, but having once gained their confidence he did what no previous explorer had done -- learned the Tibetan language.
BLUE EARTH CITY, Minn., Oct. 18. -- Albert E. Cline, until recently a Methodist minister, has run away. He has forged notes and checks to the extent of several thousand dollars, and is a bigamist.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Physicians have reported to the Board of Health of late an unusual prevalence of scarlet fever, amounting almost to an epidemic, and within the past three weeks there has been a visitation of the trouble in Girard College, the 1,580 pupils of which are exceptionally free, as a rule, from endemic disorders.

-- The Latin dictionary which will be compiled by the commission appointed by the German Government will probably extend to ten volumes of 1,200 pages each. The chief editor is Prof. Martin Hertz, who will have under him ten editors and at least fifty searchers, writers, and compilers. The time allowed for the prosecution of the undertaking is twenty years.

DES MOINES, IOWA, Oct. 18. -- The panic stricken Republican campaign managers have not had an opportunity to recover from the fever into which they were thrown by the letter of Judge James G. Day repudiating the party, of which he has been an honored and lifelong member, before an almost equal surprise and disappointment is in store for them.

Senator Washburn of Minnesota is in danger of being pronounced a heretic by the orthodox Blaine maniacs. He calls himself a Republican of the Blaine persuasion, but it must be noted that he makes a reservation when he talks of Blaine in connection with the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1892. He says: "Blaine can have the nomination if he is alive."

The editorial discussions of our present canvass for State officers and members of the General Assembly in Harper's Weekly command attention. Mr. Curtis has well earned all the authority and importance which his opinions carry -- authority and importance attested as well by the curses of enemies of good government as by the praises of its friends.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Two peculiar cases now engage the attention of the courts in the disposition of lunatics, as to their legal death or their legal life. Vice Chancellor Pitney, sitting in Camden, to-day granted a writ of habeas corpus for the release of James Rutherford of Cape May from the Trenton asylum, and for a commission of lunacy to decide at once whether he is insane or not.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 19. -- A case of typho-malarial fever has been broken up by the electropoise, This is merely a small silver cylinder, with rounded ends, called a polarizer, having an insulated wire attached, and a rubber band at the end to bind to the ankle. With this instrument attached to a living body, the electropoise -- that is what it is called -- is complete.

The wedding of Miss Susie Stanford Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Bacon, to Einle George Money, eldest son of the late Col. Money of the English Army, took place last Thursday morning in Grace Church, Cobham, Va. The social prominence of the bride and groom made the wedding one of the most fashionable that has been celebrated in that exclusive neighborhood this season.

The Hamburg-American steamship Rhaetia, which sailed from Havre Oct. 7, arrived in Quarantine at a late hour-last night. Capt. Ludwig, her commander, brings additional information concerning the disabled Edam, of the Netherlands-American Line. Oct. 13, while in latitude 48 39 north, longitude 38 west, the Rhaetia sighted a steamship showing three balls, indicating that her propeller had been lost.

A hearing was held yesterday before Commissioner Louis J. Heintz of the Street Improvement Department of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, relative to the opening of certain streets. Plans were submitted by Chief Engineer Louis Riess for the drainage of a large section of that part of the city between East One Hundred and Sixty-first Street and Pelham Avenue, Fordham, and the construction of sewers,

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 19. -- A large party of Philadelphians accompanied the Philadelphia Senators to Harrisburg to-day. The party included Mayor Stuart and Private Secretary Beitler, District Attorney Graham, Francis B. Reeves, Experts Faunce and Brown, Chairman Van Osten of the Councilmanic Committee of Investigation, Attorney Rufus E. Shapley of counsel for McCamant and Boyer, and all the accused magistrates except Neall.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 19. -- The bugler who called for the horses to-day called down the rain also, and the rain did not stop during the afternoon. Rain during the forenoon kept away the crowd. The people there were mainly New-Yorkers and near-by residents. No description need be given of the races. The horses ran in mud, and the horse that got the best of the start won.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 19. -- The revival of bull fighting in the City of Mexico yesterday was in the name of charity. A committee of ladies of this capital, with Mrs. Diaz, the wife of the President, at their head, organized the show for the benefit of the sufferers from the floods in Spain. It was one of the greatest spectacles of the Mexican national sport ever witnessed on the North American continent.

Although the operations of the New-York Life in the North and West have proved fruitful themes for the present exposures of mismanagement and corruption in the high executive offices of the company, it appears that the South is an equally fruitful field, especially in so far as regards that particularly obnoxious style of conducting a life-insurance business known as Dinkelspielism, which is the equivalent for deception, swindling, and general unreliability.

The Methodist Churches are, of course, not committed to the view of divorce taken by the eminent layman who yesterday read a paper on that subject before the Eoumenical Council. Nevertheless the views expressed by Judge SIBLEY are those which there is reason to believe are held very extensively throughout the Church, and they will appear to members of some other communions to be of an alarming laxity.
" The little, epitomized pocket edition of the great Alexander Hamilton."

The village authorities of New-Brighton, S.I., were very angry yesterday over an attempt which had been made by the Crystal Water Company to steal the right of way through two village streets. The Crystal Water Company supplies the Village of Edgewater, while the Staten Island Water Supply Company has its mains through New-Brighton and Port Richmond Streets, and there has been an understanding between them that neither should encroach upon the other's territory.

There has been a great deal of unnecessary bitterness between the followers of BLAINE and those of HARRISON, if we may believe Col. GEORGE W. HOOKER, member of the Republican National Committee from Vermont. The Colonel says not only that BLAINE can have the Republican nomination next year if he wants it, but that HARRISON is "for him."

Baron Constantine do Grimm furnished the New-York Concert Company with twenty painting for costumes to be used in "Poor Jonathan,'' which were rejected. He wanted $:00 for them, but as he had previously furnished fifteen paintings for costumes to be used In "The Grand Duchess" for which he had charged only $100, the Aronsone thought $300 was rather hlgh and offered him $200.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 19. -- Gov. Humphrey has addressed a letter to the Attorney instructing him to commence proceedings in the name of the State to annul the charter of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Company. This company has its corporate existence under the laws of Kansas, which require the general offices to be situated within the State. The offices of this company are at Sedalia, Mo.

Twelve of the fourteen men who started in the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden were on the track last night. McDowell of Philadelphia gave up the struggle early in the day, and Robb, one of the English contestants, had to quit in the afternoon, owing to a fall he received. O'Flanagan, the Irishman, began to show signs of distress early in the day, and so did Wood, the Englishman wth the ponderous legs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The failure of Harrison Loring, the Boston shipbuilder, was unlocked for by Navy Department officials, though it was known that he was at times pushed for cash and always wanted the payments on the vessels under construction at his yard at the earliest possible moment.

Whatever may be meant by the policy of "reciprocity," which is interpreted in so many ways by the Republican statesmen and organs, it is plain that it does not include reciprocal good feeling between the three great Republican leaders, BLAINE, MCKINLEY, and HARRISON. As a matter of fact, there is nothing in the McKinley tariff providing for reciprocity directly.

More of the alleged wrongdoing of ex-President John Hoey of the Adams Express Company was disclosed yesterday in the complaint in a suit brought by President Sanford in the United States Circuit Court at Trenton. N.J., to recover about $700,000, money said to belong to the Adams Express Company and to have been misappropriated by Hoey.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The eleventh day's session of the Ecumenical Methodist Council opened with Mr. William Mardeu, Wesleyan Reform Union, England, in the chair.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Work on the new gymnasium of the Military Academy has so far progressed that the appearance of the building and its value for the purpose to which it will be devoted can be estimated. It is built of West Point granite, broken-coursed, rock-faced ashlar. It is three stories high, and will cost $90,000 independent of the equipment, upon which $5,000 will be spent.

The old Elijah Miller homestead on the Mamaroneck Road, about two miles out of the Village of White Plains, was the scene of a murder Sunday afternoon, the victim being Mrs. Johannah Tussel, aged forty-five, wife of George Tussel, who occupied the building, now a tumble-down old shanty. All the stories respecting the tragedy are very conflicting.

A meeting of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held last evening at St. Luke's Hospital. The members present were George Macculloch Miller, the Rev. Dr. George S. Baker, the Rev. Henry S. Day, A.B. Ansbacher, Henry Rosenwald, A.B. de Frece, R.W. Moeller, Oscar E. Schmidt, Robert Waller, Jr., and Mrs. Richard Irvin.

Does the Civil Service Reform Association read the papers? Has it seen the reports of violations of the law relating to assessments of employes in the Federal service by Collector HENDRICKS, Postmaster VAN COTT, Congressman-elect WADSWORTH, and other members of the Republican State Committee?

It was reported in our dispatches of yesterday from Seattle that the Interior Department had recently employed a considerable number of special agents in the work of detecting the fraudulent acquisition of timber lands in the region around Puget Sound. The old game has been played in that region.

Among the State issues which ought not to be lost sight of in the present canvass is that of correcting the present unequal and grossly unfair apportionment of the State for representation in the Legislature. The constitutional provision which absolutely required an enumeration for this purpose to be made in 1885, and to be followed by a new apportionment, has not yet been complied with.

In his speech at Harlem last night Mr. FLOWER devoted his attention chiefly to the World's Fair issue, a subject in which the people of that section had a peculiar interest and with which Mr. FLOWER himself was specially familiar. He was doing his utmost at Washington to secure the fair for New-York, while Mr. FASSETT was doing his utmost at Albany, under the orders of "Boss" PLATT, to prevent it from being located here.

I am over fifty years old and I am reputed to possess at least an average share of shrewdness and to be up to the tricks of the times. A few afternoons since I was walking leisurely along upper Broadway in Brooklyn, with my hands clasped behind me, counting the profits of the day, and thinking of the good dinner awaiting me.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Lighthouse Board now has positive information that the schooner Drift, temporary lightship on the Winter Quarter Shoal, was on her station at the time of the wreck of the Despatch, and the failure of the look-out on that vessel to see her light can only be explained by the supposition that the weather was very thick.

FORKED RIVER, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The fishing season for Barnegat Bay is about over, but the hunting season is at hand. Present indications point to an abundance of game. Wild geese and ducks have already appeared, and their comparatively early arrival warrants the belief that they will be more plentiful than usual as the season advances. The geese that have been seen so far have been mostly on the wing flying southward.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- No allusion to Mr. Fassett's leadership in the Senate could be satisfactory without exposing his devotion to the "rag ring," which become a child -- and a healthy and wealthy child -- of the Quarantine ring. It was born in 1884 and lived until 1887, when the courts strangled it to death. Its operations were hold and defiant.

THE TIMES makes a strong point against Mr. Fassett's sincerity in his promise to give the State pure government, and, indeed, his perception of what honest government really is, when it recalls the fact that as Secretary of the Republican National Committee he reported the sickening resolutions of indorsement and eulogy for Quay and Dudley when these Worthies retired from the committee last July.

SHANGHAI, China, Sept. 24. -- A telegram received from Vladivostock, Siberia, states that sixteen Russian convicts (exiles) sentenced to work on the new Trans-Siberian Railway overpowered their guards and escaped beyond the military lines. Having only their convict clothing they knew the uselessness of attempting to leave the country, and so have set upon a systematic course of murder to obtain other clothing.

The Rev. Dr. Edward P. Ingersoll is the latest Republican to follow the Rev. Dr. Cuylor into the Democratic camp in Brooklyn. The disgust among Republicans at the ridiculously weak tickets handed out to them by the order of "Boss" Platt is growing every day, and gentlemen who have been and are still Republicans on national issues are coming out for Boody and Kenna.

The Brooklyn Park Commission have it in their power to add very greatly to the attractions of the park to horseback riders by giving them access, under proper regulations and limitations, to the noble field stretching the whole length of the park boundary on the south and known as the Parade Ground.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The Hon. Archibald Scott Cleghorn, the father of the Princess Victoria Kalulani, heiress apparent to the throne at the Hawaii Islands, is in the city. He is on his way home from England, where his daughter is now attending school. He talked very freely this evening about Hawaii and the relations between that country and the United State, He said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Gen. O.O. Howard, in his annual report as Commander of the Department of the East, devotes much space to a discussion of the problem of the defense of the Atlantic coast. He says:

We have no means of knowing what arms and ammunition Mr. FASSETT has put by in his arsenal for use at the close of the campaign. It may be that he is holding his heaviest and deadliest fire for the final encounter. But if he has no such force in reserve we hardly need tell him, since he must know it instinctively, that his campaign has already passed the point of greatest enthusiasm and expansion.
READING, Penn., Oct. 20. -- "Beatrice Collins, the New-York counterfeiting woman, has escaped jail," was the announcement which startled the public this morning.

The Bostonians have been accustomed to large and demonstrative audiences since their first presentation of "Robin Hood" at the Standard Theatre, but the one which greeted them yesterday afternoon was the largest and the most enthusiastic of them all. The occasion was a "professional matinee," and the profession turned out in force to honor it.

THE TIMES has often pointed out that the admission to citizenship of improper persons in large numbers is not the fault of the naturalization laws, but of the failure of the courts to enforce those laws. This truth is now receiving in this city an exemplification that is very discreditable to our courts, and that would horrify us if we were not unfortunately hardened by previous exhibitions of the same character.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 20. -- The career of the most audacious swindler in the South was brought into temporary eclipse yesterday, when Harry Silverman was arrested at Sheffield, Ala., for procuring an indorsement on certain notes of hand by false pretenses. Silverman has operated in several States with varying fortune. Some time ago.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen failed to report yesterday upon the petition of certain citizens to restrict the running of Hudson River trains on the west side to the night time. Chairman Morgan said that he had been unable to examine the briefs submitted as carefully as he wished. Since the report had been promised yesterday, some of the Aldermen expressed their disappointment bluntly.

The attention of the policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company is called to a little item amounting to $108,000, which represents a sum of money literally thrown away by President Beers in his efforts to foist upon the Legislature of this State that ponderous publication known as "The Public Service of the State of New-York."

There was a large attendance last evening in the Twenty-third Street Baptist Church, this city, at the marriage solemnized by the Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., between Miss Louise Gousset, daughter of Cyprien Gousset, the large confectioner of 105 South Fifth Avenue, and Charles H. Darrow, Jr., son of Charles H. Darrow, the bookbinder of 26 Reade Street.

The Board of Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners for the City of New-York, appointed by the provisions of Chapter 4 or the Laws of 1891, having determined upon the route or routes and general plan of construction of a rapid-transit railway for the conveyance and transportation of persons and property to be established in the said city, in addition to the already existing lines, respectfully represent:

J. Sloat Fassett made one speech three times night in small halls to mixed audiences of men, women, and children. The burden of this discourse was the cleanliness of the streets in the City of Berlin. There was a long array of figures quoted glibly about the tax rates, which Mr. Fassett insists have been increased by "the striped abomination of Fourteenth Street."
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20. -- Sunol is now the Queen of the Turf. She made a mile in harness in 2:08 1/4 at a late hour this afternoon, on the kite-shaped track at Stockton.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 20. -- An explosion of natural gas in the cellar of the building occupied by George W. Snaman, carpet dealer, 133 Federal Street, Allegheny, at 11 o'clock this morning, badly damaged the building and dangerously injured five persons. The building took fire, as did several frame buildings in the rear.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- A meeting of citizens was held here to-night to take steps toward securing the intercollegiate races at this point on the Hudson. C.L. Waring, Manhattan Athletic Club, presided. Graduates of the various colleges were present and entered enthusiastically into the plan. A committee of fifty was appointed to progress the movement, headed by C.L. Waring. Over $1,000 has been pledged toward expenses.

The report of the Rapid-Transit Commission on the plan of construction for the proposed underground roads will probably give the same general satisfaction that was felt at the adoption of the routes. It is evident that the Commissioners have given a thorough study to the problem with a view solely to reaching the wisest conclusion, and the result will therefore be accepted as the best attainable.

The unanimous decision of the Judges of the Supreme Court in this department that the elevated roads are entitled to have the damage they have done to property estimated by juries will operate a still further delay in the obtaining of justice against the corporation. So long as its managers carry their points, they will submit with equanimity to the moral disapproval of their conduct expressed by Judges.

Army officers stationed here are showing interest in the military possibilities of the bicycle, in view of the contest now proceeding at Madison Square Garden. Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles was in the city Monday, and was an attentive student of the questions involved. As presented by him, the application lies in the mounting of a courier on a bicycle instead of on a horse.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 20. -- A Vancouver, B.C., dispatch says that one of the passengers by the Empress of India from Hongkong to that port has a tale of terrible suffering to relate, such indeed as few in Canada have ever experienced. Scarcely yet has he recovered from the effects of his long period of misery and privation.

The Democrats of Ohio are learning that their up-hill fight against MCKINLEY is due mainly to that unfortunate silver plank that was thrust into the platform by the Cleveland Convention by little more than a bare majority vote. It was plain in this part of the country at the time that it was a grievous mistake and would repel support which the party might otherwise have had.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Messrs. P.B. Worrall of Fred Butterfield Co., Daniel McKeever of Herman Sternbach Co., and Ernest Werner of Werner, Joseph Hollister, representing the purchasing worsted importers of New-York, visited Secretary Foster to-day, and had a talk with him about the oppressive and embarrassing conditions under which the importers of worsteds are laboring in New-York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 20. -- Sheriff Crosby announced this morning that William Coy, who is in jail charged with the murder of John Whalen, had made a confession to him and State Detective Pease to-day. Coy has been nervous and has slept but little during the week that he has been in jail. He asked to see the Sheriff privately, and told him he wished to make a confession.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- In the Court of Appeals to-day the order affirming the order of Justice Pratt, refusing a stay of proceedings in the case of the People, respondents, vs. Nicola Trezza, appellant, was affirmed. This was an appeal from an order of the General Term, Second Department, affirming an order denying a motion of a stay of proceedings.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Parlor F of the Lafayette Hotel was the scene of Senator Quay's reception to-day, and he took possession of the room bright and early. Mr. Quay's change of hotels was quite inconvenient as well as mysterious to the city politicians. A phalanx covered the Continental corridors by noon in expectation of the usual call from above, but none came.

The steam launch Strae was launched yesterday from the works of Charles L. Seabury Co., Nyack-on-Hudson. She is 55 feet long, 9 feet beam, and draws 3 feet of water. The Strae is designed as a day launch, and is also arranged for cruising. Her frames are of selected white oak, planking of cedar, and copper fastened throughout.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The twelfth and last day's session of the Ecumenical Methodist Council opened this morning, with the Rev. Dr. Thomas Allen of the Wesleyan Methodist Church, England, in the chair.

BOSTON, Oct. 20. - "There is no use waiting for the first rainy Saturday in October," said Mrs. M.E.S. Ingersoll, the earnest apostle of mudless gowns for womankind, and she went out in her famous short dress to-day, and "far and few" were the people who bothered their heads to look after her as she went quietly through the muddy streets.

While Mr. FASSETT has been telling the people of the interior of the State how badly this day is governed by Tammany, the interior County of Oneida has been discovering that it has been plundered for years by Republican officials. Among these is former County Clerk HENRY J. COGGESHALL, how and for some years member of the State Senate, and at present seeking a re-election.
The New-York Press, which devotes its energies to the support of McKinleyism, published the following two or three days ago;

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Mr. Laurence Gardner of this city, Secretary of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, who has just returned from an extended Western Trip in company with Senator Faulkner, Representative Bynum, ex-Representative McAdoo, and Gen. Chauncey Black, brings back an account of enthusiastic receptions everywhere and gratifying earnestness in the work of organization for political work.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 20. -- This has been a very quiet day at the State capital. Most of the Senators who were here last night staid over, spending the day in the Senate Chamber writing letters, or visiting the various executive departments.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 20. -- The Clarion Ledger, the organ of Major E. Barksdale, who is running for the United States Senate against Senator George, contains the following significant editorials to-day:

In spite of all the agreements and promises that railroad men have made to each other about not paying commissions to agents, an Eastern road is charged with breaking faith. It is said that a confidential circular has been issued to agents by Peter McDonnell, General Agent of the New-York, Ontario and Western road, notifying them that commissions will be paid on all prepaid orders secured by them on transcontinental passenger business.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20. -- The recent earthquake in Central and Northern California occasioned phenomenal results in Sonoma County. On the Polpula Rancho of J.E. Poppe the ground was cracked and seamed in various places. From these narrow openings in the earth large quantities of water of various temperatures have been gushing forth ever since.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Oneida was an original Flower county. In 1882 its nine delegates to the Syracuse Convention were instructed for Roswell P. Flower for Governor.
