Two years later there was a very vigorous boom in this section for Flower for President, and the two delegates to the National Convention were Flower men, although bound by the unit rule to vote for Cleveland.

Tattersall's sales of thoroughbreds were concluded yesterday when Mr. Easton disposed of fifty-nine animals for a total of $47,540, an average of about $806. This average was brought up to so good a figure by the sale of a number of imported animals, one of which -- the stallion Simon Magnus -- went for $10,000, the purchaser being Pierre Lorillard, the owner of the Rancocas Stud.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Commissioner Raum talks about the public discussion of his forthcoming departure from the Pension Office as if it was none of the business of the public, and in language like that which made the name of a distinguished New-York railroad magnate famous a few years ago. He says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Secretary Tracy made an entirely new departure to-day in ordering Commander W.H. Brownson to duty at the Columbian Iron Works, Baltimore, as general inspector of the construction of Cruiser No. 10.

It is amusing to note the vehemence with which the few out-and-out advocates of the New-York Life attack everything and everybody that ventures to disagree with them. Their tin swords have been valiantly unsheathed in defense, but alas! their efforts so far have fallen short of their purpose.

WASHINGTON Oct. 20. -- 'l:hero will probably be a recommendation by the Secretary of the Treasury before the Congress gets through with its appropriations for a deficiency appropriatlon to pay bounties for sugar. An appropriation of $10,000,000 was made to meet the bounty provision in the Tariff bill, the calculation being that that would be more thn enough to satisfy all demands upon he Government for home-made sugar.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 20. -- The capital of Russia to-day is en fite from palace to tenement, for the Czar has decreed that this, the fifty-fourth, anniversary of the battle of Navarino, where in 1827 the combined British, French, and Russian fleets, under Sir Edward Codrington, the distinguished British Admiral, annihilated the Turkish and Egyptian Navies, should be celebrated with special pomp and significance.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 21. -- The most sensational suit that has come to trial in twenty years in Minnesota was that begun yesterday, before Judge Hooker, by Ignatius Donnelly against the St. Paul Pioneer Press for $100,000 for libel. It involves not only the Pioneer Press but ex-Congressman W.L. King of Minneapolis, and indirectly a Minnesota State Senator and United States Senator.

SALEM, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The eighteenth annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of New-Jersey began here to-day in the Broadway Episcopal Church. Mrs. S.J.C. Downs presided. At the executive meeting the work of the committee that built the State headquarters at the Waverly County Fair Grounds was approved. The building is 30 by 60 feet, is well built, and of the best material. It is in a fine location, and cost $2,300.

If the Harrison Administration, at Washington, had made the formal announcement at its beginning, as a feature of its policy, that it intended during its four years of control of the Government to oppress, harass, and annoy the merchants of New-York City to the full extent of every opportunity, it could not better have accomplished its purpose than it has done, without the formal announcement.

The policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company who doubt that their company under President Beers is being grossly mismanaged have only to refer to the expensive methods now being employed by him to procure new business to dispel those doubts. A few days ago it was stated in these columns that Mr. Beers's bonuses for new business had recently increased to $4 per $1,000, besides the regular commissions paid the agents.

Jacob Sloat Fassett and some of the rest of Mr. Platt's candidates went out campaigning again last night, and they had an experience in the by them hitherto unexplored regions of the east side that they are not soon likely to forget. To use a favorite expression of the gentleman from Chemung, he for once "got up to his elbows" in it.

CORVALLIS, Oregon. Oct. 21. -- Egenton Hogg, the receiver of the Oregon Pacific Railroad, appeared in the State Circuit Court yesterday to show cause why he should not be remove. A petition was filed by employes, who have claims against the company amounting to nearly $1,000. The Judge ordered that the road be sold as soon as proper advertisements can be made and the proceeds be applied to the payment of the employed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Superintendent James F. Pierce of the State Insurance Department has had his attention called recently to the fact that certain persons in New-York City and elsewhere in this State were organizing fire insurance companies in New-Hampshire for the purpose solely of doing business in this State under what is known as the Special License act.

Believers in the possibilities of boom were a good deal encouraged yesterday. Stocks were all strong, and there was hardly a notable exception among those fairly active that failed to score an advance.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 21. -- Sir George Baden-Powell and Dr. M.M. Dawson, the British Commissioners to the Bering Sea, returned to the city this morning. After breakfast they drove down to Rideau Hall, and saw his Excellency the Governor General and the Hon. C.H. Tupper, Minister of Fisheries. Sir George Baden-Powell said to THE TIMES'S correspondent:

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 21. -- The monument to the late Henry W. Grady was unveiled in Atlanta to-day. The streets of the city were thronged with visitors from every State in the South, and when the veil fell from the bronze statue, which stands on Marietta Street, between the Government Building and the Capitol, 30,000 persons joined in cheers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 21. -- A week ago a sensational marriage occurred at Bismarck, N.D., the parties being Capt. Lewis A. York, for thirty years Assistant Paymaster in the United States Navy, and Evelyn, Countess d'Ezychlinski of Russia. It now appears that even a more sensational part of the drama was enacted at Fargo.

The European tension seems to have been very considerably relieved within the past few weeks. Just after the"Cronstadt incident" and the French manoeuvres it seemed that France was convinced that the hour for which she has been waiting twenty years had at last arrived.

Considering the fame of Australia as the home of the eight-hour system, and the essentially working-class nature of her citizenship, it is rather surprising that so little actual labor legislation is to be found in the statute books of the great and progressive English colonies included within the proposed Australian Federation.

The official canvass of the Newark City election shows the re-election of Mayor HAYNES by a plurality of 196. Mr. LEHLBACH, the Republican candidate, filed his protest against the canvass on the ground that the returns did not "correspond with the ballots actually and lawfully cast." He claims to have evidence of fraud, and proposes to contest the declared result of the election by every lawful means.
George W. Van Siclen, Secretary of the Holland Trust Company, resigned that office yesterday afternoon. His resignation was accepted by the Trustees and James B. Van Woert was elected his successor.

STOCKTON, Cal., Oct. 21. -- Two more world's records were beaten over the kite-shaped track here this afternoon, both performers being bred at Pale Alto, both sired by Electioneer, and both driven by the veteran trainer and master reinsman, Charles Marvin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Major Gen. Schofield, commanding the army, has made his annual report. In speaking of the Sioux outbreak, he says that this campaign teaches the lesson that the entire military force of the United States would be wholly inadequate to prevent great loss of life and damage to property if a general Indian outbreak should occur.

LONDON, Oct, 21 -- The Valparaiso correspondent of the Times says: "The Chilean authorities show a more friendly feeling toward the American sailors than was expected. The Intendente assures me that the report that the Captain of the United States war ship Baltimore consulted him in regard to the safety of landing men is without foundation.

The Board of Aldermen of Long Island City Tuesday night considered for the second time the application of the New-York and Long Island Railroad Company for a right of way for the proposed tunnel into that city under the East River, and voted to give the company the franchise. One of the conditions Imposed is that the tunnel must come to the surface within the city limits.

The attention of the New-York Associated Press has Oeen called to a circular said to have been distributed by telegraph throughout the country, and purporting to have been signed by "W. M. Laffan. Vice President and General 1ianager of the National Associated Press," (who Is also understood to be the owner of Laffan's News Agency.) containing some satemerits that require correction.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- The published statement that the blunder in the million official ballots printed by City Printer Brown for City Cour Judge in New-York was due to the official notice received from the Secretary of State's oiIieo is denied by Deputy Secretary of State Benedict. l-lo says the blunder is in uo way due to the [aoeretary' office.

The Farrow court-martial proceeded yesterday morning at the Army Building. The prosecution introduced as a witness Capt. John A. Payne, retired, United States Army. He had acted as an agent for the sale of lots at Barnegat Park, and had, in that capacity, visited many army posts. He was successful as an agent. He said that Lieut. Farrow was looked upon as the head man at Barnegat Park.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- Adjt. Gen. Porter said this evening that he intended to furnish the National Guard at an early day with advance copies of the school of the soldier and the school of the company, as they will appear in the new drill regulations recently approved by the Secretary of War.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 21. -- Last week W.C. Cronemyer of the United States Iron and Steel Tin Plate Works at Demmler, Penn., sent to President Harrison a box of tin manufactured at the Demmler works. This morning Mr. Cronemyer received the following letter from President Harrison:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- When the committee of distinguished clergymen, appointed by the Board of Missions to visit Washington and urge the President to insist on the Spanish Government making reparation for the damages suffered by American Protestant missionaries in the Caroline Islands, arrive here, they will probably find that there is very little chance that the Spanish Government will promptly do anything in the matter.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Dr. Duffield, Professor of Mathematics in Princeton University, has made the following statement in regard to the charge of heresy made against Dr. Patton:

The Dunn Building, a four-story pedimented structure, known as 1,550 to 1,554 Third Avenue and 177 East Eighty-seventh Street, which was built by the carriage maker who gave it its name, on the site of his factory destroyed by fire two years before, met its predecessor fate last night.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- The Court of Appeals, in an opinion just rendered in the suit of Edward Roberts against the New-York Elevated Railroad Company and the Manhattan Railway Company, has laid down the rule as to the acceptance of the testimony of real estate experts in the suits for damages to property by the elevated roads.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21. -- Pimlico track was lumpy today. The bright sunshine and brisk winds took up and whisked away slush and mud somewhat during the afternoon, but it will take the wind of to-night, and the now hopefully expected sun of the morrow to take all the moisture out of the lumps, and give the Baltimore Jockey Club its first day of good racing conditions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 21 -- A special to the Star from Salina, Kan. says: "The State Farmers' Alliance Convention was called to order this morning amid considerable confusion and uncertainty. With the arrival of delegates last night and this morning a strong and determined fight against the re-election of President Frank McGrath has been developed.

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association last evening a resolution was adopted authorizing the President of the association to address a letter to the Postmaster General and one to the Secretary of the Treasury calling attention to the soliciting of political contributions from persons in the Federal service by the Republican State Committee of New-York, of which committee Messrs. VAN COTT and HENDRICKS are members.

Funny Mr. Meyer, who has been persuaded by "Boss" Nathan that he can be elected Mayor of Brooklyn, changed his plan of campaign once again yesterday. He had tried the "middle class" games and found it failure. Then he appealed to race prejudice, but his managers concluded that the people would not select a man for Mayor merely because his father was born in Germany.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 21. -- This has been an important day in the special session of the State Senate, but the most interesting portion of the proceedings did not take place until afternoon.

The scheme by which T.C. Platt of Tioga is trying to corral the labor vote through the aid of certain labor leaders of doubtful repute was exposed yesterday by the Democratic State Committee. The statement issued by the committee begins with a copy of the circular which Gen. Husted sent out to the Chairmen of the Republican County, City, Town, and Village Committees.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment resumed consideration yesterday of the departmental estimates for 1892. As a result of the day's work estimates were passed upon amounting to about $7,500,000. Estimates for the Police Department were first considered. A total allowance of $5,018,801.65 was made, against an allowance of $4,809,515.38 for the present year. The amount asked for 1892 was $5,345,693.30.

The urgency and necessity of a flee raw material enactment can be demonstrated by nothing better than by an examination or metal and its manufactures, specifically iron and its manufactures, along with an examination of the wool schedule. The results of an inquiry into the comparative cost of coal mining and iron mining in the leading competing countries -- America, England, and Prussia -- may, therefore, prove of interest.

There was a big Democratic rally at the Palace Rink in Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, last night. Nearly ten thousand enthusiastic citizens of the city over the bridge assembled to listen to common-sense talks on the issues of the campaign by such speakers as Roswell P. Flower, William F. Sheehan, Gov. Leon S. Abbett of New-Jersey, David A. Boody, Gen. Isaac S. Catlin, and Mayor Chapin.

The letter of Mr. FRANCIS M. SCOTT accepting the nomination of the County Democracy for Judge of the Supreme Court states with admirable clearness and conciseness the position of that organization in the present political canvass. He says: "I am convinced that the public interests require the election of the Democratic State ticket, and that that result can only be secured by the co-operation of all Democratic organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The decision of Judge Hughes in the habeas corpus case of Pay Clerk Van Vranken yesterday was a surprise to naval officers familiar with the history and practice of court-martial trials in the navy, and if it is fully sustained by the Supreme Court, it will make a great change in the administration of justice in the navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Secretary Rusk has received from Mark W. Harrington, the chief of the Weather Bureau, a special report of the operations of the bureau since its transfer to the Department of Agriculture July 1 last. Mr. Harrington says the service has been reorganized with a view of carrying out the expressed intention of Congress to especially develop and extend its work in the interest of agriculture.

GALESBURG, Ill., Oct. 21. -- The Chicago, Burlington and Quiney fast passenger train No. 5 which left here at 10:30 o'clock last night, met with a terrible accident at the pottery switch near Monmouth, sixteen miles west of here, twenty-five minutes later. The train was running at a high rate of speed. The switch was partly open and the locomotive left the main track and started on the side track.

Now that the general plan of a system of rapid-transit roads has been decided upon by the commission, discussion is promptly turning to the question whether capital can be induced to go into the undertaking. The test of that question will come when the commission is prepared to offer the franchise for competition.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 21. -- Statistics of the exports from this country during the fiscal year ended June 30 have just been published. They show a healthy increase of foreign trade in Mexico, for in merchandise exports there has been a gain of more than $1,000,000 over the previous year, and an increase of more than $8,500,000 over the average for five years past.

There will be a commotion about the offices of the United States Board of General Appraisers this afternoon the like of which has not been seen since the board was created, and disclosures are promised of a conspiracy to injure the commerce of this port and the business of its merchants such as will arouse the indignation of every man having a particle of civic pride.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 21. -- The Republican campaign seems to be breaking up in Iowa. Several things have occurred in the last few days which have hurt the party badly. One is the result of the Clarkson visit to Des Moines, at which time he brought no money -- nothing, in fact, but a vigorous piece of his mind upon the method of running the campaign, which, he said, had been botched.

During his recent visit to London, a number of pencil sketches, pen and inks, water colors, and oils by Dante Gabriel Rossetti were picked up by Mr. J.M. Bouton, the bookseller, and are now on view at his shop, 8 West Twenty-eighth Street. Among the relics of Rossetti is an old account book and a blotter in which many old prints have been pasted. A water color half-length represents Goethe's Mignon in "Wilhelm Meister."

The Democrats of Harlem had the laugh on their Republican neighbors last night and proved the truth of the old maxim, "He laughs best who laughs last." On Monday night the Republicans had all the fun as they saw 6,000 Democrats parading under torches in a torrent of rain and thousands more plodding through the mud to the great Democratic ratification meeting.

As one of the "suspects" on the New-York World's Fair Commission and as a more or less active worker thereon. I have had opportunities to note and study the probable relations of the fair issue to the political problems with which we are now confronted, and therefore venture to submit for your consideration the following:
PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 22. -- A special telegram to the Oregonian from Pendleton says:

Daniel Lane, who was arrested for fraudulent registration in the Fifth Assembly District, pleaded guilty in the Court of General Sessions yesterday before Judge Martine and was remanded for sentence. He made the following confession:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 22. -- The town of Suterville, twenty-nine miles from Pittsburg, is greatly excited by the expulsion of the Rev. Alexander Laird and John McElroy from the Sons of Temperance for drinking fresh cider. In addition, David Warren, Robert L. Wilson, Robert Hunter, A. Priddy, and John H. Owens are booked for expulsion next Tuesday.

" When I think of America I do not fear for anything. With your sixty millions of people now and your coming hundreds of millions and the giant forces that go with them, I know that all will be well. You speak the English language; you are with us; you will choke the Atlantic with the cinders you throw overboard from your ocean steamers, and for all things good the nations will be one."

The Baptist pastors from all over the State will gather at Oneida next Tuesday, Wednesdays, and Thursday. The New-York State Pastors' Conference, of which the Rev. J.W.A. Stewart is Chairman, will there hold its twenty-fourth annual meeting, and the Baptist Missionary Convention of the State of New-York will hold its eighty-fourth annual meeting.

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- Another measure to which Mr. Fassett when Senator lent his assistance was the cause of a scandal and a legislative investigation in the session of 1886. Subsequent developments made Mr. Fassett's position at that time better understood.

It rained cats and dogs and blow a gale of wind in the Eastern District of Brooklyn last night. The streets were rushing torrents of water, the crossings had vanished, the surface cars were like so many refrigerators on wheels, and umbrellas turned inside out as soon as opened.

FONDA, Oct. 22. -- A popular uprising of the people in Fulton and Hamilton Counties has been given expression in "an address to the people of the Assembly district." It strikes the death-note of the Harrison regime in one of the Stanchest Republican and most pronounced protection Assembly districts in the State.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22. -- The statement recently made by Gen. John Beatty, the Republican Stalwart, to the effect that the Democrats had little money on which to prosecute their campaign, while the Republicans were in very comfortable circumstances through the courtesy of the ironmasters and manufacturers who were contributing liberally for the benefit of Major McKinley, is corroborated.

DEL RIO, Texas, Oct. 22. -- The full details of the pursuit and capture of the Southern Pacific train robbers reached here to-day. Jones Sitter struck the trail at a place near Juno on Tuesday, and leaving Frank Bendel behind to inform the rangers who were following on the trail, he pressed on in pursuit of the robbers.

The figures for the two greatest sales of thoroughbreds ever held in this country and England will be of interest to the general reader who is not thoroughly familiar with such matters, in connection with the recent Belmont sale. The greatest sale in America previous to that one was the clearing-out sale of the Rancocas Stud, which was held in 1885-6. These are the figures then obtained:

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- Again last evening the fierce gales which have been sweeping over England, Ireland, and the south of Scotland for nearly two weeks renewed their work of destruction. Dispatches from Sandgate, Kent, late yesterday evening gave notice that an unknown bark was ashore near that town. A fearful sea was running in the Channel and the local lifeboat went to the rescue of the endangered mariners.

PCI'SBURO, Penn., Oct. 92. -- President Roberts of tile Pennsylvania Riallroad, who is now in Pittzburz refused to-night other to conform or deny the story published today that be and a party of English oaphallat had been over the Northern Pacific Raod with a view of securing of it for the Pennsylvania company.

The Gibbs lion has devoured the Cowie lamb in the Thirteenth District, and intense and blessed harmony reigns. Mr. STEWART will have no Republican opponent in the Eighth Senatorial District, GIBBS has only two Democrats and a Prohibitionist to overcome in the Assembly fight, and the solemn business of denouncing the wickedness of GIBBS has been postponed for a year.

Again Mr. WARNER MILLER'S fidelity to party, in spite of the snubs and rebuffs administered by PLATT and his minions, induces him to allow himself to be used to promote the triumph of those who despitefully use him. The day he left for Europe the Republican State Committee met to fix the time and place of the State Convention, but neither then nor afterward were his wishes consulted or regarded.
A great many thoughtful Republicans are seriously asking themselves what will be the effect of Fassett's election.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 22. -- At 12.30 A.M. a vessel was discovered ashore on Romar Shoals, off Sandy Hook. She proved to be the Moses B. Bramhall, Capt. Smith, from Charleston to New-York, with a load of yellow pine railroad ties. At the time she went ashore the surf was smooth, but toward morning the wind changed to the northeast, and a high sea was running.

The cable railroad over the Brooklyn Bridge took a cranky turn last evening which resulted in a prolonged blockade and stoppage of travel, to the intense exasperation of thousands of people homeward bound. It was at the busiest time of the evening travel, and the chill blasts of an Autumn storm roared through the bridge station in a way that threatened pneumonia, rhematism, and chills.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller returned yesterday from Europe in the steamship City of New-York. He was met at the pier by General Manager Davis and Treasurer H.B. Slaven of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company, A.C. Cheney, President of the Garfield National Bank, and a few other business and personal friends, but by no members of the Republican State or County Committees, except Mr. Cheney.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- To all persons in the navy and in the Naval Reserves it will be interesting to know that the new artillery and infantry tactics recently issued under the editorial hand of Commander Charles M. Thomas are being readily taken up a the Naval Academy, where Lieut. William F. Fullam, one of the board that prepared the manual, is one of the instructors.

It is a little late in the day for the Republican managers in Brooklyn to claim that their candidate, Mr. MEYER, has been "brutally proscribed" because he is a grocer of German descent. He has not been proscribed at all. He could hardly complain if some of his customers who are perfectly willing to buy groceries of him should decline to employ him as a lawyer, since he knows nothing about law.

A circular has bean sent out by the People's Municipal League in behalf of its Enrollment Committee for the Eleventh Assembly District, asking voters to enroll themselves as interested in the workings of the league. Each circular is accompanied by a postal card, which is to be signed by the person receiving the communication and mailed to the Chairman, Dr. Francis P. Kinnicutt, or to any member of the committee.

That the importers of this city are fully awake to the importance of the struggle which has been forced upon them by the domestic manufacturers and their representatives in the Harrison Administration was well established by the impressive demonstration made by them in defense of their rights and of the commerce of this port before the Board of General Appraisers yesterday afternoon.

I have read with pleasure your daily reports of the "management" (t) of the New-York Life, and, as they say in the classics, "them's my sentiments." If the press does not "show up" these wrongdoings, who well! If the press does not show where the policy holders' cash is going, who will! If the press does not cause the President of the New-York Life to resign, who will!

SALEM, Mass., Oct. 22. -- The second day of the adjourned hearing in the Searles will case began to-day with the same crowded courtroom as heretofore. Another lot of business letters from Stillman Hubbard to Mrs. Searles was road. Oct. 11, 1887, a letter inclosed a note to Mr. Huntington in which Mrs. Searles says she must repudiate the agreement signed by Timothy Hopkins until she knows what it is.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 22. -- One of the best-known of the city's landmarks has just been doomed to destruction by the local Board of Levee Commissioners. The new embankment necessitated by the ravages of the river along the front of the upper portion of the town will lie directly through the pleasure grounds known as the Carrollton Gardens.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 22. -- The Senate this morning resumed the examination of Deputy Superintendent John Q. Stewart. He was cross-examined by Lyman D. Gilbert. His testimony was to the same effect as yesterday regarding the school year in Philadelphia, which, he said, began and ended with the calendar year.

NEWARK, Oct. 22. -- Mrs. Annie Eidler, a young married woman, died at the City Hospital today of a self-administered dose of poison. Her husband and herself, with their little child, and a boarder or two, lived at 59 Rutgers Street, Yesterday afternoon she locked the child in her rooms and went to the home of Mrs. Charles Koehler, her friend, at 615 South Eighteenth Street.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Oct. 22. -- A sensation was caused here to-day by the suicide of ex-United States Consul James Murray. About 11:30 o'olock this morning he rose, and taking a loaded rifle that was in his room, stood before a mirror in his night dress.

Secretary of State James G. Blaine arrived last night at the Grand Central Station on the 7:32 Shore Line train from Boston, and is now occupying Rooms 24 and 25 at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He is accompanied by Mrs. Blaine and Louis A. Dent, his private secretary, Miss Hattie Blaine and James G. Blaine, Jr., who were with him on the journey from Boston, went on to Washington last evening.

A short time ago a young cooker spaniel owned in this city gave birth to six most promising and beautiful puppies, handsomely marked, and giving every evidence of being thoroughbreds of extended pedigree.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22. -- San Franciscans who have been watching developments in the Post Office site scandal were laughing to-day at the list of "respectable leading citizens" who have made affidavits, which Commissioner John P. Irish has sent to Secretary of the Treasury Foster, indorsing the selection or the Seventh and Mission Streets swamp lot.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 22. -- Reports from the Provinces of Sunbirsk and Samara show that the Local Government is unable to cope with the prevailing distress, and that relief has not reached the more remote districts. The work of distribution is not properly organized. Numbers of prosperous persons are receiving help, while many who are entirely destitute are dying of hunger.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 22. -- James Neal, of the firm of Brown Co., ironmasters, of Pittsburg, was married this evening to Miss Jennie, only daughter of F.F. Adams of Erie. The ceremony took place at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, the Rev. John Huske officiating. The best man was Henry Graham Brown of Pittsburg and the maid of honor was Miss Mary McDowell of Portland, Me.

The Evening Post of this city has been arguing -- at least, it was arguing a while ago -- that national issues have no proper place in the State canvass. In discussing the Massachusetts campaign, however, it admits that it "is fought on national issues mainly, and of these the silver question appears to be the most prominent."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The United States revenue cutter Rush, which sailed Monday from San Francisco for Bering Sea, proceeds direct to Unalaska, Alaska. The run to Unalaska is, for the Rush, one of eleven days' duration. At Unalaska the vessel will coal and leave there immediately for the seal islands of St. George and St. Paul.

Is Ship Broker John C. Austin alive or dead? This is a question of great and increasing interest to his relatives and friends, and of importance at the present time to two insurance companies of this city, each of which has a policy on his life calling for a large amount of money in case of death.
President Warner Miller of the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company returned from Europe in the best of health. To a TIMES reporter, who asked him for the results of his trip, he said yesterday:

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 22. -- Advices received here from Asuncion, the capital of the Republic of Paraguay, bring news of an attempt there to overthrow President Juan G. Gonzalez. The attempted revolution, however, was promptly suppressed by the troops loyal to the Government.

William C. Bolton President of the Bolton Drug Company of Brooklyn, who got a divorce from his wife in South Dakota and then married Miss Schuler in Newark, N.J., returned to Brooklyn yesterday and was arrested on a charge of abandonment preferred by his first wife. He was released in $300 bail. Mr. Bolton said he had gone to South Dakota after his Newark wedding and had had another ceremony performed there.
SUSANVILLE, Cal., Oct. 22. -- A man named Yarwood was arrested here to-day on suspicion of being a forger wanted in New-York. The description fits him exactly.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29. -- The fact that the Southeastern Mississippi Valley Association will not disband, but will amalgamate with the Southern Railway and Steamship Association, will be a great surprise in railroad circles. The Southeastern Mississippi Valley Association was organized by the lines which had withdrawn from the Southern Railway and Steamship Association and was formed in opposition to it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 22. -- An important agreement has been entered into between the Indlaha friends of Judge Gresham and those of President Harrison, by which theformer have premised to cease their opposition to the President's renominaon and the latter are to lend their influence to Gresham in(1896.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 22. -- There was an encounter between Chief of Police Rylands and Capt. Pinkerman of the police force at Police Headquarters to-day. Although a revolver was drawn, the quarrel luckily ended without bloodshed.

The defense in the Farrow court-martial began yesterday morning, with M.W. Conkling as its first witness. Mr. Conkling testified: "I became connected with the Barnegat Park Company in December, 1888, when I made arrangements with Farrow and Larner to negotiate notes of the company received for sale of Barnegat Park property.

Mr. FLOWER could not be expected directly to repudiate the construction generally put upon the declarations of the Saratoga platform on the subject of ballot reform, nor should any candidate for Governor be asked specifically to pledge himself to approve a particular enactment in advance of its consideration by the Legislature.

The protected manufacturers and members of Trusts who are united in what is called the Protective Tariff League maintain a bureau which supplies arguments and other material to the McKinley press. A sample of this material was shown in the League's assertion that the story of the reduction of wages at the Trenton potteries last Winter and of the long strike which followed that reduction was an "extravagant myth."

There is a matter at the Custom House affecting his department which Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt may think it well to investigate while here. In the first week of this month examinations were held in this city for places in the classified service. For examination for appointment as Inspectors about ninety candidates presented themselves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- George W. Quintard, one of the assignees of Harrison Loring, the Boston shipbuilder, was at the Navy Department to-day to talk over plans for completing Cruiser No. 11 and the three navy yard tugs being built in the yard of the bankrupt shipbuilder. He was accompanied by Harrison Loring, Jr., who has had charge of much of his father's business.

John I. Davenport, the United States Supervisor of Elections, who draws a salary of $6,000 from the Government and spends about three weeks preceding election day in this city, once more is on deck making out warrants for persons alleged to intend to vote fraudulently, who, of course, are all Democrats. Last year, when there was a Congress to be selected, Mr. Davenport was on hand doing the same sort of work.

Almost the only question that has been raised with reference to the plan for an underground rapid-transit system reported by the Commissioners is whether the requisite amount of capital for its construction will be attracted to the enterprise. That the routes are the best possible seems to be admitted, and that the proposed plan of construction is the most feasible, if not in all respects the best, is hardly questioned.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 23. -- The Rev. D.S. Phelan, editor of the Western Watchman, who keeps up a correspondence with Rome that places him in possession of facts that might be considered almost official, was questioned to-day as to his views on recent rumors concerning the state of affairs now existing there and the talk that the Pope might leave.

There is not very much reason to doubt the report that an alliance is contemplated, to offset the Dreibund, and that it is meant to include Servia, Montenegro, Sweden, Denmark, and Greece, as well as Russia and France. The northern powers mentioned have reason to entertain either resentment or apprehension against Germany.

Dullness was the feature of yesterday's market. It is evident that the old bull crowd are waiting for something to turn up, and there are intimations that they know just what it is they are expecting, too. A further hint is that the development they are counting on is to come from Vanderbilt quarters.

Those insurance agents and journals that have for obvious reasons allied themselves with President Beers in the pending exposures of that officer's gross mismanagement of the New-York Life Insurance Company have seen fit to attack THE TIMES'S story regarding the New-York Life's offer to loan money on the Opera House at Marshall, Minn.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 23. -- One of the largest and most important sales of real estate in Newport for some time was made to-day through Whipple Derby, who sold for Mr. Anson Phelps Stokes his magnificent estate, comprising over thirty acres, known as "Tammany Hill." It is one of the highest and most charming pieces of land in Newport. The purchaser is Mr. H.E. Hartwell of New-York. The terms are private.

Brooklyn Grand Army men and members of the local State regiments were very much interested yesterday in the letter issued by Mrs. Ida Brownell, the widow of Gen. W.H. Brownell, stating that she had not received a penny from the proceeds of the lecture given in the Academy of Music by the Rev. Dr. Newland Maynard for her benefit soon after her husband's death, in 1888.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 23. -- There was little that was notable during the three contests of the fourth day at the Cumberland Fair Grounds except the defeat of the crack pacer Bunco, Jr., and the heat in 2:12 3/4 made by Grant's Abdallah. It was a favorable day for speed, with mild and clear weather.

There is a very respectable legal maxim which declares that no man can take advantage of his own wrong, and that is precisely what the Republican organization in this city and the Republican Party in this State are trying to do when they deprecate a Democratic success in this State as a "triumph of Tammany." In the first place, Tammany has no rational ambition to control the State of New-York.

There is, of course, no reason why a man may not at the same time hold the soundest literary views and be guilty of the shadiest moral practices. Nevertheless, we are so constituted that many of the admirers of SHAKESPEARE will consider the evidence of such practices that has been accumulated against IGNATIUS DONNELLY as what might have been expected from his attempt to prove that immortal dramas were constructed primarily as cryptograms.

The report of the British Commissioners upon the World's Fair at Chicago will undoubtedly have a very marked effect upon the public opinion, net merely of Great Britain, but of Europe, and this effect must be very favorable. The commission has visited Chicago and studied the plans and the preparations, and its recommendations are thus grounded upon actual knowledge.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. -- The joint debate to-night between John E. Russell and Henry Cabot Lodge, if it accomplishes nothing else, establishes a precedent. More of that sort of campaigning is likely to be seen and heard in the future. The subject chosen was of a very contracted and circumscribed nature. The "Administration of Gov. Russell" offered but few chances for serious attack.

A letter was received yesterday by the Police Commissioners from Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell, saying that the work exacted of the newly-appointed Police Matrons is more than they can stand. They are required, she says, to be on duty ten hours during the day and fourteen hours at night, and from 6 P.M. Saturday to 8 A.M. Monday, and are also obliged to climb the stairs about thirty times a day.

At the instance of John Hall McKay, a member of the graduating class, a petition has been signed by the old graduates praying for the restoration of the historic School, No. 35, at 60 West Thirteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, recently condemned and closed by the Board of Education. For many years Old Thirty-five had the reputation of being one of the best of the public schools in the city.

The officers of the Construction Department at the Brooklyn Navy Yard have received a semi-official notification from William Cramp Sons of Philadelphia stating that the date for the launching of the armored cruiser New-York will probably be Nov. 10. Judging by the preparations that are being made for the occasion, it will compare favorably with the launching of the cruiser Maine, which took place at the Brooklyn Navy Yard Nov. 18 of last year.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 23. -- The Senate met this morning and a new feature was injected into the proceedings when Senator Gobin offered a petition of prominent citizens of York County, asking that the Mercantile Appraiser and certain Aldermen of York County be investigated for like reasons to those applying to the magistrates and constables of Philadelphia.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 23. -- There was a heavy and holding track to-day at Pimlico and considerable money was dropped, for the backers of Kingmaker and Hoodlum were badly discomfited.

The recent gales have been making things very lively for mariners, and Captains of incoming vessels are ready to vouch that the Atlantic during the current month has been the most uncomfortable region to be found on the face of the earth.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The world of science was painfully startled to-day when it became known that Philip Herbert Carpenter, the distinguished scientist and high authority upon deep-sea dredging, whose death was announced yesterday, had committed suicide.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- John Devoy said to-day in answer to Michael Davitt's denial of statements made by Devoy in a speech here last Sunday:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Secretary Tracy and Gen. John W. Foster has a conference with the President this afternoon in regard to the Valparaiso incident, and at its close Secretary Tracy dictated the following as the latest official information on the subject:

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- From all parts of the provinces come reports announcing that a very large amount of damage has been done by the floods. In many cases the waters are still rising. There is a gap in the bank of the river Parrett, in Somersetshire, and through this opening the water is inundating the lowlands. The meadows in that locality are already submerged to the depth of four or five feet.

Secretary of State James G. Blaine remained at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday with Mrs. Blaine and his secretary, Mr. Dent. He will leave for Washington on the limited express this morning. Candidates Fassett and Vrooman were among those who were received by him yesterday.

Nothing that has occurred in many years in the relations of the importers of this city with the customs officers of the Federal Government has aroused so much indignation as the general attack upon the worsted importers from the Bradford district of England. The whole trade is charged with the undervaluation of its importations.

The action of the Philadelphia Board of Health with respect to the sanitary inspection of the sources of that city's supply of milk appears to have been caused by the influence of the University of Pennsylvania. This university has recently established a course of instruction in scientific methods of inspecting meat and milk.

ST. LOUIS, Me., Oct. 23. -- The Republic will to-morrow contain a long and carefully prepared statement of the condition of affairs among the railroads of Texas as a result of the commission's operations.

Theron H. Burden, the Republican candidate for Sheriff of Queens County, Dr. John T.D. Donnelly, and Frederick Hallet were arrested at their homes in Long Island City last night charged with altering names on a petition gotten up to which were attached the signatures of 500 independent Democrats for an independent ticket headed by Burden's name.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday it was ordered that in the police stations election night the returns be publicly announced as they are received by the officers in command, and that all the needed facilities be given to newspapers and news associations for the collection of the returns. It was also ordered that the returns be read in the courtroom at Police Headquarters.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 23. -- The importation of Welshmen by the tin-plate patriot Niedringhaus to work in his rolling mills has been taken before the Grand Jury. From statements made by all persons concerned it appears that several members of that august body are desirous of investigating the matter, but District Attorney Reynolds does not appear so anxious to push the work.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- There was published to-day the elaborate report of Sir Henry Wood and Mr. James Dredge, the British Commissioners who recently returned to this city after visiting Chicago, which was presented to the Royal Commission on Wednesday last. Sir Richard Webster, the Attorney General, presided at this meeting, at which Sir Philip Cunliffe Owen, Sir Frederick Abeel. Sir George Birdwood, and other distinguished members of the commission were present.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The all-absorbing topic of conversation among the undergraduates is football, and the comparative strength of the Yale and Princeton elevens.

There was not the usual noise and bustle about Mr. Platt's headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. The work is now all being done under cover, especially that part of it which is Platt's specialty. Gen. Husted, John W. Dwight, and the others were on duty most of the day, but no news was given out. The Republican news all came from other sources.

The Republicans held another ratification meeting at the Cooper Union last night. The meeting was under the auspices of the Republican Club. It was the most "milk-and-watery" ratification meeting of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Inquiry of officers of the Government in regard to the Valparaiso incident shows conclusively that the Administration does not regard it a simple street row for which the Chilean Government cannot be held accountable, but as an insult to the honor and flag of the United States, calling for the most vigorous diplomatic treatment.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Twenty-seven hundred persons witnessed the Yale-Orange football game on the oval this afternoon. Both the blue and the blue and orange were well represented in the crowd, and the teams were impartially applauded when they lined up as follows:

The little old building on Arch Street above Second, where Betsey Ross made the first flag of stars and stripes for the United States Army, is likely to be removed bodily and taken to Chicago for exhibition at the World's Fair. The building is owned by Mrs. Amelia Mund, and she has been asked to name a price for the property, the prospective purchaser being a Western gentleman.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Harvard stock rose to-day when the football eleven whitewashed Amherst with a score of 39 points. A cold northwest wind favored Amherst in the first half and Harvard in the second.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured on "Upper Egypt" before an audience of about 1,000 persons at the Museum of Natural History in Central Park yesterday morning. In addition to the teachers from this city and other places within convenient reach, many others who are interested in educational matters were present.

Since the popular refusal to recognize mutilated coins as money, there has been no use for five-cent nickels that have been punctured and plugged. Recently, however, the irrepressible New York boy has discovered a mission for those tabooed coins. The demand for five-cent pieces with holes in them has been increasing steadily of late, and tradesmen and saloon keepers who have been applied to for them could not understand the cause of the demand.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- A man giving the name of Charles Green and dressed as an American seaman surrendered himself to the police last evening, stating that he was wanted by the police of Philadelphia for a murder committed about six months ago. Green's statements were entered upon the blotter of the police station, and he was accommodated with a cell pending communication between Scotland Yard and Police Headquarters at Philadelphia.

SALEM, Mass., Oct. 24.--At the opening of the day's hearing on the Searles will this morning Mr. Burley began the cross-examination of Gen. Hubbard. Witness had thought and still thought that the copartnership papers were perfectly legal and valid under the law of New-York. He did not know whether Mrs. Searles ever had independent legal advice before signing the papers.

Last May the Scientific Alliance of New-York was formed by uniting the six leading societies in the city devoted to scientific research -- the New-York Academy of Sciences, the Torrey Botanical Club, the New-York Microscopical Society, the Linnaean Society of New-York, the New-York Mathematical Society, and the New-York Mineralogical Club.

Perhaps the most fashionably-attended wedding so far in the season was that which took place at high noon yesterday at the picturesque old Jay homestead, Bedford House, Katonah, Westchester, between Miss Beatrix Chapman, daughter of Mrs. Henry G. Chapman, and granddaughter of the Hon. John Jay, and George Barclay, Secretary of the British Legation at Washington, of Monkhams, Essex, England.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The weather has been extremely cold the greater part of this week, with a few flakes of snow. The cottagers have hugged cheerful fires closer than usual, and have been reminded of the rapid approach of Winter. It is said that persons who went on Graylock Mountain Wednesday encountered a brisk snowstorm.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24. -- A camera club has been organized by the men in college interested in amateur photography.

If Bragg had shown as much energy in the three days following Chickamauga as he did in that sanguinary conflict, he could have marched into Chattanooga without serious resistance, but a delay of forty-eight hours gave Thomas un opportunity to fall back with his own veterans and to reorganize the|corps of Crittenden and McCook.
BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- The freshmen have organized a football eleven.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- The great dietary attraction that has served to crowd Mechanics' Building for the past three weeks closes to-night in the very floodtide of its popularity. The public gladly would have sustained the food and health show or have allowed the food and health show to sustain it throughout the season had the managers and exhibitors seen tit to make the exhibition a permanent food and drink dispensary.

The earliest of the club elections are still a month or so distant, but the political bees are buzzing around already and improving each shining hour. Most of the clubs have anywhere from a dozen to twice as many offices to be filled, and there are generally half a dozen candidates, or would-be candidates, for each office. These would-be candidates are even now busily sowing seed, from which they expect to reap votes.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Bank of England's rate of discount remains unchanged, despite the alarmist rumors concerning the movement of bullion. The discount rates are rather weaker and the current quotations are one-eighth to one-quarter lower than a week ago. This fall has strengthened the demand for gold both from New-York and Germany, and a further and increasing demand is expected.

According to an arrangement made some weeks ago, members of the Executive Committee of the Driving Club have in turn gotten up a programme for Saturday afternoon at Fleetwood Park. Yesterday W.E. Parsons, Jr., succeeded in providing an attractive card for four races. His efforts were rewarded by an attendance, not only of members, but the public, numbering about 300.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- The question of cap and gown that has been raised in so many colleges lately is again being discussed among Wesleyan seniors, and it is probable that the custom will be adopted. At a meeting of the senior class Tuesday a committee was appointed to consider the question carefully and present a report to the class.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The annual Fall handicap meeting of the University Athletic Association was held this afternoon. Owing to a high wind directly against the short-distance runners, no records were broken. The track, however, was in good condition, and some very good new material appeared.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The coaches who for the past four weeks have had charge of the candidates for the Harvard Varsity eleven have gotten together a fine set of men, and now everything is in readiness for the coaching which Arthur Cumnock, Captain of lass year's team, is to give.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Augustin Daly said to-day concerning his London theatre:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 24. -- "Newport," a new play written by Clinton Stuart for W.H. Crane, was produced for the first time at Davidson's Theatre to-night to a crowded house. The play undertakes to delineate the different characters found at the fashionable resort, and to contrast the manners of old-fashioned Americans of established social position with the newly rich, striving for place.

At about the time that Thomas C. Platt began to feel the need of campaign funds Secretary Foster of the Treasury Department issued a circular regarding the disinfection of imported rags, which, when it is put into operation, will make possible a repetition of the scandalous methods of levying on importers, which brought the old "Rag Ring" into such notoriety some years ago.

A new stenographic association under the name of the "Stolze Shorthand Society of New-York," was formed yesterday at 325 East Thirteenth Street. The society, which is chiefly composed of German stenographers, was founded with the view of propagating the knowledge of the Stolze shorthand system which is widely used in Germany.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- The past week has been marked by the action of the upper classes which will virtually prohibit in the future all under-class rushes and will decide the under-class supremacy by a series of athletic contests, to be held annually under the direction of the upper classes. The contests will be a football game, a baseball game, and a contest for points at the Fall field day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Capt. F.A. Mahan of the Lighthouse Service may properly complain of the blundering manner in which the Lighthouse Board has introduced to the public the wrong one or two systematic arrangements of lights proposed by him to enable mariners to determine more readily whether they are safely off-shore or dangerously in-shore.

Several hundred people witnessed the members' games at Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. A cold wind blowing up the stretch precluded the possibility of any record performances being made. This was expressly the case with W.C. Dohm, America's half-mile champion, who made a trial at the 600-yard record and failed.

More candidates for the Senate, Assembly, and Board of Aldermen have put themselves on record in regard to the Battery grab. As usual, nearly everybody believes in ousting the squatter. Only one candidate declares himself in favor of grabs. He is Aaron D. Rhead, County Democracy candidate for Alderman in The Nineteenth District.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 24.--A train of thirteen cars loaded with coal was wrecked on the Columbus and Western Railroad near Goodwater this morning. As the train rounded a curve within a few yards of Hatchett Creek the engineer saw the trestle approach to the bridge on fire. It was too late to stop, and he pulled the throttle open in an attempt to cross by sheer force of speed.

The United States cruiser Boston left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock bound for Valparaiso, Chile. She proceeded down the bay under easy steam, but, instead of going at once to sea, she stopped off Tompkinsville and let go an anchor, to await the arrival of an express package from the Navy Department.

Of the principal soloists of the Bostonians, eight started as singers in church choirs. Two months ago Caroline Hamilton, the prima donna, was soprano of the Rev. Dr. McKenzie's First Presbyterian Church, San Francisco. She gave it up to join the Bostonians. Jessie Bartlett Davis, the contralto, sang in the Rev. Dr. Brooke Herford's church in Boston.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Big scores were recorded to-day by the New-Jersey Shooting Club. There was a strong wind, which did not contribute to good work at the five traps. Out of eight events first men in seven did not miss a single target. There were several ties left undecided. In five events G. De Witt Smith shot blue rock pigeons to perfection.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- At a meeting of the creditors of Harrison Loring, proprietor of the City Point Iron Works, the liabilities were stated to be $495,000, and the assets, on a basis of continuing the work, $563,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Great interest is being taken by the students and Faculty of Syracuse University in football this season. Two teams have been organized. Jordan C. Wells, for four years with the Wesleyan University team, is the new professional trainer. Several games have already been played, and with each the representative team of the university has shown marked improvement.

Ivy Stanbury had never been in the South before. So everything burst full upon her with all the charm of novelty. As they reached Antibes Station the sun was setting. A pink glow from his blood-red orb lit up the snowy ridge of the Maritime Alps with fairy splendor. It was a dream of delight to those eager young eyes, fresh from the fog and frost and brooding gloom of London.

THE TIMES has several times called to the attention of President Beers of the New-York Life the fact that the best is always the cheapest in the end. Of life insurance and life insurance contracts this is especially true. Policies sold at enormous rebates are always devised with actuarial cunning, to draw from the insured far more than the rebate offered in selling him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Some months ago a young man named Hains shot and killed another young man, his particular friend, named Hannegan, in a boat at Fort Monroe. Hains was tried and amazement followed his acquittal. Immediately returning to Washington, Hains was soon reported, by the father of the murdered man, to be persistently annoying him by what looked like atrociously cruel actions.

We confess to a feeling of considerable incredulity as to the stories now being sent to all quarters of the globe in regard to the situation at Rome of his Holiness LEO XIII. The interpretations put upon the untoward incident of Oct. 2 bear suspicious marks of embroidery, and by very skillful and trained hands.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 24. -- There has been nothing eventful in society circles to call for special reference the past week. The inauguration of the weekly naval receptions bespeaks an opening of the Winter season in good earnest.

Fire broke out at 196 and 202 North Union Street, Chicago, yesterday morning, and destroyed two buildings, partly of frame and partly of brick, three stories and basement. Nothing remains but a portion of the lower walls. The block was used by a manufactory of picture frames and moldings, and as storerooms for stock. The occupants were Starr Weir and the Hadly Manufacturing Company.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 24. -- Class officers for the coming year here been chosen as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Winter began in Russia on Thursday with the first sharp frost. Living men cannot remember any other year in which this simple announcement meant what it does now. There are literally millions of human beings, at the furthest within a six days' journey of London, to whom this frost comes as a sentence of death by starvation.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 24. -- There was royal sport at Cumberland Track this afternoon for the closing of the Western-Southern circuit, which has been on for ten weeks, starting at Chicago in August. The weather was like Summertime, and the horses reeled off the miles with the greatest ease in the warm air.

The recommendation of Gen. A. MCD. MC COOK in his annual report that San Diego should have accommodations for a regiment of infantry, a battalion of cavalry, and a battery of artillery seems to be a sound one. San Diego is our southernmost post on the Pacific, only about a dozen miles from the Mexican border.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- A striking illustration of the wonders accomplished by the McKinley bill is shown in this week's issue of the Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association, the organization which probably had more influence than any other in having the duties increased on many products of iron and steel.

If Thomas C. Platt imegines that he has lulled the Kings County Democracy to sleep by his little trick of putting up a weak city and county ticket he will find that he has been very much mistaken or has taken some very bad counsel. There never was a time during the past six years when the Democratic leaders in Brooklyn were as much aroused over an election as they are now.

The death of Mr. Parnell recalls the desperate onslaught made on him by the London Times, continuing unremittingly for years, and which culminated in the appointment by Parliament of a commission to pass on the entire matter in controversy.

ST. Louis, Oct. 24. -- It was learned this evening that United States District Attorney Reynolds is considering the matter of proceeding against the druggists' combine, otherwise known as the St. Louis Apothecaries' Association. This association is an organization formed to benefit the drug trade, one of the objects being the keeping up of the price of drugs and patent medicines.

There could be no better evidence of the importance which Republican politicians attach to the bearing of the State election upon the national campaign than the success of such pressure for harmony as has brought WARNER MILLER into line as a campaign speaker and induced GIBBS and COWIE to shake hands on the same platform in the Thirteenth Assembly District of this city.

Capt. William E. Peirce, who died Friday afternoon at his home, 487 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, was one of the best-known members of the Custom House force. He was born on Feb. 22, 1844, in Portsmouth, Va. At the age of eighteen he was a bonded staff officer in the Confederate Army in charge of the post at Raleigh, N.C.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 24. -- The passing of the Yale entrance examination by Miss Coit of New-London may not have been in vain. The public discussion created thereby last June has been followed by a quiet discussion among members of the Yale Faculty and of the corporation and others, and has developed the fact that Yale is not so much opposed to the admission of women as has been supposed. To quote one of the Faculty:

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24. -- Defalcations, like misfortunes, never come singly, and the Garcia theft of $190,000 is followed by several smaller ones. To-day Alfred Lugenbuhl was arrested for embezzling $10,000 from his employer, Charles Ballejo, one of the leading grocers of the city. Lugenbuhl is now a man of thirty-three.

Three or four times the past week the market has taken a little start as if it were going to do something, but it hasn't. Once or twice it dropped just before the close in a way ludicating that the next morning it would be severely raided, but next morning there was nothing done.

William Martin, the plucky little youth from Detroit, is now the champion long-distance bicyclist of the world. He won that distinction and about $2,000 in the race that ended in Madison Square Garden last night. At the finish the building was crowded and hundreds were clamoring for admission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- Encouraged by the success of the Country Club at Bala, near the city, and of the Germantown Club's season at Manheim, Germantown, the Merion Cricket Club has decided to fall in line with the procession. The Merion Club in days past was famous for its cricketers, but in recent years has been outshone.

Six years ago an article in the Nineteenth Century, an abstract of certain of these essays, was published, and this paper, due to Prof. Shipley, at once attracted the attention of biologists to Dr. August Weismann. In the volume under notice there are eight essays, beginning with one entitled "The Duration of Life" and concluding with "The Supposed Transmission of Mutilations," all forming part of the main study of "Heredity."

It is not necessary to repeat the arguments, now so familiar, that the absolute protection of the secrecy of the ballot is distinctly in the interest of the Democratic Party. The reason is obvious. That party includes a large proportion of the voters who are liable to intimidation by those upon whom they depend for employment, and subject to temptation, on account of their poverty, to sell their votes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Major P.C. Pope, Capt. R.S. Callum, Capt. D.P. Mannix, and First Lieut. T.C. Price, recently appointed by the Colonel Commandant of the Marine Corps to prepare a plan for the reorganization of the corps, have submitted a report, with the proposed changes embodied in a bill to be submitted to Congress.

LOON LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- A few days ago a number of Franklin County guides were grouped in the office of one of the best-known resorts in the Adirondacks. They were examining, with absorbed interest, an old weather-beaten rifle which Henry Fadden, a member of Hartwell's new lumber camp, had by the merest accident literally stumbled against in the heart of the wilderness.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Superintendent of Banking Charles M. Preston has issued a statement regarding the Ulster County Savings Institution. The plan proposed is to induce depositors to leave their money for two years without interest and at the end of that time get it in full, while those who draw our their deposits will have them scaled down 15 per cent. Superintendent Preston's statement is as follows:

The accounts given by Capt. HEALY of the revenue cutter Bear and Agent JACKSON, who has general charge of education in Alaska, of the plans for introducing the reindeer into that Territory are rather encouraging. There are great numbers of these useful animals in Eastern Siberia, under conditions of climate and food supply -- which latter chiefly consists of moss -- not greatly differing from those that are found on our side of Bering Sea.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- A large crowd of Princeton supporters saw the university eleven defeat the New-York Athletic Club at football this afternoon by a score of 28 to 0. The perfect weather proved conducive to good football. From start to finish every point was well contested, and both teams played with spirit. Princeton's spirit was probably due to a Yale man captaining the opposing side.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 24. -- Dr. V.P. Clayton, the Republican Postmaster, made a speech to the negroes of Barnwell County this week, advising them to break away from the old Republican political machine. He took the position that the interests of the colored race are identical with those of the white race; that there ought not to be any race antagonism, and that the races should come together to bring about the beet results.

The recently organized cycling department of the Staten Island Athletic Club held its first race meet and team tournament at the club's grounds, West Brighton, yesterday afternoon. The event was a very successful one, and there were several interesting races, but the cool weather and strong wind prevented fast time. It was the first bicycle meet on the track, and A.B. Rich was paced a mile for a track record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25. -- The Russian colony here is in a state of excitement over a challenge to mortal combat sent to the Russian Consul by a well-known physician. The affair arose from troubles in the Russian Greek Church in this city, which is in charge of Bishop Vladimir of the Diocese of Alaska.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- The new Tariff act cannot be promulgated before the end of the present year, therefore there will not be sufficient time to make it the subject of negotiations between the powers before the treaties with them lapse. The Government, accordingly, will introduce in the Chamber of Deputies a bill to authorize them to establish commercial relations with foreign nations during the year 1892.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25. -- Trouble has sprung up among the priests and laymen who are managing the preparations for the celebration of Archbishop Kenrick's golden jubilee, that threatens to cause the great demonstration to be abandoned. There have been several controversies during the progress of the preparations over various questions, but they all dwindle into insignificance when compared with to-day's developments.

In our Washington dispatches this morning will be found an abstract of the argument by Mr. TAFT, Solicitor General, in favor of the constitutionality of the Tariff act of 1890. We have very little doubt that the Supreme Court will find some means of sustaining the act, for the consequences of now declaring it void would be more serious than the court -- which is not courageous -- would care to face.

We have scanned the columns of our high-tariff contemporaries for some denunciation of the members of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers who ask that the Grand Jury in St. Louis shall indict Mr. NIEDRINGHAUS for having violated the law relating to the importation of labor under contract, but they are not inclined to defend their tin-plate champion.

Many of the delegates to the recent Ecumenical Council of the Methodist Church, at Washington, and particularly those delegates who come from abroad, attended St. John's Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Fifty-third Street, yesterday morning, to hear the Rev. Dr. James M. King preach on "Men and Work of the Second Ecumenical Methodist Conference." Dr. King was Secretary of the conference throughout its sessions, and he was also Secretary of its Business Committee.

Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE evidently does not share the view of some of his friends that national issues have nothing to do with this year's election in New-York. In his speech on Saturday evening he devoted a great deal more attention to them than he did to State issues, and made it entirely plain that he regarded the former as much the more interesting and important.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 25. -- The great cricket match between Lord Hawke's eleven and the eleven Gentlemen of Eastern Canada was concluded on the Rideau Hall grounds yesterday. The result was a win for Lord Hawke's team by an inning and 84 runs.

Party majorities laboriously figured out of registration tables are much less trustworthy than enlightened guesswork, but the tables show beyond any doubt that a very large vote will be cast in this city and Brooklyn. In 1888, with a registration of 286,570, there were 274,570 votes cast for the Presidential Electors, showing an abstention of a little over 4 per cent. of the qualified voters.

For some days the Republican managers have been counting heavily upon the support of independent voters, because a few prominent independents had decided to vote for Mr. Fassett. The following important document, an address to Democratic and in dependent voters of the State of New-York, has just been issued. It contains a large amount of valuable information which it will be well for voters to take into consideration:

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The last thing which foreigners who study the contemporary history of a country get to understand is the part played in the making of that history by powerful journalists. No Englishman, for example, comprehends in the least the influence upon the American civil war exerted by editor-politicians like Horace Greeley and Thurlow Weed.

There appeared in Monday's Recorder, an alleged "independent journal," a most wicked libel on the Hon. Roswell P. Flower, in which the writer, one Roger B. Towner, maliciously assails Mr. Flower's war record. No person knowing Mr. Flower would for one moment give credence to such stuff as is stated by Towner, and no person knowing Towner would believe him under oath or otherwise.

A few months ago we described some of the experiments by which CELI in France, LEMSTROM in Finland, and SPECHNEFF in Southern Russia have shown how great an influence may be exerted upon plant life by electricity, and suggested that eventually it might be possible for market gardeners to use the electric current profitably.

The financial relations that exist between the New-York Life Insurance Company and its agents is one of the most fruitful themes upon which to base charges of mismanagement against President Beers. It was this subject, in fact, that led to the present exposures growing out of the defalcation of Merzbacher, who, as an accredited agent of the company, was enabled to steal over $700,000 of its money.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Times, commenting upon the assault upon sailors of the United States man-of-war Baltimore at Valparaiso, says that, admitting the perfect accuracy of the account of the affair told by Judge Foster, who has been conducting the inquiry into the matter, it shows no justification or excuse for retaliatory violence on the part of the Chilean mob.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25. -- The decision of Judge Caldwell, intended to settle the controversy between Sedalia, Mo., and Parsons, Kan., over the location of the general offices of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, is the reigning subject of discussion among railroad men here. There has been considerable doubt as to just what the decision meant, and the controversy is apparently not yet at an end.

YORK, Penn., Oct. 25. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Chauncey F. Black has just returned from a trip through the West, and he comes home with re-renewed interest in the issue of a Constitutional Convention for ballot reform in Pennsylvania.

Officers of the Secret Service Bureau in this city are sending out circulars, based on the new law which prohibits anybody from holding counterfeit money, except in special cases where a license is issued, allowing the retention of amounts of less than $500. In its terms the law is very stringent. The way in which it proposes to destroy counterfeits is thus set forth in a letter sent out by United States Treasurer Nebecker:
Robert Bonner, the owner of Sunol, said to a reporter of THE TIMES, when speaking of the recent performance of that great mare:

A stout, well-dressed woman, with a parrot and a roll of music under one arm, and a parasol and her purse in one hand entered a crowded Third Avenue elevated car last evening. She had no sooner taken her sent than she began to pet the bird, whose yellow head at intervals bobbed up to view through a hole in the cover of the hatbox in which it was traveling.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- The cornerstone of Tufts new Divinity Building was laid to-day. The coldness of the day served to keep many away and made the services somewhat brief. Among those present were President Capen, A.A. Miner, D.D.; T.J. Sawyer, Dean of the Divinity School; Prof. Charles H. Leonard of the Theological School; the Hon. J.D.W. Joy, President of the Trustees, and the Hon. Newton Tabbott, Treasurer of the college.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- There is a suspicion in the minds of a good many persons in Washington that the Administration has found the attack of the Chilean mob upon our sailors to be an extremely opportune broil. A party of men from the Baltimore, on shore for exercise, seem to have had trouble with some Chileans, and the Americans, being, according to all accounts, unarmed, were most severely injured.

PITTtBURG, Oct. 25. -- A Post ;Vest Newton (Penn.) special says: "Officers Jones and Davlson of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad thls morning arrested Edward Lute for attinptlug to wreck a passenger train last night by placing a telegraph pole across the rails. Luoo fled when discovered, and the officers chased him several ratios through woods and swamps to his father's house.

The current week is one of uncommon interest in Episcopal Church circles. One hundred and twenty-five years ago the ceremonies connected with the consecration of St. Paul's Chapel, at Broadway and Fulton Street, were witnessed by the then leading society of New-York. This event took place Thursday, Oct. 30, 1766. The first regular church service was held in the chapel the Sunday following.
Among the passengers on board the Columbia, which arrived yesterday, was Mrs. Booth-Clibborn, a sister of Gen. Ballington Booth, the chief of the Salvation Army.

Writers of farce-comedy might puzzle their brains until their hair turned gray and then not think of anything half so funny as a little story of mistaken identity that comes from Long Island City, and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club will begin at the Bennings track to-morrow morning. All of the horses that have been at the Baltimore, and a number of others that have come from the East and West are to contest for the purses. Over 400 horses are in the stables, so that a good meeting is assured.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Pere Hyacinthe delivered an address in the Galliean Church here to-day on behalf of the movement for the revision of the Concordat. There was large audience present, including many members of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies. The Speaker disclaimed any intention to attack the Catholic religion, but he condemned superstitious abuses, such as the Lourdes vision and the Treves coat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25. -- A wonderful lake, named Alia Pakai, has been discovered on the Hawaiian Islands. Its waters are more salt than those of the Dead Sea. Samples of the water have been recently analyzed in the laboratory of Oahu College, with results of popular as well as scientific interest.

The Hon. Samuel R. Thayer, United States Minister to the Netherlands, was at the Gilsey House yesterday. He said that he was on a leave of absence, which allowed him to remain forty days in this country. During that time he expected to visit Western New-York, call on the authorities of the State Department at Washington, and visit his home in Minnesota.

The Schaus Galleries have a few specimens of work by pretty much every nationality -- French, German, American, Italian, and Russian. John Sargent's portrait of Thomas B. Reed, formerly Speaker of the House, is a picture without salient qualities; one misses the sensational element Mr. Sargent is apt to introduce into portraits of children and of ladies. He has made Mr. Reed out a decidedly commonplace large person, with a very thick neck.
