An entertainment has been arranged for Friday night by the New-York Scottish Society to celebrate the Hallowe'en festival. "A Night with Sir Walter Scott" is the subject of an illustrated lecture written by Peter Ross, that will be delivered by Charles H. Govan, and songs will be given by Mrs. Olivia Campbell Shafer, Miss Josephine McPherson, and Mr. Harry Foresman. The entertainment will be held in the Carnegie Music Hall, (Recital Hall.)

The one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of America Methodism and of the founding of the old John Street Church was duly observed yesterday at that church. In the morning was a love feast led by the Rev. J.M. Freeman and a sermon by the Rev. William Gorman of Belfast, Ireland. Mr. Gorman is from the same county as Philip Embury, the founder of the church.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 26. -- Twelve months ago Mr. George Babcock Hazard of this city was reputed to be one of its wealthiest citizens. He was somewhat eccentric in his habits.

An event has just happened in St. Louis which shows both how easy and how dangerous it is for an ecclesiastic to be wholly out of touch with public opinion. Archbishop KENRICK, a good prelate, who has never aroused any unnecessary antagonisms, is about to celebrate his "golden jubilee," and his Vicar General has taken this occasion to excite an antagonism that is perfectly unnecessary and very threatening.

The Board of General Appraisers decided the great worsted case yesterday, and decided it in accordance with the prediction of THE TIMES, in favor of the importers. The invoices were sustained in every instance, except in the few in which 5 per cent. commissions were deducted from the cost of the goods, and in those cases the only change was to allow the deduction of 2 1/2 per tout. instead of 5.

QUEEN CITY, Texas, Oct. 26. -- The negro, Lee Green, who murdered the family of Farmer Lowe, seven miles west of Queen City, Saturday, was arrested last night near Kildare and hurried to jail at Linden.
The following address to the young men of the State of New-York has been issued by the Sub-Executive Committee of the State League of Democratic Clubs:

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 26. -- The Senate retraced its steps to-night, and in spite of the fact that it had agreed to the introduction of testimony in the McCamant case and spent three long sessions last week in listening to the evidence taken before the majority committee, it decided by a strict partisan vote to take up the Boyer case to-morrow and hear counsel for the defense.
PANAMA, Oct. 16. -- Chile has relapsed into a state of peace, there being no longer any armed troops against the Government.

The explanations submitted by M. RIBOT, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, to the French Chamber of Deputies yesterday, touching affairs in Egypt, Morocco, and Italy, are reported to have been received with applause, particularly by members of the Left. But they were certainly vague.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker opened this afternoon proposals for supplying the proposed increase in the ocean mail service under the act of March 3, 1891. The provisions of this act, in the main, are as follows:

Two or three days ago we spoke of a list of 122 articles of dry goods in common use which had been prepared by one of the largest houses in Boston at the request of Gov. RUSSELL of Massachusetts, and which showed that after the passage of the McKinley bill with higher duties on these goods the prices of them had been increased.

When Secretary Foster issued his recent order which allows Mr. Thomas C. Platt's rag disinfecting machine to levy tribute from rag importers he interfered with the perfect working of so many State laws that his action has caused a great deal of surprise on the part of those who are at all familiar with the quarantine law.

The indications are that party lines will be rather closely drawn in the Massachusetts election this year, and the question is whether that line will run in a new place. The Democrats are undoubtedly united and enthusiastic in support of their candidates, but they need the help of a good many who have not heretofore been Democrats.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The beginning of the new fast-train service of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad this morning, from New-York to Buffalo, was a success in every way. The train, which is to be called Empire State Express, left New-York with almost every seat taken, and among the most interested passengers was a Chinaman, who seemed to enjoy every minute that the train was wheeling up the Hudson River route.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered the estimates of the Park Department yesterday. Last year's appropriation was $907,863.32. The amount asked for 1892 was $1,074,545, and the amount appropriated was $963,150. Commissioners Gallup and Tappen had some trouble in convincing the board that policemen's salaries should be raised from $1,000 to $1,100 per year.
Property owners were much interested in two decisions made public recently involving title to the beds of the old roadways, now closed, known as the Harlem and the Bloomingdale Roads.

At West Point, the National Military Academy, the healthy conservatism that preserves with jealous care all relics and traditions of bygone days has full swing. Nearly everything that takes rank as a connecting link between past and present is, however, locked up safely from prying eyes and itching fingers. The corps of cadets possesses a single relic, which it holds in fee simple and looks upon with undimmed pride.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 26. -- If the average Canadian were asked what he knows about Leadville he would be able at least to say that it is a well-known mining camp in the United States; but ask him where and what is kootenay, and there is act one chance in ten that he will know that it is a new mining field in British Columbia, often now referred to by Americans as a second Leadville.

For every promise made there must come a time for its fulfillment. The practice of putting out estimates of expected results on life insurance policies dates back some twenty years. The day of reckoning has arrived and the result is dissatisfaction. One of these cases was recently reported by a man who took out several large policies in the New-York Life in 1871.

Rather slight incidents connected with the Chilean question occurred yesterday. Mr. BLAINE had a long conference with the President and the Secretary of the Navy, and afterward it was announced that the San Francisco had been ordered from Callao to the Mare Island Navy Yard to have her bottom cleaned.

A letter from Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT to Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE is published expressing the writer's "hearty good wishes for the success of Mr. FASSETT and the Republican ticket," and giving some reasons for entertaining such wishes. These are couched in Mr. ROOSEVELT'S usual style, emphatic and unqualified, and no one can doubt the sincerity with which they are held.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Without having received any additional information from Chile, and in the absence of any news justifying a prolongation of the "war feeling" that was rather prematurely encouraged for a day or two by the Administration, it was decided to-day that it would be becoming and dignified to await the action of Chile, upon the requests of our Minister to that republic, before proceeding to hostilities to compel reparation and indemnity.

FOO-CHOO, China, Sept. 28. -- The Chinese Government has decided to begin an establishment for the instruction of Chinese naval officers in the handling of modern torpedoes and for the manufacture of these weapons for the supply of the war ships and defense of the coast cities. The land, an island several miles below this place, has been selected.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 26. -- By a boiler explosion here this afternoon one man was probably killed, several persons injured, and nearly half a million dollars worth of property was destroyed.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, Oct. 26. -- The United States Government to-day, through Minister Egan, formally demanded reparation from the Government of Chile for the attack recently made in Valparaiso upon a number of the seamen of the United States cruiser Baltimore. The demand is no informal suggestion that the Government at Washington expects some kind of satisfaction for the killing and wounding of the Baltimore's sailors.

I had a letter in preparation in regard to what, to me, seems practical as to the duty of those who, with myself, so ardently desire real ballot reform, when my attention was called to the able letter of Gov. Chamberlain in this morning's TIMES. He expresses my own ideas so much more forcibly than I possibly could that it seems superfluous for me to furnish it.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Deloncle interpellated the Ministers, asking them to explain their policy toward Egypt, the position they had taken on the questions at issue with Morocco in the matter of the Touat cases and the alleged British intrigues on the Tonqnin frontier. M. Delafosee also demanded that the Ministry make explanations in regard to the relations between France and Italy.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Oct. 26. -- This week closes the meeting at the kite-shaped track here, and two of the three events set for to-day were decided. It was bright and clear, but the wind increased to a gale and greatly handicapped the horses coming down the last half.

The ballot-reform issue figured very little in the speeches, and that altogether with reference to the past. Gov. HILL was condemned for the paster-ballot device, and the credit of favoring the genuine form of Australian ballot was claimed for the Republicans. But this question has assumed a new phase with reference to the future, and is worthy of a little discussion.

The last week of the campaign in Brooklyn promise to be a very lively one in the matter of meetings. Over seventy will be held before the week close on Saturday night, and of these forty will be under Democratic auspices. The most important will be the big rally at the Academy of Music to-morrow night. This will be second only to the great reception accorded to ex-President Cleveland at the Clermont Avenue Rink.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The annual Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club opened at Bennings to-day with perfect racing weather and the best class of horses that has been seen here since the club started, several years ago, to revive running at this old ante-bellum track. The attendance was good, including a number of ladies.

A clever swindler who has been passing himself off largely in Brooklyn, and to some extent in this city, as Count Roderick von Graff of Russia has taken a hasty departure for parts unknown. The immediate cause of his departure was the detection of a well-planned scheme of his to negotiate about $50,000 worth of forged notes.

Last week seemed to carry as far as could be expected the breaking of records on what must be called the "trotting" turf, though two of the most remarkable records were those made by the pacer Direct, one of the fastest miles ever paced in a race, and the other of the three fastest consecutive heats ever made in harness.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26. -- Gen. Beauregard, who is said to have been indicted by the United States Grand Jury in South Dakota, is now in St. Louis, and was seen this evening by a reporter.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26. -- At to-day's meeting of the Evangelical Alliance the topic for discussion was "The Educational Interests of St. Louis." Some exceedingly animated speeches were made by several ministers, culminating in the following resolutions being offered and adopted:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26. -- Notwithstanding the equivocal answers and even flat denials of United States District Attorney Reynolds, it is a fact that four of the men imported by ex-Congressman Niedringhaus have been summoned to appear before the United States Grand Jury to-morrow and tell under oath the story of their coming to America.

FOO-CHOO, China, Sept. 28. -- The Chinese Foreign Office has not yet succeeded in satisfying the demands of the foreign powers, as formulated by the joint note of the Ministers at Pekin in reference to the outrages committed upon foreign residents and missionaries in the Yang-tse Valley during the past Spring and Summer.

Of course, the Republican meeting in the attractive Madison Square Garden, which is well worth seeing when there is no charge for admission, was a large one, and there was considerable display of party enthusiasm, but the speaking was of a singularly ineffective order. Mr. WARNER MILLER did not seem to feel at home, and his address was a painfully labored effort.

NOHWICH, Conn., Oct. 6. -- A good idea of the extraordinary lateness of the Fall in Connecticut is furnished by the fact that there has been no frost as yet severe enough to kill flowers and garden plants. The grass is still green in Connecticut pastures and mowing lots, and the foliage of forest trees is almost as heavy it was in August.

Wall Street had a blue Monday yesterday. There was little activity and not much strength shown in anything. Two or three specialties rose and one or two went off easily, but as a whole the market showed only sluggishness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- Capt. C.C. Warner, United States Indian Agent for Nevada, has received a dispatch from Monida, Mon., informing him of the death of Sarah Winnemucca, the Piute princess. Sarah was visiting her sister, who is married to a white man, at the time of her death.

Jacob Schaefer, the famous billiardist, known all aver the billiard-playing world as "the Wizard," suffered the worst defeat of his life last night in a match game with George Slosson, "the student." In a fourteen-inch balk line game, 800 points up, he was beaten by 408 points.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- Col. J.H. Woodard, who holds confidential relations with C.P. Huntington, prints the following in defense of Timothy Hopkins and his mother, Mrs. Nolan:

NEWARK, Oct. 27. -- Carl F.R. Hartmann, Superintendent of the money order department at the Post Office here, was suspended by Postmaster Conklin this afternoon pending an examination of his accounts. Hartmann succeeded Caspar Loer, who is now undergoing a term for embezzlement from the money order department.

At a union meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Eugince s, the Order of Railroad Conductors, and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, held at Sedalia Mo., a committee was appointed to arrange for a meeting with the view of federating all employes of the Missouri and Pacific systems.

The great Democratic meeting of the business men of New York in Madison Square Garden last night was mainly an exhibition of interest in the political campaign and a display of enthusiasm for the party cause. The great amphitheatre was simply thronged with a solid mass of people.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- At no time in the recent history of this city have its people been engaged in a political canvass that had in it so many interesting features or carried with it so many important results as the one now in progress. This does not arise from the inherent value of the offices to be filled, but from the influences behind the opposing candidates.

Brooklyn Democrats were making great preparations yesterday for the big mass meeting at the Academy of Music to-night. Over 3,000 tickets for it have been issued already, and those who want to get in at all will do well to go early. Gen. Henry W. Slocum will certainly preside and Gov. Hill will make the principal speech.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 27. -- There was a very slight earthquake shock felt here by three persons Monday morning early. Two shocks, not heavy, were felt in Charleston.
ALBANY, Oct. 27. -- In his minority opinion in the decision of the Second Division of the Court of Appeals in the Tilden will case, Judge Bradley says:

CORK, Oct. 27. -- William O'Brien and John Dillon arrived here to-day and were met by a deputation composed of members of the National Federation, representatives of the Gaelic Club, the municipal officers, and a large number of priests. As the procession passed through the streets there was considerable hissing and several stones crashed through a large portrait of William O'Brien which was carried in the parade.
The twenty-fifth annual merging of St. John's Guild of the City of New-York was held last night at the Hotel Brunswick, about forty members being present.

The second recital of Alfred and Heinrich Grunfeld at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last evening, was attended by a large and generously-disposed audience. After a second hearing, it is possible to arrive at something like a definite conclusion in regard to the merits of those two musicians. Together, they are a combination in which there is much merit, for their mastery of ensemble playing is full and instructive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- While temperate indignation ought to be felt by every American at the killing of American sailors by a Chilean mob in Valparaiso, the course of the Administration has been marked by an incident or two that will justify the prudent in suspending judgment until the explanation demanded from the Junta has been made.

The New-York Democracy fired the heaviest gun of the campaign last night. A mass meeting of Democrats was held in the big Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Business Men's Democratic Association. Fully 18,000 people succeeded in crowding into the great amphitheatre. The meeting was probably the greatest that New-York has ever witnessed, not excepting those held during the excitement of Presidential campaigns.

The putting of the Miantonomoh into commission yesterday was a naval event of national importance. It marks an epoch in the development of the American Navy by which the type of "coast defender" is added to the type of "commerce destroyer," of which we have already many examples, though by no means so many as the national exigencies demand.

The decision rendered yesterday by the Court of Appeals that the Tilden will is invalid brings to an end one of the most famous will contests that have ever been carried on in this country. Since Samuel J. Tilden died, in August, 1886, the disposition of his great estate has been held in abeyance. The matter is now settled.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Oct. 27. -- The feature at the driving park to-day was the performance of the yearling pacer Rolla, by Jerome Eddy, the youngster making a mile in 2:28 1/2, and beating his own champion mark of 2:31. Ralph Wilkes, the sensational two-year-old from Kentucky recently sent here in charge of C.W. Williams, was driven in 2:18 1/2, lowering his record of 2:19 1/2.

It is plain that Mr. BOODY is making an excellent canvass himself, and equally plain that his election does not seem so secure or so easy as it ought to be. He has received a very considerable support from independent Republicans, but we do not think that it has been as great or as general as it should have been under the circumstances.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 27. -- "Chapleau has resigned." This was the rumor that flashed from one end of the city to the other to-day, following upon the statement made editorially in the Government organ, the Empire, last evening, that he need look for no promotion in the Cabinet, but would have to remain Secretary of State and clear up the irregularities of his department.

Everett F. Wheeler has made report to the Supreme Court as referee in an action brought against S.J. Geoghegan and Charles J. Gilles by Jacob Senn, the proprietor of the Hotel Lafayette Annex, at 10 Waverley Place, in favor of the plaintiff, awarding him $1,641.07 damages. Mr. Senn sued to recover damages because of the maintenance in the street near his hotel of two boilers from July to October, 1890.

ALBANY, Oct. 27. -- The Second Division Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the judgment of the lower court, declaring the Tilden trust to be invalid. The opinion is written by Judge Brown, and is concurred in by Chief Judge Follet and Judges Haight and Parker.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 27. -- The meeting of the Southwestern Railway and Steamship Association to-day resulted in little or nothing because of the absence of Mr. Ripley of Houston, who will be given time to reach the city before definite action is taken in the matter of through cotton rates. The Rate Committee of the association, however, disposed of a number of outstanding questions connected with the details of the oranization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Though Secretary Tracy has not yet announced the name of Cruiser No. 9, building alongside the Detroit at the Columbian Iron Works, Baltimore, it is understood he has concluded to name her the Mobile.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 27. -- J. W. Bruce of Canastota, N. Y., Prohibition candidate for Governor, addressed a good-sized audience here last night. He attacked the Church in such a manner as to lose many friends.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The Fall meeting of the Trustees of Rutgers College was hold this afternoon. Among the important affairs considered was that of a change in the curriculum for elective courses and university extension. On the latter, President Scott and Prof. Bevier have been hard at work for some months.
In the seventh column of its editorial page on the 23d inst. the Chicago Inter Ocean sought to explain in this way the recent reduction of wages at Mr. CARNEGIE'S great steel-rail factory:

Joaquin Sanchez, sometimes known as J. Sanchez y Larragoites, the nominal head of the Spanish-American department of the New-York Life, arrived in the city Monday on the French transatlantic steamer La Gascogne in response to a summons sent him ten or twelve days ago by direction of the State Superintendent of Insurance.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The health of Mrs. Parnel now shows some slight signs of improvement. At her request, the papers of Mr. Parnell have been placed in sealed boxes and deposited in the vaults of the Bank of Brighton.

An important feature of the Worthen plan of construction of the rapid-transit railroad reported by the Rapid-Transit Commission last week, and which will probably came up before the Board of Aldermen for consideration to-day, is the alteration and improvement that it will effect in subterranean Broadway. In the general discussion of the plans which has followed the publication of the report this feature has escaped general attention.

STOCKTON, Cal., Oct. 27. -- Pale Alto lowered his record here to-day, trotting the mile without a skip in 2:10, the quarters being 0:32, 0:31 1/2, 0:33, and 0:33 1/2. The half mile in 1:03 1/2 is the best time made by a stallion for the distance.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 27. -- The Executive Board of the National Trade Assembly No. 231, Garment Workers of North America. Knights of Labor, has issued a "special red letter" from its Chicago headquarters, urging the members of the order in this State to work against the election of Judge Rosendale for Attorney General.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- Senator Leland Stanford, in his mad pursuit of the Presidency, prints a long editorial in the Weekly Argus, his personal organ, this week, in which the California millionaire makes some ridiculous claims for the Presidential nomination. Among other things appears the following:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 97. -- Ex-Senator George O. Vanderbilt, a prominent lawyer of this county, who resides at Princeton and who is the head of the George O. Vanderbilt Iron and Furnace Company in Alabama, was charged with some serious offenses before Chancellor McGill today. William J. Fordney of Lancaster, Penn., through his counsel, petitioned for an injunction to prevent Vanderbilt from disposing of a lot in Princeton.

The first of a new set of acquisitions of Indian domains has just been effected by the Cherokee Commissioners, who have procured from the Tonkawas a cession of 80,000 acres. This tribe occupies the old Nez Perce Reservation in the Cherokee Outlet, comprising 90,711 acres, so that it parts with more than four-fifths of its land.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 27. -- The Bonaventura Stud of the late Gen. John F. Wheeless was disposed of at auction here to-day, fifty-two head being sold for a total of $14,645, an average of $281.63. Twenty-nine head belonging to other parties were sold for $11,590, swelling the day's sale to $26,235 for a total of eighty-one head, a general average of $326.36.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 27. -- The hitherto inexplicable action of the Senate in suddenly shutting off the taking of testimony yesterday was made clear to-day. The Republican members of the Senate had in some way discovered that Attorney General Hensel had come into possession of a document that goes to show that United States Senator Quay received a large sum of money in 1889 from the now convicted ex-City Treasurer John Bardsley.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 27. -- Judge Taylor of the Superior Court to-day rendered a long opinion in the case of the State ex rel. the State Board of Tax Commissioners against Philip C. Decker, President of the German Bank of Evansville.

For the past three or four days the papers all over the country have been full of stories regarding trouble in the Richmond Terminal Company, and among them was one that stated that Gen. Samuel Thomas would be elected to sue coed Mr. John H. Inman as President of the company. The stories wore emphatically denied yesterday by Gen. Thomas.

The Central Presbyterian Church, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, was filled last evening with the friends of Miss Evelyn Grace Spencer, daughter of the late Dr. George W. Spencer of Pittsburg, and of Mr. William Henry Blain, the well-known lawyer of 234 Broadway, to witness the marriage of the couple by the Rev. Charles L. Thompson of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The physicians of Trenton are kept on the jump vaccinating people owing to the presence of smallpox. One practitioner in two days has scraped eighty-five arms, and others are kept equally busy. Several new cases are reported. One merchant of South Broad Street was obliged to close his store because of the presence of the plague.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- "Do yea think that Postmaster Van Cott, Representative Wadsworth, and Collector Hendricks have violated the civil service law."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- A meeting of the Superintendents and Trustees of the various State hospitals and two members of the Board of State Lunacy Commissioners was held at the Binghamton State Hospital to day. It was opened by Senator O'Connor of this city, who is one of the Trustees of the hospital here. Tracy R. Morgan was chosen Chairman and Col. James R. Thurston of New-York Secretary.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Oct. 28. -- This was a mild clear day, and the racers were kept busy at the kite track. The sixteen young trotters in the 2:35 class were at it all the afternoon, and at dark there was no decision after six heats. The three winners of these scored new records, and seven remain to fight it out to-morrow.

A heavily-built man of medium height, with a white mustache and a bit of a goatee, and wearing a black slouch hat, stood in the corridor of the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon chatting with an acquaintance while he opened some letters. Presently another man, wearing a hat just like the first, with a jolly, florid face and a bit of sandy gray mustache, approached.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Edwin E. Marshall, who claimed to be of the United States Navy, shot himself dead at a hotel this morning, as the result of a bitter fend with his beautiful and wealthy wife. Marshall was stationed, it is said, on one of the United States men-or-war at Philadelphia, but his rank is not known in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Every Republican speaker in the campaign is defending the McKinley bill as one passed to secure high wages for workmen, and the protection papers of all kinds publish tables to show that high wages have been maintained under the bill.

To the consternation of the Republicans, the County Democracy, almost to a man, has swung straight into line for the Democratic State ticket. The bottom has completely dropped out of whatever bolt against the ticket there was.

Fort-PLAIN,N. Y., Oct. 2S. -- Harvey Wicks, a leading merchant, has declared that he wlll support Flower and sheehan. He is an influential Knight of Labor, and ran for Congress on the labor ticket in 1886. carrying Montgomery County. He was a member of the Executive Board, Knights of Labor, from this county for several years.

The best indorsement received by Martin Schenck, the Democratic candidate for State Surveyor, comes from two gentlemen who have each been elected to the position twice -- Elnathan Sweet and John Bogart. In a letter to the Engineering News they give ample testimony to Mr. Schenck's experience and ability as an engineer to refute statements in an editorial in that journal.

The better part of yesterday was spent by the New-York Presbytery of the Reformed Presbyterian Church in the endeavor to decide whether the Rev. J.C.K. Milligan and the Rev. J.F. Carson had been guilty of heresy -- the former in writing and the latter in printing a statement raising the question as to the immutability of the laws of the Church on what is denominated "The Term of Political Dissent."

The announcement by Mr. GEORGE L. NICHOLS of the First Ward, Brooklyn, that he shall vote for Mr. BOODY for Mayor is significant. Mr. NICHOLS is a Republican of prominence and a highly-respected citizen. He has in the past taken a very active part in politics and was a most efficient supporter of the amended charter by which the powers of the Mayor were so largely increased.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- W.A. Bowen and O.W. Crawford of Texas are in the city arranging with the various railroads leading into Texas for special rates to Southern and Southwestern Texas points. Mr. Bowen is Secretary of the Commercial Exchange at San Antonio, and has secured the consent of the roads to put on sale "invalid" tickets to that city, good for six months, at a fare and one-third for the round trip.

Miss Lucy E. Russell, youngest daughter of Charles W. Russell of Cedarhurst, was married yesterday afternoon to Alrick H. Man, son of the late Albon Platt Man. The wedding took place at the Church of the Holy Communion, and was performed by the Rev. William Wilmerding Moir, a relative of the bride, and the Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet, rector of the Church.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- After having been in session twelve days, the Ulster County Grand Jury completed its labors this morning. There was an immense throng in the courtroom, attracted by the announcement that indictments would be found against James E. Ostrander and Matthew T. Trumpbour for wrecking the Ulster County Savings Institution.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- The decree of the Board of Visitors has been set aside in the famous Andover case. This decision of the Supreme Court is on the ground that the Trustees are not made parties to the original proceedings. The merits of the case are not passed upon.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Yesterday the University medical freshmen, suffering under unbearable taunts, rescinded their resolution not to fight, and to-day a battle took place in Dr. Reickert's lecture room. Long before the beginning of the hour the members of the two classes began to assemble in old clothes and football jackets, and at once commenced to exert their vocal powers to the best of their ability.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 28. -- The resignation of the Hon. J.A. Chapleau, Secretary of State, and the leader of the French Canadians, continues to create great excitement throughout Canada. Mr. Chapleau spent the day in Montreal in consultation with his political supporters. Tremendous efforts are being made to effect a compromise.

TRENTON, Oct. 28. -- There is nothing bigger on hand in New-Jersey this Fall than the choice of half a dozen new Senators and of an Assembly to take possession of the new chamber Gov. Abbett has built in anticipation of its arrival The people do not, as a rule, go into transports of enthusiasm over an election of that magnitude, and a go-as-you-please air marks the contests between candidates

The Jonah-like story of "Sam and Eva" has been turned into an advertising dodge and source of profit by the thrifty officials of Mount Olivet Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, who appear to enjoy a full realization of the truth of the old adage that "it's an ill wind that blows no one good."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Mr. Moorfield Storey of Boston spoke before the Harvard Reform Club in Sanders Theatre this morning on "The Present Position of the Independent Man." Mr. Storey reviewed at length the pledges of both the Republican and Democratic parties in regard to civil service reform, tariff reform, honest money, and elections, and showed how each had fallen short of its promise.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- In the church of which he has been rector for the past twelve years the Rev. Isaac Lea Nicholson, S.T.D., was this morning consecrated Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Milwaukee. The hour for the services to begin was set for 10:30, but an hour before that time the sidewalk in front of St. Mark's was packed with people awaiting the opening of the church doors.

The first Broadway ear to run over the whole road in five months completed its trip yesterday morning at 11:30 o'clock. There were fireworks and a Jolly good time at the Morton House when the car reached that point. It was an object of curiosity, and the crowd gazed in surprise. But soon the old familiar yellow features were recognized, and then a jubilation began.

Ball Brothers' large Un.stamp works, operated in connection with their twoglass factories, at Miracle, ind. wore deBtroyed by {ire yesterday. The larg0 two-storybrlck structure, 225 foot by 80 feet, with the machinery, tsa total loss, and over 100 omDloyes. mostly glrls, are out of work. The building was Lighted by natural gas, and the large perforated pine burners wore kept lmrninff to make heat.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment finished its work with the department estimates yesterday after approving requisitions for 1892 to the amount of $35,905,212.03, against $35,960,891.23 appropriated for the present year. As there remain unexpended balances of $2,750,000, the total to be raised by taxation is reduced to $33,133,212.03.

A petition has been circulated among artists, industrial designers, architects, journalists, litterateurs, and others, to be sent to Secretary of the Treasury Foster in relation to the recent Treasury decision declaring foreign art, photographic and musical publications unmailable, praying that the embargo be removed.

Legal papers were drawn yesterday intended to put the Poughkeepsie Bridge Company in the hands of a receiver. A receivership is sought also for the connecting railway lines known as the Central New-England Railroad system.

The latest mutiny in the Grenadier Guards is even a more striking illustration than the mutinies that have preceded it of the state to which "Her Majesty's Household Troops" have sunk under the administration of her Majesty's cousin F.M. the Duke of CAMBRIDGE. That wonderful warrior, by the way, is the titular Colonel of this corps.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Military circles and the public in general were startled to-day by the publication in the colums of Truth of the details of another mutinous outbreak upon the part of the Grenadier Guards. It is looked upon as serious, in view of the three previous acts of mutiny in which the Grenadier and Coldstream Guards have been implicated within about a year and a half.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- As the result of an appointment made yesterday Senor Pedro Montt at noon to-day called at the Department of State to see Secretary Blaine. It is said that he has had a cablegram announcing his appointment as Minister from Chile to the United States, and adding that his credentials have been forwarded by mail.

George L. Nichols, one or the old-time Brooklyn Republicans, who was an active member of the party when Gen. Jourdan, Silas B. Dutcher, and Benjamin F. Tracy were winning victories, and who was instrumented in organizing the celebrated Committee of One Hundred, has decided that he cannot swallow the local ticker this year.

Most unfortunately the news that Santiago is greatly excited over a report that the Chilean Legation in Washington has been attacked by the infuriated citizens of this Republic invests with an aspect of farce an otherwise serious and unpleasant international situation. It is not surprising that the Chilean Junta should disclaim responsibility for the murderous attack on the sailors of our men-of-war.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The 2,000-ton cruiser Detroit was launched this afternoon with complete success, and amid the cheers of the largest crowd that ever assembled along the Patapsco to see a new boat slide off the ways.

ROCHESTER, Penn., Oct. 28. -- Senator Quay was called on at his home in Beaver at 1 o'clock morning and questioned as to the certifcate of deposit for $8,877 from the Keystone Bank to Bardsley, made payable by him to Senator Quay through the Beaver Deposit Bank on Nov. 29, 1889.

A still alarm to Engine No. 32 at 2:20 yesterday afternoon called the firemen to 50 Fulton Street, just below Cliff Street. The engine was there inside of two minutes, but, notwithstanding the promptness of the company, it found the building in flames from top to bottom.

The scene attending the sale of boxes and seats for the approaching horse show at the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon was a spirited one. The concert hall, where the sale took place, was brilliantly lighted for the occasion, and when Auctioneer Richard M. Montgomery took the platform there was a crowd of nearly three hundred persons present, including many of the best-known men about town and a fair sprinkling of stylishly-costumed women.

When Gov. PATTISON called the Senate of Pennsylvania together in extraordinary session to investigate the charges against Treasurer BOYER and Auditor General McCAMANT he acted in confidence that that body, of which the majority are Republicans, would take up the cases in good faith and press them to a fair conclusion, without reference to any effect the truth might have upon their party.

A quarter of a century or thereabout has passed since the appearance of the drill system in our army which is now about to be changed. HARDEE'S Tactics had remained in authority only half a dozen years before being superseded by CASEY'S, and in another half a dozen years CASEY had given way to UPTON.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The attempt made to injure Simon W. Rosendale, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, in his home by the distribution of circulars purporting to be issued by the Garment Workers' Assembly, knights of Labor, charging that Mr. Rosendale was nominated in the interest of a combination of clothing manufacturer, will fall.

The question of a fair division of rates on freight traffic to and from points west of the Mississippi River, passing through the several junctions in Illinois, occupied the attention of a conference meeting of the Trunk Line Freight Committee and the Special East-bound Freight Committee of the Central Traffic Association in this city yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 28, -- Dispatches were received here this evening from Japan announcing that there had been an earthquake at Hiogo, and the rumor was current that a great amount of property had been destroyed and that the loss of life had been considerable. The telegraph wires are down beyond Hiogo and Osaka.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- By grand procession, august ceremonial and the ceremony of solems Pontifical mass, was begun to-day in the Cathedral of Baltimore the celebration of the centenary of the Seminary of St. Mary.

MACAULAY describes one of his historical characters of whose conduct he disapproves as retiring, at the conclusion of a disgraceful bargain, "rich, contented, and infamous." It would not be just to speak of the kinsmen of SAMUEL J. TILDEN, in whose favor the Court of Appeals has now broken his will, as "infamous."

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 28. -- The Province of Manitoba received a set-back from the Supreme Court this morning. The full bench rendered judgment in the famous school case. It declared that the legislation passed by the Provincial Legislature abolishing separate schools was unconstitutional and invalid. The case was argued last May, the Hon. T.H. Blake appearing for the appellants, and Messrs. Joseph Martin and J.J. Gormully for the respondents.

Several amendments of the Constitution of the State of Maryland are to be submitted to a vote of the people at the coming election. The most important of these is copied from the Constitution of this State and authorizes the Governor to veto separate items in appropriation bills. It would be well if this prevision were more generally copied in States that are revising or amending their Constitutions.

The affairs of the New York Life Insurance Company continue to occupy the attention of business circles and of the public press in New-York in an extraordinary manner. The State Superintendent has not yet published any reported concerning the investigation, and it is said that the investigation has not yet been completed.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The ballot which is to be used next Tuesday in this city will be about one-half the size of one of THE TIME'S pages. Throughout the State the ticket will be almost as large, because never in Maryland's history have as many names been voted for at one election as are on the tickets this year.

The hearing in a will contest in which are involved some curious features was begun yesterday before Surrogate Ransom. The fight is over the estate of Thomas Monaghan, who died last September, leaving an estate worth about half u million. Monaghan came to this country from Ireland in 1841, and for many years did business as a painter at the corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 28. -- Newark Bay Boat Club's new Winter clubhouse, on West Thirty-fourth Street, this city, was destroyed by fire to-night, with its entire contents. Property belonging to the ladies of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, who were holding a fancy fair in the house, was also consumed. The fire leaves Bayonne's crack social organization without a home.

The Hon. A.D. While challenge, in the Cooper Union speech, to any thinking man to find fault with the foreign policy of Secretary Blaine meets a quick response, without regard to party lines, from those Americans who are interested in that lar-off island, Ponape, in the Pacific, where three-fourths of a million dollars of American money has been invested in missionary work.

The Hoboken (N.J.) Quartet Club laid the cornerstone of its new building in Washington Street, near Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon in the presence of a largo number of people. The club is thirty years old and has 165 members. Most of them are well-to-do, and so they decided to have a large clubhouse, which will also be one of the ornamental buildings in Hoboken.

The action of the Board of Aldermen on the Rapid-Transit Commission's report of routes and a general plan for an underground system of railroads has been prompt and unanimous in its favor. A special meeting was held at the earliest time permitted by the law for acting upon the report, and favorable action was taken without an hour's delay.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 29. -- "Hello, below!" The call came from the first mate of the steamer Gladstone at or about midnight, a few hours out from Ashland, bound to the "Soo" and beyond. The mate was upon the hurricane deck, forward, and he had stepped aft. to the rail behind the texas, to bail some one of the crew just off watch.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 29. -- Thomas Ryan, United States Minister to Mexico, passed through here last night on his way to Washington. He is accompanied by his wife. He says that work has begun in earnest to make the Mexican exhibit at the Columbian Exposition at Chicago as complete as possible, a bureau employing several clerks having been organized for that purpose in the Department of Promotion in the City of Mexico.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 29. -- This has been a day devoted to legal arguments in the Senate, interspersed with motions to change the order of procedure without notice, and for the apparent purpose of preventing the Attorney General from summing up the facts proved by the investigation before the election.

The history of all great crimes proves that the difficulty of convicting and punishing a thief increases in geometrical proportions with the amount stolen, and that when the amount reaches to millions conviction is impossible without the aid of public opinion aroused by the persistent and long-continued efforts of an unbuyable press.

BUFFALO, Oct. 29. -- A marked change in the political situation in this city has occurred within the past three weeks. The chirpy Republicans, who just after Candidate Fassett's visit predicted a tidal-wave victory for Platt's man Erie County, now content themselves with trying to convince skeptical Democrats that their chances are good for carrying the county by a modest majority or from 1,500 to 2,000.

Gleason's tactics to carry the election in Long Island City in favor of his gang of heelers this campaign fully equals those of the most unlicensed period in the history of the city, and his opponents fear that the most corrupt methods will be employed to intimidate voters at the polling places on election day. The whole of the election machinery is in Gleason's hands.

Some of the insurance press in their zeal in behalf of the New-York Life, which zeal has been duly rewarded by a bountiful order for "extra copies," have been howling that the public should await the investigation now going on before expressing any opinion on the matter, ignoring the fact that they themselves have been constantly assorting the entire innocence of the New-York Life's management in the charges brought against them.

Mr. FLOWER has stood the test of the campaign much better than Mr. FASSETT. He has made no mistakes. Though he has not hesitated to discuss the issues and has made several public addresses, no blunder in act or utterance can be charged against him, none of those follies candidates are prone to commit in moments of excitement or silliness that plague them afterward.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 29. -- The State campaign in Pennsylvania this year is little more than an enlargement or expansion of the canvass in Philadelphia. The trail of Bardsley and Bardsleyism is over it all. By the action of the Republicans in permitting Quay to dominate their convention and thus to nominate its candidates the delinquencies in Philadelphia have become state issues.

The counsel of the dissatisfied bondholders of the Poughkeepsie Bridge Company have served a formal request on Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, President of the Mercantile Trust Company, to proceed, as Trustee of the bonds, against the company, which, it is alleged, is in financial straits. The dissatisfied bondholders want a receiver appointed in order that they may be able to ascertain just how the company stands.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 29. -- During the brief stay of Secretary of the Treasury Foster in this city last evening a conference was held by the friends of Senator Sherman to discuss the Senatorial situation and decide upon a line of action in the event that the Legislature is Republican.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 29. -- Full particulars of the Alliance riot, which occurred a Buck-snort, Union County, Ark., yesterday afternoon, reached here to-night.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29. -- By action of the Democratic State Committee, taken at a meeting in this city this afternoon, the question of reform in legislative representation has been made a party issue. For months pressure has been brought to bear upon the committee in favor of a special State Convention, which should formulate the party platform on the matter.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The following life-saving stations have been given authority to secure a horse, at $10 a month, to haul the life-saving apparatus in case of shipwreck: Sandy Hook, Loveladies, Spar Cove, Long Beach, Seabright, Little Egg, Monmouth Beach, Brigantine, Long Branch, South Brigantine, Deal, Peck's Beach, Squan Beach, Corson's Inlet, Sea Isle City, Hereford, Townsend's Inlet, Holly Beach, Tatham's, Turtle Gut, and Cape May.

Lewis Lyon, President of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, died at his residence, 739 Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon of heart disease and kindred troubles. He had been ill three weeks. His funeral services will take place Sunday morning at 10 o'clock at his late residence. Dr. H.P. Mendez of the Nineteenth Street Synagogue will officiate. The interment will be in Cypress Hills Cemetery.

HARTFORD, Oct. 29. -- The breech blocks of the navy Hotchkiss six-pound rapid-fire guns have been reduced to a safety weight of thirty-five pounds. This announcement is made as the result of a series of tests just completed over the Pratt Whitney firing range at this place. The gun used in the test was a new six-pound rapid-fire gun designed for the United States revenue cutter Colfax.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Right in front of three of his youngest pupils and as the others were entering the academy at Twelfth and Chestnut Streets to begin their daily routine of studies, Harris Young Lauderbach, who for nearly forty years has taught school in this city, this morning ended his life by a revolver shot.

Preliminary steps have been taken toward organizing the Brazil and New-York Steamship Company, which proposes, if its plans are brought to completion, to set in operation a line of vessels between this port and Brazil. Editor A.H. de Paula Coelho of the United State of Brazil, whose scheme for developing trade between the two countries was outlined in THE TIMES about a month ago, has interested several American capitalists in his scheme.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Administration expects to have serious trouble with Chile. At the State Department and at the Navy Department the reply of the Chilean Government to the demand of our Government, sent on Oct. 23, was received to-day, and in spirit it is defiant, scornful, and insolent.

The Chicago Inter Ocean rejoices over the discovery of a gentleman named CONDON, who "says that the Mexican people are not at all displeased with that clause of the McKinley bill which places a duty on lead. Indeed," he continues, "the more they see of it the better they like it, for it has developed, or at any rate increased, a Mexican industry."

There was not even standing room to spare in Chickering Hall last night at the great mass meeting given under the direction of the Business Men's Democratic Association of the Ninth and Fifteenth Wards. The assemblage was so large that it overflowed into Eighteenth Street, where a widespreading and enthusiastic outdoor meeting was held.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29. -- To-day ex-Congressman La Follette made a statement over his own signature charging Senator Philetus Sawyer with attempted bribery. It created a profound sensation. Sawyer had stated in an interview that he had merely wanted to employ La Follette to look up documents at Madison, and did not know that he was Judge Siebecker's brother-in-law.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- Letters received from the Solomon group of islands give particulars of the cruise of her Majesty's ship Royalist among the islands, and the punishment inflicted by Capt. Davis on the natives for outrages committed on British subjects. The vessel visited Rubiana, and by a little stratagem Capt. Davis secured the chief, named Tooloo, from the village. He is now a prisoner on board the Royalist pending further inquiries.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The Telegraph, referring to the Chilean embroglio, says: "President Harrison was perfectly justified in acting as he did. Doubtless Minister Egan's appointment has turned out to be the worst that could have been made. His action was a notorious violation of the obligations of neutrality. But there is no reason in the world why the Chileans should adopt a defiant attitude.

The developments of the Republican State Committee meeting, which was so secretly and suddenly called last Friday, are of a highly interesting and instructive nature. It was suspected at the time, and was so stated by THE TIMES, that Mr. Platt's object in gathering the members together was for the sole purpose of learning how much money was required for election day in the respective districts and counties of the State.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 29. -- A Vicksburg (Miss.) special says: "The fine steamer Oliver Bierne laid up at Millikeu's Bend Landing at 12 o'clock last night. She had about twenty cabin passengers and something over two hundred 'deckies,' white men, who were en route to various levee works below Vicksburg. Of these men she took on ninety-eight at Greenville.

There ought to be no further dispute, either among Irishmen or among Irish-Americans, about the organization which is proper to be intrusted with the cause of Home Rule. The events that have happened in Ireland since Mr. PARNELL'S death suffice to remove any plausible or decent pretext of controversy.

Gov. HILL, in that part of his speech at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday evening which related to the "blanket" ballot, quoted a remark of Mr. DEPEW in a speech at Elmira in which the latter admitted that if the "blanket" ballot would prevent the uneducated man from voting, the Governor did his duty in opposing it.

APIA, Samoa, Oct. 15. -- Baron Senft Von Pilsach, President of the Municipal Council and adviser to King Malletoa, has resigned. The reason he assigns is that certain white residents of Samoa have been writing letters to the King about German currency and other matters, and that the King wrote direct to them in reply. Pilsach hold that no one should write or speak to King Malletoa before first securing the President's permission.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- A stir has just been occasioned by the publication of a pamphlet of forty-eight pages, entitled "Prof. Royce's Libel -- A Public Appeal for Redress to the Corporation and Overseers of Harvard University, by Francis Ellingwood Abbott, Ph. D., Cambridge, Mass." The Prof. Royce referred to is Josiah Royce, Ph. D., Assistant Professor in Philosophy at Harvard.

Mr. Roswell P. Flower was expected to address a big meeting in the Eastern District of Brooklyn last night, but he found it impossible to attend, owing to pressing engagements. He sent a letter of regret to Chairman Pearsall of the Campaign Committee, and in the course of it he said:

A shining medal, bearing on one side an inscription which says the medal is made of "Nigger Hill Tin," and on the other side another inscription which assigns to the Cleveland Tin Mining Company of Deadwood, S.D., and of New-York City, the responsibility for the existence of the medal, has been sent to THE TIMES office by a gentleman who says that he has been asked to invest some money in the company.

There is an evident disposition among the more ardent and less responsible friends of the Administration to exaggerate and thus to aggravate the trouble with Chile, but such a course is a very ill service to the Administration itself. The trouble is vexatious enough as it stands, and a proper and creditable disposition of it will not be promoted by treating it in a partisan spirit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- President Harrison has been supplied with so many suggestions as to how he may best fill the long list of judicial and other appointments that he will soon have to offer for the advice and consent of the Senate that he has undoubtedly upon his table enough advice on such subjects to fill several large volumes.

A meeting of unsecured creditors and the holders of receiver's certificates of the United States Rolling Stock Company, which failed in this city about a year ago, was held in the law office of Seward, Guthrie, and Marawetz, in Nassau Street, yesterday afternoon. There was a large attendance, and a disposition was manifested to reorganize the company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- There was some spirited racing at the Bennings track to-day and there were some surprises for the plungers. The first of these came in the third race at a mile and a sixteenth, in which Portchester, who was naturally a hot favorite, was beaten out in the stretch by the two-year-olds Pickpocket and King Mac after a driving finish.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- The Petit Journal to-day publishes a dispatch from Madagascar stating that Majunga, an important town on the northwest coast of that island, at the entrance of Bembatooka Bay, has been almost entirely consumed by a conflagration. Only ten houses are reported to be standing, and the loss is estimated at about $200,000. Majunga had an extensive trade in cattle products.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The approach of cold weather has made the executive officers of the World's Fair compel all contractors to increase the number of men in their employ, in order that most of the buildings may be pushed to completion, so far as possible, in what is left of the building season. Much has already been accomplished toward the erection of the mammoth exhibition palaces.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The News this morning says: "Some of the alarmist telegrams sent here from Washington were so obviously exaggerated that we declined to publish them. Chile's reply was proper and dignified. The Junta are not likely to add an American quarrel to their domestic difficulties. It is to their interest to be on good terms with the United States."

A most brutal murder was committed yesterday at 207 West Sixty-seventh Street. The victim was a young girl of only seventeen years, who died bravely in defense of her honor. The scoundrel who killed her made good his escape eight full hours before the police had any knowledge of the crime.

There is something strange in the mental attitude of those independent citizens, and even of those high-minded Republicans, who "view with alarm" what they profess to believe would be Tammany ascendency in the State if the Democratic Party should win at the coming election, and yet regard with complacency the consequences of a victory for Boss PLATT.

The New-York Scottish Society last night made its annual celebration of Hallowe'en the occasion of a pleasant and entertaining "Nigh with Sir Walter Scott" in the Carnegie Recital Hall. The bright little auditorium was comfortably filled with an audience which showed a lively appreciation of the performance by frequent applause.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- What promise to be, in results, the most important trials of armor plates yet made in the world will be commenced at the Indian Head naval ordnance proving ground to-morrow. These trials will be the culmination of a series of tests, beginning with the Annapolis trials of September, 1890, undertaken by the Naval Ordnance Bureau for the purpose of developing the ideal armor for war ships.

CORK, Oct. 30. -- Considerable excitement was caused here this morning among the McCarthyites by a rumor that a plot had been discovered, in which a number of the more or less rabid Parnellites were implicated, to murder William O'Brien. The police, however, declare that there is no foundation for the rumor, and that in all events they will protect Mr. O'Brien from any attempt that may be made to injure him.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The Times, in a leading editorial to-morrow, will say:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30. -- Senator Quay's attorneys disappointed everybody to-day by failing to bring the proposed civil suit for $100,000 damages for libel against the Post Printing and Publishing Company of this city. The only explanation that could be got from Messrs. Marshall, Montooth Robb, counsel for the plaintiff, was that they were too busy with other cases to prepare the papers in Mr. Quay's bill.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct 30. -- A charter was granted at the State Department to-day to the Reading, Lancaster and Baltimore Railroad Company, the line of which will run from Reading to New-Holland, Lancaster County, thence to a point on the Maryland State line in Fulton Township, Lancaster County, to connect with a railroad to be constructed from Perryville, Md., with a branch from Strasburg to Lancaster City, the entire length being fifty-two miles.

If, as has been intimated, Mr. BLAINE is delaying his answer to the late communication of Minister EGAN in order to ascertain public feeling, and decide whether an extra display of "patriotism" will help his party in the elections of next Tuesday, the country is probably safe. Patriotism of the inflammable type, which burns for a fight with no sufficient reason for one, there is absolutely none.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Some time ago the Committee of Councils that has been investigating the scandals arising from the malfeasance of ex-City Treasurer Bardsley and the failures of the Keystone and Spring Garden National Banks, addressed a communication to Secretary of the Treasury Foster, requesting that the committee's experts be allowed to examine the books of the latter institution.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 30. -- Attorney Sulzburger made to-day what was in some respects the best of the campaign speeches which, under the guise of legal arguments against the right of the Governor to call the Senate in extraordinary session to investigate the official negligence of the Auditor General and State Treasurer, the Republican Senators have permitted to be made without opportunity for reply.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- A dead silence has settled down over the State Department as to the Chilean affair. It extends beyond and rests upon the Junta Legation. Senor Montt is silent, and even Julio Foster says not a word. In official circles the insinuation is allowed to ooze out that the situation is serious, and that both the President and Mr. Blaine are with difficulty suppressing their indignation at the insolence of Chile.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30. -- Honolulu advices from a most authentic source state that the arrival there of news from the United States concerning the fatal illness of the Queen and the prospects of a revolution in the islands created a great sensation, and within half an hour after the steamer from San Francisco brought the newspapers none could be purchased at any price.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30. -- David Meriwether, born the year Washington died, builder of the first house erected on the site of the City of Keokuk, member of the Kentucky Legislature fifty-nine years ago, successor of Henry Clay in the Senate of the United States, maker of one State Constitution and citizen under three Constitutions, is still a hale and hearty old man in this city.

" The carpet trade," says the Philadelphia correspondent of the Dry Goods Economist, "is in a worse condition than it has been for years, and there are more looms standing than there are running." And yet there is scarcely any part of the McKinley act in which the increase of duties is greater than in that which relates to carpets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day announced its decision in the case of the Railroad Commission of Florida against the Savannah, Florida and Western Railway Company and other lines forming all rail and part rail and part water routes from Florida to New-York and other Northern markets. The case involves the reasonableness of rates on oranges, and the main points decided are briefly as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- A sensation has been caused by the reckless target practice of the gunboat Plucky, off Eddystone Light. She was firing at a floating target, while a lot of fishing craft were near the line of fire. Some of the first shots fell between the fishing boats, but caused no alarm among the fishermen. Then the gunboat altered her position, and the first shot afterward sank the Sunbeam.

To-day's test of ship armor on the new Naval Ordnance Proving Grounds at Indian Head will be one of the most important ever held. To our own country it will have the added interest of being competition between plates of American manufacture. In last year's battle between compound and homogeneous armor all three plates were from foreign foundries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Adjutant General Kelton has made his annual report to the Secretary of War. Speaking of the growth of military colleges, he says the data collected afford gratifying evidence of increased good results of a system that by adopting military training so as to develop in the pupils a manly bearing and deportment, and habits of ready obedience, confers practical benefits both to the youths under instruction and the State.

CLINTON, N.J., Oct 30. -- This thriving little village of 1,000 inhabitants, in Hunterdon County, was last night visited by the most disastrous fire that has ever occurred in the history of the settlement. Main Street is the main thoroughfare of the village. It was occupied by both stores and residences. The fire, which broke out about midnight, burned with frightful rapidity, and soon the flames were beyond all control.

Mr. DEPEW has repeated his attack upon one of the pet doctrines of his party's chief organ in this city -- the doctrine that after the cost of goods has been increased to the manufacturer and the wholesale merchant by an increase of tariff duties, "the individual consumer" is not required to pay a higher price, because the manufacturer and the wholesale merchant cheerfully pay the increase out of their own pockets.

The recommendation of Col. WILSON, the Superintendent of the Military Academy, that an increase should be made in the number of cadets takes the form of proposing a restoration of the President's privilege of appointing ten cadets at large each year. It would certainly seem wiser to begin with a moderate increase of this sort rather than to undertake the more extensive ones which have been proposed, through also giving Senators the right of appointment.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Ada Rehan laid the cornerstone of the new Daly's Theatre in this city at noon to-day. There was a great assemblage of men and women well known in literature and the drama at the site of the new theatre on the Marquis of Salisbury's estate, near Leicester Square, a hundred yards or so from the Empire and Alhambra Theatres, and about midway between John Hare's Garrick Theatre and Charles Wyndham's Criterion.

The Tammany ratification meeting last night was like all Tammany ratification meetings -- a large affair. The main hall was crowded so the doors, and there were overflow meetings in the small halls and in the street, and there was also a big mass meeting of German Democrats in Nilsson Hall. The crowd needed no stimulant to its enthusiasm, but there were fireworks and brass bands, notwithstanding.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- During the past week there has been a general discussion among the college students and the members of the Faculty as to the advisability of re-establishing the annual cane-spree between the freshmen and sophomore classes. This time-honored sport does not savor of the roughness of a general cane rush as held in other colleges, but is carried on in an orderly, systematic manner.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The publication of statistics comparing the population and the tax list of each town in Connecticut in 1860 with the population and the tax list in 1890 is attracting much attention. Many notable changes have taken place during the three decades. Seventy-four towns show a decline in population, while eighty-two towns exhibit gains.

PHOTOGRAPHING A FLASH OF LIGHTNING. -- Any attempt to photograph the lightning in the ordinary way by exposing a plate upon a given flash would utterly fail; for we must remember that a most complex muscular and nervous process is gone through before the operator can attain his end.

PADUA, Oct. 5. -- Thanks to canals fed by the Brenta and Bacchiglione, the distance between Venice and Padua is not so great that one cannot visit the smaller city by gondola in the morning and return in the afternoon. There needs a double set of gondoliers on such an occasion, but the time and expense are well repaid.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31. -- A new organization, which is destined in all probability to hold the balance of power in this State of already curiously-mixed politics, is being formed. The vote of the men employed on the oyster boats along the Connecticut shore is always considered at election time. There are nearly 3,000 men thus employed.

Every effort was made yesterday by the police to catch William Miller, the murderer of Minnie Rauhauser, but they were not able even to obtain a clue to his whereabouts. Capt. Berghold has eight men searching for him, and Inspector Byrnes has also several of his best detectives on the case. The police of the neighboring cities are likewise on the lookout for Miller.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Mr. Nathaniel T. Allen, a well-known and highly-respected citizen of Newton, has written a letter announcing in strong terms that he will cast, next Tuesday, his first vote for a Democratic candidate for Governor. Mr. Allen says:

Some twenty years ago a second edition of Mr. Rose's "Ignatius Loyola and the Early Jesuits" was published in London. Since then much new matter has come to light, particularly the "Letters of St. Ignatius," of which the author has availed himself in bringing out a new edition. The earlier volume did not have the accessories which render the present publication very attractive as well as valuable to lovers of art.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The closing rally of the campaign was held by the Democrats in Tromont Temple to-night. The place was packed with enthusiastic voters, and the managers were delighted that they were able to surprise the audience by introducing ex-President Cleveland, whose voice was heard in support of Gov. Russell and the Democratic ticket. Mr. Cleveland was greeted with wild applause and cheers when he entered the hall.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- During the past week Englishmen have been afforded rather a mortifying example of the worst that the Atlantic Cable can do in propagating and disseminating lies. I say mortifying, because, unhappily, American agencies seem to have a practical monopoly of this wretched business at both ends of the wire.

THE EMPEROR SNUBS SKOBELEFF. -- The day after the passage of the Danube had been made good, the Emperor crossed the river to congratulate and thank his gallant soldiers. In front of the long, massive line formed on the slope below Sistova awaiting the coming of the Great White Czar, stood Dragomiroff, Yolchine, and Skobeleff, the three Generals who had been the leaders of the successful attempt.

The Lotos Club, which in the past has had the pleasure of entertaining such distinguished foreigners as Wilkie Collins, Edmund Yates, and Charles Kingsley, was aglow last evening with the warmth of a banquet and reception in honor of Sir Edwin Arnold, poet and journalist. On every wall and in every alcove there hung such emblems as served best to enliven and refresh memories of the distinguished honors won by the club's guest.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn held its last campaign rally last evening in the Criterion Theatre. The speakers were David A. Boody, candidate for Mayor; the Hon. Charles S. Fairchild, ex-Secretary of the Treasury; the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, Judge Kenna, and Fred W. Hinrichs, President of the club.

Interest in the real estate market is now con fined almost entirely to city property. So little is heard about suburban sales that the market for this class of property may be said to have disappeared. There is nothing unexpected in this condition because the suburbs always cease to be of interest to real estate buyers at this time of year, and they do not excite attention again until the Spring season is well underway.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. -- Miss Mary Ellicott, daughter of Mr. William H. Ellicott, was married at Mount Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church at noon to-day to Lieut. Rennie Pierre Schwerin, United States Navy, by the Rev. Isaac Lea Nicholson, Bishop of Milwaukee, assisted by the Rev. R.H. Paine.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Preparations have already begun for the annual charity ball which is to be given at the Academy of Music. Preparatory to the events, charitable institutions are called upon to make application for a share of the proceeds. When this is done, a selection is made by the managers of the ball.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The Autumn opera season in London is likely to be made memorable by the production of successful novelties. At the Shaftesbury Theatre, where Signor Lago's Royal Italian Opera Company holds the boards, Mascagni's new opera, "Cavalleria Rusticana," is drawing crowded houses. It is preceded by Ricci's comic opera, "Crispino e la Comare," which prelude concludes with the famous trio, "Di Pandolfetti Medico."

Mr. HERBERT WELSH, in his article in the Forum on "The Degradation of Pennsylvania Politics," sets out with the statement that "among the most vital of public questions in the United States to-day is that of honesty in politics and of the maintenance of sound principles in the management of public affairs."

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Augustin Daly left London for America to-day, and he ought to have left it a proud and happy man. Yesterday's laying of the cornerstone of his new theatre here was a sort of formal, ceremonious acknowledgment of the conquest he has finally made complete. He has fought a long and difficult fight to secure here a position equivalent to that he holds in New-York.
The proper way to vote under the new law is simple enough, but there are some people who have never taken the trouble to find out exactly how it is done.

The story of the Royal Pension Fund for Nurses which has been successfully established in England, and which is now being followed by the establishment of a national pension fund for American nurses, is not only interesting in itself, but instructive and encouraging to all practical students of social science.

Princeton, 73; Wesleyan, 0. Casualties: Howard of Wesleyan, wrist broken, ambulance, Harlem Hospital; Pullman, Wesleyan, neck so badly twisted that he almost faced backward; Bergen, Princeton, jumped upon with such vigor as necessitated retirement and repairs for future contests; Smith, Wesleyan, kicked in the stomach and deprived of wind.

Blair's stock is falling fast, and the best proof of it is that Southern crank editors favor his nomination for the Vice Presidency. It was but a short time ago that the men who think Blair the great and only Christian statesman in America wore favorable to a proposition to try to get the Republican Party to set him up for the Presidency.

THE ARMADA. -- The squadron first seen consisted of the Queen's ships under Lord Howard; the others were Drake and the privateers. The breeze rose rapidly. The Duke flew the consecrated standard, and signaled to the whole fleet to brace round their yards and hold the wind between the two English divisions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Carnegie, Phipps Co. win. An all-American rolled armor plate equals the best armor plate made in Europe. The high carbonized and the Harveyized steel plates made by the Bethlehem Company are demolished. This, in brief, is the result of to-day's armor test at Indian Head, Md., and the most important test of its kind ever held perhaps in the United States.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- Illness prevented my attending the usual first night of Dumas's "Kean" at the Odeon Theatre, but I lost little, for I am assured that the subsequent performance gave smoothness to the general cast, and the play is quite dependent upon this quality. To be possible a play fifty-five years old must have been written by a Dumas.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 31. -- It leaks out to-night from a brief telegram from Duluth that a legal fight has begun for the possession of the stock of one of the greatest iron companies of Vermilion County. More than a million dollars is involved in the controversy. The corporation is an English one, and is known as the Iron and Land Company of Minnesota, Limited.

The managers of the Metropolitan Job Printing Company, at 38 Vesey Street, are wondering, after an experience that they had yesterday, if it pays to run a printing office. About three hundred compositors went on strike, although they were getting full wages, and their action threatened the company with the forfeiture of a bond of $40,000 for the completion last night of the printing of the Brooklyn registry lists.

NEW-BRUNSWICK. Oct. 31. -- The change in the curriculum adopted by the Trustees Tuesday, on the recommendation of President Scott, Isradical. Under it the student will elect at the end of the sophomore year the particular branches he desires especially to pursue, and there will be no loose mingling of this study with that, but a definite aim will be constantly kept in view.

At the time that the incident occurred which I am about to relate I had just attained my Lieutenancy in an Austrian lancer regiment quartered in Hungary. Our barracks held two squadrons, one of which was commanded by a certain Capt. Eichel, a very excellent and very colorless gentleman, on whose qualities it is not necessary to enlarge, since he very soon disappeared from the scene.

NEWARK, Oct. 31. -- The first step toward ousting Haynes from the Mayoralty for which the people of this city at their recent charter election repudiated him was taken in Judge Depue's court here this morning. The contest is made on behalf of ex-Congressman Herman Lehlbach, the Republican nominee, who is now conceded, even by the heelers of the bosses whose candidate Haynes was to have had an honest majority of the votes.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The advance in the Bank of England's rate to 4 per cent. was fully discounted beforehand, rates having gradually hardened. The continued drain of gold made the rise imperative, and further foreign demands in the present position may render an increased rate necessary. The bank's reserve is more favorable, but it is still below the average of recent years.

MISE EN SCENE OF "LOHENGRIN" PARIS. -- The mise en scene was submitted to Mme. Wagner and had her full approval; M. Lamoureux was retained as chef d'orchestre and M. Van Dyck engaged to create the protagonist. The details of raise en scene vary sufficiently from those to which we are accustomed at Covent Garden to deserve an especial mention.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The most successful athletic games over put up by the Cornell Athletic Club were given on Percy Field this afternoon. There were over 150 entries, and the contests were close and many of the finishes exciting. The contests between the under classmen for points added to the interest, and made thinks lively. The sophomores won, making 66 points to the freshmen's 31.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- The interesting statistics or Harvard's growth which appeared in this correspondence a short time age become more striking when they are compared with those from some of the other large institutions. Until within the present year the University of Michigan far outstripped the others in point of numbers, and her enrollment for 1891-2 shows an increase.
