At the General Theological Seminary yesterday the dedication of the Memorial Chapel of the Good Shepherd was celebrated, and the commemoration of the founders and benefactors of the institution, together with the matriculation of the junior class of students. The services comprised morning prayer at 9 o'clock, a high celebration at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, and the holding of evening prayer at 5:30 in the afternoon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 31. -- A large number of students, chaperoned by Prof. Dwight, attended the political lecture by Mr. Chauncey M. Depew in Poughkeepsie Oct. 27. Mr. Depew gracefully alluded to the delegation from Vassar.

Was ever the Evening Post known to set itself squarely and candidly right when forced to admit that it was in error? It now admits that the Democratic platform does not declare "in terms" against a blanket-ballot amendment, but insists that it does so "by implication." Now, as we have several times pointed out, what it declares against "in terms" is "any effort to hamper or restrict the constitutional privilege of manhood suffrage."

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 31. -- The Northern Pacific Railroad is now involved in an interesting contest with the State Harbor Line Commission over the possession of some tide lands at Tacoma. The case, from the peculiar points involved, is attracting wide attention.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31. -- The convicts at Briceville and Coal Creek, 305 in number, were released by the miners last night and the stockade at Briceville was burned. The convicts were being worked by the Tennessee Coal Company, a sub-lessee of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company.

November is an interesting month for stargazing, particularly if one can reinforce the naked eye with an opera glass or a field glass. At 10 o'clock in the early evenings of the month, and at 8 o'clock at its close, some of the finest constellations are above the horizon, while over us and about us is a host of smaller objects, interesting to study even with unaided vision.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Perfect weather during the week has had the effect of sending large audiences to the playhouses. Business has been exceptionally good at nearly every theatre, in spite of the fact that there have been no new productions of importance. Mr. Willard has continued his presentation of "The Middleman" at Hooley's, where the largest and most fashionable audiences of the season have nightly greeted him.

MR. LOWELL'S GOOD-WILL TO MR. CLEVELAND. -- With the coming in of Cleveland in 1885, Lowell knew that by a rule in the Department of State, rarely departed from, he was to be superseded. He had had enough of public life, and did not desire to remain; and he welcomed his successor, Mr. Phelps, with cordiality.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- At the Democratic gathering in the rooms of the Cleveland Democracy Club to-night a letter from ex-President Cleveland to Herbert P. Bissell, President of the club, was read. In this letter, which bears the date of Oct. 27, Mr. Cleveland says:

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The 1St of November usually marks the opening of the social season in the Oranges. This year promises to be the most brilliant ever seen. Receptions, afternoon teas, dances, cotillions, germans, and lunches innumerable are already announced, and the list is far from complete.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 31. -- Senator Quay was on the witness stand over an hour this afternoon during the hearing of his suit for criminal libel against A.G. Barr and James Mills of the Pittsburg Post. At the conclusion of his testimony the accused men were held in $2,000 bail for trial.

ILLUSTRIOUS SMOKERS. -- Nearly all the poets and members of the literary profession have been addicted to tobacco in-one form or another. Milton dearly loved his pipe; Addison, Congreve, Philips, Prior, and Steele smoked prodigiously. Sir Walter Scott smoked, and so did Campbell. Beattie, Campbell's biographer, says, "Tobacco pipes mingled with the literary wares which filled every corner of the bard's sanctum.'

FAMILY LIFE IN PARIS. -- Whole families in Paris pack into fiats of two or three rooms, out of which they always reserve a salon, which once a week is set out to receive visitors, but invariably closed to visitors on any other day. "Madame est sortie," says the concierge, and no one is allowed to go up to the fifth (or even sixth) floor, where they nestle.

Delegates from three colleges -- Cornell, Columbia, and the University of Pennsylvania -- met yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and formed what is to be known as the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. Bowdoin was expected to send delegates, but did not. The delegates present were: Cornell -- Commodore T.J.D. Fuller; Columbia -- W.B. Peet, Prof. Goodwin, Capt. McKee; University of Pennsylvania -- Messrs. Hunter and Beaumont.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Allen Stifling of New-York, the Secretary and Treasurer of the Stirling Company, boiler manufacturers of Barberton, Ohio, and a large stockholder in the concern, filed a bill in the United States Circuit Court to-day to enjoin other stockholders in the company from holding a meeting on Monday for the alleged purpose of voting him out of office and preventing him from voting the stock he holds in the concern.

Two intimations were given out from Washington yesterday that are significant, though opinions may differ as to what their real significance is. One was that at the Cabinet meeting on Friday the President had declared that, rather than accept the insult offered to the United States by Chile, he would resign his office.

HOW MR. LOWELL REFURNISHED HIS HOUSE. -- In 1855, Longfellow having resigned his place as Professor of Modern Languages and Literature, Lowell was appointed his successor, with leave of absence to perfect himself in his studies. He went abroad, but did not remain so long as he had intended.

Those that predicted that amateur photography would soon lose its interest to the many that took it up when first the boom started are surprised at the remarkable tenacity with which the fad, as they are pleased to term it, holds the young men and women. Every week almost a new society is formed in some city, and the army of picture takers who pursue the art for pleasure is fast increasing.

The very serious difficulty which confronts the Deputy Superintendent of Insurance in the matter of identifying the books of the Spanish-American department of the New-York Life Insurance Company, which books have for so long a time been under the somewhat questionable guardianship of Joaquin Sanchez, was discussed yesterday in the presence of a TIMES reporter by a former clerk in that department.
A novel idea for house parties is for all the members of one, upon returning to town, to unite in giving a dinner of some unique and pretty design suggestive of the good times had together.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- By the will of Lovicy D. Paddock of Boston, the following public bequest is made: To Boston University, $30,000, for a trust fund, to be known as the Paddock Fund, the income only to be used, one-half to be devoted to educating women who are earnest workers, and one-half paid poor young men woo are striving to obtain a good education.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, Oct. 31. -- There are no new developments to-day in the state of diplomatic strain existing between the United States and Chile. The members of the American colony are expecting any moment to hear that the United States Government has sent an ultimatum to the Junta.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- About 100 loading commercial travelers from various States of the union hold a meeting in this city to-day and organized a society to be known as the Commercial Travelers' Home Association of the United States. Some time ago an informal meeting was held at Jamestown, N.Y., and the present society is the offspring of that gathering.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 31. -- One of the principal events of the week and also of the season was the annual supper of the Lenox Club, which took place in the Lenox Club house Friday evening. There were brought together on this occasion a very large number of the cottagers, many of whom came up from New-York. It was a sort of "good-bye" festival

The Trustees of St. Luke's Hospital are now asking a round million for the eight lots in the southeast corner of the hospital property, on which the Union Club has had its eye for the last six months. Notwithstanding this rise of $150,000 on the price, the eye of the Union Club -- or at least the eye of the club's committee -- still rests longingly on the St. Luke property.

SCOTLAND, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Connecticut is overrun with tramps, whose only object in life seems to be to beat the railroads. John Roberts, about thirty years of age, was cut into a dozen pieces while trying to steal a ride here tonight.

Prof. Hardy has temporarily forsaken his mathematical ways and his vocation as a writer of charming novels in order, in this volume, to relate the story of a brief, but gentle and noble life. Joseph Hardy Neesima was a native of Japan, who came to this country in his youth for light. Through accident he attracted the notice of Mr. Alpheus Hardy of Boston, the philanthropic father of Prof. Hardy.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured to teachers at the American Museum of Natural History on "Beetles, Bees, and Ants" yesterday morning. In the exhibition room just outside the hall were many boxes of the insects, mounted, to which the attention of the teachers was especially called, as it was only on rare occasions that they are placed on exhibition.

" Oh, I wonder how it would fit me! Try it on me and see!" The rapid exclamations came in an enthused little voice springing up from somewhere near the floor. The baby shopper, who thus made everybody smile, was enraptured over one of the pretty hood-bonnets for the little women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The United Elates Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $162,960,850, as follows: Currency 6s, $10,244,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $199,400; 4 per cents, $120,868,350; 2 per cents, $21,645,100.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Pre-election week in Boston has seen society events at a standstill, while the air has been rife with political discussion, or perhaps more truly with political bickering. The issue of the hour seems to turn on men quite as much as on principles, and the joint debate that has so caught the public fancy promises to result in nothing more important than the knocking of small chips from shoulders.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The big armored cruiser New-York, now building at the yards of William Cramp Sons, will be ready for launching, it is announced, during the first week in November. The new vessel is named after the State of New-York, and will be the most powerful armored cruising war ship yet built for the navy of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Inspector General J. C. Breekiuridge, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, says that the work of inspecting the National Guard in encampments was never so completely accomplished as during the past year. For this duty fifty-seven officers were detailed and forty-nine encampments were held in twenty-seven States and Territories, twenty-one States and Territories having no organized militia or holding no encampments.

Tammany Hall's Committee on Organization met yesterday afternoon in the small hall of the Wigwam. It was an unusually interesting meeting, because at it the various district leaders made their reports and were supposed to give, in a general way, accurate information as to the situation in the twenty-four Assembly districts.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The new basis of representation adopted by the Democratic State Committee at New-Haven will be applied for the first time in the selection of members of the State Convention to be held here in April for the appointment of delegates to the National Democratic Convention. It will add 66 delegates to the State roll, the present number being 504.

NYACK, Oct. 31. -- An extremely interesting case, in which a substantiated charge of usury was the principal element, was furnished by a decision of the Court of Appeals yesterday. The facts are as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- There are no apparent signs of the Republican stronghold of Monroe giving less than its usual Republican majority. The Democratic leaders concede a Republican majority on the State ticket of 3,000, while the Republican managers estimate it as high as 5,000 and 6,000. It is probably safe to predict that the figures will reach a fair average between these two estimates.

At 9 o'clock yesterday morning the double flat buildings 119 and 121 West One Hundred and Fourth Street were rapidly and almost completely destroyed by flames. Twenty-one families were rendered homeless. None of the tenants saved anything worth the name. Water ruined what the flames spared.

" Hold on there! This won't do. That man has two wives already and I propose to stop him from getting a third." These words were excitedly shouted by Lawyer Reppe Saturday night, as he rushed into the house at 161 Division Street where a wedding party had gathered, and as the rabbi was about to pronounce a comely young woman and more mature Polish Hebrew man and wife.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Indications in Clinton County point toward a large vote being polled next Tuesday. Both parties are actively at work, and with little or no defections on the State ticket. Each party will poll its relative strength. While there is some disaffection in the Republican Party over the county ticket, it is expected that the result on the State ticket will be little affected.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1. -- The election in Mississippi, Tuesday, is for three Railroad Commissioners, District Attorneys, all the members of both branches of the Legislature, and for all county officers. The Railroad Commissioners and District Attorneys have no opposition.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The freshmen of the University of Rochester are in disgrace. They decided Friday night to celebrate Hallowe'en then and there, because the regular night fell on Saturday. They began their work early yesterday morning.
BEVERLY, Mass., Nov. 1. -- Beverly was visited to-day by the most disastrous fire which ever gained headway in the town, and the total loss will reach nearly $200,000.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H. Nov. 1. -- One of the boldestrobberies ever perpetrated in this city occurred this morning between the hours of 1 and 4, when the house on Market Street occupied by George Scott, Vice President of the Portsmouth Brewing Company, was entered and robbed.

By his long-delayed letter of explanation concerning his attack upon the McKinley bill, Mr. BLAINE has not conciliated the high-tariff association over which Mr. THOMAS DOLAN presides. Immediately after the Congressional elections of 1890 this association declared that by his sharp criticism of the McKinley tariff Mr. BLAINE had "aimed a deadly stab" at his party at the time when the Democrats were trying to cut out "its vitals."

BEAVER, Penn., Nov. 1. -- United States Senator Quay has for several days been in consultation with his Philadelphia counsel, Rufus E. Shapley. The result became apparent to-day, when the Senator instructed Mr. Shapley to commence suit in Philadelphia to-morrow against ex-Congressman James Kerr, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, to recover $100,000 damages for libel and conspiracy to libel.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- Although the advantage has been with the Republicans from the start in the political contest, they do not see their way clear to giving the figures of McKinley's plurality. The Republicans are for the most part very confident of both the State ticket and the General Assembly, but the most conservative and reliable calculators are much at sea.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Not unlike the close of many other campaigns in this county, this one leaves many regrets and disappointments. A few days ago the Republicans seemed to have everything well in hand, but appearances have changed, and the men who are willing to back their judgment with cash are staking their money on the Democrats.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- When the witty Abbe Gallani declared that Virtue was more dangerous than Vice, because its excesses were not open to the restraints of conscience, he might well have beheld, in prophetic vision, the present Czar of Russia.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The indications are that Fassett will carry Oneida County by about 600 plurality. The Democrats have the most efficient organization here in many years, and certain revelations affecting the integrity of Republican county officials will help the Democratic State ticket. Sheehan may lose some votes because of Vrooman's extensive personal acquaintance here, but from no other reason.

BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- The Maverick National Bank will suspend payment to-morrow morning. The decision to close its doors was reached after a protracted conference of the Clearing House Committee of the Boston national banks at 1 o'clock this morning. It is stated positively that the failure will not entail any widespread financial evil.

Answering the question of an inquiring student of political economy, the St. Louis Republic asserts that the tariff tax on the barrel of whisky recently shipped from Scotland to President HARRISON was "paid by the foreigner," the foreigner in this case being "Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE, Laird of Cluny Castle, Scotland."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1. -- Ohio politics, combined with practical politics in Hamilton County, present at the present time a picture most interesting, if not beautiful, to contemplate. In the local field there are six particular tickets, all of which have elements of strength, but as fractions will hardly be suggestive of recognition unless combined in a harmonious whole, which at this time is not promising.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The campaign that has just closed in Pennsylvania has some very peculiar features as well as very peculiar complications. The fact of the Bardsley robberies would have had little effect upon the politics of the State, colossal as those robberies were, but for the fact of the late exposure of innumerable other robberies in almost every department of city and State authority.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- A conservative view of the political situation in this State on the eve of election furnishes no ground for an absolute certainty in prediction. Prominent Democrats and Republicans admit that the result of Tuesday's election cannot be predicted, and that only the returns on Tuesday night will furnish a solution of the political enigma.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The attention of the leaders in educational circles has been attracted by a recent proposition for the introduction of a course of complete university education into Boston's public-school system. This proposition appeared in the form of a set of resolutions presented to the Board of Aldermen by Mr. Keenan, one of its members, and these having become the subject of much comment may well be considered here.

The Supreme Court of Massachusetts has at length brought to an end the trial of the Andover professors for heresy by a decision which is legal rather than theological and relieves Dr. SMYTH, the presiding officer of the seminary, from any further disqualification for his duties. The decision does not touch at all the question of his theological soundness.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 1. -- In Colorado only one State office, that of Justice of the Supreme Court, will be filled at the election on Tuesday. Colorado is indisputably Republican, therefore the only interest taken in the contest is in the size of the Republican plurality.

WORCESTER, Nov. 1. -- The campaign in this State virtually closed last night. Several meetings will be held to-morrow evening in various parts of the Commonwealth, but they will have no direct influence on the great body of voters whose verdict is to be rendered Tuesday. The case has been made up, the arguments are all in, and the jury are ready to retire.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 1. -- The contract entered into between the Executive and Salvador Malo for the establishment of a line of steamers between China and the Mexican Pacific ports has been declared forfeited by the Mexican Government. The concession called for four yearly trips from Hongkong to Vera Cruz, or Oakaca, on the Pacific coast, and only two were made, hence the trouble.

Mr. Gibbins's satisfactory work -- the Industrial History of England" -- has led him into studies of a general nature, and in the present volume he takes wider ground and shows us the history of commerce.

STOCKTON, Cal., Nov. 1. -- Yesterday was a good day for record making on the Stockton track, but the "world beaters" were not out. Next Tuesday Palo Alto will go against his record of 2:10, and the yearling, Bell Bird, will try to lower her record of 2:26 3/4. Marvin got four new Electioneers in the list yesterday, making twenty-two for that family this season, and ninety-four all told.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- Maryland, this week, elects all her State officers, several new Judges, and all her county officers, and Baltimore City elects a new Mayor and City Council and the principal local officers. It is the largest election, as regards the number of candidates, in the history of the State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A dispatch was received to-day by Secretary Tracy, from Capt. Schley, which substantiates the press dispatches from Valparaiso regarding the manner in which the sailors of the Baltimore were handled by the Chilean police on the occasion of the riot. The facts stated in the dispatch are what have been understood heretofore, but this official report is accepted by the Department as accurate, and intensifies the feeling of resentment.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton delivered to the congregation of All Souls' Church yesterday a eulogy on the character and work of George Jones, the founder and editor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who was a member of All Souls' congregation for twenty years. He took his text from Psalms, cvii., 10, "The memory of the just is blessed."

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The outlook is that Orange County will give a Republican majority of over 200, although the Democracy has done its utmost this year to keep the majority down. The effort to out Rosendale, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, will fall flat, for the workingmen hereabout view the charge made against him as an election canard.

-- In his handsome volume on the sword Egerton Castle gave a pretty large list of works in various languages that deal with swordsmanship in its various phases, yet not long ago an Italian book appeared from the pen of Cavaliere Jacopo Gelli, called "Bibliografia Generale della Scherma," which proved conclusively that the subject had been hardly touched.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 1. -- The political situation in Nebraska is so badly muddled that no man can make a forecast of next Tuesday's result that he himself will believe. The situation is this:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- C.H. Laurence, the electric railroad boomer of New-York, who is at the head of the new street road in this city, was arrested yesterday for this week passing a worthless check of $45 on Frank Haydn, proprietor of the Tint House, Buffalo. Friends of Mr. Laurence here made the matter right, and he was discharged.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 1. -- The State campaign in Virginia has been one of the most remarkable in the history of politics here for many years; not remarkable for excitement or the special interest manifested in it, but rather on account of the hide-and-seek sort of game that has been going on.

The Rev. R. HEBER NEWTON'S eulogy of Mr. GEORGE JONES, delivered yesterday in All Souls' Church, and printed in full in this issue of THE TIMES, abounds in terse phrases of accurate characterization that show the pastor's intimate knowledge of the character of his parishioner. It was true of Mr. JONES in his management of this paper that he "sincerely sought his ideal and honestly strove to attain it."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 1. -- The McDonald oil field, near this city, touched the world's record to-day by producing 77,000 barrels of oil in twenty-four hours. The prize has heretofore been held by the Bradford field, which is nearly ten times as large as the McDonald, and made the record nine years ago. To-day's performance was accomplished without bringing in any new wells, the drills having suspended operations over the Sabbath

When John Bull has his annual naval manoeuvres, he is apt to feel rather lugubrious and disconsolate by reason of the many shortcomings they develop. They rarely leave him with the comfortable sense of having secured protection for his island by his liberal outlay, while sometimes he is thrown into a state of decided nervousness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The result of yesterday's armor test at Indian Head, Md., proved a complete surprise to the majority of army and navy officers in this city. The impression given out by Commodore Folger that the Harvey plate alone would stand the trial had taken general hold. Of the three plates tested, the Carnegie, Phipps Co. nickel-steel, low-carbon, rolled plate was supposed to possess the least toughness.

The article in a recent number of Harper's Weekly on the action of independents in the campaign now pending in this State has attracted wide attention, and is deserving, as is everything written by Mr. Curtis on political duty, of respectful consideration. Mr. Curtis's independence has been shown courageously for many years, and it cannot be doubted that his course has been dictated by real principle.

An address to the Democratic voters of the State of New-York was issued last night from the Democratic State Headquarters. It is signed by Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the State Committee, and by Mr. Griffin, Chairman of the Executive Committee. It is as follows:

NASHVILLE, Nov. 1. -- GOV. Buchanan, who is in Knoxville consulting with Attorney General Pickle in regard to the proper steps to be taken in connection with the riot at Briceville and Coal Creek, is expected to return here to-morrow. Immediately after his return he will take positive action, but what it will be no one yet know.

The absolutely positive and perfectly incompatible estimates of 20,000 majority for Mr. FASSETT and 60,000 majority for Mr. FLOWER made by the respective leaders of the two political parties in this State will be accepted as inspired or spurned as ridiculous by the citizen who is not a professional politician, according to his party leanings, his hopes or his fears.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- The consecration of the Most Rev. Dr. P.L. Chapelle, (rector of St. Matthew's Church, Washington, D.C.,) as coadjutor to Archbishop Salpointe, of Sante Fe, New-Mexico, and titular Bishop of Arabisso, Asia Minor, took place this morning in the cathedral, in the presence of a congregation which filled every part of that venerable edifice.

The hunting season opened yesterday, Nov. 1. To be more exact, it begins to-day, for there is a law that prohibits gunning on Sunday as well as fishing. Undoubtedly there will be a great many rabbits and quail shot to-day, and it is not likely that the old law that has rusted so long will be brought forth against any of those who go out to try their luck.

A special public meeting for men, under the auspices of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor, was held at the Church of the Reconciliation, 248 East Thirty-first Street, last evening. Addresses were delivered by the Rev. James O.S. Huntington, on "The Duties of Citizenship," and by Francis Lynde Stetson, on "Honest Voting."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 1. -- In spite of the fact that the Presidential election is twelve months away, and that Kentucky is hopelessly Democratic, the Republican factions are to-day as busy as bees in Summer. The preliminary skirmishes show that the battle of the factions will be one of the most bitter contests ever fought in the State. Of course it will be the old one between the "ins" and "outs."

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 1. -- A local paper last evening published a letter from W.S. Porter of Eldora, which reveals a most startling condition of affairs. He made an examination of the report of the Railroad Commissioners for the year, the commission being composed of Republicans.
I would like to add a few words to your description of President Beers's friend Dinkelspiel.

In your issue of this morning an article appears headed "Jefferson Davis's First Wife," in which mention is made of two of President Taylor's sons-in-law, while a third is wholly ignored. A third daughter of the President married Brevet Brig. Gen. Robert C. Wood, Surgeon United States Army, whom, as the old friend of my father, the late Dr. Thomas G. Mower, Senior Surgeon and Medical Purveyor of the United States Army, I personally knew.

The beautiful clubhouse and grounds of the Hoboken Turtle Club are in the hands of the Sheriff of Westchester County, who seized them to satisfy several judgments against the club, obtained by persons who had made repairs upon the buildings and furnished supplies for the club's use.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- President Harrison may be very indignant because of the defiant and ugly course with which the United States, as represented by Minister Egan, has been treated in Chile, but it is incredible, as asserted by some of his friends, that he has expressed a determination to resign rather than permit the insult of Chile to go unavenged.

Hallowe'en was royally observed this year by the Gaelic Club. Commencing Saturday at the clubhouse, 17 West Twenty-eighth Street, and transferred from there to the country clubhouse, Taitlin, Woodside, L.I., the exercises closed only last night.

TRENTON, N.J, Nov. 2. -- The turbine wheel of Martin L. Dunn's flour mill near Bordentown was stopped for several days. An investigation was made by one of the millers, and it was found that the wheel was clogged with eels, some as thick as a man's wrist, it was necessary to cut the fish away in sections.

One hundred members of the National Guard, State of New-York, participated in the sharpshooters' match at Creedmoor Saturday for money prizes and the gold marksman's badge given by the National Rifle Association. The latter was won by G.T. Musson of Company K, Twenty-third Regiment, whose property the badge now becomes, as he has won it three times this year.

A few months ago, in illustrating the interest his railroad company had in enlarged commercial relations with the United States. Mr. Seargeant, the General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railroad of Canada, said that his road was paying between $300,000 and $400,000 a year in duties on the American coal it used. The company desired to use more American coal, and it would prefer to get it without paying the tax.

Chancellor McGill yesterday gave the cause of rapid transit in Jersey City a notable "lift." The Jersey City and Bergen Railroad Company proposed to run trolley wires for the impelling of its cars from the car stables on the Heights down through Montgomery Street to the ferry. The Board of Aldermen granted the company the use of the streets for an electric road.

TERRYVILLE, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Preparations are being made in this vicinity to celebrate the centennial of American clock making in 1893, and at the same time fittingly to honor the man who n beginning the great industry founded the village that bears his name.

Mr. John H. Inman thus explained the Richmond Terminal situation yesterday: "Some days ago I suggested to Mr. Exstein Norton, who has been a close personal friend of mine for twenty-five years, that it would be an excellent thing for the Richmond and West Point Terminal properties if he would take a hand in their management.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The final authorization has been given for the sale of the United States revenue steamer Bibb, now at Ogdensburg, N.Y. The Bibb has been sold to Cleveland (Ohio) people. The vessel long ago ceased to be of further service. She was built as far back as 1861, and since 1870 has been under constant repair.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 2. -- From official returns issued by the Dominion Government to- day, it is learned that the total number of Chinese immigrants registered is 9,748. The actual number now in Canada reaches 6,678. This disposes of the report about the thousands who are smuggled across the boundary into the United States.

Over the signature of "J.R." the Press has found fault with an article which you published, by which I demonstrated that our wool growers have not found the benefits which they had expected from the McKinley tariff. I did not suppose it would please the protectionists to see how prices of our wool had declined and importations of the foreign article increased.
BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- The Boston News Bureau prints the following:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- Flour quiet and unchanged. Wheat -- Notwithstanding the bullish reports in the shape of dry weather, the Russian ukase prohibiting experts, , the market here declined this morning, and subsequently showed no recovery, later weakening off still more, and finally selling at 78@1c below Saturday's close; No. 2 red, cash 92 38@92 12c; November, 92c nominal; December, 93 78@95 18c, closing 94c bid; May, $1.00 78@$1.01 34, closing $1.01 18.

On the evening of Monday, Dec. 7, a musical entertainment of unusual interest will be given at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, by the pupils of Miss Nora M. Green. The occasion is to be the opening of Sherry's new ballroom. The net receipts of the concert will go toward giving working girls bits of country life next Summer.

President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company has put forth a statement in reply to the story that is being so effectively used against him by the friends of honest insurance, regarding the New-York Life's promise to build a twenty-thousand-dollar opera house in Marshall, Minn., provided the people of that town subscribed $300,000 of insurance.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The cornerstone, figuratively speaking, of an enterprise that promises to become an enjoyable feature of Saratoga life was laid last week, in the purchase by a dozen well-known residents of the village and Summer visitors of Saratoga Lake property. These gentlemen have bought about fifty acres of land on the west shore of Saratoga Lake, nearly opposite the White Sulphur Springs Hotel and the famous "Snake Hill."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- Chairman Neal of the Democratic Executive Committee seems to have changed his views as to the plurality claimed for Campbell. Figures are meeting an astonishing cut at the hands of the Democratic estimate experts. This would appear to be the result of information received to-day from the outposts, and indicates in a measure the position from a Democratic standpoint.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A number of the campaigners who have been on the stump for several weeks past in one or more of the States where important elections occur to-morrow have returned to Washington, and there is considerable speculation as to the result of the election. Some betting is being done, but the situation is generally regarded as too doubtful to encourage indulgence in that pastime.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- In the United States Circuit Court Judge Thayer handed down an important decision in the case of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company against the Forest Park and Central Railroad Company and the St. Louis, Colorado and Kansas City Railroad, in which he declares an issue of $700,000 worth of bonds, $200,000 worth of which were sold, to be void.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Franz von Suppe's one-act comic opera, "The Jolly Students," was produced at the Broad Street Theatre to-night by Rudolph Aronson's company. The house was crowded and the piece was successful, It is thought here that the music is particularly bright and tuneful and the libretto concise and full of humor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2. -- San Franciscans are making an earnest effort to secure one or both of next year's National conventions. A meeting has been called by Mayor Sanderson, on advice of leading politicians, to consider ways and means. One hundred and fifty leading Republicans, and an equal number of Democrats will meet for this purpose next Wednesday evening.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- In the Court of Appeals the Maybrick case was begun to-day. Sir Charles Russell, Q.C., in opening his argument, said that the appeal raised a most important question. The plaintiffs, for whom he appeared, were the executors of the late Mr. Maybrick, who had effected an insurance of $10,000 with the defendants, an insurance company, in favor of his wife, Mrs. Florence E. Maybrick, now confined in Woking Jail.

New-York's great chrysanthemum show opened yesterday in the Madison Square Garden, under the management of the New-York Florists' Club. The display is unequaled by any ever before made in this country, and the attendance of thousands of visitors assures the success of the monster exhibition beyond question and gives stronger grounds for the promoters to hope that hereafter the chrysanthemum show will be one of the regular Autumn sights of the metropolis.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- Asa P. Potter, President; Col. Jonas H. French and Thomas Dana, Directors of the Maverick National Bank, were arrested by United States Marshals to-night, the former at his Summer residence in Cohassel and the two latter at their residences in this city.

The paragraph in your issue of to-day in regard to the American Association and the town of Middlesborough, Ky., contains erroneous statements which unless corrected, are injurious not only to the business interests concerned, but to the character of the gentlemen engaged in their local management.

The New-York Life scandal has cast a sort of upas-tree blight over the life insurance business, and all the other companies will be glad when it becomes a thing of the past. Deputy Superintendent Michael Shannon of the Insurance Department states to THE TIMES that his report concerning the investigation of the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company will be completed about the middle of November.

PLAINFIELD, Conn., Nov. 2. -- The murder at Anthony on Saturday proves to have been more sensational than was inferred from the vague reports which first reached here by telephone. The scene of the tragedy was a little cottage near the apex of Anthony Hill, not far from the station of the New-York and New-England Railroad.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- At the meeting of the Chicago Presbytery to-day the report of the Committee on the Revision of the Presbyterian Creed was presented. The committee was composed of the Revs. Henry F. Freeman, W. H. Swift, W. G. K. McClure, and M. W. Stryker. The report says:

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The political contest in Columbia County to-morrow promises to be the fiercest in many years. There is a large county ticket to be elected, for which offices the Republican nominees are mostly present office holders, all with good records. The Democratic nominees are mostly young men who are very popular in their party.

The campaign closed at the Hoffman House and the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where the political headquarters are, last night with absolute confidence on the part of the Democrats, with a semblance of confidence on the part of the Republicans, and with the betting at two to one in favor of the election of Mr. Flower.

NEWARK, Nov. 2. -- When Judge Depue sat this morning for the further consideration of the application for a judicial investigation into the frauds by which the Abbett bosses in Newark made an apparent majority for their man Mayor Haynes at the recent charter election, one F.W. Stevens, whom the ring has made County Counsel, appeared in behalf of Mayor Haynes.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Times's Valparaiso correspondent thinks he has solved the problem why "the United States, contrary to national traditions, should have supported the cause of despotism in Chile."

PITTSBURG, Nov. 2. -- A personal investigation of the extent of the tinned plate industry in the vicinity of Pittsburg discloses the fact that it is not the gigantic industry Republican stump speakers have been claiming.

A heroine has been discovered. She is Mlle. Louise de Beaulieu, who a few days ago was authorized to sell matches in the streets on the ground that she had been deprived of her arm by a gunshot received in 1870. Her license also states that she was decorated with the military medal and eight medals for saving life by her intrepidity and heroism.

The picture galleries, the hall of sculptures, the gold gallery -- with its rich display of tapestries, jewels, and rare specimens of the silversmith's art -- and all of the nooks and corners of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were inspected by nearly 2,000 persons last evening, the occasion being the semi-annual exhibition and reception of that interesting institution.

It is not probable that MCKINLEY has won any votes in Ohio by asserting on one platform after another in his journey through the State that tin plate costs no more than it did before the McKinley bill was passed. There are some Republicans and wavering voters in Ohio who look at official price lists and who read journals in which the truth is told about the effect of the tariff on tin plate.

In a long, loose, flowing gown of a rich brocaded stuff, elaborately embroidered in gold, with three girdles of great silver medallions around her waist. Sarah Bernhardt, a trifle stouter and seemingly ten years younger than when she was here last, received visits from a few friends at the Hoffman House Sunday night. Mme. Bernhardt has just arrived from Buffalo, where she played Friday night in "Jeanne d'Arc."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Cold weather kept nearly all except the "regulars" away from the race track at Bennings to-day, and the running under the management of Starter Howe began rather inauspiciously. The fields were not large, the betting was rather tame, and favorites won but two out of the five races.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows that the interest and non-interest bearing debt decreased $4,025,527.50 during October. The total cash in the Treasury is $740,530,258.68.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- One of the most interesting and pathetic cases that ever came before the Probate Court of this county was decided to-day, when Judge White pronounced Mr. Luke Senior insane, and arranged with his friends to have him put under restraint. Mr. Senior is the leading member of the widely-known firm of Senior, Beckman Co., proprietors of the Northern Ohio Woolen Mills of this city.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2. -- About a year ago Mrs. Anna Sneed Cairns sold her fine female seminary property in the aristocratic suburb of Kirkwood to negroes for the establishment of a manual-training school for colored boys. Mrs. Cairns had been at loggerhe ads with the Town Board of Kirkwood for a long time, and it was charged that she made this sale for spite.

A most tragic meeting between father and son, who, after a long separation, descried each other standing on different sides of the impassable gulf that divides this world's sheep from the goats, occurred near the City of Vladivostock lately, where the construction of the New Siberian Railway was commenced in honor of the Czarowitch's visit.

While the great bulk of the votes at any election are always cast for the candidates of the two political parties in accordance with the preference of the individual voters for the principles and policies maintained by those parties, the decisive factor is a fluctuating minority, which is impelled to one side or the other by some different motive from mere party attachment.

A monument to the Union soldiers and sailors of Portland, Me., who fell in the war of the rebellion, was formally presented to that city on Wednesday evening, Oct. 28. The presentation address was made by Gen. John Marshall Brown, President of the Monument Association. In the course of it he said:

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 2. -- The world's record for hop growing has just been broken at Kent, in this State, with a yield of 5,592 pounds of dry hops to the acre. The average yield in New-York and in the hop districts of England and Germany is not more than 650 pounds to the acre, while the average of Washington hops is 1,600 pounds.

A few days ago Gov. RUSSELL of Massachusetts read in the course of one of his public addresses a table showing how the prices of table glassware have advanced under the McKinley tariff. This table had been prepared for him by one of the largest houses in Boston. We published it, and our readers may remember that the advances were from 6 to 16 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The interest in the Chilean affair was revived in a measure this morning by a visit of Senor Don Pedro Montt to the Navy Department. He came about 10:30 and remained with Secretary Tracy for an hour. The Secretary then escorted Senor Montt to Secretary Blaine's office. The two Secretaries and the Chilean Minister were closeted for just fifteen minutes, and then Senor Montt returned to the legation.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 2. -- The greatest exposition ever seen in the South was opened to-day in Augusta under auspicious circumstances. It is by no means local. Exhibitors are here from Massachusetts, New-York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, New-Jersey, Connecticut, Rhode Island, the Carolinas, Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Texas, and other States, and when the exhibits are all in place it will be the completest exposition of Southern achievement ever made,

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 2. -- Col. Engledue of England and William Clark of Winnipeg, who went to the Pacific Coast, recently, on the behalf of a financial syndicate in the old country, to examine into the suitability of British Columbia for the proposed Scotch crofter emigrants, are in the city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- The returns so far as received at midnight indicate the election of William McKinley for Governor by a majority estimated at anywhere from 5,000 to 10,000. The new ballot law, applied for the first time to-day, has operated satisfactorily, but the returns are obtained less promptly than under the old and well understood method.

By a desperate effort the Quay power in Pennsylvania has been saved from defeat. The Republican candidates for Auditor and Treasurer are elected by majorities of from 20,000 to 40,000, which is the normal strength of the party in the State. In Philadelphia, Mr. REDWOOD WRIGHT, the Democratic candidate for City Treasurer, is defeated by some 10,000, which shows a very great falling off for the Republicans.

John Pierce and David Lahey, both members of what is known as the "Battle Row" gang, who make their headquarters in the neighborhood of First Avenue and Sixty-third Street, have been enemies for some time. They met yesterday morning at Sixty-third Street and First Avenue, when the old quarrel was renewed.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- The Democrats have swept everything. Frank Brown is elected Governor over Vannert by nearly 20,000 plurality, and the Democrats have elected eighteen of the twenty-six Senators, and at least seventy of the ninety-one members of the lower branch of the Legislature. Later returns will probably increase this proportion.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra made its first appearance here this season at Chickering Hall last night. The audience was not so large as it might have been had not the excitement of an election been in the air, but it endeavored to atone for its lack of numbers by an abundance of enthusiasm. The programme was composed of well-known music.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Mr. Fassett received the election reports at his residence, and early in the evening foresaw inevitable defeat. He was tired, but cheerful and in good spirits, and took his defeat philosophically.

The much-talked-about sullen and surly temper of the Kings County Democracy showed itself yesterday by getting out for Flower bright and early and rolling up a plurality of nearly 15,000 for the State ticket. The returns came into Police Headquarters very slowly, and at midnight only 600 of the 647 districts had been canvassed. These gave Flower 14,313.

The next Senate will consist of 16 Republicans and 16 Democrats. The Assembly will consist of 60 Republicans and 68 Democrats. The names of Republicans are printed in roman. The names of Democrats are printed in italics. Those members who have been re-elected are indicated by a star. (*)

The Philadelphia Record publishes a letter which first saw the light in the Advertiser of Chilicothe, Ohio, to which it had been sent by Mr. J.H. TAYLOR, a gentleman who had friends in Chilicothe and who wanted to relate for their instruction his experience in Mr. WANAMAKER'S store. Mr. TAYLOR said:

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Adolphus Chamberlain, one of the shrewdest and most noted criminals in the country, was captured here this morning by S.H. Carpenter, Chief of the Montreal (Canada) Secret Service, and Detective Pilger of this city. He is wanted in Canada for forgery, but there are places in this country where he is wanted for similar offenses.

WILMINGTON, Vt., Nov. 3. -- This quaint little Vermont town will celebrate to-morrow its connection with the outside world by the opening of the Deerfield Valley Railroad. This is a thirteen-mile stretch of narrow-gauge road that runs from Wilmington to Readsborough and there meets a branch road that connects with the Fitchburg system at Hoosac Tunnel, twenty-four miles away.

DUBLIN, Nov. 3. -- Mr. McDermott, nephew of the late Charles Stewart Parnell, to-day publicly horsewhipped Mr. Timothy Healy, M.P., the most bitter of the anti-Parnell leaders. The horsewhipping received by Mr. Healy was the indirect outcome of the language used by him at Longford on Sunday last, when the anti-Parnell leader referred to Miss Parnell and to the widow of the late Charles Stewart Parnell.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- Russell is undoubtedly reelected Governor, but by a decreased plurality. Up to 11 o'clock the returns from the country towns show an average gain of 15 for Allen. Gov. Russell appears to be holding his own in the cities.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3. -- The release of the convicts at the Coal Creek, Briceville, and Oliver Spring mines continues to be the leading topic throughout the State. The offering of rewards by the Governor and the announcement that the Governor, upon his return to this city from Knoxville, would state what he intended to do, have added much to the interest felt in the situation.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 3. -- Dispatches from various counties in Kansas show that the Alliance did not hold its own at to-day's election. The returns are very slow in coming in, and only 47 counties of the 100 in the State have been heard from. These forty-seven counties are scattered all over the State and represent every political phase.

Two notable results of the election in this city are the self-destruction of the County Democrats and Mr. RICHARD CROSER'S conversion to the blanket ballot. It appears that some 5,000 of Mr. MAURICE J. POWER'S followers, nearly the whole of what is now left of the County Democracy, voted Fassett "paster" ballots yesterday, thus reducing the majority of Mr. FLOWER from 70,000 to 60,000.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- The election today was one of the most quiet, orderly, business-like and satisfactory ever held in Cincinnati. The new election law based on the Australian system was tried for the first time. The city has for several years enjoyed a registration law administered by an honest and efficient non-partisan Board of Elections.

The murder of Charles F. Blisch, the proprietor of the Eagle Hotel at Peekskill, on Monday afternoon, was the principal topic discussed in that village yesterday. The murderer, Henry L. Betts of Brooklyn, was taken on board the 11:15 A.M. train to Tarrytown and thence by carriage to White Plains, where he now occupies a cell in the county jail. Neither he nor his counsel, D. Wiley Travis, will say anything about the case.

The result of yesterday's election in this State is an unmistakable verdict against the Republican Party under the leadership of THOMAS C. PLATT. The fact that the heavy losses of the party were in the Republican counties of the interior and upper part of the State makes it peculiarly significant.

A large company, including some of the best-known literary men of the country, will be present to-night at the Carnegie Music Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, to hear the first of a series of fifty lectures to be delivered through the States by Sir Edwin Arnold. The lecture will be the only one given by Sir Edwin in this city. The receipts will go to St. Mark's Hospital.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- The wildest excitement has prevailed in the hotel corridors and wherever election crowds are congregated over the rumor that Asa P. Potter, President of the defunct Maverick Bank, had shot himself. Mr. Potter was in the Parker House at 6 o'clock and went out with Lawyer Dickinson, his counsel.

THE TIMES heartily and most sincerely congratulates Harper's Weekly and the Evening Post upon the failure of their efforts to elect Mr. FASSETT. The Evening Post, to be sure, has exercised the Mugwump privilege of "climbing a tree." It has apportioned its praise and its blame -- much more of the latter than the former -- impartially between the two candidates, refraining, though not without visible difficulty, from "indorsing" and supporting either.

RICHMOND, Nov. 3. -- The Democrats have had a walk-over in Virginia at to-day's election. The Independents cut no figure and the Republicans did little better. The Democrats will have 38 members of the Senate, Republicans only 2, and the Independents none. In the House of Delegates the Democrats will have far more than two-thirds and may have seven-eighths of 100 members elected to that body.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 3. -- In spite of the fact that a very light vote has been polled the election to-day has been the most hotly-contested of any struggle ever witnessed in Nebraska. The light vote is due partly to the weather, and partly to the Australian ballot system of voting which has proved cumbersome, especially in Omaha, where there are 119 candidates to be voted for on the State, county, and city ticket.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Cook County to-day elected two Superior Judges, a County Superintendent of Schools, eight County Commissioners, and two Trustees of the sanitary or drainage district of Chicago. The proposition to refund $1,350,000 county bonds maturing May 1, 1892, was also voted upon.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 3. -- At this hour every indication points to the election of the entire Democratic ticket by a handsome majority.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- Returns from the city and State are coming in very slowly, but enough are now at hand to indicate that the Republicans have carried everything. Gregg, (Rep.,) is elected Auditor General by about 50,000 majority. Morrison is elected State Treasurer by probably 47,000 majority.

The election in all parts of New-Jersey yesterday was an unusually quiet and unexciting one. The Democrats felt so assured that the leaders had fixed things beyond redemption that they deemed hustle and hard work unnecessary. For the same reason the Republicans deemed hustle and hard work profitless, and matters were generally allowed to drift along in foreordained channels.

Yesterday's election in this city witnessed the casting of 240,234 votes. Of these, 234,134 were divided between the Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor. The number of voters registered was 261,523.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- Returns from eight precincts in the State outside of Cincinnati show a net Republican gain of 353. There are 2,800 precincts in the State, and, as yet, very few of the Democratic precincts have been heard from. If the same ratio of Republican gain continues, McKinley's plurality in the State will be from fifteen to twenty thousand. Returns are coming in very slowly.

There was a Democratic landslide in New-York State yesterday. Mr. Flower was elected Governor by a plurality of over 40,000. New-York City gave a Democratic plurality of 58,847, notwithstanding the treachery of several thousand County Democrats, who used Fassett paster ballots.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The racing here to-day attracted one of the best crowds of the season, the contests being with these results:

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 3. -- Judge Ross of the United States Circuit Court to-day granted the motion of the defendants to instruct the jury to return a verdict of not guilty in the case of the United States against George A. Burt and Ricardo Trumbull, who have been on trial here for a week charged with fitting out the Chilean steamer Itata with arms to cruise against the Government of Chile.

On a very full vote, Kings County has given the Democratic ticket the very heavy majority of 15,000. This is nearly twice as great as the majority of 1889, and is one-fourth larger than Mr. CLEVELAND'S majority in the county in 1888. On the other hand, it is about one-fourth less than the total majority in the Congressional tickets last year, when the vote was much lighter.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 4. -- Vote buying was conducted openly in Montgomery County yesterday. There was not the money in the canvass that was expended by John Sanford last Fall. Men stood about the polls with greenbacks displayed, and caught much of the usual "flood-wood."

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 4. -- The dissensions in the Cabinet which imperiled the Abbott administration have been adjusted. Hon. J.A. Chapleau, Secretary of State, who resigned a few days ago because he was not given promotion in the Ministry, has practically won the day. He wanted the railway portfolio, formerly held by the late Premier Sir John MacDonald.

DUBLIN, Nov. 4. -- Dispatches from Waterford, where the convention of the National Federation is being held, say that great excitement prevails there. The streets are crowded with uproarious mobs of people, ready for any kind of a disturbance. The police, in their efforts to control the mob, have been making a free use of their batons, with the result that several civilians have been injured.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4. -- While there have been rumors in circulation in East Tennessee in the last two days that a mob intended to attack the branch prisons at Tracy City and Inman, it is thought there is little foundation for them. There are 620 convicts at these prisons, and extra guards have been placed on duty at each of them.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Tony Hart died at 2:20 o'clock this morning at the Worcester Lunatic Hospital, where he had been confined for many months. His life during the time was frequently despaired of, but he had rallied each time before, showing remarkable tenacity of life.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- The Democratic majority in Maryland will reach 30,000. Full returns have been received from all but two counties, and they will give Democratic majorities. The Republicans only carried two counties in the State, Alleghany and Garrett. Several counties that have been regarded as Republican strongholds give Democratic majorities.

The results of the elections were widely discussed yesterday and some interesting opinions were expressed. There was surprise and gratification on one side and surprise and chagrin on the other. The peculiar features of the vote in New-York State furnished an abundance of food for thought to the leaders of each political party.

The plurality by which Roswell P. Flowe has been elected Governor of the State of New-York is increased by later and more complete returns to 45,648. For Lieutenant Governor, Mr. Sheehan is elected by a vote somewhat smaller than that given for the head of the ticket. The official returns also show the election of the remainder of the Democratic candidates for State offices.

ALBANY, Nov. 4. -- "The data is not yet at hand upon which one can fairly base any judgment as to the vote in the interior of the State which contributed to Democratic success," said Attorney General-elect Simon W. Rosendale this evening. "The campaign on the part of the Democrats was managed with great skill. I spent some time in New-York, and had good opportunity of judging as to some of the work done.

The result of the elections of Tuesday, taken as a whole, is distinctly favorable to the cause of good government in the Nation and, with one marked exception, in the several States. Whatever may be said to the contrary, national issues were necessarily involved. In Massachusetts, as expressly declared by Gov. RUSSELL, and as maintained in the discussions of the canvass, there was little else.

The revision of the returns of the vote in this State somewhat increases FLOWER'S plurality, but shows no significant variation in the figures for the several counties. Comparison is made with the returns of 1888 for the vote for Governor, when, on account of the Presidential election, the vote was somewhat heavier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- While the Navy Department officials regard the possibility of hostilities with Chile on account of the killing of two American seamen in Valparaiso in a sailors' row as being very remote, they evidently do not propose to be taken at much of a disadvantage if some rash or ill-advised action on one side or the other should bring on trouble.

WATERTOWN, Nov. 4. -- The people of Watertown did not vote unanimously to make Roswell P. Flower Governor; but now that he is elected all make haste to tender their congratulations and do honor to their fellow townsman. Early this morning flags were flung to the breeze all over the city, by Republicans as well as Democrats.
BUTTE CITY, Mon., Nov. 4. -- The worst mining accident of the year took place at the Anaconda Mine this morning, when seventeen miners were killed.
BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Henry Cabot Lodge has this to say about the election:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The overwhelming victory of the Republicans in this State yesterday is scarcely more surprising to the Democrats than to the Republicans. Nobody expected it, and both sides seem to be about equally dazed by the result.

The next day after John I. Davenport made his attack on Judge McAdam of the Superior Court, declaring that if the Republicans gained control of the State Legislature he should move for Judge McAdam's impeachment for malfeasance in office for the manner in which he had conducted the naturalization business preceding the election, it was rumored that Judge McAdam meant to take some action in the matter.

Revised returns of the vote in this city on Tuesday, received up to a late hour last night, with three election districts still missing, show that the total vote polled for Governor was 237,234. Of these there were polled for Roswell P. Flower (Dem.) 145,156, and for Jacob Slost Fassett (Rep.) 85,959, giving Mr. Flower a plurality of 59,198 votes.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 4. -- Ex-President Hayes arrived in this city to-night from Cincinnati, accompanied by his son, R.P. Hayes, and Dr. J.L.M. Curry. The latter and the ex-President are Trustees of the Peabody and Slater Educational Funds, which are largely distributed among colored and white institutions of this State.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- A dispatch which has been received here from Rio de Janeiro, the capital of Brazil, brings news of what seems to be little less than another revolution. Congress, the dispatch says, has been dissolved and martial law has been proclaimed at Rio de Janeiro and throughout the provinces. The cablegram also announces that a dictatorship has been established in Brazil.

John Kappler, who was more generally known as John Kremer, the janitor of a row of apartment houses on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Twelfth Street belonging to Frank Greenwood, made a desperate attempt to murder his wife, Marie, yesterday morning. Then he committed suicide by hanging himself.

Mr. J.W. Gleed of Topeka, a leading Kansas lawyer, is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Mr. Gleed is the legal representative of a number of large financial institutions operating in half a dozen Western States. He is also an instructor in the Kansas Law School, and has contributed much to the magazines and newspapers upon financial and other topics.

NEWARK, Nov. 4. -- Ten electric cars, a snow plow, and some other equipments of the Newark Passenger Railway Company wore consumed by fire this morning. They were stored in a long shed belonging to the company, at Bergen Street, Rear ]Railroad Avenue. The covering or an electric wire running into the shed had been worn off, ann the contact of he exposed and charged wire with the woodwork started the flames.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Mr. Fassett was busy in his library to-day, poring over telegrams from various parts of the country and answering them. He did not appear like a man who had just passed through a hard political battle and come out second best, and he said he felt well, was in the best of spirits, and could endure another such siege without fear of physical injury.

It is very seldom, indeed, that an argument has such an effect upon a deliberative body as was made upon the New-York Presbytery by the answer of Dr. BRIGGS to the charges against him. His trial had been ordered, by a small majority, indeed, upon charges upon which the evidence was precisely the same after he had finished his argument yesterday that it was when the charges were formulated.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- The statement made last night that the Messrs. Knight, General Freight Agent and Freight Traffic Manager of the Wabash Railroad, had pleaded guilty to the indictments charging them with violation of the inter-State commerce law, proves to be erroneous. Their plea was, "Not Guilty," and bonds were furnished in $1,000 each.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- The Republican victory in this State Tuesday is the result of an unusually heavy vote. Throughout Northern Ohio the vote in all the strong Republican precincts has been almost up to the figures in Presidential years, and with that increase came something like the pluralities of a Presidential election.

The Philadelphia Press appears to have one set of political morals for Pennsylvania and another for New-York. It construes the great Republican majority in its own State as "the answer of an intelligent people to the disgraceful efforts of the Democrats to use individual crimes in the manufacture of political capital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Brig. Gen. D.W. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, says that the labor involved and difficulties to be surmounted in supplying our fortifications with new model disappearing carriages for large guns is perhaps greater than that of supplying the guns themselves, and unfortunately this work is some years behind the guns.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- When J.T. Finnerty stopped off the Keokuk and Northwestern train at the Union Station this morning he was arrested by Detectives Zeigler and Smith. The arrest was made on a telegram from Montrose, Iowa, from Finnerty's wife, stating that her husband had kidnapped their fifteen-months-old boy.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4. -- All of the later returns received fully confirm the dispatches of last night, indicating a perfect Democratic victory in Virginia. The Democrats will have 38, and possibly 39, out of the 40 members of the Senate. The House, which is composed of 100, will be almost certain to stand not less than 85 Democrats and 15 Republicans and Independents combined.

The United States cruiser Philadelphia, flagship of the North Atlantic station, passed out by Sandy Hook at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Philadelphia is bound for the Island of St. Thomas, in the West Indies. She should arrive there within five days.

There is startling news again from Brazil. The Congress has been "discharged," martial law has been established, and the President of the republic has become a dictator. Meanwhile the statement made by the head of a prominent Brazilian house in this city, which will be found in another column, is extremely interesting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The reported revolutionary movement in Brazil, accompanied by a declaration of martial law and establishment of a dictatorship, is likely to cause another demand upon the already strained resources of the navy, for it is regarded as necessary for the protection of American interests that a United States naval force be at hand there in case of a formidable outbreak.

Another great throng of women and children, with a man or two sprinkled in here and there, filled the big Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening, admiring the most successful flower show ever held in this country. Tuesday's crowd was thought to be quite equal to the full capacity of the Garden, but yesterday's was even larger, a fact which shows that the show is growing in popularity, as it deserves.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 4. -- The position of Governor General of Canada is one of no small importance and emolument. The Executive Government of Canada continued under the act of confederation to be vested in the Queen, and the Governor General, or chief executive officer, carries it on in behalf of the Queen, and in her name.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- The returns have come in very slowly to-day, but they rather tend to increase Gov. Russell's plurality. The Journal's estimate to-night is 8,000, and the Transcript's 9,000. On those Republican concessions the Democrats are hopeful that last year's figures will yet be reached.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 4. -- Yesterday's election in Iowa proves to have been pretty nearly a landslide. Gov. Boies's plurality will reach very nearly 12,000. Eighty counties complete give him over 10,000, and the remaining nineteen counties will probably increase that to the figure first named. Every candidate on the Democratic State ticket is elected beyond question.
BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Everybody in Massachusetts wants to know how it happened. Well, it happened this way:

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 4. -- Dispatches received from all parts of Kansas indicate Republican success in most of the counties. These dispatches are from about 85 of the 106 counties of the State. The People's Party was successful in not more than six of the counties reported, and in all of the State there are large decreases of the People's vote, while the Republicans made heavy gains.
The New-York Life is not a subscriber for THE NEW-YORK TIMES

A large meeting of underwriters was held yesterday in the local association rooms in the Mutual Life Building in pursuance of a call of the committee appointed some time ago to procure signatures to a tariff agreement. Seventy-three companies responded, and E.A. Walter, President of the Citizens' Insurance Company of New-York, was appointed Temporary Chairman.

T. Brigham Bishop, once the acknowledged leader of bucket-shop dealers in this city, has at last landed in Ludlow Street Jail. He was arrested in Jersey City Monday last by the Jersey City police, aided by two of Pinkerton's men, and at the request of the Sheriff of the county. In 1886 Bishop ran a bucket shop and what he styled as a "private bank" at 45 Broadway.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5. -- Kenneth Smith, a Scotchman, has arrived here and tells an interesting story of how land sharks in Southern California robbed him and his countrymen of nearly $300,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- Col. Jonas H. French, in default of $75,000 bail, has been committed to Charles Street Jail. Since his arrest on Monday night, for his connection with the Maverick Bank troubles, he has been in the custody of the United States Marshal. He has been making the most strenuous efforts to obtain bail.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 1. -- Of all the members of the Imperial Court of Russia, the Count and Countess Scheremetiew are the only two who are treated by the Czar and Czarina as personal friends and relatives. They are the sole persons having access to the monarch and his consort who are permitted to say what they please and to talk to Alexander and the Empress in a perfectly free and unconstrained fashion.

Last night the American Numismatic and Archaeological Society gave an exhibition of a medallic portrait gallery of historical interest at its cosy rooms, 101 East Twentieth Street. The gallery consisted of thirty-two medals -- a few among the many in the society's cabinet -- containing the portraits of people who have been prominent in this and other countries.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5. -- A pathetic story of the career of an insane girl and an attempt of the local health authorities to dispose of her dissected body by burying it in the Potter's Field without the knowledge of her mother, who is a wealthy resident of St. Louis County, came to light yesterday. The girl was Miss Maggie Long, who until death was an inmate of the city insane asylum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Gossip about the appointments which Mr. Harrison has to make has started up again with considerable activity, upon the assumption that the announcements are to be made very soon, now that the elections are over. It is probable, however, that nothing will be done until Congress meets.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 5. -- It is the impression among New-Haven Democrats that the result of Tuesday's elections points unmistakably to Grover Cleveland as the party's candidate for President. In this opinion ex-Gov. Waller coincided. He said to-day that the result in New-York had fixed the party's choice, while the result in Ohio had fixed the issue--the tariff.

There was a spirited debate in the Chamber of Commerce yesterday on the silver question, ending in the adoption, on a light vote, of a series of resolutions which repeat the recommendation of last month of the repeal of the law authorizing the purchase of four and one-half millions of ounces of silver per month, call the attention of President HARRISON to this recommendation, and provide for a committee to urge it upon Congress.

The silver question came up before the Chamber of Commerce again at its meeting yesterday and again was made the subject of a lively debate. Most of the time of the session was given to the discussion which was started by J. Edward Simmons offering a resolution which, as finally adopted, took this form:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- McKinley's plurality continues to stand in the twenty-thousand notch. All efforts made up to the present moment fail to budge it. The figures are most interesting. In old rock-ribbed counties like Auglaize, Defiance, and Mercer, where no Democrat in good standing ever scratches a ticket, the Republicans make extraordinary gains.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- The Railway Age and Northwestern Railroader, in its issue of to-morrow, will make a statement concerning the work of railway men in the Iowa election. It refers to employes only and asserts that the railway employes of Iowa did good work in the political campaign in that State. It further says: "The movement will not be checked by any such campaign outcry as has been raised against it in Iowa.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5. -- A large and enthusiastic meeting, including nearly all the prominent Democrats and Republicans in the city, was held last night to consider what inducements San Francisco could offer to persuade both political parties to hold their National Conventions here next year.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 5. -- The Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church has made the following assignments of presiding Bishops to the annual conferences for the next six months:

The woven fabrics used by every country under the old dispensation of things had almost entirely been produced by the people themselves. Since steam has given such development to manufacturing with the help of machinery and to transportation, many inroads have been made and much displacement of labor used to the old methods has been going on.

AMOY, China, Aug. 29. -- Amoy is one of the "treaty ports" of the Chinese Empire; that is, it is one of the few ports of this exclusive Government at which foreign vessels are allowed to enter for commercial purposes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Under the authority contained in the act of Congress approved Sept. 26, 1890, the Director of the Mint has submitted new designs for silver coins, which have met with the approval of the Secretary of the Treasury and the approbation of all who have seen them. The designs are intended for the half-dollar, quarter-dollar, and dime. They were prepared by Mr. Charles E. Barber, the Engraver of the Mint.

The Tammany Committee of Twenty-four met at Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon. The leaders of the various Assembly districts made reports as to the work done in their Assembly districts election day. With very few exceptions the leaders reported that the County Democracy captains had worked openly for Fassett.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The races at Bennings to-day were run in a cold drizzling rain, and only 500 or 600 people were at the track. The favorites took two out of the four flat races, one other went to a well-played second choice, and Larchmont, an 8 to 1 shot, carried off the mile dash.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Hotchkiss, daughter of Horace L. Hotchkiss, the banker, to Waldron Williams yesterday noon in All Souls' Church was one of the most notable social events thus far during this season. Miss Hotchkiss is very popular in fashionable New-York circles, and Mr. Williams is an alumnus of Columbia College of the class of '85 and a well-known member of the University Club.

The annual report of the Board of United States General Appraisers to the Secretary of the Treasury has just been made public. This is the first report made by the board. After speaking of the "difficulties and embarrassments" that the board has labored under, the board devotes considerable space to an argument to establish an excuse for its existence.

A woman while bathing at Manhattan Beach one day last Summer dived and came up with a horse collar around her neck, somewhat to her surprise. For this and other reasons the Manhattan Beach Hotel, Land and Improvement Company, of which Austin Corbin is President, has filed a claim with the Controller against the City of New-York for $50,000 damages, and if the money is not paid voluntarily the company will bring suit.

The committee of Boston gentlemen appointed to conduct a test of slow-burning materials has made an interesting report. The members of the committee were C.J.H. Woodbury, Vice President of the Boston Manufacturers' Mutual Fire Insurance Company; C.M. Goddard, Secretary of the New-England Insurance Exchange, and D.L. Lord, Superintendent of Public Buildings at Chelsea, Mass.

It is the opinion of Mr. DEPEW and of the New-York Tribune that Republicans should base their prognostications for next year upon MCKINLEY'S success in Ohio, not upon FASSETT'S defeat in New-York. In Ohio the national tariff policy of the Republicans was embodied in the candidate; and that policy was fully and constantly discussed in the canvass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Assistant Secretary Bussey of the Interior Department has filed with Secretary Noble his annual report for the last fiscal year. The Assistant Secretary has appellate jurisdiction of all cases arising under the pension laws, and his report is confined to a review of the work of the Board of Pension Appeals under his supervision.

CORK, Nov. 5. -- There was another serious election fight at midnight last night between the Parnellites and the McCarthyites. Many persons were injured.
