William O'Brien, M.P., Thomas Condon, M.P., and John Gilhooley, M.P., were among the injured. All three were hit by stones hurled at them by the Parnellites.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 5. -- The Senate met this morning. No call of the roll was ordered, and the Lieutenant Governor declared the Senate open for the transaction of business, although at no time in the forenoon was there a quorum of Senators in their seats. The Democratic Senators had been reinforced by Rapscher, Henninger, Dunlap, and Markley, and Porter, McCreary, Thomas, Showalter, and Lemon were added to the Republican ranks.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The County Election Board this afternoon finished the official count of the election returns in this, Campbell's own county. Campbell has a majority of 3,266, as against 3,575 two years ago.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 5. -- Passengers on the Missouri Pacific train which left Omaha at 10:30 o'clock last night were treated to an old-fashioned "hold up" at West Side, a suburb, at 11 o'clock.

Although the queenly rose, with the soft and subtle fragrance of the Orient clinging to her velvet petals, invaded the chrysanthemum show at Madison Square Garden yesterday and took it by storm, the attractions of the chrysanthemums were scarcely inferior. All of the cut chrysanthemums were renewed by fresh flowers of brilliant hues, and the display of chrysanthemums in vases was finer than at any previous time of the exhibition.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Senator Sherman was seen at his home to-day, and, asked for his views on the election, he said:

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 5. -- Assistant Attorney General Maynard arrived here this evening and was met at the station by the Chairman of the Democratic City Committee. The two got into a cab and hurried up-town and have not yet been seen. Murphy of Troy was also expected, but has not yet arrived. It is believed that the movement has reference to the contest of the Senatorship.

The fact that MCKINLEY in the City of Cleveland and the county in which that city is situated fell nearly 1,000 votes behind his associates on the Republican ticket has been pointed out in our dispatches as indicating that several hundred Republicans in Cleveland voted for CAMPBELL on the tariff issue.

WEST POINT, Nov. 5. -- West Point and Annapolis are far behind other colleges in athletics, and graduates of both are asking why is this so. They have the unusual advantage of selection by physical examination, all candidates of weak constitutions being rejected, yet until within a very recent period these institutions have hardly been mentioned in this connection, and their superior brawn has not been allowed to show itself.

In commenting upon the report to their Government of the British Commissioners who have visited Chicago, THE TIMES took occasion to point out that the whole country was now fully committed to the fair, and that the failure of the fair or anything short of a positive and pronounced success would be a discredit to the whole country, and not to Chicago alone.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Very little news is obtainable here in regard to the revolution in Brazil. Only traffic cable messages are allowed by the Brazilian authorities to be transmitted to Europe, and even these messages are carefully studied by the officials so as to make sure they are not cipher dispatches.

John F. Mines, for many years a well-known newspaper writer in this city, died yesterday at the Charity Hospital. He had been arrested on Tuesday night for intoxication, and sent to the workhouse. It was soon discovered that he was suffering from alcoholism, and he was removed to the hospital, where he died. Mr. Mines was a bright and successful writer, but the desire for drink caused his downfall.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 5. -- Thirty hours after the polls closed it was not possible to say positively which party has carried the State, or, rather, which has elected its candidate for the Supreme Bench. As was stated some days ago, at the outset the Republicans faced an adverse majority of 55,000. The Independents matched them in numbers and were actively hostile.

The policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company propose now to take a hard in investigating its affairs. A representative meeting was held last night and a committee appointed, with power to increase its number to seventy, to take such action as may be necessary to correct abuses in the management of the company, restore public confidence, and protect the interests of policy holders.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Congressman Flood, speaking of the defeat of Mr. Fassett, said:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 5. -- The Cabinet crisis is over. The Premier and Mr. Chapleau have come to an understanding, and have agreed to publish the following statement of their little difference and its settlement:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Dr. Mott Smith, Minister of Finance of Hawaii, who is on a special mission to this Government, arrived in Washington to-day from New-York, accompanied by Mr. C.K. Bishop of Honolulu, who is an ex-member of the Cabinet and President of the Board of Education.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 5. -- In a large, well-lighted room on the top floor of the big Ferguson Building, in Third Avenue, there will soon be on exhibition the greatest display of architectural designs ever shown in this country. The plans are for the building of the Carnegie Library for Pittsburg. One hundred architects are competing for the honor of designing the new building and also for the prizes offered by the Carnegie Library Commission.

A determination to maintain both east-bound and west-bound freight rates rigidly according to schedule was officially expressed at a largely-attended meeting of trunk line Presidents and their assistants in this city yesterday. Incidentally some dissensions in the special committee of the Western roads which has had charge of the east-bound rate question were patched up -- on the surface at least.

Julio Campo, a South American, who, though but twenty-nine years old, alleges that he is a General in the Army of the United States of Colombia and a Commissioner from that republic to the World's Fair in Chicago, is under arrest at Police Headquarters with a shameful charge of larceny, committed under outrageous circumstances, on record against him.

The members of the Italian Independent Club gave a cordial welcome to Giuseppe Giacosa, the Italian dramatist, at a banquet in Martinelli's, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, last night. Signor Giacosa is the author of "Dame de Challant," a play which will be presented in this country for the first time by Sarah Bernhardt at the Standard Theatre.

The result of the late election makes the adoption of the blanket ballot in this State a practical certainty, whichever party may control the Legislature. The Republicans were already pledged to it too positively to make retreat possible, and those Democrats who were formerly opposed to it have been converted, the paster ballot device of its arch-enemy, Gov. HILL, being the instrument of their conversion.

During the lifetime of Mr. PARNELL the ancient and contentious City of Cork never vindicated its well-earned reputation for vivacity so completely as it has done in the four weeks that have elapsed since his death. A very lively electioneering season has been crowned by a fight, in which three Irish members of Parliament received more or less severe contusions.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 5. -- Miss Maggie Matthews, formerly a student of Lindenwood College, and well known in St. Louis society, committed suicide to-day at St. Charles. Her parents now reside in Albany, N. Y., but formerly lived here. She took morphine.

Interesting facts are the product of the election returns here in the City of New-York. They show that there is no longer any Republican Twenty-first District, nor any Republican Seventh District, nor any Republican Eighth or Thirteenth District. They have all gone over to the Democrats. The Republican oasis in this desert of Democracy is the Eleventh Assembly District.

VALPARAISO, Nov. 5. -- As was announced a few days ago, the Liberal Party in Chile won a sweeping victory in the recent elections, and this fact makes the election of a Liberal President a foregone conclusion. The Constitution of Chile provides that the electors chosen by the people shall meet to elect a President of the Republic.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- The conservative nature of the new basis of representation selected by the Democratic State Committee has disarmed opposition both within and without the party ranks. The arguments of that opposition were that the Democratic constitutional reformers meditated an assault upon the time-honored "rights" of the towns, and proposed to hand over the legislative branch of the Government to the slums of the cities.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Alfred C. Hobbs, a once world-famous inventor, died in this city this morning, aged eighty-eight. He was born in Boston and passed the first twenty-five years of his life in that city. He was connected with two of the old volunteer fire companies in the capacity of Foreman. He was also a Captain in the Washington Light Guards.

The "General" Campo who is accused of robbing the dead body of Mrs. Charles H. Traitteur, and his alleged accomplice, George H. Simpson, were brought before Justice Divver in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. Affidavits were made against the accused by the dead woman's husband, C. H. Traitteur, and by Veda Hansen, a Norwegian servant girl.

The Iroquois tribe is after the scalp of Capt. Brogan, the conservator of the peace who presides over the Mercer Street Police Station. This is not the ferocious Indian tribe that once held undisputed sway over Western New-York, nor yet the scarcely less belligerent Chicago coterie presided over at one time by Carter Harrison, but a Tammany namesake domiciled at 4 West Thirteenth Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- George W. Woodcook, aged thirty-three, son of W. Woodcock, a retired butcher living at 148 Lexington Avenue. iew-York City, died hero to-day from the effects of fallln down stairs in a house kcp by Kitty Dean. 115 South Feeder Street. The accident occurred yesterday afternoon at4 o'clock, and he died to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Advices received by the Times to-day from Rio Grande do Sul declare that the army and navy compelled President da Fonseca to assume the dictatorship and that there is considerable agitation in the Province of Rio Grande do Sul, where the late events at Rio Janeiro are considered to be but a prelude to the restoration of the empire.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Ten thousand Democrats celebrated the victory of the Democracy in Gloversville, Fort Plain, and Amsterdam to-night. A special train carried the Democratic hosts from Gloversville to Johnstown, where they paraded the streets with banners and brass bands, and listened to speeches in the Opera House.

Judgment in the case of the will of Paran Stevens was delivered Thursday by Judge William G. Choate and was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday. It is voluminous and is adverse throughout to the claims set up by Mrs. Paran Stevens, widow of the deceased, both as beneficiary and as an executrix.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- A dispatch received here from Rio Janeiro states that the elections for members of the new Chamber of Representatives are expected to take place in January. Congress will revise the Constitution and will retain its republican and federative character.

Dr. Edmund Charles Wendt of this city, who sailed Thursday on the Furst Bismarck, is commissioned by the Medical Record to devote the entire Winter to a careful study of the sanitary and climatic conditions of the French and Italian Riviera. Dr. Wendt will also undertake an investigation of the recent typhoid-fever epidemic which scattered the American colony at Florence.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Although three whole days have passed since election, the excitement in the County of Dutchess has by no means subsided, nor is it likely to until after the canvass of the vote for Senator by the Board of Supervisors. This canvass will be commenced next Tuesday, and probably three days will be occupied in going over the returns.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- A dispatch from Valparaiso to-day says that Admiral Jorge Montt has been unanimously elected President of the Republic of Chile.
Ballot reform means among other things that the State shall print and distribute at public expense the ballots to the voter at public elections, and that such State-printed ballots shall be voted.

CORK, Nov. 6. -- At the close of the polling to-day Mr. Flavin was generally credited with the victory. The poll boxes were escorted from the outlying districts by troops and police. The counting of the ballots will commence in the morning. The supporters of Flavin claim a majority of 1,200 for him, while the Parnellites believe that they carried the election by a majority of 100.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6. -- The Democratic Legislature elected on Tuesday will be one of the busiest which has met here for some time. It will convene in Richmond on the first Wednesday in December.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 6. -- A meeting of leading Republicans, all active in the State Republican League, was held here to-night, and a Blaine-McKinley League was formed. The purpose is to organize similar leagues in all the counties, the theory being that the next campaign will be on the tariff and reciprocity issues.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 6. -- The discussion over the proposed change in the boundary line between the States of Ohio and Indiana, by which a slice of Indiana, twelve miles wide at the north and narrowing to a point at the Ohio River would go to Ohio, excites the greatest interest in the debatable ground.

An official judgment on the recent trial of armor at Indian Head is not to be looked for until the five remaining plates have been tested, so that complete comparisons can be made. But it is clear enough that there were surprises in the trial. Disappointment and gratification must have been intermingled, with the general result of leaving the latter predominant and the outlook bright for American ship armor.

The Conservative leadership in the House of Commons may be said to have settled itself rather than to have been settled, in the appointment of Mr. BALFOUR to the First Lordship of the Treasury. He is, in fact, the leader of the Conservative side, was so when the nominal leadership belonged to the late Mr. SMITH, and would have continued to be so if it had devolved upon Mr. GOSCHEN.

The United States Mint has been in labor and has produced a design for a new half dollar. The various persons, artists, and wild men who competed for the privilege of designing the national coins failed to meet the views of the Director of the Mint, who has set to work the engraver of the mint.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 6. -- Pittsfield's first elopement in several years occurred to-day, when Mrs. D. J. Hill deserted her four young children and ran away with a man whose name is said to be William Cornell. Hill, who came to Pittsfield four years ago, is a veterinary surgeon, and about fifty years old. Mrs. Hill is good-looking and not over twenty-five years old.

In the last days of the Massachusetts campaign the leading topic was the McKinley tariff, and among the Republicans whose addresses concerning the tariff won no votes for their ticket was Collector BEARD. We have read some of this gentleman's speeches with surprise, because his work in an important Federal office has made him familiar with those provisions and effects of the new tariff which he has misrepresented.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 6. -- There is trouble among about 1,000 of the employes of Jones Laughlin's iron mill on the south side. This is the big concern of which ex-National Republican Chairman B. Frank Jones is the head. Yesterday the men, who are paid by the day, wore informed by their bosses that a note from the office ordered them to work ten hours instead of nine, as they had been doing.
SANTIAGO, Nov. 6. -- The newspapers here have for several days been publishing wild stories about a conspiracy, formed among the refugees at the American Legation, to kill Gen. Canto.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Returns made to the State Railroad Commissioners show that there were 5 fatal accidents to passengers in Connecticut during the year ended June 30 last, 39 fatal accidents to employes and 92 to trespassers. In addition, there were accidents, not resulting fatally, to 56 passengers, 290 employes, and 65 trespassers.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- The affairs of the Maverick National Bank are being straightened out as rapidly as possible. Thomas P. Beal has had his bond as receiver approved by the court. Examiner Ewer is accumulating money for checks received since the bank's suspension, and it is expected that this will be released when the receiver takes charge.
The Supreme Commandery of the Knights of Malta met in Jersey City yesterday and adopted the report of Supreme Commander Owen R. Wilt. The most important thing in the report was the following:

BARDSTOWN, Ky., Nov. 6. -- News has just reached here that Zacnarlah Ward, a prosperous farmer living near Chaplin, a small town in Nelson County, about twenty miles from Bardstown, was poisoned by his wife yesterday. Ward is not dead, but he is so low that he is expected to die at any time. The poison used was strychnine, and was put into a cup of coffee by his wife.

One of the significant incidents of the late elections in the Western States was the poor figure that was cut by the Farmers' Alliance and the practical disappearance of the "silver craze." It shows that politicians who give way to delusions instead of adhering firmly to sound principles make a serious mistake.

We have repeatedly directed attention to the disclosures made in testimony taken during an investigation of the telephone business by a legislative committee in this State four years ago concerning a certain "interference" case in the Patent Office, and to the report of that committee as to what was established by that testimony.

The fact that S.L. Dinkelspiel, alias "Sam" Dinkelspiel, alias "Sam Lewis," is again in the city, traveling under an assumed name and affiliating with his old friend and fellow-speculator, William H. Beers, President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, revives memories of the swindles that have been perpetrated on unsuspecting policy holders by that nimble crook.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6. -- A Florence (Ala.) special says: "The Bank of Florence failed this morning to open its doors. The officers refuse to make a statement, and the assets and liabilities cannot be ascertained."

Mrs. E.B. Custer, the widow of the famous Gen. Custer, pleasantly entertained a large audience last night at Grace Reformed Church, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, with a paper on "Life on the Western Plains." Mrs. Custer is well known by her books describing army life in those parts of the country where an army has lately been a necessity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- "The reason why the Republicans elected their representative in Congress from the Fifth Michigan District? Yes, I will tell you," said ex-Postmaster General Don M. Dickinson. "The vote was divided between the Republican candidate and two Democratic candidates. The combined vote of the straight-out Democrat and of the Industrial candidate was very much larger than the vote by which the Republican was elected.

A series of lectures on the "Nature and Elements of Poetry" will be delivered by Edmund Clarence Stedman, at the Berkeley Lyceum, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, the first Nov. 10, the others Tuesday and Friday evenings till Dec. 8. They will be delivered under the management of the University Faculty of Philosophy of Columbia College, and, what is somewhat unusual, this course in English will be open to the general public.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 6. -- The Republican Senators to-night are very much in the position of the old Justice of the Peace who was ready to give judgment upon bearing one side of his first case, and was so confused when he heard the other side that he wished he had rendered judgment with the case only half heard.

There was an increased attendance at the chrysanthemum show yesterday. Though the show is essentially of chrysanthemums, the roses received their share of attention. Great bunches of La France, Mermot, Meteor, Papa, Gontier, American Beauty, Madam Cusire, Madam Hoste, and other hybrid varieties were replaced for those faded, though some of the hardier specimens have remained from the opening.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- The coming wedding of the Quaker City is that of Mr. George W. Childs Drexel, the son of Mr. A.J. Drexel, the banker, and Miss Irick of the well-known New-Jersey family of that name. The nuptials Nov. 18 will be celebrated in the tiny Episcopal Church at Vincentown, N.J., the bride's home. Bishop Scarborough is to officiate.

" This hall is not large enough for our purposes," said Prof. Albert S. Bickmore yesterday morning, standing at the entrance of the lecture room in the American Museum of Natural History in Central Park and watching the people as they went into the room. When the hour came for closing the doors every seat was taken, and about one hundred persons were obliged to go away unable to obtain even standing room.

By the explosion of a gasoline tank in a barn in the rear of Washburn's block, Orange, Mass., yesterday, a tire was started that resulted in the loss of about $200,000 worth of property. The flames quickly spread to the Washburn Block, which was completely gutted, thence to the American House, Wait's block, Ballon Block, owned by A.P. Putnam, and the Congregational Church, all of which were burned to the ground.

Directors Talcott, Spalding, and Day of the New-York Club held a meeting yesterday afternoon and formally engaged P.T. Powers as manager of the Giants in place of James Mutrie. Powers is a resident of Jersey City, and has managed several ball teams successfully. He is a genial, whole-souled person, and will do his best to make good the defections in the team.

THE GIRAFFE. -- The flesh of young giraffes, and of fat cows especially, is excellent; there is the least musky flavor perhaps, but it is not unpleasant. The tongue and marrow bones are great delicacies, the latter particularly furnishing the rarest and most delicious banquet of the African hunter.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- It is the same old story; no book, however good, however great, where reason, motive, cause and effect, need to be explained, can be brought to the stage in good, understandable form. Balzao is no exception to this rule, and, however eagerly we waited the Theatre Libre representation of M. Tabareni's adaptation of "Pere Goriot," we knew that literary disappointment must result from the requisite clipping and chopping.
READING, Penn., Nov. 7. -- This week's long obituary list includes these prominent old folk, who died in the vicinity of Reading:

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- Chairman Joseph O. Burdett and Secretary J. Otis Wardwell will positively not be candidates for re-election as officers' of the Republican State Committee. This they both freely and frankly asserted to a TIMES correspondent who talked with them at Republican headquarters this forenoon, coupling it with the statement that they had determined to retire at once and permanently from the committee and devote themselves to their private business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Secretary of the Treasury has announced the following new regulations to govern the free importation of articles for exhibition at the World's Columbian Exposition at Chicago:

The Republican machine managers of Brooklyn must feel very proud of the record they have made in the recent campaign. They had such an opportunity as rarely comes. The Democratic delegation to the State Convention at Saratoga returned home avowedly "surly," with well-defined and deep-rooted grievances against the party management, and there was a real division as to the State ticket to work on.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7. -- The convicts will be sent back to the East Tennessee mines. This was determined upon this evening. They will be returned under a very strong guard, but whether it will be composed of a civil force or the State militia has not yet been decided.

THE BIGGEST SAILING SHIP AFLOAT. -- The French five-master France is the largest sailing ship afloat. She was launched in September, 1890, from the yard of Messrs. D.W. Henderson at Partick for Messrs. Bordes et Fils, and her dimensions are as follows: Length, 361 feet; breadth, 49 feet; depth, 26 feet.

" Alabama," revived by Mr. Palmer at Palmer's, five months after the abrupt breaking of its successful run at the Madison Square Theatre, has defied the theatrical croakers and put them in the wrong. Not for the first time. They are, in fact, generally wrong. The fetiches they cherish are always unreasonable, but a fetich is never within reason.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Williams strengthened her hold on the New-England intercollegiate football championship to-day by defeating the Technology team by the score of 30 to 0. The game was well contested, but Williams was superior to her opponents at every point.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 7. -- The United States Naval Academy Battalion was given its final Fall drill to-day in the new infantry tactics for the navy. Commander Charles M. Thomas, President of the recent board on the revision of tactics, and Ensign E.J. Haessier, member of the same board, were present to witness the work of the cadets.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 7. -- Prof. Little has published the first of a series of annual Library Bulletins. It is an excellent thing and is gotten up in the form of the annual catalogue. Besides the librarian's report it contains an account of the improvements made in the college in the past year, donations received, purchases made, The obituary record of graduates of the college is given with unusual detail and correctness.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 7. -- Yale proposes to match brain as well as brawn with her Cambridge rival. Some time this Winter the Yale Union, a debating society, will have a metaphysical and logical tussle with a like organization in Harvard. The arrangements for this novel contest will be made on the day when the Yale and Harvard elevens line up in Springfield.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Yale played her first championship football game of the season at the Yale field this afternoon and defeated Wesleyan by a score of 76 to 0.

FRANKFORT, Ind., Nov. 7. -- Information was brought to this city to-day to the effect that a new and fatal disease has made its appearance near Kirklin, Ind. A few days ago one of the children in the family of John Wyman was attacked with a peculiar disease that battled all medical skill, and in forty-eight hours the child was dead.

HARTFORD, Nov. 7. -- The decision of the Supreme Court affirming the constitutionality of the law passed by the Legislature in 1882 prohibiting the exportation of game from the State is to be tested in the Supreme Court of the United States, the case having been carried to that tribunal for final adjustment.

The Hotchkiss Ordnance Company is particularly busy at present. The work in the United States is bring handled by the Pratt Whitney Company of Hartford, Conn. Twenty-five one-pounder guns are being made and fifty six-pounder guns. The Hotchkiss guns are all rapid-fire pieces. The forgings for the guns are made at Midvale, Penn. All the one-pounders now being supplied are of the long-barrel type.

As fresh as when they were first brought to the Madison Square Garden from the hothouses, the beautiful chrysanthemums at the chrysanthemum show were viewed yesterday by nearly 12,000 persons. It is estimated that by the close of the exhibition to-night the aggregate attendance since it was opened will have reached fully 50,000.

The Crescents of Brooklyn routed the Oranges of New-Jersey at football yesterday afternoon on Eastern Park, Brooklyn, by a score of 28 to 0. The game was the first of the season for the American Football Union championship.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 7. -- Newport's popular drive, Bellevue Avenue, presents a woefully-deserted appearance compared even to a week ago. The stores kept by New-York transients are all closed, and windows and doors boarded up for the Winter are seen on both sides of the avenue and adjacent fashionable streets.

It is not surprising to learn that the restlessness prevailing of late in Samoa, which caused the Iroquois to be sent to Apia, is due in large part to the Berlin treaty. Chief Justice CEDERCRANTZ is complained of on such a variety of grounds as to suggest that some of the natives find a grievance in pretty nearly all he does.

The Rev. PRICE HUGHES, one of the most eminent of the delegates from the English Methodists to the Ecumenical Conference of the Methodist Church, has published in London a final letter upon the procedures of that body, which is mainly concerned with the vices and distresses of American cities.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- Joseph Allen, Joe Jefferson's chief sponsor and keeper of the elegant house and grounds at The Crow's Nest, at Buttermilk Bay, laughs heartily over the announcements of the pet deer which have been presented to the Park Commissioners of Paterson, N.J., by the veteran actor. He says: ...

The annual parade of the New-York Fire Department and the presentation of the Bennett and the Stephenson Medals took place yesterday afternoon. The reviewing stand had been erected in Riverside Avenue, at Seventy-fourth Street, and there the white and gold banner of the Fire Department waved side by side with the Stars and Stripes.

With reverence for Edinburgh, Mr. Laurence Hutton wandered through the old city, threaded "closes," "wynds," swept past "bows," entered "ports," climbed "lands," crossed "brigs," and, for better information, maybe, took a glass of ale in "a change-hoose," and all with a purpose. He was bent on finding out all he could of those shrines where the great bookmen of Scotland had lived or the churchyards where their mortal remains lay sleeping.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 7. -- The closing of the doors of the Corry National Bank to-day has astounded the general public, as the institution was regarded as one of the safest banking houses in this part of the State. A rumor that the withdrawal of State moneys had crippled the institution was found to-night, upon investigation, to be without foundation.

VIENNA, Oct. 12. -- He who travels to Vienna from Venice by way of Trieste will hardly wonder that the German sovereigns who once made the Austrian capital their headquarters laid claim to Italy also as part of the Holy Roman Empire. The land all about the head of the Adriatic and far to the northeast beyond Trieste is Italian in climate, in architecture, in modes of agriculture.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., Nov. 7. -- A scheme is on foot to establish a conservatory of plants, to be used in conjunction with the botanical department. Instructor Gifford has the matter in hand. The building will contain a separate apartment for tropical plants, a good assortment of which will be procured.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 7. -- The magnates of both League and Association have at last come to their senses, and the fight which has been so financially disastrous is to be ended. Both organizations have shown more stubbornness than business sense in this unpleasantness, and the exchequers of some clubs were drained dry in consequence, as they had to keep up with the procession.

There was a crush of passengers and a blockade of traffic at the City Hall station of the elevated railroad shortly after 5 o'clock last evening. There is a crush there every night, but the crowd last night was much greater than usual, and the pressure greater, insomuch that there was much discomfort and some danger.

THE STEAMBOAT IN VENETIAN CANALS. -- At intervals along the Grand Canal and among the waterways exist traghetti. Here the gondole gather, and the gondoliers quarrel or sleep all day. The men are dressed in white trousers, a blue shirt, a scarf wound round the waist, and a straw hat.

The holiday which Tuesday brought, especially coupled with the Indian Summer weather which preceded and followed it, was taken advantage of by many members of the society world, who went into the country. They are now returning to town to prepare for the horse show, which opens to-morrow week. The clubs were almost as deserted last Sunday as on a midsummer Sunday, and after 10 A. M. on Tuesday were very lonesome.

Although the lot of a policeman "is not happy one," as the song goes, yet, considering the exposure to the weather incidental to patrol duty, the business is not an unhealthy one. According to the report of the department for 1890, it appears that in a force of 3,502 of all ranks there were but 41 deaths. The death roll includes 3 Sergeants, 3 Detective Sergeants, and 35 patrolmen.

Of the various investigations that the next House of Representatives is bound to undertake none will prove richer in results, and none, if properly conducted, is more demanded by the public interests than that relating to the office of the Controller of the Currency. We are willing -- nay, we are anxious -- to concede to Mr. LACEY all the probity of intention and all the professional ability claimed for him by his friends.

The financial outlook for the Yale-Princeton championship football game on Thanksgiving Day is of the most roseate description. At the Manhattan Athletic Club it was estimated last night that the receipts from all sources would not fall far short of $75,000. These figures were based upon the outcome of the auction sale, which there took place, of boxes, reserved sittings in the grand stand, and of places for carriages and drags and tally-ho coaches.

SOCIAL LIFE IN LONDON IN ELIZABETH'S TIME. -- The ordering of the household was strict. Servants and prentices were up at 6 in the Summer and at 7 in the Winter. No one on any pretense, except that of illness, was to absent himself from morning and evening prayers; there was to be no striking, no profane language. Sunday was clean-shirt day.

CAIRO, Sept. 8. -- A fair-minded stranger if at all observant and intelligent, who would make a journey from New-York to San Francisco with adequate stoppages and opportunities of talking with representative men, could gain some accurate notion of American questions and institutions. But in Oriental countries there are no representative men, and there is nothing that corresponds with what in the West is called public opinion.

This would seem to be a good time for a bargain at auction in real estate. The market has dropped to that point of dullness in which buyers are not at all eager unless they can secure property at prices which owners would have positively refused to accept a few months ago, and with which the majority even at this time refuse to be satisfied.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- With several new theatrical productions during the week, there has been nothing worthy of high commendation. The novelties were "Mr. Potter of Texas," at the Columbia, and the Royal Midgets in "Gulliver among the Liliputians," at the Chicago Opera House. "Mr. Potter of Texas" drew good houses, and the Royal Midgets drew poor houses, which they certainly deserved.

The Rev. H. Pereira Mendes devoted himself at yesterday's services in the Synagogue Shearith Israel to a discussion of the proposed Jewish exhibit at the World's Fair Exposition at Chicago next year. He approves the suggestion of a monument.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- There is serious trouble among the members of the Pastimes Club, the aristocratic athletic association of the city, which has just completed a magnificent new clubhouse on Vandeventer Avenue. There are 1,200 members. Twenty-five have just withdrawn, and many more have announced their determination to follow their example.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The coldest night of the season is reported by Delaware County people to-day. The thermometer this morning at Stamford and Hobart, they say, was about zero, and the ponds and small streams were covered with ice. There was excellent skating at Hobart.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7. -- A special from Akron, Ohio, says: Two Howard Street business blocks collapsed at 1:10 o'clock this afternoon. Fortunately nobody was killed. One of the blocks was a stone-front, four stories high, occupied by Herrick Son, crockery jobbers and retailers. The other was of brick, three stories high, occupied by the bakery and confectionery establishment of S.B. Lafferty.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- Mr. Alphonso de Figueredo, Brazilian Consul at St. Louis, said this evening, concerning recent events in Brazil:

A photographer visited Broad Street last week for the purpose of obtaining some views of that kaleidoscopic block between Wall Street and Exchange Place. Had he been a free dispenser of grit-edged securities he could not have attracted a crowd about him in any less time than he actually did. The substrata of Wall Street humanity ranged up before the camera in full force.

A rumor was current last night that the United States man-of-war Baltimore had been sunk off the coast of Chile. Few particulars went with the rumor, and statements varied as to the cause. One version of the affair was to the effect that a torpedo had been exploded under the man-of-war.

PROVERBS. -- The Turks have proverbs without number; and very polished and cynical Turkish proverbs are. The taciturn Arabs prefer proverbs to every other form of speech, and use them with singular dignity and aptness. The Koran seems to have been enriched with them for the express purpose of quotation.

" Let me tell you, they use the black bottle at Old Bellevue more than you have any idea of. When they think you give them too much trouble or believe you are not worth saving, they give you a drink, and that's the end of you."

The appearance of strength which the market took on in the face of the Boston bank troubles, proved to be deceptive. Such an event as the failure of a bank having $10,000,000 of deposits might well have been expected to cause a serious decline in prices, but the measure of its depressing influence seemed to be about one per cent. only. But it was seeming only.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 7. -- At a meeting of the undergraduates held last week, an Advisory Committee on Athletics was decided upon, to act as a board for the selection of members of the various athletic teams and to aid the several Captains. The plan is as follows: The university will elect a committee to serve until June, when it must report to the students, giving such suggestions as are judged beneficial to athletics.
ALBANY, Nov. 7. -- Gen. Palmer, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, has issued the following order:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- United States officers brought to this city this evening from Atlanta, Ga., three of the most notorious mail robbers and swindlers in the United States. They are Charlie Diamond, Tom Bacon, and Charles Stratton.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 7. -- It has long been a recognized custom at Williams College to have a yearly rush on the soldiers' monument between freshmen and sophomores. This year a Trustee of the College requested that the rush be discontinued, and the sophomores accordingly voted to abolish it. Many made bold to say at the time, however, that the rush would come off anyhow.

Great is the princess among gowns! In this season of rich gowning, the princess is to be princess indeed. Its reign is to be undisputed. Other gowns there are, but none as yet to equal it in rank. Women who are cast in classic mold will affect the princess in its severest outlines and give thanks for a gown so simple and so charming.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 7. -- Dispatches received from Havre, France, state that the cotton cargo of the British steamship Chollerton, which reached there on the 5th, is on fire and burning fiercely. The cargo consisted of 4,580 bales, but how much of this has been destroyed is not known.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 7. -- The college tennis tournament in doubles has been finished, Stearns (college champion in singles) and Esty winning from Reed and Wales, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Good weather and the best card of the week resulted in drawing a good crowd to the track at Bennings this afternoon. The sport was excellent, the finishes being sharp and exciting as a rule. Betting was brisk throughout the afternoon, but the plungers fared badly, for Dr. Hasbrouck was the only favorite that succeeded in first catching the judges' eye during the afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- The greatest football game that Philadelphia has ever seen was fought to a finish to-day at the Germantown Cricket Grounds, Manheim, when the University of Pennsylvania was defeated at the hands of Princeton by a score of 24 to 0. At least fifteen thousand people witnessed the game. Never before has there been such a representative social gathering on the ball field.

RUSSIA THE AGGRESSIVE POWER. -- Many things have combined to make Russia essentially an aggressive power. The geographical position of the country, cooped in between two inland seas, and buried for more than half the year under the snows of an arctic Winter, makes expansion a necessity of her existence; and it scarcely needs the testament of Peter the Great to remind us of the direction which that expansion is likely to take.

This reprint, in book form, of articles contributed by Mr. Dobson to the periodical press carries out the author's original intention, he says, and is made after revision, but the contents of the book, especially the first three of the sketches, bear strong marks of the form of publication which they first received.
BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- Boston has been shaken from centre to circumference this week -- that is, from Hub to tire -- and in the romance of the six days past there has been literally not a dull page.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- There is a touch of pathos in the fact that the correspondence now proceeding between Jules Claretie and Mme. Bernhardt, relative to the latter's return to the Comedie Francaise, contemplates her coming back to play motherly parts. She has arrived at a point where she is willing to settle down to assume roles like Andromaque, Athalie, and Agrappine, which, if not precisely venerable, mark a definite breaking with youth.

Francis I. made a gift to the State, by letters patent dated June 15, 1530, of jewels amounting in value to 3,675,267f. of the present time. There were eight pieces -- a necklace of eleven diamonds, one of which, the "Fusee de Bretague," was more beautiful than the others; and seven bagues -- not rings, as would be the modern translation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $153,129,900, as follows: Currency 6s, $10,294,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $198,950; 4 per cents, $120,988,850; 2 per cents, $21,648,100.

One of the worst effects of extreme party spirit in our politics is the development of a disposition to cheat and to seize an unfair advantage even on the part of men who would scorn such practices in private relations. Party zeal may be excused when it is confined to efforts to induce men by legitimate means to vote and to vote for particular candidates.

AMERICAN WILD FLOWERS. -- What most impresses the nature-loving Englishman while traveling in America is the newness and rawness of the country, and the almost universal absence of that harmonious interblending of wild nature with human cultivation which is so charming over a large part of England.
The following marriage notice, which appeared in one of the afternoon papers yesterday, is the climax of a sensational story which will be a surprise to the friends of the persons concerned:

A.J.P. Moore, son of N.A. Moore of Berlin, has just returned from a four months' visit at J.K. Viles's sporting camp on Tim Pond in Maine. The nearest town to the pond is Eustis, which is itself twenty-eight miles from the railroad. Then it is twelve miles further by buckboard from Eustis to Tim Pond, which is named for a former guide once famous in that locality.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The best game of football ever seen in Ithaca was played to-day between Cornell and Lehigh, who have been bitter rivals for several years. Cornell won by 24 to 0, making three touch-downs in the first half and two in the second. About 1,500 persons saw the game, including many of Cornell's alumni and a large delegation from Lehigh.

In response to an appeal from those who are fighting against the attempt of the lottery in Louisiana to fasten itself upon the State by getting the sanction of the Constitution for an infamous and corrupt contract, a number of the most prominent and respected citizens of New-York have joined in a call for a meeting at Chickering Hall next Thursday evening to protest against this monstrous iniquity, which concerns the whole country.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 7. -- The campaign just closed has been the cause of righting a wrong committed four years ago, that was, to some extent, the cause of the overwhelming defeat of Judge Nicholson, an Alliance candidate for District Judge.

A woman, driven by the vicissitudes of life to throw her home open to boarders, finds the experience, as most other women who try it do, difficult, to say the least. But she says, philosophically: "I am learning human nature. I have discovered that the soft-voiced, refined-looking woman often carries tigerish claws beneath her velvet, and that the frank-looking, well-dressed man may develop into a 'Meddlesome Matty ' before my eyes.

THE MODERN CHILEAN POLITICIAN. -- The modern politician is the outcome of the higher education and the war with Peru. The first has endowed a number of young men with an acquaintance, more or less superficial, with sundry things unknown to the bulk of their fellows. They can read French novels in the original, and recognize a right-angled triangle when they see one.

" When I read in THE TIMES this morning," said a well-known resident of this city yesterday -- a gentleman who for a number of years has been spending the Winters in St. Augustine, "of the arrest of T. Brigham Bishop, and read also that he is known as 'the ex-king of bucket-shop keepers,' I almost lost my long-standing confidence in human nature.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- No one outside of France can form any idea of the value of the patriotic protestation of kindly friendship shown in the subscription to the Russian loan. Seven times! That does not mean much in itself, for even the peasants know that only one-quarter of the subscription is really legitimate; but what is true and real and sincere is that everybody brought their mite.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Stagg's plucky football eleven scored a touch-down against Harvard on Jarvis Field this afternoon, and although Harvard ran up 44 points in the two halves, the game was by all odds the most disappointing of the season to Harvard supporters.

It would seem that the amateur photographers would never tire of hunting with their cameras for street scenes in the city. Every object of any interest in New-York has been taken a hundred times, yet the picture takers any pleasant day may be seen on the streets, taking snap shots, or in the Park, reproducing the old scenes again. Election day was utilized by many for suburban trips.

If the claims made by Queens County Democrats last night turn out to be well founded, the next Assembly will be more strongly Democratic than was supposed on Friday. Tuesday night it was believed that James A. McKenna, Democrat, had been re-elected in the Second District of Queens County. Wednesday the election of George L. Weeks, his Republican opponent, seemed to be so sure that the Democrats conceded their defeat.

WEALTH AND FREEDOM. -- Given wider and wider freedom, the opportunities of growing rich will broaden and develop until they reach the whole people. Wealth, unless artificially arrested, has the true democratic tendency. In a free industrial state of society, by a law that seems almost universal, those things that are acquired by the small section of the rich tend to pass to the large section of the not rich.

There were reported in the week ending at noon yesterday 733 deaths, 1,009 births, and 320 marriages. The records of the Bureau of Vital Statistics show a decrease of 4 deaths in the past week as compared with the preceding week. The reported mortality -- 733 -- is 43 above the average for the corresponding week in the past five years, and represents an annual death rate of 22.51 in an estimated population of 1,698,784.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 7. -- Gov. David R. Francis was interviewed to-night on Tuesday's elections. He unhesitatingly said he was convinced the result meant that Cleveland would be nominated and elected President.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7. -- There is trouble between the copyright branch of the Department of Agriculture and the authorities at Washington over the registration by American citizens of copyrights in Canada. United States authors and publishers are very dissatisfied, in fact, indignant over the fact that they are refused the privilege of copyrighting in Canada, notwithstanding the treaty between England and the United States, which sanctions such registration in all the British possessions.

Congressman Benton McMillin of Tennessee said yesterday, at the Hoffman House, that his observations of the campaign in New-York and its results had led him to think that national issues had played a considerable part in the fight.

While China has already paid in full the claims for the mission buildings destroyed at Wusieh last June, the damages done to American property in Ponape more than a year ago, and the indignities suffered by our missionaries there, have as yet received no redress. Of course, there are points of difference between the two cases.

In his introductiory chapter the author brings out clearly the paradoxes of the Spaniard, and how for well-understood reasons, with all the prestige and power of old Spain, that country has been forced to yield her territory in the New World, foot by foot; how she lost "her proud position in the front rank of nations," until to-day, of the continent Columbus discovered, Cuba alone is hers.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 7. -- A good deal of noise has been made by the Republican organs over the cost of the extra session of the Senate. Reference to the actual figures will show that the extra session is not nearly so expensive as State officials who fail to do their duty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7. -- Special Police Officer John Gillen was shot and killed this afternoon by a Chinaman named Chew Su Chan, who also shot and probably fatally wounded Joseph Cowell, a milkman, besides wounding G. Barbaris, a restaurant keeper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The first address before the Convention of Christian Workers to-day was made by Thomas B. Ironside, the Superintendent of the Market Street Mission, Morristown, N.J. He told how they were carrying on this work and the methods adopted in reaching people who were out of the range of the churches.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Nov. 7. -- Genuine spruce gum has almost disappeared, as a regular article of merchandise, from the Bennington market. Formerly the supply was abundant, the price low, and the quality first-class. But the supply now depends on mere chance, the gum picker giving little attention to the gathering of the commodity, as there is no money in the business.

BOSTON IN LINCOLNSHIRE. -- There is the Town Hall, which has the appearance of a bit of an old monastic building. Within its walls are transacted all the weighty and important business of the corporation of the Borough of Boston. Originally it was the Hall of the Guild of St. Mary -- the last of the trade guild halls.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The alumni and friends of Princeton University, as well as those who were acquainted with Frederick Brokaw, who was drowned at Long Branch last Summer while trying to rescue a young woman, will, no doubt, be gratified to hear of the success of the proposed plan of a new athletic field as a memorial to one of Princeton's greatest athletes.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The ascending progress of the Procurator of the Holy Synod, M. Pobiedonostseff, in influence and authority, is marked at each successive stage by fresh impositions upon the Jews.

Mr. Seidl was fortunate again last night in his choice of soloists for the Lenox Lyceum concert. He presented to the audience an unfamiliar singer in the person of Miss Olive Fremstadt, a young contralto, and a familiar but always welcome artist in Miss Maud Powell, violinist. Miss Fremstadt chose for her principal number the well-worn aria from "Don Carlos."

A new chapter in the work of revision of the Presbyterian Confession of Faith will be completed this week. The Presbytery of New-York is to meet at 10 o'clock this morning at the Scotch Presbyterian Church, in Fourteenth Street, to receive the report to be submitted by its committee which was appointed to consider the revision as proposed by the last Presbyterian General Assembly.

The storeroom and warehouse of the J.H. McLain Machine Works at Canton, Ohio, took fire at noon yesterday. The building, a two-story frame structure 85 by 210 feet, was tilled with finished products and a stock of supplies and raw material of the Canton Steam Pump Company. It was entirely destroyed. The loss to the McLain Company is $40,000; insurance, $20,000. The Canton Pump Company's

At St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Rylance preached the first of a series of sermons on "The Higher Criticism." Yesterday's sermon treated of its spirit, method, and aims, the text being taken from Hebrews, i., 1: "God, who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in times past unto the fathers by the prophets, hath in these last days spoken unto us by His Son."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Stewart D. South, the Building Inspector of this city, died to-day of smallpox. He was taken sick a week ago. This makes only three deaths from the disease since the epidemic broke out. All the other cases are doing well.

The service at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church yesterday morning was notable for the musical accompaniment. Bruno O. Klein's new "Paschal Mass" was rendered for the first time in New-York, under the direction of Frank G. Dessert, the organist. The regular choir was reinforced by a chorus of sixty selected voices and the solo parts were taken by Deane Creamer, soprano; Annie Dunne, alto; William Xanten, tenor, and J.J. Dossert, bass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Secretary of Agriculture's report for the year bears date Oct. 27. If the elections had turned out better it is probable that it would have had a later date, and that it would have made much more of the returns to point the significance of tariff sentiment in Massachusetts and Iowa. But it is boastful enough, and it is not uninteresting.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 8. -- A mine accident which resulted in the death of eight men and the fatal injury of three others occurred in No. 1 shaft of the Susquehanna Coal Company at Nanticoke late this afternoon.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 8. -- When the people of Iowa voted last Tuesday and chose a Governor for themselves, they also suggested a candidate for the Vice Presidency for the Democratic Party. It would be difficult to decide which the Democrats of the State think of more for Horace Boies, the Governorship of his State, or his nomination on the ticket of their party next year as a candidate for Vice President.

The table of majorities in the New-Jersey Assembly districts shows a total of 12,082 for the eighteen Republicans and of 22,447 for the forty-two Democrats who were elected last week to seats in the lower house of the Legislature. A majority is shown all over the State of 10,365 in favor of the Democrats. The average majority of the Republican members-elect is 670; that of the Democratic members-elect is about 535.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- "That's what Abbettism has done for the State of New-Jersey!" exclaimed Gov. Abbett in the Democratic State Committee rooms on election night. The wires had been momentarily ticking in fresh announcements of Democratic triumphs in the Assembly districts. The Governor was beginning to feel that, after all, perhaps, his sceptre was still safe.

The promoters of the project for an inter-oceanic canal on the Nicaragua route have not at any time overlooked the fact that this route is in the neighborhood of a volcanic region, but in the history of volcanic disturbances in the country lying between Mexico and the Panama isthmus they have found nothing that should restrain them from making a waterway on the line selected.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The defalcation of E.S. Hoagland of Ithaca, amounting to $3,700, is one of the most deplorable cases on record. For several years past he has been employed by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company at that place as agent, and few men in that city were more popular than he. His integrity was unquestioned until three days ago.

Some friends of Willis Holly entertained him at dinner last night at the Fellowcraft Club. Most of them were newspaper men, who have known and worked with Mr. Holly during the twenty years he passed on the press of this city.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Joseph Mayer, proprietor of the Arsenal Pottery, estimates now that his loss by the conspiracy of his invoice clerk, W.W. Sweet, and the firms in New-York and Philadelphia, will exceed $100,000. Sweet's wife, Lizzie, a young woman, has also been arrested and placed in jail for carrying fine ware away when she came to the pottery at noon with lunch.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and his partners in the great iron firm of Cooper, Hewitt Co. will on Jan. 1 relinquish control of the iron works which bear their names and retire from that branch of industry. They will be succeeded by a company of American and English capitalists, who will extend the plant. It is reported that this is the first step of Messrs. Cooper and Hewitt toward retiring altogether from business.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 8. -- A double suicide by drowning occurred to-night about three miles outside the harbor. Two persons, a man and a woman, took their own lives by jumping together from a boat.

Lucian Jones of 303 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street had Edward Hanitzsch, President of the Henry Elias Brewing Company, arrested for fast driving on Saturday afternoon. Mr. Hanitzsch was riding on Seventh Avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street. In the middle of the block Jones attempted to cross the street. There were many carriages there, and Mr. Hanitzsch was close upon Jones before he saw him.

It often seems as if the public-school system were in at least as much danger from its friends as from its enemies. The object of a considerable part of the Catholic clergy is notoriously and, indeed, avowedly to secure a division of the fund raised by taxation for the support of the public schools, and the diversion of part of this fund to their own schools.

There is something even more revolting in the idea of mental starvation imposed on a race than in that of purely material oppression. In the ninth article, published this morning, on the persecution of the Jews in Russia, facts are given to show the terrible extent and the malignant ingenuity of this species of injury inflicted on these unfortunates.

Secretary RUSK is so firmly of the opinion that hides should be taxed in order that the shoe manufacturers of Massachusetts, as he says, "may have something to kick about," that he has put into his annual report "a most earnest recommendation" to that effect. Of course, the Secretary does not expect that the new Congress will make such a change in the tariff.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8. -- When the full facts are understood, the public will better recognize all the difficulties under which Gov. Campbell was placed during the recent contest, and when this is known people will wonder why McKinley's majority over the Governor was not 50,000 instead of 21,000. Even here in Ohio there are but comparatively few who fully appreciated the demoralized condition of the Democratic Party.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Nov. 8. -- The last incident of the closing days of the United States court here was the resignation of Commissioner James T. Beach, which was accepted. There was a clash between Commissioner Beach and Judge Phillips during the term over a number of trivial cases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Something of a hurrah was indulged in by the Bureau of Statistics at the beginning of October in a pamphlet called "The Foreign Commerce of the United States for Comparative Periods under the Old and New Tariffs," the work being, as was stated upon its title page, "prepared by the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, Treasury Department."

Who will distribute the "fat" and marshal the blocks of five for the Republicans in the Presidential canvass next year? QUAY'S marvelous success in converting the pious WANAMAKER'S dollars into votes for HARRISON firmly established his reputation as the greatest majority-maker in the party, but his reputation in other respects has suffered such frightful damage since the campaign of 1888 that the Republicans would never dare to put him in his old place again.

Harris Plitt, a tailor and dealer in tailors' trimmings, of 44 Allen Street, was yesterday arraigned in Essex Market Police Court and was charged with incendiarism by Fire Marshal James Mitchel. It was alleged that, to obtain $3,000 insurance on his stock, he had endangered the lives of nearly one hundred people, who live in the tenement over his store.

The policy holders of the New-York Life Insurance Company are under very great obligations to THE TIMES for its courageous, determined, persistent, and fearless demands for an honest and thorough investigation into the financial condition, management, policy, and business methods of their company. The contest with the officials, which began in June last, has been a difficult and trying one.

While Dr. JAMES T. EDWARDS, who is to succeed COMMODORE P. VEDDER in the State Senate, was dominated and supported by the Democrats of the Chautauqua-Cattaraugus district, and while he was denounced as a renegade by the Vedder and Platt men of the district, he has been a lifelong Republican, and has never announced any change of party faith.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- The Sommerfelds, father and son, who tried to commit suicide yesterday, opened the veins of their arms besides shooting themselves with a revolver. When found both were bathed in blood. Felix died Saturday evening. Sigmund still lives, although there is bullet imbedded in his brain. He is conscious at intervals, and there is a bare chance of his recovery.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8. -- Senator George G. Vest, in the course of an interview to-day on the recent elections and on national politics in general, said:

GOOD SPRINGS, Penn., Nov. 8. -- Charles H. Cristenford, a young man who has been in the employ of John H. Weise Co., produce dealers of Klingerstown, has absconded with over $1,000 in money and valuable papers belonging to his employers, and has taken with him the pretty sixteen-year-old daughter of Jacob Flecher, with whom he has been keeping company for the past year.

There was a large congregation yesterday at All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, to hear the Rev. R. Heber Newton preach on the Briggs trial and the lesson to be drawn there-from. Dr. Newton announced his text as from the thirteenth verse of the thirteenth chapter of the First Epistle of Paul to the Corinthians, "Now abideth faith."

The Boston Journal, the Indianapolis Journal, the Tariff League's Economist, and, in fact, the majority of our high-tariff contemporaries, will now find it necessary to send their most trustworthy reporters by the first and fastest trains to interview Mr. J.W. JONES of Hutchinson, Kan.

Mr. MILLS has returned to Washington, where the members of the new House of Representatives are gradually assembling, and has begun his canvass for the Speakership. As will be seen from our Washington dispatches, there is not likely to be a very serious contest in the Democratic caucus.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Dispatches received here to-day from Pernambuco show that the troubles in Brazil are approaching an acute crisis, and there is much anxiety expressed in financial and commercial circles regarding the outcome of Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca's action in dissolving Congress and again assuming the role of Dictator, and many grave doubts are expressed as to the success of this latest political move.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- There was a very good attendance and some excellent sport at the Bennings track this afternoon. Favorites won all but the last two races, and the betting was lively in all the events.

Senators Aldrich and Hiscock, members of the sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee which has been conducting the tariff investigation, were at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. They had just come from Washington, where they began the task of putting the information that the committee had acquired, through the labor bureau, into shape for a report.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The political enthusiast is not absolutely unknown even in Massachusetts, in spite of the alleged coldness of her people. Since last Tuesday he has not only felt called upon -- and that, naturally -- to show himself well pleased with the Democratic victory, but he has even gone so far as to suggest that Gov. Russell's name would be presented to the National Convention as a candidate for Vice President.

The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Tabernacle Church of Jersey City, and his assistant, the Rev. J. Lester Wells, had the pleasure last night of seeing a work upon which they have been laboring for the past year successfully started. From the indications and the interest that all showed in it, its future is very bright. Its supporters believe that Christian work along certain lines will be revolutionized.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -In the provision pit to-day a good deal of short product was covered, because it was a favorable time to get out of short sales without greatly disturbing prices. The market at no time looked like a full-size one, yet some good short lines were taken back. There was covering by Doud, Wright Wolff, Roloson, and Tennant. Roloson purchased not tar from 250,000 ribs.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- President Patton and a committee of the faculty have sent circulars to the alumni and friends of the college setting forth the needs of an infirmary for the university and soliciting subscriptions. The Sanitary Committee of the college, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, has decided that, with the growth of the university this, has become a necessity.

When young Julius Levin crossed the ocean from England on the steamer City of Chicago last Spring he got acquainted with J. Elmer Grimm, a musical director. On arriving, Levin, who is only eighteen years old, took Grimm to a hotel in West Street, and at the first opportunity departed with Grimm's clothing, valued at $60. The boy was arrested and pleaded guilty before Recorder 8myth.

The New-York Life Insurance Company's policy holders who wonder where their dividends are going need but turn to the price that is being paid for the company's new business to realize that there, at least, is a very material cause of the company's greatly-increased expenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The United States Supreme Court Chamber was crowded this morning with prominent members of the bar, present to hear arguments in the celebrated case of Thomas Henry Cooper against the Judge of the United States Court for the District of Alaska, better known as the Sayward Bering Sea sealeries case.
RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 9. -- A decree has been issued repealing the law for the conversion of the Brazilian 5 per cent. paper bonds into 4 per cent. gold bonds.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- The Italian opera season at the Auditorium was opened to-night under adverse circumstances, so far as the weather was concerned, a constant downpour of rain making the approach to the house very disagreeable, but the magnificent Auditorium was crowded by a brilliant and distinguished audience.

Thomas F. Grady, Tammany's silver-tongued orator, got his reward yesterday for various services as a political speaker, in an appointment as Police Justice to succeed Henry Murray. Mr. Murray's term expired Nov. 4, 1889. Be has since held over. His successor will serve the unexpired term, which will end Nov. 4, 1899. Until then Mr. Grady will draw a salary of $8,000 per year.

The right to the production in this country of Emile Zola's "La Reve" is being tested in a suit that is on trial before Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court in Special Term. The plaintiffs in the action are Laird Lee of Chicago and the defendants are Rand, McNally Co., also of Chicago. The book was published in 1888, and the suit was begun soon after its publication.

The battle formation of the United States Naval Academy infantry battalion, as shown in the final Fall drill last Saturday at Annapolis, is essentially German in character. It needed only the sound of whistles along the line and a slight change of uniform to almost persuade the observer that he was witnessing the manoeuvres of a German infantry battalion.
OTTAWA, Nov. 9. -- The Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance, was interviewed to-day in regard to the reciprocity question. He said:

ROME, Nov. 9. -- The Marquis di Rudini, the Italian Premier, to-day delivered a long speech at Milan. Part of his speech was devoted to the financial situation of the Government, and he announced that a complete equilibrium had been established in the budget. Not only were the estimated receipts fully equal to the expenditures, but even a small surplus in receipts might be expected.

State Senators C.P. Vedder, George Z. Erwin, John Laughlin, and H.J. Coggeshall were at the Hotel Metropole yesterday. Senator Vedder said that himself and Mr. Erwin had come to New-York to attend to some business connected with their Chicago real estate, which, he said, they had not purchased until two weeks after the World's Fair had been located.

When Mr. FLOWER becomes Governor at the beginning of the coming year he will find a large number of public officers holding over beyond the constitutional or statutory terms for which they were appointed, and several more whose terms are about to expire. There have been two reasons for the holding over of so many officers.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- The barroom of the Lindell Hotel was this evening the scene of a sensational affair, in which Ernest Meakin, a young Englishman; Charlie Van Studdiford, a young society man, and four drummers were participants.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The recommendation of Secretary of Agriculture Rusk that the duty on hides provided for in the reciprocity section of the new tariff law be imposed in all cases where the countries from which such hides are shipped have not granted equal concessions does not, apparently, cause much concern to the shoe and leather men of Boston.

The Keystone Democratic Club is first in the field in this city in formally naming a ticket for the Presidential campaign. Grover Cleveland of New-York and Gov. Horace Boies of Iowa are the names suggested.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- Between the day Mr. Flower assumes the office of Governor and the end of his term he will have at his disposal the appointment of successors to all the most influential offices within the gift of the Governor. Nearly every man holding an appointive office in any State department or bureau is dependent upon the new Governor for his retention.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 9. -- Goldwin Smith delivered a lecture on "Jingoism" before a large audience this evening, under the auspices of the Young Men's Liberal Club. It was, as he announced, the last political lecture he will deliver, as, to use his own words, his sands have run low, and he wishes to retire to complete some literary work he has now in hand.
BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- Receiver Beal furnishes the following as the state of the Maverick National Bank, as shown by its books at the close of business, Oct. 31, 1891:

Jay Gould's little third-track grab for his west side elevated road has been as successful as have been about all of that sly gentleman's "operations." Verily, Jay Gould is a sly person -- "sly, devilish sly," a regular "Joey Bagstock." Nothing could have been more characteristic of him than the manner in which he has succeeded in fooling the public and breaking the law in getting this third track.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- For three days the Chief Justice and Associate Justices of the Supreme Court have listened to lengthy arguments to save the neck of the negro, Frank Lingo, now under sentence of death for murdering Annie Miller in Camden. It was a remarkable argument, because it is a pertinent turn in two celebrated Jersey mysteries.

A very smooth performance of "Romeo and Juliet" was given at Hammerstein's Harlem Opera House last evening by Miss Gale, for many seasons leading actress in the support of Mr. Booth and Mr. Barrett, assisted by many of her old associates. Mr. Creston Clarke was Romeo, and Mr. H.A. Weaver, Jr., Mercutio. "Ingomar," "As You Like It." "The Hunchback," "The Lady of Lyons," and "The Duchess of Padua" are billed for the week.

Although CRISPI is no longer the Prime Minister of Italy, his words carry more weight in Europe than those of any other Italian statesman -- certainly more than those of his official successor. His reputation, either for sagacity or for dignity, will not be enhanced by the publication of that part of his letter to a French friend which asserts that the Pope "would sell his soul to recover the temporal power of the Papacy."

The fiftieth birthday of the Prince of WALES is an occasion which necessarily calls out the congratulations of the British press, although it presents a rather difficult thesis to the congratulator. The London Standard composes a eulogy that might have been made with equal pertinency upon the Prince's great-uncle GEORGE IV. of sacred memory, eighty years ago.

One of our neighbors, the Sun, is frequently moved by the appeals of its readers to discuss questions of social propriety and to diffuse the light of its accumulated wisdom for the instruction of perplexed lovers. Sometimes our neighbor is induced to rise above the problems of etiquette and unrequited love and to give advice to more mature applicants concerning provisions of law.

Dispatches from Saratoga published in the Tribune of Wednesday, Sept. 16, informed the readers of that journal that the Hill men had been beaten "when they attempted to have the committee [the Committee on Resolutions of the Democratic Convention] adopt as its silver plank Gov. HILL'S remarks in favor of the free coinage of silver by international agreement."

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- A fearful tragedy was enacted at the home of G.E. David, an aged resident of Green Township, Pike County, Penn., on Thursday last. A young farm laborer named Simon P. Field entered the premises of David armed with a shotgun. As David opened the door Field discharged the contents of the gun full in his face, blowing out both eyes and literally denuding his face of flesh.

DENVER, Col. Nov. 9. -- The Mansion Livery Stables, Eighteenth and Lawrence Streets, were almost completely destroyed by fire between 3:30 and 4 o'clock this morning. Four men, possibly six, rooming in the upper portion of the building, were suffocated, and many horses met death in the same way.

The Government test of armor plates, to be concluded during the present week at Indian Head, Md., is one of the most important events in the history of the new navy of the United States. As already show in the columns of THE TIMES, the initial test of last week demonstrated the ability of American establishments to fabricate armor plates equal to the best productions in Europe.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- State Superintendent of Banking Charles M. Preston gave to the public to-day the details of the examination of the Ulster County Savings Institution. Mr. Preston first gives a tabulated statement of the assets of the bank, the market value of them, , showing the deficiency to be $365,918.50, and the amount due depositors, $2,474,465.89.

Work at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday was unusually active. Nothing could be learned from Capt. Erben, the commandant, concerning his orders. Capt. Erben would only admit that he had imperative orders to have all vessels at present in commission at the yard prepared for sea with all possible haste. The commandant is carrying out his instructions in a decidedly characteristic fashion.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9. -- There have recently been several disgraceful scenes at the cemeteries and at the doors of Catholic churches, due to the refusal of Catholic priests to allow Grand Army men to enter the churches or cemeteries wearing uniforms and carrying banners. The latest affair was caused by Father Goller, who, while conducting the funeral of an old soldier, objected to the regalia, and enforced his objections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Now that the Speaker-ship fight is coming on, the District of Columbia begins to indicate its preference, and it will make it known more clearly when the contest is warmer.

We are confident that we are in accord with public opinion when we express regret that the Evening Post has seen fit summarily and without notice to repeal that excellent provision of the contract labor law which relates to professors for colleges and seminaries. This provision was set forth as follows in the act of March 3, 1891:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Not since Frank Hiscock and James J. Belden became the leaders of the two Republican factions in this Congressional district has there been such a wide breach in the party as to-day. The feeling is the most bitter that can be imagined, especially on the part of Senator Hiscock, who sees his re-election slipping away from him.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 9. -- The proclamation of Gen. John Palmer, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, objecting to the participation of members of that order in reunions. , where the Confederate flag is displayed, is the topic in Grand Army circles. A manifesto of this kind was foreshadowed several weeks ago, and the comrades are not taken by surprise.

In utter contempt of the restrictions of the law which allows the elevated railroads to construct additional tracks only with the consent of the local authorities and the property owners along the line, the Manhattan Railway Company has practically completed its third track on the west side above Fifty-ninth Street.

The splendid new quarters of the Mercantile Library in the building erected by the library and the Clinton Hall Association, on Astor Place, were formally opened yesterday with fitting ceremony. It is a coincidence that the day was the seventy-first anniversary of the Library Association. The building was opened for public inspection at 2 o'clock. The formal exercises began at 3 o'clock.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Judge Danforth of the Court of Appeals, retired, has given an opinion on the question of the eligibility of a Park Commissioner for the Legislature. The opinion is in the case of Franklin D.
