Sherwood, Republican Senator-elect in the Twenty-seventh District, but it also has a direct bearing on the case of Assemblyman-elect Curran of the Second Monroe, or Rochester district.
ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- The statement of election expenses filed with the Secretary of State by Controller-elect Frank Campbell says:

It is not surprising that Major MCKINLEY should think that McKinleyism has been, is, and will continue to be the chief issue, and practically the only issue between his party and the Democrats. Even if the facts were not so strongly on his side, it would be natural that he should think his own child the biggest, smartest, and most promising of all the children extant.

George F. Thomas, Sr., a demented old man of Flatbush, L.I., shot and dangerously wounded George E. Waldo, a relative, late on Sunday night. Thomas is seventy-five years old, and was formerly with the Appletons, publishers of this city. He edited their Guides to Travelers. Waldo is thirty-nine years old, and single, a lawyer at 32 Nassau Street, this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- The canvass for the Senatorship in Ohio opened with the knowledge that the Legislature was Republican, and is now the absorbing topic of conversation among these interested in public men and measures. The Leader of this city has undertaken to make a canvass of the members-elect, and will publish the result to-morrow morning.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 9. -- The Charleston arrived at Yokohama Sept. 21 from San Francisco. On the 24th Admiral Belknap transferred his flag to her, and henceforth she will be the flagship of the Asiatic squadron. Great crowds came on board to see the new cruiser, and her fame has been heralded by all the newspapers in this part of the world.

Heller, Rothschild Lang, woolen merchants of 690 Broadway, have been the victims of systematic robbery for the last three months. Woolen clippings and piece goods to the value of $1,000 have disappeared. As the firm could not discover the thief, Detective Sergeants Heidelberg and Jacobs were detailed on the case, and they soon traced the thefts to the firm's porter, Benjamin Techner of 57 Eldridge Street.

A young and handsome woman, tastefully attired, but with no baggage, went to the Grand Union Hotel Sunday evening and applied for a room. She registered as Mrs. Viola Greylock of Washington, D.C., and was assigned to Room 118, on the third floor. She spent the evening in her room, and yesterday morning went out several times.

DES MOINES, Nov. 9. -- The Iowa Democracy celebrated their recent and greatest triumph at the polls in a big demonstration here to-night. Gov. Boies was the principal speaker, although Lieut. Gov. Bestow and Judge Kinney, who were elected on the ticket with him, were also present. The Governor spoke for a half hour to a great crowd, which filled the Grand Opera House to its doors.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Never in the history of Syracuse University has there been so much rivalry and feeling between classes as at present between the sophomores and freshmen. The sophomores were victorious in the cane rush, where the feeling began.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Nov. 9. -- It is learned here, through Washington sources, that the Treasury Department will this Winter call upon Congress for a new vessel to replace the revenue cutter Wolcott, stationed on Puget Sound. The extensive smuggling operations in this section demand the presence of a strong force.

" We are preparing to manufacture a smokeless powder," said John F. Lohse of the California Powder Works, "that we think will be satisfactory to the Government, and we have a small plant now under way at Benicia. It is largely experimental as yet, and we would prefer to say nothing about it until we have demonstrated our ability to do something worth talking about.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- A dispatch from Pernambuco brings further alarming intelligence regarding the situation of affairs in Brazil. The Province of Grao Para has followed the example set by Rio Grande do Sul, and to-day it declared its independence. It is expected that this will be followed by a similar declaration by the Province of Bahia.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 10. -- The contested case for the State Treasurership of Marvin H. Sanger against E. Stevens Henry was down for trial in the Superior Court, before Judge Thayer, this morning. Ex-Judge Stoddard and Lawyer Hammersley of Hartford and State Attorney Doolittle were on hand, representing the plaintiff, and Lawyers Hyde and Gross of Hartford the defendant.

A very important sale was begun yesterday morning in the auction rooms of Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, at 64 and 66 White Street. Nearly every important dry goods, furniture, and carpet house in the country was represented. It was the sale of over 2,640,000 yards -- over $2,000,000 worth -- of carpets, the surplus product of the largest carpet mill in the world.

The Jersey City police have just discovered that some forger of considerable skill has been taking the name of Miss Winnie Davis, daughter of Jefferson Davis, in vain. He has sent letters in her name to United States Senator Gordon of Georgia and Dr. William Morrow of Nashville, Tenn., soliciting a loan of $1,000 upon Mrs. Davis's ninety-day note.

A man of quiet dress and pale, shaven face, in company with a young and attractive woman in a slate-colored gown and blue wrap, passed early yesterday afternoon into the City Hall and, unheeded by the habitues of that building, made their way up stairs to the Governor's Room. They were joined there presently by two friends, one of whom entered with City Clerk Ehrlich.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10. -- The following private letter has arrived here from an attorney who has been employed in investigating just how far Minister Egan is responsible for the disturbed condition of affairs between the United States and Chile. It is strongly Congressional in tone, but makes allegations and charges that are well worthy of investigation. The text of the letter is as follows:

Six months ago the statement that the New-York Life Insurance Company is "solvent" and has a "substantial surplus" would have interested nobody. At that time the company's financial standing was high. What is more, there was widespread confidence in the management of the company. Its policy holders felt no insecurity whatever.
ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- These statements of campaign expenses were filed with the Secretary of State to-day:

ST. PAUL, Nov. 10. -- A special to the Dispatch from Hayward, Wis., says two men and a boy are dying, three men seriously injured, and many others suffering from painful wounds as the result of a terrific explosion of dynamite which occurred at 12:30 o'clock this morning.

Contains, on Page 9, a report of the beginning at the auction rooms of Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, State Street, of the sale of the surplus product of the carpet mills of the Alexander Smith Sons' Carpet Company of Yonkers.

The gales and heavy weather of the last month have added many derelicts to the number of such wanderers, and the idea of reward has tempted several vessel agents and tug owners to send out vessels to search for those nearest the coast whose cargoes are known to be valuable. In many cases these vessels are comparatively new, and they have been abandoned owing to their being dismasted and uninhabitable.

The village Trustees of Mount Vernon met last night to consider what action should be taken with regard to supplying the New-Rochelle mains from the Mount Vernon reservoir. Both the New-Rochelle and the Mount Vernon water companies get their water from the Hutchinson River, New-Rochelle being up stream. Mount Vernon began to suffer from the drought about six weeks ago, and started pumping water from the Bronx River.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10. -- The difficulty between the Belt Line and the Brotherhoods of Locomotive Engineers and Locomotive Firemen culminated this morning in the declaration of a strike and boycott, which is likely to be far-reaching in its effects.

Suspense over the choice of a successor to the late Henry Wilder Allen was ended yesterday, when word reached the city that Gov. Hill had appointed County Clerk Leonard A. Giegerich Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, and that William J. McKenna, chief clerk in the District Attorney's office, had been appointed County Clerk. Official papers bearing the appointments had not reached the city last night.

For some time past there has been a great deal of interest in municipal circles, and among the public generally, of Newcastle, regarding a proposal to increase the Mayor's salary, seeing that the sum allowed does not cover the whole of the expenses the Chief Magistrate is called upon to meet. At present it is 300. A few days since it was resolved by the Finance Committee to let the matter remain in abeyance.

Two facts were clearly set forth at yesterday's hearing in this city before the special committee appointed to secure Congressional action relative to safety railway appliances. One was that the railroad companies do not desire any compulsory legislation, and the other was that the yard switchmen, almost to a man, favor the old-fashioned link-and-pin car coupler.

We are glad to announce the conversion of the Evening Post to the faith long held and preached by THE TIMES that the building of a dam to impound the waters of the Croton Valley should have begun and proceeded concurrently with the building of the aqueduct. "Of course we can all see now," says the Post, "that the construction of the great dam should have been begun simultaneously with that of the great aqueduct."

The identity of "Viola Greylock," the young woman who attempted suicide at the Grand Central Station on Monday afternoon, is as much a matter of speculation as at first. She positively refuses to tell anything about herself or her friends.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The Santiago correspondent of the Times telegraphs a long diatribe against false Chilean news sent by correspondents or invented in America, taking his text from the report of the blowing up of the United States cruiser Baltimore. He says:

It is plain from the reports of the Washington correspondents that the election of Mr. MILLS as Speaker of the next House is, to say the least, extremely probable, and, for reasons that are creditable to him and to his party. Should he receive that proof of confidence in his character and ability, it will be because he deserves it and because his party recognizes his deserts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Edward O. Leech, the Director of the Mint, has submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury a report of the operations of the mints and assay offices for the last fiscal year, of which the following is an abstract:

Among the prominent Democrats of Western Pennsylvania there is none better nor more favorably known than Mr. John B. Larkin, formerly Postmaster of Pittsburg. He is a native of that city and has lived and made his career there. He is not only a close observer, but has for many years been one of the most active workers in the party west of the Alleghanies.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 10. -- At the opening of the session of the Board of Canvassers this afternoon it was voted first to canvass the city returns. At the end of the canvass of the Second Ward Mr. Haight presented the following communication from John A. Bernhard protesting against the canvassing of the votes cast for Dr. Richard Curran on the ground of his ineligibility:

DUBLIN, Nov. 10. -- William O'Brien publishes a long letter in the Freeman's Journal denouncing the conduct of Redmond and Harrington in trying to deceive the Irish public by pretending, on the strength of their hope that he had lost Mr. Parnell's letter, that it disclosed some dark treachery toward Mr. Parnell or their Liberal allies.

During the last two or three days public interest has centred on two things -- elections and football. At last the political campaign is over, so there will be quiet in political circles for some time. Not so in the football field. Several weeks must elapse before she football fever will have run its course. Football is a mighty game, testing the courage, skill, and muscle of the players as no other athletic sport does.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Nov. 10. -- Some of L.T. Michener's friends have disclosed a secret which involves the Harrison Administration in an attempt to use the Pension Office to carry Indiana in the next Presidential election.
The following statements of expenses were filed by candidates yesterday in the County Clerk's office:

One of the pleasing habits of John Y. McKane of Gravesend, L.I., is to inflict rude shocks on persons who exhibit doubt as to his ownership of that cheerful Summer resort. The Kings County Water Supply Company got one of these shocks, and it was so violent that it shock the interest off the company's bonds before it was ripe enough to pluck, and nearly shock the hinges off the office safe.

It is a common observation that the perception of moral distinctions is greatly affected by custom and by self-interest. Wrongs that are very familiar, that have become a part of the daily life of a community, fail to excite the reprehension that is felt for them in places where they are exceptional. Familiarity breeds indifference in such matters, and the public conscience becomes quiescent under the influence of evils that are all-pervading.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Every man admits having seen "Nos Intimes" thirty years ago; women do not remember even the title of the play of M. Sardou. Perhaps it is for this reason that the Vaudeville Theatre, with a very old comedy, thoroughly well known to play readers at all events, attracts fashionable audiences with innumerable pretty faces.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The Elizabeth town Gaslight Company, which supplies the light to this city, got a decided rebuff yesterday from a number of women at Elizabethport who threatened to burn down a naphtha storage shed that the company had just erected at the corner of South Park and Fourth Streets. The old shed was destroyed by fire a few days ago, and several barrels of naphtha in it exploded and were consumed.

CALCUTTA, Nov. 10. -- Further details regarding the cyclone which passed over this part of India on Monday of last week show that the damage done is very extensive. In Orissa, a province of Bengal, the cyclone cleared a path through the forests, uprooting gigantic trees. Every dwelling in the path of the cyclone was swept from its foundations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The court room was well filled with leading members of the bar when court opened this morning and Solicitor General Taft resumed his argument.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Miss Helen Grace Downer, the pretty twenty-four-year-old daughter of Benjamin Downer of 27 Belmont Avenue, Jersey City Heights, attempted suicide in the ocean to-night, but was rescued. Miss Downer has an invalid father, and has been suffering from insomnia and melancholy for a year. At times she labors under intense mental excitement.

BATH, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- At the meeting of the canvassers of Steuben County to-day the Hon. I.W. Near of Hornellsville presented the protest of Col. Charles E. Walker, Democratic candidate for Senator, against counting the votes cast for Franklin D. Sherwood, the Republican candidate, on the ground that he was ineligible because he held the office of Park Commissioner of Hornellsville contrary to Section 8, Article III. of the Constitution.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 10. -- James and William Meachen of this city have just been notified that they, jointly with four other brothers, have fallen heir to an estate in England valued at the enormous sum of $6,000,000.

The first of the Seidl SoolBty's concerts was glvou in he Brooklyn Academy of Music last alght. The orchestra was, of course, that of .anton Seidl, and the soloists wore Mine. Fursch5ladL soprano, and Arthur Frledheim, pianist. here was a large audience present, and the society's season began with every evidence of an a_nred fingnolal gucesan.

One of the expected results of the late election in Iowa is the repeal of the prohibition law, and in view of that prospect the Prohibitionists are making an attempt to resurrect the old prohibition amendment of the Constitution, which was ratified in 1882, but declared by the Supreme Court of the State in the following year not to have been constitutionally adopted.

One of the rules of the elevated roads says that intoxicated persons must not be admitted to the cars. That rule is apparently a dead letter at most of the stations. An up-town Sixth Avenue train which left Park Place at about 7 o'clock last evening carried two passengers whose presence was an annoyance to twenty or thirty other occupants of a car and a shameful insult to the women in the car.

HARTFORD, Nov. 10. -- After a seven months' absence from the Capitol, the House will resume the "first day" of the session of 1891 to-morrow. Both parties will caucus concerning the situation during the forenoon, the Republicans having been called to meet at 11 o'clock and the Democrats at 12.

The attention of Attorney General MILLER will not be diverted, we hope, from the re-part that after the 1st day of January next the Duke of MARLBOROUGH and the Hon. ASHLEY PONSONBY, Secretary to her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland and Empress of India, will be members of the Steel Beam Trust.

The authorities of this city have been relying upon Providence for the last month to avert a water famine, and now they are warning people against waste and threatening to put them upon a short allowance. Until the coming of yesterday's rain there was a prospect of serious inconvenience and discomfort and of great pecuniary loss from lack of an ample supply of water.

Governor-elect FLOWER has sent to Mr. CHAPIN, Congressman-elect, a letter that is characteristic of his kindly nature, and that can hardly fail to be gratifying to the receiver. He congratulates Mr. CHAPIN on his election to Congress, and reminds him that it opens a career of greater usefulness than any he has heretofore pursued.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 10. -- The example set by the New-York Presbytery in the case of the Rev. Dr. Briggs was followed to-day by the Presbytery of Allegheny in its treatment of the Rev. J.H. Bausman, pastor of the Rochester (Penn.) Presbyterian Church.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 16. -- It is reported from diplomatic circles in Pekin that France and Russia have agreed that, in view of the recent attacks upon their subjects by the Chinese mobs during the past Summer and the ineffectual efforts made by the Chinese Government to give protection to foreigners, these countries should make reprisals upon China for the injuries incurred.

The man who insures himself in the New-York Life Insurance Company nowadays may be prepared to find that company ready to grant him any inducement, no matter how extravagant, in its efforts to place upon the books a large amount of new business before the close of the year. Agents are prepared to grant tremendous rebates, or, if the case demands, to waive a whole year's premium.

In the Court of Common Pleas yesterday Judge Bookstaver appointed Louis B. Hasbrouck, Dr. John Vanderpoel, and Seth H. Robinson a commission to inquire into the mental condition of Mrs. Louise S. Cowen. Mrs. Cowen is sixty-eight years old and the mother of Assistant Corporation Counsel Sidney J. Cowen, who made the petition for the appointment of the commission.

The remarks of the Marquis DI RUDINI upon the relations of the Kingdom of Italy to the Papacy were perhaps objectionable as being superfluous. Nothing has lately occurred to make timely any official restatement of those relations, unless it be the disorderly conduct of the French pilgrims, the treatment of whom by the Pope left nothing to be complained of by the Italian Government.

OTTAWA, NOV. 10. -- A great commotion has been caused here by the publication of an interview in an Ottawa paper with Mr. Philip Robinson, war correspondent of the London Times, who is here working up the political situation.

SHANGHAI, China, Oct. 16. -- Piracy still prevails along the Chinese coast despite the efforts made by foreign and native men-of-war to prevent it. It was supposed that with the beheading of fourteen of the pirates who wrecked the English steamer Namoa in March last, almost within sight of Hongkong, an effectual check had been put upon this style of robbery, but every few days other cases of piracy are reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Every friend of the Democratic cause of tariff reform will need to be on his guard against specious arguments advanced to prevent the election of Mr. Mills to the Speakership. Left to themselves and their own good judgment, the vast majority of the members of the Fifty-second Congress would, if the course of the party has been marked out, speedily decide in favor of Mr. Mills.

The great auction sale of carpets which was begun in this city yesterday is an object lesson to all who desire to understand the effect of that part of the McKinley tariff which relates to carpets and the wools which are the carpet manufacturers' raw material. It is well known that the carpet industry is not in good condition.

Before Mayor Grant departed on his rather unexpected trip to Europe yesterday he is said to have determined upon all the appointments to the School Board which he is required by law to make this month. The terms of seven Commissioners -- Messrs. Moriarty, Hunt, Tamsen, O'Brien, Sanger, and Peaslee, and Mrs. Powell -- will expire on Jan. 1, and under the law the Mayor is required to appoint their successors during the preceding November.

Mayor Chapin, Controller Jackson, and Auditor Weber met again yesterday in the Brooklyn City Hall and appointed Henry Haggerty and William Watson Police Justices under a law passed by the last Legislature. These appointments resulted from a deal by which Watson, who poses as a Republican, got the bill through the Republican Senate.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 11. -- A letter from Rio Grande City says: "It has been definitely ascertained that Calavero Garza, the man who led the recent revolutionary movement against the Mexican Government, has fled to Central America. He worked his way to the Mexican coast and thence took a sailing vessel for the Isthmus.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 11. -- The unexpected did not happen to-day. Twenty-eight Republican Senators popularly supposed to be of fair average intelligence deliberately voted that the Pennsylvania Constitution was unconstitutional. Then the Senate adjourned and each Senator and employe drew his pay and went home.
LISBON, Nov. 11. -- The Portuguese Government, in view of the grave state of affairs in Brazil, has decided to send some war ships to protect Portuguese interests in that republic.

Brooklyn Republicans were very much disgusted yesterday when they learned of how the gag rule had been applied by Chairman W.W. Goodrich at the General Committee meeting on Tuesday night. Very few of them had attended the meeting, thinking that Mr. Goodrich was still in California, where he went as soon as Meyer was nominated for Mayor, and that there would be nothing done.

The Trustees of Barnard College held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon, and, owing to the close relationship existing between Barnard and Columbia, the Trustees and President of the latter institution were invited to be present and hear how well Barnard College had done in the last three years. Arthur Brooks, President of the board, took the chair.

The administration of the New-York Life Insurance Company is remarkably persistent in compromising its affairs as much as possible. Although nearly a month has passed since the cashier and mathematician of the company publicly preferred his charges, the company has taken no steps that even partially weaken the effect of those charges.

A gentleman by the name of "PHIL' ROBINSON, who describes himself as a "war correspondent" of the London Times, has been retailing wisdom regarding Canadian affairs and their relations to this country. He announces that the movement for reciprocity with the United States is only a trick of the disloyal who hope in this way to shut out British imports from Canada.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Nov. 11. -- Deputy Marshal Fanmill passed through the city this morning with Mrs. Lottie Murphy, from Washita, Indian Territory, charged with counterfeiting. Mrs. Murphy is one of a gang several of whose members have been arrested. Her sister was arrested a few days ago for the same offense. All of the dies and receipts for making the spurious money have been captured, and the business has at least been temporarily checked.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 16. -- The Chinese Government has made a new departure from its usual policy of exclusion of foreign improvements and inventions, and is gradually introducing the two great civilizing influences of her Western neighbors -- the electric telegraph and the railroad.
POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The steamer Alert, while coming in Little Egg Harbor Inlet yesterday afternoon, lost Mr. Samuel Joyce of Philadelphia. He was drowned.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11. -- The Hon. W.W. Smith of Topeka, Kan., was at the Southern Hotel to-day. Mr. Smith is in the political "push" in Kansas, having been State Senator from Marshall County and State House Commissioner, and he is one of the best advised and most active among the political workers of the State.

The Treasury Department has just issued a circular to customs officers in regard to the importation of printed matter through the mails, after replying to letters from citizens asking for information about the matter.

It seems that the Aqueduct Commission has not been idle or indifferent in the matter of providing greater storage capacity for the water supply of this city, and decided some time ago upon the construction of a new dam on the Croton River at the site known as Cornell's, which will be put under contract as soon as the title to the necessary land can be secured.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- A heavy gale set in last night in the South of England and Ireland. It increased in violence and soon spread over the whole of England, blowing with hurricane force. To-night the weather is clear, and the gale has apparently subsided.

A notable Murray Hill wedding yesterday afternoon was that of Miss Jean Pollock Brown, daughter of Mrs. E. Bergh Brown of 309 Madison Avenue, and Walter Jennings, son of Mr. O.B. Jennings. The ceremony was performed at 3:30 o'clock in the South Church, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Terry, assisted by the Rev. Dr. John Hall.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Timothy Harrington has written a letter in which he charges William O'Brien with concealing the most important part of the Parnell correspondence in the negotiations held by the Irish leaders in Boulogne at the beginning of the present year, when dissension first arose in the ranks of the Irish Nationalists.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- Notwithstanding the evident desire of the Cramps to put the new war ship New-York in the water on Dec. 1, there may yet be a postponement of the launch owing to the numerous details yet to be finished prior to that event, and which can never be accurately estimated upon in point of time to complete.

DES MOINES, Nov. 11. -- The man who, having taken hold of the bear's tail, could neither hold on nor let go, was in a happy frame of mind compared with the Republicans of Iowa in their relations with the Prohibitionists. This condition is so plainly the result of political jugglery that the defeated party here can only express surprise that it did not come to its present state much earlier than it did.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- The Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad met here to-day and adopted two important resolutions. One declared a script dividend of 20 per cent. on the common stock payable Dec. 31, and the other provides for an issue of the common stock of the company of the par value of $5,096,600.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The first of the series of intercollegiate football games (League) was played here to-day between elevens from Union College and Syracuse University and resulted in a victory for Union by the score of 75 to 0. The last half was played in twenty minutes and 26 points were made in that time; then darkness caused a halt.

The first thing considered at the annual meeting of the National League of base ball clubs held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday was the protest filed by James Hart, President of the Chicago club some time ago asking that the games played between the New-Yorks and Bostons in the last series, and which gave the Bostons the championship, as they won all of them, be thrown out.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 11. -- Sir Baldwin Walker is once more the defendant in a suit for damages, the amount claimed being $20,000. A couple of years ago the British war ship Lily was wrecked on the coast of Labrador. At the instance of Sir Baldwin, who was in command of the Emerald, she was sold at auction, and was bought by Herbert Brookfield of this city.
OTTAWA, Ontario. Nov. 11. -- Moose hunting has begun in Quebec Province, and many hunters are now in search of the noble game.
George R. Lawrence, one of the most promising young lawyers of Pittsburg, Penn., killed himself with a pistol in the Everett House, Union Square, some time yesterday morning.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 11. -- The schools of this State pretending to give a higher education have hitherto been so inefficient as to furnish good ground for the severest criticism of the standard of the average Northwestern college. Small institutions in Olympia. Walla Walla, Spokane, Seattle, Tacoma, and Whatcom have borne the sounding title of "university" while teaching the studies of Eastern grammar and high schools.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 11. -- There were only two absentees on the Republican side when the House of Representatives was called to order this afternoon. In the caucus preceding the session Representative George Bulkley of Fairfield took the ground that all of the Democratic State officials below Governor were elected, and that the House should unite with the Senate in this declaration.

The Fifty-first Congress, with its billion scattered in every direction, made only a moderate contribution to the work of national defense by land and sea. It pared down the conservative estimates for the army gun factory. It made a liberal provision for the new navy during its first session, but in the second authorized only one new ship, although that, to be sure, was the costly triple-screw cruiser No. 13.

A letter has been received in this country within the last few days from an officer on the general staff of the German Emperor which declares in effect that war in Europe cannot be postponed beyond next Spring. The importance of this letter is all the greater in view of the fact that it has been received by an official high in the United States Government.

Morris S. Wise, Chairman of the special committee on commercial trade marks, reported to the Board of Trade and Transportation, at its meeting yesterday afternoon, the draft of a bill entitled "An act to authorize the registration of trade marks and protect the same."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- The Post Office at Highwood in the town of Hamden was entered by burglars at 2:30 o'clock this morning. They blew open the safe with a charge of giant powder which almost completely wrecked the building, and then robbed the safe of $600 in money and stamps and two gold watches. The explosion was heard all over the town and shattered windows on the neighboring streets.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- A dispatch from Santiago this afternoon brings the intelligence that the Chilean Junta is prepared to surrender the executive authority it has exercised since Balmaceda's downfall to the newly-organized Congress.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Dr. Charles A. Barnes of Mechanicsville, N.Y., was arrested in this city this morning on a telegram from Sheriff H.J. Woodworth of that place.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 11. -- Near Lagarto, an isolated little town in Live Oak County, one night last week occurred a very peculiar murder. Antonio Vera and Sebastian Torres, well-to-do Mexican ranchos, loved a girl named Chiquita Flores. Vera first met Chiquita, courted her, and was to marry her when the Fall crop of cattle was sold.

A further hearing was held by Surrogate Ransom yesterday in the proceedings in opposition to the issuing of letters testamentary on the will of Thomas Monaghan to his illegitimate son, Thomas Monaghan, Jr. The objection is made by another Thomas Monaghan, Jr., who is a legitimate son of Thomas Monaghan, but who was named William.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 11. -- No little sectional and religious feeling has been stirred up in this city within the past few days by the candidacy of J.A. O'Keefe of Lynn, Mass., who has been supported by the Democrats before the Board of Education for the vacant place of Principal of the High School, the most important place in the gift of the board.

STOCKTON, Cal., Nov. 11. -- The most marvelous performance of the year of phenomenal harness racing was the performance of Senator Stanford's two-year-old colt Arion over the kite-shaped track here yesterday. He trotted a mile without a single break or skip in 2:10 3/4, thus lowering his own record by 3 3/4 seconds and proving him to be the most wonderful horse ever bred.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11. -- Hallon D. Pearce, by his attorney, this afternoon applied for a writ of habeas corpus to compel Mr. and Mrs. John Frank, his wife's parents, to restore his wife to him.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- A railroad accident occurred at 11 o'clock last night at the Erie Company's long switch about a mile west of this city. A heavy eastward-bound freight train stood on the switch, when a westward-bound freight attempted to back down on the same siding in order to let the Chicago express passenger train go by.

More of the alleged illegal transactions of John Hoey while President of the Adams Express Company was disclosed yesterday in a suit brought in the United States Circuit Court at Trenton, N.J., by Henry Sanford as President of the Adams Express Company and a stockholder thereof. The suit was to restrain John Hoey and Josephine Hoey, his wife, and Frederick C. Hoey, their son, from disposing of any of their property.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Several instances of irregular and fraudulent practices of the Republicans at the last election in Dutchess County have been published in the press of New-York.

There is nothing surprising in the fact announced by the Attorney General of the United States on Tuesday before the Supreme Court, that an agreement had been reached between our Government and that of Great Britain for submitting to arbitration the main questions involved in the Bering Sea controversy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Patent Commissioner Simonds has been in demand to-day by a greater number of newspaper men than he has met in one day since he had in charge the passing of the International Copyright bill through the House of Representatives. The search seems to have been set on foot by the same man who reported that the President, regardless of the limitations of the Constitution, was about to declare war with Chile.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 11. -- The American Bankers' Association began its seventeenth annual convention to-day. There are about 300 delegates in attendance, including a large number from the Southern country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11. -- It is clearly manifest that the managers of ex-Gov. Foraker's Senatorial fight overstepped the mark in a most provoking manner when they started out claiming everything and intimating that as they had "a dead sure thing" they were not particularly anxious about cultivating new acquaintances.

The Commissioner of Public Works transmitted to the Aqueduct Commissioners late yesterday afternoon, after the stated meeting of the Commissioners had taken place, final plan sheet No. 5 of 1891, and six similar property maps showing the lands required for the construction of a high masonry dam for a reservoir between Quaker Bridge and Croton Dam, to be known as "Corneil's" Dam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11. -- Sixteen miners have returned from the gold fields of Alaska, and are loud in their complaints against outrageous treatment received at the hands of the Alaska Commercial Company.

A good many policy holders in the New-York Life Insurance Company have made inquiry, since the present trouble with the company's management began, concerning the date of the annual elections. None of them appears to know when the election takes place, and none appears to have given the matter any thought until forced to do so in self-defense.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- Brockton owes its existence to the manufacture of shoes, and its growth has all come since hides were placed on the free list. Her leading shoe manufacturers, regardless of politics, condemn in strong terms the taxing of hides, proposed by Secretary of Agriculture Rusk.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The Democrats of this city held their convention this afternoon at the City Assembly Rooms, to nominate candidates for Mayor, Alderman at Large, who shall be President of the City Council, and four Freeholders. State Senator Marsh, Chairman of the City Democratic Executive Committee, called the convention to order. Ex-Assemblyman Matthews was selected Chairman and ex-Alderman Smith Secretary.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 12. -- The American Bankers' Association closed its session to-day. A committee on nomination presented the names of R.M. Nelson of Selma, Ala., for President and John Jay Knox of New-York for Vice President, besides a list of members of the Executive Council and Vide Presidents for the various States. The nominees were elected.

Mr. RUSSELL B. HARRISON'S paper in Montana has found in the Pittsburg Dispatch a paragraph in which that journal complains that when we directed attention to the recent reduction of wages in the factories of Mr. CARNEGIE and Mr. B.F. JONES we "omitted to mention the fact that the tariff on the product of these works was reduced nearly 40 per cent. by the McKinley bill."

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 12. -- The official returns of the late election were computed at the State Department to-day as follows: For Auditor General -- Gregg, 414,583; Wright, 356,431; Hague, 18,511; scattering, 236. For State Treasurer -- Morrison, 412,994; Tilden, 358,617; Drayton, 18,429; scattering, 236. Constitutional Convention -- For, 173,813; against, 420,598.

Seldom save in times of political excitement is there held a meeting so large and so enthusiastic as was that which gathered at Chickering Hall last night under a call to the people of New-York to meet and voice their sympathy with the people of Louisiana in their fight against the Louisiana State Lottery, which is seeking to have its existence prolonged by a constitutional amendment.

Thomas E. Chace, the alleged opium smuggler, whose arrest was noted in yesterday's TIMES, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday for examination. The charge against him is based upon the fact that 1,000 pounds of unstamped opium was discovered in a trunk in his possession, in a downtown hotel, upon which no duty had been paid. It had come from Montreal.
Considering the gravity of the charges there is no escaping the conviction that the finding of the department must inevitably damn either Mr. Banta or Mr. Beers.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- A dispatch received here to-day from the Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Senhor Chermont, says that the reports declaring that disorders are prevalent in a number of places throughout the country are not based on truth, and that the allegations made that a movement is under way for the restoration of the monarchy are absolutely without foundation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Richard Curran may be ineligible for the Assembly, but whether that is true or not it is pretty nearly certain that John A. Bernhard, the Democratic contestant for his seat, is not qualified to take the place.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 12. -- In the Church of the Sacred Heart to-day Charles Ludlow Livingstone of New-York was married to Miss Mary Emily Keating, daughter of A.F. Keating of this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Father Kane. The maid of honor was Miss Katharine Keating, sister of the bride. The ushers were Messrs. E.H. Keating. A.F.K. Pane, C.C. Griffin, and Paul Dunlevy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The work of the Dutchess County Canvassing Board continues slowly. In about every election district clerical errors, affecting no candidate's votes, are found. Amenia has been passed, and so has Beekman. In Clinton clerical errors have been found, and a committee has been sent there to get the returns corrected.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Within a stone's throw of the Haymarket armed Anarchists to-night again met the Chicago police. The result was a most ignominious defeat for the men of the red flag.

The Philadelphia Ledger, with persistent fidelity to the public interests, whatever the party may suffer, makes a suggestion to Gov. PATTISON that may bear fruit. It points out that the Senate has decided that it has no jurisdiction in the cases of BOYER and MCCAMANT, because the offenses charged are such as should cause the offenders to be proceeded against both by impeachment and indictment.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 12. -- The midnight train from Chicago on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road was robbed by masked men near Western Union Junction at 1 o'clock this morning. The junction is twenty-three miles south of this place.

The time within which candidates at the late election in this State are required by the act of April 4, 1890, to file a statement of their election expenses expires to-day, and, presumably, the statements are all on file. The substance of many of these has been published, and they plainly show that the chief purpose of the law has not been attained.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 12. -- About 5 o'clock this morning fire broke out in the centre of Ybor City, a suburb of this city. Fire alarm and telephone wires were in bad order and there was a long delay in getting the fire companies at work. The water pressure was also too low for effective service.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12. -- Thomas E. Chace, the Providence man arrested in New-York charged with opium smuggling, is a man about fifty-five years old, and, until a couple of years ago, was identified with two or three businesses that were not successfully managed. A dozen or more years ago there was a dyewood concern in this city, under the title of the Providence Dyewood Company, of which he was Treasurer.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 12. -- Anent the article in to-day's Baltimore Herald atttacking Mr. Mills, the Republic will say to-morrow editorially: ...

The convention of the Church Temperance Society, which assembled in this city yesterday, will do good, if in no other way, by calling the public attention to the efforts and the objects of the society. The Prohibition Party, so called, has never achieved any valuable results. Its efforts have been directed exclusively to obtaining a legal prohibition of the manufacture and sale of intoxicating drinks.

The robbery of an express car on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad is the boldest performance of the kind that has been chronicled for a long time. It was much bolder than the recent robbery of an express car in this State, as that did not involve an interference with the movement of the train.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The Santiago correspondent of the Times says that further advices received from Rio Grande do Sul are to the effect that the garrisons at San Gabriel and Bage have also revolted against the Dictatorship of Gen. da Fonseca. The chief members of the opposition are Viscount Pelotas, Baron Juguy, and Gens. Astrogildo and Tavares.

Mr. CHAPIN'S latest demonstration in the Mayor's office of Brooklyn is as remarkable as anything that has preceded it. He has taken it into his head -- generally supposed to be a cool head -- to try to force on the Board of Education a member of the name of BARTHMAN, who was compelled to resign, after investigation, under charges affecting his financial honesty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Information has been received at the Department of State to the effect that in three towns in the Brazilian Province of Rio Grande do Sul the military have joined the citizens in opposing the domination of the Fonseca Government.
The following business was transacted at the Erhange and Auction Room yesterday. (Thursday,) ov. 1S:

If the silly statement printed in the Baltimore Herald charging Mr. MILLS with having made pledges in regard to the composition of the Coinage Committee of the House in case he is chosen Speaker was inspired by the opponents of his candidacy for the office it was very poor tactics, for it is so absurd in itself and so speedily and effectually refuted that it can do him no possible harm.

At 6:30 o'clock last evening over a hundred friends of Mr. and Mrs. Albert S. Rosenbaum assembled in the large reception room at Delmonico's, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, to witness the marriage of their daughter, Annie Sophie Rosenbaum, to Solomon Kalten Lichtenstein, a young lawyer of this city. The beautiful floral decorations were attractive because of their originality.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 12. -- Before Notary Public Charles Sherwood in this city this afternoon the deposition of ex-Vice President Clapp Spooner of the Adams Express Company was taken in the case of the express company against him. The matter in the document now in the hands of Clerk Shelton of the Superior Court refers particularly to the loan made to ex-President Hoey on the Hollywood property in New-Jersey.
ST. LOUIS. Nov. 12. -- Democratic leaders and party men of prominence from all parts of the State met here in force to-day, and took action of importance to the party.

The tenth annual convention of the Church Temperance Society met yesterday at Annex Hall, 16 Fourth Avenue. The aim of this society is to make men temperate, and to do it not by espousing the cause of prohibition, but by the reclaiming of individuals. There were three sessions yesterday -- at 10 A.M., at 2:30 P.M., and at 7:30 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- The annual cane spree between the freshman and sophomore classes was held Thursday night on the campus in front of Witherspoon Hall. This is an old-time custom and does not savor of the roughness of the general cane rush as it is held in other colleges, but it is more a trial of strength and skill, in which the better man wins.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 13. -- The Globe Loan and Trust Company, which was supposed to be doing business in this city for the last seven months, lending money to owners or purchasers of houses for homes and allowing them to return principal and interest in monthly payments on an installment mortgage, has suddenly collapsed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 13. -- It is learned that the conferences that have been going on here for the past twenty-four hours between the Democratic Mayors of St. Paul, Minneapolis, and Stillwater, and the Alliance leaders of the First Second and Fifth Minnesota Congressional Districts had for their object the laying of the groundwork for Democratic fusion on Presidential Electors and the State ticket next year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- The fight for the Assembly seat for this district has developed into a war of legal giants, and every technicality is used by each side to gain an advantage, however slight.

A good deal of party infatuation has been exhibited in the Republican interpretation of the significance of the recent elections. The plain fact is that national issues entered largely into the contests in the several States, and in a general way the people passed judgment upon the relative merits of the party policies involving those issues, but in each State the result was affected in a greater or less degree by local causes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The attack upon the sailors of the United States steamer Baltimore was made Oct. 16, nearly a month ago, but up to this time neither the State Department nor the Navy Department has been supplied with any account of the attack that explains its suddenness, or furnishes any specific occasion for so violent an exhibition of dislike for Americans.

Some Western statesmen, in explaining the sudden diminution of the power of the Farmers' Alliance in the Northwest, have been giving very far-fetched reasons for a result of which the real reason is very simple. In Kansas the Alliance vote was this year about half of what it was in 1890 -- 70,000 against 140,000.

The United States authorities are hauling Gov. Abbett's State Riparian Board over the coals for an invasion of territory they have no right to go upon. THE TIMES has already told the story of the controversy between the State and the National Government over the shore front off Communipaw and Greenville. Abbett's State Board wanted to gobble up the reefs at deep water in the name of the State and sell them for commercial use.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- County Clerk Conway was to-day removed from office on the charges presented to the Governor several months ago. The removal causes no surprise. Conway expected it, and, if reports in circulation are true, he sought, when it was too late, to prevent it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Brig. Gen. Thomas L. Casey has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War, including his recommendations for appropriations for the next fiscal year.

The funeral of Mrs. Ray R. Maynard, the wife of George H. Maynard of 313 Hart Street, Brooklyn, was stopped yesterday by Coroner Rooney, who acted at the request of the dead woman's uncle, Aaron Vandewerker. He didn't charge that there was any foul play, but he thought there was something suspicious about his niece's death.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 13. -- The local politicians of Quebec are in a peck of trouble, following on the recent investigation of boodling charges. J.P. Whelan, a well-known Government contractor, comes forward with wholesale charges. He had a contract to build a court at Quebec, and there being some difficulty about getting his money, he says he was bled right and left.

The anti-Quay Republicans in Philadelphia, who have two separate organizations, are beginning already to shape their efforts directly for the defeat of the Senator's reelection in 1893. To accomplish this they will have to secure the election of at least a sufficient number of Republican members of the next Legislature pledged against QUAY to hold the balance of power between the Democrats and the Quay Republicans.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 13. -- The Cheyenne National Bank closed its doors after a quiet run of an hour to-day, and posted a notice announcing its temporary suspension on account of lack of funds to meet demands of depositors. The liabilities are $260,000, and the bank is solvent, with $40,000 in exchange in Chicago and New-York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- The economies, industrial, and financial problems of the age are to be discussed by the World's Fair Congress Auxiliary. These problems have been assigned to the Department of Commerce and Finance. The department includes transportation, exchange, and distribution, with the divisions of banking, stock exchanges, boards of trade, water commerce, railway commerce, and insurance.

A number of prominent citizens of this city were amazed yesterday morning to find themselves connected by the World with a grandiose scheme for the complete regeneration of society. Their names appeared as signed to a circular letter which had, it was said, been addressed to prominent clergymen of the city.

Catharine Boulivette and Dr. Ira Richmond are under arrest at Brockton, Mass., on a charge of having a counterfeiting outfit in their possession. They had been partners in a private hospital, and a quarrel between them led to the discovery of the outfit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- The seventeen Anarchists arrested last night were taken to Justice Woodman's court to-day. The police testified to the raid on the meeting and declared that the prisoners were acting in a disorderly manner. The trial continued all day and resulted in the examination of only four of the defendants.

The trial of a suit brought by Andrew W Gill for an accounting from William R. Green as to $500,000 was begun yesterday before Judge Ingraham in Special Term of the Supreme Court. It is alleged by Gill that he and Green formed a partnership in 1888 at Denver, Col., to secure options on breweries, hotels, and mining properties, and place them with English syndicates to be formed for that purpose.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Admiral Gherardi's friends say that it is probably true that he urged upon the department, when he was here, the appointment of himself to command the United States fleet in the Southern Pacific, in case of hostilities with Chile.

The Patria Club had its first meeting of the season last evening at Sherry's. The subject for discussion was "Christianity in Politics," and it was handled in a vigorous fashion by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, ex-Corporation Counsel John A. Taylor of Brooklyn, and Assistant United States Treasurer Ellis H. Roberts. Ex-Judge Warren Higley presided.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The highly-successful London season of Augustin Daly's comedy company from New-York was brought to a brilliant close to-night. The advice given by the metropolitan press to its readers not to miss the final performance of the company, when that paramount favorite with the public here, "The Last Word," was to be given, evidently did not go unheeded.

Secretary RUSK appears to have made some inquiries about leather since the recent elections, for he now expresses the opinion that if a duty should be imposed on hides the manufacturers of shoes would escape the punishment which he longs to inflict upon them. Immediately after the election he was deeply moved by the ingratitude of certain voters in Massachusetts. What he said was reported by the New-York Tribune as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- The Board of Supervisors surprised everybody to-day by refusing to provide for the publication in the two party organs of this city, the Union and Advertiser and the Democrat and Chronicle, of the official proceedingss of the board. The following resolution was adopted:

Quotations for Mr. Thomas C. Platt's United States Express Company's stock have been declining in a way that has attracted a good deal of attention in Wall Street. Two sales of the shares were reported on the Stock Exchange yesterday. One was of a fifty-share lot and the other of a six-share lot. In both cases the price reported was 40.

One of the most noticeable points of difference between our war ships and those of Chile, brought into prominence by the recent diplomatic flurry between Santiago and Washington, was that of torpedo outfits. While Chile has a supply of automobile torpedoes for all her principal vessels, we have none at all.

The racehorse Ormonde, on which an English syndicate invested 42,000 in buying him from an Argentine stud owner, was recently offered to the British Government. Mr. Chaplin, President of the Board of Agriculture, declined to accept Ormonde on the ground that he was a "roarer," holding that the affection known as "roaring" was hereditary.

ST. LUCIE, Fla., Nov. 13. -- Thus far since his arrival here, Senator Quay has had fair luck at tarpon fishing. On Nov. 7, he caught three. No. 1 was 4 feet long and weighed 30 pounds; No. 2 was 412 feet long and weighed 48 pounds, while No. 3 was 512 feet long and tipped the scales at 81 pounds.

BRIDGEFORT, Conn., NOV. 13. -- The Sir Titus Salt Plush Company, the concern recently removed from England to this city, has now a case to fight for violation of the contract labor law, and in addition the ompleyes brought with the concern from England are leaving the company and returning to their homes. In the last tuonth about fifty have left this city and taken passage for England.

Lord SALISBURY'S speech at the Lord Mayor's banquet on Monday may be taken as embodying the Conservative platform. As a general election cannot be long delayed, it is interesting to foreigners and important to Britons to know the issues upon which it is to be contested. The speeches of the Prime Minister on civic occasions have always furnished a sufficiently authoritative exposition of the programme of the party in power.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13. -- The finest ball ever given in Lexington was that which was held here to-night at Phoenix Hall and was given by Capt. J.C. Bryant and the Brown Light Infantry, a new military organization formed here a few months ago and named after Kentucky's new Governor. The hall was beautifully and lavishly decorated with flags, bunting, and military accoutrements.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Late last night the Board of County Canvassers of Sullivan County, in session at Monticello, awarded the certificate of election to the Assembly to Joseph Krenrich, Republican, by an apparent majority of 1 vote. The board stands 9 Republicans and 6 Democrats.

Mayor Chapin did not show up at the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday, so that the committee appointed by the Board of Education to find some way of having William Barthman's appointment revoked had nothing to do. This committee consists of five members, with John K. Creeney as Chairman. His associates are Messrs. Swanstrom, Rowe, Wier, and McNamee.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision reversing Surrogate Ransom's ruling that the shares in the estate of Mrs. Cornelia M. Stewart received by Charles J. Clinch and Sarah N. Smith, under the distribution by ex-Judge Hilton at the close of the litigation over the Stewart will, were subject to the collateral inheritance tax.

Whatever may be the truth about the situation in Brazil, it is plain that it is very much more serious than the official dispatches admit. The Government is itself responsible for the suppression of information, having taken possession of the telegraphs, and this is a fact from which only unfavorable conclusions can be drawn.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 13. -- In the trial of the Whisky Trust case against the State Live Stock Commission for destroying 125 head of cattle, a portion of which were afflicted with lumpy jaw, the testimony to-day was of a peculiar kind.

CHICXGO, NOV. 13. -- A double murder was committed last night, the vietims being Mrs. Gretchen Lenzenbager, who kept a saloon at 444 outh Clark Street, and her fifteen-year-old son George. The woman was choked to death by robbers, who then beat and choked the boy [ until life left his body.

It would be difficult to imagine a system of espionage more complete than that which President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company is exercising over the employes in his office. Every clerk is as closely watched as if he were a murderer or some other criminal. Employes seen whispering together or conversing in low tones are "spotted." Employes who read THE NEW-YORK TIMES at their desks do so at their peril.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- This city was full of politicians of both parties from all over Columbia County to-day, as it was expected that the Board of Canvassers would complete their labors and report to-night. There was much excitement when a resolution was carried to adjourn to Monday, the board not having officially canvassed a single district in the county.

The second of the series of three pigeon-shooting matches at 100 live birds, at thirty yards rise, with fence boundary under Hurlingham rules, between E.D. Fulford and John L. Brewer of Hammonton, N.J., for $200 a side on each match, took place yesterday on the grounds of the Jersey City Heights Gun Club at Marion. N.J. Shooters from all parts of the country were present.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 14. -- It is believed that this is the only place in the United States where the old English custom of celebrating Pope Night is continued yearly in remembrance of the discovery of the plot of Guy Fawkes to blow up the Parliament House in London, with the King, Lords, and Commons, on Nov. 5, 1605, in revenge for the penal laws against Roman Catholics.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Charles M. Morton, alias William Lumbard, who was arrested yesterday on the charge of uttering a forged draft on the Farmers' Bank of Wheatland, Cal., depositing it in the bank at Utica, N.Y., is one of the most remarkable characters ever known by the police of this city. At the time of his arrest and since his incarceration he has scarcely uttered a word.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14. -- Young Mr. Baird of Madera Bank fame, under arrest here charged with forgery of bank stock, notes, and other papers to the extent of $100,000, spent the forenoon to-day in the office of the Chief of Police, where a number of friends called upon him. Baird was detained in custody as a prisoner on route to Madera, and was spared the humiliation of being placed behind the bars.

THE FEMALE BOGTROTTER. -- We are becoming a little surfeited with these wild women as globetrotters and travelers. Their adventures, which for the most part are fictions based on a very small substratum of fact, have ceased to impress, partly because we have ceased to believe, and certainly ceased to respect.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14. -- In the book of Job are found the solemn and beautiful words, "Man that is born of a woman is of few days, and full of trouble. He cometh forth like a flower, and is out down; he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not."

It would be misleading to say that no life of Sir John Franklin has heretofore been written. Of his arctic voyages and overland journeys, of the various expeditions to learn his fate, the fullest accounts were long since printed, and some of them the world almost knows by heart. And yet it is true that no conservative biography such as the present has heretofore been attempted.

Although the campaign is over, the People's Municipal League has not finished its work. The Executive Committee held a meeting on Friday night and discussed how it might further the cause of municipal and ballot reform.

The market has been dominated the past week by the local situation in respect to the coal stocks, and the foreign situation, which affects all securities having an international market. Last Monday the selling of stocks was comparatively large. London sold and the traders sold, the latter the coalers principally; so that the whole list was weak.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Nov. 14. -- President Scott has announced these subjects for the seniors' essays: "Silver Legislation in the United States for the Past Twenty Years," "The single Tax Theory," "The Present, and Future of Irrigation in the United States," "Federal Representative Legislation in Adjusting the Relations of Labor and Capital."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The second trial of armor plates manufactured by American establishments took place to-day at the grounds at Indian Head. That the test was interesting was evident from the large attendance of critical observers, more than 200 of whom were at Indian Head at the cost of some personal discomfort at 9 o'clock this morning, when the firing began.

THE GRINGO. -- There is a popular delusion to the effect that the Chileans call themselves "the English of South America." No one within the memory of man ever heard them do so, and the statement seems to have had its birth in the self-flattering imagination of some Anglo-Saxon writer.

THE PARISIAN HOUSE OWNER. -- The owner some dozen years ago of a rather dilapidated dwelling in the Rue Neuve des Mathurins -- a fussy little man -- being informed that an applicant for his vacant third floor had presented himself, desired him to be shown up, in order that he might treat with him in person.

The Professor of Mathematics at Columbia College, in the volume under notice, presents a fairly ample sketch of geodesy, and promises at some future time to give a critical history of this most interesting study. There must have been implanted in early man at least that curiosity which prompted him to find out where he was, or the relationship between his own field or range of mountains or country with other sections of the land.

The Crescent football team of Brooklyn defeated the New-York Athletic Club's team yesterday on the Polo Grounds and thereby won the championship of the Amateur Football Union. The playing of the Crescents was not marked with that amount of brutal slugging which characterized their work when they met the Manhattan Athletic Club team at Eastern Park two weeks ago; still, the disgrace of marring of a fair game fell against the Brooklyn team.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The receipts from the big University-Princeton football game at Manheim on Saturday last amounted to $8,800. Of this 10 per cent. went to the proprietors of the ground, and the remainder was divided equally between the two contesting teams.

An interested audience listened yesterday morning to Judge Shipman's charge to the jury in the trial in the United States Circuit Court of Mrs. Mary E. Russell's suit against James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park, N.J., to recover $16,000 for malicious prosecution. The first thing for the jury to consider, Judge Shipman said, was whether Bradley caused the action against Mrs. Russell to be begun.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The literary event of the week is Churton Collins's acknowledgment of the authorship of the Cornhill Magazine article, published long ago, on "Tennysonian Origins." By a republication in an extended form, under the title "Illustrations of Tennyson," Mr. Collins does not profess to accuse the poet of plagiarism, but he brings up parallel passages showing that Tennyson borrowed ideas and phrases by the wholesale from previous authors, always, however, improving them.

The first Winter entertainment of the Young Men's Hebrew Association took place last night at the Hebrew Institute at East Broadway and Jefferson Street. The large auditorium was filled, and many who came to attend the entertainment were unable to get in. There was some delay in opening the doors caused by the temporary disability of a dynamo which furnishes light to the establishment, but, once started, the affair was an entire success.

It would seem that the Barthman "pull" in Brooklyn is at once potent, extensive, and complex. Having been used to induce Mayor CHAPIN to reappoint to the Board of Education a member who, he declared, ought to resign as unfit to associate with honest men, it has now proved equal to inducing at least one member to withdraw his protest against the reappointment.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- S.C. De Soissons passed last night in a cell of Police Station No. 4, on Lagrange Street. This man is well known about town, and there is probably not an artist about Boston whose acquaintance he has not tried to cultivate.

DURATION OF THE LIGHTNING. -- Authorities differ as to the time of duration of the lightning flash; but all agree that it is less than the 10,000th part of a second. The experiment which establishes this fact is due to the late Sir Charles Wheatstone. A disk, divided into alternate sectors of black and white, is caused to rotate very rapidly on its axis, and by daylight it appears of a uniform gray.

The National Convention, is six months or more off, and there is ample time for new circumstances to occur and new problems to develop. At present, however, everything points to Grover Cleveland as the Democratic candidate for President. In such States as the party succeeded in at the late elections the platforms conformed to his principles.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 15. -- The details of the massacre at Lo Canas, by which many of Chile's promising young men were killed, is thus told in the Chilean Times:

" Fuss and feathers" seems a peculiarly appropriate characterisation of the work of the artist in millinery materials this Fall. Certainly there never were quite so many feathers, and of fuss the like never has been seen. Gowns maintain an appearance of simplicity, though it is an appearance merely, but bonnets and hats make no such pretense.

QUEBEC, Nov. 14. -- The country was startled the other day by the publication in a Toronto paper of a charge made against the Provincial Government to the effect that they had blackmailed John P. Whelan, contractor, to the extent of $115,000. Phelan was contractor for the construction of the Quebec Court House. The contract price was about $200,000, but before it was completed it cost the Province some $900,000.

Miss Bessie Remsen Webb, daughter of Gen. and Mrs. Alexander S. Webb, was married yesterday afternoon at her home, 15 Lexington Avenue, to George Burrington Parsons. The invitations to the wedding were limited to the immediate connections of both families.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 14. -- A sensation was created in society circles about 1 o'clock this morning by a pitched battle between Robert Breckinridge, son of the silver-tongued Congressman, Col. William C.P. Breckinridge, and Dault Arnold, a well-known society young man of Frankfort and a preacher's son.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 14. -- W.W. Thomas of Portland gave the donation which enabled Messrs' Cheever and Bond to purchase the bust of the Hon. Cyrus Hamlin which has just been received by the college. The Hon. Cyrus Hamlin graduated in the class of '34 and has held many important positions, among them being the Presidency of Robert College of Constantinople and the Presidency of Middlebury College.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 14. -- There are more cottagers here than usual in the middle of November, and several of them will remain for some weeks yet, but none of them through the Winter. The weather this week has been delightful.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- The managers of ex-Gov. Foraker's Senatorial campaign gave out last night some information calculated to produce a sensation and put the friends of Senator Sherman in a new, if not pleasant, position. It is charged that for some time past it has been known that influences have been brought into the contest suggestive of boodle, but that heretofore nothing could be learned calculated to justify the making of the charge.

HARTFORD, Nov. 14. -- The observance of Thanksgiving in the town of Norwich, in this State, is attended by an interesting custom, dating back at least 100 years. The city is built on a series of hills, known as "The Jail Hill," "Laurel" and "Geer's," while in Norwich Town the local designations include Greeneville and "The Falls."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The scene at Marcus Hook to-day was interesting, as 100 armed workmen and the Sheriff of Delaware County were necessary to preserve the security of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad in the possession of its wharf property there.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 14. -- Brown played her tenth and last game of the season this afternoon before a much larger crowd than has attended any previous game this year. It was a game too one-sided to be particularly interesting, and the only features were that no one was hurt and that the referee, Aldrich, gave perfect satisfaction to both sides.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- An event of no little international interest will occur next Tuesday, in the reception to be given by the leading French Canadian Societies of this city to the Hon. Wilfrid Laurier, a distinguished member of the Dominion Parliament, and the leader of the Opposition party. He will be accompanied by 150 prominent citizens of Montreal.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The students who covered themselves with glory and everything else with green paint on Hallowe'en are suffering considerably from nervousness, as the President has as yet failed to announce the decree of punishment. It is not at all likely that Dr. Hill will allow the matter to rest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Senor Montt, the Chilean Minister, was formally presented to the President at 11 o'clock this morning by the Secretary of State. The Minister was accompanied by Senors Anibal Cruz, Secretary of Legation, and Guellermor Arenanetegan and Valentin del Campo, attaches. They were all in full evening dress, in accordance with the custom in South American countries on state occasions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Secretary Foster has just loaded upon the Treasury service a person who had many references, but none from his most recent employers. He has made William H. Barker, alleged to be of New-York, a special agent of the Treasury at $8 a day and his expenses.

It was unfortunate that a little journey I made to Niagara Falls a short time ago was made before the Empire State Express began to run. That train might have carried me to Buffalo in eight hours and forty minutes, but the train I went in took eight hours and forty-four minutes, and every New-Yorker knows what, in these hustling times of haste, four minutes may possibly be worth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $154,612,550, as follows: Currency 6s, $10,415,000; 4 1/2 per cents, $198,950; 4 per cents, $121,350,600; 2 per cents, $21,648,000.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 14. -- Fifty miners employed in the Leggett's Creek colliery of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company had a thrilling escape from death on Wednesday. The great pump which was used to draw water from the mine, and which generally put it out in a steady stream, broke, and the colliery began flooding rapidly.

During a family fight yesterday morning at 667 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, Philip Cummings stabbed his brother-in-law, John Tenant, in the neck, severing an artery. Cummings was held without bail, as Tenant's condition was reported by Ambulance Surgeon York to be critical.

WHAT CAME FROM THE RUBBING OF AMBER. -- Inventions from the hand of man are always cumulative. He begins on his own account, taking nothing whatever from the hand of Jove. He begins from small things. He progresses from small to large, and at last attains perfection. We could find no grand development in human mechanism that had not been carried out in this manner, step by step.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Miss Katharine Stuart Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gilman Hoffman of Arlington Avenue, East Orange, and Edward S. Retts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Betts of Brooklyn, were married Tuesday afternoon by the Rev. George S. Bishop, D.D., of the First Reformed Church at the residence of the bride's parents.

To those who are not unmindful of the growth and power of trade combinations in this country or of the slow and almost imperceptible movement of legal proceedings for the restraint of them, a recent decision of the Michigan Supreme Court is peculiarly interesting. The suit was that of one LOVEJOY, a manufacturer of knives, against one MICHAELS, a manufacturer of machines used by coopers in making hoops.

The agency for handling cellulose in the United States has been secured by Ostheimer Brothers of Philadelphia, who are now arranging with the Navy Department for the placing of cellulose on the hulls of the new United States battle ships Indiana, Massachusetts, and Oregon. The cellulose manufacture is at present controlled exclusively in France.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14. -- Antiquarian W.W. Snaith has obtained conclusive evidence that the trunks found on the schooner Marie Victoria, which was wrecked at Bic in the Autumn of 1864, were the property of J. Wilkes Booth, the assassin of President Lincoln.
WASHINGTON, Nov. l4. -- Senhor Mendonca, the Brazilian Minister, this morning received the following cablegram from the Minister of Foreign Relations at Rio de Janeiro, dated yesterday:

London, Nov. 14. -- These small islands have been so rocked and shaken in the clutch of a tempest during the past week, so drenched and flooded by further rains, so harrowed by tales of wreck and destruction by land and by sea, that we have very little to talk about here in London except the storm.

A curious case of plagiarism, which in all likelihood was unconscious, has happened to a sculptor, Mr. H.H. Kitson of Boston. His design for a fountain at Providence, R.I., in honor of Elisha Dyer had already been accepted, with one slight modification, when it was stated that a nearly identical fountain had been designed by Herbert Adams in Paris, and placed in the year 1889 on a public square of Fitchburg, Mass.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 14. -- The chrysanthemum show, held for four days in Masonic Hall, closed Friday and was a success, cottagers who attended the show in New-York declaring that for variety and excellence the Newport exhibition more than held its own. This is not to be wondered at when it is remembered that the gardeners of Cornelius Vanderbilt, W.S. Wells, Joseph Tuckerman, and others exhibited the choicest treasures of their culture houses.

NEWARK, Nov. 14. -- The Essex County Freeholders were called together this afternoon by an urgent letter from Warden Murray of the county penitentiary at Caldwell. A water famine exists there, and the sanitary condition of the prison is such that an epidemic is feared among the convicts. The jail is also overcrowded. Two prisoners have to sleep in some of the cells.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- About thirty suits, based upon claims aggregating in the neighborhood of $125,000, were begun in the State courts to-day against Louis Adler, the cloak manufacturer, who failed last evening. Most of the suit brought are in attachments, and garnishee writs were taken out against the Bank of Commerce, which holds a chattel mortgage on all of Adler's property.

HARTFORD, Nov. 14. -- Trinity closed a very successful season to-day by defeating the Massachusetts Institute of Technology 22 to 0. The game was one of special interest, as the teams had not met for four years, and then Trinity was defeated. But she redeemed herself this afternoon and won "in a canter." A large crowd witnessed the game, and every good play was fully appreciated.

Some ladies and gentlemen have interested themselves in getting up a Palestine bazaar in aid of the Louis Down-Town Sabbath and Daily School. The affair, which promises to be both elaborate and unique, will be held In the Carnegie Music Hall, at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, on the evenings of Wednesday, Thursday, and Saturday.

The most serious result of the recent election to the Brooklyn Republican organization is the effect it has had upon the Germans. The refusal of the silk-stocking element to support Henry Meyer has certainly alienated the multitude of Germans who did support him. They are feeling very sore over the matter now, and are vowing to get revenge at the very first opportunity.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Application was made to Judge Samuel Edwards at Special Term here to-day to fix bail in the cases of James E. Ostrander and Matthew T. Trumpbour, charged with wrecking the Ulster County Savings Institution.

Fireman John P. Breen of Engine Company No. 12, in North William Street, has gotten himself into a little trouble which may cost him his position in the department. Breen was off duty all Thursday night. With several companions he made a tour of the Water Street and South Street saloons, and about 5:30 o'clock Friday morning he entered Foley's saloon, at James Slip and South Street.

" Hi -- hey -- hold up there, mare, will you? What did you say, mister? A light? Yes. That's Trotting Cob, that is. The missus'll give us a cup of tea, but that's about all.
