Devil fly away with the mare. What is it? Something white in the road? Water, by --. Thank the Lord they've had plenty of rain this year.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 14. -- Apropos of the recent visit of American explorers to the great falls of Labrador comes a very interesting narrative given by Mr. W. Ogilvie, Dominion Land Surveyor, of a trip from Ottawa to Moose Factory, the Hudson Bay Company's station on St. James Bay, in which he passed through a country hitherto unexplored.

The lecture room of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, at Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, was crowded Wednesday evening, the occasion being the presentation of the claims of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institution of Tuskegee, Ala., to the consideration of those interested in education.

Mr. FORAKER expresses himself entirely satisfied with the prospect of the Senatorial election in Ohio, and at the same time says that the Republicans of Ohio know what they want and do not care for the opinion of "outsiders." If he is really cheerful because of this condition of the Ohio Republican mind, it is the harshest comment on his party in his State that we have seen.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Frederick Turner, ex-Secretary and Treasurer of the Knights of Labor, who is accused of being $13,000 short in his accounts with the order, made an explanation to-day that was as sensational as were the charges. The charges made up the principal feature of the Knights of Labor Convention at Toledo, Ohio, this week.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 14. -- The political situation in Louisana is daily growing more exciting. Five parishes of the fifty-eight have already held their primaries, and of these Supreme Justice McEnery, the lottery candidate, was successful in Orleans, Tensas, and East Baton Rouge -- a total of 172 votes -- while Capt. Adams, the candidate of the Farmers' Alliance and of the anti-lottery factions, has captured Avoyelles and Natchitoches, with 52 votes.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The "Big Six" of the Plainfield Common Council, whoso notorious legislation of the past two years has involved the city in so much expensive litigation and aroused so much disgust among the taxpayers of the city, have attempted a bold stroke to secure their re-election at the approaching municipal battle of the ballots.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- The visitor to Horticultural Hall this week might half believe himself transported to Japan, for an Occidental wealth of color has run riot there which strongly belies New-England austerity. Yet New-England has become permeated with the Eastern enthusiasm for the chrysanthemum, and a gardener looks for no prouder triumph than the evolution of a new variety of this peerless November queen.

NEWARK, Nov. 14. -- It is now said that the trouble between Pastor Gutteridge of the Davis Memorial Church in Harrison and C.P. Kinsey, Superintendent of the Sunday school, over the use of the expression "nigger" by an elocutionist at a recent entertainment gotten up for the benefit of the Sunday school by Mr. Kinsey is the culmination of a series of church disagreements.

NYACK, Nov. 14. -- The last week has been a notable one for hunting accidents in Rockland County. The fair weather has brought out many gunners every day, some living in this county, and others coming from New-York and Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14. -- The work of securing $50,000 in subscriptions for the preliminary guarantee fund for the expenses of the National Republican and Democratic Conventions, in the event of either or both conventions being held in this city, has been completed by a committee of business men. The committee appointed to go to Washington to lay San Francisco's offer before the National Committees of the two parties left here to-night.

THE HISTORY OF TWEEDS. -- "I had not been many weeks in Edinburgh before one of my friends in the cloth trade wrote me from London, inquiring about a 'coarse woolen black-and-white checked stuff, made in Scotland and expected to be wanted for trousers,' and asked me to send some patterns of it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The new university catalogue for the present year will be ready for general distribution in a few das. The advance copies show that its general make-up and appearance is similar to last year's; there is, however, a slight condensation of the course of study and the use of thinner paper. A limited number of copies will be bound in cloth, similar to the Harvard catalogue.

The opening reception of the Protestant Half-Orphan Asylum yesterday, in its new building at Manhattan Avenue and One Hundred and Fourth Street, served to introduce to a large and representative gathering of well-know people one of the most worthy of the city's charities.

One of the significant indications of the day is the avidity with which the several organizations of the National Guard hereabout have taken up the study and practice of the new drill regulations. The sometime prevalent disposition to distrust the availability, not to say advisability, of the proposed change in the scheme of instruction has entirely disappeared, and the late doubters are among the foremost in extolling the new order of affairs.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 20. -- One of the most extraordinary spectacles which it has ever been my lot to witness was the funeral here last week of his Holiness Dionysius V., the Pontifet Maximus of the Oriental Greek Orthodox Church. During forty-eight hours his body lay, or rather sat, in state before the high altar of the Patriarchal Church of the Phanar.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 14. -- The Darmouth-Williams championship football game came off this afternoon, and resulted in a victory for Williams by a score of 14 to 6. Williams clearly outmatched Dartmouth and played a strong team game. Her game was steadily buck the centre, and in this she admirably succeeded, for her rush line was by far the heavier.

The habit of reading while accomplishing the inexorable distances of New-York seems to be a growing one. People begin to understand that forty minutes off each end of the day soon aggregate an appreciable sum of one's short space. Men used to possess the monopoly of reading newspapers, but now women are almost as frequently seen buried behind the day's news as their brothers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Washington Star is annoyed at a dispatch, published in THE TIMES, concerning the interest that is manifested in the District of Columbia about Mr. Crisp's candidacy for the Speakership, and, after some general criticisms of it, it declares that it will keep its hands off the Speakership fight and let the members do the choosing.

Yale's football giants beat the sturdy eleven of the University of Pennsylvania by a score of 48 to 0 on the Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. The game was a beautiful one, abounding in brilliant plays and characterized by a spirit and a dash that did credit to the Pennsylvania boys, who played a fine game, though they did not score.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Chief of Police John B. McNeill to-day solved a novel mystery, which had baffled the department nearly two months. Elizabeth Loran, an intelligent domestic employed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Purvince, is the cause of the trouble. She came to this country from Ireland about nine months ago, and came to Bayonne last June and has been a servant ever since at the Purvince villa.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- The sophomore class at Yale is earning a reputation for disorderly conduct, of which the class members appear to be proud, but which is causing the Faculty much annoyance. There is a feeling on the part of the class members that they have been unjustly treated, and they claim that their pranks have been spied upon, instead of being met in a spirit of frankness and candor.

The election in the South Moulton Division of Devonshire is by far the most significant and surprising, and by far the most encouraging to the Liberals, of all the bye-elections that have occurred since Lord SALISBURY took office. In this case a "Unionist" majority of 1,689 has been converted into a Gladstonian majority of 1,272, in a total vote of some 7,000.
BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- That has been a very brave man who has ventured to make himself heard in Boston this week. Woman, with a very big W, is all over town.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Harvard played its last football game before the Yale game, against the Boston Athletic Association eleven, this afternoon, winning by a score of 51 to 12.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 14. -- The subjects for the junior oratorical contest which takes place on Washington's Birthday have been selected and are as follow: 1, Russia; 2, Prince Bismarck; 3, Imagination in Science; 4, Moral Progress of the Nineteenth Century; 5, The Taking of the Bastile; 6, John Ericsson; 7, Westward the Star of Empire Takes Its Way; 8; The Province of the Ideal; 9.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore has made a count of the number of persons who have attended the lectures in the American Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, and found that for the two lectures last week there were 2,067.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- About 2,000 people assembled on the university field this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock to witness the first football game ever played between Princeton and Cornell on the university grounds.

The abrupt termination of the racing meeting at Washington has set managers of race meetings to thinking a bit. The result of that thinking has brought them to the conclusion that there has been a little too much racing. The Baltimore meeting that followed the close of the racing season in this State was a failure from a financial point, which was no doubt due in part to the rainy weather.

Mr. OSBORNE HOWES, Jr., of the Boston Rapid-Transit Commission, has recently submitted to that body a report upon the local transit systems of European cities which contains many points of general interest in this country. He deals first with the tramway and surface railway systems, beginning with those of Liverpool, Manchester, and Birmingham.

Lenox Lyceum was packed to its utmost capacity last night when Anton Seidl gave the fifth of his Sunday evening popular concerts. These entertainments appear to be growing in popularity, and while a good deal of the attendance is to be attributed to the attractive power of the soloists engaged by Mr. Seidl, the steady undercurrent of influence with the public flows from the strong personality of the conductor himself.

It is the present practice in inspecting all carriages of naval guns to fire a three-pounder rapid-fire gun projectile through the carriage plates. This is done to obtain ballistical results. If the carriage framing is weak it will show it when pierced by one of the shells. A heavy oaken block is placed between the sides of the carriage. The block serves to stop the projectile. Two shots are fired, one through each side.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- "Yes, it has been a capital night for observations," said Prof. Pickering of the Harvard Observatory in response to a query as to whether the night had been satisfactory for observing the total eclipse of the moon.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The Chronicle's correspondent at Shanghai says: "The capture of Tehwei, near Foo Chow, Tuesday, by 15,000 rebels, was a well-organized rising. The rebels were armed with repeaters and led by capable men. The outbreak was directed mainly against the authorities, though anti-foreign cries were heard.
There is but one man for the Democrats to nominate in 1892 and that man is Grover Cleveland. We believe that no one would say so more emphatically than Gov. William E. Russell.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15. -- The Times-Democrat's Tyler (Texas) special says: "Just after a successful career of twenty years, during which it had built up a reputation as one of the solidest and soundest financial institutions in the State, the banking house of Bonner Bonner has been forced to the wall. The news that it had failed spread like wildfire throughout this city this morning, and soon was the topic on every tongue.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The water question in the Oranges is taking an alarming shape. There is imminent danger of a water famine, not over two weeks' supply being in the reservoir. The condition of the water is so bad that it is unfit for drinking purposes.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 15. -- Mgr. O'Breyn, Chamberlain of the Pope, has arrived here for the purpose of participating in the celebration of the golden jubilee of Archbishop Kendricks. He says that the Pope is in splendid health. After some preliminary skirmishing, he was to-day induced to speak of the recent Papal encyclical on the "Condition of Labor."

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 15. -- A well-known citizen of New-Orleans, who holds one of the New-York Life Insurance Company's ten-thousand-dollar policies, has Just been rudely awakened to a sense of the looseness of President Beers's management of that concern, and as a result of his experience, he is making this neighborhood ring with denunciations of everybody who is a party to his discomfiture.

Sacher Masoch, in this story of Galician peasant life, has paraphrased the Biblical Job. Theofil Pisarenko suffers from as many plagues as does Job, and through his patience and, above all, his good common sense he overcomes fire, cholera, boils, infundations, famine, and temptations, and finally helps to civilize the wild country and its ignorant and superstitious inhabitants.

In the course of some comments upon the recent auction sale of carpets, the Carpet and Upholstery Trade Review says: "It seems pertinent to remind manufacturers that the best method of getting rid of surplus production is to place it on foreign markets." But our manufacturers cannot sell carpets in foreign countries except at a considerable loss so long as their raw material is heavily taxed.

In our local columns this morning will be found a statement as to the inconvenience suffered by the public from the inadequate provision for the sale of stamps at the New-York Post Office. We regret to say that this is not a new cause of complaint, and that it is not now called to the attention of Mr. VAN COTT for the first time.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16. -- One of the most threatening fires Cleveland has had in several years broke out at 8 o'clock last evening, and before it was extinguished at midnight it had destroyed $200,000 worth of property and resulted in the death of one fireman and the serious injury of two others.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15. -- It is now conceded by some of the strongest advocates of his election to the Senate that Gov. Foraker's forces are not only losing heart but weakening. The support that the Governor has received at the hands of Mr. McLean's Commercial Gazette has not added one vote to the original number pledged to the Governor.

Some one is being very badly deceived in regard to the Ohio Senatorship. We publish this morning a Washington dispatch containing an interview with ex-Gov. FORAKER, in which that gentleman expresses the utmost confidence in his own election, and declares specifically that Senator SHERMAN is misled by his office-holding friends if he thinks that he will-get the Hamilton County Republican delegation in the Ohio Legislature, or any part of it.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has attacked the integrity of the management of the New-York Life Insurance Company, and charges the President, William H. Beers, with dishonesty and incapacity, and using his power in the promotion of his own interests and that of his family and friends. This great corporation has over one hundred millions assets, belonging to its policy holders, which is said to be practically in the control of one man.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15. -- The Snow Hill Messenger hoists at the head of its columns the names of Arthur P. German of Maryland for President and Isaac P. Gray of Indiana for Vice President in 1892.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- I am very much afraid that no one will contradict me in saying that never in the memory of man or child were women as ugly, as stupidly fashioned, in their grotesque attire, as now. Without being ultra, every woman looks as if she were dressed for a masquerade ball, and without rhyme or reason, for she is made up of odd bits of every period.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- During the past week discount was quoted at 3 for three months and 2 1/2 for short; there was no demand. Money is plentiful, the Bank of England having received during the week 1,127,000 in bullion, partly gold from Brazil and partly repayments from the provinces. There is 250,000 still to come from Brazil, and large shipments are reported from Australia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Ex-Gov. Foraker begins to think that his opponents will compel him to fight for the Senatorship. It had been his purpose, he says, to make a comfortable canvass, free from unpleasant accusations or epithets. The course of the Sherman men, who are alternately abusing and ridiculing him, has recently provoked him.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Is was so cloudy here at the time of the eclipse that the astronomers at Dearborn Observatory were unable to make observations.

The Parnell memorial service last night called out an audience that filled the Academy of Music to its capacity. It was thoroughly in accord with the sentiment of the occasion, and lost no opportunity to applaud the memory of Parnell and of other Irish leaders whose names and deeds were mentioned. The green or Ireland gave the tone to the decorations: on the stage was a large painted portrait of Parnell, draped about with green.

While one of the new steel cruisers was being placed in dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard a short time ago, a naval mariner of the old school stood silently watching the operation. The style of the vessel evidently did not meet the approval of the old man of the sea, who had fault to find with the protuberance at the stern and the general model of the craft.

The amount of extra work caused the County Clerk by the ballot-reform law is more than would at first be supposed. Beginning with the nominations as they are filed, each one has to be gone over carefully to see that it conforms to the law in every respect.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 15. -- A report reached here late this afternoon that the Sandwich Savings Bank, at Sandwich, had closed its doors. The Hon. James O. Lyford of this city, Chairman of the Board of State Bank Commissioners, said this evening:

The voyage of the White Star steamship Taurio, which sailed for Liverpool Saturday afternoon, come to an inglorious conclusion on the Dry Romer Shoals at 6:45 that evening. The Taurio is under command of Capt. Roberts, but the vessel was in charge of a New-York pilot at the time of the mishap.

An English physician who has been studying Darwinism in the nursery imparts his discoveries to the world through the Nineteenth Century. He had read BRET HARTE'S "Luck of Roaring Camp" -- probably as a bachelor -- and scoffed at the newborn baby in that tale who seized the finger of Mr. Kentuck and "wrestled" with it.

Homesickness for France is the only reason that the friends of Charles Jeaunez, who lives at 106 Washington Street, can give for his attempted suicide with an axe, in the cellar of the City Bank Building, 52 Wall Street, yesterday. Jeaunez is a porter, who has been in the country about three years. He went into the bank building to work yesterday.

The rise of SLUPSKY in St. Louis has not escaped the attention of some of our sharp-eyed contemporaries in the East, but while they have been impressed by the advent of this new force in politics their comments display a curious ignorance of the causes of SLUPSKY'S sudden elevation and of SLUPSKY'S relation to various political movements in his town.

What policy holders are interested in knowing is how far the Directors are responsible for the enormous amount of stealing and embezzlement practiced by agents and others, and whether such is reconcilable with efficient management and its effect upon the dividends of the insured.
BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- The Boston Post will announce to-morrow the discovery of the foundation of a new political party in Massachusetts.

The clouds were closely scanned by the officials connected with the Department of Public Works yesterday, but there was not much to encourage them. The gray sheen of cloud that obscured the skies for the most of the day was not apparently of the rain-bearing order, and the chill wind was a dry one.

During the past few years an entirely new aspect has been given to the question of tariff reform. It may be said to have become distinctly recognizable first on the occasion of the report of the Tariff Commission of 1883, which Mr. SHERMAN recently praised so heartily, and, on the whole, so justly.

Quite the most sensational year in the history of harness racing has practically closed for the fleet steppers of America, though the open weather on the Pacific slope, continues to afford opportunities which the ambitious California turfmen improve to the full. Of the many wonderful things done by the trotters and pacers since the sulky racers made their appearance this season the latest feat is by far the most marvelous.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 16. -- Wood Davis, the Kansas crop statistician, makes public a statement of the world's crop, of which the following is a summary:

The handwriting which appeared on the wall after the recent overwhelming Democratic victory in this State has been the object of earnest scrutiny by many prominent Republicans who do not wear smoked-glass goggles nor do their thinking by proxy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- At the adjourned meeting of the Chicago Presbytery to-day the report of the Assembly's Committee on Revision was rejected by a tie vote. Dr. Stryker offered the following resolution:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 16. -- A daring escape occurred at the county jail this evening. The prisoner who got away was T.C. Bodlen, who was lodged in jail a week ago by a Government detective, after his arrest in Atlanta on the charge of belonging to a gang that has been committing mail robberies on an extensive scale in New-York, Chicago, Nashville, St. Paul, Louisville, New-Orleans, Pittsburg, and Cleveland.

There was considerable of what looked like cheap melodrama in the way Immigration Commissioner H.J. Shulteis saw fit to make his advent to this city yesterday. It is not known what views his apologists may take of his yesterday's performance at the Barge Office, but there will be those who will be likely to insist that this young man's head is too big for his hat.
PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The Chamber of Deputies, after a long debate, to-day approved the tariff of 25f. on salted meats, as fixed by the Senate.

The Board of Governors of the Amateur Athletic Union and the delegates to the union's annual meeting spent most of the day yesterday at the Astor House in discussing affairs interesting to athletes throughout the country. There were several things that came before them that they should have settled, but instead of that the board referred them to committees, and there is no knowing when these committees will be ready to report.

A variety of stories relative to the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company were in circulation in Wall Street yesterday. Although most of the stories were absurd on their face, the price of the stock dropped about 4 points while they were going the rounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- In the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia Chief Justice Bingham to-day delivered the decision of the court on the demurrer of the defendant in the case of The United States against Charles A. Newton, who is charged with violating Section 12 of the Civil Service act, approved Jan. 16, 1883, which is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Argument was begun in the United States Supreme Court to-day in the anti-lottery cases, in which the constitutionality of the recent anti-lottery law is involved. The suits are those brought by the United States against John D.N. Rapier, publisher of the Mobile Register, and George W. Dupre, publisher of the New-Orleans States, for violation of the law prohibiting the sending through the mall of newspapers containing lottery advertisements.

The law requires that the Rapid Transit Commission must have the consent of the Park Department and the Commissioner of Street Improvements before it can take any further steps involving expense. The Park Department is expected to act upon the matter to-morrow, and Commissioner Heintz is understood to have his consent ready for transmission as soon as the Park Board shall have acted.

Sir John Steell, who died at Edinburgh last week at the age of eighty-seven, was certainly one of the most eminent and most successful sculptors of the present century. He was the son of a woodcarver at Aberdeen, but was brought up at Edinburgh, and, on completing his education, he went to Rome, and resided there for several years, returning to Edinburgh in 1833, when his professional career commenced.

Sharp at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a wonderfully trim and "swagger" cavalryman who looked, because of his showy uniform, as if he might have been one of Gen. Burd Grubb's groomsmen at his recent wedding in Scotland, stepped into the ring at Madison Square Garden. A call "to saddle" was sounded from his silver cornet, and five grooms led into the ring five thoroughbred stallions.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 16 -- Members of the Olcott Debt Committee of New-York will tomorrow meet the Virginia Debt Commission here and submit a plan for the settlement of the State debt. The members of the New-York committee come, they say, at the invitation of Gov. McKinney, who is chairman, ex officio, of the Virginia commission.

The St. Paul Pioneer Press (Rep.) ridicules the talk, of which it says it sees a little, about running Hill for President. "If Hill were nominated by his party," it says, "the Electoral votes could be counted just as well the evening after the convention adjourned as they could after election." The Pioneer Press thinks that Hill would probably carry New-York and possibly New-Jersey, but not another State outside of the South.

The Excise Board gave a hearing yesterday in the cases where the City Reform Club had secured evidence of the violation of the law by saloon keepers on election day. President Meakim presided, and Commissioners Koch and Fitzpatrick were present. The City Reform Club was represented by its President, W.G. Welling, and by its counsel, Charles Wheeler Barnes.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 16. -- The salt-water fishing along the coast of Maine during the season of 1891 has been the best known there for years. While this statement holds good as regards all kinds of fish usually caught in the salt waters of Northern New-England, it is especially true of the mackerel catch, which is treble that of any season since 1881.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 16. -- The greatest legal battle in the history of Wisconsin will begin in this city to-morrow. Judge Nowman of the Sixth Judicial Circuit has been called to preside in the place of Judge R.G. Siebecker of the Ninth Circuit, who announced his prejudice in the case of the State against ex-State Treasurer Harshaw.

The New-York Presbytery has again plunged into the sea of discussion. It met yesterday to pass upon the report of the committee appointed to consider the report on the revision presented to the last General Assembly by the committee representing that highest body in the Church. That General Assembly report was by resolution ordered to be submitted to all Presbyteries for their amendment and criticism.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- As a south-bound West Shore train pulled into the station at Cranstons to-day, Charles W. Buchler, aged sixty-four years, a wealthy and retired physician of 251 West Forty-fifth Street, New-York, either fell or threw himself directly in front of the approaching locomotive. His left arm was crashed so badly as to necessitate amputation, and he was otherwise seriously hurt.

Senator SAXTON has announced his intention of introducing on the first day of the coming session of the Legislature an amendment of the ballot law providing for the use of the blanket ballot. He gives very strong reasons in favor of adopting the blanket ballot in preference to the present objectionable system, which are substantially the same that have been previously urged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The chances for the election of Representative Mills as Speaker have always been so promising since his candidacy was announced that it has seemed improbable that the opposition to him would ever become formidable. Instead of diminishing, these favorable indications multiply.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 16. -- A tragic sequel to the suspension of the Cheyenne National Bank is afforded in the deliberate suicide of George L. Beard, the young cashier of the broken bank, in his rooms, opposite the closed house, early this morning.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 16. -- Reports from the famine-stricken districts of the empire continue to show the despair and suffering entailed upon the poorer classes by the scarcity of food. The Government is fully alive to the exigencies of the situation and is doing everything in its power to help the sufferers.

The argument before the Supreme Court at Washington against the validity of the law excluding newspapers which contain lottery advertisements from the mails exhibits a pretty weak case. It seems to rest only upon two grounds, one that the law is an abridgement of the freedom of the press, and the other that Congress transcended its constitutional power for the regulation of the mail service of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Every one except his medical attendants, nurses, and close relatives is excluded from the sick room of William J. Florence, the comedian, who lies fighting for life with pneumonia in the Continental Hotel. Mr. Florence is reported somewhat better, but he is still a very sick man.
HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 16. -- The eastern field trials commenced to-day with the Derby Stakes. The spotting system has been adopted, and the result will not be known until the series is finished.
BELGRADE, Nov. 16. -- Ex-King Milan hag signed a renunciation of all his legal and constitutional rights in Servia.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Vienna correspondent of the Times says: "The negotiations of Col. Grant, United States Minister, with the Austrian Government in regard to the pork prohibition have made such good progress that, although the particulars are kept secret, it is expected that a few days will see a definite announcement of the repeal of the prohibition of the importation of American pork."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Senhor Mendonea, the Brazilian Minister here, has received the following cablegram from the Brazilian Minister of Foreign Relations:

The announcement yesterday of the sudden death of John H. Bonn, the President of the North Hudson Railway Company, at his home, on Weehawken Heights, was received with mingled expressions of regret and surprise. It was known that Mr. Bonn had overworked himself in his railroad enterprise, and that he had been directed to seek rest; but no one knew that he was dangerously ill.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 16. -- General Master Workman Powderly this afternoon gave the following statement to the Associated Press concerning the charges made by ex-Secretary Turner in an interview printed in the Pittsburg, Cincinnati, and other papers yesterday:

A committee of Republican politicians was appointed yesterday for the purpose of going to Washington to induce the National Committee of their party to select this city as the place for holding the next Republican National Convention. It is not easy to see what advantage to the party would be derived from holding the convention here, and apparently railroad and hotel men are chiefly interested.

The Hon. John A. Kasson of Iowa, formerly United States Minister to Austria, was at the Murray Hill Hotel Sunday evening. He said to a TIMES reporter that two or three elements had entered into the recent campaign in Iowa, and he took a somewhat original view of the situation.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Another hearing in the matter of the intermediate accounting of Edwin Young as executor of the will of the late Thomas Cornell, whose estate amounted to over $2,000,000, took place in the Surrogate's Court here to-day. The executor was represented by H.C. Soop, and Mrs. Nellie Carpenter by Albert Cardozo, Jr., of New-York, and Judge Clearwater appeared for Mrs. Cornell and the wife and children of S.D. Coykendall.

Grover Cleveland is a real leader. He is a man of brains, a far-seeing man, and a man of deep convictions. Moreover, Cleveland is honest and bold, and these are the two qualifies that make him pre-eminent. There are many able public men in this country -- many intellectual politicians who talk and write like statesmen. But they lack courage.

The people of Chicago continue to take a lively interest in the arguments of those who desire to limit the height of buildings in that city. Some weeks ago we commented upon the remarks of Gen. FITZ-SIMONS concerning the folly of overtaxing in the business centre of Chicago the crust of clay that covers in that region a layer of "semi-fluid matter" which is about thirty-six feet thick.
" It will be Cleveland and Boles or Cleveland and Gray, but always Cleveland."

Frank Taggart. fifty years old. a laborer employed on the Third Avenue cable construction, was killed yesterday afternoon by Jumping-from the front platform of Car 10S of the Third Avenue surface road. He got on the car going up town at Twenty-fourth street and at Eighty-fourth Street he jumped off the platform, stumbled, and pitched head foremost into the excavation for the cable road.

Pheasant farming should be worth a venture, judging from the success which has been achieved at Liphook, where one was established about twelve years ago, and from which, a few days since, 2,000 pheasants were dispatched to St. Petersburg for the reinforcement of the game preserves of the Czar of all the Russias.

The popularity and, in the sense of popularity, the success of the Horse Show were beyond dispute before the doors were opened yesterday. The situation was very well described by a ticket speculator who, by way of apologizing for charging three times the advertised price for seats at the end of the week, declared that he had never known anything like the demand in New-York, "barring ADELINA PATTI."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Not for ten years was there such a gathering of noted corporation lawyers as appeared before Judge Edward T. Green of the United States Circuit Court to-day in the Hoey case. Clarence A. Seward and Barker Gummerer represented the Adams Express Company, and Elihu Root, John G. Burrill of New-York, ex-Chancellor Runyon of New-Jersey, and Thomas N. McCarter of Newark appeared for Mr. Hoey.

BOSTON, Nov. 16. -- The third day's session of the dual convention of the World's and the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union was opened with devotional exercises conduct-by Mrs. E.S. Burlingame of Providence. A.W. Minor was presented and reproached Gov. Russell and Mayor Matthews for their non-acceptance of the invitation to be present at the convention last Friday. He also paid his respects to certain newspapers.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 16. -- William Ruddy, a young man aged twenty-six years, committed suicide in a most sensational manner at his home in this city this morning. It is alleged that Ruddy came home and found that his mother had drunk to excess, and this so troubled him that he resolved to make away with himself.

We have called attention from time to time to the peculiar manner in which the Union Elevated Railroad Company in Brooklyn employs the extensive and valuable franchise bestowed upon it. Unlike the Kings County Road, it seems bent on getting all that it can from the public and giving as little as possible in return.

The annual banquet of the Chamber of Commerce, which takes place to-night, promises to be an interesting and important event, as it usually is. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Director of the Mint are among the guests of the Chamber, as well as Mr. WILSON of West Virginia, and Mr. BLAINE is expected to,be present.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16. -- The municipal election which will take place in December has been converted into a contest over the licensing of barrooms. The issue has been precipitated by the Rev. Sam W. Small, who, several weeks ago, put out a ticket pledged against the issuance of licenses. Since then the citizens generally have put out a conservative ticket, pledged to maintain the status quo.

The forthcoming trials of her Majesty's first-class cruisers Blake and Blenheim, the largest vessels of their class that have yet been launched, loud interest to the following tabulated particulars of some of the most important cruisers of the world. The Blake was launched at Chatham on Nov. 23, 1889, and the Blenheim at Blackwall on July 1, 1890.
VICTORIA, B.C., Nov. 16. -- Several of the crew of the ship Sarah, wrecked at Carmah Point Nov. 7, have arrived here, giving the first detailed information of their thrilling experience.

It is no wonder that the election in South Moulton, upon which we have already commented, should have had a very depressing effect upon the Tories, and especially upon the "Unionists." The reversal of a "Unionist" majority into a Gladstonian majority equally larger is a fact that cannot be explained away.

WARWICK, R.I., Nov. 16. -- The campaign of 1892 was opened in three different villages in this town this evening by the organizing of Democratic clubs. At Arctic resolutions were passed indorsing the Administration of Grover Cleveland and pledging the club to work for him from now on. It was decided to call the organization the Cleveland and Boies Democratic Club of Warwick, R.I.

Judge Lippincott succeeded yesterday in getting two more of the crew of Hudson County ballot-box stuffers behind the bars. They were Christian A. Holderer and Patrick Boulger, who committed election frauds at the Second Precinct of the Fourth District in 1889. Winkler, who was indicted with them, was acquitted.

VIENNA, Nov. 16. -- Notwithstanding the denials made by high officials of the statement published in the Tageblatt Saturday that the Emperor had declared that the European situation was critical, that paper to-day insists that its report was strictly correct. It was this report that was at the bottom of the panic which prevailed on the Boerse Saturday.

BOSTON, Nov. 16. -- The Globe says there is bitter feeling and great disappointment among a large number of Harvard men over their inability to secure tickets to the Harvard-Yale football game next Saturday at Springfield, and they lay the blame upon F.W. Moore, manager of the Harvard eleven, who had charge of the sale at Cambridge.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 16. -- By the timely arrest of the principals this noon by the Sheriff of this county and his deputies, Editor H.V. Sevier of the Evening Telegram and Benjamin Harrison of the Daily Florida Standard were prevented from shooting each other full of holes on the "field of honor."
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- In an interview Mr. McCormick, the English World's Fair Commissioner, said:

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 17. -- The Virginia Debt Commission and the Olcott committee of New-York spent several hours this afternoon discussing the proposal for a settlement of the debt submitted by the latter. The debt commission is composed of Gov. McKinney, Lieut. Gov. J. Hoge Tyler, Speaker of the House Cardwell, and Senators Berry and Wickham, and Members of the House Tyler of Prince William and Dabney of Albemarie.
RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 17. -- Marshal da Fonseca has issued a decree authorizing a special credit of 13,000,000 milreis, to be expended for war materials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The argument of the anti-lottery eases was resumed in the United Stales Supreme Court to-day by Mr. J.C. Carter of New-York, who made the point that there was a difference between things mala in se, or which all conceded to be crimes, and things mata prohibila, which Legislatures might declare to be offenses.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- An order to show cause why a temporary mandamus should not be issued was served on the Board of Canvassers of Onondaga County to-day to compel them to canvass the vote of and issue a certificate to Rufus T. Peck as Senator for the Twenty-fifth District. Argument was heard before Justice Kennedy this afternoon and the case held open until to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 17. -- The ease of the People's Fire Insurance Company against D.W. Holt of Pittsburg, which is on trial in the United States Court here, is of peculiar interest to insurance companies. There are fifteen other suits of the same nature against Holt, all to recover the amount of policies paid him, the total sum being $125,000.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17. -- The cold wave which reached this city last evening was the cause of one of the most disastrous fires which has visited St. Louis in many years. At an early hour this morning one person was probably killed, two badly hurt, and $1,500,000 worth of property went up in smoke.

The speech of Mr. FOSTER at the banquet of the Chamber of Commerce last evening was evidently deliberately prepared and was ingeniously adapted to his audience. Although he announced that he was not the defender of the act of 1890, his remarks were plainly directed to combat the opinion expressed by the Chamber of Commerce that that act should be repealed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The statement of the world's crop of grain, issued by Wood Davis of Kansas, is a little later than one recently issued by the State Department, and for that reason may be correct in putting the world's yield, outside of America, as lower and the needs of the short-crop countries higher than they appear to be in Consular Report No. 133, for October.

A year ago the meeting of the National Farmers' Alliance would have been an event of national importance and of a keen personal interest to all the aspiring politicians of the West and South. Now that body assembles at Indianapolis without disturbing the public mind and without exciting anybody but its own members.

Last Thursday the market price of the stock of the Bell Telephone Company was $185 per share. For a long time it had been in the neighborhood of $180, but in the week preceding Thursday there was an advance of $3 or $4. On Friday there were sales at $193, on Monday there was an addition of $5, and shares were sold yesterday at $210.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- The commerce of Philadelphia, which has long been languishing, gives promising signs of a strong revival. Subscription books for a new line to Mexico were closed to-day, and it was announced that sufficient capital had been secured to justify the chartering of two or three boats and the inauguration of a regular steamship service between this port and Mexico.

President Depow of the New-York Central Railroad has received a letter from the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, which he will doubtless refer to the operating department, of which Mr. H. Walter Webb is the head. The letter reads as follows:

WILMINGTOM. Del., Nov. 17. -- To-day the investigation by the Levy Court Committee of the charges that Tax Collectors John J. Dougherty and George W. McKee, Democratic officials, had sold poll-tax receipts to the Republican committee and then returned as errors the men whose taxes were thus paid, ended in the presentation of two reports to the court.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 17. -- To-day the United States Patent Office issued a patent to Emile Berliner assignor to the Bell Telephone Company, for a combined telegraph and telephone, which has been pending in that office since June 4,1877. It is understood that the Bell Telephone Company believes that this patent covers features which are necessary to the practical use of telephones.

A larger audience than is usually present at the meetings of the New-York Historical Society filled the lecture room of the society's building at Second Avenue and Eleventh Street last evening on the occasion of the eighty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the institution. President King presided, and, after prayer by Bishop Potter, gave a short review of the work done by the society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Commissioner Herman I. Schulteis, who has made so much of himself as a discoverer of atrocities in the steerage of an ocean steamer, was known in Washington before. Through the influence of Mr. Gompers, the head of the Federation of Labor, he was appointed to the office he holds. He is ambitious for notice, and has sought it, from time to time, through the newspapers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day granted a permit allowing the Catskill Mountain Railway Company to suspend the operation of the Catskill Mountain Railroad and Cairo Railroad between Catskill and Cairo from Dec. 12, 1891, to May 2, 1892, also that portion of the Catskill Mountain Road from its junction with the Cairo Railroad to Palenville until June 13 next year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The United States Consul General at Vienna, in a dispatch to the Department of State dated the 24th ult., says:

STOCKTON, Cal., Nov. 17. -- Marvin drove Pale Alto, the famous Electioneer stallion, in 2:08 3/4 to-day, breaking the world's stallion record, and winning for the Pale Alto Stable all records of the world. He made the mile without a skip, breaking after he passed the finish. It was a wonderful performance. His quarters were 0:31 3/4, 1:03 1/2, 1:36 1/2, 2:08 3/4.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Times this morning publishes a letter from Robert Louis Stevenson, the well-known novelist and writer, who for some time past has been living at Samoa. It is dated Upolu, one of the islands of the Samoan group, and recites some of the events which have occurred at Samoa recently.

The "water famine" and the warm weather both came to an abrupt end yesterday. With a fine sense of the proprieties, they made their exit together. The "water famine" came to an inglorious end with the advent of the rain, which began Monday morning and continued all day yesterday, covering New-York and the Croton watershed in Westchester County with its mantle of moisture.

It appears that some Irishmen, or Irish sympathizers, were not anxious to have Dr. Chauncey M. Depew deliver an address at the Parnell memorial meeting on Sunday night. Some were fearful lest he might "make a break" and set somebody, if not the two factions, by the ears. So he was visited and written to by many uneasy sons or grandsons of Erin.

The announcement from Brazil that a serious effort is now to be made to provide funds to build the long projected railroad from the Brazilian port of Santos to Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, calls for some comment upon the present condition of railroads in the new republic and upon the outlook for the future.

The greatest difficulty encountered in the canvass of election returns by the County Boards is due to utterly inexcusable errors on the part of election officers, and these are, of course, due to the incompetency of the persons appointed. But no errors can be corrected except those of omission in the statements of the returns and those which are "clerical merely."

CHRISTIANIA, Nov. 17. -- The elections for members of the Storthing, or Great Court, have just been held. Thus far returns have been received from 98 of the 114 districts. The figures now at hand show the return of 58 candidates of the Radical Left, the party led by Mr. Steen, the Prime Minister, which advocates the appointment of separate foreign Ministries for Sweden and Norway.

It was a success, the dinner which the Chamber of Commerce gave last night. There was an eager thronging of guests, the hall in which they met was crowded, and those who spoke in the hour of the coffee and the cigars had something to say which was well worth hearing.

The launch of the armored cruiser New-York is to take place Dec. 2. A dispatch stating this fact came yesterday from the builders, William Cramp Sons. With the network of scaffolding down, the size of the new war ships hows to marked advantage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day transacted the following business:

The jury in the Supreme Court, before Judge Beach, where the suit of Actress Agues Hallock Barry to recover $3,000 from William Barry of the Barry and Fay company, because, as she alleged, he struck her, was unable to agree and was discharged yesterday morning. The suit will now be given a new trial. Mrs. Barry is the wife of Thomas Barry, the manager of the Gaiety Theatre in Albany.

There was very little excitement caused on the Produce Exchange yesterday by the news that the French Chamber of Deputies had approved the tariff of 25f. on salted meats, as fixed by the Senate. It was the general opinion that the American exporters would not be able to profit for some time, although a good many firms has had agents in France opening the Way for business.

Seventy families were made homeless, three persons injured, and over $100,000 worth of property destroyed by a fire which broke out in the cellar of the four-story frame tenement at 120 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning. This is one of a row of poorly-constructed frame buildings extending from Floyd to Stockton Street, and the only wonder is that at least half of the 300 people in them were not burned to death.

William J. Jenner, a broker, of 210 West One Hundred and Ninth Street, was complainant in the Tombs Police Court yesterday against Lewis M. Muller, aged thirty-three, described as a builder, residing at 241 Union Street, Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- "The Republican Temperance Guard of Massachusetts" was tiffs afternoon born in Wesleyan Hall. Its objects are as follows:

The bidding was neither spirited nor liberal at the opening sale of the Verestchagin paintings in the American Art Galleries last evening. There was a large assemblage of ladies and gentlemen, who cordially evinced their appreciation whenever a particularly fine picture was displayed. The buying, however, was confined to a few.

It was not to be expected that the prosecutors of Dr. BRIGGS would abandon their efforts to procure a condemnation of his utterances merely because the New-York Presbytery had decided to dismiss the charges against him. The "Princeton rush line," temporarily discomfited by that action, has now returned to the charge and has taken an appeal to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 17. -- A storm of wind, cyclonic in its force, swept through the section of country lying north of this city at 8 o'clock this afternoon, causing much destruction. Alfred Smalley, owner of the Smalley Stone Crushing Works on the side of the mountain back of Zelbring's mills, was just leaving the works for home when a dense blackness loomed up across the mountain tops.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 17. -- After a prolonged session, extending late into the evening, the delegates to the Knights or Labor General Assembly were able to complete their work. The majority of the delegates will leave for their homes tomorrow morning, but the members of the Executive Board and general officers will remain here for at least three days to finish up the business of the assembly.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- The severe storm today brought with it a tornado such as has never before been seen in Rockland County. It damaged property to the extent of $15,000 or $20,000 at Piermont, and gave that village a startling sensation.

Paderewski is his name. It is not a pretty name, and it is not a pretty man; but he can play the piano. Moreover, he can play upon the piano and with the piano. Yet he is not the ideal pianist. If he had the power of a Rosenthal, the enormous musical force of a D'Albert, the intellectuality of a Rummel, and the celestial tone color of a Pachmann, he would be the ideal pianist.

Immigration Commissioner H.J. Shulteis, the small man with a big head who preferred a charge of immorality against immigrants on the Servia and talked so blatantly about wishing to have the whole world hear what he had to say to Col. Weber, when it came to the point yesterday said very little. In fact, he denied that he made some statements which he did make in the presence of a dozen witnesses.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- During the day a very high wind has prevailed here, and considerable damage has been done about the city. Trees and signs have been blown down and in some sections chimneys have been blown off.
The Executive Committee of the Street-Cleaning Aid Society met yesterday at 222 West Thirty-eighth Street. It was the first meeting of the committee since the society was organized last May.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 17. -- Revised and corrected unofficial returns represent the Legislature elected two weeks ago as standing politically as follows: Senate -- Republicans, 17; Democrats, 14; Independent, 1. Dr. Edwards of Chautauqua. Assembly -- Democrats, 64; Republicans, 63; Independent, 1, William J. O'Dair, who was elected by both Republican and County Democratic votes, and who defeated Joseph Blumenthal in the Twenty-second New-York City District.

The anti-grab committee of citizens in charge of the movement to turn the elevated road out of Battery Park will resume aggressive measures shortly in case the Park Commissioners fail to act. It is now nearly six months since the Commissioners were asked to do their duty and oust the squatter. The case was fully argued. No new light has been thrown upon it since early in the Summer.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- At the fourth day's session of the dual temperance convention to-day John G. Woolly spoke briefly of his reformatory called "Rest Island." E.H. Hickey spoke of the work in removing pernicious literature from railroad trains. Mrs. O.B. Gause reported on providing speakers for Sunday and other outside meetings of the convention.

When L.O. Vanuxem, the Philadelphia agent of the New-York Life Insurance Company, presented President Beers of that company with a twelve-thousand-dollar Rembrandt all the other agents attached to the company looked wise and said nothing. When the notorious "Sam" Dinkelspiel, alias Lewis, the swindler and gambler, called upon the company's agents to contribute toward a silver service which he was to present to President Beers, the agents again looked wise and said nothing.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17. -- The Supreme Council of the Farmers' Alliance was called to order in Tomlinson Hall this morning by President Force of the Indiana Alliance, with nearly all the 120 delegates, and 500 spectators in attendance.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- William J. Florence, the comedian, is still alive, and his physicians and friends refuse to abandon hope of his recovery, though at one time this morning the famous actor seemed to be at the very door of death. At this hour, midnight, Dr. Donnelan has just come from the sickroom. To the question, "Doctor, do you think there is a chance for recovery?" the doctor replied:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Assistant Secretary Soley has made inquiry concerning the report printed in THE TIMES of Saturday in an extract from the letter of a seaman on board the Baltimore that the sailors of the San Francisco had a collision with a mob in Valparaiso a few days before the attack on the men of the Baltimore.

New-York is gradually becoming something of a storm centre in the contest for the Speakership of the House of Representatives, as, indeed, it tends more and more to become in all political contests. The candidates of every kind and degree of promise drop in here casually or by appointment to look after their interests or to find out whether they have any interests here.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Exchange Telegraph Company gives publicity to sensational news from Rio Janeiro. No explanation is given as to how the news was allowed to be cabled, and as it is known that the Government has taken complete control of the cables and has refused to permit any intelligence not favorable to its interests to be telegraphed out of the country, to-day's dispatches are not accepted here as certain to be accurate.

The Electrical Engineer to-day prints an article on the recent experiments made by Edison with a view to devising a street railway system which shall be applicable to cities where the trolley system is not permitted and which shall not cost more than a cable road to install. It says:

Yesterday was fruitful in reports of marine casualties and strange tales of the sea. One of them, which was cabled from London, is a happy sequel to what has long been a mystery of the ocean. It told of the arrival at Rotterdam of the German ship Camelia, and that the vessel had on board Capt. Moule and seven men of the American schooner Tames.

The cold wave is much earlier than anybody expected it, considering its intensity. There is the more reason for expecting that it will pass presently and be succeeded by a season of mild and possibly rainy weather. This would be very favorable for our water supply, which gives New-Yorkers their principal interest in the weather.

Acting Mayor Arnold carried out the wishes of Mayor Grant yesterday in the appointment of School Commissioners and Inspectors of Schools. The following Commissioners were appointed for a term of three years from Jan. 1, 1892:

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 18. -- When the returns from the First District, town of Dover, came before the Board of Canvassers of Dutchess County to-day, Mr. Hanna presented the statement of the Inspectors that the defective ballots were counted as blanks. There were seven of them, four Democratic and three Republican, pasted on the backs of official ballots.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Charles R. De Freest, Clerk of the Democratic State Committee, is in anything but a pleasant humor to-night. A. very cleverly-conceived plan which gave every promise of proving successful was upset.

A series of frauds in the construction of school buildings, running back through the administration of George W. Debevoise as Superintendent of School Buildings, and by which the city has been defrauded out of several thousands of dollars, was laid bare yesterday by the Committee on Buildings in a report to the Board of Education.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18. -- Thus far the future prospects of the Alliance have not been greatly improved by the Indianapolis meeting. In fact, the contrary seems to be the case. The two great organizations, the Alliance and the Farmers' Mutual Benefit Association, are no nearer amalgamation, the third-party movement has brought on a bitter factional fight in each, and there is an absolute certainty of a split on the Sub-Treasury question.

The grounding of the steamship California in the middle of the harbor of New-York, and in one of the most essential of the channels -- that running between Governors Island and the Brooklyn shore -- is only one more proof of the condition into which this great port has fallen from various causes, chief among which is its neglect by the Federal Government.

HURON, S.D., Nov. 18. -- The South Dakota Railroad Commissioners were in session here last night devising means to relieve the grain blockade that has bean increasing in magnitude for the last two weeks. The storm of Wednesday and Sunday delayed thrashing, and farmers have taken advantage of the opportunity to haul their grain to market, so all storage room has been exhausted.

The extension of the Bell telephone monopoly for a term of fifteen years beyond the expiration of its original patents, which appears to be practically established by the issuing of a patent Tuesday to Emile Berliner, assignor to the American Bell Company, has created considerable surprise among men of that profession in this city.

College men thronged the corridors of the Hotel Marlborough yesterday, where the forty-fifth annual convention of the Theta Delta Chi Fraternity was in session. There were seventy-five delegates present, representing twenty colleges. The following is a list of the delegates by colleges:

Mayor CHAPIN of Brooklyn, who has been confined to the house by illness, is expected to be at his office to-day, and will be likely to receive a delegation from a majority of the Board of Education, who will ask for an opportunity to exchange views and facts on the reappointment of BARTHMAN.

One of those original combinations of opera and play for which the Amberg Theatre has been noted drew large audiences during the earlier days of the week. On Monday a short piece called "The Play Actors of the Emperor" was given in order to exhibit Herr Matkowsky, and then certain instruments were added to the orchestra.

The members of the American Ornithologists' Union, and a small number of visitors to the public sessions of its ninth congress, now in session at the American Museum of Natural History, listened yesterday morning to the paper by President D.G. Elliot, on "The Inheritance of Acquired Characters."

Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Department of Public Works returned from the Croton watershed yesterday, bringing the cheerful news that the average total precipitation of water over the whole watershed in the storm from Monday morning to Tuesday night was one and one-tenth inches.

The Valparaiso affair has produced a good deal of random surmising as to the damage which the Chilean war vessels might do to our Pacific seaboard. Visions of the bombardment of San Francisco have been conjured up, and some alarmist theories have been started as to the ravages which the South American republic could inflict on our commerce.

If Postmaster General Wanamaker awards contracts for carrying the ocean mails to those bidders whose propositions were opened recently he will furnish a very comfortable thing for each of the steamship companies concerned. He will add to the revenue of each a considerable sum of cash, for which he will ask very little in return in the way of extra trouble or labor.

ABERDEEN, S.D., Nov. 18. -- It is learned from Alonzo Wardall and George C. Crose, the heads of two very important divisions of Alliance work in the Northwest, that the business department of the Alliance in twenty-two States of the Union has united with leading business men of New-York City and formed a company similar in its plan of operation to the celebrated Rochdale system in England and to the Zion Cooperative Store in Utah.

The Republican organization in this city, lashed into a senseless fury by the stinging defeat in the last election, now proposes to make a direct charge on the Federal Administration for patronage, civil service rules or no civil service rules. This state of things was clearly indicated at yesterday's meeting of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, hold in the Tribune Building.

CHICAGO, Nov. l8. -- There was at the opening on provisions just such difficulty in making sales in December pork as some of the bears have been predicting. The close Tuesday, was at $8.62; the opening at $S8.30. Shorts, especially the big shorts, were inclined to make purchases on the decline. There result was, instead of the opening demoralization increasing it was checked. Hog receipts were at the bottom of the weakness.

OTTAWA, Nov. 18. -- About 1 o'clock to-day Mr. J.R. Arnoldi, late Chief Engineer of the Public Works Department, was arrested by Inspector O'Leary of the Dominion police force, on a warrant charging him with conspiring to defraud the Government. The arrest was known by only a few who happened to be in the rotunda of the Russell House.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Chairman Finley has for two days been trying cases of alleged violations of agreement on the part of the Burlington, the Rock Island, the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City, and other roads. The contention is that these lines last September reduced home visitors' excursion rates to one fare for the return trip, while the agreed rate was one and on-third fare.

Joaquin Sanchez, the Director in Chief of the Spanish-American Department of the New-York Life Insurance Company, who took the books of that department to Barcelona, Spain, several months ago in order to prevent their contents from being made public, and who was subsequently summoned by the Insurance Commissioner to return to New-York with the books, is said to have sailed for Europe yesterday.

The Mayor's appointments to the Board of Education, which have now been announced, are quite as good as was to be expected, but not all that could be desired. Of the four members reappointed, Messrs. SANGER and O'BRIEN have done intelligent and zealous service. There are four new members, including Mr. HOPPER, who is appointed to fill a vacancy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Rev. Dr. Reese F. Alsop of Brooklyn, N.Y., opened the second day's proceedings of the Protestant Episcopal Church Congress, this morning, with an address on Socialism. He rapidly sketched in outline the theories of Henry George and the delightful dream of Bellamy, and pointed out the differences between the most noted advocates of Socialistic theories.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 18. -- Congressman Vincent A. Taylor of the Twentieth Ohio District, who is a close friend of ex-Gov. Foraker, was in town yesterday on his way home. He is shouting for Blaine. He said:

ST. PAUL, Nov. 18. -- St. Paul last night suffered one of the most disastrous fires in its history, the buildings damaged being those of Griggs, Cooper Co., wholesale grocers, and Farwell, Ozmun, Kirk Co., wholesale hardware. The total loss is estimated at from $900,000 to $1,000,000. The losses are covered by insurance.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction in their provisional estimate to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment this year, ask for $2,881,145, as against a call for $2,166,237 last year. The great item of increase is occasioned by a call for $567,999 for new buildings, as against $160,000 asked for last year for the same purpose.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 18. -- A crowd again besieged the doors of the little Court House this morning long before they were opened, and the courtroom was packed as on yesterday. Almy, who passed a sleepless night, was brought into court promptly at 9 o'clock, showing every evidence of the strain through which he is passing, and looking dejected.

The United States gunboat cruiser Concord, Commander O.A. Batcheller, sailed yesterday morning at 7 o'clock for St. Thomas, West Indies. As stated in yesterday's TIMES, the Concord is under orders to join the flag of Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi, who is aboard the flagship Philadelphia, lying in the harbor of St. Thomas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- William J. Florence, whose hold on life seemed so small on Tuesday, continued to slowly improve to-day, and there is generally a more hopeful outlook of a favorable termination of his illness. The physicians by no means say that the distinguished actor is out of danger; indeed, the natural weakness consequent upon the hard battle with death is now the main cause for alarm.

The cultivation of flax for the fibre and the manufacture of linen are by no means infant industries. The old mummies, unearthed after 5,000 years, are wrapped in linen. Babylonia carried on an extensive trade in linen fabrics centuries before Herodotus chronicled the fact. Tacitus tells us of the ancient Germans being clad in linen, and away into the Middle Ages linen tunica and sheepskins were the chief articles of clothing of the peasantry.

The recent decision of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia against Charles A. Newton, who was charged with violating Section 12 of the Civil Service act, has been received with a great deal of pleasure by the civil service reformers. The section in question is as follows:

A man who gave the name of John Westerman went into the jewelry store of Harris Leivin, 604 Grand Street, Tuesday evening, and asked to see some gold watches. Leivin put a tray of watches upon the counter, and while the customer was looking at them a second man entered and called for silver watches. As soon as the storekeeper turned away Westerman grabbed the tray of gold watches and ran out of the store.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- A dispatch from Santiago, Chile, to the Times says that the differences which have been interfering with perfect unity of action by the Provisional Junta of Rio Grande do Sul are disappearing and the members of the Junta are now acting in harmony. They have made one of their number, Dr. Assiz Brazil, Minister of War, and have placed Gens. Osari and Tastares in command of the forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18. -- A Honolulu letter says: "Honolulu has been treated to a genuine sensation in the arrest and detention of the owners of the British yacht Beadle, who were charged with smuggling 30,000 English sovereigns into that port.

The Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, last night completed the official count of the vote cast in this oily at the last election. They will meet to-morrow at 2 P.M. to declare the result.

Ex-President Cleveland is entitled to a large share of the credit for the victories in New-York and Massachusetts. Without his timely and effective aid Flower and Russell would have been defeated, and as a consequence Cleveland stock is quoted higher than ever.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- In the Senatorial contest that is now going on in this State two distinct influences have been at work from the first. At the convention of the Farmers' Alliance in this city last Summer the avowed object of many of the leaders in the movement was the defeat of Senator John Sherman and his forced retirement from public life.

The trial of the suit brought by ex-Congressman James J. Belden against ex-Judge Stevenson Burke and his associate Directors of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railroad Company, the railroad company, Winslow, Lanier Co., Drexel, Morgan Co., and the Central Trust Company was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge Ingraham.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 18. -- Postmaster S. L. Winter of Woodbine, Harrison County, has absconded. He left home a week ago and has not since been heard from. An investigation of his affairs shows that he has been speculating on the Chicago Board of Trade and losing heavily. It is not known whether the Government funds have been tampered with.

Plenty of chance has been given the rising generation of artists at the Autumn exhibition of the National Academy of Design; this year the older men have abstained to a large extent and left the field free.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19. -- In a fit of murderous insanity Charles Durgin this morning attacked his two sisters, Gertrude and Adelaide, with a poker and then rushed to a police station and gave himself up. Both girls will probably die. The story as told by young Durgin himself gives the only connected version of the horrible affair obtainable. He is only twenty-one years old, but has a criminal record in many States. He said:

As many men and women as could find seats in the Collegiate Church, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, last evening, listened to speeches in favor of more parks and playgrounds for the children in this densely populated town. The meeting was called by a committee representing. The New-York Union of Religious and Humanitarian Societies for Concerted Moral Effort.

A concerted movement is now on foot by fire insurance companies which have been writing large amounts of farm property business to advance rates on that class of risks. The reason put forth is that for years the companies have lost money in this line. The rates are now made by special and local agents.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- A semi-official dispatch has been received here from Shanghai stating that the situation arising from the recent action of Chinese mobs in attacking and threatening foreigners in the Province of Hunan is more satisfactory, owing to the energetic action of the representatives of the foreign powers.

In a little room at the Bible House yesterday were stored about 4,500 articles of clothing, and more was expected. These articles were the results of the first year's work of the New-York City Branch of the Needlework Guild of America. The clothing consisted of flannels, shirts for men, socks and stockings, skirts and dresses, and all kinds of wearing apparel for babies, besides bedclothing.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- The trouble of the striking coal miners in the Department of Pas-de-Calais were one of the subjects under discussion in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. M. Basley, the Socialist Deputy, who presided at the meeting of miners' delegates held at Lens last Sunday, when a general strike was agreed upon, asked that the mines be placed under the control of the State.

The success of Ignace Jean Paderewski is assured. No pianist has made such a sensational impression here since Anton Rubinstein. This is not saying that Paderewski is a Rubinstein, but in truth he approaches nearer to that great master of the piano than any one else to whom this public has had the happiness to listen. That the man has his limitations is, of course, an indisputable fact.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19. -- The San Francisco, flagship of the Pacific Squadron, which left here April 8 for Chile, returned here this morning. The vessel was present at the closing scenes of the Chilean revolution.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The presentation of "Esmeralda," a four-act comedy by Mrs. Frances Hodgson Burnett, at the Casino of the Union County Country Club this evening, was a decided success. Those who had seen "Esmeralda" as presented by professionals in previous seasons were very anxious concerning the difficulties attending its performance by amateurs, but their doubts were swept away to-night before the magnificent exhibition of the capabilities of the participants.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Several days ago ex-Inter-State Commerce Commissioner and ex-Attorney General Augustus Schoonmaker wrote a letter favoring resumption for the Ulster County Savings Institution. The letter was in answer to certain inquiries propounded by several heavy depositors. Recently the Freeman published the following criticism of the Judge's letter:

When the outrageous Ship Subsidy bill was passed by the Billion-Dollar Congress we predicted that its effect would be not to establish new lines of steamships, but to add to the profits of those already existing. Postmaster General WANAMAKER laid out a great scheme of mail routes and called for bids for carrying the mails upon them under the Subsidy act.

Among the most interesting events of the horse show have been the two competitions among the mounted men of the Park police and the mounted men of the Metropolitan Police. That the work of these horsemen is of great public value is well known to all who have occasion to frequent the Park or the drives in the northern part of the city.

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- There has been issued from the office of the Regents of the University a circular which aims to outline briefly the plan of the new department -- university extension -- for which the Legislature appropriated $10.000.

The writer was much interested in TUE TIMES'S article of Nov. 3 on "Our Country Roads," and knowing that your journal has for years done good service in advocating improvements in this direction, he ventures to offer two suggestions:

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 19. -- The State Equal Suffrage Association is in session. This afternoon, resolutions were adopted pledging the association to renewed efforts to secure full suffrage. An effort will also be made to secure the passage of an act by the next Legislature giving women the right to vote for Presidential Electors.

No sensible person will question the justice and propriety of the death sentence passed upon ALMY by Judge DOE of the New-Hampshire Supreme Court yesterday. The man ALMY appears to be a criminal by native propensity. The murder he committed in Hanover was brutal in the extreme, and he had confessed the crime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The three armor plates tested at Indian Head last Saturday have been taken from their backings, and the board in charge of the trials inspected them to-day. They found the relative condition of the plates and backings about as indicated by the appearance of the faces.

The members of the Republican County Committee met last night in Grand Opera House Hall and tried hard to convince themselves that they were happy. It was the first meeting held since the election. William Brookfield, the Chairman of the County Committee, as well as the Chairman of the State Committee, put as good a front as possible on things when he called the meeting to order.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The local end of the contest in the Twenty-fifth Senatorial District, composed of Onondaga and Cortland Counties, between Rufus T. Peck, Republican, and John A. Nichols, Democrat, was decided to-day when Mr. Peck's certificate was filed in the County Clerk's office on an order made by Justice of the Supreme Court George N. Kennedy, a Republican.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- On Monday next the Republican National Committee will meet at the Arlington Hotel in this city, to name a time and place for holding the next National Convention, and to issue the necessary call.

During the recent campaign our high-tariff friends professed to believe that the Cobden Club was an organization possessing enormous wealth, which it was using freely in efforts to "break down American industries." The sum commonly mentioned as the club's contribution to the Democratic campaign fund in Ohio was half a million dollars.

PERTH, Ontario, Nov. 19. -- The demonstration in honor of John M. Haggart in Agricultural Hall in Perth, to-day, was most enthusiastic. The hall was elaborately decorated with mottoes and banners, while the galleries were crowded with ladies. William Lees, M.P., presided. He introduced Mr. Rogers, who presented Mr. Haggart with a very complimentary address.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 19. -- When the Court House doors were opened this morning the waiting crowd came in with a rush, packing the building to suffocation. Almy came into court wearing a haggard look, but he appeared unconcerned and took his accustomed place. The court was called to order quickly, and Counsel Burleigh began his argument for the defense. He admitted murder, but only in the second degree.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 19. -- Complaint was made to the Humane Society at Washington, Penn., several days ago that 100 negroes, recently brought to the Snowden Mines of the Pittsburg and Chicago Gas Coal Company, were being ill treated. An investigation discloses a condition of affairs bordering on slavery.
Cornelius N. Bliss was unanimously elected President of the American Protective Tariff League yesterday in place of Edward H. Ammidown, resigned.

Judge Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas has sent to Theodore F. Miller, as referee, a suit brought by the Teachers' Land and improvement Company against Vice Principal William H. Van Cott and Reno R. Billington, a lawyer, to recover $4,900. The company is made up of teachers in the public schools, and was formed, it is alleged, partly through the efforts of the defendants for the purpose of buying land for speculative purposes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Willard S. Norvell was arrested in this city this morning by officers of the Treasury Secret Service on a charge of having stolen $500 from the United States Treasury.
