He was formerly a clerk in the National Bank Redemption Agency of the Treasurer's office, and is alleged to have committed the theft while engaged in his duties of examining packages of national bank notes sent to the Treasury for redemption.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 19. -- "My God You don't tell me!" was the exclamation which fell from the lips of Joseph Jefferson when informed this evening that his companion and bosom friend, Florence, was dead.

Yesterday was the first day's sale of Verestchagin's collection of Indian and Russian pieces of art in metal and religious emblems. There were not many people present at the sale, and the bidding was limited to a few. Among the buyers were Charles A. Brown, Mrs. E.A. Bass, Mrs. Lathrop, A.E. Olarowsky, W.S. Scott, Charles Bishop, and C.T. Chapman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Mr. Mills, Mr. Crisp, and Mr. Springer, all of the candidates for Speaker who have appeared here to begin canvassing, were out of the city to-day, and all were supposed to be in New-York. The supposition is here that all have gone to New-York to seek the support of the New-York delegation. Even Mr. Springer expresses hope that he may capture it.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 19. -- War has been declared between the American Cotton Oil Trust and the independent mills in Tennessee, Eastern Arkansas, and North Central Mississippi, and henceforth there will be a boom in the price of cottonseed, which will put many dollars into the pockets of the farmers, while it reduces the profits of the crushers and refiners to a minimum.

Gov. Campbell of Ohio was in New-York yesterday. He stopped at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and received numerous callers, who congratulated him on the splendid campaign that he had made and discussed with him the prominent features of the fight in which he was worsted. Gov. Campbell told a TIMES reporter that he was in fine condition after the battle.

The recent express-car robberies near Milwaukee and near Utica are so unlike those we have been accustomed to hear of that we must no longer connect them with the general idea of disordered civilization. That such robberies are still possible except in a neighborhood practically given up to plunder and rapine does not speak well for the wisdom and sagacity of those in whose charge valuable express matter has been placed.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The Board of Canvassers of Columbia County got down to real work to-day, and the result was that all the remaining districts were canvassed, except the First District of New-Lebanon, where there is a question regarding one vote. These returns were sent back for correction.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Telegrams received in this city to-day from Buenos Ayres announce that the whole province of Rio Grande do Sul has risen in arms against the Dictatorship of Gen. da Fonseca. Dr. Assiz Brazil, recently appointed Minister of War by the Provisional Junta in that province, and who is head of the Insurgent Committee, has sent a message by telegraph to the Minister of Finance demanding the resignation of President da Fonseca.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The third day's session of the Episcopal Congress was presided over by Bishop Dudley or Kentucky. The Rev. Dr. C.W. Shinn of Newton, Mass., read the first essay of the session, on the general subject of "New and Old Parochial Methods." In it he said:

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- Many citizens of this State are convinced that Gov. Hill is determined to steal the Senate. That the Republicans elected a majority of the members of the Senate, not the slightest doubt exists in the minds of the great body of the people.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 19. -- The following is the correspondence between the Virginia Commission and the Olcott Committee, together with the result reached on a plan for the settlement of the State debt:

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- Inspector General Thomas H. Barber has submitted to Adjt Gen. Porter the recorded result of his annual inspection of the State troops. He says in his report that the inspection shows a general improvement, and that in most commands the advance has been marked. In a few cases, however, progress has been slow, and the organizations have little military merit.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- Little but the Senatorship is talked of in places of public resort, and the interest is manifestly on the increase. The earnest friends of ex-Gov. Foraker tell of wonderful gains where least expected, but very shrewdly withhold the names of Senators or Representatives that were claimed by the friends of Mr. Sherman.

It is proposed to have a public exhibition of the working of the engines of the new cruisers Cincinnati and Raleigh, now in process of erection at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, just so soon as it is found practi cable after all the engine parts are assembled. A statement to this effect was made Wednesday by Chief Engineer Samuel L.P. Ayres, Chief of the Department of Steam Engineering at the Brooklyn Yard.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 19. -- The decision of the Supreme Court of Canada that the Manitoba Schools act is void by reason of its being beyond the authority of the Legislature of the province to pass such an act brings forward in another form the everlasting conflict between Church and State in the matter of education. This question is one of world-wide import.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission has, after long and patient efforts, succeeded in getting two rich Chicago shipping firms and one railroad man indicted for indulging in the rebate practice. The Federal Grand Jury in Chicago yesterday brought in indictments as follows:

The arrival in New-York of Mr. Sanchez, the Manager of the Spanish-American Department of the New-York Life, accompanied by twenty cases containing the accounts of that department, in response to the peremptory orders of the New-York Insurance Department, now conducting its investigation of the company, does not seem to have produced that feeling of enthusiasm on the part of the latter which was anticipated.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Theodore Hoffman, the Republican clerk of the Dutchess County Board of Canvassers, refused to-day to give the board a certified copy of yesterday's proceedings with resolutions censuring him attached, and on motion of Mr. Vail, the Democratic leader, resolutions were adopted preferring charges against Hoffman for neglect of duty, citing the facts and providing for forwarding a copy of the complaint to Gov. Hill by messenger.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- William J. Florence, the distinguished actor, died at 8:20 this evening in his room at the Continental Hotel, to which he had been confined since last Saturday night. Death came so peacefully that Mrs. Barney Williams and Mrs. Wyard, his sisters-in-law, and Dr. J.S. Donellan, who were by the bedside, did not know he was dead until he had ceased breathing several minutes.

The courts are called upon to determine the action of Boards of County Canvassers to quite an unusual extent this year, and to an extent that would be altogether unnecessary if the canvassers were content to perform their legal duties without concerning themselves with questions with which they have nothing to do.

BATH, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- So far as the Canvassing Board of Steuben County is concerned, the wrangle over the Senatorial contest in this district was finished to-day when the resolutions formerly passed in regard to Sherwood's ineligibility were rescinded under a peremptory mandamus granted by Justice Adams of the Supreme Court.

The death of Mr. FLORENCE will be felt by many thousands of persons who never knew him off the stage as the loss of a friend. This might be said, glibly, of many other distinguished actors; it generally is said when an actor of note dies; but not with the same force. FLORENCE had an uncommon measure of geniality which was always felt in his acting.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The many errors in the recording of the votes cast for Mr. Worden in the Second Rensselaer Assembly District were due to clerical errors on the part of the Inspectors. The names of the candidates for State, County, and Senate offices were printed, but for the Assembly the returns read as follows:
The New-York Sun recently published from Belford's Monthly a three-column eulogy of Isaac Pusey Gray, ex-Governor of Indiana, by John A. Holman. It advises its patrons to road it and says:

ELIZABETH, Nov. 19. -- A horrible grade-crossing accident took place here this morning by which two men were killed, one of them being literally cut to pieces. Abraham Diamond and David Kreanis, two butchers of this city, were on their way from Job Winans's slaughterhouse in Linden Township, and just as they reached Dark Lane crossing on the Pennsylvania Railroad the east-bound Southern express, running at high speed, came cashing down upon them.

The Executive Committee of the Republican National League reconvened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock at the Plaza Hotel. The number of delegates was increased by the arrival of Mr. Chris of Arizona. In all, twenty-seven States and Territories were represented at yesterday's meeting. The work of Thursday was resumed. Those States whose reports of work had not been made reported.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 20. -- The dedication of the Colorado Mining Stock Exchange Building and the opening of the first national mining congress were celebrated here Wednesday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The camp of the "Big Six" has been thrown into confusion by the publication of a series of letters from their opponents for re-election on the subject of city bonds. At the Democratic Convention, when the "Big Six" ticket was placed in the field, the stringent plank of the platform was the one in which the issuing of city bonds was condemned.

Striped bass fishing continues to improve in Hell Gate several of the larger size bass have been caught, and up the Hudson the fishing has been much more encouraging. Unfortunately for the anglers, there is not mush time remaining before the Winter weather will stop angling and send the fish into permanent quarters till Springtime.

Application was made yesterday to Judge Booketaver, in the Court of Common Pleas, to have confirmed the report of Charles A. Runk passing on the accounts of Clarence F. Birdseye, as assignee of the firm of Baker Clark, wholesale grocers, who failed about four years ago. The application was opposed by J.H. Hull and Albert Stickney, representing creditors who had filed exceptions to the report.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- There was a secret meeting of New-England Democrats at the Parker House yesterday. All the Democrats in New-England who were elected to Congress last Fall were there except three. The only absentees were Messrs. Daniels of New-Hampshire and Sperry and Wilcox of Connecticut. Their great desire was to reach some sort or an agreement on the Speakership question.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Some of the Democrats who are watching the progress of the canvass for the Speakership, and who are regarding it as a part of the campaign of next year for the Presidency, are beginning to suspect that there is more of an effort being made for the benefit of Hill as a candidate than appears on the surface, although surface indications are not lacking.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- The body of William J. Florence was removed from the Continental Hotel this evening and, attended by a few relatives, taken to New-York, where the funeral will take place from St. Agnes's Church.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 20. -- Amherst met Williams on Pratt Field this afternoon in the most stubbornly fought football game that has ever been seen on the home grounds. The Williams eleven were heavier, and were expected to outmatch the lighter men; but through two forty-five-minute halves Amherst's weaker line kept her opponents from scoring, the game resulting in a tie -- 0 to 0.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- News concerning the situation in Brazil continues to be very meagre and unsatisfactory. The last advices by way of Santiago indicate that the provisional Junta in authority in the State of Rio Grande do Sul is taking active measures to strengthen its position and to maintain the opposition of the State to Fonseca's dictatorship.

The approval of the routes and of the general plan of the Rapid-Transit Commission and consent to the construction of the proposed roads have now been obtained from all the local authorities that have any jurisdiction in the matter. The Board of Aldermen acted unanimously at the earliest time permitted by the law, holding a special meeting for the purpose, and the Mayor approved their action without delay.

The counting in of PATRICK J. RYAN for the Assembly from the First District of Onondaga County by the Democratic Canvassing Board seems to be an outrage upon the election laws of this State. It is one of the advantages of the official ballot that there can be no variation in the spelling of the names of candidates.

The first public rehearsal of the fiftieth season of the Philharmonic Society took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The large auditorium was packed and many persons stood throughout the performance. Undoubtedly, curiosity as to what the new conductor of the Philharmonic would do with that august body was a factor in crowding the house.

The movement now on foot partly to undo the good work of last year in founding the new Yosemite National Park may well excite suspicion. It appears that several of the neighboring counties of California object to having had so much taxable area taken from them, and desire to secure the restoration of sundry townships.

Calculations upon the Electoral votes of the States to be cast next year must be considerably modified, on account of the changes produced by the admission of six new States since the election of 1888, and by the effect of the new Congressional apportionment based upon the census of 1890.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. -- John W. Mackay, the bonanza king, was asked last night who Nevada would return to the United States Senate next year.

PRINCETON, Nov. 20. -- The university football eleven played their last game of the week to-day, defeating the reserves by the score of 36 to 6 The team did not play in championship form, and nearly every Princetonian has given up all expectation of winning the great Thanksgiving Day match. "Hope" is the strongest word used even by the most sanguine.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 20. -- The Yale football team went to Springfield this afternoon on a special train. During their stay in that city they will be the guests of Stagg, at the quarters of the Christian Workers, two miles out of the city, where they will have the use of excellent grounds, free from observation, on which finally to rehearse their tricks and signals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- About 8:30 to-night, when a crowd of New-York men swarmed into the already-crowded hall of the Arlington Hotel, the throng was greatly surprised to find among them Gov. Hill, who was being hustled about with as little regard for the safety of his person as if he were an ordinary boomer for the National Convention.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- An application was made to-day at Special Term of the Supreme Court in this city to show cause in the relation of Obed Wheeler, Republican member of Assembly elect in the First Assembly District of Dutchess County, why six votes cast in the First Election District, Town of Dover, and returned by the Inspectors of Election as blank ballots, should not be canvassed by the Board of Canvassers as blanks.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Never in the history of Onondaga County has there been such a wild scene of excitement and confusion in a similar body as took place in the Board of Canvassers to-day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20. -- Harvard's football team left Cambridge for the Yale game this afternoon, and went down to Springfield on the 4 o'clock train over the Boston and Albany Road. All the football enthusiasm of the week and season came to a climax to-day, and over 1,500 students collected in front of University Hall to give the team a royal send-off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The steam drying process to which United States notes are treated after they leave the printing presses at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing is thought by many Treasury officials to be the cause of the unsatisfactory condition of the notes after they have been in circulation a short time.

The criticism that has been bestowed so lavishly on the Director of the Mint for the designs for the new coins has been based, so far as we have seen, on photographs of the coins. The actual coin is not good, but it is by no means bad relatively to the coins of other nations, and its real badness is not, as has been too generally assumed, the fault of the Director of the Mint.

In its weekly report of the wool market in this city the Wool and Cotton Reporter of the 19th says: "Probably there never was a time when the future looked as gloomy for the carpet manufacturer as at present." In its editorial columns the same journal says: "The carpet maker must look for a wider market, to come either from a curtailed production or from new channels for the distribution of his goods.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- The subject that will be talked about at the political and economic reform congresses during the World's Fair have just been provisionally settled by President Bonney. Separate international congresses are to be held on each of the themes as follows:

The current elections in Norway indicate a very decided triumph in the new Storthing for the Radicals. The recent political change in that country, by which the Radical Ministry of STEEN succeeded the Conservative Ministry of STANG, was accomplished on the issue now again presented -- the creation of a separate Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The annual report of the Secretary of War was made public to-day. It reviews the entire status of each branch of the army service, together with the subject of coast defenses, pensions, promotions, war records, national cemeteries, and soldiers' homes.

Some curious incidents attended the issue of the Berliner telephone patent, and the Commissioner of Patents may find it expedient to explain them. This is the patent which was granted upon an application that had been kept alive in the Patent Office for more than fourteen years, while devices which it covers were in use, and by means of it the Bell Company hopes to extend for fifteen years the term of its monopoly.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- The Board of County Canvassers of Columbia County completed their labors this evening. There was a large audience of onlookers, as it was supposed the session would develop some spicy arguments by members and lively tilts between the counsel, but the proceeding were devoid of all such embellishment.

The football match at Springfield to-day is really the most important event of the year in this sport. Nominally, the championship is to be decided at the match in this city next Thursday. That is the championship of the Intercollegiate Association, in which Yale and Princeton will take part and from which Harvard is virtually debarred by the action of the Faculty forbidding its team to play out of New-England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The general subject of discussion at this morning's session of the Episcopal Congress was "The True Policy of Diocesan Missions." In the absence of the Rev. Dr. Atwill of Kansas City, the Rev. Gustave A. Carstensen of New-York City read the first essay of the session. He said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Not for many months has the hall of the Arlington Hotel been so crowded as it is to-night. The approaching meeting of the Republican National Committee, and the strife between cities that desire to be named as the place in which the Republican Convention shall be held, have drawn together hosts of partisans of the different places and turned the hotel into a sort of boomers' headquarters.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 20. -- Prof. E. Stone Wiggins, the Canadian astronomer, was interviewed by THE TIMES'S correspondent regarding the recent eclipse of the moon.

PARIS NOV.. 20. -- The troubles in the coal districts of the Department of Pas-de-Calais are assuming a threatening phase, and it is feared that serious disturbances may occur. The miners are very bitter toward the men who, in spite of arguments and threats, continue to work in the mines.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- There is a big political fight, brewing not only in this county, but in this Congressional district.

Friday had been set long before the day arrived as the great one of the horse show, and the demand for accommodations at the Garden for that day and evening had been the greatest from the beginning of the sale of tickets. There seemed from the programme to be no especially good reason for this, unless it was that the contest of the day and evening were the showy ones.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20. -- The American Tobacco Company, commonly known as the Tobacco Trust, has incurred the ill will of a large number of retail dealers in St. Louis by advancing the price of cigarettes and making promises that are misleading.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 20. -- Rabbi Samuel Sale of Temple Shaar Emeth recently preached a sermon in which he argued that there should be one universal day of rest. He said, among other things:

The Palestine Bazaar, which had made the Carnegie Music Hall, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, a place of rare attractions for four days, came to an end last night. As a result of the fair the Louis Down-Town Sabbath and Daily Schools will be about $10,000 richer. That was the conclusion reached by the committeemen when they set themselves to the task of figuring up the receipts last night.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- Two candidates for Speaker were hero on Friday, George H. Bush of Ulster and John Connelley of New-York. Bush was accompanied by his chief of staff, Percival Farquhar, member of Assembly from the Third New-York District. They registered at one of the leading hotels. Connelley came up between trains.

Nearly everybody has heard Francis Wilson's song about the omniscient ostrich that knew it all. Well, Brooklyn has the original, the Great American Ostrich. It is a peculiarly youthful-looking bird, long and angular in its physical development, with a small, octagonal-shaped head. It has a temporary nest under several of the eaves of the City Hall, but it spends very little of its time there.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The few students who remained in college to-day received with great enthusiasm the reports from the Yale-Harvard game. Though McClung's three-minute touch-down was a reminder of last Thanksgiving, still the sympathy of the college at large was with Yale, and cheers for Yale were frequently heard upon the campus during the afternoon.

The annual Fall games of the Twenty-second Regiment Athletic Association were held last evening at the armory. Sixty-seventh Street and the Boulevard. The different events were well contested, and those who took part in them were rewarded by applause from a host of friends who crowded the galleries and comfortably filled all the space on the main floor not needed for the athletes.

An accident occurred in Brooklyn at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by which four men lost their lives and four more came near sharing their fate. It happened at the Intersection of Liberty Avenue and Hill Street, where the Brooklyn City Water Works Company is excavating for a big pipe that is to extend from Fish Creek to the works of the company.

In reference to the published report that the National Cordage Company had purchased the binding-twine plant of William Deering Co. of Chicago, an officer of the cordage company, who was seen by a TIMES reporter at the company's offices, 132 Front Street, yesterday, said:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The remains of Daniel Van Yenling, a former Pennsylvanian, passed through Pittsburg this morning en route to Clarion, Penn., in charge of his brother. Yengling was Superintendent of the Gugenheim Mining Company, at Monterey City, Mexico, and was murdered last Friday by three discharged Mexican employes.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- The City Council at its last meeting passed two ordinances, one granting exclusive privileges to the Louisiana Electric Light Company and the other to the Municipal Ice Company. Both corporations are mainly owned by Mr. Maurice Hart. Mayor Shakespeare promptly vetoed the ordinances, causing considerable comment on 'Change. In an interview on the subject the Mayor spoke with great freedom. He said:

It is very much to be hoped that Congress will, at its coming session, take up seriously the question of the reorganization and improvement of the Postal Service. The need is very pressing, and the conditions are favorable, more so, in some respects, than they are likely to be again in some time.

The show which has prevailed among us during the past week seems to have been about equally one of feminine as of equine beauties. The person who has staid at home and merely read the reports must have discovered this. In one paragraph the glossy coat of some four-footed thoroughbred was commented upon and in the next the handsome toilet of Mrs. Societe was described.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The "Sarah Hale Donation" of South Coventry, founded in 1803 for the promotion of Christian knowledge, is one of the oldest Church funds in the State It has been brought to public attention during the week by the election of Andrew Kingsbury of North Coventry as one of the Trustees, succeeding the late Chauncey Howard of this city, who was a blood relative of Nathan Hale, the Revolutionary spy.

A project talked about for the last twenty years has reached the stage of committee. Fifteen gentlemen have been appointed by the New-York Historical Society to devise means for the erection of a new building to contain the books, manuscripts, paintings and antiquities now inadequately housed on Second Avenue.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- Gen. J.B. Gordon, commanding the United Confederate Veterans, to-day promulgated the following:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 21. -- For the first time this season the naval cadets met with a defeat at football this afternoon. The victors were the Lafayettes of Easton, Penn., who claimed to have done the work with five substitutes on their team.

There has been some discussion about the possible action of the State Board of Canvassers in declaring candidates for the Senate to have been elected who do not appear on the face of the returns to have had the greatest number of votes. The duties of the State board, like those of county boards, are purely ministerial.

It has looked like a bull market the past two days. There was not much doing the early part of the week, and a further dip in Delaware and Hudson with a drop in the Richmond Terminal securities contributed to make the general list flat. But a slowly improving tone manifested itself, and when New-York Central began to rise on large buying, it started the whole market.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Under the act passed by the last Legislature, chartering the new Cape Cod Canal Corporation, it was provided that all the rights guaranteed thereunder "shall cease to exist unless within ninety days after the passage of this act the Boston, Cape Cod, and New-York Canal Company shall deposit with the Treasury of the Commonwealth $500,000 or United States bonds of the par value of $500,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Recent dispatches from this city have not fully represented the attitude of the Democratic Party in New-England in the contest for the Speakership of the National House of Representatives. An effort has been made to give Mr. Crisp of Georgia a preponderance of the public sentiment in the East, as against Mr. Mills of Texas. This is not only unfair but untrue.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- All along the iron rails that form the radiating spokes from the Hub the temperance women are speeding away. The great world's convention is over, and in the person of hundreds of its delegates, reform principles, fanned to new ardor, are heading for the ends of the earth. The cold-water fountain, with its innumerable outlets, is prepared to play as never before.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Nov. 21. -- The extension department of Rutgers has prepared a circular to be sent throughout the State. It is proposed to have a full course of twelve weekly lectures and half courses will be delivered when the full course is not desired. The lectures are designed to be instructive and educational, but not so technical as to be uninteresting to the general public.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The papers of this city tonight, on apparently good grounds, associate the Russian ukase prohibiting the export of wheat and wheat products with the failure of the overtures of M. Vishnegradsky, the Russian Finance Minister, to Berlin financiers, to reopen the German market to the Russian loans.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The opera season at the Auditorium continues to be successful from the artistic as well as the financial standpoint. Some of the singers new to the country have improved on the impressions made by their first appearance last week. Others who promised much have failed in some respects to come up to expectations. Marie Van Zandt has shown herself to be another unfortunate victim of excessively good advertising.

I have noticed with pleasure that THE TIMES has as usual endeavored to expose the efforts to hoodwink the public that have been so strenuously made of late by the statements to the effect that the Bell Telephone Company has practically secured a monopolistic control of the telephone business for the next seventeen years by the issue of the Berliner patent.

NEW-ORLEAN'S, Nov. 21. -- This city is enjoying a sound market and a prosperous condition of finances this Fall. The cotton, sugar, and molasses product has been larger than expected, and the grain export large and continuous. The past week shows the largest week's movement in cotton on record, being 124,540 bales, representing $5,000,000.

The time is at hand when people disposed to be charitable begin packing barrels and bundles to go to different "missions" and "institutions." I have for many years been interested in such work, and have gained much experience and insight into its workings and results, and will now ask the aid of your valuable paper in making room for an appeal I wish to make to the people at large.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The Lehigh football team will not take its customary trip this Thanksgiving, but will go to New-York and watch the Yale-Princeton game instead. The day before Thanksgiving it will play Lafayette in Wilkesbarro for the second place in the championship of Pennsylvania.

ANDREA FERARA SWORDS. -- If one were to judge by the number of these blades still extant in a limited area, the great Venetian swordsmith must have done a very large export business. This thought occurred to me during the Glasgow Exhibition of 1888, where there were at least forty swords exhibited, all marked with the name of "Andrea Ferara."

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- The Journal in its latest edition has dispatches from Washington which say that Senator Chandler called at the Treasury Department to-day and made a request in the matter of the Maverick Bank. Secretary Foster was not there. He went directly to Controller Lacey, saying that he came simply as a private citizen, and not in his Senatorial capacity.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Next Sunday, Nov. 29, will be devoted in this quaint old New-Jersey town to a celebration of the centenary of the Springfield Presbyterian Church. It will not be the centenary of the church society which was organized 145 years ago, but of the present house of worship.

It seems pretty severe to charge our fathers and mothers, the latter in particular, with having looked like guys only as long ago as the war of the rebellion. To see them now, dressed becomingly and fully conversant with the canons of good taste, it does not seem possible that they once went about arrayed in garments the style of which would subject the wearer to ridicule nowadays.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 21. -- Much to the regret of the best people here, the quarrel between Editors Seviere of the Evening Telegram and Harrison of the Daily Standard has been revived, and the prospects are that there will be a hostile encounter, if words can provoke one.
A fire yesterday morning in the tenement house 39 Baxter Street, which extended to 37, created a panic, and actually caused the death of one woman.

-- Almost the first thing which strikes a foreigner in talking to Englishmen, even of the best class, is the scarcely-veiled contempt with which they all speak of book learning. I was astonished once to find that a gentleman who had been mentioned with unfeigned respect as "a good man all round," was not of a high order of intelligence.

The overwhelming defeat of Gleason and his gang in the recent Long Island City election is looked on by the people as marking the beginning of another epoch in the city's history. Sixty-four out of sixty-five of the people's candidates were elected. Gleason and Gleasonism had brought disgrace upon the city and its finances were at such a low ebb that its coffers were practically empty.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana," which is being produced at Signor Lago's Shaftesbury Theatre, has proved to be as great a success in London as in the many other cities in which that short, but delightful, opera has been sung. There is no doubt that the attractiveness of the opera has been enhanced by the excellent rendering of Mascagni's music by the Shaftesbury orchestra, which is under the direction of Signor Arditi.

The Rapid-Transit Commission had received up to the close of business at noon yesterday the consent of over fifty property owners to the construction of the proposed road. Some of them are for large and valuable properties.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- It is reported in Democratic circles here that Lieut. Gov. Jones while here Wednesday and Thursday of this week approached three State officials and other prominent Democrats on the subject of the resignation of Gov. Hill.

VIENNA, Oct. 21. -- If Prince Liechtenstein and Counts Harrach and Czernin have private collections of old masters containing pictures of fabulous value, others in Vienna collect the modern masters. Herr Gustav Freiherr von Springer is a well-to-do, not to say a wealthy, citizen, whose dwelling is one of the sights of the town, and is divided into the suites appropriated to his own use and portions devoted to business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Representatives Mills, McMillin, and Crisp returned from New-York to-day and, with Bynum and Springer, have resumed the contest for the Speakership in the Capitol. Mr. Mills is gratified with the result of his visit. Mr. Crisp is said to have received assurances that Representative Cummings has settled the Speakership contest in his favor. Mr. McMillin is buoyant with hopes of success.
" It seems to me that if I had one dozen trimmed with really good lace, and another with tiny little tucks and cambric frills, that would be almost enough," said Millicent Earle.

The earnestness of Secretary of the Navy Tracy's reform policy in navy yards has been actually tested during the past four weeks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. In the course of four weeks a State election has been conducted under heated partisan efforts, followed closely by exigencies calling forth activity in the fitting out of war ships seldom seen here since the close of the last war.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21. -- Cardinal Gibbons has arranged for a solemn mass of requiem to be celebrated in the cathedral on Monday next, for the repose of the soul of William J. Florence. The family of Mr. Patrick Riley and other friends of the dead actor called upon his Eminence, and he promptly complied with their request for the mass of requiem.

HARTFORD, Nov. 21. -- The hearing in the quowarranto proceedings, involving the right of Judge Morris of New-Haven to the Governorship of the State, will begin before the Supreme Court in this city Monday. The preliminaries have been arranged between counsel, and it is understood there will be no delay in arguing the case.

The Smith College Glee Club will visit this city in the Thanksgiving recess and give two concerts. One will take place Friday evening and the second Saturday morning at 11. Both will be given in the Mendelssohn Assembly Rooms, 108 West Fifty-fifth Street. Tickets may now be obtained at Brentano's. Several well-known artists will assist the young women from Smith College.

The managers of that charity know as "Happy Days for the Little Mothers" desire that the little mothers may have a happy day at this, the Thanksgiving season. On Saturday, therefore, an entertainment will be given to a number of these little ones. There will be music and recitations, and last and best of all, an abundance of ice cream and cake.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 21. -- Now that the political campaign is over, there is another contest in progress in Cowley County that bids fair to have a more bitter ending than did the one just closed. This contest grows out of the prohibitory law, which has been only reasonably well enforced, although probably as well as in any of the other counties on the south line of the State.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- What with Russia on the one hand and the rioting South American States on the other, the gentlemen of Western Europe who are addicted to finance may well believe themselves deserted by the gods. Nothing very definite has happened this week, but, all the same, its close sees things worse than its beginning.

The Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York met last night at the college to consider the report of the committee appointed some time ago to look into the progress of the college. The report was an able and concise statement of the needs of the college. It also contained some suggestions as to the future course of the institution.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Some additional interest has lately been given to the observation of total eclipses of the moon by the suggestion of certain observations for which such occasions are particularly advantageous. The occurrence of a total lunar eclipse Jan. 28, 1888, afforded an opportunity for attempting observations of the kind above mentioned at the observatory of Harvard University.

Preparations are going on rapidly for the food exposition to be held in the Lenox Lyceum from March 2 to April 5 next by the Retail Grocers' Union. Several days ago circulars were issued to food producers, manufacturers, and to others interested in the various ramifications of the grocery trade, and they have elicited already enough responses to make the success of the undertaking certain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21. -- An officer of the cruiser San Francisco, speaking of the operations preceding the capture of Valparaiso, said: "The number of men engaged in operations are variously stated at from ten to thirty thousand on each side. The truth is that the Congressionalists had about ten thousand and Balmaceda twice that number, besides between eight and ten thousand more within six or eight hours' call.

CHICAGO, NOV. 21. -- Chicago business men will soon be brought into closer connection with Eastern correspondents. Capt. James E. White, General Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service, who was formerly Superintendent of this division, said yesterday that by the beginning of the new year a fast mail train would be put on the Pennsylvania Railroad from Chicago to New-York.

Yesterday saw the conclusion of the sale of the Verestchagin collection. The striking paintings, bric-a-brac, religious emblems, artistic jewelers' work, beautiful embroidery, weapons from India. Turkestan, the Caucasus, and other parts of Russia and Turkey, and handsome rugs of all sizes and patterns will be distributed probably over the length and breadth of the land, and after Tuesday not a single article of this famous collection will remain at the American Art Galleries.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 21. -- The announcement of the agreement between the representatives of the State and the Olcott Committee on an equitable plan for the settlement of Virginia's debt is received with rejoicing throughout the State. For twenty years Virginia's finances have been subject of more or less controversy. Since 1877 the debt has been a source of almost constant agitation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- It has been announced that the experiment which was tried last year in reference to the method of the senior oratorical contest, familiarly known as chapel stage speaking, will be repeated this year, and will be put on a permanent basis.

Mr. Brewster's career, as here laid bare, is an inspiring one. He was a lawyer, man of letters, politician, and Cabinet officer in his time, and to these honors he rose by the force of native talent that had been repressed by peculiar obstacles. Mr. Brewster was descended from the well-known colonial New-England family, and early entered upon a life of hardship quite worthy of the early history of his ancestral line.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Following close on the annual round-up of voters in this part of the State comes the annual round-up of the turkeys, geese, and ducks that the farmers' wives and daughters were busy fattening while their husbands and fathers talked politics.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- A memorial address for the late Dr. Joseph Leidy, the famous anatomist, was delivered this week before the alumni and students of the university by Dr. William Hunt of the Board of Trustees.

The last election, so far as this city is concerned, showed two things that will occupy the attention of the politicians for some time. The first is that the Republican machine in this city is badly in need of an overhauling, and the second is that there are more weak spots in Tammany Hall than any one who does not follow politics closely had supposed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Philadelphia has been well represented among the prize winners at the New-York Horse Show the past week. A.J. Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad sent superb stock to the metropolis, and the Wideners of the Traction Company were well represented. Mr. P.A.B. Widener, by the bye, has a stable at Ogontz, near the city, that in fittings and furnishings is said to outrank anything of the kind in the country.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The big and historic Bastable Block, one of the oldest in Syracuse, was burned early this morning, together with the Dime Museum and the Standard Theatre, at which the Fay-Foster Burlesque Company were filling an engagement.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 21. -- Grouse Creek Road, in Cowley County, has attained a somewhat unenviable reputation in the last few years. To the ghost hunter it should form a rich field.

Three thousand gallons of water were wasted and nearly $6,000 damage was done yesterday by the blowing out of a plug in the automatic sprinkler system on the sixth floor of the building facing Harry Howard Square, and fronting on both Walker and Canal Streets. The building, which is owned by Oxley, Giddings Enos, manufacturers of gas fixtures, is seven stories high, and is occupied by the owners and several other manufacturing firms.

Amateur photographers of this country are fast approaching a high standard in picture taking and picture making. Every Winter better work is turned out than in the previous season. The road for improvement seems broad and extensive, and suggestions of improvement in little things are constantly presenting themselves to the picture men.

The society record of the past week may be best summed up by saying that it comprised the horse show and nothing besides. Not alone did the gay world of the metropolis pour itself into the Madison Square Garden every day and evening of the week, but its ranks were augmented by detachments from the society worlds of Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Chicago, and by equally large contingents from the suburbs.

In New-York's shopping quarter there is nothing quite so characteristic of the city as the jewelry windows. Their glitter and show, the money represented, and perhaps also the hard, cold, unsympathetic nature of the gems which orm so conspicuous a part of their contents, are fit exponents of the city's life.

The final boxing and wrestling contests in the tournament of the Long Island Amateur Athletic League were held last evening in the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn. As on the first occasion, the attendance was large and the sport good.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 21. -- Owing to the late strike of the Chaudiere Mills hands and the cessation of all sawing operations for a month the log booms on the Ottawa River are much larger than usual, and there is considerable anxiety as to the possibility of their being swept away when the Spring freshets begin and the ice-shove takes place.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- This city was stirred last week as it never has been before in the same way by an extraordinary entertainment given at the new Hospital Building, at Market Street and Madison Avenue. The building is not quite completed, and to take advantage of the opportunity it presented for giving an entertainment, and at the same time get the public to become better acquainted with the building, this project was planned.

LAKEWOOD, N.J. Nov. 21. -- Great preparations have been made by Mr. Fred Sterry, manager of the Lakewood Hotel, for the first grand hop, which will be given there on the evening of the 28th inst. More than one thousand in vitations have been sent out, and the affair promises to equal, if not excel, the magnificent entertainments of that kind given by Lakewood Hotel Company last season.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 21. -- A great many cottages may be opened here within a few weeks if the water famine in New-York should assume alarming proportions. Some of the cottagers have kept their cottages open that they may return to them at any time. Lenox has an abundant supply of very pure water.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Nov. 21. -- After purchasing about 2,000 acres of iron lands in Minnesota, a deal for a great iron tract north of the international boundary in Keewatin, in which Leopold, King of the Belgians, is a party, has fallen through.

-- Any carefulstudy of the way in which Von Moltke, during a long and anxious period, maintained a firm grip upon the French capital and manoeuvred subordinate armies over a great part of France, serves to reveal his sterling qualities as a director of war. Throughout this period he retained a complete hold of the entire situation.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 21. -- The Lyceum of Natural History held its first regular meeting Thursday evening in the biological laboratory. Papers were read by McKean, '92, and Redfield, '93.

The Bureau of Education at Washington has issued a circular of information upon sanitary conditions for schoolhouses, by Dr. Albert P. Marble, Superintendent of the public schools of Worcester, Mass., and during the last year President of the National Education Association of the United States. Dr. Marble has made a study of the problems of ventilation, heating, lighting, draining, and schoolhouse construction.

The horse show that closed last night has undoubtedly been the most successful popular amusement that has ever been offered in this city. The attendance has been at least 80,000, which is probably a considerable understatement. Even so, it is quite unprecedented. When the baseball craze was at its height, there was never anything approaching an average attendance at the games of 13,000 people every day for a week.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- To comprehend Russia one must have seen Moscow. Viewed solely as a spectacle, I should think there is nothing else in the world more remarkable. Considered as the key to the strange, baffling enigma of the retrogressive Tartar Empire in Europe, it furnishes the most fascinating and enthralling of studies. Frankly, Moscow ought to have a book by itself.

There is no name, except Washington's, that is more familiar to Americans in connection with the Revolution than Patrick Henry's. He is known to us all as the orator of that great struggle -- great in its consequences, if not in its actual proportions -and no other has given to the memory of his countrymen phrases so intimately associated with independence.

In a communication from the administration of the New-York Life Insurance Company in this place to the Sonn- und Montags-Zeitung it is claimed that the alleged uneasiness among the insured of the New-York has not found the least expression, although the opponents of the company are sparing no efforts to engender this uneasiness.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 22. -- The administration of the Northern Ohio Asylum for the Insane, under Superintendent Eyeman, promises to be noteworthy for the valuable reforms begun. The civil service system adopted is already showing good results.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 22. -- Since the publication in THE TIMES of Nov. 16 of the NewYork Life Insurance Company's transactions in this city under President Beers and the Dinkelspiels, almost every policy holder in town has evidenced an extreme desire to have his contract examined by an expert in order to ascertain the extent to which he has been swindled.

M.D. Corate of 507 Columbus Avenue was knocked down and trampled upon at Eighty-fifth Street, corner of Columbus Avenue, last evening by a horse that he was driving and which he had left standing. Dr. Thurman of 101 West Eighty-sixth Street found that he had a fracture of the collar bone and a lacerated scalp. He was, however, able to gohome.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- There has been more commotion in the Republican Party of this State since the election of Gov. Russell in 1890 than in the twenty years of its history previous to that time. Having failed so disastrously at the last election with a new and young candidate, the party is rather inclined to turn its attention again to the veterans of official and party service than to undertake any experiments, however promising.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Nov. 22. -- One of Dubuque's fairest young women is missing. She is Mrs. Cora Duncan, wife of Melvin G. Duncan, General Secretary of the World's Accident Insurance Association of Dubuque. Mrs. Duncan's elaborate wardrobe and jewelry, and John D. Bush, the wealthy son of Dubuque's dead millionaire Mayor, are also missing.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- Last Wednesday morning Cheney Kilburn, President of the Hale Kilburn Manufacturing Company, the largest makers of fine furniture in this city, sitting in his office in consultation with a business man, was startled by a resounding thump on his desk, and turned to see reposing there a fist in which was an enormous card.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Discount was in fair demand during the past week at 3 for three months and 2 1/2 for short. The gold movements during the week were unimportant. The rate of American exchange remains rather above a point warranting gold remittances from here. The prospect of a demand for the Continent also lessens as the depression on the foreign Bourses abates.

We see no good reason why New-York should join in the competition of the cities that seek the glory of having the Republican National Convention of 1892 held within their gates. It is difficult to see what would be gained by the city, the party, or any aspirant for the Presidential nomination from having that assembly here.

Mr. TRACY, the Secretary of the Navy, is doing a great deal for the cause of honest and decent politics and for the firm establishment of republican institutions in the United States. His steady and practical application of business principles to public business in the navy yards accords with his quiet obstinacy in disregarding the spoilsmen of his party.

Although the Shanghai correspondent of a London newspaper recently made the startling discovery that the ordering of the Charleston from China to Honolulu was only a preliminary to the seizure of the Sandwich Islands by the United States, it is doubtful whether that vessel will do much more than make the customary pause there for coaling and a general observation of affairs.

At 2:40 yesterday afternoon, when the Brooklyn Bridge was crowded with its usual throng of Sunday pedestrians, a man climbed to the top of the rail skirting the very highest point of the south roadway and stood there in a dramatic attitude, as though to command attention.

The Berliner telephone patent was granted upon the urgent recommendation of Examiner GUSTAVE BISSING. We have published that part of his letter of Oct. 29 to the Commissioner of Patents in which he says: "It is, in my opinion, of the highest importance that the term of the patent granted on this application should begin to run at the earliest possible moment."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Chief L.G. Shepard of the Revenue Marine Division of the Treasury Department has submitted to Secretary Foster his annual report of the work performed by the service during the past year and its condition. He says, in part:
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 22. -- The News and Courier to-morrow, apropos of the Speakership contest, will say:

The Church congress held last week at Washington was the most successful that has been held in several years. The great distances which separate men of the same faith from one another prevent the massing of great numbers at places where the congress is held, and this makes an American quite different from an English congress.

Yesterday, from early morning till late at night, there were many visitors to the bier of the actor, William J. Florence, in Parlor 15, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. At 10:30 o'clock at night the order was given that no more visitors were to be admitted, and after the family had gathered in the room to take a last farewell look the coffin was closed.

Prof. Charles A. Briggs lectured last evening in the Church of the Covenant, Thirty-fifth Street and Park Avenue, his subject being, "The Bible and the Church." The church was crowded. Chairs had to be placed in all the aisles in order to accommodate the throng, and many were compelled to stand. Prof. Briggs was listened to with the closest attention throughout the discourse.

Since the disaster Saturday at the trench dug by the Brooklyn Water Works Company for its new main, at Liberty Avenue and Hill Street, Brooklyn, the scene has been one of the busiest. Not for an hour has the work of digging been suspended. That four lives have been sacrificed is beyond doubt; that there have not been more than four lost is still a matter of uncertainty.

Our Washington dispatches this morning give an account of one of the devices resorted to by Mr. GORMAN to bring about the defeat of Mr. MILLS as a candidate for the Speakership nomination. It amounts to a mere "deal" in the patronage of the House of a kind for which Mr. MILLS has expressed his practical and determined aversion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22. -- The now famous San Francisco Grand Jury which has driven Boss Buckley and other boodlers to Canada, and which has already indicted three State legislators, will meet again Tuesday.

Allusion has heretofore been made in THE TIMES to certain alterations made necessary aboard the new United States cruiser Philadelphia to insure the stability of that vessel. The various incidents connected with the recent raising of the Philadelphia's meta-centric height were duly mentioned, and it was commonly supposed when the cruiser sailed a few days ago for St. Thomas, West Indies, that she was in a perfectly stable condition.
Got any good butter?" asked the woman.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 22. -- This city is now in the midst of an exciting local political campaign, the chief bone of contention being the Mayoralty. The election is only ten days off, and both parties will put forth unusual efforts during the coming week. It is a peculiar campaign, both candidates being likely to suffer from defections from their respective parties.

Commissioner Peck of the Bureau of Statistics of Labor of New-York, in his eighth annual report, treats very exhaustively of all the questions which have interested workingmen and employers during the past year. Of some of the changes he says, in a summary of his report:
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22. -- The Picayune's Havana special, via Key West, Nov. 21, says:

The presumed object of the "Bureau of Statistics of Labor" of this State is to collect, classify, and arrange statistics and facts relating to the condition and interests of labor, and to deduce from them such conclusions as may be of value. The report of the bureau, in order to be useful, should be a clear and concise statement of facts and a dispassionate elucidation of their significance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Happily for the Democratic Party, and unfortunately for Mr. Crisp as the candidate for Speaker of a faction of that party, the ulterior purpose of the advocacy of Mr. Crisp's election has been made known early enough to make it impossible for any Democrat to plead ignorance if he should ever be taxed with having made a serious blunder in voting for him.

Mr. and Mrs. A.S. Herman celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage last evening at their residence, 246 East Sixty-eighth Street, with a dinner to their nine children, thirteen grandchildren, and two representatives of the fourth generation. Later in the evening Mr. and Mrs. Herman received the congratulations of three or four hundred friends, with a number of very valuable presents.

Comments on Mr. FOSTER'S Chamber of Commerce speech continue to come from all parts of the country. It probably surprises Mr. FOSTER himself to find that the least favorable are still from the West. Apart from the journals of his own loyal State, where nothing that an Ohio man in office can say will excite criticism, the Western papers are almost uniformly very hard on the Secretary.

The failure of the Mayor to reappoint Mr. W.N. WILMER, as an Inspector of Schools in the Fifth District is likely to direct more attention to the crusade which that gentleman had been making against saloons and houses of ill repute in close proximity to schoolhouses than it would have received if he had been continued in office.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23. -- The State of Ohio has been foremost in many reforms in the management of State charities and benevolences and in the care of dependent and depraved classes, but the founding of a State asylum for epileptics and the epileptic insane, the cornerstone of which was laid at Gallipolis a week ago, is doubtless the most notable departure from precedents Ohio has ever made.

Years ago a policy bolder of the New-York Life Insurance Company applied at its office for a loan on real estate, He was referred to Samuel Cooper, formerly a real estate agent in this city. Mr. Cooper for some fifteen or twenty years was the "middleman" through whom intending borrowers had to approach the company.

TOPEKA. Kan. Nov. 23 -- The annual report of the Kansas City. Fort Scott and Memphis Road, made to the State Board of Railroad Commisioners, shows total earnings from oporation of $4.709,191; operating expenses, $3.227.289; income from operation, $1,475.852. The deduction for interest, taxes, and miscellaneous expenses amounted to $1.21B,971, leaving a net income of $256,880, from which a dividend of 2% per cent. on preferred stock was declared.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Speakership contest begins to settle itself, as the friends of Mr. Mills might have expected when the effect of the possible election of Mr. Crisp began to be understood, through the publication of the means by which it was to be secured by German and the protectionist, allies who have come to Mr. Crisp's assistance.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 23. -- On Wednesday last Mr. Theodore Vail and his sister, Miss Daisy Vail, came to Richmond from their home in New-York to act as groomsman and bridesmaid on the occasion of the marriage of Mr. Henry Rohmer and Miss Pinkie Lyons.

It seems that Signor CRISPI'S declaration in favor of the neutralization of Alsace and Lorraine is esteemed in Europe to have brought that suggestion within the sphere of practical politics. It will be remembered that in adopting it, he coupled it with a condition that, upon the neutralization of those provinces, France should join the Triple Alliance.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Gov. Hill fired a bomb into the Onondaga political camp to-night when a special messenger arrived in town from Albany and served important papers on George G. Cotton, the Republican County Clerk and Clerk of the Board of Canvassers. The Canvassing Board was in session at 5 o'clock, when the messenger sought out Mr. Cotton and served this paper on him:

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Of the 40,000 and more miners in the Pas de Calais coal fields there are to-day only 100 at work. The condition of affairs is hourly becoming more alarming. With the remembrance of the bloodshed which resulted from the Fourmies coal miners' disturbances, the military authorities display a little hesitation in dealing with the disorderly strikers, and the result is that the strikers are becoming more dangerous.

The funeral services of the actor William Jermyn Florence were conducted yesterday morning at St. Agnes's Church, on East Forty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue. The chancel of the church was filled with floral offerings, and a large company was present, in which were included many of the leading members of the theatrical profession in this city.

That the Democratic members of the House of Representatives from New-England should be strongly attracted by the great services of Mr. MILLS in the cause of tariff reform is natural, and it is natural that this confidence in and admiration for him on that account should make him their choice as Speaker of the House, where he could do so much for the cause that is so dear to them.

Henry Cranston, the popular landlord of the New-York Hotel, is apparently in a financial condition not the most pleasing to him and his numerous friends. Judgments have been entered against him, and the receiver of the New-York Hotel property. The New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, which represents the various owners, has obtained from the Supreme Court leave to sue him to foreclose a mortgage on the furniture and effects in the hotel.

Commissioner Gilroy came out yesterday with a denial of the statement made in one of the city papers last Saturday that officers of his Department had wasted 25,600,000,000 gallons of water since June 13. Mr. Gilroy says that the statements are attributable to ignorance or malicious perversion, and he proceeds to deny it in detail by a comparison of the rainfall and the storage capacity of the reservoirs.

Among the many objections to the paster ballot which experience has revealed is that of affording facility for evasion of that provision of the law which forbids the marking of ballots so that they may be identified. The ballot law says: "No voter shall place any mark upon his ballot by means of which it can be identified as the one voted by him."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- There was much excitement in the Board of Canvassers of Dutchess County this afternoon. The committee appointed last week to make a tabulated statement of the returns in the hands of the board had placed their statement in the hands of E. Wright Vail, the Democratic leader.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- The Cecilia Musical Organization is bringing forward an innovation in the concert line this Winter. In past years there has been one thing that has deterred many people from attending the Cecilia's admirable concerts, and that has been the price of admission. At all times their concerts have been crowded with the best musical people of Boston, but the Cecilias are not satisfied with this.

Washington, Nov. 23- The annual engagedment of De Wolf Hopper and his company in Washington began to-night at the new National Theatre. The theatre was ceowded on every floor, while hundreds were content to stand during the evening.Among Hopper's auditors were 150 members of the Columbia Athletic Club, besides many persons of prominence.

St. PETERSBURG, Nov. 28. -- There are at present twenty-four grain ships at Odessa loading with wheat, whose cargoes are not yet completed. The authorities have given permission for these ships to continue their loading until their cargoes are completed despite the fact that the ukase prohibiting the export of wheat from Russia goes into effect to-day, and have instructed the officials at that port to clear the vessels as usual when they are loaded.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 23. -- Gov. Hovey's condition is critical., He is sinking rapidly and his friends have almost given up hope.

A trefoil and triplicate of talents appeared yesterday at Amberg's Theatre; it was red-letter night there before the first strains of the operatic afterpiece, the "Cavalleria Rusticana," were heard. The several leaves of the Dreiblatt were Matkowsky, Kaintz, and Eggeling in Goethe's "Clavigo."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Notwithstanding the severe rainstorm which prevailed here to-day and the three inches of water which covered the university field, the university football eleven played their regular practice game against the reserve eleven. The reserves were greatly strengthened by the brilliant work of Small and Bergen, the latter being first half back substitute on the Varsity team.

A special dispatch to THE TIMES from Halifax, N.S., yesterday said: "Eighteen years ago the Nova Scotia Legislature granted a charter to build a railroad across this Province from Lunenburg, seventy miles to the Bay of Fundy Mortgage bonds were issued to the extent of $1,000,000 on the security of the roadbed, bearing interest at 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- A tremendous wind and rain storm, amounting almost to a hurricane, passed over this city about 12:30 P.M. to-day, doing a great deal of damage.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 23. -- One of the most interesting and amusing features of the present fight between the Sherman and Foraker influences in this State is the attitude of the press. Geographically it appears to be the solid northern, eastern, and central portions of Ohio against the southern, southwestern, and extreme western sections.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Three women and a boy were burned to death between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning in a fire which gutted the Old Homestead Hotel, at Third and Pine Streets. They were Mrs. Buchanan, pastry cook aged fifty; her son, aged seven; Mrs. Carrie Marsh, dishwasher, and Maggie Wilson, aged nineteen, waitress.

WILMINGTON, Del, Nov. 23. -- The pillory in use in this State is of effective but primitive construction. It is combined with the whipping post, a long plank extending through the upper part of the post. There are orifices in which the culprit's neck and wrists are securely fastened while he stands upon a platform. The position is an exceedingly painful one.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 23. -- Advices dated Yokohama Nov. 9 state that a severe and prolonged shock of earthquake occurred on Oct. 28, a few minutes before 7 o'clock in the morning. It was the severest earthquake shock experienced since the terrible catastrophe of 1855, and must be ranked as a national calamity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Republican National Committee heard to-day the of pleas of all the cities which desired to entertain the National Convention and then selected Minneapolis as the place in which to hold it and named June 7 as the time.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- The great football game of Saturday has been the chief subject of conversation about college to-day, and the keenest disappointment is shown by almost every student. Yale's magnificent exhibition is unstintedly praised, and it is unanimously conceded that she far outplayed Harvard at every point.

Whatever political considerations there may have been in the selection of Minneapolis as the place of holding the Republican National Convention, the choice is not likely to conduce to the comfort of the convention. The hotel accommodation of the town is as good, very likely, as of any town of the same size, and is quite adequate to the ordinary needs of the place.

RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 23. -- A deputation of naval officers waited on Gen. da Fonseca to-day and stated that his acts as Dictator had created profound dissatisfaction among the people of the country, and that if he refused to accede to the popular request for his resignation they would not be answerable for the consequences.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Experience at the late election in some parts of the State demonstrates that the present ballot law is not a perfect safeguard against the buying of votes by unscrupulous politicians. The law prohibits under what were supposed to be effective penalties the affixing of any mark to the ballot by which it may afterward be identified.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- The Wesleyan football players were out this afternoon and played their last practice game before meeting the University of Pennsylvania in New-York on Wednesday. The work this afternoon was the best that the team has done this year, and the college feels greatly encouraged. The Pennsylvanians have a very strong team, and expect, according to their own boasts, to defeat Wesleyan by a score of 40 to 0.
