Informal conferences among members of the Citizens' Committee who are managing the anti-grab movement led to a determination yesterday to call a meeting of the Executive Committee for the Friday afternoon preceding the next meeting of the Park Commissioner. All the members of the committee are of one mind in relation to the importance of obtaining from the Park Commissioners a definite answer to their petition without further delay.

The transmission of power from Niagara Falls to Chicago by electricity has been proposed in connection with the World's Fair. This is a project well worth the serious consideration of the World's Fair committees, for the carrying of force to a distance by means of the power contained in the cataracts of Niagara has ceased to be regarded as chimerical.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Mr. Wermuth, the Imperial Commissioner to the World's Columbian Exposition, has filed an exhaustive report with the German Government concerning his visit to the United States and the observations he and his colleagues made during their stay in Cyicago. Mr. Wermuth acknowledges the cordial treatment he received in official and private circles and the accommodating spirit shown to him by everybody with whom he came in contact.

In your issue of to-day appears a letter from ex-Attorney General Augustus Schoonmaker, in which he makes several statements regarding the Ulster County Savings Institution which are calculated to mislead, and several others regarding the Kingston Freeman to which I must take exception.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 23. -- The Republican State Central Committee has been called to meet in this city on Friday evening next, for the purpose, it is said, of devising means to prevent Senator Brice from taking his seat.

Two subjects of live public interest were considered at the adjourned annual meeting of the New-York County Medical Society in the Academy of Medicine last night. One was a report on the sanitary condition of primary schools in this city, which was submitted by Dr. Henry E. Chapin of the Committee on Hygiene and Chairman of the section on public health.

BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- At the adjourned meeting of the Boston Chamber of Commerce to-day resolutions were adopted protesting against the discrimination which makes Boston pay 5 cents more on a hundred pounds for freight from Chicago than New-York or Portland, and denying the statement of J.F. Goddard, Commissioner of Trunk Lines, that this "basis" was satisfactory to the great majority of the Boards of Trade and trade centres.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Sub-Executive Committee of the National Republican League met at the Arlington Hotel this evening. The following members were present: James S. Clarkson, President, and Andrew B. Humphrey, Secretary of the league: R.W. Austin, Alabama; W.A. Hamill, Colorado; J.F. Bacon, Delaware; J.C. Edwards, Illinois; F.D. Jackson, Iowa; E.S. Little, Kansas; William P. Riley, Kentucky; T.E. Byrnes, Minnesota; James A. Blanchard, New-York; Horace M. Deal, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were to-day appointed as follows:

The shareholders of the Erie Railway had reason to feel well pleased with the reports laid before them at their annual meeting yesterday. The figures showed that during last year the amount of traffic reached the highest point known since the railroad was built. The statement was also made that the physical condition of the road was never so good as now.

About 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning a disastrous fire broke out in Ilion, N.Y., and the high wind that prevailed at the time made the local Fire Department unable to cope with the names. As soon as the fire was discovered an alarm was sounded and word was sent to Herkimer, Mohawk, and Utica for help. The losses are as follows: Grimes Pelton, $20,000; insurance, $12,300 on building.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- At to-day's session of the Supreme Court the case of Catherine Seaman, as executrix, , of Cincinnati, against David B. Cooke, B. Thurber Strickland, and Harvey Westcott was called for trial.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The long-talked-of trial of Mgr. Gouthe-Soulard, Archbishop of Aix, began to-day before the members of the First Division of the Court of Appeal Great interest was manifested in the trial not only by all Catholics, but by every one who is interested to see if the position assumed by the Government would be upheld by the courts.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- About 1,000 college students and alumni assembled on the university field this afternoon to see the university football eleven play their last practice game of the season. The eleven played against the Princeton reserves, the latter including all the substitutes of the Varsity team. The reserves had their strongest team, and were allowed two or three extra men in order to give the university team better practice.
PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The Right Hon. Edward Robert Bulwer-Lytton, Earl of Lytton, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., LL.D., British Ambassador to France, died suddenly to-day from heart disease.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 24. -- The remains of Indiana's late Governor, Alvin P. Hovey, who died yesterday, were conveyed to the State Capitol this morning, where they lay in state throughout the day. In the centre of the beautiful rotunda the massive casket rested upon a support draped with flags, and the sombre black decorations of the building were set off with exquisite flowering plants.

One of the most significant items that forms a part of the New-York Life Insurance Company's annual reports for recent years is that of "not taken" policies. Last year the company's report shows that 7,768 policies were not taken, representing a face value of $32,894,164, which is more than $2,000,000 in excess of the "not taken" policies in 1889, and $10,000,000 more than "not taken" policies for 1888.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 24. -- The Rev. James I. Brownson, D.D., pastor of the First Presbyterian Church here, and distinguished as a theologian, will on Thanksgiving Day celebrate his golden jubilee, the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination. He has held his present pastorate forty-three years. The entire Washington Presbytery and about 1,500 persons who have at times been in his parish will attend the celebration.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 24. -- Notwithstanding the unexpected obstacles and difficulties which have occurred in connection with the prosecution during the present year of what has become a permanent as well as an important industry of British Columbia, the actual catch of seals has exceeded very considerably that of 1890, which was looked upon as a good season.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 24. -- An incident remarkable in religious history has just occurred here. The Rev. Dr. William A. Bartlett, pastor of the New-York Avenue Presbyterian Church, and one of the most eminent and progressive theologians in the United States, has been invited by the Rev. Father Mackin, pastor of St. Paul's Chapel, to sit in the Board of Directors of the House of the Good Shepherd.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The movement among the Conservatives, which resulted in a decision by the conference to-day against the Government's continuing to maintain Irish legislation as the principal feature of its policy, has been previously described. The main object of the movement is to apply to England the principles of the Irish Land Purchase act.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- November corn touched 70 cents to-day. The November price last Friday was 52 cents. Up to the close to-day there was still outstanding one short line of a little less than 1,000,000 bushels. During the day there were some negotiations looking to a private settlement. If it was made, the price will probably be back around 50 cents before to-morrow night.

It is frequently said of the public-school system of this city that no satisfactory measure of reform can be expected from the Board of Education until the board itself is reformed and the present Superintendent of Schools is displaced.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 24. -- Gov. Tillman's message to the Legislature this morning is a powerful State paper, cutting and slashing at the old regime of Hampton, Hogood, Civil Service Commissioner Thompson, and Richardson, the Governors of South Carolina since the political revolution of 1876.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The folly of trying to colonize voters in a small city where every citizen is personally known to the election officers was demonstrated in Plainfield to-day. The charter municipal election is to take place next week, Tuesday, and, as this was the last day of registration, the ward heelers of both parties wore very busy getting the lists in shape for the coming battle of the ballots.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Conrad Burger, a farmer living at the foot of Hussey Hill, Ulster County, claims to have found gold-bearing rock on his farm. Specimen rock has been sent to New-York City and pronounced by competent judges to be impregnated with gold. Mr. Burger says that a short time ago he leased that part of this farm on which the rock is found to three men for twenty years.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- As indicated in these dispatches last week, Gov. Hill has determined to steal the Senate, and has set about doing it in the boldest and coolest manner. A highwayman never "stood up" his victim with greater assurance than David B. Hill has the electors of the Fifteenth Senatorial District, which includes the Counties of Columbia, Dutchess, and Putnam.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 24. -- The hearing in the quo warranto case against Gov. Bulkeley was opened in the Supreme Court yesterday. Judge Fenn of the Superior Court was assigned by Chief Justice Andrews to the vacancy on the bench, no objection being raised to that course.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- There has been a general scaling down of the estimates for the next fiscal year in all the bureaus of the Navy Department, and Secretary Tracy evidently does not expect to get very large appropriations from the new Congress. The entire amount asked for by the bureau is $3,529.976.17, under the following heads:

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 24. -- According to the report of the Connecticut Board of Health for October, diphtheria is fast taking the place of consumption and tubercular diseases as a contagious and prevalent malady. The mortality from this disease in the State was double that from typhoid fever. There were only three diseases -- consumption, pneumonia, and infantile diarrhea -- where the death rate was larger.

The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, of which the energetic and popular Dr. Charles L. Thompson is pastor, has broken the ice of conservatism and decided that it will join in the liberal plan of Church work that is so ably illustrated by Dr. Rainsford, in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Parish, and Dr. Greet, in St. Bartholomew's Parish, also of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Talk about election returns is now beginning to turn toward the State Board of Canvassers. That board consists of Secretary of State RICE, Controller WEMPLE, State Treasurer DANFORTH. Attorney General TABOR, and State Engineer and Surveyor BOGART, and it is required to meet at Albany on or before the 15th of December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- "It's a pretty poor fight, I should say," said Mr. Mills to-day, referring to an article in a New-York paper opposing his election, "when a paper that calls itself Democratic attempts to frighten its readers with the Republican bugaboo about free trade."

In speaking of the recent Liberal Congress at Newcastle-on-Tyne, and pointing out that it was, in effect, the American National Convention, we took occasion to point out that the institution was much more necessary for the party in opposition than for the party in power, seeing that the "platform" of the Ministry is their legislation enacted and proposed.

Benjamin Peters Hutchinson, who is called "Old Hutch" by those who do not respect his preferences in the matter of titles, is not to become a member of the Produce Exchange after all. When the Committee on Admission met yesterday afternoon it had before it a letter in which the famous operator withdrew his application for membership.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- All day yesterday the members of the Republican National Committee listened to doleful stories about the "misfortunes" that the Grand Old Party has encountered in the West, and, for a time, to the anxious appeal of Col. Shepard to save New-York from a "bloody revolution."
THE TIMES has received from the Congregation B'nai Israel of Sacramento, Cal., J. Leonard Levy, Rabbi, the sum of $1,407.70 for the relief of sufferers from famine in Russia.

A motion for a stay pending appeal in the case of Sylvester F. Wilson, convicted in the Court of General Sessions of abduction, was argued yesterday before Judge Patterson, in Supreme Court, Chambers. Wilson's counsel said that Judge Martine, before whom his client was tried, now had under consideration an application for the appointment of a commission to pass on his sanity.

STOCKTON, Nov. 24. -- Millard Saunders bids fair to rival Charles Marvin as a conditioner and educator of young horses. At the kite-shaped track here to-day he succeeded in making two new records for yearlings at both the trot and the pace.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 24. -- Citizens of Minneapolis had hardly got well at work this morning congratulating one another over their victory in securing the Republican National Convention before it was announced that the Democrats of both this city and St. Paul were laying plans to secure the Democratic National Convention also.

The manufacturers of plate glass must be classed with those who have not been moved by the pitiful appeal addressed by Senator SHERMAN to the "combines" at the close of the debate on the McKinley bill. We find the following in the Pittsburg Commercial Gazette of the 19th inst.:

A man with a little ready money and a desire to turn an honest penny by dabbling in trotting-bred horses could have made a lot of money if he had been at Tattersall's yesterday. There was a sale of some sixty head of trotting and pacing stock by William Easton, and there were a lot of good youngsters in the consignment. But purchasers were few, and the stock went at absurdly low prices.

There was a story in circulation yesterday that all was not harmony at the Union League Club, and that the coming election, Jan. 14, would be more than usually interesting from the fact that there were two tickets in the field.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 24. -- Judge Rising's division of the District Court was packed to suffocation this morning when the crier called it to order, and far down the hall a mass of men and women were jammed together, eager to hear the decision in the famous Graves-Barnaby poisoning case.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Judging from present appearances in the political contest now going on in Onondaga County, Gov. Hill and Democratic State Committeeman William B. Kirk are playing a desperate game, their purpose being to have Patrick J. Ryan, Democrat, seated in the next Assembly from the First District.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- Judge Edgar L. Fursman, sitting in Special Term, to-day, on application of George M. Beakes, granted a peremptory mandalsus competing the Board of County Canvassers of Sullivan County to reconvene and reconsider their action in awarding the certificate of election to member of the Assembly to Henry Kienrich, and to canvass the vote as it appeared on the free of the returns as they were originally returned to the County Clerk.

Mr. SIMMONS, the author of the resolutions adopted by the Chamber of Commerce on the silver law of 1890, has recently called attention to the anomalous provision of that law by which the Treasury is compelled to buy silver to the amount of 54,000,000 ounces per year, and is not allowed to sell any.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Chief of Police Martin of Port Jervis brought a man here tonight who is charged with the murder of Mrs. Amelia Gregory, the farmer's wife who was killed near this city on Oct. 14 last. The prisoner is a hard-featured young man of perhaps twenty-eight years. He formerly worked as a farm hand near here, and was also employed for a time as a laborer at the State Insane Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Although several references have been made from time to time, in Washington dispatches to THE TIMES to the lack of stability of the cruiser Philadelphia, the publication of the accounts in THE TIMES of to-day and yesterday have more particularly interested the friends of persons on that vessel, owing to the minuteness of the analysis of the causes of instability.
" CRISP is a Randall Democrat, while MILLS is a Mills Democrat," says the Fort Worth (Texas) Gazette. "That is the difference between the two aspirants for the Speakership."

The principal charge against County Clerk COTTON of Onondaga County upon which the Governor calls him to account so promptly, aside from that of refusing to furnish a certified copy of the Board of Canvassers' certificate of election of PATRICK J. RYAN for Assemblyman, is a pretty serious one if it is sustained.

It is reported in the Crockery and Class Journal that the managers of the Pennsylvania Glass Works, at Anderson, Ind., recently ordered a reduction of 25 per cent, in wages, and that this order has been followed by a strike. It is also said that the concern paid a dividend of 64 per cent. last year.

The anniversary of the evacuation of New-York by the British was fittingly observed yesterday by the Society of Colonial Dames of America. The meeting was held at the residence of Mrs. Hamilton Fairfax, Madison Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. There were about seventy members of the society present. Mrs. King, the President, presided.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The wildest excitement and enthusiasm that have been seen in Princeton for a long time have had entire possession of this little classic town throughout the entire day. Every nerve was strung to the highest pitch in anticipation of seeing, probably, one of the greatest games of football in college history.

In the annual report of the New-York Life Insurance Company to the State Department at Albany for the year 1886, there appears the item "Cash in bank and deposits in foreign countries, $3,029,664.67." In a memorandum attached to this annual statement, this item is explained at some length by a subdivision, in which this appears: "Cash with banks and bankers of other cities, $491,000."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25. -- A meeting was held at the Southern Hotel by a committee of the Western Freight Association to consider the matter of import rates. There were present the general freight officials of the Santa Fe, Chicago and Alton, St. Paul, Illinois Central, Rock Island, Kansas City, Fort Scott and Memphis, Missouri Pacific, and Burlington Roads.

The members of the Brooklyn Fire and Police Departments were very much disgusted yesterday to learn that they were not to be paid their salaries for the current month before Thanksgiving Day. It has been a custom for years to pay the November salaries before that general holiday, but yesterday Controller Jackson decided that he would not continue the practice.

With only thirty Democratic Representatives in Washington, the three or four "headquarters" maintained by the different candidates for the Speakership are naturally a little dull Mr. CRISP seems to be occupied chiefly in correcting the blunders of his most active supporters and in preventing them from making others.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Once the friend of Booth and a popular and respected actor, Nelson Decker, now an object of charity, lies dying in his room at the Edwin Forrest Home at Holmesburg, after a determined effort, early yesterday to end his clouded existence.

ANNAPOLIS, Mid., Nov. 25. -- The regular Thanksgiving ball was given by the naval officers at the new boathouse to-night. Mrs. Pay Director Fulton and Commander Cheston received. The hall was tastefully decorated with bunting.

Ariadne's thread is required to lead us through the maze of the tariff in its relations to the woolen industry. The industry is so complicated and comprises so many subdivisions that without a rigidly-systematic treatment of the most important branches the space of a few letters would barely suffice to give an adequate idea of the importance of the subject.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- When the Dutchess County Board of Supervisors convened to-day the room was filled with spectators. Mr. Vail, the Democratic leader, asked the clerk if the changes ordered had been made on his tally sheets, and the clerk replied in the negative.

The military ceremonies attending the Thanksgiving Eve celebration of the Forty-seventh Regiment did not want for spectators last night, the spacious armory at Marcy Avenue and Heyward Street, Brooklyn, being crowded in every part. Added interest was lent to the annual celebration of the command in consequence of the announcement that the ceremonies set forward by the organization would be performed in accordance with the much-talked-of now drill regulations.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- David B. Hill, the partisan, sat in the Governor's chair to-day as Judge, jury, and counsel in the charges made by William B. Kirk, Mayor of Syracuse, against George G. Cotton, County Clerk of Onondaga County.
On the 21st inst. the Electrical Review published an editorial article entitled "Barking at Shadows," the opening sentences of which were as follows:

The editorial in the Evening Post of last night in regard to an order made by Judge Kennedy, requiring the returns of the election of a member of Assembly in the Second District of Onondaga County to be sent back to the Inspectors of Election for correction, contains several errors.

BUFFALO, Nov. 25. -- It is estimated that there are 2,000,000 bushels of grain afloat here, with a big fleet coming in every day. The storm has kept the elevators from doing much work this week, and if that were the worst of it, a few days of good weather would see the cargoes out and the boats could go on their way. But the elevators are almost full now.

" Said Commissioners [of rapid transit] shall have exclusive power to locate the route or routes or such railway or railways over, under, through, or across the streets, avenues, places, or lands in such county except such as are contained in public parks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25. -- The suit brought By M.W. Fox against the Hale Norcross Mining Company is bringing out some sensational developments that go to show that Fox was correct in his assertions that the stockholders of the company have been robbed of over $2,000,000 during the last four years.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 25. -- For three days the jury in the Lumpy Jaw case has been out and there is no verdict. The jurymen remained in their room until the middle of the forenoon to-day, when Judge Shaw took compassion on their misery and ushered them back into the courtroom. It was then announced that no verdict had been or could be reached by the eleven men.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 25. -- The average Kansas politician is never so happy as when endeavoring to do something new. His present attempt to create a "proxy Senator" is in line with this leading principle of his life. W.E. Sterne, the reputed father of the scheme, has for the foundation of his plan the bill that passed the State Senate last Winter, and which received the support of the Republican members of the House.

Arcadins Soltz, President of the New-York and Pleasantville Investment Company, was arrested yesterday on complaint of Abraham Salzman of 4 Montgomery Street who charged him with obtaining money under false pretenses. The complainant averred that certain property which he bought from Soltz as unencumbered, proved to be mortgaged to the amount of $2,500.

The selection of Minneapolis for the meeting place of the Republican National Convention of next year was avowedly made with the hope that the influence of the convention might counteract the effect of the series of Republican defeats in the vast and important region of which that town is one of the principal centres.
The Sun publishes your editorial upon the Speakership:

There was a protracted and earnest conference of the Directors of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Company in this city yesterday. The question of reorganization was discussed in all its bearings, and there were covert allusions to possible changes in the personnel of the board.

The case of FRANKLIN D. SHERWOOD, Republican candidate for the Senate in the Twenty-seventh District, is an illustration of the defiant disregard of constitutional mandates which has become so common with the politicians of his party.

It was with the keenest sense of comfort that the fortunate possessors of ticket coupons settled themselves in their seats in Daly's beautiful theatre last night. They had come to welcome home, after a long period of absence, their favorite band of comedians, and they found such agreeable changes in the playhouse as made them open wide their eyes in admiration.

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 25. -- The conference of the National Union of Conservative Associations resumed its session this morning in Masonic Hall. The same enthusiastic crowd of spectators was present, and the utmost interest was manifested in the proceedings of the conference. The time allotted to the proposers of resolutions was limited to twenty minutes, and succeeding speakers were allowed only ten minutes in which to state their views.

The "national convention" of the English Conservatives constructed a platform which indicates that they have not studied the American precedents with great care. The art of platform building as it has been practiced in this country for several generations is to seem to offer to every doubtful voter whatever he may please to want, without making any committals so explicit as to create inconveniences for the party in case of its success.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Early in August "Deacon" S.V. White put corn to 70 cents and held it there for a few hours. From that figure the price rapidly declined, until when the "Deacon" failed it got almost to 40 cents. To-day November corn opened at 69 cents, and closed with 75 cent bid. The private settlement of the one big outstanding November short line did not go through.

Either the Park Commissioners ought to get a higher-priced lawyer or else dispense with law and argument altogether, and brazen it out as a Jay Gould board. The muttonhead who drew up their "statement" in the Battery Park grab ease has made them ridiculous.

It is fortunate for Brooklyn that there is one chapter in the record of Mayor CHAPIN that can serve as an encouragement rather than a warning to Mr. BOOBY when he shall assume the office. It is the one relating to the specific administration of the municipal civil service rules.

The advisory board yesterday made its report to the Virginia Bondholders' Committee on the proposed agreement for the settlement of the State's debt. The report is signed by Grover Cleveland, Thomas F. Bayard, E.J. Phelps, George S. Coe, and G.G. Williams. It approves and recommends the plan and reviews its provisions, as printed in THE TIMES.

Some of the published reports may convey erroneous impressions as to the origin of the Kunstlerfest to be held on Dec. 3. The artistic arrangement of the German-American part of the Centennial celebration in 1889 was due almost entirely to the ingenuity of my friend Joseph Keppler. But he had, unfortunately, miscalculated the cost. It amounted to nearly $21,000 instead of his estimate of $15,000.

It is evident that the Brazilian Government, under its new chief, has not relaxed its censorship of foreign dispatches. The authorized statements that the accession of PEIXOTOU is satisfactory to everybody must therefore be taken with as much allowance as the similar statements respecting the Government of his predecessor, when his predecessor was really in extremis.

The first hearing in the case of the Standard Gaslight Company against Wallace C. Andrews, its former President, will be had in the Superior Court, before Judge McAdam, next Monday or Tuesday, it having been definitely determined that no amicable arrangement can be reached between Mr. Andrews and the committee of Directors appointed for the purpose at Tuesday's meeting.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 25. -- The Yale football team, with its retinue of coachers, trainers, and the hospital corps, left for New-York this afternoon on a special train. Their departure was cheered by hundreds of students, who will follow them to-night or in the morning. The players left with the most confident expectations of winning from Princeton to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- When Mr. Randall was last a candidate for Speaker of the House, and was soliciting the support of his Democratic associates, his campaign was conducted very much in the same way that the supporters of Mr. Crisp are now urging that gentleman upon the Democrats of the Fifty-second Congress.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The Chronicle's correspondent at Tien-Tsin says: "The outbreak in the north, officially described as a raid of Mongolian robbers, proves to be an insurrectionary movement of serious dimensions. Dispatches received to-day state that in Mongolia and some northern districts nearer the capital the revolutionary feeling is spreading rapidly, and the number of rebels is becoming alarming.

From the official statement of the vote of Massachusetts at the last election it appears that Russell, the Democratic candidate for Governor, was the only man on his ticket elected. Out of 321,673 votes he received 157,982 votes. Allen (Rep.) received 151,515, Kimball (Proh.) 8,968,Winn (People's Party) 1,772, (Robinson (Sec. Labor) 1,429, all others 7.

Passed Assistant Engineer W.M. McFarland, United States Navy, who has been assigned to duty in the Revenue Marine Bureau in conjunction with Chief Engineer J.W. Collins, United States Revenue Marine, will, among other duties, dispose of the machinery designs for the four new and fast revenue steamers now being gotten up. Through the present, arrangement the latest ideas from Commodore Melville's bureau will be combined with those found necessary in the Revenue Marine Service.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Official announcement was made yesterday that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company would, on Tuesday, Dec. 1, begin running passenger trains into the Grand Central Station on Harrison Street, and would at the same time transfer its freight office from the lake front to the Wisconsin Central, Freight House on Taylor Street.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- A curious story has just been made public, which appears to show that the Vatican has had an emissary in the very household of the Marquis of Salisbury. The story is thus told in a letter written by a lady who was recently a guest at Hatfield House, the residence, in Hertfordshire, of the Prime Minister:

Michael Sliney, the young cartman who is accused of having killed his friend and associate, Robert Lyons, in the butcher's shop of Martin Lyons, 152 Cherry Street, was taken to the Coroners' office yesterday for examination.

With the tooting horn, the rasping bazoo, and the resounding drum, the grotesque Ranger made merry yesterday and gave noisy expression to his spirit of thanksgiving. He was in every section of the city, and in every conceivable guise. He paraded on foot and on horseback, in four-in-hand coaches, and on two-wheeled drays, in coal carts, milk wagons, light sulkies, and on bicycles.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- The cadet football team is to leave here to-morrow afternoon for Annapolis to try conclusions with the naval cadet team in a game to be played on the Naval Academy grounds on Saturday afternoon. The men have a special car from New-York to Annapolis and return. They will be in the charge of Lieut. D.L. Tate, Third Cavalry.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 26. -- Distinguished prelates of the Catholic Church are beginning to arrive here to participate in the celebration of the golden jubilee of Archbishop Kenrick. Cardinal Gibbons arrived this evening.

In spite of threatening weather that fulfilled its threats, what must have been the greatest crowd that ever assembled to witness an athletic contest in this city, or in this country, was drawn together yesterday by the game of football that was to decide the championship of the colleges. The sport was well worth its seeing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The annual report of S.I. Kimball, General Superintendent of the Life-Saving Service, shows that at the close of the last fiscal year the establishment embraced 238 stations -- 178 on the Atlantic, 48 on the lakes, 11 on the Pacific, and at the Falls of the Ohio at Louisville.

Eugene Augustus Hoffman, Jr., the elder son of Dean Hoffman of the Union Theological Seminary, died yesterday at his father's residence, 1 Chelsea Square, of consumption, from which he had been suffering for several years. He was twenty-nine years old and a native of Burlington, N.J., where he was born while his father was rector of St. Mary's Church in that place.

The wind was south by east, with a "force of one," as the sailor men say, when the teams lined up in the middle of the field. That is to say, there was little soft air moving from the eastward of south, just enough to make the flags on the tall poles lazily wag their tails like good-natured dogs that never had a "scrap" in their lives.

The article in this morning's TIMES entitled "Worse Than a Blunder" seems to be a little superfluous in view of the fact that David B. Hill has been "pounded" so persistently during his Gubernatorial career.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Ten thousand football enthusiasts saw the Chicago University Club eleven beat Cornell to-day by 12 to 4. It was great game, and the gathering that witnessed it was worthy of the occasion.

FLORENCE, Nov. 26. -- This afternoon there was unveiled in the old Protestant Cemetery in this city, in the presence of American and English residents and the United States Consul, James Verner Long, the new headstone at the grave of the Rev. Theodore Parker, which was erected with subscriptions collected by Theodore Stanton among European and American admirers of Mr. Parker.

In a broad and general way, hunting parties may be divided into two great classes, those that people hear about, and those they do not. From the nature of the division, the first class is familiar. There is the start, the finding of game, the killing of it in unlimited quantities, and the triumphal march back home. This is hunting.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 26. -- In few of the older States of the Union are the country roads as poor and as unsuitable as in Connecticut. This is chiefly due to a lax system of contract and sub-letting. Men of influence in town and city politics, who know little about grading and loss about surface dressing, generally succeed in getting most of the work.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 26. -- It being Thanksgiving Day made no difference, and this morning, at 11 o'clock, Paul Conrad, Joseph L. Herwig, P. Felix Herwig, L. Poche, A.J. Bachemin, W. Valeton, Joseph P. Horner, J. Brulatour, P. Voorhies, and M.F. Arnoule appeared before United States Commissioner William Wright to answer the indictments found against them at Sioux Falls, N.D., charging them with a violation of the anti-lottery postal laws.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26. -- The Evening Post to-day prints an interview with Senator Stanford on the subject of the recent performance of his trotting horses on the Stockton "kite" track. Mr. Stanford said:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Of course it was just as Princeton men expected, although they hoped it might be different. No college bells are ringing. No fires around the historic cannon are blazing. Why should there be with the score 19 to 0 in Yale's favor? The Princetonians have decided to change their colors for the time being and adopt the color of the New Havens, "blue," for they feel decidedly so to-night.

Senator John G. Carlisle of Kentucky was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Tuesday, having come from Washington in response to a request from Senator Aldrich of Rhode Island for a conference on the tariff investigation which they as members of the Senate sub-committee have been conducting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26. -- Among the passengers on the steamer Mariposa from Samoa was the United States Land Commissioner, H.C. Ide, who was sent down to Samoa to straighten out the land titles in conjunction with the English and German Commissioners. Mr. Ide was compelled to resign his position on account of illness in his family. Speaking of the affairs in Samoa, he said:

The official figures of the vote in Massachusetts at the recent election show with great clearness not only that independent voting is much practiced in the Bay State, but that the admirable blanket ballot in use under the Massachusetts law offers no impediment to the perfect freedom of the voter's choice among the candidates. Gov. RUSSELL, was the only Democrat on the State ticket who was elected.
A small-sized riot was created on a train on the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad yesterday afternoon due to the brutal conduct of a drunken guard who was called "Jim." His number was 942.

Go any way you will to Boston, take one of the Kennebec steamers leaving every day at 5 P.M., and you will arrive in Gardiner in time for breakfast. To a good sailor it is permissible to get up at daybreak, when the steamer reaches the mouth of the river, for a view of the craggy clius of Seguin Island, on which there is a first-class Government light and all the modern fog appliances.

There is a certain naval officer who has on several occasions come very near rendering himself immortal as a wit, although those who know him best say that a sense of humor is not his most conspicuous quality.

ST. THOMAS, West Indies, Nov. 18. -- The visit of the Philadelphia and Kearsarge of the North Atlantic squadron to the Island of St. Thoma has again given rise to a great deal of specula tion regarding the ultimate ownership of the Island, and brought hopes to the hearts of the people here that St. Thomas will soon belong to the United States.

Through the medium of an Autumn festival the practical operation of the Workingman's School in West Fifty-fourth Street was made known yesterday to several hundred visitors. The classroom, the kindergarten, and the workshop were all thrown open to inspection. Most of the classes were full, and interesting object lessons were given in each room.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- The result of the election in this State is construed by the farseeing Democrats to mean the renomination of Mr. Cleveland by the next National Democratic Convention. Had the result been different, it is argued that the free and unlimited coinage advocates would have insisted upon the nomination of a candidate favorable to the views of the extremists.

One of the pet creations of President William H. Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company is the Manhattan Safe Deposit and Storage Company in the basement of the New-York Life Building at 346 and 348 Broadway. But for the important fact that the stock of this truly remarkable safe deposit company figures for a very large sum among the sworn assets of the New-York Life no space would be devoted to it.

Among the many causes of thanksgiving which our neighbors in Brooklyn doubtless enjoyed and digested with their turkey and cranberries yesterday, the free supply of water was not the least. No one who has not gone through the experience of even thirty-six hours "water famine" can have a complete idea of not merely the inconvenience, but the actual suffering, that it may cause and the dangers it may bring in its train.

A uniform route across the Atlantic for all steamers leaving Liverpool for New-York and another separate route for steamers leaving New-York for Liverpool have long been regarded by the large steamship companies and by all thoughtful persons interested in the North Atlantic trade as a pressing need of the time.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- A stranger giving the name of Richard P. Schoem, hailing from New-York and Utica, appeared hero yesterday and said that he was going to open a dry goods store. He leased a store. He offered a six-hundred-dollar draft at the Merchants' Bank drawn on the Fourth National Bank of New-York, which the bank officials refused to honor on the ground of his being a total stranger in the city.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Nov. 26. -- A fire, which broke out about 12:30 o'clock this morning, proved to be the most disastrous that St. Albans has known for many years. The total loss is estimated at $150,000. The flames were first seen in a small barn rented by Charles Bailey, a hackman, and situated in the rear of a store in Main Street.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- A collision occurred at Messengerville at 5:30 o'clock this morning on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad between a south-bound freight train and a passenger train which left New-York at 9 o'clock last night. The passenger train, under the charge of Conductor Kettle and Engineer Keitung, was bound north on the single track.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Copies of the naval report of M. Cochery of the Budget Committee were to-day circulated in the Chamber of Deputies. The report sets forth that France now possesses 30 iron-clads, 26 cruisers, 15 dispatch boats, and 54 torpedo boats.

Although it is now pretty well settled that there will be no legislation on the silver question in the next session of Congress, unless contingencies should arise to compel it that cannot be foreseen, it is worthy of note that changes in the law continue to be discussed, and in the very nature of the situation they must be.

TORONTO, Nov. 26. -- In Oxford, one of the strongest Liberal counties in Ontario, a letter has been received from the Hon. Oliver Mowat, Premier of the Liberal Government of Ontario. Mr. Mowat says in the letter:

Yesterday was the ninety-third birthday of Dr. Elijah Whitney, the oldest physician in New-York, if not in the entire country. The occasion was to be celebrated by a family reunion at the doctor's residence, 351 West Fifty-first Street, but this was prevented by the doctor's sudden and serious illness, and what was to have been a day of thanksgiving, in a double sense, was turned into a day of anxiety and sadness.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 26. -- The fact that the term of Senator George Gray will expire on March 4, 1893, makes next year's political contest unusually interesting and important, and the Republicans will put forth desperate efforts to capture the Legislature and give Senator Higgins a Republican colleague during the remainder of his term.
PARIS, Nov. 27. United States Consuls in France give their views concerning the prospects of the Chicago Worlds Fair in their various districts as follows:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27. -- The Hon. Mackenzie Bowell, Acting Minister of Railways and Canals, speaking of the memorial submitted to Secretary of State James G. Blaine by the Lake Carrier Association of Buffalo, complaining that the Canadian Government discriminates against American citizens in violation of Article 27 of the treaty of Washington by imposing tolls on the Welland Canal, says: "It is a grave charge could it be substantiated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- It is the intention of the War Department to issue soon an order that will effect the first really sweeping change in the United States Military Academy at West Point since its foundation, ninety years ago. The scope of the order has already been unofficially announced, and the seal of the department will probably be affixed to the official paper during the coming week.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Military Academy football eleven, with their substitutes and a score of enthusiastic officers, left to-day for Annapolis, where the annual game of football between the two academies will be played to-morrow. Last year's game, the first of the series, was won here by Annapolis. This year the military cadets will fight hard to retrieve that defeat and they will fight, with a good chance of winning.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- The College Association of the Middle States met at Barnes Hall to-day, under the auspices of Cornell Faculty.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Postmaster General to-day announced the acceptance of bids for carrying the United States mails on ocean routes, under the act of March 3, 1891, as follows:

The notion of a Zollverein is at the bottom of a scheme that has appealed with much force to many worthy persons in England under the name of "Imperial Federation." It is the same notion which Mr. BLAINE has been endeavoring to graft upon the American tariff under the name of reciprocity.

There was a long session of the Rapid-Transit Commission yesterday, at which the commission discussed with Engineer W.B. Parsons the details of the plan of construction, the location of stations, and other matters. Inquiries had been made by many property owners as to the depth at which the road would run past their properties, and some sketches were made for their edification.

Alice Bartholomew, a child, was injured by stepping into a hole in the waiting room of the Poughkeepsie and Highlands Ferry Company in 1887. After several appeals she received $7,000. The mother, Esther Henzie, has sued the company for $10,000, because she has had to support her child and has been deprived of her services. Decision was reserved.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- There is prospect that the trade between the Atlantic seaboard and the Northwest, especially that from New-England, will be permanently lost to Chicago. The "Soo" and the Canadian Pacific have filed a claim upon the business which a month's correspondence with Chairman Midgley has failed to relax.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Assistant Manager Baldwin of the Cornell team was very indignant at the way Galbraith of the Cornell team was beaten by some one on the All University team on Thanksgiving Day. Galbraith was hurt in an encounter with Alford, the left half back of the All University team. Baldwin said, in speaking about it:
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The first authentic information conveying the results of Mr. de Giers's sojourn in Paris has reached the Foreign Office through the British Embassy at Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker has never quite forgiven Commissioner Roosevelt for having caught him in making statements that were not exactly consistent with truth, and now he is understood to have found an opportunity to discredit him and perhaps to force his resignation from the public service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Sun has proved so good a friend of Mr. Mills in his canvass for the Speakership by suggesting a series of progressive parallels that other newspapers could complete that it will be glad of the opportunity that Senator Pugh of Alabama has provided for adding one more to the series of propositions.

Postmaster Van Cott has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Mariposa arrived at that port Thursday, Nov. 26, with mails from Australia, New-Zealand, and Hawaii of the following dates: Melbourne, Oct. 31; Sydney Nov. 2; Auckland, Nov. 7; Honolulu, Nov. 19. These mails are due to arrive in New-York the morning of Tuesday, Dec. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Santiago correspondent of the Times says that the people of the Province of Rio Grande do Sul think that the changes arising from the deposition of Marshal da Fonseca are not radical enough, and new complications are feared.

BERGEN POINT, Nov. 27. -- Th0 Lehigh Valley Ilallroad contractors attempted to steal a march upon the City of Bayonne to.day by resuming operations. Chief of Police John B. [cNeil stopped them for Street Commissioner Peter Girth, who had watched railroad material arriving lor two days before the contractors began building a viaduct across Aforrts ('anal at Avenue B, where the company built an abutment across the street.

" Both the Dinkelspiels," said a gentleman yesterday who had recently returned from Europe, "are still in the employ of the New-York Life. 'Sam' or 'Simon' Dinkelspiel is particularly active, notwithstanding the fact that when I saw him, only a few weeks ago, he seemed to be seriously ill Two of his most intimate friends told me he was much worried over the constant attacks that are being made upon him.

EELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Brewer Peter Breidt of this city, Le Grand Spencer, brewery engineer, and August Worth were confronted by three masked highwaymen. Thanksgiving Eve while on their way home from Cranford, where they had been spending the evening with Martin Hess, who keeps the Cranford Hotel.

The estimates made by Secretary TRACY for new naval construction during the next fiscal year are so moderate that even a Congress bent on economy may wisely sanction them in its appropriations. In fact, while frugality is properly the watchword for the successor of the Billion Congress, our navy is not the branch of the Government which should feel the effects of this general policy.

There is a fresh stir at the Custom House over the seizure of three trunks brought here by Mrs. W. Minnich on the steamer La Bretagne about six weeks ago. There were twenty-six Paris-made dresses in the trunks, valued at a good many thousand dollars altogether.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- No one familiar with public opinion in Ohio can doubt that a strong effort will be made to unseat Senator-elect Calvin S. Brice this Winter. Under the pressure of Republican sentiment Senator Sherman has sent the following letter, dated Nov. 16, to Judge L.W. King, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee:

The members of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will move into their elegant new clubhouse at Oyster Bay, L.I., early in February. The house, with the wide piazzas surrounding it on three sides, covers a space 119 by 53 feet in size. It is an imposing three-story structure, with a mansard roof, resembling in the style of architecture a colonial mansion.

" The Pulpit and Politics" was discussed before a large audience in the Montclair Club Hall in Montclair last night. It was the sixteenth in the series of popular discussions under the auspices of the Outlook Club. The Rev. Dr. B.B. Tyler, who opened the discussion, based his argument in favor of the integrity of the pulpit and against the intrusion of politics upon the authority of Scripture.

DETROIT, Nov. 27. -- Several shipping disasters are reported from up the lakes to-day. The steam barge Oswegatchie, lumber-laden, left Alpena Tuesday with the barges Goodell, with 230,000 feet of lumber; H.C. Potter, 350,000 feet of lumber, and the schooner A.J. McBrier in tow. When off Sturgeon Point the Oswegatchie got in a heavy sea and soon sprung a heavy leak. The barges were cut adrift.

There is a good deal of comment in labor circles over the action of State Factory Inpector Connolly in asking Mrs. Bremer, Deputy Factory Inspector, to resign, and in his objection to having her husband write any letters for her to the Factory Inspection Department.

We published some months ago a summary of those portions of the annual reports of the New-York State Board of Charities which relate to the shipping of paupers and lunatics from Europe to this country by way of Canada, and to the reception and support of many such immigrants in the institutions of this State.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- There was much excitement at the Horse Guards to-day upon the receipt of intelligence from Aldershot, where is situated a great military camp and barracks, that an attempt had been made by some of the soldiers to hang an unpopular petty officer.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- The much-advertised meeting of the Republican State Central Committee, called for the purpose of seeing how they could unseat the Hon. Calvin S. Brice, was held to-night in the rooms of the Lincoln Club. The gathering was a large one.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 27. -- Chauncey I. Filley has returned from Washington, where he represented St. Louis in the fight for the location of the next Republican National Convention.

HARTFORD, Nov. 27. -- The Prohibition campaign in this State for 1892 will be given an early start, the initial convention being called for Wednesday, Dec. 9, when delegates to the National Convention will he selected. The call has been issued by Messrs. Nathan Babcock, Henry G. Smith, and Edwin P. Augur, the executive officers of the State Central Committee.

ST. MARY'S, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- A disastrous riot occurred at Yorkville, a small village on the Chicago and Erie Railroad, about twenty-five miles northwest of this city, to-day that resulted in the fatal wounding of three of the participants and dangerous injuries to two others.
" Buddha" means "to know." It is a title of sainthood, not a personal name, given to many religious teachers in old India who followed the teachings of Gautama Buddha.

Although the United States is the most powerful of all nations, she does not depend altogether upon the number of her trained military men to maintain her position. While other nations have academies to suit every branch of military service, the United States has but a single soldier factory -- that one up the Hudson River at West Point.

The Oratorio Society began its season on Friday afternoon with a public rehearsal at Music Hall. The programme performed then was repeated last night in the presence of an audience of respectable size and kindly disposition. The music presented was of a most admirable order. Two works, Brahms's "German Requiem" and the third part of Schumann's "Faust," constituted the evening's entertainment -- if such serious artistic matter can be regarded as entertainment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The football season at Princeton has entirely closed, and not even a "scrub" match between class teams or eating clubs is now engaged in by the most ardent admirers of the Rugby game.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- Dramatic criticism is not always a pleasure nowadays. In their ardent, feverish search for novelty, both authors and managers seem frequently to be at sea. In such contradictory prospect, frequently tending to utter disaster, no wonder that clever minds turn to the more certain future of old by-gone plays such as "Kean," and the still more recent and astonishingly prosperous selection of "Nos Intimes."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Bishop Phillips Brooks will address the students and conduct chapel exercises this afternoon. The Rev. Joseph Twichell of Hartford, Conn., will preach in the college-chapel to-day.

Mr. BALFOUR has embarked with especial rashness upon the dangerous waters of political prophecy. In his speech Friday at Glasgow he declared and repeated that "Ireland would never attain her desire to have a Parliament sit in Dublin," The assertion is conclusive of nothing but the speaker's own present position.

BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 28. -- A Rio Janeiro telegram announces that the Government has issued a decree reinstating Senhor Castilho as Governor of the Province of Rio Grande do Sul. The decree has created a ferment throughout the province.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- If Baltimoreans have cause to be proud of anything, after their beautiful women, it surely is the "Monday Night German," which is the pet name for the "Bachelors' Cotillon Club." For years this club has been celebrated, and it is always a social event in the "smart set." It has been in existence for about twenty-five years, and is a regular landmark in our society history.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Twelve years ago George M. Robeson, the Secretary of the Navy, was so prominently identified with national affairs that he was a principal figure in the cartoons of the comic papers and a target for the editorial paragraphers. It has never been definitely settled whether it was the caricaturists or the glass blower, Thomas Ferrell, that caused the confidential friend of Gen. Grant to seek obscurity and remain there.
Mayor Chapin took his first step yesterday in reference to the Barthman scandal in the Brooklyn Board of Education, and acknowledged the receipt of the following letter:

In the season of gales, when vessels, sometimes called lame ducks, come into port with the loss of spars, sails, and rigging, and sometimes with the loss of men, the readers of stories of the sea have a certain amount of sentiment aroused, but the Captains, agents, and owners of vessels take more practical views of the subject, and sentiment has very little consideration in their minds when the damages are under inspection.

It was an ideal place to pick up some stray facts about Niagara Falls, past and present. We were seated in a snug room on the ground floor of the Cataract House -- Mr. Porter, the owner of that house; Mr. Uriah Welch of the International Hotel, and myself. The time, I say it regretfully, was something past mid-night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 28. -- The mysterious King, alias Dennis, alias Spinole, who, it is said, returned the kidnapped Beals child, was arrested this morning at 4 o'clock. He is the chief conspirator in the abduction, and was undoubtedly the man who delivered the child and obtained the five-thousand-dollar ransom last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 28. -- The college athletic season ended with to-day's game between the Yale and Harvard freshmen. Next in order will come the contest of brains. The proposed debate between the Yale Union and the Harvard Debating Society is an assured fact. There will be two contests of this interesting and novel character, the first at Cambridge about the middle of January and the second at New-Haven in April.

The country realizes that Mr. Cleveland is not afraid to use the veto power. For this it admires him. He would veto a New-York or Buffalo extravagance at national expense with the same freedom that he would employ in Maine or California. But the politicians understand this also, and to them it means more than abstract theories.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore gave a lecture before the teachers at the American Museum of Natural History on "Food Fishes from Fresh Waters" yesterday morning. He gave a very entertaining description of the work of supplying streams from the fish hatcheries, and from his own experience told fishermen where some choice trout and salmon may be had.

Manager Chapman and Director Gatto of the Louisville Baseball Club are trying their utmost to get Taylor and Jennings back into the Louisville fold. Both these players have signed New-York contracts and they will be Giants in 1892. They are high-priced men and will command big salaries here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28. -- The Rev. Thomas Hill, D.D., LL.D., S.J.D., President of Harvard College from 1862 to 1868, died at Waltham, Mass., on Saturday, Nov. 21. The following obituary, which appeared in a recent issue of the Crimson, is interesting:

Ernest A. Jurgens, who had been for some time manager of the Eden Musee, went to Europe on Nov. 14. Just before he left, the officers of the American Amusement Company, which owns the Musee, discovered that Mr. Jurgens had been using some of the company's money in his own enterprises. The amount is variously estimated at from $8,000 to $15,000.

One of the important duties imposed upon the next Legislature is the election, in joint session, on the first Tuesday in April, of a State Superintendent of Public Instruction. It is a position which calls for peculiar fitness and extraordinary qualities.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28. -- Fish culture has now reached a most important stage in Canada, and every year millions of eggs are gathered from the haunts of the various fish and artificially hatched in Government breeding houses.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The debate in the Reichstag on the budget to-day was unwontedly lively. After Herr Buhl (National Liberal) had spoken in defense of the policy pursued by Prince Bismarck during his tenure of office as Chancellor of the empire, and had commented adversely upon the course adopted by Chancellor yon Caprivi, Herr Bebel, the Socialist leader, criticised the rapid increase of the imperial debt and of the army and navy appropriations.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- On the occasion of the recent attempt to secure subscriptions for the Russian loan in Berlin, I ventured to treat the failure of that attempt as proof of how wonderfully Germany had become consolidated in feeling and national sentiment since the dismissal of Prince Bismarck. Yesterday's scene in the Reichstag furnished equally eloquent testimony to the same thing.

POMONA, Cal., Nov, 20. -- The orange crop in Southern California this year is unusually large, notwithstanding the facts that there was a very satisfactory production last season and that full crops are expected only in alternate years. This means exceptional prosperity for everybody who has an orchard in bearing, but next year a very light growth will be looked for.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Nov. 28. -- The Davenport Democrat to-morrow morning will print a symposium of political opinion, made up of letters from about 100 Democratic members of the Fifty-second Congress. The correspondence represents thirty States. The expression of opinion was suggested by a letter asking the views of each Congressman as to the advisability of placing the name of Gov. Boies on the Presidential ticket in 1892.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28. -- The investigation of the Public Accounts Committee of the House of Commons last session revealed the fact that very serious irregularities had been carried on in the various branches of the civil service. Major Henry F. Perley, Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works, was cashiered for receiving $2,000 worth of jewelry from Owen Murphy of the firm of Larkin, Connolly Co.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- Dr. William B. Clarke, Professor of Geology and Director of the Maryland State Weather Service, thinks Maryland should illustrate its varied climatic and geologic resources at the World's Fair. He says: "There is no State in the Union that has a better opportunity of presenting at the World's Fair an attractive display of its natural products and climate than Maryland.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- With the close of the Intercollegiate Football Association's championship season, Syracuse University's football team is fourth, when at the opening of the series of games it was predicted that they would be near the head. Colgate won the pennant over Union, Hamilton, Syracuse, and Rochester. Colgate also won the baseball championship.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- While grand opera at the Covent Garden and Shaftesbury Theatres has taken on a new lease of life, and while comic opera, too, is flourishing, the attempt of Manager D'Oyly Carte to establish genuine national opera at the Royal English Opera House has resulted in failure. His production of Sir Arthur Sullivan's "Ivanhoe," of which much was expected, involved him in a loss of over 36,000.

BOSTON, NOV. 28. -- Boston was thrown into a state of mental perturbation, that is curiously slow to subside, by the recent action of the visiting English artist and decorator. Walter Crane, who, it will be recalled, outraged public sentiment by his condemnation of the action of the law at a recent meeting held in Paine Memorial Hall to commemorate the hanging of the Chicago Anarchists.

A writ of habeas corpus has been issued by Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court, on application of Mrs. Kate Randolph of Hoboken, requiring the Sisters of the Protestant Episcopal House of Mercy in this city to bring into court Mrs. Randolph's fifteen-year-old child, Lizzie. The girl left her home in 1889, and was taken charge of by Mr. Gerry's society, which, with her mother's consent, placed her in the institution.

The fifth annual doll sale for the benefit of the Virginia, the Memorial, and the Jewell Day Nurseries was held yesterday morning and afternoon at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, and was both financially and socially a success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The plan which Senator Sherman suggests to the Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee of Ohio as the one most likely to lead to an investigation of the eligibility of Senator-elect Calvin S. Brice brings to mind the parallel case of Adelbert Ames, Senator from Mississippi from April 1, 1870, until he resigned in 1874.

Those of the Essays of Elia which treat of the drama and the art of acting form a continual source of pleasure to persons who are fond, in a sensible way, of the stage, and cherish memories of their own relating to it. One may turn to them again and again, when the Lamb mood is on him, and find their charm ever potent.

Judge Holmes of the Supreme Court has decided, in the case of Gertrude P. Sheifield against Horatio G. Parker and Francis J. Parker, that the defendants, executors of the estate of the late Judge Joel Parker, will not be allowed in their accounts as executors the sum of $10,000. expended in the purchase of stock in a mortgage company, which, since the purchase, has gone into liquidation.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 28. -- The Lake Shore was the scene of a serious run-in accident this evening on the Boston and Chicago special going East, which left Chicago at 10:30 A.M. On the edge of the city the road runs under the Miami and Erie Canal, through the tunnel some seventy-five feet long. Some 200 yards east of the tunnel is a target.

The orang outang of Lord MONBODDO was introduced into scientific circles by LAMARCK at the threshold of the century, and became much later a popular figure under CHARLES DARWIN. It may be recalled how THOMAS LOVE PEACOCK made him a "striking" character in fiction when he wrote "Melincourt" and described Sir Orang liaut-ton, the speechless, who obtained a baronetcy and a seat in Parliament notwithstanding his inability to articulate.

" Oh no, I assure you, you are not boring Mr. Marshfield," said this personage himself in his gentle voice -- that curious voice that could flow on for hours, promulgating profound and startling theories on every department of human knowledge or conducting paradoxical arguments without a single inflection or pause of hesitation.

Ask the average man what are the most conservative institutions in New-York, and he is very likely to tell you that the banks enjoy that distinction. On that supposition the Clearing House, which is merely an association of banks and other financial institutions, should be extremely conservative and suspicious of new things. There are some people, however, who think that it carries conservatism too far in one way at least.

HARTFORD, Nov. 28. -- The feature of the forthcoming report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in this State will relate to the benefit insurance associations which have organized branches in Connecticut, the intention being to present exact statistics in regard to these various orders. Those to be dealt with are not under the supervision of the Insurance Department.

The sun enters the sign of Capricornus on Dec. 21, and, astronomically speaking, Winter then begins. The sun then touches his furthest limit in southern declination, 23 degrees 27 minutes, the days are at their shortest, and from that time onward for a period of six months the shadows of night no longer encroach on the light of day.

Speaking generally, a university don abroad is a pitiable sight. He knows neither German nor Italian, and even when he professes to know French he has only to risk a few phrases in that language to show conclusively that he does not. In a few years he forgets his Greek entirely, and would mind it difficult to read an easy Latin book without a crib.

The real estate market showed its strength during the last week in two important sales that occurred Monday. About 350 lots of property were offered, and every lot was sold at prices quite satisfactory to the sellers and evidently pleasing to the buyers. The property came upon the market without reserve, the auctioneers being instructed to sell it for what it might bring.

The club field has been pretty well cultivated in New-York City, but there is just one spot which has not been worked. That particular spot is the possible opening for a university athletic club. Unless all signs fail, the long-existing want will be filled within a very few months. With athletic clubs New-York is, to be sure, well provided.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28. -- An enthusiastic fisherman who has just returned from the Ottawa district tells the following thrilling story of his experience with the Canadian wolf.

The suit of the Whisky Trust against the Live Stock Commissioners of Illinois has ended in a disagreement of the jury, but it is reported that the plaintiff will make another effort to punish the Commissioners for what appears to have been an attempt to prevent the sale of diseased cattle for the beef market in Chicago.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- It was expected that Sheriff Johnson would be accompanied to Justice Kennedy's court to-day by Supervisor Thomas J. Welch, a Democrat and one of the Onondaga Board of Canvassers. The Justice issued papers for contempt of court against Mr. Welch yesterday on account of his failure to bring the corrected election returns from the Third Ward into court, as ordered by the mandamus.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The opening hop at the Lakewood for the season was given this evening. Preparations for the event had been in progress for a number of days past. The grounds were illuminated with an artistic arrangement of Chinese lanterns, and presented a beautiful appearance. The dance was held in the assembly rooms of the hotel, which were exquisitely decorated with flowers and growing plants.

In an old book of records of Sharon Township, Medina County, Ohio, one of the flourishing counties of the Western Reserve, is found the following order given by officers who were styled "Overseers of the Poor." This is only a specimen, one of many of which include women as well as men:

NAGASAKI, Japan, Oct. 17. -- Another instance of the unjust annexation and subjugation of the native tribes in the East Indies by the Government of Great Britain has just come to light. For several years the policy of England seemed to tend toward the annexation of all the more important of the islands of the East Indies not colonized by Spain or Holland, without regard to the wishes of the natives.

A movement is on foot to curtail the railroad pass custom. It was started in Chicago by some very prominent Western railroad men, and a meeting to discuss the matter will be held in that city next Tuesday. The gentlemen who have taken the initiative in this movement have earnestly endeavored to interest the Eastern roads in their scheme.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- One of the largest syndicates ever formed for the importation of spruce timber from Canada for pulp mills has been formed by five of the largest pulp concerns in this State and Canada. A meeting was held in Toronto at the Mail office this week, when the preliminaries were arranged.

The big hall of the New-York Athletic Club was well filled last night by persons who watched with interest the progress of a series of spirited boxing contests. Well-known professionals took part in the contests, and some of the encounters elicited frequent outbursts of applause.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Prof. David P. Todd, director of the Amherst College Observatory, has much to say in regard to the observations made and conclusions reached concerning the recent eclipse of the moon. The professor received THE TIMES'S correspondent in the observatory, which crowns an elevation of the campus, and consented to give for publication some facts which will be of popular interest.

Some time has passed since the collapse of the Panama Canal Company and the termination of work on the isthmus, but the receiver or liquidator is still spending a comfortable sum of money in behalf of the bankrupt organization. The report submitted a few days ago shows that the expenses are $504,000 per annum.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- Boston's dearest charity, the Kindergarten for the Blind, is made the motive for the unique doll show that is now on exhibition in Tremont Street, one door south of the Tremont Theatre.

An illustrated edition of Dean Stanley's "Historical Memoirs of Westminster Abbey" appears opportunely with A.D.F. Randolph Co., for if Americans like nothing else in London they are certain to become ecstatic concerning the Abbey. The frontispiece of the second volume is a pen and ink of the Abbey taking in St. Margaret's, by Herbert Railton, a young English etcher who has been making a specialty of London views and London buildings for some years.

As a people the Southern mountaineers are not mercenary, and, whether fighting on the side of the Union or the side of secession, compensation was with them a secondary consideration. In the Union Army they were better fed and better clothed than they ever had been in times of peace, and this fact, coupled with their innate love of fighting, made many of them look upon the war as an undisguised blessing.

Ada Rehan has returned to us, and her spell is re-established. By one who is compelled to listen to the cackling, the growling, and the chatter of ordinary voices on the stage night after night, in these times when the art of vocal expression is sadly neglected, the charm of her speech is best appreciated.

LEXINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The combination sale of thoroughbred stock held at Treacy Wilson's stables here to-day by Tattersall's of New-York was a thorough success, the seventy-three animals disposed of fetching a total of $54,800, an average of $779. The average was pulled down by a lot of inferior stock that sold for prices running from $100 to $300.

Politicians of the David B. Hill type, who are themselves devoid of moral scruple, are incapable of judging of the force of the moral sense of the people as a factor in political action. A generation ago there was a sublime assertion of that force which produced a revolution in the fortunes of this Nation, and there have been many a time since spasmodic displays of it on a lesser scale.

Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co.'s failure pretty nearly monopolized the attention of Wall Street yesterday. There were all sorts of rumors afloat in the Street. That had been the case on the day before, but one day is not enough to use up the supply of reports about a smash-up such as that of the Washington Building bankers and brokers.
" A good many things have been said and proved showing that the census work of Mr. Porter is worthless," said Supervisor W.J.K. Kenny yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Clyde Fitch's preposterous farce, "Pamela's Prodigy," turns out to have worked havoc to much bigger and more tangible things than its author's reputation, Mrs. John Wood took it, against the earnest advice of her bright young partner, Arthur Chudleighs, and its condign failure created a state of affairs which broke up the partnership and lost the lease of the Court Theatre.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 28. -- The first University Bulletin of the year has just been published. It is a sixteen-page pamphlet brimful of information concerning all the departments of the college.

SHANGHAI, China, Oct. 21. -- Since matters are beginning to assume so critical a state in China with regard to the safety of foreign citizens and missionaries, the condition of the Chinese Army and Navy becomes a matter of interest.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Mrs. Alden Freeman of Munn Avenue gave a social and dance at her residence Saturday evening.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28. -- The young gentlemen in gray who represent Uncle Sam at West Point came down here to-day to play football with the midshipmen at the Naval Academy. They came in a special car, with the pet of the Third Cavalry, Lieut. Tate, at their head, and with a hundred other young officers to do their shouting.

Major McKinley, after a rest of about three weeks, left last night for his home in Canton, Ohio, where he will remain until he is called to Columbus to assume the office of Governor. He expects to devote his time from Monday until he is inaugurated to the preparation of his message.

The wish of Postmaster JOHNSON of Baltimore is reported to have uttered that lightning might strike Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT is a rather brutal and doubtless extravagant expression of a perfectly natural feeling on his part. He might have gone a little further and wished that Heaven had never created honest and able men to hunt down tricksters, spoilsmen, and Postmasters like himself.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 28. -- The progress of the primary elections in Louisiana for a Democratic State ticket, which embraces also the lottery amendment to the Constitution, indicates that Capt. Adams, the anti-lottery farmer candidate, will, after all, make a very respectable showing against ex-Gov. McEnery. A week ago the record of delegates elected stood: McEnery, 268; Adams, 113.

The Custom House officers had a good deal to say yesterday about the case of Mrs. Minnich whose trunks, containing a very valuable lot of dresses, were seized and then released on the payment of the duty in cash and the filing of a bond. It was in this case that "influence" is said to have played an important part.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The Thanksgiving Day business at the theatres was unprecedented, even for Chicago. The matinee performances drew out large audiences, which is seldom the case on holidays. At the Chicago Opera House, which led in the box-office receipts, "Sindbad" played to $1,400 at the matinee and $1,800 in the evening.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- W.H. Son traveled through the Western States for fifteen years. He was at the head of a large clothing establishment, with headquarters at Chicago, and was considered the best clothing salesman in this country. He assisted in the organization of the salesmen in the interest of Cleveland's election in 1888, and mustered 40,000 men at the Palmer Club, the Cleveland recruiting quarters of the Western metropolis.

An attempt was made yesterday to murder the Rev. Dr. John Hall, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. A poor, insane man fired three shots from a revolver at the famous Presbyterian clergyman at short range. All of the bullets went wide of the mark.

President D.I. Payles and the Board of Directors of the Smithtown and Port Jefferson Railroad Company will hold a meeting to consider a proposition of the Long Island Railroad Company to purchase the first-named road. If the purchase is made the great suit involving hundreds of thousands of dollars brought by the Long Island Railroad Company will be discontinued.

The testimony recently taken by a committee of the Chicago City Council in the course of an investigation concerning the expediency of limiting the height of buildings has encouraged those who oppose the erection of structures from sixteen to twenty stories high in that city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- With to-morrow will begin the ending of several "booms" for the Speakership. There will be five candidates in the city before night, and four of them will be fated for defeat.

Fifty-three young men, representing churches of every denomination in the city, met at 222 West Forty-third Street yesterday morning and organized an association to be known as the Young One Hundred Friends of New-York City. The association is to be an adjunct of the Union for Concerted Moral Effort. The membership will be limited to 100. The object of the association will be work in the slums of the city.
