The evident sympathy of THE TIMES, shown by Harold Frederic's articles, has emboldened me to ask your assistance in developing a plan for the benefit of the poor Russian Jews who have been forced to seek homes among us.

Our dispatches this morning from Nagasaki, Japan, and from Shanghai, China, confirm the impression we had received from previous advices that the recent disorders in the Chinese Empire were probably inspired by secret societies aiming at the overthrow of the Tartar dynasty. They also confirm the report that the Chinese Government is prepared to make liberal compensation for the losses to missionaries and missions and to punish the offenders where they can be found.

The conception we have of the French Revolution is accurate, for no social cataclysm has been more thoroughly discussed, and yet there are always novel incidents of the movement, perhaps more personal than general, that help to precise the outlines. M. Imbert de Saint-Amand does not enter into the lists with Taine or Thiers, Quinet or Lamartine, but, taking special men or women, he particularizes certain lines and brings out personal details.

It is a significant evidence of the change that has taken place in the temper and purpose of the Democratic Party that the leaders who are to-day insisting with most force and reasonableness that the tariff shall be the one objective of the party policy are from the South, where, beyond doubt, the silver question has attracted more attention than in any other part of the country.

MILAN, Tenn., Nov. 29. -- Mr. Lucien Barrow of Medina left his home two weeks ago to look after some land interests in Fayette County, to be gone only a few days. His family became uneasy at his continued absence, and Mr. Barrow's brother went in search of him, but returned without any clue. The affair remained a mystery until Friday, when the missing man returned to his home. He relates a thrilling experience.

The sixtieth Industrial Exposition of the American Institute closed Saturday night. A great crowd, estimated at about 7,000 persons, visited the Institute during the evening. The big fountain in the main building spurted and splashed merrily, the Whitehill-Corliss engine which has furnished the power for Machinery Hall ran smoothly and with a joyous hum, while the band up in the main balcony dispersed music over all.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The report of Secretary of the Interior Noble deals at length with the work of all the bureaus of his department. Among the most important subjects embraced are the following:

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Advices received here from Shanghai are to the effect that the rebel forces in Manchuria have defeated the imperial troops sent to suppress the rising in that region. The imperial forces numbered 4,000 men, and their defeat causes the Government the gravest anxiety.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- Bessie, the ten-year-old child of State Senator Graves of Missouri, has just undergone three difficult surgical operations in this city, all of which have been successful. The operations were on the ear, mouth, and right eye. Those on the ear and mouth were performed by Dr. D. Hayes Agnew and that on the eye by Prof. George E. Deschweinitz of the Polyclinic.

Reports in the Pittsburg Republican papers seem to leave no room for doubt as to a recent reduction of wages in the OLIVER ROBERTS wire factory, but some of our high-tariff contemporaries who rely upon Mr. J.W. JONES of Hutchinson, Kan., for all their news concerning reductions said to have been made will wait for advices from that gentleman before they say anything about the case.

If long and conspicuous party service counts for anything, Mr. Mills should certainly wield the gavel. As Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee he has been the leader of the House, and, next to Mr. Cleveland, he is the leading exponent of tariff reform. As the recent elections have made that the question for 1892, the country will naturally expect the election of Mr. Mills.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- The Press to-morrow will publish the following:

The examination into the affairs of the New-York Life Insurance Company, which has been in progress since June last, will, Deputy Superintendent Shannon says, be concluded by about the middle of December. The Insurance Department has had a large force of clerks at work in the office of the company and also at Albany, and another force is at work making appraisals and abstracts of titles.

In addition to raising the guaranteed value of the Brooklyn Handicap to $25,000 and giving a stake of the net value of $20,000 for two-year-olds -- the Great American Stake -- the Brooklyn Jockey Club has made the Fort Hamilton Handicap for three-year-olds a guaranteed stake of $10,000. This latter will be the most valuable handicap for horses three years old ever run for in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- There will be issued this week from the statistician's office of the Inter-State Commerce Commission the third annual report on the "Statistics of Railways in the United States." This report gives comprehensive statistics covering the operations of railways for the year ending June 30, 1890, and a statement of earnings from passenger and freight service, together with operating expenses and fixed charges for the nine months ended March 31, 1891.

It is not Mr. Howells's business to make what Grand Street or Division Street would call "a real pleasant novel." His inclination of late is to be morbid; he writes on cheerless topics, and in a saddened manner. You conclude "An Imperative Duty" with spirits which are depressed. You are conscious that the author wanted you to feel blue and chilly, and you are aware that he has succeeded.

One thing made clear by the last series of trials at Indian Head is that the resources of this country for turning out ship armor are equal to all demands likely to be made upon them. It was there found that the rolling process used by the Pittsburg works could yield plates capable of meeting the requirements imposed by the naval authorities.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- "You will be a delegate to the Minneapolis Convention next year!" was asked of Chris Magee of Pittsburg to-day.

Clad becomingly in black lace, with a large white chrysanthemum at her throat and the green seal ring of the dead high priestess on her finger, Mrs. Annie Besant, the distinguished English convert to Theosophy, lectured last evening at Chickering Hall on "Mme. Blavatsky and Reincarnation."

The Rev. R. Heber Newton spoke of James Russell Lowell, and the moral lesson to be derived from the life and writings of the poet and statesman at the service in All Soul's Church yesterday morning. There was a large congregation present.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- The results of last night's accident on the Lake Shore in this city have been more serious than at first feared. In addition to the two who were killed outright, five more have since died and several others cannot survive. The wounded also sustained more serious injuries than was supposed at the time.

A prominent feature of the current reports of the military establishment, from that of Secretary PROCTOR down, is their testimony to the improvement in the condition of the enlisted men. "At no period of its century of existence," says Adjt. Gen. KELTON, "has the army been better paid, better subsisted, or afforded more means of improvement and rational recreation than during the past year, or composed of more intelligent, cheerful, and contented men."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29. -- If appearances go for anything, the murder of Harm Ah Keong in the Chinese Theatre on Friday night will be avenged, and that in a very short time.

It is a curious indictment that Mr. W.J. STILLMAN has brought against journalism in the current number of the Atlantic. His general proposition that the practice of journalism tends to be fatal to excellence in literature would probably be disputed by very few journalists; but, on the other hand, we hope that there are not many who would concede the accuracy of his statement of the reasons why his proposition is true.
TRACY, Minn., Nov. 29. -- A large portion of the business part of this place is in ashes to-night from a disastrous fire which broke out on Front Street at 11 o'clock this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29. -- A letter from Melbourne says the Elder exploration expedition has arrived safely at Esperance Bay, Western Australia. The chief of the expedition, David Lindsay, F.R.G.S., reports that the country to the west of the South Australian border is grass-covered sand hills and sand plains, with a good many spiunifex, granite, and diorite hills in groups or isolated peaks, with a sandstone range and belt of desert gums.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 29. -- Bishop Phillips Brooks preached here three times to-day, twice in St. John's Chapel, and also at the evening service in the Williams College church. His remarks in the evening were on the subject of "service," and were directed to the students.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- A gentleman who is connected with the Hudson Democratic Society in Jersey City -- an organization that embraces the leading Democrats in the wicked county on the Hudson River front -- says that the drift of the Gubernatorial gossip among its members indicates a movement against Senator George T. Werts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Commodore Melville, Chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy. After detailing the work accomplished during the past fiscal year and the condition of the machinery of the vessels of the navy, the report touches upon the needs of the various navy yards.

The Church of the Covenant, Park Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, was crowded last night to hear the second of a series of Sunday night lectures on doctrinal subjects by the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs. The talk was on "The Light of Reason."
Our neighbors the Equitable are taking the roof off their building. Suppose some Asmodeus should lift the roof off the New-York Life. Whew!

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Mr. Balfour, in a political address at Huddersfield to-day, said that Ireland as an electoral cry was played out. The Liberal leaders appeared to be in doubt whether to play on home rule or the agricultural vote. Mr. Gladstone took one side and Sir William Vernon-Harcourt the other. This was a judicious arrangement, being planned so that, whatever turned up winning card, they could carry the game between them.

The real attitude of the Governor of the Credit Foncier toward the Panama Canal project is disclosed in his interview with the Paris correspondent of a London paper. An attempt has been made to induce the French Government to take up the abandoned work by means of an agreement of some kind with the Credit Foncier.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 30. Everything is now in readiness for the launching of the new Government cruiser New-York, which will take her initial plunge from the shipbuilding yards of Messrs. Cramp Sons Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- At the end of the first day of the last week of the contest for the Speakership, the election of Mr. Mills seems to be so well assured that the prospect of a serious opposition in the caucus is now smaller than it has been at any time since his candidacy was announced.

The German residents in Paris have taken offense at a notification sent out by the police that if they do not furnish the police with the information required by the law governing the registration of aliens they will be prosecuted for their neglect. It seems to us that the action of the police is entirely legitimate, and that the Germans have no cause of complaint.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- That so-called sterling Democrat and political adventurer, David B. Hill, continued his programme this afternoon for stealing a State Legislature. Having for six years defied the Legislature and usurped its prerogatives, it is not surprising now that Hill, at the close of his executive career, should attempt to meddle with the third fundamental branch of government and tread under foot the rights and privileges of the Judiciary of the State.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- In Bank Superintendent Preston's schedule of the assets of the Ulster County Savings Institution there is one item of "Secured loans, $10,200," which has given rise to a great deal of discussion. It has been claimed openly that this amount represented money loaned illegally on collateral not recognized by the statute as proper security.

MUNICH, Nov. 1. -- An innocent tourist impressed with the prominence of Germany as the great military power of Europe arrives after nightfall in Munich and begins by making a mistake. He sees a huge square attached to the Central Station laid with rails which contains wagons for the iron tracks and scores of great wains that look like the commissariat's part of an army.

Ex-President and Mrs. Cleveland and baby Ruth left the city yesterday afternoon for Lakewood, N.J., where they will probably be domiciled until Spring. They were accompanied only by some of the family servants. The trip was made over the Jersey Central Railroad, and upon arriving at Lakewood the Cleveland party was conveyed at once to Mr. Nathan Straus's cottage, which had been put in order expressly for the use of the ex-President's family.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Frederick S. Moore, one of the alleged election colonizers who was arrested on the charge of fraudulent registration in the First Ward, was to-day bound over to await the action of the Grand Jury. Waiter L. Hetfield, the "Big Six" candidate for Councilman in the First Ward, appeared as Moore's counsel and made a great effort to secure his discharge.

Morris M. Budlong, a well-known lawyer whose office was at 20 Nassau Street, went up to the District Attorney's office yesterday morning. He was sitting in Assistant District Attorney Wellman's room when he was taken suddenly ill. It was thought he had been seized with a stroke of paralysis and he was promptly carried to the Chambers Street Hospital, where he soon afterward died.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The actual charges made against Capt. Boileau and Capt. Butcher which led to their names being stricken from the army list are not as yet known, but the conjecture that they grew out of the retreat from Manipur is probably correct. The St. James's Gazette to-day publishes the following comment upon the sentence:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The three tariff cases involving the constitutionality of the McKinley Tariff act came up for argument in the United States Supreme Court this afternoon. All the Justices were present. Notwithstanding the great importance of the suits, only a small audience listened to the argument.

We give in another column a joint resolution as to the tariff which Mr. W.J. COOMBS of the Third District proposes to introduce in the House at its opening. It is worthy of careful attention, because Mr. COOMBS is thoroughly acquainted with the subject of his resolution. It will accomplish the object of its author in giving the Democratic members "something to talk about."

Although the consents received yesterday by the Rapid-Transit Commission were few in number, there were many inquiries by owners of property fronting on the lines of the proposed road as to the probable manner in which their property would be affected by the road, and Engineer Parsons and his assistants were kept busy answering questions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Public abuses spring up and grow so quietly, gradually, and naturally as to become monstrous and insufferable before they begin to attract attention, and even then there is a feeling that nobody is to blame, and, indeed, that whoever would lift a hand to reform or remove them is an invader of vested rights.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Several interviews were had to-day with leading English holders of Virginia bonds in regard to the latest plan for funding the State debt. All of them were bitterly opposed to the proposed plan of settlement.

NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 30. -- There has been a very lively jubilation among Norwich Republican high-tariff men and others in all parts of the country over the following paragraph that appeared about a week ago in the Norwich Evening Record:

DENVER, Col., Nov. 30. -- Over fifty more men were examined for jurors in the Graves murder trial to-day, and when the court adjourned to-night the jury had not been completed. It now looks as though it will take all of to-morrow and possibly Wednesday before this part of the work is done.
Ex-Senator Thomas M. Palmer of Michigan, President of the World's Fair Commission, was in this city yesterday. He left in the afternoon for Michigan.

A merry twist in November corn was the feature of trading on the Produce Exchange yesterday. The actual dealings were not heavy, amounting to only twenty-one boatloads, or 168,000 bushels, but the price was run up 14 cents a bushel in short order.

Mrs. William J. Leary of 39 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, the mother-in-law of Andrew W. Lenox, a traveling salesman of Martinez, Yabore Co. of this city, received the following telegram late Sunday night.

The points involved in the tariff cases now being argued before the Supreme Court are extremely interesting, not merely in themselves, but in the treatment they may receive at the hands of that august tribunal. Two or these points are really vital. One is that the bounties on sugar are unconstitutional, and that the provision for them vitiates the whole bill.

The little black walnut cage on the fifth floor of 146 Broadway which serves as the office and headquarters of the Grant Monument Association has not contained as many members of the association in months as it did yesterday, on the occasion of the special meeting to take action on the resignation of President William R. Grace from that office and from all further connection with the association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Justice Kennedy's court was filled to suffocation this afternoon with prominent politicians of both parties and members of the legal fraternity. The greatest interest centred in what the Justice would do concerning the absence of Thomas J. Welch with a part of the election returns from the Third Ward that disappeared with the missing Supervisor.

The Boxing and Wrestling Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union held a meeting in the Sporting Times office yesterday, and voted on the entries for the coming championship tournament to be held in the Metropolitan Opera House. The preliminaries will be held on Thursday of this week, and the finals will be decided on Saturday.

TROY, Nov. 30. -- Joseph H. Choate of New-York, Robert F. Wilkinson of Poughkeepsie, and Judge J. Ryder of Hudson came here this afternoon to make an ex-parte motion for an order requiring the Dutchess County Board of Canvassers to show cause why a mandamus shall not issue compelling them to reconvene and recount the vote.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 30. -- Railroad circles are considerably stirred up on account of a threatened rapture between the Board of Rulings and the Queen and Crescent and Louisville and Nashville systems. Ever since the inauguration of the boycott against the Chicago and Alton, the Louisville and Nashville and Queen and Crescent have maintained a neutral position, not paying commissions themselves, but accepting tickets issued by the Alton.

Among professional politicians Grover Cleveland is unpopular, perhaps the most unpopular of all the great men that have attracted public attention; but among the people he is indisputably the most popular man in the United States. Why there should be so great a difference of opinion between the people and their politically-accredited representatives is not difficult to explain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Navy Department has been informed of the arrival of the Yorktown at Sota, Chille, a coaling port a short distance from Valparaiso, and it is expected that she will take coal aboard and reach Valparaiso Harbor some time to-morrow.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 30. -- Probably if the Republican leaders of Iowa had been clear visioned enough to foresee the great grief that prohibition had in store for them, they never would have taken the bantling to their bosom and nursed it into that life and strength which has enabled it to destroy the party.

The following resolution relative to legislation for the reduction of customs duties will be offered in the House of Representatives at the opening of the session of Congress by William J. Coombs of Brooklyn, the Representative for the Third District:
Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Tiffany, surrounded by their children and grandchildren, celebrated the golden anniversary of their wedding last evening.

Mr. S.D. McCormick, a Southern lecturer of distinction, will deliver a free lecture, under the patronage of President Seth Low of Columbia College, Thomas G. Shearman, George William Curtis, Chauncey M. Depew, Hugh R. Gardon, Carl Schurz, Roger A. Pryor, R.W. Gilder, and others, at Columbia College, Room 11, Law Building, on Thursday evening, at 8 o'clock.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 30. -- During the last three months the fresh fish of Puget Sound have, for the first time, been put into the markets of New-York and Chicago. About 600,000 pounds of salmon and halibut, packed in refrigerator cars, have kept perfectly and sold well, and so, though the shipments thus far have been comparatively small, the success attained will lead to much larger shipments next season.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- The Republicans have suddenly began to realize that their prospects of controlling the Legislature are menaced, and for the first time are displaying signs of animation and resentment. Albany to-night is filled with lawyers. The most distinguished Republican counsel arrived at the Delavan House about 8 o'clock this evening in the person of Joseph H. Choate.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- In the case of George H. Tilden, respondent, vs. Andrew H. Green, et al., appellants, a motion for reargument was submitted in the Second Division, Court of Appeals, to-day. James C. Carter of counsel for appellants submitted a long brief, asking for a reargument. In it he says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- W.J. Pollock, the Superintendent of the free-delivery system, Post Office Department, has made his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1891. It shows that the number of free-delivery offices in operation at the close of the year was 519, an increase of 65 over the preceding year. The cost of this service was $9,072,060, which is $22,424 less than the appropriation for that purpose.

Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co.'s failure is now in the courts. Proceedings against the firm were begun yesterday by two creditors, one of whom secured orders of arrest for the members of the house, which has been wrecked as few houses have been on the checkered history of Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Mr. Wanamaker will begin, Dec. 15, the distribution of the big and little new postal cards. In preparation for the new issue, 50,000,000 of them have been sent to Chicago and St Louis, and the New-York office is well supplied.

Mr. Joseph Pennell, the artist who has just arrived in London none the worse for his arrest in Russia, is a much-maligned man. Truth says he "persisted in sketching and photographing after the police warned him to desist." But the police didn't warn him; they just arrested him. Some one else -- the Vienna correspondent of the Times, we think -- said he was advised by the British Consul.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 1. -- The People's Party State Central Committee to-day issued an address to the people of Kansas, in which the attempt is made to prove that during the past year material advancement was made in strength and numbers. The election returns are so manipulated as to produce the desired result, both the Democratic and Republican votes being successfully juggled.

Theodore M. Banta was born in the City of New-York, Nov. 23, 1834. He entered the College of the City of New-York at its opening in January, 1849, and completed a two-years' course, taking high honors for proficiency in mathematics. Immediately on leaving college he obtained employment in the shipping and commission business, in which he was occupied for several years, afterward holding for two years the position of accountant in a large importing house.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Those who go to Lakewood to find rest will probably find it there. Rest and pine trees are the stock in trade of this neat little Jersey village. As one man expressed it, one rests so vigorously in Lakewood and gets so tired when night comes, one sleeps as soundly and as long as a healthy baby.

W. Van Benthuysen yesterday gave to a TIMES reporter some interesting remarks on the subject of the recent issue of a telephone patent to Emile Berliner, in the course of which he urged that, under the decisions given in the various telephone cases, there is not even a shadow in the Berliner patent on which the Bell Company can rest a claim for a farther monopoly of the telephone business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Postmaster General to-day issued the following order, directing that all promotions of clerks in the fifty Post Offices now under the civil-service law and rules be made only after a competitive examination. This is, in effect, an extension of the system established for promotions in the Post Office Department in Washington July 1. 1891:

The Democratic State Committee adopted a very impudent resolution about the Governor of the State yesterday, and if the actual incumbent of the office were an honorable gentleman instead of a political blackguard he would administer a prompt and sharp rebuke. The resolution declared that "it would be detrimental to the best interest of the State and of the Democratic Party" for Gov. HILL to relinquish his office before the expiration of his term.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The Rev. Father Kirwan, the rector of St. Mary's Catholic Church at North Clinton and Main Streets, in East Orange, opposed the erection of the trolley wire poles for the new electric road from Newark to West Orange with a pistol this morning. Father Kirwan's congregation owns the corner. Last Summer a handsome rectory of brick was erected on one part of the lot.

The Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association discussed three important matters yesterday and failed to agree on any of them. A report was submitted by Commissioner Farmer showing the condition of the immigrant passenger traffic business. The facts showed that agents outside of the Trunk Line Association were getting altogether too large a proportion of the business to suit the trunk lines.

Mr. J. Seaver Page, Secretary of the Union League Club and a prominent merchant of this city, has discovered that the people of Chicago and the West are disposed to regard New-York as being inimical to the interests and success of the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Acting Rear Admiral Walker, who has been in Washington for some days, does not like the idea of going to the South Atlantic with his squadron, consisting of the Chicago, Atlanta, and Bennington, and the plans of the Navy Department for the South Atlantic station may be all disarranged again.

Rapid progress was made yesterday in the trial of Michael J. Gallivan for killing James Cummings in the former's livery stable, at 121 West Forty-fifth Street, Christmas Day, 1890, before Recorder Smyth and a jury, in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions. The jury was completed, the prosecution put in all its evidence, and the defense a large part of its testimony.

The management of life insurance companies should be honest and should give a strict account of every dollar received. The officers should be given good salaries, but no commission should be given them under any circumstances; that they should not be allowed to borrow from the funds of the office is a proposition too apparent to require either discussion or elaboration.

The plan sketched in our news columns by Mr. J. SEAVER PAGE for testifying the interest of New-York in the World's Fair at Chicago may have a partial success. It would be practicable to assemble a large number of distinguished and influential persons to eat their dinners at Delmonico's under the presidency of Mr. DEPEW.

SPRINGFIELD,Mass., Dec. 1. -- A horrible double tragedy was enacted at the Hotel Warwick either last evening or early this morning. George E. Barr, proprietor of the hotel, it is thought, shot and killed his wife and then took his own life.

Prof. Tyndall's profound knowledge, with his calm and impartial judgment, renders an article of his in the September number of the Fortnightly Review, entitled "On the Origin, Propagation, and Prevention of Phthisis," worthy of particular attention. Somewhat extended in form, the following sypopsis, it is believed, will present the salient facts:

It is several years since an exhibition of the bronzes and water colors of A.L. Barye, the French sculptor, was held at the American Art Galleries. This loan exhibition of Barye bronzes, reinforced by a superb exhibit of paintings by French artists, was given by the American Branch of the Barye Monument Association, of which Mr. W.T. Walters of Baltimore was President and Mr. Cyrus J. Lawrence of New-York the Treasurer.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- In the Divorce Division of Her Majesty's High Court of Justice, before Mr. Justice Butt, there was commenced to-day a case which has excited much comment, particularly in the higher walks of English life. This case is the application of Countess Russell for a judicial separation from her husband, Earl Russell, the grandson of the great Lord John Russell, on the ground of cruelty.

There was a crash on the Hudson River Railroad at Tarrytown yesterday. The Croton local train, which left the Grand Central Station at 5:40 P.M. with Conductor Edwards, ran up all right until it reached Dobbs Ferry, when it got behind a freight train, and from there for some distance north had to run very slowly, and consequently lost much time.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- The final arrangements for the launching of the new armored cruiser New-York have been completed, and at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon the blocks holding the vessel will be knocked away. Then the largest Government cruiser ever built in America will take her natal plunge into the waters of the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day continued the hearing of the three suits brought by New-York and Chicago importers to test the constitutionality of the McKinley Tariff act.

A fire occurred early yesterday morning on the third floor of the five-story building at 28 College Place, occupied by Siebel Richter and P.J. Handel. dealers in crockery, whose stock was damaged to the amount of $800. A. D. Gwinner, dealer in lamps, sustained a los of $300.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 1. -- A petition signed by 500 business men in Danbury has been received by the Grand Army authorities in this State asking that the twenty-fifth annual encampment of the Connecticut department in January be held in that city.

Complaints were received by the Board of Police yesterday of the obstructions to the sidewalk on the north side of Warren Street from Washington to West Street, caused by the produce dealers in the neighborhood making the street a storage plays for boxes, barrels, and crates. Complaints were also made of the nuisance created by peddlers and vendors of all sorts of merchandise crowding the sidewalks in Park Place, from Broadway to College Place.
HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 1. -- Another official who had the handling of his employer's money and who went wrong with it will return to the United States from this city under extradition proceedings.

The more the affairs of the firm of FIELD, LINDLEY, WIECHERS Co. are investigated the more astonishing is the result. The one man who could tell what has become of the money is reported to be in a condition of health that renders it impossible to question him. But it is because men are liable to attacks of illness and fallible in memory that the art of bookkeeping has been invented.

There is a small valley in the northwestern portion of the northwestern State of our Union, Washington, named Skagit. This valley, including the valleys and divides and highlands tributary to it, contains about 5,500 square miles. It thrusts a broad, long, and exceedingly fertile hand northward across the boundary between British Columbia and Washington, and the fingers of this hand terminate on the southern slope of the Frazer River divide.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- Speaking of the decisions in the elevated railroad cases to-day, Chief Justice Ruger of the Court of Appeals said that he thought they finished up the litigations over the rights of the elevated roads. "We have now passed upon all the questions that could be raised," he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Bush changes as have occurred during the last twenty-four hours in the Speakership fight have been caused by expediency and through a lack of that courage and discernment for the want of which Gen. Grant has made the Democrats unfavorably famous.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 1. -- The union Job printers of this town have for the past two months been on a strike for a shorter day and better pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Commodore Theodore Wilson, Chief of the Bureau of Construction, in his annual report recommends that the Galena, (wrecked on Gay Head and afterward recovered,) the tug Speedwell, and the Intrepid be sold, as they are useless to the Government and a source of expense.

We publish this morning a very interesting statement in which Mr. W. VAN BENTHUYSEN, who is familiar with the long history of litigation concerning telephone patents, sets forth the grounds for his opinion that the Bell Company will not be able to extend the term of its monopoly by means of the patent recently granted to BERLINER.

This is the very striking title chosen by Lieut. ALLEN R. FOOTE for an article in the December Forum, embodying the "Protest of Loyal Volunteers" against the present system, or rather the present scheme, of pensions. Lieut. FOOTE entered the Union Army as a volunteer in 1861 and was under fire at a skirmish three days before the battle of Bull Run.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- There was a great gathering of lawyers in Circuit Court here to-day. Those who attracted the most attention wore Joseph H. Choate of New-York, R.F. Wilkinson of Poughkeepsie, Judge Cady of Hudson, and Matthew Hale of Albany, who were present to make motions in the Dutchess and Steuben Counties Senatorial cases.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1. -- A bold and successful train robbery took place on the St. Louis and San Francisco Road, near Glendale Station, about ten miles from this city, shortly before 10 o'clock last night. The robbers had their plans well laid, and they escaped with money and valuables amounting, perhaps, to $20,000, possibly more.

MIDDLETON, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- A telegram from Officers Vail and Barrett of the Middletown police force, dated at the Addison (N.Y.) station of the Erie Road at 1 o'clock, states that they have Frederick McGuire and Mrs. Brown, the alleged murderers of Mrs. Amelia J. Gregory, in custody there and will reach this city with their prisoners to-morrow morning.

A company of well-known gentlemen met at Sherry's last evening to honor Artist Frank B. Carpenter and to obtain a view of his latest picture, "International Arbitration." The picture is interesting outside of its artistic merit from the fact that it is to hang in the hall of Windsor Castle, Queen Victoria having accepted it as a gift from the American people.

Many hundreds of Brooklyn's prominent people returned to their homes from the Academy of Music in that city last night serene in the consciousness of duty well performed in the promoting of a noble charity and of having witnessed what was beyond question the most brilliant and successful spectacle, artistic and social, known in the annals of the City of Churches.

The 8,150-ton armored cruiser New-York, which is to be launched to-day at Philadelphia, is much larger than any American war ship yet set afloat, and larger, too, than any yet planned, except the three big belted cruisers Indiana, Massachusetts, and Oregon. What distinguishes her is a happy combination of speed, coal endurance, and fighting power.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- The color question is again agitated in Grand Army circles here. Some weeks ago Col. James Lewis, Commander of Post No. 14, wrote to Commander in Chief Palmer requesting the issue of orders to the Department Commander for the recognition of the colored posts. His reply was that the Commander in Chief had decided that these posts must be recognized by the officers of the Department of Louisiana and Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Commodore Wilson, in his annual report as Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair, dwells at length on the importance of the New-York Navy Yard and the necessity of having it fully equipped with the most modern machinery and ready for any emergency. He says:

The United States cruiser Newark, Capt. Silas Casey commanding, sailed from this port yesterday for York River, Va., where she will fall in with the Bennington and Atlanta. These two vessels are engaged in extended work in small-arm target-firing. The Newark was recently called upon to send a part of her South Atlantic charts to the Bennington, and the remainder ashore.

The members of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association are indignant at the action of the Amateur Athletic Union taken in regard to the prizes that are to be offered at the games to be held in the armory Saturday night. Several prominent members of the regiment said yesterday that they would pay no heed to the order of the union, but would go ahead and make a test case of the matter.

Capt. John H. Leo, master of the American schooner William H. Bradley, which foundered off Cape Charles in a cyclone Oct. 10, who arrived on the steamship Orizaba from Havana Monday night, came up to the city yesterday. To a TIMES reporter he told the story of his shipwreck and subsequent experiences more fully than they were related in THE TIMES of yesterday.

There was another fight in the Board of Aldermen yesterday over the effort of several of its members to do away with the danger to persons living in Eleventh Avenue resulting from the tracks of the New-York Central Railroad below Sixtieth Street. Alderman Morgan, as Chairman of the Railroad Committee, submitted an adverse report on the proposed resolution which provided that the tracks should be fenced in.

The Railroad Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, consisting of Chairman Coffey and Alderman McGarry, McGrath, Thomas, and Wafer, gave another hearing in the Common Council room yesterday on the application from the local surface railroads for permission to substitute the trolley system for horses as a motive power.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 1. -- The news to-day from Oliver Springs that negro miners have been forced by white miners to leave that place, and that nearly all of the men employed by the Cumberland Coal Company have struck because the company had caused the arrest of some of the men who intimidated the negroes, strengthened the belief that serious trouble may be looked for when the State sends the convicts back to the mines.

The Manhattan Electric Light Company and all of the Directors of the Harlem Electric Lighting Company who voted for a resolution setting aside $200,000 of the bonds of the latter company to secure a judgment that had been entered against it in favor of the former were yesterday declared by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court to be in contempt of court unless the resolution was rescinded and the bonds restored.

ROME, Dec. 1. -- In the discussion on the budget in the Chamber of Deputies, to-day, Signor Luzzati, Minister of the Treasury, said that the Government had set itself to remedy the defects of previous budgets. Excessive expenditures and overestimation of receipts had caused the budget for 1891 to show a deficit of 1,000,000 lire, which the new economies and financial measures would amply cover.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 1. -- The report of Prof. T. Mendenhall, Chief of the United States Geodetio and Coast Survey, concerning the Indiana-Ohio boundary line, was made to Gov. Chase this morning. It is a duplicate of that made to Gov. Campbell at Columbus yesterday. Ohio has disputed the correctness of the Indiana line, claiming that it was too far east at the northern extremity of the State.

There is every reason now to believe that convicted murderer will be put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing next week. Martin D. Loppy, convicted of the murder of his wife, is sentenced to die in the week beginning Dec. 6. The intervention of Gov. Hill is the only thing that stands between him and the penalty of his crime.

The strangest chapter in the history of the failure of Field. Lindley, Wiechers Co. is to be told this morning. It adds to the allegations made against Edward M. Field charges that, in the last hours before the crash, he raided the strong box in which his father, Cyrus W. Field, kept his securities and left it empty of valuables.

The Census Bureau has recently issued a preliminary statement concerning the cotton industry. The Bureau does not assert that this statement is accurate and complete, but takes the precaution to say that it is put out "subject to correction." There are indications that corrections of very considerable importance will be required.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The Pullman Palace Car Company is after some of the rich drawbacks heretofore chiefly enjoyed by the importers of tin plate. A section of the McKinley law provides that if imported goods are made into any manufactured article and sent abroad the duties on the imported goods shall be all refunded except 1 per cent.

William F. Sheehan of Buffalo, Lieutenant Governor-elect, was yesterday chosen by the Democratic State Committee as the successor to Hermann Oelrichs as New-York State's member on the Democratic National Committee. The selection was a surprise. Many of the members did not know who they were going to vote for when they gathered at the Hoffman House at 10 o'clock.

The new building for the Home of Industry and Refuge for Discharged Convicts, on Sixty-third Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, which was to have been thrown open yesterday, will not be completed until about the 14th or 21st of this month.

As the time draws near for Superintendent Pierce to complete and make public his report on the condition of the New-York Life, the anxious policy holders who have long been waiting for some conclusive outcome of the affair are turning their attention particularly toward Mr. Beers and the date of his withdrawal from the company.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 1. -- This city has a kidnapping sensation, different in some respects from the Beals case in Kansas City. Little Anna Brewer has disappeared, leaving no trace.

William Barthman, whose appointment as a member of the Brooklyn Board of Education by Mayor Chapin has caused so much scandal during the past month, decided yesterday to appeal to the courts to force his way into the board. He tried to take his seat yesterday, but was practically refused admission in that his credentials were laid on the table.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 1. -- In Justice Kennedy's court this afternoon the mandamus against the Board of Canvassers of Onondaga County came up for a hearing and an explanation as to the missing election returns from the Third Ward of Syracuse. It was known that the returns had been sent back from Albany, but where they were was a matter of conjecture on the part of the board.

A number of ladies met yesterday afternoon at the house of Mrs. Ralph Trautmann, First Vice President of the Board of Lady Managers of the Columbian Exposition, for the purpose of listening to an informal talk from Mrs. Potter Palmer, the President of the board, who came from Chicago few days ago. Among other things she said:

It was reported yesterday that arrangements had been completed for the transfer to an English syndicate of the five milk-condensing factories at Carpentersville, Ill., and at Brewster, Wassaic, and Walden, N.Y., which have been owned by the Borden and Millbank families for over twenty-five years.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- A TIMES correspondent called upon Nathaniel C. Moak to-day and asked him his view of Francis C. Barlow's remarkable opinion as to the course of a court to compel the sending back of returns to Inspectors to compel them to make returns according to the ballots themselves. Mr. Moak said:

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 2. -- It was learned here to-day that J.M. Benson, Treasurer of Bladen County, had absconded with $6,000 of the county's money. Benson has for several years held the position of Treasurer of his county, and for the past two years has been largely engaged in the mercantile business at Elizabethtown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The forthcoming report of E.S. Lacey, Controller of the Currency, gives full information in relation to the organization, supervision, and liquidation of national banks during the year ended Oct. 31, 1891. Among the statements made are the following:

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- A terrific dynamite explosion occurred at 2 o'clock to-day at Haverstraw at the Clinton Dynamite Works, near the north entrance to the West Shore tunnel. How it happened cannot yet be told, but throughout Haverstraw, Congers City, Nyack, Rockland Lake, and other places within twelve miles windows were broken and people were much startled.

That ex-Police Justice Jacob M. Patterson is sitting on a tottering throne as the nominal boss of the Republican machine in this city -- by permission of T.C. Platt, of course -- is becoming more evident every day. The chances are that, by the time the County Committee's new Executive Committee is ready to organize, Mr. Patterson will have hard work to get back as the Executive Chairman.

Yesterday was another busy time for the seven members of the National Trotting Association constituting the Board of Review, and the parlors occupied by this turf tribunal at the Murray Hill Hotel were thronged from the opening at 10 o'clock.

DENVER. Col., Dec. 2. -- The task of selecting a jury for the trial of the celebrated Graves murder case occupied the attention of Judge Bentley and the lawyers all day yesterday and to-day, and the end is not yet.

The Hoboken police were asked to solve mystery yesterday. It centered around the death at St. Mary's Hospital in that city Tuesday night of an unknown man. At noon of Tuesday a boy rang the bell at the hospital gates. When the sister answered the ring, he pointed to a covered wagon that stood at the door, and said that he had a wounded man there who needed treatment.

John McGlenzey, Chairman of the Employing Plumbers' Association, appeared before the Committee on Building Laws at the Mutual Life Building yesterday and submitted his views with regard to the importance of wire lathing in building. Neither the present law nor the bill framed by the committee contains any allusion to this subject.

A motion was made before Judge McGown in the City Court yesterday morning by David May of the firm of Howe Hummel for a new trial of the suit of Julia E. Hetsch against T. Brigham Bishop of bucket shop notoriety. Bishop received in trust from Mr. Hetsch, a printer, $2,000, which he converted, and for the recovery of which judgment was granted Mrs. Hetsch to whom Mr. Hetsch had reverted the claim.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Treasurer E.H. Nebeker has submitted his annual report to Secretary Foster. Its features are as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- The new armored cruiser New-York was launched to-day amid the applause of 40,000 people. The new daughter of the Empire State, the largest and most powerful craft in the United States Navy, took the water this afternoon at 2:40 o'clock. She glided down the long inclined ways, hesitated, then plunged into the blue waters, and, with a long, graceful sweep, floated far out into the middle of the Delaware.

The disclosures of THE NEW-YORK TIMES relating to the New-York Life Insurance Company, apart from their specific purpose, have had the excellent effect to cause the public to treat insurance business with more circumspection than heretofore.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 2. -- Connecticut sportsmen have had fine luck lately. Partridges have been scarce all the season on account of bad weather in the Spring, which, it is believed, destroyed the young birds in great numbers, but quail have been unusually abundant, and both the early and late flight of woodcock were large. Gray squirrels are few.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 2. -- For the first time since 1853, and for the second time in the history of the city, the Democrats elected their candidate for Mayor to-day. The campaign was one of the most exciting ever witnessed in this vicinity, there being five candidates in the field. Two elections were necessary to decide the result, as under the statutes a majority vote is required to elect.

The proposition made to the State Board of Canvassers by the counsel of Republican Senators-elect whose seats are threatened by GOV. HILL'S burglarious operations is to the last degree fair and candid. It is merely an offer to submit all disputed questions to judicial decision, both parties uniting to secure the final and controlling decision from the Court of Appeals at the earliest possible moment.

The project of establishing an inland or protected route along the Atlantic and the Gulf for our smaller war vessels, and also for the use of our coastwise merchant marine in case of war, has been revived by the taking of soundings for this purpose during the past season. It is not a new project, having attracted considerable attention several years ago, when Congress authorized a preliminary investigation of it.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 2. -- Gen. Black, Pension Commissioner under Cleveland, and Gen. Winston, ex-Minister to Persia, stopped here a few hours to-day waiting for a train to take them to Washington. Both are ardent supporters of Congressman Springer, whose election they think would be a happy solution of the determined fight between the friends of Congressmen Mills and Crisp.

An accident occurred on the New-York and Harlem Railroad at One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street and Railroad Avenue at 5:25 last night which was remarkable from the fact that, while a carload of passengers were overturned without serious result to any, two men who were walking along the track at the time were killed.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- Pursuant to the call of Secretary of State Frank Rice, the State Board of Canvassers met to-day at 11 o'clock, and within half an hour every member was convinced that, so far as canvassing any returns was concerned, the board's hands were tied.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- A question of civil rights was decided by Police Justice Woodman this morning, and while the city won a victory technically, in reality it has suffered a decided defeat.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 2. -- The wooden steamship John G. Christopher was successfully launched this afternoon at the yard of the Jackson Sharp Company, in this city, in the presence of a large number of spectators. As the vessel glided into the water the christening was performed by Mrs. John G. Christopher, who broke a bottle of wine over the bow.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- It was announced this evening that President Patton had received a letter from Mr. Isaac Brokaw of New-York City, father of Frederick Brokaw, who lost his life at Long Branch last Summer in a heroic act, trying to save a drowning girl, stating that he fully appreciated the steps which had been taken by the college in the direction of a memorial to the heroism of his son.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The interest in the suit of Countess Russell against Earl Russell for a judicial separation was shown to-day by the crowding again of the courtroom of the Divorce Court. Immediately upon the opening of the court the Countess resumed her place in the witness box and Sir Charles Russell took up his cross-examination at the point where it was broken off yesterday by the adjournment of the court.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 2. -- President William Weihe of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, an organization which has a membership of 35,000 skilled workers, is the least talkative of labor leaders hereabout. Today he broke his rule, however, and said in reply to questioning:

Private Roderick R. Schneider, Company A, First Artillery, United States Army, born at Chemnitz, Saxony, died of starvation at Cape Sabine June 18, 1884. That is a simple record, but in the one word starvation there is a story of Private Schneider's part in the Greely expedition and its privations and sufferings. His story, written by himself, is told in whole for the first time to-day.

CARROLLTON, Ky., Dec. 2. -- An Enoch Arden romance with a somewhat different termination has just leaked out here. The parties to it are colored. Nearly fifty years ago Samantha and Alex Richards were married somewhere in Virginia. A year or two later Alex was sold by his master, Judge John Richards, and taken to Natchez, Miss. After the war he drifted North, and finally settled at Parkersburg, West Va.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 2. -- The annual report of Factory Inspector William S. Simmons, which was filed with the State authorities yesterday, shows that 435 factories were inspected during the year ending Nov. 1. Of this number 235 had been previously visited by the Inspector. The number of operatives employed in factories inspected was 55,922. In 193 factories no changes were ordered.

We are persuaded that if the various gentlemen who are making a struggle for the Speakership of the House of Representatives against Mr. MILLS could clearly see what is the feeling of the mass of intelligent supporters of their party, they would also see that the gratification of the ambition of any one of them by an election would be very dearly purchased.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Peter C. Kellogg Co.'s sale of trotting bred stock was concluded here to-day, the sale aggregating $37,105. The sale yesterday amounted to $16,880, making a total for the two days of $53,085. Prices ruled low throughout, even for the best bred ones in the lot. The animals sold to-day that brought over $500 were as follows:

We can hardly believe that the expectation of the French press of a Papal rebuke to those Bishops that are just now scolding at the Government is well founded. If the Bishops are checked at all, it will be privately, but the chances are that they will be allowed to fume until they are cooled off.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Mr. D'Oyly Carte, whose attempt to establish genuine national opera at the Royal English Opera House resulted recently in a heavy financial loss, compelling him to dismiss the singers he had engaged and to close the theatre, is about to make another effort to retrieve his fortune.

At yesterday's session of the Board of Education the proposition to increase the salaries of janitors, which had long been before the board, was adopted unanimously. It was said that the average addition would amount to $120 per year, and would increase the budget next year by about $17,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 2. -- There is a suspicion that efforts are being made by supporters of Gov. Hill for the Presidency to influence the Democracy of Western Pennsylvania, which has all along been unmistakably for the renomination of ex-President Cleveland.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 2. -- Before Judge Douglas this morning, in the Supreme Court, was tried the suit of Robert E. Carbrey against Edwin Longnecker. The plaintiff's story was that, Sept. 30, 1889, an official order was received from the bureau directing Commander Higginson to discharge Carbrey, who at that time was enlisted as a landsman, if he so desired.

When the hungry place hunters of the Republican ward associations in Brooklyn came to lay their charges against Secretary TRACY before the Executive Committee of the county they were surprised to hear from Naval Officer WILLIS and Mr. W.W. GOODRICH that they were making fools of themselves and openly contradicting the repeated professions of the party as to civil service reform.

" Two mild scandals which wore threatened about the recent horse show have blown over," the New-York correspondent of the Philadelphia Times said in that paper yesterday in his New-York gossip. Following this was a story that while the net profits of the horse show, recently held at Madison Square Garden, had been $50,000, less than $25,000 was turned into the treasury of the Horse Show Association.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- People who got receipts in Armour's Elevators to-day on delivery were astonished to find on application to the different insurance companies that policies could not be obtained. The insurance men claimed that their risks were all full and that they could write no more on the house.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 2. -- The order issued yesterday by Judge Edwards of Troy for the Dutchess County Board of Canvassers to show cause why a writ of mandamus should not be issued in the matter of returns on Senator was served on Chairman Howatt and Clerk Hoffman of the board to-day. The one served upon Howatt was handed him at his home, Hyde Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- In twenty-four hours the Speakership contest, which has been hotter to-day than on any day since it began, will probably be over. The caucus will still remain, but the preparation for it will have been completed.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 2. -- There is a movement on foot to consolidate the three provinces of Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, and New-Brunswick into one province of the Dominion. If the proposals are carried out, two Lieutenant Governors, two Provincial Legislatures, and two Legislative Councils will be abolished, together with other expensive machinery of government. It would result in the saving of at least $500,000 annually.

The revelations which have been made in the last two days of the crooked work of Edward M. Field have by no means ended the story of the failure of Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co. His own friends are among those who admit that there is yet much to be brought to light, although they insist that they have no idea what will be revealed.

The publication in yesterday's TIMES of numerous quotations from the New-York Life Insurance Company's reports for the last ten years, showing irrefutable proofs of President Beers's gross mismanagement of that company, went a long way toward satisfying the policy holders as to the probable outcome of Superintendent Pierce's report of the condition of the management of that company.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 2. -- Gov. McKinney's message was presented to the Legislature today. It advises against hasty legislation, and calls attention to the fact that the usual State officers and a United States Senator are to be elected and a reapportionment of the State is to be made in the course of the current month.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Fred McGuire and Mrs. Sarah A. Brown, the alleged murderers of Mrs. Amelia J. Gregory, arrived here by the Erie Railroad at 6 o'clock this morning, in custody of Officers Vail and Barrett. Justice John Wiggins opened his court for a hearing a 9 o'clock. Assistant District Attorney A.D.N. Powelson appeared for the people and Theron A. Reade of this city for the prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- A disastrous collision occurred between two merchant vessels, a steamer and a schooner, in Delaware Bay last night. Fortunately no lives were lost, but the schooner sunk and the steamer was damaged considerably.

Yonkers is very much excited over the adventure that befell young Harold Jaffray, the fourteen-year-old son of J. Hamilton Jaffray, one of the wealthy citizens of the city, in his father's house on Tuesday evening. Mr. Jaffray's residence is at the corner of North Broadway and Lamartine Avenue. His wife and three sons, of whom Harold is the youngest, live with him. Harold is a very delicate child.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 2. -- The Jersey City, Newark and Western Branch of the Lehigh Valley Railway Company was defeated in its street-usurping scheme in Bayonne, N.J., by the City Council Tuesday night. The company built a stone wall across Avenue B near the Morris Canal last Summer to lay its tracks upon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The University Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs gave their first concert of the year this evening in Taylor's Opera House, Trenton, N.J. All the members of the Glee Club were in good voice and rendered the selections in old-time college style, carrying the many alumni who heard them back to the time when, as seniors, they sang the familiar college glees on the steps of old Nassau Hall.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- The Young Men's Democratic Club of Canton, one of the most influential political organizations in Ohio, celebrated with a banquet to-night the fourth anniversary of Grover Cleveland's tariff reform message. The banquet was held at Bast Hall, which was beautifully decorated. Covers were laid for 400. W.A. Lynch was toastmaster.

To-morrow Cruiser No. 9, building at the yards of the Columbian Iron Works, Baltimore, Md., will be launched and named the Mobile. The new vessel will form still another addition to the gradually-increasing navy list of the United States.

UTICA, Dec. 8. -- To the list of protected industries which have reduced the wages of their workingmen the New-York Mills Cotton Company must now be added. The President of the concern is W. Stuart Walcott and the Treasurer is Samuel R. Campbell. Both are ardent and active Republican politicians and, of course, devout disciples of McKinleyism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3. -- Mining stock brokers here are complaining at the effect of the Hale and Norcross suit on their business. The public refuses to come into their offices and sink money when the inside workings of the mining and milling companies are given away in court.

A call went out yesterday morning for a meeting of the anti-grab Citizens' Executive Committee, to be held this afternoon. This is merely a formal matter, for members of the committee practically agreed to a meeting nearly a fortnight ago. While definite conclusions may not be reached, the meeting will be as important as any yet held by the committee.
The trial of Michael Gallivan for killing James Cummings at the Excelsior Stables on West Forty-fifth Street on Christmas Day was concluded yesterday before Recorder Smyth and a jury.

It behooves the express companies to take very energetic steps toward stopping the train robberies that have been more frequent during the past few months than ever before in the history of the country. At present, treasure is no safer on the through lines that traverse the most populous parts of the United States than it used to be on the overland stage coaches passing through a wilderness.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 3. -- Mr. Hume, the husband of Charlotte Behrens of the Robert Mantell theatrical company, who was reported to have left New-York with the avowed intention of taking Mr. Mantell's life, has not arrived. At least he has not made his presence known. Mr. Hume was earnestly hunted for in Pittsburg to-day, but could not be found.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Theodore Hoffman, County Clerk of Dutchess County, received a notice from Gov. Hill to-day that charges had been preferred against him for misconduct in office. The charges were made in this city by Lewis Germond, the Democratic Chairman of the Board of Supervisors, and were put in shape by the Democratic attorney of the board.

Tens of thousands of handsomely-engraved Christmas souvenirs, costing extravagant sums, are being distributed broadcast over the land nowadays by venerable President Beers of the New-York Life Insurance Company, in the hope that by such means his fallen fortunes may be bolstered up to withstand the probable blow that threatens to come from the Insurance Department at Albany.

Having on Sunday notified Major-Gen. Josiah Porter, Adjutant General of the State of New-York, that he was to be reappointed, Governor-elect Flower on Monday caused notices to be sent to the several members of the General Staff of the Commander in Chief, or what is popularly known as the "military family" of the Governor, informing each of them that he would succeed himself.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 3. -- The Judges of the Supreme Court will meet in New-Haven on Saturday for consultation in the quo warranto case. Judge Carpenter of this city, who has been suffering from a malignant attack of neuritis in the left arm, will be able to take part in the conference. It is not expected that a decision will be reached on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- First Assistant Postmaster General Whitfield stated to-day that the needs of the New-York Post Office in the matter of additional clerk hire and allowances, which have been under consideration for some time, have been adjusted by him on the recommendation of the Chief of the Salary and Allowance Division, who personally visited New-York to confer with Mr. Van Cott.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The marriage of Miss Jane Frances Pendleton, daughter of the late Minister to Germany, to Arthur Tilghman Brice of Riggs's Bank took place at noon to-day at St. John's Church. The Rev. Dr. Douglass officiated. The only decorations in the church were La France roses, which filled the gold vases on the high altar at the rear of the chancel.

" La Dame de Challant" is a play with an atmosphere and a background. Its story, if told briefly in narrative, would seem to be intensely romantic. It is, indeed, only a new telling of the old tale of love and hate, intrigue and lust, beginning with laughter and merrymaking, ending with the headsman's block.

The feebleness of the measures hitherto taken by the Imperial authorities in China against what now appears to be the most serious uprising since the Tae-Ping rebellion is manifest, Nor can it be wholly accounted for by the fact that the insurrection has hitherto had its run in the dependencies -- in Manchooria and Mongolia -- and not in China proper.

It is a significant indication of the inefficiency of the Board of Education as at present organized, that there should be occasion for the wholesale consolidation and abolition of schools recommended at Wednesdays meeting by Superintendent JASPER. Every one of these cases should have received the attention of the board long ago.

ELIZABETH, Dec. 3. -- In the United States Circuit Court of Appeals a decision which, it is said, establishes a precedent has just been rendered in the case of the National State Bank of Elizabeth against Waldo Danforth and Sheriff Seth B. Ryder of Union County, executors of the estate of the late Edward G. Brown. The latter was a prominent citizen here, and one of the chief bride builders in New-Jersey.

C.L. Meshler and James Livengood, general agents of the New-York Life with headquarters at Lincoln, Neb., are not only misrepresenting facts, but are going at so fast a rate that even the story of mismanagement that you publish in your daily cannot keep pace with them.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- The legislative tangle presented several new and interesting features to-day. When the Board of Canvassers finished its fifteen-minute session, every one, Republican and Democrat alike, seemed to think that both sides were sincerely desirous of submitting the questions in dispute for adjudication to the Court of Appeals.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 3. -- The third meeting of the Sea Island Cotton Planters' Protective Union was held yesterday at James Island, two miles from Charleston. The subject discussed was the present poor price for Sea Island cotton. The low-country cotton planters are so crazed by their losses this year that they want an export duty on cotton seed and an import duty on Egyptian cotton.

It is very desirable that the consents of a majority of the property owners along the Broadway line of rapid transit laid out by the Commissioners should be obtained. The consents freely given would indicate a state of public opinion favorable to the construction of the road and would tend to discourage the selfish opposition of the few individuals who have always opposed any undertaking of the kind.

It was the custom of our high-tariff contemporaries a few months ago to say that the production of a few tons of tin, the metal, in California had been caused "by the McKinley bill." Their readers were taught that the tin ore had been mined and reduced because the establishment of new tin-plate factories had caused for the first time in this country a demand for the metal.

A Lodge of Sorrow was held last night at Scottish Rite Hall, Twenty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, under the direction of the Lodge of Perfection of New-York City, Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite of the Northern Masonic Jurisdiction. Invitations were extended to include Master Masons, and the hall was well filled with persons from all parts of the city.

Artistically, socially, and financially, the Kunstlerfest, or Artists' Festival, held at the Carnegie Music Hall last evening was a most pronounced success. From an artistic standpoint the affair was worthy of the skilled minds and hands that planned and executed it. Society favored it with its presence to such an extent that the gathering was one of the most brilliant that has been brought together in this city.

While Attorney General MILLER is engaged in defending McKinleyism in court he should not wholly overlook the Trust combinations, for the suppression of which the so-called Anti-Trust law was passed, and concerning which he addressed a curious letter to his subordinates several months ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Postmaster General John Wanamaker has made public his report on the department for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1891. The revenue of the department has been upward of $5,000,000 more than in any previous year, he says, and if Congress deems it advisable, the service may be made self-sustaining on July 1, 1893.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Among the decisions by the General Term given recently is one of interest in regard to money deposited in savings banks. The judgment for the defendant, in the case of Beaver vs. Beaver, obtained at the retrial of that case at the June Ulster Circuit this year, has been reversed.

St. Louis, Dec. 3. -- The true sentiment of the Democracy of Missouri on the subject of the Speakership is most clearly set forth by C.L. Ewing of Lexington, Mo., in a letter to the Republic. Mr. Ewing is a representative Democrat, is Clerk of the Circuit Court of Lafayette County, and is thoroughly posted as to political sentiment throughout the State. He writes as follows:

Although the boycott against the Chicago and Alton Railway has not been formally declared off, it cannot be continued consistently without also being directed at the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy. The latter road, according to a dispatch from Chicago, has notified the Board of Ruling of the Central Traffic and Trunk Line Associations that it will immediately resume the payment of passenger commissions in Eastern territory.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- John T. Stapler, one of Trenton's successful manufacturers, committed suicide this morning by putting a bullet in his head. He was ready to start for Bermuda, and before entering a carriage to go to the station concluded he would take a revolver. He went up stairs to get it, and his long absence caused some suspicion and his wife began a search for him.

Mills is more in harmony with the Democracy on the leading issues now before the people than is Crisp. He has had greater experience in Congress, and has distinguished himself more in National politics. Therefore he is likely to be the choice for Speaker of the Fifty-second Congress.

Congressman Henry H. Bingham of Philadelphia was in New-York yesterday. He said he should go to Washington just in season to attend the opening session. "I expect Mills will be the Speaker," he said. "As nearly as I can follow the fight, he seems to be the man. He is the natural candidate of the party, tad under the logic of the situation he should be elected."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3. -- William Walker, one of the best-known young men about town, committed suicide at a house of shady character by taking poison some time last night. He was a son of the late Benjamin Walker, who amassed a large fortune as a pawnbroker.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3. -- The celebration of the golden jubilee of Archbishop Kenrick this week has been replete with incidents and events without precedent, but the most conspicuously unusual event occurred to-day, when Cardinal Gibbons visited the floor of the Merchants' Exchange, attended by distinguished Church dignitaries, and was welcomed and presented to the vast throng by President Bernheimer, a Hebrew.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- When Justice Edwards took his seat on the bench in the Circuit Court this morning, Deputy Attorney General Maynard and William J. Roche of this city moved for an order vacating the stay granted against the State Board of Canvassers on Tuesday in the matter of the Dutchess County returns.

It was announced yesterday in the city the the order of suspension in the case of the court-martial ordered for Major Throckmorton, Second United States Artillery, had been revoked and that the trial would proceed at the Army Building Dec. 9.

The New-York Society of the Sons of the Revolution held its annual meeting yesterday at Fraunce's Tavern, at Pearl and Broad Streets, President Frederick Samuel Tallmadge in the chair. The Secretary's report showed a membership of 859 in the society, and that there had been an increase of over 200 during the year.

The negotiations which have been dragging along during some years for the purchase of the Cherokee Outlet seem to have come to an end, the committee appointed by the Cherokee Council having agreed upon $8,700,000 as an acceptable price. The amount, we believe, originally offered was 7,528,443, subject to an offset for certain sums already paid, making the net offer $7,113,847.

Not since its organization has the Electric Club had gathered within its spacious parlors at 17 East Twenty-second Street such a number of distinguished practical electricians and telegraphers as assembled there last night to listen to and take part in a discussion of the question of Government control of telegraphs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Col. W.H. Michael, Clerk of Printing Records and editor of the Congressional Directory, is about to issue his interesting magazine again. It contains the usual sketches furnished by the subjects of the sketches themselves of the new members of the new Congress. They are not without interest as indicating the characteristics of the men whose histories they briefly relate.

Charles W. Gould, assignee of the broken firm of Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co., returned to the city yesterday, but went out of town again early in the afternoon. He found that the statement of the condition of the firm, upon which the clerks had been at work for several days, had not been completed, and therefore he was as much in the dark as ever concerning the real state of things.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- John McManus was hanged at 10:09 o'clock this morning for the murder of Eugene Maginnis. Death resulted in twelve minutes from strangulation. The body, after being allowed to hang for twenty minutes longer, was cut down. McManus up till yesterday declined to listen to the ministrations of the priest who visited him, but last night he relented and made his last confession.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 3. -- There was a larger attendance and better bidding at the Bruce Edmondson sale of thoroughbreds here to-day. There were fifty-five animals sold, and they fetched $44,475, an average of $808. In the two days of the sale the 111 animals sold brought $61,620, making a grand average thus far of $546.

It was rather a chilly experience which befell an emissary of Secretary of State Blaine who came to New-York a day or two ago to get points for use in coming reciprocity negotiations. He had every opportunity to secure such information as he was seeking, but, unfortunately for him, there did not appear to be many facts to bear out his chief's way of thinking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- The allied railroad interests extending from New-York and Boston to St. Paul and Minneapolis has for weeks been endeavoring to effect an agreement in rates between the seaboard and the Northwest. It was mentioned several days ago that the Soo Line declined to advance the through rate from $1.05 to $1.20, its authorized differential, and that in consequence negotiations had ceased.
The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, and there was a large attendance. President Charles S. Smith was in the chair.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- At Norwood, St. Lawrence County, at the junction of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg and Central Vermont Railroads, the latter company has decided to build a grain elevator with a capacity of 250,000 bushels and a roundhouse with stalls for twenty locomotives. A Chicago firm has the contract for building the elevator, and work will be begun immediately.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- The Board of Supervisors of Montgomery County has employed Westbrook, Borst Perkins to prosecute the County Superintendent of the Poor, Abram P. Van Alstyne. He failed to make a report of his finances and his bondsmen appealed to the board for protection. They wrote:

LONDON, Dec 3. -- Sir Charles Russell to-day continued his presentation of the case for Earl Russell, which had been interrupted by the adjournment of the court yesterday afternoon. Sir Charles declared that the petitioner for the separation, Countess Russell, had not only exaggerated such facts as she had brought forward, but had suppressed others which she thought would be detrimental to her claims.

The squadron of evolution has been a long time getting ready for its Winter's work, but the preparations are now made. The Chicago and the Newark had still work to be done on them in repairs and fitting out after the Atlanta and the Bennington started, about fortnight ago, for the rendezvous at Hampton Roads, and on the way thither the Benington managed to break one of her air pumps.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 4. -- The Penitentiary Board of Control to-day closed its report for the year. From advance sheets the following data is obtained: Above expenses of maintaining the penitentiary the board paid into the State Treasury for the year 1890 $19,000, and had $13,360 worth of wagons and farm products on hand.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- County Clerk Hoffman, against whom charges of misconduct in office have been preferred by Lewis D. Germond, Chairman of the Dutchess County Board of Supervisors, left for Albany to-day, accompanied by his counsel, Charles Cossum, to appear before the Governor at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Dr. George A. Westfall or this State, a member of the United States Topographical Survey, has mysteriously disappeared in the Colorado Mountains. With his wife and a man named Dennis Sullivan he left this State for Colorado last June. In Chicago he left his wife and, with Sullivan, he went to Denver and started on foot for Buffalo Park, 185 miles distant, where he was to occupy a deserted cabin.
