At about 5 o'clock yesterday Afternoon, while the storm was at its height, a strong wind swept down First Avenue, and the result was that every electric light pole on the east side of the avenue from Thirty-ninth to Twenty-third Street was broken down. No lives were lost, but several persons had narrow escapes from death.

From its beginning nearly to its end the Speakership contest at Washington has appeared to have been contrived to sustain and perpetuate the tradition that the Democratic Party always makes a fool of itself at the critical moment. If there be a periodicity in its folly it can not be denied that another attack is about due.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Recently the Board of Alms Commissioners of this city asked the Common Council for an appropriation of $22,000 for the support of the poor and insane, in addition to about $12,000 of excise money, making $34,000 in all. This led to the appointment of a committee of Aldermen to examine into the affairs of the Alms Commissioners.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4. -- The Bruce Edmonson thoroughbred sale closed here to-day, 40 head being disposed of for $14,940, the average being $375. This makes a total of 151 head sold during the week, for $76,275, an average of $506 per head. The best sales made to-day, all of them yearlings, were the following:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Paymaster General Edwin Stewart of the Navy has submitted to Secretary Tracy his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1891. The most important portions are as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The heavy gales that have prevailed recently on the Atlantic and along the English Channel have caused numerous wrecks and other maritime disasters, which have entailed unusually heavy losses upon marine underwriters. Twelve of the gentlemen who have been engaged in underwriting marine risks at Lloyds have resigned, owing to the heavy losses they have sustained, chiefly on vessels wrecked or abandoned in the Atlantic.

CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 4. -- A terrific wind and rain storm, the severest for many year, passed over the Cumberland Valley this afternoon, doing damage to the amount of $75,000. In this city several new buildings were partially wrecked, trees were uprooted, houses blown to the ground, and streets flooded with water.

With the departure of the cruiser Chicago for Hampton Roads on Wednesday, all the vessels of the new navy recently in port are gone. The Miantonomoh is the only seagoing vessel at present in commission at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It has been a lively Fall at the Brooklyn-yard, and the manner in which war ships have been fitted out for long cruises speaks well for the efficiency of this department.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Dec. 4. -- The inquest in the case of Mrs. Annie T. Leonard's murder was continued to-day before Coroner Poston and a jury. Prosecutor of the Pleas Charles H. Ivins took a seat beside the Coroner. The first witness was Charles T. Leonard, husband of the murdered woman. He said he was a farmer, thirty-seven years of age.

The first news of the explosion that reached the Stock Exchange was sent by A.M. Leopold, a broker, whose offices are at 84 Broadway. Mr. Leopold's office windows are almost directly across the street from those of the building in which the explosion occurred, facing them at such an angle as to afford a view of the side as well as the front of 71.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4. -- It looks as if there was to be a general shaking up of Senator Quay's office-holding lieutenants in Western Pennsylvania by order of the President. There are allegations concerning the mismanagement of affairs in the office of Internal Revenue Collector Samuel D. Warmcastle so serious that the Collector will visit Washington to-morrow to ascertain just what the special agents of the Treasury Department have discovered about him and his subordinates.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4. -- The gorgeous displays and social meetings that will make the celebration of the golden jubilee of Archbishop Kenrick memorable in Church history are not its only features of importance. Several important meetings and conferences of the Church dignitaries were held in secret. One of these meetings was of the committee having in charge the organization of the National Catholic Congress of 1893.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The suit of Countess Russell for a separation from the Earl ended to-day, with a verdict in favor of her husband. The Countess was condemned to pay the costs of the action, which are heavy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 4. -- On Nov. 18 the immense wholesale houses of Griggs Cooper, and Farrell, Ozmun Kirk, at Third and Waconta Streets, burned, and the loss footed up $1,000,000. This afternoon there came an awful sequel, when ten men were crushed to death by the fall of the partition wall between the structures. The dead are:

An order has been issued by Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court directing the Mayor, Counsel to the Corporation, and Commissioner of Public Works to show cause in the Supreme Court, Chambers, on Monday next, why they should not be restrained from executing a contract with Martin B. Brown for the publication and distribution of the City Record during the year 1892.

While the widespread and terrible dearth in Russia absorbs attention, there is region, it appears, on our own continent which is suffering the horrors of famine. In the northern provinces of Guatemala, and also in Chiapas, the southernmost State of Mexico, whole families, say the reports, have died either of starvation or of disease caused by insufficient food.

Robert S. Seebold, ex-Postmaster of William's Bridge, who was convicted of forgery in the Court of General Sessions, was sent to the Elmira Reformatory yesterday by Recorder Smyth. Seebold acted as his own lawyer. Recorder Smyth said that no lawyer could have defended him more ably. The specific charge under which he was convicted was forging the names of two men to a guarantee by which he procured groceries from Acker, Merrall Condit.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 4. -- The worst wreck ever experienced by the New-York and New-England Railroad occurred at East Thompson, Conn., at 6:30 o'clock this morning. Four trains collided with each other, killing three men and injuring four others.

There was only a short public session of the Board of Review yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. This was held late in the afternoon and came in the nature of a request for a hearing from H.C. Potter of Middlebury, Vt., owner of the black mare Tempest, record 2:19.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Secretary Tracy finally settled the question of the command of the South Atlantic station this morning by ordering Acting Rear Admiral Walker to proceed to that station with the Chicago, his flagship, the Atlanta, and the Bennington. The Newark was at the same time detached from his squadron.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Twelve barges were upset on the Hudson River this evening, and it is feared a large number of persons were drowned. The barges were loaded with brick and were towed by the Cornell Towing Company's steamboat Townsend.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 4 -- Secretary Rusk's proposal to exclude from the United States Canadian as well as British cattle, in order to force the British authorities to revoke the order under which American cattle exported to Britain are slaughtered at the port of landing, causes great uneasiness and not a little resentment among Canadian breeders.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- There was the utmost interest here to-day in the uncertainty surrounding the election contests, and it was not until late this afternoon that word was sent out that all parties had come to an amicable understanding as far as continuing the contest locally was concerned.

It really does not seem that there is any useful moral to be extracted from the attempt to blow up RUSSELL SAGE with dynamite, an attempt which would be farcical if its incidental results had not been so tragic. The man who fell a victim to his own stupid devices was neither a robber nor an Anarchist.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- In a bulletin of the General Alumni Association of Union College attention is called to the fact that the outlook this year for Union is very bright. The college year opened Sept. 17, with a freshman class numbering over eighty, the largest for a generation. A large proportion of this class is registered in the classical course.

The treatment by the Chamber of Commerce of Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER'S request for an expression of opinion upon the advisableness of establishing a permanent Census Bureau is so cautious as to be comical. Nothing more non-committal has been promulgated since Artemus Ward's review of the poem which he "trusted might be read in other towns."

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 5. -- The following is the substance of a petition that will be presented to the Legislature this Winter in regard to the Cape Cod Ship Canal Company by George S. Hall, William A. Clarke, Jr., and William Faxon, Jr., of Boston:

CHARLESTON, S. [C., Dec. 5. -- New-York and Charleston are as unlike as two cities could well be, for one is perhaps the most cosmopolitan and the other the most provincial of American cities. Charleston was, not excepting even Boston, for over a century the most English city in America, while New-York did not have its first attack of Anglomania until a few years ago.

Mr. HARRISON has sent an interesting letter to the heads of the various executive departments. He reminds them that two years ago he "suggested" to them that they consider whether a record might not be kept of the services of the classified clerks, as a basis for promotion. Unfortunately the suggestion was only acted on in some of the departments, and even then only partly.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The death of Dom Pedro at 12:40 o'clock this morning was peaceful and almost painless. He received the last sacrament of the Church at 10:30. Immediately after the death of the ex-Emperor all present in the room knelt and kissed the hand of the Countess d'Eu, who, upon her father's death, instantly became invested with all his rights to the throne of Brazil.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The discovery, last evening, of Richard Burke's dead body in an old shanty at Hawthorne Avenue and Halsted Street reveals a peculiar story of eccentricity. Mr. Burke was well known in that vicinity, and when he was not seen yesterday in his accustomed place the suspicions of his neighbors were aroused. Later in the day the house was searched.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- The whaleback barge C.W. Wetmore was signaled off Point Lobos, California, yesterday. The Wetmoro is the first of the whaleback class of vessels to make a trip to this coast, and left Philadelphia for Seattle 106 days ago. The carries a cargo of machinery for a shipbuilding plant to be set up on Puget Sound for the consuruction of whaleback barges.

" Why was Dr. Seward Webb blackballed at the Union Club?" is getting to be a chronic question in club circles. They say that history moves in cycles; certainly the history of Union Club blackballing would appear to do so, at least as far as Dr. Seward Webb is concerned. Just about a year ago -- possibly, a little less -- he encountered blackballing No. 1 at the hands of the Union's Governors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Republican members of the House met this evening in the room of the Committee on Judiciary. When ex-Speaker Reed entered the chamber his colleagues greeted him with every manifestation of admiration. It was necessary to wait some time for a quorum.

The importance of securing coaling stations for vessels of the United States was never so urgent as at the present moment. The majority of the new war ships have little or no sail power They depend almost entirely for motive power on their machinery. Let one of these now cruisers run short of coal and have no means of obtaining a fresh supply and her condition is at once little short of helpless.

The large showrooms of Geo. C. Flint Co., at Nos. 104, 106, and 108 West 14th St., are crowded with specimens of some of the most artistic furniture ever offered for sale, ready made, in this city. Six floors are filled with sample pieces, no two of which are alike. It may be noted that each article is plainly marked with its price. The marked prices are never deviated from for anybody.

The recent presentation by Sir Edwin Arnold of the manuscript of a meritorious and intrinsically valuable poem to the Lotos Club recalls an incident that marked the visit of Henry Irving to this city in 1889. Like Sir Edwin, Mr. Irving had been an honored guest at a Lotos Club banquet. The enthusiasm of the lotos caters is boundless and their hospitality is proverbial.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 5. -- The college authorities have made the following rule, somewhat remodeled from a former one: "No student who has a full or partial condition in any subject, or who is under college censure, will be permitted to take part in any game in an organization not connected with the college, or to be sent as a delegate, representative, or manager of any society or organization."

The tariff bill prepared by Congressman William J. Coombs, and given to the public through the columns of THE TIMES, has certainly done one thing it was intended to do -- it has given the Democrats something to talk about. The politicians have been discussing it constantly, and they say it seems to be, in its main idea, just what they want -- a scheme that is simple and can be easily explained.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5. -- The season of fashion was announced last Monday night when the Scots held their customary brilliant fete for their patron saint. The shops have been gay with novelties in ball costume spiced with the tartan, cairngorm, sporran, and the Scotch etceteras that "the land of the heather" knows so well how to monopolize.

Tiddlewink Tales. By John Kendrick Bangs. Illustrated by Charles Howard Johnson. New-York: R.H. Russel Son. Jimmieboy made it all up. Mr. Bangs had nothing to do with the story, only such perfunctory business, perhaps, as stringing together what Jimmieboy said, and the putting in of occasional punctuation marks in the narrative.

The sculptor Jonathan Scott Hartley has issued at his own expense a practical text book for the art student who works at figures. "Anatomy in art" is a workmanlike production which will be of service to sculptors. In eight chapters, abundantly illustrated by plates, Mr. Hartley goes over skeleton, muscles, and the general principles governing muscular anatomy and the expression of head, face, and body.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- The new 2,000-ton United States cruiser Montgomery was launched this morning from the yards of her builders, the Columbian Iron Works of this city. The vessel slid from the ways at 11:13 o'clock, the christening ceremony being performed by Miss Sophia Smith, daughter of Passed Assistant Engineer J.A.B. Smith, United States Navy.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 5. -- News of the serious results of the great drought that has for several months been afflicting the people and stock of the State of Durango, Mexico, was brought here to-day by Lawrence C. Mauchel, who is the owner of several hundred thousand acres of ranch land in the northern part of the drought-stricken district.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 5. -- Five hundred spectators witnessed the whippings at New-Castle this morning. There were three victims. William Wood and Edward Smith, the burglars who robbed Robert Smith's dwelling and murderously assaulted the awakened owner, took forty lashes each and stood one hour in the pillory.

The story of England's wars with the Afghans is one of the lesser known portions of history to us in this country, but it is none the less interesting and worth study. The brilliant pen of Archibald Forbes has never been employed with more effect nor upon a better theme than in this volume.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- A sensational chapter has been added to the history of the old Christ Church in Cambridge by the action of it rector, the Rev. Dr. James Field Spalding, who last Sunday morning announced from the chancel his conversion to the Roman Catholic religion. Dr. Spalding has not arrived at his present standpoint by any sudden change.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The Rev. John Barrows, Chairman of the General Committee on Religious Congresses at the World's Fair, has made his first report of progress to President Bonney of the World's Congress Auxiliary. The report shows the most remarkable interest in the proposed gathering among leaders of religious thought all over the world, and promises a series of religious conferences that will excel in magnitude and interest any similar meetings ever held.

We understand so little in this country of the grandeur of an Anglican Bishop, that this volume, the autobiography of Charles Wordsworth, Bishop of St. Andrew's, comes to us like unto a revelation. No King has ever exactly written his own truthful memoir, (though some have said they did,) but Bishops have.

On an elevated train the other day a glimpse was had of a kind act, the doer of which little suspected that she was noticed. Among the passengers was a sweet-faced young woman, dressed in fresh but not deep mourning, such as one might wear for a young child. At one of the stations another woman got on carrying baby.

Sharpness of vision varies. It may be-rarely general; often it is special. "An eye may be 'sharp' for birds but blind to botany; keen for Indian arrowheads and dull to entomology, but never omniscient." In his paradoxical way, as Thoreau puts it, "a man absorbed in the study of grasses tramples down oaks unwittingly in his walks."
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Term examinations began to-day and will continue for two weeks. The honor examinations will be held in the morning as heretofore, and the regular ones in the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Democrats of the Fifty-second Congress have failed to agree upon a candidate for Speaker.

A writer in the Westminster Review has some suggestions to make upon what is a subject of never-ceasing interest to all dwellers in cities, that of cab service. The London cab service is excellent, and is far better than in former years. By no persons are its advantages more highly appreciated than by the many thousands of American visitors, who make continual use of it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- Lawrence McCully, First Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Hawaii, is here. The Justice said: "I received a few days ago a letter from the Hawaiian Chief Justice, in the course of which he said the Queen is well. Many of the reports regarding her Majesty's ill health and the restlessness of the natives have been greatly exaggerated.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The Journal Official to-day publishes a decree authorizing the import of American pork into France. The ports of entry, however, are limited, and importations can be made only at Dunkirk, Havre, Bordeaux, and Marseilles.

ASBURY PARK, Dec. 5. -- A good-sized row has developed in the Republican Party of Neptune Township, which threatens to disrupt the G.O.P. not only in this community but throughout the County of Monmouth. The cause of all the dissatisfaction is the recommendation by ex-Speaker Sherman B. Oviatt of John L. Coffin for the office of Postmaster of Asbury Park.

Early in the morning of Sept. 5 the Cunard steamship Etruria left her wharf in this city on her way to Liverpool. The day had broken chill and cheerless. The weather was thick and a nasty, drizzling rain was falling as the huge vessel swung out into the stream. There had been little bustle of preparation after daybreak, most of the work of loading having been done the night before.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- The Harvard Union held its first prize debate of the year last night. Since the announcement of the forthcoming debate against Yale considerable more interest has been shown in the Harvard Union, and last night there was a large audience to hear the debate, which was to decide who should represent Harvard.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Notwithstanding contrary reports, Louis Harriot, the farm hand accused of the murder of Mrs. Charles Leonard at Atlantic Highlands, has made a confession of the crime. The county officials have suppressed the facts in hopes that the prisoner would divulge more about he murder, but it is reported they have struck a clue to-day, and secured reliable information.

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- Gov. Hill has put his hand upon the legislative and Executive branch of the State Government, but he has been unable, as to-day's developments prove, to bend the judiciary to his purposes. The orders issued today by Judge Edwards at Hudson and by Judge Barnard at Poughkeepsie have sent a thrill of pride and satisfaction through every honest lawyer and every citizen who believes in the faithful execution of the laws.

ST. LOUIS Mo., Dec. 5. -- As has been previously stated, a great deal of Church history was made during the past week by the dignitaries of the Catholic Church in attendance on the golden jubilee celebration of Archbishop Kenrick, and from absolutely authoritative source some additional important portions of that history was obtained to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 5. -- The Grand Jury of Hennepin County this afternoon returned an indictment against Timothy E. Byrnes for uttering forged papers. Owing to the prominence of Mr. Byrnes the indictment creates a great deal of excitement, especially in political circles. Mr. Byrnes is National Organizer of the National League of Republican Clubs.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The quiet village of Haverstraw had not yet recovered from the excitement caused by the explosion at the Clinton Dynamite Works on Wednesday evening last when the inhabitants were again shocked by a new calamity, which at first seemed to be much more serious than was really the case. This second startling event was the accident to a number of barged during the severe storm last night.

The Merchant Tailors' Association of Philadelphia deserves well, in a small way, of its country. It has grappled with the question of proper vestments for waiters on occasions of ceremony, a question which has been rendered burning by the difficulty on such occasions of distinguishing Philadelphia waiters from other Philadelphians.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- "There is nothing new under the sun; not even Paris can create an original sensation." Thus spoke the wise men of yesterday, but to-day another story is told, and the light comes from Russia. To honor her imperial guests the supreme powers of the reception committee -- an occult, but most active corporation -- felt obliged to invent some fresh amusement.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 5. -- One of the best pieces of research work done at the Johns Hopkins University by Prof. Rowland, who has just perfected a wonderful ruling machine, was the making and publishing a forty-five-foot-long photograph of the normal spectrum, with the wave lengths put down on the plate in direct proportion to the distance measured along, and thus made easy of study.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The caucus attracted some open supporters of the different candidates who have not been conspicuous during the hotel canvass. Senator Gorman, the most powerful ally of Crisp, took possession of the Speaker's room, and with three or four of his lieutenants about him directed the proceedings in Crisp's behalf.

The launch of the 2,000-ton cruiser Montgomery at Baltimore yesterday was no doubt somewhat overshadowed by the taking to the water, a few days before, of the great armored vessel New-York, which has more than quadruple the Montgomery's displacement, and is by far the largest American war ship afloat.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- At a recent banquet given by the alumni of Jefferson Medical College to three new professors in that institution, there was witnessed the rather unique coalescence of representatives of Jefferson and of the Medical Department of the University of Pennsylvania. The graduates of these two schools have in the past constituted two almost wholly distinct cliques, with considerable pride in the Alma Mater of their origin.

" Is it true that Roosevelt Hospital is so private that only members of the founder's family are admitted, and so rich that its bed-posts are made of gold and its bed coverings of silk I" was the question asked.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 5. -- To-day ended the period allotted to artillery drills for the Fall season. The proposed drill that was to have taken place to-day at the close was changed into an infantry drill by the battalion of cadets on account of the arrival of Commodore Francis M. Ramsay of the Navy Department and formerly Superintendent of the Naval Academy.

About 1,100 persons attended the lecture given by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore at the American Museum of Natural History in Central Park yesterday morning. The subject was "Greece," with especial reference to Athens. The illustrations were many and gave views from many points in the city, illustrating the architecture, the religion, and the business of the Greeks.

There have never been so many amateur photographers traveling abroad with a special view to picture taking as this past Summer. The European outfit has not been deemed complete without the camera. Several well-known picture takers visited Norway and Sweden and have brought back some fine scenery of village life in those countries, as well as the beautiful bits of mountain and river scenery of the "Land of the Midnight Sun."

The Board of Electrical Control does not intend that the electric-light poles which were blown down along First Avenue on Friday night shall be replaced by other poles. The companies will be compelled to use the conduits. Such, at least, is the positive declaration of Secretary Theodore Moss of the Board of Electrical Control.

Gov. HILL'S foray upon Republican Senatorial and Assembly majorities may yet succeed, but his schemes are not prospering. In the First Assembly District of Onondaga Judge KENNEDY and Judge O'BRIEN have agreed that the Board of Canvassers must count the votes for MUNRO, the Republican candidate, as they were cast, not as they were entered in the returns by the Inspectors.

Chairman Callanan expects to call the anti-grab Citizens' Executive Committee together this week in order that plans may be pushed forward without delay to oust the Battery Park squatter. Now that it has been definitely decided to take an appeal to the courts, the only unsettled matter of importance in this connection is in regard to the manner of raising funds.

ROME, Dec. 5. -- On the occasion of the Episcopal Jubilee of the Pope, which will occur Feb. 19, 1893, there will take place at Rome grand religious fetes, in view of which pilgrimages will be organized from all parts of the world. A central committee for these pilgrimages had been formed in Rome, under the Presidency of Mgr. Rodini-Jodesohi, which will correspond with the committees that may be formed in other countries.

The New-York alumnae of Mount Holyoke College, Massachusetts, had their twenty-sixth annual gathering yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The meeting, which was followed by a dinner at 4 o'clock P.M., was mainly of a social nature, and was largely attended. Miss Charlotte Morrill of Brooklyn, the President, called the meeting to order.

A syndicate, consisting of C.H. McDonald and Fred Gerken, has made an offer to the New-York Driving Club for its five years' lease of the Fleetwood track and buildings and of all its movable property. The consideration offered is about $25,000 a year. A meeting will be held by the driving club in the Hotel Metropole on Wednesday next at 7 P.M., at which the propofition will be considered.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- A new movement of no small importance has recently appeared at the university. At a meeting held a few days ago a New-England club was formed by students from the Eastern States, who will devote their energies to "booming'' the university in that quarter. It is said that New-York, Ohio, Illinois, and other clubs will be formed, including several covering the Southern States.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- The germans, for so long the great feature of Baltimore society, have again begun and were held on Monday and Friday of last week and on Tuesday, Dec. 1. The debutantes are now all introduced, for, no matter how many luncheons, teas, dinners, or weddings the "bud" may indulge in, no young girl feels fully "out" until she has appeared at Lehman's, where these three different cotillions meet.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Of the $177,500 which the Messrs. Monroe admit holding in their bank vaults to the credit of Messrs. Parnell, Biggar, and McCarthy as Trustees, nearly every cent came from the pockets of men and women of Irish blood in America. It has seemed of first importance to find out all about this big sum of money and tell them how the question of its use now stands.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5. -- A visit to the scene of the East Thompson railroad wreck this morning brought out a number of new facts concerning the affair. It was definitely ascertained that only two men, Engineer Harry Taber and Fireman Jerry Fitzgerald, were killed by the collision of the trains and subsequent burning of the wreck.

There are several men now connected with New-York newspapers who had the good fortune to be more or less in company with Dom Pedro when he visited this city in 1876, and to these the announcement of his death was very unpleasant news. None of the other royal personages who have come to New-York has left behind him so many friends among the newspaper men as were left by Dom Pedro.

LENOX, Mass., Dec. 5. -- Several of the cottagers who came up to Lenox to spend Thanksgiving are still here. Among them are John E. Parsons, Mrs. Kuhn and her son Hamilton Kuhn, Dr. Greenleaf, and D.W. Bishop. The weather has been remarkably fine during the week, and everybody has enjoyed driving about in the daytime and sitting beside their fire-places in the evening.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- A younger brother of Mr. Henry Arthur Jones, the well-known dramatist, whose successful play "The Dancing Girl" is now nearing its three hundredth performance at the Haymarket Theatre, has, under the nom de plume of "Silvanus Dauncey," made his first bow to the public as dramatist in a four-act play, "The Reckoning," which was produced at the Globe Theatre yesterday.

The recent action of Superintendent Pierce of the Insurance Department with regard to the management of the Flour City Life of Rochester and the action of one of his predecessors in office, Superintendent John A. McCall, Jr., in the case of the Fireman's Trust Insurance Company of Brooklyn, have both been recited at length within the last few months by those who have taken an interest in the purification of the New York Life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Minister Batcheller's family are now fairly settled for the season at 6 Dupont Circle, where he will remain with them until Dec. 20, when he will return to Portugal. Their presence In Washington society this season will be a source of genuine rejoicing to the wide circle of friends made during their former residence in this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 5. -- B.S. Barrett, the ex-piano dealer of this city, who disappeared more than a year ago, leaving behind him about $7,000 worth of forged promissory notes, which he had used as collateral, and who was recently captured in West Virginia, was sentenced in the Criminal Court to-day to six years in the penitentiary.

The examination of Mrs. Mary Minnick, accused of smuggling a large quantity of valuable gowns and other articles which were seized by the Customs Inspectors, was continued yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields. Mrs. Minnick's counsel had promised Assistant United States District Attorney Evarts that he would have Mme. Connelly, the Fifth Avenue dressmaker and alleged employer of Mrs. Minnick, present, and asked that a subpoena should not be served on her.

The recent news of an Apache outbreak has already been followed by the contradiction which in such cases is very apt to come sooner or later. The explanation offered is that the killing of a settler, which had created the rumor, was the work of a culprit named FAY, "who wore moccasins"; and this affords more of a basis than such alarms sometimes have.

The first two volumes of Heinrich von Sybel's history carried its narrative, after a retrospective glance, from the accession of Frederick William IV., in 1840, down to the outbreak of the Schleswig-Holstein troubles. The third volume was devoted to these troubles and the resulting war with Denmark in 1864.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The department of architecture is arranging for a series of lectures by eminent specialists to be given monthly through the college year. The first of these lectures will be given next week by Mr. Wilson Eyre, Jr., of Philadelphia, who will speak on the "Art of Architecture" and who will illustrate his lecture with lantern slides.

Every window in the Holland House, at Fifth Avenue and Thirtieth Street, was glowing with light last night when the doors were opened to hundreds of visitors bidden to see the beauties of the new hostelry. The corridors, stairways, parlors, reception rooms, dining rooms, ballrooms, and office were crowded, and many were the congratulations and good wishes expressed to Messrs. H.M. Kinsley and Baumann, who are the managers of the establishment.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 5. -- The Canadian Northwest mounted police is one of the most valuable bodies in the public service. The force is small, but a most excellent state of efficiency is maintained, and the discipline is excellent. The corps is composed of ten divisions of 100 men each and 52 officers, including medical officers.

By all means see Sarah Bernhardt as la Comtesse de Challant. No person who values the art of acting, who is capable of feeling the emotional thrill that great acting engenders, should miss that memorable performance. Go to mediaeval Italy by way of the Standard Theatre and see the romance and intrigue of that era illumined by genius.

Mrs. Delia Parnell and John Howard Parnell were passengers for Liverpool yesterday by the Cunard steamship Aurania. Others who sailed by that vessel were Col. H. Coker Adams, E. Grant Powell, Andrew Hamilton, John T. Lord, A. H. Paget, Sinclair Tousey, and Mr. and Mrs. J. Lainson Wills.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- Sensational developments in the suit against the Directors of the Hale Norcross Mining Company were followed to-day by the filing of four additional suits of a similar nature by Theodore Fox, the well-known mining man, claiming the mines are run in the interest of the Directors, who by fraudulent means secured large profits.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The twenty-three-hundred-thousand-dollar suit brought by Ernest Dale Owen, trustee, against John F. Boyd, the Nevada Bank of California, and other San Francisco parties has been dismissed in Chicago, and is to be transferred to the Federal court at San Francisco. The suit is for the value of ore dug on what is known as the "Ronquillo grant" in Presidio County.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 5. -- Returns issued by the Dominion Government show the total net debt of the Dominion on the 30th ult. to have been $236,392,111. The revenue declined $105,406 last month, owing to the removal of the sugar duties. The expenditure on account of consolidated fund was $3,881,487 for the month, compared with $3,514,811 for Novemvember, 1890.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The Reichstag has been discussing the Government bill providing that the immunities enjoyed by the members of that body from arrest or imprisonment shall be suspended when an adjournment of the Reichstag exceeds thirty days.

Now an altogether new international complication is threatened. The New-York Life Insurance Company proposes to appeal to the Government in Washington to procure it relief from a fine of 1,500f. imposed by the Republic of Switzerland for its refusal to file there an annual statement of its affairs.

One of the gratifying proofs of the progress of naval Construction in this country is that, although many more shipyards are now building war vessels for the Government than were so employed a few years ago, the guns are ready for them in good season. The Washington factory turns out their batteries promptly and methodically, with its enlarged experience.

A New-England Thanksgiving modernized: a family reunion at dinner: the "county people" in for the evening's jollity: an old colonial mansion: eight sets dancing in the great hall: a fireplace as big as the log cabin of the pioneer and fed by trunks of grand old trees that deserved a better fate: the dais-hearthstone the vantage ground for onlookers at the dance.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 5. -- With the ending of the college athletic season comes increased interest in intellectual enjoyment, and, in some cases, a needed increase of application to intellectual pursuits. Recitations for the Fall term ended this afternoon, and the dreaded midwinter examinations will begin Monday and continue until the 16th. The Winter term will begin Jan. 7.

The final wrestling and boxing bouts for the championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided in the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There was a large crowd in attendance and the contests were of a very interesting character.

In these days of change in military methods, of progress in the art of war, of new guns, new powder in new guns, and new projectiles in front of new powder, army officers are a busy set. It is not now so much a question of drawing their salaries regularly on the last day of each month for the month following as it is of keeping abreast of the advance movement.

AMHERST, Dec. 5. -- F.S Allis, '93, of Erie, Penn., has been elected business manager by the Board of Editors of the Olio, the college annual. The Olio is expected from the press the latter part of the current term.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The work of clearing up the Senatorial muddle in the Fifteenth District, which was begun last Wednesday at Troy by Supreme Court Justice Edwards, was hastened toward a conclusion to-day by Senior Justice Barnard, sitting in Special Term.
ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Mrs. Clarence H. Kelsey gave a card party at her residence, 21 Clinton Street, East Orange, Tuesday evening.

The attempt to assassinate Russell Sage on Friday was yesterday a matter of history. Not that people were not talking about the work of the crazy dynamiter who exploded his death-dealing bomb in Mr. Sage's office, but they talked about it in a matter-of-fact way. Down on Wall Street business was quiet, and the event was made a topic of conversation simply to while away the time of the customary dull Saturday.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 5. -- With the ending of the college athletic season comes increased interest in intellectual enjoyment, and, in some cases, a needed increase of application to intellectual pursuits. Recitations for the Fall term ended this afternoon, and the dreaded midwinter examinations will begin Monday and continue until the 16th. The Winter term will begin Jan. 7.

The final wrestling and boxing bouts for the championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided in the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There was a large crowd in attendance and the contests were of a very interesting character.
" Lowell's religious message" was the subject of the Rev. R. Heber Newton's discourse at All Souls' Church yesterday morning. In the course of his remarks Mr. Newton said:

An extremely amusing fight -- to Democrats -- is that which is now going on between the good Col. Elliott F. Shepard and Mr. Bernard Biglin. To the Republicans it is not half so fanny. Incidentally, it involves the Grand Old Party's local machine, and bares to the world the fact that the Republican house is divided against itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Superintendent of Census has prepared a report as to the expediency of establishing a permanent census bureau, together with a draft of a bill prescribing its organization, duties, This has been done in response to a resolution adopted by the Senate in February last.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Slight changes, that can only be developed in to-morrow morning's caucus of the Democrats of the House, have been assured to the Mills men to-day, and it is not at all improbable that Mr. Mills will lead Mr. Crisp on the first ballot.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The Rev. Frank C. Colby, pastor of the First Baptist Church, preached a sermon to-night to a large audience on the "Rumselling Druggists of This Town." His text was, "Woe to the drunkards of Ephraim!" The divine declared that nearly every one of the score of druggists in Asbury Park retailed rum in violation of the excise laws of the town.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6. -- The Occidental and Oriental steamship Belgie arrived from Hongkong and Yokohama this morning. A Yokohama letter of Nov. 10 says: ...

GREAT FALLS, N.H., Dec. 6. -- The head of Hiram Sawtelle has been found. Last Tuesday morning Isaac Sawtelle made a full statement of the killing of his brother, drawing a map on which he marked where the crime was committed and where the body and head were buried. The head, he said, was wrapped in the dead man's underclothing.

The Buffalo Express (Rep.) insists upon it that, gerrymander or no gerrymander, a Republican Senator can be elected to fill the next vacancy provided a good man is picked out before the State election and the people are informed that every vote cast for a Representative or State Senator is a vote cast for him. The people are tired of haphazard candidates, it says, the Hiscocks, Beldens, and Platts.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Discount was easy during the week past at 212 for three months and 2 for short. Money is now so abundant that it is regarded as certain that the Bank of England rate will be reduced at the beginning of the new year unless some unforeseen gold movement occurs.

Coroner Faherty's inquest this evening into the circumstances surrounding the death of Conductor Lewis of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, at the Arlington Flats in Jersey City last Monday evening, is expected to afford no end of food for the tongues of the gossips.

The society known as the Sunday Breakfast Association of Brooklyn, whose scheme of temperance work was outlined in yesterday's TIMES, began work yesterday morning by filling the empty stomachs of nearly a hundred tramps and unemployed dock hands with a substantial breakfast.

Charles Atwater died at the residence of his son-in-law, David Daggett, 193 Church Street, New-Haven, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning of Bright's disease. He was seventy-six years old. He was born in New-Haven in 1815, was graduated at Yale in 1534, and then studied theology at Princeton for a year. He afterward engaged in the grocery business in Philadelphia, where he was married to Miss Mary Montgomery.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 6. -- The News and Courier will print a strong editorial favoring Mills for Speaker to-morrow morning. It will say:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Crisp men can easily be arranged in groups under the leadership of Gorman's sub-lieutenants, each of whom is an anti-Cleveland man first, and an anti-Mills man because it is considered more prudent to attack the friend of Cleveland than it is to assail Cleveland himself, and thus provoke national indignation.

The motto of "Alaska for the Alaskans" which a Juneau newspaper lately advised it readers to "unfurl" probably had reference to the white residents, or carpet-bag clement, of that flourishing Territory rather than to its genuine native population. But the Governor informs the Interior Department that this latter population also has needs, and among others that of having its true legal status defined.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 6. -- The Picayune's Dallas (Texas) special says: The following explains itself:

The Philadelphia Press publishes an interview with Secretary NOBLE, whom it describes as "the leonine member of the Cabinet, surcharged, like a thunder cloud, with the details of his department." We quote the following from it:

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- Cable dispatches from Rio Janeiro say that the news of the death of Dom Pedro met with no official recognition in the Brazilian capital. A number of merchants and shopkeepers in Rio Janeiro closed their places of business for the day out of respect for the ex-Emperor, but otherwise the death of the former ruler of Brazil was marked by no demonstration of any kind.

At yesterday's meeting of the New-York Federation of Labor the delegates from the Brewers' Union asked that a special boycott be imposed upon George Ehret's brewery, and that trades unions in the New-England States, where a great deal of Ehret's beer is sold, be requested not to drink his beer because Mr. Ehret discharges all his employes, who, he finds, have joined the union, or are seen reading the Journeymen Brewers' Journal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Mr. S.E. Morss, the editor of the Indianapolis Sentinel, who suffered a severe attack of nasal hemorrhage yesterday afternoon, rested quietly to-day, and Dr. Sowers, his physician, reports him as being easy and comfortable.

The Senate which will convene to-day has a very large proportion of new members. The most noteworthy of the men who will be missed from the Chamber are Messrs, EVARTS and EDMUNDS. The latter will be succeeded by Mr. REDFIELD PROCTOR, an able man and an upright one, but of a type very different from that of Mr. EDMUNDS.

Dispatches from Mexico recently published by some of our high-tariff contemporaries show again the effect of the McKinley tariff upon the smelting industry. American capital has bean invested in several mines in Coahuila, where silver-lead carbonates are taken out. These ores, the dispatches say, "were formerly shipped to the United States to be smelted, but since the new law went into effect they are sent to Monterey."

From Monday morning of this week until Thursday nobody came to my house, in West One Hundred and Fourth Street, nor to any house in the block in which I live, to cart away the ashes and garbage. The barrels were put out Monday night and they staid out unnoticed by any employe of the city all through Tuesday and Wednesday and up to the middle of Thursday forenoon.

Yesterday was jubilee Sunday at Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, in East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street. The church was out of debt, and the mortgages on the property were to be burned. The building was filled with the congregation, which came to hear the service and see the incineration. Mrs. U.S. Grant came with Bishop John P. Newman, who preached the sermon.

Emil Paul is one of New-York's characters. Several years ago he gained some notoriety by eating quail for thirty days at the expense of Gabe Case. After that he took part in several pedestrian contests and was fairly successful. One of his feats was the breaking of the record made by James Gordon Bennett from Grace Church to Jerome Park.

The Rev. Dr. David J. Burrell of the Fifth Avenue Marble Collegiate Church began a series of sermons to young men on "The Bible" yesterday afternoon in Association Hall, corner of Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. He discussed the inspiration of the Bible.

The Secretary of the Navy has submitted to the President, under date of Dec. 3, 1891, the annual report of the Navy Department for the past fiscal year. Secretary Tracy prefaces his report by stating that protected Cruiser No. 13, a sister to the triple-screw cruiser popularly known as the "Pirate," is the most important construction undertaken during the year.

The people of this country are deeply interested in the "new navy." Recent international complications have demonstrated the possibility of war and emphasized the importance of a navy. The press for some time past has devoted much attention to the service. Everything relating to ships, guns and torpedoes is gladly accepted for publication.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- The report of a terrible mining disaster comes from St. Etienne, in the Department of Loire, and the centre of one of the richest coal fields in France. An explosion of fire-damp occurred at noon to-day in one of the numerous coal pits in that region, and many of the workers were unable to escape from the mine. According to advices so far received, 73 men perished in the pit.

" The work on the new Naval Observatory has advanced so far that the transfer from the old to the new site will shortly be undertaken. The failure of the contractors has delayed the work of the new building, now in its final stage, but the Government is amply protected, and arrangements are now making under the provisions of the contract by which its early completion may be assured.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 6. -- Sitting Bull was murdered. Conrad Disstler, who made the sixty-mile march across the sand plains of the Sioux Reservation from Fort Yates to Grand River with Troop F. Eighth Cavalry, Dec. 6 last, told the story of the killing of the aged chief here this afternoon. He was shown the affidavit of Sitting Bull's wives charging that Bull was murdered, and said it was substantially correct.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6. -- The North China Daily News of Shanghai, which arrived by the steamer Belgic to-day, makes a long editorial comment on the United States Navy. After reviewing the English and French Navies, especially men-of-war, the article says:
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Chronicle's Shanghai correspondent telegraphs that the rebels have met a complete, crushing defeat. He says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The usual decorous quiet is expected to characterize the assembling of the Senate to-morrow. An unusually large number of Senators will stand before the Vice President to take their oath of office, for thirty-two of them (nearly one-half of the membership of the Senate) are either new to that body or begin new terms of service.

The nineteenth anniversary of the Church Mission to Deaf-Mutes was appropriately observed last evening at the Church of the Intercession, Boulevard and One Hundred and Eighteenth Street. The pretty church was well filled with regular worshippers, and those who worship not by word of mouth. The service was conducted in two languages; in English and in the sign language of the deaf and dumb.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Thousands of curious people loaded all the lines of street cars traveling toward the Capitol this morning, and the halls of the big building streamed with the huddled throngs, in wet clothing and with wet umbrellas, long before the time for Congress to meet. It was reasonably certain that there would be no Congress in shape to do business at 12 o'clock, but the crowd was eager to see the opening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Crisp, Hill, free silver, and protection have won. Mills is beaten.

RIO JANEIRO, Dec. 7. -- President Peixotto today formally received the various representatives of foreign Governments accredited to Brazil, and he also received the Brazilian and other naval officers whose vessels are at present at Rio Janeiro.

On the twenty-ninth ballot in the Democratic House caucus yesterday Mr. STAHLNECKER of the Fourteenth New-York District deserted Mr. MILLS, and on the next ballot Mr. CRISP was nominated, receiving 119 votes to Mr. MILLS'S 104 and Mr. SPRINGER'S 4. The desertion of Mr. STAHLNECKER was due to the exertions of Lieut. Gov.-elect SHEEHAN of this State, who arrived at Washington yesterday and devoted all his energies to making this break in Mr. MILL'S lines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7. -- News from China brought by the Belgic is very meagre. The situation is well stated in an article of the North China Daily News of Nov. 7, of which the following are the main points:

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- When Judge Edwards bustled into the Clerk's office of the Supreme Court in the City Hall this morning at 9:10 o'clock, he found two flocks of counsel awaiting him. One was the Democratic flock, consisting of Isaac H. Maynard, Deputy Attorney General Delos McCurdy, and Judge Gilbert of Delaware County, as counsel for the Democratic Party and the State Board of Canvassers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- When Mr. McMillin formally withdrew from the contest, he made this address:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7. -- Politicians in Missouri, in office and out, have for two months been puzzling their heads over the question as to whether or not the Governor would call an extra session of the Legislature, and the Governor has kept his own counsel so well that even those who consider themselves his most intimate friends have been kept busy guessing.

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The case of the people against Assemblyman Frank P. Demarest, indicted several months ago by the Grand Jury of Rockland County for forgery in the first and second degrees, occupied the attention of an adjourned term of the Rockland County Court at New-City all day to-day.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Henry Gower appeared at the Memorial Hospital, Orange, Sunday night suffering from three large stab wounds in his right arm. He had been quarreling with his brother in front of the Orange Valley Congregational Church, when the latter drew a pair of barber's shears and stabbed Henry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Hill-Gorman-Brice combine was busy all day trying to bring about the defeat of Mr. Mills. It pulled every string calculated to aid Mr. Crisp. Last night the Tammany men in the city threw out hints of operations that were to be carried on to-day, through the aid of William F. Sheehan, Lieutenant Governor-elect of the State of New-York.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 7. -- "The deserted farms of New-Hampshire are being filled up by those who want Summer residences or who want to go into the business of keeping Summer boarders," N.J. Batchelder, the State Commissioner of Agriculture, said to a TIMES'S correspondent a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Senate Chamber, it is generally conceded, has not looked so handsome in years as it does at the present time. The faults of decoration which were so marked last year have been corrected, and the big apartment now contains no evidence of bad taste in its adornment.

Yesterday's dispatches told of the arrest in Troy of a man registered at the American House as Harry Webster, who is known to have been an agent of the New-York Life Insurance Company in Brooklyn, where he went under the name of Claudius B. Laselle. The charge against the man is that of swindling, and the detective who arrested him says a number of charges of grand larceny have also been preferred against him.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Nellie Morris and Nellie Barry, the young girls who were supposed to have left here with dime-museum performers, have been found in New-York and will be returned to-day. It is now stated that they were lured away by a woman who, finding that their absence had been made public, deserted them in New-York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7. -- A dispatch has been received by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company stating that the new steamer Nicaragua, Capt. Nickerson, struck on a reef below Acajutla, on the coast of Salvador, Friday night and was wrecked. Arrangements were immediately made to send the tug Vigilant to the scene of the trouble.

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- The final pronunciamento of David B. Hill was issued from the Capitol to-night. It is an address congratulatory to the people of the State over the Democratic triumph in the Legislature. It is signed by Edward Murphy, Jr., Chairman of the Democratic State Committee; Dan Griffin, Chairman of the Executive Committee, and Sam Beardsly, Secretary.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 7. -- There were expectant looks on the faces of the immense assembly which crowded the criminal division of the District Court this morning. These looks, however, gave way to expressions of disappointment when, at 10 o'clock sharp, Judge Marsh announced that Judge Rising was still too ill to preside, and adjourned court until tomorrow morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Theodore A. Hoffman, County Clerk of Dutchess County, was served this morning by William H. Wood, counsel for the Democratic majority in the Board of Canvassers, with this document:

Two hundred Sons of St. Nicholas sat down at tables at Delmonico's last night, and, after listening to the addresses made by the speakers, rejoiced, as they have not done since this time last year, that they were the descendants of the old Dutchmen who founded the City of New-Amsterdam.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- The will of the late T.O.H.P. Burnham, the millionaire bookseller, who left $500,000 to charitable and other institutions, was not admitted to probate to-day. Charles Burnham of Mew-York, a nephew, has entered an appearance, and there will be a contest. Augustus Flagg, who was named as executor of the will, has refused to accept the trust.

The first regular or annual meeting of the New-York State Board of Trade will be held in the rooms of the Albany Chamber of Commerce on Feb. 17, continuing for a day or two. Each of the constituent bodies is entitled to send three delegates, and efforts are making to have a number of trade bodies which did not take part in the organization of the State Board in Rochester represented at the coming meeting.

The business of Russell Sage was resumed yesterday at 71 Broadway as if nothing had happened. At 7 o'clock in the morning a force of laborers was put at work clearing out the debris of last Friday's explosion in Mr. Sage's offices, and two hours later a sign was hung up at the door of the adjoining offices of the Manhattan Railway Company announcing that Mr. Sage's headquarters were within.

The armed guards stood just outside the prison yards for four hours after the execution. They refused to take any requests for an interview to the Warden, and when newspaper men approached them repeated their order, "Get back to the other side of the street."
The Chicago Tribune publishes the following editorial paragraph:

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The number of people who are anxious to listen to the revelations in the St. John divorce case has become so large that it was found necessary this morning to adopt measures to prevent the unprivileged from entering the courtroom. When the courtroom opened this morning there was a rush to obtain seats.

SING SING, Dec. 7. -- A human life has again been taken at the prison here by the new method of electrical execution. Martin D. Loppy, the wife murderer, paid the penalty of his crime just about noon to-day. He was the sixth condemned murderer to be placed in the electrical chair by the State.

When Sir Piercie Shafton, in SCOTT'S novel of "The Monastery," was in a precarious position, it will be remembered that he attempted to depart from it in the disguise of a milkmaid. Being hailed by a suspicious sentry with a demand to know who she was and where she was going, the disguised euphuist made answer: "I am she, O most bucolical Juvenal, to whose charge are committed the milky mothers of the herd."

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The great topic of conversation in fashionable aristocratic circles to-day is the engagement of Prince Albert Victor to Princess Victoria Mary of Teck. On all sides the utmost satisfaction is expressed, and there is no doubt that the match is a "love affair" to a far greater extent than the majority of royal betrothals.

Seven Russian Hebrews yesterday appeared at the British Consulate in State Street and made a formal charge against a foreman of the cattlemen employed on the steamship France The complainants stated that they had been engaged to go as cattle tenders on board the vessel and had agreed to demand no other compensation for their services than their food and passage.

Still another war ship is to slide from the ways to-day, the 1,050-ton gunboat at Bath, following the recent lead of the 3,100-ton armored cruiser at Philadelphia and of the 2,000-ton cruiser at Baltimore. Three new ships launched within a week, of various types and from different ports, must give a gratifying idea of the industrious efforts making to build up the navy.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 7. -- Lieut. G.M. Fry, an officer in the English Army, who for several years has served with the Princess Royals Seventh Dragoon Guards, known as the Black Horse, now stationed in India, arrived here to-day. He arrived in New-York ten days ago from South Africa.

At a meeting of the West Side Excise Reform Association last night in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, West One Hundred and Fourth Street, to oppose the extension of the retail liquor traffic in the district between Eighty-sixth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets, west of Central Park, the Rev. Father Walter Elliott of the Paulist Fathers, the Rev. Dr. G.E. Strobridge of St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church, and James W. Pearsall made addresses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Democratic caucus resumed its session promptly at 10 o'clock this morning, and, without any preliminary proceedings, the Secretary began to call the roll. The call disclosed the presence of 212 members, but others were constantly arriving.
The annual report of the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge to the Mayors of the two cities was completed last night, and will be forwarded to the Mayors' offices to-day.

If those Democrats who are personally hostile to Mr. Cleveland and would prefer the nomination of some other candidate for the Presidency -- or if any person who himself cherishes aspirations for the next Democratic nomination -- are seeking to influence the election of Speaker for that purpose, they have chosen an occasion for the promotion of their private and personal aims and ambitions most unfortunate for themselves and for the party.

A jollier company has not met at a dinner table this season than one which gathered at the Union League Club last night at the invitation of Gen. Thomas L. James. The dinner was given to Frederick W. Vanderbilt, but it had more than that significance. For six years Gen. James has regularly given a dinner to some friend on the evening of Dec. 7, and has invited other friends to help enjoy it.

Despite the fact that there has been considerable rain of late the water supply in this city is by no means so abundant that annoyance is not felt. The supply in the Murray Hill district is still scant and in some of the residences between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, from Forty-second Street up, it is impossible to get water above the first floor during certain hours of the day.

In the Commersbuch, where the German student finds his ballads, there is a jovial lay which begins: "Als die Romer frech geworden," and goes on to describe the battle in the Teutoburg Wood, when Arminius destroyed Quintilius Varus and various legions. The Meininger Company of German actors at the Thalia Theatre played last night a spectacular drama ay Heinrich von Kleist, founded on the same historical fact.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7. -- W.P. Bentley, of the firm of Bentley Peabody, and one of the most prominent lawyers in the city, was mercilessly cowhided on Market street, near Broadway, this morning, by James F. Sutherlin, who was aided and abetted by Harry P. Sutherlin, his brother, and William B. Harris, his brother-in-law. From a mass of contradictory stories the following version of the affair is sifted:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The Board of County Canvassers convened to-day. The clerk read the order of Judge Barnard directing the board to count for Isaac W. Sherrill, Republican candidate for County Treasurer, all the marked ballots previously thrown out, and give Mr. Sherrill the certificate of election, or show cause at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

The Manhattan Electric Light Company early yesterday morning gave up the attempt to erect new poles in place of those blown down in First Avenue by Friday night's storm. The new poles which were carried to First Avenue to be set up were removed and the company bowed to the inevitable.

The Pennsylvania and the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroads yesterday notified their Western connections that they could no longer receive shipments of grain to be reconsigned at Chicago for Eastern points. These were the latest of the roads east of Chicago to give such notice, and the movement of grain through Chicago is checked, as none of the Western lines will allow any more of their cars to be brought East.

So many people were anxious to get into the Court of Oyer and Terminer in Brooklyn yesterday to see Brig. Gen. J.V. Meserole's son, Darwin James Meserole, tried for the murder of Theodore W. Larbig that the doors had to be closed and only those admitted who had been subpoenaed as jurors. A panel of 400 had been drawn, so that the stuffy courtroom was pretty well crowded.

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- Gov. Hill has removed Theodore A. Hoffman, Clerk of Dutchess County, and appointed in his place Storm Emans, who was elected County Clerk at the recent election. The following is the opinion in the case:

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- It is reported that the Channel steamer Victoria struck the pier at the entrance of the harbor of Calais to-night and was unable to make the harbor. She was therefore obliged to put to sea again.

The motion of John M. Emra, as a taxpayer, through William McMurtrie Speer as attorney, for an injunction to prevent the awarding of the contract for the printing of the City Record to Martin B. Brown, was argued yesterday before Judge Ingraham in the Supreme Court, Chambers. Mr. Emra's application is made in the interest of Samuel J. Brown, a printer, who would like to have the contract for printing the City Record himself.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 6. -- There is a possibility that Kansas may be taken from the Republican column next year, although the leaders of that party do not acknowledge the probability of such a result. Leading Democrats are already endeavoring to form a fusion with the People's Party, claiming that if they succeed in the consummation of their plans they will have at least 30,000 majority.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 8. -- The Rev. J.H. Bausman, pastor of the Rochester (Penn.) Presbyterian Church, who has been accused of heterodoxical teachings for some time, to-day refused to tender his resignation as pastor of the church, and practically defied the Presbytery of Allegheny. When the committee which had been appointed at the last meeting to investigate the trouble between Mr. Bausman and his congregation was requested to report, the Rev. Dr. William Campbell, Chairman, responded.

Up to noon yesterday Mrs. Timothy L. Woodruff, wife of the young Republican politician of the Twenty-second Ward, Brooklyn, had in her handsome residence at 17 Seventh Avenue a demure little boy who wore a livery and assisted the groom. Mrs. Woodruff knew the boy as Eddie McDonald, but neither she nor the groom knew the boy's place of abode prior to his entering her employ three months ago.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 8. -- The most interesting and sensational trial known for years in this State began in the General Sessions Court here this morning, when William J. Gibbons, a young man, was arraigned on a charge of setting fire to a barn owned by E.I. Dupont de Nemours Co, the great powder manufacturers, on the night of Dec. 26, 1889.

Wolcott Balestier, joint author with Rudyard Kipling of "The Naulahka," the serial novel now running through the Century, died on Sunday in Dresden of typhoid fever. Mr. Balestier's ability was of an unusually high order and his personal qualities had made him popular.

The results of the Republican primaries held all over the city last night make it certain that the Republican machine will run along in the same old rut, that Platt will remain in pernicious control, and that unless something unexpected occurs between now and the organization of the Country Committee, Jacob M. Patterson will be continued as Chairman of that committee's Executive Committee.

" Promises to the people, on which votes are sought, are a primary obligation," says Representative WILLIAMS of Massachusetts in giving his reasons for not voting for CRISP in the House election. This doctrine will astonish the old political "rounders," who look upon "promises to the people" as of no binding force after election.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 8. -- The Graves Trial was resumed to-day after a delay of several days, caused by the illness of the Judge. Judge Rising arrived at the court room in a private carriage shortly before 10 o'clock. He looked pale, and the traces of sickness were plainly visible in his face. He looked much better, however, than he did when he last sat on Thursday.

Dr. MACDONALD'S account of the killing of LOPPY is the first authentic and authoritative report of an execution under the existing law that has been given to the public before the public had lost all interest in the event. It varies in several respects from the accounts given by the reporters. This is not to be wondered at and nobody is to blame for it, least of all the reporters.

SANDWICH, Mass., Dec. 8. -- Clifton Dennis, a well-known song evangelist from Chicago, who has been holding revival meetings in New-England the past year, unexpectedly arrived last night at the residence of kinsfolk. Later, with nothing on bus a night garment, he walked to the residence of a neighbor, where he broke down the fence and the front door and made a great disturbance.

William J. O'Dair, who was elected to the Assembly in the Twenty-second District over Joseph Blumenthal, Tammany, is evidently heading toward Tammany Hall. He was nominated by the Republicans, People's Municipal League, and the County Democrats, and in the days when it looked as if he might have the deciding vote in the Assembly for Speaker, he was very careful not to say whether he was going to be with the Republicans or the Democrats.

WEST PLAINS, Mo., Dec. 8. -- The railroad wreck which occurred two miles north of here last night was more disastrous than first reports indicated. The scene that followed the collision was horrible. In the caboose of the construction train were thirty-four men, and not one of them escaped injury. Four were killed and many others dangerously hurt, some of them fatally.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- In a State where tariff reform is such a burning question opinions in regard to the result of the Democratic caucus in Washington are of much interest, especially when the effect on the Presidential nomination in 1892 is considered. Below are given the views of several well-known men.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 8. -- The Picayune's Havana special says:

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Miss Mary Theresa Olivia Cornwallis West, eldest daughter of Col. Cornwallis West, M.P., of Ruthin Castle, Ruthin, and Mrs. Cornwallis West, a society beauty, was married to-day at the historic Church of St. Margaret's, Westminster, to Prince Hans Heinrich of Pless.

ORANGE, Dec. 8. -- Kate Weiss, employed in the No Name Hat Factory in Orange Valley, had a frightful experience with an electric-light wire yesterday afternoon. She is employed to run a binding and a stitching machine, and between the two machines hangs a portable electric light pendant, with a rubber-like attachment that enables the shifting of the light from one machine to the other as occasion requires.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- The annual meeting of the stock and income bond holders of the Ulster and Delaware Railroad Company was held here to-day. Edwin Young, R.C. Pruyn, Joseph Cornell, C.C. Clark, W.A. Read, J.D. Layng, A. Van Santford, H.C. Soop, Davis Winne, T.C. Hornbeck, A.S. Staples, S.G. Dimmick, and Horace G. Young were elected Directors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -- Joseph McKay, who is in jail at Ukiah, Cal., charged with stage robbery, has been found to be the son of Joaquin Miller, the "Poet of the Sierras." The real name of the young man is Harry Miller. He is twenty-two years old, and is the son of the poet and the latter's first wife, Minnie Myrtle.

Last year the Finance Committee of the New-York Life Insurance Company voted a bonus of $25,000 to President William H. Beers, $15,000 to his son-in-law, the First Vice President. Dr. Henry Tuck, and $10,000 to the Second Vice President. Archibald H. Welch. So far as is known, no attempt has been made by the officers of the company or by their apologists to deny these facts.

In the excitement over the failure of the caucus of Democratic Congressmen in Washington to nominate a Speaker on Saturday night, the Republican caucus held on the same evening has received small consideration. Indeed, it was a small affair, but it seems to have been thought proper to go through the for mality.

Work at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is still active, notwithstanding the absence of all cruising ships of war, with the exception of the double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh. From the fact that there is no repair work in progress, the steam engineering and construction departments are able to devote nearly undivided attention to the construction of the machinery and hulls of the Maine and Cincinnati.

The relatives of E.H. Rath, the Flushing (L.J.) real estate dealer who was killed and cremated in the East Thompson railroad disaster, on the New-York and New-England Railroad last Friday, are indignant over an intimation which they think emanates from the railroad company, that Mr. Rath was not killed, but is alive and in concealment for the purpose of defrauding life insurance companies which had issued policies on his life.

The Paris courts have decided that the heirs of the Countess Civry are entitled to a share of the Duke of Brunswick's estate. The City of Geneva, where the Duke died childless in 1872, fought the claim, and is condemned to pay the costs.

BATH, Me., Dec. 8. -- This was a gala day for all Bath, the occasion being the launching of the new United States gunboat Machias. Gen. Hyde issued to the public a general invitation, which was heartily responded to. In the early morning special trains began to arrive, and at 2:30 P.M. the city presented a lively appearance.

In the last campaign the Republican State Committee sent out circulars to some of the employes in the different Federal offices, requesting "voluntary contributions" to aid the Republican cause. As Postmaster Van Cott was a member of the State Committee, it was charged that he had violated the civil service law and many awaited with some interest to see whether his infraction of the law would be noticed by officials high in power.

The announcement in the Journal des Debats of a commercial convention between Germany and the United States may pretty safely be distrusted. The convention is declared to provide for the admission of German beet sugar free in return for a decrease from 5 marks to 3 1/2 in the duty on American cereals imported into Germany.

HARTFORD, Dec. 8. -- The State Prohibition Convention for the selection of national delegates and the inauguration of the campaign of 1892 will be held here to-morrow under favorable auspices. The State Central Committee will hold a meeting prior to the convention for the purpose of mapping out the Winter's work for the party, the plans in general to be submitted to the State delegates for approval.
ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- In the Tilden will case in the Second Division of the Court of Appeals today the motion for reargument and motion to amend remittitur was denied, without costs.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 8. -- The announcement here this morning that Major L. Cooper Overman, the Government engineer who has been in charge of this district up to a few weeks ago, had been ordered to Fort McHenry under arrest, charged with malfeasance in office, created a sensation, and has been the talk of the town all day.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The Times this morning expresses the opinion that, during the coming session of the United States Congress, the Democrats will only be able to embarrass their opponents by cutting down supplies to prevent the lavish expenditure which the Republicans desire to make in order to commend extreme protection to the public.

BUFFALO, N.H., Dec. 8. -- At 7 o'clock this morning fire broke out in the planing mill and yards of Lee, Holland Co., on Court Street. It was discovered in the shaving room, above the boiler room, into which shavings are brought by suction through pipes. This room is walled up solidly with brick and is completely fireproof. Dust in the shaving room exploded and caused disaster.
The Wholesale Fruit and Produce Association has adopted the report of its committee to prepare a proper standard for packages for fruits and vegetables.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8. -- Judge Woernor of the Probate Court has decided a most interesting and important dispute over an estate. Some thing over a year ago, the Rev. Peter Kettwood died. For many years he had been the pastor in charge of the Bethel for river men and the very poor of the levee district, at a salary of $700 a year.

The examination of Custom House Broker William Cutajer, who is charged with presenting false invoices as regards weights of shipments of goods on the steamer Fulda from Genoa, which he was getting through the Custom House for various grocers in the city, developed some evidence yesterday to the effect that he attempted to bribe the weighers and prepare the road for a series of illegal acts.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8. -- Word has been received here that Gov. Francis has definitely determined to convene the Legislature in special session for the purpose of redistricting the State and fixing the territory that will be comprised in the Fifteenth Congressional District, which Missouri gains under the new census and apportionment.

The harm the Democratic Party suffers from the election of Mr. CRISP as Speaker will be measured by the extent to which he allows the enemies of the party to guide his official action. He knows perfectly well who these enemies of his party are, and he knows their purposes. They were the most zealous and efficient of his campaigners.

It is not surprising that the representatives of Yale should have objected to accepting the returns of the gate money for the football match on Thanksgiving Day, although, according to these, Yale's share reaches the comfortable sum of $14,425. The crowd was the greatest that has ever been seen at a sporting event in New-York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -- Jim Gillis, an old miner of Sonora, Tuolumne County, makes public for the first time the mystery in the life of the late Prentice Mulford, who for years was his friend and companion. Mulford came to the mines near Sonora at the age of twenty-one, and served as a butcher, a miner, and a school teacher.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- The Court of Appeals will listen to argument of counsel in the matter of the four disputed election cases on Friday of this week. This morning Mr. Matthew Hale, representing the Republican end of the dispute, and Delos McCurdy, the Democratic side, appeared at the opening of the court. The latter stated the case to the full bench.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- This city has been selected as the place of the meeting of the National Democratic Committee that is to decide upon the time and place of the National Democratic Convention. The date of the meeting is Thursday, Jan. 21. This was decided upon by the Executive Committee of the National Committee, which met at the Arlington to-day.

" Margaret Fleming," a play in five acts, written by James A. Herne, a well-known actor and stage manager, was presented in Palmer's Theatre yesterday afternoon. It was thus brought into the notice of the habitual and critical theatregoers of New-York, who were largely represented in the audience, but it is not a new play.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 9. -- The testimony of the State to-day in the trial of William J. Gibbons, charged with firing a large barn owned by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., went far toward establishing the existence of the alleged conspiracy on the part of the barn burners to wreak vengeance on the du Ponts by a wholesale destruction of their property.
